title: The Persuasive Art of Portraiture
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: U.S. Says Labor Union Leader Will Resign and Admit Fraud
description: Arthur A. Coia, the president of the laborers' union, one of the nation's largest building trades unions, has agreed to resign in October and plead guilty to fraud charges as part of a deal with Federal prosecutors, Government officials said yesterday.

title: An Irish Tenor Named Joyce Inspires a Musical
description: Which came first, the words or the music? That's not a bad question to ask about James Joyce's exquisite short story ''The Dead,'' as imbued with music as any work in the Western tradition. And it's not a bad question to ask of James Joyce, whose ear for music was second to none in the Anglo-Irish tradition.

title: N.F.L. MATCHUPS WEEK 4
description: SUNDAY 1 P.M.

title: BANK TALKS
description: One of South Africa's leading banks, Nedcor, has approached a larger rival, the Standard Bank Investment Corporation, about merging their operations into what would be Africa's largest bank. As the banking industry here looks to reorganize amid growing competition from local and overseas banks, a marriage between Standard, the country's second-largest bank, and Nedcor, the fourth largest, has been the object of frequent speculation. Executives from Nedcor are expected to meet with their counterparts at Standard next week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRAUB, ROSE
description: TRAUB-ROSE. Sutton Place Synagogue extends condolences to our dedicated member, Raymond Senter on the loss of his beloved mother. Our sympathies to the family. Allan Schranz, Rabbi Robert W. Berend, President

title: INTERNET AD AGENCY IS SOLD FOR $690 MILLION
description: CMGI Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the Flycast Communications Corporation, an Internet advertising agency, for about $690 million in stock, CGMI's third acquisition of an advertising company in two weeks as it takes on the on-line marketing leader Doubleclick Inc.

title: Rising Incomes Lift 1.1 Million Out of Poverty
description: Lifted by the strong economy, American households are climbing out of the income stagnation that has plagued them for years.

title: Save the Salmon or the Dams?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMPSON, WILLIAM M.
description: THOMPSON-William M. 90, of Madison, CT. On September 27. Predeceased by Mary Lamb, wife of 65 years. He will be greatly missed by three children, eight grandchildren, and six greatgrandchildren. Memorial service to be held at a later date.

title: Save the Salmon or the Dams?
description: To the Editor:

title: Bernadette O'Farrell, 75, Actress Who Played Maid Marian on TV
description: Bernadette O'Farrell, an actress best known for her role as Maid Marian in the 1950's television series ''The Adventures of Robin Hood,'' died this week at 75, The Daily Telegraph of London reported on Wednesday.

title: Who's on First at Excite@Home, Anyway?
description: The board of the Excite@Home Corporation yesterday canceled a meeting set for Monday to vote on splitting the company's Excite Web portal from the At Home cable modem venture, apparently because Cox Communications Inc., one of the venture's big shareholders, threatened to veto the plan, an executive close to Excite@Home said yesterday.

title: Group Allowed to Assert Bias in School Financing
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan ruled yesterday that a coalition of New York City advocacy groups could assert in a coming trial that the state's system of school financing is racially discriminatory.

title: Pepon Osorio
description: Ronald Feldman

title: U.S. to Revisit Accusations Of a Massacre By G.I.'s in '50
description: The Secretary of Defense ordered the Army today to undertake a new and thorough review of reports that American soldiers killed Korean civilians at the beginning of the Korean War nearly 50 years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICH, STEPHANIE HILLARD
description: RICH-Stephanie Hillard, died on September 18th. Age 93. Born in New York City, she was a graduate of The Brearley School and Vassar College. She was married twice; first to C. Victor Barry, then to Edward N. Rich, Jr. of Annapolis, MD. She is survived by her daughter, Lelia Matthews, four grandchildren and three great grandchildren.

title: Suing Big Tobacco: Worth Another Try
description: To the Editor:

title: Criticism Appears to Doom Republican Budget Tactic
description: A Republican strategy to help finance the party's spending plans by delaying Federal tax breaks for working-class families appeared doomed today by opposition from the party's senators and its leading Presidential candidate, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas.

title: 'Impossible Landscapes of the Mind'
description: Hirschl & Adler Galleries

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions yesterday about Johnnie L. Cochran Jr.'s new post at a New York personal injury law firm misstated the location of a fatal crash last year that led to a case on which he worked. It was in Brooklyn, not Queens.

title: More Fraud Found at City Workers' Union
description: Vote fraud in New York City's largest union of municipal workers during its 1996 contract-ratification vote was far greater than previously known, a private investigative firm hired by the union disclosed yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WYNN, LARRY, BORN LESTER LITWIN
description: WYNN-Larry, born Lester Litwin in Brooklyn, New York, died on September 28, 1999 at Englewood Hospital, in New Jersey. Following the Crash of 1929, a stockbroker named Thomas R. Cox volunteered to pay for his college education. After three years at William and Mary, he transferred to Washington & Lee, graduating in 1934. Wynn played semi-professional basketball and softball before he got a job writing songs and singing for a live radio show. He sang with Dinah Shore and played gigs with the well-known Palmer Brothers as Larry Wynn and the Wynners. But it was a session with Billie Holiday (she recorded one of his songs, ''I'm All For You'') that inspired his biggest hit. In 1940, saxophonist Louis Jordan recorded ''Five Guys Named Moe,'' and the song was popular for a number of years, fading until producer Cameron Mackintosh borrowed the title for a musical. Five Guys Named Moe bowed on Broadway in April 1992 and was nominated for two Tony Awards, including Best Musical. The show continues to play to audiences worldwide. Wynn also enjoyed a sucessful career as a salesman in radio and television. He married Evelyn Dawson in 1959. They remainedtogether until her death in 1990. Wynn wrote a weekly well-known column for the New Jersey Bergen Times, until his death. He is survived by a nephew, Edmund Dawson of Hawthorne, New Jersey and Mr. Dawson's daughters, Susan, Wendy and Lisa.

title: Woman, 18, Is Injured by Gunman on Bike
description: An 18-year-old woman who was chatting with a man on a Brooklyn street corner was wounded late Wednesday by a shot fired by a man on a bicycle, the police said yesterday.

title: In Strategy, Valentine Is One-Upped by Cox
description: Bobby Valentine keeps losing the strategic wars. As a result, the Mets should be declared missing in action very soon.

title: Right Bank Is Luring Paris Dealers
description: One night two years ago, the Paris antiques dealer Ariane Dandois recalled, she was at a dinner party, bored stiff.

title: Ah, Sweet Mysteries of Wealth by Way of the Internet
description: NO one knows how many billions of market value has been created by the Internet. But whatever the number is, it is comforting to know that one can still get in and get rich fast.

title: That Very Special Blue B-L-A-N-K-E-T
description: Elmo the Muppet's first movie gets off to an enchanting start. Bert and Ernie welcome everybody; Elmo wakes up in polka dot pajamas in his own adorable little-child's bedroom and sings a tribute to his comforting blue blanket; Elmo spills orange juice on his blanket; Elmo goes to the laundromat to wash it, and a lot of people and Muppets from ''Sesame Street'' are there. The Henson magic is at work.

title: Brazil's Efforts on Budget Imperiled by Court Rulings
description: The country's highest court invalidated two important tax increases today in surprise rulings that could hurt the Government's efforts to narrow the budget deficit. The rulings unnerved investors and stocks tumbled nearly 3 percent.

title: Officer Charged in Theft Of Money From Prisoner
description: A Newark police officer stole $2,550 in cash he found on a female fugitive from Florida, a grand jury charged yesterday.

title: Dmitri Likhachev Dies at 92; Protector of Russia's Heritage
description: Dmitri S. Likhachev, a Russian literary scholar revered as a guardian of national culture and a voice of reason and moral authority, died today in a hospital in St. Petersburg. He was 92 years old.

title: Lowe Unit Handling Roche Campaign
description: Hoffman-La Roche Inc. in Nutley, N.J., part of Roche Holding A. G., is undertaking the first direct-to-consumer brand campaign for any of its products with advertising for a new weight-loss medication, Xenical. Spending is estimated at $70 million to $75 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALMER, ROBERT
description: PALMER-Robert. On September 29, Devoted husband of Eleanor, loving father of Nancy Bick, Jane Bennett and Bruce Palmer and of their spouses, Mel Bick, Walt Bennett and Janet Kraus. Adored grandfather of Jill, Todd, Greg, Douglas, Karen and Phoebe. Long-time stock investor, golfer, sailor, philanthropist, member of The United Church of Rockville Centre. A true gentleman always. Service on Saturday, October 2 at United Church, 430 Morris Ave, Rockville Centre at 2:00 PM. Viewing at Fairchild Funeral Home, 20 Lincoln Ave, Rockville Centre, Friday, October 1 at 2-4 PM and 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers, a donation to your favorite charity.

title: The Dissidents Do Not Speak to All of China
description: To the Editor:

title: Public Interests; Introducing Campaign Y2K
description: The millennium was at hand -- only three months away and counting. Everywhere Americans turned, they saw harbingers of great change. There was flooding in North Carolina, pestilence in New York. The first sex controversy of the 2000 Presidential race turned out to involve Gary Bauer and Steve Forbes. The first great issues debate centered on the advisability of getting into World War II.

title: The Dissidents Do Not Speak to All of China
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN ARSDALE, LEONARD V.
description: VAN ARSDALE-Leonard V. Age 85. Peacefully, at home on September 29, 1999. Beloved husband of Diana Cort-Van Arsdale. Devoted brother of Ruth Carroll Foster. Loving father of Sophia Brooks, Peter Van Arsdale, Laura Summer & Sarah Van Arsdale. Loving stepfather of Hayley Cort, M.D. and Daniel Cort. Cherished grandfather of Anna, Allen, Jessica, Nathan, Kelsa, Martin & Amanda. Services, Schwartz Bros-Jeffers Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, 11AM, Sunday, October 3, 1999.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLZER, ANN
description: HOLZER-Ann. We mourn the passing of Ann Holzer, an elegant lady, most valued member, and a dear friend to everyone in our organization. Neil Barton, Pres., and Members of Long Island Professional Antiques Dealers Association

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCARTHY, ARLEEN M.
description: McCARTHY-Arleen M. October 24, 1920-September 27, 1999. Peacefully, after long illness valiantly met. A memorial gathering of friends will be arranged at a later date. For information call 212835-6239. Contributions in Arleen's memory to the Actors' Fund would be appreciated.

title: Taking From the Rich And Giving to Themselves
description: Nobody beats the British when it comes to concocting cinematic visions of society as a fetid swamp of debauchery and sadism. And ''Plunkett and Macleane,'' the film debut of Jake Scott, a British director from the world of music video, fits right in to a nasty tradition that embraces everything from Ken Russell's portraits of the artist as sacred monster to the kitchen-sink nihilism of ''Trainspotting.''

title: Executive Change At Bozell Chicago
description: Mike Powell has been named executive creative director at the Chicago office of Bozell, part of True North Communications, succeeding David Wojdyla, who left to start his own agency, & Wojdyla in Chicago. Mr. Powell, 40, had been group creative director at Euro RSCG Tatham in Chicago, part of the Euro RSCG Worldwide unit of Havas Advertising.

title: Gore Aide Tied to Effort to Undercut U.S. Tobacco Suit
description: A top campaign consultant to Vice President Al Gore helped the Philip Morris Companies develop television advertisements this spring to undercut support for a planned Federal lawsuit against the tobacco industry.

title: Russian Troops to Chechnya
description: Ground troops entered the breakaway republic and took positions a few miles inside the border, after air strikes on the capital. Page A5.

title: Football Flotilla: Anchors Aweigh for West Point
description: Last year Chris Broderick of Rumson, N.J., his wife, Clare, and four other family members spent two and a half hours driving to an Army football game at West Point, N.Y. On Saturday the Brodericks and nine other relatives and friends spent the same amount of time going to the same place. But this time they traveled by high-speed ferry.

title: Treasuries Rise as Sellers Pause for Rest
description: Treasury bond prices were up for the first time in four days yesterday for several reasons.

title: The Market Sets Value
description: To the Editor:

title: Standing Humbly Before a Noble Family Tradition
description: FAITH OF MY FATHERS

title: A Flash, and an Uncontrolled Chain Reaction
description: Workers at a Japanese nuclear fuel factory were mixing a liquid batch of uranium yesterday when suddenly there was a flash of blue light, the ominous flash of radiation at the moment when the uranium begins a chain reaction or, in the language of the age, goes critical.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Russia's Next Blunder
description: Russia is creating a political mess and possibly a regional war as it continues to bomb Chechnya, the province that humiliated Moscow's troops only a few years ago. Some 60,000 people have fled elsewhere in the region, creating a ''humanitarian catastrophe,'' in the words of Ruslan Aushev, the leader of neighboring Ingushetia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANGA, HARRY, DR.
description: LANGA-Harry, Dr. His family, many friends and colleagues mourn the passing of Dr. Harry Langa on Wednesday, September 29. He was the source and recipient of much love from his beloved wife Evelyn as father, brother, grandfather and great-grandfather. He is survived by his loving wife Evelyn, his children Robert, Roz, Steven; his step-children Ira and Michael Rubin; grandfather of Jeffrey, Kenneth, Laurie, Michael, Danny, Beth, Joel, Jocelyn, Nicole and Jared, his great-grandchildren, and his sister Nell Seifer. He was the author of the book ''Relative Analgesia in Dental Practice'' and a teacher and lecturer all over the world. Funeral service will be at the Schwartz Brothers Funeral Home, Queens Blvd and 76th Road, Sunday, October 3, 9:30AM. All donations are to go the the Dr. Harry Langa Scholarship Fund at the N.Y. University Dental School. 345 E. 24 ST. ATT: Suzanne Ryer

title: Counting the Sizable Risk, in 'Rads,' of Those Exposed to the Radiation
description: Minor doses of radiation released in the nuclear accident at the Tokaimura uranium processing plant are likely to have mild medical effects, but the worst amounts, affecting a few workers at the plant, could prove fatal.

title: Move by Olivetti Backfires With Stock Traders
description: The head of Olivetti S.p.A. struggled today to reverse the most serious trouble he has faced since gaining control in May of Telecom Italia. The chief executive, Roberto Colaninno, said he would meet with institutional investors next Tuesday in Milan and on Wednesday and Thursday in London in an effort to halt a flight of investment capital from the Italian telecommunications giant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADAMS, ROMAINE BRISTOW
description: ADAMS-Romaine Bristow. Of Austin, Texas, New York City, and Newport, R.I. and wife of Warren S. Adams II. Died peacefully in NYC on September 25, 1999. She was the beloved mother of Louise Wheeler Grosvenor. Adored grandmother of Charles Burnett Grosvenor Jr. of Austin, Texas, Leslie Grosvenor Holloway of New Canaan, Connecticut and a devoted great-grandmother of Madeline Louise Holloway, Alexander Grosvenor Holloway and Claire Cordelia Grosvenor. She was dearly loved by her family and greatly admired by her many friends. Her great-grandfather Benjamin Helm Bristow was Secretary of the Treasury in President Grant's Administration. She was the daughter of Louise and William Bristow of NYC and Newport. She was a member of the Colonial Dames of America, The Colony Club of NYC and the Spouting Rock Beach Association & the Clambake Club of Newport. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in her memory to the Youth Foundation, Inc., 36 West 44 St, NYC 10036. A funeral service will be held at St. James Church, 865 Madison Avenue, NYC 11AM on Tuesday, October 5, 1999.

title: A Day of Joy and Jubilation, All Very Carefully Staged
description: China celebrated the 50th anniversary of Communist rule today, orchestrating a nationwide festival of patriotic pride that presented a seamless-looking display of political unity and popular happiness.

title: INSIDE
description: Yankees Clinch Division; The Mets? Don't Ask

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the Jewish holidays of Shemini Atzereth and Simhath Torah, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Saturday and Sunday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Yanks Clinch East, but (Ahem) Best Record Is Undecided
description: Joe Torre's eyes were red before the first streams of champagne ran down his cheeks tonight, after the Yankees clinched the American League East by routing Baltimore, 12-5. There are playoff games to be won or lost in the month ahead, but Torre and other Yankees ignored all that, paused and reflected.

title: Top Pataki Adviser to Quit For Job on Bush Campaign
description: Charles A. Gargano, Gov. George E. Pataki's top economic adviser, will leave the state government soon to take a top position in George W. Bush's Presidential campaign in New York, advisers to Mr. Pataki said today.

title: Tower to Rise Above Port Authority Terminal
description: In yet another indication that the search for increasingly rare development sites in Times Square is pushing westward, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey selected a developer yesterday to build a $500 million, 35-story office tower atop the bus terminal at 42d Street and Eighth Avenue.

title: Jets Hope Smith's Return Will Let the Defense Rest
description: When he was 32 years old, he was picked on unmercifully by opposing quarterbacks. Now Otis Smith, who will be 34 in a few weeks, is among the half-dozen oldest starting cornerbacks in pro football and has not played in two months, since breaking his left collarbone in practice Aug. 5.

title: Beware, the Parenting Police
description: In the Western world, anxious parents love to follow scientific studies that tell them what to do with their babies.

title: Sports of The Times; This Team May Watch From Stands
description: SIX weeks ago, there was speculation that Masato Yoshii would be dropped from the Mets' post-season roster. This was based on the assumption -- credible at the time -- that the Mets would actually make it to the playoffs.

title: McPhee Gets One-Month Ban
description: Woody Hayes would have understood, wouldn't he?

title: Record Payout In Settlements Against Police
description: New York City paid out a record $40 million in the last fiscal year to resolve legal claims and lawsuits that accused its police officers of brutality, up 40 percent from the prior year, according to an analysis by the Comptroller's office.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARFUNKEL, HAROLD J.
description: GARFUNKEL-Harold J. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Harold J. Garfunkel, a cherished friend who was deeply devoted to the Jewish community. As a dedicated leader, he embraced the compassionate commitment of his father, who was a founder of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, the predecessor to UJA-Federation. Following in his father's footsteps, he served as a life trustee of Federation, and was a longtime officer of Altro, one of our earliest beneficiary agencies. We extend our sincerest condolences to his daughter, Marjorie Baker Bachrach, and his son-in-law, Robert Lee Bachrach; his daughter, Deborah G. Bloch, and his sonin-law, Robert W. Bloch; and his entire family. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair James S. Tisch, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec V.P.

title: Art Lovers Peruse Exhibit and Defy Giuliani
description: Nibbling shrimp and baby lobster tails, talking on cell phones and solemnly contemplating such works of art as a sink and plumbing nestled in what looked like a musician's case lined in red velvet, New York's culturati gathered proudly last night at the Brooklyn Museum of Art in defiance of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's bruised esthetic sensibilities.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COPPER HIGHER. Copper prices were higher on news that Phelps Dodge had agreed to buy Cyprus Amax Minerals, a move that could reduce excess production. December copper was up 1.6 cents at 82.65 cents a pound.

title: TWO MORE ACQUISITIONS ARE ANNOUNCED BY WELLS FARGO
description: Wells Fargo & Company agreed yesterday to buy North County Bancorp for $21 a share in stock, about $112 million, to add San Diego-area branches. North County, which is based in Escondido, Calif., has nine branches, $349 million in assets and 250 employees. Wells Fargo, based in San Francisco, also said it would buy the closely held real estate investment bank Eastdil Realty L.L.C. of New York for undisclosed terms. Eastdil specializes in debt, corporate real estate and other services. With the deals, Wells has made three acquisitions in two days. On Wednesday, the bank said it had agreed to buy Ragen Mackenzie Group, a small Seattle retail brokerage firm, for about $252.3 million in stock.

title: Fed Is Now Expected to Leave Rates Unchanged
description: The economy is still growing at a rapid clip. Commodity prices are rising. With unemployment low, workers are demanding and getting higher wages.

title: Health Insurer Shares Fall on Threat of Suits
description: Shares of Aetna Inc., the United Healthcare Corporation and other major health insurers fell amid reports that trial lawyers were preparing lawsuits on behalf of managed-care patients.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENGELBERG, LAZAR
description: ENGELBERG-Lazar. 96. Died peacefully at home in New York City September 27, 1999. A survivor with his wife of 57 years Lena of the Holocaust. Surviving with his wife are his loving brother and sister-in-law John and Lee Hauser.

title: Critics Say G.O.P. Move Undercuts H.M.O. Bill
description: Supporters of a comprehensive House bill to regulate managed care are accusing the Republican leadership of trying to scuttle the legislation by tying it to a separate bill that contains tax credits that Democrats strongly oppose.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARNOLD, NICK
description: ARNOLD-Nick. March 1, 1947-September 28, 1999. Beloved son of Grace Melito, adored brother of Lucia, loving father of Josh, Andrew and Diana. Writer par excellence for Joan Rivers, Johnny Carson, Cher, David Letterman and countless others; courageous gentleman, renaissance man, and friend of all. Mass at 11AM, Saturday, October 2nd, at the Good Shepherd Church, Bedford Drive, Beverly Hills, California.

title: The Game's Up for a Pitcher, A Thief and a Suburban Dad
description: Blue Streak

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHANTZ, ROSE
description: SCHANTZ-Rose. Devoted wife and mother, born October 20, 1923. Died September 29, 1999. She is survived by her husband Morris, sons Philip and Ricky, daughters Sherri and Penny, brother Abe Glass, and sister Harriet Goldenberg, and three grandchildren.

title: That Old 3-D Magic, With Smoke and Tigers
description: Movies are not a hospitable medium for magic, at least not the kind of magic practiced in Las Vegas by Siegfried and Roy.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: TIBCO BUYING XEROX'S INCONCERT UNIT FOR $34 MILLION
description: Tibco Software Inc., which makes software that links computer programs together for businesses, agreed yesterday to buy Inconcert Inc. from the Xerox Corporation for $34 million in cash. Tibco, based in Palo Alto, Calif., which first sold shares to the public in July, said that the acquisition of Inconcert, based in Cambridge, Mass., would help it offer more products to the telecommunications industry, including software that handles billing and operating systems. Inconcert's customers include AT&T, Sprint and Qwest Communications International Inc. Its Teoss product line helps businesses exchange invoices and other information between departments, Tibco said.

title: Political Memo; Giuliani Base Is Shored, But the Risks Are High
description: If there is one place in New York where Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani can generally count on a warm reception, it is the Metropolitan Opera House, where he has for years been reliably cheered by performers and audiences alike, an affirmation of both Mr. Giuliani's support for opera and his perceived record at improving the quality of life in the city.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NURSE, EUGENE
description: NURSE-Eugene. Devoted husband of Annarose. Beloved father of Dorian Tricarico and Rosemary. Father-in-law of Frank. Loving grandfather of Dana, Alexandra Eugene & Francesca. Dear brother of Ronald and Roy. Reposing at Pitta Funeral Home, 300 McDonald Ave., Brooklyn until Monday 9:15AM. Mass of Christian burial at the Immaculate Heart of Mary Church, Fort Hamilton Pkwy. and East 4th St. at 9:45AM. Visitation Saturday and Sunday 2-5PM and 710 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Calvary Hospital or St. Rose Home.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Major Stock Gauges Finish 3d Quarter on Positive Note

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY /Technology; Looking Under the Hood of a Hybrid Honda
description: HONDA and Toyota started with the same concept, an automobile powered by both an internal-combustion engine and an electric motor, and each company will begin shipping such hybrid cars to dealers in a few months, the first of what environmentalists hope will be a flood of innovative cars from companies around the world. But the two Japanese companies that will be the first to market have assembled similar ingredients into products as different as a potato chip is from a French fry.

title: Fund Adviser Is Indicted In $3 Billion Fraud Case
description: Martin A. Armstrong, the investment adviser and chairman of Princeton Economics International, was indicted by a Federal grand jury yesterday on charges that he defrauded foreign investors in connection with the sale of $3 billion in securities issued by Princeton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GHAREMANI, DR. FERIDOUN
description: GHAREMANI - Dr. Feridoun. Temple Beth-El of Great Neck records with profound sorrow the passing of its member. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his bereaved family. Shelley M. Limmer, President Jerome K. Davidson, Rabbi

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: A 'Lucia' Shorn of Accrued Acrobatics
description: Wednesday's performance of ''Lucia di Lammermoor'' at the Metropolitan Opera was the 525th the company has presented, but the first to follow Donizetti's score. Display items accruing from long after the composer's death, including sustained top notes at the ends of numbers and the cadenza with flute in the mad scene, were scrupulously expunged, and the mad scene was also restored to its putative original form by the provision of a glass harmonica, an instrument producing spooky tones from rubbed glass containers, though Donizetti may have replaced this by a flute even before the first performance.

title: Nassau Escalates Its War Against Mosquitoes
description: Sharply escalating its effort to kill mosquitoes that may be carrying the West Nile virus, Nassau County said yesterday that it would start aerial spraying across the county tomorrow night.

title: Removing the Bullets and Trying to Judge a Show
description: The handmade shotguns displayed as sculpture that resulted in the arrest on Wednesday night of the gallery owner Mary Boone were hardly a novelty for the artist, Tom Sachs.

title: The New Hard Men in Timor's Capital: Freedom Fighters
description: There was a new presence in the streets of Dili today: hard, no-nonsense men with berets, flowing hair and tiny two-way radios, the victors in a 24-year war of independence for East Timor.

title: China's Anniversary Party
description: The People's Republic of China, whose birth Mao Zedong triumphantly proclaimed from Tiananmen Square 50 years ago today, can claim some proud achievements. Ordinary Chinese citizens now enjoy higher standards of health, nutrition, education and personal comfort than at any previous time in the Middle Kingdom's long history. Beijing is also reclaiming its status as a great world power for the first time since foreign imperialists began imposing humiliating concessions on the Manchu emperors a century and a half ago.

title: BRACKNELL BUYING NATIONWIDE ELECTRIC FOR $76.7 MILLION
description: The Bracknell Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Nationwide Electric Inc. for $76.7 million in cash and stock. Nationwide Electric, based in Minneapolis, is a privately held electrical services company with annual revenue of more than $225 million. Bracknell will also assume $15 million of Nationwide Electric's term debt and a revolving credit line. Bracknell, a Toronto-based provider of electrical, technical and facility-management services, reported revenue of $220.5 million for the nine months ended July 31.

title: U.S. Resolves A Dispute With Russia On Computers
description: The United States and Russia have quietly resolved a long-simmering dispute over the illegal sale of sophisticated I.B.M. computers to Russia's leading nuclear weapons lab, American officials said today.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: In London, stylish food and stylish clothing found each other a long time ago. One of the city's most chic and animated dining scenes can be found on the fifth floor of Harvey Nichols's department store, and Nicole Fahri, the clothing designer, did not think twice about installing an up-to-the minute cafe in her London shop on Bond Street.

title: Belgrade Again Forces Protesters to Halt
description: Riot policemen stopped a march of anti-Government demonstrators tonight for the second consecutive night, clubbing opposition leaders without provocation and stampeding thousands of people back toward the center of Belgrade.

title: Ex-Compaq Chief Takes a New Job
description: Eckhard Pfeiffer, who stepped down as chief executive of financially troubled Compaq Computer in April, said today that he would become chairman of Intershop Communications Corporation, a maker of Internet communications software with offices here and in Germany.

title: A HALF-CENTURY IN CHINA: THE WITNESS; Watching the Old Order Collapse, and the Communist Revolution Take Hold
description: On April 22, 1949, Chiang Kai-shek's Nationalist capital, Nanjing, lay prostrate before Communist troops swarming across the Yangtze River in their climactic offensive of the Chinese civil war.

title: BOEING WINS ANOTHER ORDER FROM DELTA FOR 737's
description: Delta Air Lines Inc. said it would buy 18 more Boeing 737-800 aircraft in an order valued at as much as $976.5 million as it replaces older, noisier Boeing 727's. The orders, placed in the last three months, build on a previous purchase of the planes, Delta, which is based in Atlanta, said. Delta's total order now includes 125 of the 737's. Delta wants to keep pace with competitors, which are also replacing older, less fuel-efficient planes. Boeing's 737-800 is a single-aisle plane that can seat 162 to 189 passengers, depending on its configuration.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCHI, FRANCESCA (NEE DEL COL)
description: MARCHI-Francesca (nee Del Col). Co-founder of Marchi's Restaurant, Manhattan. Beloved wife of the late Lorenzo. Devoted mother of Mario, Robert and John. Loving sister of Basilio. Also survived by four grandchildren and four great grandchildren. Reposing at Perazzo Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker St., NYC. Funeral mass Saturday, 10 AM, Madonna Church on the Hill. Entombment Madonna Mausoleum. Visiting Thursday 7-9:30 PM and Friday 2-5 and 7-9:30 PM. In lieu of flowers donations to St. Rose's Home, 71 Jackson Street, NYC 10002 would be appreciated.

title: The Team's Sale Is Moving Slowly
description: More than a month after signing a letter of intent to acquire the Islanders, Bob Gutkowski's $180 million bid to buy the team is moving slowly, with no certainty of success.

title: Margaret Kilgallen -- 'To Friend and Foe'
description: Lane Twitchell

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASHFORTH, BETTY THOMSON OVERTON
description: ASHFORTH - Betty Thomson Overton. Widow of George Thayer Ashforth, died on September 27, 1999. She was 91 years old and a resident of Greenwich, CT. Betty was born March 10, 1908 in Dallas, Texas. She was the daughter of Garland Bruce Overton and Louise Lanier Maney Overton. Her early years were spent in Dallas, TX and Louisville, KY. She was a 1931 graduate of Bryn Mawr College, and worked at Macmillan & Co., publishers in New York. Later she was Editor of Art and Production at Farrar and Rinehart, New York. On February 28, 1942, she married George Thayer Ashforth, a son of Albert B. Ashforth. George Ashforth was then head of the Jokake School for Girls in Phoenix, AZ. During the war, both she and her husband contributed to various war relief efforts. In 1947, she began to assist her husband with his new duties as Executive Director of Five Points House, a foundation for dependent children in Pomona, New York. In 1964 they moved to Greenwich, CT. Betty Ashforth is survived by her son, George Bruce Ashforth, her sister-in-law, Elsie L. Ashforth, nephews G. Bruce Overton III, Henry A. Ashforth, Jr., and Alden B. Ashforth, nieces Eleanor A. Harvey, Marna A. Geoffrey, Diana A. Chase, Mabel A. Goldman and Gay A. Wilson and numerous grandnieces and grandnephews. The burial at Putnam Cemetery, Greenwich will be private. Contributions in lieu of flowers may be made to the Greenwich Library, Greenwich, CT

title: University Stands Firm In Using Race In Admissions
description: Disregarding the strongly worded advice of a Federal judge, the University of Georgia announced today that it would continue to use race as a factor in admitting up to 20 percent of its freshman class.

title: Soul Music
description: Playwrights Horizon has set itself the daunting task of adapting James Joyce's music for the page to music for the stage with its version of ''The Dead,'' which begins previews tonight. Joyce, right, was himself a fine tenor, and his story -- in which he wanted to say something about Ireland's musical soul -- is as imbued with music as any work in the Western tradition.

title: Sometimes Accepting an Identity Means Accepting a Fate, Too
description: Kimberley Peirce's stunning debut feature, ''Boys Don't Cry,'' tells the strange and resonant story of Brandon Teena, who despite being born Teena Brandon, went on to create a charismatic identity as an attractive young man. When Brandon was found out, raped and murdered, this tabloid-ready tale attracted the kind of omnivorous media attention that distorts the truth beyond recognition and milks reality dry.

title: A Portal Leading to Self-Parody
description: Among the hits to emerge from this year's New York Film Festival -- like Pedro Almodovar's ''All About My Mother,'' Kimberley Peirce's ''Boys Don't Cry,'' Mike Leigh's ''Topsy-Turvy'' and Kevin Smith's ''Dogma'' -- none is more endearingly nutty than ''Being John Malkovich.'' None is more intriguingly prophetic, either. In this irresistible first feature by the stellar video director Spike Jonze, the reigning fears and obsessions of a technology-crazed, voyeuristic culture are given an even wilder workout than they got in ''The Truman Show.'' And the bizarre, masklike facade of today's lonely Everyman is again in the spotlight, even before Milos Forman's film about Andy Kaufman comes to town.

title: Communist China at 50: It's Stability vs. Reform
description: Wang Ruoshui was on Tiananmen Square that electric day half a century ago today when Mao Zedong announced: ''The People's Republic of China is founded! From this time on, the Chinese people have stood up!''

title: A Small Hockey Town Takes on the Big Guys
description: When it comes to capturing the bone-crunching, high-velocity world of sports, Hollywood has a surprisingly spotty record, often preferring to present the game as metaphor (''Field of Dreams'') instead of diving into the bruising reality of the arena. But ''Mystery, Alaska,'' an upbeat meat-and-potatoes movie that is a striking change in directorial style for Jay Roach, who oversaw the garish Austin Powers romps, conveys some of the thrill and ferocity of ice hockey while skillfully folding together multiple personal dramas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUBROW, HELEN
description: DUBROW-Helen. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Hillard Dubrow. Adored mother of Heather, fond sister of the late Harriet Falk and Cecil Volk. At Mrs. Dubrow's request services and burial private. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to Hillard Dubrow MD Fund at Lenox Hill Hospital, NYC. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St. on Saturday 2-5pm.

title: An Entree of Skewered Patrons and Mixed Nuts
description: There is life in prison without parole. There is walking on a bed of stainless-steel spikes without your shoes on. There is being shackled to the wall of a dark chamber crawling with giant tarantulas. And then there is the restaurant business.

title: Seeking Catcalls From the Masses: Back to the Futurists' Revolution
description: You could get the idea from a day in the galleries that the art world wants to tear down the house it used to live in. Let bygones be bygones, the galleries say, and conventional art be gone. Installations, photography, mixed media and performance art elbow aside painting and sculpture; plastic and stuffed dolls stand in for marble and bronze. Outrageousness replaces beauty. Detritus reigns.

title: Jim Nutt -- 'Portraits'
description: Nolan/Eckman Gallery

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: A Hard-Line Palestinian Returns to the West Bank
description: A leading Palestinian radical, one of the few renegades who had remained committed to armed struggle against Israel, returned home from Damascus today after 32 years in exile.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 8.

title: Review/Fashion; The Studied, the Buoyant and the Silly
description: This is a city that disguises itself well; it is Marcello Mastroianni on the outside and Gidget underneath. No matter how full the streets are with perfectly attired men cycling to work, no matter how decorous the homes and offices, Milan is a city whose people are capable of egregious transgressions of urbanity.

title: New Center Will Combat Computer Security Threats
description: The Treasury Department will announce today that the Federal Government and the financial services industry have established an information clearinghouse to combat threats to computer security and vulnerabilities in computer systems.

title: City Must Shield Workfare Force On Harassment
description: The Giuliani administration violated Federal law when it turned away women who said they were being sexually harassed while working for their public assistance benefits, the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission ruled in a decision made public yesterday.

title: Suing Big Tobacco: Worth Another Try
description: To the Editor:

title: Campaign Retooled, but Gore Makes Usual Stops
description: On the first day of his retooled campaign, Vice President Al Gore spent a day much like any other. He addressed corporate officials in New York City, walked the streets of a depressed upstate town and returned to the city to meet with reporters and then financial contributors for his second fund-raiser in two days.

title: Cnet Shifts Duties To Leagas Delaney
description: Cnet Inc., which offers on-line and television programming about computers and high technology, is unexpectedly shifting the duties for creating the TV and radio commercials that are a central part of its $100 million marketing campaign to the San Francisco office of Leagas Delaney from Citron Haligman Bedecarre Euro RSCG in San Francisco.

title: Big Quake Inflicts Little Damage in Mexico
description: A big earthquake gave southern Mexico a good shake today but did surprisingly little damage.

title: Besides the History, There's the Art, Mostly Vintage
description: Until the upstart Metropolitan Museum of Art came along in 1872, the New-York Historical Society, founded in 1804, was the place in town to see American art. Begun as a repository for United States and New York State historical materials, the society became an art museum as well in 1858 when it was given the collection of contemporary American art formed by Luman Reed (1795-1836), a New York merchant and art patron.

title: Ernst Einstein, 76, Carpet Store Founder
description: Ernst Einstein, a founding partner in Einstein Moomjy Inc., the carpet-store chain, died Wednesday in a hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 76.

title: Fighting the Battle Of Money and Greed
description: With his uncommonly assured first two films, ''Spanking the Monkey'' and the pitch-perfect ''Flirting With Disaster,'' the writer and director David O. Russell didn't need much to make an indelible impression. His timing was fabulous, his ideas fresh and his taboo-busting imagination much to be admired. Now Mr. Russell moves onto a much bigger battlefield with ''Three Kings,'' an absurdist, gimlet-eyed ''Catch-22'' for the Persian Gulf war. It's ultimately a much more ambitious and impassioned work. But it isn't nearly as successful a showcase for this filmmaker's extraordinary talents.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Chicago Journal; In a City With Cattle in Its Past, the Cows Have Come Home
description: Now he had seen it all. The exasperated Chicago police sergeant called to alert the authorities at City Hall. Get this, he told them: A fiberglass cow is standing in the middle of Michigan Avenue.

title: Coke in Move Against Bias Suit
description: Lawyers for the Coca-Cola Company asked a Federal judge yesterday to punish the lawyers for four black employees who filed a racial discrimination lawsuit against the company, saying the plaintiffs' lawyers had falsely accused the company of shredding documents related to the case.

title: Ford Planning To Spin Off Parts Division
description: The Ford Motor Company plans to spin off its giant auto parts division directly to shareholders and give wage and job guarantees to the division's factory workers in a contract under negotiation with the United Automobile Workers union, people close to the matter said.

title: A Mighty Port's Final Call; Bayonne Army Terminal Closes, Its Future in Doubt
description: An era ended today, not with a bang but with a mournful happy hour at Kapps Bar and Grill on Broadway.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MAUTNER, MATTHEW ERICH
description: MAUTNER-Matthew Erich. Darling Mackie, you are always, always with me. Mo

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: Some Changes In Direction

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALEY, BARBARA
description: PALEY-Barbara. Attorney at Law. Beloved daughter of Sidney and Frieda. Dear sister of Eileen. Cherished niece. Services Friday, October 1, 1999, 11AM at the Dix Hills Chapel of I.J. Morris, Inc., 21 East Deer Park Rd, Dix Hills, L.I. Active in Long Island politics and member of Washington, D.C. law firm. Graduate of Hofstra University, Yale Graduate School and Georgetown Law School.

title: Some Power-Hungry Pigs And Other Political Animals
description: Collectivizing the farm turned out to be a rotten idea, Jessie the dog lets us know at the start of ''Animal Farm,'' TNT's stylish, shrewd but oddly unengaging version of Orwell's classic. Barely mentioned in the book, here Jessie is its melodious-voiced narrator. ''It was a storm of judgment,'' she says as the camera roams over the lush, rain-ravaged countryside and she recalls how the rebellious animals took control of the farm, only to have their socialist dreams destroyed by a megalomaniac leader, a pig named Napoleon.

title: Defender Of Art Show But Not a Fan
description: SEVEN o'clock in the morning found Peter F. Vallone yesterday where he is every day at that hour: in a pew at St. Francis of Assisi Roman Catholic Church in Astoria, Queens. He joined 18 of his neighbors in prayer, and heard Msgr. Thomas Campbell read a passage from Nehemiah about how the people gathered around and listened attentively as the law was explained to them.

title: INSURER'S BIG GAIN
description: The big French insurance company Axa S.A. reported first-half profit of 1.47 billion euros, or $1.55 billion, up more than 59 percent from a year earlier. Earnings soared partly because of the $5.7 billion acquisition in February of the British insurer, Guardian Royal Exchange P.L.C. Without its results Axa's earnings increase would have been about 27 percent, to $1.23 billion. Earnings from casualty and property insurance rose by 80 percent, to $370 million, while profit from life insurance remained stable at $630 million.

title: Celebrating Strength
description: To the Editor:

title: O.K., a Toast To a Century: Which One?
description: OPENING nights at major institutions in this city look remarkably alike from both sides of the footlights. Carnegie Hall on Wednesday had at least the most glamour onstage -- the Vienna Philharmonic and Lorin Maazel in the first of four concerts. But the message there was pretty much the same as the one sent out by the New York Philharmonic a week ago (tried and true Dvorak and Tchaikovsky) and the Metropolitan Opera on Monday (tried and true Mascagni and Leoncavallo). The Philharmonic and the Met had their stars to display (Mstislav Rostropovich and Placido Domingo, respectively). The Vienna has become almost as much of an institution in New York as it is at home.

title: DaimlerChrysler Says Storm Will Cut Profit
description: DaimlerChrysler A.G. confirmed late on Wednesday that Hurricane Floyd would reduce third-quarter earnings by 9 cents to 12 cents a share.

title: Visa to Trim Jobs In Reorganization
description: Visa International Inc., the world's biggest credit card association, said this week that it would dismiss 120 to 140 people as it gives its member banks more control over the business.

title: Dunston Composed Despite Mistake
description: Shawon Dunston retreated on Brian Jordan's fly ball to right field in the 11th inning and expected it to harmlessly drop into his glove. Dunston spotted the ball flying through the black night, glanced at the fence as he approached the warning track and then peeked up and lost sight of that white speck. It is an outfielder's nightmare.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KILSTOCK, PHYLLIS
description: KILSTOCK-Phyllis. The Officers and Board of Directors of the American Associates, Ben-Gurion University of Negev, mourn the passing of our dear friend Phyllis Kilstock who together with her husband generously supported many programs at BGU over the years. We extend our deepest sympathies to her husband Kurt and to her children Debra, Frances and Richard; and to her grandchildren. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jules I. Whitman, President Edith & Solomon Freedman, Greater NY Regional Co-Chairs Bernard C. Moscovitz, Exec VP, AABGU

title: INSIDE ART
description: Another Estate, More Picassos

title: ALBUM OF THE WEEK
description: ROYAL TRUX: ''Veterans of Disorder'' (Drag City). Rock may be losing its sense of confusion. Easily sorted into camps and sounds these days, and into both the mainstream and the substreams, the music is more calculated than ever to make you feel a certain way, happy or sad, or angry or obnoxious. So it's nice to hear the eighth Royal Trux album and think one more time, What on earth are these people up to?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAUL, JANE M. HUNTER
description: PAUL-Jane M. Hunter. September 13, 1917-September 28, 1999. Beloved mother, grandmother, sister, aunt, wife; survived by daughter Barbara, son Herbert; daughter and son-in-law Rosalind and Stephen; brothers Edward and Richard; sister Edith; proud grandmother to Dana and Allison; loving aunt to her many nieces and nephews. Best friend. From the Depression to the Millennium, you were our rock and our heartirreplaceable you.

title: Private Collections Routine at Museums
description: The Brooklyn Museum of Art's particular mix of art and commerce -- an exhibition of art that is owned by one private collector and partially financed by an auction house -- may not pass muster at City Hall, but it violates no hard-and-fast rules in the precincts of the museum world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FABIAN, CHARLOTTE
description: FABIAN-Charlotte. Beloved wife of the late Heinz Kurt Fabian. Dear sister of John Ellis, loving aunt, great-aunt and great grandaunt. Graveside service 10:30AM today at Cedar Park Cemetery, Emerson, New Jersey.

title: Sixdegrees.com Narrows Review to 3
description: Sixdegrees.com in New York, which operates a Web site devoted to ''personal community'' networks, has narrowed a review for its first account, with billings estimated at $6 million to $10 million, to three finalists. They are: DiMassimo Brand Advertising in New York, Grace & Rothschild in New York and PSK in Boston. A decision in the review, being handled by Pile & Company in Boston, is expected later in October.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the groundbreaking for the National Museum of the American Indian misstated the previous occupation of Kevin Gover, who now heads the Bureau of Indian Affairs. He was previously a lawyer in private practice. He is not a law professor at Yale.

title: Glimpses of the World AIDS Has Wrought
description: Gay men have sexual encounters in a car parked on a Paris street, in a young stranger's apartment, in a New York subway station, beside a perfect beach and in a hospital room. Lesbians talk about H.I.V. while strolling near dawn by the Seine. Condoms are everywhere.

title: History or Propaganda?/ Communist-Era TV Show Stages a Controversial Return : 'Major Zeman' Leads Czechs to Question Their Past
description: PRAGUE  Call it the last case of Major Zeman. Czechoslovakia's favorite television detective during Communist rule is back on active duty in the Czech Republic, and this time his dogged pursuit of lawbreakers and bourgeois agitators has put the public broadcaster, Czech Television, in the dock.

title: Gunter Grass Gets Nobel Prize in Literature
description: Gunter Grass, whose epic first novel, ''The Tin Drum,'' tackled the theme of Germany's agonized identity, which he has examined from various angles throughout his life, was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature today by the Swedish Academy in Stockholm.

title: A Man Who Knew the Elite But Wasn't Known Himself
description: Narrated by Walter Cronkite, a peculiar documentary titled ''Uncommon Friends of the 20th Century'' is built on the relationships of a Zelig-like Floridian named Jim Newton with some of the foremost figures of this time.

title: Boy Next Door Is the Next Best Thing
description: As teen-age romantic comedies go, ''Drive Me Crazy'' ranks among the easy to take.

title: See the Show, Buy the Rat
description: With a dead shark, dismembered plastic heads, and, of course, plentiful elephant dung, the ''Sensation'' exhibit at the Brooklyn Museum of Art does not exactly lend itself to cute merchandising. But that hasn't prevented the museum from trying.

title: Advisers to Regents Back CUNY's Remedial Plan
description: A panel of outside experts advising the New York Regents recommended yesterday that the City University of New York be allowed to proceed with its plan to bar students needing remedial instruction from its bachelor's degree programs.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN FALLS The yen fell against the dollar after an accident at a Japanese uranium processing plant made traders nervous about holding Japan's currency. The yen fell to 106.27 to the dollar from 106.98 on Wednesday.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: J. P. Morgan to Take Korean Brokerage Stake
description: J. P. Morgan & Company agreed today to take a 10 percent stake in the SK Securities Company, settling a $380 million lawsuit and ending more than a year of legal wrangling with several Korean financial institutions over losses in derivative securities.

title: Led by Republicans, House Approves Bill Giving the Fetus Legal Protection
description: Despite a veto threat from President Clinton, the House of Representatives today passed a bill that would grant a measure of legal protection to the human fetus by establishing new criminal penalties for anyone who injures or harms the fetus while committing another Federal offense.

title: I.O.C. Push For Reform Seeks Rules On Bribery
description: The International Olympic Committee, seeking to reform itself in the wake of the Salt Lake City corruption scandal, has asked to be governed by a Paris-based economic group's antibribery rules that were adopted by 34 countries in 1997.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about the Consumer Product Safety Commission's warning against having children under 2 sleep in adult beds misstated the given name of a woman in Fremont, Calif., who says she and her husband sleep with their infant daughter. She is Valerie Wright, not Jennifer.

title: GORE AND BRADLEY POISED TO ENGAGE IN EARLY DEBATES
description: Vice President Al Gore and former Senator Bill Bradley are poised to begin an unusually early and intense series of debates in the run-up to the primary season next year. As a start, their campaigns said today that they had agreed to take part in a nationally televised town meeting four weeks from now in New Hampshire.

title: Art Dealer Says Arrest Is an Attack On Rights
description: After being led from her eponymous Fifth Avenue art gallery in handcuffs late Wednesday and spending a sleepless night and the better part of a day in custody, the art dealer Mary Boone assailed the police yesterday for arresting her on charges of illegally distributing ammunition that was part of an exhibition.

title: Residential Real Estate; Luxury Project in Hoboken, but Not on the River
description: Four blocks inland from Hoboken's reviving Hudson River waterfront, construction crews are reshaping nearly an entire block into a 302-unit luxury rental apartment complex, to be called Hudson Park.

title: Most Divorces Are Valid
description: To the Editor:

title: SFX Continues Buying Spree
description: SFX Entertainment yesterday acquired Tellem & Associates, which represents Nomar Garciaparra, Kobe Bryant and Reggie Miller, continuing its buying spree of sports agencies. It began last year with the purchase of David Falk's firm, which was best known for its star client Michael Jordan.

title: Bradley Pulls Ahead of Gore In Latest Fund-Raising Lap
description: In another sign that his bid for the Democratic Presidential nomination is gaining strength, former Senator Bill Bradley has raised more money than Vice President Al Gore in the last three months.

title: On My Mind; St. Joseph's Murder
description: The beginning of the amateur video shows the first day of worship in the handsome new church -- the congregation taking communion from the Catholic priests. The film is dated Feb. 14, 1999.

title: Japanese Fuel Plant Spews Radiation After Accident
description: In the worst accident in Japan's troubled history with nuclear power, an out-of-control chain reaction Thursday at a fuel plant 87 miles northwest of Tokyo spewed high levels of radiation into the air. Thirty-five people were exposed, three of them seriously injured, and 300,000 residents were ordered to stay indoors.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Watch Out For a Breakout

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVENTHAL, ANNE (NEE WEISMAN)
description: LEVENTHAL-Anne (nee Weisman). Beloved wife of Moe. Adored Aunt and Great Aunt. Services Friday, 1PM, at Schwartz Brothers Jeffer Memorial, Queens Blvd at 76th Rd, Forest Hills.

title: Indexes Close Out Negative Quarter With a Positive Day
description: Stocks closed out a largely negative quarter on a positive note yesterday as a rally in the bond market helped to push major market indexes higher.

title: Talks Seek to Halt Yonkers Teachers' Strike
description: Teachers' union and school officials in Yonkers continued negotiating past yesterday's midnight strike deadline and into this morning in an attempt to agree on a new contract.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JEROME, ROBERT
description: JEROME-Robert. The Simon Wiesenthal Center extends its sincerest condolences to our trustees, long time supporters and friends, Elaine and Norman Brodsky. May the entire Jerome and Brodsky families be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem and know of no further sorrow for a long time. Simon Wiesenthal Center Rabbi Marvin Hier, Dean and Founder Nelson Peltz, Co-Chairman Rhonda Barad, Eastern Director

title: Missing What Didn't Add Up, NASA Subtracted an Orbiter
description: Simple confusion over whether measurements were metric or not led to the loss of a $125 million spacecraft last week as it approached Mars, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today.

title: Gustavo Leigh Guzman, 79, Who Served in Chilean Junta
description: Gustavo Leigh Guzman, who was a key figure in Chile's four-man military junta led by Gen. Augusto Pinochet but who later broke with the junta, died Wednesday at the air force hospital in Santiago, Chile. He was 79.

title: Majestic and Brooding, A Fort Holds Its Ground
description: The most vivid memory I have of my childhood visit to Fort Ticonderoga was not what I witnessed but how I reacted to what I saw.

title: Hartford Puts Off Sexually Charged Exhibit in City Gallery Next to City Playground
description: It may not have the cultural or political wattage of New York City, but Hartford has touched off its own tussle over taste and publicly financed art.

title: A Night for Giuliani to Pay Tribute to the Reagan Legacy
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani wrapped himself in the legacy of Ronald Reagan tonight in a speech that glorified the former President and seemed an unusual approach for an unannounced Senate candidate who would need Democratic votes to win in New York State.

title: Two Unlikely Candidates To Win Mr. Congeniality
description: If ''Happy, Texas,'' a risk-free satire that picked up some positive buzz at this year's Sundance Film Festival, catches the public's fancy, it will be because the nonsensical story of a pair of crooks ducking the law in a small Texas town is so soft-hearted it wouldn't hurt a fly. Almost everybody in this not-so-funny comedy is giddy and cuddlesome with a gosh-oh-gee enthusiasm that is at first engaging, but quickly becomes a sign of a desperation to be liked.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WYKER, MILDRED, ''BILLIE.''
description: WYKER-Mildred, ''Billie.'' On Sept. 26 in Palm Beach, FL. Beloved wife of the late Salie Wyker, loving mother of Pat Silbert and Bob Wyker, devoted grandmother of Michael Silbert, Scott Silbert, Laurie Dunning, Shelley Sharkey, Kenneth Wyker, Amy Campbell & ten great grandchildren. Memorial Service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, NYC at 3PM on Sunday, October 3, 1999.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- Real or Virtual? You Call It; Digital Sleight of Hand Can Put Ads Almost Anywhere
description: A NEW form of advertising is rewriting an old saying to declare: Now you don't see it, now you do.

title: Senate G.O.P. to Allow Vote On Pact to Ban Nuclear Tests
description: In an abrupt but calculated reversal, the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, offered today to schedule a quick vote on a treaty banning nuclear testing, expressing confidence that Republicans have the votes to defeat one of President Clinton's top foreign policy goals.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: New Video Releases
description: Pushing Tin

title: Thomas Foster, 49, Poultry Farm Owner
description: Thomas O. Foster, 49, a philanthropist, amateur racing driver and executive of Foster Poultry Farms, one of the nation's largest privately held businesses, died Sept. 22 at his home in Hickman, Calif., a farming hamlet in the San Joaquin Valley. He had diabetes and related heart problems, a company spokeswoman said.

title: A Trove of Titles At the Library
description: In 1988 the MacArthur Foundation Library Video Project set out to alert the public that libraries were good places to find many titles one didn't find lying around the average video store. Librarians needed to be reminded, too.

title: The Dissidents Do Not Speak to All of China
description: To the Editor:

title: Riding a Rare Breed of Horse
description: My horse, named Jorp, was a good-natured, shaggy-maned Icelandic mare who liked to trot beside a friend from the stable, a gelding named Glofaxi. On a dirt road bordering a forest in Vermont, Jorp stayed toward the head of the pack, but clearly wanted to keep Glofaxi a little in front. As collected as tin soldiers, we were moving at an exhilarating flying pace, which is an amazingly smooth running gait characteristic of Icelandic horses, a rare breed on these shores.

title: HELP WITH THE MAIL
description: Two foreign postal services signed a contract with South Africa to help manage the country's post office, in another step in the Government's effort to revamp and privatize many of its state-run companies. The British Postal Consultancy Service and New Zealand Post International will play leading roles in efforts to modernize the post office, expand its service and make it financially independent. Last year, the South African post office lost about $45 million. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: Kevin Hatcher Acquired By Rangers for Popovic
description: The Rangers, who have the highest payroll in hockey history, increased it again today.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''A major accident resulting in a radioactive leak has happened. We apologize from the bottoms of our hearts.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOMON, ESTELLE
description: SOLOMON-Estelle. On September 30, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Murray. Loving mother of Hope Silvera Kerr and the late Phyllis Polonicki and Lawrence Solomon. Adoring grandmother of Jodi Montgomery and Marc Silvera. Dear great grandmother of Evan Rose Silvera. She will be deeply missed. Graveside Service Friday, 1PM at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, Long Island.

title: Homegrocer.com Selects Wieden
description: Homegrocer.com in Seattle, an on-line grocery and delivery service that plans to expand nationally market by market, has awarded its first national branding account to Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Tea, Russian-Style, For an Arts Group

title: WHAT'S IN A NAME
description: After its $2.4 billion acquisition of a Dutch competitor, Royal Hoogoovens, British Steel P.L.C. said it would change its name to Corus Group P.L.C. The announcement reflected a trend among European blue-chip companies to reinvent their branding after big mergers. There is also a trend among British companies to drop national labels. British Petroleum became BP Amoco after last year's acquisition of the Amoco Corporation.

title: Save the Salmon or the Dams?
description: To the Editor:

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Passionate Life in a Lab With Dead Animals
description: IT'S always nice when you see a scientist in playfully patterned scrubs; it suggests that English, rather than Science, is the language of choice. But Dr. Tracey S. McNamara, head of the pathology department at the Bronx Zoo (those are geckos, by the way, on her scrubs) quickly disabuses you of that.

title: Rangers Hoping Fleury Cuts Rivals Down to Size
description: After each Rangers practice this preseason, during every post-skate sprint, the littlest member of the team -- indeed, the tiniest member of the National Hockey League -- always took the longest possible route.

title: A 3d Journalism Program Loses Its Director
description: Bill Kovach, the curator of the Nieman Foundation for Journalism at Harvard University, submitted his resignation to the foundation's advisory board this week, becoming the third head of a major university-based program for journalists to resign in the past year.

title: Disarm Timor Militias, U.S. Warns Indonesia
description: SINGAPORE  As soldiers of the Australian-led force in East Timor prepared to move toward the sensitive border with Indonesia, Defense Secretary William Cohen of the United States warned the Indonesian military Thursday that it must disarm militias responsible for violence in the disputed territory.

title: Health Care Reforms in California
description: The enactment of new health care reforms in California shows that state leaders are well ahead of Congress in addressing the need for managed care regulation. While many states have moved forward with consumer protection laws aimed at health maintenance organizations, the sweep of the California legislation contained in 21 bills, along with similarly broad legislation in Texas, sets an important standard by which to judge national reform.

title: Suing Big Tobacco: Worth Another Try
description: To the Editor:

title: Mets Feeling Drained, With Prospects Bleak
description: Bobby Valentine made the long, numbing walk back to the Mets' clubhouse alone last night, booting things as he plodded through the dark, sloping tunnel. An umpire's thumb spared Valentine the agony of watching his team fall almost hopelessly behind in the playoff race.

title: Underwriting of Stock and Bond Issues Slowed in September
description: So much for the post-Labor Day rush on Wall Street.

title: City Union Is Offered Transit and Domestic Partner Benefits
description: The city has reached a tentative agreement with the largest municipal union to offer city workers a break on mass transit fares and to extend medical-leave benefits to unwed workers caring for domestic partners.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EINSTEIN, ERNST
description: EINSTEIN-Ernst, a partner in Einstein-Moomjy, The Carpet Department Store, died suddenly on Wednesday. He was 76 years old. He died from complications associated with cancer. He continued to be active in the business while living with Parkinson's disease for the last 25 years. Born in Frankfurt, Germany, Ernst Einstein fled Nazi Germany in 1933. With the help of his future wife, Charline, he escaped the Nazis by hiding in France under a false identity. He was a kind man who survived the war without bitterness. After the war, he lived in France until moving to New Jersey in 1955. That year, he formed a partnership with his identical twin brother, Ted Einstein, and Albert and Walter Moomjy, which created the carpet business now known as EinsteinMoomjy, Inc. The chain today consists of five locations, four in New Jersey and one in Manhattan. Einstein was known for his exquisite taste and vision and for his expertise and fine eye for oriental rugs. As one example, in 1971, when Nixon first lifted the embargo on trade with China, he flew to London so that Einstein-Moomjy would be the first to import oriental rugs from China. He was gracious and charming and equally loved by customers and employees. Above all, he was an affectionate husband, father and grandfather. In addition to his wife, the former Charline Ollier, he is survived by two daughters, Rita Davis of Bryn Mawr, Penn., and Jessica Kaufman of Easton, Conn., and two sons, Jean Einstein of Westwood, N.J., and Gilles Einstein of Greenville, S.C., and 10 grandchildren. The memorial service is scheduled for 10 AM Sunday, October 3, at Higgins and Bonner Echo Lake Funeral Home, 582 Springfield Ave., in Westfield, N.J. Memorial donations may be made to the Melvin D. Yahr Parkinson's Research Fund, Mt. Sinai Medical Center, 5 E. 98th St., 7th Floor, New York, NY 10029.

title: MEAD TO PAY $550 MILLION FOR TIME ORGANIZER PRODUCTS
description: The Mead Corporation, the office products manufacturer based in Dayton, Ohio, agreed yesterday to buy the At-A-Glance division of Cullman Ventures Inc. for $550 million in cash. At-A-Glance, a brand of time-organizing products, will become a subsidiary of Mead, which expects to complete the purchase in the fourth quarter. At-A-Glance products include diaries, appointment books, desk calendars, posters and planners. Buying the unit, which is based in Sidney, N.Y., gives Mead the At-A-Glance brand name along with other brands including Day Minder, Standard Diary and Landmark.

title: Corporate Intrigue, Steamy Seduction
description: When Abel Ferrara began making a directorial name for himself in the early 1980's, it was as a bad-boy filmmaker with tastes for lurid sex, gritty violence and gripping, stylish stories of life in the fast lane going wrong. It's a sign of the times that Mr. Ferrara, whose cinematic obsessions have barely changed, has come to seem positively tame. But even though the threshold for on-screen exploitativeness has been raised ever higher, this filmmaker's work still retains its peculiar innocence. Nobody could have made ''Bad Lieutenant'' without taking it to heart.

title: Officemax Shares Fall 18% On Revised Profit Forecast
description: Officemax Inc., the seller of office supplies, said today that earnings in it its fiscal second half would miss expectations because of higher advertising and Internet spending, sending its shares down 18 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FREUNDLICH, LILLIAN
description: FREUNDLICH-Lillian. There will be a musical service of remembrance for Lillian Freundlich, pianist, teacher and coach and her husband Irwin at Christ and St. Stephen's Church, 120 West 69 St. (East of Broadway) on Sunday, October 3 at 3 P.M.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CALIFORNIA WATER SERVICE GROUP, San Jose, Calif., California's largest publicly traded water utility, agreed to buy two water systems in Washington for $11.5 million in stock and assumed debt.

title: PUGET SOUND ENERGY ACQUIRING AN ENCOGEN POWER PLANT
description: Puget Sound Energy Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire a power plant from Encogen Northwest L.P. for $164 million in cash and debt assumption. The purchase of the 160-megawatt heat and electricity plant near Bellingham, Wash., would reduce Puget Sound's cost of power from the natural-gas-fired plant by 20 percent, the company said. Based on an above-market power purchase contract signed in 1990 under the Public Utility Regulatory Policies Act, Puget Sound was required to pay Encogen fixed and escalating fees through mid-2008 for the plant's output of the plant. Puget Sound, based in Bellevue, Wash., is the state's largest electric utility.

title: Cut to the Manager: It's the Lone Leader's Marathon of Misery
description: Reaction shots of managers or coaches are usually filler during a televised game -- Look, he's standing there! He's looking at a clipboard! -- especially when a camera spots a coach without identifying him.

title: FENDI GETS OFFER
description: The Rome-based design house Fendi has received a joint takeover offer from the French luxury goods conglomerate LVMH-Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton and Prada, the Italian fashion house. Alda Fendi, one of the five Fendi sisters who now own the design house, told reporters at the Milan shows that the offer, reported in The Wall Street Journal, was the third that Fendi had received, after bids from Gucci Group and the Texas Pacific Group of Dallas. The Fendi sisters are reportedly asking about $875 million for the company, which had revenue in 1998 of $320 million.

title: After All That Yelling, Time to Think
description: AS is almost always the case in the culture wars, the event that provokes the skirmish turns out to be much less entertaining and far less significant than the political fight it kindles.

title: Parting the Sea With Slapstick
description: The sprawling biblical narrative of the sort that Cecil B. De Mille used to whip up is the cinematic genre being spoofed in ''Epic Proportions,'' the flailing attempt at a comedy that opened last night at the Helen Hayes Theater. But it's understandable if you find yourself thinking of another type of popular melodrama from a bygone era, the kind in which the winsome heroine is cruelly held captive and tortured while she strains to stay plucky and hopeful as she prays for deliverance. For there before you, smiling as though her life depended upon it, is Kristin Chenoweth, the undersize actress with the outsize presence who walked away with last season's revival of ''You're a Good Man, Charlie Brown.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EAGLE, MILTON, M.D.
description: EAGLE-Milton, M.D., 80, died peacefully in his sleep on September 30 in Jacksonville, Florida. Formerly of Jericho, Long Island. Beloved husband of Shirley, loving father of Terry and proud grandfather of Davis and Sarah Lyn. Loving big brother to Seymour. Doctor, healer. Funeral services will be held Sunday, 10 AM at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: German Bank Will Enter Japan Market
description: Deutsche Bank A.G. teamed up today with Sakura Bank Ltd. of Japan in an effort to take advantage of Japan's liberalized market for underwriting bond and stock offerings.

title: Put Bikes by the Water
description: To the Editor:

title: Suzanne Kuhn
description: Bill Maynes Gallery

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RABINOVICH, JOSEPH
description: RABINOVICH-Joseph. On September 30th, 1999. Beloved husband of Marcelle. Devoted father of Joyce Barkin. Adoring grandfather of Frances and greatgrandfather of Nicholas and Spencer. Also survived by children Matthew, Daniel, Jamie and Adrienne. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Friday and Saturday, 7-9 PM, with service on Sunday 11:30 AM. Contributions in his memory may be made to Temple Emanu-El, 1 East 65 Street, New York, NY 10021.

title: No Jail Term in Biotechnology Stock Fraud
description: David Blech, once a top biotechnology stock promoter, will serve no prison time for defrauding his customers and Bear, Stearns & Company of millions of dollars in a scheme to retain control of his securities firm, which is now defunct, a Federal judge ruled yesterday.

title: Devils Aim To Avoid Another Bad Spring
description: The Devils finished first in the Eastern Conference last season with a fairly young team but failed dismally in the playoffs because they lacked a dominant player capable of carrying them. They were eliminated in the first round of the playoffs by Pittsburgh, the last-seeded team in the conference.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINTHROP, ROBERT
description: WINTHROP-Robert. The Boards, Faculty and Staff of the New York-Presbyterian Hospital and the Joan and Sanford I. Weill Medical College of Cornell University are deeply saddened by the passing of our friend and esteemed Life Trustee, Robert Winthrop, who had served with distinction on the Board of The Presbyterian Hospital. Our deepest condolences are extended to his family. New York-Presbyterian Hospital Daniel B. Burke John F. McGillicuddy Co-Chairmen, Board of Trustees David B. Skinner, M.D. Vice Chairman, President and CEO Weill Medical College of Cornell University Sanford I. Weill Chairman, Board of Overseers Antonio M. Gotto, Jr., M.D. The Stephen and Suzanne Weiss Dean

title: FAMILY FARE
description: Wake-Up Call For a Kingdom

title: Southern Comfort
description: Southern restaurants occupy a quiet but flourishing niche in New York. Here are a dozen of the best examples. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times by William Grimes, Mr. Asimov and others.)

title: Coy on Candidacy, Beatty Keeps His Options Open
description: He didn't say he would and he didn't say he wouldn't. But Warren Beatty held an enthusiastic crowd of Hollywood's liberal elite in the palm of his hand for half an hour Wednesday night as he denounced the influence of money in politics and the rightward drift of the Democratic Party and insisted that its Presidential candidates not forget society's least fortunate, whether or not he runs himself.

title: For Giants, Pressure Is On to Get More Sacks
description: Keith Hamilton doesn't stay awake at night worrying about it, but the Giants' paltry sack total is beginning to be a nagging problem.

title: Clemens May Open Playoffs
description: Roger Clemens jogged the streets around Camden Yards late this afternoon, burning off the adrenaline that overwhelmed him in the six innings he pitched earlier in the day. He ran for nearly an hour, and no doubt the perfectionist in him reviewed and rethought all that he had done wrong.

title: ART REVIEW; Surprises From the Hand Of a 16th-Century Master
description: The drawing as detonator is the real subject of ''Giulio Romano: Master Designer,'' at Hunter College.
