Many of these drawings are also objects of delectation, and Giulio gave them his best shot. But since many were meant to be transferred to another medium by another pair of hands, it was an explosion of energy that he had in mind.

title: Debate Flares As Exhibition On Jerusalem Is Set to Open
description: The Walt Disney Company's exhibition on Jerusalem continued to draw controversy yesterday, the day before it was to open to the public, as prominent Jewish and Arab-American organizations complained that it portrayed a Jerusalem shorn of what they said was crucial political context.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BERNSTEIN, LOTTIE
description: BERNSTEIN-Lottie. You are with me. Love beyond space and beyond time. George

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Latest Study Unable to Link Diet Drugs to Heart Damage
description: Two years ago, doctors at the Mayo Clinic reported that 24 women who had taken the combination of diet drugs called fen-phen had highly unusual and grave heart valve damage. In response, the manufacturers withdrew two of the drugs from the market, and thousands of patients sued, asserting that the drugs had damaged their hearts.

title: Islanders Reduce Payroll, Optimism
description: While the Rangers spent the summer revamping their roster by adding several high-priced free agents, the Islanders were busy doing the opposite. They dumped many high-salaried players from their already modest roster in a series of moves that left the team with one of the most anonymous lineups in the National Hockey League.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article yesterday about the appointment of Donald M. Stewart as president and chief executive of the Chicago Community Trust included an outdated reference to his role at the College Board. Mr. Stewart left the board last June, after more than 12 years as president and chief executive, and joined the Carnegie Corporation as senior program officer and special assistant to the president.

title: Save the Salmon or the Dams?
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Urges Tough Love for Students Who Are Failing
description: President Clinton today told governors and executives at a conference examining educational standards that students who are held back because they fail to vault newly raised bars should be treated with tough love.

title: After 8 Days of Bombing Chechnya, Moscow Cuts Links
description: In a move that could intensify the conflict in the northern Caucasus, Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin today cut Moscow's last links with the elected government of the breakaway republic of Chechnya.

title: Peace in Turkey
description: To the Editor:

title: SAFEWAY CONSIDERS BUYING OTHER SUPERMARKETS
description: Safeway Inc., the third-largest United States supermarket chain, said yesterday that it would consider acquiring other supermarket chains and a share buyback program because of a decline in its stock price. Buying more supermarket chains remains one of Safeway's growth strategies, its chief executive, Steven Burd, said at a securities conference in San Francisco. The company runs 1,649 stores in the United States and Canada and had revenue last year of $24.48 billion. It also may consider a stock-repurchase program if its stock continues trading at current levels or below, Mr. Burd said. Safeway's stock dropped more than 10 percent on Thursday on concern that growth in same-store sales was slowing. Safeway's stock fell another $1.8125 a share, to $36.25.

title: Corrections
description: A review of music-education software in Circuits on Sept. 23 gave an erroneous price supplied by the publisher, GVOX for Learn to Play Music With Ricky Recorder. It costs $49.99, not $59.99.

title: Revlon Is Taken Off the Block, and Shares Plunge
description: Having failed to find a buyer willing to pay the price he wanted, Ronald O. Perelman said yesterday that he was taking Revlon Inc. off the market and would instead try to sell two units of the ailing cosmetics giant to raise much-needed cash.

title: Illinois Court Lets Patients Sue H.M.O.'s
description: The Illinois Supreme Court has ruled that patients can sue health maintenance organizations for malpractice, declaring that decisions on what treatments the companies will cover amount to medical care.

title: New Indonesian Assembly Begins Trying to Organize Next Election
description: The new national Assembly convened today, and in an irreverent demonstration of the first precarious steps toward popular Government, members booed when President B. J. Habibie arrived.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an art review in Weekend yesterday about ''Sensation: Young British Artists From the Saatchi Collection,'' at the Brooklyn Museum of Art, gave a misspelled surname in some copies for an artist whose portrait of an English murderer is in the show. He is Marcus Harvey, not Heavey.

title: Setting Test Standards: a Kind of Tough Love
description: To the Editor:

title: House Republicans Stung by Bush's Criticism
description: House Republicans expressed a mixture of confusion and bitter betrayal today after Gov. George W. Bush of Texas criticized their proposal to finance the party's spending plans by delaying Federal tax breaks for working-class families.

title: Toys 'R' Us Decks Its Shelves; Hoping to Learn From the Ghost of the Christmas Just Past
description: Last fall, shoppers at Toys ''R'' Us, armed with holiday wish lists, often left the chain's cavernous stores frustrated and empty-handed. Not just the hot sellers like Furby stuffed animals were in short supply; the stores even ran out of stocking-stuffers like Crayola Crayons. And the company felt the pain acutely in its bottom line.

title: The Real Reagan, According to Deaver
description: To the Editor:

title: McHale and Thompson Enter Hall of Fame With 3 Others
description: In one corner of the hotel ballroom, a smiling Kevin McHale doled out a healthy supply of one-liners, including, ''I used to have pictures of Bill Walton on my wall as a kid, he's so old.'' Across the room, an introspective John Thompson said he would probably be remembered for ''things that have kept me out of the Hall of Fame.''

title: Protests Falter as Belgrade Turns the Law Against the Opposition
description: The demonstrations against President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia appeared to flounder tonight, with opposition leaders unsure how to respond to Mr. Milosevic's willingness to use the police and an arbitrary legal system to defend himself.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIFE, BERNARD
description: FIFE-Bernard, after a long battle with Parkinson's disease. Dearly beloved husband of Arlene. Devoted father of Susan Davis and Marilyn Cragin. Cherished grandfather of Aaron, Barry, Julia, Gabe, Eli, Will and Caroline. Funeral service will be held at Temple Emanuel, Great Neck, NY at 11:30AM on Sunday, Oct 3rd.

title: Two Big Men Signed for Practice
description: The Knicks filled out their training camp roster at 17 players yesterday by signing two big men to league-minimum deals in an effort to make up for the absence of Patrick Ewing and Chris Dudley on the practice floor.

title: A City, Its Art and Reputation Are on the Line
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIDOFF, ESTELLE TOPPER
description: DAVIDOFF-Estelle Topper. Died Wednesday, September 29, 1999 at the JFK Medical Center in Atlantis, Florida. Born in the Bronx, she lived in Rockland County, NY where she raised her three sons. She moved to Manhattan, NY in 1971. Ms. Davidoff has resided in West Palm Beach, Florida since 1987. Ms. Davidoff tutored children for Bar and Bat Mitzvahs at Temple Beth El in Spring Valley, New York during the 1960s. She also served on the staff of Manhattan Borough President Percy Sutton in the 1970s. Ms. Davidoff is remembered by friends and family as always having a zest for life, a love for animals, a passion for travel, and a flair for style. Surviving are her sons S. Robert Davidoff, Thomas R. Davidoff, and E. Martin Davidoff, her daughters-inlaw Ila Feld Davidoff, Sheryl Chait Davidoff and Sheila Temkin Davidoff, and her grandchildren Steven, Jonathan, Nikki, Jill, Sherri, Jamie, Laura, and Joshua. The family will be sitting shiva after the funeral at 3353 Justin Circle Drive in West Palm Beach, Fla. The family of E. Martin Davidoff will be sitting shiva at 16 Independence Drive in East Brunswick, NJ from Sunday evening, October 3, 1999 through Thursday morning, October 7, 1999. The remainder of the family will be sitting shiva during that time at the home of Thomas R. Davidoff, 209 Turnberry Court North in Atlantis, Florida. Contributions may be made to the Estelle Davidoff Animal Protection Foundation, P.O. Box 555, Dayton, New Jersey 08810.

title: Columbia Men And Women Win
description: Columbia, led by Ray Biersbach's second-place finish, placed its five runners in the top seven and won the team title for the fourth year in a row yesterday in the Metropolitan Intercollegiate championships at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx. Columbia finished with 22 points, and Manhattan was second with 72.

title: INDONESIAN CAR TALKS
description: A group of investors led by Newbridge Capital Ltd. and Gilbert Global Equity Capital may buy a 19.9 percent stake in PT Astra International, Indonesia's largest car maker, a Government spokesman said. The group -- which includes the son of an Astra founder, William Soeryadjaya -- is negotiating with the Indonesian Bank Restructuring Agency, an official with the restructuring body said. But he said Astra was resisting the agency's efforts to examine its financial records.

title: FRESH AMERICA HALTS ITS BID FOR FRESHPOINT
description: The Fresh America Corporation, a supplier of fruit and vegetables to the the Sam's Clubs wholesale stores of Wal-Mart Stores, said yesterday that it had canceled its plan to buy the closely held Freshpoint Inc. for about $101 million in stock. Fresh America, based in Dallas, said in May that it would buy Freshpoint to form one of the world's largest produce distributors. Fresh America did not say why the proposed purchase was not completed. Fresh America, which had sales of $609.5 million last year, also named Colon Washburn, 54, chief executive. He replaced David Sheinfeld, who will remain a director. Fresh America's shares fell 75 cents yesterday, to $5.3125, in Nasdaq trading. Its shares have fallen more than 60 percent since July 1.

title: Dr. John J. Conley, 87, Pioneer in Treating Head and Neck Cancers
description: Dr. John J. Conley, a New York surgeon who made important contributions to the treatment of cancers of the head and neck, died on Sept. 21 in a hospital in Manhattan. He was 87 and lived on the Upper West Side.

title: Mount Sinai Settles Suit On Medicare Claims
description: The Mount Sinai School of Medicine has agreed to pay more than $2.2 million to resolve civil charges that the center improperly documented services, resulting in an excess windfall of Medicare funds. Mary Jo White, the United States Attorney for the Southern District, announced the settlement yesterday.

title: A Torrent Of Kindness
description: My hometown's traffic signals are blinking underwater. You can see brown river currents go red, yellow, green.

title: A City, Its Art and Reputation Are on the Line
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan's Nuclear Lesson
description: It was nowhere near as bad as the 1986 accident at the Chernobyl nuclear reactor in Ukraine, which spewed radiation over a vast territory. It was not even as scary as the 1979 accident at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant in Pennsylvania, which had the entire nation on edge wondering if the reactor core would break through its confinement and reach the outer world. (It didn't.) But the nuclear accident this week at a fuel processing plant at Tokaimura was certainly the worst in Japan's history -- and a vivid reminder that nuclear energy is a demanding technology that severely punishes human error and inadequate technical designs.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BREGSTEIN, JERRY
description: BREGSTEIN - Jerry. Twenty years. You are often in my thoughts, always in my heart. Lorraine

title: Setting Test Standards: a Kind of Tough Love
description: To the Editor:

title: Officials Back Badillo Amid Furor on Hispanic Remarks
description: With a lengthening lineup of Hispanic political leaders calling for the removal of Herman Badillo as chairman of the City University of New York, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday that they would stand by him, though they described as inappropriate his remarks about Dominican and Mexican students that ignited the uproar.

title: A New Focus In the Assault On Gridlock
description: In his latest assault on gridlock in New York City, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that the Police Department would begin an aggressive crackdown on Tuesday on drivers who double-park.

title: Phillips Tells League Of Umpiring Complaints
description: General Manager Steve Phillips of the Mets talked to Len Coleman, the National League president, and Sandy Alderson, the executive vice president for baseball operations, in the commissioner's office yesterday about his concerns over the umpiring in recent days.

title: Charles A. Federer Jr., Stargazer-Editor, 90
description: Charles A. Federer Jr., who six decades ago combined two money-losing journals, The Sky and The Telescope, into what became a successful and influential magazine for amateur astronomers, died on Tuesday in Mystic, Conn. He was 90 and lived in the nearby town of Stonington.

title: Purdue, on a Roll, Shows No Sign of Letting Up
description: How long has it been since ''Purdue Boilermakers'' and ''football power'' have shared the same sentence?

title: INSIDE
description: Moscow Cuts Chechnya Ties

title: Chandler Unlikely To Play Tomorrow
description: Falcons quarterback Chris Chandler is not expected to play tomorrow against the Baltimore Ravens after aggravating a strained hamstring last week, the team said.

title: Counting Controversy as Blessing
description: This verdant, affluent suburb of Washington is known for the discreet coexistence of the Central Intelligence Agency and Patrick J. Buchanan, the maverick Presidential candidate who lately takes predawn jogs around his C.I.A. neighbor's perimeter, all the better to plot his next intrigue against the Republican Party.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Aetna Appoints Liaison to Physicians
description: Aetna Inc., the biggest United States health insurer, said today that it had named a division president, John Kelly, director of the company's new office of physician relations to improve Aetna's ties with doctors.

title: A City, Its Art and Reputation Are on the Line
description: To the Editor:

title: TRADE MINISTER'S NEXT LIFE
description: Sir Leon Brittan, a European Union official responsible for trade policy, plans to leave the European Commission to join Warburg Dillon Read, the investment arm of the Swiss banking giant UBS A.G. Sir Leon, a British conservative, will join the bank on Jan. 1 as vice chairman responsible for advising clients on strategic and government-related issues. Alan Cowell

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISPASS, BERNARD
description: ISPASS-Bernard. Beloved husband of Frieda, devoted father of Ken and Enice Ispass and Elise and Richard Resnik, cherished grandfather of Dara, Brad, Samantha and Michael, loving brother of Laura. To know him was to love him. Services Sunday 10am at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page chart yesterday describing the accident at a nuclear fuel plant in Japan mislabeled symbols for both the level of radiation during the accident and the normal background level of radiation. The levels were shown in thousandths of a rem, or millirems, not in rems. Thus the normal background level is 0.02 millirem -- or 0.00002 rem -- per hour.

title: Leave Party, Reform Chairman Tells Ventura
description: Fueling a feud that may be making the Reform Party more vulnerable to takeover by an outsider, the party's lame-duck chairman demanded yesterday that Gov. Jesse Ventura of Minnesota resign from the party because of his assertion in Playboy magazine that ''organized religion is a sham and a crutch.''

title: Corrections
description: A sports picture caption yesterday about the the New Jersey Devils player Petr Sykora misstated his tenure with the team. This is his fifth season, not his first.

title: COMING ON SUNDAY: ISRAEL'S Y2K PROBLEM
description: There are Jews who want to seize the Temple Mount by any means necessary. And Christians who want to see the Jewish temple rebuilt -- and destroyed to bring on Armageddon. And Muslims who will never give up the Dome of the Rock. Will the peace process be stalled by the apocalypse? A report by Jeffrey Goldberg, in The Times Magazine.

title: TXU to Sell Six Power Plants in Texas
description: The TXU Corporation, which owns the largest utility in Texas, said today that it would sell six natural gas-fired power plants in an auction expected to bring in at least $1 billion, more than 10 times the plants' book value.

title: Hewlett Trims Its Forecast For Quarter
description: After warning that sales growth would not be quite as robust as Wall Street had hoped, the Hewlett-Packard Company's new chief executive criticized the company's ''inadequate performance management'' today and said that some employees in a lagging division would be dismissed.

title: YORK INTERNATIONAL SET TO CUT ABOUT 1,200 JOBS
description: The York International Corporation, the world's largest industrial-refrigeration company, said yesterday that it would cut 1,200 jobs and shut three European plants. It also warned that it would miss third-quarter earnings estimates because of weaker sales in Latin America and the integration of Sabroe A.S., a Danish supplier of refrigeration systems, which it acquired in June. York said it would earn 65 cents to 70 cents a share in the third quarter. It had been expected to earn 95 cents. Fourth-quarter earnings will also be below forecasts. Shares of York tumbled $11.0625, to $24.25.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a brief report in SportsThursday about the arrest of the basketball coach at St. Mary's College on a rape charge misstated the location of the college. It is in St. Mary's City, Md., not in California.

title: KOREA IMPORT SURGE
description: Imports into South Korea rose by 40 percent last month, to $10.1 billion, the highest rate in four years. The Government attributed the increase to an economic rebound, rising crude oil prices and increased demand for computer components as part of a state-sponsored program to supply inexpensive computers designed for mass consumption. Despite the influx of imports, South Korea had a trade surplus of $1.9 billion last month and $17.2 billion so far this year.

title: Veteran Asks That Memorial Honor Only War Dead
description: Tony Pia vividly remembers the morning almost 30 years ago when he saw workers dismantling a three-sided wooden structure inscribed with the names of almost 10,000 Stamford men and women who had served in World War II.

title: School Overcrowding Is Down But Still Persists, Union Says
description: While overcrowding in New York City schools has declined this year, pockets of severe overcrowding in the north Bronx and in Queens remain, forcing schools to use non-classroom space for teaching, officials of the teachers' union said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEIT, SOL
description: LEIT-Sol. Happy birthday. We think of you always. You were missed at Ben and Matt's Barmitzvah's. Love Bobbie and Family

title: 2 Officers Convicted Of Assaulting Man Who Was Later Killed by Train
description: Two New York City detectives were convicted yesterday of beating a man who was later struck and killed by a train in a nearby subway station.

title: U.N. Troops' New Focus: Militias in West Timor
description: International forces opened what they called a decisive phase in the campaign to secure East Timor today, sending troops for the first time into the western region of the territory, where militias that oppose them have a strong presence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAGMAN, SHOALA R.
description: WAGMAN-Shoala R. of Rye, NY. Died October 1, 1999. She was 67. Born April 24, 1932 in Brooklyn to Joseph and Minnie Blitz. In 1954 she married Leonard W. Wagman in Brooklyn. Shoala was a Real Estate Developer for over 15 years. In addition to her husband she is survived by a son David of Rye, NY, three grandchildren, a brother Sam Blitz of Long Island and a sister Lenore Stillson of Florida. She was also a member of the League of Women Voters. Please contact the Zion Memorial Chapel for the funeral arrangements 914-381-1809.

title: Venus Williams Plans School Break
description: Venus Williams, one victory away from the successful defense of her Grand Slam Cup title after beating Martina Hingis, confirmed yesterday from Munich that she would take a break from the tennis circuit next week to attend college at an art institute, which she declined to identify, near her home in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla.

title: Woolridge Fired By the Sparks
description: The Los Angeles Sparks of the Women's National Basketball Association fired Coach Orlando Woolridge, citing philosophical differences.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the Jewish holidays of Shemini Atzereth and Simhath Torah, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today and tomorrow. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Rockets Are Sending Pippen To Trail Blazers for Six Players
description: A disgruntled Scottie Pippen, who skewered his teammate Charles Barkley this week and seemed to be campaigning mightily for a trade from the Houston Rockets, got his wish last night.

title: The Real Reagan, According to Deaver
description: To the Editor:

title: Yonkers Teachers Strike Over Longer Class Hours
description: Teachers went on strike here today in the state's fourth-largest school district, taking to picket lines in protest of new class schedules they said were unilaterally imposed by the Superintendent.

title: Reassuring Public Is I.O.C. Goal
description: The International Olympic Committee decided to let a foreign antibribery treaty govern the actions of its members and cities bidding for Olympic Games to reassure the public that there would be no repetition of the recent Salt Lake City Olympic corruption scandal, a committee spokesman said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A theater review in Weekend yesterday about the play ''Fully Committed,'' at the Vineyard in Manhattan, misidentified an actress in ''Full Gallop,'' an earlier show with the same director. She is Mary Louise Wilson, not Mary Elizabeth Wilson.

title: Blueprints Built Into the Genes; An Architect's Body of Work May Be More Than Just a Metaphor
description: It was only a matter of time. And space. Sooner or later someone was bound to suggest that architecture is a biological function. Since classical times, buildings have been likened to bodies. Now the metaphor has grown up: buildings are not just like bodies; they are deeply biological.

title: We Don't Need A New Subway Line
description: Capital improvements planned by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority should accomplish two things: reduce crowding on the subways during rush hour and support economic expansion by accommodating more workers bound for midtown Manhattan. By these criteria, the agency's plan for the Second Avenue subway is either too much or too little.

title: U.S. Is an Inspector With Its Own Problems
description: President Clinton told the Energy Department and the Pentagon today to review the safety of civilian nuclear-fuel processing. But experts inside and outside Government said the Energy Department owns the plants that are most vulnerable to an accident like the one in Japan.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Comments to a Key Union Serve as Prelude to Debates
description: The debates that Vice President Al Gore and former Senator Bill Bradley are promising began in a virtual way today as each candidate pleaded with an important labor union for support and directly criticized his opponent.

title: A Biographer Who Claims A License To Blur Reality
description: Back in 1985, when President Ronald Reagan selected Edmund Morris as his official biographer, the writer vowed he would produce ''a substantial, scholarly book.'' Fourteen years later, after years of worrying he didn't ''understand the first thing'' about his subject, Mr. Morris has produced a book that is anything but scholarly or substantial. He has produced a bizarre, irresponsible and monstrously self-absorbed book -- a Ragtime-esque ''memoir'' featuring a self-annotating narrator out of a Philip Roth novel and childlike hero out of ''Being There.'' Even worse, this loony hodgepodge of fact and fiction is being sold not as a novel but as ''the only biography ever authorized by a sitting President.''

title: Will Season Turn Around? Will It Turn for the Worse?
description: Realistically, how disastrous is an 0-3 record for the Jets, who will be in Denver on Sunday for a game that is more about survival than a rematch of last season's conference championship? Now the two clubs that met in that game have zero victories between them -- the first time that both conference finalists have started a season at 0-3. An 0-3 start is not insurmountable. In fact, one team -- the 1992 Chargers -- even won a division title after starting at 0-4. But they are the only club to ever make it to the playoffs after such a dismal beginning.

title: A City, Its Art and Reputation Are on the Line
description: To the Editor:

title: Not to Worry: Rooms to Spare For New Year's
description: Despite everything you may have heard about millennium madness, out-of-towners have not booked every overpriced hotel room in New York City for New Year's Eve. They have not snapped up every $3,000 seat in the Rainbow Room, purchased every $1,000 ticket to every ''gala'' event, hired every limousine -- or even every baby sitter.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: U.S. VISION INC., Glendora, N.J., acquired 24 optical departments situated in stores owned by Boscov's, Reading, Pa., for an undisclosed price to strengthen its business in the mid-Atlantic region.

title: Giuliani Endorses Bush for President
description: Flush with Republican pride after a visit to the Reagan Presidential Library in California, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani endorsed Gov. George W. Bush of Texas for President yesterday, saying he could restore the ''sense of unified purpose'' that Americans had during the Republican administrations of the 1980's.

title: BAA STOCK SLUMPS
description: The shares of the world's biggest airport operator, BAA P.L.C., plunged after the company warned that its profit would not meet estimates because the abolition of duty-free sales within the European Union had cut revenue. BAA said pretax profit for the fiscal year that ends next March will fall as low as $:460 million ($759 million), as much as 8 percent below analysts' estimates. The year before, pretax profit was $:516 million. The operator of 15 airports around the world, BAA generates half its sales leasing and running stores. That business shrank after the European Union abolished duty-free shopping on July 1.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, MARTIN
description: COHEN-Martin. Died on September 21, 1999. Retired IBM Marketing Rep. Survived by brother Arnold, children, Susan, Barry and Jeffrey and their spouses Ronnie, Ellen and Lisa. He will be missed by his grandchildren, Allison, Bryan, Joshua and Zachary and his loving cousins. The entire family mourns his untimely passing.

title: GOLD MINE LAYOFFS
description: The weeklong rally in gold prices was not enough to stave off job cuts at one South African mine. Following through on plans announced in August, the joint venture of Vancouver-based Placer Dome Inc. and Western Areas Ltd. of South Africa laid off about 2,500 miners at its mine near Johannesburg. The National Union of Mine Workers said it would challenge the layoffs in court.

title: In 'Boom,' More Lint Lines Pockets of Poor
description: From the vantage point of his college major, business administration, and his current calling, homelessness, Jesse Martin offered his considered summary of the latest Federal findings on the booming economy.

title: A Rare Airing for the Bruckner Fifth
description: Period instrument orchestras do their scholarly best to recreate lost timbres and performance styles, but the variety of sounds a listener hears when comparing competing ensembles suggests that speculation plays an important hand. The Vienna Philharmonic is not a period instrument group in quite the same sense that Vienna's Concentus Musicus is, but it devotes itself to the music of a receding past, and its players use instruments that have not been altered to take into account 20th-century structural refinements or the international preference for a more rounded, Gallic sound. If the Concentus Musicus is a dinosaur reconstructed from fossilized bones, the Philharmonic is an antique scorpion preserved in amber.

title: Sports of The Times; Wishing And Hoping For Mets
description: ROBIN VENTURA slammed a game-winning hit in the 11th inning last night and Mets fans went wild. But all you needed to see to understand the intensity of the Mets' madcap chase for a playoff berth was the scene inside the Mets' clubhouse 15 minutes after the victory.

title: Setting Test Standards: a Kind of Tough Love
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Addresses Religious Right On His Terms
description: In a striking departure from other Presidential candidates -- past and present -- Gov. George W. Bush of Texas delivered a speech to the Christian Coalition today that mentioned abortion only in passing and did not touch on school prayer, gay rights and other matters vital to religious conservatives.

title: Ted Arison, Carnival Founder, Dies at 75
description: Ted Arison, who parlayed a single used cruise ship into Carnival Cruise Lines and other holdings, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Tel Aviv. He was 75 years old.

title: Senate to Begin Debate on Nuclear Test Ban Treaty Next Week
description: Senate leaders agreed today to begin debate next Friday on a landmark treaty banning nuclear testing, and in a sign of the Administration's uphill fight to ratify the accord, Defense Secretary William S. Cohen cut short by a day his trip to Asia to return here and prepare strategy with the White House.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARISON, TED
description: ARISON-Ted. The American Committee for the Tel Aviv Foundation expresses profound sorrow at the passing of our Founder, original Chairman, leader and most generous donor, Ted Arison. Ted was a giant. Through his example, he brought many other supporters and donors as well. He did more for the Tel Aviv Foundation and the City of Tel Aviv-Jaffa than any other. Our heartfelt condolences go out to his beloved wife, Lin, and his son and American Committee Board Member, Micky Arison and his family, his daughter and generous supporter, Shari Arison Dorsman and her family, his sister Aviva Tamir and his niece, our dear friend Talia Glantz. American Committee for the Tel Aviv Foundation Uzi Zucker, Chairman Ira Riklis, President Shimon Topor, Sec./Treasurer Jeannie Gerzon, Exec. Director Ron Huldai, International Chairman and Mayor of Tel Aviv-Jaffa David Harnik, General Manager, Tel Aviv Foundation

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: NO. 11 PURDUE 4-0

title: At a Quiet Art Show in Yonkers, The Roar of a Culture War Echoes
description: The Hudson River Museum of Art is not on the itinerary of New York's culturati. But the visitors who came here today to see exhibits about birds of prey, astronomy and Westchester's historic places were chattering just as loudly as the chattering classes about The Mayor, The Museum and The Virgin Mary.

title: Hungry to Win, the Giants Have a Lot on Their Plate
description: No football coach wants to call his fourth game of the season a must-win situation. And today, Giants Coach Jim Fassel would not use that term.

title: The Real Reagan, According to Deaver
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEUSTADTER, HELENE, NEE LERNER
description: NEUSTADTER-Helene, nee Lerner. Congregation Shearith Israel, the Spanish & Portuguese Synagogue, mourns the loss of the mother of its Segan and esteemed Trustee, Peter Neustadter. We extend our deepest sympathy to Mr. Neustadter, his wife Naomi, and his family. The burial and Shibah are being observed in Israel. Alvin Deutsch, Parnas

title: Nuclear Peril Is Over but Japanese Anger Isn't
description: For years, Tomi Oshiro lived practically in the shadows of this town's nuclear fuel plant, yet she, like most people in town, had no inkling of the perilous work going on inside the nondescript building.

title: Their Wives Are Dead, So What Else Is There to Do?
description: Reggie Conyngham-Jervis is not an effusive mourner. In the person of Albert Finney, seated in a London hospital waiting room, he turns to a man who has just told him that his wife, like Reggie's, died the night before and says, barely looking up from his newspaper, ''Well, look at the bright side, what?'' That man also turns up at Reggie's wife's funeral and murmurs sympathetically, ''One day at a time, eh?'' To which Reggie replies brusquely, ''Whatever you say, old chap.'' This is one repressed Englishman.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an art review in Weekend yesterday about ''Sensation: Young British Artists From the Saatchi Collection,'' at the Brooklyn Museum of Art, gave a misspelled surname in some copies for an artist whose portrait of an English murderer is in the show. He is Marcus Harvey, not Heavey.

title: BANK BIDDING WAR LOOMS
description: Sweden's biggest bank, Svenska Handelsbanken A.B., is ready to top a bid for Christiania Bank A.S., Norway's No. 3 bank, from MeritaNordbanken, Handelsbanken's chief executive, Arne Maartensson, said. Last month, MeritaNordbanken, Scandinavia's No. 2 bank, offered to buy Christiania for 44 kroner a share, a total of 24.3 billion kroner ($3.1 billion). ''We'd be prepared to pay more than 44 kroner for Chrisitiania; the synergies would be bigger than with MeritaNordbanken,'' Mr. Maartensson said. MeritaNordbanken was formed nearly two years ago by the merger of Finland's Merita, and Sweden's Nordbanken.

title: Democrats End Threat to Block Court Nominees
description: An impasse over confirming Federal judges ended today as Senate Democrats gave up their efforts to block a vote on a judicial candidate favored by Senator Orrin G. Hatch, the Utah Republican who is chairman of the Judiciary Committee.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORUZZI, LUCY (NEE SARRO)
description: CORUZZI-Lucy (nee Sarro). Left this world on 30 September, 1999, in NYC, aged 72. Widow of Hugo Coruzzi. Mother of Laura, Gloria and Celeste Coruzzi. Grandmother of Aidan Coruzzi Daly, Eva Coruzzi Schneider and Giovanna Coruzzi Kupiec. Sister of Rudy Sarro. Wake at Perazzo Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker St., NYC. 212-777-7108, Saturday, 7-9:30PM, and Sunday 25 and 7-9:30PM. Funeral Mass Monday, 4 Oct., Our Lady of Pompeii Church, 25 Carmine St., NYC. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPITZER, RABBI JULIE RINGOLD
description: SPITZER-Rabbi Julie Ringold. The staff and lay leadership of the UAHC Greater NY Council of Reformed Synagogues mourn with profound sorrow the loss of our beloved friend and teacher following a courageous battle with cancer. Her tireless devotion to justice, learning, and the preservation of human dignity will long continue to bless and inspire us. Funeral services will be held on October 4th, in Jacksonville, Florida. A memorial service will also take place on October 17th, at 11AM at the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue in New York. Ernest M. Grunebaum, President Rabbi Peter B. Schaktman, Associate Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VACCARI, ANTHONY J.
description: VACCARI-Anthony J. On September 30, 1999, of Malverne. Member of the Art Directors Guild. Beloved husband of Lorraine (nee Schultheis). Devoted father of Rev. Peter I., Rev. Andrew J., Michael A. Esq., Dr. Maria E. Vaccari-Loiodice, and Rosemary E. Mysel. Survived by one brother, one sister, and ten loving grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Catholic Health Services or the Malverne Ambulance Corp. For further information, Malverne Funeral Home, (516) 593-7230.

title: How to Sue the Police (and Win); Lawyers Share Trade Secrets of a Growth Industry
description: The combustible encounter between a litigious society and a gung-ho police force has produced the seemingly inevitable: a how-to course by lawyers, for lawyers, on suing the New York Police Department.

title: FRANKLIN SELECT STUDIES SALE OF SOME ASSETS
description: Franklin Select Realty Trust said yesterday that its board would meet on Saturday to consider selling all of its real estate assets to Value Enhancement Fund III L.L.C. for $105 million in cash. The buyer would also assume debt of $26.5 million. Franklin, based in San Mateo, Calif., is an equity real estate investment trust that owns and operates office buildings in suburban markets in California. It had revenue of $17.9 million in 1998. The acquiring fund is managed by New York-based Lend Lease Real Estate Investments Inc., a manager of real estate for pension funds and institutional investors.

title: David Rall, 73, Specialist in Environmental Health
description: Dr. David Platt Rall, a cancer specialist and a leader in environmental health research, died on Tuesday in Bordeaux, France. He lived in Washington and was 73.

title: AFFILIATED COMPUTER WILL ACQUIRE CONSULTEC
description: Affiliated Computer Services Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired Consultec L.L.C., a unit of the General American Life Insurance Company, for $105 million. Consultec, based in Atlanta, provides software and services to the health care industry, including Medicaid programs in about 20 states. The company had revenue of about $107 million for the year that ended on July 31. Affiliated Computer, a provider of outsourcing and computer technology services based in Dallas, reported revenue of $451.3 million for the year ended June 30. Its shares fell 43.75 cents, to $40.1875, on the Big Board.

title: Pettitte Shaky but Yanks Close In on Home Field
description: David Cone was shaken out of sleep this morning by a pounding on the door of his hotel room, and there were shouts and screams, voices he recognized. Some of his teammates had just arrived from Baltimore, where the Yankees had clinched the American League East title hours before.

title: Editorial Observer; Waiting for the Prize Money and Good News
description: In the middle of this decade, as mailboxes across the country filled with junk mail of every kind, all competing for the personal attention and dollars of the American family, the two biggest sweepstakes mailers in the nation, Publishers Clearing House and American Family Publishers, became more aggressive in the language they used to make people think they were about to win something big.

title: U.S. FOODSERVICE ADDING SUPERIOR AND CHRISTIANSON
description: U.S. Foodservice agreed yesterday to acquire the combined operations of the Superior Products Manufacturing Company and the Christianson Sales Company, distributors of food-service equipment and supplies based in New Brighton, Minn. U.S. Foodservice, a food distributor based in Columbia, Md., did not disclose the financial terms of the acquisition. U.S. Foodservice said Superior and Christianson had sales of $127 million in the last 12 months. The companies have been owned and operated by Warren G. Christianson since 1957. U.S. Foodservice, which had sales of about $6.19 billion for the fiscal year ended July 3, expects to complete the acquisition by Oct. 29.

title: Former Stockbroker Barred From Industry
description: Christine Beyer, a former New York Stock Exchange floor broker who admitted last year to misusing her access to the exchange to make illegal trades, has been barred from the securities industry for five years, regulators said this week.

title: Parenting in Triplicate
description: Once it was enough to send children to school clean, fed and clothed. Now schools are making parents act as lawyers as well.

title: Making an Old Story New With the Purity of a Silent
description: Why would any director in this day and age choose to make a full-length black-and-white silent movie, and a drama at that? As the Finnish filmmaker Aki Kaursimaki explains in a program note to ''Juha,'' his surprisingly gripping adaptation of a 1911 novel by Juhani Aho, ''the easyness of explaining all by words has polluted our storytelling to a pale shadow of original cinema.'' He goes on to disparage mumbled dialogue and what he calls ''hootchy-cootchy'' as contributing to the movies' loss of innocence.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, IRVING T.
description: SIEGEL-Irving T. On September 29, 1999. Loving husband of Shirley for over 60 years. Beloved father of Barbara and Harvey Klipper, and Robert and Carol Siegel. Proud grandfather of Brian and Jody Siegel. Brother of Milton, Ruth Abend, & Zeva Cohn. Service on Sunday, 1:30PM at ''Riverside Memorial Chapel,'' 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York. Contributions in his memory may be made to St. Luke's/Roosevelt Hospital Center, Attn: Stroke Program Unit, 1111 Amsterdam Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10025.

title: GANNETT IN ACQUISITION OF TUCKER COMMUNICATIONS
description: The Gannett Company, the largest United States newspaper company, acquired Tucker Communications Inc., which publishes The Patent Trader and eight other weekly publications in New York and Connecticut, for an undisclosed sum. The acquisition allows Gannett to expand its newspaper holdings in Westchester County, where it already owns The Journal News. Gannett will also gain closely held Tucker's publications in Putnam County and Fairfield County, Conn. The company declined to comment on the price of the acquisition.

title: Seeking Union Vote, The Democrats Clash
description: Appealing to an important labor union for support in the Presidential campaign, Vice President Al Gore and former Senator Bill Bradley sparred yesterday, at long distance.

title: How World Stock Markets Fared in the Third Quarter
description: What concerns investors more: Political instability or natural disasters? If Taiwan is a good bellwether, the answer would seem to be political instability.

title: Art Museum Bolsters Lawsuit Against Giuliani
description: The Brooklyn Museum of Art refined its lawsuit against Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday, contending for the first time that the Mayor should be held personally liable for his campaign to cut off public financing and evict the museum on the basis of his displeasure with an exhibition of British art.

title: SAFETY AND CRIME AT HEART OF TALKS ON GUN LAWSUITS
description: In their first major meeting with officials from cities that are suing the firearms industry, the nation's leading gun manufacturers, trying to get the suits dropped, have agreed to begin negotiations to improve gun safety and reduce the flow of weapons to criminals.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: WHEAT FALLS. Wheat tumbled about 3 percent after a Government report showed larger-than-expected grain stockpiles. Wheat for December delivery fell 8.75 cents, to $2.67 a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: American Team Will Battle Europe a Country at a Time
description: The women's match between Europe and the United States at the International Olympic Committee Championships in Lausanne, Switzerland, last week was bad news and good news for the Americans.

title: Beijing Shows Off Military Weapons to Impress the Chinese and Others
description: With a Soviet-style procession of goose-stepping troops, tanks, missiles and fighter jets setting the tone for the parade marking its 50 years of Communism, China showed off a formidable armory today, even if few of the weapons could match the latest Western models.

title: Top Leader in Iran Tries to Calm Rage Of Its Hard-Liners
description: Iran's supreme religious leader moved decisively today to head off a fresh confrontation with the country's reformist President, instructing hard-line Muslim clerics and their loyalists among the police not to ''take matters into their own hands'' in a potentially explosive dispute involving university students.

title: With Gilbert and Sullivan, Dreaming Up a Second Act
description: Mike Leigh's grandly entertaining ''Topsy-Turvy'' is one of those films that create a mix of erudition, pageantry and delectable acting opportunities, much as ''Shakespeare in Love'' did last year. Instead of a lovestruck young playwright, it presents the curiously matched personalities of the librettist William Schwenk Gilbert and the composer Arthur Sullivan in the midst of a robust, knowing, frequently hilarious look at the musical theater over which they held sway.

title: A City, Its Art and Reputation Are on the Line
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, ARTHUR E., DDS.
description: KAHN-Arthur E., DDS. On September 29, 1999. Beloved husband of Anita. Loving father of Roberta and Karen. Adoring grandfather of Levin and Matthew. Dr. Kahn was an internationally acclaimed dentist. He lectured worldwide and mentored study groups in America and Israel. He treated many prominent figures in the arts and entertainment world. He made significant contributions to the literature in the field of restorative dentistry. Dr. Kahn received his B.S. from the University of Maryland and was a graduate of N.Y.U. College of Dentistry. He had held appointments on the faculty of Boston University and the University of Pennsylvania. Dr. Kahn was a longtime collector of 20th century art. Examples from his collection have been exhibited in museums throughout the world. There will be private graveside service on Monday, October 4th. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

title: Wary About Enemies, Including One's Friends
description: Ronald K. Brown/Evidence seemed ready to make the walls of the Joyce Theater shake with kinetic excitement the other night. It's a talented company, and Mr. Brown has provided it with rousing choreography.

title: Ventura Gives Life to Gasping Mets
description: The scoreboard looms in right field at Shea Stadium, a garish monolith that blinked in yellow lights the scores from the Houston and Cincinnati games, the scores that would go a long way toward determining whether the Mets would spend the evening absorbed in bitter reflection or sustained tension.

title: Blood Quest Begins for Virus Research
description: City and Federal health officials started going door-to-door in northern Queens yesterday seeking donors of blood samples for a study to determine the overall infection rate of the mosquito-borne West Nile virus.

title: Tivo Rises 24% In Its Second Day
description: The shares of Tivo Inc. rose 24 percent today in their second day of trading on optimism for the company's TV recorder service that lets viewers pause, rewind and play back live broadcasts.

title: Guilty Plea in Adoption Scheme
description: A lawyer accused of running an adoption ring in which he and two Long Island women smuggled babies to the New York region from Mexico pleaded guilty yesterday to a conspiracy charge.

title: Menifee Faces Ecton Park
description: In horse racing, the regular season is rushing to a close, and it is playoff time -- time for 3-year-olds to race against their seniors, for fillies to test colts, for stablemates to run against one another. And the countdown intensifies today when Menifee and Ecton Park, two veterans of Triple Crown races from the barn of Elliott Walden, race against each other in the $500,000 Super Derby at Louisiana Downs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RABINOVICH, JOSEPH
description: RABINOVICH-Joseph. On September 30th, 1999. Beloved husband of Marcelle. Devoted father of Joyce Barkin. Adoring grandfather of Frances and greatgrandfather of Nicholas and Spencer. Also survived by children Matthew, Daniel, Jamie and Adrienne. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Friday and Saturday, 7-9 PM, with service on Sunday 11:30 AM. Contributions in his memory may be made to Temple Emanu-El, 1 East 65 Street, New York, NY 10021.

title: The Planets Might Just Be Aligned for This Team
description: There was something of an intimate gathering at Shea Stadium last night watching the Mets try to hang on to their season by their cuticles. Forget about the overpowering cheers the Mets had heard from the near-sellout crowds against the Braves for the last three days. That noise and that excitement did not exist at the outset in Flushing. It did by the end of the night, however.

title: For Beggars or Big Shots, Work Is a Human Condition
description: The Oxford Book of Work

title: A Wasteland That Was Once the Cradle of Hope
description: If timing is everything, then the timeliest film to be seen this weekend in New York, as Japan reels from the shock of the direst nuclear accident in its history, is ''Pripyat.''

title: The Real Reagan, According to Deaver
description: To the Editor:

title: The Battle of Brooklyn
description: The chaotic nature of the debate over the ''Sensation'' exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum of Art must not obscure the two big issues involved. They have to do with the ground rules for government financing of cultural institutions and the political censorship of constitutionally guaranteed freedom of expression.

title: New Chairman of KPMG Takes Over
description: Stephen Butler took over yesterday as chairman of KPMG International.

title: A Great Day for the Great One Ends in a Tie
description: Canada's favorite son came home to say goodbye.

title: Poker-Faced Party Music In the Style of Rural Cuba
description: Eliades Ochoa wore his guajiro hat -- a small cowboy hat, the sign of rural music -- when he led the Cuarteto Patria at the Bottom Line on Monday night. He upholds the rural Cuban styles of son and guaracha, music for acoustic guitars, percussion and trumpet that can be played as easily on a street corner as on a stage. But Mr. Ochoa is hardly a yokel. While he maintains the music's old, unplugged sound, he has not tried to freeze it in time. He has personalized the son from within, adding virtuosity and variety while maintaining the music's tone of poker-faced party music.

title: The Real Reagan, According to Deaver
description: To the Editor:

title: South Koreans Call on U.S. To Apologize For Killings
description: For decades, Jeon Eun Yong tried with no success to convince the United States and South Korean Governments that American soldiers had gunned down his wife and young children and hundreds of other civilians in 1950, during the early days of the Korean War.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about protests in Belgrade against President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia misstated the surname of an aide to the opposition leader Zoran Djindjic in some copies. The aide is Cedmoir Jovanovic, not Jankovic.

title: Course of Action
description: Hugh B. Price, the president of the National Urban League, recalls fuming as he left the last National Educational Summit, held here in 1996.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UPHAM, JOHN
description: UPHAM-John. The St. Wilfrid Club of New York acknowledges with deep regret the death of our esteemed member and colleague.

title: Sal Salvador, 73, Teacher, Be-Bop Guitarist and Kenton Protege
description: The guitarist Sal Salvador, a warm-toned be-bop improviser who performed with Stan Kenton, Bill Evans, Phil Woods and other canonical jazz figures, died at a medical rehabilitation center in Stamford, Conn., on Sept. 22. He was 73 and lived in Stamford.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FREUNDLICH, LILLIAN
description: FREUNDLICH-Lillian. There will be a musical service of remembrance for Lillian Freundlich, pianist, teacher and coach and her husband Irwin at Christ and St. Stephen's Church, 120 West 69 St. (East of Broadway) on Sunday, October 3 at 3 P.M.

title: Mohawk Stock Buyback
description: Mohawk Industries, a leading carpet maker, said this week that it planned to buy back as many as five million of its shares, or 8 percent of the stock outstanding, at a cost of as much as $98 million at current prices. The company, which makes the Aladdin, Galaxy and Mohawk brands of carpets and rugs, said that it might use some of the repurchased shares for employee-benefit plans. Mohawk has about 61.2 million shares outstanding. The stock closed today at $19.875, down 6.25 cents.

title: Auto Makers Finish Record Year on Strong Note
description: Customers drawn by hefty rebates bought more than 16 million new cars, sport utility vehicles, minivans and pickup trucks in the 1999 model year, breaking the sales record set in 1986.

title: AILING AIRLINE GROUNDED
description: A British court ordered Debonair Airways Ltd., a money-losing low-fare airline, into receivership. The airline's fleet of 14 airplanes was grounded while administrators sought new financing -- just two days after AB Airlines, another small airline, collapsed. Rivals ascribed the failures to costly route networks and competition from bigger rivals. Virgin Express, led by Richard Branson, said it was in talks to see ''what we can do to help.''

title: A City, Its Art and Reputation Are on the Line
description: To the Editor:

title: Hospital Told to Remain Open Until Hearing Is Held on Sale
description: A New York Supreme Court judge has ruled that the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital must continue to provide health services until a hearing is held on the proposed sale of its buildings.

title: California Property Deal
description: The Equity Office Properties Trust, the largest owner of office properties in the United States, bought the Palo Alto Square office complex in the Silicon Valley of California for $85 million from a partnership controlled by Sam Zell, the billionaire financier who is chairman of Equity Office. The Chicago-based real estate investment trust said the complex near Stanford University had 320,500 square feet of space and was fully occupied. Equity Office and its predecessors have managed the five-building complex for 20 years.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEINSTEIN, AARON
description: WEINSTEIN-Aaron Gone two years. Ever missed, loved, remembered Ruth, Children, Grandchildren

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARNOLD, NICK
description: ARNOLD-Nick. The way your smile just beams, the way you haunt my dreams, the way you changed my life...they can't take that away from me. I wish you lovely gossamer wings. All my love and everything forever and ever. Jo.

title: U.S. Proposes Guidelines On Forming Joint Ventures
description: The Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission published proposed guidelines today for joint ventures among businesses, indicating the sorts of agreements that do not violate Federal antitrust laws.

title: Mother of Brain-Damaged Baby Sues Hospital
description: The mother of a baby with severe brain damage filed a lawsuit yesterday against Lenox Hill Hospital and two doctors affiliated with it, charging that a failure to treat a diagnosed strep infection in the mother led to the child's condition.

title: DEMAND BY ECUADOR CREDITORS
description: Creditors have voted to demand the full repayment of $1.4 billion in outstanding Ecuadorean discount bonds, a Chase Manhattan Bank spokesman said. Chase said that because of the acceleration, ''the bonds are immediately due and payable.'' The acceleration comes after Ecuador defaulted on a $44.5 million interest payment on the bonds Thursday. The Ecuadorean Government had asked creditors to allow the country to tap funds backing the discounts to make the interest payments. But creditors rejected Ecuador's plea and instead voted to accelerate the bonds.

title: Beliefs; In a new book, a British journalist joins the contentious debate concerning the relationship between Pope Pius XII and Nazi Germany
description: Some Roman Catholic leaders are pushing to have Pope Pius XII declared a saint. By contrast, John Cornwell, in the title of his new book, calls Pius ''Hitler's Pope.''

title: Poor Belgian Girl Yearns For (What Else?) Waffles
description: ''Rosetta,'' Luc and Jean-Pierre Dardenne's terminally bleak, stoically drab portrait of a desperate 17-year-old Belgian girl, comes decorated with honors that most filmmakers would kill to have attached to their work. This grim quasi-documentary filmed with hand-held cameras (in places it's almost as jiggly as ''The Blair Witch Project'') picked up the top prize at this year's Cannes Film Festival and a best-actress award for its chunky, rosy-cheeked star, Emilie Dequenne.

title: Medical Workers Nervous Over Spread of Hepatitis C
description: Robert Cancel, an emergency medical technician in the Bronx for 13 years, hops on an ambulance every day and performs a job with innumerable risks: from traffic collisions to violent patients to H.I.V. infection.

title: Pine Mountain Club Journal; Released to the Wild, Condors Choose a Nice Peopled Retreat
description: Perched on a roof in this small wilderness community, California condor W0 is a sight to behold. Weighing in at about 20 pounds, with a wingspan around nine feet and history dating to the mastodon, its presence is awe-inspiring. But Mike Barth, a wildlife biologist, would rather it just go away.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''In an Islamic system, punishment is the authorities' prerogative. Any such act from any person is forbidden, and now that I have forbidden it, it is not only legally barred but religiously forbidden.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks Continue to Slide On Strong Economic News

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: For 2 Women in India, Heritage Torn by Hate
description: Maneka Gandhi is the other daughter-in-law, the one who did not inherit the dynasty. And oh, how the irony grates on her.

title: As Business Confidence Grows, Euro Stages a Comeback
description: After a nearly nonstop slide against the dollar for the first six months of its life, the euro is coming back into vogue.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  APFEL, IKE
description: APFEL-Ike. 6/1/52 to 10/2/92. Always loving you, Always missing you, Always celebrating your life. Always, Mom

title: A 20-Year Labor of Love For a 'Historian's Historian'
description: In the basement of Vincent Seyfried's 1960 Colonial home, on top of some wooden shelves, sit dozens of dusty bundles wrapped in brown paper and bound in twine. One is marked ''Long Island City Star 1880-81.'' Another, ''Flushing Journal 1892-1893.''

title: Kirsten Johnson, John Adams 2d
description: Kirsten Lindwood Johnson and John Willard Adams 2d were married yesterday at the First Congregational Church in Guilford, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Kendrick L. Norris, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony, in which the Rev. Robert Lord, a Roman Catholic priest, took part.

title: Paint, Patience and Countless Hours
description: THERE were still several weeks to go, but it was a madhouse, a sort of frenzied euphoria, behind the scenes at the Tomes-Higgins Designer Show House at Christ Church in Greenwich. Scaffolds and paint buckets were everywhere; carpenters, painters, muralists and interior designers were trying not to trip over each other in their down-to-the-wire dance -- before everything would fall into place.

title: Brazil Memories
description: To the Editor: A big thank-you to Daisann McLane for bringing back happy memories of the Amazon (Frugal Traveler, Sept. 5 and 19).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWARTZ, JOHN D.
description: SWARTZ-John D.. Of Fishkill, formerly of Peekskill, NY, died Saturday, October 2, 1999. Mr. Swartz graduated Colby College in 1929 with a B.S., Harvard University Law School LLB, 1933. Admitted to practice in NY, Washington, DC, and US Supreme Court. Private practice 1934 to 1941, associated with a private practitioner in New York City, specializing in anti-trust. Worked for the Federal Government 1941 to 1944, Attorney with the Criminal Division of the US Department of Justice, Washington, DC, prosecuting mail and securities fraud. 1944-1946 Trial Attorney with the NY Office of the Anti-Trust Division. 1946-1953 Special Assistant to the United States Attorney General, NY Office, AntiTrust Division. 1953-1967 Assistant Chief, NY Office, Anti-Trust Division. 1967-1992 returned to private practice, representing several major international corporations, including Sansui Electronics. Born to Abraham and Taube Schwartzman on February 22, 1907. Survivors include daughter Barbara D'Andrea and son and daughterin-law, Theodore and Vicki Swartz, brother Max Schwartzman and sister, Beatrice Finck, four grandchildren, Michael D'Andrea, Melissa D'Andrea, Matthew Swartz, and Rachel Swartz. Graveside services Sunday October 3, 2:30 PM at the New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, L.I., NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Harvard Law School. For information, contact Robert H. Auchmoody Funeral Homes, Inc., 126 Main St., Fishkill, NY. (914) 896-6166.

title: Princeton's Desperate Move Turns Freshman Into a Star
description: Against Fordham today, Princeton running back Cameron Atkinson looked like a determined teen-ager practicing for his driving test, zooming in and around defenders as if they were safety cones.

title: Canal Street, Eastern and Western
description: CANAL HOUSE ****

title: The Individualist
description: William Frawley is a passionate scavenger, a man in the habit of rescuing stray relics from the dim nooks and attics where they sit gathering dust. A fashion designer and illustrator -- he created the caricatures for Isaac Mizrahi's comic book, ''The Adventures of Sandee the Supermodel'' -- Frawley knows exactly what he's after. And he knows when he's found it, pouncing on discoveries like a man reclaiming long-lost kin. ''You definitely recognize certain things when you first see them,'' he says. ''In a weird way, you feel like you always had them in your head.''

title: Serbian Police Block Protesters' March, but Without Violence
description: Serbian police officers in riot gear blocked a march of anti-Government demonstrators tonight, but both sides avoided confrontation, and the protesters returned to the central Belgrade square from which they started.

title: Lise Carrigg and David Cancel
description: Lisa Ann Carrigg, a daughter of Jane and Robert Carrigg of North Hampton, N.H., was married yesterday to David Christopher Cancel, a son of Cecilia and Michael Cancel of Forest Hills, Queens. The Rev. Deborah Evans Hogan, a nondenominational minister, performed the ceremony at the Union Chapel in Little Boar's Head, N.H.

title: Against Irony
description: It is no wonder that Jedediah Purdy is remarkable; he has a goodly heritage (Marshall Sella, Sept. 5). Fifty years ago, his paternal grandparents were our neighbors. Harold and Sally were salt of the earth -friendly, kind, compassionate and dependable to a young family who were newcomers.

title: Sept. 26-Oct. 2; Amazon.com Opens Its Doors
description: Looking for more cash, Amazon.com opened its popular Web site to any interested merchant. Like most Internet retailers, Amazon loses lots of money. But by selling access to its 12 million customers, the retailer gains a new revenue stream without the costs associated with a warehouse of products. Merchants will pay $9.95 a month to be listed on the site. If they choose to have Amazon process credit card purchases, they will pay 4.75 percent of the total sale.

title: Ponzini on Ballot
description: In a Sept. 27 letter to Robert F. Meehan, Town Supervisor, and members of the Mount Pleasant Town Board, Robert J. Ponzini said he was voluntarily suspending himself from his position as a town justice.

title: Q&A/Theresa Coleman-Negast; Going Where Few Women Go: Sleuthing
description: IF not for the fact that Theresa Coleman-Negast, 28, does not like wearing a uniform, she might have become a police officer. Instead, she is a private eye, with her company, Universal Information Services in White Plains.

title: The Man in the White Suit Restyles the Raiders
description: As difficult as it may be for some people in the National Football League to hear, there is a man who may deserve an apology. You know who he is. He wears those horrific white suits and funny-looking glasses. He hates the league office -- and the people in it hate him.

title: You Can Take It With You
description: Final Home is not a cemetery. It's a store named for Kosuke Tsumura's line of multi-pocketed clothing, which he recently opened at 241 Lafayette Street, between Prince and Spring Streets. He calls it ''home'' because life's essentials -- keys, ATM card and a burrito -- can be stored in each garment's many pockets. Who needs a suitcase when you can wear a nylon anorak, left, with 12 pockets -- two on each sleeve and eight on the body ($500) -- roomy enough for a spare set of underwear, pajamas, toothbrush, toothpaste and the cat. A zippered, hooded acrylic and polyester fleece pullover with two pockets, one on each sleeve, might appeal to a chain smoker ($275).

title: On Politics; A Bush-Whitman Ticket? Visit www.itcouldbe.com
description: A common-sense point of view settled in among the deep thinkers in Washington in the perfect hindsight after President Richard M. Nixon's trip to Communist China in 1972. It was that only a Republican President could have made the trip, and only a President with the conservative cover of the Republican Party could have hoisted those tiny cups of mao tai with a former enemy on the left -- the way out left -- as Mr. Nixon did.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: THE SUN KING

title: In New Atlanta Era, New Jersey Wins
description: The National Hockey League returned to this city tonight for the first time since 1980 with a team named the Thrashers. The new team was introduced amid fireworks and was met with a rousing ovation from a sellout crowd at newly built Philips Arena in the season opener against the Devils.

title: Sept. 26-Oct. 2; Court Gets Sex Crimes Case
description: A law that permits victims of rape and other sex crimes to sue their attackers for damages in Federal court may seem an unlikely battleground in the federalism wars. But that is what the Violence Against Women Act became earlier this year when a Federal appeals court declared it unconstitutional as beyond the ''limited authority'' of the Federal government to enter a traditional province of state law. Now the Supreme Court has announced it will take up the case.

title: Where Seafood Gets a Full Treatment
description: WHY doesn't Long Island have places like this?'' Comments like that are often heard from Island residents who visit other parts of the country that boast one rough-and-ready fish house after another. The Island should be dotted with these casual waterfront spots that serve bountiful platters of freshly caught seafood at moderate prices.

title: Harlemites Get in the Ring With Economic Zone Officials
description: On this side of the ring, ladies and gentlemen, we have the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone, the Federal Government's appointed leader of economic development in Harlem. On the other side, we have some of the people of Harlem, as represented by residents and members of Community Board 10.

title: When Immigrants Aren't Welcome
description: To the Editor:

title: The Singer Solution to World Poverty
description: Thank you for your courageous publication of Peter Singer's against-the-flow philosophy (Sept. 5).

title: Hero of the Hanoi Hilton
description: FAITH OF MY FATHERS

title: As Neighbors Protest, Halfway House Is Halted for Now
description: Sisters of Charity Healthcare, a nonprofit corporation that operates several medical ventures on Staten Island, has suspended its plan to build a halfway house for recovering alcoholics at 333 Broadway in West Brighton. Last week's move came 10 days after Community Board 1 withdrew support for the project, and two days after residents near the proposed site picketed the group's offices with signs reading, ''No Way Halfway on Broadway.''

title: The Nation; Grand Old Spending Party
description: IN life's rich pageant, few spectacles are as dizzying as watching Congress spend the public's treasure. The sums are huge, the oratory windy, the techniques tricky as three-card monte.

title: POSTINGS: At Grand Central, Theoretical Designs for Area Between Penn Station and the Hudson; Architects Envision West Side Stories
description: Proposals by five architects who participated in a competition for plans to redevelop the derelict 12-block corridor of rail yards between Pennsylvania Station and the Hudson River will go on view Tuesday at Grand Central Terminal.

title: Miss Streit, Mr. McCleery
description: Elizabeth Paige Streit, a daughter of Margaret Brown of Darien, Conn., and Raymond Streit of Maineville, Ohio, was married on Friday on Martha's Vineyard to Matthew West McCleery, a son of Nancy McCleery of North Haven, Conn., and Michael C. McCleery of Branford, Conn. The Rev. Michael R. Nagle performed the ceremony at St. Elizabeth's Roman Catholic Church in Edgartown, Mass.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Westchester Still Reels From Floyd's Punch; Building and Road Repairs Begin as Damages Are Assessed
description: IN 1889, when 21.73 inches of rain fell during the final days of July, angry currents along the Bronx River swept a piano downstream in storm-ravaged Westchester. Despite the weather, the betting continued at Yonkers Raceway, the newspapers reported; however, track conditions were so bad that Songster fell in the second race, throwing his jockey.

title: Sept. 26-Oct. 2; A Nobel for Gunter Grass
description: Forty years after the publication of his masterpiece, ''The Tin Drum,'' a book that vividly confronted the ghosts that post-war Germany seemed inclined to forget, Gunter Grass was awarded the Nobel Prize for literature. A man of passionate political engagement, a persistent critic of what he has often portrayed as the smug complacency of German society, Mr. Grass was praised by the Swedish Academy for his portrayal of the ''forgotten face of history.'' That face has come alive with an often Rabelaisian gusto in the writings of the 71-year-old Mr. Grass. ROGER COHEN

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: All Gall Is Divided

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELOFSKY, MARY L.
description: BELOFSKY-Mary L.. (Also known as Mary L. Bell.) Age 87, died peacefully in her sleep at 6:10 AM, September 30, 1999. She was the beloved daughter of Goldie and Max Belofsky, the loyal sister of Morris Bell and Lee Chalik, both of whom predeceased her, and of Frances K. Bein, to whom she was devoted all her life. She is also survied by Dr. Martin J. Bell, Susan Sarfati, Michael Chalik, Marc Bein, Dr. Ward Bein, Laura Lind and Louise Harris, her nieces and nephews who kept a special place in their hearts for their feisty Aunt Mary. Their spouses and children will always remember her. To her speical friend, George S. Lee, of Lookout Mountain, TN, she leaves beautiful memories of their times together over many years. Mary donated her body for medical research to New York Medical College in Valhalla, NY. At an appropriate time, a memorial service will be held at the home of her sister, Mrs. Abraham C. Bein, in Briarcliff Manor, NY. Family and friends will be notified of the date.

title: Ann Pinciss, Elliot Berman
description: Ann Joyce Pinciss and Dr. Elliot Berman are to be married in New York today by Rabbi David Posner at the home of Joan and Michael Bartos, friends of the bride.

title: Corrections
description: A cross-reference on page 11 of the Travel section today, with an article about trends in the cruising industry, omits a page number for an article about shipboard Internet communications. It is on page 12 of the section.

title: Living to the Fullest In Lloyd Harbor
description: As a resident of Lloyd Harbor, I take offense at the Sept. 19 opinion essay [''No Place Like Home''].

title: F.Y.I.
description: Through the Mill

title: Town Asks for Return Of Ousted Postmaster
description: The residents of 08742 care less about about a weekly betting pool at the post office in Point Pleasant than they do about their postmaster. They want him back. So does the Borough Council.

title: Reading, Writing, Social Climbing
description: EDES GILBERT saw it all. For 15 years as the headmistress of the Spence School, she saw the parents who lobbied for their 7-year-olds to be assigned to classes with children who weren't their friends but whose parents were rich and prominent -- in the hopes that the students would become friends and so would the parents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORFIEN, HARRY, DR.
description: GORFIEN-Harry, Dr.. Passed away on September 29th after a long illness. He is survived by his sister Ray Rudin of Coconut Creek, FL, and his children Larry of New Haven, CT, Rahti (aka Claudette) of NYC and Jack of Guilford, CT. Burial at Arlington National Cemetery on Wednesday, October 6, at 10:30 AM. Donations may be made to VA Hospital, Voluntary Services, 950 Campbell Ave., West Haven, CT 06516, in memory of Dr. Gorfien.

title: My Teacher, My D.J.: Music School to Make Radio Shows
description: Early in the first installment of his new radio show, James David Jacobs visits a friend who plays music on stones and pans. Mr. Jacobs's goal is to teach how the raw sounds of nature become the cooked sounds of music.

title: Sources
description: A selective list of where to find the architects, designers and products featured in this issue.

title: Jandon Scholars
description: Westchester is offering college scholarships to academic achievers of limited means, targeting students whose families are on public assistance or living below the poverty level.

title: Freudian Slipcovers
description: When the San Francisco interior designer Gary Hutton got a call from a longtime client inviting him to lunch, he was expecting a simple catch-up session. Just after sitting down, however, the client made a startling announcement: ''I'm divorcing my husband, and my sister says she's a lesbian.''

title: In Brookhaven, Deficit Seen for Highway Dept.
description: Democrats in the Town of Brookhaven said last week that the town Highway Department is facing a deficit of at least $64.5 million, or more than $82 million when interest is included.

title: Bait and Switch
description: To the Editor:

title: Music Keeps Everyone Young
description: The youngest member of the New Jersey Intergenerational Orchestra is 6 years old, and the oldest is 88. They will play side by side at the United Nations on Tuesday afternoon to celebrate 1999 as International Year of Older Persons Toward a Society for All Ages. (Information: 908-709-0084.)

title: The View From/Cornwall Bridge; Artist Uses Steel to Capture the Beauty and Motion of Nature
description: HE can not bend steel with his bare hands, but with the help of a welding machine and some hand tools, Peter Busby sculpts it to his will.

title: A Turn Of Events Has Limits For Gold
description: TIME was, ''Worth its weight in gold'' meant something. Trouble is, for the past two decades, gold has been on a diet.

title: No Serious Harm
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: 3 Hospitals Negotiating North Shore-L.I.J. Ties
description: Long Island's three eastern hospitals are negotiating a sponsorship arrangement with the North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System that would allow them to use the system's vast array of medical and support services.

title: The View From/Elmsford; Remember Petey and Nipper? You, Too, Can Own a Pit Bull
description: HELEN KELLER had one. So did Fred Astaire. And if the Elmsford Animal Shelter has its way, lots of other people will have one, too.

title: New Hope Stirs for Downtown New Rochelle
description: For most of this decade, officials here have been struggling to find a way to stop the free fall of their city's downtown. It may be fitting, then, that New Roc City, the $190 million hope for the future of downtown New Rochelle, is capped by a 220-foot-tall, free-fall amusement ride.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORUZZI, LUCY (NEE SARRO)
description: CORUZZI-Lucy (nee Sarro). Left this world on 30 September, 1999, in NYC, aged 72. Widow of Hugo Coruzzi. Mother of Laura, Gloria and Celeste Coruzzi. Grandmother of Aidan Coruzzi Daly, Eva Coruzzi Schneider and Giovanna Coruzzi Kupiec. Lucy Coruzzi grew up on East 48 St., where from a young age she worked at her family's newsstand and luncheonette on 2nd Avenue, which was a favorite neighborhood gathering spot. After attending Julia Richmond High School, she had to decline a scholarship to Hunter College because her three brothers Joseph, Armando and (twin) Rudolph were drafted to fight in World War II. After the war, she married Hugo Coruzzi and enjoyed a deeply devoted and loving relationship blessed by the birth of three daughters. After Hugo died suddenly at age 43, Lucy raised her three young daughters alone with the support of the close-knit Sarro family. She went to work at the state rent office where she rose to Chief of Control before retiring. Meanwhile, the values instilled and effort expended in the education of her three daughters resulted in three Ph.D.s, plus a law degree for the eldest. Most recently, the role of grandmother was a new vocation on which Lucy embarked with all her considerable energy. Lucy Coruzzi lived with simplicity, generosity, optimism, and faith. Her greatest pleasure was to sit down for a family meal, and the day her life was complete was the day she first held all her three grandchildren in her lap. She enriched the lives of those around her, regardless of status or station. On 6 October 1995, Lucy hugged the Pope, and each was blessed. Our sense of loss is as great as the loving imprint she left in all of us. Her eight-year old grandson rewrote the morning headlines for September 30, 1999: ''Lucy Dies at 72; Many Sad.'' Wake at Perazzo Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker St., 212-777-7108, Saturday 7-9:30 PM, Sunday 2-5 PM and 7-9:30 PM. Funeral mass Monday, 4 October at Our Lady of Pompeii Church, 25 Carmine St., NYC, 9:30 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STORCH, OTTO
description: STORCH-Otto. Beloved husband of Dolores (nee Silece). A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at The Church of St. John the Evangelist, 348 E. 55 St. (at 1st Av) Wednesday, October 6, 10:30 AM.

title: Gore Effort Is Encouraged By Support From Union
description: In the first good news for his campaign in some time, Vice President Al Gore today received the support of a major health care workers union local.

title: A Winning Millennium Moment of Music
description: THE assignment: to sum up the width and breadth of Westchester in music, packing hints of millennial majesty, visions of past and future and an ennobling optimism in exactly 60 seconds.
