The sound should be distinctive, with allowances made for voice-overs. The reward for the composer who succeeds: $2,000.

title: The World; Britain Quietly Says It's Time To Adopt a Bill of Rights
description: THEY set out to challenge the law. But when four Britons dismissed from the British military because they are gay accused the government of violating their basic human right to privacy, they couldn't find a remedy in a domestic court. They had to take their case to the European Court of Human Rights in Strasbourg, France.

title: Sue Thy Neighbor
description: As you and your spouse pull into your crushed granite driveway after a hard day's work at the commodities firm, you both smile, secure in the knowledge that your new multimillion-dollar country seat on half an acre will always grow in value. But wait -- no, it can't be -- what are those brand-new virulently purple flamingos doing on your neighbor's previously pristine lawn?

title: Tina Evangelides And Ted Donovan
description: Christine Maria Evangelides, a daughter of Stephen G. Evangelides of Basking Ridge, N.J., and the late Alice S. Evangelides, was married yesterday to Edward Joseph Donovan 3d, a son of Judith M. Donovan of Philadelphia and the late Mr. Donovan Jr. The Rev. James Burns, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York.

title: Lives; Household Chores
description: My sister, my 11-year-old niece and I are down on our hands and knees scrubbing Ben's kitchen floor. In the background, we can hear Cat Stevens singing something about love being the answer. Ben is my all-grown-up baby brother. A few years ago, he was driving up from Florida, returning home to Vermont. Somewhere outside Bayonne, N.J., he stopped at a motel to grab a bite to eat. He walked into the dining room, sat down, perused the menu and burst into tears, sobbing. When the waitress inquired if he was all right, he stood up, slammed her against the wall and punched her in the stomach. ''I felt sorry for him,'' the waitress said and refused to press charges. We, his family, wished that she had.

title: Alsace for Novices
description: When the Hugel family introduced its lithe white called Gentil in 1992, it further burnished its credentials, dating to 1639, as one of Alsace's preminent producers.

title: The World: Uncivil Wars; No Place for Civilians
description: WAR, Gen. Omar N. Bradley wrote in his memoir, ''A Soldier's Story,'' was ''a wretched debasement of all the thin pretensions of civilization.''

title: One-Ring Rap Sounds Hollow to the Braves
description: If there is one thing the Atlanta Braves don't want to hear as they head into the playoffs once more, it is that they have to win the World Series to validate their status as the team of the 90's.

title: Subway Work Near Museum Causes Delays
description: Could the timing have been worse?

title: Sept. 26-Oct. 2; Bulworth on the Hustings
description: Time was, likely candidates for President were supposed to be governors or senators or, as the columnist Robert Novak put it dryly the other day, generals who engineered the defeat of Hitler. Then the door opened wider, to entrepreneurial billionaires and television commentators. Now, in the all-media-all-the-time age, celebrity itself may qualify candidates for a public platform.

title: Two Differing Views Of Sacred Heart Dorm
description: To the Editor:

title: Public at Last Sees the Art Behind the Fuss
description: It was a museum director's fantasy: hundreds of people waiting on a clear, crisp morning for the doors to open on a new exhibition. Enough reporters buzzing about to cover a small war. A line of art patrons that grew longer and longer, even after the doors opened and the cash registers began to rattle and hum.

title: Foreign Affairs; Hazy In Havana
description: Walking through the Partagas cigar factory in Old Havana is like smoking a box of Cohibas without ever having to light up. You just breathe deeply as you follow the raw tobacco leaves from the lower floors where they are separated into different qualities, to the upper floors where they are rolled into different brands, to the taste-test table, where our guide, Teresa, has the job of smoking different cigars all day for quality control. The best cigar rollers make about $15 a month, an average Cuban wage. Upstairs, at a raised table in front of a room with 100 men and women rolling cigars, sits the ''lector,'' who entertains the workers by reading aloud all day -- newspapers in the morning, a Cuban novel in the afternoon.

title: Streetscapes / Broadway at Waverly Place; Once Upon a Time, an Evocation of Old London
description: THE new NoHo Historic District encompasses a rich mix of buildings, from Greek Revival row houses to turn-of-the-century lofts. But what was perhaps the most unusual structure in the area is long gone -- Old London Street, a mock-medieval street of theme-park shops that was built in 1887 on Broadway opposite Waverly Place and demolished almost a century ago.

title: His Life as a Murder Suspect
description: Yale explains that suspicions raised outside the classroom will distract students within it, and thereby impair teaching -- an argument that would have proved very convenient for removing ''suspected Communists'' in the 1950's.

title: Michigan Grounds Purdue Air Attack
description: They sacked him twice, mashed him into the soggy sod another half-dozen times and finally intercepted him. There was no doubt that Purdue quarterback Drew Brees had a rough time with the Michigan defense. But it really was the players on his side of the ball who ate away at whatever stump he had hoped to use to launch his Heisman campaign.

title: A Jerry Herman Banquet
description: After life as a cabaret act, a touring and summer-stock package, a Broadway show and a CD, how does a musical revue keep going? It becomes a symposium.

title: NONPROFIT GROUPS ACCUSED OF BILKING LUNCH PROGRAMS
description: Officers of many nonprofit organizations have illegally enriched themselves by pocketing millions of dollars of Federal money that was meant to feed poor children in day care homes, Federal investigators and state officials say.

title: 2,000 Photos From a Little Shop of Rarities in Paris
description: FOR decades, curators, collectors and dealers from throughout the world came here to an antiquarian bookshop on the Left Bank, the Librairie P. Jammes, where they climbed the circular staircase to meet the owners, Andre Jammes and his wife, Marie-Therese. They came to share the couple's expertise on photography, a private passion that they pursued for more than 40 years, forming one of the finest collections anywhere.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLASIUS, LESLIE R. KANE LODGE
description: BLASIUS-Leslie R. Kane Lodge. #

title: Another Branch of Art in Brooklyn's Forest
description: THERE is more than one way to look at the Fulton Avenue strip leading to the Billie Holiday Theater in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, a neighborhood that consists mostly of struggling African-Americans and Caribbean immigrants. One can calculate the dollars it would take to overcome the poverty lurking in the doorways of the fast-food stores and the beauty-supply outlets and among the fresh-air vendors with their goods arrayed on rickety tables. Or one can see a place ripe for dreams, where people need inspiration as much as rent money to carry on.

title: Report Faults Gore Campaign Aide For U.S. Spending at Expo 98
description: Government auditors have found mismanagement and questionable spending during America's participation in the 1998 World Exposition in Lisbon, Portugal, a project overseen by Tony Coelho, now Vice President Al Gore's Presidential campaign chairman, according to a report.

title: Dreaming of Ripe, Juicy Tomatoes With Flavor?; The Very Happy Return of Farmers' Markets, From Greenwich to Hartford to 60 Other Places Around the State
description: IT was Wednesday afternoon and the parking lot behind the CVS store in Darien was a hubbub of farmers, trucks, tent-like umbrellas shielding fruit and vegetable stands from the sun as well as shoppers wending their way from stand to stand.

title: Tribute to a Jazzman
description: A standup bass guitar is rarely considered a lead instrument, but it is when it's in the hands of Rufus Reid, who is being honored today for 20 years of teaching jazz at William Paterson University in Wayne.

title: SOAPBOX; Tossing the Daily
description: WHILE I sat on my front porch enjoying the morning sun, the sight of a boy on a bike delivering newspapers reminded me of how nice it was to live in a town where a boy or girl can still hop on a Schwinn before school and earn some soda money plus put a little away for college, too.

title: Serena on Tap
description: I have a good sense of humor, love Irish jokes, Seinfeld and Steve Martin (Molly O'Neill, Sept. 5). But whoa! When do you cross the line into vulgarity? When Serena Bass reveals her plan to have her restaurant patrons move into her bar, get drunk and make out.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOBMAN, ETHEL BLOCH
description: LOBMAN-Ethel Bloch., 75, died September 28th. She is survived by Arthur, her husband of 40 years, and her daughters Sara and Carrie. A meeting to celebrate her life & 55 years as a revolutionary and member of the Socialist Workers Party will be held on Sunday, October 10th, 1 PM, at the School of International Affairs, Columbia University, 420 West 118 Street, New York, NY. 212-399-7257

title: On the Brink of Jubilation
description: Their fate and mood had been flipped end over end in little more than 24 hours, the Mets solemnly staring elimination in the face and then suddenly sticking their tongues out like disobeying children who refuse to go to bed when they are told.

title: Works of Art At Jewish Seminary
description: To the editor:

title: Forerunner of Skyscrapers Faces the Wrecker's Ball
description: The Coogan Building, a 125-year-old former racquet club at West 26th Street and the Avenue of the Americas, is not much to look at these days, and you could easily pass it by without so much as a second glance. But to some preservationists, the red brick structure with the sooty facade is a gem once deemed worthy of landmark status.

title: BY THE WAY ; Come Blow Your Horn
description: You may know the alphorn, that 12-foot-long wooden trumpet in the Ricola cough drop television commercials. People really play them, and those want to learn how go to Switzerland to learn. One player is Dr. Theordore K. Schlosberg, founder and executive director of the New Jersey Workshop for the Arts in Westfield. He owns two alphorns, and uses one of them to teach Chris Velderman, a seventh grader at the Roosevelt Intermediate School in Westfield, how to play. Dr. Schlossberg wrote to Ricola about his interest in the instrument, and he and Chris have played their horns on behalf of the company at various events. Last month, Ricola sent the pair to the Alphorn Academy of Switzerland in Montreux, where they were among 12 who studied a week with the alphorn master Jozsef Molnar (Chris is at left and Dr. Schlosberg at center). Dr. Schlosberg hopes Ricola will help him start an alphorn academy in Westfield. If audience members cough during performances, relief is sure to be near.

title: Accumulated Leave: How to Cut Back
description: Regarding the article ''Police Contract: The Hole in Nassau's Bucket'' [Sept. 19], all of us should recognize that the duties of a police officer are laden with stress. He never knows what the next call will bring. It could be a nuisance or a dangerous emergency.

title: In Bayonne, It's All for One at This Label
description: Even the name was a consensus.

title: Transferring A Home To Children
description: LAWYERS who specialize in estate planning say that one of the more effective methods of passing real estate to the next generation -- while keeping a home of one's own for as long as one needs it and perhaps avoiding probate -- is the life estate.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-19

title: An Animatronic Uprising Down on Orwell's Farm
description: An oft-repeated slogan in George Orwell's book ''Animal Farm'' and the new movie adaptation of it, which has the first of seven showings on TNT tonight at 8, is: ''Four legs good, two legs bad.'' For the two-leggers behind the movie, four legs have been very good lately.

title: Daniel Jewel and Lan Nguyen
description: Lan Thien Nhat Nguyen, a daughter of Thoi Nguyen and Hong Nhat Nguyen of Orlando, Fla., was married last evening to Daniel Herman Jewel, a son of Jane Anne Jewel and Dr. Kenneth Lee Jewel of Mountain Lakes, N.J. Rabbi Gary Bretton-Granatoor officiated at the St. Regis Hotel in New York.

title: When Immigrants Aren't Welcome
description: To the Editor:

title: Amazing Grace
description: Benjamin Braddock in ''The Graduate'' didn't take heed when the man confided ''plastics!,'' but Grace Jeffers would have known better. In the past two years, her name has been linked with plastics -- particularly, high-pressure laminates -- in the pages of Metropolitan Home, the cliquish Wallpaper, The New York Times and many other publications.

title: Analyze This
description: When you look at the wallpaper pattern above, what do you see? A lot of wing chairs? Excellent. You're definitely a design enthusiast. A mob of monsters? Hmm. Interesting. And how does that make you feel? Anxious? That's O.K., too. You're not alone.

title: Three Characters In Search Of a Memoir
description: ONCE upon a time, the Rev. Mason L. Weems wrote a book about a president who chopped down his father's favorite young English cherry tree: ''The sweet face of youth brightened with the inexpressible charm of all-conquering truth, he bravely cried out, 'I can't tell a lie, Pa; you know I can't tell a lie. I did cut it with my hatchet.'

title: Desperate to Seem 16
description: As a 16-year-old suburban female, I fit the demographic that Hollywood targets. Yet, I am disgusted with the films it spits out at us. Everyone loves my generation. We are young and contemporary and spend money. But we are too often taken for bubble-gum- chewing morons who will go to any movie with Sarah Michelle Gellar in it and then pick up a Britney Spears CD on the way home.

title: Ms. Dunne, Mr. Ferrone
description: Hilary Anne Dunne, a daughter of Denise and John Dunne of Spencertown, N.Y., and Christopher David Ferrone, a son of Regina and Gerard Ferrone of Old Chatham, N.Y., were married yesterday at St. James Roman Catholic Church in Chatham, N.Y. James Merrill, the town justice of Ghent, N.Y., officiated with the Rev. Gary Gelfenbein, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: October 3, 1999
description: Weeks

title: An Anchor of a West Side Block Expands and Renovates
description: The economic boom in Hell's Kitchen is causing long-abandoned space to be occupied, and businesses that have been there a long time are being revitalized, like Manganaro's Hero-Boy, an Italian restaurant that during less flush times was an anchor of the block on which it stands. The restaurant, opened in 1956 by James Dell'Orto Sr., is undergoing its third renovation, the first since 1970.

title: Sept. 26-Oct. 2; Yugoslavia Submits a Bill
description: Yugoslavia gave its own estimate of the damage wreaked by NATO's bombing campaign last spring. Yugoslav Foreign Minister Zividan Jovanovic told reporters that the bombing caused $100 billion worth of damage, and demanded that NATO pay the bill. Some European officials have estimated that it could cost $30 billion to $50 billion to repair the damage.

title: A Choreographer's Time For Leading and Learning
description: THE American Repertory Ballet opens its season on Saturday with a first: a distinctly non-Yankee director. This summer, Graham Lustig, an English choreographer, became artistic director of the New Brunswick-based troupe and adviser to the nonprofit Princeton Ballet School, one of the country's largest. He succeeds Septime Webre, who left to head the Washington Ballet, where Mr. Lustig was once resident choreographer.

title: The World; 50 Years Made China Change. But Not the Fear of It.
description: THE imagery China chose to send around the world as it celebrated the 50th anniversary of the People's Republic on Friday seemed a throwback to Communism's brighter days: Half a million troops and citizens on parade, endless columns of missiles and armor, fighters and bombers screaming overhead. It was enough to make an old China hand like John Paton Davies, now 91, wonder whether the ever-emotional dynamic between the United States and China was headed into ''another era in which we fear the Dragon.''

title: Relaxation Therapy
description: Bed linens, accessories and clothing in comfortable and luxurious fabrics, for lounging and dreaming, as well as for sleeping.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFF, ANNE
description: WOLFF-Anne. 87, died September 30, 1999, in Scottsdale, AZ. She and her late husband, Joel J. Wolff, were antique dealers in NY. She moved to Arizona two years ago. She is survived by her daughter Arlene (Beryl) Dulsky, step-son Michael (Sara) Wolff, sister Sylvia Jonas, six grandchildren, and eleven great-grandchildren. Crypt side services will be Monday, October 4, at 1PM, at New Cedar Park Cemetery in Paramus, NJ. Contributions in her memory to a hospice or other charity of your choice.

title: Art Deco on the Amazon
description: ''THIS is a fantastic city! You will love it,'' exclaimed George loudly from the other side of the breakfast room of the Hotel Central in downtown Belem.

title: A Lackluster Quarter
description: There were a few bright spots for mutual fund investors last quarter: Japan funds and gold funds surged 23 percent and 18.5 percent, respectively, according to preliminary data from Lipper Inc.

title: In the Region /New Jersey; A $35 Million Luxury Rental Rises in Florham Park
description: LATE in the 1980's, a wooded 40-acre site along Columbia Turnpike in Florham Park was slated to become an office development. That project never moved forward and now the property has a new owner and a different future as a luxury rental community.

title: No. 1 Destination in 2020? Try China, Then France
description: IT may not be too soon to start brushing up on Chinese. Why? Because by 2020, China is expected to become the world's top tourist destination with 130 million annual visitors, and 100 million Chinese are expected to visit other lands.

title: Desperate to Seem 16
description: If these actors had any sense, they would spend their money on less Miu Miu and Prada and enroll instead in a couple of U.C.L.A. courses to give them some iota of perspective. Then, when their retirement age comes in a year or two, they will have something to look forward to in life after Tinseltown.

title: Easing the Rules for Mortgage Approval
description: THE sisters Arlene Jones and Judith George are close. They grew up together in the Virgin Islands, and after they arrived in Brooklyn in 1978, when they were in their early 20's, they lived in apartments two blocks apart.

title: Food; Proof Is in the Pudding
description: No people are more pudding-proud than the English. And by pudding, I do not necessarily mean the gooey steamed cake that you or I might prefer, but rather the entire class of desserts that are shamelessly sweet and rich and, despite all efforts at sophistication, child-friendly.

title: Mr. Boorstein and Dr. Grossman
description: Dr. Elizabeth Lee Grossman, a daughter of Barbara N. Grossman and Dr. Jerome H. Grossman of Chestnut Hill, Mass., was married yesterday to Joshua Louis Boorstein, a son of Toni and Frank Boorstein of Alpharetta, Ga., The Rev. Thomas B. Kennedy, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Somerset Club in Boston.

title: A Dream Unfolds Unhurriedly
description: DREAM OF LIGHT (QUINCE TREE OF THE SUN)

title: A Very Fine Line
description: Perhaps the drug war exists because some people like to spy on other people and shoot at them too. Drugs are a convenient excuse that wayward law-enforcement officials can use to violate our rights.

title: Who Needs Him?
description: To the Editor:

title: Connie McVey, Michael Socolow
description: Connie Anne McVey, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. George J. McVey of Rochester, was married yesterday to Michael Joseph Socolow, a son of Sanford Socolow of New York and Anne K. Socolow of the Cayman Islands. The Rev. Charles M. Major, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at Woodend, the headquarters of the Audubon Naturalist Society in Chevy Chase, Md.

title: A Gay Son's Family
description: To the Editor:

title: Question for Japan
description: A string of embarrassingly unanswered questions stretched long in the wake of Japan's worst nuclear accident, one day after the crisis was officially declared over.

title: Back to School, 1958
description: Frank McCourt's recollections prompted a rush of memories. The return to those years was indeed rewarding to this graduate of McKee High School and former student of Mr. McCourt's. Out of the chaos described in the article, an education was received thanks to teachers like Mr. McCourt and those mentioned in the article, along with others who were not: Mrs. Popp, Ms. Joyner, Mr. Fox, Mr. Kalish, Mr. Somach. How nice to see the names of classmates (some now gone) and remember the good times together. Mr. McCourt inscribed in my year book, ''Keep your chin up.'' I have and am proud to have been at McKee and to have known all those wonderful people.

title: So All May Hear
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Region /Westchester; For Port Chester, a $120-Million Riverfront Project
description: AN ambitious $120-million redevelopment project was given final approval last week by this two-and-a-half-square-mile village, known for its distinctive globe lighting downtown and its multi-ethnic variety of restaurants.

title: Sept. 26-Oct. 2; Strong Economy Lifts Poor
description: Rising incomes lifted 1.1 Americans above the official poverty threshold ($16,665 for a four-person household) last year. But the nation's strong economy didn't help narrow the income gap between rich and poor Americans. The gap didn't widen, but a high-end household making $130,000 still earned eight times more than a family at the poverty line, which is the same ratio that's existed since 1993.

title: MetroStars, Looking to Next Season, Envision Star Power
description: The MetroStars learned a lesson or two in this season of calamitous proportions.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ZIPPRODT, PATRICIA
description: ZIPPRODT-Patricia. A memorial for Patricia Zipprodt, the threetime Tony Award winning costume designer of such notable productions as Fiddler on the Roof, Cabaret and Sweet Charity, will take place at 2 PM, Tuesday, October 5 at the Booth Theatre, 222 West 45th Street. There will be a video presentation, and scheduled participants include Barbara Cook, Joel Grey, Bernadette Peters and Gwen Verdon. Miss Zipprodt died on July 17 in New York.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Bitten by the Occasional Acting Bug
description: ACTUALLY I have nice healthy skin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MYERS, ROBERT
description: MYERS-Robert. The Staff of Steinway Child and Family Services, Inc. deeply regrets the untimely passing of our colleague and friend, Robert Myers. Bob was a compassionate, intelligent man who cared deeply about children and worked tirelessly to improve the child serving system. His leadership, dedication and friendship will be missed by all. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his wide, children, mother, the NYCDMHMR & AS and all who knew him. Mary R. Redd, President & CEO Pasquale DePetris, PhD, VP/COO

title: Silverton Rail
description: To the Editor: In June I took my second ride on the Durango & Silverton Narrow Gauge Railroad (''Three Trains Years Behind Schedule,'' Aug. 29), accompanied by my son -- a Colorado resident who had previously spurned the trip as being ''for tourists'' -- and my grandchildren, ages 9 and 12.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In /Brookfield, Conn.; Rural, With 2 Large Lakes as Bookends
description: FROM the early 1700's to the mid-1900's life in Brookfield was rural, predictable and uneventful. Not even the Revolutionary War affected its measured pace.

title: Sept. 26-Oct. 2; California Aims at H.M.O's
description: For years, consumer groups have complained that health maintenance organizations deny coverage of treatments unfairly. The state of California is offering a prescription: lawsuits.

title: Condoms at Schools Still Limited
description: SHOULD condoms be available in our schools?

title: How Gangs Started and Got Those Names
description: Street gangs have been a vivid, and troubling, part of the city's history, at least since the beginning of the 19th century. In 1807, the trustees of the African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church, at the corner of Leonard and Church Streets in lower Manhattan, pleaded with the City Council to do something about gangs of white, working-class youths that harassed their worshipers on Sundays, according to Edwin G. Burroughs and Mike Wallace in their monumental history ''Gotham'' (Oxford University Press, 1999).

title: Distant Rumbles of a Korean War Massacre
description: To the Editor:

title: Against Irony
description: I can only hope that your writer quoted the gushing comment of an Exeter faculty member about Jed Purdy (''I feel I have met a young William Buckley'') with some irony intended. It's hard to imagine that the obviously sincere and wholesome Purdy would savor being compared with a man who has used the knowing smirk as a personal trademark throughout his career.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: TOUR

title: With Luck, Mets Fans Will Have to Stay Up Late
description: If the Mets sneak into the playoffs this weekend, their fans should start guzzling coffee now.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FEIDEN, ROBERT T.
description: FEIDEN-Robert T.. You're always in our hearts and we miss you every day. Mom, Dad and Rica

title: A Definition of 'Heterosexist'
description: To the Editor:

title: Liberties; Cultural Drifter
description: Here are some things you might not know about George W. Bush:

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-3-99: Salient Facts; The New Givers
description: HOW MUCH IS BEING GIVEN AWAY?Americans are donating more to charity than ever -- $175 billion in 1998 alone. Much of that comes from low- and medium-income families, but this year, high-tech millionaires -- previously criticized for not contributing enough -- have made a number of high-profile donations. Observers say that by steering clear of the biggest, most august charities, these entrepreneurs -- most notably Bill Gates, whose billion-dollar education grant will largely go to community-based scholarship funds -- will change the way Americans think about charity.

title: For Britain's Dome, The Time Has Come
description: When the first stanchions went up in 1997 for the mammoth cupola being erected here to mark the millennium, the image that rose in the mind's eye of many Britons had the pale coloration and oversized contours of a white elephant.

title: When Savings Bonds Sputter
description: LAST May, Richard P. Drury, 74, a retired civilian employee of the Army who lives in Hilton Head, S.C., was reading a newspaper article that led him to a startling discovery: 15 United States savings bonds held by him and his wife, Carol -- and worth a total of $3,707.90 -- had not been earning any interest for at least three years.

title: Ecton Park Tops Menifee
description: SUPER DERBY

title: Houseplants' Vacation Is Near an End
description: Move houseplants summering outside to progressively shadier spots, easing the transition to reduced indoor light levels. Inspect leaves and stems for aphids, scale and mealybugs, and check the drainage holes in the pots for slugs, sow bugs and earwigs. Dislodge pests with a hard stream of water or wash with a solution of a few drops of mild soap in a gallon of water, and rinse.

title: Sports of The Times; Hooray for Ryder Cup Celebration
description: ON a platform near the 15th green on Saturday during last weekend's Ryder Cup matches at The Country Club in Brookline, Mass., a young British voice was heard saying, ''Stay out, Davis, stay out,'' as he listened to a radio description of Davis Love 3d's birdie putt on the 18th green. Suddenly he smiled.

title: Going Home Alone
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Rockers Have A Mind, and a Label, Of their Own
description: IT is 6:30 P.M. on a Friday, and Michael Iurato of Childlike Records is waiting for Erika Simonian to show up at his apartment here to negotiate a record deal.

title: Alicia Ballenger, Terry Denson
description: Alicia Marie Ballenger, a daughter of Jessie and Josephus B. Ballenger Jr. of Naugatuck, Conn., was married yesterday to Kevin Terrence Denson, the son of Catherine and Frederick L. Denson of Webster, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. J. Barrie Shepherd performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHALL, SIDONIE
description: SCHALL-Sidonie. On September 30, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Henry. Loving mother of Ravenna and Steven. Dear sister of Elza Talbot, Mendel Stewart, Judy Cliffe and Terry Gottlieb. Adoring grandmother of Alexander, Gavin and Kira. She will be profoundly missed. Service Monday, 9:30 AM, ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: HOPE FOR SALE: A special report.; Business Thrives on Unproven Care, Leaving Science Behind
description: For years, Dr. Larry Norton tried to conduct a medical study to determine, once and for all, whether bone marrow transplants could really save the lives of women desperately ill with breast cancer.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Wildlife Photographs

title: In Hartford, Highway to Heaven
description: AS a success waiting to happen, ''Camino Real'' is legendary; for once, that overworked adjective is not. A new cult is engulfing Tennessee Williams's failure of 1953, between ''The Rose Tattoo'' and ''Cat on a Hot Tin Roof.'' Four regional theaters (Hartford is the third) will have had separate productions of ''Camino Real'' between July of this year and May of next.

title: When the American Century Began
description: THE West Gallery of the Montclair Art Museum is now entered through a parted curtain. The room is lined with high mahogany wainscoting. The seating is a plush circular bench. ''It's called a borne,'' said Diane Fischer, the museum's associate curator, realizing the word is unfamiliar. ''We're tempted to keep it.''

title: The Web Hasn't Replaced The Storefront Quite Yet
description: MORE bad news for bricks-and-mortar retailers: A new survey has found that 30 percent of the personal computers bought by American households in the last six months were purchased directly from the manufacturer. That represents a sharp jump -- up more than a half -- from the previous six months, according to the market research firm Odyssey, based on its twice-yearly surveys of the technology buying habits of 2,500 American households.

title: Sept. 26-Oct. 2; Clinton Tells Prayer Group Of Spiritual Counseling
description: The annual White House prayer breakfast has become a confessional for President Clinton. At last year's gathering, held in the midst of the Monica Lewinsky scandal, he tearfully admitted that he had sinned. Mr. Clinton stuck to the same theme this year, seven months after he was acquitted at a Senate impeachment trial. He thanked his family and others for forgiving him and revealed that he has been undergoing regular spiritual counseling to recover from what he labeled ''one of the most difficult years in my life.'' MARC LACEY

title: The Mystery of the Frogs at Porter Pond
description: AT the mucky edge of Porter Pond in Sterling in August 1997, Joseph A. Gerst Jr., then 11, scooped up a bucket of frogs and realized most of them lacked legs. His father called state biologists, and for the last two years they have been trying to figure out what happened to the frogs.

title: Turnpike Rest Stops and Other Cold War Battle Sites
description: A pocket park across from Newark Penn Station with a granite monument commemorating the World War II hero John A. Basilone seems a humdrum urban sight. But it was a Cold War hot spot, a designated meeting spot, or yavka, for K.G.B. agents.

title: Pippen, on His Way to Portland, Takes a Parting Shot at Barkley
description: Charles Barkley once called a future Hall of Fame player a ''big, old crybaby,'' a comment that stung his teammate and seemed to insure that the two would never play together again. But two years later, Barkley and that teammate, Hakeem Olajuwon, were coexisting on the same frontline, trying to summon their strength for one more playoff run with the Houston Rockets.

title: Misplaced Person
description: Out of Place

title: An Early Thanksgiving
description: THOSE who are really in the spirit of autumn can celebrate Thanksgiving early this year. Harvest Thanksgiving, that is. Lotus Music and Dance Studios, a center for multicultural exchange, is sponsoring a celebration of the Thanksgiving, an Iroquois holiday, at the American Indian Community House on Lafayette Street today.

title: In a Place With Few Parks, A Push to Claim a Corner
description: Two months ago the vacant lot at Grove Street and Myrtle Avenue was anything but empty. After an intense summerlong campaign to remove two junk cars, a pool table, a wrecked boat and dozens of rats, the vacant lot is now just that. But residents want something more: a park.

title: Desperate to Seem 16
description: As a 15-year-old girl, I feel that the actors and actresses in your article should concentrate less on ''looking'' 16 than ''acting'' 16. It's not believable when beautiful girls in their 20's play teen-agers because they lack the qualities of confusion and awkwardness that are vital in portraying teens.

title: Trying to Make the Toughest Yard Is Among the Giants' Offensive Problems
description: Sometimes what makes a team win or lose comes down to the simplest things. Like being able to get 1 yard when it is really needed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, ARTHUR E.
description: KAHN-Arthur E.., DDS. On September 29, 1999. Beloved husband of Anita. Loving father of Roberta and Karen. Adoring grandfather of Levin and Matthew. Dr. Kahn was an internationally acclaimed dentist. He lectured worldwide and mentored study groups in America and Israel. He treated many prominent figures in the arts and entertainment world. He made significant contributions to the literature in the field of restorative dentistry. Dr. Kahn received his B.S. from the University of Maryland and was a graduate of N.Y.U. College of Dentistry. He had held appointments on the faculty of Boston University and the University of Pennsylvania. Dr. Kahn was a longtime collector of 20th century art. Examples from his collection have been exhibited in museums throughout the world. There will be private graveside service on Monday, October 4th. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANSDORF, SEYMOUR
description: MANSDORF-Seymour. Lived in Tamarac, Florida. Passed away on September 30. Beloved husband of Sheryl, father of Debbie, Mindy and Leslie, grandfather of Alison, Howard and Aryn. Donations may be sent to the American Heart Association.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, IRVING T.
description: SIEGEL-Irving T.. On September 29, 1999. Loving husband of Shirley for over 60 years. Beloved father of Barbara and Harvey Klipper, and Robert and Carol Siegel. Proud grandfather of Brian and Jody Siegel. Brother of Milton, Ruth Abend, & Zeva Cohn. Service on Sunday, 1:30PM at ''Riverside Memorial Chapel,'' 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York. Contributions in his memory may be made to St. Luke's/Roosevelt Hospital Center, Attn: Stroke Program Unit, 1111 Amsterdam Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10025.

title: Growth of Golf Courses Increases Maine Home Sales
description: TAKING a cue from Southern states, developers in Maine have begun to emphasize the availability of new golf courses and the expansion of existing ones in their sales of new homes to a market made up increasingly of vacationers or retirees.

title: Distant Rumbles of a Korean War Massacre
description: To the Editor:

title: Bradley's Health Plan Has a Major Flaw
description: To the Editor:

title: Sept. 26-Oct. 2; Smithsonian Gets Huge Gift
description: In the past month, the Smithsonian Institution has received huge gifts from two refugees who were driven from the same homeland.

title: Late-Night Hosts in Search of Their Niches
description: WHEN CBS announced in early 1998 that Craig Kilborn would replace the departing Tom Snyder as host of ''The Late Late Show,'' the powers-that-be at Comedy Central were not pleased. Mr. Kilborn, who had been the anchor of the satirical newscast ''The Daily Show'' since its debut in the summer of 1996, was one of the cable channel's few bona fide stars, and they had hoped to keep him around for a while.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAGMAN, SHOALA R.
description: WAGMAN-Shoala R.. The law firm of Cohen Hennessey & Bienstock mourns the loss after a long illness of Shoala Wagman, the wife of Leonard W. Wagman, our law colleague and dear friend. Shoala Wagman and Harriet Cohen were old friends. Our deepest sympathy to the entire family. Shoala will be missed. Harriet Newman Cohen Patricia Hennessey Peter Bienstock Martha Cohen Stine Bonnie Rabin

title: Hitler in Love
description: HITLER'S NIECE

title: In Chechnya, Its President Vows to Resist Russian Force
description: Chechnya's president vowed today to repulse a Russian invasion that he said had already started, adding that the fighting forces of his republic were united and far stronger than during the two-year war that ended in 1996 and dealt a humiliating blow to Russia's once-proud army.

title: A Scourge of Scallops Still Defies Logic
description: LIKE many other diehard East End baymen, Walter A. Bennett of Springs will be on the water early tomorrow for the opening day of scallop season in Peconic Bay.

title: Anger Over Work Evokes Anti-Catholic Shadow, and Mary's Power as Icon
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's battle with the Brooklyn Museum of Art over a painting combining an image of the Virgin Mary with elephant dung and pornographic photographs is being waged on the emotionally charged terrain of hallowed symbols.

title: Even if the Fed Is Idle, Rates Are on the Rise
description: TO the relief of many investors, members of the Federal Reserve Board have made clear that they will not be voting to raise interest rates at their meeting next Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GWYN, NICHELLE
description: GWYN-Nichelle. Departed on September 29, 1999 after a long battle with multiple sclerosis. Viewing will be held from 3 to 8 PM, Monday, October 4, at James L. Perkins Chapel, 210 W. 145th Street, Manhattan. Services will be held at 10 AM Tuesday, October 5, at St. Philip's Church, 204 W. 134th St. A private interment service will follow at Frederick Douglass Memorial Park in Staten Island. Nichelle is survived by her daughter, Nia; devoted mother, Lillian; father, James; and one sister, Kyela.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'GARA, WILLIAM F.
description: O'GARA-William F.. On September 28, 1999. Born in NYC, October 31, 1933 and served in the U.S. Navy from January 1957 until 1959 when he was discharged with honors for a military related disability. Behind a closed door, Mr. Jospin -- sweating with effort -- was repeating to himself: ''I am from the Left. I am from the Left. I am from the Left.''

I was there on a visit with my grandchildren, in the east-central part of the city. I was awakened by the first onslaught of helicopters. And the noisy parade continues for hours. It is abominable.

Beloved husband of Anne Klineman Lazere; predeceased by cherished wife, Beulah Meistrich Lazere; father of Susan Reichwald, Arthur and Andrew Lazere; grandfather of Jake Lazere, Jeffrey and Andrew Reichwald; great-grandfather of Nicole and Hailee Reichwald. As a result, he is moving the headquarters for his Presidential campaign from Washington to Tennessee, where he spent his boyhood summers. He cuts the ribbon on the Nashville headquarters this week in a move that he hopes will also cut his expenses. KATHARINE Q. SEELYE

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Material Girl
description: Hooking up with a winner is the only maneuver that Rita Zapata, the protagonist of Yxta Maya Murray's second novel, WHAT IT TAKES TO GET TO VEGAS (Grove, $24), can envision to gain her some respect within her East Los Angeles community. As Rita acknowledges in Murray's streetwise narrative, when at 16 you've already been written off as scandalous by the community's all-powerful and viper-tongued Latina League, your only recourse is to snag a good man. And in the impoverished Mexican-American culture in which Rita comes of age, this means a boxer who's got what it takes to land a pay-per-view prizefight in Vegas. After sleeping with and being ditched by most of the neighborhood's going-nowhere-fast street fighters, Rita sets her sights on Billy Navarro, a charming but brutal boxer from Mexico, and the plot traces the pair's heavy-breathing but precarious relationship. Despite the selfishness behind Rita's repeated missteps, we're touched by how ignorantly she desires the consumer goods that she associates with respectability -- from custom-interior Cadillacs to the complimentary bottles of fancy shampoo you in get in your room at Caesars Palace. After a while, however, Rita's upbeat though fated-for-deflation epiphanies become taxing, as does the incongruity of street language spiked with more ''literary'' metaphors. And the story's resolution, after episodes of violence that unfold like a television movie, has a recovery element that is at odds with the rest of the novel. Still, Rita's narrative maintains a fast clip, and the novel's strength lies in Murray's candid though poignant description of the ''Eastelayer'' world -- of the bustling consumerismo of Cesar Chvez Avenue, of boxing champions whose personal mythologies are memorized by every schoolchild, of the sad-sack lives of wannabe boxers who wind up working at Denny's. Barbara Sutton

title: MUSIC: Crossing Music's Borders In Search Of Identity; Downtown, a Reach For Ethnicity
description: WHAT is jazz? Throughout the 1980's, New York's downtown improvisers delighted in dancing around this question. Not that it should ever have been posed to them. Although inspired by free jazz, the saxophonists John Zorn and John Lurie, the songwriter Arto Lindsay and the guitarists Marc Ribot and Bill Frisell were not quite jazz musicians. They were installation artists whose raw material was sound; they scavenged for quotations from their vast record collections and from the city's musique concrete.

title: Weary of Lugging, Students Turn to Luggage
description: The sound of plastic wheels on concrete could be heard for blocks as swarms of children descended on the Dalton School Wednesday morning. Looking like little executives en route to the airport, they walked, skipped and ran with heads held high as they wheeled their book bags and backpacks into school.

title: Iona Housing Crunch
description: To remedy a student housing shortage, Iona College in New Rochelle is building a third dormitory. The college, which has 4,502 students, is responding to an increase in enrollment, Lois McMahon Fahey, a college vice president, said on Wednesday. The freshman class, which has 803 students, is the largest in 11 years.

title: The Singer Solution to World Poverty
description: Instead of urging Americans to forgo restaurant meals and new clothes, Singer should urge them to give up their pets. Money saved on pet food, pet toys, pet grooming and pet medicine could then be donated to human causes. But eliminating pets would serve another purpose as well: without pets, humans will forge deeper relationships with other humans.

title: Lauren Dermer, Jesse Brouhard

Dermer of Livingston, N.J., was married last evening to Jesse Allen Brouhard, a son of Eleanore and Robert Brouhard of Davis, Calif. title: Sky Watcher
description: ON any fall morning, birders line the hawk-watching platform overlooking the sea here and perk up at the occasional shouts from the main birder on the premises, the only one who gets paid -- though not much -- to do what they often pay to do. All day long, he watches hawks. He is 22 years old, and he can hardly believe he has this job.

If Van de Velde's version of events is true, then he indeed appears to be another Richard Jewell; however, it would have been more interesting and informative if your writer had seen fit to do a little more investigating of his own.

description: Matsumi Kanemitsu:

title: Ideas & Trends: In the Clutch; That Team Didn't Choke; It Just Stinks
description: CLUTCH and choke -- as sporting terms, they came from auto racing and spread to other sports. Hemingway, writing about Joe DiMaggio, defined ''clutch'' performance for all time: ''Grace under pressure.'' ''Choke'' has never needed a Hemingway to define it.

title: Lift Anchor, Hudson Park Orders Houseboat
description: Anchored off Pier 25 at North Moore Street is a houseboat called the Town Hall made of wood and debris scavenged from the harbor. For years, David Pearlman, 66, his wife Betsy Terrell, 47, their children and their pets all lived there. The family had a jazz band, too, and the group, the Flying Neutrinos, played at clubs all over New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARISON, TED
description: ARISON-Ted. The American Committee for the Weizmann Institute of Science mourns the passing of our beloved friend and longtime generous advocate and supporter, Ted Arison. His deep, personal involvement in the advancement of brain research will continue for generations at the Arison Neurobiology Building at the Weizmann Institute of Science in Rehovot, Israel. His recent gift to the Institute's Jubilee Endowment Drive creates the Arison Laboratory for Human Brain Imaging. Moreover, his grant for science teaching allowed the Weizmann Institute to help thousands of young children develop visual literacy and sharpen their scientific thinking. Ted Arison, who received an Honorary Ph.D. from the Weizmann Institute in 1996, supported a remarkable range of institutions of the arts, education, historical heritage, science and medicine. Through these causes, and especially through his close relationship with the Weizmann Institute, Ted Arison leaves behind a magnificent legacy of caring and contributing enormously to science for humanity. We express our deepest sympathy to his wife, Lin; daughter, Shari; son, Micky; the grandchildren and to the entire family. Robert H. Asher, Chairman American Committee Albert Wilner, M.D., President Martin Kraar, Exec V.P. Gershon Kekst, Chairman Weizmann Institute of Science Haim Harari, President

title: The Atrocity Allegations
description: Defense Secretary William Cohen has now ordered a ''complete and thorough review'' of fresh allegations that American soldiers machine-gunned hundreds of helpless South Korean civilians under a railroad bridge nearly 50 years ago during the first desperate weeks of the Korean War. A description of the massacre, complete with eyewitness reports from retired American servicemen, appeared in a startling report by The Associated Press that landed on the front pages of many newspapers Thursday morning.

title: Chasing the Gum Chewers of Russia
description: ONCE a forbidden pleasure denounced by Soviet officialdom, chewing gum has become entrenched in Russian pop culture.

title: You're a 'Beamer,' She Said, And Picked Me to Model
description: THE fashion designer Elisa Jimenez first trained her eyes on me last spring at a trendy downtown clothing store where she was giving one of her bizarrely ritualistic custom fittings. One of her customer-acolytes was sprawled on the shop floor on top of a piece of shimmery tea-stained fabric redolent of exotic oils, while Ms. Jimenez expertly snipped around her and fastened the material with transparent monofilament fishing wire. She bit the line in half, burnt a few holes in the hem for a lace effect and turned and smiled at me. She then grabbed my shoulders and looked straight into my eyes. ''You're a beamer!'' she said.

title: The Days of Risque Jokes and Reading Voltaire
description: ''CAROLINE is clever, Emily is a mother to me, Louisa is an angel and Cecilia is a child,'' says Sarah Lennox of her rich and beautiful sisters. Asked to describe herself, she adds, ''I think I am a disappointment.'' Stella Tillyard, the author of ''Aristocrats,'' the story of the Lennox sisters from 1740 to 1832, labels Caroline an intellectual, Emily a keeper of secrets, Louisa an angel indeed and Sarah as the most extreme. Cecilia, the baby, isn't much of a factor in the ''Mobil Masterpiece Theater'' version of ''Aristocrats'' (a three-part production beginning next Sunday night on PBS), but an odd, thwarted kind of feminism is.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the sale of a piano that belonged to Marilyn Monroe misstated the year of her death and her age at the time. It was 1962, not 1963; she was 36, not 35.

title: Tarnished Game

description: ALTHOUGH Long Island has lost many of the manor houses built around the turn of the century, they are rapidly being replaced by a new generation of much smaller houses that offer similar luxuries and comfort.

description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey, and New York.

description: The gun control group Ceasefire New Jersey has announced its endorsement of 52 candidates for state Assembly.

title: A Glacial Cocktail Party
description: TO sense the delight of a cruise on the Skorpios III along the southern coast of Chile, imagine this scene the day we returned to the ship for lunch after a morning spent gazing in awed silence at the sapphire beauty of a mile-wide glacier. As some of us competed to find the right superlatives to describe the experience, the Colombian priest on my right raised his wine glass and toasted the captain, Constantino Kochifas, at the other end of the table with the words: ''Captain, you have brought us to the gates of Heaven.''

title: Desperate to Seem 16
description: Your Sept. 5 issue left us, the parents of a 15-year-old and a 17-year-old, feeling totally befuddled. Do we find our kids a manager, blow off higher ed and encourage them to hustle like the actors in ''Teenseltown''? Or do we home-school them hoping they'll end up at Harvard like Jed Purdy (''Against Irony'')? Perhaps Serena and her son Sam (''Serena on Tap'') have the perfect solution -- that the old (going into business with your parents) can be new.

title: Polemical Prize
description: Hearing the news that Gunter Grass had at last won the Nobel Prize called to mind the one time I saw him in the flesh. It was a bitter January morning in 1986 at the PEN Congress, an international gathering of famous writers who had convened in New York for a weeklong discussion of ''The Writer's Imagination and the Imagination of the State.''

title: East Carolina Repels Army For 5-0 Start
description: Unbeaten East Carolina did not need a dramatic comeback today.

title: Hotel Rooms Scarce for Sydney's Games
description: If you plan to attend the Olympic Games in Sydney in September 2000 but have not yet ordered tickets, they are still likely to be available, although the hardest to find are those for the opening and closing ceremonies, diving, the basketball finals and certain swimming and gymnastics events. Cartan Tours, the official United States agency, said that Olympic committee rules gave priority to those who applied by April 30, then to those applying between May 1 and Sept. 15 and then to those who apply now through next Jan. 31. In all cases, Cartan said, ticket distribution for particular events is determined by a random selection by computer. If you do not have room reservations or family or friends in Australia, do not be surprised if you wind up in anything from a college dorm to a campground. But even that will be expensive, and probably a long commute to the event. Although 11,000 new hotel rooms are expected to be ready by September, there will be only 35,000 rooms for the expected 250,000-plus visitors. And 80 percent of those are reserved for Olympic officials and visitors on packages that usually include games tickets, air fare and lodging. The cheapest such package from Cartan, at $4,900, includes six nights at a private home. Visitors who go on their own will be lucky to find a room in a private house, and they can expect to pay $1,800 to $2,500 a week.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: FORT GREENE

description: AHAB'S WIFE

title: A Coffee Bar Where Everything's for Sale
description: Shawn and Stephen Schwartz, 29-year-old cousins who used to work in the record industry, wanted a place they could go that would offer an atmosphere conducive to talking and relaxation, a place where the intensity level was somewhere between a loud bar and a coffee shop at which people aren't encouraged to interact. They, and a third entrepreneur, Ben Wild, created Halcyon, a coffee bar that's also a store for used records and retro furnishings.

title: A Survivor From the Golden Age of the Daffodil
description: ONE of the fascinations of buying an old house with an ''established yard,'' as real estate ads call it, is discovering the gardening tastes of its previous owners. Some former owner of my old farmhouse planted a hedge of lilac, spirea and forsythia closer to the house than I would have preferred, and I sometimes wish for the cedar tree by the driveway to be magically transformed into an oak.

Burns of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Leo Gorman performed the ceremony at St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich.

description: Romantic love, love gone wrong, parental love, young love and love of family propel a rich assortment of films on television this week.

title: Sept. 26-Oct. 2; The Perils of Babyhood
description: The Government insisted the advisory was purely a matter of safety. One outraged child-rearing expert called it ''self-righteous baloney.'' And many parents did not know what to think when the Federal Consumer Product Safety Commission warned that sleeping with infants and toddlers can be dangerous.

With the lawsuits flying -- city vs. museum (violating lease, promoting interests of private collector) and museum vs. city (violating First Amendment) -- the curious hordes will come and go, talking not of Michelangelo but of elephant dung and pickled sharks.

Some choices have proved astute: Copland's ''Appalachian Spring,'' Hanson's Symphony No. 4, Menotti's ''Consul'' and Sessions's Concerto for Orchestra. Others, from this distance, can only seem mysterious.

title: Change in the Stock Markets
description: The New York Stock Exchange has fought off challenges for more than two centuries. But now it faces technological changes and regulatory rumblings that could transform the whole business of stock trading. The exchange and other stock markets are losing business to electronic trading systems. For some trades, the venerable New York market still uses hand-waving traders crammed onto the floor of a building in downtown Manhattan to match buyers and sellers. By contrast, electronic communications networks, or E.C.N.'s, use electrons, which hold the potential to execute trades cheaper, faster and on terms fairer to investors.

title: Mysterious Sidewalk Messages Deciphered, and Banished
description: When cryptic stenciled images began appearing on sidewalks throughout the city last month, many people were bewildered by what seemed to be an esoteric artistic statement. Then it turned out that the stencils, featuring the numbers 212 and the letters DMX above AYFI and a question mark, were ads referring to the Reebok slogan ''Are You Feeling It?'' Now the city has ordered the images removed, and the artist commissioned to produce them will absorb some of the cost.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; That Metropolitan Woman
description: ''This young woman ought to be ashamed of herself,'' was the usual observation of early 20th-century moralists about Audrey Munson, arguably the most popular nude female model of the Beaux-Arts school. In AMERICAN VENUS: The Extraordinary Life of Audrey Munson, Model and Muse (Balcony, $27.95), Diane Rozas, a photographer, and Anita Bourne Gottehrer, in her first book, have made an extraordinary effort to reclaim long-forgotten facts, newspaper clippings and vintage photographs of this once celebrated life. Indeed, so popular was Munson that at one time the Metropolitan Museum of Art housed 30 pieces of art based on her poses. Born in 1891 into the conservative world of upstate New York, she was still a teen-ager when she and her mother arrived in New York City. In fewer than 10 years, she was said to have posed for more civic art commissions than any other model. By 1915 Munson's image increasingly turned up in private collections as well. As a magazine cover girl, she gained a national reputation and was invited to appear (naked, of course) in films. Since she had no acting ability whatever, this second career was to end badly; her first movie, however, publicized as morally depraved, was one of the highest grossing films of its day. Munson left New York and found herself less and less in demand as artistic tastes changed. At 39, she was committed to a mental institution, where she spent the last 65 years of her life in virtual anonymity. Munson died in 1996 at the age of 105. Lynn Karpen

title: Messier Is Not Ready to Have His Number Join Gretzky's
description: The jaw juts out as menacingly as ever when Mark Messier hears something he does not like. He may be 38 and coming off an injury-plagued season that limited him to 59 games, the fewest he has ever played in his brilliant career. But mellowing? Not a chance.

title: The Different Paths of Giants, Crossing at Last
description: AS a dance student at the Juilliard School in the 1960's, Carla Maxwell studied with both Jose Limon and Antony Tudor, two of the century's seminal choreographers. Aside from their Juilliard connection, the two -- the first a pillar of midcentury American modern dance, the other a master of subtle, psychologically astute classical ballets -- were not likely to find their paths crossing.

description: Partners at Baker & McKenzie, which with 2,400 lawyers is America's largest law firm, will vote this week to elect a new chairman. Only one lawyer, Christine Lagarde, has been nominated for the job of managing the firm, based in Chicago but with offices around the world.

description: Carlos Aparicio's methods for creating interiors are, to say the least, atypical for a rigorously trained architect. ''Everything is born out of poetry for me,'' he says. ''My starting point is often a dream. I actually dream some of these pieces.''

The project had been in development for 15 years, and I had long since abandoned the idea that it would ever be made.

title: FIVE QUESTIONS: for MARK MILLMAN; London Fog: The Lessons Are Clear

In its heyday, London Fog was perhaps the best-known manufacturer of rainwear and outerwear in the country. Its products were sold mainly through upscale third parties, like department stores.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFMAN, CLARA ADLER
description: HOFFMAN-Clara Adler. Of Boca Raton, FL. Formerly of Islip, NY. Died on September 30, 1999 at the age of 98. She is now, after a separation of 35 years, reunited in heaven with her beloved husband, ''Buddy''. The daughter of Dr. Charles and Sadie (Simon) Adler. She grew up in NYC. In 1925, while working as an advertising director of WMCA, she married Dr. M. Robert (Buddy) Hoffman. They moved to Islip, L.I. in 1927 where Buddy practiced dentistry until his death in 1964. Buddy and Clara were a founding family of the Jewish Center in 1934 and Sinai Reform Temple in 1948 both located in Bayshore, NY. Clara's greatest joy was that she was part of a four generation dental family. Her father, brother and husband were dentists. Her son is a retired dentist and her oldest granddaughter is a dentist married to a dentist. She is survived by her sister, Helen Fischler, of San Diego, CA; her children Dr. Gerry and Lorna Hoffman, Charles and Anita Hoffman; her grandchildren, Dr. Sharon and Dr. Mark Gilbert, Douglas and Patricia Hoffman, Linda and Brian Sterling, Marnie Hoffman and Seth Hoffman. She will be missed by her seven great grandchildren, Rebekah, Matthew, Thomas, Gregory, Timothy, Emma and Aaron. Funeral services were held at Gutterman-Warheit Memorial Chapel, Boca Raton, FL on Friday, October 1, 1999. In lieu of flowers please make contributions to Sinai Reform Temple, Brentwood Road, Bayshore, New York.

title: A Show Whose Time Has Come and Gone
description: THE Paper Mill Playhouse has opened a new season, if not a new window. With ''Mame,'' the State Theater of New Jersey is on the line: new sets, new costumes, a new star for the occasion, and an old musical. (In show business, 33 years is old.) ''Mame'' is favored in community and dinner theaters, but it has not been produced in a big-time revival since 1983. And that was a one-month Broadway flop with the show's original star, Angela Lansbury, still presumed to be the possessor of the musical role although scores of leading ladies have played it. Such a fast failure might have been a tipoff about the dubious commercial possibilities now for a show that was already dated then.

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-3-99: The Ethicist; A Line to Cross
description: After eight weeks on strike, after most of my union colleagues returned to work under threat of being replaced, I, too, crossed my own union's picket line. I'm still struggling with my actions. I was required to join the union (it was a closed shop). I came to view the leadership as incompetent and just plain wrong. When I tried to dissent, I was hooted down. In the meantime, I was in real danger of losing a job I held dear. The 'moral' position seemed to be to stick with the union; but is it not moral to decide for oneself when one disagrees with one's representatives? /R.H. Detroit

title: MUSIC: Crossing Music's Borders In Search Of Identity; 'I Hate World Music'
description: I HATE world music. That's probably one of the perverse reasons I have been asked to write about it. The term is a catchall that commonly refers to non-Western music of any and all sorts, popular music, traditional music and even classical music. It's a marketing as well as a pseudomusical term -- and a name for a bin in the record store signifying stuff that doesn't belong anywhere else in the store. What's in that bin ranges from the most blatantly commercial music produced by a country, like Hindi film music (the singer Asha Bhosle being the best well known example), to the ultra-sophisticated, super-cosmopolitan art-pop of Brazil (Caetano Veloso, Tom Ze, Carlinhos Brown); from the somewhat bizarre and surreal concept of a former Bulgarian state-run folkloric choir being arranged by classically trained, Soviet-era composers (Le Mystere des Voix Bulgares) to Norteno songs from Texas and northern Mexico glorifying the exploits of drug dealers (Los Tigres del Norte). Albums by Selena, Ricky Martin and Los Del Rio (the Macarena kings), artists who sell millions of records in the United States alone, are racked next to field recordings of Thai hill tribes. Equating apples and oranges indeed.

title: A Pinch of Saffron Adds Smoky Flavor

Around $5 a gram for the best quality, it is more expensive than white truffles or beluga caviar. But a little of this precious seasoning, which adds a rich canary color in addition to a tantalizing hint of pungent, slightly smoky flavor, goes a very long way.

title: The Mississippi, the Amazon, the Nile . . . the Sepik?
description: Certain rivers -- the Mississippi, the Columbia, the Nile, the Yangtze, the Rhine, the Danube, the Amazon -- readily come to mind when travelers contemplate taking a voyage on a vessel smaller than an oceangoing cruise ship. But how about the Sepik? This 700-mile-long river is a major waterway on the 342,000-square-mile island of New Guinea, the second largest island in the world after Greenland.

title: Notes From Offshore
description: AFTER an hour back in New York I cease to believe anyplace else exists: isn't everywhere apartments and pavement, Key Food and Cathay Laundromat and Regina Bakery and the trumpeting blare of the 4 train? Months flash past without my feeling the least desire to leave. Even days when the streets collapse together like the latticework gate of an old elevator and my hair reeks of cigarette smoke, all I really want is to lean out my window and watch the orange barge of the Staten Island Ferry at the end of my block. Travel enough for me.

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-3-99; Bashing The Burbs
description: Remember that Talking Heads song in which David Byrne's on a plane, looking down at the baseball diamonds and whatnot, thinking, ''I wouldn't live there if you paid me to''? It came to mind when I was watching ''American Beauty,'' the new suburban tragicomedy that begins with an angel's-eye view of mile after mile of right-angled streets and indistinguishable houses. I guess it's someplace in Illinois -- at one point you see an 847 area code on a sign -- but it's meant to be suburbia-in-general, a nasty-neat wasteland of consensual conformity and enforced gentility. You reflexively brace yourself for the weird, dark underside, which in this case involves teen-age pot dealers, right-wing gun nuts and -- golly! -- adulterers and homosexuals.

title: Desperate to Seem 16
description: Your timing of Lynn Hirschberg's article (Sept. 5) could not have been better. Just the night before, I had complained to my wife and some friends at dinner that our teen-age daughters (among us, we have five) had very little but sexually suggestive and exploitative teen flicks to select from. Hirschberg's portrayal of aspiring actresses angling for their shot at celluloid celebrity reinforced my worst fears that the general dumbing down of Hollywood will produce few strong women who might inspire our daughters. I didn't spot the next Meryl Streep in her piece.

title: BENEFITS
description: In Support of Hospitals

title: His Life as a Murder Suspect
description: James Bennet (Sept. 12) adds to a sensational and sensationalized case only his personal impression that James R. Van de Velde is guilty. Employing one of the more facile conventions of magazine journalism, the piece ends on a note of ostensible neutrality: the reader is reminded that Van de Velde hasn't been charged with any crime, and is given the crumb of a quote from Kingman Brewster's tombstone to chew on. The mugging, though, has already been accomplished, especially in the passage that renders at length Anna Ramirez's gradual erosion of faith in her accused friend. Why weren't any of Van de Velde's less doubting friends, the ones we are told remain certain of his innocence, quoted or paraphrased at equal length? The effect would have been genuinely neutral, rather than superficially so -- although less convenient for drawing a conclusion without being seen to draw it.

title: Political Briefing; An Idaho Wedding On a Political Scale
description: Representative Helen Chenoweth of Idaho doesn't do things in a small way.

title: Could This Pig Save Your Life?
description: In an unmarked warehouse in the middle of a wheat field in central Ohio, a hulking 300-pound pig lies on her back, her legs tethered to a crude iron gurney in a bare, well-lighted room. The animal has been sedated into a light state of sleep, and the pale pink expanse of her belly rises and falls rhythmically with each breath. A young man in green hospital garb has just sliced a six-inch incision between the sow's nipples; now he pokes around her innards with latex-gloved hands.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELL, JOHN POWERS
description: BELL-John Powers. Age 45, of Upper Saddle River, NJ, died on Friday, October 1, in Ridgewood, NJ. Visitng hours will be on Sunday from 2-4 and 7-9 PM at the Wanamaker & Carlough Funeral Home, 41 Eagle Valley Rd., Sloatsburg, NY. Mass will be on Monday, at 10 AM, at Our Lady of Mt. Carmel Church, Tuxedo, NY. Memorial contributions to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital.

title: Art Gallery Owner Describes Night in Jail
description: In the 1980's, her imperious attitude, outspokenness and stable of talented artists carried her to the top of the ultra-competitive and ultra-lucrative world of New York art dealing. But in a matter of hours Wednesday night, Mary Boone says, she was reduced to a meek, frightened prisoner who spoke only when spoken to, feared beatings by prostitutes and drug addicts, and dutifully asked for permission to go to the bathroom.

title: Closing of Old Dental Clinics Seen as Strike Against Poor
description: A Health and Hospitals Corporation plan to close 10 of 16 neighborhood clinics that provide free dental care to low-income young people has angered some community leaders. But the hospitals corporation, which will close the clinics on Oct. 15, says that their equipment is outdated and that better care will be available at alternative sites.

title: A Photographer on the Blurred, Chaotic Edge
description: DAIDO MORIYAMA'S vision resides in the heart of darkness, literally and figuratively. The world he records is black, stunned rather than illuminated by light, threatening, chaotic, incomprehensible, compulsively erotic, obsessed, eccentric, fixated on consumption, devastated by accidents, always off kilter, sometimes ruined, sometimes empty -- a world unaware of its own instability, a world in need of Prozac.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FERRARA, RONALD A.
description: FERRARA-Ronald A.. Born Oct. 6, 1938 died Nov. 22, 1994. Forever cherished and missed. Love always, Jane.

title: Finding Life Is, After All, a Cycle
description: I HAVE happy memories of our old biker gang. Most Saturday mornings we would dress in black T-shirts and stick-on tattoos and ride around the neighborhood terrorizing old ladies and stray cats. We liked to imagine that we were the direct inheritors of the Hell's Angels tradition. But, when it rained, our mothers would keep us indoors. When the neighbors complained, our bikes were confiscated.

title: Seven Decades of Illustrations
description: WHETHER high art should mingle with low art, or high culture with mass culture, seems to be a burning question these days. So the current show at Connecticut Graphic Arts Center in Norwalk is something of a timeout.

title: Back to School, 1958
description: Your excerpt from Frank McCourt's new book (Sept. 12) had special resonance for me. I taught English in the New York City public high schools for 34 years. As a beginning teacher, I, too, was given the most difficult classes and received no help from administrators who were more interested in timely completion of paperwork than in my teaching abilities.

title: Sept. 26-Oct. 2; Man Dies in Gene Therapy
description: An 18-year old patient died four days after receiving a gene therapy treatment at the University of Pennsylvania. If the therapy proves to be the cause, it will be apparently the first treatment-related death in a gene therapy trial.

title: Police Bewildered by Shooting Near Rap Star's Midtown Studio
description: The police said yesterday that they remained puzzled by a shooting outside a building in midtown Manhattan that contains a recording studio owned by Sean Combs, the rap star better known as Puff Daddy.

title: Is Reebok Still Reeling Or Poised to Rebound?
description: IN the great sneaker face-off, Nike Inc. has cleaned the floor with the competition. It had 34 percent of the $13.8 billion United States athletic shoe market last year, nearly three times that of its long-suffering rival, Reebok International, with 13 percent. And Nike's market capitalization, at $16.25 billion, is about 28 times Reebok's.

title: Yonkers Primary
description: It is now official: Margaret M. Mulrooney, 46, a lawyer in private practice, has won the Democratic nomination for mayor of Yonkers, final election figures show.

title: John Tsao and Sharon Lee
description: Sharon Sarah Lee, the daughter of Eletheria Wan of Monroe, N.Y., and Robin Lee of Jersey City, was married yesterday to Sheng-Chieh Tsao, the son of Jane and John Tsao of Lake Jackson, Tex. The Rev. Robert Dent performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Monroe.

title: The Romantic
description: To Eugenio Zanetti, a house is a stage set dressed by subconscious memories. ''It's like looking at your childhood, but in a dream, correct?'' says Zanetti, an Oscar-winning production designer whose films include ''The Haunting,'' ''What Dreams May Come,'' ''Restoration'' and ''Flatliners.''

title: Back to School, 1958
description: I eagerly read Frank McCourt's article about being a teacher in a vocational high school, especially since I am one myself. I laughed so hard that tears were running down my cheeks. I laughed because he so perfectly captured the black comedy that is education in any underfinanced and understaffed school.

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-3-99: ShopTalk; Spy - Spy
description: Kalugin, 65, volunteered for the K.G.B. in 1952. He served in a variety of high-ranking posts, mostly undercover in the United States. After he publicly called upon Mikhail Gorbachev to reform the institution, he was stripped of his rank -- and elected to Parliament. He now works as an international business consultant. Sichel, 77, joined the O.S.S. during World War II. He served in Germany, Washington and Hong Kong. He retired, with the U.S. Distinguished Intelligence Medal, to run his family's wine business. Days after the two met for the first time, in Berlin, at a conference on the cold war, they sat down to discuss the life of a former spook.

title: State Scrambles to Control a New Virus
description: WHAT started as a project to control one deadly mosquito-borne virus, Eastern equine encephalitis, has turned into a race to understand an alien one that has infected birds and mosquitoes in Connecticut only weeks after it killed people in New York.

title: 'Kids' Welcome, Dress: Baggy
description: Fashionable skate kids are as plentiful as parking meters on the sidewalk outside the popular street-wear stores Supreme, 274 Lafayette Street (Prince Street), left, and its neighbors 555 Soul and X-Large. But the clientele is increasingly Japanese, said Supreme's owner, James Jebbia. ''Believe it or not, we've become more popular in Japan than over here,'' he said. Together, these stores ''represent the hard-edged hip-hop urban skater kid that people have come to associate with New York,'' Mr. Jebbia added.

title: Allyson Carine and Steven Soldo
description: Allyson Marie Carine, a daughter of Anne-Marie and Arthur G. Carine Jr. of Cliffside Park, N.J., was married yesterday to Steven William Soldo, a son of Catherine and Richard Soldo of Ridge, N.Y. The Rev. Donald Desmond, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Church of the Most Holy Trinity in East Hampton, N.Y.

title: A Supplier Of Toys To Grown-Up Technos
description: Tucked between a Chinese beauty parlor and a restaurant supply store is Zakka, 147 Grand Street (Lafayette), a shop that caters to the Japanophile techno set. Its Japanese-born owner, Toshiki Okazaki, moved from SoHo several months ago for the cheaper rent.

title: The Prince's New Clothes
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLACK, JACOB M.
description: BLACK-Jacob M.. September 30, 1999. Husband of the late Shirley (nee Spitz); father of Donald and Judy Black, and Myron and Patricia Black; brother of Fanny Steindler; grandfather of Eric, Kevin, Karen and Keith Black and Donna Grieco and step-grandfather of Andrew Weinraub and Susan Donlan; also survived by 8 greatgrandchildren. Relatives and friends are invited to funeral services Sunday 3:15 PM from Goldsteins Rosenbergs Raphael Sacks Suburban North, 310 2nd Street Pike, Southampton, PA. Interment Monday 11:30 AM, at Wellwood Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY. Shiva observed at the home of Donald and Judy Black, Monday evening and Tuesday. Friends wishing may contribute to the Heritage Towers, 200 Veterans Lane, Doylestown, PA 18901.

title: JERSEY DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Taking Their Destiny Into Their Own Hands
description: The Mets had skidded two games from the wild-card lead with only three games to play when Bobby Valentine listened to his voice-mail messages.

title: Crossing the Hudson, via Miami
description: Not just anybody is allowed to perform ''Jewels,'' George Balanchine's three-act plotless ballet to music of Faure, Stravinsky and Tchaikovsky. But then, the Miami City Ballet is not just any company: its artistic director is Edward Villella, the former New York City Ballet star who danced in ''Jewels'' under Mr. B. himself. And that's one reason the Balanchine Trust has granted the rights to the Miami dancers.

title: Distant Rumbles of a Korean War Massacre
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOSTER, GLEN S.
description: FOSTER-Glen S.. An Olympic medalist yachtsman, died peacefully on Friday, October 1, 1999, at Memorial Sloan-Kettering. He was 69 years old. Mr. Foster died of esophageal cancer. Mr. Foster attended the Fay School, Phillips Academy at Andover, MA, Brown University and Columbia University. Mr. Foster spent his career as a Specialist on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange as a Partner in Foster, Marks & Natoli. Mr. Foster sold his firm in 1994 to Spear, Leeds & Kellogg, where he continued his working career. A world class yachtsman, Mr. Foster represented the United States and won a Bronze Medal in the 1972 Olympic Games in Munich. In later years Mr. Foster competed in 8 meter, 6 meter, 5.5 meter and the Dragon Yacht classes, most recently winning the Scandinavian Gold Cup for the third time only two weeks ago in Torbole, Italy. He was a member of the New York Yacht Club, the Royal Yacht Squadron and the Imperial Poona Yacht Club, and an Honorary Member of the Sewanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club and Key Biscayne Yacht Club. He was a Member of the Board of Directors of the Herreshoff Museum/America's Cup Hall of Fame in Bristol, RI, the Acorn Foundation in New York City, the Afterguard of the New York Yacht Club Young America Challenge for the 2000 America's Cup matches in New Zealand. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, October 7, 1999, at 12 noon, at the Dana Chapel of Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, at 921 Madison Avenue at 73rd Street. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Fund for Renewal of Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, where Mr. Foster was a member, or to the Herreshoff Museum, P.O. Box 225, Bristol, RI. He is survived by his loving wife, Kay, and his mother, Margaret Arrott.

title: World Cup Under Way In Europe
