description: ''You're going to get hammered,'' said an elderly Irish gentleman standing outside Lansdowne Road stadium with a ticket in his hand and an impish look on his weathered face. ''You know that, don't you?''

title: Against Irony
description: I found the photo of the Purdys, barefooted in their living room, charming, and I read on. Here was Opie with an I.Q. Bill Moyers loves him. How disappointed I was to read that this young man who states that ''we need a way of thinking and doing that has in it more promise of goodness'' endangered the very life of your writer Marshall Sella by going down winding roads at 60 miles per hour on his motorcycle with Sella on the back! Seems this lover of nature scared the heck out of the birds too. Ironic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBLATH, LILLIAN ENNIS
description: ROSENBLATH-Lillian Ennis. On September 29, 1999, of Garden City. Beloved wife of the late Daniel H. Cherished companion of Salvatore Cannizzaro. Loving sister of Arthur J. Ennis. Fond aunt of three nieces, one nephew, and eleven great-nieces and nephews. For information, Fairchild Sons Funeral Home, Garden City, NY.

title: Kristen Langdon and Lee Cohen
description: Kristen Beth Langdon, a daughter of Marie and Brian Langdon of Monroe, Conn., was married yesterday to Lee Eric Cohen, the son of Susan and Lester Cohen of Ridgewood, N.J. The Rev. Janet Cooper Nelson, the chaplain of Brown University, performed the nondenominational ceremony at Manning Chapel at Brown in Providence, R.I.

title: Cox's Two Worlds Unite Sensitivity With Rage
description: If you thought the Jets were getting an undisciplined, angry man when they plucked Bryan Cox out of oblivion 14 months ago, talk to the Broncos.

title: Choral and Guitar Pieces Mix in a Katonah Recital
description: THOSE who like choral chamber music along with the piano, the classical guitar and a bit of Flamenco can find it all in a recital by Frederick Draper of Putnam Lake next Sunday at 3:30 P.M. in the Katonah Village Library.

title: Bradley Finally Ready to Rub Tall Shoulders
description: For most of his nearly 40 years in the limelight, Bill Bradley, the former Senator and basketball star, regarded celebrity -- his own, in particular -- with a gimlet eye. Once asked if too much fame inevitably ruined the famous, he replied, ''Absolutely.''

title: Sept. 26-Oct. 2; Union Reaches G.M. Deal
description: The United Automobile Workers union and the General Motors Corporation agreed on a new four-year contract that gives the auto maker's 143,200 blue-collar workers a lump-sum bonus of $1,350 plus annual raises of 3 percent on top of adjustments for inflation. In mid-September, the union reached a similar deal with DaimlerChrysler. Next up is the Ford Motor Company, where an agreement could come as early as this week.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the choreographer Ronald K. Brown misspelled the surname of the executive director of the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, who commented on the way dance presenters support underrecognized artists. She is Ella Baff, not Bass.

title: Lindsay Mergens, Robert Radick
description: Lindsay Ann Mergens, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William J. Mergens of West Palm Beach, Fla., was married yesterday in Montauk, N.Y., to Robert Martin Radick, a son of Annette P. Radick of Bedminster, N.J., and Barry G. Radick of Manhattan. Judge John Gleeson of Federal District Court in Brooklyn performed the ceremony at the Montauk Point Lighthouse.

title: Summer's Harsh Sun Diminishes Fall Crop
description: All summer, the farmers who grow apples and pumpkins battled the drought to bring in a diminished and stunted fall crop. Now the only thing that can make matters worse are heavy rains, which would rot the crops and drive away customers.

title: A Place for Milk, Eggs and a Mortgage
description: AT the Edwards supermarket here, sandwiched between a checkout and a refrigerated case stocked with smoked salmon and herring in cream, is not the bakery or the produce aisle but a branch office of a bank.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: The Nation: Timeless; Buying Years for Women on the Biological Clock
description: THERE is perhaps no more unsettling noise in medicine than the sound of infertility specialists tinkering with the biological clock. Witness the ethical uproar over their latest technological triumph, the apparent reversal of menopause in a 30-year-old ballerina who suffered from ovarian cysts. Doctors removed her remaining ovary, froze the tissue, and, two years later, reimplanted it. Now, they say, she is producing eggs again.

title: Most Despised
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: For New Issues, A Contagion of Red Ink
description: It is a truism that Internet companies that go public are unprofitable, but that often doesn't stop their stocks from soaring.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRAUB, ROSE
description: TRAUB-Rose. Wife of the late Louis Senter and Lawrence Traub. Mother of Sylvia and Marvin Rubin and Raymond and Madelaine Senter. Grandmother of Lori and Fred Suser, Lisa and Ken Kornblau and Lindsay Senter. Greatgrandmother of Samantha, Jennifer, Stephanie and Danielle. Services private.

title: Sarah Hopkins, Anirudh Bansal
description: Sarah Camille Hopkins, a daughter of Camille and Martin Hopkins of Chappaqua, N.Y., was married on Friday to Anirudh Bansal, the son of Mita and Sudhir Bansal of Pleasantville, N.Y. Judge Alfred J. Lechner Jr. of Federal District Court in Newark officiated in his chambers.

title: Basic American With a Flourish or Two
description: ''IT'S cute, cozy and warm with two fireplaces'' is the way Joseph Lester accurately describes the Ivy Cottage, his nearly year-old restaurant at 38 Hillside Avenue in Williston Park (877 2343). Mr. Lester, a chef trained at the Culinary Institute of America, cooked at the Waldorf, Copacabana and Le Petite Marmite in Manhattan, as well as the Piping Rock Inn on the Island, before opening his own place, a 50-seat storefront designed by a Scotsman. And indeed this charming (and slightly cramped) nook would be a perfect fit in the Scottish Highlands, with its trellises, fairy lights, hanging copper pots, fresh flowers, tiny table lamps, floral wallpaper, faux brick walls, lace curtains, golden candlestick holders and white tablecloths.

title: Veronica Lopez, Mark Sedway
description: Veronica Lopez and Mark Alexander Sedway were married yesterday at the James Burden Mansion in Manhattan. Rabbi Michael Barenbaum officiated.

title: Crime
description: With HARD TIME (Delacorte, $24.95), her first V. I. Warshawski novel in five years, Sara Paretsky lightens up on the political oratory and goes back to the basics that shot this terrific series to the top of its class: an expertly plotted story drawn from the legally trained author's specialty field of industrial espionage; a topical issue to give it gravity and the moral perspective to make it matter; a playing field of flint-hearted villains impervious to these higher values; and a hero with the righteous anger and the street-fighter skills to make these guys eat dirt.

title: Civic Affairs, Indeed: Huntington Tunes in to Report on Scandal
description: SUSAN J. SCARPATI-REILLY describes it as a ''five-and-ten trashy novel.'' Her problem is that it's not intended to be a novel, and it's mostly about her.

title: Brilliant Transcribers
description: To the Editor:

title: The Sheltering Sky
description: PLAINSONG

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAOU, ARTHUR
description: DAOU-Arthur. On October 2nd, 1999, in Djoubeil, Lebanon. Beloved husband of Suzanna (Nana) Mann Daou; adored father of Antony, Peter, Annabel Pisarro, Maria, Jon, and Christopher; beloved grandfather of Paul Pisarro, Sebastian, Nicholas, and Isabella Daou; loving uncle of Alexander and Timothy Oberweger, Molly JongFast; beloved father in-law of Vanessa Daou of Lebanon, Joachim Pisarro and Vanessa Daou of NYC; beloved brother in-law of Claudia Mann Oberweger and Gideon Oberweger, Erica Jong Burrows and Ken Burrows; beloved son in-law of Seymour and Eda Mann. We love you, we miss you.

title: Plugging The Dike At Work
description: Every once in a while, a worker's absence, for vacation or whatever other reason, brings a request for a colleague to take on new or unfamiliar duties. It's the old sink-or-swim situation. Sometimes it's a near-drowning experience, but it can also offer buoyant memories.

title: At SUNY-Old Westbury, Questions on Development
description: In July 1998, six weeks after I assumed the role of interim president at SUNY College at Old Westbury, the college's interim vice president for development revealed a campus development plan about which I had no prior knowledge.

title: A Very Long Walk Down the Runway
description: Once upon a time, Miss America contestants primped mightily to look exactly like Rita Heyworth, and everyone involved did their best to keep their mouths closed -- except when they smiled.

title: Take the Shuttle, Buy a Book
description: Tucked away next to the Discovery Channel store in the subway shuttle passage of Grand Central Terminal is the third location of Posman Books. It opened a month ago with 35,000 general interest titles. The other Posman stores, at 1 University Place near the New York University campus, and 70 Fifth Avenue, near New School University, are more academically focused, said Jo-Anne Ferris, the Manhattan district manager.

title: Liquid Asset
description: The Million Dollar Mermaid

title: Disclosure as Free Speech
description: Although former Speaker Newt Gingrich has left the House of Representatives, a nasty private lawsuit involving two members of Congress, and arising out of the House ethics investigation of Mr. Gingrich, churns on. A Federal appeals court panel, by a 2-to-1 vote, recently decided to revive a suit filed by Representative John Boehner, Republican of Ohio, against Representative Jim McDermott, Democrat of Washington, under the Electronic Communications Privacy Act. The panel's ruling poses a serious threat to press freedoms, and if upheld could make it harder for anyone to bring to light truthful information of public importance.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: A Tuscan Childhood

title: The Season Heats Up
description: A 'Sensation' arrives, the Metropolitan Opera opens, and galas help breast-cancer and immunology research.

title: Jews (f)or Jesus
description: To Rabbi Peter Kasdan, this was not the good book. It wasn't even close.

title: Homage to Plastic, And to Bruce Lee
description: Tony Chan and Bill McMullen, a graphic designer, have crammed every nook of Goto, their closet-size store at 85 Kenmare Street, at Lafayette Street, with exotic gadgets and memorabilia, most of which is from Japan.

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-3-99: Word & Image; One TV Nation, Divisible
description: I have never watched MTV, and my kids, who watched it faithfully, never shared my ritual interest in ''60 Minutes.'' For an age-neutral viewing experience, our family needed a Super Bowl or an O.J. verdict. Now our splintering is evident everywhere. Fault lines appear not only among the generations but also between the races. Differently colored folks go for different TV strokes, as if, Bill Cosby notwithstanding, blacks and whites can't laugh or cry at the same things.

title: Noise Overhead
description: To the Editor: Airplanes shatter the solitude not only in the Grand Canyon but in nationally designated wilderness areas.

title: Distant Rumbles of a Korean War Massacre
description: To the Editor:

title: Battle in Congress Over Milk Prices Pits East Against Midwest
description: For most families, the outcome of a battle in Congress over milk prices will mean just a few cents a week at the supermarket counter. But the livelihoods of tens of thousands of dairy farmers are at stake, and the issue has provoked a civil war between lawmakers from the East and those from the Midwest.

title: For Soft-Drink Makers, a Dry Spell
description: AS Coca-Cola's share price dropped below $48 in trading last week, from a high of over $88 last year, investors were wondering: Can it get any worse?

title: Bradley's Health Plan Has a Major Flaw
description: To the Editor:

title: Hatch Dreams a Senator's Dream
description: In the last quarter-century, only one senator, Bob Dole in 1996, has won his party's nomination for President.

title: A Shameful Appeasement
description: The latest evidence that liberalism is not what it once was: The deafening silence of virtually all of New York's major cultural institutions in the wake of Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's attack on the Brooklyn Museum of art.

title: After 49 Years, Rabbi Leaves Post at Sing Sing
description: IN the 49 years that Rabbi Irving Koslowe was a chaplain at Sing Sing Correctional Facility here, he witnessed 17 executions -- including those of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg. With a career spanning those of 13 wardens and superintendents, he was one of the last living, let alone working, appointees of Gov. Thomas E. Dewey.

title: Creative Writing
description: Some of the most imaginative flowerings of modern literature are in a special genre: the personal expense account. What has been the wildest, woolliest item you have tried to put on your account? And for how much? How did you explain it, and what happened? Or if you're a boss, what has been the most striking item you have encountered? Send your stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your name and telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Orgonomics
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLACQUE, BEY, VALERIE
description: BLACQUE-BEY-Valerie., 59, of New York City, died in St. Louis, MO. of cancer on Wednesday, September 29, 1999. Daughter of the former June Blossom of New York City. Beloved sister of Melinda Moon Kiefer and sister-in-law of William Kiefer, Jr., both of St. Louis; dear sister of Richard Blacque and sister-in-law of Elizabeth Blacque of Bryn Mawr, Pa., loving aunt to Allegra and Aurelie Clement-Bayard and Wilkie Kiefer of St. Louis. A Memorial Service at St. Peter's Episcopal Church on Friday, October 15, 1999 at 12pm with Colombarium Interment following. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions to St. Peter's Episcopal Church, 110 North Warson Road, St. Louis, Mo. 63124.

title: Dow Watchers' Alert: Here Comes October Dread
description: SEPTEMBER, historically the worst month for the Dow Jones industrial average, has been worse than normal. Now, here is October, which is the second-worst month of the year for the Dow. And on Tuesday, Federal Reserve policy makers will meet to decide whether to raise their short-term interest-rate target for the third time since June.

title: The Baseball Race: Down to Final Day
description: The 162-game season comes down to just one game today for three teams in the National League, as the Mets and Astros won yesterday and the Reds lost. The Astros gained a one-game lead over the Reds in the N.L. Central race with a 3-0 victory over the Dodgers.

title: Back to School, 1958
description: No one has better captured the reality of teaching than Frank McCourt has. The irony is that he did his best teaching serendipitously, when he used the crumbling compositions left behind by his predecessor, instead of relying on the assigned novels. That couldn't happen today, with pressure to teach to the test.

title: Distant Rumbles of a Korean War Massacre
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIFE, BERNARD
description: FIFE-Bernard. To Bernie, a man of principle, a leader of our community. We remember you most as a loving husband and fathera wonderful friend. Bernice and Sid

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Sept. 19 showing changes in Britain's telephone numbering system referred incorrectly to their effect on those London numbers that now begin with the city code 0181. Under the new system, they will begin with 0208, not 0207.

title: Hitching a Ride on the Great White Whale
description: IN the opening sequence of Laurie Anderson's new ''Songs and Stories From 'Moby Dick,' '' Ms. Anderson stands alone, center stage on a raised platform, her back to the audience. A small figure against a large horizontal screen showing a panoramic film of ocean waves crashing slowly at her feet, she plays an electric-violin solo, drawing a bow back and forth across her body in long, steady motions. A deep wailing sound fills the stage and seems to loom over members of the audience, enveloping them viscerally in Ms. Anderson's world: the world of a master storyteller whose combination of images, words and melodies will keep them riveted for, in this case, an hour and a half.

title: But No One Was Singing
description: After a long summer drought, September called for all manner of rain gear. Popular were inexpensive plastic ponchos that are as disposable as the $4 umbrellas, which blow out as quickly as the costly designer variety. Functional and elegant were hooded nylon parkas, above and bottom right. Burberry plaids remain as popular as ever. And for the limousine riders, a short trench coat and an envelope bag serving as a head covering seemed fine for the dash from the car to the door.

title: A Battle-Scarred Burger Warrior
description: LIKE some other chief executives, Robert J. Nugent shares the limelight with the founder of his company. In this case, however, the ''founder'' is a clown with an oversize Ping-Pong ball for a head.

title: Dame Edna Speaks Her Mind, And Yours
description: SHE sat alone at a small round table in what Barry Humphries would later call ''that strange spooky room above Sardi's,'' dressed in a sequined frock that had more going on than the Times Square redevelopment project. The facade of Radio City Music Hall was appliqued on one shoulder, an embroidered Broadway zoomed up the other, and her eyeglasses -- the so-called face furniture that is so much a part of her look -- were reminiscent of another imported lady, the Statue of Liberty. With a torch at one temple and a row of spikes at the other, the glasses make air-kissing an extreme sport. This was, of course, her idea of New York day wear. At night, Dame Edna Everage goes all out.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about health concerns over heavy exposure to carbonless copy paper misstated the name of a class of chemicals, used in such paper, that a University of Florida study found could be transferred to human skin. They are alkyl biphenyls, not alkyl biphenols.

title: From Bogs, Not Vines
description: The trick in making cranberry wine is to capture the essence of the berry while tempering the fierce acidity that in cranberry juice can be so intimidating.

title: A Doll's House
description: In 1961, when I was 4, hair was a more mesmerizing mark of gender than anything glimpsed through the boys' room door. And no hair was more mesmerizing than Barbie's: when she appeared, fully grown, at the American Toy Fair in 1959, her tightly furled ponytail made her look like a kore, the idealized ancient Greek maiden -- or, to cite a more timely example, like Thalia Menninger, the temptress played by Tuesday Weld on ''The Many Loves of Dobie Gillis.'' As the Kennedys' Camelot ruled and Barbie evolved, the options for her coiffure came to include the ''bubble cut,'' which resembled the hairstyle of the President's wife, while its most popular color -- platinum blonde -- evoked Marilyn Monroe, long rumored to have been his mistress.

title: Q and A
description: World War I Cemeteries

title: Can 'Neurobics' Do for the Brain What Aerobics Do for Lungs?
description: THREE years ago, in chatting with a guest at the Holiday Inn she manages in Binghamton, N.Y., Candace Jones found herself confiding in him about her problems renovating the hotel and managing her staff.

title: From: Noah@Ark. Subject: Rain.
description: IT is not nearly as romantic as a message in a bottle, but electronic mail is certainly a much faster and more efficient way to communicate with friends and family back on shore from a ship at sea. For example, passengers on the Norwegian Sky, the first ship to offer 24-hour Internet access to passengers, were able to write home instantly when the ship, on one of its first voyages, ran aground in Canada last month. This inauspicious beginning for this new era of floating E-mail access notwithstanding, nearly every other major cruise line is also going full speed ahead to equip its ships with Internet-connected computers.

title: Paris Encounter
description: To the Editor: Pamela Whitney Hawkes's essay, ''Postcards to Myself'' (Aug. 22), reminded me of an experience my husband and I had in Paris last summer. We were sitting on a bench in the Place des Vosges so my husband could sketch the stately mansion there. A debonair man sauntered by and stopped to watch my husband. Saying he lived nearby, he related stories of his family and the Place des Vosges. He said his father wanted to live in the Vosges but his mother feared it would cost too much to heat the large rooms with such high ceilings. He suggested we return here another day to visit the home of Victor Hugo, which was closed that day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROHT, GEORGE
description: ROHT-George. Loving husband of Helen Geffen Roht, father of Naomi and doting grandfather of Laura and Rafael. A memorial service will be held Sunday, October 10, 3 PM, at the Jewish Cultural Center, 548 Main St., Roosevelt Island.

title: The Buchanan Doctrine
description: A Republic, Not an Empire

title: After Rise From Poverty to Power, the Luster Fades for a Folk Hero of India
description: Like a maharajah in a royal tableau, Laloo Yadav, self-proclaimed tribune of the downtrodden, sailed to this remote, dirt poor village in a wooden boat, standing grandly at its prow. His bejeweled fingers flashed as he waved to the people on shore. A servant held an umbrella aloft to shade him from a blazing sun.

title: The Iconoclast
description: This is definitely not the kind of house you expect to find in a quiet Seattle neighborhood. Its tough gray concrete facade is screened by what looks like an old brick wall and punctuated by something that resembles a steel cage. Unlike its more conventional neighbors, this house seems to give nothing away.

title: Rediscovering an Old Dramatic Partner: Dance
description: IN the last couple of seasons, the musical theater, both in New York (''Fosse,'' ''Footloose'') and in London (''Oklahoma!,'' ''Swan Lake'') seems to have rediscovered dancing -- not as an ornament or a practical interlude to entertain the audience while the actors or singers change costume, but as a resource in itself that can help advance the themes or story of a show, or, in the cases of ''Fosse'' and ''Swan Lake,'' embody them fully.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMAS, WILLIAM ANDREW
description: THOMAS-William Andrew., of 333 E. 95th Street, New York, NY 10128, died September 19. He was a musician, composer and computer consultant for banking and investment. Survived by his mother, Jean Hewitt Thomas; and sister, Heather Thomas Nackley. Memorial service at 11 AM Saturday, October 16, at USCGA Chapel, New London, Conn. Donations to St. Albans School, Mount St. Albans, Washington, DC 20016.

title: Insurers to Pay Out $84 Million to Flood Victims
description: New Jersey residents and businesses will collect $84 million from private insurance companies as a result of the tropical storm that washed over the state on Sept. 17, according to preliminary reports.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 12 about Al Pacino misspelled the surname of his co-star in the forthcoming film ''Chinese Coffee.'' He is Jerry Orbach, not Ohrbach. The article also misidentified the college attended by Michael Corleone, Mr. Pacino's character in the ''Godfather'' trilogy, and misstated the part of the trilogy in which Lee Strasberg made his film debut. The college was Dartmouth, not Harvard. The film was ''The Godfather Part II,'' not ''Part III.''

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Mitsubishi Mirage LS; Basic Transportation Without Deprivation
description: FOR those given to class envy, the current crop of megadollar sport utilities and luxury sedans could easily cause a rise of the proletarian gorge. But workers of the world, take heart.

title: Wendy Suk, Michael Kelly
description: Wendy Elizabeth Suk, a daughter of Gloria Suk of Bridgehampton, N.Y., and the late Richard Suk, was married yesterday to Michael McNaboe Kelly, a son of Joan and Edmund Kelly of Bedford Corners, N.Y. The Rev. Patrick J. Callan performed the ceremony at the Queen of the Most Holy Rosary Roman Catholic Church in Bridgehampton.

title: Sailing in Search of Dragons
description: WE were snorkeling off the side of an old-fashioned wooden schooner in the glittering seas of Indonesia when the news arrived that those scaly, flesh-eating lizards known as Komodo dragons are every bit as agile in the water as they are on land.

title: Lending His Name, and Tools, to Charity
description: TIM ALLEN may be best known as a stand-up comedian, the star of the television show ''Home Improvement'' and the voice of the hero Buzz Lightyear in the animated film ''Toy Story.'' But he hopes to become as trusted and honored a name in tools as Paul Newman is in food -- with similar benefits for charity.

title: Fans' Favorites
description: To the Editor:

title: Groups Restore the Old Look Of the Butler-McCook House
description: ON a recent morning, a steady summer rain beat against the windows of the Butler-McCook Homestead, the oldest house in downtown Hartford. Karin Peterson, associate director of the Antiquarian and Landmarks Society of Connecticut, which owns the house, peered through the rain-streaked glass at the home's newly restored gardens, blooming in the back yard.

title: When Everything That Had Worked Didn't
description: As Hurricane Floyd raged through eastern states last month, Jack McKeon sat in the comfort of his office at Cinergy Field in Cincinnati and made a bold prediction.

title: Cheaper Cars, Once Strippers, Now Come Dressed to the Nines
description: ITH the average new car selling for more than $20,000, at a time when even subcompacts flash gold badges and flaunt fancy CD players, the thrifty consumer searching for bare-bones transportation would seem forgotten. Or is it the penny-pinching customer who has disappeared -- gone the way of the shade-tree mechanic, the front-door vent window and spinner hubcaps? There no longer seems to be any demand for Spartan, stripped-down cars.

title: A New World Spin on Mediterranean Dishes
description: NOW in its fifth year, Cafe Meze continues to offer the dishes inspired by the sunny lands bordering the Mediterranean. But while preparations pay homage to ethnic tradition, what makes them contemporary is the New World spin this kitchen puts on them. To judge by the loyal clientele and, on weekends, a crowded dining room, this talent hardly needs further discussion.

title: Smitten With Words, Theirs and Others'
description: IT was a typical late-summer night, a muggy dusk swollen with cicada choruses outside the Barnes & Noble bookstore here. A perfect night for poets, said Brian Burns, the spiritual leader of the Sachem Poets Society, who had gathered to entertain browsers and iced coffee sippers. The standing-room-only crowd lingered for the soul-warming verses that echoed past the ''Cooking for Dummies'' display as Sachem's bards sang of themselves and invited newcomers to join in.

title: HacK, CouNterHaCk
description: ''Would you like to see how to knock someone off the Web?'' Silicosis asks.

title: Lehigh Offense Makes Lions Cry Uncle
description: You knew it was going to be a strange game when both team's mascots were ejected from the game in the first quarter for fighting on the sidelines. The Lehigh Mountain Hawk caught the Columbia Lion in a hammerlock and wouldn't let go.

title: Peggy Cullen and Andy Matlow
description: IN 1971, Peggy Cullen and Andy Matlow were free-spirited, arty, footloose undergraduates at Goddard College in Vermont, and madly in love. Then, in 1973, they discovered she was pregnant. ''It blew us apart,'' Ms. Cullen said. ''It was a relationship interrupted by something we couldn't handle.''

title: Wild Style
description: CHARLES HAMADEE has three passions in life: women, art and food. Bursting with enthusiasm, Mr. Hamadee encourages guests at his restaurant to recognize the beauty of all three. He uses the word ''unbelievable'' time and again to describe the numerous female inspirations for his bronze wall sconces, his intricate Mexican-pebble walls and Yoshiharu Suzuki's liberating cuisine.

title: A Prayer for the Dead
description: All Souls

title: Our Towns; After a Flood, Immigrants Vanish Again
description: ON the day after Floyd stormed by, the Rev. Lou Kilgore woke early and experienced a kind of secular epiphany. Outside, the sky was churning with the thrum of Coast Guard helicopters stabbing their spotlights through the predawn gloom at hundreds of people clinging to rooftops as the Raritan River ran 14 feet deep down Main Street. And Mr. Kilgore, the pastor of Bound Brook Presbyterian Church, suddenly had a thought: ''The invisible have become visible.''

title: New Jersey's Fired Chief of Troopers Blames Reverse Discrimination
description: The man who was fired as Superintendent of the New Jersey State Police after making public comments linking minority groups to drug crimes said today that his removal was an example of reverse discrimination and that Gov. Christine Todd Whitman had planned all along to replace him with a minority-group member.

title: Golf Losing Out To Sumo Civility
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Julie Taiber, Adam Candeub
description: Julie Marie Taiber, the daughter of Susan and Thomas Taiber of Waverly, Iowa, was married last evening to Adam Candeub, the son of Helene Candeub of Jenkintown, Pa., and the late Dr. Leon Candeub. Rabbi Sol Serber officiated at the Elk's Lodge in Waterloo, Iowa.

title: Sports of The Times; In the Desperate Final Moments, the Mets Always Know the Score
description: AFTER a 24-hour binge of depending on the kindness of their fellow union members, the Mets did not follow the flickering numbers on the scoreboard or the moving images on the television screen.

title: Charity Flows in Floyd's Wake
description: From big tobacco companies to private foundations to a Pennsylvania youngster who taped four quarters together and mailed them in, Americans have moved quickly to help victims of Hurricane Floyd in eastern North Carolina.

title: Samovars and Borscht: A Russian Star Returns
description: If a restaurant can have a soul, the Russian Tea Room's must be that of Rasputin. The jewel box on 57th Street has shrugged off everything from Prohibition to nouvelle cuisine as New York City has expanded and evolved around it for the better part of the century. This month, after an extensive redesign by the new owner, Warner LeRoy, who also owns Tavern on the Green, the restaurant will open once again, with a modern Russian menu by Fabrice Canelle, formerly of the Brasserie Savoy in San Francisco.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODSKY, CHARLES
description: BRODSKY-Charles. ''Charlie'' September 30, 1999. Beloved husband of Sara Jacoby-Brodsky. Father of Joyce (Dr. Richard) Unger and the late Ellen Goff. Father-in-law of Dr. Paul Goff. Step-father of Dr. Mel (Sandy) Jacoby & Dr. Steven (Carroll) Jacoby. Brother of Syd Goldman. Also survived by 4 loving grandchildren. Funeral services will be held Tuesday in Fla.

title: This Isn't York, After All
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Sept. 19 about walking the Pembrokeshire Coast Path in Wales misstated the ages of two buildings. The dairy cottage in which the author stayed dates from the 16th century, not the 19th; the places rented by the National Trust include a castle that dates from the 19th century, not the 18th, and clings from a cliff.

title: Reaching Out to Gay Voters, Bradley Calls for Equal Rights
description: Stepping up his efforts to woo liberal Democrats as he pursues the party's Presidential nomination, former Senator Bill Bradley told a gay and lesbian group here tonight that Americans should be guaranteed equal Government benefits and protection from discrimination regardless of their sexual orientation.

title: CHILEAN MILITARY FACES RECKONING FOR ITS DARK PAST
description: The arrest of Gen. Augusto Pinochet in London a year ago has opened a quiet and long-postponed reckoning in Chile over its years of dictatorship that is finally bringing former military officers to task for the deaths or disappearances of thousands of political opponents.

title: 'Just Revenge'
description: To the Editor:

title: Political Briefing; It's a New Campaign But the Same Refrain
description: After Senator Connie Mack, Republican of Florida, announced last March that he would not seek re-election, it seemed for a while that just about every politician in the state would jump into the contest to replace him. But the race began to take some shape as the political dance by candidates and would-be candidates subsided, and by midsummer Bill Nelson, the Insurance Commissioner, had emerged as the leading Democrat and Representative Bill McCollum of Altamonte Springs as the leading Republican.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: WORLDVIEW IN PAINTING -- Art and Society Selected Papers. By Meyer Schapiro. Braziller, $30.

title: Israel's Y2K Problem
description: Yehuda Etzion, rebel, settler, archterrorist of the Jewish underground, thin like Jesus and hostage to the fever-dream of imminent redemption, parks his car by a rocky switchback on the western slope of the Mount of Olives. He leads me up the incline, to the chalk-colored ground where he comes to pray and to look to the west upon what one day, he believes, will be his. Just below is the Garden of Gethsemane, where Jesus was betrayed and arrested. Just to the north is Mount Scopus, where the prophet Jeremiah watched the Babylonians burn Jerusalem. Immediately behind us is a house of modern prophecy, home to American evangelical Christians who have come on one-way tickets to the Promised Land. They are here to watch the Parousia, the Second Coming of Christ, and they are here to encourage the Jews to rebuild their Temple, the Throne of David on which the Christ will sit.

title: Tracking a Leak? Check Water Valves
description: THE basics of the water system in a home are easy to understand. After water enters the house, the supply line splits into a cold and a hot line. The hot line starts with cold water, but it is routed to a heater where the water is heated to a temperature of about 140 degrees Fahrenheit. Both lines are routed to fixtures in the bathroom, kitchen, laundry room, and so on, where they may tapped for water.

title: Nieuw Haarlem Is Revisited 341 Years After the Conquest
description: Was it a Dutch invasion? Or perhaps a second invasion?

title: Warming to Bar Association, Whitman Appears at Gala
description: Governor Whitman, still in talks with the New Jersey State Bar Association over its role in State Supreme Court nominations, went to the association's 100th birthday party last week. Among the guests was Justice Peter G. Verniero, whose nomination led to the rift.

title: Islander's Start Is Anything But Promising
description: It was only one game, but because it was against the National Hockey League's perennial doormat, the Tampa Bay Lightning, the Islanders' season opener had some extra meaning.

title: Marika Alzadon, Samuel Cole
description: Marika Dy Alzadon, a daughter of Norma Dy Alzadon and Dr. Ricardo Pena Alzadon of East Hanover, N.J., was married yesterday to Samuel Allen Cole, the son of Betty Cole and Dr. Steven A. Cole of Long Branch, N.J. Cantor Joel Spindel officiated at the Highlawn Pavilion, a restaurant in West Orange, N.J. The Rev. Mark Olenowski, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUERINOT, JOSEPH V.
description: GUERINOT-Joseph V.. Born Rochester, N.Y. 1928. Died Brajac, France, September 28, 1999. Long time dear friend of Robert Strobridge, Jeanne Kleinfield, B. & V. Connelly. Educator, scholar, bon vivant, chef sublime. Portsmouth Priory Oblate who drew others to the Benedictine way. Joe and Stro, welcoming hosts at their Dordogne farmhouse where conversation flourished: humourous, profound, provocative, satiric, loving.

title: Corrections
description: An essay on Sept. 5 about visits to writers' homes mistated the identity of the character who wore a ball gown the color of a yellow moth in the book ''A Girl of The Limberlost'' by Gene Stratton-Porter. It was Edith Carr; Elnora Comstock was her rival for the affections of Philip Ammon.

title: Hell on High Water
description: Knockdown

title: Commercial Property /521 Fifth Avenue; Making a Vacant Second Floor Attractive for Retail
description: INITIALLY, the second floor of the building at 521 Fifth Avenue at 43d Street seems attractive. Floor-to-ceiling windows on two sides bring natural light deep into the interior of the space, which was completed in 1929.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANE, WILLIAM LLOYD
description: LANE-William Lloyd. Husband of Carol, father of David, brother of Robert D. Lane, brother-in-law of Ro Lane. We present a toast to a great brother and uncle who was always there for his nephews, Robert D. Jr., Richard D. and Stephen (SKIP) Lane. Much loved.

title: A Very Fine Line
description: Michael Pollan's article (The Way We Live Now, Sept. 12) was not the first time I have heard a good argument for legalizing the so-called illicit drugs, but it is the first time I have read such a cogent argument. The question now is, what would happen if we actually behaved in such a practical way as to have all dangerous drugs accessible with a doctor's prescription. For one thing, it would put the largest group of criminals out of business. Also a lot of lawyers who rely on that business -- not to mention all the empty prisons and the civil servants who depend on them for a living! As you can see, there are many who would not easily acquiesce to Pollan's point of view. Too bad for us!

title: Kira Budoff, Adam Sexton
description: Kira Anne Budoff and Adam Reid Sexton were married on Friday in a civil ceremony at the Municipal Building in New York. An officer of the Marriage Bureau officiated.

title: The World; No More Magic Touch In Japan
description: THIS has been the decade of myth-shattering about Japan. First went the belief that Japan's bureaucrats had a golden touch with the economy; instead, they turned a downturn into a decade-long disaster. Then the country's image as a uniquely safe society was forever damaged by a deadly terrorist attack on the Tokyo subways. The Kobe earthquake revealed that the Government, after endless earthquake drills, was unprepared to handle the real thing.

title: Los Naturales
description: Pedro Martinez, the best pitcher in baseball, is Dominican. So is Manny Ramirez, New York folk hero and, along with Martinez, an American League m.v.p. front-runner. Sammy Sosa, who has earned the right to be mentioned in the same breath as Babe Ruth, is Dominican, too.

title: Distant Rumbles of a Korean War Massacre
description: To the Editor:

title: Charting New Directions
description: MANY cruise passengers will experience an extraordinary New Year's Eve with fireworks to greet the dawn of the 21st century, and it is still possible to find space on some ships.

title: The Screech of a Broken Record
description: Investors took the measure of the largely negative third quarter that ended on Thursday -- and sighed. They swallowed hard on Friday after hearing further condemnation of the surging economy.

title: Putt Line Marred
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Political Briefing; A California Special: Republican Tremors
description: The Republican Party of California, once the mightiest in the land, has been in a free fall since the last election, which saw Democrats capture not only the Governor's office and just about every other top state job but also control of both houses of the Legislature.

title: Laura Jamison, John Therese
description: Laura Jamison and John Therese were married yesterday at the Riverside Church in New York. The Rev. Fanny Erickson, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony, in which the Rev. Richard B. Leslie, an Episcopal priest, took part.

title: The Crew Makes A Boat a Yacht
description: BASICALLY, what I am is a matchmaker,'' said Sandy Carney, who manages yacht charters for the Alden Group in Jamestown, R.I. Ms. Carney, whose venerable organization sells and charters the output of many builders along with designing and building Alden yachts, regularly visits the major charter shows here and abroad, checking out the boats and most particularly their crews. She wants to be sure crew personalities will fit with those of her clients.

title: The Friars Tune Out Antics Then Dominate the Gaels
description: The bus had arrived hours earlier, and after running through pre-game warm-ups, the St. Anthony players were just going through the motions, waiting for the game to begin -- or, more precisely, waiting for the home team to show up at the field.

title: F.B.I. Raids The Office Of a Big Donor To Politicians
description: Federal agents investigating campaign-finance irregularities searched the Englewood, N.J., office of a prominent contributor to both major political parties on Friday and carried away several boxes of records and documents.

title: Baseball Before It Became a Game for Softies
description: IT was a Currier and Ives, not a Kodak, moment. On a grassy pasture that was once a plowing field, under a crisp blue sky, nine men in wool caps, bibbed blouses, baggy, button-top trousers and suspenders were poised in a 19th-century tableau, bare knuckles on their knees. Completing the landscape: a gambrel-roofed gentleman farmer's house, a red barn and an old cider press in the distance.

title: New Tactic Goes Citywide After It Ends Drug Bazaars
description: A two-year-old effort to rid the Lower East Side of its street-corner drug bazaars has worked so well that senior police officials say they want to expand it to every precinct in the city.

title: Ms. Krumplitsch And Mr. Gould
description: Kellie Anne Krumplitsch and Nicholas Howard Gould, both Internet executives in New York, are to be married this evening in the Penthouse at Studio 450 in Manhattan. Justice Ernst H. Rosenberger of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Manhattan is to perform the ceremony.

title: Orgonomics
description: To the Editor:

title: A Point of View
description: To the Editor: After reading Nancy Beth Jackson's article ''Figeac's Flair for the Egyptian'' (Aug. 29), I wonder how many people have written about Christophe Boisvieux's photograph of the sculptural reproduction of the Rosetta stone that illustrates the article. It appears upside down because of the angle from which it was photographed.

title: Foes and Backers Square Off Over School Chief's Firing
description: When Gloria Morgenstern walked into the office of Superintendent Joseph F. Quinn three weeks ago seeking to know how a testing company's blunders would affect left-back students, she expected a boilerplate response.

title: Updated Nuclear Hot Line
description: The United States and Russia, updating the ''hot line'' concept between leaders of the world's most heavily armed nuclear powers, opened a new state-of-the-art video-conferencing center today that will enable Russian and American nuclear officals to see, as well as talk, to each other during a nuclear-related emergency.

title: Ideas & Trends; Not Gonna Do It, That Bush Family Thing. Well, Maybe.
description: AT a recent banquet here of some formality, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, a man seldom inclined to sartorial musings, recalled a conversation with his wife, Laura, about what he planned to wear.

title: Self-Help Directory
description: Westchester Self-Help Clearinghouse, a program of Four Winds/ Westchester Jewish Community Services, is now offering its 12th edition of the Directory of Self-Help Groups in Westchester.

title: Off-Season Hamptons House-Sits Go the Way Of the Dodo
description: NOT so long ago, a pauper with a tent to pitch -- or a friend to move in with for the summer -- could live like a prince the rest of the year in the Hamptons.

title: Well, It All Began When Mahler Got Disney Thinking
description: TAKE two young American composers, add commissioning money, two librettists, a few jettisoned collaborators, a major symphony orchestra, a dose of high hopes, some tantalizing hints about a major motion picture and one colossal entertainment company with a mighty powerful chairman who hears a Mahler symphony and jots down his concept for a musical work to commemorate the millennium, and what do you get? High stakes and two new choral symphonies.

title: The Wired Bunch
description: Consumers bewildered by the furious pace of technology change -- and the feeling that their computer is outdated when it is barely weeks old -- need not direct their frustration at any single company. They can take aim at Keith Martin, a 31-year-old New Jersey businessman, and his electronic dog.

title: In Pediatrics, a Lesson in Making Use of Experimental Procedures
description: If there is a model for an effective way to handle experimental procedures, it is the world of pediatric cancer.

title: Correction
description: An article on Aug. 15 about an investigation of pharmaceutical prices on Long Island misstated the role of Medicare, the Federal program for the elderly. It has never provided prescription drugs or co-payments for pharmaceuticals.

title: FIRST PERSON; The Beats on the Block
description: WHEN I first met the great Beats Allen Ginsberg, William Burroughs and Jack Kerouac in the early 1960's I had no idea they were such pack rats! Under the surface chaos, the bacchic bottles of burgundy used as drums at poetry readings, the all-nighters, the pot and mescaline, the coast-to-coast cruises, lay a self-belief and orderliness.

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-3-99: Questions for David O. Russell; Love and Rockets
description: Q: Your other movies, ''Spanking the Monkey'' and ''Flirting With Disaster,'' both dealt with sex. Which is harder to direct -- sex or war?

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Sept. 19 about the re-release of the movie ''Caligula'' misstated the type and amount of damages awarded in a sexual harassment suit brought by a cast member against the film's producer, Bob Guccione. In the original case (Thoreson v. Penthouse International Ltd.), the plaintiff won $4 million in punitive damages, as stated in the article, and $60,000 in compensatory damages. But when the case was heard on appeal, the punitive damages were ruled unavailable in sex-discrimination cases.

title: Karen Chelius and John Bates
description: Karen Chelius, a daughter of Maureen O. Chelius of Westfield, N.J., and the late Prof. James R. Chelius, was married yesterday in Princeton, N.J., to John Andrew Bates, the son of Catherine H. Bates of McLean, Va., and Carl E. Bates of Arlington, Va. The Rev. Sue Anne Steffey Morrow, a United Methodist minister and dean of religious life at Princeton University, performed the ceremony at the Princeton University Chapel.

title: Together on Screen With the Star He Was Long Ago
description: AT the age of 60, white-haired and soft-spoken, Terence Stamp has evidently come to terms with that other Terence Stamp who became an overnight star in Peter Ustinov's 1962 movie version of ''Billy Budd,'' that high-living younger self who was a fixture in English tabloids as an icon of the Swinging 60's.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on Tuesday described the ways in which the investigation of possible Russian money laundering through the Bank of New York had been snared in an old rivalry between the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the office of Robert Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney.

title: Mirror, Mirror, Which Narcissus Is Fairest?
description: A discussion at a recent luncheon became rather involved. The topic was the differences among narcissus, daffodil and jonquil.

title: The Many Guises of a President
description: VITALY KOMAR and Alexander Melamid are a different kind of folk-artist team. The essence of their sophisticated art is the common man -- what he thinks about the world and his thoughts about and reactions to art and culture.

title: Back to School, 1958
description: Seven Septembers ago, when I started teaching in the New York City public schools, I was issued the same supplies that Frank McCourt was given by his principal in 1958: a red roll book, a stack of Delaney cards and a spare copy of the student textbook. I find the similarities between 1958 and the 1990's oddly comforting. I have met many people who exonerate the public-school system for its failure to serve students well by saying that students today aren't what they used to be. In the old days, I'm told, students were taught good behavior at home.

title: London Bans Cars On Some Soho Streets
description: Several streets in Soho, one of central London's busiest areas, are now closed to traffic every afternoon and evening in a one-year trial period. The plan, which includes new one-way traffic routes and bicycle lanes, will be monitored, and the findings discussed at the end of the trial.

title: A Chain Whose Links Chose One Another
description: ''SIX Degrees of Separation,'' the title of the group show at the Forrest Scott Gallery here, refers not to any theme that unites the half-dozen contemporary artists, but rather to the way the show was put together. The first artist selected, an up-and-coming young New York-based painter named Erin Parish, was asked to choose another. This second painter (Joe Andoe, a much better-known artist in what might be called early mid-career) chose a third, and so on. The results feel a little different from the kind of group show organized by a single individual making the choices, or by a committee with its give and take, its compromises. It has a different kind of diversity and a different kind of unity -- not necessarily better, but more indirect, almost unconscious.

title: Objectivity Lacking In Report on Activists
description: The Westchester section on Sept. 19 carried an In Brief item, ''Activists in Jail.''

title: Another Source of Noise That Maddens Citizens
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Japan Shops
description: When the Japanese pop star Cornelius comes to New York, he heads for Lafayette Street. ''It's one of the first places I go,'' he said. Cornelius (a k a Keigo Oyamoto) made time last week -- between interviews and sound checks for his concert at Irving Plaza -- to fill a few bags with the latest T-shirts and gear from the shops strung from Houston to Grand Streets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHERNEFF, J. ROBERT
description: CHERNEFF-J. Robert. You gave so much of yourself to so many of us in so many ways, our sense of loss is overwhelming. You held us together for close to 50 years, and now we hold you in our hearts forever. The Shabbas Group

title: The Lee Krasner Who Was Herself And Only Herself
description: DURING the hot summer of 1956, in the cramped upstairs bedroom that served as her studio, Lee Krasner found herself unhinged by a painting she had just completed. It consisted of monstrous abstracted body parts violently dismembered, aggressive sexual organs, gouges of glaring yellow and one blank, terrifying eye.

title: The Unsung Comeback of the Large Car
description: AS the 2000 model year arrives, sport utility vehicles have captured the hearts and garages of millions of Americans, while sales of large cars and minivans are lagging.

title: Christine Pardo, Thomas Tormey
description: Christine Ellen Pardo, the daughter of Marilyn N. Pardo of Larchmont, N.Y., and the late Allen T. Pardo, was married last evening to Thomas Augustus Tormey, the son of Kathleen O'Connor of Lakeland, Fla., and William F. Tormey of Dublin. The Rev. Walter F. Modrys performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title: Is This Hero a Boulevard or Street?
description: The proposal before Community Board 12 seemed straightforward: pay homage to a Dominican hero by adding Juan Pablo Duarte Boulevard to a 21-block stretch of St. Nicholas Avenue through the heart of Washington Heights, a largely Dominican neighborhood. Local leaders gathered 850 signatures supporting the idea, and Councilman Guillermo Linares planned to submit the measure to the City Council after receiving support from the community board.

title: Bird Food Is a Casualty of the War on Drugs
description: What do 40,000 pounds of birdseed have in common with America's war on drugs?

title: Jennifer Quasha, Theodore Deinard
description: Jennifer Catlin Quasha, the daughter of Leigh C. French of Greenwich, Conn., and Wayne G. Quasha of London, was married yesterday to Theodore Benedict Deinard, the son of Lile H. Deinard of New York and the late Ethan C. Deinard. The Rev. Terence Elsberry performed the ceremony at St. Ann's Episcopal Church in Bridgehampton, N.Y.

title: Singles Nibble, Mix and Wander As a 6-Story Jewish Center Opens
description: THE SETTING -- Mingling to the beat of Latin jazz, some 400 young people gathered Tuesday evening for the opening of a Jewish cultural center on West 67th Street called Makor, which means source in Hebrew.

title: A Wilton Tradition To Library's Benefit
description: DO not expect candles at the Candlelight Concerts in Wilton Congregational Church -- the minister long ago decided that they made a mess and were probably a fire hazard as well -- but musical excellence has remained a hallmark of the series since its official birth 52 years ago, and actually for some three decades before that.

title: U.N. Troops Have Shifting Role and Strategy in Enforcing Peace
description: The United Nations strategy for dealing with regional conflicts has undergone a significant shift, as shown by its new involvement in Kosovo and East Timor, and a third mission under consideration in Sierra Leone, United Nations officials and other diplomats say.

title: Yachting's Trans-Atlantic Record Challenged
description: Steve Fossett sets sailing records the way Mark McGwire crushes home runs -- with startling regularity. In 1978, Fossett, buoyed by a growing fortune in the securities market, began to make up for an idle boyhood with forays into mountain climbing, marathon swimming and triathalons. But it was not until 1991 that Fossett got truly serious about his fun.

title: Seville
description: Seville was immeasurably enriched by its 1992 World's Fair, an event that marked a return to a prominence and prosperity not seen since the 17th century, when the city monopolized trade with the New World and was a major port of entry for treasure-laden ships.

title: Criticism on a Different Runway
description: Last Sunday, Ralph Lauren learned that his sense of fashion doesn't please quite everyone. He had entered one of his cars, a black 1938 Bugatti 57SC Atlantic, in the Louis Vuitton Classic, an annual concours d'elegance, or beauty pageant for antique cars, at Rockefeller Center. One of only four of its type ever made, this Bugatti has a magnesium alloy body so difficult to weld that it is held together by a prominent riveted spine. It's the Batmobile's sinister older brother.

title: Q. & A.
description: Overheated Apartment In a Co-op

title: Object Fixation
description: We all have our home fashion phobias, but with the dizzying array of products, materials, textures and colors available in today's market, the only thing we'll have to fear about decorating our living rooms is fear itself.

title: At Yale, Manic Hypochondria
description: THE cast includes Argan (an invalid), Toinette (his maid), Harem Women, Show Girls, Keystone Kops and Hillary Clinton. Microphone in hand, she talks of health care, the millennium and Monica, St. John's Wort, too.

title: She May Have The Last Laugh, And a Fortune
description: WHEN last we left her, Anna Nicole Smith, the Playboy centerfold and former Guess jeans model, was at war over how to hold a proper funeral for her husband, J. Howard Marshall 2d, the Texas oilman who was one of the richest people in America when he died at age 90.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 19 about the popularity of the extended Spanish-language mini-series known as novelas misidentified the male lead in one of them, ''Corazon Salvaje.'' He was Eduardo Palomo, not Guy Ecker.

title: Peacekeepers Patrolling Dili Silently Stalk A Small Hotel
description: The objective was the Hotel Dili.

title: His Life as a Murder Suspect
description: The evidence that points to Van de Velde seems scant: he wasn't responsive to Jovin as her thesis adviser. However, using my intuition (just as the New Haven police did), I have discerned other ''evidence'' all but implicating Van de Velde:

title: An Energetic Irish Troupe That Keeps on the Move
description: THE major artistic challenge facing theater in Ireland today may be what to do about all those plays. The nation's illustrious history of dramatic writing hangs over contemporary Irish theater like a combined blessing and curse; modern companies either seem to be searching for the next Synge or O'Casey (or McDonagh) or trying to steer the theater away from the almighty word altogether.

title: The Human Costs of War
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Media Talk; Raffish, Easy to Read, but Not a Tabloid
description: Call Ken Chandler's New York Post conservative, and he smiles and says that ''the strength of The Post is that it wears its emotion on its sleeve.'' Suggest that it loses money, and the newspaper's new publisher will smile and say he never discusses finances. Question its accuracy, and he smiles and says that everyone makes mistakes. But call it a tabloid, and Mr. Chandler frowns over his mug of tea.

title: The New Palm: Web Access but at a Price
description: Palm Computer Inc. will roll out its wireless Palm VII nationally on Monday, hoping to stimulate wider interest in the Internet-linked palm computer by cutting $100 from the price offered in New York trials. Palm says it has also added new on-line features, including the ability to trade stocks and participate in auctions.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We really haven't won anything yet.''

title: Recording Industry Escalates Crackdown on Digital Piracy
description: For years, frustrated record companies have watched helplessly as millions of illegally copied songs circulated on the Internet, but a crackdown on digital piracy that will have a wide-ranging impact on consumers is about to begin.

title: Corrections
description: The State of the Art column in Circuits on Sept. 23, about a new Microsoft computer mouse called the Intellimouse Explorer, misstated the operating-system requirements. Windows 98 is needed -- and Windows 98 Second Edition recommended -- for only the version that has the mouse link to the computer through a Universal Serial Bus connection, not for all versions.

title: N.F.L. Week 4; Pittsburgh Finds Wrong End Zone
description: JAGUARS 17, STEELERS 3

title: After a summer of high-profile coverage of Hispanic culture, some wonder if it will last.
description: WHEN editors at New York magazine were planning their recent issue on Latinos, they searched for the magazine's last cover on the city's Hispanic population. They found one, about East Harlem, published in August 1972 under the headline, ''The Big Mango: Latin Impact on New York Style.''

title: Media Talk; Hachette Plans to Buy the Rest of George
description: After months of speculation about whether Hachette Filipacchi magazines would continue to finance George magazine, the company has decided not only to support George financially, but to wholly own it.

title: Missile System Passes a Test As a Target Is Destroyed
description: The United States military has successfully tested a crucial element of the proposed national missile shield, shooting a mock warhead out of the sky over the Pacific Ocean with an interceptor launched from thousands of miles away, Pentagon officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, LILLIAN BERKOWITZ
description: STERN-Lillian Berkowitz. Mother, grandmother, aunt; widow of Sidney Stern. The last of her generation, passes at age 89, leaving one son Michael, six grandchildren Elana, Baldin, Adina, Sidney Alex, A.B., Zoe Stern, and nieces and nephews of the Stern, Scheer, and Berkowitz families. Funeral Monday, October 4, Sinai Chapel, 16205 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows; 718-445-0300.

title: Soaring Softly Is Back
description: FLOWER BOWL INVITATIONAL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHSCHILD, MAX
description: ROTHSCHILD-Max, of Bell Harbor. Owner Rothschild Provisions 45 years. Survived by wife, Ann, 2 daughters, and 8 grandchildren.

title: The Big City; Clever Beasts And Burdens On Their City
description: FROM a public relations standpoint, animals have been problematic for New York. Besides the burgeoning populations of rats and cockroaches, there is our famous four-legged neurotic, Gus, the polar bear in the Central Park Zoo who required the services of a therapist from California.

title: Compressed Data: Y2K Pulse; Year 2000 Concerns? Check the Latest Poll
description: It is widely acknowledged that no one can be sure how prepared the world is for Year 2000 computer problems. But polls and surveys looking into that question have been appearing ever more frequently.

title: Broncos and Mirer Meet Again
description: Quarterback Rick Mirer may be the newest Jet among the starters, but he is the most experienced against the Broncos. Yesterday was the ninth time he had faced them, and he has won three and lost two against them in his last five starts.

title: Yonkers Cancels Classes As Mediator Enters Strike
description: After nearly 14 hours of negotiations over the weekend, the two sides in the Yonkers teachers' strike agreed yesterday to call in a state mediator.

title: Far Right Gains in Austrian Vote, but Outcome Is in Doubt
description: A national election in which the outside world may have shown more interest than Austrians did ended rather inconclusively tonight.

title: The U.S. Should Let Cuba Be Cuba
description: To the Editor:

title: Belarus Sees Its Dissidents Disappearing
description: As Viktor Gonchar left for his Thursday night trip to the baths, a ritual in Minsk, the capital of Belarus, he told his wife to watch the evening news. The President had excoriated his critics in a speech, and Mr. Gonchar, a leading political dissident, believed a crackdown was imminent.

title: The On-Line Brokerage Battle
description: HEARD the pitch about dumping your full-service broker? Remember the ad about the stock-trading teen-ager with his own helicopter? Seen the television spot where the hunky stud muffin rubs the bunions of an older woman who is basking in her on-line investment wealth?

title: Trying to Save a Soaked Alternative Haven
description: Laurie Sansone, the town librarian, walked into the mildewed shell of the Palmyra Tea Room and Art Gallery, with its undulating wooden floors and its mud-covered furnishings, the other day and asked the dirt-splattered people cleaning up, ''I heard you still needed some help?''

title: Why Americans Had to Go to War
description: To the Editor:

title: Polls Show Hindu Nationalists Leading in Monthlong Vote
description: As the final round of voting ended in India's monthlong marathon national elections, two exit polls indicated today that the coalition headed by the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party was winning a parliamentary majority, but by different margins.

title: Financier Is Said to Acquire A Significant Stake in RCN
description: Vulcan Ventures Inc., the investment group controlled by Paul Allen, has made its biggest move yet into telecommunications by agreeing to invest about $1.7 billion in the RCN Corporation. The deal is set to be announced today, RCN said yesterday.

title: Advanced Micro to Offer A 700-MHz Computer Chip
description: Securing the bragging rights for the world's fastest PC chip, Advanced Micro Devices Inc. will announce on Monday that it is shipping a 700-megahertz version of its Athlon microprocessor. That outpaces the fastest model of the Intel Corporation's Pentium III chip currently available, a 600-megahertz chip.

title: Brown Is Back, as Is Running Game
description: Running back Gary Brown's return was supposed to be just the tonic the Giants needed to boost their anemic offense today. And the Philadelphia Eagles, ranked No. 27 in the National Football League against the run, giving up an average of 141.7 yards a game, were going to be the perfect foil.

title: Siemens-Clarent Deal
description: The Clarent Corporation, a small maker of equipment that transmits telephone calls using Internet technology, plans to announce today that Siemens of Germany, one of the world's biggest makers of telecommunications gear, has agreed to incorporate Clarent's technology into its products. The deal appears set to give Clarent a boost against competitors like Lucent Technologies Inc. and the 3Com Corporation.

title: Russians Hunt Rebel Leader, But Shoot Chechen Villagers
description: It was lunchtime on a clear sunny day today and the Russian artillery, positioned on the steep mountains to the east, was in action, pounding this village in southeastern Chechnya with several volleys of heavy missiles.

title: Dad's Dead, but He Still Likes to Chat
description: It is estimated early in ''Life Afterlife'' that 50 million people say they have had the experience of communicating with those, to use a preferred phrase, ''on the other side.'' You can hear several of them testifying to their encounters during tomorrow night's HBO documentary.

title: Equity and Debt Offerings Scheduled This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIGHBERGER, JOHN K.
description: HIGHBERGER-John K., Reverend. On October 2, 1999, of Ramsey, NJ. Beloved husband of the late Helen Stewart Foster Highberger (1993). Devoted father of Judith S. Highberger of Ramsey and William F. Highberger of Pacific Palisades, CA. Loving grandfather of Helen Barbara Highberger and Anna Mary Highberger both of Pacific Palisades, CA. Born in Connellsville, PA, Rev. Highberger left Waymart, PA, and was installed the Ramsey pastor on May 11, 1945. He brought with him a wealth of talent and experience. He received his bachelor's degree from Washington and Jefferson College, his bachelor and master's in theology from Princeton Theological Seminary. Rev. Highberger was Pastor of the First Presbyterian Church, Ramsey, from 1945 to 1973, and Pastor Emeritus since then, and also Assistant Minister at the Saddle River Reformed Church, Upper Saddle River, from 1974 to 1976. Ecumenism was always at the core of Rev. Highberger's ministry. When the Jewish community organized in Ramsey, they worshipped in the Presbyterian Church. He was especially known for working ecumenically within Ramsey. A funeral service will be held on Tuesday, October 5, 1999, at 10 AM, at the First Presbyterian Church, Ramsey. Visitation Monday 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at Van Emburgh Sneider Funeral Home, 109 Darlington Avenue, Ramsey. Interment Princeton Cemetery, Princeton, NJ. Donations to the Ramsey Ambulance Corps will be appreciated.

title: Compressed Data; Support for Sellers In Electronic Auctions
description: Andale Inc. wants to take the fleas out of the electronic flea market. The start-up E-commerce company, based in Santa Clara, Calif., plans to unveil a new service this week that provides back-office support for people who make their living selling goods on electronic auctions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LENSE, ROBERT
description: LENSE-Robert. Passed away on October 2, 1999. Beloved and dedicated husband to Rose Marie, married for 51 years. Loving father to Richard, JoAnn and Ronald. Devoted brother to Jack and Daniel and loyal friend to countless others. Robert was a proud graduate of the U.S. Merchant Marine Academy, Class of 1944, who held a Masters Seaman's License. Services today at 12 noon, at the U.S. Merchant Marine Academy in Kings Point.

title: Sports of The Times; Collins Should Replace Graham as the Starter
description: IT'S been part of the job description for a Giants coach for four decades: deciding on the quarterback.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMEDRESMAN, MAX
description: SMEDRESMAN-Max. On October 2, age 80 (1919-1999). Survived by his wife Joan and his children Ruth Rosen, Peter and Steven, and grandchildren. He will be deeply mourned by his family and missed by his colleagues in the pharmaceutical industry. Services today, 11:15 AM, ''Sinai Chapels,'' 162-05 Horace Harding Expwy, Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: Jets' Johnson Catches Season Slipping Away
description: A small group of Jets players was sitting around the locker room late last week in a sort of trance. Then one said the obvious: ''This is it, isn't it?'' The ''it'' was the Denver game yesterday.

title: Media Talk; No Good Way to Break the Bad News
description: News about the media travels fast these days, so it is no surprise that news of Mortimer B. Zuckerman's sale of The Atlantic Monthly was leaking out a day before Mr. Zuckerman was ready for it. But it did mean that Mr. Zuckerman had to move quickly on that most sensitive of issues: how to tell the staff in Boston that the magazine was being sold.

title: NBC and Lou Dobbs Plan Joint Newsletter and Radio Show
description: Lou Dobbs, the financial news anchor and executive who quit the Cable News Network last June, has made a deal with NBC for a joint venture that would create both a financial newsletter and a radio program and would enable him to appear periodically on NBC programs.

title: U.S. and Russia Seek New Ways To Detect Cheating on Test Ban
description: As the White House and Senate Republicans prepare for a bruising battle over a landmark treaty banning nuclear weapons tests, top Russian and American nuclear officials said today that they had agreed to consider new ways to prevent cheating on the pact.

title: In America; The New Al Gore
description: Al Gore dropped by a few days ago and insisted he's a changed man.

title: Fassel Turns to Collins, Who Leads Giants Past Philadelphia
description: It was late in the third quarter today, seconds after his third interception, when Giants quarterback Kent Graham rose from a jumble of bodies on the field and jogged toward the team bench.

title: Wicked Look At Hollywood Fails to Draw TV Viewers
description: What happened to ''Action''?

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about Congressional Republicans' response to criticism of their budget proposals by Gov. George W. Bush of Texas misspelled the surname of the policy director for Mr. Bush's campaign. He is Josh Bolten, not Bolton.

title: It's Festive but Weird: Mets Wash Off Labels
description: The pitch bounced in the dirt and skipped past the catcher, and the rookie raced down the third-base line. Robin Ventura, the on-deck batter, pointed with both hands to home plate (''I was making sure,'' he would say later), and Melvin Mora stepped on it, bringing the rest of the Mets charging out of the dugout in a rush and igniting a joyous celebration on the field.

title: Wild Pitch, Wild Victory, Wild Wait
description: When the wild pitch rolled in the grass and Melvin Mora was on his way home with the winning run yesterday, Robin Ventura arrived at the batter's box so quickly he had to wait for Mora to touch home plate before he could jump into his arms.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAUGHAN, NORBERT F.
description: GAUGHAN-Norbert F., Most Reverend, Ph.D. Age 78. Second Bishop of the Diocese of Gary, IN. Passed away Friday, October 1. Survived by his brother, William and his wife, Eleanor Gaughan of Pittsburgh, PA, the late Bernardine Rygiel, the late Sister Patricia, and the late Vincent; and many nieces and nephews. Funeral services and visitation times are as follows: Wednesday, October 6, 3-8 PM, St. Anthony Home, Crown Point, IN; Thursday, October 7, 10 AM to 12 noon, Cathedral of the Holy Angels, Gary, IN; 12 noon, Mass of Christian Burial; Friday, October 8, St. Emma Monastery, Greensburg, PA, 2-9 PM; Saturday, October 9, Funeral Liturgy, Blessed Sacrament Cathedral, Greensburg, PA, 10 AM. Interment, St. Emma Monastery. Bishop Gaughan was ordained a priest on November 4, 1945. Doctor of Philosophy, University of Pittsburgh. Numerous assignments, Diocese of Greensburg. On October 26, was ordained Auxiliary Bishop of Diocese of Greensburg. July 24, 1984, nabed Bishop of the Diocese of Gary, IN, until to his retirement in 1992. For more information, contact Baron Funeral Home, 1235 119 St, Whiting, IN; 219659-4400.

title: Same Place, Same Teams, but No Ticket to Super Bowl
description: It was only eight and a half months ago that the Jets and the Broncos were the class of the American Football Conference and met here for the right to go to the Super Bowl.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCDONALD, CRAIG ANTON
description: McDONALD-Craig Anton. Writer and teacher, of New York and Mexico, died on September 25, 1999. He was 42. He is deeply mourned and profoundly missed by his extensive family of friends in New York and elsewhere. A memorial service is planned for October 16. For information, call (718) 851-3174. Donations to the Brooklyn Animal Rescue Coalition may be made in his memory.

title: Patents; Two partners devise a method for easier collection of sales taxes from the Internet.
description: PAUL FRANCISCO and Frederick Petschauer don't want to go down in history as the guys who made it easy for the Government to wrest taxes out of hard-working Americans. But if taxes are as inevitable as death, they may inevitably include taxes on Internet sales.

title: When Parents Share a Bed With the Baby
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KILMARX, HELEN WOOD
description: KILMARX-Helen Wood, of Scarsdale, New York, died September 1, 1999. Mother of Meredith Wood, Jr. & Kingsley Wood. Grandmother of John Scott Wood, James Stewart Wood, Kingsley Wood, Jr. and Leslie Wood Pellech. Greatgrandmother of Emma Elizabeth Wood and Kingsley Wood III. A memorial service will be held at Hitchcock Presbyterian Church in Scarsdale, NY on October 15th at 2PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her memory to Vassar College, Poughkeepsie, New York 12601.

title: Romancing Russia
description: To the Editor:

title: Russia's Ominous Moves on Chechnya
description: With Russian troops menacing Chechnya and the Russian Government refusing to recognize the elected Chechen government, another ill-fated conflict looms in the war-ravaged Caucasus region. The last Russian-Chechen war brought humiliation on the Russian Government and especially Russia's military, a force that gained an international reputation for being big, brutal and ineffective. This new Chechen venture by the Russians begs for rethinking in Moscow, since it not only destroys a delicate peace with Chechnya, but also threatens to worsen the very terrorist actions that apparently launched this risky Russian assault.

title: Why Americans Had to Go to War
description: To the Editor:

title: I.B.M. Invests In Campaign To Promote Its Software
description: I.B.M. has long had the dubious distinction of running the biggest software business that nobody ever heard of. But the International Business Machines Corporation plans to change that with a major marketing and advertising campaign that is to begin on Wednesday.

title: SUNY Faces a $110 Million Budget Gap, and It's Growing
description: The State University of New York has a $110 million hole in its budget, about 5 percent of the total, and the gap is growing. State and university officials are calling it the system's most serious budget crisis in recent memory.

title: Sports of The Times; Once Again, An October 3 To Underline
description: It was already a famous date in New York baseball history, even before the wild pitch skittered away, allowing the Mets to celebrate something, at the very least an airplane ride to Cincinnati.

title: MORE AMERICANS WERE UNINSURED IN 1998, U.S. SAYS
description: The number of Americans without health insurance rose last year by 833,000, to 44.3 million, despite a strong economy and a new law intended to provide coverage for children, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: Longtime Foes Join to Promote Jobs and Earth
description: After battling each other for years, environmental groups and labor unions have recently formed an alliance that will push to protect jobs and the environment at world trade talks scheduled for early December.

title: Partners & Shevack Wins Tourism Work
description: The Empire State Development Corporation has named Partners & Shevack/Wolf in New York to handle creative and media duties for its tourism promotion and business development assignments, known as the ''I [Love] New York'' campaign. Billings were estimated at more than $10 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHOEM, GERALD N.
description: SCHOEM-Gerald N. Age 77, of Ann Arbor, MI. Formerly of Philadelphia, PA, and Maywood, NJ. Husband of Sara. Father of Mark and David; brother of Robert. Beloved grandfather of Davida, Jesse, Adina, and Shana. Services are at 1 PM, today, at Congregaton Beth Israel, 2000 Washtenaw Ave, Ann Arbor, MI.

title: Mora Used His Memory and His Eyes to Seal Victory
description: Melvin Mora inched slowly off third base yesterday and stared closely at Brad Clontz's right hand, searching for small clues. Mora was a teammate of Clontz's on the Mets' Class AAA Norfolk team last year, so he was poised when he saw Clontz, now a Pittsburgh reliever, gripping the ball with two fingers pressed close together.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Demanding the Right Size Government
description: Something odd is happening to government at the end of the 20th century: It is flying apart and coming together, all at the same time.

title: Atom Plant Cut Corners On Safety, Japan Is Told
description: Under pressure from plant management, Japanese nuclear workers may have routinely skipped critical safety steps for years in order to increase the production of uranium fuel, press reports said Sunday and today.

title: In Museum Case, Judge Has Eye for Law, if Not Art
description: The Federal judge who is to decide the first courtroom round between Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the Brooklyn Museum of Art does not consider herself a connoisseur of art, those who know her say, but they find her a thoughtful, cautious and conscientious jurist.
