title: Gore Will Keep Campaign Chairman Despite Report of Mismanagement at World Exposition
description: Vice President Al Gore said today that his campaign chairman would stay on despite a Government report criticizing him for questionable expenses and payments during his tenure as head of the United States pavilion at last year's World Exposition in Portugal.

title: BASEBALL; Victory Ends Nail-Biting Time for Houston
description: For once, it was easy.

title: Akio Morita, Co-Founder of Sony and Japanese Business Leader, Dies at 78
description: Akio Morita, the co-founder of the Sony Corporation who personified Japan's rise from postwar rubble to industrial riches and became the unofficial ambassador of its business community to the world, died on Sunday in Tokyo. He was 78.

title: E-Planet Ceases Operations As Effort to Get Financing Fails
description: A technology company that was spun off in 1997 by the Interval Research Corporation, the Silicon Valley research laboratory financed by the Microsoft co-founder Paul Allen, ceased operation late last week after failing to find new financing.

title: A Glitch in Communication Scuttles a Pair of Favorites
description: Practitioners of bridge, chess, go, backgammon and other intellectual recreations normally run on parallel but separate tracks and never meet. They did meet, however, at the third Mind Sports Olympiad, in London in August. The bridge events were a triumph for a young Norwegian, Espen Erichsen, who won the pairs with Unal Durmus and the teams with Andrew Robson, Michael Courtney and D. Bakshi.

title: Natwest Is Said to Consider Big Asset Sale
description: Hoping to stave off a $34 billion hostile bid by the Bank of Scotland, National Westminster Bank P.L.C. is considering a plan to sell 5 billion [pounds], or $8.27 billion, in assets in an effort to remain independent, according to executives briefed on the plan.

title: When Parents Share a Bed With the Baby
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLITKIN, NATALIE W.
description: PLITKIN-Natalie W. Beloved and devoted wife of Henry J. Plitkin for 63 years; mother of Elizabeth Brinnitzer; and mother in-law of Bernard Brinnitzer. She was deeply loved by all three. Died October 2, 1999, after a long illness. Funeral Tuesday, 1:15 PM at ''The Riverside'' 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. Visiting hours Monday, 7-9 PM.

title: Dueling Bids Emerge for Sprint, 3d-Largest Long-Distance Carrier
description: A takeover battle for the Sprint Corporation, the nation's third-largest long-distance company, erupted over the weekend as two suitors emerged with competing offers, people close to the companies said.

title: 'Dutch' Presented Newsweek With an Unexpected Challenge
description: When Newsweek's editors won the exclusive rights to excerpt ''Dutch,'' Edmund Morris's biography of Ronald Reagan, they did not know exactly what they were getting. Not until the managing editor Jon Meacham was 50 pages into Edmund Morris's work did the penny drop. A just-the-facts-ma'am magazine had some fiction on its hands.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LENZNER, LAURA ADASKO
description: LENZNER-Laura Adasko. On October 3, 1999, at age 50. Beloved wife of Allan. Loving mother of Benjamin, Sam and David. Dear daughter of Mary Adasko and the late Herbert Isaac Adasko. Devoted sister of Hardy Adasko. Loving aunt to several nieces and nephews. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Wednesday, 11:30 AM. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Thoracic Oncology Service, Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital, 1275 York Avenue, New York, NY 10021.

title: TECHNOLOGY; Career Sites Gain Rapidly, Along With Job Hopping
description: A mere two years into his career on J. P. Morgan's high-technology trading floor on Wall Street, John F. Parker got the itch. ''I needed to make a move,'' he said. ''I needed new challenges.''

title: Unburdening the Third World
description: President Clinton made a dramatic and important announcement last Wednesday when he pledged to cancel the debt owed to Washington by the world's poorest nations, as long as they used the savings for health, education and other anti-poverty programs. His promise comes on top of an Administration pledge the week before to seek $1 billion for an initiative that would mainly retire poor nations' debts to international lenders. It is now up to Congress to provide the money, and other wealthy nations to match Mr. Clinton's commitment.

title: A Congressman's Lament on the State of Democracy
description: AFTER 30 years in Congress, David Obey is in the slough of despond.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUSHNER, SAM
description: KUSHNER-Sam. We mourn the passing of our long-time Senior Gabbai. Shiva at 530-D Grand St. #

title: A Scientist Rallies Allies For Besieged Art Museum
description: It took a physicist to galvanize many of New York City's most important cultural institutions to take a stand in the battle over the ''Sensation'' show at the Brooklyn Museum of Art.

title: Dysfunction Still in Huddle As Knicks Regroup in Camp
description: Almost the identical characters from last season's enchanted tale will assemble today when the Knicks open training camp in Charleston, S.C., just over three months after they climbed a magic beanstalk and followed a trail of bread crumbs to get to the National Basketball Association finals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, ROSE
description: COHEN-Rose. Of NYC, on Saturday, October 2, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Philip Cohen; mother of Victor of Potomac, MD, Annette Brody of NYC, and Joel of NYC. Also survived by six grandchildren Jill, Lori, Philip, and Wendy Cohen; David and Karen Brody and three great - grandchildren. Services Monday 10 AM at Schwartz Bros. Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Blvd at 76th Road, Forest Hills. Interment to follow at Beth David Cemetery.

title: Citing Oil Price, Schumer Urges Using Reserve
description: Citing steep rises in the prices of gasoline and home heating oil, Senator Charles E. Schumer called on the Clinton Administration yesterday to start selling oil from the United States' strategic oil reserves -- a store of hundreds of millions of gallons stockpiled for emergencies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOSTER, GLEN S.
description: FOSTER-Glen S. An Olympic medalist yachtsman, died peacefully on Friday, October 1, 1999, at Memorial Sloan-Kettering. He was 69 years old. Mr. Foster died of esophageal cancer. Mr. Foster attended the Fay School, Phillips Academy at Andover, MA, Brown University and Columbia University. Mr. Foster spent his career as a Specialist on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange as a Partner in Foster, Marks & Natoli. Mr. Foster sold his firm in 1994 to Spear, Leeds & Kellogg, where he continued his working career. A world class yachtsman, Mr. Foster represented the United States and won a Bronze Medal in the 1972 Olympic Games in Munich. In later years Mr. Foster competed in 8 meter, 6 meter, 5.5 meter and the Dragon Yacht classes, most recently winning the Scandinavian Gold Cup for the third time only two weeks ago in Torbole, Italy. He was a member of the New York Yacht Club, the Royal Yacht Squadron and the Imperial Poona Yacht Club, and an Honorary Member of the Sewanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club and Key Biscayne Yacht Club. He was a Member of the Board of Directors of the Herreshoff Museum/America's Cup Hall of Fame in Bristol, RI, the Acorn Foundation in New York City, the Afterguard of the New York Yacht Club Young America Challenge for the 2000 America's Cup matches in New Zealand. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, October 7, 1999, at 12 noon, at the Dana Chapel of Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, at 921 Madison Avenue at 73rd Street. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Fund for Renewal of Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, where Mr. Foster was a member, or to the Herreshoff Museum, P.O. Box 225, Bristol, RI. He is survived by his loving wife, Kay, and his mother, Margaret Arrott.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TENENBAUM, JEANNE
description: TENENBAUM-Jeanne. A memorial gathering will be held on Thursday, October 7, at 5:30PM at the Ethical Culture Society on West 68th Street and Central Park West.

A remarkable person who inspired us all by her character, independence and courage. Services Monday, October 4, 1999, at 11:15 AM, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and 76th Street, NYC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARISON, TED
description: ARISON-Ted. The American Committee for the Tel Aviv Foundation expresses profound sorrow at the passing of our Founder, original Chairman, leader and most generous donor, Ted Arison. Ted was a giant. Through his example, he brought many other supporters and donors as well. He did more for the Tel Aviv Foundation and the City of Tel Aviv-Jaffa than any other. Our heartfelt condolences go out to his beloved wife, Lin, and his son and American Committee Board Member, Micky Arison and his family, his daughter and generous supporter, Shari Arison Dorsman and her family, his sister Aviva Tamir and his niece, our dear friend Talia Glantz. American Committee for the Tel Aviv Foundation Uzi Zucker, Chairman Ira Riklis, President Shimon Topor, Sec./Treasurer Jeannie Gerzon, Exec. Director Ron Huldai, International Chairman and Mayor of Tel Aviv-Jaffa David Harnik, General Manager, Tel Aviv Foundation

title: Agents' Dismissals Signal New York's Fade-Out in Film Business

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOMAN, GEORGE F.
description: LOMAN-George F. Age 82, on October 2, 1999, of Darien, CT. Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Farrell Lines, Incorporated, since 1978, and member of the Board of Directors of the American Steamship Owners Mutual Protection & Indemnity Association, Maritime Association of the Port of New York & New Jersey, and India House, New York. He was a recipient of the United Seamen's Service 1998 Admiral of the Ocean Sea Award, member of the International Maritime Hall of Fame of the Maritime Association of the Port of New York & New Jersey, and recipient in 1999 of that association's first Humanitarian Award. He graduated Harvard in 1938 and received his law degree from Harvard Law School in 1942. He was a former Senior Partner of the Stamford, CT, law firm of Cummings & Lockwood. Among his many professional accomplishments, he was Connecticut State Trial Referee from 1983-1993, past President of the Connecticut Bar Association, former President of India House, Fellow of the American Bar Association, Life Member of the National Defense Transportation Association and Navy League of the U.S., and a former Director of the Darien, CT, Red Cross and Silvermine Guild of Artists. He enlisted in the U.S. Army as a private in 1942 and rose to the rank of Lt. Colonel. He participated in the D-Day Invasion of southern France in 1944 and later served in the U.S. Army Reserve until his retirement in 1970. He is survived by his wife, Mary Farrell Loman; daughter, Patricia Loman Dailey; and sons, John Farrell Loman and Peter Hadden Loman and 10 grandchildren, all of Darien, CT. Funeral arrangements are private. A memorial service will be held at 4 PM, on October 6, at the First Congregational Church of Darien, 14 Brookside Road, followed by a reception at the Wee Burn Country Club, 410 Hollow Tree Ridge Road, Darien. Contributions in honor of Mr. Loman may be sent to the Autism Society of America.

title: When Nothing Gets Between the Art and Its Viewer
description: Imagine two big orange cats nearly five feet high sitting on a long wooden table covered by a white embroidered cloth. Their eyes are a lurid blue, and they look, as cats often do, both mysterious and smug. They are linked by a golden chain, and around the neck of each is a golden oval brooch with an inscription. ''Fear,'' reads one. The other reads, ''Denial.''

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the News Watch column of Circuits on Thursday about a PricewaterhouseCoopers survey of Internet use cited one finding incorrectly. Nineteen percent of those surveyed this year said they would not be willing to make any purchases on line; in 1998, that number was 30 percent. Those percentages reflect only the respondents' attitudes, not whether they actually made purchases on line.

title: Hillary Clinton's Exploratory Run Is Both Low Profile and Low Risk
description: When Hillary Rodham Clinton was first asked about Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's attacks on an art exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum of Art, the First Lady said she did not have enough information about the dispute to offer an opinion. When Mrs. Clinton finally weighed in, she couched her position in cautious terms, saying simply that she agreed with Peter F. Vallone, the City Council Speaker, who had denounced Mr. Giuliani four days earlier on the museum issue.

title: A Body Part Returns As the Leading Lady
description: A mere three years ago, when Eve Ensler first sat in front of an audience at Here in the South Village and performed her one-woman show, ''The Vagina Monologues,'' she was an unknown quantity. Last night, when a return engagement of the show opened at the Westside Theater, she was a bona fide phenomenon, all because of a dozen or so short monologues about a body part. A body part that 30 years after the sexual revolution people are still a little embarrassed about naming aloud. Ms. Ensler has performed the show as far away as Jerusalem and Stockholm and as close to the American heartland as Oklahoma City. Famous women, including Susan Sarandon, Whoopi Goldberg and Glenn Close, have recited a monologue each at benefit performances.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMOLEN, ARTHUR E.
description: SMOLEN-Arthur E. Friends and family will greatly miss the special love and devotion of Arthur E. Smolen, born in Brooklyn, April 28, 1918. He was a devoted husband of 56 years to Selma, loving father to Ellen, devoted brother to Florence, caring uncle and great uncle to Carol, Andy, Michael, Jodie, Marcia and Amanda. He was a loyal and dependable friend to many. For more than 35 years, Arthur was a dedicated employee of Loews Corporation, where he was a Vice President. He was a hard working man who took great pride in his involvment in the success of this Fortune 500 company. Arthur proudly served in the U.S. Armed Forces during World War II for which he received the Purple Heart. He died October 2, 1999, of natural causes. The family will receive visitors at Riverside Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, Monday evening, October 4, from 7-9 PM. title: The High Court Returns
description: The exact contours of the new Supreme Court term that begins today are still taking shape. So far, the justices have agreed to hear only 44 cases -- far short of the 75 or so cases the Court is likely to decide before adjourning in June. Yet the sparse docket already contains a rich array of significant cases destined to transform, for better or worse, the legal landscape on issues of civil rights, campaign financing, tobacco regulation, the separation of church and state, and the relationship between the Federal Government and the states.

Fraikin last year had revenue of $450 million and is France's largest industrial vehicle leaser, Iveco said. Fraikin has nearly 30,000 vehicles in France, Britain, Belgium, the Netherlands, Spain and Luxembourg among 205 offices.
