title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCUS, PEARL
description: MARCUS-Pearl. On October 2, 1999, at the age of 102. Beloved wife of the late Moe. Dear aunt of many nieces, nephew, great-niece and great-nephews, and greatgreat-nieces and nephews. Commital service Tuesday, 2 PM, at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY

title: Golden Boy Stalked by a Phantom
description: With ''Pola X,'' a noisy epic swirl of breast-beating, hair-tearing angst and portentous symbolism, the 39-year-old director Leos Carax captures the dubious title of French cinema's reigning mad romantic. This sometimes intoxicating, often infuriating film about the frenzied downward spiral of a naive young writer in search of ultimate truth was adapted from Melville's 1852 novel ''Pierre, or the Ambiguities.''

title: Reviews/Fashion; In Milan, Innovation Is a Sometime Thing
description: Gianni Versace had a lot of inspired ideas like working within an ethos of rock-and-roll while living in an atmosphere of grandeur, with books and Renaissance masters on the walls. He constantly came up with styles that flaunted the atrocious taste of one world while preserving the ideals of the other. A rock starlet may have looked like a sinner in a gown with diamante bondage straps. But her couture drapes were straight out of the Greeks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RALL, DAVID, DR.
description: RALL-David, Dr. The members, staff and Board of The Environmental Defense Fund deeply mourn the loss of our friend and colleague, Dr. David Rall. Dr. Rall headed the National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences and served as U.S. Assistant Surgeon General for nineteen years. A longtime Environmental Defense Fund Board member and recognized pioneer of modern environmental medicine, Dr. Rall was a dedicated scientist, and tireless advocate for public health and a clean, safe environment. His life and work will always be an inspiration for medical and environmental professionals. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife, children, grandchildren and brother.

title: Anxieties Higher Than Test Scores
description: If you've noticed a rise in the anxiety level of high school students, take it as a sure sign that College Board examinations are here again. On Saturday half a million teen-agers will endure the standardized college-entrance test that may determine whether they will be accepted by the colleges of their dreams. Tonight's ''Frontline'' report looks into the origins and consequences of the much-debated three-hour multiple-choice tests of verbal and mathematical skills.

title: Pitching Aces Needed to Gain Upper Hand
description: So this is what the Mets and the Cincinnati Reds were playing for last night: the Mets for the right to face Randy Johnson, which they earned with a 5-0 victory; the Reds for the right to see Greg Maddux, Tom Glavine, John Smoltz and Kevin Millwood. Some right.

title: BOVIS IS SOLD
description: Abandoning its plan to sell shares of Bovis Group, its construction unit, on the London Stock Exchange, the Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Company sold Bovis to the Lend Lease Corporation, an Australian real estate development and financial services management concern, for $:285 million [pounds] in cash, or $471.8 million. The sale is part of a move by P.& O. to shed its ancillary businesses to refocus on its traditional concerns: cruises, ferries and ports. The company sold its Earls Court and Olympia exhibition operation on Friday for 183 million [pounds].

title: Denver Journal; In the Mile-High City, Football Fans Feel Low
description: The sun shone brightly here today, but a pall hung over the city nonetheless.

title: Study Finds a 7-Year Itch, and a 4-Year One
description: It is well known that nearly half of all marriages end in divorce. With that in mind, a psychology professor from Wright State University surveyed husbands and wives once a year over the first decade of their marriages to observe how marital quality changes over time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARISON, TED
description: ARISON-Ted. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) express profound regret at the loss of Ted Arison of Miami and Tel Aviv. Mr. Arison was a Technion Guardian who had reached the highest level of commitment to the Technion, the ATS and Israel. For his exemplary support of the Faculty of Computer Science, the Technion awarded him an Honorary Doctorate in 1999. We extend heartfelt condolences to his wife Lin and the entire Arison family. American Society for TechnionIsrael Institute of Technology Lawrence S. Jackier, President Irving A. Shepard, Chairman of the Board Melvyn H. Bloom Executive Vice President

title: Air Canada Deal Rumors Drive Shares Higher
description: Weekend news reports that Air Canada was close to signing up new investors including United Airlines, in an effort to thwart a hostile $1.8 billion takeover attempt by the Onex Corporation, created a flurry of interest in Air Canada shares today.

title: The Shock of the Natural; Works in Brooklyn Have a Long Tradition
description: Call them shocking, schlocky, ''sick stuff,'' profane, inane, puerile, gross, engrossing, brave, self-indulgent, profound or not worth the fluid they're pickled in, but the most ferociously debated art objects from the hand-wringing ''Sensation'' show at the Brooklyn Museum of Art have a long and hoary history behind them.

title: NEW FINANCIAL NEWSPAPER
description: The Brazilian media companies Globo and Folha are investing $50 million to create a business newspaper that will compete with Gazeta Mercantil, Brazil's leading business daily. Globo, Brazil's largest media company, and Folha, the publisher of Folha de S. Paulo, the country's largest-circulation newspaper, hope to start publishing the yet-to-be-named daily by the second quarter next year. The companies will have equal control of the new venture.

title: Hernandez Never Met an Argument He Didn't Like
description: Orlando Hernandez lived most of his life in Cuba, where opinions are not necessarily respected or welcomed and where, in some cases, they are grounds for imprisonment. But the fear of a dictator did not prevent Hernandez from developing into a fine debater.

title: When Nobel Mingles With Politics; Art From the Left
description: To the Editor:

title: The marketing implications of the bidding war for Sprint are the buzz of Madison Avenue.
description: LIKE the chatty teen-agers from ''The Telephone Song'' in ''Bye Bye Birdie,'' consultants and analysts were busy gabbing yesterday, in this instance sharing the 411, as the youngsters say now, on the advertising and marketing implications of the bidding war for Sprint, which was apparently won last night by MCI Worldcom Inc.

title: As Jakarta Hopes for a Peaceful Transition, Even a Street Rally Turns Polite
description: When Indonesia's highest legislative body last met, in November, the streets of this capital were stained with blood as students clashed with soldiers and the police.

title: A Success Story Unravels In Gunshots and Death; Murder Suspect Embodied Immigrant Hopes, But Some Say They Saw a Disturbing Side
description: Agustin Garcia was the American dream incarnate. With his sharply tailored suits and his black Jeep Cherokee, Mr. Garcia was proof to other Dominicans in Washington Heights that hard work and an education had their rewards.

title: Mets Fans' Ride: Lighting Candles and Reaching for Antacid
description: All the prayers to St. Anthony, the patron saint of miracles, paid off for Angela Frontera.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, MARIE GRIMALDI
description: KAPLAN-Marie Grimaldi of Chatham Twp., formerly of Oradell, N.J., Bayside, NY and Manhattan, on October 3, 1999. Wife of the late Richard W. Nollenberger and Milton A. Kaplan. Loving mother of Maria (Ria) Nolen of Chatham. Sister of the late Frances Grimaldi Halpin. Grandmother of Patrick McHale. A funeral Liturgy will be celebrated at St. Patrick's Church, 85 Washington Avenue, Chatham on Friday, October 8th, 1999 at 10:00 AM. Friends may call at the Wm. A. Bradley & Son Funeral Home, 345 Main Street (Rt. 124), Chatham, NJ, Thursday, October 7th, 1999 from 6:00-9:00 PM.

title: Too Much Medicine?
description: Lawsuits cost companies money, but so does the mere threat of lawsuits. That is what must be remembered in the debate over whether people should be allowed to sue their managed care companies. California just passed a law allowing patients to sue their health insurers, and Congress is debating the issue.

title: Corrections
description: A map yesterday with an article about the Barra da Tijuca neighborhood of Rio de Janeiro, where many of the city's newly rich people live, situated it incorrectly. It is in the southwest part of the city, not the northeast.

title: U.S. to Deport Saudi Suspect In a 1996 Terror Bombing
description: The Clinton Administration announced today that it had decided to deport to Saudi Arabia a suspect in the terrorist bombing there that killed 19 American airmen three years ago. It also said it had information concerning the possible involvement of Iranian officials in the attack.

title: Urgent Inspections Ordered For Japan's Nuclear Plants
description: Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi ordered emergency inspections today at all of Japan's nuclear-fuel treatment plants and reactors.

title: Fassel Holds a Secret: Who Will Start?
description: Jim Fassel has not made a decision about who will start at quarterback on Sunday when the Giants play the Cardinals in Arizona, but today he appeared to be leaning toward naming Kerry Collins to replace the beleaguered Kent Graham.

title: TEXAS INSTRUMENTS IS BUYING POWER TRENDS
description: Texas Instruments Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the privately held Power Trends, a maker of circuit board devices, for stock valued about $145 million. Texas Instruments, based in Dallas, said it would issue 1.68 million shares for the purchase, which it expects to close by the end of the year. Power Trends, based in Warrenville, Ill., will become a unit of Texas Instruments. Shares of Texas Instruments rose $4.40625 each, to $90.4375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: When 'Silent Strokes' Evoke Depression
description: A ''silent stroke'' has none of the warning signs of a larger stroke: severe headaches, dizziness, loss of motor skills. Often victims do not realize they have had strokes. As small blood vessels in the brain become blocked or ruptured, victims may experience memory loss, difficulty with concentration or trouble walking.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRESEMANN, JOACHIM
description: STRESEMANN-Joachim. Age 92. Died on October 3, 1999 in New York City. He was the son of Gustav Stresemann, who served as Chancellor and Foreign Minister of Germany during the Weimar Republic, and Kaete Stresemann. After studying law and economics in Germany and England he moved to New York where he was with Chase Manhattan Bank. An excellent pianist, he continued his interest in music and art and served on the Boards of the Bruno Walter Foundation, the Cosmopolitan Arts Foundation and others, a generous friend to many. He is survived by the family of his older brother, Wolfgang Stresemann, who was the General Manager of the Berlin Philharmonics for 22 years and died in 1998 in Berlin, Germany.

title: In a Front-Line Chechen Village: Missiles, Bombs and Resistance
description: Local men armed with Kalashnikov rifles moved quietly through the woods on the edge of this Chechen village today. Russian forces were just 500 yards away, across the field and behind a line of trees, they said.

title: Prospecting for Diamonds on the Outer Planets
description: Neptune in the sky with diamonds. And, perhaps, Uranus and other giant gas planets, too.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JOHANSMEYER, EDNA NILSSON
description: JOHANSMEYER-Edna Nilsson. (Dec. 30, 1920-Oct. 11, 1977) Bernhard Frederik (Jan. 26, 1915Oct. 5, 1979). Beloved parents, remembered vividly and missed profoundly.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: A Spacecraft Lost to the Metric System
description: To the Editor:

title: No Indictment Against Lawyer Held in Theft
description: A grand jury has found no basis for bringing criminal charges against a Brooklyn prosecutor who was arrested in July after a court officer said he saw her stealing a wallet from a handbag in a Brooklyn courtroom.

title: Detecting Colon Cancer
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, SUSANNE
description: SHAPIRO-Susanne. Beloved wife of the late Alvin. Wonderful mother of Michael, Steven and Laura. Dear sister of Carol, Iris and Linda. devoted grandmother of Alex, Matthew and Randolph. Dearest mother-in-law of Emily, Barbara and Richard. Sister-in-law of Mickey and Bernie. A remarkable woman who was deeply loved. We will miss you so much. Services Tuesday, 12:15PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Mattel Warns of Yet Another Profit Shortfall
description: In the latest development at the embattled Mattel Inc., one that could lead to the downfall of its chief executive, the toy maker warned investors yesterday that its third-quarter profit would fall by as much as 55 percent because of sharply lower revenue at its recently acquired Learning Company division.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PASHMAN, MORRIS
description: PASHMAN-Morris of Clifton, NJ on October 3, 1999, age 87. Beloved Husband of the late Tema L. nee Wolfe. Devoted Father of Linda (Richard) Blair-McCrohan, & Louis (Linda) Pashman. Loving grandfather of Andrew Blair, Scott Blair, Daniel Pashman, and Howard Pashmen. Great-grandfather to Jennifer Blair, Michael Blair and Brandon Blair. Services will be held at Jewish Memorial Chapel, 841 Allwood Rd., Clifton, NJ October 5, at 10:30 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOWMAN, GEORGE F.
description: LOWMAN-George F. Age 82, on October 2, 1999, of Darien, CT. Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Farrell Lines, Incorporated, since 1978, and member of the Board of Directors of the American Steamship Owners Mutual Protection & Indemnity Association, Maritime Association of the Port of New York & New Jersey, and India House, New York. He was a recipient of the United Seamen's Service 1998 Admiral of the Ocean Sea Award, member of the International Maritime Hall of Fame of the Maritime Association of the Port of New York & New Jersey, and recipient in 1999 of that association's first Humanitarian Award. He graduated Harvard in 1938 and received his law degree from Harvard Law School in 1942. He was a former Senior Partner of the Stamford, CT, law firm of Cummings & Lockwood. Among his many professional accomplishments, he was Connecticut State Trial Referee from 1983-1993, past President of the Connecticut Bar Association, former President of India House, Fellow of the American Bar Association, Life Member of the National Defense Transportation Association and Navy League of the U.S., and a former Director of the Darien, CT, Red Cross and Silvermine Guild of Artists. He enlisted in the U.S. Army as a private in 1942 and rose to the rank of Lt. Colonel. He participated in the D-Day Invasion of southern France in 1944 and later served in the U.S. Army Reserve until his retirement in 1970. He is survived by his wife, Mary Farrell Lowman; daughter, Patricia Lowman Dailey; and sons, John Farrell Lowman and Peter Hadden Lowman and 10 grandchildren, all of Darien, Ct., and brother Albert Henry Lowman of New Canaan, Ct. Funeral arrangements are private. A memorial service will be held at 4 PM, on October 6, at the First Congregational Church of Darien, 14 Brookside Road, followed by a reception at the Wee Burn Country Club, 410 Hollow Tree Ridge Road, Darien. Contributions in honor of Mr. Lowman may be sent to the Autism Society of America or the United Seamen's Service.

title: NOTEBOOK
description: O'Neill Takes Batting Practice

title: Making a Cause Out of Bad Art
description: Countless articles have been written, for reasons all too well known, about the Brooklyn Museum of Art's exhibition ''Sensation'' -- exponentially, perhaps, more than the show deserves. I do feel, however, that too many articles missed what I view as a truly important point, and that I should not remain silent any further.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODHEIM, ROBERT
description: BRODHEIM-Robert. On October 4, 1999. Beloved husband of Sonja. Services Wednesday 12:45PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Interment Knollwood Park Cemetery.

title: Editor of the Reagan Book Overcame Qualms
description: On the night that Edmund Morris first shared his eureka moment with the editor of his long-awaited Ronald Reagan biography, Robert Loomis suffered a rare but severe attack of the literary shakes.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Wary on Plastics
description: To the Editor:

title: Drug Buying On the Web? Be Careful, Study Says
description: People who order prescription drugs via the Internet may be paying more than they would at a drugstore and taking chances with their health, researchers at the University of Pennsylvania Medical School report.

title: Wild, Rolling and Galloping Yet Controlled
description: The music Ben Allison writes for his octet, Medicine Wheel, is fast-moving and carefully put together, with echoes of all that young jazz musicians are listening to these days: techno, funk, Ellington, North African music and so on. But what distinguishes Mr. Allison's mixtures is that they aren't lumpy, shallow demonstrations of A coexisting with B; he uses all kinds of felicitous arranging devices to make the ensemble cohere, harmonies and rhythms and panning effects and changes in texture that run through the band like waves.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELLMAN, CEIL
description: GELLMAN-Ceil. Died October 3, 1999 in Miami, Florida. Beloved mother of sons Melvin & Jerome Gellman and daughter Elaine Rabinowitz. Also survived by eight grandchildren and ten greatgrandchildren. Services Wednesday 11:30 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, New York.

title: Vibe/Spin Ventures Faces Possible Sale
description: Miller Publishing Group has retained Salomon Smith Barney to explore a possible sale of Vibe/Spin Ventures L.L.C., the publisher of the music-and-culture magazines Spin, Vibe and Blaze.

title: A Black Cloud Over Blue Cohosh
description: Blue cohosh, an herbal dietary supplement that has long been used by midwives and American Indians to induce labor and is sold over the counter as a menstrual remedy, may be dangerous for women of childbearing age, a new study suggests.

title: For Franco, It's a Toast At Twilight
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 4 -- John Franco did his best to tune out the circumstances. He screened his calls, watched television and tried to relax, trying most of all not to think about how close he was to finally making the playoffs.

title: Pacific Exchange Approves Issuing Shares
description: Members of the Pacific Exchange approved a plan today to convert their stock-trading floors into a for-profit subsidiary in an attempt to keep the money-losing operation alive.

title: When Nobel Mingles With Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMOLEN, ARTHUR
description: SMOLEN-Arthur. The counselors of the Service Corps of Retired Executives note with sadness the passing of our esteemed colleague. As a volunteer, he gave the benefit of his business experience and wisdom to many aspiring business clients. He will be sorely missed.

title: Bernard Buffet, French Painter, Dies at 71
description: Bernard Buffet, a French painter whose barren landscapes, harsh still lifes, gaunt religious scenes and sad circus clowns brought him early fame and fortune but little enduring critical esteem, died yesterday at his home in the Var region of southern France. He was 71.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUNNINGHAM, JOHN P.
description: CUNNINGHAM-John P. On October 4, 1999 at age 83. Proud retired Fire Lieutenant with 27 years of service, also Secretary of United Retired Firefighters Association. Loving husband of Anne. Dear father of William C., Jaqueline Santora, Margery McKechnie and Anne Taylor. Also survived by three grandchildren and three great grandchildren. Cremation to be held privately. Memorial mass to be announced.

title: Graf to Be Honored At Her Retirement
description: Steffi Graf, whose abrupt decision to retire in August surprised the tennis world, will be appearing at the year-end Chase Championships at Madison Square Garden next month after all, but not as one of the 16 invited singles players.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the events calendar of the Westchester section on Sunday for appearances by Lady Bird Johnson at Westchester Community College in Valhalla misstated two dates. Mrs. Johnson will attend the dedication of a demonstration garden to her at the Native Plant Center this Friday (not Saturday) at 10:30 A.M. and a wildflower symposium on Saturday (not this Sunday) from 8:30 A.M. to 1 P.M.

title: A Long Season's Journey Into Night
description: Regardless of the outcome of last night's Mets-Reds game, mass quantities of baseball fans tonight and tomorrow night will be watching Bud Selig's productions of ''The Late Show'' when ESPN carries 11 P.M. Eastern games featuring the Mets or Houston in Arizona.

title: Buffalo Knocks Miami From Unbeaten Ranks
description: The Buffalo Bills knocked the Miami Dolphins off the unbeaten shelf tonight with an opportunistic, hard-hitting defense.

title: The Final Four, Finally
description: Here is a scouting report on the National League division series, prepared by Murray Chass.

title: Giuliani and Safir Defend the Police in Fatal Shooting of a Hammer-Wielding Man
description: In a string of news conferences yesterday, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Police Commissioner Howard Safir defended the Police Department's handling of the fatal shooting of a hammer-wielding, mentally ill Brooklyn man, while the man's family criticized what it described as false statements made by city officials immediately after the August shooting.

title: Jerald C. Brauer, 78, Theologian and Divinity School Dean
description: Jerald C. Brauer, who as dean of the University of Chicago's Divinity School helped build the institution into an internationally known center for the study of theology, died on Sept. 26 at his home in Chicago.

title: Japan's Nuclear Accident
description: To the Editor:

title: On Baseball; After 11 Years, a Real Mets Celebration
description: Now the Mets had something to celebrate. Now they could jump up and down and embrace each other, look as foolish as they wanted to tonight, soak each other with champagne, get smashed. For a few hours at least.

title: When Good Intentions Backfire and Create Food Aversions
description: Do you think your toddler or preschooler is living on thin air? Has mealtime become a battle of wills? How many of these admonitions are familiar to you?

title: Museum Says Giuliani Knew of Show in July and Was Silent
description: More than two months before Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani unexpectedly denounced as ''sick stuff'' a show of young British artists at the Brooklyn Museum of Art and ordered a cutoff of city financing, the Mayor and other top city officials were briefed about the exhibition and raised no objections, the museum's director, Arnold L. Lehman, said in court papers filed yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GASTON, VICTOR HOWARD, SR.
description: GASTON-Victor Howard, Sr. Died September 20, 1999 at age 73 in Wilson, NC. Memorial service and reception November 14, 3:00 PM, Riverdale Presbyterian Church, 4763 Henry Hudson Parkway West, Bronx, New York.

title: Corrections
description: An artist's rendering in some copies on Thursday with an article about the award of a contract to build a 15-story addition to the Federal courthouse in Brooklyn was published in error. It showed a planned 32-story state courthouse in Brooklyn.

title: Schwab to Offer Customers After-Hours Trading Session
description: The crowd at the after-hours trading post continues to grow, with Charles Schwab & Company, the largest on-line broker, announcing yesterday that it will begin offering a late stock-trading session to its on-line retail and investment advisory customers in November.

title: MORE STORES FOR SEARS CANADA
description: The No. 2 department store chain in Canada, Sears Canada Inc., has acquired large downtown stores in five Canadian cities from the T. Eaton Company for 30 million Canadian dollars, or $20 million, and said it would keep running them under the Eaton's banner. The purchase of the stores, including a flagship site in Toronto, adds to the 13 mostly suburban Eaton sites that Sears Canada, a unit of Sears, Roebuck & Company, bought two weeks ago for 50 million Canadian dollars. Eaton, once Canada's most respected retailer, is insolvent. Sears Canada said the purchases would provide jobs for about 3,500 of Eaton's 13,000 employees.

title: Reviews/Fashion; A Touch of Evil on the Paris Runways
description: Visions of the Baader-Meinhof gang, parasols brimming with feathers, birds chirping over the sound system -- what else can it mean except that the French collections have begun.

title: Russia Is No NATO
description: To the Editor:

title: Stone's Throw From Disaster In the Field
description: Chuck Knoblauch says he does not have distressing visions of a grounder bounding to him at second base in the post-season and having something go terribly awry after he fields it. Knoblauch cannot think that he may throw the ball wildly to first base, as he has done so many times before. He will not think that way. Or, at least, that is what Knoblauch tells himself.

title: Energy Chief Sees Clear Path For Reactor, But Seeks Study
description: Energy Secretary Bill Richardson said today that a Federal environmental review has found no major hurdle to reopening a nuclear reactor at Brookhaven National Laboratory here, despite local opposition. The reactor was closed in 1997 after the discovery that a storage tank had leaked radioactive tritium into the ground water for at least 12 years.

title: The Case of a Lawyer And His Judicial Sting
description: PERSONAL INJURIES

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRIGERSON, LOWELL, MD
description: PRIGERSON-Lowell, MD, on October 2, 1999 after a valiant fight against cancer. Loving husband of Joyce, adored father of Jill, Holly, and Eve, caring son of Pauline and brother of Jay, devoted grandfather of Caroline, Rebecca, Johanna, Abigail, Zachary, Samantha and Ethan, and dedicated physician. Remembered with love, honor, and devotion by family, friends and all touched by his care. Services to be held at Morris Funeral home in Dix Hills, New York at 12:30 on Tuesday, October 5.

title: Plant Owner Admits Toxic Waste Leaked
description: The owner of a marine-paint manufacturing plant admitted yesterday that he had poured toxic waste into leaky underground storage tanks near houses and a day care center in Lakewood, officials said.

title: A Critical Nuclear Moment
description: After a two-year delay, the Senate is now racing toward a vote next week on ratifying a critically important arms control treaty. Ratification is by no means assured. But approval of the nuclear test ban treaty, which prohibits participating countries from conducting nuclear weapons tests, is manifestly in the best interests of the United States. Washington neither plans nor needs to conduct any further tests. The treaty's main effect would be to halt the programs of other countries. Since no new nuclear weapons can be reliably developed without testing, ratification of the treaty by enough countries would freeze the nuclear weapons race worldwide.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LENZNER, LAURA ADASKO
description: LENZNER-Laura Adasko. On October 3, 1999, at age 50. Beloved wife of Allan. Loving mother of Benjamin, Sam and David. Dear daughter of Mary Adasko and the late Herbert Isaac Adasko. Devoted sister of Hardy Adasko. Loving aunt to several nieces and nephews. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Wednesday, 11:30 AM. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Thoracic Oncology Service, Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital, 1275 York Avenue, New York, NY 10021.

title: Go On, Take a Chance on Love. It's Not Only Human.
description: In ''The Faculty,'' last year's film about high school students whose bodies are taken over by aliens, a football hero who turns surly is asked whether he has also turned extraterrestrial. His perfect comeback: ''I'm not an alien, I'm discontent.'' The script was written by Kevin Williamson, the creator of the television hit ''Dawson's Creek,'' but he is not the only writer to take the phrase teen-age alienation literally.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OHRINGER, MILTON H.
description: OHRINGER-Milton H. October 3, 1999. Age 86. Devoted husband of Ray B. Ohringer. Devoted husband and beloved brother-in-law, uncle and great-uncle. Services, 12:45, Thursday, October 7 at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. & Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in memory of Mr. Ohringer to The N.T.I.D. Foundation, 52 Lomb Memorial Dr., Rochester, NY 14623-5604, attention: Michael J. Catillaz.

title: Kean, Ex-Governor, Won't Seek Senate Seat
description: Former Gov. Thomas H. Kean, viewed by some as the strongest Republican contender for the United States Senate since Gov. Christine Todd Whitman dropped out of the race, said yesterday that he would not seek the nomination, either.

title: A Spacecraft Lost to the Metric System
description: To the Editor:

title: Respecting Your Elders
description: To the Editor:

title: South Korea to Back More Daewoo Debt
description: Alarmed by the possibility of a new financial crisis caused by the Daewoo group's near-collapse, the Government said today that it would inject $16.5 billion into a fund created to purchase debts of the insolvent conglomerate that are held by South Korea's fragile investment trust companies.

title: Cellular Pioneer Weighs Taking Big Stake in Iridium
description: Craig O. McCaw, the cellular telephone pioneer, is considering taking a large stake in Iridium L.L.C., the troubled satellite telephone venture that filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy in August, according to people close to the negotiations.

title: For Single Parents, One Less Worry
description: Single mothers have been stereotyped, politicized and vilified, but a new Cornell study of young children offers them some comforting news: in and of itself, single parenthood seems to have no effect on how a child does in school.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPITZNAGEL, YVONNE A. (NEE ALEXANDER)
description: SPITZNAGEL-Yvonne A. (nee Alexander). On Sunday, October 3, 1999. Of Summit and Loveladies, NJ. Wife of John T. Spitznagel. Mother of Yvonne T. and John T. Spitznagel, Jr. Daughter of Teresa and the late Louis Alexander. Sister of Eugene R. and the late Louis R. Alexander. Funeral mass 10:30 AM Wednesday at St. Teresa of Avila Church, Summit. Visiting at Brough's Funeral Home, 535 Springfield Ave., Summit, NJ, 2-4 and 7-9:00 PM Tuesday. Donations may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Scientists Unmask Diet Myth: Willpower
description: A thin person, the kind who has always been thin, is confronted by a chocolate cake with dark fudge icing and chopped pecans. Unmoved, he goes about his business as if nothing has happened.

title: A Closer Look at the Busch Case
description: The story of Gidone Busch, a crazed, hammer-wielding man who was killed by police this summer in Brooklyn, has always raised uncomfortable questions. With his menacing history and his erratic behavior the week of the incident, Mr. Busch had much in common with the many mentally ill in this city who often find little relief in the available health care system. Too often, this legion wanders the streets, eventually ending up in the nearest hospital or jail. In Mr. Busch's case, the hammer, which had apparently been transformed into a religious artifact somewhere in his raging mind, became a final provocation that drew the deadly police fire that night in Borough Park.

title: A Cloud Lifts, and Yankees Just Look to Add to Success
description: The Yankees practiced yesterday under a sky of cast-iron gray, a gloom that fairly reflected their collective mood through much of the 1999 season. They won a league-high 98 games and will open the playoffs today at Yankee Stadium against the Texas Rangers in the three-of-five-game division series. But it has been a hard year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPENCER, MARIAN
description: SPENCER-Marian. The Board of Directors of ARC, Fort Washington Senior Center, on behalf of the seniors and staff, mourn the passing of their dedicated Director. We extend sincere condolences to her family and friends. A Memorial Service will be held Friday October 8, 1999 at 11:30 A.M. at ARC, 21 Wadsworth Avenue. Donations may be made to ARC, Fort Washington Senior Center.

title: State Farm Is Told to Pay Policyholders $456 Million in Auto-Parts Case
description: An Illinois jury ruled yesterday that State Farm, the nation's largest auto insurer, had breached its contract with policyholders by requiring body shops to use lower-priced generic parts for crash repairs, rather than parts made by auto manufacturers.

title: With Sport Utility Vehicles More Popular, Overall Automobile Fuel Economy Continues to Fall
description: The average fuel economy of new vehicles fell to 23.8 miles per gallon in the 1999 model year, the lowest level since 1980, as Americans continued to shift from cars to less fuel-efficient light trucks, particularly sport utility vehicles, the Environmental Protection Agency has concluded in a new report.

title: Ethnic Issue Lying in Wait In Senate Race
description: HILLARY RODHAM CLINTON is visiting Warsaw today (the one in Poland, not the town that she surely knows from her acute listening is in upstate New York).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKELSTEIN, HAROLD
description: FINKELSTEIN-Harold. Beloved husband of Ethel. Loving father of Marc and Carol and Patti and Kevin Teamkin. Devoted brother of Martin and Elaine Koeppel and Alma and Sam Rosenblum. Cherished grandfather of Liza and Michael Ball, Kim and Craig Weiner, Jordan Finkelstein, and Rachel and Hayley Teamkin. Services ''Boulevard - Riverside,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, at 9:30 AM, Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAWLESS, JOHN M.
description: LAWLESS-John M., of NYC and Phoenicia, NY, on October 2nd, 1999. Beloved husband of Elinor. Loving father of Elinor Lawless Ringer and John M. Lawless, Jr. He had a distinguished career as an attorney with the Appellate Division, 1st Department, of the Supreme Court of the State of New York until his retirement in 1976. A memorial celebration of his life will be announced at a later date.

title: Blood Shortage: Answers Scarce, Too
description: Early last month, officials at the Hoxworth Blood Center in Cincinnati took a look at the supply figures coming in and reluctantly reached an inescapable conclusion: it was time for another emergency blood appeal.

title: PALM TO PALM COMBAT
description: Psion P.L.C. of Britain said it would introduce a new hand-held electronic organizer this month, offering Internet access through a mobile phone or wireless modem and linked to a free Internet-service provider. Psion is Europe's biggest palmtop producer but has not dented the supremacy of the 3Com Corporation's Palm series in the United States. The company said its new product, the Revo, would sell for around $500.

title: Lessons to Apply In Mosquito War
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN SLIDES. The yen weakened after a Bank of Japan survey suggested that businesses were not planning to spend enough to sustain economic growth. In New York, the dollar settled at 106.23 yen, up from 104.96.

title: A Car-Free Midtown
description: To the Editor:

title: Using Music as a Canvas for Choreography
description: Always a major showcase on the dance scene, the International New Dance Festival here has lived up to its name since 1985. This year, the accent is on emerging African choreographers who show a less traditional side than some might expect. But this focus does not preclude appearances by some of Europe's big-time experimentalists.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRIFFITHS, DAN
description: GRIFFITHS-Dan. The New York University Community mourns the passing of the long-time former Dean of its School of Education. Few undertakings are as profoundly important to our society as the training of educators, and Dean Griffiths devoted his life work to this mission. He will be remembered as an excellent educator, a distinguished researcher, the accomplished author of many books and articles, a proud contributor and advisor to many public boards and committees in the field of education, a highly regarded member of this institution, and a good friend. He will be missed. L. Jay Oliva, President Martin Lipton, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: CONCENTRIC NETWORK TO BUY INTERNET HOST
description: The Concentric Network Corporation said yesterday it planned to buy 9 Net Avenue Inc., an Internet host, for $54 million in cash and shares. Concentric said the acquisition of 9 Net Avenue of Secaucus, N.J., gives it more distribution channels. Concentric, which sells electronic business products, posted revenue of $109.8 million for the last 12 months. The company, based in San Jose, Calif., said it believed it would be the second-largest Web hosting provider when the purchase is completed this month.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Russia has enormous power, hundreds of times more than we have. But we have spirit, we believe in independence and in Allah. They do not believe in anything, not in God or anything.''

title: INTRAWARE BUYING 2 CONCERNS TO WIDEN ON-LINE SERVICES
description: Intraware Inc., which helps its corporate customers research and purchase software over the Internet, agreed yesterday to acquire the closely held Bitsource Inc. and Internet Image Inc. for about $48 million to expand its on-line services. Intraware will pay $11 million in cash and stock for Bitsource, which has about 28 employees, and $37 million in cash and stock for Internet Image, based in Fremont, Calif. The addition of Bitsource, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., will enable Intraware's clients to manage their software licenses on line, while Internet Image will enable customers to distribute upgraded software to their computers. Intraware shares fell $1.5625, to $24.3125.

title: Weicker Cool to Reform Bid
description: Lowell P. Weicker Jr., the former Governor of Connecticut, said today that he did not plan to seek the Reform Party nomination for President, and associates said he instead might endorse former Senator Bill Bradley.

title: Radio City, With Face Lift, Reopens
description: After a face lift that cost $70 million -- double the original estimates -- and left the stage dark for seven months, Radio City Music Hall reopened last night in a blaze of lights and celebrity hoopla befitting one of New York City's more enduring show-business icons.

title: Will Dam-Busting Save Salmon? Maybe Not
description: The big hydroelectric dam sits deep in a valley framed by softly rounded, grass-covered mountains that look from a distance as if they have been sanded down and then covered with beige and blond velvet. Great expanses of sun-dappled blue water, more reservoir or lake than river, stretch above and below the concrete-and-earth barrier. That is part of the problem.

title: Detecting Colon Cancer
description: To the Editor:

title: GERMAN WIRELESS STAKE SOLD
description: Europe's second-largest phone company, France Telecom S.A., agreed to buy a 17.2 percent stake in the German wireless company E-Plus Mobilfunk G.m.b.H. for $1.86 billion in cash to give it a foothold in Europe's biggest wireless market. France Telecom bought the stake from Vodafone Airtouch P.L.C. and will seek to buy the rest of the company from its three other shareholders. E-Plus is Germany's third-largest mobile company, with three million subscribers.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MCI Worldcom to Acquire Sprint in a $108 Billion Deal

title: The Mets Eliminate Cincinnati, The Doubts and the Frustration
description: The two weeks seem like a season in miniature now, full of doubt and exhilaration, replete with team meetings and lineup shuffles, a collapse that nearly swallowed their year before they revived last weekend in three games of frenetic intensity at Shea Stadium.

title: Dramatic Fervor In Spite of a Cold
description: A chorus of moans from a full house at the Metropolitan Opera greeted the announcement by the general manager, Joseph Volpe, prior to the performance of Verdi's ''Otello'' that Placido Domingo had been suffering with a bad cold. But, Mr. Volpe added, Mr. Domingo had agreed to sing the title role anyway, although ''he asks for your indulgence.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Metro Business; Appliance Seller Cuts Jobs
description: Tops Appliance City, a retailer of home appliances and consumer electronics in New York and New Jersey, has announced it is cutting an unspecified number of jobs and focusing its sales strategy by discontinuing sales of personal computers and small electronics in favor of more major appliances, housewares, kitchen cabinets and counter tops.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PACIFIC DUNLOP LTD., Melbourne, Australia, said its Ansell rubber and latex unit had agreed to acquire Johnson & Johnson Medical's worldwide medical glove business for $98 million.

title: Austrian Right's Gains Upset Mainly Foreigners
description: As foreign newspapers suggesting that Austria was only steps away from pushing a Nazi into power appeared on Vienna's streets, Austrians seemed a bit irritated by the fuss today, complaining that the foreigners were inflating the danger and pointing out that the elections held on Sunday were still too close to call.

title: Public Interests; Pumped-Up Politics
description: It is an absolute rule of modern politics that women will not vote for men who look as if they're going to yell at them. Both the major parties have taken this to heart, and as a result we have a crop of Presidential candidates who are desperate to show they know how to get along, to play nice, to work well with others. No Newt clones need apply.

title: CROATIAN PHONE STAKE SOLD
description: The Croatian Government accepted Deutsche Telekom's $850 million bid for a 35 percent stake in Hrvatske Telekomunikacije, the former state telecommunications monopoly. It rejected a $641 million bid from a consortium of Telia of Sweden and Telenor of Norway.

title: Federal Courts' Power in Death Penalty Cases Is Reviewed
description: With Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg in her accustomed seat, the Supreme Court opened its new term today by hearing arguments in a Virginia death penalty case that could define the authority of Federal judges to overturn erroneous convictions and sentences issued by the state courts.

title: NBC Buys Rights to Televise the Triple Crown, Long Held by ABC
description: NBC Sports broke ABC's long grip on the Triple Crown thoroughbred races yesterday by buying their television rights for five years starting in 2001.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, LILLIAN
description: STERN-Lillian. We mourn the loss of our esteemed member and extend heartfelt condolences to her family. Temple Israel of Great Neck George N. Abrahams, President

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Other Photo Ops Come With Fame

title: Top Democratic Fund-Raiser Resigns
description: Beth Dozoretz, the finance chairwoman of the Democratic National Committee, has resigned as the Democratic Party's chief fund-raiser.

title: Tom Joe, 64, Policy Maker On Poverty
description: Tom Joe, an expert on Government antipoverty programs and a recipient in 1986 of the MacArthur Fellows award, died on Saturday at his home in Arlington, Va.

title: Sports of The Times; 1,704 Games Later, Valentine Tastes Champagne
description: HE had felt champagne trickle down his face, back before there were frown lines on it. It was minor league champagne then, for championships won in the training grounds of baseball.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FORMAN, SIDNEY
description: FORMAN-Sidney. With profound feelings of sorrow, we mark this first anniversary without you. Your wisdom and guidance will stay with us forever. You are sadly missed. Your children, Paula, Marsha, Mitchell, Arthur, Grandchildren, Great-grandchildren.

title: Editorial Observer; In Describing Health Care Plans, Less is More
description: What is the difference between a policy that promises to cover 100 percent of Americans for medical costs and a policy that covers 95 percent of them? About 1,285 pages.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   WESTERMAN, NELLIE
description: WESTERMAN-Nellie. October 5. With all our love, Barney and Jacki

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STANKO, MICHAEL L.
description: STANKO-Michael L., Chief Technology Officer with the law firm of Pillsbury Madison & Sutro in San Francisco, passed away quietly on September 30, in San Francisco, California of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. He was a pioneer in computer automation and paperless data storage, connecting large law firms between different cities and countries. Prior to joining Pillsbury, he was the Director of Information Systems with the law firms of Latham & Watkins and Paul, Hastings, Janofsky and Walker, both in Los Angeles. He was the author of numerous articles on legal technology, as well as a regular presenter at various Bar Associations and legal technology conferences. The childhood resident of Westbrook, Connecticut. He attended Xavier High School in Middletown, Connecticut and Boston College in Newton Massachusetts. He was the son of the late Michael J. Stanko. He is survived by his mother Joan G. Stanko of Westbrook, Connecticut, sisters and brothers-in-law Katherine and Oiver Connolly of Tullamore, Ireland, and Louise and Kenneth White of Avon, Connecticut. He also leaves nephews Michael, Alan and Kevin Connolly and K.R. White, and nieces Claire Connolly and Danielle White. A memorial service will be held Tuesday, October 5, 1999, 11:00 AM at the Holy Family Church in Glendale, California. Contributions in his memory may be made to Xavier High School, Middletown, Connecticut.

title: MCI TO BUY SPRINT IN SWAP OF STOCK FOR $108 BILLION
description: MCI Worldcom Inc., the nation's second-largest long-distance telephone company, has agreed to acquire the Sprint Corporation in a stock swap valued at $108 billion, people close to the talks said yesterday. The boards of both companies approved the merger last night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, ROSE
description: GOLDSTEIN-Rose. Age 96, in Delray Beach, FL. Beloved wife of the late Jonathan Goldstein, loving mother of Marsha Ozer and mother-in-law of Martin Ozer, devoted mother of Ivy and Craig Zuckerman, Tracey and Scott Schweber, Jennifer and Michael Korten and Jeffrey Ozer. Proud great-grandmother of Sam, Jake, Emily and Henry. Her family will cherish the memory of a warm, sweet and compassionate person who leaves a legacy of love, caring and family devotion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RANKIN, JAMES F.
description: RANKIN-James F. Age 59, died Saturday, October 2, 1999. He is survived by his wife Linda, son Robert & daugther-in-law Shivaunn, daughter Jami, his mother Dorothy & granddaughter Darian. Services to be held at St. Aedan's Catholic Church, Pearl River, New York on Tuesday, October 5, at 10:30 AM. Donations can be made to the Don Macbeth Memorial Jockey Fund, P.O. Box 18470, Encino, CA. 91416. For information please contact Assumma Shankey Funeral Home in Pearl River, NY.

title: NOVACARE SELLING OUTPATIENT OPERATIONS
description: Novacare Inc. agreed yesterday to sell its outpatient physical rehabilitation and occupational health operations to the closely held Select Medical Corporation for about $155 million. Novacare said the agreement also calls for Select Medical to assume $45 million of debt. Select Medical, based in Mechanicsburg, Pa., will operate more than 40 long-term acute-care hospitals and more than 700 outpatient rehabilitation clinics in North America after the deal, Nova Care said. Novacare, a physical rehabilitation company based in King of Prussia, Pa., had revenue of $1.5 billion for the fiscal year ended June 30.

title: Iomega Sees Quarterly Loss
description: The Iomega Corporation, maker of the Zip storage drive for personal computers, said today that it would lay off about 140 workers and take a $25 million to $30 million charge. Iomega said it expected about $20 million of the charge to be taken in the third quarter and the remainder in the fourth quarter. The company expects to report a third-quarter pretax loss of $5 million, excluding the charge. Revenue for the quarter is expected to be about $349 million. The company said it would stop production at its plant in Avranches, France, where disks that store computer data are made.

title: Sports of The Times; Dent Sees Yankees Differently Now
description: INSIDE the Texas Rangers' clubhouse yesterday afternoon, a man who haunts Boston as if he were the Babe himself took a moment from positive projections of a series not yet played to reflect on a proud and irrefutable past. Told he was recently spotted on the Classic Sports Network making another glorious trip around the Fenway Park bases, Bucky Dent flashed happily back to the defining swing of his professional life.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLITKIN, NATALIE W.
description: PLITKIN-Natalie W. Beloved and devoted wife of Henry J. Plitkin for 63 years; mother of Elizabeth Brinnitzer; and mother in-law of Bernard Brinnitzer. She was deeply loved by all three. Died October 2, 1999, after a long illness. Funeral Tuesday, 1:15 PM at ''The Riverside'' 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. Visiting hours Monday, 7-9 PM.

title: Debates Too Scripted
description: To the Editor:

title: TV Guide Sold For $9.2 Billion In Stock Deal
description: Gemstar International Group, which develops Interactive program guides, said yesterday it was buying TV Guide, the nation's best-selling magazine, with a weekly circulation of about 12 million, for $9.2 billion in stock.

title: Giuliani Says He'd Defend Other Faiths Against Offensive Art
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that if another of the city's 41 publicly financed cultural institutions exhibited a show that in his opinion aggressively attacked a religion, he would cut off city financing in the same way that he did for the Brooklyn Museum of Art.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TERK, IRVING
description: TERK-Irving. The management and staff of Partners Cleaning, LLC extends our deepest sympathy to Steve, Judy, Ben and Elizabeth Terk on the loss of their beloved father and grandfather.

title: Ewing Says He'll Play When His Pain Subsides
description: Patrick Ewing morphed into an image he didn't recognize last season when he became the picture of an aging superstar lurching forward and seizing up on the court like a jalopy, one kick of the tires from falling apart.

title: A Fresh Start for Opera in a Renovated Paris Theater
description: It is a measure of Parisians' appetite for opera these days that the yearlong closing of the Theatre du Chatelet for renovation left a good many music lovers feeling hungry. Not that the Paris National Opera failed to offer pleasing fare at the Palais Garnier and the Bastille Opera. It is just that for a decade under Stephane Lissner the Chatelet consistently offered highbrow programming for those who considered the Paris Opera's repertory to be tad conventional.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIFE, BERNARD
description: FIFE-Bernard. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) express profound sorrow at the loss of Bernard Fife of Great Neck, NY, a leader and active supporter from the early days of the organization. His was a second-generation commitment, passed down by his father who visited the Technion with Albert Einstein. Mr. Fife was a member of the Board of Regents and a past member of the Board of Directors who supported many projects including the Bernard and Arlene Fife Scholarship Fund and the Elias and Bertha Fife Materials Testing Laboratory. We extend heartfelt condolences to the Fife family. American Society for TechnionIsrael Institute of Technology Lawrence S. Jackier, President Irving A. Shepard Chairman of the Board Melvyn H. Bloom Executive Vice President

title: Kamensky Says He'll Be Ready for Home Opener
description: RYE, N.Y., Oct. 4 -- Valery Kamensky did not practice today with his Ranger teammates. Instead, he rode a stationary bicycle.

title: I.B.M. to Introduce a New Generation of Computer Processor
description: The International Business Machines Corporation on Tuesday will announce a new generation of computer processors known as the Power4, challenging a competing chip being developed by the Intel Corporation and the Hewlett Packard Company.

title: Bush Visits New York in an Early Sortie Into Democratic Territory
description: With a packed schedule of fund-raising appearances and speeches to traditionally Democratic audiences, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas embarked yesterday on a three-day campaign sweep across New York, a state that he and his aides think can emerge as contested ground in a Presidential election for the first time in more than a decade.

title: Laura Adasko Lenzner, Artist, 50
description: Laura Adasko Lenzner, an artist who worked in pastel, died on Sunday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. She was 50 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHERNEFF, J. ROBERT
description: CHERNEFF-J. Robert. Of Ashley Falls, MA. Died October 1, 1999 at his home. The owner of Ashley Falls Antiques with his wife Jeanne, he was a former executive vice president of Hill & Knowlton, Inc. In the 1940's, he served as Director of Sports Publicity at Columbia University and as a correspondent for The New York Times and Associated Press. He served on the Mount Vernon, N.Y. School Board from 1961-66. Born in Brooklyn, N.Y., Mr. Cherneff received his B.A. Degree from Columbia in 1942 and served in the United States Navy during World War II. In the the 1930's-40's, he helped to run the family-owned Field and Stream Club, later Camp Deerfield, in Wilmington, Vermont. Mr. Cherneff is survived by his wife, his brother, four sons and seven grandchildren. The family has requested that in lieu of other remembrances, donations be made to the Anya Foundation c/o the family or to Fairview Hospital in Great Barrington, MA.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Evidence of Cannibalism

title: A Madonna's Many Meanings in the Art World
description: The only good thing to come out of the Brooklyn Museum of Art debacle may be that it forces everyone to think again about how art communicates. Had Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani not singled it out, Chris Ofili's ''Holy Virgin Mary'' would certainly have gone almost unnoticed in the current ''Sensation'' exhibition, being a work that, under normal circumstances and in the context of all the really outlandish art in the show, doesn't deserve much attention.

title: Ear Infections Getting Tougher to Treat
description: As doctors and parents know, it often takes more than one course of the pink stuff to cure a childhood ear infection, because the offending bacteria are becoming resistant to standard antibiotic treatments. But new research suggests just how widespread the problem is.

title: Foundations Can Give More, And Protect Assets, Study Says
description: Charitable foundations could give away 60 percent more money than they do now without eroding the total value of their assets, a study for a group of progressive foundations has found.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMEDRESMAN, MAX
description: SMEDRESMAN-Max. The officers and leadership of UJA-Federation of N.Y. mourn the passing of Max Smedresman, devoted husband of Joan Smedresman; cherished father of Ruth Rosen, Peter, and Steven; and beloved grandfather. His compassion and concern for those less fortunate will live on in the generous gifts he created for their benefit through UJA-Federation of N.Y. and the Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society. Our sincere condolences to the entire family. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair James S. Tisch, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec V.P.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERNBERG, ANITA
description: STERNBERG-Anita. Beloved wife of Alvin. Devoted mother of Jodie & Nancie. Cherished grandmother of Austen. Adored mother-in-law of Jonathan. Sister of Barry. Services on Tuesday at 11 A.M., at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York.

title: Memphis Blacks Find Poverty's Grip Strong
description: On the face of it, the 1990's have been good to George Jones. A 58-year-old black man in a city with a history of chronic poverty and acute racial tensions, Mr. Jones opened his first McDonald's restaurant here in the 1980's with a loan from a Chicago bank after Memphis banks had turned him down. He now owns six McDonald's restaurants and sits on the board of a Memphis bank.

title: People
description: * Jeff Finkler, chief creative officer at Leo Burnett Toronto, part of the Leo Burnett Co. unit of Leo Group, was named to the new post of vice chairman and executive creative director at a sibling agency, Leo Burnett U.S.A., Chicago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDRICH, CARL ROBERT
description: FRIEDRICH-Carl Robert, 65. A loving family man, of Pleasant View Drive, Great Barrington, died October 3, 1999 at his home. Funeral services will be Wednesday, October 6, 1999 at 11:00 AM at the First Congregational Church in Great Barrington. The family will receive friends Tuesday, October 5, 1999 from 4:00 pm to 7:00 pm at the Finnerty & Stevens Funeral Home in Great Barrington. Donations to Hospice Care in the Berkshires or the First Congregational Church in Great Barrington, through the Finnerty & Stevens Funeral, 426 Main Street, Great Barrington, MA. 01230.

title: A Debate Over Warnings About Rabid Bats
description: A bat conservation society says New York State's Health Department is scaring people needlessly about the threat of contracting rabies from bats.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOSTER, GLEN S.
description: FOSTER-Glen S. An Olympic medalist yachtsman, died peacefully on Friday, October 1, 1999, at Memorial Sloan-Kettering. He was 69 years old. Mr. Foster died of esophageal cancer. Mr. Foster attended the Fay School, Phillips Academy at Andover, MA, Brown University and Columbia University. Mr. Foster spent his career as a Specialist on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange as a Partner in Foster, Marks & Natoli. Mr. Foster sold his firm in 1994 to Spear, Leeds & Kellogg, where he continued his working career. A world class yachtsman, Mr. Foster represented the United States and won a Bronze Medal in the 1972 Olympic Games in Munich. In later years Mr. Foster competed in 8 meter, 6 meter, 5.5 meter and the Dragon Yacht classes, most recently winning the Scandinavian Gold Cup for the third time only two weeks ago in Torbole, Italy. He was a member of the New York Yacht Club, the Royal Yacht Squadron and the Imperial Poona Yacht Club, and an Honorary Member of the Sewanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club and Key Biscayne Yacht Club. He was a Member of the Board of Directors of the Herreshoff Museum/America's Cup Hall of Fame in Bristol, RI, the Acorn Foundation in New York City, the Afterguard of the New York Yacht Club Young America Challenge for the 2000 America's Cup matches in New Zealand. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, October 7, 1999, at 12 noon, at the Dana Chapel of Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, at 921 Madison Avenue at 73rd Street. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Fund for Renewal of Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, where Mr. Foster was a member, or to the Herreshoff Museum, P.O. Box 225, Bristol, RI. He is survived by his loving wife, Kay, and his mother, Margaret Arrott.

title: Listen, Doctors
description: To the Editor:

title: Of Mice, Men and a Gene That Jump-Starts Follicles
description: Wig makers, tremble! Purveyors of hair restorer, whether F.D.A.-approved or purest snake-oil, brush up on bankruptcy law! Messrs. Michael Milken, Ted Danson, Marv Albert and all hairpiece wearers; Governor Ventura and the proudly bald, and all those about to become so -- listen carefully, for a sudden ray of hope is playing upon all your shining pates!

title: CNN Reaction to Dobbs Deal Is Low-Key
description: Executives from the Cable News Network yesterday reacted to reports that NBC had a partnership deal with Lou Dobbs, the former CNN executive and anchor, with a carefully worded statement citing its continuing contract with Mr. Dobbs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAMBERT, ANNE B.
description: LAMBERT-Anne B. On October 3, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin. Sister of Lillian Behren Friedman and Bertram S. Behrens. Aunt of Anne, Gail, Andrea, Richard and Jonathan. Services private.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about plans by Hachette Filipacchi magazines to buy the 50 percent stake in George magazine that it does not already own misspelled the name of the company's parent. It is the Lagardere Group, not Largardere.

title: Ford Motor Posts Record Sales For Model Year Just Ended
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it had shattered a 21-year-old sales record in the 1999 model year. But the company still lost market share to foreign auto makers.

title: This Splintered Isle; Economically, There Have Always Been Two Englands
description: When the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Gordon Brown, traveled to New York last month to extol his own stewardship of the British economy, he was in an ebullient mood, and the figures did nothing to darken his day.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: Lost Worlds Rediscovered as Canadian Glaciers Melt
description: The body of a hunter that appeared this summer after five centuries in a British Columbia glacier is part of a wider, equally rich trove of artifacts that are suddenly melting out of receding glaciers across the border in Canada's Yukon Territory.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Neuberger Berman is ready to go public, but at what price?
description: IF only Neuberger Berman executives could time the markets the way a good mutual fund manager might.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERMAN, SIDNEY H., M.D.
description: SILVERMAN-Sidney H., M.D. The Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center records with sorrow the passing of Sidney H. Silverman, MD, distinguished and esteemed Emeritus Attending of the Department of Obstetrics & Gynecology. Dr. Silverman was affiliated with Brookdale for over forty years. Our condolences to his bereaved family. Edwin L. Schulman, Chairman, Board of Trustees Frank J. Maddalena, President and CEO Sheldon S. Berman, MD, Sr. Vice President and CMO

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices Again Avoid Church School Aid Issue
description: The Supreme Court once again sidestepped the national debate over public tuition assistance for religious education, refusing today to hear a challenge to an Arizona program that provides a tax credit to those who want to support parochial schools.

title: Deutsche Telekom's Trans-Atlantic Strategy Hits a Snag
description: The wild bidding for the Sprint Corporation has left Europe's biggest telephone company grasping for a trans-Atlantic partner.

title: Broken Confidence Leads to Guilty Plea
description: One day last February, a prisoner who had been convicted of credit card fraud wrote to his lawyer, Paul E. Davison, and expressed anger at the sentence he had received, which is not unusual. But he also mentioned that he had obtained the home address of the judge who had sentenced him, which is unusual.

title: Heartthrob Of Salsa (Not Ricky)
description: To the broad American pop public Marc Anthony's hit ''I Need to Know'' makes him a bright newcomer. For Spanish-speaking listeners, he's already a superstar: the heartthrob who can sing salsa. As he pursues the English-speaking audience, his past is his greatest asset.

title: Uncommon Denominator of Art and Medicine
description: It was a fairly typical issue of The Journal of the American Medical Association: six articles on traumatic brain injury, another on whether children should have their tonsils and adenoids taken out, an editorial titled ''Otitis Media: The Pharyngeal Connection.''

title: One Spending Bill Passes; Others Languish
description: With the clock running in overtime, Congress gave final passage to the sixth of 13 spending bills for the new fiscal year today, financing Federal transportation programs. But Republican leaders faced growing dissent and disarray over how to pass the rest of the bills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, NATHAN W.
description: SCHWARTZ-Nathan W. On October 3, 1999, of New York City. Beloved husband of 57 years to Blanche, dear brother of Pauline Raiffe, also survived by his nephew and nieces. He was the best of the best.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOCH, ROSE
description: BLOCH-Rose on Sunday, October 3, 1999. Rose (nee Polivnick) of South Orange, NJ. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Harry Bloch. Loving mother of Doris Lehman and Joel Bloch. Loving mother-in-law of Myron Lehman and Caryl Bloch. Cherished grandmother of Michael Lehman, Amy Lehman and Peter, Paul, David and Alice Bloch. Also survived by six great grandchildren. Graveside service at Old Montefiore Cemetery Queens, NY on Wednesday October 6, 1999 at 10:00 AM. Information: Menorah Chapels at Millburn 2950 Vaux Hall Rd. Union, NJ.

title: Accounts
description: * Deere & Co., Raleigh, N.C., to FCB Chicago, part of True North Communications, to handle its commercial and consumer equipment account, which had been at Publicis & Hal Riney, San Francisco, part of Publicis S.A. Billings were estimated at $25 million.

title: Executive Leaving Wieden & Kennedy
description: Chuck McBride, a well-known creative executive, is leaving Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore., to become executive creative director at the San Francisco office of TBWA/ Chiat/Day, part of the TBWA Worldwide unit of Omnicom Group.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL FALLS. Crude oil fell on speculation that higher output by Norway and Venezuela next year will counteract production cutbacks. In New York, crude oil for November delivery fell 78 cents, to $23.76 a barrel.

title: For Nets, Freakish Injuries, Sotto Voce
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., Oct. 4 -- Keith Van Horn was standing in the lobby of the Hackensack University Medical Center today talking about the sore left hamstring that will make him a spectator when the Nets open training camp on Tuesday. After calling the injury a ''freak thing,'' the club's star forward anticipated the interrogator's direction and went on the defensive.

title: DEAL FOR TEMPLE-INLAND'S PAPERBOARD MILL
description: The Westvaco Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire Temple-Inland Inc.'s bleached paperboard business for $625 million. Westvaco, a New York-based forest-products company, said the transaction included the Temple-Inland mill in Evadale, Tex., and a long-term contract under which Temple-Inland would supply wood fiber to the mill. Westvaco also said it planned to eliminate 300 jobs in its packaging operations as part of a program to produce $35 million a year in pretax savings. On the New York Stock Exchange, Westvaco's shares rose 18.75 cents each, to $25.8125, and Temple-Inland rose 75 cents, to $59.875.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRACHTENBERG, MARY
description: TRACHTENBERG-Mary. At the age of 91. Beloved wife of the late Meyer Trachtenberg. Beloved mother of Dr. Albert Trachtenberg and the late Harold M. Tract and Mildred Bernstein. Mother-inlaw of Pam Trachtenberg. Grandmother of Moira, Myles, Nancy, Marc and Laurence. Great grandmother of nine. Funeral services today, 12:30 PM at Beth Shalom Chapels Inc., 760 Smithtown Bypass, Smithtown, NY. In lieu of flowers donations to UJA or charity of choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUFFER, SHIRLEY
description: BUFFER-Shirley. On October 4, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Herman. Devoted mother of Steven, Brian and Nancy. Loving grandma to the light of her life, Alex. Finally with The Bear. Funeral service Wednesday 11:30AM at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, New York.

title: Lessons to Apply In Mosquito War
