title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADAMS, DAVID GEORGE
description: ADAMS-David George. Born May 25, 1906. Devoted his life to working for the Episcopal Church for which he became the Comptroller of the Diocese of New York. He passed away after an extended illness. We will all miss his gentle warmth, goodness, and the Irish twinkle in his eyes. There will be a graveside service October 9, 11AM, at Christ Episcopal Church, Bronxville, N.Y.

title: Children and Guns
description: To the Editor:

title: Travelocity Makes a Deal To Dominate Web Market
description: Travelocity, the on-line travel service, said yesterday that it would acquire a smaller rival, Preview Travel, in a deal that will vault it past Microsoft's Expedia to be the largest travel site on the Web.

title: Thanks to a 'Horrible Worm,' New Ideas on Hemoglobin
description: By solving the mystery of how a loathsome worm thrives inside the human gut, scientists have arrived at a sweeping new theory of how hemoglobin, the common protein that ferries oxygen to tissues, evolved.

title: Palmeiro Lets The Rangers Know The Past Is Past
description: Rafael Palmeiro sensed that he would be most comfortable returning to the Texas Rangers this season, even though he loved playing for Baltimore and even though Peter Angelos, the Orioles' owner, obviously shared those feelings. After all, Angelos offered Palmeiro $50 million to stay. But Palmeiro bolted to Texas for $45 million over the next five years and excelled. He increased the production of an already lethal lineup and became another leader in the clubhouse.

title: When Nobel Mingles With Politics; Communism in Italy
description: To the Editor:

title: Front Row
description: The Music Men

title: The Leader In U.S. Radio To Buy No. 2
description: Clear Channel Communications, the nation's largest owner of radio stations, announced yesterday that it would buy the country's second-largest owner, AMFM Inc., for $17.4 billion in stock and $6.1 billion in assumed debt. The deal creates the largest radio company in the world in terms of revenues and number of stations, reaching an approximate weekly audience of 100 million.

title: Nursing Two Babies
description: To the Editor:

title: Executives Seeking Caps On Donations Stand Strong
description: Leaders of a group of business executives who have endorsed a ban on unlimited campaign contributions announced today that their ranks had doubled to 209 members since the committee was chastised last summer by Senator Mitch McConnell, the Senate's most outspoken critic of overhauling the campaign finance system.

title: Analyst Sells Rights to Book On Business Impact of Internet
description: Henry Blodget is finding it much easier to get published since he gave up journalism.

title: Parents and Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: Insurer Is Told to Pay In Auto-Parts Case
description: State Farm, the nation's largest auto insurer, was held in breach of contract by an Illinois jury, which ordered it to pay $456 million in compensation to policyholders for requiring body shops to use lower-priced generic parts for crash repairs, rather than parts made by auto manufacturers. The damages could grow if a judge finds that State Farm committed fraud, and the class-action case may have a sweeping impact on the insurance industry.

title: Parents Scramble to Cope on 2d Day of Teacher Strike
description: It was Day 2 of the teachers' strike in Yonkers, and the big issues of the strike tended to be obliterated by the small, personal and urgent ones of people's lives.

title: Here We Go Again: Same Teams, New Season
description: Here is a scouting report on the American League division series, both rematches of last year's first round with comments on the Yankees and Texas Rangers by Buster Olney and comments on the Cleveland Indians and Boston Red Sox by Murray Chass.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the Pop and Jazz Guide of the Weekend section on Friday about a concert by Los Van Van that night at the Manhattan Center referred incorrectly to the band's relationship with Cuba. It was not recently banned there.

title: KIMBERLY-CLARK MOVES TO TRIPLE HEALTH CARE BUSINESS
description: The Kimberly-Clark Corporation, the world's largest maker of tissue paper, said yesterday that it planned to buy additional health care businesses to triple the size of its medical operations to $2 billion in the next few years. Last month, the company, based in Dallas, completed its purchase of Ballard Medical Products, the largest producer of suction catheters used to clear the airways of patients on ventilators. Including Ballard, Kimberly-Clark's health care unit has about $700 million in sales. Kimberly-Clark said that health-care-related businesses provided a better growth opportunity than its other divisions. Shares of Kimberly-Clark rose $1.50 each, to $54.25.

title: JDS UNIPHASE TO BUY MAKER OF FIBER OPTIC EQUIPMENT
description: The JDS Uniphase Corporation agreed yesterday to buy Epitaxx Inc. for $400 million in stock, as the company, the No. 1 maker of fiber optic equipment parts, aims to supply more of the components used in phone and cable TV networks. Epitaxx, based in Trenton, makes products that detect and receive laser pulses that carry information on glass fibers. The purchase gives JDS Uniphase a bigger share of the market for optical components, where sales are rising by more than 40 percent a year. Epitaxx is majority owned by a unit of the Nippon Sheet Glass Company. The shares of JDS Uniphase, based in San Jose, Calif., jumped $9.75 each, to $125, in Nasdaq trading. The stock has more than tripled this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPITZER, JULIE, RABBI
description: SPITZER-Julie, Rabbi. The Jewish Community Relations Council sorrowfully mourns the passing of our dear colleague and friend, Rabbi Julie Spitzer, Director of the UAHC Greater NY Council of Reform Synagogues. May her family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Gedale B. Horowitz, President Michael S. Miller, Executive VP

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARK, EDWARD
description: MARK-Edward. 95, of Manhattan, formerly of Great Neck, NY, died peacefully on October 3rd, bringing to a close a long, productive and loving life. He cherished his wife of 45 years, the late Libbie Berman Mark. He leaves his children, Judith Tanur and Reuben Mark, and his grandchildren, Rachel Tanur, Marcia Tanur, Lisa McLoughlin, Peter Mark and Stephen Mark. He will also be deeply missed by the spouses and loved ones of his children and grandchildren, Arlene Mark, Michael Tanur, Thomas, Elizabeth, Victoria and Anna Karin. His circle of loving care also extended, in addition to his great-grandchildren, to his nieces, nephews, grand-nieces and grand-nephews. Funeral services will be held on Thursday, October 7, at 11:30 AM at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street. Please omit flowers.

title: X-Rays Offer New Glimpse Of a Dynamo In the Sky
description: Using the orbiting Chandra X-ray Observatory, astronomers have discovered a new feature in one of the most intensively studied objects in the sky, the Crab nebula. A new image shows rings of X-rays and a jet around the nebula's central star and powerhouse. Floating like a tangled wreath of smoke in the constellation Taurus, the Crab is the remains of a star that exploded in 1054. At its heart, a pulsar, the dense magnetized remnant of the star that exploded, spins 30 times a second, generating energy at the rate of 100,000 suns. Astronomers say the rings are caused by high-energy particles flung from the star and that they might provide clues to how energy is transmitted from the pulsar to the nebula.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, FREDERICK
description: FRIEDMAN-Frederick. On September 29, 1999 in his 100th year. Beloved husband of Rae. Loving father and father-in-law of Audrey and Ralph Wagner, Sheila and Daniel Gereb, Jeffrey andJanet Friedman and Herbert and Karen Friedman. Devoted grandfather of Lisa and Peter Wagner and Mark, Marjorie and David Gereb, & great grandfather of Alexander and Ethan Goldberg, and Noah Wagner-Carlberg.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALD, MORTIMER
description: WALD-Mortimer. Of Verona, NJ, peacefully at home on October 5, 1999. Beloved Husband of Martha nee Wechsler. Predeceased by his first wife Evelyn nee Wagner. Devoted father of Judith Beardsall. Dear brother of Henry and Harold Wald, and Roseann Schwab. Brother-in-law of Florence and Lynn Wald, and Walter Schwab. Services will be held at King Solomon Cemetery, Dwas Line & Allwood Rds. in Clifton, NJ, October 5 at 1 PM, Jewish Memorial Chapel, Clifton, New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIMMERMAN, RUTH PASCAL
description: ZIMMERMAN-Ruth Pascal. Cherished by her daughter, Joan Shore; beloved by her grandsons, Jeffery, Steven and Gregory Shore; and adored by her greatgranddaughter, Odessa Shore. Services were held on Sunday, October 3, in Manhattan.

title: Whitman Calls Reverse-Bias Suit Baseless
description: Insisting that she would not waver in her effort to improve the New Jersey State Police, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said today that the reverse-discrimination suit filed by a former state police superintendent was ''baseless.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDEY, THELMA BARASCH
description: RUDEY-Thelma Barasch. On October 4, 1999, died peacefully at home at age 92. Barnard and Teacher's College Columbia University graduate. Lover of languages and the arts. Dearly beloved wife of the late Samuel Richard Rudey. Devoted mother of John and Laurie Rudey and Liz and Kirk Rudey Ruebenson. Loving grandmother of Matthew Aaron, Spencer Richard, Amanda Kathryn Rudey and Kate Anna Rudey Ruebenson. Sister of Clarence S. Barasch, Jacqueline B. Schneider and the late Gladys B. Blum. Dear sister-in-law, aunt and great aunt. Services Wednesday, October 6th, 11:00 AM at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Ave. at 65th St. Contributions in her memory may be be made to the Thelma and Samuel Rudey Book Fund in care of the Director's Office, Harvard College Library, Cambridge, MA. 02138.

title: An Architect With a Film Director's Eye
description: IMAGINE something cinematic -- a jiggly-camera documentary, perhaps, or a Philip Glass opera with singers standing in front of a movie screen -- about the architect Bernard Tschumi.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENNETT, SIDONIE
description: BENNETT-Sidonie. The Board of Directors and staff of the Tanenbaum Center for Interreligious Understanding join our esteemed President, Georgette F. Bennett, her son Joshua-Marc, and the rest of the family, in mourning the loss of her mother. Sidonie will be greatly missed by all of us who knew her.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHBERGER, HYMAN
description: FISCHBERGER-Hyman. Young Israel of Oceanside expresses heartfelt condolences to our past president, David Fischberger, and family, on the loss of his beloved father. May the family be comforted among those who mourn for Tzion and Yerushalayim. Jay Yaacov Schwartz, Rabbi Evan Torczyner, President

description: Mars Coordinates

title: Kensu Yak Farm Journal; The Unfenced Life, Under the Celestial Mountains
description: In this now independent and remote nation, where people's lives are shaped by breathtaking mountains, swift horses and forbidding glaciers, a hunter and yak herder named Jakshylyk Osmonakunov perfectly embodies the collective spirit.

title: Microsoft and M.I.T. to Develop Technologies
description: In a move that is expected to have a significant impact on the role of technology in university education, the Microsoft Corporation and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology will announce today a partnership to develop educational technologies.

title: INSIDE
description: Supreme Court Opens Term

title: Culture Shocked by Modernity
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: And Cabaret, Too

title: INSIDE
description: Judge Nominee Is Rejected

title: Martin Davis, 72; Created Modern Paramount
description: Martin S. Davis, the fiery executive who reshaped the unwieldy conglomerate Gulf and Western Industries into the entertainment and publishing giant Paramount Communications, died Monday in Manhattan. He was 72 and lived in Westport, Conn.

title: Dior's Parody of Rapper Style Misses the Latin Beat
description: PARIS  Does John Galliano know more than we do about the financial strategy at Dior? Is a merger with Hermes (not to mention Gucci and Versace) really on the Tarot cards? And was that why the designer sent out denim skirts dangling drunkenly over laced-up boots, all tricked out with prints for which Hermes might sue for copyright? Not to mention the afro wigs that made the upside-down clothes look like Lauryn Hill's rapper style?

title: A Souffle That Can Stand on Its Own
description: WHEN the warm lemon souffle arrived at my table at Palio, I was at first surprised and then intrigued. Unlike most souffles, this one had no dish to help it keep its shape. It sat regally on a thin slice of cake, surrounded by berries. One bite and I knew I had to have the recipe.

title: Rangers Failing Physical Tests
description: When the Rangers lost to Ottawa in their home opener at Madison Square Garden last night, their depth chart resembled a hospital chart with Mike Richter, Valery Kamensky and Tim Taylor all out.

title: American Airlines and Union Are Sued Over Pilot Seniority
description: After 10 months and countless hours of negotiations, American Airlines and the union representing its nearly 10,000 pilots have not resolved their dispute over the acquisition of Reno Air, a small carrier based in the West. And with the emergence of a third aggrieved party, ending the simmering conflict might become even more complicated.

title: More Than Just a Burger
description: IN the Washington where I grew up in the 1950's and 60's, fine dining meant a restaurant where the menu was not printed on the place mat and where yellowing photographs of mostly dead politicians decorated the walls. Iceberg lettuce was a delicacy. ''Foreign food'' -- at the Orient (Chinese), Gusti's (Italian), Old Europe (German), Hofberg's (quasi-New York deli) -- all achieved a similar consistency, which is to say glutinous. You knew you were eating ''gourmet French'' when onion soup appeared with a crust whose thickness and sheer tensile strength could compete with that of a two-day-old chicken potpie.

title: Acquisitions By 3 Companies
description: Three big agency companies are making acquisitions that are indicative of the growing interest in fields outside traditional advertising.

title: Who Will Be the Judge of Art?
description: To the Editor:

title: Inspired by the Traditions of Africa But Ruled by a Contemporary Spirit
description: How can one remain inspired by tradition but break free of its cliches as a creative artist? That is the question that several modern-dance choreographers from Africa have answered impressively and sometimes brilliantly at the International New Dance Festival here.

title: CALENDAR
description: Portugal on Parade

title: Dow Finishes a Bit Lower After a Day of Big Swings
description: In a session punctuated by the Federal Reserve's decision to leave short-term interest rates unchanged yesterday, stock prices climbed, then plunged and finally recovered to close almost where they started.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMON, JULES EVERET
description: SIMON-Jules Everet. Born NYC October 25, 1915 passed away L.A. October 4, 1999. Attended Ethical Culture Schools, Kings College, Columbia University, Lt. U.S. Army Air Force WW II, Asst Dir UJA/Federation for 40 yrs. Survived by wife Julie, son Jody, daughter-inlaw Andrea, grandsons Jonathan and Joseph, brother, Arthur.

title: Ruling Sets Back Libel Suit Of Guard in Olympic Bombing
description: Richard Jewell's libel suit against The Atlanta Journal-Constitution suffered a significant setback yesterday when a state court ruled that Mr. Jewell, a former security guard, became a public figure in the days after the 1996 bombing of Centennial Olympic Park in Atlanta that left two people dead.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TERK, IRVING
description: TERK-Irving. Of Miami Beach, died on October 2, 1999. Loving husband of Mildred, dear father of Judy & Steve, Jeffrey and Valarie, and Henry and Wendy, also survived by six grandchildren and one great grandchild.

title: Boeing to Buy Some of Its Jets and Lease Them
description: In its latest bid to try to lift its anemic profits, the Boeing Company announced yesterday an ambitious and risky deal to buy 44 of its 757-model passenger jets, convert them to cargo planes and lease them to DHL International Ltd., the package delivery company.

title: Showalter Puts His Precise Stamp on the Diamondbacks
description: Ejected from a game only once this season, Arizona Diamondbacks Manager Buck Showalter did not sneak back into the dugout, under disguise or otherwise.

title: Sports of The Times; E-Z Pass Playoff: Root for One
description: THAT other Noo Yawk baseball team reappeared last night in all its usual October splendor.

title: Where Baby Sleeps
description: To the Editor:

title: KOREAN BANK TO CALL OFF ISSUE
description: Weeks of plummeting share values in South Korea caused the nation's fourth-largest commercial bank to postpone indefinitely its plans to sell $1 billion of stock to foreign investors. The decision by Korea Exchange Bank reflects worries about a stalled recovery because of the nation's worst economic recession and will make it more difficult for the bank to expand its business. It is the third time in the last three months that a Korean company has delayed the sale of its shares overseas or set a price that was lower than expected. Commerzbank A.G. of Germany owns 30.4 percent of Korea Exchange Bank.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 22 in the special E-Commerce section about ordering goods and services on the Internet referred incorrectly to the criteria of an on-line dating service, Match maker.com, for matching couples. The service does not pair people by height and weight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTLIEB, WILLIAM
description: GOTTLIEB-William. We were saddened to hear of the sudden passing of our dear friend, William Gottlieb. Bill's generous support of our programs and the Kraft Center for Jewish Student Life was an inspiration to us all. He will be sorely missed. Robert Pollack, President Jewish Campus Life Fund at Columbia University Charles Sheer, Rabbi Earle W. Kazis, Chairman

title: Stottlemyre's Extra Worry
description: Mel Stottlemyre, the Yankees' pitching coach, must concern himself with Orlando Hernandez, Andy Pettitte and the other Yankee pitchers. But he will have a Diamondback on his mind late tonight: Todd Stottlemyre, his son, is scheduled to pitch against the Mets in Arizona.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMOLEN, ARTHUR
description: SMOLEN-Arthur. Guiding Eyes For The Blind and the Ken Venturi Guiding Eyes Golf Classic Committee mourn the passing of our friend and longtime supporter, Arthur Smolen. His efforts have significantly helped to enrich the lives of many blind individuals through the use of trained guide dogs. Our deepest sympathy to the Smolen family.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR IS MIXED. The dollar was little changed after the Fed indicated it was inclined to raise interest rates. In New York, the dollar settled at 106.41 yen, up from 106.23. The euro traded at $1.0743, up from $1.0735.

title: A CBS Internet Portal Builds In Data for Ads
description: CBS introduced an Internet portal yesterday, modeled after Yahoo and other directory services that are the most popular sites on the World Wide Web. It is hardly an original idea: Walt Disney, the NBC unit of the General Electric Company and AT&T all own pieces of portals already.

title: Small Designers Cater to Need for Personal Touch : The Quest for Individuality
description: PARIS  Could it be that Gucci is not the only role model for fashion success? Could it be that mega-brands, luxury conglomerates and being bought out by Prada are not the only daydreams of today's fashion designers?

title: Alfonzo Bashes Grand Slam in 9th For Mets Victory
description: The Mets applauded themselves all the way around the bases, rejoicing that their good karma had not ended.

title: Graham's Concussion Gives Collins the Start
description: Jim Fassel had been leaning toward replacing Kent Graham with Kerry Collins, even though the decision for Fassel meant choosing between his loyalty to Graham and his curiosity about Collins. But yesterday, an injury -- the most common cause of personnel moves in the National Football League -- forced Fassel's hand.

title: FOOD STUFF
description: Ice Cream Flavors Taste And Sound Very French

title: In Chechnya's Capital, War Imperils Rebuilt Lives
description: The apartment blocks along Avturkhanov Street are a ghastly reminder of the last war here in Chechnya's capital. Most are abandoned ruins that still bear shrapnel marks and shell holes from the Russian bombardment four years ago.

title: Apple Computer Rolls Out New Assemblage of iMacs
description: Apple Computer Inc. announced a new family of its iMac computers today, including an entry-level model priced below $1,000.

description: FIFE-Bernard. The Board of Governors and Members of High Ridge Country Club acknowledge with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Bernard Fife. We extend our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife, Arlene, and their family. Morton West, President Daniel Amster, Secretary

title: Bush Says G.O.P. Stresses Wealth At Expense of Tackling Social Ills
description: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas used a speech about his proposals for improving education yesterday to issue a pointed critique of the Republican Party, saying it had put too much emphasis on economic wealth and too little on social problems.

title: Federal Report Praising Electroshock Stirs Uproar
description: A preliminary draft of the United States Surgeon General's Report on Mental Health, not yet released to the public, has touched off an uproar among some consumer advocates, who say it gives too rosy and uncritical a picture of electroshock therapy.

title: Dogs Search For Boy, 3, In Mountains Of Colorado
description: After four days of trying to find a 3-year-old boy from Littleton, Colo., in the rugged mountains northwest of here, the authorities scaled back their search today and are reassessing their approach.

title: Treatment Without Trials
description: To the Editor:

title: A Federal Case of Small Change; U.S. Prosecutes a Hospital Cashier Over $7 and Loses
description: It seemed more People's Court than Federal Court.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOCERA, PATSY
description: NOCERA-Patsy. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Patsy J. Nocera, associated with The Times from April 1959, died October 4, 1999.

title: Campus Housing in Short Supply
description: The Howard Johnson Hotel in Boston's Kenmore Square has all the trappings of a AAA-approved lodging: piped in elevator music, key-card doors, burgundy carpeting.

title: Art Farmer, 71, Be-Bop Master Of the Trumpet and Fluegelhorn
description: Art Farmer, one of the more important second-generation be-bop musicians, an improviser who could say a great deal in a few notes on the trumpet and fluegelhorn and later on his own hybrid instrument, the ''flumpet,'' died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 71 and lived in Manhattan and Vienna.

title: INGERSOLL-RAND PUTS TWO VENTURES UP FOR SALE
description: The Ingersoll-Rand Company, a maker of industrial machinery, said yesterday that it would sell two ventures -- one that makes pumps and another that builds compressors -- as soon as possible. The announcement followed the news on Monday that its partner in the ventures, the Halliburton Company, was selling its stakes to Ingersoll-Rand for $1.1 billion. Based on that price, the total value of the ventures -- the Dresser-Rand Company and Ingersoll-Rand Pumps -- would be about $2 billion. The ventures' sales have been hurt by their ties to the boom-and-bust energy industry. Ingersoll, based in Woodcliff Lake, N.J., plans to use proceeds from a sale to buy less-cyclical operations.

title: Sprewell Told to Pay $104,940
description: Two days after training camp opened, Latrell Sprewell is finally expected to join his teammates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARK, EDWARD
description: MARK-Edward. 95, of Manhattan, formerly of Great Neck, NY, died peacefully on October 3rd, bringing to a close a long, productive and loving life. He cherished his wife of 45 years, the late Libbie Berman Mark. He leaves his children, Judith Tanur and Reuben Mark, and his grandchildren, Rachel Tanur, Marcia Tanur, Lisa McLoughlin, Peter Mark and Stephen Mark. He will also be deeply missed by the spouses and loved ones of his children and grandchildren, Arlene Mark, Michael Tanur, Thomas, Elizabeth, Victoria and Anna Karin. His circle of loving care also extended, in addition to his great-grandchildren, to his nieces, nephews, grand-nieces and grand-nephews. Funeral services will be held on Thursday, October 7, at 11:30 AM at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street. Please omit flowers.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RUBENSTEIN, HENRY
description: RUBENSTEIN-Henry. Henry my love, it's been seven long years apart, but forever in my heart. Beatric

title: The Challenge of Putting Dickens in the Spotlight
description: It might seem churlish to begin a discussion of Dickens with a complaint about length. But anyone attempting the daunting task of adapting one of his voluminous novels for the stage has to be deeply concerned not only with how to impress, but also how to compress.

title: KOREA FIRST DEAL ADVANCES
description: All the paperwork behind the planned sale of a controlling stake in Korea First Bank to a United States-based private equity fund, Newbridge Capital Ltd., is expected to be completed by the end of November, Newbridge's managing director, Weijian Shan, said. He said the final closing of the transaction might take longer because of United States bank regulatory requirements. Mr. Shan said Newbridge had chosen a Westerner with long-term banking experience as the new chief executive of Korea First Bank, but he declined to identify the banker. Samuel Len

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: GOLD RISES. Gold rose as banks, mining companies and speculators labored to get out of bets on lower prices that came after years of declines. In New York, gold for December delivery rose $8, to $326 an ounce.

title: Another Giant Seeks to Deflect Cable TV Criticism
description: The AT&T Corporation, facing persistent criticism for not giving independent Internet service providers direct access to its far-flung cable television systems, has decided to offer such access within a few years and is trying to find concrete ways to demonstrate that commitment, executives close to the company said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TARR, ANNETTE (KOLIN)
description: TARR-Annette (Kolin) on Monday, October 4, of Marlborough, MA, formerly of NY & FL. Beloved wife of the late Sidney Tarr and Howard Mandel. Devoted mother of Mark and Rene Mandel of Framingham, MA, Wendy Sue of Mystic, CT, and Susan Tarr & Hans Proppe of CA. Cherished grandmother of Roger Morehouse, Susannah & Jeremy Mandel. Dear sister of Marshall Kolin. Remembrances may be made to Alzheimers Association or a charity of one's choice. 617-277-8300.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 1 about the awarding of the Nobel Prize in Literature to Gunter Grass of Germany misstated the number of other German authors who have received it since 1929. The number is three, not two; in addition to Thomas Mann and Heinrich Boll, the Nobel was awarded in 1966 to Nelly Sachs, who shared it with S. Y. Agnon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLTHUSEN, LENORE
description: HOLTHUSEN-Lenore. At age 86, beloved wife of the late Henry F. Holthusen, loving sister of Shirlee Stout, of Indiana, Maxine Smith, of South Dakota, Jean Penn, of New York, Robert Sutter, of Ohio, and the late Ruth Richards, of Kentucky. Adored aunt of twelve nieces and nephews. A member of the Shelter Island Yacht Club where she had a summer residence. A graduate of Columbia University. She was an avid bridge player which brought her much pleasure. A Memorial Service will be held at Saint Thomas Episcopal Church, 1 West 53rd Street, New York City, on Friday, October 8, 1999, at 2 P.M.

title: Who Will Be the Judge of Art?
description: To the Editor:

title: Maybe You, Too, Could Be In a Subway Driver's Seat
description: Tired of that dreary office? Want to put your career on track? Then opportunity awaits, since the New York City subway system is looking for a few good motormen (and motorwomen, too.)

title: Chill in the Air Keeps Bug Sprayers on Ground
description: As temperatures fell below 50 degrees, Nassau County announced last night that its plans to begin a three-day aerial insecticide campaign against disease-carrying mosquitoes would be postponed until 5 to 10 P.M. today, tomorrow and Friday.

title: Houston Franchise Could Set Mark
description: With a plan to pay a $700 million expansion fee, Bob McNair of Houston is expected to get the National Football League's 32d franchise today, defeating a proposal for Los Angeles by the talent manager Michael Ovitz and the billionaire Ron Burkle.

title: Rise in Average College Cost In '99 Is Lowest in 12 Years
description: The average cost of attending college this school year rose 4.6 percent at private institutions and 3.4 percent at public institutions, the lowest increases in at least 12 years but still higher than the national rate of inflation, the College Board reported yesterday.

title: The Usual Story: Oates (and Rangers) Frustrated
description: When Johnny Oates was a young player with Baltimore, he decided that Yankee Stadium was a most inhospitable place. However, when he played for two very good Yankee teams in 1980 and 1981, he totally changed his perception.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOWMAN, GEORGE F.
description: LOWMAN-George F. Age 82, on October 2, 1999, of Darien, CT. Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Farrell Lines, Incorporated, since 1978, and member of the Board of Directors of the American Steamship Owners Mutual Protection & Indemnity Association, Maritime Association of the Port of New York & New Jersey, and India House, New York. He was a recipient of the United Seamen's Service 1998 Admiral of the Ocean Sea Award, member of the International Maritime Hall of Fame of the Maritime Association of the Port of New York & New Jersey, and recipient in 1999 of that association's first Humanitarian Award. He graduated Harvard in 1938 and received his law degree from Harvard Law School in 1942. He was a former Senior Partner of the Stamford, CT, law firm of Cummings & Lockwood. Among his many professional accomplishments, he was Connecticut State Trial Referee from 1983-1993, past President of the Connecticut Bar Association, former President of India House, Fellow of the American Bar Association, Life Member of the National Defense Transportation Association and Navy League of the U.S., and a former Director of the Darien, CT, Red Cross and Silvermine Guild of Artists. He enlisted in the U.S. Army as a private in 1942 and rose to the rank of Lt. Colonel. He participated in the D-Day Invasion of southern France in 1944 and later served in the U.S. Army Reserve until his retirement in 1970. He is survived by his wife, Mary Farrell Lowman; daughter, Patricia Lowman Dailey; and sons, John Farrell Lowman and Peter Hadden Lowman and 10 grandchildren, all of Darien, Ct., and brother Albert Henry Lowman of New Canaan, Ct. Funeral arrangements are private. A memorial service will be held at 4 PM, on October 6, at the First Congregational Church of Darien, 14 Brookside Road, followed by a reception at the Wee Burn Country Club, 410 Hollow Tree Ridge Road, Darien. Contributions in honor of Mr. Lowman may be sent to the Autism Society of America or the United Seamen's Service.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks Fluctuate Sharply On Interest Rate Decision

title: Taking on Campaign Finance Laws, Locally
description: It has been said that small is beautiful, and that all politics is local. New Jersey Common Cause, an advocacy group, has apparently been listening.

title: Foreign Affairs; A Deadly Embrace
description: Flipping through the room-service menu at my Havana hotel the other morning, I noticed it listed four types of breakfast: American, Continental, Creole and Russian. Now, there aren't too many places in the world where you find ''Russian breakfast'' on the menu, especially this one, which consisted of caviar, smoked salmon and champagne for $125! Only a Russian businessman with an account at the Bank of New York could afford that breakfast.

title: A Cornucopia of Copland, Rare Morsels Included
description: Aaron Copland, who died in 1990, spent the last 30 years of his life in a spacious yet simple house in the upper reaches of Westchester Country, not far from the Hudson River. There he worked in a lovely glass-walled studio that overlooked lush, green woods.

title: Liberties; Here Comes The Son
description: If Al Gore is stiff because his father always expected him to be President, perhaps W. is loose because his father never expected him to be President.

title: With Merger, No Doubts On Who Calls the Shots
description: Bernard J. Ebbers is making quite a habit of this: buy a company, install its chief executive as his titular boss, then slowly phase the executive out, and continue on his merry corporate shopping spree.

title: ASARCO BOARD RECOMMENDS REJECTION OF 2 TAKEOVER BIDS
description: Asarco Inc. said yesterday that its board unanimously recommended that shareholders reject takeover bids received from the Phelps Dodge Corporation and from Grupo Mexico S.A. The board at Asarco, a New York-based copper producer, authorized management to begin seeking the best possible offer for the company, it said in a regulatory filing. On Sept. 22, Phelps Dodge sweetened its offer to acquire Asarco and the Cyprus Amax Minerals Company in a three-way merger. Cyprus Amax accepted the bid, but Asarco did not respond until yesterday. Phelps Dodge's offer is now $9 in cash and 0.288 of a Phelps share. Grupo Mexico's bid, made on Sept. 27, is $26 a share in cash. Asarco's shares slipped 12.5 cents, to $26.75, yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FENN, ELIZABETH
description: FENN-Elizabeth, died on October 2nd, 1999. An artist, art director, fashion and advertising illustrator in Paris and New York; former president of the Pen and Brush Club of New York. She was the mother of Suzanne and Karen Fenn; the grandmother of Vincent Puig and Aline Puig-Colart; and the great-grandmother of Blandine, Alice and Marine Puig. She will be deeply missed by her family and many friends.

title: Devils
description: The Devils reacquired defenseman Ken Sutton yesterday, mainly as an insurance policy, for future considerations. The Devils had lost Sutton to the Washington Capitals in the waiver draft.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ACKERMAN, ELAINE
description: ACKERMAN-Elaine of Yonkers, New York, a principal and Vice President of Caprice Travel Agency, Inc., 1179 Yonkers Avenue, Yonkers, N.Y. succumbed to cancer at her home Tuesday, October 5, 1999. Mrs. Ackerman was born May 29, 1926 in the Bronx and attended school in New York City. She was the wife of the late Myron Paul Ackerman. She is survived by her daughter, Debra Ackerman of Yonkers, N.Y., her son David Ackerman, his wife Gail and her grandchildren, Justin & Alexandra of Westfield, N.J., and her two beloved nieces Susan Tyler of New York City and Vicki Ebeling of Yonkers, NY. Service Wednesday 1:30 PM ''Riverside Memorial Chapel'', 21 W. Broad St., Mt Vernon, NY. Interment to follow Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, NY.

title: Mr. Bush's Triangulation
description: Perhaps emboldened by his lead in the Republican Presidential race, George W. Bush has delivered a surprising critique of his party and, implicitly, its Congressional leadership. Yesterday, while campaigning in New York, the Texas Governor blamed fellow Republicans for what he said was an overly obsessive focusing on the economy at the expense of social needs. As if on cue, Republicans in Congress let it be known that despite the big Federal surpluses, they were considering budget cuts that could eviscerate Head Start, school aid for poor students, health research and other programs.

title: Scent of a Man: Fragrance Sales Boom; Spritzers Abound, Much to the Delight of Designers and Department Stores
description: On his lunch hour, Jonathan Jung made a special trip to the men's fragrance counter at Bloomingdale's to sample a scent by the Italian designer Giorgio Armani called Acqua di Gio. He had smelled the cologne on an insert in Men's Journal, a magazine that emphasizes male fitness rather than fashion, and wanted to daub it on his own skin.

title: 14-Hour Days? They Have Other Ideas
description: Like any recent law school graduate, Joseph was eager to make a good impression on his new employers. ''I showed up at 9 A.M. my first day here and left at 2 A.M.,'' he said of his job at a large Boston firm.

title: HBO Plans a Drama Based on 'Stiffed'
description: Home Box Office has acquired rights to the newly published Susan Faludi book, ''Stiffed: The Betrayal of the American Man,'' and plans to turn it into a television drama next year.

title: Tough Test for Vermeil And Undefeated Rams
description: Tales about Dick Vermeil that circulated throughout the league in his first two seasons in St. Louis were unflattering and embarrassing. Vermeil, who turns 63 this month, had coached 20 years and then spent the next 13 off the sidelines, much of that time as a football analyst on television. In 1997 he jumped back on the field, as the Rams' head coach, and his teams won five games the first year and only four games last year.

title: F.C.C. Chief Says Phone Deal Faces Stiff Review
description: The head of the Federal Communications Commission sharply questioned today how MCI Worldcom's $115 billion agreement to buy Sprint could benefit consumers and warned that the companies would have to meet a high standard to persuade him to approve the deal.

title: Who Will Be the Judge of Art?
description: To the Editor:

title: Justice Souter on Campaign Cash
description: The Supreme Court devoted the second day of its new term yesterday to hearing arguments in an important campaign financing case with serious implications for the current campaign reform fight in Congress and, more broadly, the integrity of American politics.

title: A Vote for Another Cheddar
description: To the Editor:

title: Auto Workers In Canada Avert Strike
description: With less than two hours to spare before a threatened strike, the DaimlerChrysler Corporation reached an agreement with the Canadian Auto Workers union on a new three-year contract covering the company's 13,800 workers in Canada.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: As Only He Can, Valentine Gloats in Moment
description: Bobby Valentine was a churning bundle of celebration on Monday night, a man who had finally exorcised some demons and now was not going to miss a moment, not going to forgo the chance to revel in an accomplishment many doubted he would ever achieve.

title: In New Russian Tea Room, Emphasis on Food
description: GLASS dancing bears? Spangles and bangles? It's the sort of thing expected of Warner LeRoy, the impresario of the renovated Russian Tea Room, who probably exhales glitter every time he yawns. But when the Tea Room opens to the public on Monday, Mr. LeRoy is hoping to wave his wand and achieve a magical transformation in an area in which he has never been known to excel: the food.

title: Treatment Without Trials
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEZNER, LAURA ADASKO
description: LEZNER-Laura Adasko. We will forever be touched by your creativity, courage, love. Walking down Broadway will never be the same without you. We'll miss you. Betsy Blachly-Chapin, Ellen Rafel and Irene Selver

title: Treatment Without Trials
description: To the Editor:

title: Fiddling His Way Toward Perfection
description: Sitting in the kitchen of John Hartford's house feels a lot like being on a riverboat. Through the irregular wooden room's small white-fringed windows, all that can be seen is a whitewashed rail and a picturesque stretch of the Cumberland River. Gathered in that room one afternoon late last week were three young pickers, with Mr. Hartford -- surrounded by a metronome, a microphone and a tape recorder -- perched at the head of the long kitchen table.

title: Yellow Freight Awards Accounts
description: Yellow Freight System in Overland Park, Kan., the transportation company owned by the Yellow Corporation, has awarded its advertising and marketing accounts, with billings estimated at $15 million, to two agencies.

title: Protecting Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHALFIN, VICTOR
description: CHALFIN-Victor. Temple B'nai Sholom mourns the loss of our dear, longtime member. We send our condolences to the family. Services Gutterman's, Rockville Centre, Thursday, October 7, 10:15. Dr. Barry Dov Schwartz, Rabbi Jeffrey H. Greenfield, President

title: MODERATE INFLATION IN TAIWAN
description: Taiwan's inflation slowed in September as clothing prices sank and supplies of food and other goods remained ample after the earthquake that struck the island on Sept. 21. The earthquake is expected to push up prices for food in future months, as well as for construction materials and some consumer goods. The consumer price index, the most closely watched inflation measure, rose an unadjusted 0.59 percent in September from a year earlier, to 103.40, said the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics. It surged 1.14 percent in August.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JACOBS, MELVIN
description: JACOBS-Melvin. 8/26/26-10/6/93 One of a kind-of which there is no kind. Roz and Peggy

title: Despite the Jets' 1-3 Mark, Outlook Remains Upbeat
description: They have only one victory after a month. They have suffered still another serious setback because of injury. And yet, the title race has already begun for the Jets.

title: Japan Replaces Leader Of Bank-Overhaul Agency
description: The widely respected leader of the commission in charge of reorganizing Japan's banks was replaced today, and some industry analysts called it a sign that the Government might not be as aggressive in further reforms of the system.

title: Failed at Your Last Job? Wonderful! You're Hired.
description: At age 30, Michael Barach quit a lucrative job as a vice president for marketing for a $100 million furniture company to take charge of a start-up called Cartoon Corner -- a concept similar to the Disney Store, but with generic cartoons on the merchandise.

title: Gore, Seeking A Stronghold In New York, Attacks Rivals
description: In a day of campaigning that seemed more typical of the final days of an election, Vice President Al Gore yesterday tried to nail down commitments from the Democratic leaders in the New York area who can turn out votes in a Presidential primary against Bill Bradley and voiced a full-throated criticism of the Republican front-runner, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas.

title: Primedia Unit in Deal
description: Primedia Inc. said this week that its Intertec Publishing unit had acquired the Multimedia Publishing Corporation, a producer of trade shows and publications focusing on telecommunications technology and services. Terms were not disclosed. Primedia, a publishing giant in New York, said the acquired properties, based in Houston, include a semiannual trade show -- the Telecom Business Conference and Expo -- and two publications: Telecom Business and Telecard World.

title: German Insurer Discussing Takeover of Pimco
description: Pimco Advisors Holdings L.P. confirmed yesterday that it was in talks to be acquired by Allianz A.G., the huge German insurance company, in a deal that could be worth more than $4 billion.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Sept. 25 about an appeal by Gov. George W. Bush of Texas to Patrick J. Buchanan to stay in the Republican Party misstated the name of a group whose representatives met with the Governor and discussed Mr. Buchanan. It is the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, not the American Israel Public Relations Committee.

title: The Bankers Behind the Biggest Deal
description: At 11 A.M. on Monday, Bernard J. Ebbers, the chief executive of MCI Worldcom, faced a moment of truth.

title: ANNAN SAYS U.N. MUST TAKE OVER EAST TIMOR RULE
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan presented a sweeping plan today for the United Nations to take full control of battered East Timor and guide the territory to statehood over two to three years.

title: No Fear of Times Square
description: To the Editor:

title: Broadway's Critic-Proof Composer Says This Is (Still) His Moment; Like His 'Scarlet Pimpernel,' Frank Wildhorn Keeps on Going
description: Admit it, Frank, you're the tiniest bit depressed.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PARIS, SAMUEL L.
description: PARIS-Samuel L. Two years have taught us so much. We have learned so well to appreciate what you made possible. Always in our thoughts. Shirley, our children, our four granddaughters.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: A Night Off From the Art War

title: Sales of Industrial Robots Up, Report by a U.N. Agency Says
description: Sales of industrial robots are flourishing worldwide, except in Asia, because of a huge demand from car makers in the United States and Europe, a United Nations economic agency said today.

title: Review/Fashion; John Galliano Goes Wandering On the Heath
description: John Galliano's collection today for Christian Dior was all horse and no rider. Spectacularly overestimating the world's supply of women who can picture themselves in a skirt with saddle flaps hanging off the side, Mr. Galliano came a cropper as the French spring ready-to-wear shows headed into the fourth day.

title: Commercial Real Estate; This Time, Best Views Go to Workers
description: Like many other Internet companies, Tempest Software, a start-up concern in lower Manhattan, has departed from many traditional corporate patterns, and the way its new offices are being designed is no exception.

title: Fed Leaves Rates Steady, For This Time
description: The Federal Reserve voted today to leave interest rates unchanged, but warned that it was still concerned about the potential for inflation and might raise rates soon if the economy did not cool off.

title: INDONESIAN PETROCHEMICAL TALKS
description: The world's third-largest publicly owned oil company, BP Amoco, said it was looking to buy into Chandra Asri, Indonesia's only producer of ethylene. BP Amoco, a British-based company, is in talks to merge its local polyethylene venture with Chandra Asri before taking a 50 percent stake in the merged entity, said Jim White, head of BP Amoco Indonesia.

title: Governor And Mayor Halt Feud To Help Bush
description: Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani put aside their intermittent five-year feud last night and appeared on the same stage in support of Gov. George W. Bush's Presidential campaign, heaping praise on Mr. Bush and even each other as they posed, if slightly uncomfortably, for a display of unity.

title: Mercurial but Resilient, Argentine Opera Perks Up
description: It took three architects to complete the acoustically superb and richly detailed Teatro Colon here -- one died early in the construction, another was murdered by his butler, who was involved with his wife -- before the scheduled inaugural performance of ''Otello'' in 1908. Then, taking Verdian melodrama to another level, Antonio Paoli, the great Puerto Rican tenor who was to sing Otello, came down with the flu, forcing in a last-minute slapdash ''Aida.''

title: Inspired by a Movie Heroine, A Girl Escapes One Life
description: The torment of adolescence in an unhappy family is depicted deftly and sensitively by the Canadian filmmaker Lea Pool in ''Set Me Free'' (''Emporte-Moi'').

title: Nets-76ers: A Bitter Rivalry Taking On an Early Bloom
description: By having the brass to open training camp only an hour east of Philadelphia today, the Nets have angered the Philadelphia 76ers and added more drama to the rancorous relationship that is developing between the two clubs. If the teams' players match the off-the-court fireworks of the past month with fierce and competitive play, the up-and-coming 76ers could become something the Nets' president, Michael Rowe, said the franchise has never had: a truly bitter rival.

title: Cranberry Farmers Accused of Deception
description: A coalition of state environmental and public interest groups, charging that cranberry farmers had deceived state officials about their need to use sensitive wetlands to expand their bogs, called yesterday on Gov. Christine Todd Whitman to withdraw her support from the expansion request.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LENZNER, LAURA ADASKO
description: LENZNER-Laura Adasko. On October 3, 1999, at age 50. Beloved wife of Allan. Loving mother of Benjamin, Sam and David. Dear daughter of Mary Adasko and the late Herbert Isaac Adasko. Devoted sister of Hardy Adasko. Loving aunt to several nieces and nephews. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Wednesday, 11:30 AM. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Thoracic Oncology Service, Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital, 1275 York Avenue, New York, NY 10021.

title: Exposing America's Role in Chile
description: The arrest of Gen. Augusto Pinochet of Chile last year in London sparked the Clinton Administration to examine America's own role in Mr. Pinochet's 1973 coup and subsequent reign of terror. In February the Administration began to search its files, and relevant materials are being declassified in three installments. Several agencies, notably the State Department, are releasing valuable information. But the Central Intelligence Agency, while disclosing material on human rights abuses in Chile, has balked at declassifying files about Washington's involvement in them. With the second installment of documents due out soon, the C.I.A. needs to understand that full disclosure of Washington's role is in America's interest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEUSTADTER, HELENE
description: NEUSTADTER-Helene. Congregation Kneseth Israel, Far Rockaway, NY, mourns with heartfelt sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, and extends condolences to the entire family. Tzvi Flaum, Rabbi Ralph Pelcovitz, Rabbi Emeritus Noah Fleschner, President

title: Obuchi Picks Aide Linked To Buddhists For Cabinet
description: Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi shuffled his Cabinet today, adding a member of a Buddhist-backed political party to give his Government the support of the largest coalition in Japan in more than 40 years.

title: Senate Rejects Judge Chosen By President For U.S. Court
description: The Senate rejected one of President Clinton's nominees for Federal court judgeships today, voting along party lines after a bitter debate over whether the Missouri judge was too reluctant to vote for the death penalty.

title: After 23 Years, the Supreme Court Turns Again to the Limits on Campaign Contributions
description: The Justices of the Supreme Court came face to face today with the legacy of the Court's performance on the matter of money and politics, hearing arguments in a case from Missouri that challenges the continued validity of the $1,000 contribution limits the Court last examined and upheld 23 years ago.

title: Trooper Chief Faces Inquiry On Tampering With Test Score
description: In the latest incident to sully the image of the New Jersey State Police, investigators are looking into allegations that the department's Acting Superintendent improperly helped two trooper recruits get jobs last year by striking negative comments from their psychological evaluations.

title: Saint's Bones Land in New York to Start U.S. Tour
description: The remains of a young French saint whose simple faith has become an example of serenity and a subject of veneration for many Roman Catholics arrived in New York City yesterday, beginning a four-month tour of the United States and Canada.

title: JURY CHARGES 3, ONE A BANK AIDE, IN RUSSIAN CASE
description: A Federal grand jury in Manhattan indicted three Russian immigrants and three of their companies yesterday, the first criminal charges to come out of the investigation of possible money laundering at the Bank of New York.

title: A Big Party, in Control
description: To the Editor:

title: Astros Get Jump On Braves' Maddux, Then Pull Away
description: The Astros began today as underdogs, but they ended the day leading their series with the Braves.

title: Both Parties Seek a Graceful Way To Put Off a Nuclear Treaty Vote
description: With both sides acknowledging that the Senate would soundly reject a landmark treaty banning underground nuclear testing, Democrats and Republicans today each sought a face-saving way to put off a vote and declare victory.

title: In Role of Yankees' D.H., It's the Comeback Kid
description: Darryl Strawberry lifted up his blue T-shirt to show the nasty scar that runs across his navel and his lower abdominal muscles, a permanent reminder of where he did not want to be at this time last October.

title: N.Y.U. Library Scofflaw Taken Out of Circulation
description: A 44-year-old former New York University student was arrested, the police said yesterday, after he refused to return more than 500 overdue books to the campus libraries, despite dozens of calls and letters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENFIELD, LEO
description: GREENFIELD-Leo. Beloved husband of his devoted wife, Dianna. Cherished father of Kimberly (Keith) Jordan. Adored brother of Bernice Silverman. Dear uncle of Bennett Shaffer and Adam and Noah Silverman. Service 10 AM Thursday at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue, New York.

title: The Lesson of Game 1: No Need to Be Afraid
description: Not only did the Mets win their last three games of the regular season and force a playoff for the playoffs, not only did they win the playoff and advance to the post-season, not only did they defeat the upstart Arizona Diamondbacks in the opening game of their National League division series. As if all of those deeds last night weren't sufficient to shut up the doubters and the critics and the vacillators, the Mets also exposed Randy Johnson as a myth.

title: The Onion That Won't Make You Cry
description: A WALK through the Union Square Greenmarket last Wednesday revealed an incongruous scene. The fizz of summer had gone flat but had not quite disappeared. The piles of tomatoes had dwindled to a few crates of forlorn fruits; there were no more crowds sorting through corn.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: EARTHGRAINS CO., St. Louis, said it would close a plant in Johnson City, Tenn., and cut 95 jobs to streamline operations.

title: Hernandez and Yankees Manhandle Texas
description: Orlando Hernandez passed his manager in the Yankees clubhouse yesterday afternoon and grinned, and Joe Torre suspected Hernandez's expression was meant entirely to reassure him. As in, ''Don't worry, I've got everything under control.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, PRINCISS
description: LEWIS-Princiss. Tifereth IsraelTown & Village Synagogue mourns the loss of its member and extends heartfelt condolences to her entire family. Rabbi Laurence A. Sebert Rabbi Abigail Sosland Carol J. Green, President

title: Frontrunner In Indonesia Seems to Fall Off the Pace
description: Suddenly, the odds-on favorite in the race for the presidency is looking vulnerable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEWART, DAVID
description: STEWART-David. Born February 24, 1964, died October 2, 1999. Lived in Arcata, CA. Known as Light Eagle. ''The Circle of Loving Companions Will Hold You Forever In Our Arms.''

title: Giuliani Offers Senatorial View on Defense
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that if he were a United States Senator, he would use the debate over a treaty that would ban underground nuclear testing to pressure President Clinton for a stronger national strategic defense policy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, DOROTHY REFSON
description: STONE-Dorothy Refson. Fifth Avenue Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of the beloved mother of its esteemed member, Mr. Philip S. Refson, and extends heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family. Dr. Sol Roth, Rabbi, David Yagoda, Chairman, Dr. William Schwartz, President

title: For Manufacturing Jobs, Boom Towns Past and Future
description: Smaller cities in the South and West have enjoyed the fastest growth in factory jobs since the late 1980's, led by Boise, Idaho, where Micron Technology employs 9,000, a research report shows. Boise is expected to stay hot as its high-technology boom fuels traditional industries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRALL, LILLIAN W. (NEE WEISS)
description: KRALL-Lillian W. (nee Weiss), 87 years, of Clearbrook, Monroe Township, NJ, on October 4, 1999. Surviving are two sons: Martin D. of NYC, formerly of Bethesda MD, and Chuck of Los Angeles, CA; A sister Bertha Konowitz of CT and two granddaughters, Kirstie of NYC, formerly of Bethesda, MD, and Elisa of Washington, DC. For information, M. David DeMarco Funeral Home, 732-521-0555.

title: Rights of Indians
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRITZER, BEATRICE
description: KRITZER-Beatrice, 88. On October 4, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Milton. Loving mother of Ruth Greenwald and Carol Basner and sons-in-law, Fred and Mickey. Cherished grandmother of Nancy Hagan, Jay and Andy Greenwald, Amy Kuriloff, Julie Assael and the late Margaret Basner. Proud great grandmother of seven. Private graveside service on Wednesday, October 6. Shiva will be observed on Thursday afternoon & evening at the home of Carol Basner, 312 Westwood Road, Woodmere, NY.

title: Treatment Without Trials
description: To the Editor:

title: Marker For Cancer Of Prostate May Fight It
description: The logic has long sounded so compelling that few have questioned it: A particular protein seeps out of the prostate of a man who has prostate cancer. The more of that protein in the bloodstream, then, the worse it must be for the cancer patient.

title: G.O.P. Leaders in House Offer Alternative on Patients' Rights
description: House Republican leaders, trying to stave off passage of a bipartisan bill defining a wide range of new patients' rights, threw their support today behind an alternative measure that would allow injured patients to sue health insurance companies in some circumstances.

title: To Build a Better New York Subway
description: To the Editor:

title: Striking Yonkers Teachers Focus Ire on Superintendent
description: It has been in some ways the most personal of stalemates, with an angry union squared off against a superintendent who has been a lightning rod for discontent.

title: Rule No. 1 in Picking a Bottle: Forget Rules
description: THE matching of food with wine is a culinary minefield. There are those who insist that anything goes with anything, and then there are those who equate the union of lamb chop and red wine with the holy state of matrimony. These are the ones who inflict us with lines like ''I'm not sure a '96 cabernet would marry well with the canard a l'orange.''

title: National News Briefs; Doctor to Be Airlifted From the South Pole
description: Dr. Jerri Nielsen, who has been treating herself for a breast lump while trapped in a research station at the South Pole, will be airlifted out as soon as possible, at the urging of doctors in the United States.

title: Metro Business; 1440 Broadway Is Sold
description: Investment Properties Associates has agreed to sell a 25-story, 690-square-foot building at 1440 Broadway near Times Square to Max Capital Management Corporation for $152 million.

title: Moscow Says It Holds North Chechnya; Rebels Vow Defiance
description: Russia said today that its troops had seized the northern third of Chechnya in a bold attempt to hem in Islamic militants who have taken refuge there.

title: Business Travel; Year 2000 concerns are causing some airlines to cut more flights than usual for New Year's Eve.
description: AIRLINES typically reduce the number of flights on Dec. 31, because experience has taught them that most people have already arrived at their destination by then, in plenty of time to welcome in the new year. But this Dec. 31, a number of airlines are cutting back more than usual.

title: In Taiwan, A Push for New Fibers
description: TAIPEI  The traditional function of clothes is to protect one from the elements or, at the very least, preserve one's modesty. A garment should preferably also come in the latest fashionable shape and color. But that is no longer enough.

title: I Call You at Dinner Time
description: This feature, which will appear regularly on this page, is a first-person account of working. Angelo L. Morales, 42, a telemarketer, is director of new-business development at Access Telemarket Inc. in Methuen, Mass. He has helped raise money for the Republican National Committee and sold subscriptions to TV Guide. He oversees 30 callers, mostly women, on the evening shift.

title: My Transforming Moments
description: Geraldine Laybourne is chairman and chief executive of Oxygen Media Inc., a multimedia company in New York that is developing a cable network for women.

title: Death Threats Against Mayor Said to Rise
description: In a rare glimpse of the city's security mind-set, the New York Police Department's intelligence chief said yesterday that the number of death threats against Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is rising, and that the department has become increasingly concerned about the possibility that city and private institutions will be the targets of terrorists.

title: You Really Can Go Home Again If You're Gore and Home Is Nashville
description: Clint LeMoine understood exactly what Vice President Al Gore meant last week when he said he was moving his Presidential campaign headquarters from ''K Street in Washington to the aisles of Kmart in Nashville.''

title: Accounts
description: * Powertel Inc., West Point, Ga., a provider of wireless personal communications services in the Southeast, to Martin/Williams Advertising, Minneapolis, a unit of Omnicom Group, as its agency of record. The account, with billings estimated at $15 million, had been handled by Pollak Levitt & Nel Advertising, Atlanta.

title: Wallace Rejoins Knicks After Two Years in Exile
description: It was in the middle of a telephone conversation with Coach Jeff Van Gundy over the summer when John Wallace booted up his uncanny, megabyte memory and recalled the details of a sequence most players would choose to erase.

title: To Build a Better New York Subway
description: To the Editor:

title: New Shops Showcase an International Roster : Paris's Eclectic Boutiques
description: PARIS  The ever-expanding boutique scene here is an eclectic mix of Italian, Dutch, Japanese, American and even French newcomers. Certainly, the most unusual is Paola Frani, 3 bis Rue des Rosiers, where, in a Christo-inspired environment of draped swags of unbleached cotton, nothing is quite what it seems.

title: 32 Nobel Laureates in Physics Back Atomic Test Ban
description: A group of 32 Nobel laureates in physics urged the Senate yesterday to approve the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty, calling it ''central to future efforts to halt the spread of nuclear weapons.''

title: Independent Serb Journalists Defend Their Work
description: When a Montenegrin journalist suggested that the independent Serbian news media needed ''de-Nazification'' as much as the Serbian people, two respected Serbian editors had heard enough and stalked out of a Western-sponsored conference in disgust.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A New System For Nasdaq Is Disclosed
description: THE chairman of the National Association of Securities Dealers, Frank G. Zarb, disclosed details yesterday of an electronic system that he said would make trading Nasdaq shares more efficient and fairer for investors.

title: U.S. Told It Must Pay $550 Million or Risk Losing U.N. Vote
description: The United States has to pay the United Nations $350 million more than the $200 million already appropriated by Congress for back dues to avoid being stripped of its vote in the General Assembly, the organization's chief financial officer said today.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORITA, AKIO
description: MORITA-Akio. The Staff and Trustees of The Museum of Modern Art are deeply saddened by the passing of Akio Morita, a long time friend and supporter of the Museum. With his wife Yoshiko, a Trustee of the Museum, his interest and generosity were far reaching. To Mrs. Morita and other members of the family, we send our profound sympathy. David Rockefeller, Chairman Emeritus Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Agnes Gund, President Glenn D. Lowry, Director The Museum of Modern Art, NY

title: Rising Above Midcentury Gloom, Powerfully
description: It is a commonplace in writing about the arts that the mood of a work does not necessarily reflect the passing mood of its creator. Yet often those moods do indeed coincide; if such instances seem exceptional, it is because relatively few works conceived in the grip of strong emotion also possess the broad vision and magnanimity that allow an artwork to transcend its circumstances and survive its time.

title: See Warren Run (40 Years Ago)
description: Is Warren Beatty running for President?

title: Williams Catches Fire As Texas Folds Tent
description: Bernie Williams glided across center field, his eyes staring straight into the black night and his mouth opening and closing while he sprinted after a deep fly ball. Williams grabbed Juan Gonzalez's blast in right-center and slid across the grass as he caught it. All the while, Williams looked in control.

title: Ottawa
description: A group of 200 Ottawa Senators season-ticket holders are suing the team's star player and captain, Aleksei Yashin, and his New Jersey-based agent, Mark Gandler, over Yashin's refusal to play this season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORENSTEIN, LEO L., MD
description: ORENSTEIN-Leo L., MD. The Officers and Members of The New York Psychoanalytic Institute and Society express their deepest sympathy at the death of their respected and beloved colleague and member.

title: Enjoyment Without Gouging
description: To the Editor:

title: Francis C. Turner, 90, Dies; Shaped the Interstate System
description: Francis C. Turner, often called the chief engineer of the Interstate System of highways that redrew the map of America, died on Saturday at a hospice in Goldsboro, N.C. He was 90.

title: The Ego Of a Novelist Crowds An Old Manse
description: When the life of an artist is described in ''Give Me Your Answer, Do!,'' the rancorous and sentimental new play by Brian Friel, you can bet that it won't be pretty. Both the German composer Schumann and the American blues master known as Leadbelly are invoked with tales of the unspeakable horrors they endured. And as for the two novelists who figure in this comic drama, suffice it to say that the wife of one of them is moved to observe, ''How wretched you are!''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUMSTEIN, ANNA
description: BLUMSTEIN-Anna. Died peacefully in New York City on October 4, 1999, at age 90. Beloved wife of the late Abraham Blumstein, devoted mother of Stanley Blumstein, Adele B. Roberts, and Barbara Kolbrener, proud motherin-law of Karen Kruger, Dr. I. Lloyd Roberts, & Jack Kolbrener. Remembered lovingly by eight grandchildren and fourteen great grandchildren. Services are on Wednesday at 11:30 AM at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opp LIRR), Great Neck, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASEY, JAMES P.
description: CASEY-James P. The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York, records with profound sorrow the death of James P. Casey, a Life Member of the Society, and extends sincere sympathy to his family. Willia, J. Cronin, President Robert J. Reilly, Historian

title: MINING COMPANIES IN TALKS
description: The London-listed mining company Lonmin P.L.C. said it was in early talks with Ashanti Goldfields of Ghana to purchase the 68 percent of the African gold-mining concern that it does not already own in a deal valued at roughly $650 million. The transaction would restore Lonmin, part of the former trading conglomerate Lonrho P.L.C, as a mining company. Lonmin's South African mines make it the world's third-largest platinum producer. Ashanti is the continent's third-largest gold producer. Alan Cowell

title: August Economic Indicators Slipped 0.1%
description: The index of leading economic indicators fell in August for only the second time in 11 months, as a drop in stocks and a shorter manufacturing workweek offset gains in orders for nonmilitary and consumer goods.

title: An Imaginative Hand in the Theater District
description: IT was dessert time, and three young women, tucked into one of Local's cozy booths, were doing some serious fork work. The conversation had come to a dead halt. You could hear the tiny taps of metal against china as the microsurgery sped forward. One of the three looked up from her banana toffee dome and said, almost carelessly, ''This is the best dessert I have ever eaten in my life.'' Her companions did not even look up from their plates. The tapping went on.

title: Op-Art; Writers & Commerce: A Brief History
Not Insured, And Not Worried
description: Last week we learned that poverty in the United States has been declining of late, but now we're told that the number of Americans without health insurance has risen to 44.3 million -- 833,000 more than a year ago and 4.5 million more than when Bill Clinton took office in 1993. Even in households with annual incomes of at least $50,000, the number of people without insurance increased last year, to 12.2 million.

title: As Options Fade, G.O.P. Is Considering Broad Cuts
description: Republicans in Congress today weighed across-the-board Federal spending cuts of $16 billion, a last-ditch attempt to keep their promise to stop draining Social Security funds to run the Government.

title: Biotech Companies Feel Overlooked by New York
description: For many years, New York City officials have turned a cold shoulder to the biotechnology industry, prompting entrepreneurs trained in prestigious local medical research institutions to set up their companies in more hospitable places, according to a number of scientists and others in the field.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Sept. 25 about the College Board's creation of a commercial subsidiary to start a Web site for college applicants gave an outdated name for another company that operates a Web site with test-preparation courses and services relating to college admissions. That company, now a unit of the Washington Post Company, is known as Kaplan Educational Centers, no longer Stanley Kaplan.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLUCKAUF, IRMA (NEE SCHACK)
description: GLUCKAUF-Irma (nee Schack). Died October 4, 1999 in her 87th year. Beloved wife of the late Paul. Loving mother of Joan and Jorn Haahr and the late Peter. Devoted grandmother and great grandmother. Services Wednesday, October 6, 1:15 PM, at The Riverside, Amsterdam Avenue and 76th Street. Contributions in her memory may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: Subtleties of Pan-Latin Fare in a Changing East Village
description: A DECADE ago, when the quirky Bernard Organic French Cuisine opened on Avenue C in the East Village, the location was considered perverse, if not downright dangerous. But the food was good, and it drew a wide-ranging crowd, uneasy but excited at the prospect of hearing a few gunshots between bites of mushroom souffle, or stepping over some used hypodermic needles while hurrying to cars waiting at the door.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the photographer and Buddhist nun Marilyn Silverstone on Monday misstated the given name of a photojournalist whose work, along with hers and others', will be exhibited at the Scottish National Portrait Gallery in Edinburgh beginning Nov. 5. The photojournalist is Eve Arnold, not Eva.

title: Wine Sauce With a Secret
description: I FIRST had this mysterious, dark pinot noir sauce last spring, at a Seattle restaurant called Brasa. It was served without much ceremony over asparagus, which it vaulted to another level.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHARDSON, LEE D.
description: RICHARDSON-Lee D., 73. Died on Saturday at his home. Beloved husband of the late Elane Richardson. Cherished father of Rachel and Jonathan. Devoted brother of Dolores Levine. Services will be held on Wednesday, October 6, 1:30 P.M. at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be made to the Actor's Fund, 729 7th Avenue, 10th floor, New York, New York 10019.

title: In Rare Step, Clinton Will Go to Teamster Dinner
description: In a move that could shore up Vice President Al Gore's labor support, President Clinton will speak tomorrow at a New York dinner honoring the president of the teamster's union, James P. Hoffa, becoming the first President to appear so prominently with the historically troubled union in decades.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLITKIN, NATALIE W.
description: PLITKIN-Natalie W. Beloved and devoted wife of Henry J. Plitkin for 63 years; mother of Elizabeth Brinnitzer; and mother in-law of Bernard Brinnitzer. She was deeply loved by all three. Died October 2, 1999, after a long illness. Funeral Tuesday, 1:15 PM at ''The Riverside'' 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. Visiting hours Monday, 7-9 PM.

title: Rush-Hour Rail Crash in West London Kills at Least 26
description: Two commuter trains slammed into each other and burst into flames during the morning rush hour today, killing at least 26 people and severely injuring scores more on the same section of track in West London where an alarmingly similar crash occurred two years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULNICK, ALBERT S.
description: MULNICK-Albert S. Age 89, of Long Branch, New Jersey, formerly of Farmingdale, NJ and New York City, died on October 5, 1999. Loving husband of Ruth for 36 years. Devoted father of Jerry, Monte, Steve, and Phyllis. Beloved grandfather of Andrea, Janice, Harvey, Mollie, and Michael, and adored great grandfather of Corey, Drew, Jordan, and Carly. Services today, Wednesday, October 6, 1999, at 1 P.M., at BloomfieldCooper Funeral Home, Kings Highway and Route 35, Ocean, NJ.

title: Hurrah for Cranberries (but You Knew That)
description: ANOTHER old wives' tale may be on the threshold of sound science. Since the turn of the century people have suggested that cranberries help to cure bacterial infections of the kidney and bladder, but no one had ever been able to prove it. For years cranberry growers have been frustrated because they could not advertise a claim they were convinced was true.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TENENBAUM, JEANNE
description: TENENBAUM-Jeanne. A memorial gathering will be held on Thursday, October 7, at 5:30PM at the Ethical Culture Society on West 64th Street and Central Park West.

title: Just Hold the Music
description: IF you are looking for a quiet, pleasant place in Morningside Heights for coffee and a muffin in the morning, it's hard to beat TOAST, as airy and amiable a spot as there is in the neighborhood. But the music gets awfully loud at lunch and dinner, and since I've never understood the combination of loud music and eating, I'd just as soon leave the dining room to those who don't mind it and take my meal home.

title: Priest vs. 'Big Chicken' In Fight for Labor Rights
description: It was an incongruous sight, the white-haired priest in black shirt and white collar, standing in an immense poultry house filled with thousands of clucking birds and the acrid stench of manure.

title: The Thick and the Thin
description: To the Editor:

title: To Build a Better New York Subway
description: To the Editor:

title: Wealthy Nassau Makes Itself a Fiscal Mess
description: From the quaintest village hall to the largest county seat, in Albany, Trenton and Washington, governments at every level of society are enjoying record surpluses amassed during the nation's long economic expansion.

title: Fliers From Transit Union Draw on Class Distinctions
description: Class warfare has largely disappeared from New York's labor scene, but the Transit Workers Union has embraced it with a vengeance in its campaign for a new contract.

title: So Close, Borges's Worlds of Reality and Invention
description: SELECTED NONFICTIONS

title: Last Berth Up for Grabs
description: The winner of the last playoff spot will be determined on Saturday when the Miami Fusion plays host to the Colorado Rapids and the New England Revolution visits D.C. United.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTOCK, HERBERT, DR.
description: WEINSTOCK-Herbert, Dr. Of Eastpointe, Florida. Formerly of Great Neck, New York. Adored husband and shining star of Adele for 56 beautiful years of marriage. Loving father of Diane and Robert Meltzer, Wendy & Robert Morris, Mark & Ann Weinstock. Devoted grandfather of Jocelyn, Darren, Michelle, Alana, and Marisa. He was a gentleman and a gentle man. Always patient, never complaining, he was the dearest. We were privileged to have had him. Graveside service in New York. Donations may be made to the American Heart Association.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHUB, RUTH L.
description: SHUB-Ruth L. on October 5, 1999 formerly of Sarasota, FL. & Wingdale, NY. Mother of Michael, Charles & Ellen Shub. Grandmother of Wesley, Sarah, Jonathan & Jessica. Service Wednesday 3 PM at Beecher Funeral Home, Pleasantville, NY. Interment private. Donations to Alzheimers Association, Manatee/Sarasota Counties Chapter, Inc., 1230 South Tuttle Ave, Sarasota, FL 34239, in her memory would be appreciated.

title: DANISH BID WITHDRAWN
description: Denmark's third-largest bank, Kapital Holding A.S., said it was withdrawing its $804 million bid for the Danish lending agency FIH A.S. because the asking price was too high, clearing the way for a takeover by Swedbank A.B. of Sweden. Swedbank, Scandinavia's third-largest bank, offered last month to buy FIH for $919 million. Kapital said it could not justify a higher price. Swedbank also said its chief executive, Reinhold Geijer, had been removed by the board for reasons not related to the bid for FIH.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUMBA, DOROTHY HEIER (NEE EISENSTADT)
description: ZUMBA-Dorothy Heier (nee Eisenstadt). Of Miami Beach, FL. On October 5. Daughter of the late Rabbi Ben Zion, Talmudic scholar, and the late Sarah Eisenstadt; beloved mother of Robert Heier, adored wife of the late Alfonse Zumba; loving sister of Murray, the late Joseph, and Prof. Abraham S.
