Eisenstadt; grandmother of Stephanie and Carolyn Heier, caring aunt and great-aunt, generous benefactor of Judaic causes. Visiting hours 6-8PM at the Chapel, Thursday, October 7, I.J. Morris Funeral Home, 1895 Flatbush Ave (718-377-8610). Graveside services Friday, October 8, 11 A.M., Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, L.I.

title: Share the Wealth
description: To the Editor:

title: William Wegman's dogs take the plunge into TV commercials for the Honda Odyssey minivan.
description: A CANINE ''family'' is being enlisted to help stimulate sales in a product category where the competition resembles a, well, dogfight.

title: Behind the Scenes, Raising the City's Profile
description: IF there is such a thing as an unofficial permanent government in New York City -- the people who really run the place, while politicians surface and sink -- then you might call Samuel H. Lindenbaum the secretary of housing and urban development.

title: TELECOM ITALIA PLANS CUTS
description: The Italian phone company Telecom Italia S.p.A. said it planned to eliminate 13,000 jobs in its fixed-line operations, 9,000 of them through attrition. It also said its consolidated earnings before special items, taxes, depreciation and amortization were projected to rise 8 percent in 2000.

title: Zimmer A Victim Of Yanks' Power
description: Chuck Knoblauch lined a foul ball into the first-base dugout in the fifth inning, and last night immediately had a different feel for the Yankees. The ball hit Don Zimmer in the jaw and the left ear, causing the 68-year-old coach to tumble off the bench and to the cement floor.

title: Legal Dispute Could Further Delay Nuclear Waste Plan
description: The Energy Department's plan to bury thousands of tons of high-level nuclear waste at Yucca Mountain in Nevada faces a new complication, a charge that the law firm it has chosen to shepherd the project through regulatory approval has a conflict of interest.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Competition has produced a price war in the long distance market. The merger appears to be a surrender. How can this be good for consumers? The parties will bear a heavy burden to show how consumers would be better off.''

title: Russia Raids Bank in Laundering Inquiry
description: The police raided a leading bank tonight as a Russian investigation into possible money laundering through the Bank of New York appeared to be gathering momentum.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: SHELL CANADA SELLING PROPERTIES FOR $524 MILLION
description: Shell Canada Ltd. agreed yesterday to sell its Plains business to Apache Canada Ltd., a unit of the Apache Corporation of Houston. Shell said the sale price, before adjustments, was about $524 million. It also said it expected to report an after-tax gain of about $160 million on the sale, which is to close Nov. 30, subject to regulatory approval. Shell Canada Ltd., a unit of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, said the sale included its conventional oil properties in southeast Saskatchewan and north-central Alberta and its interest in an oilfield and a gas plant in Alberta, as well as selected landholdings in Western Canada. Apache is a fossil-fuel production and exploration company with 1998 sales of $876 million.

title: Batter's Up, but Little Fans Aren't, for Late Game
description: Danny Friel is about as big a Mets fan as 9-year-olds come. Just this year, he's gone to John Franco's baseball camp, shaken hands with Al Leiter and spent his birthday at Shea Stadium with his family and his best pals.

title: Sibling Revelry: When More Isn't Merrier
description: THE first night I uncovered parkerhouse rolls in a bread basket, at Wild Blue, I thought they were a novel revival. At a time when strong and chewy sourdough is almost a cliche, why not bring back soft and buttery yeast rolls from the Betty Crocker heyday?

title: Fighting History and a Lack of Respect
description: In Nomar Garciaparra, the Boston Red Sox have the American League batting champion. In Pedro Martinez, they have probably the best pitcher in baseball. And yet they are seen by many as the eighth-seeded squad among eight teams in the playoffs. Certainly they are fourth among four teams in their bracket.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; Agency Confronts Mexico Airline Company as Monopoly
description: When Jorge Garcia, a travel agent, books a flight between Mexico City and New York, the round-trip price for the cross-continent flight is typically $400, maybe less. When Mr. Garcia reserves a round trip between here and San Luis Potosi, only 260 miles away, the cost is $340.

title: Sprint's News Shakes Up Kansas City
description: Just days after the dedication of a $920 million headquarters complex in Kansas, the Sprint Corporation spent today issuing reassurances that its pending acquisition by MCI Worldcom Inc. would not lead to substantial cutbacks in its operations in the Kansas City area.

title: Subway Series Dreams
description: A cynic might ask whether Bobby Valentine, the Mets manager, scripted his team's maddening, roller-coaster finish in an effort to steal some attention from the Yankees, a team so steady that people start asking what's wrong when they win only 98 games. But this is a moment for enjoyment, not cynicism. The Mets are back in the playoffs for the first time in 11 years. Beyond that, two New York teams are in the post-season together for the first time since 1956, when the Yankees beat the Brooklyn Dodgers in a seven-game series highlighted by Don Larsen's perfect game.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OHRINGER, MILTON H.
description: OHRINGER-Milton H. October 3, 1999. Age 86. Devoted husband of Ray B. Ohringer. Devoted husband and beloved brother-in-law, uncle and great-uncle. Services, 12:45, Thursday, October 7 at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. & Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in memory of Mr. Ohringer to The N.T.I.D. Foundation, 52 Lomb Memorial Dr., Rochester, NY 14623-5604, attention: Michael J. Catillaz.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREIREICH, ROZSI (PREISLER)
description: FREIREICH-Rozsi (Preisler). Of Briarwood, NY. Died at home on October 5, 1999. Companion of Harry Schachter; mother of Andrew and Ronald; mother-in-law of Bonnie Freireich, Tina Potter and Barbara Klein; grandmother of Tracy, Gaea, Zoe, Jennifer, Garrett and Alix; great grandmother of Mackenzie and Kendall. Rose was a wonderful woman, much loved and respected by her family and many friends. She was born on April 23, 1916 in Debrecen, Hungary, the youngest of five children. She left Nazi Europe and emigrated to Cuba in 1938, and to the U.S. in 1941. She settled in the Bronx, later in Queens, where she raised two sons of whom she was very proud. Rose graduated Queens College in 1970 and worked in the New York City public school system for 15 years. Rose was truly the center of our family. We will miss you and never forget you, Draga Rozsi. Services on Wednesday at 12:30, Jewish Memorial Chapel, 841 Allwood Rd, Clifton, NJ. Donations may be made to Jewish Association for Services to the Aged (JASA) or the Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society (HIAS).

title: Fatal London Crash
description: Two commuter trains collided in London, killing at least 26 people and severely injuring scores more. The search for victims was suspended at night to await equipment to lift a mangled car that it was feared would reveal dozens more bodies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, MARTIN S.
description: DAVIS-Martin S. The President, the Board of Trustees and the entire Montefiore community deeply mourn the untimely death of our dear friend and esteemed colleague, Martin S. Davis. A devoted member of the Montefiore Board of Trustees and its Executive Committee since 1991, Martin Davis was actively engaged in the leadership of the medical center throughout his tenure and fully committed to improving the health of the boro of the Bronx, which was his boyhood home. A man of vision and compassion, with a singular devotion to causes that truly matter, Martin Davis melded extraordinary skills in business with philanthropy to enrich the lives of countless individuals. His vision and his unyielding devotion to imrpoving childrens' health care helped to inspire The Children's Hospital at Montefiore, and he served as co-chair of its Steering Committee. His leadership of that initiative and his magnificent generosity will leave an enduring legacy to children and their families for generations to come. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to his beloved wife, Luella, and his son Philip. He will be missed by all whose lives he touched. Spencer Foreman, MD, President Jay B. Langner, Chairman Board of Trustees Montefiore Medical Center Irwin Redlener, MD, Pres The Children's Hospital at Montefiore

title: FOOD CHAIN
description: Saving Vitamins in Cooking Peppers

title: Rangers' Offense Continues to Find Frustration, Not the Net
description: The Rangers are finding out just how lonely the number one really is.

title: Sports of The Times; Two of the Best Teams Money Can Buy Give a Twist to Fairy Tales
description: IN the span of two weeks, the amazing Mets have crisscrossed the country in pursuit of a dream. They have traveled to the South to the red clay of Georgia, to the East in Pennsylvania, to the Midwest to Ohio. Last night, amid Arizona's desert and cactus, the Mets stunned Randy Johnson and the Arizona Diamondbacks, 8-4, to take a 1-0 lead in the division series, and they began yet another chapter of an unlikely journey.

title: End of Sprint's Europe Venture Is Seen
description: The chief executive of the Sprint Corporation, William T. Esrey, said yesterday that the company's Global One joint venture with France Telecom S.A. and Deutsche Telekom A.G. would be bought by one of the three partners within months.

title: INTERNET SERVICES COMPANY IN DEAL TO ACQUIRE TESSERA
description: IXL Enterprises, an Internet services company, agreed yesterday to acquire Tessera Enterprise Systems for $120 million. IXL, which is based in Atlanta, said the purchase of Tessera -- a provider of customer-relationship management systems based in Boston -- would give it advanced data warehousing and data-mining technologies. The acquisition will be the first in more than a year for IXL, which has more than 1,700 employees and 20 offices in five countries. The company posted revenue of $126.3 million in the last 12 months.

title: THE CHEF
description: BISCOTTI hold on to their super crunchiness with ferocity: not even an overheated New York City apartment can make biscotti go limp. They get a little of their crunch from baking soda and a lot of it from the way they are baked. Almost by definition biscotti are double-baked, the first time to cook them, the second time to dry and crisp them.

title: Internet Seek and Find
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Reality Hits Singers In the Home Stretch; On a Real Stage, Bracing for an Audience
description: As it approaches, the premiere of an opera, almost unbearably languorous in its gestation, gallops toward opening night with frightful speed.

title: Leonard S. Shoen, 83, Founder Of U-Haul, the Trailer Company
description: Leonard S. Shoen, who created the multibillion-dollar do-it-yourself moving industry in 1945 when he welded together a trailer, painted it an attention-grabbing orange and called his little company U-Haul, died on Monday morning after he drove his car into a utility pole near Las Vegas, Nev., his hometown for the last 20 years. He was 83.

title: DIALOGUE: A Struggle Over the Republican Soul; George W. Bush, the Betrayer
description: George W. Bush sent Republican conservatives an unmistakable message this week: Go pound sand. I don't need you.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dividend Increases Slow Even as the Economy Soars

title: Report on Acid Rain Finds Good News and Bad News
description: Over the last two decades, countries in northern Europe and North America have been enacting regulations to reduce smokestack emissions of sulfur in an effort to curb acid rain and its harmful effect on the environment. Today, in what researchers say is the first comprehensive look at the effect of those reductions on rivers and lakes, an international team of scientists is reporting a nearly universal decrease on both continents in the levels of sulfates, the major acidifying pollutant deposited by acid rain in surface water.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TROY, DONALD
description: TROY-Donald. The Board of Directors, Volunteers and Staff of Hospice Care Network offer sincere condolences to fellow Director, Romayne Kovach Troy, and the Troy family upon the untimely passing of their husband and father. John King, Chairman Maureen Hinkelman, CEO

title: Too Much Time Off Dulling Isles' Skates
description: The only thing worse for the Islanders than losing to the lowly Tampa Bay Lightning in the season opener was dwelling on the loss for more than a week before getting a chance to play again. But that is exactly what the Islanders have been forced to do because of an eight-day layoff between their first and second games of the season.

title: MITCHELL ENERGY CONSIDERS A POSSIBLE SALE OR MERGER
description: The Mitchell Energy and Development Corporation, an oil and natural gas company, hired Goldman, Sachs & Company and Chase Securities Inc. yesterday to explore strategic alternatives, including a sale or merger. Mitchell has a market value of about $1.7 billion. Its class A and class B shares have both more than doubled this year, and George Mitchell, 80, the chief executive, wants to take advantage of the run-up, analysts said. Mitchell, based in the Woodlands, Tex., had 1998 revenue of $701 million. Its class A shares rose 81.25 cents, to $23.75, and the class B shares gained $1.25, to $23.125.

title: Yahoo's Revenue And Profit Rise
description: Yahoo Inc., the No. 1 Internet directory, said today that its third-quarter revenue more than doubled as both its audience and advertising sales rose.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAGNER, ROBERT DEAN
description: WAGNER-Robert Dean, on October 6, 1999 at age 73. An esteemed and beloved professor of English Literature at Sarah Lawrence College from 1953 until his retirement in May of 1999. He served as Dean of the College from 1971-1976, and as head of the Sarah Lawrence College Summer School in London. He leaves his brother C. Roland Wagner; his wife Anneliese; his daughters Elise and Carrie; son-in-law Robin Stout; grandchildren Leah and Alice; and his companion Susan Silver. Funeral Service Friday, 11 A.M., Beecher Funeral Home, Pleasantville, NY. Interment Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, New York. Memorial donations in his memory may be made to Sarah Lawrence College, Bronxville, New York.

title: Fighting the Clock: The Baby Boomers' Quest
description: To the Editor:

title: Datek Online's Chief Agrees To Step Down
description: Under pressure from his own management team and a group of outside investors, Jeffrey A. Citron agreed to step down yesterday as chairman and chief executive of Datek Online Holdings and to relinquish any role in the company he helped fashion into a Wall Street powerhouse.

title: In Malaysia, Women Cover Up But in Colorful and Trendy Way : Headscarf Chic
description: KUALA LUMPUR  Visitors to Malaysia are often surprised to learn that the custom of wearing headscarves  almost universally adhered to by Muslim women in the country today  barely existed 30 years ago.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, the cover article in The Times Magazine on Sunday, about threats to the peace process caused by the claims of different religions on the Temple Mount in Jerusalem at millennium's end, omitted a passage from a paragraph in which an Israeli official speculated about who might instigate violence on the Dome of the Rock, the mosque atop the Mount. The paragraph, which began at the end of page 65, should have read:

title: SINGAPORE PRESS PROFITS
description: The company that publishes virtually all of Singapore's newspapers and several of its magazines, Singapore Press Holdings Ltd., exceeded expectations with a 17.5 percent increase in earnings, to $326.33 million (Singaporean), or $193.6 million (United States), for the year ended Aug. 31. Investment income, wage freezes and tax benefits helped offset a 6.1 percent decline in revenue to $844.8 million (Singaporean), though the company said it expected Singapore's improving economy would probably help to strengthen advertising sales this year.

title: U.S. Wields Defter Weapon Against Iraq: Concrete Bomb
description: American fighter jets patrolling northern Iraq are using an innovative new weapon against President Saddam Hussein: concrete.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: HYPOVEREINSBANK A.G, Munich, said it had bought a 20 percent stake in Babcock & Brown, San Francisco, a company that arranges aircraft leasing financing, for $120 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AITKEN, S. THOMAS
description: AITKEN-S. Thomas, of Palm Beach Gardens, FL., and North Caldwell, N.J., on October 4, 1999. Beloved father of Thomas Wells (and Jennifer) Aitken of North Andover, Mass.; Heather Hyatt Aitken of Brentwood, Calif. Friends may call from 7-9 PM Thursday and 2-4 and 7-9 PM Friday at the Dancy Funeral Home, 9 Smull Ave., Caldwell (973-226-1166). A funeral service will be held 11 AM Saturday in the First Presbyterian Church at Caldwell (corner of Bloomfield & Roseland avenues). In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Center for Hospice Care, 3 High St., Glen Ridge, NJ 07028; Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Lung Cancer Research, 1275 York Avenue, Box E, New York, NY 10021; or Alliance for Lung Cancer Support, Advocacy & Education, 1601 Lincoln Ave., Vancouver, WA 98660. Interment will be private at Riverdale Cemetery, Lewiston, New York.

title: Helping Chechnya
description: To the Editor:

title: The Literary Myth Updated With High-Tech Presentation
description: The mythological hero, setting forth from his commonday hut or castle, is lured, carried away, or else voluntarily proceeds, to the threshold of adventure. There he encounters a shadow presence that guards the passage. The hero may defeat or conciliate this power and go alive into the kingdom of the dark, or be slain by the opponent and descend in death. . . . When he arrives at the nadir of the mythological round, he undergoes a supreme ordeal and gains his reward. -- Joseph Campbell, ''The Hero With a Thousand Faces''

title: New Mexico Governor Resists Draft Efforts by Libertarians
description: Embracing Gov. Gary E. Johnson's support of legalizing drugs as a symbol of his political independence, a local group announced today that it was starting a campaign to draft him as the Libertarian Party candidate for President.

title: A Brazilian Politician Stirs Fear and Debate on Debt
description: Investors in Brazil are beginning to get nervous over the future possibility that the Government might try to renegotiate its domestic debt, which has nearly doubled in recent years.

title: For Nets' Marbury, the Time Is Now to Rank Among Best
description: For three years, Stephon Marbury has been described as a great young point guard, meaning he has the potential to be one of the top playmakers in the National Basketball Association.

title: Daimler in Deal With Canada Workers
description: Less than two hours before a strike deadline, the DaimlerChrysler Corporation reached an agreement late Tuesday with the Canadian Auto Workers union on a new three-year contract covering the company's 13,800 workers in Canada.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Whose Story Is It Anyway?
description: The lives of friends and acquaintances are as necessary to fiction writers as the runaway slave was to Huck Finn, so beware of the novelist or short-story writer as friend. If you don't, then sooner or later you might be pridefully reading your chum's work and the light bulb of recognition will pop in your head and you'll say, ''Whoa, that's me.''

title: U.S. Presses Security Council for Sanctions Against the Taliban
description: The United States asked the Security Council today to impose economic sanctions on the Islamic Taliban movement in Afghanistan, demanding that the Afghans turn over Osama bin Laden, a Saudi-born militant wanted in the United States.

title: Guerrilla Marketing Is Going Mainstream
description: THE moon hung in the sky over Union Square, and fans of the fusion-jazz group Incognito were lined up in front of the Irving Plaza theater, waiting for the doors to open. Ivan Ramirez, ''guerrilla marketer,'' spied an opportunity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDEY, THELMA BARASCH
description: RUDEY-Thelma Barasch. On October 4, 1999, died peacefully at home at age 92. Barnard and Teacher's College Columbia University graduate. Lover of languages and the arts. Dearly beloved wife of the late Samuel Richard Rudey. Devoted mother of John and Laurie Rudey and Liz and Kirk Rudey Ruebenson. Loving grandmother of Matthew Aaron, Spencer Richard, Amanda Kathryn Rudey and Kate Anna Rudey Ruebenson. Sister of Clarence S. Barasch, Jacqueline B. Schneider and the late Gladys B. Blum. Dear sister-in-law, aunt and great aunt. Services Wednesday, October 6th, 11:00 AM at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Ave. at 65th St. Contributions in her memory may be be made to the Thelma and Samuel Rudey Book Fund in care of the Director's Office, Harvard College Library, Cambridge, MA. 02138.

title: Chrebet Back on His Feet And Passes Parcells Test
description: In a Jets locker room in which Otis Smith grimaced and Vinny Testaverde and Leon Johnson hobbled around on crutches, Wayne Chrebet today wore his broadest smile in a month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, MARTIN
description: DAVIS-Martin. A sister Department of Pediatrics in NYC recognizes the major contribution of Mr. Martin Davis to furthering the cause of children's health here in NYC. As former Vice Chairman of Pediatrics at Montefiore Medical Center and a contributor to the initial steps of the creation of the Children's Hospital at Montefiore, I came to respect with the deepest admiration Mr. Davis' commitment to children in need. His desire to create a superb Children's Hospital for children in the Bronx and nearby communities was reflective of his overall values in providing the best for children. The children's environment and I, as an advocate for children, will miss his devotion, creative leadership and dedication. My sincerest condolences to the family and friends who have lost such a distinguished leader. Steven P. Shelov, MD, M.S. Chairman, Dept. of Pediatrics Maimonides Medical Center Professor of Pediatrics S.U.N.Y. Health Science Center at Brooklyn

title: School Official Wants to Mark Israeli Atrocity
description: Urging Israeli teachers to face a dark chapter in their country's past, Education Minister Yossi Sarid has recommended that a massacre of Israeli Arabs 43 years ago this month be marked for the first time in the nation's classrooms.

title: In Style Campaign Aims to Build Brand
description: In Style magazine in New York has begun its first national branding campaign, created by Big Picture Communications in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LENZNER, LAURA ADASKO
description: LENZNER-Laura Adasko. We will forever be touched by your creativity, courage, love. Walking down Broadway will never be the same without you. We'll miss you. Betsy Blachly-Chapin, Ellen Rafel and Irene Selver

title: Davis, Not Strawberry, Is the D.H.
description: Chili Davis, who recently lost part of his responsibility as the everyday designated hitter to Darryl Strawberry, will start tonight's game and face the Rangers' Rick Helling. Joe Torre told both players of his decision after yesterday's workout.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Fading dividends don't always mean the dawn of a recession.
description: IF the measure of corporate America's financial health is its ability and willingness to increase dividends to shareholders, then you might think the country is in a recession.

title: Where's Sprewell? Somewhere In the Ether
description: The wired Latrell Sprewell has a beeper, a cell phone and an E-mail address but has not used one of those methods to communicate with the Knicks this week. Not even an old-fashioned flare.

title: Accounts
description: * Coleman Co., Wichita, Kan., the camping and outdoor leisure-activities products company, to FCB Worldwide, Southfield, Mich., part of True North Communications, to handle its account, which had been dormant. Billings were estimated at $5 million to $10 million.

title: Advanced Micro Says Loss Is Smaller Than Expected
description: Advanced Micro Devices Inc. reported a loss for the third quarter today that was smaller than expected as sales of its new Athlon line of microprocessors accelerated.

title: What Pressure?
description: Rick Helling has the arduous task of trying to make sure that the Rangers do not return to Arlington, Tex., after tonight's game trailing the Yankees by 2-0. If that happened, the series would basically be over. But Helling curiously claimed there is no additional extra pressure on him after the Rangers were buried, 8-0, in Game 1.

title: The Little Black Dress Makes a Comeback
description: PARIS  Quietly propelled by the return of an elegant femininity, after a long period of retirement, a former prima donna of fashion  the little black dress  is making a comeback as a chic and timeless uniform for fashion-jaded consumers.

title: Anxious Pill Maker Puts ABC Interview of Its Chief on the Web
description: A diet-product company yesterday posted on the Internet a complete, unedited videotaped interview between an ABC News correspondent and the company's chief executive in an effort to publicize its concerns that ABC would broadcast an unfair report on the medical risks of its popular dietary supplement.

title: Lehigh Phoenix Rises From Big Steel's Ashes; Eastern Pennsylvania Region Recovers By Turning to Technology Companies
description: When Christopher Reed left here nine years ago to study engineering at Penn State, he assumed he was gone for good. A steelworker's son, he had had firsthand experience with the havoc that the steady decline of Big Steel had wreaked on the area's job market. ''I figured I'd be in California by now,'' Mr. Reed said.

title: Creating Painterly Swirls With Light and Open Spaces
description: The human condition was Jose Limon's preoccupation as a pioneer of American modern dance, and chances are that he would have been pleased with ''The Plain Sense of Things,'' a haunting new work by Doug Varone that opened the Limon Dance Company's season on Tuesday night.

title: Of One Man Who Saw Evil, And Preferred Not to Focus
description: ''A Visitor from the Living,'' a 65-minute documentary by Claude Lanzmann, is a transfixing addendum to this filmmaker's ''Shoah.'' Filmed in 1979, it essentially consists of a single conversation between Mr. Lanzmann and the elderly, distinguished-looking Maurice Rossel.

title: Metro Business; Drug Maker to Cut 700 Jobs as Sales Dip
description: American Home Products Corporation plans to cut 700 jobs as the drug maker's struggling agricultural-chemicals business loses sales to rival Monsanto Company.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It can stub your toe, but there's no chance of collateral damage.''

title: A Subsidy for Health Insurance?
description: To the Editor:

title: Thatcher's Back and She Hasn't Changed a Bit
description: The posters announcing tonight's talk at the Conservative Party conference by former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher declared, ''She's back,'' but the Tories learned with a mixture of delight and dismay that she never really went away.

title: Sports of The Times; A Bump on the Road For Valentine's Band
description: THE Mets return to New York today after an exhilarating three days on the road that saw them accomplish most of want they wanted. Despite last night's 7-1 loss to Arizona, the Mets got more than they bargained for. They defeated Cincinnati in a playoff on Monday to gain the National League wild card, then took Game 1 of their three-of-five-game division series with the Diamondbacks on Tuesday.

title: The Flailing, Failing Rangers Are Baffled
description: It's not as if the Yankees possess some secret formula on how to shut down the fearsome offense of the Texas Rangers. It's not as if the Rangers are numb to the strategy that is destroying them; the Texas coaching staff has reminded the Rangers players to swing only at strikes and to ignore the slop the Yankees' pitchers are throwing out of the strike zone.

title: Harvard's $2.1 Billion Tops Colleges' Big Fund-Raising
description: Universities do not usually set fund-raising goals that they cannot meet, but when Harvard decided in 1992 that it would try to raise $2.1 billion by Dec. 31, 1999, the task seemed herculean: the university would have to collect an average of nearly $1 million a day for seven years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HINES, KENNETH ARDEN, JR.
description: HINES-Kenneth Arden, Jr., of Boston and Osterville, Mass., former Sr. Vice President of Citibank in New York, died unexpectedly October 5. Mr. Hines was born in Meadville, Pennsylvania. He was a graduate of Middlesex School and Yale University. Currently, he was Chief Financial Officer of Cambridge Trade Finance Corp. in Boston. Mr. Hines was an avid sailor. He is survived by his wife, Jody, of Osterville; a son, Kenneth A. Hines III, of Bridgewater, Mass.; a brother, Edward Hines, of Normal, Ill.; and a granddaughter. A memorial service will be held at 11 AM Saturday, October 9, at West Parish Congregational Church, Meeting House Way, West Barnstable, Mass. The family requests that memorial donations be made in the name of Kenneth A. Hines, Jr., to West Parish Congregational Church, Route 149, West Barnstable, MA. 02668 or The American Cancer Society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEUSTADTER, HELENE, (NEE LERNER)
description: NEUSTADTER-Helene, (nee Lerner). The Trustees of Congregation Shearith Israel extend to our fellow Trustee, and Co-Segan, Peter Neustadter, his wife Naomi and their daughters our shared loss on the death of his mother in Israel. Peter's leadership and devotion to our congregation were a source of pride to his mother as they are to us.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COCOA SLIDES. Cocoa fell after Dutch processors announced a bigger-than-expected drop in grinding amid sluggish demand from chocolate makers. In New York, cocoa for December delivery fell $27, to $948 a metric ton.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about dues owed by the United States to the United Nations referred incorrectly to a statement by Joseph E. Connor, the Under Secretary General for Management. He said that without cash reserves, the United Nations had lost financial flexibility, jeopardizing its existence. He did not speak specifically of cash reserves due by Dec. 30.

title: Amalia Rodrigues, 79, Queen Of Fado, Lisbon's Sad Songs
description: Amalia Rodrigues, the Portuguese singer who was considered the queen of fado, died yesterday at her home in Lisbon. She was 79.

title: Between Roots and Reputation; City College Struggles to Remake Itself and Its Image
description: By almost any measure, City College, long the flagship campus of the City University of New York, is in crisis. Morale is low. Enrollment is sliding. The education program may be closed. And despite a widely respected faculty and nationally ranked programs, a reputation is in tatters: the Harlem campus that was once lauded as the Harvard of the poor is now derided as a vast remedial factory.

title: Rooms With a Caligula-Slept-Here Look
description: CRUMPLED dish towels dry on an exposed radiator, paint flakes off a windowsill and electrical cords snake their way to a low table decked with dirty cups and saucers. Scattered crumbs and coffee scum are clearly visible.

title: INSIDE
description: London Toll Reaches 70

title: Shares Surge in Broad Rally; Dow Climbs 187.75 Points
description: Stocks gained yesterday, as investors shifted their attention to earnings and away from the prospect of higher interest rates.

title: American Team Progresses In Computer Championship
description: Winning a world bridge title without touching a card sounds like an impossibility, but it will happen next month in Boston. Six Americans and four Russians will ''face'' off in the OKBridge championship final for a purse of $10,000. They will not really be face to face because play is, and has been throughout, electronic, each competitor sitting at his computer. This is not an official world championship, although it has the blessing of the World Bridge Federation, which is not unlikely to give it some retroactive recognition.

title: A Book That Teaches Children How to Read
description: Maybe Johnny can't read, but if he can crack open the latest booklike electronic gadget, there may be hope.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: A Nonbook Party

title: Ginsberg Items (Some Beat) for Sale
description: ''Don't make a museum out of me,'' the poet Allen Ginsberg admonished his staff in his final days. ''When you die, you die.''

title: Items Found on the Internet Dress Up a Museum's Exhibition
description: AS if New York museums needed more publicity, the Whitney Museum recently revealed that it had been involved in a fierce bidding war for a 25-year-old copy of Playgirl magazine.

title: Alex Lowe, 40, Alpinist, Dies, Swept Away on a Tibet Ascent
description: Alex Lowe, an American climber whose versatility and tenacity in pushing the limits earned him a reputation as perhaps the country's finest all-around mountaineer, was presumed killed on Tuesday after vanishing in a massive avalanche on Shisha Pangma in Tibet. He was 40 and lived in Bozeman, Mont.

title: Deciding How Much World to Let In
description: IN a high-tech world, shades -- sunglasses for windows -- are becoming a necessity rather than merely a fashion statement. Glare is a problem, especially on a computer screen, but no one wants to work, curtains drawn, in a dark room. Well, take off your Ray-Bans. Solutions range from low-tech Mylar UV blockers to high-tech remote-controlled shade systems.

title: Car Crash Galvanizes A Politician In Belgrade
description: The faltering campaign to oust the Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic is at another turning point, with an aggrieved and angry Vuk Draskovic, a prominent politician who has held himself aloof from two weeks of rallies, moving closer toward engaged opposition.

title: Martinez Is Aching, And So Are The Red Sox
description: In the Indians' dugout, they watched the man on the mound and the numbers on the scoreboard and they noticed something change dramatically in the fourth inning. Pedro Martinez, Boston's sterling starting pitcher, had been throwing fastballs of more than 90 miles an hour, according to the radar gun reading that was posted in big, bright lights. Martinez also had a 2-0 lead.

title: Richter Injury Turns McLean Into the Starter
description: Kirk McLean was signed by the Rangers to be Mike Richter's backup. After spending his first full season as a backup goaltender in Florida last season, McLean said he has even become comfortable in the role.

title: London's Fashion Tribes Find Inspiration on Dancefloor : Glamour Comes Back to the Club
description: LONDON  Nightclubbing hasn't profoundly influenced fashion since Bianca Jagger shook her Halston-clad booty in the '70s New York superclub Studio 54. When disco died, champagne, cocaine and glamour were replaced by jeans, T-shirts and a pocket full of E. You could not  and, God forbid, would not  dance to nosebleed-inducing techno music in anything more than a tight, white pair of Calvins.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SULAM, EDNA
description: SULAM-Edna. The board and staff of the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services mourn the passing of Edna Sulam, the mother of Carol Zicklin, a JBFCF trustee. A loving wife, mother, grandmother and great-grandmother, Mrs. Sulam was also a volunteer in Florida for the City of Hope. We extend our deepest sympathies to Mrs. Zicklin and to Mrs. Sulam's husband, Gabriel; her son, Donald; her four grandchildren; and her five great-grandchildren. Joseph S. Kaplan, President Alan B. Siskind, Ph.D., Executive Vice President Paul Levine, CSW, Associate Executive Vice President Pinchas Berger, CSW, Director, Jewish Connections Programs

title: The Water, The Whale And a Bold Bass Guitar
description: Water, the mother of metaphors, means music, narrative writing or for that matter just about anything else you can think of. The sea is legato, Wagner's endless melody. Waves are the phrases within it, establishing meter and rhythm. Currents determine tempo.

title: In City, 'Right' To Double-Park Is Lost, It Seems
description: It has long been part of New York's social contract: car owners who have to struggle with the city's byzantine parking rules are permitted -- wink, wink, nudge, nudge -- to double-park while one side of a residential street is being cleaned, and police officers are not pressed into issuing them tickets.

title: Poverty Rate Persists in City Despite Boom
description: Despite the strongest economy in years, nearly one out of four New York City residents had incomes below the Federal Government's poverty threshold last year, a rate that has barely dipped since the last recession and that is twice as high as the national average, a new analysis of poverty in the city concludes.

title: Garden Q. & A.
description: Just One Bloom

title: GERMAN ORDERS SOAR
description: German manufacturers reported the biggest rise in monthly orders in almost a decade in August, heightening expectations of a rise in European interest rates as the region's biggest economy picks up steam. Orders rose 5.1 percent in August, the Finance Ministry said, the fifth monthly increase and the biggest gain since December 1989. The increase was almost four times a revised 1.4 percent rise in July and exceeded by a wide margin the gain of 0.4 percent that analysts had forecast. The report said that figures were helped by some big-ticket orders from abroad.

title: DIALOGUE: A Struggle Over the Republican Soul; George W. Bush, the Bold Leader
description: Tucked away in Gov. George W. Bush's education address on Tuesday was a provocative critique of modern-day conservatism.

title: Japan Seizes Nuclear Fuel Company's Records
description: The police seized records today from the company that runs the fuel-reprocessing plant where Japan's worst nuclear accident occurred last week. Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi, vowing to make his country ''once again feel secure,'' visited the site later.

title: A Subsidy for Health Insurance?
description: To the Editor:

title: Getting Files Off Old Disks
description: Q. I have a number of files on old 5 1/4-inch diskettes that I'd like to retrieve, but I no longer have a computer with a floppy drive that will read them. Is there any way I can get these files onto my new computer?

title: Collins's Big Shot Comes With Few Guarantees
description: Kerry Collins has been patiently waiting for this opportunity since training camp and now it is here. Collins will be the Giants' starting quarterback Sunday against the Arizona Cardinals. He will replace Kent Graham, who is out with a concussion.

title: CONSO ACCEPTS $66 MILLION BUYOUT FROM MANAGEMENT
description: The Conso International Corporation agreed yesterday to be taken private in a buyout worth about $66 million led by senior management. In the transaction, each of Conso's 7.3 million shares outstanding will have the right to receive $9 in cash, except a portion of the shares held by J. Cary Findlay, the chairman and chief executive, which will be converted to equity in the surviving company. Conso, based in Union, S.C., makes decorative cord and narrow trimmings, hand-assembled tasseled accessories and sewing supplies. It had revenue of $119.7 million last year. Mr. Findlay said the company had been disappointed in the valuation of its stock. Shares of Conso soared 59 percent yesterday, rising $3 each, to $8.0625.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits last Thursday about the diversion of Web surfers to pornographic sites while they are looking for legitimate sites misidentified the Federal statute that covers individual suits over deceptive business practices. A person can sue under the Lanham Act, which, among other things, deals with unfair competition, not the Federal Trade Commission Act.

title: BASEBALL PLAYOFFS
description: METS 1 vs. ARIZONA 7

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORITA, AKIO
description: MORITA-Akio. The Staff and Trustees of The Museum of Modern Art are deeply saddened by the passing of Akio Morita, a long time friend and supporter of the Museum. With his wife Yoshiko, a Trustee of the Museum, his interest and generosity were far reaching. To Mrs. Morita and other members of the family, we send our profound sympathy. David Rockefeller, Chairman Emeritus Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Agnes Gund, President Glenn D. Lowry, Director The Museum of Modern Art, NY

title: Year of 6 Billion People, Living Dangerously
description: According to the United Nations, the world's population will reach 6 billion next Tuesday. The United States Census Bureau says that mark was reached in July, but quibbling over dates aside, that is still a lot of people, and advocacy groups are trying to use publicity surrounding the date to increase awareness of population issues. At Zero Population Growth's Web site, for example (www.zpg.org), surfers can download a Y6B (for Year of 6 Billion) kit and can watch a world population counter increase by about 3 people a second.

title: Fighting the Clock: The Baby Boomers' Quest
description: To the Editor:

title: No Magic in Mets' Bats as Arizona Draws Even
description: The predictions should be tossed aside, the expectations shelved. The Mets were supposed to be in the post-season but had to scurry to unearth their invitation from the trash heap hours before the party began.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMERON, WILLIAM ALLAN
description: CAMERON-William Allan, of East Hampton, N.Y., and New York City, on October 5, 1999 at his home in East Hampton. He was 71 years old. Mr. Cameron died of lung cancer. Mr. Cameron was a graduate of Princeton University and the Harvard Law School. He spent his entire legal career at the firm of Carter, Ledyard & Milburn in New York City. During his years there he was Chairman of the Trusts and Estates Department and served on its Executive Committee. Mr. Cameron was Chairman of the South Fork-Shelter Island Chapter of The Nature Conservancy and also served on its New York State Board. He was a member of the Union Club, the Downtown Association and the St. Andrew's Society of New York City and The Maidstone Club and the Devon Yacht Club in East Hampton. He is survived by his wife of 23 years, the former Katharine Torrey; his daughters Jean Cameron-Smith of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., and Anne Cunningham of Villanova, Penn.; four grandchildren; and his stepchildren, Karen Forkner Wells of Houston, Tex., and Stanley Forkner of Darien, Conn. Also by his sister-in-law, Mrs. Alexander Cameron, her daughter, Laurie Cameron Carson, and his sister-in-law, Mrs. James Allan Cameron, and his cousin, Robert Cameron, all of Southampton, N.Y.; and his cousins, David Cameron of Woodbridge, Va., and J. Hamilton Allan of Stevenson, Md. There will be a private family service on Saturday, October 9, at the East Hampton Presbyterian Church, Main Street, East Hampton. A memorial service will be held at 11 AM Thursday, October 21, 1999 at the Central Presbyterian Church, 593 Park Avenue at 64th Street. In lieu of flowers, gifts may be made to The Nature Conservancy's South Fork-Shelter Island Chapter, PO Box 5125, East Hampton, NY 11937.

title: Brazilian Fears Kidnappers
description: Ronaldo Da Costa, 29, of Brazil, thought his life would change when he ran the fastest marathon in history -- 2 hours 6 minutes 5 seconds. His life has indeed changed since that performance a year ago in Berlin, but not for the better.

title: A Spot That Cradles Those Who Pause
description: STANDING on Rockefeller Plaza, looking across the skating rink toward Fifth Avenue, it looks as if a prairie had flown in and landed on the Channel Gardens. Grasses the color of wheat nod their seed heads in the breeze, and sparrows swoop across the water channels. The yellowing leaves of crape myrtles drift across the slate walkway, as fall moves through the city.

title: Trial in Subway Pushing Spotlights Insanity Defense
description: When Andrew Goldstein goes on trial for murder in a Manhattan courtroom this morning for pushing Kendra Webdale in front of a subway train, the state's mental health system and the reach of the rarely used insanity defense are expected to be on trial as well.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, DOROTHY REFSON
description: STONE-Dorothy Refson. It is with deep regret and sorrow that we announce the passing of our beloved mother, grandmother, and great-grandmother on October 3, 1999. Deeply mourned by Philip & Debra Refson, Sylvia Adler (Refson) and John Fischer, Dickie and Marilyn Refson; by grandchildren Jonathan & Sarah, Miriam, Beverley and Guy, Tanya, Alicia, Fiona, Jeremy, Oliver, Daniel, and Tal; and by great-grandson Joshua. Shiva: Ha'Hazavim 7, Ramat Poleg, Netanya, Israel.

title: Federal Fugitive Is Slain When Halted by Officers
description: A fugitive wanted on a Federal warrant was fatally shot when confronted by officers yesterday, a Federal Bureau of Investigation spokeswoman said.

title: U.N. Governance in East Timor
description: To avoid months of chaos in East Timor, Secretary General Kofi Annan wants the United Nations to take full control of the territory and spend the next two to three years readying it for independence. This is a timely and constructive proposal that deserves Washington's encouragement.

title: Reagan Author Defends His Device
description: Edmund Morris, whose memoir of President Reagan's life threads fiction through fact, began a 14-city tour last night promoting a book that has provoked fascination and scorn.

title: Sports of The Times; Patience Saves Pettitte And Yankees
description: ANDY PETTITTE pitches for the Yankees tonight, entrusted with the responsibility of sending the Texas Rangers home knowing the odds of their winning this division series equate to Elizabeth Dole's chances of pulling out the Republican Presidential nomination against their former owner, George W. Bush.

title: Corrections
description: A subheading yesterday about a Western-sponsored conference of Serbian, Montenegrin and Albanian journalists to discuss their coverage of the Kosovo conflict misstated the site. It was a resort in Montenegro, not in Belgrade.

title: In 1971 Tapes, Nixon Is Heard Blaming Jews for Communist Plots
description: The release of the latest batch of conversations secretly taped by President Richard M. Nixon depict him again as un-self-consciously anti-Semitic, informing his aides at one point that the Communist conspiracy against the United States was made up entirely of Jews, except for Whitaker Chambers and Alger Hiss.

title: Astros Find Millwood Is a One-Hit Wonder
description: With the Atlanta Braves facing a crucial situation, Kevin Millwood pitched a dominant game.

title: DANCE
description: Taking a Bow With One and All

title: For a Gay Officer, First Love, Then Malice
description: IT wasn't actually their idea to tell the newspapers about what they call their wedding, say New York City Police Officers Elizabeth Bryant and Marilyn Trapanotto. The president of the Gay Officers' Action League approached them a couple of days before the ceremony in June 1997, saying it would be a good thing, so they agreed. As it turned out, Ms. Bryant and Ms. Trapanotto liked the New York Post article about two lady cops who ''tied the lavender knot'' so much, they framed it.

title: Sydney Games Take Shape Physically and Financially
description: Last year, Michael Knight, the president of the organizing committee for next year's Sydney Olympics, ran into Peter Ueberroth, who held a similar job for the successful 1984 Los Angeles Olympics.

title: For a 2d Ave. Subway
description: To the Editor:

title: KOREAN STOCKS SURGE
description: South Korean share prices surged 5.5 percent as foreign investors returned to the volatile market in search of bargains after steep falls in recent days. The main stock index shot back through the 800-point mark, after falling to a four-month low of 791.55 on Tuesday. The main index surged 43.76, to close at 835.31. Trading volume totaled 275 million shares, worth 3.4 trillion won ($2.8 billion).

title: A Low-Key Iraq War Turns Low-Tech Too
description: American fighter jets patrolling northern Iraq are using an innovative new weapon against President Saddam Hussein: concrete. Wary of killing civilians, the Air Force has begun filling 2,000-pound laser-guided bombs with concrete instead of explosives and dropping them on military targets near populated areas, American officials say.

title: British Train Crash Toll 70; Many Missing
description: The death toll from Tuesday's train crash in London, Britain's worst in more than four decades, rose to at least 70 today, the police said. An intercity express plowed into a three-car commuter train that had apparently barreled straight through a red light, investigators reported.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ETRA, MINNIE
description: ETRA-Minnie. The Jewish Center mourns the passing of its longtime member. May her entire family be comforted among those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Jacob J. Schacter, Rabbi Samuel Goldman, President Elza Weinman, Sisterhood

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SARATH, SYLVIA

description: The City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, accused Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday of breaking a commitment to restore public access to the steps of City Hall and Mr. Vallone said that in protest he would boycott a ceremony today marking the reopening of the newly renovated City Hall Park.

description: A Family Affair Of Flying Feet

title: FOREIGN STAKE IN SEOULBANK
description: Lee Hun Jai, the chairman of South Korea's Financial Supervisory Commission, said a foreign bank or investment consortium was likely to gain a stake in Seoulbank and take over management of the bank, a spokesman for the commission said, quoting Mr. Lee. The Government's negotiations to sell Seoulbank to HSBC of Britain failed on Aug. 31, and the Government retained Morgan Stanley to put together a new management team for Seoulbank.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN FALLS. The dollar rose against the yen, getting support from sales of yen for euros as traders converted yen into dollars and then bought euros. In New York, the dollar settled at 107.51 yen, from 106.41 on Tuesday.

title: Jordan's New King Assuming Key Role in Mideast Talks
description: Not long ago, King Abdullah planned a quick trip abroad, to Vermont, to serve as best man at the wedding of a Deerfield Academy classmate.

title: Lawyers File Motion In Coke Bias Suit
description: Lawyers for four black employees at the Coca-Cola Company filed a motion yesterday that included invoices from a Staples store in Atlanta, showing that someone at Coke had ordered a shredding machine in late April, after a discrimination lawsuit was filed.

Adored grandmother of Max and Claire, fiancee & beloved friend of Milton Kaye and his family. Her enthusiasm for life and caring for others made her special to all who knew her. Service at 11 AM, Friday at Stephen Wise Free Synagogue, 30 West 68 Street, New York City.

title: House Republicans Battling Budget, Democrats and Bush
description: These are uncomfortable days for Republicans on Capitol Hill.

Donations to Mercy Hospice or American Cancer Society, Long Island Divsion, will be appreciated.

title: City Schools Expect Much Greater Need For New Teachers
description: New York City will need more than 41,000 new public school teachers over the next five years as an unusually large number of teachers become eligible to retire, education officials said yesterday.

description: In percent

title: Trapped in the Web Without an Exit
description: PAGE-JACKED. Mouse-trapped. Innocent surfers diverted from perfectly benign sites to on-line pornography enclaves and unable to escape. Streaming Webcast at 11.

title: Support Grows in Congress for a Pension Overhaul Plan That Would Aid High Earners
description: Support is growing quickly in Congress for a vast expansion of retirement tax breaks for business owners, executives and highly paid workers, moves that Republicans and Democrats alike say would be popular with voters.

title: Another Makeover For AOL
description: AMERICA ONLINE, the world's largest Internet service, this week announced the worldwide debut of a new version of the basic software used by its 18 million subscribers. AOL customers do not need the new software, AOL Version 5.0, but it is actually a pleasant improvement over earlier versions. It maintains AOL's traditional emphasis on ease of use instead of jazzy, cutting-edge innovation, but it does add a handful of new features intended to appeal to a Norman Rockwell audience.

title: A Powerful Artwork
description: To the Editor:

title: In a New Town, Gore Heralds a New Day
description: Arriving in Tennessee to cut the ribbon on his headquarters, Vice President Al Gore today continued his efforts to put a new face on his Presidential campaign, naming a black woman to his inner circle and promising supporters a ''rip-tootin' '' candidacy.

title: F.C.C. Begins Rewriting Rules For Industry in Consolidation
description: Federal officials this week began setting the conditions they will impose on a wave of proposed mergers that promises to consolidate, blur and redefine the nation's phone, cable and broadcast industries in a matter of months.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUNN, JOAN DEARY
description: LUNN-Joan Deary. Died October 2, 1999. Joan Deary Lunn worked at RCA Victor records under the name of Joan Deary for over 40 years. She moved to Hollywood in the early 1960's where she was in charge of A&R administration for the California office under Steve Sholes. Joan was the first woman Manager, Director, and Executive Director in RCA Victor history. She ended her career with RCA Victor as the Executive Director of all A&R Administration. During her tenure at RCA she worked with numerous recording artists. However she is best known as the originator and producer of RCA's Elvis Presley anthology series of albums. This series of creative works included historically relevant information, previously unheard recordings, and 'out-takes' of Elvis's recording sessions, providing Elvis's legions of fans access to behind the scenes antics, and allowing them to understand more about the man behind the legend. Joan received numerous gold and platinum records, awarded by the recording industry. She was the producer of the Elvis Presley 'Silver' album set, an eight record set which also achieved gold album status. She was nominated for a Grammy award in 1984 for the Elvis album 'A Golden Celebration.' She was active with, and frequently served as the invited speaker before Elvis Presley fan clubs throughout the United States and Europe. She was recently honored for her outstanding work in support of the Elvis Presley Memorial Chapel by the Elvis Presley Memorial Foundation of Tupelo. She is survived by her sister, two sons, two grandchildren, and two great grandchildren. Services were held on Wednesday, October 6 at Saint Charles Roman Catholic Church in North Hollywood. Following the services a burial was held at Forest Lawn, Hollywood Hills, California.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROMBERG, LORRAINE
description: BROMBERG-Lorraine. On Oct. 6, 1999. Beloved daughter of the late Benjamin and Emily. Loving sister of the late Babette. Also survived by dear friends and cousins. Services Thursday 12 P.M. at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. & Amsterdam Avenue. Gathering Sunday 1-4 P.M. at the Bromberg residence.

title: ELECTRICITY COMPETITION EXPECTED
description: South Korea's Commerce, Industry and Energy Ministry said it planned to open the local electricity market to competition next year. Currently, state-run Korea Electric Power has a monopoly. The Government plans to set up a power exchange market in January to trade various power products, and it plans to allow electricity fees to be set by market forces.

title: Tutored by the Great Outdoors
description: THE playground at Southern Pines Elementary School used to be four acres of thorny, barren land and some rickety play equipment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKLIN, ANNA MAY
description: FRANKLIN-Anna May. October 2, Anna May, age 90, wife of the late Francis Franklin, survived by nieces, nephews, sister-in-law and many loving friends. According to her wishes, her remains were donated to Mt. Sinai Medical School.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARNETT, LOUISE A.
description: BARNETT-Louise A. On October 6, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Jack. Devoted mother of Nancy Brand and Joyce Feldman. Mother-in-law of Eric Holm and Joel Feldman. Cherished grandmother of David, Eric and Jonathan. Loving great grandmother of Leah. Interment Friday, Mount Pleasant Cemetery.

title: Computers That Think Outside the Box
description: ONE of the latest problems computers are taking on is evolution -- their own, that is.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTLIEB, WILLIAM
description: GOTTLIEB-William. The Partners, Associates and staff of Goldberg Weprin and Ustin LLP express their profound sadness at the untimely passing of our friend, William Gottlieb. We will remember Bill for his zest of life, business acumen, sincerity, and genuineness. We share the grief of his loss with Bill's family, and we extend our heartfelt condolences to them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMON, JUDITH G.
description: SIMON-Judith G. Devoted wife of the late Dr. Samuel Simon, loving mother of Greg, Robert, Catherine and Paul and dear grandmother of Sam, Maggie and Emily. Cherished sister of Gloria Davis. Contributions in her memory to the American Cancer Society.

title: COME ON-A HER HOUSE WITH: Rosemary Clooney; Still a Girl Singer, at 71
description: SHE has a lived-in laugh, a deep, rueful chuckle made of good times and bum times, of cigarettes and singing and long, hard nights on the road. Somewhere around the first sip of the second cocktail in her elegant old living room, it dawns on a visitor just what a life Rosemary Clooney has lived.

title: Cruise Industry Gets a Tough Lecture at a Senate Hearing
description: Senator John McCain warned the cruise industry today that Congress might restrict its access to American ports unless the companies did a better job of abiding by United States laws and insuring the safety of passengers.

title: Brooklyn Museum Receives Support in Legal Battle With Mayor
description: As Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the Brooklyn Museum of Art prepare for a hearing in Federal court tomorrow, a surge of support for the museum's legal position has begun to emerge, some of it from institutions queasy about the art at the center of the conflict.

title: AOL Lets Lycos Use Its Messaging Feature
description: America Online Inc., the leading Internet service provider, will provide its instant messenger feature to users of the Lycos World Wide Web site, allowing Lycos customers to trade private messages with AOL subscribers.

title: African Identity
description: To the Editor:

title: MEDIA METRIX TO ACQUIRE ADRELEVANCE FOR $65.7 MILLION
description: Media Metrix Inc., which tracks the popularity of World Wide Web sites, agreed to buy the closely held Adrelevance Inc. for as much as $65.7 million in stock to offer clients the ability to monitor on-line advertising. The New York-based Media Metrix will pay $59.4 million and may issue additional Media Metrix shares valued at about $6.3 million if Adrelevance meets unspecified post-closing goals. Founded in 1998, the Seattle-based Adrelevance has 32 employees. The shares of Media Metrix, which had revenue of $6.3 million last year, fell $2.4375, to $59.0625.

title: Exhibitions And a Tour
description: By the Great Eameses

title: Compaq Slims Down
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation has never been known for sleek PC designs, and until now its Presario computers have taken up more desk space than those of most of its competitors. But this week Compaq introduced the Presario 3550, a supermodel-thin system that includes a 15-inch flat-panel L.C.D. monitor, a ''slim tower'' case that is less than half the size of other Presarios and a set of flat-panel speakers from Monsoon, all in a metallic midnight-blue casing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, IRVING I.
description: KLEIN-Irving I. On October 6, 1999. Beloved husband of Evelyn Gellis Klein. Loving father of Dr. David Klein. Cherished grandfather of Shira and Liel. Services Thursday 10AM from Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd (76 Road) Forest Hills, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OESTREICHER, DAVID J.
description: OESTREICHER-David J. On October 5, 1999. Father of Carol Chisholm and Jill. Loving grandfather of Shawna. Brother of the late Anthony. Best friend of Terri Cook. Reposing Redden Funeral Home, 325 West 14th Street, New York City, New York, Thursday and Friday 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. Mass of Christian burial Saturday, 9:30 A.M., St. Veronica's Church.

title: A Rebellious Team Player -- Charles Whitlow Norwood Jr.
description: ''I've got a lot of professional memory,'' Representative Charlie Norwood said this afternoon, reflecting on his experience with managed care companies in the years he practiced dentistry in Augusta, Ga.

title: Why Stars Require Kid-Glove Treatment
description: Jeff Van Gundy was going on yesterday about players who don't understand what it takes to play in the National Basketball Association; how some just don't get it.

description: McINERNEY-Annette R., longtime resident of The Cloisters, at Tudor City, NY on October 5, 1999. Retired Executive Secretary of Exxon. Beloved sister of James and John, the late Helen Kerwick, George, Frances Hyland, Robert, Edith Rodgers and Claire. Reposing at Dimiceli & Sons, Inc., 182 Lexington Avenue, New York, NY. Visiting, Thursday, 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 PM. Mass of the Resurrection, Church of St. Agnes, 143 East 43rd Street, New York, New York, on Friday, at 10:00 AM. Interment at St. John's Cemetery.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Management page in Business Day yesterday about failures that have been an asset for some executives misspelled the surname of a professor at the Stanford Business School who said managers who had made errors were increasingly sought by Fortune 500 companies. He is Irv Grousbeck, not Grousebeck.

title: Honesty in Sweepstakes
description: To the Editor:

title: A Couple of Close Calls Go the Diamondbacks' Way
description: The tone of the second game of the division series between the Mets and the Arizona Diamondbacks last night was set by two early plays that were this close. Each call went the Diamondbacks' way, and that's why they made their way to New York tied with the Mets at a game apiece. The plays, however, could easily have been called in the Mets' favor had the umpires been watching television replays.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTOCK, HERBERT DR.
description: WEINSTOCK-Herbert Dr. We are fortunate to have had you for our friend for so many years. We treasure the times we spent together. Our hearts go out to you Adele, and your wonderful family. With all our love-The B. G. A.

title: Designers Open Up For Public
description: SLOWLY, the ''to the trade'' barrier is crumbling. Architects, designers and furniture manufacturers are becoming friendlier. This week, they are meeting the public, giving slide shows, showing -- sometimes even selling -- their products. During Design Days NY, which ends tomorrow, the ordinary curious person can freely roam through 21 showrooms that are usually open only to architects and designers.

title: Thais Rediscover and Redesign Traditional Silk Clothes
description: UBOL RACHATHANI, Thailand  For a third-generation weaver whose textiles have attracted Thai royalty and high society, Tao Taesujariya's design work doesn't get much respect from his workers or even his mother.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUNT, ROSAMOND PIER
description: HUNT-Rosamond Pier. In Bedford, MA. On October 5, 1999. Daughter of the late Arthur Stanwood Pier who taught at Harvard University and Saint Paul's School and is the author of 34 books. She was the former wife of William Morris Hunt. Mother of Elise Hunt Roselli, actress; Demi, author and artist; and William Morris Hunt III, President of Coldwell BankerHunt-Kennedy of New York; sister of Dr. Arthur Stanwood Pier, Jr. Mrs. Hunt was one of the most respected and revered painters of the last generation, winning the most prestigious prizes in New England for her inspired water colors. A memoral service will be held at Trinity Church, Copley Square, Boston on Saturday, October 9th at 2PM. Private interment Milton Cemetery. Inquires to J.S. Waterman & Sons-Eastman-Waring of Boston.

title: In Cuba, Seeds of a Design Renaissance
description: IF one thinks of architecture in Cuba today, it is of splendid but decaying Colonial buildings floating like the ghosts of grand dowagers through the movie ''Buena Vista Social Club.'' Or the freshly primped, restored buildings in Old Havana. Visitors will also find the capital bursting with 20th-century buildings in a spirited Cuban fusion of international and tropical styles: Art Deco movie theaters, streamline Moderne apartments, sassy 1950's hotels in Morris Lapidus Modern and, crowning them all, the Expressionist art schools of the 60's, once as ripe as mangoes in their sensuality and revolutionary spirit.

title: Pettittes Stay Close Despite the Distance
description: Andy Pettitte continually tells his father to focus on his eroding health and forget about baseball, and Tom Pettitte responds by telling his son to focus on baseball and forget about how he feels. The telephone conversations occur almost every day. The son lectures the father, the father lectures back and they both hang up reminding themselves to be more emphatic the next time.

title: Inside the Flashy Shoe That Encourages Children to Step on It
description: TECHNOLOGICAL advances can be both good and bad, as Alfred Acree found out one night in April 1993.

title: Pepsico Profit Rises 6.7%, Slightly Beating Expectations
description: In a performance that slightly beat expectations, Pepsico Inc. reported a 6.7 percent increase in third-quarter profit yesterday on the strength of higher earnings at its Frito-Lay and Tropicana units.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  USDAN, LEO J.
description: USDAN-Leo J.,85. Formerly of Englewood, New Jersey, died at Monmouth Medical Center in Long Branch, NJ, on September 17, 1999. He is survived by his daughter, Adrienne, his son, James, former wife, Selma, and sisters, Beatrice Lieben, and Zipporah Epstein. Mr. Usdan was a graduate of Yeshiva University.

title: Mayor Shows City to Bush And Bush To the City
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani escorted Gov. George W. Bush of Texas on a tour of what was clearly ''Rudy's New York'' yesterday, taking the Republican Presidential candidate to a Queens welfare-turned-jobs-center, a firefighters' memorial service and an Italian restaurant for a pizza lunch on a Bedlam-like Arthur Avenue in the Bronx.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: AUTO RACING

title: Restoring Radio City
description: Radio City Music Hall has been grandly restored, and suddenly a page in a very old book -- the W.P.A. New York City Guide, published seven years after Radio City opened to the public in 1932 -- becomes almost precisely accurate for the first time in decades. ''Nearly everything about the Music Hall is tremendous,'' wrote the W.P.A. authors. Tremendous in scale the theater has always been. But until this week a reader of the guide's descriptions would have wondered what had happened to the ''rich henna of Ezra Winter's large mural above the stairway'' or the brocatelle wall covering or the works by Yasuo Kuniyoshi, Henry Billings, Stuart Davis and others.

title: NEUBERGER BERMAN'S OFFERING IS PRICED AT $32 A SHARE
description: Neuberger Berman Inc.'s initial public offering was priced at $32 a share last night, valuing the New York money-management firm at $1.6 billion. Neuberger, expected to trade on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol NEU, sold 7.25 million shares through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs. At $32 a share, Neuberger is valued at about 12 times estimates for this year's earnings, which compared with about 15 times earnings for the index of mainstream asset managers tracked by Putnam, Lovell, de Guardiola & Thornton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANN, ALVIN A.
description: DANN-Alvin A., on October 6th, 1999. Loving husband of Rosalind, father of Hillary and Marlene, Steven and Betsy, brother of Mike and Barbara, grandfather of Jeremy, Jake, Gabrielle, Derek and Tom, uncle & devoted friend. We all love you very much and we will miss you greatly. Services Friday, October 8th, 11:30am at Plaza Memorial, 91 Street and Amsterdam Ave. Call funeral home for details.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROCCHILD, RICHARD
description: ROCCHILD-Richard. October 7, 1986. It is 13 years today since you died so suddenly so full of dreams and illusions, youth and beauty, when only 24. You left us so alone, but we found strength in all the joy you gave us. We are so much richer in spirit because of you. And now you have it all, don't you? Wait for us... Love, Raymond and Val

title: Residential Sales
description: MANHATTAN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, INA
description: LEVINE-Ina. On behalf of the Board of Directors, families and children of Shai Lifeline, we extend our deeply felt condolences to Mr. William Levine and his entire family on the untimely loss of his dear wife, Mrs. Ina Levine. May the entire family be comforted together with all the mourners of Zion. Rabbi Simcha Scholar, Executive Vice President Samuel Zaks, Director of Development

title: Conferees Agree on Way To Keep the F-22 Alive
description: The House and Senate tonight struck a deal that would allow the Air Force's $70 billion F-22 fighter jet to proceed to the assembly line if it could pass new stringent flight tests.

title: Treasury Prices Hold Steady Ahead of September Job Data
description: Treasury prices were little changed yesterday as investors failed to follow through on early buying. Market participants wound up instead focusing on the employment report coming tomorrow.

title: NEWS WATCH
description: BOOTED -- A computer crash has cost the Texas Rangers dearly in their American League division championship series, now under way against the Yankees in New York. Mike Munoz, a left-handed Ranger pitcher who has been effective against the Yankees this year, was scratched after he dropped a new computer on his foot, fracturing a toe. He was trying to get the computer out of its box, he said.

title: ISLE OF CAPRI CASINOS IS IN DEAL TO BUY LADY LUCK GAMING
description: Isle of Capri Casinos Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Lady Luck Gaming Corporation in a $59 million cash transaction. Isle of Capri, based in Biloxi, Miss., will pay $12 a share for Lady Luck's 4.9 million common shares, as well as redeem the company's preferred stock for $22 million. It will also assume $177 million in debt. Isle of Capri also agreed to acquire the 50 percent stake not already owned by the Lady Luck Gaming Corporation in the Lady Luck Casino and Hotel in Bettendorf, Iowa, for about $62.4 million in stock. Isle of Capri, which owns riverboat and dockside casinos, posted revenue of $508.5 million in the last 12 months. Shares of Lady Luck Gaming jumped 24 percent yesterday, rising $2 each, to $10.125.

title: A Monk's Keys to Happiness, and to the Best-Seller List
description: So you want to be happy? Just follow this procedure. ''Generally speaking, one begins by identifying those factors which lead to happiness and those factors which lead to suffering. Having done this, one then sets about gradually eliminating those factors which lead to suffering and cultivating those which lead to happiness. That is the way.''

title: Curiosity in Dole Exceeds Support
description: Ask June Shockency, a sergeant-at-arms in California's Republican Party, what she thinks of Elizabeth Dole and her face brightens: ''intelligent, outgoing, warm,'' she says. But ask Mrs. Shockency about Mrs. Dole's message the last time she heard her speak, and there is a pause. ''I really can't remember,'' she finally says.

title: BRAZIL OUTPUT GROWS
description: Brazil's industrial output rose in August for the first time in three months, indicating that declining interest rates had begun to stimulate business at companies that were hurt by the high cost of borrowing. Production rose four-tenths of a percent from July but was unchanged compared with August a year earlier, Government data showed. A separate report showed sales of motor vehicles in Brazil rose 2.1 percent in September from August, reflecting a rush by consumers to buy cars before a tax benefit expired.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURRAY, SHIRLEY FOERDERER
description: MURRAY-Shirley Foerderer, of Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y., on October 5, 1999, peacefully at home. Wife of Francis W. Murray III, daughter of Percival E. and Ethel Brown Foerderer, sister of Mignon Foerderer Davis and Florence R. Foerderer, mother of Charles F. Ames, Shelley A. Hartz and P. Foerd Ames, and grandmother of Ashley, Loren, Lia, Walker, Will & Grace. Memorial service at 2 PM Saturday, October 9, at St. John's Church, Cold Spring Harbor. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the following: Thomas Jefferson University Development Office, Foerderer Fund-In Memory of Shirley Foerderer Murray, 925 Chestnut Street, Suite 110, Philadelphia, PA. 19107. For information, contact A.L. Jacobsen Funeral Home, Inc., of Huntington Station, New York.

title: Clinton Adds Stiffer Penalities to Military Code for Bias Crimes
description: President Clinton today signed an executive order amending the military criminal code to add stiffer penalties for crimes motivated by hatred based on the victim's race, religion, ethnicity or sexual orientation.

title: I.N.S. Thwarts Basic Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: Russians Seize All of Chechnya's North and Strike From West
description: Russian forces have expanded their operation in Chechnya, moving more troops in from the west, after seizing control of the entire northern part of the republic, Chechen commanders here said today.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Virtues of Persistence, Persistently Applied

title: Chloe's Rock Chick Softens Up; Givenchy Goes Sporty : Divining What Women Want
description: PARIS  How women feel about themselves and their clothes is the subject of the spring/ summer collections. And judging by the show he sent out Wednesday, Alexander McQueen at Givenchy doesn't have a clue.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  POE, EDGAR ALLAN
description: POE-Edgar Allan. Beloved Father of the Modern Detective Story. Bronx, NYC resident, he died in Baltimore at only 40 on October 7, 1849. He lives on brilliantly in his unique creative works. Mystery Writers of America

title: Bush Softens View of G.O.P. After Outcry by Conservatives
description: Facing a backlash from some conservative Republicans, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas yesterday softened his stern appraisal of the Republican Party, which only a day before he had characterized as too fixated on affluence and not sensitive enough to people's needs.

title: New iMac Offers More Than a Choice of Colors
description: With its announcement of new models this week, Apple has significantly redesigned and improved the iMac, a popular computer for home and school users.

title: Editorial Observer; A Texas Visitor Has Gov. Pataki Dreaming
description: Running for Vice President of the United States has traditionally been hard on the political ego. A born leader must suddenly turn into an eager follower. Ambitions must be carefully contained, differences muted. Thus New Yorkers were treated this week to uncomfortable scenes of their Governor, George Pataki, feverishly tap-dancing at the tryouts for Gov. George W. Bush's Presidential road show.

title: SAP Consolidates Account at Ogilvy
description: SAP A.G. in Walldorf, Germany, has consolidated its global account for general and Internet advertising, direct marketing and other communications at Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide in New York, a unit of WPP Group P.L.C. Though billings were not disclosed, Adweek estimated them at $100 million.

title: On-Line Help for Inquiring Young Minds
description: YAHOOLIGANS

title: Document Thief's History Repeats Itself, Police Say
description: Last Friday, Basil A. Panagopulos, an autograph dealer in Greenwich, Conn., got a phone call from a man who wanted to sell some rare documents, including papers of Thomas Alva Edison and Presidents Thomas Jefferson and James Monroe.

title: The Big City; A Republican Sees an Issue: Education
description: WHEN the Rev. Floyd Flake introduced George W. Bush to New York's conservative establishment Tuesday, it was probably the first time in the history of the Manhattan Institute for Policy Research that a luncheon speaker was described as ''my homeboy.'' And that was not the most incongruous moment of the day for a Republican from Texas.

title: Quest for Beauty Went Awry at Hands of a Fake Surgeon, Miami Police Say
description: The bodybuilder, a former Mr. Mexico and a runner-up Mr. Universe, just wanted his pectorals enhanced. But he woke from his anesthetic-induced sleep to find that the plastic surgeon, who turned out not to be a doctor at all, had given him women's implants. He had breasts.

title: Devils Elevate Rolston to First Line
description: The Devils have been looking for someone to reach the 30-goal plateau for a long time. No one has accomplished that feat for them since 1994, when John MacLean, now with the Rangers, had 37 goals, and Stephane Richer, now with Tampa Bay, had 36.

title: Charity Concerts to Go on Internet
description: WHEN the curtain rises Saturday afternoon on Netaid, a series of international benefit concerts to raise money for world anti-poverty programs, pop idols like David Bowie, Sting and Sean ''Puffy'' Combs are scheduled to perform. But the real star of the show is more likely to be the Internet.

title: Arizona Pitcher Can't Keep Control
description: The Arizona Diamondbacks traded three players to get the closer Matt Mantei into their bullpen.

title: Yeltsin Son-in-Law at Center Of Rich Network of Influence
description: It is three hours by air from Moscow to Omsk, a sprawling collection of fraying low-rises set on a Kansas-flat plain by the oil fields of Siberia.
