Every month or two, a well-dressed, bespectacled young man arrives by commercial jet here and is whisked away to a corporate apartment not far from the Omsk Oil Refinery, Russia's largest and most modern petroleum complex. After a day or two of unspecified business, he leaves as he came.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRUNNER, ROBERT F.
description: BRUNNER-Robert F. A resident of Rye for 38 years, died at his home on Tuesday October 5, 1999, after a lengthy illness. Born in Springfield, NJ, to Frederick F., and Emily Carl Brunner, he was 64 in August. A 1957 graduate of Union College, he married Barbara Clapp, on September 15, 1964. Mr. Brunner was a 40 year employee of Philips Electronics N.A., most recently as Corporate Travel Director. He was a member of several professional travel organizations, including NBTA and ACTE. His extensive involvement in local, civic and community organizations included the original ''Ban The Bridge'' Committee and The Rye City Boat Basin Commission. He served as a Rye City Councilman, and for many years as a member of The Rye City Board of Assessment Review. Mr. Brunner was Treasurer of The Rye City Republican Committee for many years, also serving as its District Leader. He was an active member and retired President of The Rye Fish and Game Club and was a Member of The Mamaroneck Elks Lodge. He is survived by his wife, Barbara, daughter, Emiiy Howard, of Rye, NY, daughter, Kimberly Worrell, of Atlanta, GA, and grandchildren, Alexandra and William. A Memorial Service is scheduled for 11 A.M. Saturday October 9, 1999, at Christ's Church in Rye. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The American Cancer Society, 2 Lyon Place, White Plains, NY 10601.

title: Online Help for Inquiring Young Minds
description: Online Help for Inquiring Young Minds

title: A Wicked Mother-in-Law With Treachery in Mind
description: You would have to comb the annals of the world's soap operas to come up with a villainess more conniving than Margaret (Nabila Ebeid), the wealthy, scheming wife of a corrupt Egyptian industrialist in Youssef Chahine's frantic, action-filled political drama, ''The Other.'' When Margaret's beloved only son, Adam (Hani Salama), impulsively marries Hanane (Hanane Tork), a beautiful but impoverished newspaper reporter, without her permission, she goes to desperate lengths to manipulate her son and destroy her daughter-in-law.

title: 'Voices in Dark' Closing
description: ''Voices in the Dark,'' a drama by John Pielmeier, is to close after the matinee on Sunday at the Longacre Theater, 220 West 48th Street, Manhattan. The play, directed by Christopher Ashley and starring Judith Ivey, will have run for 68 regular performances and 12 previews.

title: Israel Changes Its Style in South Lebanon
description: The operational nature of the chronic low-level warfare in southern Lebanon has markedly changed over two months as both Israeli and Shiite Muslim guerrillas look ahead to the Israeli troop withdrawal pledged by Prime Minister Ehud Barak.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARPER, ROSE SILBERT
description: KARPER-Rose Silbert on October 5, 1999. Beloved wife of Abraham. Loving mother of the late Martin and Stephen. Survived by brother, Harry Silbert; daughter-in-law, Diane H. Karper; grandchildren, S. James Karper, Jr. and Annabelle H. Karper. Graveside service Thursday 1 PM, at Sharon Garden Cemetery, Valhalla, New York.

title: Business Owners Protest Limited Flood Aid
description: Main Street reopened on Tuesday for traffic, three weeks after Tropical Storm Floyd flooded the downtown here. But business owners complained at a rally today that because of a lack of government help, most of them were uncertain when they would reopen, if at all.

title: Wrestler Is Injured In L.I. Competition
description: A professional wrestler was seriously injured Tuesday night during a match at Nassau Coliseum that may leave him paralyzed.

title: Techie Volunteers Fill a Need at Charities and Schools
description: THE Lenox Hill Neighborhood House has been providing services to the needy on the Upper East Side of Manhattan for more than a century. But the past year has seen a threefold growth in the number of people served by the agency's education programs, and David Kirchoff, its director of community services and education, credits this expansion to a new breed of technically adept volunteers.

title: Anthropology Project: Study Your Own Friends
description: ''Wasteland'' wants to be a dramatic version of ''Friends'' with Zeitgeist pretensions. Those pretensions will cause trouble every time. The series, about six college friends now in their 20's and still huddled together in New York City, was created by Kevin Williamson, who so entertainingly combined adolescent soul-searching with soap opera gloss in ''Dawson's Creek.'' But in ''Wasteland'' the soul-searching seems artificial and the dialogue borrowed from generations of bad daytime soaps.

title: NATWEST PLANS TO DROP BID
description: One of Britain's four main clearing banks, National Westminster Bank P.L.C., said it would probably drop its $17.7 billion bid for the British insurance company Legal and General Group P.L.C. as the bank tries to fend off its own suitor, Bank of Scotland P.L.C., which made a $34 billion hostile bid a few weeks weeks ago. Legal and General said it was disappointed about the likely collapse of the deal. Its shares fell 2.3 percent, to 169.25 pence ($2.81). Natwest shares fell nearly 1 percent, to 1,435 pence ($23.82).

title: BOOKSELLER TO BUY BABBAGE'S ETC. FOR $215 MILLION
description: The nation's top bookseller Barnes & Noble Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the closely held Babbage's Etc. L.L.C. for $215 million in cash and assumed debt, expanding its sales of video games and entertainment software. Babbage's Etc. is one of the largest United States sellers of video games and entertainment software. Barnes & Noble will get 495 stores run under the names Babbage's, Software Etc. and Game Stop, as well as the gamestop.com retail Web site. Barnes & Noble said it expected the acquisition to add 10 cents a share to earnings in its fourth-quarter ending in January.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LUPARELLO, MICHAEL
description: LUPARELLO-Michael. Our 4th wedding anniversary. I love you with all my heart forever. Kathleen

title: But High Costs Deter Investors : Japanese Begin To Open Market
description: TOKYO  Workmen are digging up streets in Tokyo's central wards, laying a fiber-optic cable network that MCI Worldcom will use to provide telecommunications services for commercial enterprises at prices below those of Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corp. and other carriers.

title: WORLD MUSIC
description: A Sicilian Group With Medieval Sounds

title: HEALTH CARE BILL PASSED BY HOUSE INTENSIFIES FUROR
description: The House of Representatives today passed a bill creating tax breaks to help millions of people buy health insurance. But it also took a procedural step that may jeopardize legislation to define patients' rights and regulate health maintenance organizations.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: When Dials Were Round and Clicks Were Plentiful
description: IT'S hard to imagine Jon Walz, a film producer and vintage-phone collector in Los Angeles, getting as worked up in 20 years about today's cordless telephones as he does about his Western Electric 302 rotary dial phone. To hear him lovingly describe its clickety dial, the chime of its two-toned ringer and the shiny Bakelite handset (the size and weight of which make him feel small in comparison when he picks it up), Mr. Walz could just as well be referring to a long lost toy truck, or even an old teddy bear.

title: Essay; Those Chinese Agents
description: The Chinese Embassy here sent two of its senior commercial ministers to Capitol Hill last week to impugn the testimony of a Chinese citizen now resident in Arizona.

title: Williams Speaks Up and Takes Lead
description: The largest locker in the Yankees' clubhouse belongs to Bernie Williams, for he has the longest tenure of any player. Located in a corner, it provides enough room for Williams to stretch out on the floor and take naps, and he uses an adjacent locker to house some of his worldly possessions -- most notably, an amplifier for his guitar.

title: Talking to the Web On Your Telephone
description: To most people who follow wireless communications, phone-based Web browsing means reading two or three lines of text on a tiny display screen. But Nuance, a voice-recognition company in Menlo Park, Calif., has created an invisible Web browser called Voyager that responds to voice commands instead of pushed buttons. It is designed to be used by people speaking through a regular or mobile phone.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the sale of TV Guide to the Gemstar International Group and the creation of a merged company, TV Guide International, misstated the publication's future relationship to News Corporation, the Rupert Murdoch company and a 44 percent shareholder. The company will keep a 20 percent stake, not end its association with TV Guide.

title: In America; The Money Machine
description: The George W. juggernaut rolled through New York this week, with the candidate taking some brilliantly aimed shots at his own party, brokering an end (at least temporarily) to the nasty feud between Gov. George Pataki and Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, visiting a black church upstate and a black school in Harlem, making an educational policy speech at the right-leaning Manhattan Institute, and visiting for more than an hour with John Cardinal O'Connor, who has not been well.

title: VS&A PLANS TO BUY GP STRATEGIES FOR $158.8 MILLION
description: The GP Strategies Corporation, a technical and management training company, said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by VS&A Communications Partners III L.P. for about $158.8 million in cash. The New York-based GP Strategies said VS&A Communications, an affiliate of the closely held Veronis, Suhler & Associates Inc., will pay $13.75 a share for GP Strategies, which has about 11.6 million shares outstanding. The acquisition came as GP Strategies shares had fallen 28 percent since the beginning of the year. GP Strategies shares rose $1.625 yesterday, to $12.4375.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RACHLIN, BLANCHE
description: RACHLIN - Blanche. Beloved mother of Alan & Henry and mother-in-law of Charlotte D. Moslander. Services Riverside Cemetery, Rochelle Park, New Jersey, Friday, October 8, at 11 AM. Contributions to American Cancer Society.

title: Rowland Calls for an Overhaul in Election Laws
description: Struggling to keep his head above a bribery scandal that threatens to swamp his administration, Gov. John G. Rowland of Connecticut urged legislators today to undertake a sweeping examination of state election and ethics laws.

title: Police Seek Pattern in Brooklyn Murders
description: New York City police detectives are investigating whether the recent strangulation and slashing murders of four women within a small section of northern Brooklyn are linked, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; The Long, Delicate Dance With Chinese Leaders
description: A GREAT WALLSix Presidents and China, An Investigative HistoryBy Patrick E. TylerIllustrated. 476 pages. Public Affairs. $27.50.

title: I.N.S. Thwarts Basic Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TRAKIS, PETER C.
description: TRAKIS-Peter C. October 7, 1965June 24, 1998. Your birthdaythe candles have gone out but you live in our hearts forever

title: Justices Consider Arguments Of Race in Hawaiian Voting
description: Harold F. Rice is a native of Hawaii, but he is not a ''native Hawaiian'' or even a ''Hawaiian'' under the law of a state that reserves those terms for descendants of the people living in the islands in 1778, when Capt. James Cook of Britain and his crew arrived.

title: Deal on A-Test Ban Stalls As Senate Vote Approaches
description: A deal to postpone a Senate vote on a treaty banning underground nuclear tests stalled today because of the Republicans' aim to avoid having the pact become a campaign issue in 2000 and the Democrats' desire to keep the accord alive next year.

title: Union Pacific Gives Big Lift To G.M. Unit
description: The Union Pacific Corporation said today that it had ordered 1,000 locomotives worth more than $2 billion from a Canadian division of the General Motors Corporation. It was Union Pacific's biggest step yet to improve a railroad network that was so slow and snarled two years ago that some customers rebelled and began sending freight by truck.

title: Metro Business; Utility to Buy Power Plant
description: Public Service Enterprise Group, which owns New Jersey's largest utility, has agreed to buy a 400-megawatt power plant in Albany from Niagara Mohawk Holdings for $47.5 million.

title: N.F.L. Goes Back to Houston for $700 Million
description: The value of professional sports teams took another dramatic boost today when the National Football League approved Robert McNair's $700 million bid for an expansion franchise in Houston.

title: STEEL UNITS TO BE SOLD
description: Australia's biggest steelmaker, the Broken Hill Proprietary Company, said it planned to cut its steel business in half and sell operations worth around $3 billion (Australian), or $1.98 billion (United States), to make the division more profitable. The company wants to divest itself of units producing steel pipes and steel products used in construction like beams and girders, known as long products, and to sell its two United States-based steel operations. Analysts said the move would make the remaining steel businesses more attractive to a potential offshore buyer.

title: The Fight for Patients' Rights
description: House Republicans approved a tax package yesterday that expands tax-free medical savings accounts, a change that could lure healthy and wealthy people out of insurance pools. That is bad enough, but the Republican leadership, knowing that Democrats oppose such accounts, have decided to attach that legislation as a poison pill to any patients' rights bill that comes out of the House. That ploy is an attempt to block a sound bipartisan patients' rights bill that will be debated today.

title: A RAPE DEFENDANT WITH NO IDENTITY, BUT A DNA PROFILE
description: In an unusual legal strategy that stretches the law to match the developing science of DNA, a prosecutor in Wisconsin has filed rape and kidnapping charges against a defendant who has no name. John Doe is known only by his DNA code, extracted from semen samples from three rapes and tested after six years in a police property room.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: A Report and Safir Differ on Shooting
description: The Police Department's internal preliminary report on the fatal police shooting of a mentally disturbed man in Brooklyn does not, as Commissioner Howard Safir said the morning after the incident, say that the police opened fire only as the man was beating a fallen sergeant with a hammer.

title: Hindu Nationalist Coalition Leads as India Begins Ballot Count
description: The colossal job of counting more than 350 million ballots in India's national elections got under way Wednesday, and results tabulated by this morning showed that the Hindu nationalist-led coalition had taken a strong lead against the alliance headed by the Congress Party.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARDNER, SHIRLEY C.
description: GARDNER-Shirley C. Beloved wife of A. Alfred. Loving and adored mother of Stephen and Judy and Joel and Gayle. Dearest sister of Gloria Ackerman. Cherished grandmother of Allison, Drew, Jamie and Bradley. Services Thursday 11:15 A.M. ''Parkside'' Chapels, Queens Blvd., at 66th Avenue, Forest Hills, NY

title: As Net Turns 30, the Sequel Is Still in Previews
description: THIRTY years ago this fall, the Internet got its start as the Arpanet, a Government-financed computer network for universities and military sites. That network has gradually morphed into today's Internet, which 200 million people around the world use, misuse, cherish and curse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, PAUL DANIEL
description: KATZ-Paul Daniel. Suddenly on October 2, 1999. Age 57. Beloved husband of Gayle Sherman. Dear son of Blanche & the late Alexander and brother of Vera Pavone and Laura Strowe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZOWITZ, RALPH
description: KATZOWITZ-Ralph. Former husband of Suzanne Kayden. Son of Ida Katzowitz. Brother of Harvey (Janice) Katzowitz and Evelyn (Martin) Berg. Uncle of Meredith Katzowitz, Jeffrey (Penny) Berg and Ira Berg. Services were held in Israel.

title: Chief of AT&T's Cable TV Operation Quits
description: In the most significant executive departure from the AT&T Corporation since C. Michael Armstrong took over as the company's chairman in 1997, AT&T announced yesterday that Leo J. Hindery Jr., chief executive of AT&T's cable television operation, had decided to leave the company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CELLO, OLGA OPIELA
description: CELLO-Olga Opiela. October 5, 1999 in Marin County, CA. Resident of Tiburon, CA. Formerly of Jamaica and Malverne, NY and Boca Raton, FL. Born, August 15, 1908 in Manhattan. Student at Washington Irving H.S. and Maxwell Teachers Training School. Taught in New York City schools at Shimer J.H.S. and P.S. 160 and at Polk Street School, Franklin Square. Widow of Patrick J. Cello. Survived by three sons, Gregory (Fayetteville, NC), John (Tiburon, CA) and Patrick (Goshen, NY), six grandchildren Patrick, Christine, Lorraine, Deanna, and John and by nine great grandchildren. Funeral and burial on October 8 in Marin County, CA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REIGELUTH, ROBERT SEELYE
description: REIGELUTH-Robert Seelye. Age 82, died at his home in New Haven, CT. on October 6. He is survived by his wife, Mary, his four children and his fourteen grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at 2PM on October 9 at Trinity Church on the Green, New Haven.

title: Settlement Ends Yonkers School Strike
description: Teachers and school officials settled a strike today that kept schools here closed this week. After 48 hours of talks produced a tentative settlement on a two-year contract early this morning, the agreement was overwhelmingly ratified by union members this evening, 1,247 to 47.

title: And You Were (Almost) There
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Where Once A Car Owner Got a Break
description: A City Councilman from the Upper West Side accused police officials yesterday of mounting a ''pervasive neighborhood blitz'' that singled out car owners in his district, where drivers have double-parked on side streets with impunity while alternate-side parking restrictions were in effect.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  URBONT, MICHAEL
description: URBONT-Michael. Age 43. After a courageous battle with Leukemia. Beloved husband of Lisa, adored father of Lauren and Alana, and devoted brother to Fran, Gail, and Ira. Cherished Uncle of David, Brooke, Meredith, Allison, Daniel, and Jesse. Michael will be remembered by his adoring fans of the Thunder Rose Band as well as his colleagues at the District 27 Board of Education, and by a host of friends who thought the world of him. The funeral will be held Friday, October 8, 1999, at 12 Noon, Temple Emanuel, Neptune Blvd, Long Beach, NY. Shiva will be observed at the Urbont residence, 619 W. Market Street, Long Beach, until Thursday, October 14.

title: Henderson in October: Ahhh, Stolen Moments
description: In the last 23 games Rickey Henderson played during the regular season, he was on base 33 times. He tried to steal eight times and was successful five times. In the first two playoff games against the Arizona Diamondbacks, Henderson was on base six times with hits and walks. He tried to steal five times and was successful five times.

title: German Companies Offer $3.3 Billion in Wartime Slavery Suit
description: Germany's largest companies and the German Government offered $3.3 billion today in compensation to Nazi-era slave laborers -- several thousand dollars each for the dwindling number of surviving victims.

title: Ex-Monopoly Battles Competitors : Bezeq Israel Faces Realities of Market
description: JERUSALEM  Until the mid-'80s, getting a telephone in Israel was no easy task. It often required protekzia, or contacts in Hebrew. Hundreds of thousands of people were on waiting lists to receive phone lines. In some areas, the wait could last for years. But that all changed in 1985 when the Israeli government decided to turn the phone service, then a division of the Ministry of Posts, into a state-owned company.

title: Gorilla Monsoon, 62, Villainous Pro Wrestler
description: Gorilla Monsoon, one of the most famous athlete-entertainers ever to don tights and climb into the professional wrestling ring, died on Wednesday at his home in Willingboro, N.J. He was 62.

title: Kilroy Was Here, and Just About Everyone Else
description: The royal road of Tennessee Williams's ''Camino Real'' is crowded with refugees fleeing life's disappointments. It dead-ends in a plaza that resembles a circle of Dante's hell, populated by whores, pickpockets, beggars, vendors, soldiers, a blind singer and laughing streetcleaners who cart off the dead.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: MAZDA OUTSOURCING DEAL
description: In a step that may further the spread of American-style corporate service businesses, the Mazda Motor Corporation will hand responsibility for much of its information technology to IBM Japan Ltd., a subsidiary of I.B.M. Such outsourcing agreements, while commonplace in the United States, are relatively unknown in Japan. Mazda, an affiliate of the Ford Motor Company, will pay IBM Japan 50 billion yen ($467 million) over the next decade to maintain its computer networks and some 10,000 personal computers.

title: Mattingly Pays a Graceful Visit to the Stadium
description: Don Mattingly, the last team captain for the Yankees, returned to Yankee Stadium to toss out the first pitch last night. Free from George Steinbrenner's strict regulations, he sported a goatee as he strutted to the mound.

title: House Hears Grim Tales About Managed Care
description: One after another, the lawmakers told anecdotes about constituents who had been harmed when they were denied coverage by their health maintenance organizations.

title: Weight of U.S. Treaty Vote Emerges at Vienna Panel
description: Speakers at a conference convened to press for ratification of the nuclear test-ban treaty suggested today that the ban might founder among other holdouts, including Russia and China, if it was not approved by the United States Senate.

title: Experts Say Test Ban Could Impair Nuclear-Arms Safety
description: The scientists in charge of maintaining the safety and reliability of the nation's nuclear arsenal said today that they might not be able to do their job without nuclear tests that would be outlawed under a test ban treaty.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Columbus Day

title: Barbara Broughel -- 'Opium Works'
description: Frederieke Taylor/TZ'Art

title: HOUSE PASSES BILL TO EXPAND RIGHTS ON MEDICAL CARE
description: By a surprisingly lopsided vote, the House passed a bill today to give patients a wide range of new rights, including the right to sue health insurance plans that cause injury by denying care or providing substandard treatment.

title: Parcells Is Calling Plays To Balance Jets' Attack
description: Saying that he wanted to be sure to maintain a balance, Coach Bill Parcells acknowledged today that he has taken over the play-calling of the intermittently troubled Jets offense.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: American Home Products To Settle Diet-Drug Case

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMERON, WILLIAM ALLAN
description: CAMERON-William Allan, of East Hampton, N.Y., and New York City, on October 5, 1999 at his home in East Hampton. He was 71 years old. Mr. Cameron died of lung cancer. Mr. Cameron was a graduate of Princeton University and the Harvard Law School. He spent his entire legal career at the firm of Carter, Ledyard & Milburn in New York City. During his years there he was Chairman of the Trusts and Estates Department and served on its Executive Committee. Mr. Cameron was Chairman of the South Fork-Shelter Island Chapter of The Nature Conservancy and also served on its New York State Board. He was a member of the Union Club, the Downtown Association and the St. Andrew's Society of New York City and The Maidstone Club and the Devon Yacht Club in East Hampton. He is survived by his wife of 23 years, the former Katharine Torrey; his daughters Jean Cameron-Smith of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., and Anne Cunningham of Villanova, Penn.; four grandchildren; and his stepchildren, Karen Forkner Wells of Houston, Tex., and Stanley Forkner of Darien, Conn. Also by his sister-in-law, Mrs. Alexander Cameron, her daughter, Laurie Cameron Carson, and his sister-in-law, Mrs. James Allan Cameron, and his cousin, Robert Cameron, all of Southampton, N.Y.; and his cousins, David Cameron of Woodbridge, Va., and J. Hamilton Allan of Stevenson, Md. There will be a private family service on Saturday, October 9, at the East Hampton Presbyterian Church, Main Street, East Hampton. A memorial service will be held at 11 AM Thursday, October 21, 1999 at the Central Presbyterian Church, 593 Park Avenue at 64th Street. In lieu of flowers, gifts may be made to The Nature Conservancy's South Fork-Shelter Island Chapter, PO Box 5125, East Hampton, NY 11937.

title: Sephora, a luxury beauty products vendor, plans a campaign to raise its profile among consumers.
description: THROUGH the centuries, beauty has inspired philosophical musings from ''Beauty's but skin deep'' (John Davies of Hereford, 1616) to ''Beauty is in the eye of the beholder'' (Margaret Wolfe Hungerford, 1878) to ''Beauty's where you find it'' (Madonna, 1990). Now comes an advertising and marketing blitz seeking to add ''Beauty is how you see it'' to that list of pithy sayings.

title: Operation Move Along
description: Last year, jaywalkers in New York City were complaining about the tickets they got under Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's new rules for crossing the street. Then came drunken drivers who lost their cars because their blood-alcohol level was too high. Next were the drivers who got heavy fines for clogging intersections.

title: Results Show Voters' Pragmatism
description: Laloo Prasad Yadav, the canny son of an illiterate cowherd, who ruled impoverished Bihar State for almost a decade in the name of the poor and low caste but who failed to improve their standard of living, lost his Parliament seat on Wednesday. His National People's Party's share of seats also fell precipitously.

title: Deal for Allegheny Banks
description: The F & M National Corporation, a banking company that operates in Virginia, West Virginia and Maryland, has agreed to buy State Bank of the Alleghenies for $53.3 million in stock, adding three branches in Virginia. State Bank, which is closely held, has branches in Allegheny and Bath counties, in the Allegheny Mountains along the West Virginia border. State Bank, based in Covington, Va., has assets of about $155.6 million. F&M, based in Winchester, has assets of $2.9 billion.

title: It's City Hall Park, Where Everything Old Has Been Made New
description: At an event brimming with civic ceremony and history, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani presided yesterday over the reopening of City Hall Park, unveiling a renovation that has restored 19th-century grandeur to the grounds and that both supporters and detractors say will stand as a lasting monument to his legacy.

title: Bradley's Health Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: Public Interests; Let Georges Do It
description: George W. Bush was in New York this week, and by the time he had left, everybody here was speculating like mad about Gov. George Pataki's chances of getting the Republican Vice-Presidential nomination. This is no small matter for the state. Mr. Pataki is a career politician with no place left to climb. If we don't find him another job soon, he's going to turn into Mario Cuomo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NORBOM, CONSTANCE MARTIN
description: NORBOM - Constance Martin, Ph.D., of Manhattan, on September 27, 1999. Retired professor of physiology at Hunter College of the City University of New York, researcher, author of books on endocrinology. Beloved wife of Henning Norbom, mother of April Martin and Brenda Trammell, stepmother of Thomas Norbom, grandmother of Emily and Jesse Martin-Alexander, and Kristin and Ashley Norbom.

title: MOLSON PLANS TO CLOSE A BREWERY IN ONTARIO
description: Molson Inc., Canada's biggest beer maker, will close its brewery in Barrie, Ontario, next September and dismiss 414 workers, resulting in a fiscal third-quarter charge of $128 million. Molson is cutting costs and focusing on its Toronto brewery. It has cut 70 jobs this year, 19 percent of its 3,600 workers. Including Barrie, the company has seven breweries in Canada. Molson has been eliminating jobs and selling businesses unrelated to beer in the year to help its stagnant stock. Equipment from Barrie will be moved to Toronto.

title: Tory Leader Toughens Stand On Integration With Europe
description: The Conservative Party leader, William Hague, brought his party's annual convention to a close today with a call for tougher resistance to further integration with Europe and an attack on Prime Minister Tony Blair as a liar and hypocrite.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: FOOTBALL

title: Falling in Love With the Object of Disgust
description: ''L'Ennui'' is not the first French film to explore the excruciating erotic attachment we call possessiveness. (What would the French cinema be, after all, without its crimes of passion?) But as it follows an arrogant philosophy teacher's descent into sexual obsession, this devastating film goes as far as a movie ever has in exploring the kind of eroticized panic that can explode into violence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, HARRY
description: LEVY-Harry. We mourn the loss of our esteemed member and extend heartfelt condolences to his family. Temple Israel of Great Neck George N. Abrahams, President

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: The Author Is No Dummy

title: Nets' Van Horn Eager to Put Off-Season Studies to Work
description: There were 17 seconds remaining in a game against the Cleveland Cavaliers last season when Keith Van Horn realized he did not know it all.

title: The Anthropologist From Outer Space
description: What if an extraterrestrial who sounded like David Hyde Pierce made a nature documentary about Earth's homo sapiens? He might observe that ''the young male begins his sojourn with others of his pack'' (and the camera would focus on young men waiting in line outside a club). But he'd probably misunderstand a lot, saying something like ''The female scratches numerical symbols onto a thin white sheet of tree bark, hoping the design will please the male'' when the woman gives the man her telephone number.

title: Direct Hit, on a Chechen's White Flag
description: Two Chechen sisters lay side by side in the Ninth City Hospital, barely able to talk.

title: Sir de Villiers Graaff, 85, Leader Of South African Centrist Party
description: Sir de Villiers Graaff, who led South Africa's weak and troubled parliamentary opposition for two decades during the apartheid era, died on Monday at his farm outside Cape Town. He was 85.

title: It Was Dark And Stormy. . . .
description: Call it horror for the whole family. ''For the collector and the nostalgia buff we've got these classic monsters,'' said Craig Kornblau, president of Universal Studios Home Video. ''For the broad audience we've got 'The Mummy,' and then we have a new direct-to-video title, 'Alvin and the Chipmunks Meet Frankenstein,' for the kids.''

title: Concert for the Record Books
description: Venturing where other brave souls have failed, the members of the Flux String Quartet (above) will test their musicianship and stamina tomorrow by attempting to play Morton Feldman's six-hour String Quartet No. 2. The Flux players have yet to get through it in one sitting. But they have been building up to it, performing chunks of 90 minutes and three hours.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report on Sunday about a search by Federal agents investigating campaign-finance irregularities misidentified the New Jersey town where the search took place, at the office of David Chang, a prominent contributor to both major political parties. It was Englewood Cliffs, not Englewood.

title: U.S. Says 'Stars Are Aligned' to Vanquish an Old Foe: Syphilis
description: With the nation's syphilis rate at the lowest level since the Government began keeping statistics in 1941, Federal health officials said today that they believed they could eliminate the disease from the United States in the next five years.

title: Accounts
description: * Youdecide.com, Atlanta, a Web-based financial services company that is part of the Consumer Financial Network unit of iXL Enterprises, to DMW Worldwide, St. Louis, to handle its first account. Billings were estimated at $10 million.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: Pentagon Sets Up New Center For Waging Cyberwarfare
description: To combat the expanding threat of cyberwarfare, the Pentagon established a new center today to defend the United States from hackers and to plot ways to attack an enemy's computer network.

title: Keeping the Test Ban Treaty Alive
description: If the nuclear Test Ban Treaty fails to win ratification next week, as it probably will, Senate Republicans will deserve much of the blame. The Republican leadership has behaved in a narrowly partisan fashion that paid little heed to America's international interests and trivialized the Senate's constitutional role in evaluating treaties. But the White House failed to put together a coherent strategy for assembling the needed two-thirds Senate majority, and then allowed itself to be outmaneuvered into a compressed timetable that left too little time for an intensive lobbying campaign.

title: Silvia Kolbowski
description: American Fine Arts

title: Is All This Zippy Technology Actually Ruining Our Lives?
description: LONDON  Yesterday's technological marvels improved life by producing quantum leaps in manufacturing efficiency, helping to slash the workweek in industrial societies. The marvels of today, concentrated in telecommunications, have become objects of near-idolatry because they are supposed to be having the same impact in the service-oriented, post-industrial world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RODRIGUEZ, FREDDIE
description: RODRIGUEZ-Freddie. September 26, 1999. Devoted husband of Bay, loving father of Robin, Lauren and Danielle. Cherished grandfather of Gabrielle and Xavier. Member of District 4 Community School Board from 1987 to present.

title: Celine:Bags of Fun in the Sun Down on the Riviera
description: PARIS  Mediterranean sky blue, sexy swimsuits, shiny silver and an upbeat attitude  Celine's show Thursday was like a dose of liquid sunshine. How come the American designer Michael Kors can go to the South of France and get tangy glamour on the runway, while the stylists at most French houses seem stuck in their studios turning fashion into art?

title: Nike Identifies Plants Abroad Making Goods For Universities
description: In a significant concession to the anti-sweatshop movement on college campuses, Nike Inc. became the first large apparel company yesterday to disclose the names and sites of dozens of its overseas factories -- a move that the college groups said was vital to uncover unsatisfactory working conditions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TARRSON, E.
description: TARRSON-E. ''Bud''. We mourn the passing of our beloved friend, ''Bud'', whose warmth of spirit and generosity of heart has been a gift to us for many years. Our deepest sympathies to his wife, Linda, and the Tarrson family. Rita and Bob Gottsegen

title: Road Work May Never Make Up for Lost Time
description: RIVERS suffering through highway construction projects may console themselves with the thought that when the work is done the traffic will flow faster and their trips will be shorter. But that is not always so, according to the Surface Transportation Policy Project, a group that favors other methods to cut traffic, like mass transit and land-use planning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, SAMUEL
description: BERMAN-Samuel, 89. On September 18. Retired teacher, supervisor of golf. Loved husband for 55 years of the late Sophie, dear father of Judith Berman Brandenburg and Richard M. Berman, father-inlaw of Lane Brandenburg and beloved grandfather of David and Neal Brandenberg.

title: BASEBALL PLAYOFFS
description: YANKEES 3 vs. TEXAS 1

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SARNOFF, PAUL
description: SARNOFF-Paul. Beloved husband of Lucille. Devoted father of Alan and Nancy, Mitchell and Denise, Steven and Tracy. Loving grandfather of Mark, Valerie, Matthew, Emily, Zachary, and Leah. Dear brother of Irving and Suzanne, Norman and Ruth, Morris and Deborah Shane. Services Friday, 12:45PM at ''Gutterman's Inc.'', 175 Long Beach Rd., Rockville Centre, Long Island.

title: Unproved vs. Alternative
description: To the Editor:

title: The Technological Gap 'Is Getting Larger' : Wired World Leaves Millions Out of Loop
description: WASHINGTON  Electronic communications of every form have become so commonplace in the developed world that we take them for granted. In any busy hour, we may be paged, place a mobile phone call, use an electronic cash machine, send a fax, receive an e-mail and perform an Internet search  using technologies that have emerged largely in the last 20 years.

title: Cathy de Monchaux -- 'Mordant Rapture'
description: Sean Kelly Gallery

title: Brazil and Argentina Move to Reorganize Their Debts
description: In an effort to reduce its debt burden, Brazil announced a proposal yesterday to buy back at least $500 million of its outstanding Brady bonds. At the same time, Argentina completed a $1.5 billion bond deal that includes a new kind of guarantee by the World Bank.

title: Dole Vows More Border Agents for Drug Fight
description: With the United States-Mexico border as her backdrop, Elizabeth Dole vowed today to more than double the number of Border Patrol agents if elected President, not as a way to fight illegal immigration but to block the flow of drugs from Latin America to the United States.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the end of baseball at the Houston Astrodome misstated the affiliation of Stephen Klineberg, a sociologist who commented on the structure's role in the city's history. He teaches at Rice University, not the University of Houston.

title: BRAZILIAN SHARE SALE
description: In a transaction that could point to an improved fund-raising environment overseas for Latin American businesses, the chemical company Grupo Ultra became the first Brazilian company to issue stock in international markets in nearly two years, with a $201.7 million offering. With the money raised in the offering, Ultra plans to increase its activities, which include the distribution of liquefied gas and production of petrochemical products. Ultra's sale of American depository receipts on the New York Stock Exchange, which were priced at $13.50 each, is the first such transaction for a Brazilian company since Coteminas, a textile producer, sold shares in the United States in December 1997. Ultra A.D.R.'s closed at $11.

title: GREAT-WEST LIFECO TO BUY AN ALLMERICA UNIT
description: Great-West Lifeco Inc., Canada's largest life insurer, agreed to buy the Allmerica Financial Corporation's group life and health insurance business for undisclosed terms, expanding its presence in the United States. Great-West, based in Winnipeg, Manitoba, will get a business that had $300 million in revenue last year and has 400,000 members. Great-West said it expected to retain a ''significant portion'' of the unit's customers. The transaction follows Great-West's purchase last year of a similar United States business from Anthem Inc. for about $100 million.

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: Final Bow? Not for Now

title: 2 More Firms Will Expand Trading Hours
description: DLJ Direct Inc. and the brokerage unit of Fidelity Investments said yesterday that they would offer up to four hours of extra stock trading daily within the next month, becoming the latest on-line brokers to extend the trading day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUNICK, DANIEL
description: TUNICK-Daniel. On October 7, 1999. At age 70. Beloved uncle of Neila and Bryan Ehrenfreund and Tamar and Douglas Bursky and families. Funeral services today at 12:30 P.M. at I.J. Morris, 46 Greenwich Street, Hempstead, NY.

title: Rebel War Comes Back to Haunt Honduran Base
description: A few cattle munched idly on scraggly clumps of grass poking through the hard packed dirt and gravel of what was once Honduras's longest and busiest military airstrip.

title: Advisory Firm's Chairman Pleads Not Guilty
description: Martin Armstrong, chairman of the investment advisory firm Princeton Economics International Inc., pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges he had defrauded Japanese clients of almost $1 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDEY, THELMA BARASCH
description: RUDEY-Thelma Barasch. On October 4, 1999, died peacefully at home at age 92. Barnard and Teacher's College Columbia University graduate. Lover of languages and the arts. Dearly beloved wife of the late Samuel Richard Rudey. Devoted mother of John and Laurie Rudey and Liz and Kirk Rudey Ruebenson. Loving grandmother of Matthew Aaron, Spencer Richard, Amanda Kathryn Rudey and Kate Anna Rudey Ruebenson. Sister of Clarence S. Barasch, Jacqueline B. Schneider and the late Gladys B. Blum. Dear sister-in-law, aunt and great aunt. Services Wednesday, October 6th, 11:00 AM at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Ave. at 65th St. Contributions in her memory may be be made to the Thelma and Samuel Rudey Book Fund in care of the Director's Office, Harvard College Library, Cambridge, MA. 02138.

title: G.E.'s Profit Rose 16% in Third Quarter
description: The General Electric Company said today that its third-quarter profit rose 16 percent, helped by acquisitions and more sales of turbines, engines and contracts to service industrial equipment.

title: In Museum Suit, Lawyers Cite Court Decision Against the City
description: In an ironic twist, city lawyers have cited the court decision barring them from stopping a youth rally in Harlem last month as a legal precedent in their effort to convince a judge that the Giuliani administration has not violated the First Amendment rights of the Brooklyn Museum of Art.

title: Trade and Pestilence
description: To the Editor:

title: Airline Ruled Liable for Distress on Turbulent Flight
description: When an American Airlines cross-country flight hit severe turbulence in 1995, terrified passengers were hurled from their seats, and some were sure they were about to die. Those 28 seconds of terror, a Federal jury said yesterday, were worth $2 million.

title: Merrill Lynch Catches the Spirit; A Traditional Brokerage Firm Spouts the On-Line Gospel
description: Can you teach an old bull new tricks?

title: Cuban Pitcher Being Pursued
description: The Yankees are among the teams talking about signing Danyso Baez, a right-handed pitcher who defected from Cuba during the Pan American Games in August.

title: NATWEST SAVINGS PROMISED
description: Hoping to persuade investors to back its $34 billion hostile bid for National Westminster Bank P.L.C., the Bank of Scotland P.L.C. said the acquisition, if completed, would create $:1 billion ($1.7 billion) in savings a year through cost-cutting measures. The Scottish bank said it would reduce costs by selling assets and cutting administrative expenses by merging computer systems and eliminating overlapping back-office operations. The chief executive of the Bank of Scotland, Peter Burt, above, said his bank could squeeze more out of a takeover than any of the possible counterbidders. Sir David Rowland, chairman of Natwest, said that most of the savings would have been achieved by the bank's own cost-cutting plan and that the Bank of Scotland's bid offered ''high risk for scant reward.''

title: Biotech Can Prosper
description: To the Editor:

title: Excerpts From the House Debate on Health Care Legislation and Amendments
description: Following are excerpts from the House debate on a bill by Representatives Charlie Norwood, Republican of Georgia, and John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, providing new rights for patients, including the right to sue health insurance companies for denying care, and two substitute measures supported by Republicans, one written by Representative John A. Boehner, Republican of Ohio, and the other by two Republican representatives, Tom Coburn of Oklahoma and John R. Shadegg of Arizona.

title: HINDU-FIRST PARTY WINS SOLID VICTORY IN INDIA'S ELECTION
description: The verdict of some 360 million Indian voters was announced today: The Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party, once seen as the ugly, anti-Muslim face of Hindu revivalism, won a clear victory as the leader of a centrist coalition of 24 parties that appears likely to offer India its most durable government in several years.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.

title: The Shortest Way to Grand Central, Cabby, and Pass the Soy Sauce
description: ''Hello, Binky,'' says Eleanor Winthrop, a well-cared-for blond Upper East Side matron, into the telephone. She has an event at 4:30 P.M., 12 blocks away at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and her chauffeur is in Lenox Hill Hospital, having inconsiderately had a heart attack. ''How does one hail a taxi these days?'' Eleanor (Mary Jane Wells) asks her friend. ''Does one actually step off the curb?''

title: Any Deal for Williams Denied
description: Brian Cashman had something to say to Bernie Williams yesterday, but even before the Yankees' general manager could speak, Williams asked, ''What's up with that?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HURWITZ, RUTH
description: HURWITZ-Ruth. Beloved wife of the late George. Mother of Susan (Allen Bernstein), Dr. William, and Ina (Philip Cangiano). Grandmother of Rosalind, Joel, Jennifer, Rebecca, Gregory and great grandmother of Samantha. She will always be lovingly remembered in our hearts for her dignity, strength and determination. Service on Sunday, October 10th, 9:30 AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: A Treaty We All Need
description: During the 1990's, the United States has made a vital contribution to arms control and nonproliferation. Thanks to the common resolve of the world's powers, we have achieved a substantial reduction in nuclear arsenals, the banning of chemical weapons, the indefinite and unconditional extension of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty and, in 1996, the conclusion of negotiations on the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty. South Africa, Ukraine, Kazakhstan and Belarus have renounced nuclear weapons in the same spirit.

title: Graduates Cut a Path in a Risky Trade
description: LONDON  Although she insists she is a control freak, Meg Andrew is the sort of person that things happen to. Since she started her design business, mca, a few months ago, the things that have happened to her have been almost all good.

title: Berlin Cameron Gets CBS Unit's Work
description: Iwon.com in Irvington, N.Y., a new Internet portal majority-owned by the CBS Corporation, said yesterday that it had awarded its first account to Berlin Cameron & Partners in New York. Spending was estimated at $40 million through mid-April.

title: Increasing Bandwidth Will Bring Cheaper Calls : Undersea Cables Proliferate
description: KUALA LUMPUR  Amid the dizzying and often hard to comprehend advances in telecommunications, there is good, simple news for nearly everyone who uses a telephone: The costs of long-distance calls are expected to plummet over the next few years as the number of undersea cables multiplies and the technology that makes them run radically improves, experts say.

title: UNITRIN TO SELL PYRAMID LIFE TO CERES GROUP
description: Ceres Group Inc., a health insurer, agreed yesterday to buy the Pyramid Life Insurance Company from Unitrin Inc. for $67.5 million to expand sales to people over 65. The companies also agreed that Ceres would sell its medical insurance through agents of Chicago-based Unitrin. Pyramid is Ceres's fourth acquisition since July 1998, giving the company a total of $850 million in assets, a sevenfold increase since the first purchase. Ceres, of Cleveland, sells managed care, health insurance and specialty products and services through 50,000 independent sales agents.

title: Fund-Raising, Texas-Style
description: To the Editor:

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan area.

title: Beyond Manhattan
description: Even Manhattan partisans are aware of the extraordinary selection of restaurants in Brooklyn and Queens. Each of these 12 restaurants presents a different cuisine, and but for the length of this column, the list could have gone on and on. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times by William Grimes, Mr. Asimov and others.)

title: Rights in Britain
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in some editions yesterday with an article about the making of the opera ''A View From the Bridge,'' which will have its premiere on Saturday, reversed the identities of two singers. Catherine Malfitano was at the left and Juliana Rambaldi at the right.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Sweden, the Welfare State, Basks in a New Prosperity
description: At a time when world leaders are fascinated by the United States' economic success and its credo of less government and low taxes, Sweden seems to be defying gravity.

title: Don't Put Strings on Debt Relief
description: To the Editor:

title: First Encephalitis Death Reported in Nassau as More Cases Turn Up Elsewhere
description: A 76-year-old Mineola woman has become the first Long Island resident to die of the West Nile-like encephalitis virus, Nassau County health officials announced today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, BETTY
description: DAVIS-Betty. Beloved wife of the late Abraham. Devoted mother of Kenneth and Gary. Cherished mother-in-law of Bonnie and Joanne. Dear sister of Vic Vogel, Eleanor Fox and Harry Vogel. Loving grandmother of Daniel and Jordanna. Contributions may be made in her memory to the Mt. Sinai Hospital School of Medicine. Services today, 2PM, at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I.

title: French Fashion Tycoon Takes a Bet on the Web
description: PARIS  The latest catch for the Net is Bernard Arnault, the Paris-based fashion tycoon. Phenomenally successful at exporting French luxury-ware, he now hopes that e-ware can be profitably imported to France.

title: Time Jumps the Track
description: The Museum of Modern Art has cut the ribbon on its contribution to the millennium furor: a 17-month series of exhibitions under the umbrella title ''MOMA 2000.'' In addition to being a summing up of this venerable institution's past, it is (or so we are told) a rehearsal for its future.

title: An Irish Classic Given Cartoon Form
description: The most imaginatively precise moment in the Barabbas theater company's exasperating ''Whiteheaded Boy'' is what you might call a smell gag. An actor spears a piece of bread with a pronged utensil and holds it in front of an obviously fake fireplace. A few minutes later, the distinct scent of singed toast wafts over the audience.

title: Booming Ranger Bats Are Surprisingly Silent
description: During the regular season, the Texas Rangers had a .293 team batting average that led both leagues, their 945 runs ranked second behind the Cleveland Indians, and they led both leagues in hits, total bases and slugging percentage.

title: Ali's Youngest Daughter Gets Set to Throw Her First Jab
description: Laila Ali was on edge today. She was flicking out answers like so many stiff jabs. Most boxers get that way just before a fight.

title: Sports of The Times; Once Again, Yankees Rule Prime Time
description: IT is easy to tell a Mets fan this week -- the one looking like a tropical fish, with expressionless eyes and a gaping mouth.

title: Retail Sales Jumped 5.5% In September
description: Retail sales at stores open for more than a year rose 5.5 percent in September as shoppers bought fall fashions and back-to-school supplies.

title: Stottlemyre's Shoulder And Spirit Are Willing
description: Todd Stottlemyre threw 124 pitches on Wednesday night with a partly torn rotator cuff and a torn labrum in his right shoulder. As he slipped on his shirt afterward, he noticed that his arm was still attached. It had been a good night.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Neiman Marcus Buyback
description: Neiman Marcus Group Inc., the department-store operation to be spun off by Harcourt General, will buy back as many as 1.5 million more of its shares as it battles declining earnings and a lagging stock price. Neiman Marcus, based here, also adopted a shareholder-rights plan to protect it against unsolicited takeover attempts. The company had purchased about a million shares under an existing 1.5-million-share buyback plan. Today, Neiman Marcus shares rose $1.875, to $25.

title: Deadline Arrives For Preliminary Bids
description: The process of selling the Jets reaches its first major deadline today when interested buyers are to submit preliminary bids to Goldman, Sachs, the investment banking firm handling the transaction for the estate of Leon Hess.

title: Behrens Is Still Standing For the Jockey Gold Cup
description: James Bond stood in the morning cold in his Saratoga horse compound and reported that he would place the customary saddle blanket inscribed with ''007'' on his star Behrens when he was saddled for Sunday's $1 million Jockey Club Gold Cup at Belmont Park. But he said there was no mystery that the race would confirm Behrens as Horse of the Year and added: ''It's his to lose.''

title: KOREAN BANK GROWTH PROJECTION
description: Raising its earlier forecast, the central bank of Korea projected South Korea would post a record growth in gross domestic product of 8.8 percent this year.

title: Hard-Boiled as a Two-Day-Old Egg at a Two-Bit Diner
description: Maybe it's time for a moratorium on that most hackneyed of moviemaking concepts, the film-noir spoof. A comic sub-genre that expresses an ironic longing for dark hidden worlds of corruption and evil that the show-and-tell culture of Jerry Springer has pretty much wiped out has been turned into a wearying film-school shtick.

title: Sprewell Hasn't Reached Out to Touch Knicks
description: There has always been an eccentric quality to Latrell Sprewell in his ability to detach himself from the norm like a rocket booster. In his own world, he operates on impulse and acts on his own schedule.

title: Fed Reconsiders Policy Of Disclosing Tilt on Rates
description: Concerned that its latest attempt to be more open might be confusing investors as much as helping them, the Federal Reserve is reviewing its new practice of disclosing once-secret decisions about tilting policy toward raising or reducing interest rates, the central bank said today.

title: Pumped-Up Pettitte Puts the Yankees in Command
description: Nobody need ask Andy Pettitte whether his inner fire had burned out, as Manager Joe Torre and Pettitte's wife, Laura, wondered in July. The pitcher's competitive rage was there for all to see again in the pivotal fifth inning at Yankee Stadium last night, punctuated by an emotional display his teammates had never seen from him.

title: A Dreamy Sensuality Bridges Time and Culture
description: Francesco Clemente is the youngest artist to be given the full-rotunda treatment by the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum. In recent years Claes Oldenburg, Ellsworth Kelly and Robert Rauschenberg have filled the place to overflowing and, in particular, have imprinted the rotunda with an indelible sense of their styles.

title: Stake Sold in Oilfields
description: The Middle Bay Oil Company, an oil and natural gas explorer, agreed today to buy stakes in oil and gas fields managed by the closely held Floyd Oil Company for $94 million. The properties, primarily in Texas and Louisiana, hold an estimated 186 billion cubic feet of natural gas and oil, Middle Bay said. Houston-based Middle Bay explores in Texas, Lousiana, and Oklahoma. It had $15 million in 1998 sales.

title: Pressing the Escape Button Won't Get You Home
description: Warning: Chris Carter wants to hijack your brain. Again. And after shuddering through tonight's premiere of ''Harsh Realm'' on Fox, you may be ready to surrender.

title: Everyone's a Neighbor In a Small Prairie Town
description: PLAINSONG

title: People
description: * Robert Kamerschen was named chairman and chief executive at the Dimac Corp., Atlanta. As chairman, he succeeds David King, who remains a director. Mr. Kamerschen had been chairman and chief executive at Advo Inc., Windsor, Conn.

title: Tang Horses Are Out In Full Force
description: According to the Chinese zodiac, this is not the Year of the Horse. But it should be. Ancient Chinese horse sculptures are showing up all over.

title: Borrowing By Consumers Up in August
description: Consumer borrowing grew in August by the largest amount in seven months as spending by Americans showed little sign of abating, Federal Reserve figures showed today.

title: N.F.L. MATCHUPS -- WEEK 5
description: GAME OF THE WEEK

title: Clinton Plans Move To Preserve Forests
description: President Clinton has asked the United States Forest Service to draw up a plan to protect up to 40 million acres of national forests around the country from commercial development, a White House official said. The plan would take effect in the form a Presidential directive.

title: Citing Public Support, Trump Forms Exploratory Committee on Presidency
description: Encouraged by ''amazing'' polls, ''unbelievable'' news media interest and a ''huge'' ground swell of public support, Donald J. Trump deepened his flirtation with Presidential politics yesterday by appointing an exploratory committee to help him decide whether his next big deal should be for 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GENSER, SIDNEY
description: GENSER-Sidney. October 8, 1998. I miss you so much. Take care of Mommy. Love, Barbar

title: Ebay in Dispute With Listing Site
description: In a developing dispute over Internet auction listings, the Web site Auctionwatch.com said this week that it would continue to provide lists of items for sale on the site of Ebay Inc., which has been trying to stop the practice.

title: Leandro Erlich -- 'El Living'
description: Kent

title: Rage Against Women Said to Prompt Shove
description: The murder case against Andrew Goldstein opened yesterday with a sharp, unusually personal attack by a prosecutor, who accused him of shoving Kendra Webdale in front of a speeding subway train because he was angry at another blond woman who had just rebuffed his efforts to chat with her.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Health Plans Depict Lawyers as Threat
description: This is a new 30-second commercial that the American Association of Health Plans, the major managed care industry group, began broadcasting in Washington this week. The commercial focuses on the right to sue, the most contentious provision in the main patients' rights bill, sponsored by Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, and Representative Charlie Norwood, Republican of Georgia.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Steinbrenner Extols Team's 'Heart'
description: George Steinbrenner strolled through the bowels of Yankee Stadium last night with his chest puffed out and a confident look on his face. He was heading for Joe Torre's office to congratulate the manager after the Yankees stymied the Rangers, 3-1, to take a commanding 2-0 lead in the three-of-five-game series.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDMAN, EMANUEL
description: EDMAN-Emanuel, Dr., of Weston, MA, on Wednesday, October 6, formerly of Brooklyn, NY. Beloved husband of Priscilla (Herzlich). Devoted father of Nancy & Robert Feldman. Loving grandfather of Lisa & Aaron Rosenberg & Adam Feldman. Dear brother of Sylvia Goldberg. Graveside services at the Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY, on Friday, October 8, at 2:00 P.M. A Memorial Service will be held at Temple Israel, 175 Temple Street, Newton, MA, on Monday, October 11, 1999 at 11:00 A.M. He is remembered and honored by his loving family.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 8.

title: 'Dead Time=Tiempo Muerto'
description: Taller Boricua Gallery

title: Indians Slam Their Way To Boston With 2-0 Lead
description: For the Red Sox, their brief, shining moment in the late-afternoon sun came around 5 P.M. today and lasted for about five minutes. After that, shadows and reality descended on Jacobs Field as the power of the Indians eclipsed most Boston hopes. When the game ended, around sundown, Cleveland had an 11-1 victory and a 2-0 lead in the three-of-five-game first-round event.

title: Clinton Tour Hits 2 Blocs On 1 Street
description: President Clinton came to New York yesterday to pay tribute to two political constituencies that had proved central to his electoral success -- labor unions and gay rights advocates -- and now loom as critical to the political future of Mr. Clinton's wife and his Vice President.

title: Yasumasa Morimura -- 'Daughter of Art History'
description: Luhring Augustine

title: Fund-Raising, Texas-Style
description: To the Editor:

title: It's Now Okay to Be a Brand-Conscious Woman About Town : Makeover of Japan's Moms
description: TOKYO  Japanese women didn't have much choice when it came to motherhood and fashion: It was either frump or frumpier. This started from the maternity stage. While American and European women were enjoying the pleasures of stretch maternity jeans and evening dresses, Japanese mothers-to-be went around in plaid jumper skirts and cotton socks.

title: Judge Dismisses Cincinnati's Suit on Firearms
description: A state judge in Cincinnati dismissed the city's lawsuit against the firearms industry yesterday, saying the city was improperly asking a court to change the way guns are designed, marketed and distributed, something only a legislature could do.

title: Birchtown Journal; For Nova Scotia Blacks, Veil Is Ripped From Past
description: As a mechanic with the Canadian Air Force, Everett S. Cromwell traveled the world. But as a black man born in Nova Scotia, the wind-blown Atlantic province typically associated with Gaelic cod fishermen, he recalled, ''I never had a clue where we actually came from.''

title: National Grid to Seek More Northeast Assets
description: David H. Jones, the group chief executive of National Grid Group P.L.C., which has already agreed to buy a large utility in New England, said yesterday that his company would seek more acquisitions in the Northeast.

title: The Man Behind the Wheel at M.T.A. Talks
description: WILLIE JAMES'S favorite Psalm is No. 124:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMSON, GEORGE G.
description: THOMSON-George G. Jr. On October 6, 1999 at Boston Medical Center of surgical complications. Born in NYC February 4, 1919. Attended St. Mark's School, Harvard College, class of 1941. Enrolled in British Army, King's Royal Rifle Corps. Served in North Africa and Italy with distinction. Transferred to Jedburgh Unit, U.S. Army, serving behind enemy lines in France and China. After a career in public relations and investment banking, he retired to New Boston, NH in 1994. He is survived by his wife, Sylvia Thomson, his sister, Cara Baldwin, children, Sandra, Geordie and Ginger, daughter-in-law, Rosie, son-in-law, John, and grandchildren, Georgia, Augusta, Basil, Jack, Calypso, Josy, Duff and Elektra. Private burial on Saturday, October 9 at Waldoboro, Maine. Memorial service in NYC to be announced. In lieu of flowers, gifts may be made to Brantwood Camp, C/O J. Linvee Coolidge, 101 Tremont Street, Suite 1000, Boston, MA. 02108-5003.

title: Album of the Week
description: MESHELL NDEGEOCELLO: ''Bitter'' (Maverick). In this season of blockbusters, as Garth Brooks morphs into Chris Gaines and Trent Reznor crawls forth to top the charts again, subtler artistic transformations may be overlooked. Consider ''Bitter,'' the third album by Meshell Ndegeocello.

title: BRAZIL UTILITY SHAKE-UP
description: Representatives of minority shareholders in Cemig, a Brazilian electric utility controlled by Minas Gerais state, were ousted in a display of anti-privatization ire by Gov. Itamar Franco, the former President whose refusal to pay debts helped provoke Brazil's currency crisis last January. The Cemic executives -- from the AES Corporation, the Southern Company and Grupo Opportunity -- were dismissed after a state court ruled their 1997 purchase of a voting-rights stake in Cemig for about $1 billion did not give them veto power over investment decisions. The investors plan to appeal the decision in federal courts.

title: Corrections
description: A Public Lives profile on Tuesday about the architect Bernard Tschumi referred incompletely to the design team responsible for the new student center at Columbia University. It is Bernard Tschumi/Gruzen Samton Associated Architects.

title: U.S. Indicts a Financier Held in Germany on 36 Counts of Fraud
description: The financier Martin R. Frankel, who fled the United States and is now in a German prison, was indicted by a Federal grand jury yesterday on 36 counts of fraud, money laundering and racketeering in what prosecutors said was a scheme that siphoned more than $200 million from a group of Southern insurance companies for use for his own benefit.

title: Ingres: An Icy Eye for People
description: BEFORE he was the great man of French art, Jean-Auguste-Dominique Ingres drew pencil portraits to make money. They were souvenirs on letter-size sheets of paper. He was living in Italy.

title: New Faces in New Roles For the Giants on Sunday
description: The Giants will have a new starting quarterback Sunday. They may also have a new starting center because Brian Williams has a serious thumb injury.

title: The Boom Generation
description: Limitless prosperity, endless eco nomic growth such is the mantra that echoes in the halls of the Republic. The resulting mood is pervasive. Here at Montana State University, I teach men and women between the ages of 18 and 25, for the most part. This is not a school of rich kids. Many have to take on one or more part-time jobs to afford the tuition even a land-grant college must charge.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AITKEN, S. THOMAS
description: AITKEN-S. Thomas, of Palm Beach Gardens, FL., and North Caldwell, N.J., on October 4, 1999. Beloved father of Thomas Wells (and Jennifer) Aitken of North Andover, Mass.; Heather Hyatt Aitken of Brentwood, Calif. Friends may call from 7-9 PM Thursday and 2-4 and 7-9 PM Friday at the Dancy Funeral Home, 9 Smull Ave., Caldwell (973-226-1166). A funeral service will be held 11 AM Saturday in the First Presbyterian Church at Caldwell (corner of Bloomfield & Roseland avenues). In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Center for Hospice Care, 3 High St., Glen Ridge, NJ 07028; Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Lung Cancer Research, 1275 York Avenue, Box E, New York, NY 10021; or Alliance for Lung Cancer Support, Advocacy & Education, 1601 Lincoln Ave., Vancouver, WA 98660. Interment will be private at Riverdale Cemetery, Lewiston, New York.

title: Sensual Dreams
description: The Italian painter Francesco Clemente is the youngest artist to be given the full-rotunda treatment by the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum. The exhibition explores 25 years of his East-meets-West dream images that delve into the mind, the body and many forms of love, with works ranging from ''The Four Corners'' (right) to portraits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OESTREICHER, DAVID J.
description: OESTREICHER-David J. On October 5, 1999. Father of Carol Chisholm and Jill. Loving grandfather of Shawna. Brother of the late Anthony. Best friend of Terri Cook. Reposing Redden Funeral Home, 325 West 14th Street, New York City, New York, Thursday and Friday 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. Mass of Christian burial Saturday, 9:30 A.M., St. Veronica's Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTOCK, HERBERT
description: WEINSTOCK-Herbert, Dr. We are deeply saddened at the loss of our dear friend Herb. Our heartfelt sympathy to Adele and her family. Florence and Alvin Burnett

title: Fund-Raising, Texas-Style
description: To the Editor:

title: Insurer Halts Disputed Plan For Coverage of Auto Repairs
description: Having lost a $456 million jury verdict on Monday, State Farm, the nation's largest auto insurer, announced today that it would temporarily require that all crash repairs on its policyholders' automobiles be done with parts produced by auto manufacturers or their affiliates.

title: In Song, a Reverie About Real Estate
description: ''The Carbon-Copy Building,'' the new opera being performed through tomorrow at the Kitchen (512 West 19th Street, Chelsea), is made to be read as much as heard. It's an immersion in the realm of the cartoonist Ben Katchor, whose weekly comics -- ''Julius Knipl, Real Estate Photographer,'' ''The Jew of New York'' and ''The Cardboard Valise,'' which appears in The New York Press -- have envisioned a city full of rundown buildings and homely enigmas, glancing encounters and peculiar small businesses. With bleary washes of grays, Mr. Katchor draws a city where aspirations and grubby materiality are constantly entwined.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMERON, WILLIAM
description: CAMERON - William A. The Trustees of the South Fork-Shelter Island Chapter of The Nature Conservancy mourn the passing of their Chairman, William A. Cameron. Bill was a tireless crusader for the conservation of his beloved East End Landscape. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to his family, and hope that they, as we, will celebrate his memory in the lands and waters he helped to preserve. Nancy N. Kelley, Exec. Dir. Judy Bergsma, Polly Bruckmann, Katharine Rayner, Vice Chairs

title: Nobel Winner Is to Head Cancer Center
description: Dr. Harold E. Varmus, the Nobel Prize-winning molecular biologist who has presided over the National Institutes of Health during the greatest expansion in its 112-year history, told President Clinton yesterday that he would resign at the end of the year to become president and chief executive of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan.

title: Weldon Case, 78, Former Chairman and Chief Executive of Alltel
description: Weldon W. Case, the former chairman and chief executive of the Alltel Corporation, died on Sept. 30 at Boca Raton Community Hospital in Florida. He was 78 and lived in Boca Raton.

title: Two Fine Granddaughters, but Only One Is His Heir
description: At a wooden table on the verdant grounds of a countryside estate in Spain at the turn of the last century, two lovely girls stray from their schoolbooks to ponder the existence of God.

title: Torre Talks to Yankees And Ledee Responds
description: Ricky Ledee was a few feet from Joe Torre when the manager gathered the Yankees together in the clubhouse before the division series against Texas started on Tuesday. Torre reminded his players to appreciate where they were. Torre rarely raises his voice, but his soothing words are powerful. Ledee listened closely.

title: The Things She'll Do For Fame and a Date
description: It's easier to understand Mary Katherine Gallagher when you know about her family. Her parents were killed in a tragic Irish step-dancing accident at a talent show. She lives in the quiet town of Besamee Heights with her grandmother (Glynis Johns), who once danced on Broadway in ''Gypsy'' but is now in a wheelchair and absolutely forbids her granddaughter to go into show business. No wonder dear Mary Katherine walks around St. Monica's Catholic High School in a plaid uniform skirt that barely covers her white underpants. No wonder she practices her kissing skills and sweet-nothings patter on trees. No wonder she dreams of being a star.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: LIZ CLAIBORNE INC., New York, agreed to buy the closely held Podell Industries, Los Angeles, for an undisclosed sum to add brands to its contemporary women's clothing business.

title: 'Surface Tension'
description: Barbara Rose Haum -- 'The Girl Who Stepped on Bread'

title: Congress and White House Compromise on Elements of Spending Measure
description: In the first sign of a break in a bitter standoff, the White House and Congress compromised on changes in a $82 billion spending bill tonight.

title: On My Mind; Riding Two Tracks
description: In New York over the past few days, two major opponents in Israeli political life separately raised somber and fundamentally identical questions about the problems of achieving peace between Israel and the Arabs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDELL, ARNOLD A.
description: MANDELL-Arnold A., of New York City & Pompano Beach, FL. on October 6. Beloved husband of the late Pearl, devoted father of Jane Moross and the late Robert Mandell. Dear brother of Edward Mandell. Loving grandfather of Gary, Gregory, Rebecca & Peter. Great grandfather of Samantha and Justin. Funeral services in Fort Lauderdale, FL.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLADSTONE, ALEX
description: GLADSTONE-Alex. Age 94, of West Palm Beach, FL formerly of Fair Lawn, NJ. Survived by his wife of 76 years, Lillian; daughters, Ruth (Lou) Brod of Fort Lee, NJ and Phyllis (Arthur) Kresch of Fair Lawn, NJ; sister, Minnie Baum and brother, Julius Gladstone; four grandchildren, five great-grandchildren and two great-greatgrandchildren. Services are Sunday, 12:30 PM at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, 150 Route 4 East, Paramus, New Jersey.

title: Police to Accept Civilian Panel's Inquiry in Misconduct Cases
description: The New York Police Department will relinquish its role in investigating misconduct complaints against officers as part of an informal agreement with the independent panel whose job it is to review such complaints, officials said yesterday.

title: INSIDE
description: Financier Is Indicted

title: Microsoft Adds To McCann Work
description: The Microsoft Corporation in Redmond, Wash., has expanded its relationship with McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising by awarding a new account to McCann-Erickson Europe. Billings were estimated at more than $50 million.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO GAINS. The euro rose against the dollar on speculation the European Central Bank may raise its benchmark lending rates soon. In New York, the euro settled at $1.0710, up from $1.0697 on Wednesday.

title: Leading Environmentalists Put Support and Money Behind Gore
description: Vice President Al Gore, who prides himself for his environmental record, was stung last month when an environmental group, Friends of the Earth, endorsed former Senator Bill Bradley, his rival for the Democratic Presidential nomination. Yesterday some of Mr. Gore's supporters struck back, holding a fund-raising lunch in midtown Manhattan that featured endorsements from some leading New York environmentalists, including Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and Lawrence Rockefeller.

title: Mr. Vajpayee's India
description: Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee of India has won an impressive election victory that gives his coalition a chance to survive longer than recent governments in New Delhi. Stability would be a welcome development after a succession of inconclusive elections and short-lived ruling coalitions, including Mr. Vajpayee's, which collapsed in April. No less encouraging is his promise to revive negotiations with Pakistan, speed economic liberalization and refrain from steps hostile to Muslims and other minorities. Progress on these fronts should make the world breathe easier and clear the way for President Clinton to visit next year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, STANLEY
description: FISHER-Stanley, died October 7, 1999, after a long courageous fight, at age 74. Beloved husband for 52 years of Regina Fisher; loving, proud father of Fran Fishman and Michael and Greg Fisher. Most adored ''Pop'' of five grandchildren, Eric, Drew and Allison Fisher, and Scott and Jonathan Fishman. Dear father-in-law of Gilbert Fishman. Cherished brother of Claire Rolbein. Contributions can be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Box E, 1275 York Ave., NY, NY 10021. Services will be held on Friday, October 8, 1999, at 1 P.M., Temple Emanuel, 150 Hicks Lane, Great Neck, NY.

title: M.I.T. Economics Professor To Write a Times Column
description: The New York Times announced yesterday that Paul Krugman, an economics professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and an author known for his theories on international trade and economics, would become a columnist on the Op-Ed page. Mr. Krugman's column will appear twice a week, beginning in January, and will be The Times's first regular Op-Ed column devoted to economics, business and finance.

title: Florida State's Warrick Is Suspended After an Arrest
description: The Florida State Seminoles yesterday suspended Peter Warrick, the receiver who is a leading candidate for the Heisman Trophy, after he and a teammate were arrested in connection with a scheme to underpay for clothes at a department store in Tallahassee, Fla.

title: Language Barrier Cited In Inquiry Into Ship Fire
description: The Coast Guard is investigating whether crew members aboard the cruise ship Tropicale spoke enough English to assist passengers when a fire broke out on the ship in the Gulf of Mexico last month.

title: Touring Show-Business Royalty and Its Underworld
