description: The flinty modernism that looked so bold on screen in John Boorman's 1967 nouveau-noir classic ''Point Blank'' has become innocently nostalgic in Steven Soderbergh's hands. ''The Limey,'' which could be called the latest directorial oddity from Mr. Soderbergh if that were not such a redundancy, is a piquant throwback to that style.

title: Residential Real Estate; Brooklyn Co-op Makes A Financial Comeback
description: A four-building, 64-apartment co-op in the Kensington section of Brooklyn that avoided foreclosure seven months ago is back on stable financial footing, ending nearly five years of struggle and enabling shareholders to sell their apartments.

title: Musical Elixir Afoot
description: THE most potent antidepressant available in New York at the moment can't be had by prescription, and it isn't measured in milligrams. It is being marketed under the name ''Contact'' and is the manufacture of Susan Stroman, a director, choreographer and inspired alchemist. Advertising has it that ''Contact'' is a ''dance play,'' but those words hardly capture how the show makes you feel. ''Contact'' is a sustained endorphin rush of an evening, that rare entertainment that has you floating all the way home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHN, ALFRED
description: COHN-Alfred on October 6, 1999. Beloved husband of Joan. Devoted father of Darcy, Alexandra and Cathy. Family will welcome friends Saturday evening from 8PM at 1480 Coolidge Avenue, Baldwin, New York. Graveside services Sunday 11:30AM at Beth Moses Cemetery, Wellwood Avenue, Farmingdale, L.I.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHARDSON, LEE
description: RICHARDSON-Lee. We applaud the life and mourn the loss of our dear friend and client Lee Richardson. A great actor and a very special person. He was our loyal support from the beginning. Lee made our jobs and our lives fun and rewarding. He will always be with us. Our love to Rachel and Jonathan. ''Goodbye doctor''. Don Buchwald & Associates

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SULAM, EDNA
description: SULAM-Edna. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Edna Sulam, beloved mother of our dedicated leader and dear friend, Carol Zicklin. Devoted to strengthening the Jewish community for future generations, Carol is the volunteer coordinator of the Jewish introduction service, Links, and is a trustee of the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services, a beneficiary agency of UJA-Federation. We offer our sincerest condolences to Carol and her husband, Lawrence, a dedicated board member and former campaign chair of UJA-Federation; to Mrs. Sulam's husband, Gabriel; her son, Donald; her four grandchildren; and her five great-grandchildren. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair James S. Tisch, President John Ruskay, Executive VP (Interim)

title: Philadelphia Reprises the 20th Century
description: Most of the world's major orchestras pass through New York every year or two, but proximity and tradition have given the Philadelphia Orchestra a presence in the city that rivals that of several of New York's freelance ensembles. This season the orchestra is celebrating its centenary, and its eight concerts at Carnegie Hall -- the first was on Tuesday, the last is in May -- are part of its celebration.

title: Even Without Strings, It Could Make Music
description: Music in ancient China, or at least the music we know about, wasn't meant to just tinkle away in the background during happy hour. It was serious stuff, performed in ancestral rituals and enlisted to assert political authority. And it became a vehicle for spiritual self-cultivation, in China and beyond.

title: Cadets Triumph In Double Overtime
description: ARMY 59, LOUISVILLE 52

title: The Reality Of Welfare Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Metrocard Robs Pockets Of a Jingle
description: THIS woman we know of decided to break up with her boyfriend, and went to his place to deliver the bad news. She took the bus, using her Metrocard. She also bore in mind that she had somewhere else to go later.

title: Bradley Wants More Spending To Ease Stresses on Families
description: Former Senator Bill Bradley offered his prescription for the stresses on families of global economic competition, calling today for $3.6 billion a year in new Federal spending to expand day care services, improve community colleges and encourage the elderly to work with children.

title: Rapping in the Heartland, Eager to Shed His Skin
description: Flip Dogg is phat. He's a hip-hop kind of guy. ''I got so much juice/I'm getting loose,'' he raps in the privacy of his bedroom -- until his mother calls him for dinner. Did we mention that although Flip deals cocaine from the men's room at a local club, it's really baking soda? Did we mention that Flip lives in rural Iowa, surrounded by cornfields, barns, pickup trucks and birdsong? Did we mention that Flip is white?

title: American Standard Chooses an Outsider
description: The American Standard Companies, a maker of plumbing, air-conditioning and automotive equipment, has named Frederic Poses as its chairman and chief executive to replace Emmanuel Kampouris, who is retiring.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOA, BRUNO
description: FOA-Bruno. Age 93. Beloved husband, cherished father, grandfather and great grandfather died October 4, 1999 after a short illness. The emotional center of our family, a family shattered and dispersed by the history of the 20th century across Italy, Israel and the United States, we will forever remember him for his warm and gentle heart, his intellect and wisdow, and above all, for his love of life, optimism and singular charm. He was Italy's youngest full professor (in economics) at the age of 28, an early Zionist & dedicated anti-Fascist, he worked with Chaim Weizmann in London in the 1920s and retained a special devotion to Israel. He came to the U.S. in 1940, worked for the Federal Reserve Board, published and wrote on monetary policy & economic reconstruction in Italy, and as a consulting economist, worked with a variety of international clients. He is also survived by his devoted sister Marina Levi, 99, of Milan. A memorial service will be held Sunday, October 10, 2PM at ''Riverside Memorial Chapel'', 180 West 76 Street, New York City. Lisa, Eleanor, Pamela, Paul, Joshua, Jennifer, Jesse, Stephanie, Nora and Sophia

title: Fen-Phen Maker to Pay Billions In Settlement of Diet-Injury Cases
description: The American Home Products Corporation agreed yesterday to pay $3.75 billion in total to thousands of people who contend they were injured by taking the popular diet pill combination fen-phen.

title: How to Miss a Big Bull Market: Invest in Perelman Stocks
description: TO hear George Fellows tell it, everything is going great at Revlon Inc. Market share is rising, and consumers love the company's cosmetics. Investors should be happy that the company is dealing with a huge inventory problem that is in no way its fault.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: MIDDLE EAST

title: WACHOVIA TO BUY B C BANKSHARES FOR $134 MILLION
description: The Wachovia Corporation, the third-largest bank in the southeastern United States, agreed to buy B C Bankshares Inc. for about $134 million in stock, as it expands in the fast-growing banking market around Atlanta. Wachovia, based in Winston-Salem, N.C., said it would pay 2.914 shares of its common stock for each share of B C Bankshares. Wachovia said it expected to issue 1.6 million shares for the purchase. B C Bankshares, based in Canton, Ga., is the parent company of Bank of Canton, which has eight branches in Cherokee County, north of Atlanta, and assets of $395 million.

title: INSIDE ART
description: 'Sensation' In a Child's Eyes

title: Astros Look Longingly to Hampton Against the Braves
description: Back on their home field, and with their best pitcher ready, the Houston Astros said today that they liked their position heading into Friday's encounter with the Atlanta Braves.

title: Bush Challenges the Orthodoxy But Is Still a Devout Conservative
description: For as long as Gov. George W. Bush of Texas has been describing himself as a ''compassionate conservative,'' Republicans and Democrats alike have wondered whether the phrase was a call for a flexible new ideology or an effort to put a friendlier face on an essentially unchanged philosophy.

title: Russia Investigating Its Own Banks for Role in Suspicious Cash Movements
description: The nation's top tax official said that his investigation was pointing to a single Russian bank as the architect of the transfer of billions of dollars into accounts under investigation in the United States.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If Americans have the right to sue for a damaged fence or an unsafe toy, they should have the right to sue if their life or health has been endangered.''

title: Review/Fashion; Just How Sexy Does a Woman Want to Look?
description: There are always big thoughts to think as a fashion season winds down: how designers translated the work of their predecessors, which editors had the newest Prada bags a dozen hours after they appeared on the runway, how Ivana Trump (seated in the front row on Wednesday) would look in Alexander McQueen's studded wrestling helmet for Givenchy.

title: Grunwald Gets Deal; Willis Is Re-signed
description: The Raptors gave General Manager Glen Grunwald a four-year contract extension yesterday and signed 37-year-old center Kevin Willis to a two-year, $6.1 million extension.

title: Sega Gameworks Names a Chief
description: Ron Bension, a former chief of the Universal Studios theme park business, has been appointed president and chief executive of Sega Gameworks, which runs entertainment centers featuring arcade games and simulation rides.

title: INTUIT TO BUY ROCK FINANCIAL, AN ON-LINE MORTGAGE SELLER
description: Intuit Inc., the No. 1 maker of personal finance software, agreed yesterday to buy the Rock Financial Corporation for about $370 million in stock. Rock Financial shareholders will get 0.58 to 0.84 of an Intuit share for each of their shares. Rock Financial employs more than 600 people and had sales of $90.3 million last year. The company, based in Bingham Farms, Mich., provides home loans through its World Wide Web site RockLoans.com. Intuit, best known for its Quicken personal finance software, will combine Rock Financial with its own on-line mortgage service. Intuit's shares fell $3.125 each, to $27. Rock Financial was down 12.5 cents, to $20.

title: Survey Shows Drop In Costs for TV Ads
description: An annual survey released yesterday by the American Association of Advertising Agencies in New York reported that the average cost of producing a 30-second national television commercial declined 4 percent in 1998, to $295,000, from $308,000 in 1997.

title: E. C. Banfield, 83, Maverick On Urban Policy Issues, Dies
description: Edward C. Banfield, a professor emeritus of government at Harvard University whose work on urban policy and the causes of poverty gave him a reputation as a brilliant maverick, died Sept. 30 at his summer home in Vermont. He was 83 and lived in Cambridge, Mass.

title: Charity Led by General Powell Comes Under Heavy Fire, Accused of Inflating Results
description: At the Presidents' Summit for America's Future in 1997, Gen. Colin L. Powell whetted the imagination of many community leaders when he pledged to help children get what they needed to grow into healthy, productive adults.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUNG, LUCYLLE
description: YOUNG-Lucylle. Our sympathies to Carol Ann Young of our Board in the passing of her beloved mother. The Board of Overseers and Staff, The Brookdale Center on Aging of Hunter College

title: Watch Out for a Daughter With an Unflinching Camera
description: The first time Thomas Blake is seen on screen, in what appears to be a tiny office, he looks like an elderly small-city insurance salesman, the kind of guy who never got the promotion he deserved and can't afford to retire. In fact, he's an 89-year-old Texas multimillionaire with a photograph on the wall of himself with Clark Gable and Gary Cooper on a hunting trip in Mexico. This information lends a lot of weight to Mr. Blake's business advice to his daughter: ''Whatever you do, make money. Because that's the only recognition you're ever going to get.''

title: Martin Luther King Jr. High School Coach Is Reinstated
description: Martin Jacobson has been reinstated as soccer coach of Martin Luther King Jr. High School in Manhattan after an 11-month exile from a team that won three consecutive city championships.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Woo Lae Oak, one of Manhattan's most dependable Korean restaurants, went up in smoke five years ago. Now it is back, in SoHo this time, and with a spare, modern decor to suit the neighborhood. The walls are exposed brick, the seating is at a bistro-style banquette, and a brightly lighted open kitchen runs almost the length of the dining room, with a swooshy, stark-white panel overhead that looks as if it were lifted from the facade of the Guggenheim Museum. Each of the marble tabletops is outfitted with its own gas-fired barbecue pit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DURFEE, VIRGINIA
description: DURFEE-Virginia, (nee Fearon). Suddenly on October 6th. Devoted mother of Therese K. Durfee. Deeply mourned by George and Therese Watson and four loving nephews; Dominick, James, Alexander and Christopher. Funeral Saturday, 9:30AM from Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Ave. at 20th St. NYC. Mass of Christian burial, 10am, Old St. Patrick's Church, Mulberry Street. Visiting Friday 2-5 and 7-9 PM.

title: A Brand New Club, an Ageless Star
description: With the grand opening on Tuesday evening of a 150-seat supper club at the Regency Hotel bearing the name of the singer and pianist Michael Feinstein (who is booking the club in partnership with the Tisch family), Feinstein's at the Regency (540 Park Avenue, at 61st Street) has become the first high-end supper club to cast its hat in the cabaret ring since the demise of Rainbow and Stars.

title: Clean Up the I.N.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURRAY, SHIRLEY FOERDERER
description: MURRAY-Shirley Foerderer, of Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y., on October 5, 1999, peacefully at home. Wife of Francis W. Murray III, daughter of Percival E. and Ethel Brown Foerderer, sister of Mignon Foerderer Davis and Florence R. Foerderer, mother of Charles F. Ames, Shelley A. Hartz and P. Foerd Ames, and grandmother of Ashley, Loren, Lia, Walker, Will & Grace. Memorial service at 2 PM Saturday, October 9, at St. John's Church, Cold Spring Harbor. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the following: Thomas Jefferson University Development Office, Foerderer Fund-In Memory of Shirley Foerderer Murray, 925 Chestnut Street, Suite 110, Philadelphia, PA. 19107. For information, contact A.L. Jacobsen Funeral Home, Inc., of Huntington Station, New York.

title: The Reality Of Welfare Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Teacher Is Charged With Selling Cocaine
description: An assistant teacher at an elementary school in Brooklyn was arrested yesterday on charges of selling cocaine, the police said.

title: Brodeur Gets Ejected And Devils Lag Behind
description: In their first meeting since Pittsburgh eliminated the Devils in the first round of the playoffs last spring, the New Jersey goalie was ejected early and his team spent the rest of the game trying to catch up. But the Penguins managed a 7-5 victory tonight in the Devils' home opener at Continental Arena.

title: $100 Million To Be Given To Cornell
description: An anonymous donor has pledged $100 million to help Cornell University revamp undergraduate housing, Hunter R. Rawlings 3d, Cornell's president, is to announce today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORTON, CLAUDE
description: MORTON-Claude. Died Thursday, October 7. He was a Veteran of W.W. II. A memorial services will be held Saturday, 11 AM at Boles Funeral Home of Pinehurst, NC. He is survived by his wife Emily and three sons, Camm, Rick and Greg and four grandchildren.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: And Still, Serbs Bar Muslims In Bosnia
description: There has been little money for reconstruction of this city, because the Bosnian Serbs who took it over and are believed to have killed thousands of men who fled the occupation in 1995 will not let the former Muslim residents who survived return. The Municipal Building, a gleaming relic of the Austro-Hungarian Empire which ruled Bosnia for 40 years before World War I, is the sole exception.

title: For Enlightenment, Her Heart Will Go On
description: In the trippy opening moments of Jane Campion's ''Holy Smoke,'' Kate Winslet can be found in the midst of another bohemian rhapsody. Having roamed so gorgeously through North Africa as a young hippie mother in ''Hideous Kinky,'' Ms. Winslet this time appears in India as Ruth Barron, a headstrong young Australian seeking enlightenment. And the film's delirious credit sequence, complete with the film's title written in blow-away smoke letters, captures the full ecstasy of Ruth's adventure. Among the more lovable things about Ms. Campion's new film is its knowing why a grandiose Neil Diamond hit on the soundtrack will make this voluptuous, giddy sequence complete.

title: A Sad Judicial Mugging
description: Just when it seemed the judicial confirmation process in the Senate had reached a nadir, Republicans this week set a new low. By a strict party-line vote, they rejected a mainstream candidate for a Federal district judgeship in Missouri, Ronnie White, based on trumped-up charges about his record in death penalty cases.

title: Albany Lawmakers Pass DNA and Clinic Bills
description: The State Senate gave final legislative approval to four major bills today, including one that expands the state's DNA database for tracking criminals and another that increases penalties for blocking access to abortion clinics and for stalking.

title: Trooper in Turnpike Shooting Sues State, Saying He Was Unfit for Duty
description: In an unusual legal tack, a state trooper charged with attempted murder in a shooting during a routine traffic stop on the New Jersey Turnpike last year is suing the state and his commanders for allowing him to work even though, he claims, he was emotionally unfit for duty.

title: Time Is of the Essence (Oh, Really?)
description: Baseball is a timeless game, a pastoral endeavor unbound by the tyranny of a ticking clock. Nine innings can stretch to eternity, often joyfully. But the charms of timelessness can yield to a sense of the never-ending and that pushing the final buzzer would be an act of mercy.

title: Don't Put Strings on Debt Relief; The Debt Bargain
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLKOFF, NELLIE
description: WOLKOFF-Nellie. Loving mother of Caryl Shorin, Jack and Phyllis. Loving grandmother of Jayme, Greg, Scott and Mindi. She was loved and will be missed by all.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SENFELD, S. WILLIAM
description: SENFELD-S. William. Suddenly on October 6, 1999. Son of the late Lee Senfeld. Graveside services today at Cedar Park cemetery, Westwood, NJ.

title: Chase Is Moving 3,500 of Its Jobs From New York
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation, the largest corporate employer in New York City, is moving 10 percent of its jobs -- 3,500 positions -- to Florida, Texas and Massachusetts, the company told its workers yesterday.

title: Hedge Fund to Curb Investors' Withdrawals
description: Tiger Management L.L.C., the hedge fund group led by Julian H. Robertson, is limiting investors' ability to withdraw money in a response to about $3 billion in withdrawals this year because of dismal performance.

title: New Video Releases
description: Chambermaid on the Titanic

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOMEZ, CHARLES G.
description: GOMEZ-Charles G., age 89, died October 6, 1999. Husband of the late Lucille. Father of Richard, Michael, Anita and Joseph. Grandfather and great-grandfather. Member of Masonic Lodge 246. Service at Fredericks Funeral Home, Flushing, NY on Friday, October 8th, 2-5PM and 7-9PM.

title: McEnroe's Leadership Test Will Begin in Zimbabwe
description: John McEnroe, the colorful new United States Davis Cup captain, heard the word Zimbabwe yesterday and immediately began checking his cell phone to see if the prime name on his wish list of Davis Cup volunteers, Andre Agassi, had called in to cancel his Round 1 reservations. He had not.

title: When Children Have to Be Chic
description: LONDON  On any given day, you're still as likely to see children here headed to school in blazers and boaters, or wearing velvet pinafores in the playground, as you were decades ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HILL, FRANCES
description: HILL-Frances. On October 6, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Samuel Axelrath and the late Leon Hill. Loving mother of Hilda Shelupsky and Stephen Axelrath. Dear sister of the late Samuel Hershfield and loving companion of Louis Sarlin. Adoring grandmother of Sam and Sarah. She will be deeply missed. Service Sunday, 1:15 PM, at the ''Riverside'', 76 St. & Amsterdam.

title: WEEKEND WARRIOR; It's Not Just Speed on a Tandem; It's Conversation, Too
description: A Stanley Kubrick trivia question. In ''2001: A Space Odyssey,'' what's the last thing that HAL the computer does? Give up? As the astronaut Dave performs the final shutdown of the rogue computer, HAL experiences a moment of childhood regression and haltingly sings an old-fashioned ditty it learned when it was only a microchip that carries the refrain: ''But you'll look sweet upon the seat, of a bicycle built for two.'' Always a master of detail, Kubrick reached back to the turn of the century for an ironic counterpoint, a reference to a technology that's quaint and outdated, but particularly human in scale.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: A Forest Of Stories

title: Clinton Is Said To Plan Order To Aid Forests
description: President Clinton wants the United States Forest Service to draft a plan to protect up to 40 million acres of national forest land in 35 states from commercial development, a White House official said tonight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRESEMANN, JOACHIM
description: STRESEMANN - Joachim. We deeply regret the passing of our highly esteemed and respected founding member and actively involved trustee on October 3rd, 1999. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to his family and many friends. His quick wit, gentle guidance and quiet dignity will long be remembered. Bruno Walter Memorial Foundation (1977-Present)

title: Required for a Musical Marathon: Plenty of Sleep and Willpower
description: The four Juilliard-trained musicians of the Flux String Quartet, champions of hip new music and adventurous men in their 20's, openly admit that it was a desire to one-up the popular Kronos Quartet, a role model to the younger ensemble, that initially got them interested in giving the first complete performance of Morton Feldman's seemingly unperformable String Quartet No. 2.

title: Richter Out Tonight
description: Mike Richter's visit to southern California to see Dr. Robert Watkins, a back specialist, has confirmed what Dr. Patrick O'Leary told Richter in New York earlier this week. The Ranger goalie has a slightly protruding disk in his lower back. It is not touching a nerve and it will not require surgery, but Richter will be out 7 to 10 days.

title: Iridium Fails to Find a Market : Satellite Phone Misses Its Orbit
description: NEW YORK  If ever an industry was going nowhere fast, it is the global satellite telephone business. With two of its leading players already operating under bankruptcy-court protection, analysts say the future for this orbiting infrastructure is as dark as the far side of the Moon.

title: Store of the Big Cow Riles Land of the Quaint
description: Things figured to turn antic when Stew Leonard Jr. brought his mix of mega-retailing and showmanship to Westchester County, introducing New Yorkers to a Connecticut institution famous for pyramids of produce and flatbeds of flank steak, for perpetually cheerful employees and cuddly entertainers like Wow the Cow.

title: Wired Revolution Helps Guerrillas : Latest Technology Links Jungle Rebels
description: BANGKOK  After fleeing into the Burmese jungle on foot as military police closed in on his home, Sonny Mahinder soon found himself immersed in a world for which physics classes had not prepared him.

title: For Up-and-Down Mets, Loss to Diamondbacks Is a Reminder
description: How quickly the expectations had changed for the Mets, how rapidly they had gone from pathetic losers to presumed winners. But after their 7-1 loss to Arizona Wednesday night, -- tying their division series at 1-1 -- the Mets had to remind themselves why this result, and the way they played, felt like a disappointment.

title: 'Boogie' Writer Back in Valley
description: It's a day and night of heavy rains in the San Fernando Valley. Over the course of three hours, in the new film ''Magnolia,'' at least a dozen disparate people intersect in sometimes odd ways. There's a television game-show host and his angry, estranged daughter; there's a boy genius who appears on the game show and his ambitious father; there's a dying old man, his young sexy wife and his lost son; there's a policeman in love.

title: Mayors Choose a New Model Of Vehicle for La Republique
description: France's mayors announced their choice today: Come the millennium, Laetitia Casta, a 21-year-old model and actress, will be the model for Marianne, the symbol of the French Republic.

title: Across the U.S., Universities Are Fueling High-Tech Economic Booms
description: Behold Kendall Square: 50-odd Cambridge acres long a fallow welter of former factories, now the flourishing center of what experts call the most concentrated single cluster of biotechnology in the world.

title: Webvan Is Delaying Its Offering of Stock
description: The Webvan Group, an on-line grocer with big advance billing, temporarily shelved a public offering of its stock yesterday, not because it had more selling to do to investors, but because it had done too much already.

title: Metro Business; Oxford to Move Offices
description: Oxford Health Plans Inc., one of the biggest health insurers in the New York region, said yesterday that it would move its headquarters from Norwalk, Conn., to Trumbull, Conn., to reduce costs.

title: With Pleasure and No Pain, a Most Apolitical China
description: It's a little hard to imagine that a photographic show pegged to the 50th anniversary of the People's Republic of China could give no idea of Communist misrule. But the organizers of ''China: Fifty Years Inside the People's Republic'' at the Asia Society have accomplished that feat.

title: Internet Companies Battle for Spain's Growing Market
description: MADRID  After a timid first encounter with the Internet, Spain is rushing to embrace cyberspace as new users sign up by the tens of thousands, spurred by offers of free access and new products like soccer games broadcast live on the computer screen.

title: Treating Depression
description: To the Editor:

title: Andreas Slominski
description: Metro Pictures

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAYLOR, WILLIAM ROBINSON
description: TAYLOR-William Robinson. 93 of Lyme, CT. died October 3, 1999 in Lyme. He is the husband of Marion Gewin Taylor and father of Mary Gay Taylor, Elizabeth Wall and Margaret Boyle, grandfather of three and brother of Arnold P. Taylor. A memorial service will be held at 2:00 P.M. on Wednesday, October 13, 1999 at the First Ccongregational Church of Old Lyme, Conn., Lyme Street, Old Lyme. Donations may be made in his memory to Planned Parenthood of CT, 129 Whitney Avenue, New Haven, CT 06520 or Yale University School of Medicine, Teaching and Research Fund, c/o Lawrence Cohen, 333 Cedar Street, I-207, New Haven, CT. 06520.

title: Fear Is Stalking the Streets After Williamsburg Killings
description: Weeks before the police confirmed that they were investigating possible connections in a string of murders in northern Brooklyn, residents of Williamsburg sensed a pattern.

title: European Central Bank Leaves Interest Rate Unchanged
description: The European Central Bank decided not to stop Europe's party today, but it bluntly warned that it would probably move soon to slow things down.

title: Together By a Twist Of Fate
description: In a nutshell, Sydney Pollack's new film, ''Random Hearts,'' is about two people from different worlds, a Washington policeman played by Harrison Ford and a New Hampshire Congresswoman played by Kristin Scott Thomas. They meet when their spouses die in the same plane crash. Then they discover that the spouses were having an affair. Then they have an affair of their own.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL FALLS. Crude oil fell on signs that some producers are pumping more than they pledged in an output-cutting agreement. In New York, crude oil for November delivery fell 82 cents, or 3.5 percent, to $22.45 a barrel.

title: INSIDE
description: Arrest in 1998 Bombing

title: Rethinking U.S. Response To Calls for Disaster Relief
description: In short order, a summer drought and a late-summer tropical storm dealt a punishing one-two punch to the Northeast. Now they are challenging the Federal Government's traditional ways of responding to disasters.

title: Gen. Bruce K. Holloway, 87, Head of Strategic Air Command
description: Gen. Bruce K. Holloway, who shot down 13 Japanese planes in World War II flying a propeller fighter, then oversaw the giant jet bombers of the Strategic Air Command, America's nuclear strike force, a quarter-century later, died on Sept. 30 at his home in Orlando, Fla. He was 87.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLT, BARCLAY
description: COLT-Barclay. 86, of Elizabeth NJ. Survived by wife Julia Hewitt, son Clay and sister Cornelia Manierre. Memorial services Sunday, October 10 at Third-Westminster Presbyterian Church, Elizabeth NJ at 2 PM. For more information, please call Leonard Funeral Home, Elizabeth, New Jersey.

title: At Tight End, the Priority Is Blocking
description: They virtually passed each other one heading north, the other going south, tight ends hoping to fulfill their own dreams.

title: RECKSON SERVICE WILL BE ADDING TO TWO HOLDINGS
description: Reckson Service Industries , an investor in companies that provide services to building tenants, will pay as much as $216.2 million in cash and stock to increase its stakes in Vantas Inc. and Onsite Access Inc. Reckson, which holds 35 percent of Vantas, an owner of executive office suites, will increase its investment to a range of 77 to 95 percent. It will pay $82 million to $121 million in cash and two million to three million shares, depending on how many shareholders exercise rights to sell their shares. Reckson will pay about $34.4 million in stock to raise its stake in Onsite, of Melville, N.Y., to 42 percent. The company provides telecommunications and Internet services.

title: How a Soldier Grew Into a Monster
description: Film, marshaled by the thousands upon thousands of frames, is the devastating witness that lays bare the homicidal, corrupt, vainglorious tyranny of Mobutu Sese Seko, the longtime dictator of Zaire, in the Belgian-made documentary ''Mobutu, King of Zaire.''

title: Lethal Weapon in Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: City Administration Official Opposes Giuliani on Museum
description: The city's Commissioner of Cultural Affairs spoke out yesterday against the cutoff of city funds to the Brooklyn Museum of Art and urged Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to restore the money.

title: Journal; Pull the Plug on Brooklyn
description: Count me as one First Amendment believer who hopes that Rudolph Giuliani does shut down the Brooklyn Museum of Art as retribution for exhibiting Chris Ofili's elephant-dung-ornamented painting ''The Holy Virgin Mary.''

title: Paul Petzoldt Is Dead at 91; Innovator in Rock Climbing
description: Paul Petzoldt, a pioneer of American mountaineering and a wilderness educator who founded the National Outdoor Leadership School, died on Wednesday in Topsham, Me. He was 91 and lived in nearby South Casco, Me.

title: Inspired by Hungary's Past and Present
description: Hungarian music's traditional past and footloose present shared a double bill when the Okros Ensemble and Kalman Balogh and the Gypsy Cimbalom Band performed at the Bottom Line on Wednesday night.

title: Recurring Patterns, The Sinews Of Nature; Interest in Design Pulls Science Closer to Art
description: In a tightly braided woman's hair style from Yaounde, Cameroon, the coils seem to spread out from the neck, split into subsidiary branches, and erupt into repetitive patterns. An ivory sculpture of the Mangbetu people in Congo is also based on geometric shapes in which large patterns sprout smaller versions of themselves. So is the architecture of the Logone-Birni palace in Cameroon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOA, BRUNO
description: FOA-Bruno. Age 93. Beloved husband, cherished father, grandfather and great grandfather died October 4, 1999 after a short illness. The emotional center of our family, a family shattered and dispersed by the history of the 20th century across Italy, Israel and the United States, we will forever remember him for his warm and gentle heart, his intellect and wisdom, and above all, for his love of life, optimism and singular charm. He was Italy's youngest full professor (in economics) at the age of 28, an early Zionist & dedicated anti-Fascist, he worked with Chaim Weizmann in London in the 1920s and retained a special devotion to Israel. He came to the U.S. in 1940, worked for the Federal Reserve Board, published and wrote on monetary policy & economic reconstruction in Italy, and as a consulting economist, worked with a variety of international clients. He is also survived by his devoted sister Marina Levi, 99, of Milan. A memorial service will be held Sunday, October 10, 2PM at ''Riverside Memorial Chapel'', 180 West 76 Street, New York City. Lisa, Eleanor, Pamela, Paul, Joshua, Jennifer, Jesse, Stephanie, Nora and Sophia

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: Today's KEY GAMES

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday analyzing an advertising campaign by the managed care industry about legislation on patients' rights referred imprecisely to the Congressional Budget Office's estimate of the cost for an earlier version of the legislation. The agency estimated that that bill would increase monthly premiums by 4.8 percent by the end of five years, not 4.8 percent each month for five years.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: S.& P. 500 Gains 18 Points On Bargain Hunting Spree

title: Roche Holding Plans Sale Of Part of Genentech Stake
description: Genentech Inc. said today that Roche Holding Ltd., its parent company, intended to sell 20 million shares of Genentech common stock as soon as possible, reducing its ownership to 65 percent from 82 percent.

title: After Disease Scare, Inmates Rejoin Cleanup
description: New Jersey prison inmates will return to Bound Brook on Tuesday to help with flood cleanup, a week after officials decided to pull them out after a building inspector who had worked in the flood waters contracted Legionnaires' disease.

title: Corrections
description: A film review in Weekend yesterday about ''The Limey,'' directed by Steven Soderbergh, with leading actors including Terence Stamp, misidentified the actress with whom he starred in the 1967 film ''Poor Cow.'' It was Carol White, not Julie Christie.

title: Sprewell Lands in New York as Knicks Issue a Fine
description: On the same day the Knicks took disciplinary action against Latrell Sprewell for his mysterious and unexplained absence from training camp, the unpredictable guard surfaced in the New York area this afternoon when he checked into the same hotel he lived in last season.

title: Johnson Won't Start on 3 Days' Rest
description: The first question came at Buck Showalter almost as soon as he stepped into the interview room.

title: John McLendon, 84, Strategist In College and Pro Basketball
description: John McLendon, a Hall of Fame basketball coach at the college and professional levels who studied under the sport's founder, Dr. James Naismith, died early yesterday morning at his home in Cleveland Heights, Ohio. He was 84.

title: Her Partners Can Call Her Ms. Chairman; Baker & McKenzie Takes Small Step for a Law Firm, Giant Leap for Womankind
description: When Christine Lagarde found out she was soon to become the top partner at Baker & McKenzie, the world's second-largest law firm, she called friends all over the globe for advice on what to call herself.

title: NESTLE SELLS FROZEN FOODS UNIT
description: The Swiss food giant Nestle S.A. said it had sold Findus, a European frozen food business, to EQT Scandinavia for an undisclosed sum. Nestle had said earlier this year that it would sell Findus, which has annual sales of $607 million, as part of a broader restructuring. The sale encompasses 14 factories in seven European countries and 3,500 workers.

title: A Multicultural Chameleon; Actor's Experience Spawns Polyglot Cast of Characters
description: This is how Danny Hoch, actor, comic, emerging avatar of New York City multiculturalism, remembers where he is from:

title: FORTUM TO SELL UNIT
description: Finland's state energy company, Fortum, agreed to sell its chemical unit to the Scandinavian private equity firm Industri Kapital for 505 million euros ($540 million) including debt, to focus on natural gas and power. The sale of the unit, Neste Chemicals, the largest maker of the formaldehyde-based adhesives used in plywood, will result in a profit for Fortum of 90 million euros. The Helsinki-based company will receive 424 million euros in cash from the sale of Neste Chemicals.

title: Florida State Copes With Warrick Out
description: The coalition assembled to tout Peter Warrick's candidacy for the Heisman Trophy has been reduced to a whimper overnight.

title: In California, a Fight Over a Road's Final Miles
description: It comes barreling up from the harbor at Long Beach, six lanes across and filled with cars, then stops short at a big berm of earth that looks like an abandoned jump for Evel Knievel.

title: A Victory for Patients
description: The House's passage of a comprehensive patients' rights bill this week could go a long way toward easing public concerns about managed-care plans. Unlike the Senate, which remains a captive of the insurance lobby, the House has produced an impressive piece of bipartisan legislation that will set strong national standards for health maintenance organizations and other plans.

title: Letting Patients Sue H.M.O.'s
description: To the Editor:

title: DIMINISHED BRAZILIAN INFLATION
description: Brazil's benchmark inflation rate slowed to its lowest level in three months in September as anemic consumer demand helped to restrain price increases. Consumer prices rose 0.31 percent, compared with a 0.56 percent increase in August, the Government said. Still, it remains unclear whether inflation will continue to decline in coming months, partly because a recent weakening of the Brazilian currency against the dollar could lead to higher prices for imported items like petroleum and food.

title: Catholic Hospital Merger
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Rules Pinochet Can Be Extradited
description: A London court ruled yesterday that Gen. Augusto Pinochet can be extradited to Spain to stand trial on one charge of conspiracy to torture and 34 charges of torturing individual Chileans.

title: CANADA JOBLESSNESS DECLINES
description: Canada's unemployment rate fell three-tenths of a percentage point to 7.5 percent in September, the lowest level in more than nine years. The number of new jobs created -- 63,800 -- was more than had been added over the previous six months and twice what economists had expected. Manufacturing accounted for more than a third of the new jobs. The strong jobs report was the latest signal that Canada's economy is heating up, which may lead the Bank of Canada to raise interest rates before year's end.

title: Rapper Attitude in Designer Diamonds and Furs : Ghetto Fabulous Goes Global
description: WASHINGTON  The origins of the phrase "ghetto fabulous" are murky at best. Some suggest that its roots reach back to the first time the term ghetto was used to describe downtrodden communities populated by a single ethnic group. But the notion of ghetto fabulous did not become a popular one, did not enter the phrase book of cultural slang, until the hip-hop generation left its apartments, tenements and track houses and headed straight for designer boutiques.

title: Printer Accused of Forging Yankees Tickets
description: The owner of a Bronx printing shop was arrested yesterday on charges of producing counterfeit tickets to numerous sporting events -- including coveted Yankees playoff tickets -- which were then sold to unsuspecting fans, the police said.

title: Daniel Griffiths, 82, Dean of N.Y.U. School
description: Daniel Griffiths, a former dean of the New York University School of Education who changed its approach from anecdotal teaching to the use of modern research methods, died Oct. 2. He was 82 and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Marching in the Vanguard
description: Experimental cinema is generally regarded as an autonomous hothouse world with its own intricate set of values and vocabulary. Yet ideas that emanate from the fringe often have a way of sneaking into the mainstream. Think of ''The Blair Witch Project,'' a commercial ghost story made with jiggling hand-held cameras. Or take ''American Beauty,'' which borrows an image (and an entire esthetic of beauty) from Nathaniel Dorsky's ''Variations,'' in which the camera admired a plastic shopping bag being blown about by the wind. ''Variations'' happened to be one of the high points last year of the New York Film Festival's annual program, ''Views From the Avant-Garde.''

title: Government Panel Says Train in London Crash Ran Red Light
description: Moving with unusual speed after Britain's worst train crash in decades, a Government panel confirmed today that a commuter train had caused the crash here by running a red signal light straight into the path of a speeding intercity express.

title: Double-Parking, by the Rules
description: To the Editor:

title: Shake-Up at the Top as Natwest Tries to Thwart Hostile Bid
description: Desperate to thwart a $34 billion hostile takeover by the Bank of Scotland, National Westminster P.L.C. dismissed its discredited chief executive today and hired an outside salvage expert.

title: Talks Continue on Ford Motor Contract
description: Negotiators for the United Automobile Workers union and the Ford Motor Company continued their talks over a new labor contract past a midnight Friday deadline.

title: In China's Boom, Rural Poor Feel a Widening Gap
description: In a crumbling mud-brick house, nestled against the untidy heap that holds her family's entire wardrobe, Zheng Xingrong defines her life with a series of emphatic negatives.

title: Oil Prices Drop Some More, but Trend Is Seen as Temporary
description: Crude oil prices fell nearly 7 percent yesterday, registering a 15 percent decline for the week, after hitting a 33-month high the previous week. The volatile performance reflected reports of small increases in oil supply.

title: Citibank Manager Accused of Stealing $500,000
description: A manager at the midtown Manhattan offices of Citibank was arrested yesterday after company officials accused him of transferring nearly $500,000 from the bank to his personal accounts, the police said.

title: Cone's Future as a Yankee Unclear
description: David Cone ponders the future of his baseball career, knowing there is the sort of lingering uncertainty that he had hoped to finally shed after signing with the Yankees and grows exasperated. Cone knows that he could be pitching for the Yankees for the last time, knows it so well that he brought up the possibility today and then rambled on about it for 30 minutes.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
description: For more than three decades, it has been an unshakable principle of the computer industry: every 18 months, the number of transistors that will fit on a silicon chip doubles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANDROS, CELE L.
description: HANDROS-Cele L. Beloved wife of Richard. She was employed at AHRC for 30 years as Budget Director. She loved and was loved. Services 12 noon Sunday, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Witness Tearfully Describes Fatal Subway Shoving
description: A weeping 24-year-old woman recounted yesterday how she shunned a bizarre-acting man in a Manhattan subway station in January and then watched in horror as he abruptly hurled another young woman in front of a speeding subway train.

title: PRESIDENT ASKING SENATE TO DELAY VOTE ON TEST BAN
description: Acknowledging that he lacks the votes to approve a treaty banning nuclear testing, President Clinton pleaded with Senate leaders today to delay action. But he refused to give in to a Republican demand that he withdraw the treaty, and thus concede that it will not be enacted while he is in the White House.

title: Job Growth Falters in Possible Sign That Economy Is Starting to Slow
description: The energetic American economy may be slipping into a slower gear, as job creation came to a halt last month and the work force shrank for the first time since January 1996. But wages continued to rise at a healthy pace, the Labor Department reported yesterday, keeping alive the potential for future inflation.

title: Gap Inc. Looks Vulnerable as Sales Decline at Its Flagship Stores
description: Is Gap Inc. losing its edge? When retailers reported September sales on Thursday, the numbers were pretty good: an increase of 5.5 percent from a year earlier, according to the Goldman, Sachs retail composite index. At Gap, sales rose even more than expected, 7 percent, news that nudged the stock up $1.1875 yesterday, to $38.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIESNER, BEATRICE
description: FRIESNER - Beatrice. Dearest cousin, Biby. Thanks for the memories. Miriam, Charlotte and Families

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVIN, ALBERT
description: LEVIN-Albert. Beloved husband of Joan. Devoted father of Lon and Melanie, Scott, Nancy and Ray Greenberg, Wendy and Gary Jacobson. Loving grandfather of Jamie Rose, Talia, Rachel, Matthew, Drew and Sean. Services Sunday 12 noon at ''Gutterman's'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, Long Island.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Calm down.''

title: How Sweden Prospers
description: To the Editor:

title: British Court Rules Pinochet Extraditable for Trial in Spain
description: A London court ruled today that Gen. Augusto Pinochet can be extradited to Spain to stand trial on torture and conspiracy charges.

title: In Giuliani's City Hall Strategy, Senate Race Rolls Quietly Along
description: For months, Rudolph W. Giuliani has said that the best way to run for United States Senate is to be a good Mayor, without distractions from a campaign apparatus. But in the weeks since Labor Day, Mr. Giuliani's unannounced race against Hillary Rodham Clinton has entered a new stage, as City Hall and the Mayor's closest aides quietly build the foundation of an aggressive, very Republican campaign.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions yesterday about the decision by the Chase Manhattan Corporation to move 3,500 jobs out of New York City referred imprecisely to the portion of the company's work force involved. The positions to be relocated amount to 10 percent of Chase's work force in the New York metropolitan area, not of its entire work force, which numbers 76,500 employees across the country.

title: A Neglected Tudor Classic Finds a New Modern Style
description: The Jose Limon Dance Company is to be blessed for its mission of reviving lost classics. One such classic is Antony Tudor's ''Dark Elegies,'' a sadly neglected work that addresses the subjects of death, mourning and communal life with a somber beauty rare in dance. Presented on Wednesday night at the Joyce Theater, where the Limon company is in residence through Oct. 17, ''Dark Elegies'' has been restored by Donald Mahler and the Limon troupe with reverence and affection. But as performed here, it is beautiful in unfamiliar and sometimes unsettling new ways.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Tuesday showing United States vehicle sales in September misstated the percentage change for the Jeep Grand Cherokee. The 144 percent change in a year was a rise, not a fall.

title: Letting Patients Sue H.M.O.'s
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LERNER, ESTHER
description: LERNER-Esther. Loving wife of the late Zulie. Dear mother of Clive, Arthur and Diane Todd. Adored grandmother of eight and great grandmother of three. Dear sister of Shoshanna Kuselewitz and Aaron Silver. Graveside services Sunday, 10 A.M. at Wellwood Cemetery, Pinelawn, New York.

title: Samso Journal; In This Energy Project, No Tilting at Windmills
description: Imagine a Danish landscape: half-timbered houses sagging at midbeam, farmlands sloping toward the sea, crenelated church belfries with their masonry step notches marching up the sides.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENFIELD, EVA MILLER
description: GREENFIELD-Eva Miller. On October 8, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Loving mother of Eleanor & Henry Lowet, & Susan and Marvin Shapiro. Devoted grandmother of Stephanie and Ames, Peter & Laurie, Jonathan, Robert, Deborah & Tony. Adoring great-grandmother of Benjamin, Naomi, Daniel and Adam. Service on Sunday at 12:45 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions in her memory to the Eva Miller Greenfield Yiddish Music Fund at the Jewish Theological Seminary.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAXINOS, HARRIET
description: PAXINOS-Harriet. The Friends of the Hunter College Library and the Hunter College Foundation extend sincere condolences to Marie Fochios and her family on the passing of her sister, Harriet Paxinos. Jacqueline G. Wilson, Chair, Friends of the Library

title: A Mama's Boy, So Helpful But He's Up To No Good
description: To call Atom Egoyan's surreally atmospheric screen adaptation of William Trevor's novel ''Felicia's Journey'' a genre movie would be a little like describing ''Moby-Dick'' as a fishing manual. It's not that Mr. Trevor's insidious thriller about a lost Irish girl adrift in England's industrial Midlands and the homicidal catering manager who ''rescues'' her has epic pretensions. It's that Mr. Egoyan, Canada's most gifted filmmaker, brilliantly bends this Gothic-flavored fable to express his own tricky cinematic vision. That vision, to put it a bit grandly, is the contemplation of human fate in a universe that throws out tantalizing portents of meaning and purpose while paradoxically appearing to be absurd.

title: Ratify the Test Ban Treaty
description: To the Editor:

title: For Luxury Brands, Bottom-Line Problem Is Growth : High-Stakes Acquisitions Race
description: MILAN  The big news sweeping the fashion and luxury goods market today is not who's wearing what but who's buying what, in the high-stakes race for global leadership.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FEDERMAN, IZZY
description: FEDERMAN-Izzy. Gone 23 years. Never forgotten. Missed by all who knew you. Your family and admirers

title: Arguments Heard in Museum's Legal Battle With Mayor
description: A battle over the Virgin Mary, free speech, government money and religious sensitivity moved into the courtroom yesterday, with a Federal judge attempting to determine whether Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani was within his legal rights to withdraw financing from a museum whose artwork he found offensive.

title: Woman Is Named Editor of A.M.A. Journal
description: In a time of turmoil for prestigious scientific publications, The Journal of the American Medical Association named a new editor yesterday -- the first woman and the first pediatrician in its 116-year history.

title: The New Yorker's Bill of Rights
description: Whereas the New York City Police Department continues to issue tickets for activities ever-decreasing in potential injuriousness -- first jaywalking, then double-parking, and then the congregating in a city park without permit of more than 20 people (these the revelers at a birthday party for a black Lab named Byron) -- we the undersigned determine certain other activities of New Yorkers to be inviolable and inalienable.

title: Corrections
description: A theater review in Weekend yesterday about ''Contact,'' at Lincoln Center, misidentified the musical film noir sequence that featured the line ''She came at me in sections.'' It was from ''The Band Wagon,'' with Fred Astaire and Cyd Charisse, not ''Singin' in the Rain.''

title: Religion Journal; Humanist Jewish Group Welcomes a New Rabbi
description: A big test faced by voluntary organizations is whether they can pass their convictions to a second generation. If not, they probably face extinction, at least until someone comes along to revive their core ideas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SENFELD, S. WILLIAM
description: SENFELD - S. William. The trustees, faculty, staff, and alumni/ ae of Bard College mourn the passing of dear friend and devoted alumnus, S. William Senfeld '62. Bill, who received the Bard medal in 1996, was a loyal alumnus whose energetic involvement within the Bard community will be sorely missed. Our deepest condolences to his family and many friends. Leon Botstein, President David E. Schwab II, Chairman, Board of Trustees Michael DeWitt, President, Bard-St. Stephens Alumni/ae Association

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HILL, FRANCES
description: HILL-Frances. On October 6, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Samuel Axelrath and the late Leon Hill. Loving mother of Hilda Shelupsky and Stephen Axelrath. Dear sister of the late Samuel Hershfield and loving companion of Louis Sarlin. Adoring grandmother of Sam and Sarah. She will be deeply missed. Service Sunday, 1:15 PM, at the ''Riverside'', 76 St. & Amsterdam.

title: Militiamen's Attack on Australian Peacekeepers 'Bodes Ill for Future' : Timor Ambush:Start of a Long War?
description: SYDNEY  The ambush of Australian soldiers in East Timor this week near the border with Indonesian West Timor could be the start of a protracted guerrilla war against foreign forces mandated by the United Nations to restore peace in the territory, some Australian officials and analysts said Friday.

title: Sports of The Times; Whispers Are Getting Louder
description: WHAT once was distant has just come a little better into view; what once was a laughable, wistful thought actually seems possible. What every New Yorker is whispering is slowly becoming pronounced. The much-longed-for Subway Series is far off, but not as far off as it had been three weeks ago.

title: Xerox Warns That Results Will Be Short Of Projections
description: The Xerox Corporation, reeling from inroads that competitors are making into its markets even as its own sales force is in disarray, warned analysts yesterday that its third-quarter results would be dismal.

title: BRIGHTENED MALAYSIA OUTLOOK
description: Moody's Investors Service raised its outlook on Malaysia's credit ratings from stable to positive, citing the relative strength of the country's financial system and its resilience in the aftermath of the financial crisis that started two years ago. Malaysia's improving prospects also led Moody's to raise its outlook on ratings for the six Malaysian banks it covers.

title: Heart of Tony Bennett's World, Forever on a String
description: If Tony Bennett were to ooze, he would ooze ease. This is not to say he does not emote, but he does so with unshakable authority. As the premier surviving conservationist of the popular American songbook, Mr. Bennett could be drawing his audience into his own drama: the saga of the silvery bon vivant, outliving his friends, clinging nobly to the song in his heart as he faces mortality. But Mr. Bennett is hardly declining, and as he serves pop's standards he continues to emphasize their legend, not his own.

title: Ali Wins, but the Fight Isn't the Greatest
description: With her father sitting ringside tonight at the Turning Stone Casino ballroom, Laila Ali, the youngest daughter of Muhammad Ali's nine children, stepped into the ring to continue the legacy. And just like her father, Laila Ali made quick work of her opponent.

title: Clinton Visit Shows Warmth of Canadian Ties
description: Today, for the first time, an American President traveled to a foreign nation and inaugurated an American Embassy. President Clinton broke historical protocol in Canada, a quiet partner that trades more with the United States than any other country.

title: Plenty of Quirks and Tenses, but Not a Film Star in Sight
description: Anybody with enough money and connections can give a good party celebrating a magazine; what's much more difficult is to produce a magazine worth celebrating.

title: First Autumn Fire
description: One day last spring, the fire in the kitchen woodstove went out and was never relit. I didn't record the date, because some endings are lost in a crowd of beginnings, passing unnoticed until months later, when the oversight seems almost melancholy. So I note here the first fire of the new season: Monday, October 4, thermometer lodged in the mid-40's, a chill in the bones of the house, rain falling hard through dwindling yellow hickory leaves. When the kindling caught the first dry log -- a length of honey locust -- in its flames, the stove called all the dogs. They sprawled across the warm tiles, mouths agape. Not a half-hour had ticked away, and there we were, back on the night before the fire went out for the last time last spring.

title: Man Charged in Bombing Of U.S. Embassy in Africa
description: Federal prosecutors in New York charged a Tanzanian man yesterday with helping to carry out the bombing of the United States Embassy in his country last year, which along with a nearly simultaneous attack in Nairobi, Kenya, killed more than 200 people and injured thousands.

description: HURWITZ-Ruth. Beloved wife of the late George. Mother of Susan (Allen Bernstein), Dr. William, and Ina (Philip Cangiano). title: Politics Threatens Brazilian Utility Sales

With an eye to his political fortunes, the same maverick Governor and former President who provoked Brazil's currency crisis in January by defaulting on his state's foreign debt is now seeking to sabotage a crucial federal government program to privatize state-owned companies.

title: Strong Debut for E-Stamp
description: The shares of the E-Stamp Corporation, the company that sells postage on line, ended their first day of trading yesterday almost 32 percent above the initial offer price. Shares of the company, which is based in San Mateo, Calif., closed at $22.375 on the Nasdaq. The shares, which had traded as high as $33 during the day, started at $17, which was higher than had been expected. The offering was originally filed for 6.5 million shares at $12 to $14. Ultimately, the company offered seven million shares at the higher price.

title: Labor, Revitalized With New Recruiting, Has Regained Power and Prestige
description: When John J. Sweeney took the helm of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. four years ago, the labor movement was spiraling downward. It was steadily losing membership, politicians had dismissed it as a toothless has-been and much of the public viewed it as an irrelevant dinosaur.

description: If Todd Pratt took his presence in last night's playoff game at Shea Stadium in as low-key a way as he said he did, he must have been sleepwalking through it. Benny Agbayani might have been walking in step with him.

title: OWNERSHIP RULES IN CABLE INDUSTRY LOOSENED BY F.C.C.
description: The Federal Communications Commission decided today to loosen substantially the rules that keep one company from controlling too much of the cable industry. The new rules clear the way for AT&T to own more than a third of the nation's franchises offering subscribers television, telephone and high-speed Internet services as well as own major interests in a number of major video producers and television programmers.

description: Roger Clemens does not compete like other pitchers, it has been said. Rather, the University of Texas alumnus treats each outing like a football game against the hated University of Oklahoma.

description: New York's City Hall Park sparkled on its opening day with new plantings and the old Jacob Wrey Mould fountain dragged back from Crotona Park in the Bronx and restored. The renovation paid attention to historical details, returning the public space south of City Hall to its original geometry, with fixtures such as the fountain lights and the park's new fence modeled on the originals. But the restoration does not change the fact that the new park is utterly cut off from City Hall by chains and guards.

title: PHELPS DODGE WILL NOT RAISE OFFER FOR ASARCO
description: The Phelps Dodge Corporation said yesterday that it would not raise its bid to acquire the New York-based copper producer Asarco Inc. in response to a rival bid from Grupo Mexico S.A. that was submitted on Thursday. Grupo Mexico said it would pay $29.50 in cash for Asarco, up from its previous offer of $26 a share and topping a $28.21 cash-and-stock bid by Phelps Dodge that Asarco accepted on Wednesday. The Grupo Mexico bid is worth about $1.174 billion, compared with $1.12 billion for the Phelps Dodge offer. Asarco said yesterday that its board would consider the Grupo Mexico offer.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO FALLS. The euro fell to its lowest level against the dollar in more than a week after the European Central Bank kept monetary policy steady. In New York, the euro settled at $1.06220, down from $1.0710 on Thursday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE TAR, VERNON
description: de TAR-Vernon. We mourn the passing of our most esteemed and venerable colleague. Vernon de Tar set the highest standards for his art as organist, choral director, church musician and teacher of several generations of distinguished organists. Stephen Hamilton, Dean The New York City Chapter of the American Guild of Organists

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHEMAN, JOAN
description: SCHEMAN-Joan. You have encircled our lives with love. You have etched a place in our hearts forever. It is from there that we will find the strength. With love Marty and Randy and Brenda. Dear sister of Madeline Deutscher. Cherished grandmother of Matthew, Alexandra, Martine and Ryan. Services were held October 7, 1999. Shiva being held through Sunday at the home of Martin Scheman. Donations to Mercy Hospice or the American Cancer Society, Long Island division will be appreciated.

title: Swollen Thumb Benches Piazza
description: The news on Thursday seemed innocuous. X-rays on Mike Piazza's sore left thumb were negative, meaning he would play in Game 3 of the division series against the Arizona Diamondbacks. Piazza had received a cortisone shot to relieve the pain. But by yesterday afternoon, the thumb, swollen, was immobile and a source of even worse pain. After Piazza was examined by the Mets' team physician, Dr. David Altchek, he did not start last night's game at Shea Stadium and is only 50-50 for today.

title: Judge Assesses State Farm $730 Million in Fraud Case
description: A state judge in Illinois decided yesterday that State Farm had defrauded policyholders by requiring that damages from automobile accidents be repaired with lower-priced generic parts, and ordered the insurer to pay $730 million in actual and punitive damages.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: In Neighborhood of Ticket Flurry, Officers Routinely Double-Park
description: In neighborhoods throughout the Upper West Side, police officers have left countless tickets this week on cars that were double-parked outside bustling stores, crowded schools and stately high-rise buildings.

title: Order and the Avant-Garde In Radiant Harmonies
description: The Danish Wave '99, which has been picking up momentum over the last few weeks and runs through the end of the month, is a collaboration between the Danish Consulate and arts groups in New York, its aim being to introduce the city to music (classical and jazz), theater, film, photography and poetry from Denmark.

title: THE NEW NEW THING
description: Jim Clark is not so much an Internet entrepreneur as the embodiment of a new kind of economic man. He has built his fortune, and his legend, on nothing more than his next simple notion. A report by Michael Lewis, in The Times Magazine.

title: Spectacular Braves Put On a Display, Demoralizing Astros
description: The Atlanta Braves can make winning look routine, but today's victory was spectacular.

title: Surprise in Indian State: Politics of Promising Fails
description: Something amazing happened in Indian politics in the elections that just concluded. In the large southern state of Andhra Pradesh, the party that promised the biggest freebies lost. And the politician who warned that there's no free lunch won.

title: 24/7 MEDIA SHARES RISE ON SPECULATION OF TAKEOVER
description: Shares of 24/7 Media Inc. rose 17 percent amid speculation that the Internet advertising company was in talks to be acquired by a larger rival, Doubleclick Inc. The New York-based company's shares rose $6.875, to $47.375. Doubleclick rose $4.75 a share, to $136.625. In July, Doubleclick's chairman, Kevin J. O'Connor, said the company was seeking to buy more Internet advertising companies to expand ad sales that were now on more than 1,300 Web sites. 24/7 would be a good fit because it would add 150 Web sites to broaden Doubleclick's customer base and fend off rivals. Doubleclick is in talks to buy 24/7 Media for about $1.5 billion, the Silicon Alley Reporter Web site said.

description: LEVY-David, of Great Neck. Loving father of Michael. Cherished son of Pearl and the late Bennett. Dear brother of Robert. Also survived by many beloved family and friends. Services on Sunday at 1 P.M., at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York.

title: Chechens Report Repelling Russian Forces in at Least 2 Villages
description: Chechen fighters have repulsed Russian forces from villages along the Terek River in northern Chechnya, in their first serious resistance since fighting began two weeks ago, a top Chechen commander said today.

title: As Gore Slips, Top Advisers Second-Guess Early Moves
description: When Vice President Al Gore assembled his political high command for a meeting at his residence at the Naval Observatory last April 23, prospects for his Presidential campaign were looking good. Fund-raising was on target. Polls showed him comfortably ahead of former Senator Bill Bradley for the Democratic nomination.

title: New Mexico Bars Creationism From State Curriculum
description: Bucking recent changes in Kansas and other states that allow public schools to teach alternative views of human development, the New Mexico Board of Education voted overwhelmingly today to limit the statewide science curriculum to the teaching of evolution.

title: Stung by Defeat in House, H.M.O.'s Seek Compromise
description: The chief lobbyist for the nation's health maintenance organizations, alarmed at the prospect of lawsuits against H.M.O.'s, said today that her group would urge Congress instead to pass legislation allowing patients to take their grievances to an independent panel of medical experts.

title: Final Tuneups For Breeders' Cup
description: The racing season rushes toward a climax this weekend at Belmont Park when four of the eight favorites for the Breeders' Cup series will take their final tests en route to the Cup championships four weeks later.

title: Words and Pain Are Not Enough to Stop Mets
description: Like migraine sufferers scrambling for the aspirin, the Mets needed some soothing last night and fast. They had spent the hours preceding Game 3 of their division series trying to function with simultaneous headaches that would have sent most teams running for a dark, quiet place, devoid of reporters: catcher Mike Piazza's inflammatory reaction to a cortisone injection and Manager Bobby Valentine's inflammatory words in a magazine profile.

title: Political Notes; Another Contender for Queens Borough Presidency
description: It has been more than a year since Carol A. Gresser left 110 Livingston Street in Brooklyn and her position as a member of the New York City Board of Education. But Mrs. Gresser has been busy and plans to be busier still in the next two years. This week, she formed a committee to explore a candidacy for Queens Borough President.

title: An Appraisal; A Newly Renovated City Hall Park Offers a Mix of Bucolic and Bunker
description: Did you hear the clock strike twelve? It's midnight in the garden of City Hall. Even at lunch hour. The retro design of the new City Hall Park, which reopened on Thursday after a 10-month, $30 million reconstruction, is decent enough. But there's a sinister feel to it.

title: When a Deadly Virus Takes Flight, Literally
description: In the frosty hours before dawn yesterday, I carefully extracted a Northern saw-whet owl from a nearly invisible mist net, set up on a mountaintop in central Pennsylvania. The owl, migrating south, had been lured into the net with a tape-recording of its call.

title: EEX IS IN AGREEMENT TO BUY TESORO PETROLEUM
description: The EEX Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Tesoro Petroleum Corporation's domestic exploration and production operations for $216 million. The properties, mostly natural gas fields in South Texas and the Gulf Coast, are producing about 80 million cubic feet equivalent of natural gas a day from estimated proven reserves of 204 billion cubic feet equivalent, EEX said. EEX is a Houston-based oil and gas company operating in the Gulf of Mexico. It had revenue of $83.5 million in the six months ended June 30. San Antonio-based Tesoro also refines and markets petroleum products.

title: Memphis Mayor Is Re-elected by a Surprisingly Wide Margin
description: After one of the most raucous and highly contested election campaigns in this city's history, voters have given Mayor Willie Herenton a third term by a surprisingly decisive margin.

title: Gucci Moving to Buy Yves Saint Laurent, Fashion's Biggest Prize
description: PARIS  Yves Saint Laurent, fashion's biggest prize, appears poised to fall into the hands of Gucci Group NV after the board agreed in London on Friday to buy the iconic French couturier's parent company.

description: United Air Lines cut travel agent commissions to 5 percent from 8 percent, effective yesterday, and other airlines are expected to follow soon.

title: Police Official Blames News Coverage for Murder Increase
description: The deputy police commissioner who oversees crime-fighting strategies contends that negative news coverage has so intimidated police officers that they are reluctant to patrol aggressively and that their reluctance is why murders are increasing.

title: Quietly, Baines Just Keeps Hitting
description: There are plenty of guys in major league uniforms who are older than Harold Baines, but most are coaches and managers. Only 10 players are older than Baines, and only three are still around for the post-season. And few players of any age are hitting the baseball any better than Baines in this first round of the playoffs. Life might not begin at 40, but Baines's career is continuing at that age at a remarkably consistent pace.

title: Sliding From Slinky Waltzes Into Sticky Spider Webs
description: The second of three retrospective concerts offering music by six living Danish composers took place at Merkin Concert Hall on Tuesday night. And happily, the works by Karl Aage Rasmussen and Poul Ruders that were performed on this occasion suggested that no Danish school of composition exists other than to be true to your own voice.

title: Washington Talk; Standing Still on Campaign Finance
description: At the Supreme Court on Tuesday, the Justices talked about a lot of things that seemed to be wrong with the campaign finance system.

description: Nets forward Keith Van Horn scrimmaged yesterday in Atlantic City for the first time during training camp. After missing the first three days, he said the soreness in his left hamstring had subsided.

title: Kinder Dyes Bolster a Global Trend That Appeals to All Ages : Now It's Natural to Color Hair
description: PARIS  Not so long ago, only "loose" (or aging) women dyed their hair. Today, fewer and fewer women can remember their original hair color. Globally, hair coloring is turning into a fashion phenomenon.

Caring brother and uncle. A gentle and compassionate man, he was a good friend who touched many lives with his generosity of spirit and his devotion to social causes. He will be greatly missed. Funeral services will be held on Monday, October 11th at 11AM at Community Synagogue of Rye, 200 Forest Ave., Rye, NY. 914-967-6262.

title: Rangers' Top Line Finds Its Offense
description: To Ranger fans, it was beginning to seem like an eternity. To Theo Fleury, it was just a three-game drought.

title: AMERICAN HOME ADOPTS MEASURE AGAINST TAKEOVERS
description: The American Home Products Corporation, maker of the most prescribed United States drug, Premarin, has adopted a plan to ward off hostile takeovers after reaching a $3.75 billion settlement on diet pills once used in the ''fen-phen'' combination. The plan, a so-called poison pill, would ''provide protection against coercive or unfair takeover tactics,'' the company said after the close of trading on Thursday. The plan is intended to protect shareholders' interests if an effort is made to acquire American Home at a price that does not reflect its true value, the company said. Analysts said they believed that American Home wanted to merge with a competitor but not at its current share price. The shares rose $1.8125 each yesterday, to $50.50.

title: Image-Makers Steal the Scene : Hold That Pose
description: PARIS  CORRECTION PUBLISHED IN THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE ON OCTOBER 12, 1999:

title: HYUNDAI UNION VOTES TO STRIKE
description: Unionized workers at the Hyundai Motor Company voted to go on strike starting next week after unsuccessful negotiations with the company's management. About 34,000 of 38,000 union members cast ballots and more than 90 percent of the voters agreed to a strike, the union said. During a monthlong confrontation, the union has demanded a say in the company's decision-making process and a seat on its board. Samuel Len

title: Gay Rights in California
description: California sets an admirable example for the nation by moving ahead with legislation that will help deter discrimination against gays in public and private life. Although California earlier enacted hate-crime laws to protect gays and lesbians from violence, the three bills signed into law by Gov. Gray Davis last week will help ensure that gays receive fair and equal treatment at work, in housing and at school. The movement in California, the nation's largest state, to normalize government treatment of gays is an important step toward ending anti-gay bigotry.

description: Peace efforts hit a snag today when Israel delayed a release of Palestinian prisoners after a dispute with the Palestinians over who should be freed.

title: Sports of The Times; Davis, a Real Battler, Hits the Spot
description: IT was just a single in a deadlocked Game 2 of another division series against the Yankees' playoff pets. It was not the ninth inning, not the winning hit, not a perfect ending to a major league run of two fruitful decades filled with hundreds and hundreds of hits much more impressive than a measly ground ball through the right side.

title: Famed Cuban Band Is Set to Perform in Miami, and the Overtone Is One of Strain
description: In presenting the Cuban singer-songwriter Carlos Varela to a group of listeners in Miami Beach last year, Maria Romeu said she had bouts of panic during which she worried about his safety. One of the first artists from Cuba to perform in hostile exile territory, Mr. Varela tested the waters by singing then for select, word-of-mouth-only audiences.

title: On Line All the Time, With Delivery to Match
description: As the holiday shopping season approaches, a new on-line store is preparing to offer free delivery of products including CD's, books, video games, snack foods and gift certificates from spas. The Web site, www.urbanfetch.com, which will begin providing the service on Friday, will deliver 24 hours a day to all of Manhattan and Brooklyn Heights in an hour or less by uniformed couriers.

description: Sit with Kerry Collins, whether it's in a quiet moment inside the Giants' locker room or at a restaurant having dinner, and something somewhere on Collins will be moving.

description: Some wines are books; others, chapters. Peconic Bay's '98 riesling is a page; Bidwell's nonvintage County Gardens Blush Bouquet, a light anecdote.

description: It has been more than 50 years since any state banned an existing form of gambling, but a drive around the border roads of York County helps explain why South Carolina is poised to do just that.

description: ''RISING interest rates are bad news for banks.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CROUCH, ARCHIE R.
description: CROUCH-Archie R., devoted and loving husband, beloved father, writer and China scholar, died in Englewood, Colo., at the age of 90, on September 10. Born in Veblen, S.D., he was educated at Jamestown College, Princeton Theological Seminary, Cornell University, and received his Ph.D. from the University of Southern California. He was ordained by the Presbyterian Church and served as a missionary in China before and during World War II. The Rev. Dr. Crouch retired from COEMAR of the United Presbyterian Church, USA, as Secretary of Communications in 1971. He then began working with his wife on what would become a prize-winning scholarly work, ''Christianity in China: a Scholar's Guide to Resources in the Libraries and Archives of the United States,'' completed and published in 1989. Dr. Crouch is survived by his wife of 63 years, the lovely Ellen Elizabeth, four children, two half-sisters, one brother, and five grandchildren. Memorial contributions to honor the love and devotion of Archie's life may be made to the Presbyterian Church (USA), East Asia Pacific Office, 100 Witherspoon St., Louisville, KY 40202; or The Ricci Institute, University of San Francisco, 2130 Fulton St., San Francisco, CA 94117.

title: Swimming Against an Ebb Tide
description: IT was a lackluster, disappointing third quarter for most mutual funds, but there were notable exceptions -- many of them helped by investments in innovative companies in the telecommunications, semiconductor and biotechnology industries. And smaller growth stocks in general outpaced bigger, value-oriented issues in the three months ended Sept. 30, helping those funds that tilted in that direction.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HOFFMAN, ETHAN
description: HOFFMAN-Ethan. On your 50th birthday, your wondrous books, photographs and words will live on and on. Our hearts and minds yearn for you and miss your wit and wisdom every day. Mom, Bob, Caren, Elias, Joshua

title: Miss Brockwell And Mr. Brown
