description: Beverly Kay Brockwell, a daughter of Nancy Gaudin of Petersburg, Va., and Walter Brockwell of Lawrenceville, Va., was married yesterday to Matthew Roy Brown, a son of Bonnie and John Brown of Chesterfield, Va. The Rev. Lanny Bowles, a Baptist minister, officiated at the Fulton Hill Studios in Richmond.

title: Two Contrasting Works From New York Stages
description: WHAT is regional theater about, anyway? Conceived in the 1950's as an alternative to Broadway, it has evolved -- and sometimes devolved -- too often foregoing adventure and innovation in favor of a proven commercial hit.

title: Revamping the Variable Annuity to Make It More Competitive
description: THE variable annuity, that odd combination of mutual fund and insurance policy, has picked up a reputation for being too complex for most people to understand, not to mention overly expensive when compared with a pure mutual fund.

title: Q. & A.
description: Landlord's Liability in Dog Attack

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York.

title: Why They Kill? He Thinks He Knows
description: HANNIBAL LECHTER, wild-eyed, glares maniacally from the wall. The Joker -- in the person of Jack Nicholson -- is grinning devilishly.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-19

title: Dr. Schachter and Ms. Schoenberg
description: Carol Sara Schoenberg and Dr. Jonathan Fuchs Schachter are to be married this evening in Princeton, N.J. Rabbi James S. Diamond is to perform the ceremony at Prospect House, the Princeton University faculty club.

title: City, Suburb, City; Does Fear of Solitude Pull Some Back to 'Jungle'?
description: To the Editor:

title: Robert G. L. Waite, 80, Dies; Wrote Hitler's 'Psychohistory'
description: Robert G. L. Waite, a Williams College historian who set off a debate by bringing the psychoanalytic approach to books about Hitler, died on Monday while visiting his son Peter in Glastonbury, Conn. He was 80 and lived in Williamstown, Mass.

title: Green Space (Basil) Is Yielding to Greenbacks (Condos)
description: Roberto Gautier bid goodbye last week to the patch of string beans, lavender and basil he planted last spring in the Warren Street Community Garden.

title: Call Them Harry
description: THE LONG FIRM

title: His Life as a Murder Suspect
description: Having practiced a good deal of criminal law in my career, I have not seen a case where there is less ground even for suspicion.

title: Dara Brown, Matthew Schmid
description: Dara Evans Brown, the daughter of Karen Peterson Brown and David E. Brown of Allenwood, N.J., is to be married this afternoon to Matthew A. Schmid, the son of Veronica and Robert M. Schmid of New Windsor, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Steven Olsen is to perform the ceremony at Holy Trinity Lutheran Church in Manasquan, N.J.

title: Rutgers Has No Answer For Vick
description: He hurled a 74-yard touchdown bomb on the game's opening play, before many in the Rutgers homecoming crowd had even found their seats. Three more times in the second quarter, Michael Vick cocked his left arm to launch darts that found Virginia Tech receivers in the end zone. Oh yeah, he ran one in, too -- a sure-footed 22-yard romp.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CIPKO, PAUL D.
description: CIPKO-Paul D. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Paul D. Cipko, associated with The Times from 1950 until retiring in 1979.

title: Put Out More Waugh
description: The Complete Stories of Evelyn Waugh

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMILOVITZ, ROBERT
description: SMILOVITZ-Robert, died on Oct. 3, 1999 at home with his loving family. He was born in Bridgeport, Conn. He earned Master's and Doctorate degrees from Columbia University. He was a dedicated and innovative educator who fought to achieve civil rights, dignity, and respect for all people. For information des Groseilliers Funeral Homes in Hardwick, VT.

title: Giving Highways Their Due
description: With nicknames like the Broken Queens Expressway and the Don't Gowanus, New York's highways are more often a source of annoyance than inspiration. Steve Anderson, though, is the kind of man whose pulse quickens at such sights as the sprawling Bruckner interchange in the Bronx.

title: Layoff Over, Isles Will Learn About Themselves
description: Eight days between games in the National Hockey League can be either good or bad. The Islanders will find out today whether they benefited or were harmed by that long a layoff when they play their home opener against the Colorado Avalanche at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Creative Writing
description: Some of the most imaginative flowerings of modern literature are in a special genre: the personal expense account. What has been the wildest, woolliest item you have tried to put on your account? And for how much? How did you explain it, and what happened? Or if you're a boss, what has been the most striking item you have encountered? Send your stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your name and telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: In Haddonfield, They Come and They Go
description: THE Haddonfield Symphony's chronic conflict is simple: whether to be frustrated that its conductors and musicians keep leaving for more prestigious jobs, or proud that it finds young talent that others can so quickly spot and whisk off.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABBE, JAMES
description: ABBE-James. Of Brookville and Montauk, Long Island. On October 7, 1999. Age 87. Beloved husband of Kathryn. Father of James, Tom, Lucinda & Eli. Grandfather of six. Memorial service, Jericho Friends Meeting House, Saturday November 6, at 2 P.M.

title: A Per-Mile Bounce
description: Starting on Jan. 1, the standard deduction for business use of a car will be 32.5 cents a mile, up from 31 cents now, the Internal Revenue Service says. The move restores the mileage rate to its 1998 level.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Guide column last Sunday about the ''Walking Weekend'' brochure, available at the Prudence Crandall Museum in Canterbury and the Windham Textile Museum in Willamantic, misstated the dates of the listed events. They are today and tomorrow, not next Monday.

title: With Their Margin for Error Reduced, the Success of the Jets Will Be a Matter of Style
description: With their odd reversal of fortune, the Jets seem to be looking into a distant mirror. Here they were today in their final tuneup for Monday night's game against Jacksonville -- a week after having faced (and defeated) Denver.

title: The Arts Come Alive In School Programs
description: WHEN parents attend open house at the beginning of the school year at Hillside Elementary School, not all of them ask questions about the math curriculum or the language arts program. Instead, they seem more interested in which opera students in the second grade will be seeing, since a trip to a professional opera performance has become a tradition, said Linda Azif, a second-grade teacher here. The parents also fight over which parents will be asked to chaperone the trip.

title: How a Church Brings Life to Newark's Little Italy
description: For a century the predominantly Italian-American faithful of St. Lucy's Church have been celebrating the feast of St. Gerard Maiella with a religious procession through the streets of the neighborhood once known as the First Ward.

title: On the Acquisitions Road, Stay Alert to the Hazards
description: IT was the best and worst of times in corporate mergerville last week. On the one hand, investors were giddy over MCI Worldcom's plan for a $130 billion all-stock merger with Sprint, announced on Tuesday. Telecommunications stocks jumped on the news of the gigadeal.

title: Man Found on Subway Is Pronounced Dead
description: A 66-year-old man was pronounced dead after he was found unconscious yesterday in a subway car on the No. 7 line in Queens, the police said.

title: State Police Troopers To Receive Laptops in Cars
description: The New Jersey Turnpike Authority on Wednesday appropriated $1.5 million to buy 175 laptop computers to be installed on dashboards of State Police cars used to patrol the turnpike.

title: October 3-9; Nixon Speaks. Again.
description: President Richard M. Nixon's use of anti-Semitic remarks are fairly well known because of the use of his secret taping system.

title: American Music's Coming of Age
description: IT is probably not a point the New York Philharmonic was hoping to make in ''An American Celebration,'' the latest and most edifying of its CD compilations of archival recordings, but one thing this lavish set proves is that Ecclesiastes was right: there is nothing new under the sun. It seemed certain, after all, that debates about the Philharmonic's relationship with American music were of fairly recent vintage, if only because the American symphonic repertory we know today began flourishing in the 1930's. And what could be more current than the back-and-forth in which critics assert that the Philharmonic does barely enough American music and the orchestra responds that given the ticket buyers' clear preference for Beethoven and Tchaikovsky, it does plenty?

title: TELEVISION/RADIO; And Right After This Message, Miss Lillian Gish
description: MOVIEGOERS remember Horton Foote's ''Trip to Bountiful'' as a 1985 film starring Geraldine Page, who won the best actress Oscar for it. But there is an earlier version, a 1953 live television drama starring Lillian Gish, which has been sitting in the film collection at the Museum of Modern Art for 44 years.

title: Do AIDS Patients in S.R.O.'s Need On-Site Caseworkers?
description: For years, the city has placed homeless people with AIDS in single-room occupancy hotels, at least in emergencies. But advocates for people with the disease say the hotels are filthy, dangerous and unsupervised. And a new plan to remove city social workers from the hotels, the advocates say, will further complicate the lives of seriously ill people.

title: The Nation: Rx Redux; Fevered Issue, Second Opinion
description: THE signs are unmistakable: Washington is rediscovering the health care crisis. It did not, after all, go away with the failure of the Clinton Administration's attempt at universal coverage in 1994.

title: Meandering Along Country Roads . . .; In the Fall, the Fruit of Summer's Labor Beckon
description: ''GOD made only water,'' wrote Victor Hugo, ''but man made wine.'' We thought about this on a recent meander through the vineyards of northwest Connecticut and adjoining New York State.

title: BEST SELLERS: October 10, 1999
description: Weeks

title: Style; They Did It Their Way
description: Two things stand out about John and Dominique de Menil's house in Houston. The first is that the 50-year-old Philip Johnson-designed dwelling still seems startlingly alive nearly two years after Dominique's death. (Her husband died in 1973, and the house is currently maintained by the Menil Foundation.) A long, low antique Italian sofa still welcomes visitors in the spacious foyer, along with a huge Yves Klein canvas. In the living room, a sinuous chaise longue by the great couturier Charles James, who decorated the house, beckons near the tall sliding window. Books on philosophy, religion and poetry are still piled around the modest master bedroom; a small painting by de Chirico is hung above the dressing room's felt-covered door, to which are tacked snapshots, business cards and lists of things to do. You half expect Dominique -- with her delicate features and the ethereal bearing that veiled a keen mind and an iron will -- to appear at any moment.

title: America's Unpaid U.N. Dues
description: American foreign policy reaps important benefits when the United Nations sends peacekeepers to East Timor, relief workers to East Africa, police and civil administrators to Kosovo or arms inspectors to Iraq. But for years, Congress has prevented the Clinton Administration from paying the back dues America legally owes the U.N. This fall, there is a good chance to end the long stalemate, but only if House Republicans act responsibly.

title: Coach
description: When Pride Still Mattered A Life of Vince Lombardi. By David Maraniss. Illustrated. 541 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $26.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  EISENSTEIN, ALVIN GORDON
description: EISENSTEIN-Alvin Gordon Remembered always by his loving family and friends. 10/12/15-10/26/87

title: Undetected Indian Blasts, Cited as Monitoring Failures, May Themselves Have Failed
description: A mystery unfolded last year when India, on May 13, announced that it had set off a pair of nuclear blasts. The global network of seismometers -- sensitive devices buried deep in the earth to monitor shock waves from distant earthquakes and blasts -- recorded no faint rumbles emanating from India's underground test site in its northwestern desert. There was no blip, no twitch of pen or meter suggesting the awesome power of the atom had just been released.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In /Greenwich Village; A World of Its Own in the Big City
description: WITH its charming, narrow streets and 19th-century brick town houses, cozy taverns and leisurely pace, Greenwich Village is a world apart from the rest of high-rise Manhattan. Much of the neighborhood, from University Place to Hudson Street, has retained its historic character and quaint feel.

title: Why Higher Interest Rates Haven't Fazed Auto Makers
description: WHENEVER the Federal Reserve raises short-term interest rates or even hints that it might do so, as it did on Tuesday -- economists issue warnings about the consequences for rate-sensitive industries, notably automobiles and housing.

title: Chandler Spaulding, David Sutphen
description: Chandler Gaillard Spaulding, a daughter of Dr. Jean G. Spaulding and Kenneth B. Spaulding, both of Durham, N.C., was married there yesterday to David Andrew Sutphen, the son of Cecil Sutphen of Milwaukee and the late Judith Sutphen. The Rev. Cathy Gilliard performed the ceremony at White Rock Baptist Church.

title: In Battle of Unbeatens, Spartans Pull a Stunner
description: The rivalry between Michigan and Michigan State usually produces a lot of trash-talking, unimaginative football and, 23 of the previous 29 years, a Michigan victory. But the intrastate rivals broke with all three traditions today in a thrilling 34-31 Michigan State triumph.

title: Making Life A Bed of Roses
description: SHE was tiny and dapper in a trompe l'oeil ''jacket'' she had designed herself, its buttons and lapels coyly imagined in needlepoint. She wore her signature amber-colored sunglasses; her lipstick was rose pink and fresh. There were roses everywhere -- another signature -- blowsy ones clambering up the chintz chairs and the pillows on the slippery green silk-damask love seat; sterner ones nodded from bowls and a huge glass vase. You could smell them with every breath. She took your hands and squeezed hard. ''So pleased,'' she said, her voice low and a little flat. ''At last!''

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: PARK SLOPE

title: Fleury Can Pass, Too, in the Style of Gretzky
description: Theo Fleury is primarily known as a goal scorer. But Friday night at Madison Square Garden, Fleury showed just how well he can pass the puck, too.

title: Ms. Prendergast And Mr. Gold
description: Janice Catherine Prendergast, the daughter of Carol Prendergast of Panama City, Fla., and the late Duncan Prendergast, was married last evening to Jeffrey Martin Gold, the son of Philomena and Sheldon Gold of Flemington, N.J. Thomas R. Kupferman, a former associate justice of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Manhattan, officiated at Moran's restaurant in Manhattan.

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-10-99: Urbanist; A Well-Staged Scandal
description: Like so many culture-war battles of the past decade, Rudy vs. the Elephant Dung is misunderstood as a dispute about art, free expression and public funds. It is really about theater. The various participants play parts as ritualized and predictable as those in Japanese No drama or commedia dell'arte. Stock characters feign emotions of hurt and outrage. Behind all the masks, though, the principal feeling is glee -- glee at the publicity, at the opportunity for demagogic posturing and, perhaps most supremely, the special glee that accompanies contempt for those with views contrary to one's own.

title: Correction
description: A listing in the Residential Sales column last Sunday reversed the sale price and the listing price for 92 Highfield Avenue in Port Washington, N.Y. The sale price was $408,000 and the listing price was $399,000.

title: Sports of The Times; More Mystical Success For the Mets at Shea
description: FOR the Mets at Shea Stadium in October, it's never just baseball. It's been shoe polish and pine tar, a brawl at second base, a box of scuffed balls.

title: Hackley Gets Gift of $10 Million
description: IT is the kind of gift that could make many college development officers or independent school heads gnash their teeth in envy.

title: The World; Now, State of Siege, Colombian Style
description: A Latin American country slides toward chaos. Leftist guerrillas attack the government, right-wing death squads attack guerrilla sympathizers, peace talks falter. The economy spirals downward, scattering thousands of refugees, and fears of instability sweep through the region. The United States hurries to the rescue with hundreds of millions of dollars in aid.

title: ON BASEBALL
description: There has always been a calm demeanor about Darryl Strawberry since he arrived in the Yankee clubhouse. Watch Strawberry dress quietly near his corner locker or talk more honestly about the Yankees than anyone other than David Cone. There are never any moments when Strawberry looks as if he is rushing.

title: Long-Ago Loner as an Ancestor of the Moderns
description: TWENTY years after the last major exhibition of his work in Paris, Chardin, the 18th-century French still-life and genre painter, is the subject of yet another big retrospective at the Grand Palais through Nov. 22. Why so soon for someone who is not exactly a household name? Well, no one, it seems, can resist round numbers: 1979 was the 200th anniversary of Jean-Baptiste-Simeon Chardin's death; 1999 is the 300th anniversary of his birth. And of course there are always fresh audiences to conquer: while the 1979 show went to Cleveland and Boston, the new ''Chardin'' will travel to the Dusseldorf Kunsthalle and the Royal Academy in London before arriving next year at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York, where it will run from June 19 and through Sept. 17.

title: Ms. O'Connor and Mr. Haverland
description: Deirdre O'Connor, the daughter of Anne and J. Dennis O'Connor of Washington, was married last evening to Timothy James Haverland, a son of Sally and Thomas Haverland of Cincinnati. Judge Eugene F. Scanlon Jr. of the Court of Common Pleas of Allegheny County, Pa., officiated at the Pike Run Country Club in Jones Mills, Pa.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: We Can Report Them

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I'm not sure there's a dime's worth of difference between us, philosophically. I don't know of any moderate Texas Republicans, if you really want to know. It's conservative and more conservative.''

title: What's So Bad About Hate
description: Andrew Sullivan's apologia for hatred and governmental indifference to victims of prejudice ignores the tremendous progress that has been made in the United States against discrimination in race and employment. The worst cases of hatred -- and of actions based on them -- have emerged in totalitarian and nondemocratic regimes. Contrary to Sullivan's argument, democratic societies can rectify the brutish effects of prejudice.

title: Struggling To Make Do Off the Dole
description: EACH of us wants what the other has. Big international opera companies worry that distinctive French and Italian singing styles have melted into a kind of processed cheese, where tastes are universal and often bland. Small opera companies like the Teatro del Giglio here worry that their centuries-old trueness to themselves marks them as provincials unable to cope with any art but their own.

title: State of the Nation, and of the G.O.P.
description: To the Editor:

title: Walter Bergman, Champion Of Civil Liberties, Dies at 100
description: Dr. Walter Bergman, an indefatigable civil rights advocate who was savagely beaten by members of the Ku Klux Klan in 1961 as one of the first Freedom Riders and won compensation for the attack from the F.B.I. more than two decades later, died on Sept. 29 in a nursing home in Grand Rapids, Mich., his wife said. He was 100.

title: Brendan Johnson, Susan Stewart
description: Susan Dryden Stewart, the daughter of Leslie D. Stewart of Manhattan and the late Margery Pennefather Cowan Stewart, was married yesterday on Martha's Vineyard to Brendan Patrick Johnson, the son of Eileen G. Johnson and John A. Johnson of Villanova, Pa. The Rev. Kevin C. Gillespie, an uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at St. Elizabeth's Roman Catholic Church in Edgartown, Mass.

title: Foreign Aide
description: THE PLEASING HOUR

title: As a Disputed Subway Project Begins, Residents Rumble
description: When New York City Transit made plans last year to reactivate an old power substation on West 16th Street near Seventh Avenue, neighbors reacted with anger and alarm. They worried about noise, congestion, asbestos removal during construction and the effects of electromagnetic fields once the station was in operation.

title: Pushkin's Genius
description: To the Editor:

title: Write Those Lines!
description: Football is a contact sport, and the contact is often violent. Yet a man from Freehold has published a book that uses football as a metaphor for decreasing violence and controlling anger. It is called ''Four Downs to Anger Control,'' and the author is Tom Letson, a counselor in Howell Township middle schools and a football coach at Allentown High School. He found football analogies useful in anger-control sessions -- ''most men understand four downs and punting when you get to fourth down'' -- and decided to write a book using them. For example, readers are encouraged to view themselves as ''head coach'' of their anger, to ''officiate'' arguments and ''throw the flag'' at such penalities as profanity or name-calling. Mr. Letson is planning a version for children and a book using basketball analogies. The book, $10.95 plus $2 for each book shipped, is available from Finish Line Press, Post Office Box 6861, Freehold, N.J. 07728; (877) 346-4745; fax (732) 845-2283; e-mail (Fourdowns@aol.com) CARL SOMMERS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINDE, SYD B.
description: LINDE-Syd B. Beloved wife of the late Herman A. Linde and Dr. Louis Stanley Barnett. Loving mother of Gloria and the late Morton H. Levin, Dr. Albert Barnett, Lenore and Dr. Jack Peretz, Lee Spar, Rosalie and the late Jay Linde. Adored grandmother and great-grandmother. Dear sister.

title: O'Rourke Reflects On Life as Judge, Not Politician
description: FROM his judicial offices here, Andrew P. O'Rourke, the former Westchester County Executive, lives a professional life out of the public limelight that he once embraced.

title: It Isn't Easy Being a Superman
description: A FEW songs into ''Forever,'' the recently released second album by the rapper-producer-entrepreneur Puff Daddy, there is a skit about people phoning the ''Player-Haters Anonymous Hot Line.'' One caller confesses that he has fallen off the wagon and has been ''hatin' today.'' Another, at the end of his tether, warns the hot line counselor that he has got a key in his hand and is on the verge of scratching a big shot's Bentley.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COREN, ARNOLD S.
description: COREN-Arnold S. 4/8/22-10/12/97 Forever in our hearts. Miriam, Alice, Larry, George, Nancy, and your boys

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: October 10, 1999
description: Weeks

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLINGEN, JOYCE FOUNTAIN
description: CLINGEN-Joyce Fountain. Of Chatham Township, NJ, formerly of NYC, on October 6, 1999, the daughter of the late Florence and Quion Fountain, wife of James F. Clingen, mother of Guy and Maria Clingen, both of Westfield, NJ, sister of Audrey F. Jordan of Whispering Pines, NC. A graveside service will be held on Tuesday, October 12, 1999, at 11 AM, at the Fountain Plot in Hillside Cemetery, Plainfield, NJ. In lieu of flowers donations in her name may be made to the American Cancer Society or the Salvation Army.

title: Down Time at a Mine Has Explorers Digging In a Search for Fossils
description: THE mine was closed for the day to all but the 40 or so members of a fossil-finding expedition that descended into a newly cleared level at the green-sand marl pit mine in Gloucester County.

title: Clinton Faults Senate Over Hispanic Judicial Nominees
description: President Clinton told a national Hispanic group today that the Senate was a black hole of delay, unwilling to vote for his Hispanic nominees for Federal judgeships but afraid to vote against them.

title: Remembering Tissot
description: To the Editor:

title: The Nation: Post-Monica Skittishness; Sex, Politics and the Open Door
description: GARY BAUER ordered a glass door for his office at his Presidential campaign headquarters here last week. Nothing wrong with the old wooden one -- except that two former aides have said they left because the candidate frequently closed it to meet one-on-one with his female deputy campaign chief.

title: Laura Traverse, Harry Lerner
description: Laura Jane Traverse, the daughter of Nassrine Traverse and Dr. Norman Traverse of Boston, was married last evening to Harry Benjamin Lerner, a son of Mimi Lerner and Dr. Harvey Lerner of St. James, N.Y. Rabbi Frank Waldorf officiated at the Boston Harbor Hotel.

title: A Scramble for Office Space in Jersey City, Manhattan's 'West Bank'
description: The hottest address for investment bankers today is the former home of a toothpaste and detergent factory.

title: Sabine Bussinger, James Percelay
description: Sabine Carol Bussinger was married on Thursday to James Leland Percelay at the town hall in Rheinfelden, Switzerland. Hilde Traber, a registrar for Rheinfelden, performed the ceremony.

title: Opera Improvises With Few Dollars
description: IN a 1987 performance of ''Madama Butterfly'' by the New Rochelle Opera, two performers bowed to each other on a tight-fitting stage and got their wigs caught, holding up the performance for a minute while they untangled. The show went on, but that incident was one of many inconveniences that the company has had to endure because it has no permanent home.

title: Lessons From a School Where the Worm Club Rules
description: WORMS seem unlikely ambassadors for a troubled world, but they were popular members of the after-school garden club I helped start last year at Public School 15 -- the Patrick Daly School, named for the principal who was shot to death while searching for a pupil seven years ago -- in Red Hook, Brooklyn. These worms were teaching us to be good stewards of the earth, until their ecosystem crashed -- because of their own global warming, I think -- but we're going to try again.

title: Scallop Season Opens On Disappointing Note
description: Baymen dredging for scallops in Peconic Bay last week were finding few of the tasty shellfish and abundant signs of another poor season in waters that have yet to recover from the still-unexplained brown tide scourge.

title: Dr. Djurasovic, Ms. Stockhammer
description: Tanya Friederike Stockhammer, a daughter of Sigrid and Rudi Stockhammer of Winter Springs, Fla., was married yesterday to Dr. Mladen Djurasovic, a son of Mara and Milenko Djurasovic of Union, N.J. The Rev. Djokan Majstorovic officiated at the Serbian Orthodox Cathedral of St. Sava in New York.

title: Paula Engel, Mike Riezenman
description: NO ONE thought Mike Riezenman, 58, would ever get married. He had many passions -- Sherlock Holmes, Gilbert and Sullivan, wry jokes and Chinese food -- but domesticity was not one of them. For 20 years he had lived alone in a small, cluttered Manhattan apartment at 55th and Broadway.

title: Iran Reformers, Silenced 3 Times, Start Another Paper
description: With its three earlier newspapers shut down by court orders, a group pressing for a more democratic and tolerant Iran went a step further this week by opening a fourth daily that immediately sold out on Teheran's streets.

title: It's Time for Steelers to Act on Stewart's Funk
description: Just as the Giants did with Dave Brown, and the Tampa Bay Buccaneers did with Trent Dilfer, and the Oakland Raiders did with Jeff George, it is time for the Pittsburgh Steelers to stop fooling themselves and take a long, hard look at their quarterback, Kordell Stewart.

title: The Truth Is Way Out There
description: THE REAL SCIENCE

title: FILM; Even Auteurs Need a Break From Themselves
description: IN 1994, Alvin Straight, a taciturn, proudly independent old man, drove his John Deere riding mower across Iowa to visit his estranged, ailing brother in Wisconsin. Four years later, the director David Lynch made a movie about the journey, ''The Straight Story,'' which Disney will release on Friday. And for those who think that Mr. Lynch, best known for movies with sadistic, drug-enhanced sex and small-town violence, must have discovered Iowa's dark side -- the creepy-crawlers beneath the corn -- the news is that ''The Straight Story'' is Disney's cleanest non-animated picture since ''Son of Flubber.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, EDMUND DUTILH
description: SMITH-Edmund Dutilh. Of New York City. Died on October 6 after a long illness. He was born on March 3, 1916. He is survived by his wife Renee, a brother George, two nephews Douglas and Gordon, two nieces Mandy and Kim. He was an honorary member of the Amateur Comedy Club in New York City. He will be buried in the cemetery of the Church of the Redeemer in Bryn Mawr, Pa.

title: Storm Aid
description: The Board of Legislators has authorized a $3.5 million capital project to pay for damage from Tropical Storm Floyd.

title: Seeking a Spot for 'Kennedy'
description: The makeshift memorial of flowers, cards and notes was removed long ago from the front of 20 North Moore Street. Now some TriBeCa residents are searching for a more lasting way to honor John F. Kennedy Jr. and Carolyn Bessette.

title: Liberties; Gore's Gawky Phase
description: When Al Gore began stressing his Tennessee roots, running for President in the South in 1987, a top official for a rival campaign was dismissive.

title: Red Sox Find Answers, Raising More Questions
description: Now the real fun starts at the Fenway fun house, the guessing games and the praying of the faithful for the healing of the hurting players. When can Pedro Martinez, the Boston star, come back from his back injury to pitch? Not likely for Game 4 here on Sunday and doubtful even for Game 5, if one is needed, in Cleveland on Monday.

title: MOVIES: CRITICS' CHOICE
description: High comedy, high adventure and profound love lend color and excitement to the week's outstanding movies.

title: Scenes From The Millennium
description: I enjoyed Luc Sante's ''Triumph of the Image'' (Sept. 19). But I feel that some acknowledgment needs to be given to Walter Benjamin's 1936 essay ''The Work of Art in the Age of Mechanical Reproduction'' and to Walter Lippmann for his 1927 Vanity Fair article ''Blazing Publicity: Why We Know So Much About 'Peaches' Browning, Valentino, Lindbergh and Queen Marie.''

title: Casino Fined for Treatment Of Wealthy Customers
description: The Trump Taj Mahal received two fines totaling nearly $300,000 from the Casino Control Commission for violating regulations in its preferential treatment of high rollers.

title: In Rome Airport, Wait As the Romans Like to
description: Occupying time while waiting for a flight at Fiumicino airport near Rome (a common occurrence given the frequent flight delays) has become more pleasant thanks to the recent opening of the Enoteca Winetasting Frescobaldi, a small wine bar where some of Italy's best wines can be savored.

title: For Sale by Theme
description: Paris has Colette. New York has a flurry of stores that want to outshine Colette, the hugely popular boutique and art gallery that stocks highly unusual goods in very small supply. The latest Colette challenger is Zao, which Assaf Ziv and Tal Lancman, two Israeli fashion magazine refugees, opened last week on 175 Orchard Street (Stanton Street). The stark, gallerylike store carries no major brands, but plenty of limited-edition, hard-to-find goods, from beauty products to underground music to one-of-a-kind clothes by designers like Elana Efrati, an Israeli who puts political images and Hebrew scriptures on dresses made of paper and porcelain. Products are organized by theme, and the entire stock is supposed to change every month. Later, there will be an ''amorphic'' theme, when everything will be bloblike, from shoes to an oval celadon refrigerator by Rex, and a ''red'' theme, when everything will be, yep, red. On sale now: a Jean-Marie Massaud chair (only three were made) injected with synthetic plasma to give it the feeling of human flesh ($5,700). Aibo, Sony's electronic dog that barks, plays fetch and even appears to urinate, has already sold out. KAREN ROBINOVITZ

title: Johanna Goodman, Rodger Stevens
description: Johanna Claire Goodman and Rodger Henry Stevens, who are artists, were married on Friday in a civil ceremony at the Municipal Building in Manhattan.

title: Columbia Quarterback Has Winning Debut Against Bucknell
description: In the first start in his career, the senior Mike Glynn had one of the best days by a Lion quarterback this decade, completing 25 of 31 passes for 280 yards yesterday and leading Columbia to a 10-7 victory over Bucknell at Wien Stadium. The game-winner was Neal Kravitz's 46-yard field goal with 4 minutes 10 seconds left in the fourth quarter, but Glynn was Columbia's star.

title: A Scary (and Spiritual) Arsenal of Ageless Masks
description: FOR 30,000 years, all sorts of people have felt the need to create masks. From cavemen to astronauts, they have worn them for protection, as a disguise or as a way of transforming themselves spiritually. Masks reflect a range of human expression: funny, sinister, ascetic, wild or haunting. Our fascination with the power and mystery of masks can be seen today on movie sets, stages, factory floors, hockey rinks, battlefields and the moon.

title: Political Briefing; A Pre-emptive Strike Pays Off in the Polls
description: Remember Mayor Lincoln Chafee of Warwick, R.I., a Republican who is running to replace his father, John H. Chafee, in the United States Senate?

title: What's So Bad About Hate
description: Sullivan's insights and engaging rhetoric seem to miss the reality that a person's apparent group identity may increase his vulnerability. An acquaintance of mine lost his eye in a late-night traffic dispute and, before receiving the shattering blow of a bottle across his brow, was taunted with insults of ''homo'' and ''faggot.''

title: After Tough Year, Turkey Dusts Off Its Red Carpet
description: PITY the unfortunate Turkish tour operators and hotel managers. They have built their country into one of the world's top 20 tourist destinations, attracting nearly 10 million visitors a year, most of them from western Europe. Travel agents there tell customers that Turkey has the three things tourists care most about: sunny beaches, rich cultural heritage and friendly people.

title: 1999 PLAYOFFS: DIVISION SERIES -- Subway Series Is Just One Stop Away; Pratt's Homer in 10th Extends Met Ride
description: The ball rose off Todd Pratt's bat with one out in the bottom of the 10th inning yesterday and carried with it the Mets' increasingly startling season. The team has endured a near fatal losing streak, a one-game playoff just to get to the playoffs, a meeting with Randy Johnson and a manager's remarkably ill-timed comments. And that was all within the last 10 days. But could the Mets endure the long wait for Pratt's ball to come down at the center-field wall, in a game tied at 3-3?

title: Commercial Property /75 Broad Street; Turning Buildings Into Telecommunications Hubs
description: SOME of the control rooms installed by telecommunications companies in the 70-year-old building at 75 Broad Street in lower Manhattan resemble the bridge of the Starship Enterprise. They are symbolic of the changes that have taken place in the 33-story structure, which was once set for conversion to residential and hotel use.

title: 1999 PLAYOFFS: DIVISION SERIES -- Subway Series Is Just One Stop Away; Strawberry And Clemens Finish Business
description: They ambushed Roger Clemens here tonight, waves of attackers, one of them covering his face with shaving cream. He handed the offender his bottle of champagne. ''Here, pour this on my face, I can't see,'' Clemens said.

title: Control of the Electronic Highway
description: A bewildering series of mergers and regulatory actions in the telecommunications industry in the past two weeks could ultimately improve telephone service to consumers. But some of the mergers designed to make local phone service better risk constraining what viewers can see on their cable systems, threatening the diversity of information that is central to democracy.

title: Dialects
description: Even Malcolm X, who came up from the streets and could hardly be accused of ever accommodating whites, spoke to his audiences in a vibrant and flawless standard English.

title: Treasures of a King, Make That The King, Are Snatched Up by the Masses
description: The mystery train that carried Andrea Bauer to the MGM Grand Hotel this weekend started in her family's living room when she was just a girl, back in the 1950's. Sometimes when her father, a devoted Perry Como fan, left the house, her mother would quickly switch to a record by that new singer, the twitchy kid from Tupelo.

title: MUSIC; Making World Music Local
description: HIS white button-down shirt casually rolled up at the sleeves, Chad Stevens could have passed for a young Scott Joplin as his fingers danced lightly across the keys of the Steinway in the Rafael Hernandez auditorium here late last month. Chad, a ninth-grader, was at first reluctant to climb up to the stage, but his friends egged him on. Then he delivered a spirited version of Joplin's ''Maple Leaf Rag'' in front of a crowd of parents, students and teachers.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2000 Infiniti I30; Adding Ingredients To the Family Recipe
description: A DECADE ago, when Nissan gave birth to its Infiniti luxury division, the baby's future seemed clear: Infiniti was destined to be the BMW of Japan.

title: Steel Instead of Wood for Homes
description: THE vast majority of the houses built in the United States today are constructed with wood. About 85 percent of that wood is used for framing. Since wood has been the primary building material since Colonial times, it might seem that there is no reason for change, but wood has its drawbacks.

title: In Troubled Roosevelt, A Takeover Still Awaits A Makeover
description: LILLIAN COGGINS-WATSON is an elementary school principal who gives everything to the delicate and daunting mission of educating some of Nassau County's neediest children. She has stayed for a generation and often stops to hug pupils whose parents attended the same school. The children wear uniforms with colorful ties made from African fabric. Trained storytellers visit. Sixth graders spend a week visiting Washington, D.C.

title: Ms. Nielsen, Mr. Ballard
description: Samantha Eileen Nielsen, the daughter of William and Darragh Nielsen of Glen Head, N.Y., was married last evening to Ian Matheson Ballard Jr., the son of Dr. Ballard of Radnor, Pa., and Paula S. Ballard of Bethlehem, Pa.

title: Yeltsin Admitted to Hospital for Influenza
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia was taken to the Central Clinical Hospital this morning suffering from what his press secretary described as the flu accompanied by a high fever.

title: What Thugs?
description: To the Editor:

title: Food; Acid Reigns
description: A touch of sourness, in food as in life, often marks the end of innocence. Consider, for instance, the ripe strawberry. After it is spritzed, in the Italian manner, with balsamic vinegar, it loses its sweet and nubile affect, becoming tart -- and yet, in the opinion of many connoisseurs, delectably complex.

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-10-99: Questions for Dominique Moceanu; The Divorced Daughter
description: Q: How much of your childhood was consumed by gymnastics?

title: On the Road
description: Nature inspires art. So do city skylines. But the New Jersey Turnpike? As it moves into its 50th year of operation, the turnpike is the focus of ''Sites/Sights of Passage: Art of the New Jersey Turnpike,'' an exhibition at the James Howe Gallery at Kean University. It includes works by Allan D'Arcangelo, the Pop Art painter; Rackstraw Downes, the realist, and Gerson Lieber, a Newark-based printmaker. ''The pieces in the show were inspired directly by the turnpike,'' explained Jack Cornish, the director of gallery. In conjunction with the exhibit, a symposium is to be held on Wednesday at 6:30 P.M. in the University Center's Little Theater. Information: (908) 527-2307.

title: Hard Times in the 90's
description: To the Editor:

title: Junk Bonds Are Quickly In a Crunch
description: SATURDAY mornings have become a little ho-hum for Tim O'Hara at the Golden Pear coffee shop in Bridgehampton, N.Y.

title: Where 'Book Value' Takes on Deeper Meaning
description: ANGELA HEDERMAN makes no bones about it: she knew nothing of being a book publisher when she decided to become one.

title: Tearing Down The Facade of 'Vitamins Inc.'
description: THE scope of the conspiracy boggles the mind. For a full decade, top executives at some of the world's largest drug companies met secretly in hotel suites and at conferences. When Federal investigators were closing in, they moved to the homes of high-level European executives.

title: Veal Stew Takes on the Flavor of Mushrooms and Fresh Herbs
description: OLIVE oil, garlic and lots of fresh herbs epitomize the kind of cooking I like. For a recent dinner, I made veal stew with white wine and tomatoes topped with fried sage leaves. Instead of cooking mushrooms in the stew the usual way, I sauteed them separately in olive oil with garlic and thyme so they were crisp.

title: Amid Ancient Trees In the Highest Sierras
description: SOME rare places make philosophers of even the most hardened cynics. Until I actually placed my hand on the rough but ever-so-delicate bark of a 200-foot-tall, 2,000-year-old sequoia, these majestic trees had been a brochure abstraction. To walk beneath them, as I did recently, was like being adopted by giants.

title: In a Buyout, Life After Lilco
description: William J. Catacosinos, former chairman of the Long Island Lighting Company, who left in July 1998 amid an outcry over his $42 million golden parachute, has another act to stage. This time, the scene is Texas, the plot the first leveraged buyout of an electric utility.

title: State of the Nation, and of the G.O.P.
description: To the Editor:

title: Sleep in a Box
description: INSIDE my capsule, lying diagonally, head against one wall, feet on another, I thought of home. I live in Montana. It is a state rich with open, unpeopled spaces; a place where you can sometimes drive the back roads for hours without seeing another vehicle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWBURGER, ELEANOR PETERS
description: NEWBURGER-Eleanor Peters. Died September 27, 1999 at age 71. Spirited, smart, funny, undaunted, she was a fearless speaker of other languages, a tireless museumgoer, a life-long learner. She held a B.A. from Columbia University, School of General Studies, and worked for a time at Perspectives, an international journal of American culture. Widow of Stanley Newburger, she will be remembered and especially missed by their children Robert, Emily, Laurie and Lisa, grandchildren Zack and Emma, sisters Ruth and Liz.

title: Blond Ambition in the Urban Mosaic
description: SOMEWHERE between my second cup of morning coffee and my third reading of ''The Cat in the Hat,'' the baby sitter told me she had yet another Riverside Park tale.

title: Museum Display of Historic Painting Barred
description: A JUSTICE of the State Supreme Court here has signed a restraining order preventing the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers from displaying Jasper F. Cropsey's ''View at Hastings-on-Hudson'' in a major show of Hudson River School painters opening Friday The picture, valued at $1 million, has been the focus of an intense dispute involving the museum and the Hastings-on-Hudson school district.

title: Backtalk; Greatest College Team Ever? Untouchable, Forgotten Sewanee in 1899
description: It would be impossible today, and one would think it would have been impossible 100 years ago.

title: October 3-9; A Blueprint for East Timor
description: Kofi Annan, the United Nations Secretary General, laid out his blueprint for the new nation of East Timor -- Timor Loro S'ai in Tetum, the local language. The two-to-three year project promises to be the biggest operation the United Nations has had to mount since rebuilding Cambodia in 1992 and 1993. With a United Nations peacekeeping force assuming responsibility for defense, the organization will be expected to take over East Timor's gutted towns and depopulated civil administration and organize everything from garbage collection to a new legal system. Putting the troops in place could take a few months, but Mr. Annan made it plain that civilian administrators should move into the dangerous political vacuum much sooner. The Security Council is likely to give the go-ahead in the next week or two. BARBARA CROSSETTE

title: THE GUIDE
description: Museum of Horrors

title: Oh, Grow Up
description: THE RISE AND FALL OF

title: To Young Tycoons, Bathtime Is an Opportunity, Not a Chore
description: Surrounded by their bath products, which are beaded and bedecked with the paper parasols seen on tropical drinks, the two entrepreneurs talked business strategy in their Cobble Hill testing lab.

title: In the Region /Connecticut; State Grants Play Big Role in Saving Open Space
description: IN the last few months, with the help of a state grants program, almost 1,700 acres have been added to the 460,996 acres of conservation lands owned by Connecticut state agencies, municipalities, private nonprofit organizations, water companies and utilities.

title: Greenwood Lake Rallies to Win
description: Racing for only the fourth time in a career that began at Saratoga just two months ago, Greenwood Lake charged through the homestretch at Belmont Park yesterday, passed More Than Ready and went on to win the $400,000 Champagne Stakes by 2 lengths over Chief Seattle.

title: Construction Irks Owners Near a Beach
description: The walls of his bungalow on Beach 24th Street were shaking, Neil Dunker said, when he braced his kitchen cabinets and boxed his armada of 37 miniature ships that nearly vibrated off their shelves.

title: Corrections
description: A report last Sunday about the wedding of Elise J. Harmon and Donald George Varga Jr. included an outdated reference to the official who performed the ceremony. It was Judge Kimba M. Wood of Federal District Court in Manhattan; the Rev. Leroy Aarons took part.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KINSELLA, JOHN L.
description: KINSELLA-John L. September 30, 1999 (retired acting chief inspector NYCPD) of Vero Beach, formerly of Southold. Beloved husband of Cynthia, loving uncle of Jane Mohring. Funeral Mass at 10 AM Tuesday, October 12, 1999 at St. Patick's Church, Southold. Burial to follow in Calvary Cemetery.

title: POSTINGS: Real Estate Board Report; Condo Prices Pass $400 a Foot
description: Condominium prices in Manhattan soared in the second quarter of the year, according to data compiled by the Real Estate Board of New York, with median prices for both prewar and postwar apartments going above $400 per square foot -- the highest level since the board began tracking prices four years ago.

title: Are Fund Managers Irrelevant? An 18th-Century Theory Suggests Not
description: THE debate over index funds has been exceedingly lopsided. Reason and common sense have been almost completely on the side of those who advocate investing all of a portfolio in index funds.

title: Polly Minifie, John Snyder
description: Margaret Chapin Minifie and John Michael Snyder, associates at Washington law firms, were married yesterday at King's Chapel in Boston. The Rev. Catherine S. Gibson, an Episcopal priest and the bridegroom's godmother, performed the ceremony.

title: MY MONEY, MY LIFE; An Epiphany About Lawyers
description: THE first time I saw a lawyer cry, something shifted inside me.

title: DEALS AND DISCOUNTS
description: BANGKOK PACKAGES -- An Exotic Bangkok package from Asian Affair Holidays starts at $988 a person, double occupancy, for four nights at the Peninsula Bangkok Hotel and round-trip flights from New York on Singapore Airlines. The price includes transfers between airport and hotel, daily buffet breakfast and a half-day tour of the Grand Palace. The package is available through May (except during December). Information: (800) 742-3133.

title: Q & A/Jung-Ho Pak; Leading Orchestras From East to West
description: AFTER a two-year search the New Haven Symphony has hired a new music director, the peripatetic Jung-Ho Pak, 37, of San Diego. The Maestro has left his jobs as music director of the San Francisco Conservatory of Music and the University of Southern California Symphony, but he will continue as artistic director of the San Diego Symphony and commute cross-country.

title: Jean McMahon, John Geelan
description: Jean Helen McMahon, a television producer, and John Doyle Geelan, a lawyer, were married yesterday afternoon at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in Manhattan. The Rev. Walter F. Modrys performed the ceremony.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Poet From Wales

title: Professor Oprah, Preaching What She Practices
description: AT Northwestern University's Kellogg Graduate School of Management here, course registration is a study in perfect competition. To select courses, M.B.A. students bid against one another. Each starts with the same number of points; courses with popular professors cost more.

title: The Nation; It's Infectious: Fear That's Out of Proportion
description: AS public health threats go, they could not have been more different. The West Nile-like encephalitis virus, which broke out in New York City in August, travels by mosquitoes that feed on infected birds and then bite humans. It tends to sicken the elderly the worst. The E. coli epidemic, which happened simultaneously in upstate New York, was food-borne. E. coli strikes the elderly too, but more often makes children the most ill. One disease, never before been seen in the Western Hemisphere, is in fact generally quite benign. The other is somewhat common, with the potential to greatly sicken many people under the right circumstances.

title: Ms. Robinson, Mr. Hamilton
description: Anne Elizabeth Robinson and Andrew Hamilton Jr. were married yesterday by the Rev. Fred R. Anderson at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: By Building a Coalition, a Utility Resolves Prickly Issues on Dams
description: FOR decades in the Pacific Northwest, hydroelectric dams have generated as much conflict as electricity.

title: Ford and Auto Workers Avert Strike With Tentative Agreement
description: After round-the-clock negotiations lasting nearly 30 hours, the United Automobile Workers union reached a tentative agreement today with the Ford Motor Company on a new contract for its 101,000 unionized workers.

title: Too Much Rest for This Driver
description: Medical researchers, confirming what many suburbanites already know, have reported that long-distance commuters suffer from chronic sleep deprivation. But Thomas Purves, chairman and chief executive of BMW's operations in the Americas, would like his commute to be longer.

title: The World; In the New Yugoslavia, a Familiar Dead Hand
description: COMMUNISM may have died 10 years ago in Eastern Europe, but it lives on, after a fashion, in Yugoslavia -- both in patterns of power and habits of mind. The failure of political and social transformation helps explain why efforts to oust President Slobodan Milosevic are faltering.

title: White Flight
description: IT didn't take Lincoln Schnur-Fishman long to learn how to walk the walk and talk the talk. And then he vanished as abruptly as he had appeared.

title: Nassau's Woes Cannot Be Blamed Only on Gulotta
description: As a registered Republican in Nassau County, I just received a letter sent by the Nassau County Republican chairman, Joseph N. Mondello, to the party faithful. It's a shame that Mr. Mondello paints County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta as the only villain in all of Nassau County's financial woes and sets up the 14 Republican legislators as the potential heroes. Remember, although Mr. Gulotta is not blameless, only the Legislature can pass a budget or raise taxes.

title: Correction
description: The What's Doing column on Sept. 19, about Vancouver, misspelled the name of a street in the heart of the city's Asian neighborhood. It is Cambie, not Canby.

title: Teen-Ager Slain on Subway As Robbers Demand Chain
description: Two armed men entered the last car of a No. 2 subway train in the Bronx on Friday night and announced a robbery. As they walked through the car, most of the few passengers avoided eye contact or pretended to be asleep, witnesses later told the police.

title: Why Whitman Is Staying Home
description: Even though there was time for a short speech or three, Governor Whitman's reception for the Crossroads Theater Company in New Brunswick last Tuesday was just a swell party. No plaques, no proclamations, no certificates, no awards.

title: See the Original
description: To the Editor:

title: At 75, a Maverick Has a Big Band 'Talking'
description: ZENLIKE in his disinclination to judge most things, John Cage could be picky about music. He preferred Mozart to Bach, found Beethoven and Brahams uninteresting and failed to hear what appealed to intelligent people about jazz, a music whose sequential improvisations and reiterated beat, he supposedly once said, reminded him of a series of dramatic monologues delivered one after another, with a clock ticking in the background.

title: A Cubic Zirconia Wouldn't Do
description: On a recent Saturday night at Sway, a buzzing SoHo nightclub, Lian Tal, a 23-year-old waitress, scanned the tables filled with young women in their Earl Jeans jackets and Tracy Feith dresses and pointed out the fashion statement they all had in common.

title: Candice Martinez, Jeffrey Neuman
description: Candice Joy Martinez, a daughter of Dr. Ligaya G. Martinez and Dr. Candido F. Martinez of Englewood Cliffs, N.J., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Abbott Neuman, the son of Nancy and Mark Neuman of Lewisburg, Pa. The Rev. Robert Wolfe, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Cecilia Church in Englewood, N.J.

title: ART/ARCHITECTURE: UP AND COMING -- Roberto Cortazar; A Portraitist of Consciousness
description: THE view from the high-rise building in which the painter Roberto Cortazar lives and works, in an outlying district of Mexico City, offers a reminder that the sprawling metropolis below can resemble a huge, restless organism in constant motion. Sometimes Mr. Cortazar regards this city, where he was born 37 years ago, as ''a kind of body,'' he said. The human body itself is a form, he added, ''and like any form in the universe, from a cell to a planet, it's also extremely complex.''

title: Melissa Lowe, Bradley Edwards
description: Melissa Ann Lowe, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Lowe Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Bradley Alan Edwards, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Russell E. Edwards of Phoenix. The Rev. Michael R. Moynihan performed the ceremony at St. Michael the Archangel Roman Catholic Church.

title: Opening a Closed Position: Once an Inscrutable Riddle
description: Although the Queen's Gambit was known as early as the late 15th century, it took a long time to become popular. The reason is that the close formations it led to were in general not understood; when these came up at random in king pawn games, they were also roundly mishandled.

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-10-99; Microbes on The Move
description: In late November 1995, while on a reporting trip to the island of Zanzibar, off the coast of East Africa, I was bit repeatedly by mosquitoes. This is not uncommon, and I paid it no mind -- I was already suffering from what I believed to have been shigella, a nasty gastrointestinal parasite, and I was feeling miserable anyway.

title: Punish the Taliban
description: To the Editor:

title: City, Suburb, City; Does Fear of Solitude Pull Some Back to 'Jungle'?
description: To the Editor:

title: OPINION; Quality Teachers and Hen's Teeth
description: MUCH has been written recently about the scarcity of qualified public school teachers and administrators, particularly in underprivileged areas where they are needed most. However, the problem is even more widespread and serious than is commonly known.

title: The Hollow Man
description: DUTCH

title: The Index Monster In Your Closet
description: MICROSOFT. General Electric. I.B.M. Wal-Mart Stores. Cisco Systems. These are the companies that have led this decade's bull market. The next time a shareholder report for your stock mutual fund comes in the mail, take a look at its top holdings: You may find a lot of these big names.

title: Beijing and Shanghai Open Airports Slowly
description: Perhaps they drew a lesson from the disastrous opening days of Hong Kong's new airport, but for whatever reason, Beijing officials are being cautious and coy about the schedule of their own eagerly awaited new airport. The large, H-shaped new terminal of the Beijing Capital Airport has been built right next to the dingy old terminal, where travelers must often elbow their way through crowds to check in or find a taxi.

title: Art and Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Out of the Ashes
description: FIREBIRD

title: Dialects
description: The very idea of dialects is that they are the ''in'' lingo of special groups and not universally understood. That's why it's considered amusing when white people, for instance, try to work rap phrases into conversation. Even as American English absorbs, gradually, certain slang and technical terms, let's hold on to a body of commonality: no one wants to hear Dan Rather end a story with ''Dat is some phat chick, bro!''

title: Clinton Jolts Canadians With a Plea On Federalism
description: Canadians on both sides of the nation's deep linguistic divide say they were stunned by President Clinton's unexpectedly passionate appeal here for national unity and federalism.

title: Art Museum Trustees Say City Hall Pushed Them Too Hard
description: The board of trustees of the Brooklyn Museum of Art has long been a placid little backwater for the rich and powerful of New York City. Once, years ago, there was a bit of a dust-up over a decision to buy an Albert Bierstadt by selling a Winslow Homer. Some trustees resigned in protest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, BENJAMIN
description: MILLER-Benjamin. Age 88, on October 9, 1999. Beloved husband of Frances Miller. Loving father of Myra Gordon, Nancy Wald, Judith Miller and Helene Linker. Devoted grandfather of Steven Gordon, Emily Fowler, Karen, David, Richard and Jonathan Wald, Josh and Melina Auerbach, Sarah and Alex Linker and the late Avra Gordon. Adoring great-grandfather of Max and Bethany Fowler. Funeral services private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANDROS, CELE
description: HANDROS-Cele. The Board of Directors, staff, participants and friends of the Association for the Help of Retarded Children wish to convey our heartfelt condolences to Richard, husband of the late Cele Handros. We grieve Cele's death because she was an important member of the AHRC family, beloved by her colleagues and by the members of the Board of Directors as well. Cele was diligent to a fault in her commitment to work of the highest calibre. She was loyal to her friends and colleagues, as well as to the mission of the Association. Cele was in every possible way the ideal AHRC staff person. AHRC depends on the loyalty, care and diligence of many people, but none more so than Cele. Warm, engaging, amusing, yet passionate in her work and in her belief in the Agency's task, Cele will be deeply missed. It is often easy to say that no person is easy to replace, but it is quite clear that we can never replace Cele. A member of our staff and family for over thirty years, Cele would have been honored at an upcoming NYSARC 50th Anniversary Convention for her three decades of dedication. No honor, no celebration can adequately capture this unique and wonderful person.

title: The Ethicist
description: I write to express my pleasure in your Ethicist column. Most people wish to do the right thing, but our confusing times often make this difficult. So we need some guidance.

title: Losing the Human Factor In Spraying for Mosquitoes
description: For years I have chosen not to spray my home with pesticides. I encouraged my neighbors to look into the risks and alternatives to using pesticides and sprays on their lawns. But the other night I sat at home with my husband, windows tightly shut, our children asleep in their beds, waiting and watching as a helicopter criss-crossed our neighborhood. My property was being coated with malathion.

title: Our Towns; Can Footsteps Flatten A Showroom?
description: MOVIE idea: We see a steaming jungle. It is the Lower Jurassic period, in an area that will one day become the Hudson River Palisades. To the east, the Atlantic coast is just forming, but Manhattan's sparkling armature is still 195 million years distant.

title: Foreign Affairs; Arms Control in 30 Seconds
description: This is a column about why the Senate should ratify the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty. But first, a word about cable TV.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Debate Over Treaty Revisits Old Riddle
description: In debating the historic treaty that would ban all underground nuclear testing, the Senate is reliving one of the most divisive arguments of the cold war: do international arms control treaties enhance or imperil America's nuclear deterrent?

title: F.Y.I.
description: A Playground of Tears

title: Pushkin's Genius
description: To the Editor:

title: Caring for the Lawn, From Bottom to Top
description: THE grass is green again. Rainfall has brought the lawns back. For those skeptics who did not believe that grass goes dormant during the dry summer, the facts are hard to dispute.

title: PULSE; Nails The Color Of Money
description: When Essie Weingarten realized that her national cosmetics supply company, Essie, sounded like the initials for ''stock exchange'' (S. E. Get it?), she started giving her nail polishes such financially correct names as Bonds Beige, Options Pink, Futures French and T-Bills Putty.

title: Q&A/Randolph Scott-McLaughlin; Aiding the Underdog in the Steps of an Idol
description: AS a law student at Harvard University in the early 1970's, Randolph Scott-McLaughlin met his idol, William M. Kunstler, the lawyer who often defended radical causes, and has spent the years since trying to emulate him.

title: To the Edge of Your Seat and Back
description: DID you ever order the ''Extreme Carver'' sandwich at Boston Market? Have you pre-ordered from Amazon .com one of the new books about that Australian yacht race caught in the 1998 storm that killed six people? Does your wardrobe include any of Ralph Lauren's RLX ''technical'' athletic gear, Donna Karan's Ducati line of motocross-inspired men's wear or a Timex Expedition watch, which looks remarkably like a regular Timex except it has the word ''expedition'' on it?

title: Drying Out Waterlogged Homes
description: ONE unsettling reminder of last month's devastating assault by Tropical Storm Floyd has been the sight of soggy furniture along curbs and driveways in suburban metropolitan New York neighborhoods rarely touched by flood waters in the past.

title: City, Suburb, City; Does Fear of Solitude Pull Some Back to 'Jungle'?
description: To the Editor:

title: Nina Rifkind, Marc Lerner
description: Nina Leora Rifkind, a daughter of Dr. Arleen Rifkind and Robert Rifkind of Manhattan, is to be married this afternoon to Marc Harold Lerner, the son of Susan Lerner and Dr. Laurence M. Lerner of Manhattan. Cantor Mark Kula will officiate at the Loeb Boathouse in Central Park.

title: Rebecca Frankfurt, Lee Nadler
description: Rebecca Michelle Frankfurt, a daughter of Kay and Stephen Frankfurt of Westhampton Beach, N.Y., is to be married this afternoon to Lee Warren Nadler, a son of Myron Nadler of New York and the late Jill Isacson-Nadler. Cantor Deborah Stein Davidson is to officiate at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Editorial Observer; Presidential Campaigns of the Rich and Ironic
description: According to Jedediah Purdy, the earnest 24-year-old author of the new book ''For Common Things,'' irony is the scourge of our era -- a smirking, self-knowing stance that serves as a ''marker of worldliness and maturity'' while sheltering us against the betrayals and disappointments of politics. And to think that he wrote that before Jesse Ventura, Warren Beatty and Donald Trump toyed with the Presidential race.

title: He Gets No Satisfaction From Artistic Abstraction
description: ''I WANT to reconnect the man on the street with art,'' says J. Seward Johnson Jr.

title: Serenely Redefining Continental Cuisine
description: ''HELLO, you've reached Camille's fine Continental restaurant . . . '' the recording says at this Carle Place newcomer. What, a 1999 restaurant describing itself as Continental? In recent years that passe label has become a negative one, calling to mind snooty service and fussy, over-sauced food.

title: Before Dying in Stolen Car, Teen-Ager Had Sought Help
description: To Bill Graves and many others at George Washington Carver School here, 14-year-old Kenneth Jackson appeared to live in an in-between world of not quite: not quite neglected in a home where he was constantly at odds with his father and his father's live-in girlfriend, and not quite nurtured to achieve the good things that many of his teachers believed he could.

title: The West Wing
description: DEEP BACKGROUND

title: Rachel Rubin And Eric Cole
description: Rachel Fanya Rubin, a daughter of Judith and Lawrence Rubin of New York, was married last evening to Eric Adam Cole, the son of Thelma and Herbert Cole of Fort Lee, N.J. Rabbi Alfred Gottschalk performed the ceremony at the Park Avenue Synagogue in New York.

title: A Bleak Hour for South Africa Miners
description: For days, the miners listened to the crackle of good news from their battered radios and prayed that the soaring price of gold would save them. But the banner headlines that have thrilled Government officials, economists and mining executives were not enough to stop the layoffs.

title: Cozying Up to the Prairie's Edge
description: FLYING into Winnipeg, the capital of Manitoba, one might wonder where and when it will ever appear. The landscape that leads into the city goes on and on -- miles of flat prairie wheatfields in summer, flat white snow in the winter -- relieved only by a farmhouse here, a hamlet-with-grain-elevator there, and the arrow-straight country roads connecting them.

title: The Yankees Have Established a Certain Tone Among Themselves
description: THE Yankee welcome wagon is not always as overt as Chuck Knoblauch and Derek Jeter donning full catcher's regalia to greet Roger Clemens in spring training.

title: Gore Calls Bradley to More Debates
description: Standing before 3,000 Iowa Democrats and the man who is blocking his path to the Democratic Presidential nomination, Vice President Al Gore tonight challenged former Senator Bill Bradley to an immediate series of debates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCH, MIRIAM
description: FISCH-Miriam. The Yeshiva University family is saddened by the passing of a highly respected member of the Jewish community, beloved wife of the late Marcus Fisch and mother of Suzie (and YU Trustee Joseph) Wilf, YU Benefactors, and Erwin (and Lynn) Fisch, YU Guardians. Miriam Fisch was a Holocaust survivor whose courage and determination saved the lives of her husband and children during the liquidation of the Lvov ghetto and Nazi occupation of Poland. She transmitted her zest for life and love of Judaism and Klal Yisroel to her children, grandchildren, and greatgrandchildren, all of whom she nurtured and adored. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-10-99: On Language; Go Figure
description: The editorialist at The New York Times was scratching his head in unabashed puzzlement at the conflicts within the Reform Party.

title: Paine Award
description: Jimmy Breslin, Newsday syndicated columnist and author, will be the 1999 recipient of the Thomas Paine Journalism Award.

title: Sports of The Times; Which Will It Be: Sudden Fame or Sudden Calamity?
description: THE managers made the moves they make in their sleep without losing a Z. When they had a one-run lead to protect, they made the standard late-inning defensive switch. Except Bobby Valentine's saved the game, while Buck Showalter's cost him the season.

title: City, Suburb, City; Does Fear of Solitude Pull Some Back to 'Jungle'?
description: To the Editor:

title: Reconsidering The Corporate Retreat
description: To the Editor:

title: Pamela Lloyd, Renny Gleeson
description: Pamela Boardman Lloyd, a daughter of Barbara Horwich Lloyd and Boardman Lloyd, both of Cambridge, Mass., was married yesterday to Lawrence Gleeson 4th, a son of Catherine Gleeson and Mr. Gleeson 3d of Belfast, Me. Wilbur A. Levin, a Massachusetts civil marriage celebrant and friend of the bride, officiated at the home of the bride's mother.

title: Night Fever: Staying Alive
description: The lightning bolt can strike twice. The bolt, John Travolta's signature dance-floor pose as Tony Manero, the disco hero in ''Saturday Night Fever,'' has managed to stay alive two decades after the 1977 film's debut. His dance move was recently adopted by Glen Goeis, a writer and director, for ''That's the Way I Like It,'' a Miramax release, due Oct. 15. Set in the 70's, the movie follows a young Singapore couple on the night they enter a dance contest.

title: On Politics; Whitman and Verniero Face Charge of Hiding Information
description: Col. Carl A. Williams spent so many years as a blunt, hard-charging commander in the New Jersey State Police that his career seemed somehow unfinished when he left the force six months ago without making at least one last vainglorious stand.

title: Q & A
description: Holidays in London

title: Nittany Lions Sweat Some, but Still Win
description: Penn State looked hot and bothered. Hot because its game here against Iowa was played in 70-degree weather, nothing like the cool breeze it had left back on its Eastern campus. Bothered because the Nittany Lions kept slipping early and because Iowa kept bouncing back, making them sweat.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: Virginia Woolf

title: Apple Growers Are Testing New Varieties
description: HONEYCRISP, Sunrise, Ginger Gold, Goldrush, Rubinette and other new apples -- including one that is said to taste tropical and some so new that they have no official names yet -- are being grown in orchards around Connecticut. Standbys like McIntoshes and Macouns are definitely not disappearing, but scientists and growers keep experimenting, and more apples are on the way.

title: India Christians in Peril
description: To the Editor:

title: Toothless Satire
description: To the Editor:

title: Scenes From The Millennium
description: Bran Ferren's predictions on the future of computers surpassing human intelligence (''The Creators'') makes doctors, cabbies, lawyers and most other professions obsolete except one: his.

title: Elderly Residents Fear Loss Of Views as Precious as Air
description: Every morning for the last 23 years, Manya Drazhner, an 82-year-old Ukrainian immigrant, has gone to the window of her second-floor apartment and gazed out at the bustling activity at nearby Boston Road and Pelham Parkway.

title: When the Stars Come Out to Play Politics
description: It looks as if Mad magazine is scripting Presidential politics. Donald Trump has announced his Presidential exploratory committee. He is dreaming of Vice President Oprah Winfrey, insisting that if the talk show host runs with him, they will win. The actress Cybill Shepherd is said to be pondering her own chances for the White House. Can Rob Lowe, star of the new NBC drama ''The West Wing,'' be far behind?

title: To Find Goat's Milk and Cheese, Find Some Goats
description: COME autumn, the operative word in food and flavors is hearty. There's probably no menu item that fits the bill quite like goat cheese. Studded with black peppercorns and drizzled with olive oil, warmed and served with Belgian endive, baked in a quiche or sprinkled on a pizza, chevre is hard to ignore and for some, harder still to love.

title: Amy Schatz And Max Rudin
description: Amy Lyn Schatz and Max Rudin were married last evening by Rabbi Marcelo R. Bronstein at the Century Association in New York.

title: In Atlantic City, Suicide Is Casino Gambling's Unspoken Worry
description: The hotel towers of a dozen casinos dominate the flattened landscape. An overpass on the Atlantic City Expressway welcomes visitors to ''America's Favorite Playground!'' With 34 million visits last year -- from busloads of elderly, young hipsters and others who lost $4 billion in the casinos last year -- favorite may indeed be accurate.

title: Paris Opera Debut: 'Pret-a-Porter'
description: Call it the garage sale of the century. Under a huge tent set up on the Place de la Bastille, the Opera de Paris will empty its bulging wardrobes and sell off 10,000 ballet and opera costumes for prices varying from $3 to $160. This is the first such sale by the famous Paris opera house. Culling its collection for lack of storage room, the opera has picked out costumes designed for 120 productions that will never again be performed, ranging from a 1927 ''Rosenkavalier'' to a ''Benvenuto Cellini'' sung in 1993. There are costumes created in 1951 by Erte for Verdi's ''Traviata,'' a glittering ''Carmen'' wardrobe designed by Lila de Nobili in 1959 and one for Serge Lifar's ''Romeo et Juliette'' designed by Georges Wakhevitch in 1955.

title: Ms. Whittemore And Mr. Tartt
description: Margaret Goodhue Whittemore, a daughter of Helen and Reed Whittemore of College Park, Md., is to be married this afternoon in Washington to Mitchell Stewart Tartt, a son of Nancy Willard Tartt and Jo Cowin Tartt Jr., both of Washington. The Rev. Frances Wolf is to perform the ceremony at Grace Episcopal Church in Georgetown.

title: Amy Colson and Eyal Attar
description: Dr. Amy Esther Colson, a specialist on infectious diseases, and Dr. Eyal Chai Attar, a hematology and oncology specialist, are to be married today in Washington. Rabbi M. Bruce Lustig is to perform the ceremony at the Washington Hebrew Congregation.

title: THEATER; His Actors Come First, the Plays Second
description: EUGENIO BARBA'S office is at the top of a typical Scandinavian bare wooden staircase at one end of the Odin Teatret's theater complex in the west of Denmark. It is a small attic room with a sloping ceiling that reflects the A-line architecture of the roof. His window looks over trees and fields used to the brutal winters of northern Europe. This combination of isolation, Nordic endurance and the actors he has gathered around him provide much of what inspires this southern-born Italian, arguably one of the most important theater directors in Europe today.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; A Hallucination in Every House
description: Maxfield Parrish was once the best-known artist in the country; in 1925 about one in four American households, by one estimate, had a reproduction of his painting ''Daybreak,'' a subtly erotic vision of youth set in an Arcadian landscape. From the outset of his career, Parrish hitched his fortunes to the technologically expanding publishing industry, doing his first magazine cover for Harper's Bazaar in 1895 and thereafter earning mass-market popularity with his winsome book illustrations, art posters, calendars, theater sets, murals and paintings -- some, like ''Daybreak,'' specifically commissioned to be reproduced and sold as prints. This unabashed embrace of commercialism, not considered unseemly for a fine artist early in the century, was later reviled by art world arbiters like Clement Greenberg, who wrote severely of Parrish's ''hallucinatory high-octane realism.'' The rise and fall of critical assessment of the artist is the crux of Sylvia Yount's ambitious MAXFIELD PARRISH: 1870-1966 (Abrams/Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts, $39.95); if the case she builds for returning him to an honored place in art history is not airtight, it is certainly meaty. That Parrish had incredible facility as a draftsman and colorist, particularly in some of his wickedly original illustrations for children's books, is evident throughout the vivid reproductions in the book (these images, after all, were largely designed for printing). And Yount discusses how the curator Lawrence Alloway was the first to revive Parrish in a 1964 exhibition as a progenitor of Pop Art, with its playful conflation of art and commerce (Andy Warhol was an avid Parrish collector). Yet Parrish, who by the age of 60 had immersed himself in landscape painting, did his own disparaging at that time: ''There are countless artists whose shoes I am not worthy to polish whose prints would not pay the printer.'' Hilarie M. Sheets

title: GOING OUT
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Stacy Einhorn, Jason Helfstein
description: Stacy Cheryl Einhorn, the daughter of Shelley and Steven Einhorn of New York, was married last evening to Jason Stuart Helfstein, a son of Madalyn and Lewis Helfstein of Head of the Harbor, N.Y. Rabbi Henry M. Weiner officiated at the Pierre in New York.

title: . . . And Through Rural Towns; Antiques and Art Add Sparkle to a Bed and Breakfast Excursion
description: TRAVELERS in search of fall foliage in full glory are on the road these days. And so my husband and I decided to take a weekend excursion in the northeast corner of the state.
