Our two-and-a-half-day exploration took us from Canterbury to Brooklyn to Pomfret and Putnam. No malls, no billboards; along the way we were lulled into another age by old barns, houses and churches as well as vistas of pastures, orchards and graveyards by farmers' old stone walls. Some of the houses have been converted into bed and breakfasts, restaurants and galleries. ''With technology,'' said Sandy Spackman, the owner of Chickadee Cottage, the bed and breakfast we chose in Pomfret, ''people can live in a rural environment, in a bucolic historic setting, work out of their homes and maintain their professions.''

title: In the Flower District, A Crop of High-Rises
description: SEVEN years ago, Manuel Castedo moved his architectural practice into a 24-story loft building at 307 Seventh Avenue, near 27th Street, that was filled with furriers.

title: Learning From Experience: Kittles Wants Knee Healed
description: As the Nets practice, Kerry Kittles casually strolls along the sideline paying no more attention to his team than the public relations assistant who glances intermittently at the court while conversing with the media.

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-10-99; What They Were Thinking
description: June 26, 1999, Coney Island, Brooklyn

title: Center Opened
description: Planned Parenthood Hudson Peconic has opened an expanded center in New Rochelle, its sixth in Westchester.

title: An Entrepreneur's Unlikely Mix
description: MIKE LYNCH would probably have stumped the panel on the old ''What's My Line.'' His twinkly blue eyes, impishly salty language and well-cut suits would point to hard-driving real estate type, maybe, or brash young entrepreneur.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENFIELD, EVA MILLER
description: GREENFIELD-Eva Miller. On October 8, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Loving mother of Eleanor & Henry Lowet, & Susan and Marvin Shapiro. Devoted grandmother of Stephanie and Ames, Peter & Laurie, Jonathan, Robert, Deborah & Tony. Adoring great-grandmother of Benjamin, Naomi, Daniel and Adam. Service on Sunday at 12:45 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions in her memory to the Eva Miller Greenfield Yiddish Music Fund at the Jewish Theological Seminary.

title: FILM; Straining to Live Black
description: I WAS born in 1970, and was lucky enough to be growing up in New York City during hip-hop's childhood. Although I was reared in a nominally Jewish single-parent household in Queens, I grew up writing graffiti on trains, b-boying (breakdancing) and rapping.

title: Ellen Brennan, William Galvin 3d
description: Ellen McAuliffe Brennan, a population specialist at the United Nations, and William Walter Galvin 3d, an investor relations executive, were married yesterday. The Rev. Jeffrey Walker performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REED, DABNEY (FREEMAN)
description: REED-Dabney (Freeman). Of Manchester-By-The-Sea, MA. October 5, 1999, at age 65, formerly of Amherst, MA, and Southampton, NY. Beloved wife of Nathaniel Reed. Loving mother or Wrenn Dabney Reed of Brookline, MA, Priscilla Reed Anderson of Boston, MA, and Timothy Nathaniel Reed of Boston, MA. Sister of Daniel A. Freeman III of Norwell, MA, and Robert W. Freeman of Metamora, MI. She also leaves one granddaughter, Grace Lois Anderson. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, October 13, at 11 AM, at St. John's Episcopal Church, 705 Hale Street, Beverly Farms, MA. Another memorial service will be held in Southampton, NY, on Saturday, October 23, at 10 AM, at St. Andrew's Dune Church, Gin Lane. Burial service will follow at Southampton Cemetery. Friends and family are invited to attend. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in memory of Dabney Reed to The Children's Aid Society, 105 E. 22 St, NYC 10010.

title: Mylinda Hull and Darrin Baker
description: Mylinda Hull and Darrin Baker, actors in New York, are to be married today by Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegal at the Town Club in New York.

title: Rara Avis at G.M.: A Director From Japan
description: When Nobuyuki Idei, Sony's chief executive, was named to the board of General Motors last week, he joined only a handful of other Asian executives who are directors of United States companies. Among the few are Goro Watanabe, vice chairman of Mitsui Chemicals, who serves on DuPont's board, and Minoru Makihara, chairman of Mitsubishi, who is on I.B.M.'s.

title: In the Region /Long Island; Demand for Space Spurs Industrial Construction
description: IN the 10 years since its developer purchased 300 acres of pine woods here, the Heartland Business Center just west of the Sagtikos Parkway has grown to three million square feet of mostly industrial space.

title: October 3-9; Wanted, Whoever He Is
description: Some wanted posters of the future may have no photographs, no names, only strands of DNA, if a Wisconsin prosecutor's charge against an unknown suspect is upheld. And the notion of a time limit for filing criminal charges may go the way of the powdered wig.

title: In a Rough Quarter, a Small Victory for Stock-Picking
description: SEISMIC shifts are often imperceptible in the stock market until well after they have taken hold. But 1999 is looking more and more like the year that index mutual funds lost their star quality.

title: A Bright Addition to a Budding Restaurant Row
description: THE Columbus Park section of Stamford, where the new Girasole Ristorante is situated, is fast becoming a real restaurant row.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHEMAN, JOAN
description: SCHEMAN-Joan. You have encircled our lives with love. You have etched a place in our hearts forever. It is from there that we will find the strength. With love Marty and Randy and Brenda. Dear sister of Madeline Deutscher. Cherished grandmother of Matthew, Alexandra, Martine and Ryan. Services were held October 7, 1999. Shiva being held through Sunday at the home of Martin Scheman. Donations to Mercy Hospice or the American Cancer Society, Long Island division will be appreciated.

title: Doing Your Bidding, Rock Style
description: What do I hear for the leopard-skin spandex pants?

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENTHAL, FRANCES RESSNER BENDER
description: ROSENTHAL-Frances Ressner Bender. In our hearts today as yesterday

title: A New Building for Delaware's Archives Is Going Up
description: JACQUELINE F. SKINNER seemed an unlikely person to push for the construction of an $18-million government building.

title: Report Says Coast Guard Flounders in Rescue Ability
description: In the stormy early hours of Dec. 29, 1997, after an ill-fated decision to abandon the protected waters of the Intracoastal Waterway and head out to the open sea, the captain of the 34-foot sailboat Morning Dew set a course for safe harbor in Charleston, S.C. Neither he nor his three young crewmen would live to see the coming new year.

title: Honoring a Revered Figure At the Expense of Another
description: A proposal to change the name of a middle school in the South Bronx has upset the family of the school's current namesake and has raised questions in the neighborhood about the appropriateness of honoring one person at another's expense.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Say Goodbye

title: Chasing Moonbeams in Sausalito
description: A CLOUD-COVERED sunset turned rippling water pink and then orange as we paddled our two-person kayak into the shallows of Sausalito's Richardson Bay. A baby harbor seal poked his nose out and watched as we lined up next to seven other kayaks, creating a temporary neon-colored raft.

title: A Poor Example
description: To the Editor:

title: What's So Bad About Hate
description: I consider myself fortunate to have read Andrew Sullivan's article (Sept. 26). While I have always been uncomfortable with antigay sentiments directed toward me, I am even more uncomfortable with the idea that I am in need of ''hate crimes'' protections. The proposal of such legislation doesn't make me feel more protected; it merely suggests that I suffer from some special weakness. As much as we may pretend otherwise, I don't think it's in the human genetic code to respect people who are weak and victims. We feel sorry for them, but we don't respect them.

title: Fools for Love From Shakespeare's Pen
description: IF the Newton Schenck main stage at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven were reconfigured into a runway, it could advertise a drop dead gorgeous fashion show, and forget about Shakespearean pretenses. But keep the sets.

title: A Leader's-Eye View Of Leadership
description: LAWRENCE A. BOSSIDY spoke of the value of hiring those who have failed. L. Dennis Kozlowski shook his head at the ''absurd'' valuations of Internet companies, while Charles B. Wang talked about having dot-com envy. Shelly Lazarus defended the $80-million-plus pay package that Hewlett-Packard recently awarded its new leader.

title: City, Suburb, City; Does Fear of Solitude Pull Some Back to 'Jungle'?
description: To the Editor:

title: Taylor Plosser, Richard Davis
description: Taylor Caldwell Plosser, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Gray Plosser Jr. of Birmingham, Ala., was married last evening to Richard Jon Davis, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Davis of West Orange, N.J. The Rev. John Rowan Claypool 4th, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony with Rabbi Laurence A. Schlesinger in the courtyard of St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Birmingham.

title: Ticket Sales Begin For Millennium Dome
description: Starting Jan. 1, visitors to the Millennium Dome now under construction in Greenwich, on the outskirts of London, will be able to see 14 exhibitions -- covering the mind, the body, the environment, faith, money and just about every other aspect of modern existence. The centerpiece will be the Millennium Show, a 28-minute live performance in the middle of the dome in a sunken arena the size of Trafalgar Square that accommodates 12,000 spectators, 5,000 of them seated. The performance involves acrobats, musicians and visual effects illustrating a story of social and political upheaval and forbidden love inspired by Shakespeare, mythology and the Bible.

title: How Best to Run On the Road
description: RUNNING on the road has gotten much easier lately. In most cities, even in Europe, you can traipse through a hotel lobby in your soiled running gear without drawing scorn from staff members or guests. In an elevator, people will ask about your running. The concierge can often help with running information; chances are the hotel will have a fitness center with a treadmill.

title: Layden Tries to Mend Team and Front Office
description: Allan Houston went to Charleston, S.C., last week to ready himself for the coming season. But he also allowed himself some time to remember the surreal events of last season, how the fractured Knicks came together when it mattered.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Not a Happy Country
description: Though a steady stream of memoirs, travel books, investigative reporting and fiction flows toward Western readers from China and Japan, it's hard to name even a handful of titles that provide a cultural window on contemporary Korea. Pak Wanso published her first novel in 1970 at the age of 38 and has since become one of South Korea's most prominent writers of realist fiction. The 10 stories collected in MY VERY LAST POSSESSION: And Other Stories (M. E. Sharpe, cloth, $45; paper, $22.95), written between 1974 and 1995, offer glimpses of a society at once anchored in and imprisoned by strict Confucian mores and buffeted by war, political unrest and massive emigration. In ''Thus Ended My Days of Watching Over the House,'' the arrest of a professor by the secret police tears the careful wrappings of his family's propriety. Allowing his meticulously trained bonsai trees to wither, the professor's wife enjoys a new intimacy with her son and daughter and talks back to her mother-in-law for the first time. Pak seems comfortable with both parable and satire. ''Granny Flowers in Those Heartless Days'' is a two-part moral lesson on the wartime subversion of traditional roles, while the sharp humor of ''A Certain Barbarity'' skewers a family that panders to a rich relative visiting from Japan, pointing up a national relationship marked equally by envy and hatred. In a darker mode, ''Three Days in That Autumn'' is told by a doctor who avenges her own rape every day in her work as an abortionist. Pak's voice may be diffused by the combined efforts of five different translators, but her messages in these stories are vividly focused. Janice P. Nimura

title: Dialects
description: Having lived in Europe for 15 years, where dialects have been barriers to social and political unity for centuries (and are still so in many countries, with highly destructive consequences), I can't see how Fox can arrive at the conclusion that dialects should be nurtured and encouraged rather than allowed to die a natural death. Switzerland? She couldn't have cited a worse example. Economic and political unity there has done nothing to establish social unity. (Speak German in Ticino for a royal reception!)

title: Centennial Concert for Temple
description: WHEN Debbie Friedman, the award-winning cantor, educator, songwriter and purveyor of Jewish music, gives a concert at Temple Beth Abraham in Tarrytown next Sunday at 4 P.M., she will help mark the centennial of the temple. Therein lies a bit of Westchester history.

title: State of the Nation, and of the G.O.P.
description: To the Editor:

title: Dealing with Diabetes in School
description: THE sixth-grade class attended by Catherine Agonis was going on a trip for five days to a nature center in northern Connecticut. Catherine's mother asked teachers if an adult, who knew how to take action if her diabetic daughter's blood sugar dropped, could accompany Catherine. The teachers said no and that Catherine should stay home. Except for teachers, the trip was to include only children, they explained.

title: October 3-9; Train Crash in Britain
description: Britain's worst train wreck in decades provoked soul-searching about safety measures on the national railroad system since it was sold to private investors three years ago. The debate raised the question of whether national assets like the railroads should be shielded from raw market forces and run by the state. The police said more than 70 people were believed to have died in the crash between two trains in west London on Tuesday, and scores more were unaccounted for. ALAN COWELL

title: Political Briefing; Of Gay Marriages, Religion and Speech
description: San Francisco has one of the nation's largest and most politically active gay and lesbian communities. So no issue is hotter in that city at the moment than a statewide initiative to be voted on in 2000 that would bar the state from recognizing gay or lesbian marriage.

title: In the Region /New Jersey; How East Windsor Stemmed a Route 571 Exodus
description: WHEN Lockheed Martin closed its 120-acre space satellite complex off Route 571 in East Windsor last year, it was the latest in a series of moves of commercial tenants caused by mergers or consolidations over the last five years. Their actions threatened to leave about half of the mile-long Route 571 corporate corridor -- 1.9 million square feet of space in the buildings between Route 535 and Route 130 -- a ghost town of sorts.

title: Florida State Uses Warrick's Words
description: Peter Warrick, the Heisman Trophy candidate freshly suspended for grand theft, asked his Florida State teammates before today's game against Miami to focus on the Hurricanes, not on his problems.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELOFSKY, MARY L. (ALSO KNOWN AS MARY L. BELL.)
description: BELOFSKY-Mary L. (Also known as Mary L. Bell.) Age 87, died peacefully in her sleep at 6:10 AM, September 30, 1999. She was the beloved daughter of Goldie and Max Belofsky, the loyal sister of Morris Bell and Lee Chalik, both of whom predeceased her, and of Frances K. Bein, to whom she was devoted all her life. She is also survived by Dr. Martin J. Bell, Susan Sarfati, Michael Chalik, Marc Bein, Dr. Ward Bein, Laura Lind and Louise Harris, her nieces and nephews who kept a special place in their hearts for their feisty Aunt Mary. Their spouses and children will always remember her. To her special friend, George S. Lee, of Lookout Mountain, TN, she leaves beautiful memories of their times together over many years. Mary donated her body for medical research to New York Medical College in Valhalla, NY. At an appropriate time, a memorial service will be held at the home of her sister, Mrs. Abraham C. Bein, in Briarcliff Manor, NY. Family and friends will be notified of the date.

title: Correspondence/Vienna, Rightward; Something's Afoot in Austria, But It Isn't Goose-Stepping
description: WEDGED inside a crowd in Vienna's central square, listening to a politician harangue the throng while 200 student demonstrators behind you scream ''Nazis, raus! Nazis, raus!'' at him, it's important to quell those waves of memory and remind yourself: You don't speak German, stupid. Forget all those black-and-white films you watched as a kid. This isn't ''Triumph of the Will'' even if you're getting the guttural aural cues. It was your father who was in on the Normandy landing; you only caught the flick.

title: Clothes and Hairstyles Do Not a Decade Make
description: THINK smiley faces, perky rust-and-umber polyester sweater vests, Gerald Ford, John Travolta, Carl Bernstein, Chevy Chase, Werner Erhard. When the topic of the 1970's comes up, as it seems to so often these days, thoughts may drift to those obvious icons of the Me Decade. That's one reason that Mark Brazill, a 37-year-old former stand-up comedian turned sitcom writer, is an executive producer and co-creator of the hit Fox series ''That 70's Show.''

title: Ethics Code Update
description: The village of Rye Brook is updating its ethics code, requiring that many village officials and employees make annual financial disclosures. Under the proposed addition to the code, department heads and Board of Trustee members, along with members of the Planning Board, the Zoning Board of Appeals and the Village Clerk, among others, would have to disclose their finances, Charles Peretz, assistant to the Village Administrator, said.

title: Bermuda
description: Bermuda is not only one of the prettiest islands, it is also one of the luckiest. Hurricane Gert spared the island the worst of its powerful winds when it passed by last month. A beach restaurant was damaged, several roads were flooded and trees were toppled, but by the same afternoon businesses were reopening and sightseers were heading for the beaches.

title: Dialects
description: On first reading Margalit Fox's On Language column (Sept. 12), I thought it was a spoof. But on a second reading, I concluded she believes that trying to teach literate American English is a form of racial discrimination.

title: Clement Markert, 82, a Biologist Suspended in the McCarthy Era
description: Clement L. Markert, a noted developmental biologist whose decision as a teen-ager to battle the forces of Generalissimo Francisco Franco in the Spanish Civil War cast a cloud over his career during the McCarthy era, died on Oct. 1. He was 82.

title: Europe's Hip-Hop Isn't an Exact Copy
description: WHEN the French-North African hip-hop troupe Compagnie Kafig comes to New York this week on its first United States tour, its dancers may understand what it must have been like for American ballet companies performing for the first time in France, ballet's original home turf. Kafig has the challenge, after all, of presenting a cross-cultural interpretation of a distinctly American art form to a discerning American audience.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERENZWEIG, ANNE
description: BERENZWEIG - Anne. Loving mother of Jack and Harold and their wives Susan and Ellen. Cherished grandmother of Mindy, Bubba, Steven, Michael and Shana. She was preceded in death by her husband, Sidney.

title: JAMES GRANT
description: As editor of Grant's Interest Rate Observer and eloquent stock market bear, James Grant makes a statement with his briefcase. To himself.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLLARO, SALVATORE J.
description: POLLARO-Salvatore J. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Salvatore J. Pollaro, associated with The Times from 1959 until retiring in 1982.

title: Who's Family? Who's a Guest? A Condo's Rule Draws Criticism
description: While many co-op and condominium buildings have amended old rules on renting out apartments by expanding the definition of family to include unmarried partners, the managers of a building at 150 West 51st Street have moved in the opposite direction. In response, elected officials, including Assemblyman Scott M. Stringer, State Senator Thomas K. Duane and Councilwoman Christine C. Quinn, have raised concerns about possible discrimination against unmarried couples, including gay people.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: WORKING AT PLAY

title: Rapist Who Fled Hospital Surrenders, Ending Hunt
description: A convicted rapist who had escaped from a psychiatric hospital in New Jersey turned himself in last night, ending a statewide manhunt that began Thursday after he escaped in Parsippany.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: The Brass Dolphin

title: What's So Bad About Hate
description: I find much to admire in Sullivan's analysis. Whatever else, hate is always about fear. It is far too seldom that the citizens of this free country choose to know before they act. At issue for the culture is not so much the eradication of hatred; I agree with Sullivan that it can't be done. Answers? I have none. I read, I discuss, I pray, I meditate and use yoga, I exercise, I invest only in green companies and I'm kind to children. Sometimes, I write about it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOA, BRUNO
description: FOA-Bruno. Age 93. Beloved husband, cherished father, grandfather and great grandfather died October 4, 1999 after a short illness. The emotional center of our family, a family shattered and dispersed by the history of the 20th century across Italy, Israel and the United States, we will forever remember him for his warm and gentle heart, his intellect and wisdom, and above all, for his love of life, optimism and singular charm. He was Italy's youngest full professor (in economics) at the age of 28, an early Zionist & dedicated anti-Fascist, he worked with Chaim Weizmann in London in the 1920s and retained a special devotion to Israel. He came to the U.S. in 1940, worked for the Federal Reserve Board, published and wrote on monetary policy & economic reconstruction in Italy, and as a consulting economist, worked with a variety of international clients. He is also survived by his devoted sister Marina Levi, 99, of Milan. A memorial service will be held Sunday, October 10, 2PM at ''Riverside Memorial Chapel'', 180 West 76 Street, New York City. Lisa, Eleanor, Pamela, Paul, Joshua, Jennifer, Jesse, Stephanie, Nora and Sophia

title: Jakarta Sets Up Inquiry Despite Distrust Abroad
description: Indonesia, which invaded East Timor in 1975 and yielded the shattered territory to foreign troops three weeks ago, is organizing a commission to investigate reports of atrocities committed by militia groups and the Indonesian Army.

title: Backtalk; Just a Gust of Wind and Aerodynamics Swirl the Discovery of the Backdraft
description: At age 14, Junior Johnson could drive a car so fast and so well that he was hauling illegal moonshine whiskey from his father's stills in the North Carolina mountains to thirsty customers celebrating the recent end of World War II. This talent for speed made Johnson a natural to join the colorful cast of competitors when stock car racing was born in the South in the late 1940's.

title: The Importance of Matthew Barney
description: It's a sweltering Monday at the Bedford-Stuyvesant armory, a huge vaulted shed, almost the size of a football field, decorated with flags and multicolored bunting. Two men in red wool Canadian Mountie uniforms climb onto a stage in the middle of the room. A woman, 50-ish, bizarrely wasp-waisted (she models for fetish magazines) and dressed in a Victorian costume, with veil and muff, lingers in a corner.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRESS, HARVEY
description: PRESS-Harvey. Beloved husband of Ellen. Devoted father of Steven and Jonathan. Dear brother of Eileen Weiss and Stanley. Loving grandfather of Hannah, Mackenzie and Abigail. Services Monday 12 Noon at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury LI.

title: Inflation Hits the Harvest Celebration
description: FALL is the season of might-have-beens. We might have achieved our ideal weight this summer or the perfect tan. We might have learned to Jet Ski, or have painted the house, or cleared out the garage or trained the dog properly at last. But we didn't, and it's too late. What a relief! Summer's over, and all our good intentions can be put on hold until next year.

title: Footnotes
description: 1. Charles James (1906-1978), shown here in a 1930's portrait by Cecil Beaton, is a legend in American fashion. James's clients included society icons like Babe Paley, Mrs. William Randolph Hearst Jr. and Millicent Rogers, in addition to Dominique de Menil. James was a genius at cut, sculpturing garments with the skill of an engineer. But his mercurial personality and destructive behavior killed his career, and he died penniless at the Chelsea Hotel, in Manhattan.

title: Risky Cancer Therapy
description: To the Editor:

title: Student Housing at Beach Roils Neighbors
description: IT was the last Saturday of the summer, classes were set to begin the following week, and car loads of students drove along Fairfield Beach Road, finally slowing to a crawl and then stopping as they arrived at beach-front houses and condos that will be home for the next 10 months.

title: Specialty That Aids Cancer Patients
description: IF Paul Lupinacci has done his very best work, the result will be unremarkable. That is his goal.

title: Bookend; The Playing Fields of Hogwarts
description: As a boy, I went for many years to the Dragon School in Oxford. The rooms in which we lived were called ''Leviathan'' and ''Pterodactyl'' and ''Ichthyosaurus''; the men who instructed us in dead languages were (through some arcane local custom) known always by their nicknames -- ''Guv'' and ''Plum'' and ''Inky.'' A few of the boys at the school, and they were nearly all boys, had come there from the Squirrel School, down the street; and once we'd mastered our secret runes, we would proceed, as Old Dragons, to another medieval castle, full of dungeons and towers, where boys in black robes, called ''praepostors'' (the word is the source of our own ''preposterous''), would sweep into classrooms at 11:40 each morning to summon malefactors to the headmaster's study.

title: Mexican Hotly Pursues Presidency, Hobbled by a Cool Party
description: Vicente Fox Quesada, a brash-talking presidential candidate with a bold swagger, thinks he can build the frustration among Mexican voters into a runaway victory for the opposition next year.

title: October 3-9; New Life for the F-22
description: Congress will allow the Air Force's $70 billion F-22 fighter jet to proceed to the assembly line, but only if it can pass stringent flight tests. The House and Senate struck a deal under which the F-22, projected to be the most expensive fighter jet ever built at $200 million a plane, will receive $2.5 billion in research and development money this year but none for procurement until it pass a series of hurdles and milestones. TIM WEINER

title: As Usual, Astros Fail And Braves Advance
description: It was another day of celebration for the Atlanta Braves, and another day of frustration for the Houston Astros.

title: Caring for the Lawn, Bottom to Top
description: THE grass is green again. Rainfall has brought the lawns back. For those skeptics who did not believe that grass goes dormant during the dry summer, the facts are hard to dispute.

title: SOAPBOX; A Horse Race in Your House
description: SO you've never been to a racetrack? You've never felt the rush of adrenaline as your dreams of riches ride on the back of a 30-to-1 long shot? And you've never experienced the gnawing of despair as your dollars drain away in race after race in an afternoon of boastful hunches and wishful thinking?

title: Devils Do It With Defense And a Goal By Rolston
description: After allowing seven goals two nights ago in their home opener, the Devils tightened up on defense tonight and all they needed offensively was a goal by Brian Rolston for a 1-0 victory over the Tampa Bay Lightning.

title: Both Sides Now
description: THE MAGIC OF DIALOGUE

title: More Cries, More Whispers
description: BEFORE YOU SLEEP

title: All Eyes to the Sky As Adventurers Find New Thrills
description: BEFORE the opening of the ice skating rink, the regulation hockey rink and a new hotel at the vast entertainment center here known as New Roc City, the Space Shot ride vied with Westchester's first IMAX screen as the main attraction.

title: Deborah Horn, Ronald Wolfson
description: Deborah Lynn Horn and Ronald Wolfson, both history teachers, were married last evening by Rabbi Donald Rossoff at Temple B'nai Or in Morristown, N.J.

title: Britt Neubohn And Philip Hult
description: Britt Adams Neubohn, a daughter of Naneen and Axel Neubohn of London and New York, was married last evening to Philip Eric Hult, the son of Gun Denhart of Portland, Ore., and Bertil E. Hult of Djursholm, Sweden. The Rev. Steven Woolley officiated at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York.

title: At Wesleyan: Whistler's Etchings, Contemporary Works
description: THE two venues for art at Wesleyan University in Middletown complement each other. The Davison Art Center is scholarly and history-minded, while the Zilkha Gallery trafficks in immediacy and often appeals to the senses. Both spaces are at the top of their game right now.

title: A Belated Debut By a Baritone Who's Done It All
description: PIECING together the clues, the astrologically challenged reporter gathers that Sagittarians are orderly, methodical, not to be hustled. At 48, the Oklahoma-born, Paris-based baritone David Pittman-Jennings exemplifies the sign.

title: The New York Times Business Best Sellers
description: HARDCOVER

title: Stepping Beyond the Traditional in Still Lifes
description: 'Still Life'

title: His Life as a Murder Suspect
description: As a graduate student in the Department of Political Science at Yale (where James Van de Velde taught), I read Bennet's article with great interest. I first met Van de Velde at a departmental picnic in September 1998, a few months before the murder of Suzanne Jovin. I found him warm and inviting. Based on my limited interaction with him, however, it would be impossible for me to judge whether or not he could commit such a heinous crime. Under the right circumstances, virtually anyone can become a killer. Still, absent of any evidence produced by the investigators, I believe he has been unfairly banished from the Yale community. In a society where O.J. Simpson is allowed to frolic on a golf course, Van de Velde should be allowed to work as an educator. Our justice system is based on evidence, not suspicion.

title: The 'Hamlet' of Spain, In a Fevered Staging
description: IMAGINE a play that suggests Shakespeare particularly ''Hamlet'' or ''The Tempest'' -- filtered through a Pirandellian prism, with an enormous gilt-edged mirror suspended forbiddingly above the action and a gravel-strewn set providing its own aural soundscape.

title: October 3-9; Return of the Iron Lady
description: Britain's Tories, smarting from their loss to Labor two years ago, have been in need of steeling. So they sent for the Iron Lady. Former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher went to their annual party conference in Blackpool and moved effortlessly to the center stage she had occupied until being ousted from office by Tory rivals in 1990. She may have been too outspoken for the Conservatives then, but not now. Modern day Tories want to hear about British pride and the dangers of encroaching Continentals, and Baroness Thatcher obliged. ''We are quite the best country in Europe,'' she said. ''In my lifetime all the problems have come from mainland Europe, and all the solutions have come from the English-speaking nations across the world.'' WARREN HOGE

title: When the Commercial Theater Moves In on Nonprofits
description: ''MARTIN GUERRE,'' the British musical that has returned more often than, well, Martin Guerre, finally had its American premiere here on Sept. 29. It was the fourth opening for the show, counting its first one in London's West End in 1996, and a climactic night for Alain Boublil and Claude-Michel Schonberg, who first brought the idea to the producer Cameron Mackintosh a full seven years ago.

title: Robert Jumper and Carolyn Farr
description: Carolyn Farr, the daughter of Dr. Roberta Krauthamer of Westport, Conn., and Dr. David Farr of Islip, N.Y., was married last evening to Dr. Robert Duva Jumper, a son of Marie and James E. Jumper of Vallhalla, N.Y. The Rev. Bernard M. Blood, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx, with Rabbi Ari Fridkis taking part.

title: DANCE; A Troupe That Functions on Dreamtime
description: ONLY last month, Djakapurra Manyarryun was back in his homeland, Yirrkala, in a remote region of northern Australia. There, in Arnhem Land, he leads a semitraditional life: hunting local delicacies like kangaroo, snake and goanna (a huge, aggressive lizard), foraging for bush honey and fishing. Mr. Manyarryun is an important cultural custodian of his Aboriginal tribe, a dancer, a singer and a musician (playing the didgeridoo and the clap sticks).

title: A Medical Haven for Indigent Jazz Musicians
description: John Birks (Dizzy) Gillespie, the trumpeter, lived in Englewood from 1964 until his death in 1993. He lent his name to the Dizzy Gillespie Foundation, an organization at Englewood Hospital that provides free medical services to uninsured professional jazz musicians.

title: Losing the Human Factor In Spraying for Mosquitoes
description: First it was ticks carrying Lyme disease, now it's mosquitoes spreading encephalitis. Just when did nature become our enemy? It must have been long ago, for even childhood fairy tales warn of the dangers of untamed wilderness. The Big Bad Wolf may be lurking. So we seek ways to control the wilderness. It feels safe to pave large sections with asphalt and concrete, and then spray chemicals over whatever's left.

title: Risky Cancer Therapy
description: To the Editor:

title: The Shriveled Pit
description: To the Editor:

title: Scenes From The Millennium
description: A footnote to John Russell's excellent essay, ''The News of the Day, on Canvas'': Not only did J.M.W. Turner's ''The Fighting Temeraire'' capture the attention and appreciation of the British public in 1839, but almost 30 years later it seized the imagination of Turner's equal in genius, the American writer Herman Melville.

title: Formal Evening Wear In a Contemporary Setting
description: At Habit, which opened last month in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, shoppers can find contemporary women's clothing, jewelry and accessories from brands including French Connection, BCBG, Laundry and Three-Dot. In a couple of months, the store is to begin offering a new line focusing on formal evening wear, Anna V., designed by Anna Vozzo, one of the store's two owners. The 600-square-foot store is at 231 Smith Street (between Butler and Douglass Streets).

title: Think About the Next Dry Summer
description: Even a wet fall will not reverse the drought's effects on foliage. That makes this a perfect time for unsentimental evaluation: which plants did you water all summer and yet are bedraggled? Unless they're at water's edge, fringe tree (Chionanthus virginicus), sweet pepperbush (Clethra alnifolia) and queen of the prairie (Filipendula rubra) might not belong in a garden with water restrictions in summer. Look for plants that tolerated the drought and thrived, like native bearberry (Arctostaphylos uva-ursi) and witch hazel (Hamamelis virginiana), rugged Rosa rugosa, hybrid epimediums and penstemons, and free-flowering bush clover (Lespedeza thunbergii).

title: Streetscapes/Lexington Avenue and 89th Street; Family That Sought to Set an Architectural Example
description: LAST year the Landmarks Preservation Commission designated the Rhinelander Historic District, six picturesque row houses and a small apartment building at the northwest corner of Lexington Avenue and 89th Street. These joined the six Rhinelander houses at 146-156 East 89th, designated individually in 1979.

title: Starting Small but Dreaming Big
description: AS far as Konstantin Uralsky and Irina Vassileni-Uralsky are concerned, when it comes to dance, small is better.

title: Put No Price on Anguish
description: To the Editor:

title: The View From/Manhattan; A Shorter Commute
description: COMMUTING sometimes resembles an athletic event, where a few tenths of a second separates winners from losers. Those who make the daily trek from Westchester to Manhattan have their activity down to a science, regarding minutes saved and minutes lost as precious commodities.

title: Holiday Tomorrow; Columbus Day, actually Oct. 12, will be legally observed.
description: NEW YORK

title: Climbing Everest Was the Easy Part
description: ULTIMATE HIGH

title: Delegates From Israel and Egypt Share Podium
description: IF Rip Van Winkle (a Westchester resident) awoke from a 20-year sleep this week, he would probably be surprised to see Israel's and Egypt's ambassadors to the United Nations sharing a podium in Scarsdale.

title: BENEFITS
description: Art Party

title: POSTINGS: $4.7 Million Conversion in Riverdale; A Dormitory Is Transformed To Arts Center
description: Now that the $4.7-million Linda M. Lindenbaum Center for the Arts has opened at the Riverdale Country School in the Bronx, art classes have come out of the basement, the band has surfaced from a former garage and the chorus has squeezed out of a former maintenance area.

title: Back to School, 1958
description: Today's statistics tell us nothing's changed, except for the worse. In New York, the school year has started with a failed summer-school program, overcrowding, not enough teachers, endless paperwork and government-mandated social programs that have nothing to do with education.

title: A Gloomy View of Immigration
description: FROM Mississippi to Minnesota these days, there's hardly a heartland city without a Peruvian restaurant, West African hair-braiding place or Korean green grocer. Asians are now the country's fastest-growing ethnic minority group. Hispanic people will soon be the biggest one, outnumbering African-Americans by a wide margin. Nearly one in five children born today has at least one foreign-born parent.

title: Political Puzzle of 2 Texans: Candidate and House Leader
description: There are a couple of leading theories about the relationship between the Texas Republicans who may soon be running the country:

title: Thefts Plague Wisconsin's North Woods
description: Wheeling the car down the sloped pathway through a forest of soaring oak and pine trees, John Sobolewski glimpsed his beloved old cedar cabin, and noticed the door had been left open.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEEDS, ALFRED B.
description: LEEDS-Alfred B. At age 76. Of Delray Beach, Florida and Swan Lake, N.Y. Passed away October 4, 1999. Born in Brooklyn, NY, on March 24, 1923. He was a veteran of World War II, a successful businessman and in later years active in Jewish Genealogy, serving as Co-President of the Jewish Genealogical Society of Palm Beach County. He is survived by his wife of 51 years Gloria, son Alan, daughter Barbara, sisters Sophia & Isabelle & four grandchildren Mark, Shanna, Paige & Benjamin. His twin brother Jesse passed away previously. His presence in the world made life richer for an enormous number of people. His family & many friends will dearly miss his love, kindness, courage, integrity, optimism and his extraordinary generosity of spirit.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: Corrections
description: The Good Eating column last Sunday misstated the New York Times rating of the Canal House restaurant. It received two stars, not four, on Aug. 8, 1997.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWSOM, PEARL
description: NEWSOM-Pearl. Died October 8, 1999 in Rancho Bernardo, CA, age 90. Beloved wife of Philip Newsom and widow of Arthur Silverstone. Loving mother of Sandra Stern and Paul Silverstone. Devoted grandmother of Michael and Darice Stern, Wendy and Jeffrey Kohn, Peter and Lora Stern, and Valery and Joel Hector. Greatgrandmother of Jordan, Toni and Tessa Kohn, Jared Stern and Max Hector. Sister of Edith Rosebourne. Services private.

title: Richard Washburn 2d, Carolyn Foley
description: Carolyn Margaret Foley, a daughter of Mary Lou Foley of New Bedford, Mass., and the late Joseph F. Foley 3d, is to be married this afternoon to Richard Horace Washburn 2d, a son of Christine Bett Lewis of Yardley, N.J., and Richard Stevenson Washburn of Pineville, Pa. The Rev. Michael S. Racine is to perform the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in South Dartmouth, Mass.

title: Something for the Market Basket
description: Although the Finger Lakes region has 57 producers, the wines are sold mostly upstate, with New York City getting few. Two exceptions are the whites and reds of Anthony Road and Hunt Country, which are sold Saturdays at the Union Square Greenmarket.

title: The Next Big Thing
description: STILL THE NEW WORLD

title: The Stock Market And Social Security
description: Turning to Wall Street for help may not solve Social Security's potential problems, a group of researchers has found.

title: Chechnya's Chief, Under Fire, Takes a Fighting Stand
description: The Chechen leader, Aslan Maskhadov, a former colonel in the Soviet Army, is a gray-haired man of restrained manner. Dressed in camouflage uniform, sitting on a sofa, he issues firm orders to his men in a low voice in the Chechens' urgent, hiccuping language.

title: October 3-9; Interest Rates Hold
description: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, is in a tough spot. Traditional economic models say the economy is so strong that there is a danger of inflation, but in the real world inflation is almost non-existent. So Mr. Greenspan held interest rates steady, but hedged his bets by hinting that the Fed could push rates up as soon as next month. Even the hint was enough to give Wall Street a case of the jitters. RICHARD W. STEVENSON

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GELLMAN, ARCHIE
description: GELLMAN-Archie. October 11, 1960. Beloved father, eternally missed. Gloria and Howard

title: October 3-9; A Step Back For Genetic Engineering
description: Monsanto Company, the biggest name in agricultural biotechnology, pledged not to market a controversial product that does not yet exist: seed genetically altered to produce infertile crops. Such seed would put a stop to farmers saving seed from their harvest for replanting the next year, giving biotech companies a better shot at selling them new seed annually. Monsanto does not currently control the rights to the technology and some scientists say it will never work outside of the laboratory, but it has already become so infamous that Monsanto decided to repudiate it. Biotechnology critics, referring to it as ''Terminator genes'' or ''suicide seeds,'' have been using it as a potent symbol for everything they oppose in agribusiness.

title: A Pizzeria That Is More Than Just Pizzas
description: NOT all storefront pizza restaurants are created equal. The trick for discerning diners is to figure out which ones are no more than glorified snack stands that cater to schoolchildren who want a slice or two and which ones are reasonably serious restaurants.

title: Habitats/Callicoon, N.Y.; Of Time and the River, And a Dream House
description: ED and Joyce Sykes have lived for decades in or around Callicoon, N.Y., a small town in the Catskills about two hours northwest of New York City. Surrounded by mountains, with the Delaware River at its feet, the town draws people to weekend homes, to a place so peaceful that the loudest noise is the hum of a refrigerator.

title: State of the Nation, and of the G.O.P.
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGOVERN, MARIE V. (NEE GOUGH)
description: McGOVERN - Marie V. (nee Gough). Of Irvington, New York on October 7, beloved wife of Joseph W., mother of Marie Therese Melillo, Raymond, Joseph, Philip & Lawrence. Sister of Virginia Kutner and the late Anne Madigan, Rev. Lawrence Gough, & Rev. Raymond Gough, S.J. Grandmother of 22, Great grandmother of 7. Mrs. McGovern was a trustee of Fordham Preparatory School, College of Mount Saint Vincent and Manhattan College & served as a member of the NYC Landmarks Commission. Visiting will be Sunday and Monday 2-4 & 7-9, Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Ave. (exit 17 Saw Mill), Dobbs Ferry, NY. Mass of the Resurrection, 10 AM, Tuesday at Church of the Immaculate Conception, Irvington, NY. Contributions in her memory to Catholic Charities of the NY Archdiocese or Catholic Relief Services.

title: Elegy to a Dumpscape
description: If the Fresh Kills landfill, on Staten Island, closes at the end of 2001 -- for reasons that have as much to do with politics as they do with antiquation -- it will close exactly half a century after it was supposed to. Robert Moses, New York's Cheops, had a plan to fill a wetland with garbage and then attract development to the new acreage the landfill created. But, as parents always tell their adolescent children, garbage attracts only garbage. Imagine Central Park buried in New York City waste to a depth of 155 feet, and not one but three and a half contiguous Central Parks. That's the size of Fresh Kills now, more than big enough for the burying of political reputations; nearly big enough to be a sixth borough.

title: Court Is Moving Back Into the Neighborhood
description: Teresa Cama, a lifelong resident of Red Hook, Brooklyn, stood outside her home on Visitation Place and recalled the days when the long-vacant brick building across the street was a Roman Catholic elementary school.

title: Mara Trager, Isaac Koyfman
description: Mara Emet Trager, a daughter of Dr. Roberta E. Weisbrod and Judge David G. Trager of Brooklyn, is to be married this evening at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden to Isaac Koyfman, a son of Frieda Koyfman and Dr. Simon Koyfman of Brooklyn. Judge Edward R. Korman of Federal District Court in Brooklyn will officiate at the ceremony, in which Cantor Larry Magarik will take part.

title: City, Suburb, City; Does Fear of Solitude Pull Some Back to 'Jungle'?
description: To the Editor:

title: Sir Nigel Broackes, 65, British Entrepreneur
description: Sir Nigel Broackes, a real estate developer who controlled the Ritz Hotel in London as chairman of Trafalgar House and was one of Britain's most successful young entrepreneurs during the 1960's and 1970's, died on Sept. 28. He was 65 and lived in Oxfordshire.

title: Women's Work
description: THE BOOK BORROWER

title: It's Not So Simple
description: To the Editor:

title: Birthday Rally for Sharpton, Still Shy and Modest at 45
description: THE SETTING -- The event was not scheduled to begin until 7 P.M. But when the doors opened at Canaan Baptist Church at 6:05, a line of well-wishers stretched down half of 116th Street from Malcolm X to Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevards. They came dressed to the nines in furs, silk, dashikis and hats: tilted hats, multicolored hats, hats with feathers, sequined hats.

title: Alexis Donnelly And Oren Glick
description: Alexis Cahill Donnelly, the daughter of Ellen Cahill Donnelly of New York and Robert E. Donnelly of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., was married last evening to Oren Glick, a son of Erika and Barry Glick of Franklin Lakes, N.J. The Rev. James F. Keenan, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Sagpond Vineyards in Sheaponack, N.Y., with Rabbi Roger Ross taking part.

title: Elizabeth Hickey, Jonathan Selwood
description: Elizabeth York Hickey, the daughter of Anne Ewing Hickey and James C. Hickey of Louisville, Ky., was married there yesterday to Jonathan Gunn Selwood, the son of Alexis Fuerbringer Selwood and Pierce T. Selwood of Los Angeles. The Rev. Dr. Nancy Ramsay performed the ceremony at the Crescent Hill Presbyterian Church.

title: On Baseball; Understudy Takes Center Stage
description: In the fourth inning, the Mets had a runner at second base and two out. Todd Pratt grounded out. In the sixth inning, the Mets had runners at second and third and two out. Todd Pratt grounded out. In the eighth inning, the Mets had runners at first and third and one out. Todd Pratt grounded out.

title: Morris Pashman, 87, Champion of Free Speech on New Jersey's Highest Court
description: Former Justice Morris Pashman of the New Jersey Supreme Court, whose opinions touched on areas from freedom of the press to the rights of the mentally handicapped, died on Oct. 3 at a hospital in New York City. He was 87 and lived in Clifton, N.J.

title: Literate Europeans
description: To the Editor:

title: Political Briefing; On the Same Ticket, If Not the Same Team
description: In Colorado, nominees for governor do not get to choose their running mates. Rather, at the same time each party holds a primary to choose its candidate for governor, it holds a separate primary to pick its candidate for lieutenant governor.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: OF TIME AND MEMORY

title: Look Who's Modern Now
description: IN 1988, I completed a book-length monograph on contemporary American fiction for Volume 7 of the Cambridge History of American Literature. This summer, it was published. Eleven years from pen to print? No, this isn't a joke, and no, I'm not bitter. Sometimes there's value in having to rewrite a book three times in order to weigh in on the fast-fleeting now.

title: Reading, Writing, 'Rithmetic and Sniffles?
description: Back-to-school season is usually a bonanza for suppliers of products like notebook paper, No. 2 pencils and crayons. But Kleenex?

title: State of the Nation, and of the G.O.P.
description: To the Editor:

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-10-99: The Ethicist; Apothecary Query
description: It seems unethical for Wal-Mart, which does sell guns, to refuse to sell Preven, a morning-after contraceptive. Would I be in the right to protest Wal-Mart's policy? After all, my bookstore doesn't carry every book.

title: Using Steel Frames For Homes
description: THE vast majority of the houses built in the United States today are constructed with wood. About 85 percent of that wood is used for framing. Since wood has been the primary building material since Colonial times, it might seem that there is no reason for change, but wood has its drawbacks.

title: Grand Openings
description: Carnegie Hall begins a new season and the Russian Tea Room reopens its doors.

title: A Master Everywhere Else Is Ready to Try America
description: COULD it be that one of today's most important film artists -- the critic J. Hoberman calls him ''the world's greatest active narrative filmmaker'' -- is a Taiwanese director virtually unknown here?

title: The Next Cardinal
description: One day this summer John Cardinal O'Connor ordained a new bishop at St. Patrick's Cathedral. He dipped his fingers in oil and held them to the man's head; in that moment, James McCarthy from White Plains became a successor to the Apostles. As the new bishop rose from his knees, dozens of other bishops converged in the sanctuary and hugged him. The people in the pews, as if speaking a different language, just applauded.

title: 50's Riddle Returns in Treaty Debate
description: In debating the historic treaty that would ban all underground nuclear testing, the Senate is reliving one of the most divisive arguments of the cold war: do international arms control treaties enhance or imperil America's nuclear deterrent?

title: Mets Remain Hopeful Piazza Will Be Back
description: Mike Piazza spent a second day on the bench nursing his still swollen and stiff thumb, 48 hours after receiving a cortisone injection that caused an inflammatory reaction.

title: Dana Goldberg, David Woloch
description: Dana Karen Goldberg, the daughter of Rosalie and Richard Goldberg of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married last evening to David Martin Woloch, a son of Nancy and Isser Woloch of Manhattan. Rabbi Anne Ebersman performed the ceremony at the Space, a photography studio in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKER, JOEL J.S.
description: PARKER-Joel J.S. Of Hilton Head Island, SC died at his home on Thursday, October 7. He was 68 years old. Mr Parker was born in Washington, DC; was educated at the Norwood School, Lake Placid, NY and at Colgate University. His father, Philo W. Parker, was Chairman of the Standard Vacuum Oil Company and Chairman of the Board of Trustees at Colgate. Joel Parker was for many years a resident of Bronxville, NY where he was a respected community leader, serving variously as Town Councilman, Fire Commissioner and President of the Chamber of Commerce. He was a member and past Governor of the Siwanoy Country Club and President of the Bronxville Field Club. Since moving to Hilton Head in 1992, Mr. Parker served on the Beaufort County Transportation Committee, the Town of Hilton Head Land Bank Commission and was active in other humanitarian organizations. He was a member of the Sea Pines Country Club, served on its Golf Committee, and was honored to be appointed an 18th hole announcer at the Annual MCI Heritage Golf Tournament. He also served as a Governor and Secretary of the Hilton Head Island Senior Men's Golf Association. He was a real estate broker associated with The Sea Pines Real Estate Company and held CRS and GRI degrees. He is survived by his beloved wife, Diane Aspinall Parker, by his daughters Cynthia Landis of Plymouth, MN and Dana Rogers of Boulder, CO. Also by a son, Joel Jr. of Copallis Beach, WA and by his brother, Peter Parker, of Rochester, NY. He is predeceased by his other son, Stephen H. Parker, who died in 1997. Hilton Head has lost a most valued friend and citizen. A memorial service will be held at the Providence Presbyterian Church on Monday, October 11 at 2PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions to American Hospice Care, 41 Goethe Road, Bluffton, SC 29910 would be greatly appreciated by the family. For more information contact the Island Funeral Home.

title: Sprewell and the Knicks Finally Schedule a Talk
description: Latrell Sprewell could use a good icebreaker to cut the tension bound to fill the room when the Knicks' coach, Jeff Van Gundy, and general manager, Scott Layden, meet with him on Sunday.

title: That MCI Deal Sure Ain't Chump Change
description: It's almost too mind-boggling. Six of the 10 largest announced merger and acquisition deals have been in the telecommunications industry and have totaled nearly half a trillion dollars, according to the Securities Data Company, which tracks such activity. No surprise, then, that last week's $115 billion acquisition of the Sprint Corporation by MCI Worldcom Inc. is the granddaddy of them all.

title: O'Neill, Sore Ribs Not Improving, Is Afraid He May Be Out Indefinitely
description: Paul O'Neill, the Yankees' right fielder, was out of the starting lineup for Game 3 tonight because of bruised ribs, and he feels he will be out indefinitely unless he improves quickly.

title: Ports of Call In Chelsea
description: BRIGHT FOOD SHOP+

title: Where W. Got Compassion
description: To deal with serious social problems like illiteracy, drug abuse and mental illness on a long-term basis requires an enunciated public policy that no collection of religious do-gooders can ever implement. It takes a sustained effort by government to elevate the least fortunate in our society to a point where everyone can participate at a level of competence.

title: Beats From the Streets
description: Everything about Evelyn Glennie's ''Street Songs'' tour with the King's Singers, which stops at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center Thursday, says streetwise. The charismatic, hearing-impaired Scotswoman, who virtually invented the show-biz percussion recital, teamed with the popular English male sextet on a recording, ''Street Songs,'' which the tour publicizes.

title: PERSONAL BUSINESS; Back at Work But Never Far From Family
description: THREE years ago, I closed my old black-and-white laptop. My intention was to back off from my job as a freelance financial writer for a few months so I could spend more time with my children.

title: From Five Retirement Portfolios, Another Vote for Diversification
description: A VOLATILE stock market was particularly punishing to big growth stocks and value issues in the third quarter, while many small stocks and overseas investments fared better. That gave an edge to investors with diversified portfolios, including the five money managers who have assembled hypothetical retirement portfolios for The New York Times.

title: With Most at Safe Distance, U.S. Troops Start Role in East Timor
description: The United States military has arrived in East Timor in force, although the bulk of its troops participating in the international peacekeeping mission here will remain safely aboard a warship in the waters off this looted, burned-out shell of a city.

title: Anti-Bias Task Force Says No to a Pilgrim
description: AS a symbol of bigotry, it is hardly a burning cross or a white-hooded rider. But the official anti-bias watchdogs of the Town of Southampton are campaigning for a revision of the town's official seal, a 70-year-old design which appears on town documents and road signs.

title: October 3-9; India's Hindu Party Gains A Solid Victory
description: When election returns were counted in India, the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party emerged in a commanding position, able to lead a centrist coalition of 24 parties that offered hope that India would now have a durable government, rather than the shaky one that the party had been leading. The big loser was the once-dominant Congress Party, which had hoped to return to power but suffered a humiliating defeat instead.

title: Correction
description: A brief report in the Private Sector column last Sunday about the election of Christine Lagarde as chairman of Baker & McKenzie referred incorrectly to her status among the 20 largest law firms in the country. Ms. Lagarde, who was elected last Thursday, is not the only woman to lead one of these firms. Mayer, Brown & Platt, the nation's ninth-largest firm by revenues, also has a woman, Debora de Hoyos, as its leader, with the title of managing partner.

title: Roosevelt's Pettus Tops Defenders and Troubles
description: Jerone Pettus was dazed by a blow to the head in the third quarter and then was cramping so badly in the fourth quarter that he needed to be stretched after almost every play. But it was not until he saw his teammates celebrating Roosevelt's 19-13 victory over Malverne High School that he was stopped, speechless, with tears in his eyes.

title: Worst View in the State? Now Stop That
description: DEAR whoever's in charge of naming stuff in this state:

title: No Longer Also-Rans, Overseas Stocks Surpass U.S. Brethren
description: SOME managers of international funds are beginning to remember what winning feels like. But just barely.

title: A New Loft Scene? Word of Mouth, B.Y.O.B. and Jazz
description: In the mid-1970's, a profusion of jazz groups plied their trade in lofts and galleries in lower Manhattan in a phenomenon that became known as the loft movement. It fizzled in the early 80's, but two New Yorkers have recently stepped into the breach with a weekly jazz party they call ''Sunday sessions.''

title: October 3-9; A Presidential Visit To the Teamsters
description: For decades, American Presidents have shied away from meeting with leaders of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters because of that union's malodorous past. But President Clinton cast such caution aside by attending a dinner honoring James P. Hoffa, the union's new president and the son of its most famous leader. Union officials say Mr. Clinton spoke at the dinner in the hope of persuading the teamsters to endorse Vice President Al Gore. White House officials say the President appeared at the dinner because the teamsters union is such a large, important organization. These officials also noted that thanks to a 10-year Federal cleanup, the union is far less corrupt than it used to be. STEVEN GREENHOUSE

title: Colonie Girls Slip Past Saratoga Springs for Title
description: Colonie High School of Albany beat its upstate New York rival, Saratoga Springs, to capture the Girls Eastern States Championship yesterday in the Manhattan College cross-country invitational at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx by 59-61.

title: This Old House
description: GAP CREEK

title: For a Priest and for Poland, a Tangled Identity
description: Past the ditches where thousands were executed by the Nazis, the crematory described as having ''a daily yield of about 1,000 bodies,'' the gas chamber being visited by a group of Israeli schoolchildren, the priest walks in silence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURKEWITZ, GRACE
description: TURKEWITZ-Grace. My beloved and esteemed cousin. Her warmth and supportive friendship were always a source of strength and pleasure for me. Sunny

title: I'll Take a Havana, Good Humidor Man
description: CIGARS and ice cream are usually not easily confused. But when Jonathan K. Osmun pulls up in his white step van, honks the horn and slides open the service window, customers asking for the flavors of the day sometimes do a double take when the answer is Scotch, Amaretto and cognac rather than chocolate chip or cookies and cream. Neither cones nor cups are available. His oversized coolers are fitted with humidifiers, not ice.

title: Ideas & Trends; In E-Commerce Frenzy, Brave New World Meets Old
description: WHEN Amazon.com declared two weeks ago that it was beginning a bold campaign to become an Internet shopping bazaar, Wall Street applauded. And why not? Amazon, a corporate poster child of the New Economy and pioneer of on-line retailing, would be collecting money from any business, large or small, that wanted to set up shop under its cyber-tent.

title: Where W. Got Compassion
description: Compassionate conservatism (David Grann, Sept. 12) appears to be a combination of Marvin Olasky's encounters with Communism, Judaism and atheism, along with a smattering of egotism and myopia. Olasky looks a little like Harry Potter grown up, and that's enough to take the magic out of any movement.

title: Buoyed by the Promise of Strong Earnings
description: With the enthusiasm of bloodhounds catching the scent of fleeing prey, investors sniffed the promise of record third-quarter earnings and sent markets to their best gains since July.

title: JERSEY DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Watching Time Go By, on Multicolored Wheels
description: Jose DeJesus's eyes danced over the Muhammad Ali clock, the Fisher-Price clock, the Andy Warhol 15-minute clock and the hundreds of other time-related knickknacks glued to the van in front of Dean & Deluca at Broadway and Prince Street on a recent afternoon. ''I am amazed,'' said Mr. DeJesus, 32, a delivery man for a photo lab.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STAMM, SHIRLEY
description: STAMM-Shirley. On October 8, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Jack Stamm. Dear mother of William and Howard. Cherished sister of David Fischer. Services today October 10th, 11:30am at ''The Riverside'' 76th St & Amsterdam Ave.

title: His Life as a Murder Suspect
description: I finished James Bennet's article (Sept. 12) and immediately reread it, certain that I must have missed something the first time. But after my second reading, the question remains: Why is this man a murder suspect? The article does not so much as hint at a shred of evidence linking him to the crime.

title: Melissa Pantel and Raymond Ku
description: Melissa Elena Pantel, a daughter of Dr. Ernestine Pantel and Dr. Jordan Pantel of Ardsley, N.Y., is to be married this afternoon to Raymond Ku, the son of Dr. Laureen Ku and Henry Ku of Oceanside, N.Y. Rabbi Harold S. White is to perform the ceremony at the Church Center for the United Nations in Manhattan.

title: Cecilia Powers, Stephen Owen
description: Cecilia Powers, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Powers of Farmington, Conn., was married yesterday to Stephen Bates Owen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen C. Owen of New York. The Rev. Andrew C. Mead performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York, where he is the rector. The Rev. Joseph Kelly, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GITENSTEIN, MILTON P.
description: GITENSTEIN-Milton P., age 87. Suddenly on October 7, 1999. Son of the late Israel and Rose Gitenstein. Loving and beloved husband of 57 years of Bernice (Narins) Gitenstein. Devoted father of Deborah C. Brudno (David Bernstein), Judith A. Gitenstein, Henry J. Gitenstein (Harriet), and the late Ross George Gitenstein. Proud grandfather of Eric and Maxwell Gitenstein. Caring brother and uncle. A gentle and compassionate man, he was a good friend who touched many lives with his generosity of spirit and his devotion to social causes. He will be greatly missed. Funeral services will be held on Monday, October 11th at 11AM at Community Synagogue of Rye, 200 Forest Ave., Rye, NY. 914-967-6262.

title: Back to School, 1958
description: I think it is ironic that Frank McCourt is so opposed to vouchers, when he benefited from the oldest voucher system in the United States -- the G.I. Bill (Sept. 12). I used the bill to earn a Ph.D. from Yale. I spent my entire career teaching in the public schools and as dean of a state university. I am convinced that choice is a vital factor in education. If parents are able to choose a school, they will make sure that it is doing a good job.

title: FILM: UP AND COMING -- Shawn Hatosy; Down to Earth but Rising
description: ALEC Baldwin, who should know, says that 23-year-old Shawn Hatosy is ready for stardom: ''He has that quality you have to have in America to be a movie star -- half altar boy, half bank robber.''

title: Look Closer to Home For Sources of Noise
description: To the Editor:

title: Womack Left To Chase Down A Bad Memory
description: Tony Womack sat hunched over in a folding chair in front of his locker in the silent visiting clubhouse at Shea Stadium yesterday. Facing an empty wall, the Diamondback outfielder wore a vacant stare, his teeth clenched.

title: If Offense Is Up, It's Because Pitchers, Not the Ball, Are Wound Tighter
description: Conspiracy theorists won't buy it, but Major League Baseball has conducted tests that show the baseball was not the reason baseballs flew out of and all over ball parks in record numbers again this season.

title: The View From/Brookfield; A Teacher's Lawsuit: Free Speech or Libel?
description: VERONICA BERRILL, 73, seems an unlikely plaintiff in a libel lawsuit that is expected to go to trial later this month in Danbury Superior Court. A mother of seven and an English teacher for more than 20 years at Brookfield High School, she describes herself as someone with ''a lot of faith in God.'' Colleagues have said she is sweet, gentle and basically unflappable.

title: Community Activists In Norwood
description: To the Editor:

title: Ideas & Trends: Brute Force Over Cunning; Going, Going, Yawn: Why Baseball Is Homer-Happy
description: MAJOR league baseball teams have padded their considerable coffers in recent years by linking corporate sponsors to almost every play in the game, from the ''AT&T call to the bullpen'' to a ''National Arbitration and Mediation umpires lineup.'' (No kidding; it's a dispute-resolution business.) If baseball wants a perfect corporate match, however, it should call the folks over at Anbesol and pitch a tie-in for home runs, because we're getting a little numb to it all.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE TAR, VERNON L.
description: de TAR-Vernon L., 94, died on Thursday, Oct. 7, 1999, at Kendal at Longwood, Kennett Square, PA. A 1927 graduate of Syracuse University. He was on the faculty at the Juilliard School, Union Theological Seminary, Yale University Institute of Sacred Music. He was the organist and choirmaster at Church of th Ascension, NYC, from 1939-1981. Husband of the late Irene de Tar; survived by daughter, Nina A. Fuller, three grandchildren, two great grandchildren. Memorial service will be held at 1 PM on Saturday, Oct. 16, at Church of the Advent, Kennett Square. Memorial contributions: Kendal Music Program, PO Box 100, Kennett Square, PA 19348; Music Program, Church of the Advent, 401 N. Union St., Kennett Square, PA 19348; or Organ Fund, Church of the Ascension, 12 West 11th St., NY, NY 10011.

title: Hudson River Grant
description: Gov. George E. Pataki has a new grant program to protect and preserve natural resources in the Hudson River Estuary.

title: Special Funds For Special Customers
description: WHO says gambling doesn't pay?

title: The Garde Returns to Life, Again
description: EVEN though the theater originally opened in 1926 -- when movie palaces were movie palaces -- who's to argue with what management calls the ''premiere season'' of the Garde Arts Center in New London?

title: In the New World of Euro Arts
description: PICK your Europe, any Europe. Postcards and Eurail passes; monarchy and empire; the world wars and the cold war; the French Revolution of 1789 and the ''velvet revolution'' of 1989; the persisting ghosts of Churchill, de Gaulle and Marx; of Picasso, Lorca and Diaghilev. Pick your soundtrack: Janacek, Stravinsky, Brel or Bartok. Or the Wagnerian scoring of a compounded realpolitik too brutal and surreal to bear. Europe in the 20th century has been a riveting Grand Guignol in history's music hall, bloody, clamoring, irresistibly resurgent, always back with a second act.

title: Dialects
description: There is a reason to teach standard English to black, inner-city teen-agers: so that they can interact with the English-speaking world, not just with their peers in the ghetto. Walter Cronkite can so interact; that's why his English is, yes, superior to that of black teen-agers. And that's why it should not be withheld from them. Telling teen-agers that slovenly syntax don't make no never-mind ain't, like, no favor; it just insures that another generation will be stuck on the bottom rung of the economic ladder.

title: Collaborating Authors
description: To the Editor:

title: Uncluttered and Calm Spot in White Plains
description: IN the large dining room, two tall, thin ficus trees cannot replace the charm once supplied by pots of plants and baskets of greenery, which all but covered the ceiling. But the now uncluttered brick walls, well-spaced tables and dim lighting remain, offering serenity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHECHTER, MARSHALL
description: SCHECHTER - Marshall. The Board of Directors and the Staff of The Evan B. Donaldson Adoption Institute extend their heartfelt condolences to the Schechter family upon the loss of Dr. Marshall D. Schechter. Dr. Schechter was an exceptional professional who contributed profoundly to the advancement of our understanding of adoption and a warm and generous gentleman who graced our lives. He provided leadership and guidance to the Institute in immeasurable ways. He will be deeply missed. Curtis R. Welling President of the Board Madelyn Freundlich Executive Director

description: Three bags containing parts of a man's body were found outside an industrial park on Friday morning in Queens, the police said yesterday.

title: From Kittens to Kilts to Hacked Heels
description: Michael Kors's affection for the jet set, whether in Palm Beach or St.-Tropez, might have produced the most hilariously atrocious results (tiaras in the afternoon, white mink in the cabana) if this American designer wasn't such a practical dreamer.

title: Lives; The Knockdown
description: I assumed the old woman was unkind. I had seen her many times in my Cambridge neighborhood, walking her dog, Honey, a tiny mutt with withered legs and a tawny coat that looked threadbare. Whenever she saw me with my dog, she crossed to the other side of the street, shuffling along in her slippers. ''Come on, Honey,'' she would mutter. She never smiled or said hello.

title: I.R.S. IS ALLOWING MORE DELINQUENTS TO AVOID TAX BILLS
description: Understaffed and caught in a set of mixed signals from Congress, the Internal Revenue Service for more than a year has let many tax delinquents go without paying tax bills that total billions of dollars.

title: Margo Alexander, Shepard Murray
description: Margo Ellen Alexander, a daughter of Dr. Gail F. Alexander of Dallas and Dr. Martin M. Alexander of Greenwich, Conn., is to be married this afternoon on Martha's Vineyard to Shepard Paul Murray, a son of Nancy Steinmetz Murray and Stanley H. Murray of Greenwich. The Rev. Joel Baehr, a Unitarian Universalist minister, is to perform the ceremony at the Old Whaling Church in Edgartown, Mass.

title: In Jackson Hole, the Grazing Takes a Sophisticated Turn
description: ENSCONCED near the Teton Range to the northwest and the Gros Ventre Range to the northeast, Jackson Hole remains relatively isolated, and its 6,500 year-round residents take brawny pride in their rugged Shangri-La. For hunters, fishermen, rafters, skiers and hikers, this piece of Wyoming is indeed a paradise. And in recent years, a lively restaurant scene has joined the list of enticements.

title: With Ruffles And Flourishes
description: Mick Jagger wore one. So did Jimi Hendrix. Ruffled shirts have been in -- but mostly out -- of vogue since the late 60's, but the look is no longer reserved for prom victims and flamboyant guitar heroes. With the most hyped of all New Year's Eves approaching, designers are showing ruffles as a more festive alternative to staid pleats for dress shirts and as flashy sportswear to keep that celebratory spirit all day long. Short-sleeved ruffled tuxedo shirts from Prada's Pre collection will arrive at Barneys next month in colors like pink and lavender in lightweight nylon ($490). D&G included a rowdy pink and green floral ruffled tuxedo shirt in its fall and winter 2000 runway show and is selling more subdued white ones ($300). Tommy Hilfiger's spring 2000 collection featured a white ruffled cotton evening shirt with appliqued flowers and crystals.

title: Despite Local Fears A Motel Gets a Go-Ahead
description: A Bronx judge ruled last week that the owner of a new motel on the corner of Boston Road and Pearsall Avenue could open for business. The decision ended a seven-month court battle waged by a local group.

title: Passing Along the Art Of Appalachian Fiddling
description: The mountain-hollow art of old-time Appalachian fiddling, long withering under the pressures of youthful emigration and homogenized broadcast entertainment, is hanging on by a few well-bowed strings here in a backwoods master-apprentice program.

title: Two Towns Maligned
description: To the Editor:

title: When Italians Were Newcomers
description: GAY TALESE, who wrote of his family's immigration to America from Italy in ''Unto the Sons,'' will be the first of a series of speakers in programs that accompany the exhibition ''The Italians of New York: Five Centuries of Struggle and Achievement,'' at the New-York Historical Society.

title: Ilene Penn and Craig Miller
description: Ilene Ruth Penn and Dr. Craig Alan Miller are to be married this evening by Rabbi Richard A. Davis at Bridgewaters, a caterer in New York.

title: Out of the Ball Park; For Black Americans, Baseball Loses Its Luster
description: Standing across the Harlem River from Yankee Stadium, atop some of baseball's most hallowed ground, Michael Franklin, 13, leaned against a black metal fence, largely unmoved by what others were calling the magic of October baseball. He lives in Polo Grounds Towers, a housing project built on the remains of the legendary home of the New York Giants, and later the New York Mets.

title: Dialects
description: The article is an insult to the majority of African-Americans who speak standard American English, casually and naturally, as they have from childhood. If Fox says it is all racial, how does she account for the great respect all across America for the oratory and logic of Martin Luther King Jr.?

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KARP, LEONARD DAVID
description: KARP-Leonard David. Sept. 26, 1924-Oct. 15, 1968 I only had ten years with you. I will miss you forever and love you always. Happy 75th, Daddy! Your daughter Carolyn, son-in-law Seth, and twin grandchildren, Drew Lloyd and Felicia Heather

title: A Pilot Up to His Old Tricks, Upside Down
description: THE loud buzz of the engine went quiet as the small red airplane began spiraling toward earth, trailing smoke behind it. Though disaster seemed imminent, the handful of onlookers at Republic Airport in Farmingdale on a recent cloudless Saturday craned their necks and smiled.

description: Route 130 in southern Burlington County is a true New Jersey byway.

description: Danielle Brett Glosser, the daughter of Sandra L. Glosser of Aspen, Colo., and Daniel I. Glosser of Newport Beach, Calif., is to be married this evening to Howard Judson Riker, a son of Stephen J. Riker of Bedford, N.Y., and the late Susan G. Riker. Rabbi Avis D. title: Student Loan Defaults Above Average in State
description: The rate at which people default on their Federally backed student loans in New Jersey is higher than the national average, largely because students feel unsatisfied with their education, according to the Federal Department of Education.

title: Got a Best Friend?
description: Who's your best friend? Somebody you met in kindergarten? On your first job? A neighbor who dropped by to lend a hand and turned into an important part of your life?

title: The Other Side of Muir Woods
description: GROWING up in Marin County in California, one of my favorite places was Muir Woods National Monument, the sky-scraping grove of 1,000-year-old coast redwoods just north of San Francisco. Dwarfed by huge ferns and the trees, I would feel like a Lilliputian in a giant's landscape, exploring immense hollow logs and running across the forest floor.

title: Lee Richardson, 73, an Actor Noted for His English Accents
description: Lee Richardson, an actor whose career spanned more than four decades of stage, film and television work, died on Oct. 2 at his home in Manhattan. He was 73.

description: SILVERSTONE-Pearl. See notice today under NEWSOM-Pearl. Died October 8, 1999.

title: Scenes From The Millennium
description: In his article ''In God's Place,'' Alan Lightman writes that ''science cannot answer the question of why the universe came into being in the first place or whether it has any purpose.'' Neither, I might point out, can religion.

description: Here we are with nearly 12 weeks still to go until the new millennium, and it is probably safe to say that millions of Americans are already tired of hearing about it.
