title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLADE, RHEA
description: SLADE-Rhea. Of Boca Raton, FL, formerly of Brooklyn on October 8, 1999 at age 91. Devoted wife of the late Aleck Slade, prominent Staten Island real estate investor. Loving mother of the late Barbara Tarshis and Edward Slade. Loving mother-in-law of Dorothy Slade. Adoring grandmother of Carol Tarshis, the late Elinor Tarshis, Michael and Andrea Slade Weitzner, Stefanie Slade and Larry Slade. Dear sister of Ruth Goldine, Marvin Fine, Alice Bull, and the late Rose Leder, Sam Fine, Ed Fine, and Rhea's twin Irving Fine. Memorial services at Boulevard Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY, 1:30PM on Sunday October 10.

title: But Whose Side Is He Really On?
description: The technology revolution reshaping Wall Street was the topic for a daylong conference on Wednesday at Pace University in Manhattan. But the ambient excitement about the new E-market was not shared by the luncheon speaker, Alan C. (Ace) Greenberg, chairman of the Bear Stearns Companies.

title: Sparkle of Opera In 'Die Fledermaus'
description: THE Crystal Opera Consortium opens its eighth season this weekend, while Connecticut Opera and Connecticut Grand Opera and Orchestra brighten the vocal scene the following week.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH/Lisa G.; The 'G' Is for Goodies
description: YOU have precious cargo in here!'' Lisa G. told her cabdriver. Ms. G., a morning radio personality (now on WOR-AM's ''Rambling With Gambling'' show after spending many years on WQHT-FM, Hot 97, with the rappers Ed Lover and Dr. Dre), was speeding home to her small Upper East Side one-bedroom apartment on the night of Oct. 2. Her cargo consisted of pastries by an impressive set of friends -- Jacques Torres, from Le Cirque 2000; Erik Blauberg, from the ''21'' Club, and Alfred Stephens, from Mesa Grill -- for her annual end-of-summer all-dessert bash.

title: Mary Andrews, George Brown
description: Mary Jeanette Andrews and Dr. George Patrick Brown were married yesterday at St. Andrew's Church on Block Island in Rhode Island. The Rev. Donal Kehew, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Edward Murray, Bailey Dalton
description: Rachel Bailey Dalton, the daughter of Dr. Cecile Dalton and Dr. David Dalton of Radnor, Pa., was married last evening to Edward O'Brien Murray, a son of Helen Hovdesven of Wilmington, N.C., and Richard Murray of Dallas. Rabbi David Greenberg officiated at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club in Scarborough, N.Y.

title: Still on the Fringes of Sitcom Stardom?
description: Steven Engel, a television writer whose recent hits include ''Dream On'' and ''Just Shoot Me,'' knew what he wanted in the female lead of his new sitcom, ''Work With Me.'' He wanted someone sexy and smart, goofy and poised, an actress who could deliver a raunchy joke and look sweet doing it. He wanted Nancy Travis.

title: Unlikely Hero Sends Mets to Next Round
description: METS 4, ARIZONA 3

title: 'Good and Evil,' and Jazz
description: EVEN though Jim Williams was acquitted after his fourth trial, there's really no question that he gunned down his young lover, Danny Hansford. Williams, a brilliant, witty antiques dealer in Savannah, Ga., was even on the verge of abandoning his story that Hansford had fired at him first. Find it on page 346 of ''Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil,'' the true-crime book set in a magical city whose mossy secrets rise like the dark side of Brigadoon.

title: Swept Away
description: ELVIA SUTER was strolling down Bay 54th Street, a dead-end block in the tiny Brooklyn community of White Sands, when she stopped and gestured toward a 50-foot oak tree. An abandoned blue Chrysler filled with garbage was parked next to it.

title: October 3-9; 3 Indicted in Money Case
description: A Federal grand jury indicted three key figures in the investigation of about $7 billion in suspect funds that moved through the Bank of New York over the last three years. The three Russian emigres named -- a former Bank of New York executive, Lucy Edwards; her husband, Peter Berlin, and a business associate, Aleksey Volkov -- are charged with running an illegal wire transfer business, but investigators indicated last week that further indictments are on the way. The investigation is examining whether the enormous money transfers involved money laundering, the process of washing ''dirty'' money through a series of bank accounts until it looks ''clean.'' Investigators say that is hard to prove and federal investigators still haven't uncovered proof of it at the Bank of New York. TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN

title: The 'People's Car' Aims at a New Class of People
description: VOLKSWAGEN won't be keeping many manufacturing secrets when it begins making a new luxury car late next year. The factory in downtown Dresden, Germany, will have walls of glass, allowing customers and passers-by to watch the cars being built.

title: Eping Chang and James Fahn
description: Eping Chang, a daughter of Lin Chung Hua of Tainan, Taiwan, and Chang Chi Neng of Bangkok, Thailand, is to be married this afternoon to James David Fahn, a son of Charlotte Zmora Fahn and Dr. Stanley Fahn of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y. Rabbi Edward Schechter is to officiate at the Westin Harbor Island Hotel in San Diego.

title: 'Why They Kill'
description: To the Editor:

title: Immigrants Build A Bridge of Barrels
description: WHEN Robert Peterkin finds himself with an extra $100, he spends it on two pairs of sneakers he'll never wear. Instead, he puts them aside until he gathers other household items -- rice, macaroni, underwear, combs, shoes. Then he packs it all in a four-foot-deep barrel to ship to the wife and four children he left in Haiti 10 years ago.

title: Science vs. the Bible: Debate Moves to the Cosmos
description: Scientific lessons about the origins of life have long been challenged in public schools, but some Bible literalists are now adding the reigning theory about the origin of the universe to their list of targets.

title: One-Way Tickets
description: THE GREAT SHAME

title: Police Officers' Statements in Louima Case Become an Issue in Latest Trial
description: For two years, they have been hovering in the shadows of one of the most heavily publicized cases of police brutality in New York City: two police officers charged with lying about what they saw when Abner Louima was tortured in a Brooklyn police station.

title: Jessica Schaetzl, Christopher Carter
description: Jessica Heather Schaetzl, a daughter of Maureen and John Schaetzl of Hamden, Conn., was married there yesterday to Christopher Matthew Carter, a son of Judith E. Carter of Peabody, Mass., and Clairmont P. Carter Jr. of Nashua, N.H. The Rev. Robert G. Heffernan performed the ceremony at St. Joan of Arc Roman Catholic Church.

title: Back to School, 1958
description: I am disappointed that McCourt chose to end his article by promoting ''busy work.'' Copying old student manuscripts, even if they were written by father, Uncle Sal or an aunt who died in childbirth, does not constitute responsible teaching. He lost a grand opportunity to show young educators that teachers are honed in the crucible of the classroom. I wonder if some insightful twist might make ''Silas Marner'' readable. Or perhaps the students could have been motivated to write their own stories -- the prototypes were at hand.

title: Political Memo; New York Lore: The Mayor Will Get You for That
description: Before New York's major cultural institutions came out against Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's attack on the Brooklyn Museum of Art, museum directors fretted that the Mayor would get angry at them and then he would get even.

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-10-99: Counterculture; George www.Bush.com
description: You can tell that a robust political sphere has all but disappeared these days by the metaphors we use about it. There are now essentially three: sports, entertainment and business. These other fields of life -- more vibrant than ever -- have essentially eclipsed their former master. Politics is now either a game, in which teams are handicapped, managers fired and players ranked. Or it is a movie, replete with actors, production values, celebrity scandals and studio bosses. Or else it is a business. Especially a business. Especially now. The campaign-finance laws play into this, of course, filling the media with details of dollars and contributors more than policies and ideas. So does the accelerated primary schedule, which has made the campaign begin even earlier and fund-raising the preoccupying, determinative task of any would-be President.

title: Live From Radio City!
description: After closing for a restoration that left it dark for seven months and cost $70 million -- twice the original estimate -- Radio City Music Hall was scheduled to reopen last Monday in a blaze of lights befitting one of New York City's most enduring show-business icons.

title: Memento Mori: An Album of Lost Buildings
description: People walk their familiar day-to-day paths. On that corner is a tenement. Here is a church. The bright lights of a theater flicker. Then, one day, for no particular reason, something changes. But what?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SRULOWITZ, EMANUEL (MANNIE)
description: SRULOWITZ-Emanuel (Mannie). Of Miami Beach, FL. Formerly of Crown Heights. Age 88. Beloved husband of Eva Gold Srulowitz for 60 years. Father of Meyer and Esther of Woodmere, N.Y., Seymour & Judy, Shirley and Harry Nagel, of Monsey, N.Y. Loving grandfather of fourteen and greatgrandfather of twenty-five.

title: Reconsidering The Corporate Retreat
description: To the Editor:

title: Cuts Open Gaps in Social Services Net
description: WHEN Nassau County's Department of Social Services announced in April that it would no longer provide many substance abusers with transportation to treatment centers, Halina Schafer felt ''a sense of terror'' among the drug-addicted women in the intensive five-day-a-week treatment program she runs in Freeport.

title: Disabled Reach Pact With City in Transportation Suit
description: New York City Transit officials have settled a Federal lawsuit brought against Access-a-Ride, the city's transportation program for the disabled. Under the agreement, the city has promised to reduce the rate at which it denies people rides because of high demand.

title: Schools Find Pluses in Shift To Marathon-Length Classes
description: Deborah Valentino's seventh-grade English class had just passed the 60-minute mark when she suddenly swung open a classroom window, hoping the autumn air would act like a cold washcloth on the faces of her 25 students.

title: Abby Bush, David Baer
description: Abby Lynn Bush, the daughter of Joyce A. Lilholt of Canton, N.Y., and Lon Bush of Lowville, N.Y., is to be married this afternoon to David Baer, a son of Susan T. Baer and Dr. John E. Baer of Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. Joel B. Warren, a nondenominational minister, will officiate at Crabtree's Kittle House, a country inn in Chappaqua, N.Y.

title: As Benefits Expire, the Experts Worry
description: Wisconsin, of all places, suddenly has the jitters about cutting families off welfare.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALEXANDER, DONALD LOUIS
description: ALEXANDER-Donald Louis, 64, of Midlothian, VA. died October 6, 1999. Born in Queens, beloved father of Christine, Donald, Jennifer, John and husband of Sandra. He was the General Manager of Packaging Corporation of America. He attended St. Paul's Episcopal School in Garden city and was a graduate of Dartmouth College, 1956. Contributions may be made to The Dartmouth College Scholarship Fund.

title: The Ethicist
description: Perhaps the satirical purpose of Randy Cohen's column (Sept. 12) would be more clear if it were renamed ''Ethics Lite.'' As it is, some future researcher may take it at face value and think that we had no more serious ethical questions in the last year of the 20th century than what advice to give your mother-in-law about disposing of a canister of spent film. Or whether your car should be repaired by a mechanic with disagreeable opinions.

title: Two Shows Explore a Career's Work at the Edge of Abstraction
description: HELEN FRANKENTHALER bridges a significant gap between first-generation Abstract Expressionists and today's most experimental painters because she has always probed the ever expanding edge of abstraction. She is best known for her staining technique by which she applies super-thinned paint to an un-primed canvas, and she is one of the most exceptional artists in the United States.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: BOOKSTORE

title: Real Charm and Fake Jewels Society Ladies Can't Resist
description: PRINCESS MICHAEL OF KENT is coming to town, but alas, I'm going to be in London, doing my bit on QVC,'' Kenneth J. Lane, the costume jeweler, announced to guests assembled for lunch at his baronial Park Avenue duplex last week.

title: Plan Would Replace Railroad's Aging Fleet
description: LASHED by withering criticism from commuters frustrated over equipment failures, poor service and maintenance lapses, the Long Island Rail Road is being offered a chance for redemption in the five-year capital plan approved last month by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SENFELD, S. WILLIAM
description: SENFELD - S. William. The trustees, faculty, staff, and alumni/ ae of Bard College mourn the passing of dear friend and devoted alumnus, S. William Senfeld '62. Bill, who received the Bard medal in 1996, was a loyal alumnus whose energetic involvement within the Bard community will be sorely missed. Our deepest condolences to his family and many friends. Leon Botstein, President David E. Schwab II, Chairman, Board of Trustees Michael DeWitt, President, Bard-St. Stephens Alumni/ae Association

title: The World: Presidential Wish Lists; Seeking Glory Far From Home
description: FROM inside the White House, Bill Clinton's chances of carving out a place in history as a master of foreign policy don't look so bad. The White House, in fact, has a wish list of fairly spectacular goals, and at least some of them seem tantalizingly reachable.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: THE EXTRAORDINARY MRS. R

title: The Search Engine
description: The United States obviously occupies a strange place in the world. It is the capital of innovation, of material prosperity, of a certain kind of energy, of certain kinds of freedom and of transience. Silicon Valley is to the United States what the United States is to the rest of the world. It is one of those places, unlike the Metropolitan Museum of Art, but like Las Vegas, that is unimaginable anyplace but in the United States. It is distinctively us. Within this unusual place some people have clearly been more unusual than others. Many of those who sought and found fortune in Silicon Valley in the 1990's could just as easily have found it on Wall Street in the 1980's or in London in the 1860's. But a certain type of person who has made it big in Silicon Valley could have made it big at no other time in history. He was built to work on the frontier of economic life when the frontier was once again up for grabs. He was designed for rapid social and technological change. He was the starter of new things.

title: A Touch Is All It Takes
description: Predictions of the decline and fall of fashion are greatly exaggerated. So what, if the streets of New York are not filled in the daytime with three-piece suits or serious dresses? This is the late 1990's, and the New York scene tells the story of a vigorous generation on the go, with men and women dressing to their own music. And that means looking good by suiting up in casual and comfortable clothes. For one woman, a leopard-spotted bag adds just the right touch. For others, a bit of red hits the spot, including red socks to fill stiletto-heeled shoes. And in a mix-and-match vignette befitting the spirit of the age, she wears leather pants, so he simply must wear a leather shirt.

title: City College Is Doing Its Job Well
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It's too easy to be a

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the appointment of a Japanese Cabinet member who belongs to a party backed by a Buddhist organization misspelled the given name of the honorary president of the organization. He is Daisaku Ikeda, not Daisuki. The article also misspelled the name of the organization at one point. It is Soka Gakkai, not Gakkagi.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARTNER, MARTIN A.
description: BARTNER-Martin A. Of Verona, NJ, on Sunday, October 10, 1999. Beloved husband of Audrey (nee Mayer). Devoted father of Douglas and Lisa Coleman. Dear father-in-law of Cecilia and James. Loving grandfather of James, Kelly and Alex. Funeral service Monday, October 11, at 2 PM, in Temple B'nai Jeshurun, 1025 South Orange Ave., Short Hills, NJ. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Martin A. Bartner Cancer Research Foundation, c/o Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Box E, 1275 York Ave., NYC 10021.

title: The Senate Confronts Soft Money
description: When campaign finance reform comes before the Senate this week, Trent Lott and other enemies of cleaning up the system will make the usual predictions that reform cannot win. In fact, the Republican leadership's barricade against change is crumbling. Under pressure from a growing number of business leaders, and rising outrage over a projected $3 billion to be spent in the current campaign, some important Republicans are thinking about supporting the McCain-Feingold ''soft money'' ban. Senator Chuck Hagel of Nebraska is planning to offer amendments, a welcome sign that he and others might be showing up to help pass the bill, not block it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AEDER, MILTON
description: AEDER-Milton. On October 9, 1999. Husband of the late Helen Brady. Brother of Arthur, Marvin and Shirley Ezra. Zaider of Dan Brady. Favored uncle of 27 nieces and nephews, grandnieces and grandnephews.

title: In America; Cheating the Schools
description: The numbers are stark. The system is unfair. New York City kids account for 38 percent of the state's public school enrollment but get only 34 percent of the state's school aid.

title: Calendar Conjures Memories Of the First Bermuda Victory
description: The world championships to be played in Bermuda in January will celebrate half a century of competition. At stake in the open series will be the Bermuda Bowl, first presented in 1950 when top teams from the United States, Europe and Britain played a triangular contest, finishing in that order. That began the modern series of regular world contests.

title: The Defense Isn't Worried
description: There is no open animosity brewing between the Giants' defense, which has played four strong games, and their offense, which once again played miserably in a 14-3 loss to the Arizona Cardinals yesterday. The offense has not played a good game this season.

title: Gore's Confident Campaign Manager, Penance Complete
description: DONNA BRAZILE, who was just named Al Gore's new campaign manager, did not supply a terse, ''that was a long time ago, in another country'' response when asked about the night she stepped down from another Presidential campaign, Michael Dukakis's in 1988.

title: Dr. Sidney H. Silverman, 75, Obstetrician
description: Dr. Sidney H. Silverman, a specialist in obstetrics and gynecology who practiced for 45 years in Brooklyn and Queens and on Long Island, died on Sept. 27 at his home in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 75 and had lived in Florida since retiring in 1990.

title: American Ballet Theater Offers Lecture Series
description: The history, philosophy and work of American Ballet Theater will be discussed in ''A.B.T. at 60,'' a series of six talks held in conjunction with the Guggenheim Museum and its Works and Process program. The talks, at 8 P.M. at the Peter B. Lewis Theater at the Guggenheim, will begin Friday and Saturday with discussions of the importance of dramatic ballets in the company's history.

title: Media Talk; 'Role of a Lifetime,' Reagan Biography, Will Be Reissued
description: While critics debate Edmund Morris's memoir of Ronald Reagan and its blend of fact and fantasy, an upstart publisher is preparing to reissue a rival biography, contending that Mr. Morris failed to deliver a definitive account of the former President's life.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAUSER, SHEILA
description: HAUSER-Sheila. Beloved wife, mother, passed away Saturday, October 9. Services 1:15 PM, Wednesday, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Sydney E. Salmon, 63, Specialist in Treating Bone Marrow Cancer
description: Dr. Sydney E. Salmon, a cancer researcher and founder of the Arizona Cancer Center in Tucson, died on Wednesday at his home in Tucson. He was 63.

title: Global One Partners Likely to Disband
description: France Telecom S.A., Europe's second-biggest phone company, expects to reach an agreement with its partners over ownership of its Global One phone alliance within two months, the company's chief executive, Michel Bon, said today.

title: Easing on Software Exports Has Limits
description: When the Clinton Administration recently announced plans to relax restrictions on exports of data-scrambling software, a key issue that escaped notice was that the new policies affect only shrink-wrapped software, not the original source code -- the lines of instructions that programmers actually write. When it comes to source code, the Under Secretary of Commerce for Export Administration, William A. Reinsch, said last week that, ''nothing has changed.''

title: At advertisers' meeting, media companies pay handsomely for the right to promote themselves.
description: THE theme of the 1999 annual conference of the Association of National Advertisers is ''Brand Building for the 21st Century.'' But it might as well be called ''Payback Time 3.''

title: I.B.M. to Take Part in Alliance With Other Computer Giants To Better E-Commerce Security
description: I.B.M., the world's largest computer company, said today that it would become part of an industry alliance to create better security for electronic-commerce transactions.

title: Spanish Rider Wins Men's Elite Title
description: Everybody else among the nine leaders of the elite men's road race snaked left during the final few hundred yards at Verona, Italy, yesterday, but Oscar Freire, a 23-year-old Spaniard, decided to move out alone, heading dead-ahead on the right. He crossed the finish line four seconds ahead to become the new world champion.

title: Bill Can Help H.M.O.'s
description: To the Editor:

title: Some Arts Groups Silent on Museum Dispute
description: Within a week after Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani first threatened to evict the Brooklyn Museum of Art over the ''Sensation'' exhibit, so many of the city's high-profile art institutions signed a letter objecting to his actions that the holdouts were conspicuous by their absence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIN, NATALIE
description: LEWIN - Natalie. Congregation Shearith Israel, the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue, mourns the loss of its devoted member and extends its deepest sympathy to her family. Alvin Deutsch, Parnas

title: Powell's Contribution
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURKEWITZ, GRACE
description: TURKEWITZ-Grace. Our beloved and cherished friend. We will miss your friendship forever. Our condolences to Bob and your family. Forever in our hearts. Phyllis and Ira Franke

title: Compressed Data; A Satellite Model For Streaming Media
description: As the Internet moves to broad band, the market for Internet audio and video, so-called streaming media, is expected to explode. But congestion associated with this bandwidth-hogging traffic can crash Web sites, drown out conventional traffic and degrade the quality of the sound or picture.

title: A troubling historical account and a sensational interview raise questions about what news lasts.
description: ANY journalist who gives a talk to a lay audience is almost certain to be asked this question: How do you decide what is news? These days, the question may need to be rephrased. There are so many outlets and news organizations or quasi-news organizations pumping out information that many things seem to matter, at least for a moment. A better question may be: How do you decide what news lasts?

title: A Met 'Aida' May Rival the Pyramids in Grandeur, if Not in Age
description: Although any number of productions, mostly by Franco Zeffirelli, have shown that it is possible to fill the vast stage of the Metropolitan Opera House if cost is no object, few have taken the additional step of seeming to overwhelm that space. Sonja Frisell's production of Verdi's ''Aida,'' which returned to the Met on Friday evening, is one that does, and remarkably, this was the production substituted in 1988 for a planned Zeffirelli staging that promised to run too rich even for the Met's blood.

title: INSIDE
description: Berlin's Leftists Gain

title: Mexicans Criticize Flood Relief Efforts
description: With eastern Mexico awash in brackish waters from the region's worst flooding in decades, opposition politicians have charged in to fan citizen anger. They said that the disaster had been caused by Government negligence and that relief efforts had been sluggish.

title: COLT'S TO CURTAIL SALE OF HANDGUNS
description: The Colt's Manufacturing Company, which invented the six-shooter, the companion of cowboys and Texas Rangers, is abandoning much of its 144-year-old retail gun business in an effort to limit its liability in lawsuits.

title: Against the Rangers, Trouble Comes in Two Different Sizes for the Coyotes
description: If Theo Fleury's style is that of a gnat, buzzing through traffic in a general attempt to annoy, it is only natural that Todd Harvey's approach has a little more sting. After all, the 6-foot, 200-pound Harvey is six inches taller and about 20 pounds heavier than his diminutive Rangers teammate.

title: Larry Wynn, 89, Lyricist for 'Five Guys'
description: Larry Wynn, a lyricist who wrote the words for the 1941 novelty hit ''Five Guys Named Moe,'' died on Sept. 28 at Englewood Hospital in New Jersey. He was 89 and lived in Cliffside Park, N.J.

title: Silverbulletday And Behrens Suffer Upsets In the Mud
description: In the mud and the mist of Belmont Park, two of the top candidates for Horse of the Year tumbled from the pinnacle yesterday: Behrens ran second to River Keen in the $1 million Jockey Club Gold Cup and the great filly Silverbulletday ran second to Beautiful Pleasure in the $500,000 Beldame.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIESNER, BEATRICE
description: FRIESNER-Beatrice. On October 8, 1999 of Branford, CT., wife of the late David Friesner, beloved mother of Dr. Esther FriesnerStutzman of Madison, CT., loving mother-in-law of Walter Stutzman. Also survived by two loving grandchildren. Mrs. Friesner was a respected teacher in the New York City schools for 40 years. Funeral services were held at the Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY. Memorial contributions may be sent to Connecticut Hospice, 61 Burban Drive, Branford, CT. 06405.

title: Disney 'Millennium Symphonies'
description: Think big. Be happy. Probably these words were not in the contracts Aaron Jay Kernis and Michael Torke signed with the Walt Disney Company to write ''millennium symphonies,'' but they might as well have been. Both composers took the opportunity to write for a large orchestra with choir, boys' choir and soloists, and both were encouraged also to be affirmative in ways that only the common chord knows: their works both, curiously enough, ended in D major.

title: Young & Rubicam Wins Gifts.com's Account
description: Gifts.com in Pleasantville, N.Y., a new Web site selling gift products that is jointly owned by the Reader's Digest Association and Startek Inc., has awarded its first account to units of Young & Rubicam Inc. in New York. Spending was estimated at $20 million. The decision came after a review that had been narrowed to Y.& R. and other agencies that included Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide in New York, part of the WPP Group P.L.C. Y.& R. units that will work on the Gifts.com account are: Y.& R. Advertising in New York, for consumer advertising and strategic development; Wunderman Cato Johnson and the Media Edge, both in New York, for the media duties, and Landor Associates in San Francisco, for design and brand identity.

title: Endorsement of Gore Is Assured, President of A.F.L.-C.I.O. Says
description: The president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., John J. Sweeney, said today that Vice President Al Gore would receive the powerful labor federation's endorsement at its convention here this week.

title: Reputed Mafia Chief Faces New Racketeering Charges
description: When Alphonse Persico, a reputed Mafia leader, was acquitted of murder and racketeering charges in Federal District Court in Brooklyn five years ago, his lawyer said his newly freed client wanted only to spend time with his three young daughters. And that is what he has been doing since, the lawyer said yesterday, along with helping to run legitimate businesses owned by Mr. Persico and his relatives.

title: Holiday Today
description: Columbus Day, actually Oct. 12, will be legally observed.

title: Notion of a New Al Gore Begins to Take Root
description: It was a rare moment of introspection for Vice President Al Gore.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRECKER, RUTH (MENAKER)
description: PRECKER-Ruth (Menaker). On October 10, 1999, of Roslindale, MA, formerly of Jamaica Plain, MA, and Bronx, NY. Beloved wife of the late Leo. Loving mother of the late Sheila Freeman. Cherished grandmother of Douglas M., Kenneth M., and Clifford M. Freeman and great-grandmother of Jessica, Michelle, Shoshana, Jacob and Leo. Services at the Levine Chapel, 470 Harvard Street, Brookline, MA, on Tuesday, October 12, at 1 PM. Memorial observance Tuesday only, at the home of Douglas Freeman. Remembrances may be made to the Alzheimer's Disease and Related Disorders Association, One Kendall Square, Building 200, Cambridge, MA 02139.

title: Connolly Gives a Glimpse Of the Islanders' Future
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y., Oct. 10 -- Sometimes, it is hard to believe that Tim Connolly, the Islanders' rookie center, is only 18. He seems so much older when he is faking a veteran defenseman or making a snappy pass or shooting the puck past one of the league's top goaltenders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHREIBER, MARILYN BLANCHE (NEE KRAMER)
description: SCHREIBER - Marilyn Blanche (nee Kramer). Of Fort Lee. Beloved wife of Sanford. Devoted mother of Barbara Schreiber and Jane Marcus. Sister of Carol Hunger, Raymond Kramer and Arthur Kramer. Loving grandmother of two grandchildren. Service at ''Wien & Wien,'' corner of Park and Passaic, Hackensack, Tuesday, 11:30 AM; 1-800-322-0533. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the American Heart Association, 7272 Greenville Avenue, Dallas, TX 75231.

title: A Year After a Gay Man's Killing, Laramie Braces for a Second Trial
description: The rail fence remains, a lonely span of timber at the end of a rutted limestone trail, separating only one side of prairie from the other.

title: Patents; Steinway patents a piano, the Rhapsody, in blue, to commemorate George Gershwin's birthday.
description: SINCE it went into business in 1853, Steinway & Sons has introduced many design and mechanical innovations in its legendary pianos. Last week Steinway received its 122d patent -- a design patent that protects the look of a new, extravagantly detailed piano called the Rhapsody.

title: BASEBALL PLAYOFFS
description: John Valentin drove in seven runs as the Red Sox borke the record for most runs in a post-season game. SportsMonday

title: A Better Way to Treat the Old
description: At a Roman Catholic nursing home in Albany a year ago, the order of Carmelite nuns that runs it broke from tradition by asking the aged applicants who were about to become residents: ''What time do you like to get up in the morning? When do you like to have breakfast? What do you like to eat?'' The Teresian Home had decided to end the tyranny of structure and schedule that herds old people through the day in nursing homes across the country: up at 6:30 A.M., dressed for breakfast at 7:30 to 9, lunch at noon in a dining room with scores of others, showers at a certain time, naps at a certain time, dinner at 5 to 5:30 P.M. and back in bed by 8, two to a room, on long hallways.

title: New Statue in Stamford Honors Jackie Robinson
description: A life-size statue of Jackie Robinson will be unveiled here on Friday.

title: U.N. Bolsters Border Troops In East Timor
description: The United Nations-backed peacekeeping mission here said today that it would triple the number of its troops along the border with the Indonesian-controlled half of this island in an effort to thwart attacks by anti-independence militias based there.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEMBITZER, ROBIN, M.D.
description: DEMBITZER-Robin, M.D. September 24, 1999. Beloved daughter, beloved sister, beloved friend. Gifted physician, gifted artist. Donations in her memory may be sent to the Crohn's and Colitis Foundation, 386 Park Avenue South, 14th Floor, NYC 10016.

title: The Big City; Move Along, A V.I.P. Needs Your Space
description: IF the Mayor and the police are determined to continue Operation Move Along, the campaign against double-parking, they might at least give it an honest name. This should be known as Operation Get Out of My Space. It's like Captain Kidd leading a campaign against piracy.

title: Art as a Mirror
description: To the Editor:

title: Perilous Parking
description: To the Editor:

title: Web Catches On With Fleet Street
description: Peter Martin, a senior editor, strides briskly through the newsroom of The Financial Times, gesturing to a bank of computer terminals where journalists craft the news for FT.com, the paper's Web site.

title: Eritrea's Big Leap Falls Victim to 15 Months of War
description: There were only two tourists here on a recent day, a pair of sunburned French women wandering alone in the dusty streets surrounded by Ottoman buildings in a centuries-long slide into rubble. Many residents of this port city were off fighting at the front. And the port itself was not doing well, handling just over half as much cargo as it should.

title: Media Talk; Publisher Cautious on Unabomber's Book
description: There are certain publishing rituals that necessarily must be abandoned when an author lives in a Federal prison cell under 23-hour lockdown with just a 13-inch black-and-white television for company.

title: CLINTON OPPOSES A PLAN BY ALLIES TO GIVE SERBS AID
description: With winter fast approaching, the United States and its allies are deeply divided over whether to increase the isolation of Yugoslavia and its leader, Slobodan Milosevic, or to offer some aid to ease the hardship of Serbs in the hope of encouraging a more vital opposition.

title: Milt Jackson, 76, Jazz Vibraphonist, Dies
description: Milt Jackson, the jazz vibraphonist who was a member of the Modern Jazz Quartet for 40 years and was one of the premier improvisers in jazz with a special brilliance at playing blues, died on Saturday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan. He was 76 and lived in Teaneck, N.J.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Ford Agreement With Union Puts Conditions on Spinoff

title: A Mystery in Louisiana Governor's Race
description: Ever since he began running for a second term, Gov. Mike Foster of Louisiana has been dogged by one political embarrassment and mix-up after another.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Thursday about the ways that some Web site designers trick Web surfers referred incorrectly to one method of avoiding certain tricks. Programming created with Javascript can be avoided by disabling Javascript, not Java, through the user's Web browser.

title: Seizing the Initiative on Privacy; On-Line Industry Presses Its Case for Self-Regulation
description: By the stilted linguistic standards of government reports, the Federal Trade Commission gave the on-line industry a pistol whipping in June 1998. After reviewing the privacy practices of World Wide Web sites, the commission told Congress that the industry had ''fallen far short of what is needed to protect consumers.''

title: West Bank Shooting Starts What Accords Could Not
description: Inside the casbah, two men hustled past the bullet-pocked refrigerator cases into the Abu Salhieh family butcher shop. The butcher raised his meat cleaver in joy. The men hauled a lamb slaughtered in celebration: after 23 days in the hospital, the butcher's younger brother was about to be released.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: When Jobs Move Away
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Raises Objections To New Force in Europe
description: A plan to create a defense arm for the 15-nation European Union is stirring fears among American civilian and military officials in NATO about unnecessary replication the allies can ill afford.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLACK, EDWARD
description: BLACK-Edward. Age 90. Beloved husband for 63 years of Muriel Fleischman Black, wonderful father of Jo Ann and Howard Chase, adored and adoring Grandpa Eddie to Adam Chase, loving brother to five siblings and Uncle Eddie to every child he ever met. He was ''The Baron'' of the New York Journal American for many years before going into the public relations business. He served in Great Britain in World War II. Eddie was blessed with an extraordinarily outgoing personality, a great sense of humor and genuine kindness and generosity to all who crossed his path. Services were held Sunday, October 10, in Miami. Contributions in his memory may be made to ''Alzheimer's Care Committee/Notables'' of Douglas Gardens, 5200 Northeast Second Avenue, Miami, FL 33137.

title: Collins, Too, at a Loss To Explain the Woes
description: Kerry Collins now has seen the Giants offense up close, and from the inside. In the wake of the Giants' stumbling 14-3 defeat to the Arizona Cardinals, he had a new theory as to what ails the team offensively.

title: One Wide-Reaching Slash Could Settle Budget Battle
description: Running out of weapons in their politically charged fight to finance the Government without using Social Security money, Republicans in Congress are turning to the crudest of fiscal tools, an across-the-board cut in spending.

title: To Middle School, by Bus, Subway and Ferry
description: Akshay Ganesh, a 12-year-old seventh grader who lives on Staten Island, rolls out of bed every weekday about 6 A.M. He has 20 minutes to eat breakfast and get dressed before heading out the door to catch the S66 bus to catch the 7 A.M. ferry to Manhattan.

title: An Echo of Bush Pere
description: To the Editor:

title: J. Walter Thompson Gets Safeway Account
description: Safeway Inc. in Pleasanton, Calif., the supermarket chain, has awarded the media planning and buying duties for its account, with billings estimated at $30 million to $35 million, to the J. Walter Thompson Retail Group in Detroit, part of the J. Walter Thompson Company unit of WPP Group P.L.C.

title: Citing Radiation Fatigue, Cardinal Misses a Mass
description: Conceding the physical toll of radiation treatments, John Cardinal O'Connor did not say Mass yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral in Manhattan, but said he hoped to be back next Sunday.

title: Credit Offerings Scheduled for This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to tomorrow's auction of three- and six-month bills and a 52-week bill being auctioned on Wednesday. Today is a Federal holiday and there is no trading in United States Treasury securities and no trading of futures on the Chicago Board of Trade, closed for observance of Columbus Day.

title: Ford's Deal With Auto Workers Has an Unusual Twist
description: In difficult labor talks with the Ford Motor Company, the United Automobile Workers union finally agreed to an unusual compromise: it would allow the company to spin off its giant auto parts unit as long as Ford did not spin off workers with it, people briefed on the deal said today.

title: Flutie Puts on a Display, and It Terrorizes the Defenders
description: Buffalo quarterback Doug Flutie's bag of tricks is large. As they say in basketball, he creates. He frustrates a defense with a run, bobbing and weaving his way through linebackers and safeties who always seem to be surprised by his speed. His passes are like good fastballs. His decisions are rarely bad ones.

title: Code Talkers' Story Pops Up Everywhere
description: They are old men now, drifting into town in their boots, blue jeans and silver belt buckles. Like other aging veterans of World War II, they meet once a month on Saturday mornings for a blend of poignant and prosaic duties: planning parades, disbursing money for the funeral expenses of one old comrade and a small scholarship for the son of another and reviewing the coffee budget, $21.69 this month.

title: Physician Is Arrested In Rape of Patient
description: A physician in Brooklyn was arrested Saturday after a female patient accused the doctor of rape, the police said.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: After Paying Pataki's Fare, A Free Office
description: When the Hungarian-American Chamber of Commerce of New York and New Jersey paid for two trips by Gov. George E. Pataki to Hungary a few years ago, the group was based in suburban New Jersey and listed its official address as its president's home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMANN, PAUL M.
description: HERMANN-Paul M. On October 9, 1999. Beloved husband of Marion. Loving father and father-in-law of Jacqueline and Jeffrey, Corinne and David. Cherished grandfather of Michelle and Julia, Sabrina and Grant. A memorial service will be held on Monday, October 11, at 11 AM, at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Rd., Scarsdale, NY; 914-723-7727. Donations to Jansen Memorial Hospice, 69 Main St., Tuckahoe, NY.

title: Unsung Success in Revamping Software Holds a Clue to the Turnaround at Apple
description: Much has been said and written about the turnaround at Apple Computer in recent years, as measured by its return to profitability, the resurgence of its share price and the explosive sales of its fruit-colored iMac machines. But in fact, the seeds of Apple's remarkable renaissance were sown in a contentious meeting that took place here in January 1997 and that involved the unsung part of Apple's business: software.

title: One Woman's Push to Undo Justice That Was Too Quick
description: When it comes to eyewitness testimony, you can't always believe your eyes. Such is the lesson of tonight's ''Dateline'' report on a Greenwich Village murder in November 1990 that brought a quick arrest and second-degree murder conviction for an 18-year-old man, whom seven witnesses told a jury they had seen at the crime scene.

title: Stations Challenge Digital-TV Standard
description: Facing angry opposition, nearly 300 of the nation's 1,600 television stations filed a petition with the Federal Communications Commission on Friday, formally requesting a revision in the nation's digital-television standard that was approved almost three years ago.

title: Johnson Is on His Mark When Curtain Goes Up
description: So you think Monday night football is pressure, Keyshawn Johnson said.

title: Otto Storch, 86; Helped Transform Magazine Design in the 50's
description: Otto Storch, a magazine art director and advertising photographer who introduced an expressive typographic style to women's magazines as part of a revolution in editorial design, died on Sept. 29 at a hospital in Manhattan, where he lived. He was 86.

title: The Boxer as Antihero In and Out of the Ring
description: Jose Limon was identified with epic themes in his choreography. But many of his contemporaries in the modern dance of the 1940's favored the equivalent of the urban short story, especially if it had a social-protest subtext.

title: Doubters Fuel Yanks' Drive to Repeat Their Championship Ways
description: The Yankees sipped, sprayed and splashed champagne on another methodical night in Arlington, Tex., a scene that was so familiar to them it was eerie. Once again, the Yankees ejected the Rangers from their division series in three games. Once again, Darryl Strawberry was the focus of a wet celebration.

title: For Nets, Reserves Show Up Starters
description: More than 200 people filed into the bleachers at the Atlantic City Convention Center today, eagerly awaiting a demonstration of basketball prowess by Stephon Marbury and Keith Van Horn of the New Jersey Nets.

title: Political Memo; Gore and Bradley Take Steps Out of Character
description: In an unlikely role reversal, the front-runner for the Democratic Presidential nomination, Al Gore, is behaving less like a front-runner, or a Vice President, and more like a brawling insurgent. And Bill Bradley, who is the true insurgent, is behaving more like the man to beat.

title: Valentine Stirs Pot, and the Braves Are in It
description: After the Mets clinched a trip to the National League Championship Series with a victory Saturday, Bobby Valentine spoke of the ghosts the Atlanta Braves would face: a New York team that Chipper Jones mocked less than two weeks ago but which has risen from the ashes of its self-immolation.

title: BBDO to Promote New Jersey Devils
description: The New Jersey Devils of the National Hockey League has named BBDO New York, part of the BBDO Worldwide unit of Omnicom Group, as the team's first agency of record, handling assignments to promote the Devils as a brand and to build awareness of the team in off- and on-line media. The amount of billings was not disclosed.

title: Monday Morning Quarterback
description: Highlights and lowlights from the weekend.

title: TECHNOLOGY: Digital Commerce; How can technology investors move into areas like Africa? One entrepreneur sees the answer in satellites.
description: THE technology sector's financial success the last three years has been largely a North American phenomenon.

title: Redemption After a Nation's Nightmare
description: THE INDUSTRY OF SOULS

title: Abandoned R.V. Isn't Going Anywhere
description: At first glance, the twisted, fire-scorched shell of the abandoned Gulfstream Sun Voyager camper parked along the Joe DiMaggio Highway appears to be there on purpose, a piece de resistance that ran out of gas on the way to the Brooklyn Museum of Art, perhaps.

title: These Aren't the Days, My Friends; Russian Singers See Young Snub Brighton Beach Clubs
description: Misha Gulko sat in a dinner club on Brighton Beach Avenue in Brooklyn, tripping excitedly on his words as he tried to recount the decades of his fame, from Khrushchev to Yeltsin, in just a few minutes.

title: Chechens Confident of Driving Out Russians
description: In the dead of night, without lights, cars drove along a narrow track, over the Terek River and into a small village. Voices called a low greeting from the roadside. ''Allah-u-Akbar,'' the rallying cry of the Chechen forces. The men, quiet and serious, returned the greeting.

title: Media Talk; CNN Rejects Advertisement From Salon
description: Does mighty CNN view teeny Salon magazine, the on-line journal of culture, news and opinion, as a competitor?

title: THIS WEEK
description: EVENTS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHMAN, HELEN
description: RICHMAN-Helen. On October 9, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Irving Richman. Loving mother of Harold Richman and the late Rhett Behrmann. Mother-in-law of Sheila Richman. Dear sister of the late Isabelle Singer and Bernard Wallach. Adoring grandmother of Adam, Andrea, Annie and Sheridan. Dear great-grandmother of Alec and Davis. She wil be deeply missed. Services today, 2 PM, at the Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. Cemetery Mt. Hebron.

title: Jury's Heavy Burden: Considering Insanity in Subway-Pushing Case
description: Sometime in the next four weeks, 12 jurors in Manhattan will have to decide a just fate for Andrew Goldstein. Since their deliberations will touch directly on the bitterly contentious issues of insanity and criminal guilt, any conclusion the jurors reach is sure to be roundly criticized.

title: Running on New York Time in a Subway Series
description: The Mets obviously are the stepchild of these playoffs, the Yankees the preferred progeny. But the Mets' day is coming. When the World Series begins in 12 days, the Mets will be the Yankees' equal in the eyes of baseball and television officials, who will have no choice but to show the Mets playing at the same time and on the same network as the Yankees.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the theatrical composer Frank Wildhorn misstated the record he set in having three musicals simultaneously on Broadway. While he was the first American composer in 22 years to stage three shows at once, he was not the first composer: Andrew Lloyd Webber of Britain, now Lord Lloyd Webber, had three musicals on Broadway in 1982, 1988, 1990, 1993 and 1994.

title: Compressed Data; Creative Labs Adopts Windows Audio Format
description: Digging deeper into the digital music market, Microsoft said last week that Creative Labs' Nomad II portable player, scheduled for release in January, would be able to store and play music in the Windows Media Audio format.

title: A Bush-Pataki Ticket?
description: To the Editor:

title: Crackdown in Iran
description: The student protests that convulsed Iran in July were the largest public outpouring of emotion there since the 1979 revolution. The demonstrations -- for cultural freedoms and greater democracy -- were peaceful until paramilitary groups and security forces attacked the students. Now, in a terrifying illustration of the kind of strictures the protesters challenged, four people have been sentenced to death on charges of organizing the demonstrations.

title: Yankee Fans and Met Fans: Mutual Denigration Society
description: This is the time when grown-ups in blue plastic helmets look perfectly normal on crowded city streets. When friends, lovers, family members and co-workers find themselves discovering ugly things about one another. When perfect strangers plunge into passionate debates at the sight of the letters N and Y.

title: Parishioners Are Stunned By Arrest Of a Priest
description: In April, Miriam Garay had her four children baptized by the Rev. Morgan Kuhl at St. Mary of the Assumption Roman Catholic Church on the north shore of Staten Island. Yesterday, she was there again, stunned to learn that the priest who had blessed her family's entrance into Catholicism had been arrested, accused of trying to have a sexual liaison with a teen-age boy.

title: Teen-Ager Is Wounded By Police in Harlem
description: A police officer shot and injured a fleeing teen-ager in Harlem who refused to drop his gun on Saturday night, officials said yesterday.

title: After Meeting Knicks, Sprewell Shrugs Off Fuss
description: A black Mercedes crawled through a half-full lot until the driver behind the tinted windows rolled to a stop in a no-parking zone.

title: Hidden Within Technology's Empire, a Republic of Letters
description: When I was a boy ''discovering literature,'' I used to think how wonderful it would be if every other person on the street were familiar with Proust and Joyce or T. E. Lawrence or Pasternak and Kafka. Later I learned how refractory to high culture the democratic masses were. Lincoln as a young frontiersman read Plutarch, Shakespeare and the Bible. But then he was Lincoln.

title: Boston Flattens Cleveland in Record-Setting Victory
description: It rained all day and it stopped at night, and then came the thunder and the lightning of the Boston Red Sox bats. Much of it was from John Valentin, who had two home runs among his four hits and seven runs batted in. But so many others contributed for 24 Boston hits in an astounding 23-7 thrashing of the Cleveland Indians in Game 4 of the first round of the American League playoffs.

title: Get by Chipper Jones? There's Still Jordan
description: When Brian Jordan left the St. Louis Cardinals and signed with the Atlanta Braves before this season, he envisioned winning a championship in Atlanta.

title: Sea Launching Of a Satellite Is Successful
description: Ushering in a new era in rocketry, a multinational company has launched a communications satellite into space from a platform floating in the Pacific Ocean, the first such launching from sea rather than from land.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAFFE, ESTELLE
description: JAFFE-Estelle. On October 9, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin. Devoted mother of Ann and Edward. Service today at 10 AM, ''Parkside'' Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn (near Ave. V). Donations can be made to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, SANFORD
description: STERN-Sanford. On October 9, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Marcia. Loving father of Lisa, Adam and Geoffrey, and father-inlaw of Linda Block and James Ricciardi. Adored son of Laura Stern and the late Jerry Stern, and sonin-law of Betty Fox Maged and Myron Maged. Cherished brotherin-law of Jerry and Marcia Fox, and uncle of Barbara Fox, Jonathan and Kristen Fox, and Erika and Rick Eden. A charming man of incisive intelligence and subtle wit. With his wife, Marcia, he ran Lupu's in Brooklyn with great integrity and style. He loved laughter, good food and his home by the sea. Services Tuesday, October 12, at 12 noon, at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn, NY. Memorials to Cancer Care, Inc., 1180 Avenue of the Americas, New York, NY 10036.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. Members to Get On-Line Access And Discounts
description: The nation's labor movement, long a laggard on high-technology matters, is taking a leap into cyberspace with a new A.F.L.-C.I.O. program that will offer heavily discounted computers and on-line service to 13 million union members.

title: On Treaty, Chirac Is Hypocritical
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOWNE, VERNA C.
description: DOWNE-Verna C. Age 101, died October 8, 1999, in Windsor, VT. NYC resident 1954-1990. Survived by daughter Dorianne Guernsey, North Pomfret, VT.

title: Compressed Data; A Company Sells Cremations on Line
description: The Neptune Society, which sells cremations on line, calls itself ''the hottest E-commerce Web site of the year.''

title: Giants Tumble As the Offense Resists Change
description: They changed quarterbacks today, but these Giants could not change themselves.

title: City College Is Doing Its Job Well
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGOVERN, MARIE V. (NEE GOUGH)
description: McGOVERN - Marie V. (nee Gough). Of Irvington, New York on October 7, beloved wife of Joseph W., mother of Marie Therese Melillo, Raymond, Joseph, Philip & Lawrence. Sister of Virginia Kutner and the late Anne Madigan, Rev. Lawrence Gough, & Rev. Raymond Gough, S.J. Grandmother of 22, Great grandmother of 7. Mrs. McGovern was a trustee of Fordham Preparatory School, College of Mount Saint Vincent and Manhattan College & served as a member of the NYC Landmarks Commission. Visiting will be Sunday and Monday 2-4 & 7-9, Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Ave. (exit 17 Saw Mill), Dobbs Ferry, NY. Mass of the Resurrection, 10 AM, Tuesday at Church of the Immaculate Conception, Irvington, NY. Contributions in her memory to Catholic Charities of the NY Archdiocese or Catholic Relief Services.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, MINNIE
description: STERN-Minnie. October 9, 1999. New York City retired teacher, age 90. Beloved wife, loving mother, grandmother and great-grandmother. She will be missed.

title: Former Communists Surge In Berlin Municipal Voting
description: Ten years after the fall of the Berlin wall, the successor to East Germany's Communist Party drew on a ground swell of disillusionment about the transition to capitalism to surge tonight to its best showing yet in city elections.

title: Music Unlocks A Play's Secrets
description: Composers searching for opera subjects have to be wary about turning automatically to stage plays, especially great plays by well-respected authors. There are some obvious questions to ask first: Why tamper with something that already works? What will music add to it?

title: In New York Outbreak, Glimpse Of Gaps in Biological Defenses
description: On Sept. 23, nearly three weeks after Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced that New York was being attacked by a mosquito-borne virus often found in the Southern United States, senior Federal health officials convened a conference call to hear some startling news.

title: Reporter Gets A Subpoena On Interview In '95 Killing
description: A reporter for a magazine published by a civil rights group has been subpoenaed to provide tape recordings and notes of an interview with a defendant in a murder that may have been racially motivated.

title: Essay; Clinton's Consumer Rip-Off
description: ''You want to buy this new cable service that's much faster than your old modem,'' my son the information architect told me. Not wanting to become the slowpoke pundit, I called my local cable company and ordered ExpressNet. A new black box cost $150 and the monthly fee was $25.

title: Use DNA to Fight Rape
description: To the Editor:

title: Rotation Remains in Manager's Head, Officially
description: Mets Manager Bobby Valentine still has not officially announced his pitching rotation for the National League Championship Series, but Masato Yoshii will almost certainly start Game 1 tomorrow against Greg Maddux. Al Leiter would be available for Games 3 and 7 on his regular rest, meaning that Valentine would have to juggle the order in which Kenny Rogers and Rick Reed pitch. The rotation for the division series was Yoshii, Rogers, Reed and Leiter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUMENTHAL, BEN
description: BLUMENTHAL-Ben. On October 9, 1999. Devoted father of Arthur and Barbara, and the late Robert. Cherished grandfather of Peter, Lindsay and David. Graveside services Tuesday, 11 AM, at Wellwood Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY.

title: Public Role on Reactor
description: To the Editor:

title: Memo to Gore: Express Yourself!
description: He's moved his headquarters to Nashville from Washington. He's hired a new campaign manager and fired his pollsters. What else can Vice President Al Gore do to rejuvenate his flagging campaign? The Op-Ed page asked political veterans and others for their suggestions.

title: Rams (4-0) Rout 49ers, but Show a Sensitive Side
description: At the end, rather than shoot for 50, they took a knee at the San Francisco 49ers' 1-yard line. The St. Louis Rams decided that 42 points were nice enough.

title: The Yankees and Success Linked, Hand in Glove
description: Bernie Williams was among the last to depart the sweet-smelling visitors' clubhouse here, a room soggy from the champagne and beer sprayed and spilt in celebration following the Yankees' mastery of the Texas Rangers in the division series.

title: Rotfront Journal; Tidy Germans Cling to Central Asia
description: With the stroke of a pen, Irene Pauls can change her life forever.

title: Energy Companies Are Tools in Russian Power Struggle
description: Even by Russian standards, the power play last month at the top of Transneft, the country's fourth largest monopoly, was unusually nasty. In the highly charged atmosphere of Russia's yearlong election season, however, the battle was perhaps just the most public example of the fight between political clans over sources of power and money.

title: Sports of The Times; A Baseball Dream Began Back in 1921
description: IF it's not too early to dream about a Subway Series, as every Noo Yawker worth a MetroCard is doing, it's not too early to remember what a Subway Series was really like -- all 13.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Pope May or May Not Visit but Iraqis Rejoice Anyway
description: The very idea is raising hackles in the West. The plan might not come off at all. But in this capital, the expected visit is being hailed as a gift from heaven: The Pope is coming!

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEDERMAN, HERMAN L. (HY)
description: FEDERMAN-Herman L. (Hy). Beloved father, grandfather, brother, uncle and friend, former Deputy Administrative Director of the Workers Compensation Board, died on Friday, October 8, after a long illness. He is survived by his children, Paul, Barbara, Jane and Eric, and his grandchildren, Flo, Joe, Amy and Jonathan, and his brothers and sisters, Matty, Estelle, Dorothy, Murray, Ruth, Belle and Ben.

title: On Treaty, Chirac Is Hypocritical
description: To the Editor:

title: Jones, 17, Wins With Brown Sugar
description: Jennifer Jones of Marion, S.C., aboard Brown Sugar, beat a field of 50 of the East's top young riders to win the United States Equestrian Team Show Jumping Talent Search final yesterday in Gladstone, N.J., the first leg of the equitation Triple Crown, at the team's training center.

title: Con Ed May Be Near a Merger Agreement
description: The Consolidated Edison Company, New York's largest utility, could reach an agreement to merge with Northeast Utilities, New England's largest utility, as early as tomorrow, according to a person familiar with the negotiations.

title: A Long Day of Talking and a Big Night of Singing
description: After it was over, the stage at last cleared and the audience buzzing on its way out after 10 full minutes of standing applause, Arthur Miller stood in the wings backstage at the Civic Opera House here, with an expression of stunned quietude. He was in the company of just a few friends -- a noisy celebration was already under way elsewhere -- and no one was speaking much. Mr. Miller, 83, who for the first time had just seen and heard the adaptation by Lyric Opera of Chicago of his 1955 play, ''A View From the Bridge,'' had a hard time expressing himself.

title: The Stars Give a Party For a Global Web Site
description: When is a benefit not a benefit? When it's a start-up party for a Web site. Three all-star concerts were given on Saturday for www.netaid.org, a Web site intended to take on not just one cause on one occasion but long-term work on five major global issues: poverty, the environment, human rights, refugees and poor countries' debt. It was a way for stars to demonstrate concern about everything from malnutrition in Bolivia to toxic oil-refinery waste in Lake Charles, La.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUTKAY, JULIUS (JACK)
description: RUTKAY-Julius (Jack). Of Floral Park, NY, on Saturday, October 9. Beloved husband of Hillary. Loving father of Jacalynne Seidel of Warrenton, VA, and Wayne and Louise Rutkay of Millburn, NJ. Also survived by eight grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Funeral from Riverside-Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY, today 11 AM. Donations may be made to the Charles T. King Student Loan Fund, PO Box 45, Short Hills, NJ, 07078 in lieu of flowers.

title: Notion of a New Al Gore
description: Vice President Al Gore said he was trying to ''let it all hang out'' and learning how to be less studied and more authentic. Page A12.

title: E-Commerce Report; Turning small businesses' Internet dreams into reality.
description: COMPANIES hoping to do business on the Web are being bombarded with more solutions than ever -- all promising to provide services that address the problem of how to set up shop on line.

title: Perelman Aims a Shotgun At Society's Varied Foibles
description: As a humorist writing for The New Yorker, S. J. Perelman always had a reserved seat at the Algonquin round table; as a screenwriter he wrote zany Marx brothers classics like ''Horse Feathers,'' and the film adaptation of ''Around the World in 80 Days;'' as a playwright he was a bomb.

title: Equity and Debt Offerings Are Scheduled
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Resurrecting a Heisman Notion
description: There are a host of ways for college football players to get knocked out of the running for the Heisman Trophy: season-ending injuries, the poor record of a candidate's team, statistics that don't quite meet standards set by opinion-makers, or a poor performance in a big game.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ETRA, SHIRLEY
description: ETRA-Shirley. Song of Mama. We hold this image: you are sitting, elegantly dressed, not extravagant, graciously hosting. Upright, wry smile, inscrutable gaze. Proud, independent Boston Lady of no nonsense, no complaint, no regret, no words minced, great forbearance. Humble matriarch, holding still, holding firm, holding together, offering yourself to nourish others-the family glue, our protection. A brave, wise, stubborn, clear, sharp, soft, tough, tender, fierce, fiesty, feminine, force to be celebrated. We hold this image of your quiet dignity and beauty. Thank you for not stopping us, not giving up on us, letting us dream, letting us fail, letting us go. For selfless generosity never withheld. For being so strong, for caring for us in ways we are only beginning to understand. We will never forget you. Shirley Ruth Etra, award-winning grandmother of Max, Alexander, Diana and Daniel; beloved mother of her children and sons-in-laws, Julie Etra and Larry Turk, John Etra, and Gina and Kermit Stick; widow of Max J. Etra, her ''life's passion''; loving companion of Sidney Berman, and devoted friend to Danny, Paul, Stephanie, Jackie and Tony; died early Wednesday morning, October 6, 1999, peacefully in her home surrounded by loved ones. She is survived by her brothers, Richard and Robert Leeds. She was 77 years old. Memorial to be scheduled. Contributions in lieu of flowers to the American Civil Liberties Union or any organization that supports breast cancer research.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAFTEL, NAOMI
description: HAFTEL-Naomi. Beloved wife of Moses, mother of Pamela, Linda and Richard, grandmother of Jennifer, John, Allison, Jered and Julia, sister of Moses. For arrangements call, 800-395-9199.

title: Cambria Journal; Thrift Dims a Well-Loved Lighthouse
description: All is peaceful and dark along this swath of central California coastline nowadays. For some folks here, especially those with bay-window views of the Pacific Ocean, that just isn't right.

title: Universal Hopes 1999's Hits Will Silence the Rumor Mill
description: A year ago, Universal Pictures was a forlorn little puppy. The studio's entire roster of summer movies had grossed just $62 million. And to cap it all, Universal finished a lackluster year by watching its two most expensive and important films of late 1998, ''Meet Joe Black'' and ''Babe: Pig in the City'' tank at the box office.

title: Celebration Dissolves Into a Rash
description: The Yankees were supposed to be celebrating after they completed a sweep of Texas in the division series, but Derek Jeter and some of his teammates were not smiling. They were comparing rashes.

title: Wild Wildlife
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Biggest Nasdaq Market Maker Says Its Income Will Trail Forecasts
description: The Knight/Trimark Group, the biggest Nasdaq market maker, said today that its third-quarter income would rise less than analysts had forecast because of fewer trades from Internet brokers, the company's main customers.

title: Cuts in Commissions Sting Travel Agents
description: Three more airlines cut travel agent commissions to 5 percent from 8 percent yesterday, making the latest reduction in commissions all but a fait accompli for most of the industry.

title: ROUNDUP
description: DENVER

title: The importance of famous brand names is stressed by executives at an ad conference.
description: FAMOUS brand names, of people as well as products, were the name of the game yesterday at the second general session of the 1999 annual conference of the Association of National Advertisers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AEDER, MILTON
description: AEDER-Milton. Gesher records with deep sorrow the passing of the beloved brother of our Honorary President, Arthur Aeder. May the entire bereaved family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Daniel Tropper, Founder Philip Schatten, Chairman Hillel Wiener, Exec VP

title: Companies Join to Promote A Linux Operating System
description: Trying to nudge Linux software into the mainstream of computing, three companies are joining in an unusual collaboration to promote Debian, a Linux operating system.

title: Louis Claiborne, 72, Deputy Solicitor General
description: Louis F. Claiborne, a deputy solicitor general who argued more than 60 cases on behalf of the Government before the Supreme Court and was noted for the elegance of his legal briefs, died on Wednesday at his home in Wivenhoe, Essex, England. He was 72 and also had a home in Nerja, Spain.

title: Marvin G. Freid, 89, a Manhattan Dentist
description: Dr. Marvin G. Freid, who was a dentist for more than 50 years, mostly in Manhattan, died on Friday at a hospital in Cortlandt Manor, N.Y. He was 89.

title: Giving Trump A Swift Kick Upstairs
description: BY the reckoning of no less than the United Nations, the world's population hits the six billion mark today.

title: Sports of The Times; Todd Pratt Can Stand The Heat
description: TODD PRATT does not remember much about the 1997 Super Bowl only the intense heat from the pizza oven.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ERENBERG, LILLIAN
description: ERENBERG-Lillian. Beloved wife and life partner for 60 years of the late Benjamin. Devoted mother of the late Elissa Erenberg and Joel Erenberg. Loving grandmother of the late Marc Barron Erenberg, Robin Hilary and Michael Marc Erenberg. Dear sister of Betty Beatty, the late Morris and Harry and the late Bella, Renee & Annie. From her youth she championed causes to improve and protect the children of the world as well as being a tireless worker on behalf of Jewish health, welfare & secular. Service 10AM Wednesday at ''Wien & Wien'', 402 Park Street, Hackensack, New Jersey. Memorial contributions in memory of Lillian Erenberg may be directed to the Trauma Education and Injury Prevention Fund at Hackensack University Medical Center, Attention: John LoCurto, M.D., 30 Prospect Ave., Hackensack, N.J. 07601.

title: CALIFORNIA TO SET LEVEL OF STAFFING FOR NURSING CARE
description: Over the objections of the state's health care industry, Gov. Gray Davis has signed a bill that will make California the first state to require hospitals to meet fixed nurse-to-patient ratios, in an effort to force higher quality care and combat cost-cutting measures in the place where managed care was born.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, ISIDORE
description: FRIEDMAN-Isidore. The Riverdale Jewish Center extends profound condolences to Sidney Friedman on the loss of his beloved father. May the families be comforted among the mourners of Zion & Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN GAINS. The yen rose amid fading expectations that the Bank of Japan's policy makers would increase the money supply to stem the yen's rise. In New York, the dollar settled at 106.68 yen, down from 107.56 Friday.

title: Too Much of a Good Thing? Doctor Challenges Drug Manual
description: When doctors need information about what dose of medicine to prescribe, they usually consult a fat navy blue book called the Physicians' Desk Reference -- P.D.R. for short -- which is an extensive compilation of data about drugs from their manufacturers.

title: Politics of Fear And Quality of Life; Brouhaha in Brooklyn
description: To the Editor:

title: ANGLOGOLD LOOKS ABROAD
description: The world's biggest gold company, Anglogold Ltd., agreed to buy Acacia Resources Ltd. of Australia for $832 million (Australian), or $541 million (United States) in stock as it expands beyond South Africa, where costs are the highest in the world. Johannesburg-based Anglogold offered 3.5 shares for every 100 in Acacia. Acacia's board said it would recommend that shareholders accept the offer.

title: A Priest's Pain
description: To the Editor:

title: Elite College's President Takes to the Road to Attract the Disadvantaged
description: At Hamilton High School, a grand old building in a gritty slice of West Los Angeles, Ruth J. Simmons surveyed a roomful of 35 black and brown female faces and saw her own.

title: In Brazil, MCI's Planned Purchase of Sprint Truly Is a Big Deal
description: MCI Worldcom Inc.'s planned acquisition of the Sprint Corporation could send a jolt through Brazil's telecommunications industry, which has emerged as a battleground for many of the world's largest communications companies.

title: For Hardiest Mets Fans, In Line Is the Place to Be
description: Tom Walsh grew up with the New York Mets. Literally.

title: In Search of Willpower
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The President believes that it is inappropriate for him to say to the world that the United States is out of the non-proliferation business during an election year.''

title: New Jersey Officials Accuse Port Authority of Skirting Law
description: Elected officials in New Jersey yesterday denounced a land deal between the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and Continental Airlines as an attempt to circumvent local authority to redevelop an industrial area in Elizabeth.

title: Sanitation Department to Tow Motor Home Left on Highway
description: The New York City Sanitation Department has said it will remove a battered, charred shell of a motor home that was abandoned on the Henry Hudson Parkway near 108th Street, ending a bureaucratic mystery about which agency was responsible for carting the hulk away.

title: Even Parcells Can't Save This Season for the Jets
description: Recently, Bill Parcells privately fretted that the season was one of the most disastrous and painful of his coaching career. Then, at about 10:20 P.M. yesterday, as the Jacksonville Jaguars jumped to a 10-0 lead over the Jets, effectively ending the game, things got worse for the all-world coach. His season became as dead as the artificial turf at Giants Stadium.

title: VITAL SIGNS: PATTERNS; The Right Place for a Heart Attack
description: Having a heart attack in an integrated neighborhood may offer a better chance of getting cardiopulmonary resuscitation.

title: Bravos for the Return of a Diva: Barcelona's Opera House
description: If the destruction of the Gran Teatre del Liceu by fire on the morning of Jan. 31, 1994, was a nightmare, the reopening of the legendary opera house at a gala performance Thursday evening was like awakening to find that nothing had changed. As the curtain went up on a new production of Puccini's ''Turandot,'' the red-and-gold auditorium looked much as it did when the Liceu was inaugurated in 1847 and when it was rebuilt after the last fire in 1861.

title: Strategy in Schiele Art Case Questioned
description: In early January 1998, the outlook seemed dire for two families trying to regain two Egon Schiele paintings that had been confiscated from their relatives by the Nazis and later wound up at an Austrian foundation. The Museum of Modern Art, which had borrowed the works for an exhibition, had turned down pleas that it hold on to the paintings while the families contested ownership. Instead, the museum said, the works would go back to the Leopold Foundation in Vienna on ''Jan. 8 or shortly thereafter.''

title: Fans Forgive Sprewell, but Knicks Yet to Forget
description: When Latrell Sprewell sent the ball through the net with a tomahawk dunk, the 8,000 fans who attended Family Day at Madison Square Garden yesterday were more than happy to forgive him for skipping a week of training camp in Charleston, S.C.

title: NATIONAL-OILWELL TO BUY HITEC, MAKER OF DRILLING GEAR
description: National-Oilwell Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire Hitec A.S., a Norwegian maker of oil and gas drilling equipment, for $125 million in stock and cash. In the transaction, National-Oilwell will issue 8 million shares and pay about $20 million for Hitec's shares outstanding. National-Oilwell, based in Houston, makes machinery and equipment used in oil and gas drilling and production. It had revenue of $344.3 million in the six months ended June 30. Hitec specializes in automation and remote-control technologies used in drilling for oil and gas. It reported revenue of $180.4 million for fiscal 1998. Shares of National-Oilwell rose 62.5 cents to close at $13.125 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Getting the Shakes On a Personal Journey
description: Lisa Townsend

title: Proving That Time Is Not of the Essence
description: Maurizio Pollini's recital at Carnegie Hall on Sunday afternoon made two great works separated by almost a century and a half -- Beethoven's ''Hammerklavier'' Sonata and Karlheinz Stockhausen's Piano Piece X -- seem like mountains in the same chain. Both need, and here got, huge reserves of physical power and intellectual stamina. Both performances showed that brutality -- fierce discords, resolute attacks, abrupt changes of mood and sudden pauses, with the addition in the Stockhausen of clusters played with palms and forearms -- can become, if sufficiently focused, beauty.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHMAN, ARNOLD LAWRENCE
description: FISHMAN-Arnold Lawrence. Beloved husband of Grace nee Riefberg. Loving father of George and Hilary (Ted) Dette. Fond grandfather of Sarah and Jacob. Funeral was held at Weinstein Family Services, Wilmette Chapel (847256-5700). Interment Shalom Memorial Park, Arlington Heights, IL.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SILVERSTONE, MARILYN
description: SILVERSTONE-Marilyn. Memorial service Thursday, October 14, 6PM at the New York Shambhala Center 118 West 22 St, 6th Floor.

title: Front Row
description: Logos on Sleeves, Among Other Places

title: Dancing at the Precipice of the End of the World
description: A waltz does in fact open ''Cannibal's Waltz,'' Lanie Robertson's new play about Theodor Herzl and the founding of the Zionist movement, and a fine bit of dancing it is, by four actors whose feet know what Johann Strauss wanted them to do. As it turns out, that diversion is almost the only episode in the play that is totally comprehensible.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RUBIN, ROSE N.
description: RUBIN-Rose N. Family and friends will gather between 2 P.M. and 5 P.M. on Saturday October 16, 1999 at Rose's home to celebrate her life.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHELKAN, GREGOR, HAZZAN
description: SHELKAN-Gregor, Hazzan. The Cantors Assembly records with sorrow the passing of one of our founding members, past President, beloved colleague, teacher, friend and tireless worker on behalf of the Assembly and Hazzanut. The possessor of a magnificent voice, he quietly and gently served the spiritual needs of his congregants with dignity, warmth and care. We extend our sympathy to his family and loved ones. May his memory abide as a blessing. Hazzan Chaim Najman, President Hazzan Stephen J. Stein, Executive Vice President Hazzan Abraham B. Shapiro, Executive Administrator

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RINGWALD, MARGARET A.
