description: RINGWALD-Margaret A. Of Yonkers, New York, on October 10, 1999. Wife of the late Eugene, mother of Marie, Carl, Anne, Thomas & Christopher. Grandmother of Christopher, Michael, Steven, Madeleine and Jeanne. Aunt to Susan Fears. Calling hours at The Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville between the hours of 2-4 & 7-9PM, Wednesday. A Mass of Christian Burial, at St. Eugene's Church, Yonkers on Thursday, October 14 at 10:00AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLLOWAY, BRUCE
description: HOLLOWAY-Bruce. The New York Institute of Technology community records with profound sorrow the passing of General Bruce Holloway, American patriot and longtime member of the college's Board of Trustees. The epitome of courage and integrity, he will be sorely missed. Our deepest condolences are extended to his wife, daughters and his entire family.

title: Japan's Troubling Trend: Rising Teen-Age Crime
description: Insulated by the innocence of her 16 years, Hanae Nagatani had never taken seriously the threats against her.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KREGER, JILL H. (NEE MANDEL)
description: KREGER-Jill H. (nee Mandel) on October 10, 1999. Beloved wife of Alex. Loving mother Aimee and Richard. Dear sister of Susan Feigenbaum, Alan and Philip. Funeral Service Tuesday (today) 12 noon at the John J. Fox Funeral Home, Inc., 2080 Boston Post Road, Larchmont, New York 10538. Interment at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery in Queens. The family will receive friends at their home Tuesday evening, and Wednesday and Thursday starting after noon. Memorial donations to O.P.U.S., 101 N. Central Avenue, Hartsdale, NY 10530, would be appreciated.

title: Fugitive Is Arrested Near Rome
description: Giancarlo Parretti, a flamboyant former Hollywood mogul with longstanding international arrest warrants hanging over him for convictions on perjury and other frauds, was arrested today near Orvieto, a medieval hilltop town about 70 miles north of Rome.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SITZER, ESTHER H.
description: SITZER-Esther H., 88. A resident of Forest Trace, Lauderhill, Florida. Died peacefully on October 8, 1999. She is mourned by all who loved her, especially Evelyn and Bob Gomer, Helen and Paul Hodys and Bill and Kathy Sitzer. She was a lifelong active member of the ADL and a past President of Victory Chapter of B'nai B'rith. Cherished by all who knew her, she will be sorely missed. Donations may be made to ADL in her memory.

title: Colombian Folklore and Afro-Latin Rhythm
description: A band like the one led by the Colombian singer Toto La Momposina immediately commands respect. Toto -- who generally speaking is a folklorist playing century-old Colombian-Caribbean music, but has a performance style that transcends mere demonstration and enters the area of beauty -- appeared on Saturday night at Davis Hall.

title: Offense Rests for a Jets Team That Falls Deeper Into the Cellar
description: A Jets team still searching for its identity could hardly afford the lapses it committed tonight against the Jacksonville Jaguars, a quality club.

title: A Clinton Critic Pushes For a High-Stakes Vote
description: Don't get Senator James M. Inhofe started on Bill Clinton.

title: Nixon Lobbied Grand Jury to Indict Hiss in Espionage Case, Transcripts Reveal
description: On Dec. 13, 1948, Richard M. Nixon, then a young Congressman, appeared in New York before a Federal grand jury that was investigating Communist infiltration of the Government. Two days later, the grand jury indicted Alger Hiss, a former State Department official, in a perjury case that became one of the most divisive issues of the cold war and thrust Nixon permanently into the national spotlight.

title: George Forrest, 84, Songwriter For Broadway, Films and Clubs
description: George Forrest, the songwriter who collaborated with Robert Wright on the words and music for the songs ''Stranger in Paradise'' and ''Baubles, Bangles and Beads,'' died on Sunday in Miami, where he lived. He was 84.

title: In Theater, Good News, if Early, Is Bad News
description: The review was a rave, but the reaction to its publication was not.

title: Chic and Attitude With a Tango Beat
description: Compagnie Quat'zarts

title: Politics of Fear And Quality of Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Worked Hard for A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s Support of Gore
description: With the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s endorsement hanging in the balance, President Clinton did his Vice President a big favor on Sunday morning.

title: Improbably, The Tiger Survives
description: In an old Vietnamese myth about how the tiger got its stripes, a man tries to show the great cat who's boss by lashing it to a tree and setting the tree on fire. But the tiger is so powerful and so inured to pain that it strains against the flaming rope until it breaks free, its brush with extinction evident only in the black marks seared on its fur.

title: Side Effects Raise Flag On Dangers Of Ephedra
description: The herb is called ephedra, or ma huang, and it comes from a shrublike plant grown widely in Asia. It can be found in more than 200 diet supplements, in pills and powders, drinks and diet bars, for sale in health food stores and on the Internet.

title: Flu Season Starts Early, But Its Course Is Cloudy
description: The flu season does not usually start before November, so health officials in the state of New York were startled last week when the influenza A virus raced through Monroe Community Hospital, a chronic-care center in Rochester, infecting many elderly patients before they had received flu shots.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about a Coast Guard inquiry into a fire on Sept. 19 aboard the Carnival Cruise Lines ship Tropicale misstated the length of time the ship was disabled. The ship was adrift in the Gulf of Mexico for 21 hours, not two days, before the crew was able to restart one engine.

title: Corrections
description: A theater review in Weekend on Friday about ''Taxicab Chronicles,'' at New York Performance Works in Manhattan, misattributed a painting that is part of the set. It is by Mark Symczak, the set designer, not LeRoy Neiman.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ROBERT W. BAIRD & CO., Milwaukee, a unit of Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Co., agreed to buy the British investment bank Granville P.L.C. for $61 million as both companies seek to expand their business of advising midsize growth companies.

title: Appeal of Bradley's Style May Hide Potential Pitfall
description: Fletcher Lokey drove 90 minutes to hear former Senator Bill Bradley, a Democratic candidate for President, speak at a high school in southern New Hampshire last week, and he was not disappointed. ''I was electrified,'' he said afterward.

title: The Insufferably Valiant Meet the Lust for Revenge
description: You can hear the movie trailer now: ''In a world gone mad, a passionate woman wages war with the one man on earth who can save her. Their clash of wills blazes with the fire of Celtic pride and burns in the blood-soaked soil of . . . 'The Clearing.' ''

title: WASHINGTON.COM -- A special report; Information Superhighway Is Just Outside the Beltway
description: Anyone trying to understand who holds power in the nation's capital need only look in one place: the owner's box at Jack Kent Cooke Stadium, home of the Washington Redskins.

title: An Indecisive Cage Keeps Nets Guessing
description: The Nets are giving Michael Cage another week to make up his mind whether he wants to join the team this season, Nets General Manager John Nash said today after practice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEPINE, ARTHUR
description: PEPINE-Arthur, at age 62. Of 100 Furman Road, Hamden, CT. Died October 7. Husband of Suzanne Tucker. He was the Assistant to the Dean of Yale School of Drama and a human and disability rights activist. Memorial service Wednsday at 3:30PM in Battell Chapel, Yale University, New Haven, CT.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHUSTER, IRA
description: SCHUSTER-Ira. On this your birthday we will always remember a devoted father and brilliant songwriter. We will always miss you. Phoebe Lewin and family

title: Abroad at Home; Something Rich and Strange
description: What a contradictory country this is. More than any other, it has always been open to new ideas, to change. Looking to the future instead of the past, it has made itself a great force, not just in world markets but in the world of ideas. Yet there is also an America locked in rigid certainties and shibboleths.

title: Rockefeller U. Biologist Wins Nobel Prize for Protein Cell Research
description: Dr. Gunter Blobel, a cellular and molecular biologist at Rockefeller University in Manhattan, won the 1999 Nobel Prize in Medicine yesterday for discovering that proteins carry signals that act as ZIP codes, helping them find their correct locations within the cell.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: BRITISH AIRWAYS JET ORDER
description: Dealing a blow to the Boeing Company, British Airways P.L.C. said it would buy a dozen 100-seat A318 jets, with options on a further 12, from Airbus Industrie, the four-nation European consortium. Boeing had been hoping to fill the order for the short-haul jets with its 106-seat Boeing 717, whose future, analysts said, may now be in doubt. British Airways said the Airbus model, with a list price of $470 million for the 12 firm orders, would fit better with its short-haul fleet.

title: Starting Number, 11 P.M., Didn't Hurt Mets' Rating Numbers
description: Yes, those 11 P.M. Mets-Arizona games last week were too inconvenient, too late and too long. And yes, Major League Baseball needs to find a better way to accommodate viewers in the Eastern time zone when a team plays out west. But whatever the difficulty, local fans watched.

title: A PLAN IS IN WORKS TO PUT OFF A VOTE ON TEST BAN PACT
description: The White House signaled today that it would accept in principle a plan to delay a Senate vote on a nuclear test ban treaty until after President Clinton leaves office.

title: People
description: * Gregoire Sentilhes was named to the new position of president for international operations and chief operating officer at Screaming Media, New York, a Web content network. He had been chief executive at Matra Hachette Multimedia On-Line, Paris, owned by Lagardere Group.

title: Sexism in the Office
description: To the Editor:

title: Bats, Balls and Barbs: The Mets and the Braves Are Ready
description: The Mets had not even arrived this afternoon, and the Atlanta Braves were already dismissing them, flicking Manager Bobby Valentine's provocative remarks away like so many foul tips.

title: Russian Far-Right Party Is Barred From Parliamentary Election
description: The Russian ultranationalist leader Vladimir Zhirinovsky suffered a setback today when his party was barred from participating in parliamentary elections in December.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIPPERLY, MARY SHAW
description: SIPPERLY-Mary Shaw. Of Stony Brook, NY. On October 10, 1999, peacefully after a sudden illness. The 23rd member of her family to graduate from Mount Holyoke College, she worked as an editor of children's books for Charles Scribner and Sons in Manhattan. She is survived by her husband, David P. Sipperly; daughters Margaret S. Salyer of Oklahoma City and Anne S. Braswell of Ocala, Fla.; granddaughters Margaret C. Salyer and Molly S. Braswell. A memorial service will be held at 11am on Friday, October 15 at the Stony Brook Community Church, Stony Brook, NY. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the John T. Mather Memorial Hospital Foundation or Mount Holyoke College, South Hadley, Mass.

title: A Broken Rib May Keep O'Neill Out
description: A distraught Paul O'Neill learned yesterday that he has a fractured rib on his right side and has been advised by his doctors to bypass the American League Championship Series and wait, hope and pray he has healed sufficiently to play if the Yankees advance to the World Series.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PANOFF, SIDNEY
description: PANOFF-Sidney, 84. Of Hallandale, Fl. Passed away Oct. 9, 1999. Survived by his wife Lorraine. Sons Allen, Robert (Janice), and Victor. Grandchildren Sharon, Jody, Brian, Bradley, and Rebecca. Graveside services Wednesday at 11:30 AM (October 13th) at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, New York. Family suggests donations to Hadassah in lieu of flowers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORT, LEON
description: PORT-Leon. On October 11, 1999 at age 93. Beloved husband of Estelle. Loving father of Beth Ann & Allan Fuld and Penny and Peter Glazier. Devoted grandfather of Mathew and Lara Glazier, Andrew & Julie Fuld, Jody & John Atkins. Great-grandfather of Jacob Fuld. Funeral services will held at the Riverside Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue at 11:30 A.M., October 12th. Donations in lieu of flowers, may be made in his memory to the Children's Hearing Institute in New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, WALTER
description: GOODMAN-Walter. Of Great Neck. Beloved husband of Marge. Devoted father of Larry, Bob and Carol. Cherished grandfather of Andrew, Katy and Maggie. Loving brother of Lenny, Leah and the late Pearl. Services Wednesday, 1PM at''Riverside Nassau North'' Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York.

title: Timor Peacekeepers Accuse Indonesian Army
description: The United Nations-backed peacekeeping force in East Timor today accused the Indonesian Army of providing support to an anti-independence militia that fired on peacekeepers over the weekend, raising fears that the army has decided to try openly to sabotage the peacekeeping operation.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, the closing lines were omitted in some copies yesterday from a front-page article about the large number of automatic weapons on the streets of the West Bank, and one shootout that caught up the Abu Salhieh family. The affected passage should have read:

title: Corrections
description: A sports article last Tuesday about NBC's purchase of television rights to the Triple Crown horse races misattributed information about a competing bid, from ABC. The source of that information was not Tom Meeker, the president of Triple Crown Productions, but another person involved in the deal, who declined to be identified publicly.

title: U.S. Study Finds Lack of Control In U.N. Food Aid to North Korea
description: A report prepared for Congress by the General Accounting Office in Washington has found that the United Nations World Food Program is not able to monitor adequately what happens to food aid donated by the United States to North Korea.

title: Hockey Suspicions and Time Fantasies
description: Beware! Two provocative-sounding programs from those two premier PBS documentary series, ''Frontline'' and ''Nova,'' fall flat tonight. ''Nova,'' says a press release, reveals ''fascinating secrets of time travel,'' but there are no revelations except that an hourlong program can stall in a wormhole of theorizing. As for the ''Frontline'' offering, about the supposed corruption of Russian star players in the National Hockey League, it doesn't score at all.

title: Morris West, Popular Novelist Focusing on Faith, Dies at 83
description: Morris West, who used his power as a storyteller and fascination with Roman Catholic faith and morals to spin more than two dozen novels, many of them best sellers like ''The Devil's Advocate'' and ''The Shoes of the Fisherman,'' died on Saturday in Sydney, Australia, where he lived. He was 83.

title: Straight Talk
description: To the Editor:

title: NO BID BY DELLA VALLE
description: Diego Della Valle, an Italian businessman who owns the maker of J. P. Tod loafers, has decided against bidding for Church & Company P.L.C., a 126-year-old British shoemaker, because he considers the current price too high, Church said. Church's shares have risen as much as 5.2 percent since Sept. 9 on hopes Mr. Della Valle would bid against Prada S.p.A., an Italian fashion company that offered 106 million [pounds] ($175.2 million). Mr. Della Valle raised his stake in Church in early September to 9.5 percent from 6.3 percent, setting off the speculation.

title: Politics' New Wave
description: To the Editor:

title: Video Game Industry Makes Push at Self-Policing
description: In an attempt to stave off threatened state and Federal regulation of movies and video games, the nation's video rental stores and video game makers, with the cooperation of the motion picture industry, have joined forces in a push toward self-policing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOM, SOLVEIG ARTHUR
description: BLOM-Solveig Arthur, 62, died October 8, 1999 at a Bangor, Maine hospital. She was born February 7, 1937 in Flekkefjord, Norway, the daughter of Paul Arthur and Liv (Tesdahl) Tobiassen. Solveig was a devoted Christian & a wonderful wife, mother and grandmother. She is survived by her husband Henry McEwan Blom, of Boca Raton, FL. Two sons; Henry A. Blom and a wife Mary Elizabeth, of Bronxville, NY and Paul H. Blom and wife Dina, of New York City, NY. A daughter, Margaret L. Blom, and husband Robin Jones, of Surry, ME. 6 grandchildren: Ian, Kaia, Lara, Haakon, Christian and Colin. Private family services will be held at the families convenience. For information: JordanFernald, Mount Desert, ME.

title: DAEWOO TRUCK SALE LOOMS
description: A South Korean vehicle manufacturer, the Daewoo Motor Company, is negotiating with ''two to three'' European car makers about the sale of its truck and bus manufacturing operations, a Daewoo Motor spokesman said. But the spokesman declined to elaborate, saying Daewoo Motor, an affiliate of the ailing Daewoo Group, had agreed not to disclose the content of the talks. Quoting unidentified sources, a daily financial South Korean newspaper reported that Renault S.A. of France might acquire Daewoo Motor and the commercial vehicles operations of Samsung Motors Inc.

title: Humanitarian Aid in Serbia
description: European foreign ministers yesterday approved the shipment of heating oil to two cities in Serbia controlled by the opposition to Slobodan Milosevic. While the Clinton Administration is concerned that the fuel might indirectly help the Milosevic regime, the planned shipments actually do not go far enough. Heat is a basic humanitarian necessity during the cold Balkan winters, and should go to all Serbs who need it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILDRICK, STANLEY DONALD
description: WILDRICK-Stanley Donald of Chatham, NJ and E. Quogue, NY on October 10, 1999. Husband of Carolie P., father of Donald of Park Ridge, NJ, & Carolie Johnson of Chatham, NJ. He is also survived by a granddaughter Kristen, and a brother Rev. Dr. Kenyon J. Wildrick. A funeral service will be held at the Chatham United Methodist Church, 460 Main St., on Thursday, October 14, 1999 at 10:00 A.M. Friends may gather at the Wm. A. Bradley & Son Funeral Home, 345 Main St., Chatham, NJ on Wednesday from 2-4 & 7-9 P.M. Those who wish may contribute in his memory to Cancer Care, Inc., 241 Millburn Avenue, Suite 241C, Millburn, New Jersey 07041.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: BASEBALL PLAYOFFS
description: Pitching in relief, Pedro Martinez threw six hitless innings as the Red Sox completed a series comeback after being down two games to none.

title: Baby Is Found Dead in Trash On Broadway
description: A newborn baby was found dead in a garbage can on one of New York City's busiest corners yesterday, leading the police to canvass the streets and hospitals of midtown Manhattan in search of the mother.

title: SUHARTO INQUIRY ENDED BY JAKARTA
description: The Government of President B. J. Habibie announced today that it was dropping an investigation of possible corruption by former President Suharto, defying public sentiment days before an assembly is to choose the next President of Indonesia.

title: BIG FLOWER HOLDINGS AGREES TO A REVISED BUYOUT PLAN
description: Big Flower Holdings Inc., the largest United States printer of advertising inserts, agreed yesterday to revised terms of its $1.9 billion management-led buyout and warned that third-quarter profit would fall short of estimates. Big Flower said it would accept $31.50 a share in cash. The previous offer, announced June 29, called for $30 in cash and $5.25 in preferred stock. Both sets of terms valued the company at $1.9 billion. Big Flower warned that third-quarter earnings would be 5 to 10 percent lower than a year ago, when it earned 57 cents a share. The New York-based company had been expected to earn 69 cents, according to the First Call Corporation. Since the buyout was announced, Big Flower's shares have fallen 13 percent. They rose 93.75 cents yesterday, to $28.375.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVANDER, HUBERT MYLES
description: LEVANDER-Hubert Myles. On October 9, 1999. Beloved husband of Alda. Devoted father of Melanie and Ethan. Funeral services Wednesday, October 13, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Forest Hills. For details: 718-793-3883. In lieu of flowers, donations to UJA would be appreciated.

title: Abbott Posts 10% Rise in 3d-Quarter Profit
description: Abbott Laboratories said today that its third-quarter profit increased 10 percent as rising sales of diagnostic tests and an ulcer drug made up for setbacks with other medicines.

description: WERBIN-Richard. Dear husband of Sheryll and brother of Peggy Laitman. Loving father to Spencer and Linda Greenwald. Dearest grandfather to Sarah, Anne and Alison Greenwald.

description: Here is a scouting report on the National League Championship Series, with comments by Murray Chass.

title: Bruce Ritter, 72, Dies; Led Covenant House
description: The Rev. Bruce Ritter, who founded a shelter for runaways in 1969 and then resigned under pressure as its president in 1990 after being accused of financial and sexual improprieties, died Thursday at his farmhouse near Decatur, N.Y. He was 72.

description: IN NEVADA

title: Impalement, South Florida's Special Highway Hazard
description: Some drivers here fear Interstate 95, for schizophrenic traffic that plummets from 75 and 80 miles per hour to tire-smoking zero, without warning. They fear the long trains of bumper-to-bumper drivers who speed just a few feet apart with no hope of stopping in time.

title: Israeli History Lesson
description: To the Editor:

title: John Doe's DNA
description: A prosecutor in Milwaukee has found an intriguing new use for DNA evidence. With the six-year time limit for filing charges in three rape cases about to expire, he filed rape and kidnapping counts last month against an unknown man implicated by semen tests in three 1993 assaults, identifying him only by his DNA code. The warrant refers to the alleged assailant as ''John Doe, unknown male with matching deoxyribonucleic acid profile.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASSERMAN, ALBERT
description: WASSERMAN-Albert. On Oct. 9, of Boca Raton, Florida. Formerly of Kings Point, NY and Fort Lee, NJ. Beloved husband of Edith, dear father of Stephen and the late Phyllis Steinhardt, loving grandfather to Lori Scher and Geoffrey Wasserman. Shiva is being observed through 10:00 PM Thursday at the home of Stephen Wasserman, 220 East 63rd Street. In lieu of flowers, family requests that donations be made to the Alzheimers Association, NYC.

title: Overtime Is the Best Part Of Dull, Mediocre Play
description: The Devils and the Ottawa Senators had their first experience today with the National Hockey League's new overtime format, which produced the most exciting hockey of the afternoon after three periods of mediocre play had produced two goals by each team.

title: Nasdaq at Record High as Dow Falls a Bit in a Light Day
description: The Nasdaq composite index rose to a record high yesterday, propelled by a handful of telecommunications and semiconductor stocks. With banks closed, however, many traders were off for the Columbus Day holiday, leaving most stocks little changed.

title: BLUE CIRCLE SELLS UNIT
description: The British building material company Blue Circle Industries said it was selling its heating division for $793 million to Baxi Partnership. The heating division, with sales of $741 million in 1998, is one of Europe's largest manufacturers of central heating products.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: The Cult of Personality Vs. Needs of the Market; Martha Stewart, the Company, Is Poised To Go Public. But Is It a Good Thing?
description: Public corporations, however short their shelf life in the market turns out to be, are intended to be immortal. Public figures like Martha Stewart, on the other hand, usually wear out after 75 years or so. Therein lies the risk of the single-celebrity corporation.

title: Health Care Horror Stories Are Compelling but One-Sided
description: The debate leading up to the House vote last week to expand patients' rights was punctuated by a stream of health care horror stories.

title: Japanese Accused of 'Checkbook' Lobbying : Race to Head Unesco Takes on Heated Tone
description: PARIS  The executive board of Unesco begins a secretive process this week to elect a director-general from among 11 candidates, most of them political obscurities, put forward by member governments.

title: Time to Learn
description: To the Editor:

title: Noah's Kin Landed in Ireland, Don't You Know?
description: For many Americans of a certain age, their first encounter with the history and lore of Ireland came from the LP's of the Clancy Brothers and Tommy Makem or, if one was lucky, the group's concerts on the college circuit. From their albums one learned that ''Kevin Barry gave his young life/for the cause of liberty.'' One heard rude lyrics to old ballads like ''Galway Bay,'' children's ditties that included imprecations against ''King Billy'' and even an introduction to the haunting poetry of Yeats.

title: Hofstra's Passer Is Hard To Ignore
description: For Coach Joe Gardi of Hofstra, the videos in his film room are piled so high it looks as if he went to two-for-one night at a local video store. Before every home game, a gaggle of National Football League scouts watch the tapes, each one featuring the best quarterback you probably never heard of: Giovanni Carmazzi.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DURUFLE, CHEVALIER, MARIE MADELEINE
description: DURUFLE - CHEVALIER - Marie Madeleine. The St. Wilfrid Club of New York mourns the death on October 5, 1999 of Mme. Marie Madeleine Durufle-Chevalier, concert organist, Organist titulaire, St. Etienne du Mont, Paris.

title: The Italianization of Europe
description: We are quite the best country in Europe,'' Lady Thatcher, she of the tart tongue and whiplash diction, recently informed her fellow Tories. In her lifetime, she added, ''all the problems have come from mainland Europe and all the solutions have come from the English-speaking nations across the world.''

title: Montredon Journal; French See a Hero in War on 'McDomination'
description: At home here in his 500-year-old stone farmhouse, Jose Bove seems pretty relaxed for someone out on $17,000 bail.

To Elizabeth, her brother Erwin, children, grandchildren and great grandchildren, our deepest sympathy. title: Q & A

title: Pfizer Says It Donated to Group That Paid for Two Pataki Trips
description: Another large New York-based corporation with significant interests in Albany said yesterday that it had contributed to a nonprofit trade group that paid for two trips by Gov. George E. Pataki to Hungary.

title: ASHANTI BID IS RAISED
description: A British-listed mining company, Lonmin P.L.C., said it had offered to increase its stake in the Ashanti Goldfields Company to 90 percent from 32 percent. The all-stock deal, valuing the company at $784 million, would require banks to withhold demands for immediate payment of hundreds of millions of dollars in margin calls relating to the recent surge in gold prices. Shares in Lonmin, the world's third-largest platinum producer, rose 2 percent, to 581 pence. Ashanti shares, which trade on seven stock exchanges, rose as much as 27 percent in Germany, to 4.95 euros.

title: What Is a Minority-Owned Business?
description: Long united in the struggle to maintain special breaks for nonwhite entrepreneurs, some civil rights leaders and minority business groups have become divided over a basic concept: what is a minority-owned company.

title: Looking Ahead As 2 Utilities Continue Talks
description: If the Consolidated Edison Company reaches a deal to buy Northeast Utilities, the combined company will have 4.7 million customers stretching as far north as New Hampshire and will eventually be able to sell cheaper power in the New York region, analysts said yesterday.

title: Blair Gives Ulster Job to Aide Brushed by Scandal
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair brought his closest political confidant, Peter Mandelson, back into Government today, putting him in the strategically crucial position of Northern Ireland Secretary.

title: ITALY SELLING UTILITY SHARES
description: As Europe deregulates its energy market, Italy wants to cash in. It will put on the block part of the former national energy company, Enel S.p.A., in an offering that values the utility at as much as $55 billion. Starting on Oct. 25, the Government will sell 19.8 percent of Enel's stock, or 2.4 billion shares, at a price of 3.4 euros and 4.3 euros, or $3.60 and $4.50. In November, Enel will be listed on the Milan bourse and the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Global Crossing Buying a Telecommunications Unit in Britain
description: Global Crossing Ltd. said today that it had acquired the telecommunications business of Racal Electronics P.L.C. of Britain for 1 billion [pounds], or about $1.65 billion, in cash. The deal signals an aggressive push by Global Crossing into Europe, even as it absorbs the Frontier Corporation of the United States, a provider of long-distance and local phone service.

title: Medicine Ball Pops Back Into Vogue
description: The medicine ball, darling of the trimming and toning crowd before its exile to six decades of exercise Elba, has bounced back.

Harvey is survived by his wife Laurie, his children Howard, Judi, Hilary, Jordan and Victoria, his brother Bruce and his aunt Ethel. A memorial service will be held at Gutterman-Warheit Memorial Chapel, Boca Raton, FL. Tuesday (today), 1PM. In lieu of flowers, the family request donations to be directed to the American Cancer Society. From Bensonhurst, Brooklyn to Boca Raton, FL....quite a ride.

description: For millennia -- or maybe just sleepless nights that felt that long -- people with serious snoring problems could rely on only their spouses for treatment.

description: LEWIN-Natalie. On October 10, 1999. A kind, loving and generous woman. Services on Tuesday, 10 AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

description: Glaxo Wellcome Inc. in Research Triangle Park, N.C., part of Glaxo Wellcome P.L.C., said yesterday that it had awarded the creative account of its Imitrex brand, a prescription migraine medicine, to Grey Advertising Inc. in New York. Billings were estimated at $40 million.

title: Serb Opposition Leaders Boycott European Union Session
description: Leaders of the Serbian opposition to President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia found themselves criticized on two fronts today. They angered the European Union by boycotting a meeting to protest its demand to extradite Mr. Milosevic for war crimes, while Mr. Milosevic himself called them cowards, sycophants and traitors.

description: Perhaps because so many private-sector employees do not get Columbus Day off from work, or perhaps because so many Italian-American families have dispersed into the suburbs, Fifth Avenue seemed occupied yesterday by equal numbers of marchers and spectators during the Columbus Day Parade.

description: STEWART-Edward S. Jr. It has been three years. I miss your gentle voice and good counsel. Gar

description: Rutgers University's mainstream campus newspaper apologized yesterday for publishing a comic strip last Wednesday that some black students considered insensitive.

description: One lives in hope, as Andre Leon Talley, the Vogue editor, likes to say -- meaning that for every budding genius, every horribly effete or earnest display, one lives in hope of seeing a young designer finally burst flush with talent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCMANUS, MARIE
description: McMANUS - Marie. Dedicated Board member of the Northwest Bronx Community and Clergy Coalition. Marie loved DeVoe Park and helped win many improvements over three decades. At the age of 91, Marie was still attending night meetings and motivating other members. She will be remembered and missed by hundreds of her neighbors.

title: Law Limiting Terms Jump-Starts Races in New York City for 2001
description: The glare from the 2000 Senate race, the expected battle between Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Hillary Rodham Clinton, has obscured a change on the New York political horizon so extensive that choosing one new senator pales by comparison.

description: WHEN the chief executive of a company proposes that the company acquire another company that she also runs, it pays to pay attention to the details of the transaction.

title: REPSOL TO SELL ASSETS
description: Europe's sixth-largest oil company, Repsol-YPF S.A., plans to sell its British and Indonesian assets, two Argentine units and a United States oilfield, offsetting part of the cost of its $15 billion purchase of the Argentine oil company YPF S.A. Repsol-YPF aims to earn at least $2.5 billion to help to reduce its debt to less than 40 percent of its equity by 2002.

title: Italians Bare Soviet 'Spies' But the Disclosures Backfire
description: Hoping to stanch a growing spy scandal, an Italian parliamentary committee made public a dossier today identifying 261 politicians, bureaucrats and journalists as having cooperated, in some cases unwittingly, with the Soviet Union.

description: To the Editor:

title: Hudson Towns Wary of Rail's Reach; Commuter Line Extension Faces Hostility in Bucolic North Dutchess
description: With its luminous views of the Hudson River and the Catskill Mountains beyond, the terrain surrounding this Dutchess County hamlet helped inspire the Hudson River School of painting, which for more than a century helped define the American wilderness.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE SURGES. Coffee soared 7 percent as dry weather in Brazil, the world's top grower, reduced expectations for a record crop. In New York, coffee for December delivery rose 5.85 cents, to 90.95 cents a pound.

title: Major Court Challenge on How State Allocates School Funds
description: A state judge will hear opening arguments today in a case that poses the most serious challenge yet to New York State's method of financing public schools. The case mirrors lawsuits around the nation that have often forced states to allocate more money to poor schools.

description: PRESS-Harvey. October 9, 1999. In loving memory of a very special person who has touched so many with his special ways. Your passing is a loss and empty feeling that with definitely take time to heal, but will never diminish. We are fortunate to have had you for our friend for so many years. We treasured the times we spent together. Looking down from the heavens, you will see just how much you are loved and missed. description: de TAR-Vernon. The St. Wilfrid Club of New York mourns the death of Vernon de Tar, distinguished choral conductor, organist, and teacher.

title: AT&T AND BRITISH TELECOM ADD TO JOINT VENTURE
description: The AT&T Corporation, the No. 1 United States long-distance telephone company, and British Telecommunications P.L.C., Britain's biggest phone company, said yesterday that they would invest $3 billion in their Concert venture over the next five years to transmit voice, data and video faster between large cities. The network, which will use Internet protocol technology, will link about 60 cities by the end of next year, said David Dorman, chief executive of Concert.

title: A Labor Lift for Mr. Gore
description: The A.F.L.-C.I.O. endorsement of Vice President Gore, which is expected tomorrow, will give him a badly needed boost in his battle against Bill Bradley. Indeed, had Mr. Gore failed to secure the backing of organized labor this week, his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination would have been heavily damaged. But the lift comes with a cost, because it reinforces the Vice President's problems as an insider too friendly with the Washington establishment and too eager to please Democratic constituencies.

title: Of Life With Father And High-Tech Gadgets
description: Charles Dennis

title: Eze Is Winner In 3-Horse Photo
description: Eze, a 3-year-old daughter of Williamstown and granddaughter of Seattle Slew, survived a three-horse photo finish yesterday to win the Pebbles Handicap over Colstar and Jazz on the Belmont Park turf.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Nasdaq Rises to a Record As Dow and S.& P. 500 Slip

title: A Backup Catcher in the Wings for the Mets?
description: The Mets still have not decided if they will add Mike Kinkade to the 25-man roster as a backup catcher for the National League Championship Series against Atlanta. If they do -- because of the not-quite-certain status of Mike Piazza -- the Mets may considering going from 11 to 10 pitchers on the roster.

description: Lending a Hand, Resting His Feet

description: STEWART-Sylvia Lichtenstein. March 21, 1914 to October 8, 1999. Formerly of Roslyn, New York. Memorial Service will be held on Saturday, October 30, 1999, at 4 P.M. at Finnerty & Stevens Funeral Home, 426 Main Street, Great Barrington, MA.

title: Martinez to Rescue, and Red Sox to New York
description: The American League Championship Series will be a shuttle showdown pitting a team without a World Series championship since World War I against a team without a World Series championship since last October. The Boston Red Sox, wild cards, damaged goods and heartbreakers for decades, earned the right tonight to move on to face the powerful defending champion Yankees, whom they have never played in a post-season series. They did it with a resilient 12-8 victory in Jacobs Field over the Cleveland Indians, their third victory in three days, to win the series in an upset, three games to two.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANZONI, CAROL BERLIN
description: MANZONI-Carol Berlin. 52. Beloved wife of Michael G. Hron. Loving stepmother of Benjamin & Jonathan. Dear sister of Susan (Michael) Klimpl. Fond aunt of Jason & Timothy. Daughter-in-law to Sylvester (Ruth) Hron. Sister-inlaw of Richard (Mary), Dr. John (Dianne), and David Hron. A prominent labor lawyer & former co-managing partner of the law firm of Ross & Hardies of Chicago, New York and Washington, D.C. Visitation will be 2-9PM Tuesday, at Blake-Lamb Funeral Home, 1035 North Dearborn St., Chicago. Funeral service 2PM Wednesday at St. James Episcopal Cathedral, 65 East Huron St., Chicago, IL. 60611. Interment Thursday at the Washington County Memorial Park Cemetery, West Bend, Wisconsin. In lieu of flowers memorials may be made to St. James Episcopal Cathedral or the charity of the donor's choice. For further information: 312-944-5594.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIENER, ROBERT
description: WIENER-Robert. Age 82. Died after a short illness on October 9, 1999. He is survived by his beloved wife Annaabelle, his children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. A gathering of friends and family will be held Tuesday, October 12th at 2:30 P.M., at the United Nations Church chapel at the U.N. Plaza. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made to the World Federation of the United Nations Association.

title: BALLANTYNE, FILM PROJECTOR MAKER, IS CONSIDERING SALE
description: Ballantyne of Omaha Inc., the maker of movie-projection systems, said yesterday that it had hired the investment banker DonHaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. to explore a possible sale of the company. Ballantyne's shares have fallen 23 percent this year. The chief financial officer, Brad French, said the company would consider a sale, an acquisition or a merger. The company, which is based in Omaha, may be looking for a partner to build digital-movie equipment, which is expected to replace traditional film-based projectors now used in theaters, said Michael Legg, a Prudential Securities Inc. analyst. Ballantyne's shares fell 18.75 cents yesterday, to $6.25. At that price the company has a stock market value of more than $78 million.

title: Reagan Book Enters Lists As Nonfiction
description: ''Dutch,'' the biography of Ronald Reagan whose author, Edmund Morris, inserts a fictional version of himself in the narrative, jumped onto the best-seller lists this weekend -- in the nonfiction category.

title: EUROPE-SOUTH AFRICA TRADE DEAL
description: After four years of negotiations, South Africa and the European Union signed an agreement in Pretoria to phase out tariffs on most trade between the two. The pact remained in jeopardy until a few hours before the planned ceremony, as representatives of several European countries withheld support because of a dispute over whether South African companies could continue to use such terms as port, sherry and grand cru in classifying wines and spirits. Henri E. Cauvin

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUSKIN, NATHAN J.
description: MUSKIN-Nathan J., 81. On October 11, 1999 of prostate cancer at his home in Mayfield, NY. Resident of Scarsdale NY for 40 years, Lifetime career in the metal industry. Beloved huband 53 years of Nancy Hertz Muskin. Father of Lynn Lettre (Michel) of Owings Mills, MD., and Janet Rutchik (Stuart) of Germantown, MD. Grandfather of Rachel & Madeline Lettre, Robin & Rebecca Rutchik. Services Thursday, October 14 at 11:30AM at the Knesseth Israel Synagogue in Gloversville, New York. Burial is at Knesseth Israel Cemetery following the service. Contributions to the charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: PRIZE ENERGY AGREES TO ACQUIRE VISTA ENERGY RESOURCES
description: The privately held Prize Energy Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire Vista Energy Resources Inc. to create a midsize independent oil and gas company, with assets valued at more than $450 million. The publicly traded Vista Energy is the buyer, at least on paper, exchanging 58.2 million common shares and 27.7 million preferred shares it will create. The combined enterprise will, however, be named Prize Energy and be 84 percent owned by Prize Energy shareholders. Vista Energy, based in Midland, Tex., is an oil and gas production company. Shares of Vista Energy changed hands at $2.5625, up 31.25 cents, on the American Stock Exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEDERMAN, FRANCES
description: LEDERMAN-Frances. The Riverdale Jewish Center extends profound condolences to Harvey Lederman on the loss of his beloved mother. May the families be comforted among the mourners of Zion & Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the end of the Yonkers teachers' strike misstated its duration in some editions. The strike lasted four days, not three.

title: Sports of The Times; A Protege Finally Masters the Mentor
description: DURING the warm-up before the Jets' 16-6 loss to the Jacksonville Jaguars last night, Bill Parcells sauntered over to talk to Tom Coughlin.

title: Valentine and Fans Don't Faze Braves
description: Brian Jordan laughed at the suggestion that the Mets' manager, with some fairly outrageous comments on Sunday, was trying to induce the Shea Stadium fans to assist the Mets by taking the Atlanta Braves out of their game this weekend, when their pennant playoff goes to New York.

title: Bay Area Car-Rental Deal
description: Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group Inc., the sixth-largest car-rental company, said today that three of its franchise owners had bought the closely held Bay Area Rentals, increasing San Francisco area sites to 35 from 19. Terms were not disclosed. San Francisco-based Bay Area Rentals has 1,100 vehicles at its 17 sites. The franchisees of Tulsa-based Dollar Thrifty plan to change all the stores to Thrifty Car Rentals by November and will close one of the existing Thrifty stores in the area.

title: Chrebet's Hoped for Return Is Delayed
description: Jets receiver Wayne Chrebet, who had hoped to return several weeks ahead of schedule, was scratched for last night's game against Jacksonville. The wide receiver is still hobbled by a broken left foot, which has kept him out all season.

title: When It's Islanders vs. Rangers, It's Always Intense
description: Despite all the new faces on both benches, the Rangers-Islanders rivalry remains as intense as ever.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
description: Thirty years ago, on Oct. 29, the inaugural message was sent over the first thin reed of what was to become the Internet. It was nothing so portentous as ''What hath God wrought,'' the words christening the telegraph in 1844. It was just the simple word ''login.''

title: Rivera's Cool Manner Complements His Heat
description: Mariano Rivera has assumed responsibility for Sandy Alomar's home run in the 1997 playoffs, but not in the classic ''it was my fault'' sense.

title: Public Interests; My Boy Spot
description: My favorite Ronald Reagan story involves the false Lassie. Once when he was President, Mr. Reagan invited the White House press corps to his ranch in California. One of the reporters noticed the family collie and, in an effort to make conversation, asked what the dog's name was.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the News Watch column of Circuits on Thursday about new iMac models misidentified the video editing software that will be packaged with the iMac DV. The program is iMovie, not Final Cut Pro.

title: VITAL SIGNS: SIDE EFFECTS; Relax! Stress May Harm the Prostate
description: Further indication about the health benefits of relaxing: a new study suggests a link in men between stress and a chemical in their blood that has been associated, at high levels, with a risk of prostate cancer.

title: Railroad May Enter Telecommunications
description: The Norfolk Southern Corporation, the fourth-largest United States railroad, is forming a unit to lease its telecommunications system to phone, Internet and cable service providers and may eventually enter that business.

title: Russian Court Ruling Is New Blow to Foreign Investment
description: Russia's shaky foreign-investment reputation weakened further today when a court in St. Petersburg ruled that the 255-year-old Lomonosov porcelain factory be renationalized, annulling a majority stake held by executives of a prominent Wall Street buyout firm and an American-financed investment fund.

title: Health Food Homilies
description: My husband and I recently moved to a new apartment with an excellent health food market nearby. The convenience has improved our eating habits (more soy milk, less Coca-Cola), as well as the way we keep house (recycled-plastic garbage bags and 80 percent post-consumer-waste paper towels).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBERTS, BERTRAM WILLIAM
description: ROBERTS-Bertram William on October 9, 1999. Loving husband of the late Ruth Helene Roberts. He is survived by his son Kenneth Roberts and wife Kathy, daughter Janice Richman and husband Gilbert, daughter Eileen Roberts and grandchildren Jennifer Jones and husband Steve, Timothy and Gregory Roberts. Loving husband of the later Helen Brosnan Roberts. Survived by her family, Thomas Brosnan and wife Rosemary, John Brosnan, Robert Brosnan, Michael Brosnan, Mary Catherine Brosnan, Eileen Buckhaults and husband Ray and grandchildren Kerry and Robert. Also survived by his beloved sister Betty Kuehn. A loving husband, father and friend. His family and friends will dearly miss him. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Avenue at 12th Street, Garden City 2-5 and 7-9 PM Tuesday. Religious service at the Lutheran Church of Our Savior, Jefferson Street, Mineola, on Wednesday at 10AM. Interment Nassau Knolls Cemetery, Port Washington, New York. In lieu of flowers donations to the charity of your choice appreciated.

title: She Put the San Andreas Fault in Its Place
description: On a warm afternoon recently, Dr. Tanya Atwater, professor of geology at the University of California at Santa Barbara, one of the few women to be accorded membership in the National Academy of Sciences, sat at her home computer in Montecito, Calif., creating an animated film to explain how earthquakes are created along the San Andreas fault in California.

title: Fighting for the Test Ban Treaty
description: Despite the important contribution it would make to a safer world, the nuclear Test Ban Treaty stands virtually no chance of mustering enough support to win Senate ratification this week. Allowing it to be voted down would deal a damaging blow to America's foreign policy and military security. The wiser course is to delay Senate action for at least a few months, as President Clinton requested yesterday, giving the White House more time to overcome the arguments of treaty critics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEAST, CHARLES RAYMOND
description: KEAST-Charles Raymond, 86 years old, son of the late Charles Horace Keast was born in Bisbee, Arizona, on January 22, 1913. As a child, Charles Raymond Keast worked in the copper mines of Selps Dodge before going to San Francisco where he became affiliated with the Works Progress Administration (WPA), and where he was an instructor because of his musical background. In San Francisco he joined the ''Fred Waring Glee Club'' at the San Francisco Aquacade under Robert Shaw's direction. During World War II he worked as a draftsman for Bethlehem Steel. He was a student at the Juilliard School of Music, and also was a pupil of John Charles Thomas, where he performed at the Music Academy of the West. There followed long tours with the ''Shipstead and Johnson Ice Follies'' in the United States. During a break, he auditioned for the ''Song of Norway,'' which was being cast in San Francisco for the New York company. He came to New York with the ''Song of Norway'' cast and was the understudy and the alternate for the role of the poet, Nordrack. It was a major role, and he performed many times in the New York production of the ''Song of Norway.'' After the ''Song of Norway,'' he continued with roles in ''Allegro,'' which was a Rodgers and Hammerstein musical; ''The Music Man,'' and did two seasons with the Arundel Opera of Kennebunkport, Maine. After that he did two seasons as Jane Morgan's leading man at the Kennebunkport Playhouse. During this time he rejoined Robert Shaw and the Professional Choral as a soloist, and toured the entire United States; Europe, Russia and South America. He performed at the Montclair Operetta Company in the ''Song of Norway'' and ''The Merry Widow.'' He also performed at the Paper Mill Playhouse, Millburn, New Jersey. Later he toured for Columbia Concert in the United States & Canada as a member of the Chanticleers, a popular male quartet; followed by a cross-country tour with the rock group, Rick Wakeman; followed by seventeen years with the Norman Luboff Choir as a soloist. Survivors include a sister, Edna Barringer; a niece, Charlene Dandridge; two nephews, Gary and Charles Barringer; a cousin, Helen Gipson of Phoenix, Arizona; and Willis F. Meyers, a longtime companion of fifty-three years. The funeral is private. For information McCorry Brothers Funeral Home, Cliffside Park, New Jersey.

description: Jim Fassel, the beleaguered coach of the beleaguered Giants, had just finished today's news conference at Giants Stadium. Chatting with reporters, he expanded on his frustrations over his erratic offense in Sunday's 14-3 loss to the Arizona Cardinals in Tempe, Ariz.

title: Coping With Fear: Keeping Breast Cancer in Perspective
description: What descriptions come to mind in connection with breast cancer? The ones I've heard often include tragic, terrifying, horrific, devastating, terrible, monstrous and ''a woman's worst nightmare.''

title: Restoring The Sparkle To 'Jewels' By Balanchine
description: The Miami City Ballet has come a long way since its beginnings in 1986 under Edward Villella's artistic direction, and two revealing programs at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark proved nothing short of a triumph.

description: ROSENTHAL - Udith. 1919 - 1992. You are always in our hearts and mind, and you are sorely missed. Love, Your Family and Friends

description: BACHMAN-Marjorie A. Formerly of New York City and Boca Raton, FL. Beloved wife of the late George S. Loving mother of James and Richard. Dear motherin-law of Joan and Diane. Adored grandmother of Jennifer, Jill, Kimberlee and Rebecca. Sister of Arthur. The family will receive friends Tues 6-8PM at Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Ave, White Plains, N.Y. Funeral service Wednesday, 12 Noon at the funeral home. Interment Salem Fields Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Hospice of Westchester, 95 South Bway, White Plains, N.Y. 10601 would be appreciated.

title: Berkshire Hathaway Buys Furniture Seller
description: Berkshire Hathaway Inc., a holding company controlled by the billionaire investor Warren E. Buffett, said today that it would purchase the Massachusetts-based Jordan's Furniture Company for an undisclosed sum.

title: A Toast to Newton and a Long-Lived 'Principia'
description: A new paperback of an old book may not seem like a big deal, except when its author is arguably the greatest scientist of all time and the book was first published 312 years ago. So the Dibner Institute for the History of Science and Technology, on the campus of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, is giving Isaac Newton a party to celebrate the publication of the first new translation in 270 years of his landmark work, ''Philosophiae Naturalis Principia Mathematica,'' first published, in Latin, in 1687.

title: Northwest Joins Other Airlines In Raising Leisure-Trip Fares
description: The Northwest Airlines Corporation joined other large carriers today in raising leisure fares after Continental Airlines Inc. increased prices because of higher fuel costs.

title: VITAL SIGNS: PREVENTION; For Athletes, a Consensus on Concussion
description: It seems unlikely to lay a divisive issue to rest (indeed, even its authors urge much more study), but new guidelines are making their way to schools around the country with advice on how to handle head injuries on the playing field.

title: PEOPLESOFT TO ACQUIRE CUSTOMER RELATIONS SPECIALIST
description: Peoplesoft Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the Vantive Corporation for stock valued at $433 million, in a deal that adds Vantive's customer-focused services to Peoplesoft's E-business offerings. Peoplesoft will exchange 0.825 share of its stock for each outstanding share, warrant and option of Vantive. Vantive, based in Santa Clara, Calif., provides customer-relationship management services. It had revenue of $93.3 million for the first six months of 1998. Peoplesoft, based in Pleasanton, Calif., provides business application software. It had revenue of $617.6 million in the six months ended June 30.

title: Gluck's Power of Melody in a Paris Theater Reborn
description: The Theatre du Chatelet has reopened here with a weekend of Gluck. After a year of outward silence and inner banging and drilling, this historic hall near the Seine has chosen its post-renovation debut with considerable shrewdness. The problems: to find material relevant to a very French enterprise, to give it international resonance, to be original and yet to avoid the trap of novelty devoid of substance.

title: FDX Chief Will Retire at 55; Vice President Is Successor
description: Theodore L. Weise, the president and chief executive of the Federal Express Corporation, will retire in January, the package-delivery company announced yesterday. He will be succeeded by David J. Bronczek, the executive vice president and chief operating officer.

title: Accounts
description: * Cintas, Cincinnati, a uniform distribution and marketing company, to Doner, Southfield, Mich., to handle its account, which had been at Northlich Stolley LaWarre, Cincinnati. Billings were estimated at $10 million.

description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIDMANN, MARCUS, M.D.
description: WIDMANN-Marcus, M.D., on October 10, 1999, at the age of 94, after a short illness. Beloved husband of the late Dina Sander Widmann. Cherished father of Roger and Judith Widmann and Harriet and Martin Spitz. Adored grandfather of Daniel and Kenneth Widmann, and Emily McBurney, and Lisa and Jenny Spitz. Loving brother of Fina Eytan and the late Gershon Widmann. He was devoted to his family and his patients throughout his life and will be remembered for the unfailing generosity of his spirit. Service Thursday, 10 AM, at ''Riverside Memorial Chapel'',21 West Broad Street, Mt. Vernon, New York.

title: Motorola Net Rises Sharply On Demand for Cell Phones
description: Building on a yearlong recovery that has bolstered its stock price, Motorola Inc. said today that its third-quarter earnings rose sharply on soaring demand for its cellular telephones and a revival in sales of its semiconductor products.

title: Johnson, Battling Another Injury, a Symbol as Knicks Limp to a Preseason Loss
description: Larry Johnson's sculpted body is as impressive as a massive cliff hulking over the ocean. He, too, is not immune to a pounding that deprives him of a comfortable sleeping position. All the banging has left him feeling as if his body were melting down with each additional birthday candle.

title: HOMESTORE.COM AGREES TO ACQUIRE HOMEBUYER'S FAIR
description: Homestore.com said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Homebuyer's Fair unit of Central Newspapers Inc. for $85 million. Homestore.com, based in Thousand Oaks, Calif., operates Realtor.com and other real estate Web sites. Homebuyer's Fair, based in Scottsdale, Ariz., provides Internet and information services for people who are moving and companies that are relocating employees. Phoenix-based Central Newspapers is a media and information company that publishes The Arizona Republic and The Indianapolis Star.

title: D. A. Huffman, Computer Expert, Dies at 74
description: David A. Huffman, who developed a fundamental mathematical technique in the early years of computer science that remains vital to data storage and transmission, died on Thursday in a hospital in Santa Cruz, Calif. He was 74 and lived in Santa Cruz.

title: On-Line Presentations Boom as Colleges Compete for the Brightest Students
description: Colleges and universities are racing to provide applicants with virtual tours of their campuses, setting up on-line presentations that mirror actual campus visits.

title: Some G.O.P. Senators Spurn Compromise on Test Ban Pact
description: Senate conservatives today rejected a compromise by the Republican and Democratic leaders to postpone action on a treaty banning underground nuclear testing.

title: DAEWOO BOND LOSSES TO BE SHARED
description: South Korea's top financial watchdog agency said the nation's brokerage firms would share the losses from Daewoo bonds held by investment trusts. ''Investment trusts who have mismanaged their assets are to blame involving Daewoo bonds,'' said Lee Yong Keun, vice chairman of the Financial Supervisory Commission. ''But brokerages should also take responsibility for their active role in marketing and selling funds with Daewoo bonds.'' The largest brokerage firms -- securities firms affiliated with Hyundai Motor, Samsung Group and Daewoo -- are expected to suffer heavy losses because of their exposure to bonds issued by the ailing conglomerate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMON, MARION
description: SIMON-Marion, 63. Of Riverdale, N.Y. On October 8, 1999 after three years of struggling against Melanoma. Devoted sister of Gabrielle Lefer of New York and adoring aunt to Michael Lefer. Dedicated and loyal friend. Retired teacher of 25 years in the Yonkers public school system. Painter of great integrity and depth. We shall remember her for her humanity and expansiveness of spirit. She shall be with us always. Services at Mount Hope Cemetery, Oct.12th.L

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAIGE, ROBERT
description: PAIGE-Robert. Professor of Computer Science, New York University on October 5, 1999. Beloved husband of Nieba, father of Janie and Johnny. Son of Seymour and the late Beatrice. Brother of Gary. Services Saturday, October 16, 8:00PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Parcells at a Loss to Prevent Jets From Losing
description: There have been moments when Bill Parcells must have been as disappointed as he was today. But not many.

title: O'Neill Gets Ready As Torre Reviews All of His Options
description: Paul O'Neill moved cautiously yesterday, as if waiting for pain to buckle him. He threw gingerly at Yankee Stadium, ran slowly, swung the bat sluggishly, his pace gradually increasing as he became more comfortable during the Yankees' workout.

title: Being Overlooked by Pitchers Suits O'Leary Fine
description: When Nomar Garciaparra was intentionally walked the first time on Monday night, Troy O'Leary took no offense and found no great revenge when he blasted a grand slam to put the Boston Red Sox in front of the Cleveland Indians.

description: MURAD-Jacob. The Officers, Trustees, Clergy and Members of Park Avenue Synagogue mourn the passing of a devoted congregant. We extend to his wife Violet and the family our heartfelt sympathy. David H. Lincoln, Senior Rabbi Geoffrey J. Colvin, Ch of the Bd Paul S. Schreiber, President

A longtime supporter and Golden Founder together with his wife, Nancy, his exceptional commitment to tzedakah and chesed played a vital role in providing world-class and compassionate medical care to the people of Israel. May the entire family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Amer. Comm. for Shaare Zedek Med. Ctr. in Jerusalem Erica Jesselson, Chair Menno Ratzker, Pres.

description: In a cautious move toward greater openness, Unesco's executive board will hold job interviews on Wednesday for the post of the organization's director general.

description: Abandoned more than 20 years ago but still quite elegant -- yes, elegant -- an old comfort station in a small South Bronx park would be turned into a Wendy's restaurant under a deal now being negotiated.

description: GOLDMAN-Janis Meresman. Lovingly remembered today and every day.

title: JAPANESE REFINERY PACT
description: Two major Japanese refiners -- the Nippon Mitsubishi Oil Corporation and the Cosmo Oil Company -- announced a major alliance to create Japan's largest oil refining business. Nippon Mitsubishi Oil, already Japan's largest oil refiner, and Cosmo Oil, the No. 3 refiner, will unite all operations except sales and marketing on Nov. 1. Their deal, creating the world's fourth-largest oil services company, aims to reduce annual costs by 15 billion to 20 billion yen ($140 million to $188 million) within three years.

title: Business Travel; On-line reservation systems appear poised to shake up the traditional travel agent business.
description: TO a visitor, Los Angeles can seem like Queens with dazzling sunlight -- a vast, bewildering, high-density commercial and residential expanse where navigation is aided by the fact that the buildings are low enough to allow you to spot the topographical landmarks and aim the car at least at a known point on the compass.

title: Fleming Writes Her Own Story
description: There have been other books written about her life, Peggy Fleming was saying yesterday. No books were written by her. Until now.

But in this case, three strikes does not mean out.

title: A Rivalry of Ruthian Proportions

For nearly a century they have supplied a millennium's worth of memories. Here's a sample. By RAY CORIO

title: Intel Earnings Do Not Meet Expectations
description: The Intel Corporation posted third-quarter per-share earnings today that fell a few cents short of analysts' estimates because of falling prices for microprocessors and narrower profit margins.

title: TELECOM SPINOFF SEEN
description: Britain's second-biggest utility, Scottish Power P.L.C., reportedly will start taking orders on Oct. 25 for shares in its telecommunications unit Thus P.L.C. Thus, formerly known as Scottish Telecom, is valued at as much as 2.6 billion [pounds]($2.8 billion) by Goldman Sachs Group Inc., the bank managing the sale, according to The Times of London, citing Bill Allan, Thus's chief executive. That is higher than previous estimates by analysts. Scottish Power and Goldman, Sachs would not comment on the possible share sale.

title: Little-Known Power Broker Emerges in Kremlin Scandals
description: The money laundering scandal at the Bank of New York, at first dismissed by Russian bankers and politicians as an overblown sensation manufactured in America, has now made its way into the middle of Russia's own highly charged political scene.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Columbus Day parade in Manhattan referred incorrectly to Charles A. Gargano, who heads its sponsor, the Columbus Citizens Foundation Inc. He is chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, not its former chairman.

title: Earnings Beat Expectations at 3 Big Brokerage Firms
description: Three big securities firms reported better-than-expected third-quarter earnings yesterday, reflecting a strong rebound from a disastrous quarter a year earlier but a decline from a strong first half.

title: Dangerous Coup in Pakistan
description: The military coup in Pakistan is cause for alarm in South Asia and the rest of the world. A nation newly armed with nuclear weapons, and with a volatile history of wars and internal upheavals, has been seized by generals who may be inclined to favor a more confrontational approach with India. Suddenly, after fitful steps toward India-Pakistan rapprochement, the subcontinent is once again one of the most dangerous places on earth. Gen. Pervez Musharraf, the army chief of staff who ''dismissed'' Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, acted only after Mr. Sharif tried to oust him earlier in the day. But the United States and other nations must demand that the generals ensure Mr. Sharif's safety, restore him to power and respect Pakistani liberties.

title: For the Mets, Another Dreary Night in Georgia
description: There was a prominent skid mark on the third-base line of Turner Field, a glaring reminder in full view of the Mets' dugout of their stumbles tonight.

description: Bill Rodgers, who won the New York City Marathon four times and the Boston Marathon four times, has been voted into the National Track and Field Hall of Fame.

description: FEW people I know have gone food hunting in Cambodia, so I was curious when Deb Winson, a New York-based food stylist, came back with an ecstatic report. ''Everything was so fresh and beautiful, and everything was so simple,'' she said.

title: MARCHING TOWARD PLAYOFFS
description: The league had to wait until the last game of the regular season to determine the final matchup in the playoffs, which will start Saturday with 8 of the league's 12 teams. The MetroStars are one of the four teams that failed to make the playoffs, which will culminate with the championship game on Nov. 21 at Foxboro Stadium near Boston.

title: Vote Looms, But Debate On Altering Charter Falls
description: When Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced the creation of a Charter Revision Commission in June, he did not deny that a primary motivation was to block one of his principal tormentors, Mark Green, the Public Advocate, from succeeding him as Mayor.

title: More Bosses Encourage Napping on Job
description: Sterling McCullough doesn't mind getting caught napping at work. A half-dozen times in the last year, he has disappeared down a little-used hallway at Deloitte Consulting in Pittsburgh, stretched out in a leather chair and nodded off.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDLER, PHYLLIS
description: SANDLER-Phyllis. A loving and caring person who touched many lives and was an inspiration to all. Beloved wife of Eli, devoted mother of Dr. Dennis, cherished aunt, great aunt and great-great aunt. Services at Boulevard-Riverside, 1895 Flatbush Avenue at Avenue L, Brooklyn, today at 11:30 AM. She will be missed.

title: High-Risk Inmates at Low-Key Hospital
description: As recently as five years ago, the Grey stone State Psychiatric Hospital seemed a benign place to local residents who used its winding roads in the foothills of Watnong Mountain as a scenic shortcut, glimpsing the occasional patient and sometimes exchanging a wave.

title: French-Italian Alliance Takes Controlling Stake in Fendi
description: The world's biggest luxury-goods company, LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton of France, forged an unusual alliance today with the Italian fashion house Prada to take control of Fendi S.p.A., ending a months-long battle for the Rome-based design house known for its trendy Baguette bags, chic sunglasses and furs by the designer Karl Lagerfeld.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO RISES. The dollar declined against the euro as tumbling United States stocks and bonds decreased demand for the currency. In New York, the euro settled at $1.0758, up from $1.0648 on Monday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANIELS, SYLVIA APPELL
description: DANIELS-Sylvia Appell. On October 12, 1999, beloved wife of Irwin, loving mother of Arleen D. Auerbach, dear mother-in-law of Robert Auerbach, cherished grandmother of Steven & Laura, adoring great grandmother of Anya and Alex. She will be deeply missed. Service private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOIFER, LEONARD
description: SOIFER-Leonard. On October 12, 1999. Beloved husband of Pat. Cherished brother of Lydia. Graveside service at 1 PM on Wednesday, October 13th. at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, New York. For information contact Jewish Memorial Chapel, 1800-617-2303.

title: Giant Leap for Private Industry: Spies in Space
description: People passing through 14th and Constitution in Washington on Sept. 30 had no idea that the world's first private spy camera was orbiting 400 miles overhead. But the spacecraft snapped a photograph of the intersection in resolution sharp enough to show their cars, as well as surrounding buildings, monuments and city bustle.

title: Nazi Slave Labor
description: To the Editor:

title: Tan and Pumped Up, Living Campily Ever After
description: Of the many pop ditties that float like wisps of pink ice cream through ''Beefcake,'' Thom Fitzgerald's campy strawberry milkshake of a film saluting the dream world of 50's male physique photography, none captures that ethos more perfectly than ''Mr. Sandman.'' In this giddy cinematic swirl of vintage photos and film clips of young men flexing their muscles, interspersed with fictional, satirically shaded vignettes set in 1950's Los Angeles, the Chordettes' cooing plea to ''make him the cutest that I've ever seen'' distills the strained faux-naif attitudes behind those pictures.

title: Royalty Deal for AIDS Drug
description: In what could become one of the academic world's richest licensing agreements, Glaxo Wellcome Inc. has agreed to pay the University of Minnesota and one of its professors royalties on the sales of Ziagen, an antiviral drug used to treat AIDS. Based on sales projections, the total royalties could exceed $300 million, the university said in a statement.

title: Republicans Propose a Deal on Financial Services
description: As Congress moved closer today to completing legislation that would overhaul the nation's financial system, the Clinton Administration denounced a new Republican measure introduced by three top lawmakers and said it would be vetoed by the President.

title: Coca-Cola Plans New Program For Its Flagship Soft Drink
description: With demand for cola on the wane, the Coca-Cola Company is planning what amounts to a reintroduction of its flagship soft drink, Coca-Cola Classic.

title: Trial Begins in Suit Challenging New York State's Formula for School Funds
description: On the first day of a trial that could lead to major changes in the state's system of financing public schools, the plaintiffs warned yesterday that New York City students would never meet the state's new education standards without a sharp increase in state money.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIN, NATALIE
description: LEWIN-Natalie. The officers, Board of Trustees, Congregation and Clergy of The Jewish Center of the Hamptons mourn the passing of Natalie Lewin, beloved mother of our devoted member John Lewin. We extend condolences to John and his family. Rabbi David J. Gelfand Cantor Debra Stein-Davidson Donald Zucker, President

title: Politicians Speak Out but Are Wary of Restricting Film Violence
description: Some recent skirmishes in the political culture wars:

title: Wilt Chamberlain Is Dead at 63; Dominated Basketball in the 60's
description: Wilt Chamberlain, whose size, strength and intimidation made him probably the most dominant player in basketball history, and whose 100-point game stands as one of the towering records in sport, was found dead yesterday in his home in the Bel-Air section of Los Angeles. He was 63.

title: Corrections
description: A picture from The Associated Press yesterday with an obituary of the songwriter George Forrest was published in error. It showed Mr. Forrest's writing partner, Robert Wright.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Change at Patria

title: Anti-Abortion Rider
description: To the Editor:

title: Let Vice Presidents Run Solo
description: To the Editor:

title: Intimacy, if Not Fire, in Tuscany
description: One reaches up to turn the latch at 14 Via Carmignani in the nearby hillside town of Montecarlo. It was a door meant to be opened by men on horseback. From the street, one sees simply one more among a row of private houses. But beyond this particular door is a lobby, complete with bar and box office, and beyond it the Teatro di Assicurati.

title: What Makes A Big Airport Hum?; Atlanta's May Do It Best, But Growing Pains Loom
description: When he was a Marine Corps pilot in the 1970's, Michael J. Quiello learned to appreciate the teamwork necessary to take off from or land a plane safely on a rolling, pitching aircraft carrier. In his subsequent 19 years as a pilot for Delta Air Lines, Mr. Quiello, who is now Delta's system manager for international operations, has been equally impressed by the teamwork necessary to make an airport hum. And in his opinion, no large airport functions as smoothly as Hartsfield Atlanta International.

title: Boston and Cleveland Draw Eyeballs, While the Jets Draw Yawns
description: What were New Yorkers watching Monday night: Jets-Jaguars on ABC, or Game 5 of the Boston-Cleveland American League division series on Fox? Was it the hometown team, or the out-of-town contest to determine whom the Yankees would meet in the American League Championship Series?

title: Biotechnology Meets French Pride and Fears
description: FRENCH DNA

title: Gentle Drive to Make Voters Of Those With Mental Illness
description: On the morning of the 1996 Presidential election, Sharon Denny showered and dressed. She drove to the polling place, an elementary school in her neighborhood in Houston, and on the way she gave herself a pep talk. ''This is so important,'' she told herself. ''And it makes such a difference to our country. You have got to go vote.''

title: Sports of The Times; A Gentle, Good-Natured Goliath
description: IF you were ever around Wilt Chamberlain up close, you had to believe he might someday be the world's oldest living person. Maybe nobody has ever been that big, that strong, and in that good shape. And for him to die suddenly at age 63, perhaps of a heart attack, well, you just never thought anybody or anything would dare attack him.

title: Flak in the Great Hair War; African-Americans vs. Dominicans, Rollers at the Ready
description: Amid black hooded dryers, maroon floor tiles and walls awash in pink, Ana Vasquez is making her magic. Ms. Vasquez, a 39-year-old hairstylist at Classic II Unisex Salon in Hamilton Heights, alternates among three clients, washing, setting and blowdrying their tresses in less than an hour and a half.

title: High Court Is Urged to Uphold 'Citizen Suit' to Curb Pollution
description: When Congress passed the Clean Water Act 27 years ago, it included a ''citizen suit'' provision authorizing private individuals to sue polluters and collect fines that would go not to the successful plaintiffs but directly to the Federal treasury.

title: On Paper, Budget Balances Without Customary Raid on Social Security
description: Something symbolically enormous may have happened today: the Congressional Budget Office announced that the Government may have balanced the budget in fiscal 1999 without spending Social Security money.

title: Piazza Back in Lineup as Mets Go With Same 25
description: Perhaps the best indicator of Mike Piazza's improving health came when the Mets turned in their 25-man roster tonight for the National League Championship Series. The Mets, apparently convinced that Piazza was sufficiently recovered from the swollen thumb that kept him out of the final two games of their division series with Arizona, did not put a third catcher, Mike Kinkade, on the roster.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILDSTON, DR. HAROLD
description: GILDSTON-Dr. Harold. Beloved husband of Phyllis. Devoted father of Eva Rochelle Close, and the late Jessica Nan Gildston. Loving brother of Sarah Kohn. Naval Officer during WWII, and Professor at C.W. Post College of L.I.U. for 35 years. Services Sunday October 17, 1999 at 1 P.M. at ''RiversideNassau North'' Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York.

title: Heading a Year 2000 Team, as Time Runs Out
description: Cinda A. Hallman suspects she helped create the Year 2000 computer problem. As a young systems analyst fresh out of Southern Arkansas University, she joined Conoco Inc. in 1966 and wrote software for processing gasoline taxes that did not look ahead to the need to handle dates starting in the year 2000.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Despite all my advice, they tried to interfere with the armed forces, the last remaining viable institution in which all of you take so much pride and look up to at all times for stability, unity and integrity of our beloved country.''

title: Fox Drops Film Ads From Trade Paper
description: 20th Century Fox has dropped its film advertising with The Hollywood Reporter because of the newspaper's negative comments about the coming film, ''Fight Club.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLMES, WILLIAM C.
description: HOLMES-William C. Beloved son, brother, and friend of Emilie Holmes, Peter Holmes, and Frank D'Accone, at age 71 on October 11, 1999 at his home in Laguna Beach, Calif. He was Professor Emeritus of Music at the University of California, Irvine, and formerly taught at Cornell University. He published widely, specializing in Italian opera & was an accomplished musician. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Giants of Game Mourning Loss of Biggest Giant of All
description: Tommy Heinsohn remembered when he purposely threw a basketball off the backboard because he was convinced Wilt Chamberlain would block his shot.
