title: Worry Over Rates Causes Dow to Drop 231.12 Points
description: Stock prices staged a broad, sharp retreat yesterday, pulled down by rising interest rates, political instability in Pakistan and the prospect that third-quarter corporate earnings may not live up to expectations.

title: Ashkelon Journal; The Ever-So-Quiet Exodus: Israeli Cubans' Story
description: In their temporary apartment here, Zeida Quintero and Irolando Carpio watched today, for the hundredth time, a videotape of their marathon going-away party in Cuba. He smoked a hand-rolled cigar, she sipped a bittersweet Cuban coffee. Outside their window, the sea sparkled and the palms swayed, so evocative of home.

title: The Art That Dares
description: One of the most disturbing aspects of the controversy over the Brooklyn Museum of Art's exhibition ''Sensation'' is the hostility to contemporary art that it has elicited. Long after the dust settles, there will be a lingering sense that all contemporary art is offensive, even disgusting, and unworthy of our attention.

title: Blues Reconnect With Roots
description: This former plantation town in eastern Arkansas is not an obvious choice for a festival, with a crumbling downtown, a shrinking population now at 7,000 and all the economic problems and racial tensions one would expect in Phillips County, the poorest county in the state. But back in the 1930's and 40's, when Helena was a relatively thriving agricultural port on the Mississippi, it was the blues center of the Delta, with juke joints lining the streets, now-legendary musicians playing for change on the piers, and, beginning in 1941, a groundbreaking, highly influential afternoon blues broadcast called ''King Biscuit Time,'' featuring the harmonica player Sonny Boy Williamson (the former Rice Miller).

title: What's Missing in Childbirth These Days? Often, the Pain
description: More and more women are deciding that labor pain is a rite of passage they can do without and are gratefully accepting pain medicine during childbirth, doctors reported yesterday at an anesthesiology conference in Dallas.

title: EATON'S BANKRUPTCY PLAN
description: Shareholders and creditors of the T. Eaton Company, once Canada's biggest department store chain, are to vote on Nov. 19 on a debt payment plan that would permit some operations to be sold to Sears Canada Inc. for $60 million (Canadian), or about $41 million (United States). Eaton expects to have about $360 million (Canadian) from asset sales to pay off debts totaling $430 million (Canadian).

title: Biotech in the Bronx
description: To the Editor:

title: Prada and LVMH Join Forces to Buy Italian Fashion House Fendi
description: PARIS  The best-selling Fendi "baguette" bag, shaped like a French bread loaf, is now tucked under the arms of joint suitors.

title: Plea Lets Ambulance Driver Who Killed 3 Avoid Prison
description: The driver of a private ambulance that ran a red light in Brooklyn at high speed and smashed into a car, killing three children, will be spared prison under a deal supported by the children's parents, lawyers involved in the case said yesterday.

title: Chaos! Drama! It's Fine Dining
description: AT a certain trendy restaurant on the Upper East Side, a place where they serve Argentine cedar-roasted milk-fed chicken, tables are very, very hard to come by. The place is fully booked months in advance, but callers never hear the situation described that way. They are told that the restaurant is ''fully committed.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, JOHN J.
description: ROSS-John J. Youngest brother of Lillian and Danny, as a brother, he was my best friend for over 75 years and was always so cheerful and happy to be with. We will miss you, brother John, and we love you forever. Danny and Norma Ross Joan Ross and Paul Ross

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: LVMH in Deal With Prada To Take Control of Fendi

title: Phillips's Opponents Plan a Replacement Union for Umpires
description: The umpires opposed to Richie Phillips's leadership of their union moved today to replace the union with a new one that would operate without Phillips.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's reputation for seeking retribution against opponents misattributed an E-mail message that circulated among museum directors last month as they tried to devise a response to the Mayor's threat to cut off financing to the Brooklyn Museum of Art. The message, referring to a lobbyist for cultural institutions, said, ''Marty McLaughlin notes that the Mayor tends to take those who disagree with him as enemies to be punished.'' The writer was Dr. Alan J. Friedman, director of the New York Hall of Science, not Mr. McLaughlin.

title: From the Vineyard, Nature's First Wrap
description: GRAPE leaves are like escargots, a canned ingredient that seems too forbidding to use fresh in a home kitchen. But in one of those increasingly common alliances of farm and chef, freshly picked grape leaves from vineyards are turning up both in markets and on menus well beyond Greek and Middle Eastern restaurants.

title: Bank of New York Executive Resigns in Laundering Inquiry
description: One of two executives suspended in August at the Bank of New York, resigned today and said that the bank had unfairly abandoned her in the Federal investigation of possible money laundering at the bank.

title: Fight Expands Over Permit For Dumping Of Tainted Silt
description: After a three-year truce, an old feud about dumping contaminated dredging materials in the Atlantic Ocean off New Jersey has flared up.

title: Chevre Learns Some New Tricks
description: HERE in the San Francisco Bay Area, goat cheese is not just goat cheese. It has colorful names like Hyku, Humboldt Fog and Tomme Tumalo. Occasionally it masquerades as Camembert and even Cheddar. And it constantly dazzles.

title: Foreign Affairs; Bush's Big Chance
description: Now that George W. Bush is defining himself on domestic policy by trashing his own party's Congressmen, maybe it's time for him to define himself on foreign policy by trashing Pat Buchanan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEMBITZER, ROBIN C., M.D.
description: DEMBITZER-Robin C., M.D. The Mount Sinai Alumni record with sorrow the untimely death of Dr.Robin Dembitzer, School of Medicine graduate of the class of 1988. An outstanding young physician, she will be missed. We extend our sincere condolences to her sister Francine, (MSSM '89) and to the entire family. Avi Barbasch, M.D., President Jeffrey S. Freed, M.D., Vice Pres. Maria Padilla, M.D., Secretary William G. Stein, M.D., Treasurer

title: Holding Up the Gun Makers
description: It is too early to say whether the settlement talks between leading gun manufacturers and the cities that are suing them will be an important turning point in the battle to improve gun safety and stem the flow of weapons to juveniles and criminals. What seems obvious, however, is that it was not sudden pangs of conscience that led companies like Smith & Wesson, Colt's Manufacturing, Glock and Beretta to decide to pursue these negotiations.

title: Marie-Madeleine Durufle, 78, an Organist
description: Marie-Madeleine Durufle, an internationally renowned organist and teacher and the widow of the French composer and organist Maurice Durufle, died on Oct. 5 in Paris, where she lived. She was 78.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, MARY BRAYTON (DURFEE)
description: BROWN-Mary Brayton (Durfee), age 90 in New London, NH on Oct. 12, 1999. Formerly of Plandome and Manhasset. Predeceased by husband, Charles B. Brown., and daughter, Caroline Brown. Survived by son and daughter-in-law, C. Bennett Brown, Jr. and Ursula of Middlebury, VT; two granddaughters; two step-granddaughters; one great granddaughter; nieces and cousins. Funeral service on Friday, Oct. 15, 1999 at 2 P.M. at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church, Gould Rd., New London, NH. Memorial contributions to Lake Sunapee Region Visiting Nurse Assoc. and Hospice, P.O. Box 2209, New London, NH 03257 or Bryn Mawr College, Bryn Mawr, PA 19010. For information Chadwick Funeral Service of New London, NH.

title: CALENDAR
description: The Italian Immigrant Table

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: FORTUNE BRANDS INC., Old Greenwich, Conn., which makes Titleist golf balls, Jim Beam bourbon and other consumer goods, agreed to buy the closely held Boone International Inc., Corona, Calif., to expand sales of office products. Terms were not disclosed.

title: TERAYON COMMUNICATION TO BUY 2 ISRAELI COMPANIES
description: Terayon Communication Systems Inc., a cable modem maker, agreed yesterday to buy two closely held Israeli companies for about $150 million in stock to broaden its line of telecommunications products. Terayon, based in Santa Clara, Calif., said it would buy Telegate Ltd. for about $100 million to gain equipment for providing telephone services over cable television wires. It will also pay about $50 million for Radwiz Ltd., which makes gear for small businesses that routes voice and data traffic using high-speed Internet technology. Terayon also said its third-quarter loss from operations narrowed to $1.7 million from $6.5 million a year earlier. Terayon shares fell $3.1875 each, to $41.9375. The company disclosed the acquisitions and results after the close of United States markets.

title: Battle of the Fans: It's All in the Winning
description: To the Editor:

title: United Drops 'Rising' Campaign
description: United Airlines is scrapping its ''Rising'' campaign after only two years and is looking for a replacement from its roster agencies.

title: A Shelf of Treasures, Always Fresh
description: COOKBOOKS pose an unusual problem: their true value can be determined only over time. No quick read-through can distinguish the great from the merely good. No reviewer is going to cook every single recipe to see if they all work. Instead, a cookbook is a lot like other pieces of kitchen equipment: it needs to be used for months, maybe years, before you know whether it really makes it -- that it truly is, as the blurb always says, indispensable.

title: NORTHROP GRUMMAN TO TRIM 300 MANAGEMENT JOBS
description: The Northrop Grumman Corporation, the fifth-biggest United States military contractor, said yesterday that it would cut about 300 management jobs in a reorganization of its aircraft-parts business as one of its biggest customers makes fewer airplanes. Northrop, based in Los Angeles, makes the fuselage for the 747 jetliner and parts for most other Boeing planes. Seattle-based Boeing is slashing 747 production. The latest job cuts are in addition to 3,700 that Northrop plans to eliminate out of 10,000 in its commercial aircraft unit. It took pretax charges of $125 million against its 1998 earnings, mostly because of the 747 cutbacks. Northrop's shares fell $3.3125, to $59.

title: Union Leaders See Grim News In Labor Study
description: After years of blithely ignoring labor's decline, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. is force-feeding union leaders a heavy dose of bad news: that job growth is fastest in industries where unions are weakest while job losses are greatest in industries where unions are strongest.

title: A Soldier's Soldier, Not a Political General -- Pervez Musharraf
description: Pervez Musharraf, the Pakistani general who ousted the civilian Government of Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, was an unlikely coup-maker. He appeared to be an apolitical officer who had taken over the army at a time when military coups seemed a thing of the past.

title: DELL TO INVEST IN SAMSUNG
description: The leading personal computer company, the Dell Computer Corporation, will invest $200 million in the Samsung Electronics Company, in return for a supply of $8.5 billion worth of thin-film-transistor liquid crystal displays in the next five years. Dell will buy $200 million worth of Samsung bonds convertible to shares beginning in October 2000. Dell's investment will go to the expansion of Samsung's plant in the central part of South Korea, where fourth-generation displays will be produced, Samsung said.

title: Consistent Describes Braves' Maddux
description: The Atlanta Braves have an abundance of pitching, and it has the potential to give the Mets an abundance of trouble.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEABODY, BARBARA K.
description: PEABODY-Barbara K. October 10, 1999. Beloved wife of the late George, Jr., devoted mother of Christopher, Carolyn G., George III and Harry. Devoted friend of Ligia M. Barahona. She is survived by one sister, two brothers, many nieces, nephews and two grandchildren. Funeral from the Chas. Peter Nagel F.H., 352 East 87 Street on Saturday, 9:30 AM. Mass of Christian burial St. Thomas More R.C. Church, 10 AM. Visiting hours on Friday 2-5 and 7-9 PM.

title: Joint Campaign For Basketball
description: The National Basketball Association in New York and Turner Broadcasting System in Atlanta, part of Time Warner Inc., are running their first joint campaign to promote a new basketball season.

title: Head of Construction Agency Steps Down
description: After three years at the helm of New York City's main construction agency, Luis M. Tormenta has announced that he will resign as the Commissioner of the Department of Design and Construction to take a job at a private construction company.

title: A Child's Treat, Grown Up
description: AS the curtain began to fall on a long evening of tapas in Barcelona a few weeks ago, dessert arrived.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Aug. 23 about efforts by the Trans-World Group to expand its aluminum operations in Ukraine referred incorrectly to the formation and ownership of the company. It was founded by two brothers, David and Simon Reuben. Lev and Mikhail Cherny, two brothers from Uzbekistan, had no involvement in the company's formation. While Lev Cherny is a joint venture partner, Mikhail Cherny has no connection with the company. The article also misstated the date of Trans-World Group's founding. It was in 1977, not the late 1980's.

title: Viewers' Choice
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JUCOVY, MILTON E., M.D.
description: JUCOVY-Milton E., M.D. The Officers and Members of The New York Psychoanalytic Society and Institute express their profound sorrow at the death of their respected and beloved colleague and member, Dr. Milton E. Jucovy. He was Training and Supervising Analyst for many years, and contributed significantly to psychoanalysis. Deepest sympathy is extended to his family members. Albert M. Sax, President/Society Eslee Samberg, President/Institute

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROHRBERG, LILLIAN C.
description: ROHRBERG-Lillian C. Beloved wife of the late David, devoted mother of Susan Cabral, and Judith Becker, dear sister of Morris, Florence, & Theodore Eisenberg. Loving grandmother of Karen and Anna. Services Thursday 1 P.M. Mt. Moriah Chapel, Fairview, New Jersey. For information ''Wien & Wien'', 1-800-322-0533.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ERENBERG, LILLIAN
description: ERENBERG-Lillian. Beloved wife and life partner for 60 years of the late Benjamin. Devoted mother of the late Elissa Erenberg and Joel Erenberg. Loving grandmother of the late Marc Barron Erenberg, Robin Hilary and Michael Marc Erenberg. Dear sister of Betty Beatty, the late Morris and Harry and the late Bella, Renee & Annie. From her youth she championed causes to improve and protect the children of the world as well as being a tireless worker on behalf of Jewish health, welfare & secular. Service 10AM Wednesday at ''Wien & Wien'', 402 Park Street, Hackensack, New Jersey. Memorial contributions in memory of Lillian Erenberg may be directed to the Trauma Education and Injury Prevention Fund at Hackensack University Medical Center, Attention: John LoCurto, M.D., 30 Prospect Ave., Hackensack, N.J. 07601.

title: Liberties; Dragon Lady Politics
description: The good news for Bill Clinton is that New Yorkers think he's less of a threat than the West Nile virus.

title: Student Commuters
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; They Still Can't Quite Get It Right
description: THEY were caught in an apparently fatal tailspin only three weeks ago.

title: In Surprise Move, Cone to Start Game 2
description: Manager Joe Torre made a surprising decision when he changed his rotation by inserting David Cone as the Game 2 starter tomorrow and switching Andy Pettitte from the second spot to Game 4. Orlando Hernandez will remain their Game 1 starter and Roger Clemens will start Game 3.

title: It's About A Murderer And Yes, Bees, Houdini. . . .
description: With ''Cremaster 2,'' the fourth installment of his projected cycle of five experimental films, Matthew Barney proves beyond a doubt that he is not a cinematic dabbler tossing around ideas that might just as readily be elaborated in performance art or in a video installation. Larger in scale, darker in tone, and much more lavishly produced than the previous installments, ''Cremaster 2,'' which opens today at the Film Forum, is an epic avant-garde western built around classic themes but laced with an intricate (and often whimsical) symbolic framework.

title: Raytheon Further Reduces Forecast of Profit, and Shares Fall 43%
description: Less than a month after warning investors that earnings would be lower than expected, the Raytheon Company reduced its forecasts again yesterday, sending its shares plunging 43 percent after a delayed opening on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIPPERLY, MARY SHAW
description: SIPPERLY-Mary Shaw. Of Stony Brook, NY. On October 10, 1999, peacefully after a sudden illness. The 23rd member of her family to graduate from Mount Holyoke College, she worked as an editor of children's books for Charles Scribner and Sons in Manhattan. She is survived by her husband, David P. Sipperly; daughters Margaret S. Salyer of Oklahoma City and Anne S. Braswell of Ocala, Fla.; granddaughters Margaret C. Salyer and Molly S. Braswell. A memorial service will be held at 11am on Friday, October 15 at the Stony Brook Community Church, Stony Brook, NY. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the John T. Mather Memorial Hospital Foundation or Mount Holyoke College, South Hadley, Mass.

title: Southeast Asia's Art Market Shows Life, Reflecting Economic Rise
description: KUALA LUMPUR  East Asia's art market has sharply rebounded in the last few months, with paintings and Chinese ceramics fetching record prices at auction houses in Singapore and Hong Kong.

title: Let Vice Presidents Run Solo; Gore vs. Bradley
description: To the Editor:

title: AUTOCAM SHARES FALL AFTER TAKEOVER TALKS END
description: The shares of the Autocam Corporation fell yesterday after the company, a maker of precision-machined auto parts, said talks with an undisclosed bidder that had offered $21 a share had ended without an agreement. The bid, announced last month, valued Autocam at about $134.5 million. Autocam's shares fell $2.625 each, to $13.6875. Parts makers have been consolidating as car makers push them to cut costs by supplying systems instead of individual parts. Autocam, based in Kentwood, Mich., makes parts for fuel systems, anti-lock braking systems and automotive motor assemblies for the Delphi Automotive Systems Corporation, TRW Inc. and other companies.

title: Sports of The Times; Hoping to Turn Page at Turn of Century
description: OVER the weekend, the Boston Red Sox beat up on the Cleveland pitching staff badly enough to outscore the New York area's two professional football teams combined, 44-9. Now if the Red Sox can outhit the Yankees, if they can come up with someone other than Pedro Martinez to pitch, they just might find themselves with the chance to ruin two baseball teams in the town that has tormented them most.

title: PAKISTAN ARMY SEIZES POWER HOURS AFTER PRIME MINISTER DISMISSES HIS MILITARY CHIEF
description: The Prime Minister of Pakistan fired the powerful army chief Tuesday afternoon, and hours later the army struck back with a swift, apparently bloodless coup. Troops surrounded the Prime Minister's home, closed all the major airports and shut down the state-run television and radio stations for several hours.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DESIMONE, PAUL
description: deSIMONE-Paul. Beloved son of Jack and the late, Adele; brother of Diane deSimone Hamilton and James Hamilton, died suddenly October 11, 1999. He was blessed with a huge generous heart and an intelligence that was a beacon for nurturing all races and people. Paul was a renaissance man with a habit of quoting from many distinguished classic and modern works. He was a lifelong New Yorker having moved to Tucson, AZ recently. All family members and friends feel the loss of a deeply devoted human being. Private services will be held.

title: STATEMENT ON GLOBAL ONE
description: An executive of Deutsche Telekom A.G. said the company might take control of Global One, the unraveling corporate communications venture it shares with Sprint and France Telecom. ''I don't exclude that we could take over Global One,'' said Gerd Tenzer, Deutsche Telekom management board member. ''It depends on the price; it depends on the conditions.'' Deutsche Telekom and France Telecom each hold about 25 percent of the venture -- said to be worth a total of at least $10 billion -- while Sprint owns some 50 percent.

title: Tug-of-War On Furniture Up for Sale By Streisand
description: The log cabin that Gustav Stickley, America's pre-eminent proponent of the Arts and Crafts style and one of its finest cabinetmakers, built for his family in 1911 at Craftsman Farm in Parsippany, N.J., was meant to embody his vision of the power of the Arts and Crafts ideal, down to the last piece of plain oak furniture that spoke of the virtue of the simple life. As Stickley's own magazine, The Craftsman, described it that year it was to be ''a rudimentary sheltering of domestic life, a place of safety where love and friendship could be shut in and foe and danger shut out.''

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Talking baseball and who's good for stocks and who isn't.
description: GIVEN the fervor created by the success of New York's two baseball teams this year, you might think that America's former national pastime (baseball) has a chance to eclipse its current national pastime (trading stocks).

title: Austrian Demagogue
description: To the Editor:

title: FRANKLIN COVEY DISMISSES 420 MORE EMPLOYEES
description: The Franklin Covey Company, whose co-founder Stephen R. Covey wrote the best-selling book ''Seven Habits of Highly Effective People,'' said yesterday that it would dismiss 420 more employees and take a $43 million fourth-quarter charge to cover severance, site closings and discontinued products. The company, which provides leadership training products, including the Franklin Planner personal organizer, said the revamping, its second in the last year, would allow it to focus on its core businesses. It had sales of $554.9 million for the year that ended on Aug. 31 and has dismissed about 180 workers so far under a plan to cut about 600, or 14 percent of its work force.

title: Why I Paid So Much
description: I had never paid so much for an acquisition before. I bought Harry Potter in 1997 at the Bologna, Italy, book fair before it had ever been published anywhere. It's a scary thing when you keep bidding and the stakes get higher and higher. I was getting a tremendous amount of support from my company. And that's a wonderful thing, but it's a great risk. If people believe in you and you flop, then you walk out on the plank and plunge.

title: Progress in Law Firms
description: To the Editor:

title: Philip Morris Admits Evidence Shows Smoking Causes Cancer
description: Philip Morris is acknowledging that scientific evidence shows that smoking causes lung cancer and other deadly diseases, after decades of disputing the findings of the United States Surgeon General and other medical authorities.

title: Brooklyn Area Is Special Focus Of Crime Units
description: Federal and local prosecutors are to announce a pilot program today to attack crime in a Brooklyn neighborhood through a tightly coordinated effort involving nearly a dozen agencies, including the Police Department, the Federal Bureau of Investigation, parole and probation units and the Board of Education, law enforcement officials said last night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MESSINGER, JEROME S.
description: MESSINGER-Jerome S. Age 64. Died October 9, 1999. Beloved father to Sharon and Dawn. Devoted grandfather to Ashley and Joshua. His big heart and huge smile will be missed. Donations may be sent to Animals Can't Talk, P.O. Box 630408, Little Neck, N.Y. 11363.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIPERSTEIN, NANCY
description: SIPERSTEIN-Nancy. On October 8th, 1999. Beloved wife of Israel, loving mother of Diane Muller, cherished grandmother of Arlene and Alicia, devoted sister of Flora Stoller. Services were held on Sunday, October 10, 1999.

title: AMERICAN SECURITIES CANCELS PLAN TO PURCHASE CPI
description: The CPI Corporation said yesterday that American Securities Capital Partners L.P. had canceled an agreement to buy it for $37 a share, a total of $367 million. CPI, a photography services company, which runs Sears Portrait Studios, said American Securities had cited a development that could adversely affect the merger. Last Thursday, CPI said its United States portrait-studio sales were lower in the early half of its third quarter in part because of the effects of Hurricane Floyd. CPI's board said its recent financial performance reflects ''ordinary course-of-business fluctuations.'' CPI said the failure of American Securities to close the transaction breaches the agreement and entitles CPI to damages. CPI's shares fell $4.625, to $20.375.

title: Let Vice Presidents Run Solo
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERNS, WILLIAM S. JR.
description: STERNS-William S. Jr., of Ponte Vedra Beach, FL, age 88, on October 11, 1999. Beloved husband of 60 years of Harriette Beeson Sterns, father of Heidi Merrill Luxner and William S. Sterns, III, grandfather of Reed, Sara, William IV, Stefan and Olivia; W.W. II recipient of the United States Legion of Merit and, from the Belgium government, the Croix de Guerre, avec palme; indefatigable golfer and lover of all people, young and old, especially his family. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, October 14, 1999 at 3:00 P.M. at The Palms Presbyterian Church, Ponte Vedra Beach, FL. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be made in his memory to the charity of one's choice or to the American Heart Association.

title: Plants Under Attack
description: Protests against genetic experiments on crops, already heated in Europe, have reached the West Coast of the United States, with attacks that have destroyed thousands of dollars' worth of plants and ruined thousands of hours of research at the Davis and Berkeley campuses of the University of California.

title: The Overstuffed Briefcase: Few Have the Time to Open It
description: THE constant, scolding ache in my right shoulder, I am somewhat relieved to report, is not a new symptom of age, nor is it anything that will require surgery. It's my shoulder bag.

title: Princeton Bioethics Professor Debates Views on Disability and Euthanasia
description: With none of the protests that have marked his previous appearances on campus, Peter Singer, the Princeton University professor whose support of infant euthanasia in severe cases of disability has made him a lodestone for controversy, debated his views publicly for the first time tonight before 500 students and faculty members.

title: Rev. Bruce Ritter, 72, the Founder of Covenant House for Runaway Children
description: The Rev. Bruce Ritter, who founded a shelter for runaways in 1969 and then resigned under pressure as its president in 1990 after being accused of financial and sexual improprieties, died Thursday at his farmhouse near Decatur, N.Y. He was 72.

title: Iranian's Career: From Hostage-Taker to Reformer
description: If anyone could stand as a bellwether of Iran's changing political climate, it might be Abbas Abdi, a mild-mannered, soft-spoken man whose office on a tree-shaded Teheran side street seems a world away from the furies that Mr. Abdi and other militants unleashed at the dawn of Iran's Islamic revolution 20 years ago.

title: Those Improbable Red Sox, Those Inevitable Yankees
description: Four generations of New Englanders have suspected that the Boston Red Sox exist merely to lure and then torture them. In these final days of the 20th century it seems wholly appropriate that the Red Sox would meet their hated rivals, the Yankees, for the American League championship.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices Agree to Hear Starr's Appeal in Hubbell Immunity Case
description: Whatever unfinished business remains in the office of Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel, that business now includes a new Supreme Court case. The Justices today agreed to hear Mr. Starr's appeal in a case growing out of his prosecution of Webster L. Hubbell, the former Justice Department official and law partner of Hillary Rodham Clinton, on a charge of tax evasion.

title: EN ROUTE: Australia; One Superstar Wine Deserves Another
description: THE project lasted for more than six years, and it cost at least $1 million. But it produced a fitting white stablemate for Grange, Australia's superstar red wine, which was once described by the English wine writer Hugh Johnson as the New World's only real first growth. The newcomer is called Yattarna, after an Aboriginal word meaning ''little by little.''

title: President Urges Government To Reach Uninsured Children
description: President Clinton directed Federal officials today to visit America's schools and enroll children in a health insurance program that he said had fallen far short of his original goal of providing coverage to five million youngsters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BACHMAN, MARJORIE A.
description: BACHMAN-Marjorie A. Formerly of New York City and Boca Raton, FL. Beloved wife of the late George S. Loving mother of James and Richard. Dear motherin-law of Joan and Diane. Adored grandmother of Jennifer, Jill, Kimberlee and Rebecca. Sister of Arthur. The family will receive friends Tues 6-8PM at Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Ave, White Plains, N.Y. Funeral service Wednesday, 12 Noon at the funeral home. Interment Salem Fields Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Hospice of Westchester, 95 South Bway, White Plains, N.Y. 10601 would be appreciated.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Bank Has Paid $4 Million To Settle Case Over MGM
description: The French bank Credit Lyonnais has paid $4 million to the United States Government to avoid criminal charges stemming from its role in backing the Italian financier Giancarlo Parretti's takeover of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, the Justice Department said today.

title: One Treaty Doesn't Fit All
description: The poisonously partisan debate over the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty this week should prompt a re-evaluation of the American approach to arms control. The difficulties in monitoring compliance that have been emphasized in the debate are present not just with low-yield nuclear testing, but with other threats to our national security -- for example, development of chemical and biological weapons and proliferation of missiles. The surprise North Korean launch of a three-stage ballistic missile last year simply highlights how hard it is even with our remarkable intelligence capabilities to track these diverse emerging threats accurately.

title: Lab Finds Plutonium Traces in Peconic Sediment
description: Officials at Brookhaven National Laboratory said today that new tests showed the presence of small amounts of plutonium in sediment from the Peconic River, which begins on laboratory property.

title: CON EDISON BUYING A NEIGHBOR UTILITY FOR $3.29 BILLION
description: The Consolidated Edison Company agreed last night to buy Northeast Utilities for $3.29 billion in cash and stock, according to people close to the talks, in a deal that could eventually bring cheaper power to its customers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAINGER, ISAAC B.
description: GRAINGER-Isaac B. The United States Golf Association (USGA) notes with great sorrow the passing of Isaac B. Grainger, the organization's president from 1954-1955. Mr. Grainger died on October 12 at the age of 104; he resided in Wilmington, N.C. Mr. Grainger served the USGA in a number of capacities, including secretary and vice president, before assuming the duties of president. He held membership in several golf clubs including Montclair Golf Club, in Montclair, N.J.; Pine Valley Golf Club, in Clementon, N.J.; Augusta National Golf Club, in Augusta, GA.; and the Royal & Ancient Golf Club of St. Andrews, Scotland. Mr. Grainger was an acknowledged expert on the Rules of Golf, serving as chairman of the USGA's Rules of Golf Committee from 1948-1953 and vice chairman of the Rules Committee for the Masters Tournament from 1965-1982. In 1988, Mr. Grainger received the Bob Jones Award, the USGA's highest honor in recognition of distinguished sportsmanship in golf. The USGA created the Isaac B. Grainger Award in 1995 to honor USGA volunteers who have unselfishly served the Association for 25 years or more. He leaves two sons: Isaac B. Grainger Jr. of Charlotte, N.C. and John V. Grainger of Wilmington, N.C. Memorial Services will be held at St. James Church, Wilmington, N.C., at 11 A.M. on October 14. Donations may be made to the International Center for the Disabled, 340 East 24th Street, New York, NY., or Princeton University, Princeton, New Jersey 08544.

title: The Six Billion Mark
description: The world's population reached six billion this week, by United Nations estimates. The news is daunting, given that the figure has doubled since 1960. Yet six billion actually represents significant progress made in the past 30 years in reducing birth rates, improving health care and giving women greater access to education and economic opportunities. Without such modernization, population growth would have been higher than it is now.

title: U.S. Urges Pakistani Army To Restore Democracy Soon
description: The Clinton Administration urged the Pakistani military today to restore democratic government as quickly as possible, but at the same time officials acknowledged that Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif's rule had been increasingly corrupt and autocratic.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE GAINS AGAIN. Coffee surged for a second day as parched conditions dimmed prospects for a bumper crop in Brazil. In New York, coffee for December delivery rose 5.60 cents, to 96.55 cents a pound.

title: A Touch of Scandinavia Near the Edge of Chinatown
description: IF for no other reason, Good World Bar and Grill beckons because it's a bar in an old barbershop near Chinatown that serves Scandinavian food. In this increasingly franchised world, stumbling onto such an unpredictable collision of ethnicities and milieus feels like a victory for the forces of independence over the army of central control.

title: Rogers Feels Accepted
description: Kenny Rogers, the Mets' scheduled starter in Game 2 on Wednesday afternoon, sounded confident about the start, despite past post-season struggles. He also sounded optimistic about re-signing with the Mets after this season.

title: Whitman Signs Weakened Gun Bill Requiring Trigger Locks
description: Calling it a major step to prevent gun violence, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman today signed into law a measure that will make New Jersey the fourth state in the nation to prohibit the sale of any new handgun unless it is accompanied by a trigger lock.

title: Those Burgers of Yesteryear
description: To the Editor:

title: Rejuvenating Rumba From Within
description: Deep Rumba

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINK, EDWARD B., M.D.
description: FINK-Edward B., M.D., 55. Thoughtful, caring and beloved father of Jason and Laura; devoted son of Edith and the late Harold; loving brother of Elizabeth and David. Graduate of Brown University, Phi Beta Kappa; New York University School of Medicine. Physician, Butler Hospital, Providence, RI. Associate professor, Brown University School of Medicine. Services 11:30 AM Thursday at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Interment will follow at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY. Contributions may be made to the Leukemia Society of America, 75 Sockanosset Crossroad, Cranston, R.I. 02920.

title: Valpolicella Takes a Step Up
description: AT a restaurant in Verona recently I was offered a remarkable red wine, one I had never heard of before. It was called Osar, and the restaurant owner was reluctant to talk about it. ''Ask Sandro Boscaini at Masi,'' he said.

title: Fight Is Promised Over G.M. Plan to Buy Dealerships
description: The president of the National Automobile Dealers Association, one of the nation's wealthiest and most powerful business lobbying groups, bitterly criticized the General Motors Corporation today for its plan to buy 5 percent to 10 percent of its dealerships and operate them itself. He hinted that dealers might try to use their political influence to stop the company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURRAY, JOHN J.
description: MURRAY-John J. of Rutherford, formerly of Ridgefield, died on Monday, October 11. He was 66 years old. He served with the US Navy during the Korean war, and was a Graphic Art salesman for Align Media, of New York City. For information Blackley Funeral Home and Cremation Services, Ridgefield, New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COBB, HENRY
description: COBB-Henry. For the past 19 years, Henry Cobb enjoyed life with his beloved wife Eliza with whom he shared many interests and a loving devotion to their extended family. The Trustees and Staff of The Museum of Modern Art are deeply saddened and mourn his loss. To Eliza, his children, Sheila, John and Victoria, his stepchildren John and Zaidee, his grandchildren and great-grandchildren, we send our most heartfelt sympathy. David Rockefeller, Chairman Emeritus Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Agnes Gund, President Glenn D. Lowry, Director The Museum of Modern Art, NY Sir Brian Urquhart, Chairman Jo Carole Lauder, President The International Council of The Museum of Modern Art

title: When Leeks Saved the Day
description: To the Editor:

title: Folk Art Museum Plans a Six-Story Building in Midtown
description: The Museum of American Folk Art, caretaker and promoter of nearly 4,000 artifacts of American culture, is to begin construction today of a six-story museum at 45 West 53d Street. The event marks the first major new art museum construction in the city since the Whitney Museum opened on Madison Avenue in 1966. And it signals the folk art museum's move to a more prominent place in Manhattan's cultural scene.

title: Civilization, Sanitation and the Mayor
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, still outraged over an exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum of Art that he calls perverted and anti-Catholic, broke into an impromptu philosophical discussion yesterday on the merits of civilization and sanitation.

title: Facing the (Very Loud) Music : AMERICAN TOPICS
description: If you drive by City Hall on a Friday evening in Fort Lupton, Colorado, you will find teenagers listening to loud music, as in almost any small American town. The music comes not from cars parked on the square or youths sitting on the curb, but from inside the City Council chambers.

title: Chief Executive of Hertz Is Set to Retire
description: The Hertz Corporation, the world's largest car-rental company, said today that Frank A. Olson would retire as chief executive at the end of the year, and it named the president, Craig R. Koch, as his successor.

title: From a Brownie Box Snapshot to an Imprint on the American Consciousness
description: In 1900, conveniently on schedule for this centennial survey, a revolution in photography took place: the small Brownie box camera went on sale for $1, affordable enough for everyone to start taking snapshots. ''American Photography: A Century of Images'' juxtaposes that crucial fact with videotape taken this year. In a church hall in Oklahoma City, people who have survived a tornado sift through hundreds of photographs recovered from the storm and laid out on long tables. They are searching for those irreplaceable objects now taken for granted as part of every family's history.

title: Nobels for Fast Camera and Tying 2 Forces of Nature
description: Nobel Prizes worth nearly $1 million each were awarded yesterday to an Egyptian-American chemist and to two Dutch theoretical physicists for opening new perspectives on the behavior of molecules and subnuclear particles.

title: Pitching for the Rome Team, Bishop Sullivan
description: THE year was 1948 and a guy says to me, 'Hey listen, you think you're such a good pitcher, they're having a tryout for the Phillies. So go.' ''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELIAS, SARAH
description: ELIAS-Sarah. The officers, Board of Trustees, Congregation and Clergy of The Jewish Center of the Hamptons mourn the passing of Sarah Elias, beloved mother of our devoted member Sylvia Lehrer. We extend condolences to Sylvia and her family. Rabbi David J. Gelfand Cantor Debra Stein-Davidson Donald Zucker, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, FRIEDA
description: DAVIS-Frieda. On October 11, 1999. Beloved wife of Leonard. Dear mother of Harvey. Private services were held on Tuesday, October 12, 1999.

title: Divorced, Or Not? A Phone Line For Answers
description: So many anxious divorced couples are calling to see if they are in or out of wedlock in the wake of a Manhattan divorce court bribery scandal that court officials established a toll-free number yesterday to ease their fears of eternal union.

title: Boston Will Need a Reverse Curse
description: Here is a scouting report on the American League Championship Series, with comments by Buster Olney.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALDMAN, JOSEPH, M.D.
description: WALDMAN-Joseph, M.D. Of Philadelphia, PA, on October 9, 1999 at age 93. Husband of Lillian (nee Cades). Father of Julia Waldman Rasch, Julian David Waldman and Joanna Waldman. Brother of Ann Feldman. Also survived by 7 grandchildren and 1 great-grandchild. In lieu of gifts or flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to Jefferson Medical College, c/o Alumni Office, 1020 Locust St., Philadelphia, PA 19107.

title: Spectators Turn Out to Watch the Drama
description: Late-model cars lined the road leading to Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif's official residence, as citizens, hearing that a military coup was in progress, drove in to watch.

title: U.N. Worker Slain in Kosovo Was Resident of Queens
description: The United Nations employee who was killed on his first day in Kosovo on Monday was a Queens resident who had spent years working toward a peacekeeping assignment with the organization.

title: Huskey Says Yankee Fans Hate Mets More
description: Butch Huskey may not have been in Boston long enough to get a feel for the Yankee-Red Sox rivalry, but he is well aware of the venom Yankee fans can exhibit, having started his career as a Met. Huskey said that while the Red Sox hear it from the fans, he has heard worse.

title: Science and Religion
description: To the Editor:

title: Another Artist, Another Exhibit
description: Showtime will be making a movie based on the political brawl over an art exhibition accused of being obscene.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANZONI, CAROL BERLIN
description: MANZONI-Carol Berlin. The law offices of Ross & Hardies mourn the passing of our friend and partner Carol Berlin Manzoni. Carol was a prominent labor lawyer and nationally recognized expert in employment discrimination law. She was elected to the firm's Executive Committee from 1992-1998 and was Co-Chairman of the Committee from 1996-1998. We wish to extend our condolences to her husband Michael Hron, stepsons Benjamin & Jonathan and family.

title: Gore Campaign Plans to Enlist Labor and Blacks to Beat Back Challenge by Bradley
description: Having all but won the endorsement of one of the most active armies of foot soldiers in politics, Vice President Al Gore's campaign is relying on organized labor's grass-roots support in crucial states like Iowa, New York and California to beat back the candidacy of former Senator Bill Bradley in the Democratic primaries.

title: BRITISH PRICES UP SLIGHTLY
description: Britain's inflation rate remained in check during September, with prices rising just four-tenths of 1 percent from August, to 2.1 percent, still well below the Bank of England's target of 2.5 percent. Despite Britain's economic growth, retail pricing increases have stalled, in part because of the intense competition in the supermarket sector. The price of goods increased by just five-tenths of a percent from a year earlier, while the price of services rose 3.6 percent.

title: In TriBeCa, Simplicity And Soft Edges
description: A GENERATION ago, America was infatuated with the idea of gracious living. It was the Eisenhower-era consumer-culture equivalent of shibui, a Japanese concept that suggests refinement, visual harmony and an all-over feeling of well-being. It has been superseded, in New York at least, by ''edge.''

title: Clemens's Title Chase Goes Through Fenway
description: Roger Clemens had barely strutted to his locker yesterday morning when a crowd of reporters slowly descended on him. The Red Sox and the Yankees will compete in the American League Championship Series for the first time, and Clemens is one of the players who could speak candidly about wearing both uniforms. That is, if he only wanted to.

title: Wasted Opportunity Squanders a Gift
description: The No. 1 question entering the National League Championship Series was how the Mets could possibly beat Atlanta after the Braves had manhandled them during the season; worse, in the last three weeks. In trying to answer that question objectively, members of the Braves looked at other factors.

title: Hernandez's Age Comes Up Again
description: When the Yankees signed Orlando Hernandez as a free agent on March 7, 1998, they knew his birthdate on some Cuban baseball cards was Oct. 11, 1965, which made him 32 years old. But Hernandez said he was not 32, only 28. Now that a magazine has reiterated the discrepancy by reporting that Hernandez was listed as 34 in recent divorce papers, not 30 as he is said to be in the Yankees' media guide, the pitcher was quizzed about his age. ''The only one that has got a right to ask me about my age is George Steinbrenner, and so far nothing has happened,'' Hernandez said. ''George never asked me nothing about my age.''

title: Workers Rescued After Fall From Scaffold
description: Two construction workers were knocked off scaffolding in midtown Manhattan yesterday and left to dangle 70 feet above the ground in their safety harnesses until firefighters rescued them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COPPINGER, ROBERT V.
description: COPPINGER-Robert V. On October 11, 1999 in Doylestown, PA. Owner WXMC Radio, formerly with Buckley Radio Sales, Petry Co. and Metro Radio. Beloved husband of Margaret Mary. Devoted father of Donna M. Coppinger, Carol A. Wagner and the late Robert V. Jr. Brother of Jane Taylor. Also survived by his nine grandchildren & his eleven great-grandchildren. Visiting Weds. 2-5 and 7-9PM at the N.F. Walker Funeral Home, 2039 Merrick Avenue, Merrick. Funeral Mass Thursday 10 AM, Our Lady of the Miraculous Medal RC Church, Point Lookout. Interment Calverton National Cemetery.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 5 about the desecration of a Jewish cemetery in Berlin misstated the burial site of Leo Baeck, a prominent rabbi. It is in London, not Berlin.

title: Newell in French Deal
description: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., which makes Calphalon cookware, Levolor blinds and other household products, agreed to buy a 51 percent stake in Reynolds S.A., a French maker of pens and pencils, for about $64.8 million. Newell will pay $57.47 a share for 1.1 million shares of Reynolds, a 39 percent premium over Monday's closing stock price. Reynolds, based in Valence, had 1998 sales of $82 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINSTEIN, MARNIN, DR.
description: FEINSTEIN-Marnin, Dr. On October 10, 1999. Of Raanana Israel formerly of Paramus, NJ. Professor of Jewish History and Hebrew Literature at City College of New York and Columbia University. Dean of Herzliah Hebrew Teachers Institute of New York. Accomplished author, artist, musician and orator. Survived by his sister Alitta Irwin & his children, Karma Cohen and Rami Feinstein.

title: Science and Religion
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Nobel Prizes in Science

title: Giants Are Soft-Spoken In Criticism of Offense
description: Defensive players in the National Football League generally do not watch their team's offense when it is on the field. They rest on the bench.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; Czech Banking Troubles Further Squeeze a Weak Economy
description: Jiri Hovorka is angry. At 26, he runs a moderately successful car-rental business. But he is unable to expand his fleet of 14 vehicles, a move that would allow him to increase his profit and hire more employees. No bank in the Czech Republic will give him a loan.

title: School Violence Expert Focuses on Prevention
description: These are busy days for Ronald D. Stephens, an expert on school violence.

title: Islanders
description: The Islanders demoted the highly touted defenseman Eric Brewer to Lowell of the American Hockey League.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAYNOR, EDWARD H.
description: GAYNOR-Edward H. On October 12, 1999. Beloved husband of Sylvia. Loving father of Jeffrey and his wife Paula. Cherished grandfather of Adam, Jessica, Scott and David. He will be deeply missed. Service Wednesday 12:45 PM at the ''Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Army Is Restructuring With Brigades for Rapid Response
description: As a first step in what could ultimately be the most significant restructuring of the Army's combat divisions since the Vietnam War, the Army announced today that it would create two new lighter, more mobile brigades able to deploy anywhere in the world within 96 hours.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALMA, GREGORY, REVEREND, O.F.M.
description: PALMA - Gregory, Reverend, O.F.M. October 11, 1999. Devoted son of the late Joseph and Marie Josephine. Loving brother of Robert, George, Raymond, Alice Wilcken and Sister Eileen, I.H.M. Reposing at Saint Anthony's RC Church, West Houston & Sullivan Streets, NYC, Wednesday from 3:00-9:00PM. A wake service will be held at 7:00 PM. Funeral Mass Thursday, October 14 at 11:00 AM. Interment Saint Peter's Cemetery, Staten Island, NY. For information please contact Perazzo Funeral Home, 212-777-7108.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Sept. 13 about the investment banker Roger C. Altman and his role as adviser to CBS in its merger with Viacom misstated the background of Robert A. Altman, for whom the investment banker is occasionally mistaken. Robert Altman was formerly the president of First American Bankshares, a company controlled by the Bank of Credit and Commerce International. He was not the chairman of the Bank of Credit and Commerce.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HEGAZY, EIHAB
description: HEGAZY-Eihab. 10/13/67-8/24/99. Happy Birthday Baby. Not a day goes by where you're not in my thoughts. I am so grateful for all of the cherished memories that I shall carry with me always. So loving, caring and sharing, you are eternally missed. I love you always. Forever in my heart, Nanc

title: A Tumultuous Funeral, and Then Off for Step Dancing
description: ''Finnegan's Farewell'' furnishes much to lament.

title: Dow Jones Says Its Profit Climbed 28% In 3d Quarter
description: Dow Jones & Company said yesterday that its third-quarter profit rose 28 percent on higher advertising revenue at The Wall Street Journal, the largest daily newspaper in the United States.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Citizen Ross Goes to Court

title: HCC INSURANCE HOLDINGS TO ACQUIRE CENTRIS GROUP
description: HCC Insurance Holdings Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire Centris Group Inc. for $12.50 a share, a total of $171 million. Centris, based in Costa Mesa, Calif., is an insurance holding company that primarily provides medical stop-loss coverage to employers that self-insure. It has assets of $537 million. Stop-loss insurance limits medical costs that a self-insured business will incur. Centris said it expected to report a third-quarter charge of $13.5 million that included reserve strengthening for its medical stop-loss business and an addition to reserves for discontinued operations. Shares of Centris rose $1.1875 each, to $11.50.

title: A New Name, by Request
description: Harvard University is regularly kept busy warning groups and businesses against using the Harvard name in unauthorized ways.

title: Miffed Rowland Walks Off as He's Pressed About Scandal
description: Gov. John G. Rowland, struggling to stake out a consistent response to the months of questions he expects to face about a kickback scheme by one of his running mates, at first made jocular remarks about the scandal today but then became miffed and walked away when he tired of the questions.

title: Barton Beers Picks Cramer-Krasselt
description: Barton Beers Ltd. in Chicago said yesterday that it had awarded its creative and media accounts for its imported Modelo Brewery brands to Cramer-Krasselt in Chicago. Billings were estimated at $18 million.

title: FOOD STUFF
description: Grand Central: A Hub for Food

title: Final Tally In Austria Puts Far Right In 2d Place
description: With 250,000 absentee ballots finally counted, the results of Austria's Oct. 3 elections were declared official today, with the far-right Freedom Party holding onto second place by a mere 415 votes.

title: THE CHEF
description: YOU can think about sandwiches in two directions: from the inside out or from the outside in. You can decide on the filling and then choose the bread, or if you're like me, you can choose the bread and then decide what to put between the slices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEWART, SYLVIA LICHTENSTEIN
description: STEWART-Sylvia Lichtenstein. March 21, 1914 to October 8, 1999. Formerly of Roslyn, New York. Lovingly remembered by her brother, Harold Lichtenstein, her sons, Carl and Mark, daughter-inlaw, Lori, grandchildren, Rachel, Kim, Ian, and Lily, great grandchildren and other loving family and friends. Memorial Service will be held on Saturday, October 30, 1999, at 4 P.M. at Finnerty & Stevens Funeral Home, 426 Main Street, Great Barrington, MA.

title: For Seattle, Triumph and Protest
description: When Seattle beat 40 other cities in the United States early this year for the right to host a meeting of the world's governing trade organization, local leaders were exultant. Here in what is often called the most trade-dependent region of the nation, they said the meeting would be a chance to show off Seattle as a world-class center of high-tech innovation and a friend to global trade.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Some Senators Spurn A Plan on Test Ban
description: Senate conservatives rejected a compromise by the Republican and Democratic leaders to delay voting on a nuclear test ban pact. The leaders said they would resume talks, and the issue remained whether the Senate defeats the treaty or finds a face-saving way to withdraw it.

title: Word Up!
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: James Logan Is Dead at 78; Winner of the Medal of Honor
description: James M. Logan, who won the Medal of Honor as an Army sergeant in World War II by single-handedly capturing a German machine-gun position in the first hours of the landing at Salerno, Italy, died on Saturday at a hospital in Longview, Tex. He was 78.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CALLON PETROLEUM CO., Natchez, Miss., said it planned to sell 3.2 million common shares to help finance oil- and gas-exploration activities this year and next.

title: Wrestling (In the Mud) With Faludi
description: MEN of New York, turn off the baseball playoffs. Put aside your magazines glorifying babes and gear. Stop trying to win games and get promotions. Don't pretend you're enjoying this so-called economic boom.

title: Quietly and Dexterously, Senate Republicans Set a Trap
description: Senator Byron Dorgan reached the limit of his patience on Sept. 8.

title: Essay; The Year of Debates
description: In the coming year, with no White House incumbent to vote for or against, we'll be basing our nomination and election decisions largely on how candidates impress us in the televised debates.

title: Cell Phone Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: Parcells Wants Mirer To Be More Aggressive
description: Bill Parcells and quarterback Rick Mirer seemed to have different views today on what Mirer should be doing better. Parcells, however, once again nominated Mirer as his starter when the Jets face the Colts Sunday at the Meadowlands.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TERMAN, DAISY
description: TERMAN-Daisy, age eighty-eight. Wife of Isaiah Terman, mother of Jane Terman McMahan and Michael Terman, grandmother of Selena McMahan. Our artist and inspiration. Services private.

title: Beck's Regret: Bad Pitch Meets Very Good Hitter
description: As soon as the ball slipped off his fingers, just before midnight, Rod Beck knew that it was trouble. And in the short time it took to travel to the plate and for Bernie Williams's bat to meet the pitch, Beck's worst fears were realized.

title: Yanks Win, 4-3; Mets Lose, 4-3
description: The Yankees beat Boston on a 10th-inning homer by Bernie Williams, above, in Game 1 of the American League Championship Series. Game 2 is at Yankee Stadium tonight.

title: G.M. AND DAEWOO DISCUSS LINK
description: The world's biggest auto maker, the General Motors Corporation, is continuing exclusive talks with the Daewoo Motor Company of South Korea about a possible strategic tie-up. The two companies signed a memorandum of understanding in August to begin talks on a possible partnership, which some analysts say could result in G.M.'s takeover of Daewoo Motor. This week, a delegation of G.M. executives, headed by Louis R. Hughes, vice president for new business strategies, arrived in Seoul to hold talks with Daewoo officials.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANNAFIN, JOHN J.
description: HANNAFIN-John J. Of Valley Stream, New York, on October 13, 1999. Retired Lieutenant, New York City Fire Department, Retired Pressman, The New York Times. Beloved husband of Gloria. Loving father of Laurie (Michael) Otis, Mark, Daniel (Craig), John Jr., Michael (Janet), Steven and Luke. Also survived by grandchildren Shannon Otis and Michael and James. Dear brother of Daniel P., Kathleen Bergen and the late Maureen E. Sandhaas. Reposing from 2-4 and 7-9 PM on Thursday and Friday at Edward F. Lieber Funeral Home, 266 N. Central Avenue, Valley Stream. Funeral mass at 9 AM Saturday at Blessed Sacrament Church, Valley Stream. Interment is at the Holy Rood Cemetery. Donations may be made to Blessed Sacrament Church 50th Anniversary Fund.

title: Does Modern Art Speak to Us?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REDMOND, PATRICIA D.
description: REDMOND-Patricia D. Age 73 of Roswell, GA. Died October 12, 1999. She was a member of St. Andrews Catholic Church and a homemaker. Surviving are her husband, John T. Redmond of Roswell, daughters Mrs. Rhys (Christine) Thomas of Roswell, Mrs. James (Patricia) Nisivoccia of Toms River, NJ, sons John P. (Lee) Redmond, Teaneck, NJ, Timothy E. (Andrea) Redmond, Andover, MA, David J. (Barbara) Redmond, Great Falls, VA, and Phillip J. (Jennifer) Redmond, Boston, MA, Brother Benedict Desmond of Heathsville, VA, and also survived by nine grandchildren. The funeral Mass will be held Friday, October 15, 1999, at 10:30AM at St. Andrews Catholic Church with Fr. Paul Reynolds officiating. Internment will follow in Green Lawn Cemetery. The family will receive friends today, from 6 until 8pm at the funeral home. In lieu of flowers please make memorials to: Hospice Atlanta, 1244 Park Vista Dr., Atlanta, GA 30319. Roswell Funeral Home, 950 Mansell Road. (770) 993-4811.

title: After 4 Years of Crew, Still No Final Grade; He Champions Accountability, But Data Show Little Improvement
description: As Rudy Crew begins his fifth year as Chancellor of the New York City school system tomorrow, he has accumulated more power than any other school leader in a generation, and has aggressively used that power against laggard schools and educators he felt were inept. But his legacy and achievements remain in dispute.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UNGER, RICHARD ALAN
description: UNGER-Richard Alan. Died suddenly on October 12, 1999. Loving husband of Helaine. Devoted father of Ilana. Cherished son of Frieda and Lee. Beloved brother of Larry. Funeral Burlington, VT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDERS, SAMUEL
description: SANDERS-Samuel. Juilliard's Memorial Tribute for the late pianist Samuel Sanders will take place tonight at 8 P.M. in the Juilliard Theatre, 155 West 65 Street.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Buchanan Set to Quit G.O.P. In Oct. 25 Speech, Aide Says
description: In the clearest indication yet that he is planning to break with the Republican Party, Patrick J. Buchanan has begun notifying supporters that he will make a major speech on Oct. 25 in Falls Church, Va., where he is widely expected to announce that he will seek the Reform Party's nomination for President.

title: Taking On the Glam Rock Diva (and the Gender Gap)
description: Deep into the run of an established hit it's time to take chances, and with the casting of Ally Sheedy in the title role, ''Hedwig and the Angry Inch'' took a huge one. Ms. Sheedy, who has matured in recent years into an intelligent actress of offbeat charisma -- catch her brooding lesbian photographer on video in the indie film ''High Art'' -- is to say the least an unlikely choice for Hedwig, and only partly because the role of the drag queen in progress, mutilated on an East Berlin operating table, was written for a man.

title: The Spirit of the Ancients and a Classical Purity
description: The Australian Ballet may usually be down under, but it was absolutely tops on Tuesday night when it opened a weeklong season at City Center with a brash and contemporary triple bill brimming with energy and fresh ideas.

title: Kagwe of Kenya Seems the Favorite
description: A few days before his Sept. 19 race, August Cambria, the director of the Yonkers Half-Marathon, picked up the ringing phone.

title: Co-Creator of 'NYPD Blue' Says ABC Time Slot to Change
description: Steven Bochco, co-creator of the Emmy-award winning television series ''NYPD Blue,'' said today that ABC had told him the show would be moved from its Tuesday night time slot after six years. The network declined to comment.

title: 78% Have Passed Regents, but Experts Raise Concerns
description: In the first high school class that is required to pass the Regents English exam to graduate, nearly four in five students have so far succeeded, state education officials announced today. They hailed the results as evidence that raising standards has raised performance. But the data were open to other interpretations as well, experts said.

title: New Chief Named by John Hancock
description: The John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company, the sixth-largest policyholder-owned life insurer in the United States, has named its president and chief operations officer, David F. D'Alessandro, as its next chief executive.

title: Real Estate Franchising
description: To the Editor:

title: Aid for Floyd's Victims On Legislative Agenda
description: The State Senate has scheduled an Oct. 25 vote on a bill that would provide $50 million in grants and loans to victims of Tropical Storm Floyd's flooding, plus an additional $10 million for local and state agencies to cover flood-related expenses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, JOHN J.
description: ROSS-John J. Youngest brother of Lillian and Danny, as a brother, he was my best friend for over 75 years and was always so cheerful and happy to be with. We will miss you, brother John, and we love you forever. Danny and Norma Ross Joan Ross and Paul Ross

title: Pledges of Extradition Accompany Colombian Drug Arrests
description: The Justice Department announced today that Colombia had arrested the head of that nation's largest cocaine trafficking ring and other drug traffickers and had pledged to move quickly to extradite them to the United States.

title: Fighting Gang Violence With Job Prospects
description: Offering the carrot of job opportunities and threatening the stick of intensive law enforcement, Federal, state and local officials announced yesterday a pilot program to combat gang violence in a Brooklyn neighborhood.

title: Other Martinez Seeks Identity
description: He is the Martinez brother who pitched a no-hitter.

title: Republicans Would Restore Some 1997 Cuts in Medicare
description: Senior Republicans in Congress proposed today to restore some of the money they cut from Medicare in 1997, but they said they had no plans to provide prescription drug benefits to the elderly this year.

title: Type-Casting Our Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIDMANN, MARCUS
description: WIDMANN-Marcus, M.D., on October 10, 1999, at the age of 94, after a short illness. Beloved husband of the late Dina Sander Widmann. Cherished father of Roger and Judith Widmann and Harriet and Martin Spitz. Adored grandfather of Daniel and Kenneth Widmann, and Emily McBurney, and Lisa and Jenny Spitz. Loving brother of Fina Eytan and the late Gershon Widmann. He was devoted to his family and his patients throughout his life and will be remembered for the unfailing generosity of his spirit. Service Thursday, 10 AM, at ''Riverside Memorial Chapel'',21 West Broad Street, Mt. Vernon, New York.

title: Yzerman Is Chasing Lemieux
description: RED WINGS 4, BLUES 2

title: Martin Bartner, 69, Publisher of The Star-Ledger
description: Martin Bartner, a former high school sports stringer who became publisher of The Star-Ledger of Newark and helped build the newspaper into the largest in the state, died Sunday at his home in Verona, N.J. He was 69.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Investors Are Jumpy, and the Fed Is Making Matters Worse
description: WHEN the Federal Reserve policy makers want to, they can still stir the pot on Wall Street. Their Oct. 5 decision to leave their interest rate target unchanged at 5.25 percent but to hint at a future increase in rates has left investors uncertain, has tripped up stocks and has pushed long-term interest rates near a two-year high.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a World Briefing report on Tuesday about the killing of more than a score of people by left-wing guerrillas and right-wing paramilitary groups misidentified the country in which the slayings occurred. It was Colombia, not Brazil.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Can Nissan Turn on a Centime?; Trying to Revamp a Company and a Corporate Culture
description: Carlos Ghosn, the foreign executive charged with jump-starting the Nissan Motor Company, has a favorite joke: A fabulously wealthy man -- ''rich, successful beyond measure, big ranch with a big lake and mountains, you know, a little obnoxious'' -- shows a group of visitors a vast swimming pool stocked with crocodiles and alligators.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: MANHATTAN

title: A Growing Backlog For Laptop Computers
description: If you are dreaming of a laptop computer under the tree this holiday season, it may be time to wake up and go shopping. The recent earthquake in Taiwan, where many PC systems are assembled, coupled with bad timing in the manufacturing cycles for critical computer components like liquid crystal displays, means that demand for popular laptops is outrunning supply, analysts say.

title: CITATION ACCEPTS AMENDED PURCHASE PACT FROM KELSO
description: The Citation Corporation, a metal-castings maker, said yesterday that it had accepted an amended agreement to be acquired by the New York investment firm Kelso & Company, reducing the purchase price to about $620 million in cash and debt. The transaction values Citation shares at $17 each, down from $18.10 in the earlier deal. The shares of Citation, which had revenue of $724 million for the year that ended on Sept. 27, rose $1.8125 each, to $15.9375, in Nasdaq trading. In June, Kelso said it would pay about $644 million in cash and debt for Citation, which is based in Birmingham, Ala.

title: Calendar; Photographs, Jewelry, Talks and Walks
description: All That Glitters

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, SYLVIA Z.
description: COHEN-Sylvia Z. Beloved wife of the late Emanuel. Devoted mother of Leslie Cohen Berlowitz, Gary W. and Maryjo. Loving grandmother of Sarah, Willow, Connor and Georgia. Dearest sister of Abraham Kaplan. Loving sister-inlaw, aunt, cousin and dearest friend. Services Friday, 12:30PM at the Riverdale Temple, Independence Avenue, Riverdale, N.Y. For information call Weinstein Memorial Chapel 1-800-468-3232.

title: A Disappointed Clinton Says the Fight Is 'Far From Over'
description: A grim- faced President Clinton said tonight that he was ''very disappointed'' over the Senate's rejection of the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty but said the fight was ''far from over.''

title: 146% Rise in Earnings at Bear Stearns Falls Below Estimates
description: The Bear Stearns Companies posted first-quarter earnings yesterday that fell short of expectations, a trend-breaking disappointment that the securities firm attributed to weaker markets for the stocks and bonds it underwrites and trades.

title: Mrs. Clinton Takes Middle Ground: She Roots for Subway Series
description: The Mets were battling for the National League pennant in Atlanta. The Yankees were going up against the Red Sox in the Bronx. And Hillary Rodham Clinton was here in Westchester County today for a news conference devoted to epidemiology, when what is arguably the most difficult question any candidate in New York could confront this fall whizzed toward her head:

title: The Truth About Tobacco
description: After denying the truth for decades, Philip Morris now admits that cigarettes cause cancer and other fatal diseases and are addictive. In what appears to be a calculated turnabout, the tobacco company says on its new Internet Web site that ''there is overwhelming medical and scientific consensus that cigarette smoking causes cancer, heart disease, emphysema and other serious diseases.'' It also now admits that ''cigarette smoking is addictive, as that term is most commonly used today.''

title: Head Start on Texture
description: Wait long enough, and anything will become fashionable again. Ana glypta, below, the embossed paintable wallpaper popular in English Victorian homes at the turn of the century, can create the textured walls and fake tin ceilings in favor today. The manufacturer, Crown Decorative Products of Darwen, England, has a new group of subtler patterns in an easy-to-install version called Armadillo ($22 for a double roll). No soaking, pre-pasting or preparing is required. For store locations: (800) 824-4777. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SARATH, HOWARD
description: SARATH-Howard. October 13, 1999 of Lake Worth, FL. Formerly of NYC. Husband of Rosilyn. Father of Maureen (Robert) Oettinger and the late Peter. Father-in-law of Denise Sarath. Brother of Edward and his grandchildren. Alumni of NYU and former representative of American of Martinsville, VA. Interment held from Beth Israel Chapel, Delray Beach, FL.

title: Help for the Lampless
description: Now that department stores like Bloomingdale's have switched off the lights in their lamp departments, the slack is being taken up by budget-conscious retailers. Target has introduced a collection of 24 lamps in styles from American Arts and Crafts to more contemporary designs. Robert Abbey's 22-inch-tall Arts and Crafts style lamp (below) with a bronze finish and a mica shade is $79.99. The 20-inch-high Solano desk lamp by Stiffel (bottom) has a brushed aluminum finish and a linen shade; $139.99. For store locations: (800) 800-8800 or www.target.com. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: 2 Finalists Named In Domino's Review
description: Domino's Pizza said yesterday that it had named two finalists in a review for the national creative-development part of its account, with billings estimated at $120 million.

title: Time Warner Says Results Show a Strong Rebound
description: Time Warner Inc. said yesterday that it earned $369 million in the third quarter, with the cable, cable networks and publishing divisions posting substantial gains while the music and filmed entertainment divisions showed losses.

title: Times Is Said to Consider a New Tower
description: The New York Times Company is negotiating with state and city officials to build its third home in the Times Square area in 94 years, a 1.3-million-square-foot tower on Eighth Avenue, between 40th and 41st Streets, across the street from the Port Authority Bus Terminal, according to government officials and real estate executives involved in the talks.

title: In Wired World, Much Is Free at Click of a Mouse
description: For years, marketers have known that one word, more than any other, can spur people to action.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a reformer in Iran who instigated the seizure of American hostages misstated the date of the Americans' release and of President Ronald Reagan's inauguration. It was Jan. 20, 1981, not 1980.

title: 4 More Charged in Inquiry Into Pedophiles' Use of Net
description: In a continuing investigation into the possible use of the Internet by pedophiles, four more men, including a former school board member in Somers, N.Y., were indicted today on charges of having sex with boys they met through the use of a computer.

title: Escaping From Web Traps
description: To the Editor:

title: Does Modern Art Speak to Us?
description: To the Editor:

title: For Extra Support in the Kitchen
description: THE real joy of cooking is working in a well-organized space. Adding a storage unit, even one not necessarily meant for the kitchen, could mean the difference between calamity and calm. Some pieces offer temporary solutions; others may last a culinary lifetime.

title: The Cup Is Half Full
description: To the Editor:

title: Valentine Finessed, Flummoxed by Cox
description: Think of it. The manager who gets no credit for his team's eight consecutive division championships has outmanaged, outmaneuvered, outfoxed the self-proclaimed smartest manager in baseball. It's Bobby Cox 2, Bobby Valentine 0, and counting. Two more games like the two here, and the Mets will be counted out.

title: Where the Wildebeest Roam, on CD-ROM
description: NATURE: VIRTUAL SERENGETI

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''A little girl was brutally murdered in Boulder, Colo., and the killer or killers remain free today. As Governor, I have the power to appoint a special prosecutor. I am reviewing this option and will make a decision shortly.''

title: Practicing the Power Of Positive Hitting
description: Bernie Williams said he remembered Rod Beck breaking his bat with an inside fastball late in the regular season, so when the Yankees' center fielder stepped up against Beck just before midnight last night, he decided not to try to pull the ball when pitched to that way again because he might have hit the ball foul.

title: A 'No' and a 'Yes': 2 Senators Explain Their Votes
description: Following are excerpts from statements made today on the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty, one by an opponent of the treaty, Senator Trent Lott, Republican of Mississippi, the other by a supporter, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., Democrat of Delaware, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANZONI, CAROL BERLIN
description: MANZONI-Carol Berlin. The law offices of Ross & Hardies mourn the passing of our friend and partner Carol Berlin Manzoni. Carol was a prominent labor lawyer and nationally recognized expert in employment discrimination law. She was elected to the firm's Executive Committee from 1992-1998 and was Co-Chairman of the Committee from 1996-1998. We wish to extend our condolences to her husband Michael Hron, stepsons Benjamin & Jonathan and family.

title: To See Issue In Person, Judge Takes City Hall Tour
description: Led by a Federal judge yesterday, a small group of lawyers, reporters, and photographers ambled through City Hall Park and up the 11 steps of the ornate and historic building.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JORDAN, ALEXANDER BOYD
description: JORDAN-Alexander Boyd, M.D., 73, of Sarasota, Fla., formerly of New Rochelle, N.Y., passed away October 12, 1999. He is a graduate of New York University and the medical school at the University of Geneva, Switzerland. Services will be on Saturday, October 16th, in Sarasota. For more information, contact Robarts Funeral Home at 941-921-7733.

title: National News Briefs; Slatkin Takes Post With BBC Orchestra
description: Leonard Slatkin, the music director of the National Symphony Orchestra in Washington since 1996, has been appointed chief conductor designate of the BBC Symphony Orchestra, the BBC and the National Symphony announced yesterday.

title: Search Tools for the Young
description: To the Editor:

title: Scofflaws In Blue, Parking Illegally
description: The lineup of double-parked cars outside the 24th Precinct station house on the Upper West Side was longer than ever yesterday, even as the police continued their crackdown on double-parking around New York City.

title: Host of TV Show Says He Was Tortured by Palestinian Jailers
description: Maher Dasuki, a popular talk show host on a local television station in this Palestinian-ruled town, became the topic of his own program last week.

title: After Coup, Pakistan Awaits the Next Step
description: A day after Pakistan's armed forces seized power and dismissed the elected Government of Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, Pakistanis waited expectantly to find out who will rule them. The army chief, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, had said he would soon lay out the army's plans, but by last night he still had not disclosed whether he would impose martial law, call new elections or install a civilian government controlled by the military.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINDSAY, EMILIE T.
description: LINDSAY-Emilie T. Of NYC, formerly of Garden City, NY. On October 11, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Dear Aunt of James Clymer. Funeral service tomorrow, 11am, at St. Thomas Church, 5th Avenue at 53rd St., NYC. Internment following at Nassau Knolls Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the St. Thomas Choir School Scholarship Fund, 1 W. 53rd St., NYC, 10019. Funeral interst to: Morehead-McKim-Gallaher Funeral Directors, Inc.

title: Solving a Video Puzzle Is a Movable Feat
description: IF I were saying this on TV, I would request a wig and disguise my voice. Because I have something to say, and it needs to be heard.
