But it's deeply embarrassing, and potentially damaging to my reputation. I've been struggling with this for a while now. And I think at this point, it's best to be honest with myself and my readers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUGO, MARGARET A.
description: LUGO-Margaret A. Age 76 years, of NYC, NY on Sunday October 10, 1999 at her son's residence in Palermo, NJ. She was a veteran of WWII, having served in the U.S. Army Air Corps as a Sergeant. She was an Administrator for the YWCA in New York City, and a patron of the arts. She is survived by her son and daughter-in-law, John F. and Jane Lugo of Palermo NJ, and three grandchildren Stephanie, Jessica and Deanna. Her services will be private at the convenience of her family.

title: Internet Users Step Into the World of van Gogh
description: Have you ever been so entranced by a painting that you wished you could enter its world of light, color, texture and artistic imagination? The Intel Corporation, the giant computer chip maker, is inviting Internet users to do just that -- virtually, at least.

title: Organ Transplant Study Finds Wide Disparity Among Institutions
description: As Congress considers two measures that would affect the future of the nation's organ transplant system, the Clinton Administration released a study today showing startling disparities in the success rates of more than 100 hospitals that treat heart and liver transplant patients.

title: SENATE KILLS TEST BAN TREATY IN CRUSHING LOSS FOR CLINTON; EVOKES VERSAILLES PACT DEFEAT
description: The Senate today rejected a treaty banning all underground nuclear testing in a 51-48 vote that crushed one of President Clinton's major foreign policy goals.

title: France Gives Legal Status to Unmarried Couples
description: The French Parliament passed a new law today giving legal status to unmarried couples, including homosexual unions.

title: Rejecting Science; Religion in Its Place
description: To the Editor:

title: Local Governments Use Tickets to Resist Port Authority
description: A dispute between the Port Authority and local governments over what to build on the last large, undeveloped piece of property adjacent to Port Elizabeth and Newark International Airport has spilled into the streets. The local police have set up a gantlet of truck inspection stations on a major roadway into the port, reaping thousands of dollars in fines and a bumper crop in gridlock and frustration.

title: Gore Gains Labor Backing, Minus 2 Powerful Unions
description: Winning the biggest prize so far in the Presidential campaign, Vice President Al Gore gained the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s endorsement today and vowed to battle for working families, although labor leaders urged him to work harder to win the hearts and minds of union members.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUKSBAUM, RHEA
description: BUKSBAUM-Rhea. Beloved wife of the late Reuben. Loving mother of Buzz and Margo and Marlene and David Hurwitz. Dear grandmother and great grandmother. Services Thursday at ''Parkside Chapels'', Queens Blvd at 66 Ave, Forest HIlls, New York.

title: The Devils Win, but Don't Ask
description: Devils fans who found the Yankees and Mets more entertaining tonight than the Anaheim Mighty Ducks missed a victory but little else.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROBBINS, HAROLD
description: ROBBINS-Harold May 21,1916-October 14, 1997. The pages keep turning. Always remembered. Ed Golli

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUDD, WILLIAM BREWSTER
description: BUDD-William Brewster, 64, of Winchester, Massachusetts died Sunday, October 10, 1999 after a long illness. Born in Minneapolis, Mr. Budd graduated from St. Paul Academy in St. Paul, Minnesota. He received a B.E. from Yale University in 1958 and earned an MBA from the Harvard Business School in 1961. He began his career at John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company in Boston in 1960. In 1983, he joined Chemical Investment Group in New York. From 1989 to 1997, he worked at United Asset Management Corporation in Boston. He is survived by his wife, Nancy Monick Budd, four children and six grandchildren. A Memorial Service will be held at 3:00 P.M. Sunday, October 17 at The Parish of the Epiphany in Winchester. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to The Prostate Cancer Research Fund, Massachusetts General Hospital, 100 Charles River Plaza, Suite 600, Boston, MA 02114; The Nancy M. and William B. Budd Scholarship, Wheaton College, Norton, MA 02766; or The Parish of the Epiphany, 70 Church Street, Winchester, Massachusetts 01890.

title: 2 Shot to Death in Botched Robbery of Muffin Shop in SoHo
description: An owner of a SoHo muffin shop and his manager were shot to death yesterday and two people in the bakery were seriously injured during a botched robbery that ended with a running gunfight on the street between the robbers and police officers, the authorities said.

title: Williams Waits Till Midnight Hour to Top Sox
description: The underdog Boston Red Sox, who might need a little bit of luck to beat the Yankees in the American League Championship Series, were victimized by an umpire's call in the top of the 10th inning. Then Bernie Williams finished them off in the bottom of the 10th, just a few ticks past midnight early this morning.

title: Accounts
description: Aldo Shoes, Montreal, a footwear retailer, to Frierson, Mee & Kraft, New York, to handle its account, which had been at Wheatley & Rosenberg, Montreal. Billings were estimated at $10 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYER, BERNARD
description: MAYER-Bernard, DDS. On October 12, 1999. Beloved husband of Ilse. Uncle of Sandi Golden and Jane Weissler. Services held at Beth El Cemetery, Paramus, NJ, Thursday, October 14.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLONDER, JEROME
description: BLONDER-Jerome. The Board of Governors of the Palm Beach Country Club expresses its sorrow at the passing of its esteemed member and dear friend, Jerome Blonder, and offers its heartfelt sympathy to his family and friends. David L. Rudnick, President Marshall L. Hess, Secretary

title: Sights Trained Yet Again on Amherst's Elusive Belle
description: Few American literary figures are as intensely loved as Emily Dickinson (1830-1886). But few remain as elusive, which is the reason waves of fresh interest in her life and work periodically arise. One seems to be gathering strength now.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a headline in Business Day on Tuesday referred incorrectly to the company whose chief executive will retire in January. As the article reported, Theodore L. Weise, will leave Federal Express, not the FDX Corporation, its parent company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DESETTO, BENJAMIN J.
description: DeSETTO-Benjamin J. On October 13th of Bellrose, NY and Palm Beach, FL. Founder of Urban Furniture Co. and Francar Realty. Beloved husband of Dolores. Loving son of Rose. Dear father of Carole Webster and Frank. Also survived by four grandchildren and seven great grandchildren. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd, Manhasset, on Thursday 7-9 PM. Funeral mass on Friday, 9:45 AM, St Mary's RC Church, Manhasset. Interment Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery, Flushing.

title: PHILIPS REALTY HIRES PRUDENTIAL TO EXPLORE OPTIONS
description: The Philips International Realty Corporation, an owner and operator of shopping centers, mostly in New York and Miami, said yesterday that it had hired Prudential Securities Inc. to explore options to improve its share price. New York-based Philips did not specify what moves it was considering. Philips said its leasing transactions, expansion and redevelopment activity were not reflected in the performance of its shares, which had risen less than 2 percent this year. The stock rose 62.5 cents yesterday, to $16.25. Philips owns neighborhood and community shopping centers. It holds interests in 28 properties, with more than 3.8 million square feet of leasable space.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in some editions on Tuesday with an article about teen-age crime in Japan misstated the increase in the number of minors arrested for felonies. The number has grown 43 percent in a decade, not almost 57 percent.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: The Borgs Are Loose And Coming for You
description: THE news that there was going to be a fashion show at Internet World, a computer trade show and geek nirvana in Manhattan last week, was enough to attract a crowd to Booth 3633 in the convention hall. But the people who staked out chairs near the runway an hour before the show were in for a surprise. Instead of catching a glimpse of models or fashion celebrities, they were treated to the spectacle of shaggy-haired men tinkering with circuit boards on a table littered with cables and electrical tape.

title: In America; Gore Has It Made
description: The thing is, Al Gore should be -- even now, even with all the trouble he's seen, the jokes he's spawned, the missteps he's made -- unbeatable in the race for the Democratic nomination for President. Even with his campaign limping embarrassingly along, he should be able to beat Bill Bradley.

title: Once Morbid And Jittery, Now Tender And Assured
description: For the rock en espanol movement that has taken hold across Latin America, a crucial question has been whether the music can become something more than an imported style -- reggae, heavy metal, art-rock -- with lyrics in Spanish. The Fabulosos Cadillacs, a leading band from Argentina that performed on Friday night at the Hammerstein Ballroom, provide one ringingly affirmative answer.

title: Hot Dogs Sent to 6 States May Be Contaminated
description: Federal and state health officials told grocers yesterday to remove Sabrett hot dogs from their shelves if they have an Oct. 22 sell-by date, because two packages from a Saratoga Springs, N.Y., market were contaminated with listeria bacteria.

title: No Cash for Colombia
description: To the Editor:

title: Scientists Develop a Mouse That Resists Some Cancers
description: In a striking demonstration of the reach of a new anticancer technique, scientists have developed a strain of mouse that is immune to certain types of cancer, surviving injections of malignant cells that quickly raise lethal tumors in normal mice.

title: Type-Casting Our Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Economies of Scale
description: To the Editor:

title: A Damaging Arms Control Defeat
description: In a narrow and misguided show of partisanship, the Republican-led Senate yesterday forced a vote on the nuclear test ban treaty and defeated it by a margin of 51 to 48. The Senate's action -- its bluntest rebuff of a President on a major international agreement since it voted down Woodrow Wilson's Treaty of Versailles in 1919 -- is a destructive abdication of American leadership on arms control and other international issues. The harm done to United States foreign policy and national security could be considerable. President Clinton must now do what he can to limit the damage.

title: The Pope, the King and AIDS Research
description: Three years ago, Robert Albert, the owner of Coraggio Textiles in Bellevue, Wash., stopped at a cafe in San Leucio, Italy. This small town near Naples was home to a royal textile mill established by Charles III of Spain in the 1700's. It was there that Mr. Albert heard about a master weaver's original instructions for a jacquard fabric called Gondolfo, designed in 1776 for the prayer robes of Pope Pius VI. (The Pope's summer home is Castel Gondolfo.) Last year, he reopened an old mill in San Leucio to reproduce the golden-hued fabric, resplendent with birds of paradise (inset above). The silk and cotton jacquard ($149 a yard) is available to the trade through Coraggio at (800) 624-2420. Until Nov. 7, the fabric can be seen as draperies in a room by Sam Botero, below, at the Showcase Home for the Millennium 2000 at 57 East 80th Street. A $20 admission benefits Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS and the Children's Advocacy Center of Manhattan. Information: (212) 861-7879.

title: Ad Age Group Appoints a Team
description: The Ad Age Group in New York said yesterday that it had promoted three executives to form its new management team.

title: Where the Brouhaha Was Born; British Artists Have Been Taking Risks, and Flak, for Years
description: It all began in 1988 when Damien Hirst, an art student full of swagger and energy, decided to put on a show.

title: Birdcages That Confine Only Light, Lanterns That Softly Filter It
description: These lamps in exotic shapes and colors would serve well in a setting for Scheherazade's entertainments. Alon Longotsky, who collaborated on them with Bona Maggi, an Italian designer in Bali, says that the line, which took three and a half years to develop, was inspired by ''The Arabian Nights'' and Ken Russell's film ''Valentino.''

title: Type-Casting Our Children
description: To the Editor:

title: P.T.A.'s Tap Into E-Commerce As a Fund-Raiser for Schools
description: E-COMMERCE is coming to the aid of the P.T.A., and Debbie Schide is delighted.

title: NATO's New Chief Hones a Balancing Act
description: LONDON  George Robertson was attending a recent meeting of defense ministers from the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and partnership countries when a remark underscored the tensions behind the military relationship between the United States and its European allies.

title: E*Trade Loss Not as Deep As Forecast
description: E*Trade Group Inc., the on-line brokerage firm, reported a smaller-than-expected fourth-quarter loss today as it added customers at a lower cost than it did in the previous quarter.

title: Success for Yankee Staff Means Rust for Others
description: Sweat dripped off the face of Gary Tuck, the Yankees' catching instructor and primary bullpen catcher, when he returned to the clubhouse after Tuesday's workout. It had been one of his heaviest days of bullpen work since spring training, because the Yankees have so many pitchers in need of game action.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEUDERT, MONIQUE
description: BEUDERT-Monique. Born Long Island, New York, October 22, 1950. Died peacefully October 9, 1999, London, England, age 48. Beloved wife of Brian Boylan of London. Cherished daughter of Adele Beudert and the late Francis Beudert of Cold Spring Harbor, Long Island; sister of Martine Beudert of Brooklyn, Michele Richard of Old Greenwich, Connecticut, and Claude Beudert of East Hampton; stepmother of Grace and Serena Boylan of London. Studied art history at Connecticut College (B.A. 1972) and Hunter College, CUNY, New York. Worked briefly for Pace Gallery, New York, before joining the staff of The Museum of Modern Art, New York, in 1973 in the Office of the Registrar. Held a curatorial position in MoMA's Department of Painting and Sculpture from 1976 to 1984. Curator and Adviser, Paine Webber Art Collection, 1984 to 1993. Associate Curator, Tate Gallery, London, 1994 to 1999. A respected curator with a discriminating eye and an unusual sensitivity to artists and collectors-one for whom the artist and the work of art always took precedence. A voracious and insightful reader whose contributions to not one, but two New York reading groups will be greatly missed. An exceptional individual whose warmth, intelligence, humor, style, and quiet sense of purpose were widely admired in New York, London, and wherever she traveled. She brought joy to many, and her capacity for friendship will always be remembered by those who were close to her. A memorial service will be held in London in November. Donations in her memory may be sent to: Monique Beudert Fund, Studio in a School Association, Inc., 410 West 59th Street, New York, NY 10019. Contributions will be used to provide art supplies for children.

title: The Uses of a Coup
description: Governing Pakistan is a near-impossible task. Consider the daunting realities: 25 percent literacy; 70 percent of the gross domestic product devoted to defense or debt service; one million refugees from the war in Afghanistan still living in Pakistan; a home-grown terrorist cadre being trained in local religious schools sponsored by neighboring Muslim countries; Afghan-based drug trafficking; the constant threat that the 40-year, often violent confrontation with nuclear-armed India could spin out of control, and a stagnant economy with virtually no renewal conceivable for years.

title: Religious Leaders Prevail As Alabama Shuns Lottery
description: Today was a day of jubilation for the churchgoers of Alabama. To the dismay of a clearly shaken Gov. Donald Siegelman, religious leaders led his plan for a state lottery to firm defeat in a referendum on Tuesday, and there was widespread rejoicing at their display of political force.

title: Put It on the Ceiling and Call It High Art
description: WHEN Tom Wolfe wrote about this gambling oasis in the early 1960's, he reeled: ''Such colors! All the electrochemical pastels of the Florida littoral.'' Today he would be struck dumb by . . . such details! Las Vegas on the cusp of a new millennium is decked out with all the frills of the Renaissance.

title: A Concerned Cone
description: David Cone looked cool and seemed calm, all zipped up in his blue Yankees jacket with his blue Yankees cap on his head last night in cool Yankee Stadium. Talking about his scheduled start in Game 2 of the American League Championship Series, the veteran right-hander nodded as he heard every question and he composed lengthy, thoughtful answers to them. The only signs of anxiety were in his fingertips, the tools of his trade, as he pressed them together just above the table top.

title: No Charges in Death of Child Beauty Queen
description: Nearly three years after JonBenet Ramsey was found beaten and strangled in her parents' home here, prosecutors said today that they did not have enough evidence to charge anyone with her killing and they dismissed the grand jury hearing evidence in the case.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Friday about Sweden's success in preserving a welfare state while also embracing entrepreneurship and unrestricted competition misspelled the name of an industrial park started by Ericsson and I.B.M. in the 1970's. It is the Kista Science Park, not Kiska.

title: Trying On Clothes in a Virtual Dressing Room
description: COSMOPOLITAN FASHION MAKEOVER DELUXE

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

title: Trains Without Pain
description: To the Editor:

title: Program Makes Short Work Of a Longstanding Challenge
description: All of us, now and again, look at a deal and wonder whether some contract can make with the best play and defense. It may consist of 52 cards, or it may be an ending with five or six cards in each hand. It may be a situation that has been constructed as a challenge, or one from a newspaper column, or one from real life.

title: Motorola Plans to Take A Big Charge For Iridium
description: Motorola Inc. said today that it expected to take a $500 million charge against earnings in the fourth quarter, a move that would essentially write off its entire exposure to Iridium, the struggling global satellite telephone service.

title: Corrections
description: A picture yesterday with the continuation of a film review of ''Cremaster 2,'' written and directed by Matthew Barney, carried an incorrect credit. The photographer was Michael James O'Brien.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Creative Use Of Crowded Space

title: Ideas From Paris, Verdant and Rich
description: AN exhibition called La Maison Colbert in Vanderbilt Hall at Grand Central Terminal offers a very abstract sense of October in Paris. There, the art of trompe l'oeil is thriving in the third dimension. The hall is decked out like a Paris courtyard, around which are 11 rooms featuring vignettes by retailers like Hermes, Van Cleef & Arpels and Lalique.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the results of the Memphis mayoral election misspelled the surname of a political pollster who commented on the results. He is Steven C. Ethridge, not Etheridge.

title: The 0-2 Mets Are Still Alive, But Thus Far It's a Half-Life
description: Kenny Rogers could only wait, pounding the ball mindlessly into his glove, as the pitching coach Dave Wallace and Mike Piazza converged on the mound. The agony of that moment was achingly familiar for Rogers, whose long, ugly post-season history had just taken on a miserable new addition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANOFF, FRANK
description: SANOFF-Frank. A kind, gracious person who epitomized the definition of the word-gentleman. Always pleasant. Unfailingly polite. A fine businessman with whom it was a pleasure to do business. A man of his word which is so rare in todays economic environment. We will miss him. We offer our deepest respects to his wife and to his children, and the entire Sanoff family. Jerome Belson, President Nicholas La Porte, Jr. Executive Director Associated Builders and Owners of Greater New York, Inc.

title: For Indian Nations, Virtual Trade Routes
description: ON a recent trip to visit the Catawba Indian Nation in Catawba, S.C., Dan Umstead, a member of the Oneida Nation of central New York, was shown centuries-old pottery of Oneida design excavated there, some 800 miles from home. For members of the six-nation Iroquois Confederacy, which includes the Oneida, it was once common to travel half a continent on foot to trade with other Indian nations. That trade became much more difficult in the 19th century, when many tribes were moved to reservations.

title: Microsoft Sued By Priceline
description: Priceline.com, which lets consumers bid on the Internet for plane tickets and hotel rooms, said today that it had filed a suit against the Microsoft Corporation, contending that Microsoft's new hotel service violates a Priceline patent.

title: Private Eyes in the Sky Go to Court
description: SEVERAL years ago, David A. Landgrebe, a professor at Purdue University's School of Electrical and Computer Engineering who studies satellite imagery, found himself describing his research in deep technical detail to a local judge when they met socially.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, SAMUEL F.
description: GREEN-Samuel F. Passed away October 13, 1999 at the age of 100. Loving uncle to Mortimer and Adrienne Green and great uncle to Graham. Predeceased by his adoring brother and sister-in-law Louis and Doris Green. Sam was a dedicated and tireless life insurance agent for more than 60 years. He was a top producer for the Guardian, Union Central and National Benefit Life Insurance Companies and often honored by the prestigious Million Dollar Round Table. Sam was the ''consummate salesman'' who managed to carry out his business with honesty and integrity and became a role model to all who worked with him. Rest in peace, Uncle Sam. Interment private.

title: Former Tory Leaders Call Party's Position on Europe Suicidal
description: The decision by the Conservative annual convention distancing the party further from Europe was attacked by past Tory leaders today as unthinking and suicidal for the party's chances of ever getting back into power.

title: In the specialized world of technology, two multimillion-dollar quests for more attention.
description: TWO specialized high-technology magazines are waging multimillion-dollar campaigns to broaden their reach.

title: Senate Approves $8.7 Billion for Emergency Aid to Farmers
description: Driven by low crop prices, bad weather in many parts of the country and arcane farm-state politics, the Senate gave final legislative approval today to an $8.7 billion package of emergency aid to farmers.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Anger on Agenda for World Trade Meeting
description: A dispute over the agenda that appears to pit developing nations against the United States has injected a tense atmosphere into preparations for the World Trade Organization's summit meeting next month.

title: AT&T on the Electronic Highway
description: To the Editor:

title: Airbus Is Said To Win Order From Frontier
description: Frontier Airlines has decided to buy 20 new narrow-body jets from Airbus Industrie, two people close to the negotiations said, becoming the latest airline to choose the European consortium over its archrival, the Boeing Company.

title: Sports of The Times; The Rivalry That Runs One Way
description: IT would have been entirely appropriate, if completely out of character, for Bernie Williams to have taken a moment before the first pitch of the latest Yankee-Red Sox hoe-down last night by doffing his cap and saluting Jimy Williams and the entire Boston bench.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JUCOVY, MILTON E.
description: JUCOVY-Milton E., MD. On October 10, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Shirley. Devoted father of Peter, Jon and Seth. Proud grandfather of Tim, Kyra and Ethan. Loving son of the late Dr. Abraham and Sophie Jucovy and brother of the late Leonia.

title: ELTRAX TO REORGANIZE AND CONSIDER MERGERS
description: Eltrax Systems Inc., which installs networking systems for companies and governments, said yesterday that it was reorganizing into two groups and was hiring an investment banking firm to consider mergers and other options. Eltrax said it would be managed as two operating groups: a technology-services unit and a hospitality-services unit. Of about $130 million in expected 1999 revenue, $70 million will come from technology services and $60 million from hospitality, Eltrax said. The Atlanta-based company said a New York-based investment banker would evaluate options for increasing shareholder value, including a sale of assets or mergers. Before the announcement, Eltrax's shares fell 6.25 cents yesterday, to $3.50. At that price the company's stock market value is almost $80 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, MELVIN
description: KAHN-Melvin, MD. On October 13, 1999. Beloved husband of Barbro. Devoted father of Jonathan and his wife Kandis and Mark and his wife Anna. A loving grandfather of Alexander Joseph. Devoted brother of Mona Weiss. Dr. Melvin Kahn will be remembered as a man dedicated to his family and to Mount Sinai Hospital where he practiced medicine and taught for many years. We will miss him very much. Services Monday, October 18, 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st Street.

title: Encouraging Mata Haris
description: To the Editor:

title: Age Bias Case in Supreme Court Opens a New Round on Federalism
description: A Supreme Court argument in the first of the new term's federalism cases demonstrated convincingly today that the states'-rights majority on the Court had lost none of its energy over the summer recess.

title: Presidents' Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Does Modern Art Speak to Us?
description: To the Editor:

title: $130,000 Fine Rankles And Surprises Sprewell
description: Somehow, all of the artful language the Knicks have used this week to describe the punishment they doled out to Latrell Sprewell seems like a reflection off a fun-house mirror.

title: Tonight on 'E.R.,' Yoshii And Henderson Ailing
description: The Mets' dugout began to resemble an emergency room today. Left fielder Rickey Henderson left the game in the bottom of the second inning with nausea and light-headedness, a sign that the flu may be making its way through the Mets' clubhouse. Henderson looked ill before the game and pitcher Rick Reed, scheduled to start Game 4 at Shea Stadium Saturday, also had flu symptoms, Manager Bobby Valentine said.

title: Tegucigalpa Journal; In Honduras's Woeful Capital, the Bridges of Sighs
description: The bus from Boulevard Suyapa had barely pulled to a stop when Heriberto Herrera jumped off and began to work his way through a wearying and familiar maze.

title: Circling in an '87 Honda, It's the Parking Pal
description: AS the cries and curses of thousands of freshly ticketed double-parkers fill the air, victims of the city's new Operation Move Along, it might comfort them to know there is one man who not only feels their pain but has dedicated his life to combating it.

title: New Risk for Campaign Law
description: An important but little-noticed boost was given to campaign finance reform in the Senate this week. Sam Brownback of Kansas became the eighth Republican to break with his party's leadership and support the McCain-Feingold soft-money ban, scheduled for debate today. There are now 53 votes to choke off a Republican-led filibuster and pass the bill, only seven votes short of what is needed. The pressure is mounting on other Republicans to support reform. But amid these favorable developments, a move by Robert Torricelli and some other Democratic supporters of reform could undercut the cause.

title: ALLIANCE SELLS FOREST TO JOHN HANCOCK FOR $310 MILLION
description: Alliance Forest Products Inc., a Canadian forestry company, said yesterday that it had sold almost all of its timberlands in Alabama to the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company for $310 million. The sale covers about 372,000 of the 376,000 acres of land Alliance Forest owns in Alabama as well as leases it holds on another 40,000 acres in the state. Alliance, which is based in Montreal, decided in January to put the timberlands up for sale to help pay for expanding its Alabama pulp and paper output. Hancock Timber Group is the world's leading timberland investment manager with three million acres under management in North America and Australia.

title: Writer Jailed in Malaysia Is Released After Serving Four Weeks
description: Murray Hiebert finished his assignment as a foreign correspondent in Malaysia last week on a jarring note: stripped to the waist and sitting on a bare floor as a prison guard called the roll.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALL, MARGARET M.
description: BALL-Margaret M. (nee McKeogh). Entered into eternal rest on Oct. 12, 1999. Beloved wife of the late John H. Devoted mother of Mary Beth Hofstetter, Susan B. Larson, John M. Ball and Abbe J. Joseph. Loving grandmother of eight; great grandmother of six. Reposing at the Riverdale Funeral Home, Inc., 5044 Broadway at 214 St., NYC, Thursday and Friday, 2-5 & 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian burial Saturday, 10 A.M., Good Shepherd RC Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to Covenant House, 460 West 41 Street, NYC 10036.

title: What's in a Name?
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; A General Manager Has Red Sox in Blood
description: MOST baseball general managers are strangers in town. Most are hired to assemble a team for a franchise they know only from the standings. To them, one city is not that much different from any other. They sit at their office desk or in the ball park. It's their job, but no fan emotion is involved, no attachment to the franchise history. No blood, so to speak.

title: ONEX ACQUIRES CORDENA CALL FOR $51 MILLION
description: The Onex Corporation said yesterday that its Clientlogic Corporation subsidiary had acquired Cordena Call Management B.V., a European customer-contact and fulfillment company, for $51 million. Toronto-based Onex said Cordena, based in Amsterdam, had telephone and Internet customer-contact centers in Austria, England, France, Germany, Ireland, Norway and Switzerland, as well as fulfillment centers in England and the Netherlands. Cordena is expected to add $75 million to Clientlogic's annual revenue, it said. Clientlogic, based in Nashville, provides marketing services and fulfillment to technology companies.

title: CLINTON PROPOSES WIDER PROTECTION FOR U.S. FORESTS
description: President Clinton said today that he would permanently protect at least 40 million acres of Federal forest land from road building, logging and mining, using administrative actions meant to outmaneuver powerful opponents in Congress.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Profit at Apple Computer Beats Reduced Estimates

title: JOBLESSNESS HOLDS AT LOW
description: Britain's unemployment rate remained at 4.2 percent in September, a 19-year low for the second consecutive month, the Government said. The number of people claiming unemployment benefits dropped by 5,400, to 1,209,600. The Government also said wage growth increased by 4.9 percent in the quarter through August, up from 4.6 percent during the previous three months. Unemployment in Ireland also reached a record low of 5.7 percent during the second quarter, according to the Government.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBLUM, SIDNEY P.
description: ROSENBLUM-Sidney P. Beloved husband for 62 years of Sylvia Cantor. Dear father of Beth and Reuben Blumenthal, Pearl and Jerry Mann, Dr. Norman and Judith Rosenblum and Dr. Howard and Miriam Rosenblum. Brother of Birdie Silver, Jerome Rosenblum and the late Helen Winkler. Loving grandfather of twelve grandchildren and seven greatgrandchildren. He was a friend to everyone, recognized for his outgoing personality and a great sense of humor. Burial in Israel.

title: New Programs in the Works For Handspring's New Visor
description: The Visor, Handspring's new competitor to the Palm Pilot, will depend on independently developed programs and devices -- everything from MP3 players to exercise monitors -- that will fit in the Visor's expansion slot, called the Springboard. Most of the modules will not be available until early next year. However, several should be available during the holiday buying season.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: EARNINGS UP AT STEELMAKER
description: The repatriation of income from overseas units helped Gerdau, one of Brazil's largest steelmakers, to double earnings in the third quarter. Net income rose to 110 million reais, or $56 million, from 50 million reais in the second quarter. Earnings were also aided by exports, which rose 66 percent, to 286,000 tons. Gerdau did not include results from its recent purchase of the Florida-based Ameristeel Corporation.

title: The G.O.P. Torpedo
description: The Senate's decisive rejection tonight of the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty was the most explicit American repudiation of a major international agreement in 80 years, and it further weakened the already shaky standing of the United States as a global moral leader.

title: Murmurs of the Wallet At the French Show House
description: COLETTE said that you should not eat truffles unless you can eat them like potatoes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAINGER, ISAAC B.
description: GRAINGER-Isaac B. The Board and staff of ICD-International Center for the Disabled express deep regret at the passing of Isaac B. Grainger. For almost fifty years he was a devoted friend of ICD, serving with great distinction as an officer and trustee. His counsel and generosity will be missed. We extend our deepest sympathy to Isaac B. Grainger, Jr. and John V. Grainger and their families. Jeremiah M. Bogert, President Daniel B. Rosen, PhD., CEO

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Producing Fruit

title: Escaping From Web Traps
description: To the Editor:

title: Book Award Finalists Announced
description: Finalists were announced yesterday for the 50th annual National Book Awards, with the list an unusually diverse one featuring books on subjects as varied as postwar Japan and an American Indian girl on a remote island in Lake Superior.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHMELL, DAVID
description: SCHMELL-David. Died Wednesday, October 13, 1999 at age 52, peacefully after a brief illness. Beloved husband of Annette, loving father of Rachel and Joshua. Devoted son of Joseph and the late Hannah, dedicated brother to Michael and cherished son-in-law of Beatrice and Abraham Wexler. Services Thursday, October 14th, at 12:00 noon, Gramercy Chapels, 152 Second Ave., New York City.

title: State House Journal; In Massachusetts, Budget Race Is Not to the Swift
description: Massachusetts effectively claimed the budgetary booby prize for 1999 today when legislative leaders announced a long-awaited agreement that would finally let the state pass its annual financial plan -- 104 days after the fiscal year began on July 1 and dead last among all 50 states.

title: Palm Computing and Wireless Makers Form Partnership
description: The Palm Computing unit of the 3Com Corporation announced a partnership today with Symbian, a joint venture of the wireless phone makers Nokia, Motorola, Ericsson, Psion and Matsushita, forming an alliance to create a de facto standard for wireless Internet access.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE SOARS FOR THIRD DAY. Coffee prices jumped 24 percent on concern that dry, hot weather in Brazil will damage the world's biggest crop. In New York, coffee for December delivery rose 22.80 cents, to $1.1935 a pound.

title: Cleaning Up Leftovers
description: Q. Since I deleted some programs, I get the following error message every time I turn on the computer: ''Error Starting Program. A required .DLL file, WBHOOK32.DLL, was not found.'' Is there anything I can do to get rid of this message permanently?

title: Sam Cohen, Beloved Lox Slicer (Cut Thin or Thick) at Zabar's
description: Sam Cohen, who for decades occupied the No. 1 position at Zabar's salmon-slicing counter on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, becoming a star of the trade and a beloved neighborhood fixture, died Saturday of lymphoma in a hospital in Ridgewood, N.J., his daughter said. He was believed to be 86, but was orphaned as a young child so his precise age is not known.

title: A Conservative Con Ed Makes a Bold Move
description: Five years ago, when deregulation of the utility industry was just beginning in the Northeast, including New York State, Eugene R. McGrath, the chairman and chief executive of Consolidated Edison Inc. proudly showed off a large plan that covered a wall in a room at its downtown Manhattan headquarters.

title: Lawmakers Turn Back Another Attempt by Yeltsin to Dismiss His Chief Prosecutor
description: Three times now, President Boris N. Yeltsin has tried to get rid of a troublesome prosecutor general whose investigations into corruption have crept inside the Kremlin itself.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOOGAN, OWEN J.
description: MOOGAN-Owen J. On October 12, 1999. Loving husband of the late Lorraine. Loving father to Elizabeth, Teresa, Richard and Peter. Loving grandfather of Jennifer, Richard, Kathleen, Brian, Kevin and Molly. Loving brother of Patrick, Mary Jones and Eileen O'Malley. Visiting Thursday 2 to 5 and 7 to 9PM at M. J. Smith Sons, 248 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial 10:15 AM Friday, at St. Charles RC Church, Staten Island, New York.

title: Tokyo Further Clouds Issue Of What's Up With the Yen
description: The Bank of Japan moved today to expand the range of tools it could use to increase the supply of money in the economy to help weaken the resurgent yen.

title: Rhode Island Sues Makers of Lead Paint
description: The Rhode Island Attorney General sued eight paint manufacturers and a lead industry trade group in state court on Tuesday in an effort to make them pay for treating children poisoned by lead paint and removing lead paint from buildings.

title: KENNEDY-WILSON BUYS JAPANESE PROPERTY LOANS
description: Kennedy-Wilson Inc., the Los Angeles-based property management and investment company, said it had bought $250 million of nonperforming Japanese property loans for less than 10 cents on the dollar, as it continues to scour Japan for real estate bargains. The purchase brings to more than $1 billion the face amount of Japanese loans Kennedy-Wilson has bought in the last 12 months. Japanese banks are writing off delinquent loans provided to real estate buyers in the late 1980's.

title: Programs That Can Redecorate Your Computer Screen
description: LOOK into the reflection on your darkened computer monitor -- the face staring back could be lifted, tweaked, tightened, uncreased or flat-out overhauled, with the help (and high cost) of cosmetic surgery.

title: Apple Posts Quarter Results That Exceed Predictions
description: After warning last month of an earnings shortfall, Apple Computer Inc. today reported results for its fourth quarter that exceeded Wall Street analysts' revised estimates. Apple executives also predicted strong sales for the December quarter.

title: For Bidders, Jets' Value Is in Eye of the Beholder
description: The New York Jets, who play in the nation's largest market, lost money in 1997 and have produced modest returns by National Football League standards over the last two years, a prospectus written for the team's sale shows.

title: Nassau Legislators Wrest Financial Control From County Executive
description: Acting forcefully to prevent future budget deficits like the $300 million one that has embarrassed Nassau County this year, county lawmakers today voted unanimously to seize much of the control over Nassau's financial affairs from the county executive, Thomas S. Gulotta.

title: De Niro Group Replaced as Developers in Brooklyn
description: Five months after it was announced with great fanfare, a tentative deal calling for the actor Robert De Niro and Miramax Films to develop a $150-million Hollywood-style sound stage complex at the Brooklyn Navy Yard has collapsed, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, MARILYN NEE SPELLUN
description: FISHER-Marilyn nee Spellun. On October 12, 1999 at age 72 in Tucson, Arizona. Beloved mother of Marcea Wolf-Carter & sister of Arnold Spellun. Her spirit, exuberance and joy in life will continue to inspire her family & friends. Shiva will be at 320 W. 80th Street, NYC after 2PM on Sunday, October 17. A memorial service will be held at Stephen Wise Free Synagogue, 30 West 68th Street, NYC at 1 PM, Sunday, October 24. In lieu of flowers contributions in her memory can be made to the Gynecologic Cancer Foundation, P.O. Box 809301, Chicago, IL. 60680.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHEELOCK, ELIZABETH T.
description: WHEELOCK-Elizabeth T., died October 12 at her home in New Canaan, Conn. Widow of Morgan Dix Wheelock, she was also predeceased by her first husband, J. Foster Bowers, and second husband, J. Paul Stabler, both of whom died of cancer. She is survived by two daughters, Beverly Bowers Jennings and May Bowers Morris; four grandchildren, Justine Gregg Barkstrom, Kimberly A. Jennings, Cary L. Jennings and Dr. David Gregg IV. Also a stepdaughter, Eileen S. Buckley; two step-grandchildren, Linda and Mark Buckley; one great-grandson, Jackson W. Barkstrom; and one brother, Major General Charles S. Thompson. A memorial service will be held at 11 AM Friday, October 15, 1999 at St. Mark's Episcopal Church, New Canaan. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital, East 68th St., New York, NY 10021 or to St. Mark's Episcopal Church, Oenoke Ridge, New Canaan, CT. 06840.

title: Isaac B. (Ike) Grainger, 104, An Expert on Golf's Rules
description: Isaac B. (Ike) Grainger, former president of the United States Golf Association who was one of the country's leading authorities on the rules of golf, died on Tuesday at his home in Wilmington. He was 104.

title: Prosecutor Clears Babbitt in Casino Inquiry
description: Ending an investigation that had haunted Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt for 19 months, an independent counsel announced today that she had uncovered insufficient evidence to warrant charges against Mr. Babbitt or anyone else in his agency's handling of an Indian gambling project.

title: He Slept, She Slept
description: She's hot, he's not. He's hot, she's not. Couples should not let warring bedcovers drive them to a marriage counselor.

title: South Asia Paradox
description: To the Editor:

title: Real Bugs On Your PC Screen
description: IT is hardly news when a computer product is released with bugs in it, but it is rare indeed when the bugs are the cause of so much delight. The bugs -- in this case a fruit fly and a plant louse, both long deceased -- come in the box with the new Intel Play QXE Computer Microscope, along with an assortment of other tiny, slide-mounted specimens, including algae, plant spores, a hair of the dog and even the bee's knees.

title: Another Way to Get on Line Without Buying a Computer
description: Trying to get on the Internet without using a computer seems to be the current Holy Grail. The latest device to join the parade is the I-Opener from Netpliance.

title: Insurer to Pay W. R. Grace $3.7 Million for Disputed Payouts
description: W. R. Grace & Company said yesterday that it would recover $3.7 million from an insurance company for excess payments and benefits that were paid to two former chief executives, who themselves disagreed over the disclosure of such payments.

title: STATOIL GROUP SEEKS BUYER FOR ITS U.S. GAS UNIT
description: Statoil Group of Norway said yesterday that it was seeking a buyer for Statoil Energy, which produces and markets natural gas and electricity in the United States. Statoil Group said Statoil Energy needed to increase the scale of its operations substantially to operate effectively, but the company did not have the resources. Statoil Group added that with capital limited, it planned to focus its energy-marketing efforts in the Nordic region and its downstream natural gas operations in Northern Europe. Statoil Group said it had hired Credit Suisse First Boston to advise the company on the divestiture.

title: G.M. Meets With Dealers
description: The General Motors Corporation said today in a joint statement with the National Automobile Dealers Association that it would move cautiously on its plans to develop a new unit that would acquire United States dealerships and said it wanted to include independent dealers as partners in franchises it acquires. The statement was released by G.M. after a meeting between its chairman, John F. Smith Jr., and the chairman of the dealer association, James Willingham, and several other top association officials.

title: Indoors or Out, Built for the Rough and Ready
description: Spencer Fung, a London architect, has given something new to outdoor furniture: stark, bold pieces that with proper care (sanding the surface and refinishing it with tung oil twice a year) can survive many Northeast winters. Pucci International is introducing Mr. Fung's 22-piece line, which also includes indoor furniture, on Monday at its Chelsea showroom. ''The collection is called Block,'' he said, ''because I like using elemental forms and volume.'' The Java Long Seat (above, $2,400), for outdoors, is English oak on a steel base. It is 46 inches long by 16 inches deep, with a seat 16 inches high. For indoors, the Moon Table comes in oak (below, $7,100), Zebrano and wenge. It is 48 inches in diameter and 30 inches high. Pucci, 44 West 18th Street, is open by appointment; (212) 633-0452.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DERUPO, MARIO A.
description: DeRUPO-Mario A., on October 12, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Calogera (Lillie). Cherished father of Josephine Loizzo, Frank DeRupo and Anna Hugaboom. Loving father-in-law of Bernard Loizzo, Margaret DeRupo and William Hugaboom. Loving grandfather of Jennifer Loizzo, Matthew, Lauren and the late Michael DeRupo and Linda, Christine and Thomas Hugaboom. Friends may call on Thursday 7-9:30PM and Friday 2-5 and 7-9:30PM at the Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home, 125 Hillside Avenue, New Hyde Park, NY (at city line). Mass of Christian Burial Saturday 9:45AM, Our Lady of the Snows R.C. Church. Entombment St. John's Cemetery.

title: Indonesian President Asks Top General to Be His Running Mate
description: In an attempt to strengthen his hand with the politically powerful military, President B. J. Habibie today selected Indonesia's military chief, Gen. Wiranto, as his vice presidential running mate in an electoral assembly that is due to vote in a week.

title: Another Tight Spot, but Rocker Gets Job Done
description: John Rocker is a man of habit. And during the post-season, he has made a habit of getting batters out.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGUIRE, MARY MECHTILDE
description: McGUIRE-Mary Mechtilde, long time resident of Bay Ridge and retired Supervisor for Pfizer Corp. died on October 13, 1999. Daughter of the late John V. McGuire and Annie McGuire Welsh. She was a charming and dignified lady who sacrificed greatly for many years to assure the health and well-being of her invalid mother. Loving sister of Rev. John V. McGuire CssR of Saratoga Springs, Edward of Brooklyn, Thomas of Merrick, NY, Loretta Deken of St. Louis, MO and the late Maurice, Joseph and Teresa Kaldheim. She is survived by her loving brother-in-law Neil and sisters-in-law Ellen, Peggy, Katherine and Mary. She is also survived by many loving nieces, nephews, grand-nieces and grandnephews. Reposing at McLaughlin Funeral Home, Third Avenue at 97th Street, Friday 2-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Saturday 11:45AM at St. Anselms Church.

title: Congress Expands Choices on Punishing Pakistan
description: Congress moved today to give President Clinton greater flexibility in deciding whether to impose sanctions against the Pakistani military a day after the overthrow of the elected government there.

title: 'Knowledge' Factories
description: To the Editor:

title: Escaping From Web Traps
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about a motor home abandoned along a roadway in Manhattan referred incorrectly to the location near West 108th Street. It was on the Henry Hudson Parkway; the Joe DiMaggio Highway runs only from the Battery to West 72d Street.

title: Metaphysical Wrestling, With No Holds Barred
description: The questions are as old as civilization, but for two heated hours it is as though they were being asked for the first time. What if life is only the shadow rather than the substance of reality? Why are people allowed to suffer so? How much does anyone control individual destiny?

title: Council Passes Bill Requiring Use of Trigger Locks on Guns
description: The City Council voted yesterday to approve legislation requiring all gun owners to use safety devices designed to prevent accidental shootings by locking a weapon's trigger.

title: Trump Sets Record Of $100-a-Foot Rent
description: The General Motors Building has rented space for more than $100 a square foot, said Donald Trump, the building's co-owner. Mr. Trump called the rent the highest amount ever paid for office space in Manhattan.

title: Sports of The Times; Smoltz Discovers the Rush Reserved for Relievers
description: THREE HUNDRED and eighty times John Smoltz had entered a major league game, but always with the measured pace of a starting pitcher who cannot get too rambunctious too soon.

title: Safety Fears Will Discourage Cell Phone Use at Gas Pumps
description: By early next year, decals and signs declaring the potential fire hazard caused by using a cell phone while pumping gas will be affixed to gasoline pumps across the United States.

title: They Fell Hook, Line and Sinker
description: A JERK ON ONE END

title: Laxity on Taxes: Only the Rich Gain
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OATES, JAMES J.
description: OATES-James J. On October 12, 1999. Born June 27, 1935. Survived by his wife, Alice; his daughters Debra Rolland and Darlene Lelle; sons Wayne, James, Timothy and Kevin Oates; grandchildren Adrienne, Jason and Justin Lelle; brother Thomas and wife Ozell Oates; sisters Teresa McCue and Catherine Connelly. He retired from The New York Times in June, 1967 after working sixteen years as a Dispatcher in the Messenger Department. Reposing at Clayton's Funeral Home, 25 Meadow Road, Kings Park, New York, Saturday, 7-9 PM, Sunday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass Monday, 9:30 AM, St. Joseph's RC Church, Farmingdale. Interment St. Charles Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Hospice St. John, 1007 Oak St., Pittston, PA 18640 would be appreciated.

title: Sites to Help Professional Workers Who Like to Go It Alone
description: FREE agents. Freelancers. Solopreneurs. Whatever they are called, people working for themselves in American businesses form a large part of the labor force. The Department of Labor estimates that 7.5 million people, or roughly 1 in every 16 workers, are self-employed independent contractors, hired by companies on a contract basis, often for a short term.

title: Ready for Justice
description: Returning home after a year's absence, I am astonished at the change. On the eve of the anniversary of the arrest last Oct. 16 of Augusto Pinochet, Chilean democracy has weathered the storm.

title: A Few Doubts On Tyco Send Shares Reeling In Edgy Market
description: In the latest sign of skittishness on Wall Street, criticisms from a single investment manager sent shares of one of the decade's best-performing stocks, Tyco International, plunging yesterday, causing the New York Stock Exchange to halt its trading.

title: Savoring Words, Plain and Fancy
description: AS a recent meeting broke up at Kaufman Patricof Enterprises in New York, a company that designs Web sites and Internet advertising, the five co-workers at the session discovered that in addition to their corporate identification cards, they had another thing in common. They are all fans of word-a-day Web sites and E-mail newsletters for word-ophiles.

title: Justices Fault Pace of Preschool Program
description: State Supreme Court justices criticized State Education Department officials today over their slow pace in putting into effect a court order to provide preschool for 3- and 4-year-olds in the state's 30 poorest districts.

title: SALE OF PAPER UNIT
description: A European private investment fund, Apax Partners & Company, said that it had acquired the Paper Technology Group, a unit of Invensys P.L.C. the largest manufacturer of factory automation equipment in the world, for $810 million. The paper unit was formed in February from the merger of BTR P.L.C. and Siebe P.L.C. This is the second time that Apax has bid for the paper concern; it rescinded its original $1.2 billion bid in September after reviewing the company's finances.

title: Disputed Holocaust Memoir Withdrawn
description: For more than a year the publishers of a slender 155-page memoir of a young Latvian Jewish orphan's early life of struggle in two concentration camps stood firm against accusations that the memories of terror were nothing more than vivid fantasies.

title: AT&T on the Electronic Highway
description: To the Editor:

title: It's Graham for Collins, but for How Long?
description: Kent Graham is back at quarterback, the Kerry Collins era in recess. That is the new pecking order at Giants Stadium, good for at least the first half of Monday night's game with the Dallas Cowboys.

title: A New Embassy Design Reflects a Cautious World View
description: ONE side of the new American Embassy here engages the town. A wall of warm limestone, generously perforated with windows, stands across the street from old stone warehouses converted into a market of upscale shops selling antiques, books and designer fashions.

title: I.B.M.'s Palette of Colors Shows a Big Expansion
description: It has been a long time since I.B.M. stopped requiring employees to wear dark suits and white shirts, but it is still something of a shock to see Big Blue producing computers in hues that include Mars red metallic, terra green metallic, eclipse blue metallic, lunar gray metallic, Sirius red, Andromeda green and Polaris blue.

title: Williams Returns, No Racquet
description: A buoyant Serena Williams ventured back to New York yesterday for the first time since she captured her first Grand Slam title, and became the first black woman since Althea Gibson to win a Grand Slam, at the United States Open last month. In a generous mood, Williams praised Gibson, as well as her older sister Venus for paving her way toward tennis posterity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOVE, ROBERT A.
description: LOVE-Robert A., M.D., Center Moriches, formerly of Bellport, New York. Born in Brooklyn, NY, October 4, 1913. Died October 13, 1999. Son of Dr. C.R. Love and Grace Anderson Smith. B.A., Brown University, 1937. M.D., Cornell University Medical School. Rotating Intern, King's County Hospital, 1942-43. Resident Intern, King's County Hospital, 1946-49, Internal Medicine. Head of Industrial Medicine, Brookhaven National Laboratory, 1947-1978. Associate Professor, State University New York at Stony Brook, 1968-1976. Fellow, American Occupational Medical Association. ''Who's Who in the East,'' 1977-1978. Member, NY Suffolk County Medical Society. Dr. Love is noted for his extensive work in radiation and decontamination research. He served in the U.S. Navy aboard the U.S. destroyer John Paul Jones, 1943-1946. Captain, United States Naval Reserve, Ret. Predeceased by his first wife, Elinor O'Donahue, sisters Grace Blust, Harriet Smith, Margaretta Marshall and brothers C. Ruxton, Richard, and Hamilton Love. He is survived by his wife Josephine O'Connell Love, son Robert Love of Cutchogue, NY, daughters Linda Love Reil of PA, Pamela Love McChesney of CT., grandsons Robert and Christopher Love, granddaughter Amanda Reil, three great grandchildren, many nieces and nephews and his brother Freeman D. Love. Visitation will be today, Thursday, 2-4 and 7-9 at Sinnicksons Moriches Funeral Home, 203 Main Street (County Road 80), Center Moriches. Mass of Christian Burial, 10AM Friday, October 15, at Mary Immaculate R.C. Church, Browns Avenue, Bellport. Interment to follow Calverton National Cemetery.

title: The Man Who Knew It Wasn't Only Rock 'n' Roll
description: Ask anyone under 30 about Alan Freed, and the response is probably a blank stare. After all, the legendary disc jockey died in obscurity and poverty in 1965 after a tumultuous career in which he introduced ''rock 'n' roll'' to the world and broke racial barriers.

title: Just Sit Back and Enjoy the Show at Shortstop
description: Nomar leaped to steal a hit from the Yankees, then Derek leaped to swipe one back from the Red Sox, so Nomar leaped even higher to pilfer another. Derek made a sweet play in the shortstop hole, but then bounced the throw to second base for an error. Then Nomar made an even sweeter play in shallow left field, but unintentionally mimicked Derek by bouncing his throw to second.

title: INSIDE
description: Babbitt Will Not Be Charged

title: 18-Year-Old Is Wounded In Subway Stabbing
description: A teen-ager was stabbed in the 72d Street subway station on the Upper West Side yesterday afternoon, the police said.

title: Pakistan Calm After Coup; Leading General Gives No Clue About How He Will Rule
description: A day after Pakistan's armed forces seized power and dismissed the elected Government of Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, the people of Pakistan waited expectantly today to find out who will rule them.

title: Swiss Expand Inquiry on Russian Money Flow
description: The police in Switzerland have said investigations into possible money laundering and crimes by Russian executives and politicians have expanded to include Lev Cherny, a Russian emigre businessman with extensive interests in the metals industry.

title: Incognito Spinmeisters Battle On-Line Critics
description: THE scene unfolds on the Internet every day: a pack of outraged consumers takes over the discussion in an on-line forum with heated criticism of some offending product, perhaps a brand of stereo speakers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIN, NATALIE
description: LEWIN-Natalie. In honor of our grandmother Natalie, beloved wife of the late Milton Lewin and loving sister of the late Lewis Steinman. We want to send our deepest love and affection to our aunt Joan Steinman, and to all of our Steinman, Rudin and Lowe cousins, whose support and love enabled our family to deal with the sudden illness and loss of our grandmother. Jason, Becky, Sarah, Sean and Collette

title: Frank Frost, 63, Who Played Delta Blues
description: Frank Frost, one of the foremost Delta blues harmonica players of his generation, died on Tuesday at his home on the street named in his honor in Helena, Ark. He was 63.

title: From Desert Sands, a Campus
description: New Cairo, 20 miles east of Cairo, is pure desert, a city in name only. But by 2008, the overcrowded American University of Cairo -- whose graduates include Suzanne Mubarak, the wife of the Egyptian President, and Queen Rania of Jordan -- is to move to a two-million-square-foot campus on 260 acres in the now-barren suburb. Construction, costing $200 million, will start in 2001. ''We have designed this whole complex around the void,'' said Mozhan Khadem, the president of the Boston Design Collaborative, which is designing the campus with Carol R. Johnson Associates, landscape architects. Both are in Cambridge, Mass. ''Every building has an interior courtyard,'' Mr. Khadem said, and there will be reflecting pools and date palms. In Islamic architecture, he explained, ''the void becomes more important than the solid.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FANNING, CHARLES J.
description: FANNING-Charles J. The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York records with profound sorrow the death of Charles J. Fanning, a Life Member of the Society, and extends sincere sympathy to his family. William J. Cronin, President Robert J. Reilly, Historian

title: Canadian-Born Columbia University Economist Wins Nobel Award
description: Robert A. Mundell of Columbia University, an eccentric Canadian-born economist whose influence was felt from the supply-side economics of the Reagan years to the creation of the euro, was awarded the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science yesterday.

title: Hospital Official Admits Defrauding Employer
description: A former finance director at Meadowlands Hospital Medical Center in Secaucus admitted yesterday that he cheated the hospital out of $497,000 in payments he made to fictitious companies for services that were never performed.

title: Racial Discrepancy Is Reported in Surgery for Lung Cancer
description: Black patients with early stage lung cancer are less likely than whites to undergo life-saving surgery and as a result are more likely to die of their disease, doctors are reporting today.

title: SHRINKING SURPLUSES
description: China's trade surplus narrowed more than economists expected in September, as a surge in imports offset more shipments to rebounding Asian economies. The surplus totaled $3.3 billion in the month, down from the 22-month high of $4.88 billion reached in August, according to a report in The Beijing Evening News. Exports surged 20.2 percent from a year earlier to $18.6 billion, the biggest gain since February 1998. Imports rose even faster, surging 32.5 percent in September from a year ago, to $15.3 billion. In Japan, the current-account surplus shrank in August from July, in its second consecutive decline, as imports rose at more than three times the rate of exports. The surplus fell 6.4 percent to 1.1 trillion yen ($10 billion) seasonally adjusted, the Ministry of Finance said. From a year ago, the surplus fell 32.7 percent, unadjusted.

title: A Rockefeller Fixer-Upper
description: SIXTY-FIVE years ago, a brash young millionaire named Nelson Aldrich Rockefeller bought the top floor of 810 Fifth Avenue, at the corner of 62d Street, then the southernmost apartment house on upper Fifth Avenue. With its commanding views of Central Park, it seemed like the perfect place for Mr. Rockefeller, then 26, and his bride, Mary Todhunter Clark, to raise a large family.

title: Rejecting Science
description: To the Editor:

title: Construction Workers Injured By Falling Pulley in TriBeCa
description: Two construction workers refurbishing a TriBeCa building were seriously injured yesterday when a cable they were securing snapped, dropping a pulley on top of them, city officials said.

title: Pataki to Order Emissions Cuts For Power Sites
description: Gov. George E. Pataki will order power plants in New York State to make sharp cuts in the smokestack emissions that cause acid rain and smog, his aides said yesterday.

title: Let the Truth Be Known
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: An exhibit by a club that encourages creativity pays homage to a single company: Volkswagen.
description: VOLKSWAGEN may have once implored consumers to ''Think small,'' but now a prestigious advertising organization is thinking big about the auto maker's campaigns.

title: When an S.E.C. Inquiry Is an Executive's Fondest Desire
description: THE subpoenas arrived this week, and the president of the company being investigated by the Securities and Exchange Commission sounded downright exultant.

title: GERMAN CABLE BIDDERS
description: Europe's biggest phone company, Deutsche Telekom A.G., said it had drawn up a short list of possible buyers for its cable television network from the 23 original bidders and will begin negotiations in November. Mannesmann A.G. and Viag A.G., two of Telekom's competitors in the domestic phone market, confirmed that Telekom had rejected their bids. Bonn-based Deutsche Telekom will continue to talk with nine groups of bidders, mainly foreign companies, the daily newspaper Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung reported, citing banking sources.

title: A $1.6 BILLION DEAL FOR DSP COMMUNICATIONS
description: The Intel Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire DSP Communications Inc. for $1.6 billion in the largest high-technology deal in Israel's history. DSP specializes in Internet technology for cellular telephones. Though it is based in Cupertino, Calif., and its stock is traded on the New York Stock Exchange, DSP is controlled by its founder, Davidi Gilo of Tel Aviv, who will earn a reported $142 million from the sale. Some 250 of DSP's 300 employees work in Israel, according to Globes, Israel's leading financial daily. DSP shares jumped $6.9375, or 25 percent, to $34.9375. Intel shares gained $1.22, to $73.34, in Nasdaq trading.

title: WEEKEND WARRIOR; Fun With Feet: Soccer Players Looking for a Good Game
description: My introduction to soccer came when I was 8 and my family moved to Oxford for two years. Homesick for America, my brother and I would head to a local field with our baseball gloves only to find it consistently occupied by kids kicking around a volleyball. Or at least that's what it looked like to me.

title: Should Pain Be Part of Childbirth?
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: When Being Wrong Won't Hurt; Economists' Ideas Are Valued More Than Their Forecasts
description: If the forecasts of Wall Street economists are often so wrong, how do they keep their jobs? How do they make any money?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, HERBERT H.
description: DAVIS-Herbert H. On October 14, 1999. Beloved husband of Justine Davis and the late Sylvia Davis. Dear father of Arthur R. (Susan), Richard J. (Nan) Davis, Joe Clapper and Greg Clapper. Adored grandfather of Jules, Scott, Annie, Robert, Hans & great-grandfather of Jesse. Services today October 15, 10:45AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Don't These Yankees Ever Lose? Not Quite Yet
description: Don Zimmer was speaking into his right ear, Mel Stottlemyre into his left ear, and Yankees Manager Joe Torre said his mind was spinning through the tense eighth and ninth innings, his team's one-run lead in constant jeopardy, the game hinging on his every decision.

title: Public Interests; Taking Finance 101
description: I'm beginning to take an interest in the Congressional budget debate. After all, I live in a state that has not passed an appropriations bill on time since the Erie Canal was built. I have considerable expertise in legislatures that cannot repair a collapsed bridge without throwing in extra money for a football stadium or Recreational Vehicle Theme Park. So when the federal government started a new fiscal year sans budget, I felt at home. As a public service, I've prepared a cheat sheet on what's going on.

title: Corrections
description: An editorial yesterday on campaign finance reform misidentified Senator Peter Fitzgerald's home state. He is from Illinois.

title: Larger-Than-Life Czar of West 57th Street
description: WE could go on for a while about the new and fabulous Russian Tea Room, but you probably feel if you have to read another word about the 15-foot aquarium in the shape of a dancing bear you will jump in and drown. So having the owner, Warner Le Roy, more or less in front of us -- that's him, in the red-and-black houndstooth jacket, at his troublesome peak weight of 270, going over to see what The Daily News's co-publisher, Mortimer B. Zuckerman, is having for lunch -- let us confront him, if he ever sits down again, about those stories of his on-again-off-again divorce.

title: 3M TO BUY HOECHST'S STAKE IN DYNEON JOINT VENTURE
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, which makes thousands of consumer products, including Scotch brand tape, said yesterday that it would buy the stake held by Hoechst A.G. in their joint venture fluoropolymer business, Dyneon. Hoechst, Germany's largest drug maker, owns a 46 percent stake in Dyneon and said it expected the sale would generate proceeds of $300 million for its Celanese A.G. unit, which is being spun off to shareholders this month. Dyneon has more than 700 employees at five sites in the United States, Germany and Belgium. In 1998, it had sales of $350 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHEPS, DONALD
description: SCHEPS-Donald. The Board of Governors and membership of Edgewood Country Club record with deep sorrow the death of Mr. Donald Scheps, an esteemed member and extend to his beloved wife, Millie and family its deepest sympathy. Arthur I. Frankel, President Saul Friedland, Secretary

title: Red Sox Head to Boston Seeking Some Answers
description: Butch Huskey stood in the on-deck circle last night, waving the bat like a toothpick after the Yankees walked the light-hitting Lou Merloni to fill the bases and get to him. It was an interesting decision by Manager Joe Torre, who was hoping that Ramiro Mendoza could induce a double-play grounder to end the eighth inning. All Huskey wanted to do was smack a fly ball to tie the score.

title: Officials Suspend Traffic-Blocking Inspections
description: Acting on a request from Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, officials from Union County and Elizabeth called a temporary halt today to the traffic-clogging truck inspections they had begun this week near Newark Airport and Port Elizabeth to draw attention to their land dispute with the Port Authority.

title: Collier Schorr
description: 303 Gallery

title: Saatchi & Saatchi Gets PUR Account
description: The Procter & Gamble Company in Cincinnati said yesterday that it had expanded its relationship with Saatchi & Saatchi in New York, part of Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C., by naming the agency to handle the account of the PUR line of drinking-water filters. Billings have not been determined.

title: Doctor Defends Heroin Detoxification Procedure and Vows to Resume It
description: A New Jersey doctor who specializes in a heroin detoxification treatment that state officials have linked to six deaths since 1995 defended the procedure today as medically sound and said he hoped to resume performing it in local hospitals as soon as possible.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL FALLS. Crude oil prices fell as traders sold contracts that had surged 10 percent amid shrinking inventories. In New York, crude oil for November delivery fell 61 cents, or 2.6 percent, to $22.45 a barrel.

title: Marvin Wood Is Dead at 71; Coach of the 'Hoosiers' Team
description: Marvin Wood, who coached a tiny high school's basketball team to the Indiana state championship, portrayed in the 1986 movie ''Hoosiers,'' died on Wednesday in South Bend., Ind. He was 71.

title: Treaty Ricochets Into Presidential Fray
description: Immediately after the Senate rejected the treaty banning all underground nuclear testing on Wednesday night, Vice President Al Gore, personally -- and furiously -- dashed off the first television commercial of his Presidential campaign.

title: INSIDE ART
description: Serious About Cezanne

title: Soccer Fan, But an Unfit Team Player
description: Paul Ashworth, a mild-mannered English teacher in London, loves a good soccer game. ''You see all those thousands of faces contorted with fear and hope,'' he explains to his new girlfriend, Sarah Hughes. ''Just for those few minutes you're at the center of the whole world. And the fact that you care so much, the noise you've made has been such a crucial part of it, is what makes it special.'' Not only that, but ''the great thing is that it comes around again and again and again.''

title: Rocker Makes Nice With The Mets
description: A few of the Atlanta Braves players were already scattered around the field at Shea Stadium for last night's workout when one player rushed out of the tunnel and onto the field. The jersey was familiar, the number 49 on the back with Rocker emblazoned above the number. But the Fu Manchu on the face did not match.

title: Ghosts of Detroit's Past In Ford's Old Buildings
description: HENRY FORD was so intent on preserving pieces of the nation's past that he had dozens of buildings shipped here to Greenfield Village, a historical park where visitors can wander through Thomas Edison's laboratory and the Wright Brothers' bicycle shop. Yet as Ford's greatest legacy, the Ford Motor Company, looks to its centennial in 2003, several of the most important buildings from its past have disappeared or are in disrepair.

title: Advise and Consent? Not This Time
description: On Wednesday, I did something I have never done before in my 41 years in the Senate. Instead of voting yes or no on the issue at hand, I voted simply ''present.''

title: Not the Greatest Family to Grow Up In
description: In its stronger moments, Frank Whaley's sincere but wobbly first film, ''Joe the King,'' conveys the panic, embarrassment and sinking despair of growing up in a poor, strife-torn household in upstate New York. This dour little movie, set in the 1970's at the height of the roller disco craze, is especially good at capturing the mixture of shame and longing that its adolescent protagonist, Joe Henry (Noah Fleiss), feels toward his embattled parents, Bob (Val Kilmer) and Theresa (Karen Young).

title: Well, One Person in the House Thinks He's Lucky
description: Ever tried to sit still while an acquaintance recounts the minute details of a dull dream? For the teller, the weird interior logic of the fantasy is a source of endless fascination. For the listener, it can test the limits of friendship.

title: From Ravaged Villages, Forlorn Mexicans Trek for Help
description: They walked 16 hours through fog and drizzle, but when the Indian men in mud-spattered sandals arrived safely at this mountain town in search of food for their devastated hamlet, they broke into a murmured chant, thanking the Virgin for small blessings amid vast misfortune.

title: Politics and a Treaty's Demise; Who's at Fault?
description: To the Editor:

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: STOCK OFFERING TRIMMED
description: China's largest offshore oil producer, CNOOC Ltd., cut the size of its planned $2.5 billion share sale by more than half because of weak demand from investors, banks arranging the sale said. The initial public offering is now likely to raise about $1 billion after the company reduces the stake for sale to 13.88 percent from 25 percent. Falling Asian share prices and a flood of similar sales prompted the decision, said Salomon Smith Barney Inc., which is arranging the sale with BOC International Ltd., a Bank of China unit.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Go to class as much as possible. Yes, you're going to be tired. If the professor sees you every day, then if you have to leave early to catch a bus, or miss class, they might understand.''

title: Educating Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Lott's View: 'It Was Not About Politics, It Was About the Substance'
description: Following are excerpts from a news conference today by Senator Trent Lott, Republican of Mississippi, discussing the defeat of the test ban treaty, as provided by the Federal News Service:

title: LIPA Delivers Ultimatum On Shoreham
description: Delivering an ultimatum in his long battle with Suffolk County, the chairman of the Long Island Power Authority, Richard M. Kessel, said today that county officials must agree by Monday to a $625 million settlement for past overassessment of the Shoreham nuclear power plant or share in paying the full $1.3 billion he said the authority was owed.

title: Steve Wheeler
description: Richard York Gallery

title: CANADIAN AUTO PACT THREATENED
description: The World Trade Organization has ruled in an interim decision that a Canadian law permitting the Ford Motor Company, the General Motors Corporation and DaimlerChrysler to import vehicles into Canada without paying duty violates fair trade practices. Japan and the European Union had challenged the 1956 law because Canada imposes a 6.5 percent import duty on other car makers. The final ruling is due on Nov. 25, but it can be appealed.

title: The Senate's Harmful Vote
description: President Clinton's forceful and focused performance at yesterday's news conference must mark the beginning of a sustained White House effort to limit the damage inflicted by the Senate's reckless vote Wednesday against the nuclear test ban treaty. It will be up to Mr. Clinton to convince other nations, including those that have already signed the treaty, like Russia and China, and those that have not, like India, Pakistan and North Korea, that the United States remains committed to observing its provisions and eventually ratifying it in a new Senate vote. In these and other ways, his Administration must demonstrate America's continued determination to reduce nuclear dangers throughout the world. The Senate should want to send exactly the same message. Unfortunately, it did not.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGUIRE, MARY MECHTILDE
description: McGUIRE-Mary Mechtilde, long time resident of Bay Ridge and retired Supervisor for Pfizer Corp. died on October 13, 1999. Daughter of the late John V. McGuire and Annie McGuire Welsh. She was a charming and dignified lady who sacrificed greatly for many years to assure the health and well-being of her invalid mother. Loving sister of Rev. John V. McGuire CssR of Saratoga Springs, Edward of Brooklyn, Thomas of Merrick, NY, Loretta Deken of St. Louis, MO and the late Maurice, Joseph and Teresa Kaldheim. She is survived by her loving brother-in-law Neil and sisters-in-law Ellen, Peggy, Katherine and Mary. She is also survived by many loving nieces, nephews, grand-nieces and grandnephews. Reposing at McLaughlin Funeral Home, Third Avenue at 97th Street, Friday 2-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Saturday 11:45AM at St. Anselms Church.

title: From the Political to the Personal: A Pan-American Feast
description: The recent blast of popular enthusiasm for Latino music and culture has yet to find serious resonance in the mainstream New York art world. People of Hispanic descent now make up nearly 30 percent of the city's population, but most of its high-profile museums seem to have slept through that development, and only a handful of galleries regularly show Latino artists.

title: Politics and a Treaty's Demise
