description: To the Editor:

title: Jets Add Atwater To Lengthy Injury List
description: It isn't bad enough that the Jets, struggling with a 1-4 record, have to face the Indianapolis Colts (2-2), their bright young quarterback (Peyton Manning) and their dangerous receiver (Marvin Harrison) on Sunday at Giants Stadium. Now the Jets may have to do it without Steve Atwater, their wise-old free safety.

title: For Babbitt, a Wearying Exoneration
description: By the standards of some recent independent counsel investigations, the 19-month inquiry of Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt was relatively quick, leak-free and legally painless -- ending as it did with the prosecutor's announcement on Wednesday that no charges would be brought against Mr. Babbitt or anyone else.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIN, NATALIE
description: LEWIN-Natalie. Jack and Lewis Rudin and their family members are deeply saddened by the loss of their dear cousin Natalie Lewin. Our thoughts and prayers are with Johnny, Margie, Steven, Claire and their children during this difficult time.

title: Jenny Saville
description: Gagosian Gallery

title: Life 101: Useful Skills for College and Beyond
description: These are the lessons from today's class at Southampton College:

title: HYUNDAI ELECTRONICS SPINOFF
description: Hyundai Electronics Industries Ltd. of South Korea said it was in talks with foreign investors about an injection of $700 million to $1 billion into its nonsemiconductor operations. The businesses, which include the thin film transistor liquid crystal display operations, will be spun off from Hyundai Electronics by early next year. Hyundai Electronics, a unit of Hyundai Motor, said it would expand its nondynamic random access memory business, with its contribution to total sales increasing to 18 percent by 2001 from the current 7 or 8 percent.

title: Dancing Fools in the Kingdom of Disco
description: Imitation may be the sincerest form of flattery, but second-hand goods usually lack luster.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KERMELIS KNAUST, CHRISTIAN GEORGE
description: KERMELIS KNAUST-Christian George. Athlete and student from Rye, New York died unexpectedly on Saturday, October 9th at the New York United Hospital Medical Center in Port Chester, New York. He was 25 years old. He will be immensely missed by family members and countless dear friends. Memorial wake will be held on Saturday, October 16, 1999, from 7:00 to 10:00 P.M., at Coxe and Graziano, 767 Boston Post Road, Mamaroneck, NY 10543, tel. 914-698-5968. Funeral services are Sunday, October 17, 1999, 2:00PM at Rye Presbyterian Church, Boston Post Rd., Rye, N.Y. 10580, tel. 914-967-0842. Burial will be held in private. A tax exempt status is being applied for a foundation name: ''The Christian Kermelis Knaust Scholarship Foundation.'' The family would appreciate contributions made to ''The Christian Kermelis Knaust Scholarship Foundation,'' to benefit college athletes in financial need. Contributions can be forwarded in care of Christian Knaust, 115 Central Park West, Apt 28EF, New York, N.Y. 10023.

title: Klan Group Will Sue City In Denial of March Permit
description: A Ku Klux Klan group plans to sue the Giuliani administration after being denied a permit to hold a ''white pride'' rally in New York City, leaders of the white supremacist group said yesterday.

title: Politics and a Treaty's Demise; True Believers
description: To the Editor:

title: Even in Defeat, Clinton Finds a Political Advantage
description: The Senate proved Wednesday night with its rejection of the nuclear test ban treaty that it can stop one of President Clinton's policy initiatives in its tracks. But Mr. Clinton proved this afternoon that he still knows how to wield his office as a powerful political weapon.

title: John Thompson Hired as Analyst
description: John Thompson, the former Georgetown basketball coach and Boston Celtics backup center, is joining Turner Sports as a National Basketball Association analyst.

title: Corruption Allegations Investigated
description: Members of a Congressional investigating subcommittee subjected representatives of the Olympics to sharp questioning today over allegations of corruption in Atlanta's and other cities' applications to have the games awarded to them.

title: N.F.L. MATCHUPS WEEK 6
description: GAME OF THE WEEK

title: Bill on Soft Money Brings Harsh Debate
description: As five days of debate opened on a proposal to change the rules on campaign finance, the exchanges were fierce as Republicans in the normally staid Senate turned on one of their own.

title: Propelled by Different Drummers
description: ABOUT three years ago I started to notice that I no longer knew what to expect at a jazz club. The music started changing. The clunkily drawn opposing territories -- traditional versus avant-garde, or swing-centric jazz versus jazz free with a steady pulse -- became irrelevant. Lots of bands were coming up with ways to create spontaneous form onstage.

title: How Pakistan Wasted Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: PAKISTAN MILITARY COMPLETES SEIZURE OF ALL AUTHORITY
description: The new military ruler of Pakistan imposed martial law shortly after midnight today, suspending the Constitution, dismissing the Parliament and dashing hopes of a quick return to civilian rule in the world's newest nuclear power.

title: Republicans Pillory McCain in Debate Over Soft Money
description: As the Senate opened five days of debate on the campaign finance bill, Republicans bitterly turned on one of their own today and demanded that Senator John McCain prove his contentions that special-interest contributions to political parties are corrupting Congress.

title: Gore Win Not Assured
description: To the Editor:

title: Thomas H. Lake, 80, Ex-Head of Eli Lilly
description: Thomas H. Lake, the former president of Eli Lilly & Company, the multinational pharmaceutical concern, and former chairman of the Lilly Endowment, one of the largest private foundations in the nation, died on Sunday at his home in Carmel, Ind. He was 80.

title: Molding A Plywood Utopia
description: THOSE who think that there is too much irony at large in the world should hasten to see ''The Work of Charles and Ray Eames: A Legacy of Invention,'' the major fall offering at the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum. Even those of us who couldn't make it through the day without a morning dose of paradox will find this show restorative.

title: Sun Microsystems Says Profit Rose and Outlook Is Strong
description: Sun Microsystems Inc. reported earnings for its first fiscal quarter that exceeded analysts' estimates by a couple of cents, as the maker of work stations and servers continued to gain market share. Revenues were well above estimates as well, and Sun executives predicted more strong growth for this quarter.

title: Boston's Manager Still Believes in His Relief Corps
description: The Boston Red Sox have a pitching staff full of competitive guys, some of them recovering from arm surgery, many with tired arms. No starter has gone more than seven innings in this post-season, and the men of the bullpen work as if in a relay race. They have interchangeable roles and they try to get to the finish line still in the lead.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEVEE, FRANCES
description: LEVEE-Frances. Grandma, Happy 6th Birthday in Heaven. You are always in my thoughts. Love, Michae

title: Even Against All Odds, The Mets Still Believe
description: The Mets owner Fred Wilpon accompanied Manager Bobby Valentine on the field for yesterday's workout at Shea Stadium and then made his way around the diamond, shaking hands and patting backs in a conspicuous show of support for his team.

title: REXAM SELLS BOWATER WINDOWS UNIT FOR $203 MILLION
description: The British packaging materials maker Rexam P.L.C. said yesterday that it had sold its Bowater Windows Ltd. unit to a management-led buyout group for $203 million. The other major participant in the buyout was L & G Ventures, the private equity arm of the British insurer Legal and General Group P.L.C. The sale of Bowater Windows completes Rexam's exit from the plastic window frames industry. Rexam's German windows fabrication and installation business, Dyna Plastik, was sold for a nominal sum in June. In 1998, Bowater Windows and Dyna Plastik together had sales of $373 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAVON, PAUL, CANTOR
description: KAVON-Paul, Cantor. Age 75. Loving husband of Devorah Finn Kavon. Devoted father of Shira, Burt Grossman, Aliza, Moshe Deray, son Eli. Beloved grandfather of Ariel and Eytan Deray. Loving brother of Ida, Joseph Kavon, Frances A. Schloss, Morris Kavon deceased. Sister-in-law Gertrude Kavon. Beloved uncle of Martin Kavon, Judy, Maurice Stein, Rabbi Herbert Kavon, David and Susan Kavon, Robert J. Schloss, Emily Sack & Linda D. Schloss. Services Temple Beth Israel in Sunrise, Fla. Friday, at 11 AM. Donations to Temple Beth Israel, 7100 W. Oakland Park Blvd, Sunrise, FL. 33313 or the charity of your choice.

title: Operating Profit Off 21% at First Union
description: The First Union Corporation said today that its third-quarter profit from operations declined 21 percent as fees and mortgages fell and the bank lost money on securities transactions. Earnings were in line with expectations, which the company reduced twice this year.

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: Prolonging 'Contact'

title: New Video Releases
description: Election

title: Julius Nyerere of Tanzania Dies; Preached African Socialism to the World
description: Julius K. Nyerere, the founding father of Tanzania who used East Africa as a pulpit from which to spread his socialist philosophy worldwide, died yesterday in London. He was about 77 and was being treated for leukemia, and he suffered a major stroke last week.

title: Islanders Treat the Thrashers
description: The Islanders will forever be linked to one of hockey's latest trivia questions: who did the expansion Atlanta Thrashers defeat for their first victory?

title: TRADE GROUP DEFENDS ITSELF
description: The World Trade Organization disputes accusations that its policies have harmed the environment. The 134-nation trade group, which is to convene a new round of global negotiations next month, released a 59-page report intended to rebut increasingly vocal critics who accuse it of weakening environmental protection standards, a set of assertions that the group's new director general, Mike Moore, called ''pure cliche.'' While the transportation of goods, for example, can damage the environment, trade rules generally contribute to increased living standards, the report asserted. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WERT, EVE
description: WERT-Eve. On October 13, 1999 in Seattle, Washington. She is survived by her daughters, Roberta and Suzanne, son-in-law Frank, grandchildren Lisa and Steve, Liz and Stephen, Jennifer and Bob, and many beloved friends and relatives. Services Sunday 11:30 A.M. at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Visiting hours Saturday 7-9 P.M.

title: Gonna Have Some Fun When the Clock Strikes 1
description: J. Edgar Hoover always gets the silliest lines. ''Let's get everything we can on him,'' Hoover (Aron Tager) says to an F.B.I. employee in his one scene in ''Mr. Rock 'n' Roll: The Alan Freed Story.'' ''This rock 'n' roll scourge may turn out to be more dangerous than Communism.''

title: Frederick Christopher Belen, 95; Helped Automate Postal System
description: Frederick Christopher Belen, a Washington lawyer who helped speed the work of the country's growing post office through the establishment of regional distribution centers and the five-digit ZIP code, died on Wednesday at Arlington Hospital in Virginia. An Arlington resident, he was 95.

title: Perez Is Catching On as a Power Source
description: After hitting his second home run in two days against the Mets -- this one to win the game -- Eddie Perez, former backup catcher, continued to play down his talents.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-23

title: Civility, Not Bombast, And a Frisky Spirit
description: Two summers ago, the most ambitious exhibition in Europe was a citywide treasure hunt that took almost all Prague for its terrain. It was in honor of Rudolf II, the Holy Roman Emperor who reigned in Prague from 1583 until he was forced out in 1611.

title: Blair Says Ruling Out Single-Currency Plan Would Be 'Madness'
description: Saying it would be ''madness'' to rule out joining the European common currency, Prime Minister Tony Blair kicked off a rare multiparty campaign today aimed at combatting widespread antipathy in Britain to further integration with Europe.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEPOURHIET, JEANNETTE
description: LePOURHIET-Jeannette. A memorial servcie will be held for Jeannette LePourhiet of Chez Suzette Restaurant, formerly (Crepes Suzette, Restaurant Row) who passed away on October 5, 1999. Service will be held at St. Luke's Church, 308 W. 46th on Monday, October 18, 1999 at 6PM. All are welcome.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, SOLOMON
description: BERGER-Solomon. Beloved husband of Ruth (nee Topel). Devoted father of Jonathan and Shelley Berger, and Paul Berger. Adoring grandfather of Scott. Dear brother of Samuel, loving uncle. Service Sunday, October 17, 10:00 AM at Midwood Chapel, 1625 Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn, New York.

title: G.I.'s Are Called Looters of Jewish Riches
description: In the last weeks of World War II, as Soviet troops advanced from the east, Nazi officials in Hungary ordered that a train be sent west toward Germany with the collected wealth of Hungary's decimated Jews. Their wedding bands alone filled crate after crate.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: Earl A. Evans, 89, Biochemist Who Was a Leader in Research
description: Dr. Earl Alison Evans, a pioneering biochemist who built up one of the nation's leading biochemistry departments at the University of Chicago, died on Oct. 5 at a hospital in Chicago, where he lived. He was 89.

title: Peter Land
description: Klemens Gasser and Tanja Grunert

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Again, N.Y.U. Can Be Clubby

title: Blacklist of Israel's Friends Drawn Up in Jordan
description: They are making a list, and they are checking it twice. Then they plan to go public.

title: For Boston Fans, Trial by Fire to Fight Curse
description: For the first six innings, an intermittent stream of peanuts, popcorn and other unidentified objects pelted Timothy McAndrew's Boston Red Sox cap. The Yankees fan behind him went hoarse chanting ''1918! 1918!'' and a variation of the phrase ''Boston stinks!'' And a group of young, enraged and inebriated Yankees fans vowed to hospitalize Mr. McAndrew, while hurling an astonishingly vivid array of biblical and barnyard expletives at him.

title: Military Leaders Tell Congress of NATO Errors in Kosovo
description: The nation's top civilian and military officials told Congress today that allied forces were too slow in choosing targets during the Kosovo war, that the United States seriously underestimated how many precision-guided munitions would be needed, that NATO should have kept alive the option of a ground invasion and that the war was fought with too much reliance on American forces.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Better Get Lots Of Popcorn

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Spencer gives you pause. The steel door, with its crazy-shaped cutouts, suggests a nightclub, the kind where three lip piercings are the minimum. The name of the place has been rendered in a violent-looking metallic spatter typeface. Some of the letters have eyeballs and spiky haircuts.

title: Japan Banks to Merge, With Wider Effects
description: Japanese banks, consolidating at an unexpectedly quick pace, are taking steps that have implications beyond the financial world.

title: Though Life's Been a Pain, She Gets the Last Laugh
description: You'd think Kathy Buckley was making this stuff up. She was wrongly labeled retarded as a child, sexually abused, run over by a Jeep while lying on the beach (pronounced dead by a paramedic who later kept saying, ''I'm so sorry'') and stricken with cervical cancer, all before she was 30. And from this she builds a standup-comedy routine.

title: A City Reclaims Its Cultural Past
description: During the late 1940's, right after World War II, there was a rich cultural life in Trenton, including opera, ballet and symphony, that centered on the theater in the War Memorial building, completed in 1932 to commemorate local citizens who died in World War I. Unlike the sprawling performing arts centers that succeeded this compact genre, War Memorial buildings were designed to house numerous civic events. Half town meeting house, half theater, the civic auditorium as a civilizing force in the community had an architectural presence akin to museums, banks, courthouses and city halls.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZAGON, MARTIN
description: ZAGON-Martin. Born October 14, 1925. Died October 13, 1999. Teacher at High School of Graphic Arts and at LaGuardia High School. Will be greatly missed by wife, Ruth, sister Rose Stein, friends, neighbors and relatives. Services will be held at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue at 91 Street at 1 PM on October 15.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAFIR, FLORENCE B.
description: SAFIR-Florence B., 89, passed away October 4 in San Diego. Florence was a native New Yorker. She was born in Greenwich Village, and lived on West 72nd Street for more than 65 years. For over 30 years, ''Florrie'' was a school secretary at P.S. 87. In the usually anonymous city, strolling down Broadway with Florrie was an unusually neighborly experience. Elementary, junior-high, and high school kids smiled and waved. Adults stopped to chat. Some, were parents of P.S. 87 kids; some even were once P.S. 87 kids themselves, now with children of their own. Everyone remembered Florrie. As will all of us: her son, Andrew; sister, Ruth; and daughter-in-law, Marcia. There will be a private burial Sunday, October 17. Anyone wishing to express condolences, or share memories can contact Andy Safir, 3800 Carbo Court, La Mesa, Calif. 91941.

title: Fiddling With Federalism
description: The Supreme Court's ongoing reappraisal of the limits of federal power moved into new and treacherous terrain on Wednesday when the justices heard arguments in one of the term's most significant cases -- a test of Congress's authority to bind states to the federal law barring age discrimination in employment, and, more broadly, its authority to enforce the fairness principles embedded in the 14th Amendment's equal protection clause.

title: Taco Belles
description: All over New York, Mexican restaurants are popping up, serving the rapidly growing Mexican population and legions of other lovers of Mexican food. Here are a dozen of the better ones. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times by William Grimes, Mr. Asimov and others.)

title: Take My Husband, Please, Along With His Apron
description: ''The Story of Us'' offers such an arthritic vision of middle-aged marriage that it feels like the first Jack Lemmon comedy made expressly for the baby boom generation. Perhaps that would explain the casting of Bruce Willis as a jokey but sensitive suburban Dad and Michelle Pfeiffer as his beleaguered spouse. The stars, variously directed by Rob Reiner to kid around, look wistful or scream so hard that their necks turn red, are not helped by the film's elbow-in-the-ribs humor or its overbearing tactics. Though it sets out to explain why this marriage is worth saving, ''The Story of Us'' could prompt even single members of the audience to file for divorce.

title: On the Road To Epiphany
description: In 1994 an elderly man named Alvin Straight undertook a long Midwestern journey riding on a lawnmower. It was an arduous feat, but not nearly as daunting as what David Lynch sets out to do in ''The Straight Story'': make a slow-moving, folksy-looking, profoundly spiritual film that can hold an audience in absolute thrall. As the least likely filmmaker on the planet to pull off such a G-rated miracle, Mr. Lynch rises to this challenge with exhilarating vigor. Switching gears radically, bravely defying conventional wisdom about what it takes to excite moviegoers, Mr. Lynch presents the flip side of ''Blue Velvet'' and turns it into a supremely improbable triumph.

title: Muffin Shop Was Haven in Changing Community
description: It was only a bakery shop, residents of Little Italy said yesterday, a tiny four-table cafe with gourmet coffee and memorable pastries. But it stood for something more.

title: A Nuclear Safety Valve Is Shut Off, but U.S. Maintains Other Safeguards
description: The test ban treaty defeated in the Senate yesterday was a critical foreign policy objective of the Clinton Administration, but it was far from the only component of the Government's strategy to control the proliferation of nuclear arms -- which embraces a menu of measures ranging from broad treaties to tailor-made solutions like sanctions aimed at rogue countries.

title: Sports of The Times; Cone's Invisible Cliff
description: WHEN David Cone strode to the mound at Yankee Stadium for the first inning of Game 2 last night, he knew there was an invisible cliff there.

title: Shifting Sense of Scale Among Objects of Desire
description: The International Fine Art and Antique Dealers Show, manifest in its 11th incarnation at the Seventh Regiment Armory, is frequently described as the country's best. This opinion is somewhat a matter of taste; many people would justifiably counter with the Asian Art Fair, held every spring at that address.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 20.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIDERS, IRVING
description: SIDERS-Irving, 81, died suddenly on October 13, 1999. Beloved husband of Pat (nee Frost). Devoted father of Sandra and Robert Katz. Caring stepfather of Jan & Larry Nusbaum, and Dale and Richard Miller. Adored grandfather of Scott and Jill Katz, Sharon and Peter Kline, Jake and Max Nusbaum, and Olivia Miller. Proud greatgrandfather of Griffin Andrew Kline. Service Friday, 12 noon at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to the Simon Wiesenthal Center, 342 Madison Avenue, Suite 1624, New York, N.Y. 10173.

title: Residential Real Estate; New Owners Refurbish a Herald Square Stalwart
description: Built in 1913 as a hotel and converted 20 years ago to rentals, the 693-apartment McAlpin House at the southeast corner of the Avenue of the Americas and 34th Street has been a residential stalwart in the Herald Square neighborhood. Now, the company that owns the Herald Center retail complex across Broadway has bought the McAlpin, renamed it Herald Towers and begun to upgrade the apartments.

title: Times Co. Buys Massachusetts Paper for $295 Million and Posts Rise in Profit
description: The New York Times Company bought The Worcester Telegram & Gazette yesterday for $295 million, expanding its reach in Massachusetts, where it already owns The Boston Globe, and making a major investment in the newspaper industry, which is currently buoyed by record advertising.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHELAN, SONDRA
description: PHELAN-Sondra. A caring and compassionate member of the Board of Trustees of the Ackerman Institute for the Family. A graduate of our training program, she was a gifted therapist who brought warmth and understanding to all the families she met. We will truly miss her optimism and spirit. Arthur Maslow, Board Chairman Peter Steinglass, MD, Exec Dir.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOTTOMLEY, HILDA RIDGWAY
description: BOTTOMLEY-Hilda Ridgway. Of London, England, died October 14, 1999 in New Castle, NSW, Australia. Mother of eight, grandmother of 26 and great-grandmother of 34. She was a loving, proud and brave woman who raised a wonderful family despite the perils of the London blitz in World War II. We love you, Nan, and will always be very proud that you were part of our heritage. Love, The St. John and Speakman Families

title: Mayweather and Reid in Cold After HBO Contract Disputes
description: In the span of two weeks, HBO's boxing czar, Lou DiBella, has put two of the network's young stars out in the cold after they rejected contract offers. First it was Floyd Mayweather Jr., the World Boxing Council junior lightweight champion. And this week it was David Reid, the World Boxing Association superwelterweight champion.

title: States' Big Suits Against Industry Bring Battle on Contingency Fees
description: A growing wave of lawsuits by cities and states against makers of cigarettes, guns, and now lead paint, has reignited a fierce debate over the role of lawyers and the enormous fees they can earn in legal actions brought by public officials.

title: Clinton Says 'New Isolationism' Imperils U.S. Security
description: President Clinton said today that the Republicans who defeated a treaty to ban underground nuclear testing were retreating into a ''new isolationism'' that threatened national security.

title: Jim Peters
description: CDS Gallery

title: Analyze This: Institutional Investor Names Its All-Stars
description: Exultant cries of ''We're No. 2'' and ''I'm No. 3'' rang out on Wall Street yesterday as hundreds of people who would never be confused with competitive athletes learned that they had been deemed ''all-Americans.''

title: Album of the Week
description: STEREOLAB: ''Cobra and Phases Group Play Voltage in the Milky Night'' (Elektra). Stereolab has built its music on unexpected affinities: Steve Reich's Minimalism and 1960's French ye-ye pop, serene female voices and goofy analog synthesizer sounds, lounge exotica and art-rock, funk drumbeats and odd-meter 1950's jazz, dialectical musings and nonsense syllables. All of it resolves, sooner or later, into patterns that are both insouciant and orderly, creating a bustling stasis with a clarity that's reassuring. ''Out of chaos a creation binding into one form,'' a new song explains.

title: Clinton at News Conference: 'Troubling Signs of New Isolationism'
description: Following is a transcript of the news conference today by President Clinton, as provided by the Federal News Service:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STAAB, WILLIAM DU PONT
description: STAAB-William du Pont Of Essex Fells, N.J., age 93, on October 8, 1999. He was architectural partner of Krahmer, Staab and Immen of Newark and Glen Ridge, N.J. Graduate of the University of Pennsylvania, School of Architecture in 1934. Former President of the Essex Fells School Board of Education. Pre-deceased by wife Jane Hart Staab. Survived by sons William du Pont, Jr. of NYC, Christopher Ely of Honolulu, Hawaii and Jonathan Ray of New Rochelle, N.Y., daughter Jane Newton Staab of Boston and five grandchildren. Memorial Service at 11AM, October 16th at St. Peter's Episcopal Church, 271 Roseland Ave., Essex Fells, N.J. Contributions to St. Peter's Episcopal Church or to the West Essex First Aide Squad, P O Box 662, West Caldwell, N.J. 07007.

title: As the Finale Nears, Indonesians Face Off
description: Indonesia entered the final and most intense days of its political transition today with demonstrators and security forces battling in the streets as President B. J. Habibie pleaded with an electoral assembly to choose him for a full five-year term.

title: Romance, Lies and Lip-Syncers In Paris
description: ''Same Old Song'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Stephen Holden's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 26, 1998. The film -- in French, with English subtitles -- opens today at the Lincoln Plaza, Broadway at 63d Street, Manhattan.

title: Boeing Profit Beats Forecasts for Third Consecutive Quarter
description: Continuing its financial rebound, the Boeing Company beat Wall Street earnings estimates for the third consecutive quarter yesterday and promised more good news to come.

title: A Tobacco Whistle-Blower's Life Is Transformed
description: It was not the first time it had happened. Sitting with some friends in a bar-restaurant, still energized from accepting his first honorary doctorate, Jeffrey S. Wigand noticed a man approaching from the bar.

title: INSIDE
description: A New First Mortgage

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINCH, WILLIAM P.
description: FINCH-William P. Please join friends and family at a memorial service for Will, 11:00 A.M. Saturday, October 16, St. James Church, Madison Avenue at 71st. St. In lieu of flowers gifts may be made in Will's memory to Browning School or Sarah Lawrence College.

title: Steve Ross Offers Noel Coward Snapshots
description: If the impeccably dapper singer and pianist Steve Ross is to be a kindred spirit of Noel Coward, whom he is saluting in his new cabaret show at the Firebird Cafe, the two are hardly psychic twins. Mr. Ross is a gentler, less robust performer than Coward, who had a healthy streak of the music hall ham and who, when the occasion demanded, could work himself up to a near roar. Mr. Ross's peak volume is closer to an exuberant purr.

title: Should Pain Be Part of Childbirth?
description: To the Editor:

title: Richard B. Shull, 70, Stage and Screen Actor
description: Richard B. Shull, an actor whose Walter Matthau-like face was familiar from television and film and who was portraying D. W. DeWitt in the current Broadway production of ''Epic Proportions,'' died yesterday in Manhattan at the age of 70. His wife, Deborah Thomas Shull, said the cause was a heart attack.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Being Exclusive Draws Big Crowds; Private Schools Enjoy a Boom, But Demand Exceeds Growth
description: The crowds around the tables were three people thick.

title: Corrections
description: A Public Lives profile on Tuesday about Andre J. Hornsby, the Yonkers school superintendent, misstated the nature of a dispute over child support for an 8-year-old daughter. Dr. Hornsby said that in the course of his job shift from Houston to Yonkers he negotiated an increase in payments, based on a higher salary in Yonkers. He said he had never failed to make support payments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIDDLE, DONALD H.
description: RIDDLE-Donald H. The faculty, students, staff and alumni mourn with his daughter, Susan, the death of Donald H. Riddle, who was the second president of John Jay College of Criminal Justice from 1968 to 1975. It was his vision to join the liberal arts with the theory and practice of criminal justice that launched John Jay College in its unique mission. He was a patient and constant mentor to us all. Gerald W. Lynch, President John Jay College of Criminal Justice

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAPOFF, PHYLLIS
description: LAPOFF-Phyllis. Shelter Rock Jewish Center, Roslyn, New York, mourns the loss of our longstanding and devoted member. We remember her with affection. Sincerest condolences to her mother and children. Rabbi Myron M. Fenster Laurence A. Feldman, President

title: Chechnya, Torn by War, Is Also Being Tormented by Kidnappings
description: Bursts of automatic gunfire rang out in central Grozny on Wednesday, followed by an ear-splitting volley from a heavy machine gun. People were running on the street, while fighters and other armed men rushed toward the gunfire.

title: Chrysler Makes Its Place in History
description: THIS city, whose name is synonymous with the American auto industry, is strengthening that identification at several museums dedicated to the business.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: PLANS FOR KOREA FIRST UNIT
description: The state-run Korea Deposit Insurance Corporation plans to take over the New York unit of Korea First Bank and sell it to a third party, a spokesman at Korea First Bank said. If necessary, Korea Deposit Insurance will inject public funds into Korea First Bank New York before finding an investor, the spokesman said. Meanwhile, Newbridge Capital Ltd., which agreed to take over Korea First Bank, will convert Korea First Bank's New York branch office into a nondepositary financial firm. Korea Deposit Insurance holds a 97 percent stake in Korea First Bank.

title: Zeng Xiaojun
description: China 2000 Fine Art

title: Regretting a Guilty Plea In Child Molestation
description: The man who pleaded guilty to molesting a teen-ager who has admitted strangling a young boy wants to withdraw his guilty plea, the judge in the case confirmed yesterday.

title: Charles Atlas
description: XL Xavier La Boulbenne

title: Corrections
description: Two picture captions with an article in Circuits yesterday about software collections designed to change the appearance of computer screens were transposed. The Kaleidoscope program was pictured at bottom center, the DSG Themes program was at bottom right.

title: All in the Family: Mistrust, Coldness and Inertia
description: It's the lethargy that's appalling. Yes, the house that the Spragues live in is unremittingly ugly and uncared for, from the dirt-brown air-conditioning unit to the red-tile bathroom walls to the empty, misshapen wire hangers. And the family's criminal tendencies -- the police always seem to be dropping by to question one of them -- is hardly admirable. But what stays with the moviegoer, after seeing the gloomy, somewhat plodding but still arresting Australian drama, ''The Boys,'' is the maddening inertia of its characters, their seeming inability to take even the smallest action.

title: Ratings Are Up
description: Game 1 of the A.L.C.S. on Wednesday night produced a 10.8 national Nielsen rating for Fox, an increase 74 percent from the league championship game the network showed on the same night last year, between Atlanta and San Diego.

title: Around the World, Dismay Over Senate Vote on Treaty
description: Around the world today, government leaders and arms experts reacted with dismay and even anger after the United States Senate defeated, without much debate, a nuclear test ban treaty that had been decades in the making. For many, there was a sense that the treaty may now be dead.

title: QUANTA BUYS 11 COMPANIES, WITH SALES OF $150 MILLION
description: Quanta Services Inc., an electrical services provider based in Houston, said it had acquired 11 contracting companies expected to produce annual revenue of about $150 million. Quanta provides specialty electrical contracting and maintenance services for electric and telecommunications infrastructure. It had revenue of $322 million in the six months ended June 30. With these and earlier acquisitions, Quanta expects company revenue to surpass $1 billion this year. The companies acquired by Quanta are in California, Florida, Louisiana, Minnesota, New Jersey, Nevada, North Carolina and Oklahoma.

title: Shares of Unisys Slide 37%; Revenue Figures Are Cited
description: Shares of the Unisys Corporation fell 37 percent yesterday after the technology company said revenue in the third quarter had increased by 4 percent, a figure below investors' expectations.

title: Such a Very Long Way From Duvets to Danger
description: Of the two current films in which buttoned-down businessmen rebel against middle-class notions of masculinity, David Fincher's savage ''Fight Club'' is by far the more visionary and disturbing. Where ''American Beauty'' hinges on the subversive allure of a rose-covered blond cheerleader, Mr. Fincher has something a good deal tougher in mind. The director of ''Seven'' and ''The Game'' for the first time finds subject matter audacious enough to suit his lightning-fast visual sophistication, and puts that style to stunningly effective use. Lurid sensationalism and computer gamesmanship left this filmmaker's earlier work looking hollow and manipulative. But the sardonic, testosterone-fueled science fiction of ''Fight Club'' touches a raw nerve.

title: Canadian Regulators File Charges Against Executive at Corel
description: Canada's top securities regulator has charged Michael Cowpland, the president and chief executive of the Corel Corporation, one of the nation's largest computer software makers, with unlawfully profiting from insider trading in the company's shares and lying about his activities.

title: QUARTERLY DIVIDEND IS RAISED TO 50 CENTS A SHARE
description: The Ford Motor Company raised its quarterly dividend 8.7 percent, responding to investor pressure that some of its $24 billion in cash go to shareholders. The dividend increase, to 50 cents from 46 cents, was Ford's first since October 1998 and its eighth since the second quarter of 1994. It applies to class B and common shares. Ford shares rose 31.25 cents, to $53.0625. They have fallen 9.6 percent this year, even with record United States car and truck sales. The fourth-quarter dividends are payable on Dec. 1 to shareholders of record on Nov. 1.

title: De Niro and Partners Dispute Giuliani Version of Navy Yard Deal
description: Reeling from the collapse of a deal to build a $150 million sound stage complex at the city-owned Brooklyn Navy Yard, the actor Robert De Niro and top executives of Miramax Films yesterday disputed Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's account of where the deal stood before it fell apart.

title: Mosque in Nazareth Could Imperil Papal Visit, Vatican Warns
description: Angered by Israel's decision to allow the building of a mosque next to a Christian holy site in Nazareth, the Vatican warned today that such a move could jeopardize a papal visit to Israel next year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALINO, LEONORE ROMAN
description: MALINO-Leonore Roman. On October 13, 1999, peacefully at home. Born January 23, 1898. An artist and concert violinist, she was the adored wife of the late Jerome E. Malino; loving sister of the late Charles Roman, Dorothy Feldman and Pauline Kraft, and sister-inlaw to Orpha Vasquez Roman. She was the beloved mother of Emily Malino Scheuer and of the late Jacqueline Malino Wilentz, and the admired mother-in-law of former Congressman James H. Scheuer and the late Robert N. Wilentz, Chief Justice of the New Jersey Supreme Court. ''Ninor'' was the adored and devoted grandmother of James Wilentz, Laura Scheuer, Elizabeth Scheuer, Amy Wilentz, James H. Scheuer, Jr., John Scheuer, and Thomas Wilentz and was loved by all their spouses. She was a loving greatgrandmother of Benjamin and Sarah Wilentz; Damella and Laurella Dotan; Eleanor, Nicholas, Anna and Katherine Joseph; Raphael, Gabriel and Noah Goldberg; James William Scheuer; Sarah Scheuer; and Daniel and Robert S. Wilentz. Leonore was also the dear aunt of Ted Jackson, Betty Malino, Ellen Malino James, Henry Feldman, Roger Roman and Ron Roman. Funeral service, Friday, 11:30 AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Leonore R. Malino Scholarship Fund at the Juilliard School of Music.

title: BRAZILIAN LENDING INITIATIVES
description: Brazil's central bank announced several measures to encourage the country's banks to increase lending. A tax on consumer loans was lowered to 1.5 percent from 6 percent, reserve requirements on time deposits were reduced to zero from 10 percent, and legislation will be changed to allow banks to seize defaulted debtors' assets more easily. The measures are seen as freeing lending capital for the economy. But interest rates of 19 percent still make Brazilian loans prohibitively expensive.

title: Should Pain Be Part of Childbirth?
description: To the Editor:

title: Justine Kurland
description: Patrick Callery

description: Following are excerpts from the debate today in the Senate over campaign finance law that involved Senators John McCain, the Arizona Republican who favors changing the law, and Mitch McConnell, the Kentucky Republican who is a leading defender of having few rules on such matters, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: When a Beloved Blanket Means More Than Security
description: The Adventures Of Elmo in Grouchland

title: Millennium Set To Buy Leukosite
description: Millennium Pharmaceuticals Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Leukosite Inc., a biotechnology company specializing in drugs for cancer and inflammation, in a stock swap valued at $635 million.

title: Sally Mann
description: Edwynn Houk Gallery

title: Big Three for the Mets Are Scary Pushovers
description: Maybe no one should be surprised that John Olerud, Mike Piazza and Robin Ventura are not hitting Atlanta pitchers in the National League Championship Series. The men who make up the middle of the Mets' lineup did not hit the Braves' pitchers during the season, either.

title: BRAIN MAY GROW NEW CELLS DAILY
description: In a new challenge to the longstanding belief that adults never generate new brain cells, biologists at Princeton University have found that thousands of freshly born neurons arrive each day in the cerebral cortex, the outer rind of the brain where higher intellectual functions and personality are centered.

title: Clinton Vows to Veto Spending Bill Envisioned by Republicans
description: President Clinton said today that if Republicans in Congress pressed ahead with their latest plan for meeting budget targets -- an across-the-board cut in spending on all Government programs -- he would veto the measure.

title: ANOTHER WIRELESS NET VENTURE
description: A day after the palm computing unit of the 3Com Corporation announced an ambitious alliance with Nokia to make its software available on mobile phones, the Microsoft Corporation struck back by announcing its own alliance with British Telecommunications to develop new ways to get access to the Internet wirelessly using Windows CE, a scaled-down version of Windows 98 used in hand-held digital devices. Both British Telecom, which operates BT Cellnet, and Microsoft have been slow to enter the wireless arena.

title: Maytag's Net Income Shows Rise of 5.6%
description: The Maytag Corporation said today that its third-quarter profit rose 5.6 percent, exceeding reduced estimates.

title: A Disputed Study Suggests Possible Harm From Genetically Altered Food
description: A prestigious medical journal is publishing a study suggesting that genetically modified food may be harmful, even though the research has been widely criticized by scientists and was found wanting by some of the journal's own referees.

title: Parents Remain Suspects in Killing of Child Beauty Queen, Boulder Prosecutors Say
description: Prosecutors who failed to obtain a grand jury indictment on Wednesday in the killing of JonBenet Ramsey said today that the girl's parents were still suspects in the case.

title: Fractured Serbian Opposition Unites in Demanding Early Vote
description: Under pressure from Washington and the fizzling of protests against President Slobodan Milosevic, the weakened democratic opposition in Serbia united today in demanding early elections under the watchful eye of foreign monitors.

title: On My Mind; The Himalayan Error
description: Ever since their independence, the U.S. has made decisions about India and Pakistan fully aware that it was dealing with countries that would have increasing political and military significance, for international good or evil.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, HERMAN
description: KLEIN-Herman. Devoted husband of the late Sonia. Dearest brother of Florence Krugman. Loving uncle of of Steven Epstein, Jessica Schneider, Barbara Teiger & Lee Krugman. Services Friday, 1 PM ''Parkside'' Chapels, Queens Blvd at 66 Avenue, Forest Hills.

title: Knicks Tell Sprewell A Trade Is Possible
description: The exasperation lingering from last week's game of telephone tag with Latrell Sprewell and his agent may have irritated the Knicks' hierarchy to a point where the next call they return could lead to a trade of the unpredictable guard.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORSYTH, ROBERT W.
description: FORSYTH-Robert W. Died Wednesday, October 13, 1999 at the Wesley Health Care Center surrounded by his family. Born in Brooklyn, NY, he resided in Fresh Meadows, NY until 1992. He relocated to Clifton Park, NY upon his retirement from the New York Racing Association Mutual Department. He is survived by his beloved wife and best friend of 46 years, Jeanne Plunkett Forsyth, and his devoted children. Three sons, Robert G. Forsyth of Upper Saddle River, NJ, Anthony L. Forsyth of East Meadow, NY and Brian J. Forsyth of Evergreen Lake, PA. One daughter, Maureen Forsyth McGonigle of Malta, NY. Bob was also a dear father-in-law to Elizabeth Forsyth, Deborah Forsyth, Allison Forsyth and Jack McGonigle. He is also survived by his cherished grandchildren, Meghan, Patrick, Christopher, Tracy, Keith, Joseph and Michael. For information, contact Simone Funeral Home, Inc., 105 Lake Avenue, Saratoga Springs, NY. Viewing hours will be from 3-5 pm and 7-9 pm, Friday, October 15, 1999. Funeral Mass at Saint Peter's Roman Catholic Church at 10 am, Saturday, October 16, 1999. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to: Wesley Health Care Center, Inc., Meinhardt Partnership Nursing Scholarships, 131 Lawrence Street, Saratoga Springs, NY 12866 or Autonomic Dysfunction Center, Vanderbilt University, Room AA 3228, Nashville, TN 37232-2195

title: Treasuries Decline Further; 30-Year Yield Is Now 6.32%
description: Driven by some investors' concern that strong economic growth will prompt the Federal Reserve to raise short-term interest rates, bond yields climbed for a third consecutive day yesterday.

title: Mrs. Clinton Renews Fight For Universal Health Care
description: Citing a continued rise in the number of Americans without health coverage, Hillary Rodham Clinton today called for ''quality, affordable health insurance for everyone in the country,'' saying it would be a mistake to abandon the goal because of her failed effort to change the system six years ago.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Daimler and Aerospatiale to Merge Their Aerospace Businesses
description: Overcoming national jealousies and ideological obstacles, DaimlerChrysler A.G. of Germany and Aerospatiale Matra S.A. of France agreed today to merge their aerospace businesses into a European behemoth with about $22 billion in annual sales.

title: Left Field to Split Into Two Companies
description: Left Field in San Francisco, a three-year-old agency that specializes in advertising for dot-com companies, is being divided in two as a result of what were described as ''differences in management styles'' among the three managing partners.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TORRES, LYDIA J.
description: TORRES-Lydia J. You are always in our hearts and thoughts and mind. And you will always be missed by us. Funeral services at Ortiz Funeral Home, 4425 Bway, NYC, 2-5 and 7-10 PM. Mass at Incarnation Church on Saturday, October 16th. With all our love Your Family and Friends

title: Retail Sales Rise Again; Jobless Claims Fall 29,000
description: Retail sales rose in September as furniture and department stores reported their best months since early this year, Government figures showed today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORON, HYMAN
description: KORON-Hyman. Formerly of Great Neck. August 9, peacefully in San Francisco. Beloved father of Judith Hoffmann and Barry Koron and father-in-law of Kate Tompkins. Adoring grandfather of Rose Madelin Koron. Loving husband of the late Edith Schultz Koron. Loved by extended family, friends and co-workers. He spoke five languages and never said a harsh word in any. Interment 10:30 A.M. Friday, October 15 at New Montefiore Cemetery. Memorial service 1:00 p.m. at the Great Neck Library, 169 Bayview Ave. Contributions in his name may be made to the Alzheimer's Association.

title: RAID ON CREDIT SUISSE
description: Fifty officers from the Tokyo Metropolitan Police, left, unexpectedly marched into the offices of Credit Suisse Financial Products, the unit of the Credit Suisse Group that was banned from operating in Japan and was placed under criminal investigation after its executives sought to destroy evidence during an investigation by Japanese regulators. Credit Suisse expressed surprise at the raid, saying that it has been cooperating with the police since September. It is currently winding down the Financial Products group's business in Japan and adopting plans to tighten compliance in its other operations here.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.

title: For Survivor Of Holocaust, Another Test
description: HER name is not as important as her unhappy past, which comes back to stalk her every now and then.

title: A Violinist With Technique And a Tone of Many Colors
description: The Finnish violinist Elina Vahala gave a decisive and spirited debut recital for Young Concert Artists at the 92d Street Y on Tuesday night. Her control of phrasing, and especially the ends of phrases, provided evidence of a thoughtful musician who has all the technical accomplishment and confidence she needs to project her thoughts. Her intonation is sure and her tone fine, more various than sweet, going all the way from a grainy, almost reedy insistence, but perfectly formed, to soft dabs of sound.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEDERER, IRVING ALBERT
description: LEDERER-Irving Albert. October 13, 1999 in West Palm Beach, FL, at age 98. Beloved husband of Frieda Rich. Loving father of Alice Cohen and Edith Lederer, both of NYC. Dear uncle, cousin, and brother-in-law. Graveside service Friday, October 15, at Maimonides Cemetery, Elmont, New York.

title: Helping Our Youth
description: To the Editor:

title: Is There A Cure For the Losing?
description: The Mets' sick ward was still full yesterday. Rickey Henderson, who left Game 2 with nausea and light-headedness, said he felt only slightly better yesterday.

title: Court Backs Law Docking Legislators
description: New York's highest court upheld a bitterly contested law today that calls for withholding the pay of state legislators when a state budget is late, bolstering efforts to speed up the state's notoriously slow budget-making process.

title: Senate Vote: Partisanship Arrives in Foreign Affairs
description: The Senate's defeat of the test ban treaty Wednesday left many senators troubled about a level of partisanship usually reserved for the House, and wondering about the institution's ability to manage a complicated issue that affects the world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PANZARELLA, ROSEMARY
description: PANZARELLA-Rosemary D. (Anguilla), 67, died Thursday, October 14th, 1999 at St. Peters Medical Center, New Brunswick, N.J. Born in Brooklyn, she resided in New Hyde Park before moving to Bridgewater, N.J. 35 years ago. She was a secretary for the Bridgewater Raritan School District for 15 years retiring in 1993. Surviving are her husband Joseph, her mother Mary DiMaio, one daughter, three sons, two step-daughters and seven grandchildren. Funeral services Saturday 7:45 A.M. from the Branchburg Funeral Home 910 Highway 202 South, Branchburg, N.J. followed by an 8:30 A.M. mass at St. Ann's R.C. Church 45 Anderson St., Raritan, N.J. Entombment will be in the St. Bernards Cemetery Mausoleum, Bridgewater, N.J. Visitation hours today from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 P.M. at the Funeral Home (908-526-7638). In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made in her memory to ALS Association 27001 Agoura Road Suite 150, Calabasas Hills, California 91301-5104.

title: CEMENT DEAL PROPOSED
description: The world's third-largest cement maker, Heidelberger Zement A.G. of Belgium, said it would offer to buy the 44.1 percent of CBR Cimenteries it does not already own for 1.21 billion euros ($1.31 billion) in cash and stock. Heidelberger will offer two new shares and 165 euros for every three shares of CBR, valuing the Brussels-based cement company at 112 euros a share.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMOLENSKI, JULIANE A.
description: SMOLENSKI-Juliane A. (nee Sackerlotzky in Bamberg, Germany). Entered into eternal rest in NYC on Saturday, October 9, 1999 after a 2 month illness. She was the beloved mother of Gloria S. Daxland of Floral Park, NY and Cecilia S. Flynn of Norwalk, Conn. She was devoted to her sole granddaughter Juliana Lena Daxland, age 6. A funeral mass was held on Wednesday, October 13 at the R. C. Church of the Good Shepherd in Manhattan. Her remains will be returned to her hometown, Bamberg, for burial at Christmas time. An avid traveler and suppporter of the Arts, she was also a caring and devoted employee of Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center for 38 years. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to New York Presbyterian Hospital for benefit of Babies Hospital, Mr. Stephen Burke, Development Office, Harkness Pavilion #

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMRON, MILDRED
description: AMRON-Mildred. Beloved sister of Gertrude Lampe, Max Amron and Ida Horvitz. Loving aunt of Martin Lampe, Martha, Deborah and Richard Horvitz. Service 2 PM, Sunday, at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st St and Amsterdam

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE LONG, VERA
description: De LONG-Vera On October 13, 1999. Survived by her daughter June Rothenstein. Dear mother of the late Robert, George, John and Gloria Jones. Mrs. De Long has seven grandchildren, 12 great grandchildren and one great, great grandchild. Family to receive friends at the Leo F. Kearns Funeral Home, 61-40 Woodhaven Blvd, Rego Park, NY. 718-441-3300, Friday 2-4 and 6-8 PM. Mass of Christian Burial at Resurrection Ascension Church, Saturday 9:45AM. Interment to follow at Pine Lawn Memorial Park.

title: Politics and a Treaty's Demise; Reckless Power Play
description: To the Editor:

title: Looking Back on Love, With a Touch of Surrealism
description: Virtually a company reborn, the Australian Ballet under Ross Stretton's leadership has come back to New York with terrific dancing, creativity and a new ensemble spirit. The troupe from Melbourne has also returned with works by Stanton Welch and Stephen Baynes, two young choreographers developed from the ranks by Maina Gielgud, the previous artistic director.

title: Despite Tyco's Defense, Shares Fall Again
description: Investors brushed aside Tyco International's aggressive defense of its accounting practices yesterday, pushing its stock down $9 more, to $87, amid fears about the company's three-year acquisition spree.

title: A Self-Possessed Carmen, Without the Salome Shtick
description: Playing Carmen as a sultry, hip-swiveling seductress has become a tiresome operatic cliche. So it was refreshing to experience what seemed to be a consciously different take on the role from the American mezzo-soprano Luretta Bybee during the performance of Bizet's enduringly popular masterpiece by the New York City Opera on Wednesday night.

title: In a Swedish Town, the Girls Will Be Girls
description: Agnes is an unhappy girl. She and her parents have lived in the boring town of Amal, Sweden, for a year and a half, and she still has no friends. She's a vegetarian, yet her mother insists on making roast beef for her 16th birthday party. Almost nobody comes to the party, and Agnes, played by the gorgeous Rebecca Liljeberg, insults the first person who does show up, with the unfortunate bluntness of youth. (''I don't want to be friends with a palsied cripple who listens to backstreet boys.'') Agnes soon throws herself onto her bed, crying about being ''ugly, a failure, repulsive.'' By the end of the evening, she's trying to slit her wrists with what looks like a disposable shaver.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLER, REBECCA
description: KELLER-Rebecca. The Ramaz School family mourns the passing of the beloved mother of its devoted parent and benefactor, Mrs. Hinda Farber and extends heartfelt sympathy to all the members of the bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein Principal David N. Kahn, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RUBIN, ROSE N.
description: RUBIN-Rose N. Family and friends will gather between 2 P.M. and 5 P.M. on Saturday October 16, 1999 at Rose's home to celebrate her life.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE DOLLAR GAINS. The dollar rose against the yen as traders waited for signals from the Bank of Japan on whether it will move to weaken the yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 107.35 yen, up from 106.60.

title: All Science Is at Risk
description: To the Editor:

title: Hunter's Widow Opens Up
description: Helen Hunter knew days like yesterday would come, when she would have to summon the courage to talk, in her quiet North Carolina way, about her late husband -- Catfish to the baseball world, Jimmy to her.

title: Treasury and Fed Reach A Compromise
description: After decades of bickering over control of the nation's banking system, the Treasury Department and the Federal Reserve announced today that they had reached an agreement, resolving one of the last outstanding issues in the fight to overhaul the nation's financial system.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: COTTMAN TRANSMISSION SYSTEMS INC., Fort Washington, Pa., has been bought for $50 million by a group of senior executives and Sentinel Capital Partners, a New York investment firm.

title: Western Vistas
description: The once-forgotten Carleton Watkins, the greatest American landscape photographer of the 19th century, is recalled in a retrospective at the Metropolitan Museum that features his images of the West, including ''Yosemite Falls, View From the Bottom'' (1878-81), above.

title: How Pakistan Wasted Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: Gazing Across Time and Space Into Vistas of the West
description: Carleton Watkins, the photographer, was 77 and almost blind when the earthquake of 1906 struck San Francisco. Watkins's studio was downtown, and the quake destroyed everything he had: all his prints, albums, equipment, business records and glass-plate negatives; a life's possessions.

title: NAVIGANT REJECTS MERGERS AND WILL REMAIN INDEPENDENT
description: Navigant Consulting Inc., the largest United States adviser to electric and natural gas utilities, said yesterday that it had decided to remain independent after completing a review of alternatives that included a sale to another company. Last month, Navigant hired Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. to explore its options after other companies had expressed interest in combining operations. Navigant did not identify the other companies. Navigant, based in Chicago, has a market value of about $1.8 billion and had sales of $266.9 million last year. Navigant, which changed its name in July from Metzler Group Inc., said it would seek to increase profits by expanding its existing business and making acquisitions. Its shares fell $3.1875, to $41.9375.

title: Environmental Control
description: Despite managing a record nine teams into the post-season, Bobby Cox does not seem to get his share of attention as one of the better managers in the game. Many people apparently feel he just rides the arms of his pitchers to the playoffs. But his pitchers don't feel that way. Tom Glavine, the Braves' starting pitcher in tonight's game, credits Cox with creating the environment that has made it possible for the team to win season after season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLOTT, CHARLES
description: CLOTT-Charles. On October 13, 1999. Husband of Eleanor. Father of Gail. Father-in-law of the late Norman Segal. Grandfather of Phoebe, Alexis and Sophie Segal. Brother of George Clott, Belle Gross and Ruth Eisenoff. Private graveside services were held on October 14, 1999.

title: A Prostitute Undone by Ambition
description: The high-rolling life has rarely seemed less appetizing in a movie than it does in ''A Girl Called Rosemarie,'' a period drama (based on an actual scandal) set in the 1950's that looks back at the Champagne-guzzling days of West Germany's postwar ''economic miracle'' with a curdling cynicism. This debut film, directed by Bernd Eichinger, has the blunt, straightforward style of a well-made mini-series. But its attitude toward its characters is so cold that after about two hours, all you can feel about these ravenous climbers is that they richly deserve one another.

title: Japanning Boston Style, Circa 1720
description: For the colonists of Boston in the 1700's, the height of high style was japanning, a Western technique invented in the 17th century to imitate ancient Oriental lacquer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEUDERT, MONIQUE
description: BEUDERT - Monique. The Trustees, artists, and staff of Studio in a School mourn the passing of their good friend and colleague, Monique Beudert. Her love of art and passion for sharing it with young people should serve as examples to us all. She will be sorely missed. Agnes Gund, Founder Thomas Cahill, Executive Director The Studio in a School Association

title: Shares Halt Two-Day Slide, But Inflation Fears Persist
description: Stocks arrested their sharp two-day decline yesterday but regained little ground as investors digested another strong report on the economy and braced for another round of possibly unsettling inflation news.

title: The Republicans' Trip to the Past
description: The isolationists have finally taken control of the party of Theodore Roosevelt, Thomas Dewey and Dwight Eisenhower. With the defeat of the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty by the Senate Republicans, the anti-internationalism of Senator Robert A. Taft is in the ascendancy at the dawn of the 21st century.

title: CNET BUYS SAVVYSEARCH AND ITS INTERNET SEARCH ENGINES
description: Cnet Inc., which runs Internet sites with information about computers and technology, said that it had bought Savvysearch Ltd. for $22 million in cash and stock to add technology that helps clients find information faster. The closely held Savvysearch, which is based in Wellesley, Mass., provides advanced Internet search capabilities through its network of portal sites. Savvysearch has about a million users monthly and integrates more than 300 Internet search engines, Cnet said. The shares of Cnet, which is based in San Francisco and had revenue of $56.4 million last year, fell $2.0625, to $54.4375.

title: Why Clinton Plea on Pact Left Lott Unmoved
description: One day shortly after Senator Trent Lott became the Republican leader in 1996, he got an urgent phone call from Secretary of State Warren M. Christopher.

title: Sports of The Times; O'Neill Grits Teeth And Bears the Pain
description: THE glare was direct and distinct, Clint Eastwood in a pinstriped baseball suit, though it was obviously unrehearsed. After one question, Paul O'Neill had heard enough.

title: South Carolina High Court Derails Video Poker Games
description: The country's largest video gambling industry faced extinction today when the South Carolina Supreme Court ruled that the state's 34,000 video poker machines must be unplugged by midnight June 30.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a grand jury's decision not to return indictments in the death of JonBenet Ramsey referred incorrectly in some copies to the Colorado Governor who raised the possibility last year of appointing a special prosecutor in the case. It was Roy Romer, not the current Governor, Bill Owens.

title: Girardi in Front of Line From Behind the Plate
description: Jorge Posada is the catcher of the future, but as far as Yankees Manager Joe Torre is concerned, Joe Girardi is the catcher of the present.

title: Clintons Obtain New Loan for House, Without Friend's Help
description: President Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton have secured new financing on the house they are buying in Chappaqua, N.Y., the White House said today, enabling them to drop an earlier loan arrangement that had come under sharp criticism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, MELVIN
description: KAHN-Melvin, M.D. The Trustees, Faculty and Staff of Mount Sinai School of Medicine and The Mount Sinai Hospital of Mount Sinai NYU Health mourn the passing of our distinguished colleague, Melvin Kahn, M.D., Clinical Professor in the Samuel Bronfman Department of Medicine, who was associated with Mount Sinai for more than 45 years. Dr. Kahn joined Mount Sinai as an intern in 1953, after receiving his medical degree from Tulane University. He served at the Bronx Veterans Affairs Medical Center, then in the United States Air Force, and returned to Mount Sinai as a Fellow in cardiology. He joined the Attending Staff of The Mount Sinai Hospital in 1959, and was appointed to the faculty of the School of Medicine upon its establishment in 1968. He was admired as both teacher and clinician for his dedication to students and patients. He will be remembered most fondly, and he will be sorely missed. We extend our sincere sympathy to his wife, Barbro, to his sons Jonathan and Mark, to his grandson and to the entire family Helene L. Kaplan, Chair, Mount Sinai School of Medicine Stephen M. Peck, Chair, Mount Sinai NYU Health Arthur H. Rubenstein, MBBCh, Dean, Mount Sinai School of Medicine John W. Rowe, M.D., President Mount Sinai NYU Health Barry R. Freedman, President The Mount Sinai Hospital

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINHARDT, SYLVIA
description: STEINHARDT-Sylvia (nee Dinerman). Devoted wife of the late Bernard. Beloved mother of Supreme Court Justice Marsha L. Steinhardt. Cherished mother-inlaw of Jeffrey C. Feldman. Services at Boulevard-Riverside, 1895 Flatbush Avenue, at Avenue L, Brooklyn, today, at 1:15 PM.

title: The Long and Short of an Author's Life
description: GORE VIDAL

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: New York Leads on Clean Air
description: Gov. George Pataki has decided to force power plants in New York State to make dramatic cuts in the smokestack emissions that cause smog and acid rain, beyond the reductions mandated by federal law. This is a salutary move that will not only help New Yorkers but may well have important repercussions nationally.

title: One That Got Away Draws Smile From Knoblauch
description: Before last night's Game 2 of the American League Championship Series, Chuck Knoblauch was discussing a defensive lapse in the A.L.C.S. This time, Knoblauch was speaking freely and even smiling. This time Knoblauch hustled away from a controversial defensive play without causing serious damage.

title: The Rangers Start Slowly Before Completely Stalling
description: The Rangers followed their most emotional performance of the young season with their most lethargic one last night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHELAN, SONDRA SICKLES
description: PHELAN-Sondra Sickles. Born in New York, a resident of Manhattan, and at times Washington, D.C., Wisdom, Montana and Paris, France. Died on October 13, 1999 after a long illness. A graduate of Barnard College, Sondra received Masters of Science Degrees at Teachers College and the School of Social Work at Columbia University. She was a practicing Psychologist. Sondra served on the Boards in New York of the Ackerman Institute for Family Therapy, The Marymount School, The Lincoln Hall Institute for Boys, the Matheson Foundation of New York Presbysterian Medical Center, Family Dynamics and also the Ethel Walker School of Simsbury, CT. She is survived by her loving family; her husband James; and sons John of Princeton, N.J., Daniel of Madrid, Spain, Michael of Los Angeles, and Melissa Roessler of Manhattan; six grandchildren and her dog Kali. Funeral arrangements are private. A Memorial Service will take place in New York with details to follow. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the Marymount School 1026 5th Avenue, New York, NY 10028.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: Japan Comes To Manhattan

title: A Papal Visit to Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: A Big Increase In DVD Outlets
description: It's taken a while, but Blockbuster has opened its doors -- all of them -- to DVD. Since the digital video disk was introduced in 1997, the country's largest video chain has been gradually giving DVD a try, increasing the number of stores carrying the format to 900 of 4,500 wholly owned and franchised outlets. By the end of the year nearly all of the stores will carry about 200 titles for rent and an additional 50 for sale.

title: Parking Is Not a Right
description: To the Editor:

title: Sanders's Returns Worrying The Giants
description: For Giants punter Brad Maynard, the thought of punting the ball out of bounds to avoid a big return by Deion Sanders is an unpalatable idea, but the coaches are wedded to the strategy and Maynard won't argue. Considering what happened last season, it isn't an unwise approach.

title: G.M. Reports Turnaround On Earnings in 3d Quarter
description: Demand for pickup trucks, sport utility vehicles and minivans helped the General Motors Corporation earn $877 million in the third quarter, a significant turnaround from a $309 million loss in the period a year eariler.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCFADDEN, BARBARA A.
description: McFADDEN-Barbara A. The Faculty, Alumni Association, Advisory Council, students and staff of the Columbia University School of Social Work record with sadness the sudden death of Barbara A. McFadden, a 1984 graduate and past president of the Alumni Association. A leader in community, church and professional activities, she made valuable contributions in human services areas, especially minority affairs. A dedicated and respected alumna, program coordinator for Columbia's Real Estate Office and former adjunct lecturer at the School, she will be greatly missed by her many friends and colleagues. Sincerest sympathies are extended to the members of her family. Ronald A. Feldman, Dean Susan A. Nayowith, President, Alumni Association

title: Notable Quotables
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Frustrated, Russian Securities Regulator Resigns
description: Russia's top securities regulator resigned in frustration today, in the latest in a series of troubling signs that the country is ill equipped to defend the interests of shareholders and foreign investors.

title: Loss to Atlanta Puzzling to Goring
description: The Atlanta Thrashers taught the Islanders a humbling lesson on Thursday.
