description: Les Nubians

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DENNING, PETER J.
description: DENNING-Peter J. On October 15, 1999. Of Jackson Heights for forty years, formerly of Chelsea. Survived by his devoted wife, Margaret (nee Clark). Mr. Denning is a veteran of foreign wars who participated in four invasions while overseas for three years. A graduated of St. Columba LaSalle Academy and Fordham University. Mr. Denning was an Inspector with the United States Treasury Department for 35 years. Reposing at Leo Kearns Funeral Home, 61-40 Woodhaven Blvd., Rego Park, Saturday and Sunday 2-4 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian burial Monday 10:15AM at St. Joan of Arc Church followed by interment at Calvary cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEPOURHIET, JEANNETTE
description: LePOURHIET-Jeannette. A memorial servcie will be held for Jeannette LePourhiet of Chez Suzette Restaurant, formerly (Crepes Suzette, Restaurant Row) who passed away on October 5, 1999. Service will be held at St. Luke's Church, 308 W. 46th on Monday, October 18, 1999 at 6PM. All are welcome.

title: It Isn't Too Many Double-Parkers; It's Too Many Cars
description: For once, there's unanimity in New York. Everyone, from Mayor Rudolph Giuliani on down, agrees that too many people are double-parking. Even drivers admit it.

title: No More the Hero
description: Lou Merloni is a native of Framingham, Mass., and he admitted that he knows the culture of the Red Sox and their fans better than his teammates do, because he has lived in both worlds. He tried to explain why Roger Clemens will be booed so incessantly when he opposes Pedro Martinez in Game 3 on Saturday.

title: Martinez Has Several Ghosts to Defeat
description: The passions of a proud city, the hopes of a plucky team and the future of a horrible eight-decade-old curse rest on the sloped shoulders of a 170-pound pitcher with a squeaky voice, a confident demeanor and a playful personality whenever he is not firing fastballs. To succeed, this pitcher must beat the best pitcher who has ever called Fenway Park home.

title: St. John's Post-Artest Era Begins Playfully
description: The St. John's men's basketball team began practice last night to the throbbing beat of hip-hop at sold-out Alumni Hall. To what extent the echoes will reverberate into March remains the big question as the Red Storm prepares for its Nov. 19 opener against Samford.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPSTEIN, BETTY
description: EPSTEIN-Betty, on October 14, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Louis J. Loving mother of Edward Jay Epstein and Linda J. Nessel. Dear sister of Mildred Fleischman. Adoring grandmother of Richard, Lori, Kenneth, Daniel and James Nessel. Proud and inspiring greatgrandmother of Jacob and Gensiana Cicero and Timothy Louis Nessel. She will be greatly missed and will live on through her art and sculptures. Service Sunday 12:00 Noon at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in her memory to The Creative Center for Women with Cancer.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BLASER, MORRIS
description: BLASER-Morris. October 16, 1966. We never forgot you. Love The Blaser Family

title: Signal to Pakistan
description: To the Editor:

title: A Mosque in Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture yesterday with an article about reports of wartime American military looting of valuables stolen from Hungarian Jews was published in error. It should have shown Gen. Harry J. Collins (left), a commander suspected of having requisitioned valuables for his personal use.

title: Excerpts From Greenspan Talk on Financial Risk
description: Following are excerpts from a speech Thursday night by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, at a Washington conference on risk management sponsored by the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency:

title: Mets Edged, 1-0, And Trail by 3-0
description: A fine start by Al Leiter, above, was wasted as the Mets lost to Atlanta, 1-0, on a first-inning throwing error. The Braves took a 3-0 lead in the championship series; Game 4 is at Shea Stadium tonight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINCH, WILLIAM P.
description: FINCH-William P. Please join friends and family at a memorial service for Will, 11:00 A.M. Saturday, October 16, St. James Church, Madison Avenue at 71st. St. In lieu of flowers gifts may be made in Will's memory to Browning School or Sarah Lawrence College.

title: Sports of The Times; Mets Down To Their Last Tomorrow
description: FOR much of the last three weeks, the Mets' frantic fortunes were framed by looking at the small picture. One game at a time, one pitch at a time. There was always a cushion, always a tomorrow, always some next time.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a brief report in the Metro Business column yesterday about the closing of the Napier Company in Meriden, Conn., used an incorrect given name in some editions for the chief operating officer of Napier's parent, Victoria & Company. He is Richard Andreoli, not Robert.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: A Japanese Exodus in Reverse; Brazilians Work Their Way Back to the Ancestral Home
description: What urges someone like Nobotoshi Uski, a 41-year-old dentist whose grandparents emigrated to Brazil in an exodus that formed the largest community of Japanese descendants outside Japan, to reverse that trajectory and move to the homeland of his ancestors?

title: DELAY INC. -- A special report; A Lawmaker Amasses Power, and Uses It
description: Tom DeLay, the House majority whip, has never been called shy about displaying his power.

title: Bradley Defends Himself Against Gore's Attacks on Party Loyalty
description: In 1995, Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey gave one of the most bittersweet speeches of his 17-year political career, announcing to a roomful of stunned and tearful supporters that he would retire the following year. Wearily, he declared that ''politics is broken.''

title: On the West Bank, a Mellow View of Eviction
description: Prime Minister Ehud Barak's soldiers are unlikely to face much resistance when they arrive soon to dismantle this illegal settlement, a funky hilltop community of beat-up caravans, young back-to-nature types and goats.

title: Governor Pataki's Friends
description: Gov. George Pataki has become the perfect leader to reform New York's cozy relationship between those who make policy and those who donate money in order to influence policy. The reason is that Mr. Pataki knows this coziness all too well. He has been nestling into New York State's comfortable system for some time now, and although he and his aides have insisted that he follows the letter of the law, that letter all too often looks like a D- on fund-raising and government ethics.

title: Clemens and Martinez Treading Common Ground of Fenway
description: On the eve of the most striking post-season pitching matchup in a generation, the principals didn't exactly play to their reputations of single-minded combatants. In this corner, Roger Clemens was talking about the beautiful fall foliage of New England. In the other corner, Pedro Martinez, wearing a soft, off-white jacket and black-framed glasses, was saying how much he respected Clemens.

title: Murdoch Says B Sky B Is in Talks to Buy Kirch Group Stake
description: Rupert Murdoch said today that British Sky Broadcasting Group P.L.C. was in talks to buy a minority stake in the Kirch Group media company of Germany and might purchase part of Deutsche Telekom A.G.'s cable business.

title: Donald H. Riddle, 78; Led John Jay College
description: Donald H. Riddle, who as president of the John Jay College of Criminal Justice changed the institution's curriculum to produce ''educated cops,'' died on Monday at an assisted-care center in Newtown, Pa. He was 78.

title: Who's a Chairman?
description: To the Editor:

title: Daughter's Death Prompts Fight on 'Date Rape' Drug
description: Students from the Oscar Carlson High School here say that when they go to parties these days, they try to keep an eye on their drinks at all times, put caps back on bottled beverages between sips and never accept a cup from someone they do not know.

title: Sprewell and Houston Paired in Backcourt
description: Allan Houston is the one with the sunny disposition and a touch as smooth as a jazz tune. The menacing Latrell Sprewell just rocks. All edge, all the time.

title: Don't Give Up on the Test Ban
description: In this town, conventional wisdom is usually far more deadly than conventional weapons. And so it was this week with the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty. After the Senate's disappointing defeat of the treaty, the Beltway coroners wasted little time issuing their post-mortems -- determining the cause of death and judging the guilty parties -- and quickly cementing the prevailing notion that the test ban had been banished, permanently.

title: Street Crime Unit Will Be Split Into 8 Pieces
description: After eight months of intense criticism since the fatal shooting of Amadou Diallo, Police Commissioner Howard Safir said yesterday that the Street Crime Unit would be broken up into eight separate units reporting to regional commanders.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: TODAY'S KEY GAMES

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''This man is a general. He knows law and order and how to get things done. We expect him to do things for the common people.''

title: BANK ALLIANCE
description: Two European banks -- Rabobank Nederland and DG Bank A.G. -- announced a strategic alliance that will merge their corporate and investment banking businesses. The new bank, to be called DG-Rabo International, hopes to enlist other partners in Europe. The banks said they had discussed bringing Caisse Nationale de Credit Agricole of France into the fold.

title: Vaccine for Infant Diarrhea Is Withdrawn as Health Risk
description: American Home Products, the manufacturer of the only licensed vaccine to prevent the most common cause of severe diarrhea among infants and children, announced today that it was withdrawing the vaccine from the market because of concerns that it could cause a painful and potentially fatal bowel obstruction.

title: Doctors' Group Of Volunteers Awarded Nobel
description: Doctors Without Borders, which sends medical personnel to some of the most destitute and dangerous parts of the world and encourages them not only to save lives, but also to condemn the injustices they see, was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize today.

title: Dresden Choir Evokes Renewal After War
description: Dresdner Kreuzchor

title: Agreement Has Led to Boom In U.S.-Canada Air Traffic
description: The last time President Clinton came to Ottawa, Canada's capital, was in 1995. He visited the neo-Gothic Parliament building to witness the signing of an abstract piece of economic diplomacy: an open-skies agreement with Canada.

title: Protecting Forest Health
description: To the Editor:

title: Santiago Journal; At 41, a Father Figure to Chile's Gay Rights Cause
description: As a rebel student leader opposing the Pinochet dictatorship 20 years ago, Carlos Sanchez Soto lived a double life fraught with danger.

title: Artax Aiming For Two Straight
description: New York's final prep races for the Breeders' Cup will be run today at Belmont, with sprinters and milers auditioning in two stakes.

title: New York Hospitals Keep Disputed Funds
description: The Clinton Administration reversed itself yesterday and agreed to let New York hospitals keep $1 billion of Medicare money that the Federal Government had been trying to get back.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURG, JOSEPH
description: BURG-Joseph. The officers, trustees and staff of the Memorial Foundation for Jewish Culture deeply mourn the passing of Dr. Joseph Burg, the esteemed and distinguished chairman of our executive committee and a leader of world Jewry. We extend heartfelt condolences to his wife and family. Rabbi Alexander M. Schindler, President Dr. Jerry Hochbaum, Executive Vice-President

title: U.S. to Let Hospitals Keep $1 Billion
description: The Clinton Administration reversed itself and agreed today to let New York hospitals keep $1 billion in Medicare money that the Federal Government had been trying to get back.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: Battles Over Turf In Health Arena; Response to a Viral Outbreak Highlights City-State Tensions
description: The first time New York City Health Department officials learned that their state counterparts were investigating the city's strange viral outbreak, the state was announcing that it had solved the mystery.

title: Swiss Freeze Bank Account Linked to Kazakh President
description: After the Kazakhstan Government asked the Swiss to look into foreign bank accounts held by one of the opponents of the Kazakhstan President, the Swiss wound up freezing an account kept for the benefit of the President himself.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANNE, BETTY (NEE DAVID)
description: MANNE-Betty (nee David) of Manhattan, formerly of Elizabeth, NJ. Died Thursday, October 14, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Philip Manne. Loving aunt of a niece, a nephew; and a cousin. Graduate of NJ College for Women. Mrs. Manne with her husband were the founders of Amalgamated Insurance Brokers. Mrs. Manne worked until her illness for the Insurance Information Institute of NYC. Graveside services at 11:00 am on Sunday October 17, 1999 at B'nai Israel Cemetery, McClellan St., Newark, New Jersey. Information: Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Rd., Union, New Jersey. Donations in her memory may be made to N.O.W., Planned Parenthood, or the ASPCA.

title: MBNA AGREES TO BUY SUNTRUST'S CREDIT CARD
description: The MBNA Corporation, the third-biggest United States credit card issuer, agreed yesterday to buy the $1.5 billion card portfolio of Suntrust Banks Inc., extending a string of acquisitions of card businesses. Atlanta-based Suntrust, the ninth-largest United States bank, said it expected a pretax gain of about $300 million in the fourth quarter from the sale. Suntrust's 1.4 million customer cards will be issued, priced and serviced by MBNA but still carry the Suntrust name. MBNA, which is based in Wilmington, Del., and other top credit card companies are buying up the card businesses of regional banks that do not have the scale to operate efficiently. MBNA shares fell $1.4375, to $21, and Suntrust fell $2.0625, to $64.375.

title: Boston Journal; A Prayer From Fenway: Let There Be Some Way
description: Consider it the ultimate pompom waving of the cultural elite: Seiji Ozawa, who has conducted the city's acclaimed symphony orchestra for 27 years, plans to take his black-clad virtuosos to Fenway Park on Saturday to play the national anthem among the crimson hose and the pin stripes.

title: DIALOGUE: Is That an Epidemic -- or a Terrorist Attack?; A Lethal Weapon We Must Learn to Recognize
description: The flurry of rumors last week about the origins of the encephalitis outbreak in the New York metropolitan area proved how anxious we are about biological terrorism.

title: DIALOGUE: Is That an Epidemic -- or a Terrorist Attack?; Bioterrorism Is the Least of Our Worries
description: The news media are fascinated with bioterrorism. After a New Yorker article this week quoted unnamed Central Intelligence Agency analysts who speculated, apparently wrongly, that the outbreak of West Nile-like fever in New York could have been the work of Iraqi terrorists, a number of television news programs reported the story. And earlier this month, ABC's ''Nightline'' aired a weeklong docudrama in which a hypothetical anthrax attack on the subway system of a major city inflicts more than 50,000 deaths.

title: With Yoshii Hobbled, Hershiser Might Start
description: Pitcher Masato Yoshii's sprained ankle was taped yesterday, and Mets Manager Bobby Valentine said it was ''wait and see'' whether Yoshii would be able to pitch Game 5.

title: Unequal Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Taming the Braves, And Losing Bitterly
description: Al Leiter performed as advertised last night, but his effort wasn't enough to propel the Mets toward that Subway Series all New York awaits. It's highly unlikely that the Double S train, the Series Special, will stop at Shea Stadium any time soon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURG, YOSEF
description: BURG-Yosef. The Officers and Staff of United Jewish Communities deeply mourn the passing of Dr. Yosef Burg, a great Israeli leader and patriot who devoted his life to Zionism and the Jewish people. Dr. Burg was one of Israel's most respected public figures who served for many years in the Knesset, as well as in numerous Israeli governments. Dr. Burg was a tireless and devoted advocate for Israel-Diaspora relations. His lifelong commitment to the sanctity of Jewish peoplehood is carried on by his son, Avraham Burg, Speaker of the Knesset and former Chairman of the Jewish Agency for Israel. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his entire family. May they be comforted among those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Charles R. Bronfman, Chairman of the Board Joel D. Tauber, Chairman of the Executive Committee Carole Solomon, National Campaign Chairman Stephen D. Solender, President and CEO

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEATING, PIERSON
description: KEATING-Pierson. Of Greenwich, CT and Vero Beach, FL. On October 14, 1999. Beloved husband of Jane R. Wettenhall Keating. Loving father of Elizabeth, Anne, Mary, David and Carolyn, and five step children. Dear brother of Nancie Hurley and Lois Learned. Graduate of Exeter Academy and Yale University. He was a founding and active partner of the executive search firm of Nordeman Grimm. He was a Board member of Helen Keller International. His generosity of spirit, humor and enthusiasm for life will be greatly missed. Memorial Mass 2PM Sunday, October 17th, Saint Michael's Church, Greenwich, CT. Please send donations to Helen Keller International, 90 West St, Suite 200, New York, New York 10006.

title: First Lady Denounces Treaty Vote And G.O.P.
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton condemned Senate Republicans yesterday for rejecting a treaty that would have barred all underground nuclear testing, saying Republicans had ''played partisan politics at the expense of our national security'' and taking a position distinct from that of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, her likely opponent in next year's race for United States Senate.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dow Jones Industrials Drop On New Fears of Inflation

title: Isolationism Is No Threat
description: To the Editor:

title: Angry Democrats and G.O.P. Trade Blame on Test Ban Pact
description: The Clinton Administration and Democratic leaders today intensified their attacks on Republicans for defeating the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty, but Republicans answered that the oratory showed once again that Democrats were more interested in a political issue than a treaty.

title: New York City Seeks U.S. Aid on Cost of Virus
description: New York City plans to ask the Federal government to reimburse it for the cost of battling a strange viral outbreak during the summer, city officials said yesterday.

title: Rebel Chief, Denying Terror, Fights to 'Free' Chechnya
description: Spitting sunflower shells or plucking them from his broad, black beard, Shamil Basayev evinced little concern for the reports from Moscow branding him an Islamic terrorist and the mastermind behind the bombings of apartment buildings that killed nearly 300 people last month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRBY, PETER C.
description: KIRBY-Peter C. On October 13, 1999. Beloved son of the late Harry and Dorothy. Loving brother of Arthur, Dorothy, & the late Harry, Jr., and John. Friends may call Sunday, 2-5 PM and 7-9 PM at Redden Funeral Home, 325 W. 14 St, NYC. Mass of Christian burial Mon., 11 AM, St. Bernards Church. Interment Mary Rest Cemetery.

title: NORTH KOREAN TOUR DELAYED
description: The South Korean conglomerate Hyundai put on hold its plans to send a team to North Korea this weekend for a 10-day survey of possible sites for an industrial complex. In a visit earlier this month, Chung Ju Yung, left, the honorary chairman of Hyundai, met the country's top leader, Kim Jong Il, who gave his approval for a complex.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KLEIN, BARRY
description: KLEIN-Barry. I miss you and love you more than words can ever say. Not a day goes by. Love and kisses always, Sherry.

title: Commerce Dept. Pays a Call On West Bank Palestinians
description: In one long day of their regional tour, American executives were whisked into an unscheduled meeting with Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel and chauffeured by armored vans into a walled Ramallah compound to break bread with Yasir Arafat.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLEMENTE, THOMAS
description: CLEMENTE-Thomas. Of Pelham Manor, N.Y., on October 14, 1999. Beloved husband of Elizabeth Dagostino Clemente, devoted father of Elia, TJ, Jody, John and Jimmy, loving brother of Angelo, Catherine Guarneri, Rose Gallucci, JeanFederici and Elia (Mike) Clemente, grandfather of 13. Reposing Pelham Funeral Home, 64 Lincoln Avenue, Pelham, NY. Mass Our Lady of Perpetual Help Church, Pelham Manor, NY on Monday at 10 A.M. Entombment St. Raymond's Mausoleum. Visiting hours Saturday and Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M.

title: A Mosque in Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: COOPER INDUSTRIES WILL ACQUIRE REGENT LIGHTING
description: Cooper Industries, the maker of Crescent wrenches and Halo lighting fixtures, agreed to buy closely held Regent Lighting to add home-security lights to its product line and create direct contact with retailers. Terms were not disclosed. Regent, based in Burlington, N.C., sells outdoor, motion-activated and dusk-to-dawn lights for home security. It had sales of $99 million last year. Houston-based Cooper, which now sells mostly indoor home and florescent lights, said it expected the acquisition to add to profit next year. It also will give Cooper direct relationships with high-volume retailers, like Home Depot, where Regent lights are sold. Cooper's shares fell $l.3125 each, to $43.5625.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE DOLLAR FALLS. The dollar fell against the yen after Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, warned Thursday night about surging stock prices. In New York, the dollar settled at 105.42 yen, down from 107.35 yen.

title: Yosef Burg, 90, Zionist Leader Served in Many Israeli Cabinets
description: Yosef Burg, a seminal Israeli political figure who was a Cabinet Minister for 35 years as a head of the religious Zionist movement, died early today at Shaare Tsedek Hospital in Jerusalem. He was 90.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHAPIRO, HYMAN R.
description: SHAPIRO-Hyman R. You are with me every moment-in my heart and in my thoughts. Ruth

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ITC LEARNING CORP., Herndon, Va., which develops multimedia-training systems for businesses, government agencies and schools, said it would cut its work force of 140 in half as it struggles with losses.

title: MAY STORES TO ACQUIRE UTAH-BASED ZIONS COOPERATIVE
description: The May Department Stores Company, the owner of Lord & Taylor, Hecht's and other chains, said yesterday that it would acquire Zions Cooperative Mercantile Institution, a retailer with 14 stores in Utah and Idaho, for $52 million in stock. May, the fourth-biggest United States department-store company, will pay $22.50 in stock for each share of Zions Cooperative. Zions Cooperative, whose stores operate under the ZCMI name, had sales of $238 million last year. The acquisition will give May its first stores in the Salt Lake City area. Zions Cooperative's shares fell $2 each, to $20, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Protecting Forest Health
description: To the Editor:

title: Though Pressed, Pavarotti Still Hits the High Notes
description: The popular Franco Zeffirelli production of Puccini's ''Tosca'' returned to the Metropolitan Opera on Thursday night, but the buzz in the house centered on one question only: could Luciano Pavarotti, just two days after his 64th birthday, still sing the role of Cavaradossi?

title: Jets Hope Chrebet's Return Will Jump-Start the Offense
description: Wayne Chrebet, perhaps the most important missing person in the Rick Mirer offense, is back.

title: White House Inquiry Still Stews As Starr Prepares to Step Down
description: At a time Clinton Administration officials had hoped that the Whitewater independent counsel office would soon shut down, lawyers involved with the inquiry said today that the office had intensified its investigation into matters that could still prove difficult for the White House.

title: SAFECO TO PURCHASE MEDICAL INSURANCE CONCERN
description: The Safeco Corporation said yesterday that it would buy the United States group life insurance and medical insurance business of ING Groep N.V. for $34.8 million. Safeco will acquire ING's Atlanta-based Medical Risk Solutions unit, which helps employers cover unexpected health-care costs. The Seattle-based company said it expected to complete the purchase by year-end. ING is the biggest financial-services company in the Netherlands. The purchase adds to Safeco's 25-year-old medical excess loss business. The insurer sells life, home and auto insurance, and coverage for corporate customers.

title: Celebrating Carole King, Longtime Queen of Pop
description: ''There's only one universal currency in this business, and that is melody,'' writes Lewis Shiner in ''Say Goodbye,'' his new novel about the rock-and-roll game. ''It's the great unsolved mystery.''

title: BRAZILIAN LEGAL THREATS
description: The chief justice of Brazil's Supreme Court, Carlos Velloso, threatened to sue The Economist over its coverage criticizing the court's annulment of Government measures to tax the pensions of retired civil servants. Justice Velloso called the criticism unfounded. The magazine is published by the London-based Pearson P.L.C. In another legal skirmish over a financial issue, Minas Gerais, the Brazilian state governed by a former President, Itamar Franco, has sued Arminio Fraga, president of the central bank. Mr. Fraga has cautioned foreign investors against placing money in Minas Gerais.

title: Glavine a Study In Steadiness For the Braves
description: Tom Glavine stood in front of his locker after the game last night, a small crowd around him, and he spoke in quiet, measured tones. Three lockers away, a much larger crowd with cameras and notepads stood in front of an empty stall, waiting for John Rocker to arrive and provide a screaming headline or sound bite, filled with fury and emotion.

title: Man Held After Attack With Hammer, Police Say
description: An emotionally disturbed man wielding a hammer was in custody early this morning after he broke into his former girlfriend's house in Ozone Park, Queens, assaulted her and a male companion, then briefly held them and two small children hostage, the police said.

title: Slowly, Muresan Works His Way Into Shape
description: Gheorghe Muresan, the 7-foot-7-inch backup center for the Nets, has spent several months trying to work his way back to being the player who led the league in field-goal percentage with the Washington Bullets three seasons ago. He has missed all but two minutes of the last two seasons, hampered by a stretched tendon in an ankle and a compressed nerve in his back.

title: STARWOOD HOTELS SELLS STAKE IN ATHENS PROPERTY
description: Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide Inc. said yesterday that it had sold its stake in the Grande Bretagne Hotel in Athens for $186 million. Starwood, based in White Plains, owns more than 700 hotels, resorts and casinos in 75 countries. The company said its majority-owned subsidiaries reduced their holdings in Lampsa S.A., a publicly traded Greek company that owns the Grande Bretagne, to 5.7 percent from 52.8 percent. Starwood said that it would continue to operate the hotel under its existing management contract. The sale is part of Starwood Hotel's plan to sell $500 million of nonstrategic assets by the middle of next year.

title: LAS VEGAS ENTERTAINMENT WITHDRAWING OFFER
description: Las Vegas Entertainment Network Inc., an unprofitable company with no revenue, said yesterday that it was withdrawing its $95 million cash offer for Jackpot Enterprises to re-evaluate the price. The move is being made in light of statements made to Los Angeles-based Las Vegas Entertainment by shareholders seeking a higher price, Las Vegas Entertainment said. The company made an unsolicited $11-a-share bid for Jackpot, which is based in Las Vegas, Nev. Las Vegas Entertainment said the offer for Jackpot, an operator of gambling machines in Nevada, may be revised. Las Vegas Entertainment fell 12.5 cents, to $2.96875. Jackpot was unchanged at $9.3125. The announcement was made after the close of trading.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, SANFORD
description: STERN-Sanford. On October 9, 1999, my son who was the love of my life passed away. He had a great love for his uncle Jack Lupu and his aunt Rusty Remin and Morris Remin. His great joy was his first grandson Jackson who was the first born of his son Jeoffrey and Linda Stern. His niece & nephew was Diane and Robert Remin and Jerry and Ira Lupu and his other aunt was Sarah Lupu. He was a man of great intelligence and unusual wit. He will be missed by all his friends and business associates. Rest in peace my darling.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BETCHER, ALBERT, M.D.
description: BETCHER-Albert, M.D. On October 15, 1999 at age 88. Beloved husband of Gertrude. Loving father of Diane Dodge, Peter and William Betcher. Devoted grandfather of Karen Trister, Allison Dodge, Benjamin Betcher and Shannon Dodge. Dear brother of Ronnie Griff. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. Sunday 11:30AM. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Alzeimer's Association, 360 Lexington Ave, New York, NY 10017.

title: STOCK INQUIRY BY SEOUL
description: The South Korean Financial Supervisory Service said it would investigate possible illegal stock purchases in a domestic telecommunications giant, the Dacom Corporation. The LG Group and the Tongyang conglomerates are suspected of failing to report major purchases of Dacom stock to the authorities. By law, a company's failure to report huge purchases of stocks can result in fines of more than 5 million won and one year in prison for the individuals responsible.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARADBIL, DOROTHY
description: KARADBIL-Dorothy, 83, died of Cancer on October 14, 1999 at her home in New York City. Contributions in her name may be sent to Jacob Perlow Hospice, Beth Israel Medical Center, 1st Ave. at 16th St, NY, NY 10003. Private interment.

title: Josef Locke, 82, Irish Tenor Who Inspired Tears, Is Dead
description: Josef Locke, a tenor whose singing of traditional sentimental Irish songs brought tears to the eyes of audiences in Ireland and Britain in the 1940's and 50's and whose career was portrayed in the 1992 film ''Hear My Song,'' died today in a hospital in Clane in County Kildare, where he lived south of Dublin. He was 82.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HESKES, IRENE
description: HESKES-Irene. On October 14, 1999. Beloved wife of Jacob. Lovng mother of Deborah Kraut and Walter Heskes. Dear grandmother of Julia Kraut, Max Heskes and Aaron Heskes. Caring mother-in-law of Alan Kraut and Lisa Heskes. Funeral service Sunday 11:30am at ''Schwartz Bros. Jeffers Memorial Chapels'' Queens Blvd and 76th Road, FH. Call 718-263-7600 for directions

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NAGER, ROMAN (RAYMOND)
description: NAGER-Roman (Raymond). Of Yonkers. Beloved husband of Edith. Devoted father of Stuart. Loving grandfather of Adam and Jessica. Dear brother of Erika Simonson. Services on Sunday, at 11:00 AM, at Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1652 Central Park Avenue, Yonkers, New York.

title: Excerpts From Speech on Retirement
description: Following are excerpts from the speech by Bill Bradley in August 1995 when he announced his decision to retire from the Senate:

title: A Landlord Whose Tenants Vanished Pleads Guilty to Tax Fraud
description: A Manhattan landlord who came under police scrutiny after the disappearance of two tenants pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal District Court to 14 counts of tax fraud.

title: What Causes Brutality? The People Nurturing It
description: When what was formerly commonplace fades to rarity, we come to think it bizarre. Whose mother still steps behind the house to throttle a chicken for Sunday dinner? Who has seen a goiter or a face ruined by smallpox? Serious private violence used to be routine, a way people settled disputes in the ages before access to courts of law and police protection brought such violence under social control. Today, because many of us never experience such violence directly even once in our lives, its origins seem inexplicable.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a German publisher's decision to withdraw ''Fragments,'' a disputed memoir about a Jewish orphan's experience in Nazi camps, referred incorrectly to an organization of Holocaust survivors in quoting its president, Leon Stabinsky, as saying that the publisher, Suhrkamp Verlag, should have withdrawn the book far earlier. It is the California Association of Child Holocaust survivors, not the California Association of Holocaust Survivors.

title: Hurricane Leaves 5 Dead And Causes Power Lapses
description: Hurricane Irene brought heavy rains and strong wind gusts to southern Florida today, and led to the deaths of five people who were electrocuted near Fort Lauderdale.

title: Ask the Greeks: Can Myths Be Reborn?
description: Rhythm is the soul of Odin Teatret's sumptuous ''Mythos''; music is a frayed thread barely holding the limbs of the actors together as the rhythm threatens to shake them to pieces, and language is a murmur of anger and wonder.

title: Expert Panel Recasts Origin Of Fossil Man In Northwest
description: The ancient bones of Kennewick Man, found in the banks of the Columbia River in Washington State three years ago and hailed as one of the decade's most significant archaeological finds, cannot be linked to any modern American Indian tribes or to Europeans, a scientific panel has concluded.

title: Futility and Frustration Meet the Mets
description: Mike Piazza kicked first base as his eighth-inning fly ball was caught, a sudden and lonely gesture of frustration interrupting an evening of creeping, vexing futility. The Mets went down terribly quietly to the Braves last night at Shea Stadium, 1-0, and, for all the thrilling comebacks, heart-stopping hits and headline-grabbing bombast of the last three weeks, their season is now a whisper away from being finished.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUSANO, MICHAEL C. SR.
description: CUSANO-Michael C. Sr. of West Hempstead suddenly on October 14, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Lillian. Devoted father of Michael, Christopher and his wife Kara, Maria, and Stephen. Dear brother of the late Patricia. Fond cousin of John. Visiting hours will be Saturday 7-10PM and Sunday 25 & 7-10PM at the Krauss Funeral Home, Inc. 1097 Hempstead Tpke, Franklin Square, LI. Funeral Mass Monday 10 AM at St. Thomas the Apostle RC Church, West Hempstead. Interment following at Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, NY. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Stroke Foundation or the American Cancer Society.

title: BIG SELLOFF CAPS DOW'S WORST WEEK SINCE OCTOBER '89
description: A jittery stock market dropped sharply yesterday after an inflation report showed prices rising at an unexpectedly rapid rate and Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, alarmed investors by warning that the stock market might be riskier than many people believe. The market suffered its worst week in a decade.

title: The Tories Think That They Have a Campaign Issue: The Euro
description: Sensing that his beleaguered party has found an issue to cut into the governing Labor Party's domination of Britain's public life, the Conservative leader, William Hague, said today that he would tour the country to rally Britons against the European common currency.

title: EL PASO ENERGY IS ADDING CRYSTAL GAS STORAGE
description: El Paso Energy, one of the largest United States operators of natural gas pipelines, said yesterday that it would buy Crystal Gas Storage Inc. for about $208 million in cash and assumed debt. El Paso will pay $57 for each share of Crystal common stock and $1 for each share of Crystal preferred stock and assume about $40 million in debt, a Crystal Gas spokesman said. Crystal, based in Shreveport, La., owns two gas storage operations near Hattiesburg, Miss., and stakes in other gas properties in Arkansas and Louisiana. Shares of Houston-based El Paso Energy fell $1.0625, to $40.375. Crystal was up $1 a share at $46 before its trading was halted.

title: The Noise of Democracy Begins to Be Heard in Indonesia
description: The President's head snapped up in surprise. In the middle of his speech late Thursday night, someone was pointing a finger and shouting.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS RISES. Natural gas rose as utilities bought supplies in anticipation of colder weather and increased demand. In New York, natural gas for November delivery rose 14.1 cents, to $2.975 for a million B.T.U.'s.

title: Senate Democrats Win Virtual Guarantee of Test Votes on Campaign Finance Overhaul
description: Senate Democrats managed to score a parliamentary victory today that appeared to guarantee them test votes next week on a wide-ranging bill to overhaul the nation's campaign finance laws and on a more limited measure to ban unregulated donations to political parties.

title: Gore on Treaty
description: This is a new 60-second commercial made in the wee hours of Oct. 14 by Vice President Al Gore. Mr. Gore says he conceived the idea for the commercial as he received word during a flight to Seattle that the Senate had rejected the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty -- the first major treaty the Senate has rejected since the Treaty of Versailles setting up the League of Nations in 1920. This is the first commercial of his campaign.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEINTRAUB, SHEILA
description: WEINTRAUB-Sheila. 10/16/40- 10/20/90. Cherished mother, not a day goes by... Alliso

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, MELVIN, M.D.
description: KAHN-Melvin, M.D. The faculty and staff of the Samuel Bronfman Department of Medicine of the Mount Sinai School of Medicine and Mount Sinai NYU Health mourn the loss of our esteemed colleague Dr. Melvin Kahn. Dr. Kahn first came to Mount Sinai in 1953 as an intern and went on to advanced training in cardiology and renal disease at Mount Sinai and the National Institutes of Health. Based on his distinguished research contributions, his caring and expert care of his patients, and his devoted and loving service to Mount Sinai, he has served with distinction as Clinical Professor of Medicine since 1984. He was a leader in housestaff recruitment and was a wonderful role model for young physicians. We will greatly miss his warmth, his sense of humor, and his friendship. We extend our sincere condolences to his family. Barry S. Coller, M.D. Chairman

title: The Peace Prize
description: In 1995 dozens of humanitarian organizations were working to feed, house and care for the health of Rwandan refugees in camps just over the border in Zaire. The camps were full of fleeing Rwandan Hutus -- and, it gradually became apparent, full of Hutu soldiers guilty of genocide, who were directing food and other aid to their own troops. A large portion of food was going not to needy innocents, but to support the reorganization of a genocidal army.

title: Remorseful Terror Conspirator Gets an 11-Year Sentence
description: A convicted terrorist who cooperated with the Government's investigation of the plot to blow up the United Nations and other landmarks in New York was sentenced yesterday to 11 years in prison after he made a tearful apology and strongly denounced terrorism, saying it was ''evil and ungodly.''

title: Places in the Heart (and Brain)
description: Steve Young was hit in the head. Knocked woozy. More than that, it injured his brain, causing major consternation and concern among his doctors, family, friends, teammates, coaches and fans. Many warned of permanent danger if he returned to football. Many tried persuading him to quit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHELAN, SONDRA SICKLES
description: PHELAN-Sondra Sickles. The Marymount School Board of Trustees, administrators, faculty and the entire School community mourn the death of our beloved friend, teacher, colleague and trustee, Sondra Phelan. A valued member of the Board, Sondra shared with each of us her wise counsel, love of children and courageous spirit. We will miss her friendship, wit, wisdom and compassion. We extend our deepest sympathy to her husband, James; daughter, Melissa; sons, John, Daniel and Michael, six grandchildren, and her entire loving family. Kathleen Fagan, RSHM Headmistress The Board of Trustees

title: Newark Archbishop Joins Brooklyn Art Dispute
description: The leader of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Newark added his voice today to those condemning a painting of the Virgin Mary with clumps of elephant manure in the ''Sensations'' exhibit at the Brooklyn Museum of Art.

title: CANADIAN INFLATION PRESSURE
description: Canada's consumer price index rose by three-tenths of a percent in September, a 2.6 percent annual inflation rate, which is the highest since June 1995, Statistics Canada reported. The core inflation rate, excluding energy and food prices, also was 2.6 percent. The investment dealer Nesbitt Burns Inc. said the core rate, which was less than 1 percent at the beginning of the year, ''appears poised to move higher as rising energy costs spill into other prices.''

title: OIL GIANT REVISES ACCOUNTING
description: Brazil's big oil company, Petroleo Brasileiro S.A., reduced shareholders' equity by about 4.8 billion reais, or $2.4 billion, as it shifted its accounting practices to United States standards in preparation for listing its shares in New York. Petrobras, as the company is called, changed the way it accounts for drilling operations, pensions and health plans. The Government, which owns a controlling stake in Petrobras, is opening the country's oil-exploration industry to competition from outside companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALONEY, RAY (FORMERLY METH)
description: MALONEY-Ray (formerly Meth). Died peacefully October 6, 1999, Fort Lauderdale, FL, at age 86. Loving mother of John and William. Caring mother-in-law of Irene and Dale.

title: Shots Fired at Irvington Mayor's House
description: With a fresh bullet hole in her front door, Mayor Sara Bost said today that someone had fired several shots into her house Thursday morning in what she believed was an effort by a vandal to intimidate her after a confrontation last month.

title: Irving Siders, 81, Producer Who Took Shows on the Road
description: Irving Siders, a producer who exported the sights and sounds of Broadway to theaters across the nation, died on Wednesday at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 81 and lived in Manhattan.

Crowell Baker; a daughter Janann Telitz and a granddaughter Leigh Telitz. Memorial service Monday, October 18, 11AM, Trinity-St. John's Episcopal Church, 1142 Broadway, Hewlett, NY (516) 374-1415. Interment private. In lieu of flowers memorial gifts may be sent to Trinity-St. John's Church or to Family Consultation Service, 216-10 Jamaica Av, Queens Village, 11428

description: TIMONEY-Peter. In Framingham, MA. Formerly of Brooklyn. October 14. Husband of Sylvia (Pappalardo) and father of Christopher, Lisa and Laura. Funeral mass Monday at 9AM, St. Bridget's Church, Route 9, Framingham. Visitation, McCarthy Funeral Home, 11 Lincoln St., Framingham, Sunday, 3-7PM. Memorial contributions to the Jimmy Fund, 1309 Beacon St., Brookline, MA. 02446.

title: As Damage Estimates Increase, Vote in Trenton Is Set on Flood Aid
description: New Jersey legislators are nearing an agreement that would provide $50 million in assistance to victims of last month's flooding amid reports that the total amount of property damage may top $500 million, twice the state's original estimate.

description: In percent

title: Modern Hunts for the Great White Whale Leave Ahab Adrift
description: ''What is it,'' Ahab cries in his last moments of reasoned thought before the chase of the White Whale, ''what is it, what nameless, inscrutable, unearthly thing is it; what cozening, hidden lord and master, and cruel, remorseless emperor commands me; that against all natural lovings and longings, I so keep pushing, and crowding and jamming myself on all the time?''

title: A Monk in Exile Dreams of Return to Vietnam
description: From where he sat in the afternoon sunlight, the autumn foliage overspreading the nearby hills, the Zen Buddhist monk Thich Nhat Hanh could survey a former horse farm now called the Green Mountain Dharma Center, a place for Buddhist study and the future home of a monastery for several dozen monks like himself.

title: LAMB COMPLAINT FILED
description: Australia and New Zealand have formalized their dispute over lamb trade with the United States after informal talks failed. The two countries are challenging the imposition by the United States of a three-year quota on lamb imports and have asked the World Trade Organization to establish a panel to resolve the dispute. In 1998, the imports were worth about $140 million, an amount American commercial lamb farmers called a threat to their business.

title: The Yankees Can Afford a Moment of Laughter
description: Allen Watson entered Game 2 in the eighth inning to face Lou Merloni and was promptly ordered to walk him. It was the only batter Watson faced before Manager Joe Torre replaced him.

description: There has been so much concern, indeed, angst and heartache devoted to the Giants' bungling offense this week, that it's easy to forget that their defense faces a host of problems, all of them wrapped up in Monday night's opponents, the Dallas Cowboys.

title: Jury Hears A Confession In Killing
description: A flat, unemotional videotape confession by a schizophrenic man accused of pushing a young woman to her death in front of a speeding subway train was played to a Manhattan jury yesterday as prosecutors concluded the presentation of their murder case against him.

description: When Thomas Stasko, a University of Maryland graduate student, signed up for a French language immersion program in a foreign university, he decided to go to there by car.

description: Steven Ondieki of Kenya, 23, a graduate student at Fairleigh Dickinson who won the Met Intercollegiate Association title earlier in the year, captured the five-mile IC4A championship in 24 minutes 24 seconds at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx yesterday.

title: When the Market Crashed And Bridge World Began
description: The world's oldest bridge magazine will celebrate its 70th birthday this month. It is The Bridge World, which was founded by Ely Culbertson in October 1929, just as the stock market was collapsing. He intended it to publicize his bidding system, books and various commercial enterprises, but it gradually grew in stature and became the choice of good players everywhere who wanted to know about developments in the game.

title: Doctors Taking Control
description: The growth of managed-care health plans since the mid-1990's brought the explosive rise of health-care costs to at least a temporary halt. But cost control antagonized both physicians and patients. Physicians choked on constraints that insurance companies slapped on their income and professional autonomy. Patients complained that denials by H.M.O.'s of treatments recommended by physicians amounted to profit-driven betrayal.

title: Asarco Accepts Grupo Mexico's $1.18 Billion Takeover Bid
description: Asarco Inc. said yesterday that its board had voted to accept a sweetened $1.18 billion all-cash takeover bid from Grupo Mexico A.G. and that it planned to break its $1.17 billion cash-and-stock merger agreement with the Phelps Dodge Corporation.

description: If there is such a thing as a good coup, this one is winning raves in the bazaars of Rawalpindi.

Cherished and beloved husband of Linda, adored father of Craig and Scott, devoted son-inlaw of Martha Rosner, loving brother of Harriet and brother-inlaw of Herb, Charles, Sheila, David, Judi, Louis and Marcy and very special uncle to his many nieces and nephews. Steve will be remembered for his extraordinary love of family, friends and his passion for life. Services on Sunday, October 17th at 1:45 PM, Temple Beth Abraham, Leroy Avenue, Tarrytown, New York.

title: The Mentor Conservatives Turn to for Inspiration; A Gadfly and Confessor To a Harvard Lineage
description: It is the first day of the semester, and Harvey C. Mansfield has once again drawn a standing-room-only crowd of Harvard students to his course on the history of ancient and medieval political philosophy.

title: NORSTAN HIRES DONALDSON, LUFKIN TO ASSESS OPTIONS
description: Norstan Inc., a technology and communications-services provider, said yesterday that it had hired the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation to help it assess strategic options, including a sale of the business. The company said it was discussing possible combinations, without specifying what companies are interested in merging with or buying it. Minneapolis-based Norstan, which provides phone systems and other communications equipment and services, said the discussions may not result in a transaction. Before trading was halted, Norstan' shares rose $1.3125, to $8.50. At that price the company's stock is worth more than $92 million.

title: J. Franklin Hyde, 96, the 'Father of Silicones'
description: J. Franklin Hyde, a chemist who decades ago turned a useless sticky goo into a common family of industrial raw materials called silicones and who also invented a process for making an almost-pure glass used today in fiber optic technology, died Monday at his home on Marco Island, Fla. He was 96.

title: A DIFFERENT LENS
description: A thousand years ago, the ordinary person had no last name, and the self was subordinated to church and king. Then came the Renaissance explosion of scientific discovery and humanist insight and, as both cause and effect, the rise of individual self-consciousness. Man replaced God at the center of earthly life. In the fifth of six special millennium issues, an examination of the self at the center of the universe. In The Times Magazine

title: INTEREST IN CALVIN KLEIN
description: The world's No. 1 maker of luxury goods, LVMH-Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton S.A., is interested in Calvin Klein Inc., the New York fashions and fragrance maker that is seeking a possible alliance or merger, an LVMH spokesman said. The statement confirmed comments from the LVMH chairman, Bernard Arnault, at the opening of a Sephora cosmetics store in New York this week.

title: Show Tunes An Atonalist Wrote Before He Converted
description: Perhaps there is a parallel universe in which Milton Babbitt's early musical theater works were such resounding successes that he decided not to pursue his interest in abstruse atonal music (leaving that to, say, Jerome Kern) and instead composed Broadway classics. The soprano Dawn Upshaw, with James Levine at the piano, offered a glimpse of that universe on Sunday when the Met Chamber Ensemble, a group of musicians from the Metropolitan Opera, gave its first concert of the season at Weill Recital Hall.

title: Russian Troops Said to Expand Drive Across Chechen River
description: Markedly expanding their operations in the rebellious republic of Chechnya, Russian troops have crossed a strategic river and apparently control a ridge from which they could bombard the airport and suburbs of the capital, Grozny, Chechen officials said today.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARGITAY, ELINOR
description: HARGITAY-Elinor, of White Plains. Deeply beloved wife, mother, grandmother and friend to many, died unexpectedly Thursday, October 14 at White Plains Hospital with family by her side. Her passing leaves a void in the life of everyone who knew her. A health care professional and tireless volunteer, she was revered by the patients under her care and touched the lives of countless numbers of people. She was the adored wife of Dr. Bartholomew Hargitay; widow of Dr. Alexander Borsiczky; loving mother of Sandor and Veronika; cherished grandmother to Alexandra, Jessika, Maita, Edward, James, Maxwell and Alexander, and beloved mother-in-law to Sarah, Thompson and Barbara. Services will be held at 10 a.m. Monday at the Ethical Culture Society of Westchester, 7 Saxon Wood Road, White Plains. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Meals on Wheels of White Plains, 12 Ridgeview Avenue, White Plains, NY 10606.

As he continued talking, Stanley shifted the soda cup from his left hand to his now unencumbered right hand. The outside of the wrist was red, but little damage showed.

title: The Same Old Song? Homages as Updates
description: Once upon a time, a meeting between elite and popular culture was a rare, startling clash. Later it became the stuff of comedy, and by now, it's just one more bit of everyday postmodernism. Yet the urge to mix the classic and the current still strikes, usually among artists who, with an artist's necessary narcissism, see themselves reflected in the past.

title: Political Memo; For Giuliani, Making Most Of Artful War With Elite
description: When Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani complained this week about New York's ''alleged intellectual elite,'' he exposed once again a chasm between himself and what he has called one of the largest, nonthinking special-interest groups in the city. And although his friends and his critics agree that his feelings are real, the Mayor also seems likely to try to capitalize on his war with the elite in his all-but-certain Senate campaign.

title: It Takes All Kinds; Lassie: A Friend Indeed
description: Poor Lassie. Since her debut in 1938, in a short story in The Saturday Evening Post by Eric Knight called ''Lassie Come Home,'' the steadfast collie has endured an unimaginable string of horrors on our behalf. She has been shot at and stolen, trapped on cliffs and in mine shafts, caught in flash floods and blinding snowstorms, injured by everything from wild boars to lightning bolts, even carried away in a hot-air balloon.

description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Perils of the Poppy
description: ''Farewell to smiles and laughter, farewell to peace of mind! Farewell to hope and to tranquil dreams, and the blessed consolations of sleep!'' So Thomas De Quincey wrote in ''Confessions of an English Opium-Eater'' in 1822. He was among the first of many writers, artists and musicians who found themselves addicted to opium. In OPIUM: A Portrait of the Heavenly Demon (Chronicle, $22.95), Barbara Hodgson chronicles the effects the narcotic had, both positive and negative, on many of the artistic lights of the 19th century. She also analyzes the drug's effect on the general population of China, India, Britain, France and the United States. In fact, the economies of both Britain and France were so dependent on the opium trade that when China tried to stop it, the European powers made war in 1839 and again in 1856. Hodgson, the author and designer of two illustrated novels, ''The Sensualist'' and ''The Tattooed Map,'' intersperses photographs and woodcuts of addicts in opium dens throughout the book. She also includes movie stills and reproductions of the covers from magazines and books to highlight the strange fascination opium has exerted on our culture. Of special note is the cover of a 1958 edition of Claude Farr re's 1904 novel ''Black Opium''; it features a naked, voluptuous blonde rising out of the smoke of an opium pipe. The image is both absurd and sad, for opium use decreases the sex drive. But then again, as Hodgson notes in her insightful book, the pull of the drug is anything but logical. Carolyn T. Hughes

title: America's Square
description: To the Editor:

title: Backtalk; True to Form, Chamberlain Faded Away Gracefully
description: Wilt Chamberlain hated goodbyes. He could be laughing and telling jokes in the midst of a full-blown party one minute, then if you turned your head a little too long, you could look back and he would be gone. Not a word. He simply disappeared as if by magic. Many times I was with him at volleyball matches, parties, track meets and racquetball games and felt his quick disappearances even if I never saw them. His getaways took great skill and timing, but he was famous for both. Nobody could disappear as smoothly as Wilt.

title: Ignoring the Music
description: To the Editor:

title: The Sports Story That Changed America
description: IT took Grantland Rice three tries to get it right. In 1922, writing about the Notre Dame-Army game, he led with ''Notre Dame's attack is more like a modern war offensive than anything we have seen.'' Nope. In 1923, again covering the Irish and the Cadets, he began, ''Brazil can cheer about its coffee . . .'' Definitely not. On Oct. 18, 1924 -- almost exactly 75 years ago -- he finally found the right rhythm and imagery and struck hard and clean as a Knute Rockne-coached linebacker: ''Outlined against a blue, gray October sky, the Four Horsemen rode again. In dramatic lore, they were known as Famine, Pestilence, Destruction, and Death. These are only aliases. Their real names are Stuhldreher, Miller, Crowley, and Layden. They formed the crest of the South Bend cyclone before which another fighting Army team was swept over the precipice of the Polo Grounds this afternoon. . . .''

title: Markets Turn to Mush in Tumultuous Week
description: Sometimes it is best to close the shutters, turn off the lights and call it a day, or so it seemed on Friday as overwrought investors punished stocks in Asia, Europe and the United States, then headed for cover.

title: Corrections
