As portfolio manager of the $141.4 million MFS Equity Income fund, which is intensely focused on the shares of inexpensive companies, Ms. Nurme has managed to stay competitive with her MFS peers at a time when most value managers are struggling.

title: Lab's Chicken Littles Will Be Disappointed
description: In case you were worried, the world as we know it will not repeat, not -- come to a cataclysmic end a few months from now when Brookhaven National Laboratory begins smashing atoms at its giant $600-million Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider.

title: Willing To Risk A Culture Without Labels
description: ''SHOCKHEADED PETER,'' a staging of classic 19th-century cautionary tales, opens this afternoon in New York at the New Victory Theater. Its British producer, Cultural Industry, which specializes in new work in the performing arts, is run by Michael Morris. In this article, Mr. Morris and Simon McBurney, the artistic director of the English troupe Theatre de Complicite, talk about ''Shockheaded Peter,'' the dwindling of the avant-garde in Britain and a new blurring of disciplines across the arts. They spoke in Mr. McBurney's London kitchen.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about problems in improving the Roosevelt public schools after the state takeover of the district misstated its current enrollment. It is 3,250; 2,900 was the figure for the 1998-99 year.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-16

title: Hurricane Reveals Flaws in Farm Law as Animal Waste Threatens N. Carolina Water
description: In the aftermath of Hurricane Floyd, loose regulations that helped eastern North Carolina become the nation's biggest producer of turkeys and the second biggest of hogs have come back to haunt the state's public health and its environment.

title: Deborah Cuiffo, Daniel Bratman
description: Deborah Ann Cuiffo, a daughter of Barbara Streeter Cuiffo and Frank W. Cuiffo of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Daniel Aaron Bratman, a son of Diane and Mark Bratman of Cave Creek, Ariz. The Rev. William J. Boldt performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Bronxville.

title: New York Club Wants Cup, Not Memories
description: The small alcove known as Palm Court at the New York Yacht Club's headquarters on West 44th Street may be the loneliest space in Manhattan. For decades it was graced by the America's Cup, yachting's grandest prize. But for most of the last 16 years, the tiny room has harbored only memories.

title: Rangers Hoping For Power Boost
description: Not only will Mike Richter be back in goal for the Rangers tonight at Madison Square Garden, but it looks as if Valery Kamensky will return to the ice as well. Coach John Muckler is hoping Kamensky's presence will help jump-start the Rangers' power play.

title: Mets Confound Again, 4 Outs From Off Season
description: The Mets had already made improbable moves in getting to this stage of October so why not add a couple more and keep their post-season schedule going.

title: The World: All Alone; Who Needs (India) (Pakistan) (America) Anyway?
description: FOR a few days last week, it took a split screen to watch developments in South Asia, where India and Pakistan seemed to take starkly divergent paths into the next political era. India anointed another democratically elected government and Pakistan applauded yet another military coup. But beneath the surface, are these events as different as they seem?

title: Hudson River School Just Keeps on Rolling; Artists Over the Years Have Taken Up the Mantle of the Founders of an American Genre, Landscape Painting
description: THE Hudson River School was never just about scenery. The artists who initiated and cultivated what has become the American genre --landscape painting -- were on a kind of mission roughly between 1825 and 1875. They perpetuated and reflected the idea that America was a new Eden where mankind could make a fresh start. The art also embodied nationalistic sentiments. The invention of the cotton gin and the opening of the Erie Canal pointed to a boundless prosperity.

title: Czechs' Wall For Gypsies Stirs Protest Across Europe
description: At about 4 A.M. on Oct. 13, 80 uniformed policemen marched down a central street of this depressed town in the Rust Belt of northern Bohemia and sealed it off. Within a day, construction workers erected a wall 70 yards long down the street separating the two-family homes of Czechs on one side from the decrepit communal apartment buildings inhabited mostly by Gypsy families on the other.

title: A Safeguard In a Life Estate
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EULER, ALICE (REVAZ)
description: EULER-Alice (Revaz) of Bayside, New York. Died at home October 10, 1999, age 90. Beloved wife of Henry. Loving mother of Aline, Henry and the late Joseph. Devoted sister of Marguerite Muffatto and the late Suzanne Papilloud. Cherished daughter of the late Aline (Joris) and Joseph Revaz. Reposer en paix.

title: THEATER; Looking Back Warily at a Heterosexual Classic
description: THE English are a pragmatic lot. Passionate belief or fixed opinions are something that always make your average English man or woman feel uncomfortable. Faced with a fundamentalist insisting that the Bible got it right and that God did, after all, create the world in six days, the English will stop for an embarrassed pause before continuing the ever-present discussion of the weather.

title: Tenants' Woes Continue Despite a New Landlord
description: Every day in her apartment is a trial, Pamela Sanchez says. She faces hot water shortages, air leaking through the windows, an elevator that always breaks down and a lock that does not work on the building's front door, on Tremont Avenue.

title: Naomi Botkin, Howard Fishman
description: Dr. Naomi Freya Botkin, a daughter of Evelyn and Eli Botkin of Huntington, N.Y., is to be married today to Howard Alan Fishman, the son of Judith and Martin Fishman of Brooklyn. Rabbi Arthur Schwartz will officiate at the Roslyn Country Club in Roslyn Heights, N.Y.

title: Carol B. Manzoni, 52, Lawyer Who Helped Lead Chicago Firm
description: Carol Berlin Manzoni, a Chicago lawyer whose knack for recruiting clients propelled her rapid rise in the legal profession, died on Oct. 9 at her home in Chicago. She was 52.

title: Guns Are a Children's Health Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: Caroline Bozorth And George Sayan
description: Caroline Rutgers Bozorth, the daughter of Louise Mathews Bozorth and Squire Newland Bozorth of New York, was married yesterday to George John Sayan, the son of the late Ann and Cesar Sayan. The Rev. Edward Johnston, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Cosmopolitan Club in New York.

title: Jean Shepherd, a Raconteur Of the Radio, Dies in Florida
description: Jean Shepherd, the New York radio raconteur whose rambling jazzlike monologues on the air puzzled many but delighted fans over two decades, died yesterday. He was believed to be at least 70.

title: Class Action Suit Upheld Against Utility in Blackout
description: In the first case of its kind in New Jersey, Judge Paul F. Chaiet of Superior Court ruled last Tuesday that customers of G.P.U., the electric company for central and northwest Jersey, can join a class action seeking damages for outages caused by the July 4 heat wave.

title: William Gottlieb, 64, Investor in Real Estate
description: William Gottlieb, a real estate investor who was believed to be one of the largest owners of property in the West Village of Manhattan, died Oct. 5, according to The Villager, a neighborhood newspaper. He was 64.

title: Tricks The Mirrors Play
description: Chimpanzees seem to be the only creatures, besides us humans, able to recognize themselves in a mirror, to be two things at once, the observer and the observed. Some will go on mugging longer than others, but that's pretty much where the matter ends for the chimp. For our kind, with our extreme self-consciousness and our need for metaphor, myth and allegory, the fact of a literal image in a literal looking glass is just the beginning.

title: As Competition Heats Up, Bradley Sticks to Relaxed Style
description: At a wind-whipped ceremony today following a race to benefit breast cancer research, Ernestine Bradley, the wife of former Senator Bill Bradley and a breast cancer survivor herself, had just finished addressing a crowd of runners when the master of ceremonies offered the microphone to her husband.

title: Partnership, From Cradle To Campus
description: ON college campuses, there are now ''nonsmoking'' dorms and ''quiet study'' dorms. But with fresh-faced undergraduates increasingly armed with laptops, cell phones, Palm Pilots and -- most important -- ideas, it won't be long before there are ''entrepreneurs only'' halls, too.

title: Risk Growing For U.N. Staff In the Field
description: About the only good news for the United Nations this week was that seven of its staff members -- military observers, a doctor and their translator -- were released after being taken hostage Wednesday in the breakaway Abkhazia region of Georgia.

title: October 10-16; Clintons Get New Home Loan
description: President Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton have secured new financing for their house in Chappaqua, N.Y. They now have a 30-year $1.36 million mortgage, with interest for three years at 7.5 percent and afterward at 2.75 percentage points over the one-year Treasury bill rate.

title: Of Violence, Both Real And Imagined
description: MY next-door neighbors construct a little cemetery in their front yard every year about this time, and you'd think I was the meanest mother in town because we don't have a graveyard of our own. It's that weird season when evil and levity go hand-in-hand, and this was very much on my mind last week.

title: The Season To Dance
description: A Paris disco bash, a benefit to fight Alzheimer's, Sargent works on display.

title: Foreign Affairs; Reality Bytes
description: Is this a story we will read sometime in the next year?

title: Leo Lionni, 89, Dies, Versatile Creator of Children's Books
description: Leo Lionni, who introduced an introspective sensibility to children's literature through the metaphorical characters Frederick, Swimmy and Little Blue and Little Yellow, died on Monday at his home near Radda in the Chianti district of Italy. He was 89.

title: 1991 Killing Is Said To Be Revenge for Robbery of Mob Figure's Daughter
description: On a September afternoon more than eight years ago, Vincent Bickelman was found dead, shot six times while on the lawn in front of his Bath Beach home, in what police described at the time as a mysterious killing.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: NIGHT GAME

title: Ignoring the Skips In a Latin American Beat
description: SINCE May, the Brazilian real has been declining. At the end of last week, it was at 1.98 to the dollar, not far from its low for the year of 2.15, in March.

title: Resnais's 'Same Old Song' Is, for Him, Anything But
description: WHITE-HAIRED, straight-backed, good humored, Alain Resnais seemed quite amused by the idea that it took him 35 years to have his first genuine box office hit. Of course, at 77, he could well afford to display nonchalance, what with his place in the history of modern cinema having long been assured by his remarkable early films ''Hiroshima Mon Amour'' and ''Last Year at Marienbad.'' Even so, the success of this Frenchman's latest movie, ''On Connait La Chanson,'' or ''Same Old Song,'' surprised him.

title: Another Catch-All
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: The Divine Ryans

title: Daniel Fitzgerald, Kathleen Hendry
description: Kathleen Anne Hendry, the daughter of Noreen and Brian Hendry of New Hyde Park, N.Y., was married yesterday to Daniel Paul Fitzgerald, a son of Delores Fitzgerald of Corning, N.Y., and the late John Fitzgerald. The Rev. Daniel B. Brunton performed the ceremony at St. Ann's Roman Catholic Church in Lenox, Mass.

title: Restoring the Panache to a Bronx Movie Palace
description: THE Loew's Paradise theater in the Bronx has been closed for five years, but its seedy appearance will not blemish its stature in the sentimental recollections of Bronx natives of all ages. Many of them attended their high school graduation exercises there, or smooched as teen-agers while watching movies under its starry artificial sky.

title: It Takes All Kinds; Angelina Jolie: The Indiscreet Object of Desire
description: Decadence is not an organized dogma; but I, following the Marquis de Sade, will enumerate its features.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: WHITE ROSE

title: In the Age Of Radical Selfishness
description: What little I know about the self, or at least my self, comes from a year in my life that I spent living in air-conditioned hotel rooms while reporting on various subjects of interest to readers of glossy magazines. It was during this unsettling time, which began shortly before I turned 30, that I became seriously interested in the workings of the human brain. Is the brain a computer? Is the self a fictional construction of the mind? I remember very little of what I read. What I do remember is lying in bed late at night, smoking cigarettes and reading abstruse arguments from university presses that I marked up in red and blue ink like a student frantically cramming for final exams. The air in these rooms was artificial and cold. Along with scientific and philosophical treatises, I packed flannel shirts and heavy sweaters in solid colors. When I was finished reading, I called down to the front desk and requested spare blankets, which I piled on my bed for extra warmth.

title: Nonlethal Force
description: Police departments are looking for nonlethal alternatives to subdue violent suspects. Socking them with beanbags shot from a gun is one option being tested by half a dozen departments in New Jersey.

title: Lily of the Valley: Delightful, Within Bounds
description: IT'S possible to have too much of a good thing in a garden. The danger is not so much in overplanting one thing -- say, German irises or cottage roses -- and leaving no room for anything else, but in planting something that decides to take over.

title: Bowling With Others
description: THE LADD REPORT

title: An Elmont Hot Spot for Nonstop Shopping
description: AT 5 A.M. on a recent Friday at the Home Depot in Elmont, employees were moving merchandise from the receiving area to the store aisles and washing the floor when Bill Mitchell of Garden City Park walked in. He was shopping for shelving for his bathroom. At 5 in the morning.

title: Finding Plants a Winter Home
description: HORTICULTURISTS with a little room to spare can play parent to a plant and save it from the perils of the season. The Downtown Alliance is asking the public to take home more than 1,000 plants and save them from death by frost.

title: Mount Union's Streak Hits 48
description: Division III's Mount Union College set a National Collegiate Athletic Association all-divisions record with its 48th straight victory, defeating Otterbein, 44-20, today to erase the record set by the University of Oklahoma between 1953-57.

title: Philadelphia's Mayoral Race Heads Toward a Neck-and-Neck, Smile-for-Smile Finish
description: No one ever said that this city's vaunted brotherly love had to extend to the nip-and-tuck mayoral contest that is winding down toward the distinct possibility, according to opinion polls, of the first Republican mayor in 52 years. But the sheer amiability on display lately in the joint appearances of the two homestretch contenders -- a black Democratic City Hall veteran and a white Republican businessman -- makes this a campaign to behold.

title: Teachers Are Underpaid And Underappreciated
description: Dr. Tassone is correct. The future of our country will depend on having large numbers of bright, capable individuals who commit themselves to careers in education. But this goal will not be achieved by paying teachers more money. It will be accomplished when all children are given an equal opportunity to get a good education. This will mean changing the financing for special education.

title: City Blocks East River High-Rise, Pleasing Nobody
description: The City Planning Commission has taken the middle ground in a zoning battle between a developer and residents living near John Jay Park, angering both sides.

title: When Deadwood Doesn't Refer to the Table
description: THOUGH their numbers have been pushed downward in recent years, they are still far from an endangered species: deadwood directors who occupy seats on corporate boards but rarely bother to attend meetings or keep abreast of company matters.

title: Margaret Dower And John Kuhn
description: Margaret Cullen Dower, a daughter of Carol M. Proom of Canton, Conn., and W. Barrett Dower of Paris, was married yesterday to John Kenneth Kuhn, the son of Mary Jane and Paul Kuhn of West Hartford, Conn. The Rev. Edward Horstmann performed the ceremony at the Immanuel Congregational Church in Hartford.

title: Relentless Artist Uses Stencil As Weapon in the Heroin War
description: When the police recently declared some success in their efforts to rid the Lower East Side of heroin and cocaine bazaars, Jim Power pointed out that the heroin trade is still flourishing in the East Village. He has spent the last two months stenciling the words ''No Heroin'' on sidewalks in and around Tompkins Square Park in a quest to rid the area of the drug.

title: Fresh Fish and, Steps Away, the Cooking
description: ''IT ain't the Waldorf, but the fish is really fresh.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JENSEN, HAROLD JIM
description: JENSEN-Harold Jim. October 16. Print and broadcast journalist for 45 years. Beloved husband of Rachel Gordon. Loving father of Denene, Heidi and Lisa, and the late Randall, and the proud daddy of Noah. He leaves five grandchildren and his sisters June and Arlene, and brother Carl. He will be missed by the many who knew and respected him. Memorial services will be held on Wednesday, October 20, 2 PM at St. Peter's Church, 619 Lexington Ave., NYC.

title: Jennifer Fetner and Joseph Saba
description: Jennifer Alyse Fetner, the daughter of Leslee and Gerald Fetner of Teaneck, N.J., was married on Monday to Joseph Maron Saba, a son of Mary and Joseph Saba of Jerusalem and Potomac, Md. Cantor Wayne Siet officiated at the Park Savoy, a caterer in Florham Park, N.J.

title: With Testaverde Out, the Jets Can't Seem to Find the Way
description: The once-impressive Jets are leaderless as they face the wannabe Colts today.

title: QUICK BITE/Mine Hill; I'll Have the Diet Fries with that
description: Healthy eating doesn't usually consist of a juicy cheeseburger with a side of fries, topped off by a hot fudge sundae. But Weight/trimmers in Mine Hill is trying to erode the stereotypes of nutritious dining by offer such normally forbidden meals. The menu features turkey meatball subs ($3.75) and chicken Parmigiana ($5.95) rather replace bean sprouts and wheat germ. The owner, Lynn A. Fehr, said the meals were made with low-fat ingredients and carefully weighed to control portion size. Air-fried french fries ($1.95) are a popular snack; instead of using oil and a deep frier, Mrs. Fehr opts for a machine that forces hot air around the fries. The result is a healthier fresh-tasting dish. Air-fried broccoli, zucchini and battered cauliflower are also available ($1.80 each). The real treat at Weight/trimmers isn't the lunch specials or the sandwich wraps. It's the low-fat ice cream, which comprises 40 percent of the restaurant's business. ''It's just the best ice cream around,'' boasted Mrs. Fehr. And she's right. Just try to resist the German chocolate cake-flavor soft ice cream topped with fat-free hot caramel all adding up to only 143 calories ($2.35 for a small). (By contract a McDonald's caramel sundae has 360 calories.) Even Weight/trimmers' hot apple cobbler coupled with vanilla ice cream (203 calories, $3.05) can fit into a dieter's regime. Other low-fat toppings include pineapple blueberry, strawberry and peach (60 cents each extra topping). The main worry for a would-be patron of Weight/trimmers is finding the restaurant. Tucked in the corner of an inconspicuous building, Weight/trimmers is marked only by a fading sign that is visible from the highway. Through the restaurant's pink door waits the ambience of mom's kitchen, complemented by an autographed photo of

title: For Best Friends
description: Who's your best friend? Somebody you met in kindergarten? On your first job? A neighbor who dropped by to lend a hand and turned into an important part of your life?

title: For Love of the Game, No Testosterone Needed
description: Lorraine Wright knows all about the Mets.

title: A Downsized Lunch Is Unsettling in Mexico
description: AROUND 4 P.M. these days, an odd calm falls over the tables at Prendes restaurant, which for more than a century has been a prime luncheon spot for mighty decision makers in Mexico's Government.

title: Tags, A Thousand Years of Identification
description: ''Signature style.'' ''Card-carrying member.'' ''Seal of approval.'' Cliches now, but at one time personal identification was a novel, even revolutionary accessory of selfhood. For much of the millennium, ordinary people did without the trappings of personal identification: passports, identity cards, signatures, even surnames.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption on Sept. 26 with an article about churches in Virginia reversed two of their identities. St. Peter's, east of Richmond, was above; Abingdon Church, southeast of Gloucester, was on the left.

title: Near-Fatal Attraction
description: THE DANGEROUS HUSBAND

title: A Break for West
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Habitats /12th Street and Sixth Avenue; A Studio Furnished In Flea Market Modern
description: SOMETIMES, apartments furnished with fabulous finds from flea markets look like apartments furnished with junk. It takes some kind of skill, or gift, or maybe it's a gene, to know how to find the disparate pieces that will come together in some logical way.

title: Clinton Foreign Policy Shaken
description: Will the humbling of the President on the nuclear test ban treaty permanently cripple his authority on foreign affairs?

title: On Your Left, the Statue of Liberty, And Beware the Flying Curry Powder
description: Tour groups. They're as ubiquitous these days as construction sites. And like Rodney Dangerfield, tour guides feel they get no respect.

title: In Concert, Searchers Retrieve Yo-Yo Ma's Lost Stradivarius
description: Yo-Yo Ma, the world's most famous living cellist, could not have planned a more dramatic and nail-biting performance in New York City yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 3 about world music misstated the given name of a Brazilian writer, one of a group of authors to whom alterna-Latino bands were compared. He is Jorge Amado, not Jose.

title: The Orioles and the Tigers Go Out and Thoroughly Embarrass Themselves
description: During what is supposed to be Major League Baseball's showcase time of the year, some of its member teams cannot seem to do enough to embarrass themselves. The Detroit Tigers and the Baltimore Orioles have produced the most blatant cases of embarrassing behavior that has made themselves and baseball look bad.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEATING, PIERSON
description: KEATING-Pierson. Please join friends and family at a Memorial Mass, 2 PM, Sunday, October 17th, Saint Michael's Church, Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers donations to Helen Keller International.

title: Sharing the Yard With the Little Critters
description: OFTEN it is hard to realize how much the garden is shared with other creatures. My property has many rock walls and this definitely means it is home to a particular creature: chipmunks.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 3 about downtown musicians' search for ethnic identity through their work referred incorrectly to the group Pachora, which is influenced by folk styles of the Middle East. It is a quartet, not a trio. The article also misspelled the surname of a clarinetist who plays avant-garde klezmer music. He is David Krakauer, not Kracauer.

title: Where Politics Is Always Local
description: FOR weeks, the streets of Washington Heights played host to an exciting political circus. A convoy of sound trucks roamed the neighborhood, blasting the names and slogans of the competing candidates. All told, the political camps printed and distributed more than 100,000 pieces of literature. Posters were tacked up throughout the area, from travel agencies to liquor stores.

title: Devils Score With Both Sticks and Gloves
description: Sheldon Souray of the Devils and Brad Isbister of the Islanders dropped the gloves before the game was three minutes old. But it was the Devils who played with more aggression and purpose the rest of the way and skated away with a 4-1 victory tonight at Continental Arena.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISER, KURT
description: WEISER-Kurt. Died in a car accident October 14, 1999. A senior scientist with IBM and Professor at the Technion in Haifa, Israel, Dr. Weiser fled Austria in 1938, served in U.S. Army and was educated at Harvard and Cornell. He will always be remembered with great love by his wife, three sons, six grandchildren (all in Israel), and by his brother John Benno in New Rochelle, New York. Condolences may be sent to: Ora Weiser, Hachshara Yishuv 24, Haifa, Israel. 9724-8251025.

title: How a Company Lets Its Cash Talk
description: ''IT was a good day,'' Ronnie Heyman was overheard telling a friend on Oct. 5, at the end of a Senate subcommittee hearing on legislation championed by her husband, Samuel J. Heyman, the chairman of the GAF Corporation.

title: In the Region /Long Island; In Eastern Long Beach, It's Residents vs. Developers
description: A FOUR-MONTH moratorium imposed last month by the City Council on the granting of new building permits in the eastern section of this oceanfront community is pitting builders who say they are replacing dilapidated housing against residents who accuse builders of trying to change the character of their blocks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANNAFIN, JOHN J.
description: HANNAFIN-John J. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of John J. Hannafin, associated with The Times from 1973 until retiring in 1993.

title: It Takes All Kinds; Faust: The Deal Maker
description: At wine-and-cheese parties and on afternoon talk shows, we like to say that history repeats itself and that historical characters return in new disguises. We speak of Milosevic as a new Hitler, Neil Armstrong as a new Columbus. Such associations rarely work, because facts get in the way of these comfortable equations. More interesting (for me), less insidious, more revealing, is to muse on fictional characters who have become real in our collective imagination, and try to see where their endless transformations have led them, here and in our time. What has become of Job, of Huckleberry Finn, of Lady Macbeth? And my favorite, Doctor Faust?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAU, HAROLD
description: BLAU-Harold. Teacher and educator, on October 16, at age 85. Loving father of Stephen and his wife Patricia, Francine Blau and her husband Lawrence Kahn and Amy Marie Blau. Cherished grandfather of Daniel and Lisa Kahn. Devoted brother of Charles and Helen Blau, Seymour and Gerda Blau, Rosalind B. Paulson, Janice Blau and brother-in-law of Molly, wife of the late Jerome Blau. Adored uncle and greatuncle. Service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., at 81 St., Sunday, October 17, 9:30 AM.

title: A Phone Fee
description: To the Editor: I recently completed a stay at the Howard Johnson Express in Charleston, S.C. At checkout, going over my bill, I noticed two $1 telephone charges, one for each night. When I questioned it, the clerk told me that was a service fee for having the telephone in the room.

title: A New York Story About Overcoming Rejection: It's Hers!
description: IN what may one day be seen as the defining moment in her career as an actor and director, Adrienne Shelly was fired last year from an episode of the television series ''Spin City.''

title: 'White Flight' Student Exploited Trenton School
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Valentine Just Needs To Manage Himself
description: WIN, lose or rainout, Bobby Valentine is always a lightning rod for the second-guess. And as the Mets stayed alive in the National League Championship Series with last night's 3-2 victory over the Braves after a daring double steal, their manager escaped what would have been the most controversial second-guess of his controversial career.

title: Uncertainty After Death Of a Landlord
description: ''The news was on the street that night,'' said Suzanne Stout, referring to the Oct. 5 death of one of the biggest landlords in the West Village. ''It was as if the Wizard of Oz had died. The news spread over the E-mails and over the wires.''

title: American Funds Aims To Allow New Share Class
description: Capital Group's American Funds, the biggest marketer of broker-sold mutual funds, has filed proposals to allow shareholders to vote on whether some of its funds could offer class B shares, which carry back-end sales charges, as an alternative to the shares with up-front loads that they currently offer.

title: VIEW; Va-Va-Va-Voom: Learning From Marilyn
description: THE sheer ''Happy Birthday, Mr. President'' gown (Lot No. 55) may go for $1 million at Christie's auction of the personal property of Marilyn Monroe, on Oct. 27 and 28. But for me, the far more revealing relics are her colander and cheese grater (No. 401), her dogeared books, many first editions (Nos. 500 to 566), and all the intimate, mundane remains from the life of a bombshell.

title: October 10-16; No Pain, Plenty of Gain
description: Natural childbirth, drug-free in all its pain and glory, may be losing its cachet. More and more women are saying no to labor pain and yes to drugs, proffered by doctors with clever new ways of giving spinal and epidural anesthetics that numb the pelvis but still let a woman walk around.

title: Error-Prone Hofstra Gives Away Unbeaten Status
description: Hofstra's Lynde Washington had the kind of game today that every defensive back fears. The University of Richmond receivers burned him three times for touchdowns and once for a long completion to set up the put-away score.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREID, MARVIN G.
description: FREID-Marvin G., Doctor. Of Putnam Valley, New York, and formerly of Eastchester, New York. Survived by wife Eunice Humphrey. Father of Maxine and Dick Haigh, Marvin Jr. and Lee Freid. Grandfather of Jennifer and Carl Luposello, Richard Jr. and Debbie Haigh, Brian Kelly Freid & Donna Freid. Great grandfather of Mickey, Nicholas, Willie & Olivia Luposello. Dr. Freid was the son of Dr. Max B. Freid and Bertha Cowen. He had two brothers, the late Charles and Dr. Julian. He was delivered at home in the Bronx by his father on January 1, 1910. He attended Washington Square College, NYU College of Dentistry, graduating in 1932 with a DDS. At that time he was appointed as Mount Sinai's first dental intern. he graduated Mount Sinai 1933 and was appointed to the attending staff. Dr. Freid met his wife in the Spring of 1933 and they were married June 5, 1937. He started private practice in 1933 which was interrupted for service in the U.S. army during World War II. He was in the Third General Hospital Corps and served overseas with the Mount Sinai Division. He was commissioned as a First Lieutenant and then Captain in 1942. He set up hospitals in various fields of action and was promoted to Major in December 1945. He resumed his private practice in 1945 at 119 West 57 Street, New York City, retiring January 1, 1984 and stayed on the hospital staff as attending dentist and as an Associate Clinical Professor Emeritus at Mt Sinai Medical School. In 1982, he was given an award for a half century of dedicated service to Mount Sinai and the community. In 1992, he received a similar award for 60 years of service. He was awarded a citation from the Town of Putnam Valley for appreciaton for community service and volunteerism. In 1993, Putnam Valley Library gave him the Virginia Connelly Award for outstanding service. His hobbies were sailing, swimming on Lake Oscawana, bridge, New York Yankees & New York Giants. Services were private, a memorial to be announced. Contributions would be appreciate to the following: Memorial gifts in Dr. Freid's name may be made to Putnam Valley Ambulance Corps, Oscawana Lake Road, Putnam Valley, New York 10579; Hillsboro Rescue Squad, 620 amwell Road, Nishanic, New Jersey 08853; and the ALS Society. He will be remembered for his generosity, concern, kindness, compassion, always thinking of others, a mentor to many, loyal and always humble.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAVON, PAUL, CANTOR
description: KAVON-Paul, Cantor. Age 75. Loving husband of Devorah Finn Kavon. Devoted father of Shira, Burt Grossman, Aliza, Moshe Deray, son Eli. Beloved grandfather of Ariel & Eytan Deray. Loving brother of Ida, Joseph Kavon, Frances A. Schloss, Morris Kavon deceased. Sister-in-law Gertrude Kavon. Beloved uncle of Martin Kavon, Judy, Maurice Stein, Rabbi Herbert Kavon, David and Susan Kavon, Robert J. Schloss, Emily Sack & Linda D. Schloss. Services Temple Beth Israel in Sunrise, Fla. Friday, Oct. 15, 11 AM. Donations to Temple Beth Israel, 7100 W. Oakland Park Blvd, Sunrise, FL. 33313 or the charity of your choice.

title: The Piano Man Sings For Baron Shareholders
description: When it comes to having a party, mutual fund types have never been able to hold a candle to Hollywood -- or even to high-spirited accountants who want to celebrate a revision in the tax code.

title: The Other Executive's Philanthropy
description: Steven A. Ballmer, the president of Microsoft, may not be quite as wealthy as Bill Gates, his boss and college classmate, nor have his philanthropic endeavors been followed in anywhere near as much detail. But he recently gained all the attention anyone could want when his comments about a ''gold rush'' mentality in high-technology stocks drove down the market, trimming his personal stake in the company by $1.2 billion in a single day.

title: A Funkmaster Comes Home
description: The Mothership landed on Oct. 6 when George Clinton, Plainfield native and funkmaster, brought his band to the Community Theater in Morristown for the second night of a monthlong national tour. The Mothership is one of the many names given to the communal musical projects Mr. Clinton has brought to life in more than 30 years since his doo-wop hit ''Testify'' for the Parliaments. After forming the pioneering psychedelic hard-rock and funk bands Parliament and Funkadelic in the 1970's and 80's, he he now plays under the name George Clinton and the P-Funk All-Stars.

title: CYBERSCOUT
description: MAPPING SOFTWARE

title: Hilary Shaw, Peter Houldin
description: Hilary Foster Shaw, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Theodore Shaw of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Peter Rich Houldin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William M. Houldin Jr. of Washington, Conn. The Rev. Terence L. Elsberry, an Episcopal priest, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the First Church of Round Hill.

title: Soft Money's Multifaceted Foe
description: CHARLES KOLB may be this city's most unlikely champion of campaign finance reform. A conservative lawyer who worked on domestic policy in the Bush White House, Mr. Kolb acknowledges that he never expected to be doing what he is doing now.

title: After the Flood; With a Billion of Dollars in Damage, New Jersey Will Be Wringing Out a Long Time
description: IT is now a month later, yet the cocoa-colored dust clings to the roads and sidewalks, the plate glass and vinyl siding, the tennis courts, teddy bears, junked cars and defunct furnaces.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 26 about Long Island relics on display in local museums misstated the age of American Indian pottery at the Southold Indian Museum. Its oldest pottery dates back 1,500 years, not 10,000 to 12,000.

title: In Salzburg, a Fresh Skirmish in the Culture Wars
description: THE 1999 Salzburg Festival was shrouded in scandal. The shock did not come from any of the festival stages, which have indeed been more inclined to turn heads in the last seven years, since Gerard Mortier became director in 1992. With mixed success and to mixed acclaim, Mr. Mortier, who succeeded the Salzburg-born conductor Herbert von Karajan after his death in 1989, has sought to de-Karajanize the festival by making it more cosmopolitan and more contemporary. Mr. Mortier has added Messiaen to Mozart, and playwrights like the iconoclastic Elfriede Jelinek to such stalwarts as Hugo von Hofmannsthal, who was also the festival's principal founder.

title: Ms. Lesch, Mr. Mesa Sanin
description: Sara Ellie Lesch, the daughter of Dr. Judith W. Lesch and Michael Lesch of Larchmont, N.Y, is to be married this evening to Gabriel Jose Mesa Sanin, the son of Dr. Alvaro Mesa Arevalo of Santafe de Bogota, Colombia, and the late Maria Eugenia Sanin de Mesa. Rabbi Joel S. Goor will officiate in the Palm House at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. The Rev. Henry Fehrenbacher, a Roman Catholic priest, will take part in the ceremony.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BETCHER, ALBERT, M.D.
description: BETCHER-Albert, M.D. On October 15, 1999 at age 88. Beloved husband of Gertrude. Loving father of Diane Dodge, Peter and William Betcher. Devoted grandfather of Karen Trister, Allison Dodge, Benjamin Betcher and Shannon Dodge. Dear brother of Ronnie Griff. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. Sunday 11:30AM. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Alzeimer's Association, 360 Lexington Ave, New York, NY 10017.

title: Tailoring Arias to Suit the Vagaries of the Voices
description: TRANSPOSITION is in the news at the Metropolitan Opera. Sir Charles Mackerras just concluded a series of performances of ''Lucia di Lammermoor'' with three large chunks of the score restored to the higher keys in which the composer originally wrote them. At the same time Placido Domingo has been reprising two of his most celebrated roles, the tragic clown of ''Pagliacci'' and the tormented Moor of ''Otello,'' with adjustments in the other direction to accommodate the autumnal range of his tenor voice. Both circumstances are being discussed extensively -- even heatedly -- and both are being a bit misunderstood as often as not.

title: Parting of the Ways at Macari Vineyards
description: AT the toughest time of the agricultural year for wine producers and with its harvest unfinished, Macari Vineyards in Mattituck has dismissed its French-born winemaker, Gilles Martin.

title: Editorial Observer; Pakistan's Dangerous Addiction to Its Military
description: It is always tempting to see Pakistan as an artificial country carved painfully out of the remnants of the British empire, a place of such virulent sectarian hatreds and corrupt leadership that only the military can hope to govern it successfully. That view has returned now that Pakistan has suffered its fourth military coup in 52 turbulent years as a nation. Even some Pakistanis who believe in democracy but were opposed to Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif welcomed military intervention to change regimes.

title: October 10-16; Drug Arrests in Colombia
description: The Justice Department said Colombia had broken that country's biggest cocaine-trafficking ring with the arrest of the ring's leader and other traffickers. Colombian officials pledged to extradite the suspects back to the United States for trial. In 1991, Colombia stopped extraditions following a wave of killings and bombings by drug cartels, but now officials are vowing to renew the process even as they brace for possible violence. BARRY MEIER

title: Many Faces of Woman, Adding Up to More Than a One-Woman Show
description: WHO could get a word in if Harriet Jacoby and Myrna Feintuch were in the room? As self-appointed director and choreographer, Myrna is in charge of the parents' show the night before high school graduation. Harriet, who is only the dinner chairwoman, wants Myrna out; she is hell-bent on a takeover by telephone. Myrna wants the mothers in sneakers; Harriet insists on high heels.

title: Laura Seymann, Jonathan Beinner
description: Laura Leigh Seymann, a daughter of Wilma and Gilbert M. Seymann of Englewood Cliffs, N.J., was married last evening in New York to Jonathan Andrew Beinner, the son of Karen and Michael Beinner of River Vale, N.J. Rabbi Meir Berger officiated at the New York Palace.

title: Picturing a Lost Boy, Drawing on Memory
description: SOME addiction counselors classify the children of alcoholics into behavioral types: the hero child, who tries to save the family by doing everything right; the scapegoat, who constantly fails and gets into trouble, and the lost child, who goes AWOL from the family dynamic and develops a private solution, sometimes with disastrous results.

title: When the Sun Revolved Around Manhattan
description: IN the years after World War II, the art world, which for decades had trained its attention on European cultural centers, aimed a spotlight on an American one, Manhattan. Some of the artists who were primarily responsible for this change were first-generation Abstract Expressionists, Pop artists and Minimalists who laid the groundwork for what many consider a golden age of Modern American Art.

title: Smokers Always Knew
description: To the Editor:

title: A Large Quake Mostly Just Jolts Californians
description: It was the big one that wasn't quite, a magnitude 7.0 earthquake that struck the Southern California desert early this morning, shaking buildings from Los Angeles to Las Vegas, Nev., prompting sporadic power failures and knocking an Amtrak train off its tracks, but producing no reports of serious injuries or damage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLADSTONE, KENNETH
description: GLADSTONE-Kenneth. On October 15, 1999. Beloved husband of Lucille of 52 years. Dear father of Adrienne (Russ) Fierman and Robert Gladstone. Adored grandfather of Ariele, Adam, Alanna & Stephany. Dear brother of Ernest Gladstone. Services Sunday, October 17, 1:15 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions may be made in Kenneth's name to the Jewish Home and Hospital, 120 West 106th Street, NYC 10025.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about a jazz concert tour based on the book ''Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil'' included an outdated scheduling note. The performance scheduled for that night at the Westbury Music Fair was canceled and no new date has been set.

title: Storm Heads for Carolinas After Soaking South Florida
description: Hurricane Irene pushed its way up the East Coast today, slipping out of Florida after knocking down trees and power lines, spawning tornadoes, leaving more than a million people without power and causing at least five deaths.

title: Taking a Dim View Of Review of Bad Views
description: To the Editor:

title: FIVE QUESTIONS for BERNARD ARNAULT; Putting Fendi Into a Bigger Bag
description: AFTER months of behind-the-scenes wrangling, a victor emerged last week in the battle for Fendi S.p.A., the Italian luxury design house best known for its Baguette bag, a wide Tootsie Roll-shaped purse that fits snugly under the arm.

title: October 10-16; New Clinton Plan for Forests
description: Ever since President Clinton came to office, he's been at war with timber companies, paper producers and others who want to preserve and expand their use of the National Forest System to harvest timber, dig mines and build roads. In his latest battle, Mr. Clinton announced a plan that would ultimately put 40 million or more acres of Federal forests into a new category that would prevent roads from being built -- and make them off-limits to commercial activity.

title: It Takes All Kinds; Werner Heisenberg: The Radical Thinker
description: In march of 1927, Werner Heisenberg submitted to a German journal of physics the paper that contained the revolutionary theory called the uncertainty principle (''On the Perceptual Content of Quantum Theoretical Kinematics and Mechanics''). At the age of 25, this descendant of a brandy burner, a master cooper and a locksmith, this child of an upwardly mobile professor of Greek who doubted all ideologies and systems of belief and who passed this skepticism on to his son -- this young man effectively sealed off for eternity what most people think of as physical reality from ultimate knowability by the human mind. He proved that it is mechanically and therefore logically impossible for anyone ever to know at any given moment the velocity and position of an electron -- two fundamental properties of any particle -- because, roughly speaking, if you shine enough light on an electron to see it, the light itself will alter the electron's velocity. Assuming there is some kind of bedrock material world, it is in a profound way not anschaulich, as Heisenberg put it -- not ''seeable.''

title: THEATER; A Family Divorce Intrigues a Grandson, Who Writes a Play
description: ANYONE who attends a performance of ''Ancestral Voices,'' the new play by A. R. Gurney opening tomorrow night at Lincoln Center Theater, must arrive at the Mitzi E. Newhouse space prepared less to watch than to listen. For 85 minutes, five actors sit in stiff-backed chairs and read their lines from lectern-supported scripts. There are no props. Gestures are minimal. The emphasis here is on the story.

title: How 'I' Moved Heaven and Earth
description: When I was on book tour with my novel ''Straight Man,'' an academic satire, the question I got asked most frequently was just how exaggerated my portrait of the academy was. By the end of the tour, I had my deadpan response down pat: ''What exaggeration?'' If the depiction of lunacy happens to be your goal, academic life requires no embellishment, I explained. The challenge, rather, is to tone things down sufficiently so that generous readers outside the academy will find the events credible. Many of my fondest academic experiences, some ludicrous, others poignant, ended up getting blue-penciled, like the true story of an eccentric old college professor who was nearing retirement just as I was beginning my career. A gentleman who appeared to have no strong views on any subject, he faithfully attended faculty meetings but never spoke at them until the end. After matters of curriculum and policy and procedure had been debated and resolved (or, more often, tabled), after both old and new business had been attended to, after the agenda for next month's meeting had been set and there was nothing left to do but adjourn, only then would this professor raise his hand and ask, ''What about me?''

title: Emily Docken, Peter Webster
description: Emily Anne Knudsen Docken, the daughter of Nancy F. Docken of Cambridge, Mass., and Dr. William P. Docken of Boston, was married last evening to Peter Grant Webster, a son of Cynthia H. Webster of Sandwich, Mass., and David A. Webster of Boston. The Rev. Bruce W. B. Jenneker performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church in Boston.

title: Is This the Place Where All the Children Are Above Average?
description: LISA GRAY, co-president of the P.T.A. at No. 6 school in Lawrence, has a daughter in the fourth grade who had never been chosen for the district's gifted-students program, called LEAP. But in the second week of school this year, the gifted-program teacher met with her daughter's class, worked with them on the subject of decimals and gave them homework.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, CLAYTON
description: WILLIAMS-Clayton. The Center for Alternative Sentencing and Employment Services mourns the passing of our dear friend, colleague and trustee. For over 20 years, Clayton worked tirelessly to set up and maintain a community service sentencing program, dedicated to helping poor, non-violent criminal offenders. Clayton made genuinely deep and personal connections; his calm and good humored presence made his friends and colleagues feel happy and valued. Clayton emerged from his earlier life, which was filled with danger and hardship with a generous and kind spirit. We love him and will always remember him.

title: Unworldly Americans
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A brief report on page 24 of the Travel section today with an article about the Mexican state of Campeche includes an outdated reference to flooding in the region. On Tuesday, after the section had gone to press, 3,000 people in the town of Palizada near the Campeche-Tabasco border were evacuated because of rising waters from the Palizada River. Before that, the region had been unaffected by the recent flooding along the Gulf Coast.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLUCK, RUTH C.
description: GLUCK-Ruth C. Beloved wife of Samuel. Loving mother of Marjorie Blackman (Stephan) & Victor. Cherished grandmother. Services Sunday, 10:30 AM, ''Parkside'' Chapels, Queens Boulevard at 66th Avenue, Forest Hills, New York.

title: Have a Best Friend? Let Us Know
description: Who's your best friend? Somebody you met in kindergarten? On your first job? A neighbor who dropped by to lend a hand?

title: Toys 'R' Murder
description: THE INTERIOR

title: A Slightly Scary Neighbor For a Catholic Girls' School
description: In the few weeks since his East Village emporium has been open, Paul Booth has seen people make the sign of the cross as they pass the door, which is splattered with red paint suggestive of blood. Others cross the street, their faces masks of horror. A tourist from Germany stared at the window display of coffins, Addams Family bric-a-brac and realistic-looking hands, then slowly backed up, her eyes bulging.

title: I'm O.K., You're Selfish
description: America's mythic sense of self rings out from the very words ''rugged individual.'' Think of the Deerslayer, Davy Crockett, Amelia Earhart, Clint Eastwood. At times, though, the stereotype has failed to ring true; in truth, individualism has run in pronounced cycles. Just in the last 50 years, it was precisely the lack of individualism that prompted William H. Whyte's ''Organization Man'' and David Riesman's ''Lonely Crowd,'' best sellers articulating public concern about the dangers of conformity. Americans, it was feared, had become too worried about fitting in, too afraid to be independent. ''Do not fold, spindle or mutilate,'' the instruction on computer punch cards, became a slogan against docile regimentation.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: WHAT IF?

title: From I.M.F. to IMF: A Trademark Battle
description: Here's a trademark dispute with a difference: A small California mortgage bank and brokerage is being sued by, of all things, the International Monetary Fund.

title: Out of the Sky
description: To the Editor:

title: Three Dandies
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Pakistan's Ruler Pledges to Curb Corruption
description: Pakistan's new military ruler is promising to give the people what they want -- an end to the country's chronic corruption.

title: Hold the Chitterlings
description: The Ladies Auxiliary

title: October 10-16; Fessing Up to Smoking Risks
description: The Philip Morris Companies, hoping to recast its corporate image and make it more difficult for new smokers to sue, unveiled a new Internet site that describes cigarette smoking as addictive and a cause of cancer. But the company, which had disputed such evidence for decades, soon confronted new demands that it submit to Federal regulation of cigarettes and nicotine in light of its acknowledgment. BARRY MEIER

title: October 10-16; Big Move by Con Ed
description: Consolidated Edison Inc. announced plans to acquire Northeast Utilities, the largest utility in New England, for $3.29 billion in a deal that could bring cheaper power to its customers. Con Edison will become one of the largest utilities in the nation, with a base of 4.7 million customers.

title: Unlikely Opponents Agree On a Riverdale School Plan
description: Mayor Giuliani and Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew struck a $30 million deal last week to expand Middle School 141 in Riverdale to include high school grades, and to do the same with a planned middle school, M.S. 368, in nearby Marble Hill.

title: Marisa Knopf, Peter Rosenthal
description: Marisa Knopf, a daughter of Suzanne C. Knopf of Manalapan, N.J., and Martin S. Knopf of Closter, N.J., was married last evening to Peter Rosenthal, the son of Roberta and Stephen J. Rosenthal of New York. Rabbi Daniel Bronstein performed the ceremony at the Hotel Inter-Continental in New York.

title: Chilean Fjords
description: To the Editor: Just as Shirley Christian was unable to book a trip to the San Rafael Glacier from the United States, so were we. Once we got to Santiago, Chile, we booked passage through the Central Tours agency there on a luxurious catamaran called the Patagonia Express.

title: State's Representatives In Washington
description: Have a problem, or an opinion? Here's how to let somebody know in Washington.

title: Too Much History
description: The True History

title: POSTINGS: From $9 Million to $18 Million; At 65th and Fifth, 10 New Condos
description: A development group has begun reconstruction of the limestone office building at 838 Fifth Avenue, at 65th Street, noted for the inscription ''Love Thy Neighbor as Thyself'' on its facade, into 10 condominiums with offering prices ranging from $9 million to $18 million.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Lofts Welcoming Visitors

title: Face Painting, Races and Protective Suits
description: It was a fun family day at the nuclear research laboratory.

title: Reebok Got Off Lightly For Sidewalk Ads
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BERLER, ANDREW
description: BERLER-Andrew. 1949-1994. On the anniversary of your 50th birthday, we love you and miss you more than ever. Mom, Dad, Ellen

title: It Seemed Easy: Sell Shampoo To the Chinese
description: IT seemed a good idea at the time. When a business acquaintance named Jerome Axelrod approached John Paul DeJoria, the co-founder of the Paul Mitchell line of hair-care products, with a plan for distributing the company's shampoos, detanglers and sculpting sprays in the People's Republic of China, Mr. DeJoria jumped at the chance.

title: FIRST PERSON; Natural History, Condensed
description: IN ''The Sound of Music,'' as Maria leaves the abbey to become a governess, she says to herself, ''When the Lord closes a door, somewhere he opens a window.'' Like Maria, I've taught children to sing, though not in size order. However, these particular words of hers never really struck home until recently. Last month I lost a tree, the largest of our block, a casualty of congested city living. A short while later, through some urban miracle, I had a cricket.

title: Report Calls for New Focus On Aid for Minority Students
description: A task force of prominent educators has found that the performance gap between black, Hispanic and Native American students and their white and Asian counterparts persists across the socioeconomic spectrum, from kindergarten through graduate school, according to a report being released today.

title: Terra Incognita
description: I don't believe in ghosts. But standing inside the fallen stone walls of the ruins of Yapashi, I can almost feel the presence of the hundreds of souls who once inhabited this abandoned plateau. Their disappearance left the pueblo -- isolated deep inside the Bandelier wilderness in northern New Mexico -- one of the loneliest places on earth. About the only sound, other than wind blowing through ponderosa pines in the canyon below, is the ringing of blood rushing through the vessels in my eardrums, the buzzing of a brain contemplating the weird feeling of being alive.

title: Tracking Down Pedophiles Gains Impetus
description: JEANINE PIRRO, the county's District Attorney, was fuming. It was bad enough that Patrick Murphy, 45, of Port Chester, a former Pepsico executive, had been indicted for sodomy and having sex with a 15-year-old boy, but he was also HIV-positive.

title: Spraying Concerns
description: Some Westchester residents and elected officials are concerned about the effects of aerial spraying -- despite the County Health Department's assurance that the chemical used to kill disease-carrying mosquitoes is not harmful to humans.

title: Where Baseball Bows to World Series of Dominoes
description: As the sun dipped behind the Harlem River yesterday afternoon and, somewhere far away, the Yankees were being dismantled by the Red Sox, the tension under the old red gazebo in the South Bronx playground was growing so thick you could cut it with a cuchilla.

title: Katherine Jones And Harry Koster
description: Katherine Elizabeth Jones and Dr. Harry Koster were married last evening at the Masterview Studio in Manhattan. The Rev. Dr. Robert G. Stephanopoulos, a Greek Orthodox priest, officiated.

title: Breaking Away: A Television Tradition
description: Mary Tyler Moore did it, despite being the consummate single woman. So did Archie Bunker -- seven times. Even the feuding, oil-rich Ewing clan, so firmly rooted in Dallas, managed to extend its tentacles all the way to the California Coast. All three of these long-running television programs from the 70's and 80's begat successful spinoff series featuring regular cast members from the originals. And this fall, several returning shows are attempting to do the same.

title: Miss Burtschy, Mr. Sacerdote
description: Annagret Meredith Burtschy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence R. Burtschy of Charleston, S.C., was married there yesterday to Alexander Corrado Sacerdote, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter M. Sacerdote of New York. Bishop David Thompson of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Charleston performed the ceremony at the Cathedral of St. John the Baptist.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAPRON, MARGARET (PEG) M.
description: CAPRON-Margaret (Peg) M. Age 78. Of Mountain View, CA. Died October 5, 1999. Beloved wife for 57 years of William (Bill) M. Capron. Devoted mother of Alex, Margie, Bear and Seth. Tireless champion of human rights and social justice.

title: Make Room for Daddies
description: The Velveteen Father

title: Faces Are the Focus Of a Baltimore Exhibit
description: The Impressionists may be best known for their glorious landscapes, but Monet, Manet, Cezanne, Degas, Cassatt, Renoir and their colleagues also changed the art of portraiture. ''Faces of Impressionism: Portraits from American Collections,'' which opened on Oct. 10 at the Baltimore Museum of Art, illustrates the results.

title: Lottery's Opponent
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Brownfields Are Drawing Developers
description: HUGE trucks rumble over uneven ground overlooking Upper New York Bay, carrying loads of construction debris and other fill that are reshaping a site that was the town dump for most of the century. The old dump is to be capped with 4.5 million cubic yards of sediment dredged from nearby shipping channels, and is then to be covered with several feet of clean dirt to create Hudson County's first 18-hole golf course.

title: 'White Flight' Student Exploited Trenton School
description: To the Editor:

title: Going Too Far
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Promoting Violence
description: To the Editor:

title: Protecting the U.N.'s Rescuers
description: Last week was one of tragedy for the United Nations. On Monday, Valentin Krumov, a Bulgarian, was mobbed and then shot by ethnic Albanians on his first day working for the U.N. mission in Kosovo, apparently after being mistaken for a Serb. The next day in Burundi, Luis Zuniga, a Chilean who was the Unicef representative there, and Saskia von Meijenfeldt, a Dutch employee of the World Food Program, were murdered. Their equipment was stolen and they were executed by Hutu rebels upon entering a refugee camp to evaluate conditions.

title: It Takes All Kinds; Heloise: The Ultimate Lover
description: She and the millennium were young together. Heloise was born in 1100 or 1101. At 17, she became a student of Peter Abelard and then swiftly his lover, and by 19 her life in the world was over.

title: The Me Veneration
description: Once upon a time, a beauty named Narcissa committed the sin of being choosy. As punishment, the gods had her fall in love with her own reflection, thus wasting a perfectly good wardrobe, as she was the only one to admire it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, DAVID
description: STEIN-David. Artist, passed away on October 14 in Bordeaux, France at age 64. He will be remembered by his family and friends for his unique talent and charismatic personality. He is survived by his four children, his son Emmanuel, from New York and Cecilia, Fred and Jason from California.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEPETIN, MORTON
description: SHEPETIN - Morton. Beloved brother of Barbara, father of Seth and Stuart, grandfather of Scott and Robert.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGUIRE, MARGARET JOSEPH (NEE MAUNDSLEY)
description: McGUIRE-Margaret Joseph (nee Maundsley), October 9, 1999. Age 91. Of Calgary, Canada; formerly Astoria & Rocky Point, L.I. Widow of Walter B. McGuire (1963) IATSE #

title: Kate Cote and Peter Gillin
description: Kate Fariss Fraser Cote, the daughter of Mrs. Marcel O. Cote of New York and the late Mr. Cote, was married yesterday to Peter James Gillin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John T. Gillin of Devon, Pa. The Rev. James L. Burns performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York.

title: The Home of Jai Alai
description: THE BASQUE HISTORY

title: As Sons Throw Spirals, Dads Throw Punches
description: The Sterling Youth Athletic Association field is in a usually tranquil vale a few blocks from the White Horse Pike, one of the busier highways in South Jersey. Across Vassar Avenue from the ballfields and the playground in this working-class town is a neat row of bungalows, with small well-trimmed lawns and tall trees lining the curb.

title: Brilliance and Promise Will Only Go So Far
description: EARLY on in ''Fight Club,'' I found myself exulting at the scary wit with which David Fincher was pulling things off and racking up a score. It was like watching some nerveless kid play pinball in a minefield, his body flexed into the machine, his shoulders and his arrogant hips seeming to drive it into Charlie Parker choruses of bell-ringing. It's a wonder to see such prowess, and in ''Fight Club'' (which opened Friday) I'm talking about not just the creation of some grunge-heaven city but the macabre yoking together of gallows humor and smash-mouth violence, the interplay of Edward Norton and Brad Pitt, nerd and Neo (in the sense of the Keanu Reeves icon from that empty but deeply influential film ''The Matrix''). But this is one of the most glossy and treacherous pieces of cinematic black ice we have yet encountered, with good old photography turning into effects beneath our drifting tires.

title: October 10-16; Suharto Case Is Dropped
description: Many Indonesians were angry but few were really surprised. After 32 years in power during which he and his six powerful children amassed fortunes, President Suharto saw his year-long corruption case dropped for lack of evidence.

title: Guns Are a Children's Health Issue; Follow Colt's Lead
description: To the Editor:

title: American Icon, Father Of His Country
description: GEORGE WASHINGTON may be the American icon, and the image most people have of him is the straightforward one, from Gilbert Stuart portraits and the dollar bill. Over the years he has become more an impersonal, though powerful, force in the national consciousness rather than a vital human.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHAINMAN, PEARL C.
description: SCHAINMAN-Pearl C. I love and miss you so much, but I am so glad that you are now at peace. Your loving daughter, Lynn

title: After Yonkers Teachers Strike, Some Mutual Admiration
description: THIS gritty city rarely shows a soft side, like an ability to resolve conflicts with compromise or settle old scores by shaking hands.

title: SHOPPING WITH: Serena Williams; Game, Set, Dress Me In Leather
description: UNTIL not long ago, the single greatest contribution made by an American female athlete to the history of style was that spinning plate of a haircut from the skater Dorothy Hamill -- the one that for a few minutes in the 1970's changed the look of third-grade suburbanites.

title: No Sympathy From Wendell
description: Winning the game was enough for the Mets, but there was a little extra joy in seeing John Rocker victimized for the tying and winning runs. The Shea Stadium crowd continued its vocal feud with the Braves reliever, rejoicing in his failure.

title: Q&A/Hershel Sarbin; A Retiree Who Refuses to Slow Down
description: HERSHEL SARBIN of Bedford refuses to slow down. At 74, he looks back on two prestigious jobs: president and chief operating officer of the Ziff-Davis Publishing Company until retiring in 1981, then president and chief executive of Cowles Business Media. Now he is part-time partner and senior director of a marketing firm, Peppers-Rogers Group in Stamford.

title: Bad Hair Day? Cool
description: Who: Jennifer Aniston (right), at the Emmy Awards ceremony, and Madonna, at the MTV Video Music Awards show.

title: Close Your Eyes; Open Your Ears
description: Jack Benny will join the special guests this week at the 24th annual Friends of Old-Time Radio Convention in Newark. Actually, it will be Will Jordan, an impersonator, attending as Benny and Ed Sullivan, along with Joan Benny, daughter of Jack Benny and Mary Livingstone, and several dozen stars, producers, singers and announcers.

title: Wall Street Discounts The Future
description: THERE is a ''good news, bad news'' quality to the current corporate earnings season.

title: Lifting Body and Spirit
description: THE first cable car in Israel was a makeshift contraption built during the country's war of independence in 1948. Strung 160 feet high across a valley below the walled Old City of Jerusalem, it connected isolated Israeli fighters on Mount Zion with an outpost to the west, and was used to ferry out wounded and lift in supplies. The car was a crude rectangular metal box long enough to carry a stretcher, and it was cranked across the valley at night on a cable that was dropped during the day to avoid detection by Jordanian troops.

title: Conversation; The Secret Life of Biographers
description: Judith Thurman and Jean Strouse met in the late 1970's, while both were working on their first biographies. When Strouse's ''Alice James'' was published in 1980, Thurman reviewed it for Ms. magazine. Two years later, when Thurman's ''Isak Dinesen'' came out, Strouse reviewed it for Newsweek. ''Alice James'' won the Bancroft Prize in American History in 1981; ''Isak Dinesen'' won the National Book Award in 1983. This year, both writers have published new books. Strouse's ''Morgan: American Financier'' appeared in April, and Thurman's ''Secrets of the Flesh: A Life of Colette'' is just out. Recently they got together and talked about the art of biography.

title: The Pursuit of Pleasure
description: SECRETS OF THE FLESH

title: Children's Books; Bookshelf
description: HORACE AND MORRIS BUT MOSTLY DOLORES. By James Howe. Illustrated by Amy Walrod. Atheneum. $16. (Ages 4 to 8) The adventures of three happy ''now-and-forever'' friends are halted when Horace and Morris form a boys' club, saying, ''A boy mouse must do what a boy mouse must do.'' Never fear; Dolores finds a way for fine friendship to win out. The collage-and-paint illustrations of the mice are droll.

title: Messiaen's Excursion Into Rapturous Opera
description: AS it becomes clear that Gerard Mortier will be replaced as director of the Salzburg Festival when his contract expires in 2001, a new release of Olivier Messiaen's lone, immense opera ''St. Francois d'Assise,'' recorded in performance at the festival, is especially timely. The production of this opera was the main event of Mr. Mortier's first Salzburg season, in 1992, and in many ways it was a declaration of intent. New music, as much as old, was now to benefit from the festival's resources and prestige. More comprehensively, new stage directors were to change the look of the festival: ''St. Francois'' brought Peter Sellars to Salzburg for the first time.

title: The World; Doomed Treaties
description: While 1,523 treaties have been ratified, the Senate had rejected only 20 until last week. The Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty was the 21st.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; With Land Scarce, Developed Sites Are Reused
description: THE low-rise office building and warehouse on Park Avenue have been fixtures in this Morris County community for more than 40 years. But by June the two occupied structures, together totaling 74,000 square feet, will be vacated and then demolished to make way for a 150,000-square-foot Class A office building.

title: Amtrak Changes
description: To the Editor: In the Aug. 29 Travel Advisory, I was astonished to read that Amtrak promises that its new program of customer service will involve ''checking each train before departure for adequate food supplies and properly functioning plumbing.''

title: HARVARD 37, FORDHAM 30
description: Fordham and Harvard both played the finest halves of their respective seasons -- in different halves -- while demonstrating in the other the qualities that have plagued them: Fordham's youth and inexperience and Harvard's inability to close out games.

title: Volunteers Brighten City's Public Schools; 9,000 Cheerfully Paint and Plant
description: Ian Sorkin dug a plastic knife into the brick wall, chipping away at the cracked paint an inch at a time. All around him, others were noisily scraping, sawing, even stabbing with their knives because there were not enough paint scrapers.

title: On Language; Me, Myself and I
description: 'Self'' used to be a dirty word. ''The wretch, concentered all in self,'' wrote Sir Walter Scott in 1805, might get ''power and pelf'' but would wind up ''unwept, unhonored and unsung.'' Not so, said Walt Whitman a half century later. ''I celebrate myself,'' he sang in his ''Song of Myself.'' Since then, however, the notion of self as something to be celebrated has been taking a beating; Scott's sneer at self reverberates through the language. It is bad to be selfish, good to be selfless. People who are smug are self-satisfied, narcissists are self-absorbed and often self-indulgent and braggarts are self-serving. You can find a few uses that reflect well on self -- like self-reliant and self-possessed - but most praise is lavished on the rejection of self, as in self-sacrifice. And selflessness is next to godliness.

title: What Woes? The Red Sox Slug Away at Fenway Park
description: In the midafternoon sunshine, amid the festive fans outside Fenway Park, a tall man wearing a red, white and blue Uncle Sam costume carried a sign that said, ''This Yankee Loves the Red Sox.'' A younger man in a gray Boston jersey walked up to him, hugged him and said, ''It's a good day to be an American -- and a Dominican.''

title: Ideas & Trends; Wrestling With Unruly Numbers
description: THERE is no Nobel prize in metaphysics. But if there were, it would surely go to the thinker who could solve the stubborn mystery of why mathematics so often mirrors the workings of the physical world. Rocks arc through the sky in parabolic trajectories, planets swing in ellipses around the sun. And inside atoms, tiny particles move according to the mathematics of quantum mechanics.

title: Swiss Movement
description: I LIKE a place that doesn't skimp on souffles. Chez Madeleine serves its huge, airy creations with fanfare: steaming puffs of sugar, butter and egg whites that dissolve in your mouth but are plentiful enough for two. I would even say the Grand Marnier version was nearly perfect: it arrived as an apparently stable convex mound that the server slid through with a butter knife, drizzled with vanilla sauce and then left for me to savor.

title: Learning TV News Reporting in the Trenches
description: WATCHING carefully, a news maven might notice some peculiarities on ''L.I. News Tonight.'' At certain times of the year, when new school semesters are about to begin, the 15-minute nightly broadcast on Telecare offers footage of fires, accidents, murder trials, celebrities, news conferences and even heartwarming yarns. But where are the reporters doing stand-up?

title: It Takes All Kinds; Jane Austen: The Cool Artist
description: There are only two known likenesses of Jane Austen, both by her older sister, Cassandra. In one her back is turned, so that we mostly see her bonnet; in the other she is poker-faced and looking askance. ''Of events her life was singularly barren,'' her nephew claimed, and her letters, or those that her family didn't burn, reveal almost nothing of the person who wrote them. Yet the evidence suggests that Austen's life was full of inner drama. She experienced maternal rejection and sibling rivalry; she was unhappy in love and had trouble with relationships; she suffered from writer's block and bouts of depression. And her novels powerfully suggest both a world and a personality that now seems remarkably familiar. Under that bonnet and behind those vacant hazel eyes there burns the first modern sensibility.

title: Behind the Woolens, an Einstein Museum
description: Albert Einstein lived and worked the last 22 years of his life on Mercer Street in Princeton, where he was commonly seen shuffling between his home and the stores and the Institute for Advanced Study. Yet there is no statue, museum or memorial to Einstein in Princeton; there is not even a plaque to mark his house. There is only a 10-by-12-foot corner in the back of a clothing store on Nassau Street where the public can see a few artifacts, photographs, newspaper clippings, letters, and copies of calculations and doodles.

That's how Roger Clemens has to rationalize what happened here yesterday at Fenway Park. The Yankees, whose margin for error exceeds that of most teams, are still ahead by two games to one in the American League Championship Series. For Clemens, there could another day for another chance.

title: In a New Haven Cafe, Piquant Turkish Fare

And the kitchen is not timid about seasoning, which gives many dishes the piquancy of legitimacy. Though we were hampered in ordering by our waitress's limited English and poor command of Turkish names and dishes, once over that hurdle, we settled down to a satisfying meal.
