description: For months, Pakistan's Prime Minister and its top general were like two scorpions in a bottle. This week, both struck.

title: 18th-Century Letters Send Boys on Quest
description: FOR the first time in its 174-year history, two middle-school children will address the Connecticut Historical Society today when they present their research on the 18th-century letters that were found in a garden shed.

title: What Social Climbing?
description: To the Editor:

title: Steinbrenner Rejects Request by the Orioles
description: In their search for a general manager, the Baltimore Orioles asked for permission in the last few days to interview Gordon Blakeley, the Yankees' director of international and professional scouting. But George Steinbrenner, the Yankees' owner, rejected the request, according to a high-ranking baseball official.

title: Lottery's Opponent
description: To the Editor:

title: Juliette Tuakli, Kweku Ghartey
description: Dr. Juliette Modupe Tuakli, a pediatrician, and Dr. Kweku Nunoo Ghartey, an ophthalmic surgeon, were married yesterday in the Memorial Church at Harvard University in Cambridge, Mass. Bishop Gilbert A. Thompson of the New Covenant Christian Center performed the ceremony.

title: Argentine Escapades With Choice Food
description: WAS I sitting on the porch of a ranch in Argentina digging into a juicy gaucho steak or eating at Duke Falcon's in Long Beach? During every meal there I thought of that actor in the television commercial who doesn't know if he has been to some exotic spot or has been watching the Travel Channel.

title: At Last, a Plan to Improve Parkway-Route 78 Connection
description: Drivers trying to get from the northbound Garden State Parkway to westbound Route 78 in Hillside have been forced for years to take a circuitous route that involves going east on Route 78 for about a mile and making a u-turn. Plans for a direct connection between the two will get under way next year.

title: Beneath a Placid Sky, A Jungle in the Water
description: Soon after we left Montauk inlet on an uncharacteristically balmy autumn morning, bound for the ''back country'' of Gardiners Bay, our guide, David Blinken, yelled to make himself heard above the churning outboard engines and the heavy rush of wind. ''Watch for the monarchs,'' he shouted. ''They were as thick as rain here, just last week.''

title: A Golden Leash?
description: Ebit Wachner, the Yorkshire terrier belonging to Linda J. Wachner, the chief executive of both Warnaco and Authentic Fitness, would be the first to benefit if Ms. Wachner's plans for merging the two companies went through. Ms. Wachner said last week that she would use her $47.9 million proceeds from the deal to further cancer research and to buy Ebit a new collar. In an apparently paw-written note to a reporter on Ebit Wachner's personalized stationery, signed with a paw print, Ebit herself expressed appreciation last week for the publicity given these plans, adding, ''Now I'm certain to get my new collar on time.''

title: Nancy Espeseth, Kenneth Rudin
description: Nancy Marie Espeseth, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Espeseth of Seattle, is to be married this evening to Kenneth Michael Rudin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Rudin of Manhasset, N.Y. The bridegroom's father, who has been made a deputy marriage commissioner for the day by the San Francisco County Clerk, will officiate at the Palace of the Legion of Honor in San Francisco.

title: Words That Hurt
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: Because of a production error, a report last Sunday about the wedding of Britt Adams Neubohn and Philip Eric Hult omitted the last line. The final sentence, referring to the bridegroom's mother, Gun Denhart of Portland, Ore., should have read: ''The bridegroom's mother is a founder and the chairwoman of Hanna Andersson in Portland, the mail-order company for children's clothing.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FERGUSON, ANDREW B. JR.
description: FERGUSON-Andrew B. Jr. 10/6/ '34-10/16/'98. Dear Ferg, we shall not say that you are gone, too final is the sound, we say instead, you've gone ahead, where heavenly joys abound. We love you. Your family

title: Larry Bird Remembers the One Ball He Coveted
description: Nearly 13 years ago, Larry Bird completed arguably his greatest season by leading the Boston Celtics to a championship against the Houston Rockets and being named the most valuable player of the finals.

title: One Neighborhood, Two Newspapers, Two Worlds
description: Ever since a new community newspaper printed its first issue last month, Bushwick has had two publications covering one neighborhood. But the two papers present such contrasting views that it appears they cover two different places.

title: Wittiness of Creation
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: LONG BALLS, NO STRIKES

title: It Takes All Kinds; Ignatius of Loyola: The Saintly Boss
description: It may come as a surprise to you who associate the word ''Jesuit'' with fiery-eyed missionaries and steely-eyed inquisitors that I offer the founder of the order, Ignatius Loyola, as an example of an admirable leader. But perhaps you didn't know that Ignatius regularly danced for the young members of the community, and that he allowed a woman -- Princess Juana of Austria -- to become a secret Jesuit, under the code name of Matteo Sanchez.

title: Coming Back To Jamaica
description: The Jamaica Market, a building in Jamaica Center that houses about 30 shops and restaurants, was rededicated last month after a six-month, $925,000 renovation financed by the Empire State Development Corporation. The main entrance on Jamaica Avenue was reconstructed to include a glass-enclosed walkway that leads into a food court.

title: The Other End of the Telescope
description: GALILEO'S DAUGHTER

title: Inside Out
description: Something in human nature impels us to explore. Out of need, restlessness or simple curiosity, human beings found their way to the ends of the earth and are now scouting out other worlds. We were slower, though, in exploring the inner space of our own bodies.

title: Split Personalities Can Be Better Than One
description: WITH the release of his ''In the Life of Chris Gaines'' CD three weeks ago, Garth Brooks traded in the cuddly, love-handled appeal that had helped him sell almost 100 million albums for the brooding, eyeliner-wearing visage of a pop-rock alter ego no one had ever heard of. For the album cover, Mr. Brooks, the balding country superstar, put on a tousled black wig and a clump of hair beneath his lower lip, and got more grief from critics than the Village People got when they put on face paint and poet shirts for their 1981 New Wave album, ''Renaissance.''

title: October 10-16; A Nobel for Doctors' Group
description: Doctors Without Borders won the Nobel Peace Prize for adhering to ''the fundamental principle that all disaster victims, whether the disaster is natural or human in origin, have a right to professional assistance given as quickly and as efficiently as possible.''

title: Health Care Provides Degree Opportunities
description: IN the next five years, a big demand for workers will come from the health industry, generating an increase in jobs of more than 60 percent. That is the prediction of the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the United States Department of Labor.

title: DIANE ARCHER
description: AS president of the Manhattan-based Medicare Rights Center, Diane Archer travels around the country as a spokeswoman and omsbudswoman for older adults and the disabled. Her main concern is that as health costs soar and Medicare payments lag, retired people now spend 19 percent of their income, on average, for items, like drugs, that are not covered by Medicare.

title: Being Faithful to a Victorian Ideal
description: ANNETTE FORTIN knelt on the dusty floor, cleaning mahogany woodwork with a Q-Tip. It was a job she had been doing since August, though as the registrar of the Hudson River Museum here she normally has other tasks. Making every inch of carved woodwork shine in the restored Glenview Mansion was her mission before the Victorian landmark -- which is attached to the main museum -- reopened to the public last Friday.

title: FULFILLING A PROMISE: A special report.; A Sports Sisterhood, Measured in Olympiads
description: At the starting whistle, sisterhood's child springs out of the pack on pitter-pat feet that barely crush grass. She takes the lead.

title: Children's Books; By Zeppelin From Now to Then
description: Talking cats? Fez-wearing crocodiles? Bugs playing dominoes? So what else is new? Surrealism is such a natural and omnipresent element of children's fiction that it is hard to imagine any bizarre spectacle raising the eyebrows of today's youngsters. Which is exactly why Tom Pohrt's HAVING A WONDERFUL TIME (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $16; ages 4 and up) is so refreshing. Somehow, his cat who writes postcards and sketches portraits is strange and surreal anew. Pohrt's exquisite illustrations are at once true to life and engagingly jarring. That water buffalo sitting at a table at the Crocodile Cafe looks quite real and yet completely out of place. The tale is simple enough. A girl, Eva, and her cat, Sam, take a zeppelin airship to a country that looks much like a North African French colony a decade or two before the end of overt imperialism. In this land of deserts and oases, Eva and Sam encounter annoying bugs, friendly camels and fiendishly plotting crocodiles before settling into a nice hotel room overlooking the sea. En route they pass by many palm trees and a monumental cat statue. (Ancient Egyptian? Abyssinian? Hard to say.) ''Better than a postcard'' is Sam's opinion. Readers can be excused for picking up ''Having a Wonderful Time'' and assuming that they've found a glossy new reprint of some long-forgotten classic. Pohrt's illustrations and smooth, unassuming, utterly unironic prose look and sound as if they date back to some innocent pre-World War II era. One wouldn't be surprised at all if Babar or Tintin made an appearance just around the next page. Without seeming to try at all hard, ''Having a Wonderful Time'' evokes another time and another place, full of magical possibilities right around the corner but far, far away. A very nice trick, if you can pull it off. Andrew Leonard

title: Paris
description: Through Nov. 14, the Champs-Elysees is living up to its reputation as the world's most beautiful avenue by morphing into an open-air art museum for ''Les Champs de la Sculpture 2000,'' an assemblage of 52 monumental contemporary art-works between the Place de la Concorde and the Rond Point. Thanks to colored flags draped over the lampposts by the artist Daniel Buren, a taxi trip to the Etoile becomes a ride into the rainbow. Pedestrian traffic comes to a halt as strollers contemplate the stack of TV sets by Nam June Paik, pose next to the New York hot dog vendor contributed by Red Grooms and discover funhouse images of the city through Brigitte Nahon's winding wall of water-filled globes.

title: Correction
description: An article October 3 about the New York Mets' slump misspelled the surname of the player who hit a decisive home run in the 1951 playoffs. He was Bobby Thomson, not Thompson.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAKER, CROWELL
description: BAKER-Crowell, 68 years old of Lawrence, L.I. October 14, 1999. Survived by his wife, the Rev. Edyth K. Baker; a son L. Crowell Baker; a daughter Janann Telitz and a granddaughter Leigh Telitz. Memorial service Monday, October 18, 11AM, Trinity-St. John's Episcopal Church, 1142 Broadway, Hewlett, NY (516) 374-1415. Interment private. In lieu of flowers memorial gifts may be sent to Trinity-St. John's Church or to Family Consultation Service, 216-10 Jamaica Av, Queens Village, 11428

title: October 10-16; A Bird's Eye View, for a Price
description: Backyard sun bathers and lovers on the beach have nothing to fear. The resolution of the world's first private spy camera, now orbiting 400 miles overhead, is insufficiently sharp to spot individuals. But it can see much else, including buildings, roads, pipelines, bridges, tanks, ships, jets and missiles.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL / 2000 Mitsubishi Eclipse GT; Sport Coupe for Mature Audiences
description: CAR buyers can be a fickle and cranky constituency. Consider Mitsubishi's Eclipse sport coupe, which is new for the 2000 model year. The design wonks and focus-groupies on the company payroll endorsed the idea that the redesigned Eclipse should be a kinder, gentler sports coupe rather than the earthy, turbo-zinging me-machine of years past.

title: Land in Manhattan for $1 a Lot?
description: THE bird's-eye view of Manhattan, from the southern tip of the island northward at least a hundred blocks, is a continuous stream of concrete, save the expanse of Central Park and a few other swaths of greenery. Only north of 96th Street, in Harlem and East Harlem, are there still large tracts of undeveloped land. So in July when the city offered to sell nine parcels of city-owned land in upper Manhattan for $1 apiece to anyone who submitted a suitable proposal for housing, developers from Washington Heights to Long Island scrambled to submit bids. By the deadline last week, 23 groups had proposed a total of 45 projects for the sites.

title: Columbia Is Picked Apart by Penn's Hoffman
description: Penn quarterback Gavin Hoffman torched Columbia's defense for a school-record 399 passing yards and four touchdown passes yesterday to lead the Quakers to a 41-17 victory at Wien Stadium.

title: Food; Coddled Egos
description: As eating has evolved from an act of survival to a celebrated and discriminating art form, the cult of personality -- of the chef as artiste -- has taken over the kitchen. It is not just that TV chefs like Julia Child and Emeril Lagasse have become household names; it is that their celebrity has become a visible ingredient in the cuisines for which they are known.

title: When Goofy Didn't Mean Disney on Times Square
description: During the last few years, Times Square has changed from a gritty red-light district into a tourist destination. Some have lamented the demise of the freewheeling, eclectic air that once defined the neighborhood.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENRY, JANET RUTH
description: HENRY-Janet Ruth. Beloved wife of William. Devoted mother of Jodi and Charles, Lonny, Scott and Lisa, and Allison and Brad. Cherished grandmother of Jacob, Sydney, Marc, Lauren, Stephanie and Spencer. Services ''BoulevardRiverside'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI, Sunday, 1:30 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, MELVIN, M.D.
description: KAHN-Melvin, M.D. The faculty and staff of the Samuel Bronfman Department of Medicine of the Mount Sinai School of Medicine and Mount Sinai NYU Health mourn the loss of our esteemed colleague Dr. Melvin Kahn. Dr. Kahn first came to Mount Sinai in 1953 as an intern and went on to advanced training in cardiology and renal disease at Mount Sinai and the National Institutes of Health. Based on his distinguished research contributions, his caring and expert care of his patients, and his devoted and loving service to Mount Sinai, he has served with distinction as Clinical Professor of Medicine since 1984. He was a leader in housestaff recruitment and was a wonderful role model for young physicians. We will greatly miss his warmth, his sense of humor, and his friendship. We extend our sincere condolences to his family. Barry S. Coller, M.D. Chairman

title: Seeing to Herbs, Roses and Bulbs
description: The flavor of herbs harvested before killing frosts is intense, so dry them now for winter use. Pumpkins and winter squash have the best taste and texture when harvested before they are brushed with white frost.

title: A Dowager Hotel?
description: To the Editor: We read Hilary de Vries's article ''L.A. Hotels With Attitude'' (Sept. 19) and truly enjoyed her vivid personal observations. But we were disappointed to read that she considers the Regent Beverly Wilshire to be a ''dowager.''

title: TELEVISION/RADIO; 'Cat Therapist' and Other Sitcoms-Not-to-Be
description: THE fall television season has just burst upon us, and you're probably already thinking ''This (fill in noun describing the awful new series of your choice) is all they (the collective networks) could come up with? I could do better than that.''

title: October 10-16; Colt's to Curb Gun Sales
description: The Colt's Manufacturing Company is retreating from its 144-year-old retail revolver business and will offer only boutique versions of the Colt .45, the gun that won the West. Colt's, based in West Hartford, Conn., had been struggling financially even before it and other gun makers were hit with lawsuits from 28 cities and counties seeking to recover costs from gun violence.

title: October 10-16; Babbitt Inquiry Ends
description: After an 18-month investigation, an independent counsel said there was insufficient evidence to warrant charges against Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt or anyone else involved in a decision by the Interior Department in 1995 to deny a permit for an Indian gambling project in Wisconsin.

title: Natural Man
description: THE ECOLOGICAL INDIAN Myth and History. By Shepard Krech 3d. 318 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $27.95.

title: Lone Star History
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; A Fluffmeister Seeks Redemption
description: Like Frederick G. Dillen's first novel, ''Hero'' (1994), FOOL (Algonquin, $23.95) is about masculinity -- about the likelihood of failing to achieve it and the possibility of redeeming it. At 46, Barnaby Griswold is a successful and happily amoral investment speculator who worries about becoming, in his father's disapproving term, a ''fluffmeister.'' Barnaby's success is built on intuition, aided by a limitless tolerance for liquor and the kind of salesman's bonhomie that involves funny hats, food fights and conspicuous consumption. A chance meeting with two Midwestern car salesmen turned oil speculators lures Barnaby from his Manhattan playground to Oklahoma City, where he hears the voice of his dead father advising him to sell short. The triumph of this scheme depends on Barnaby's betrayal of his Oklahoma partners, one of whom takes revenge by talking to the Securities and Exchange Commission. Forced to accept a trading suspension in order to avoid jail, Barnaby loses not only his wealth and connections, but also his wife and daughters and his family's summer home. Barnaby believes that ''in circumstances like these, men resurrected their lives by winning something physical,'' and the more familiar part of his resurrection involves winning a tennis tournament and charming the inevitable pretty girl. But he also stays in Oklahoma City to care for his formidable mother-in-law, Ada, after she suffers a series of debilitating strokes. The moving but unsentimental narrative of their developing relationship, and Dillen's happily offbeat prose, add a moving and surprising twist to Barnaby's redemption. Laura Morgan Green

title: State Is Far From Reluctant To Aid Its Cities
description: To The Editor:

title: For the Barefoot Boy On Bleecker Street
description: After 18 years managing L'uomo clothing store on Bleecker Street in the West Village, Michael Adjiashvili decided to add shoes to his offerings. So on Oct. 4, he opened Tupli, a small shoe store on the opposite side of the street that in some ways functions as an annex to his clothing store.

title: Ailing Foreign Policy
description: The humbling of the White House over the nuclear test ban treaty augurs poorly for President Clinton's being able to secure any crowning foreign policy achievement in the last year of his term. Indeed, the defeat was so severe that some Administration and Congressional officials wondered if it would prematurely cripple Mr. Clinton's authority on foreign affairs.

title: The View From/Ox Ridge Hunt Club, Darien; Yale and Virginia Meet Mid Ponies and Picnics
description: RALPH LAUREN, eat your heart out. The Harriman Cup polo event, held recently on a catalogue-perfect fall day at the Ox Ridge Hunt Club in Darien, belonged more to J. Crew than to the Prince of Polo. Three thousand casual chic preppie types of all ages came to cheer on the Yale and University of Virginia alumni polo teams and, later on, dance until the sun went down. Toddlers were the must-have accessory, though a few pocketbook pooches made amusing arm candy. Snugglies with newborns riding on Daddy's chest were the ultimate necktie. In 15 years, the Harriman Cup had grown up. ''It's more of a family affair and we want them to come,'' said Eileen Bartolini Flint of Waterbury, who is a chairwoman of the Harriman Cup and runs the Yale equestrian program. ''We don't want polo to look like an elitist sport.'' Or the yuppie bacchanale it used to be, one might recall.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Artax Gets Early Jump And Doesn't Look Back
description: Artax raced to a stunning victory in the Forest Hills Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday, broke the track record for six furlongs and earned a trip to the Breeders' Cup against the world's best sprinters.

title: Schlemiels
description: Bad Jews

title: The Lost Art Of Immortality
description: By age 36, Lord Byron, the original bad boy of English literature, had made a nation of repressed women swoon despite his escapades -- he seduced boys and slept with his half sister, and threw his wife and newborn daughter out of the house -- and had written one of the great satiric poems of all time, ''Don Juan,'' which he allowed to be understood was partly autobiographical. Notwithstanding a malformed foot, he was as famous for his athletic prowess as for the brand of cynicism that made ''Byronic'' an adjective. We even owe to Byron the classic mother-in-law joke. His mother-in-law had been dangerously ill, he wrote, but was now dangerously well again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHELAN, SONDRA SICKLES
description: PHELAN-Sondra Sickles. The Marymount School Board of Trustees, administrators, faculty and the entire School community mourn the death of our beloved friend, teacher, colleague and trustee, Sondra Phelan. A valued member of the Board, Sondra shared with each of us her wise counsel, love of children and courageous spirit. We will miss her friendship, wit, wisdom and compassion. We extend our deepest sympathy to her husband, James; daughter, Melissa; sons, John, Daniel and Michael, six grandchildren, and her entire loving family. Kathleen Fagan, RSHM Headmistress The Board of Trustees

title: Penn State Batters Buckeyes to Win
description: They lost a quarterback, had two field goals blocked and sputtered three more times inside Ohio State's 25-yard line. It wasn't a great afternoon for Penn State, but one that became bearable because of the mammoth legs of Eric McCoo.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Before money came on board, all we had was each other. Women had to stick together, mother and protect each other. That was part of our culture.''

title: Male for Good Reason
description: To the Editor:

title: Jealousy in a Material World
description: AFTER years of hard work and deep soul-searching, I have finally embraced my inner princess. Oh, I guess I always knew she was there, but I had never fully acknowledged her, thinking it was wrong to crave the material.

title: POP MUSIC; The Apple Doesn't Fall Far From the Tree
description: THE Mooney Suzuki may be the only rock band in the country that can't tour this fall because it's apple season.

title: No Cheers for Braves Fans
description: Bobby Valentine seemed irked by the suggestion that Mets fans have been more abusive to the Braves than Braves fans have been to the Mets.

title: Yanks' Success Is No Accident
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Bergen Catholic Is Not Caught Napping for Long
description: After the Montclair High School football team's bus pulled into the parking lot at Bergen Catholic High School about an hour before today's game, the players stepped out, pulled on their pads and shouted brave words to each other. The Bergen Catholic players were gathering inside their gymnasium, some stretching and others sleeping. The Crusaders seemed set up for a rude awakening.

title: Q. & A.
description: Case of the Shrinking Elevator

title: Issue by Issue, First Lady Details Differences With Giuliani
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton moved to draw a series of sharp differences with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday, attacking the legacy of Ronald Reagan's economic policies two weeks after Mr. Giuliani celebrated them, and assailing Republicans for blocking a minimum wage increase and promoting the use of school vouchers.

title: The More Things Change . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: A Singer Sails On
description: Celine Dion, the Canadian pop singer, who rode ''Titanic,'' ''Sleepless in Seattle'' and ''Beauty and the Beast'' to superstardom, is coming to Caesars Atlantic City for three sold-out shows next weekend.

title: Going With the Amazon's Flow
description: IN times of high water, the Amazon overflows its grassy banks until it laps against the city wall along the Malecon, Iquitos's broad waterfront pedestrian boulevard. When the tropical sun sets, Iquitos, in northeastern Peru, turns to the river. Waiters at waterfront bars and restaurants prepare their tables for customers, artisans spread blankets laden with wood carvings and beaded jewelry, and musicians assemble.

title: Troupe Dreams
description: In some rosy future, if dreamers in Bergen County and Edison keep at it, two local opera companies will be giving professional, affordable performances. That future takes a step toward reality on Saturday, when the nonprofit Lyric Opera Company of Bergen Country presents ''A Night at the Opera,'' an evening of arias and choruses.

title: Car Registration to Be Done On Line, Rather Than in Line
description: Early next year, New Jersey motorists will be able to renew their car registrations on line or over the telephone, using a credit card, Governor Whitman announced earlier this month.

title: Delta Shuttle To Get Quieter Planes
description: Not to be outdone by US Airways, Delta Airlines said it is buying new, quieter jets to replace the aging Boeing 727's on its shuttles between New York, Boston and Washington.

title: In the Region/Westchester; Vacancies High, but Office Market Still Thrives
description: WHILE Westchester's office market continues to struggle with high vacancy rates, outside investors nevertheless continue to snap up office buildings, including problem properties that have languished on the market for years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURG, RABBI JOSEF
description: BURG-Rabbi Josef. We extend sincerest condolences to Rivka Burg and her children Avraham and Ada on the loss of her beloved husband and their father. Throughout his life, Rabbi Burg personified the highest values of chesed and service to Klal Yisrael. His friendship and efforts on behalf of the spiritual and healthcare needs of the people of Jerusalem will always be appreciated and remembered. His legacy of kindness continues in the capable hands of his children. May the entire family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. American Comm. for Shaare Zedek Med. Center Erica Jesselson, Chair Menno Ratzker, President

title: 1,200 Miles South, a Connection to Home
description: AS treasurer and a former president of the Connecticut Club of Lee County, Fla., Arnie Marcus can rattle off stories.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: Daniel Sullivan, Johanna Gaimster
description: Johanna Gaimster, a daughter of Ann Gaimster of Bryn Mawr, Pa., and George A. Gaimster of Gig Harbor, Wash., was married yesterday to Daniel Michael Sullivan, a son of Mary and Daniel F. Sullivan of Tuxedo Park, N.Y. Msgr. Joseph A. Funaro performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Assumption in Brooklyn.

title: Got a Best Friend?
description: Who's your best friend? Somebody you met in kindergarten? On your first job? A neighbor who dropped by to lend a hand and turned into an important part of your life?

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York.

title: Residents Say Tour Buses Overstay Their Welcome
description: West Side residents have long complained about buses belonging to New York Apple Tours, saying the old double-deckers double-park, idle past legal time limits, spew black smoke and draw hordes of tourists. Now opponents are asking city authorities to crack down on the company and are turning to the State Legislature for tougher laws on tour buses.

title: Gail Franck, Stephen Teager
description: Gail Jamieson Franck, a daughter of Dr. Ellen J. Franck and Ernest P. Franck of Sea Cliff, N.Y., was married yesterday to Stephen Alexander Teager, a son of Shushan Teager of Belmont, Mass., and the late Prof. Herbert Teager. The Rev. Burns Stanfield, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the Hempstead Harbor Club in Glen Cove, N.Y. The Rev. Emily Guthrie, an Episcopal deacon, took part in the ceremony.

title: Striving to Meet Foreign-Language Standards
description: A scarcity of certified language teachers and the inability to afford those who are available are making it a struggle for public schools to meet the state's new requirements for foreign languages at the elementary level.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Les Nubians; Sparkling Bordeaux
description: BONJOUR,'' ''Merci beaucoup'' and ''Je m'appelle'' flew around the balcony of the Bowery Ballroom on Monday night as fans eager for autographs flexed what little they remembered of French 101. ''Everywhere we go people try to speak French to us,'' said Celia Faussart, the younger half of Les Nubians, the hot Afro-soul duo that is proving that fine wine isn't the only popular export from Bordeaux these days. ''Sometimes we don't understand what they're saying, but it's good that they try.''

title: Prosperity as Redemption For a Boomer Generation
description: EVERYBODY knows that journalism thrives on bad news: natural disasters, wars, financial crashes. Where would newspapers be without them?

title: Teachers Are Underpaid And Underappreciated
description: I am writing in support of Frank Tassone's essay [''Quality Teachers and Hen's Teeth,'' Opinion, Oct. 10]. My wife and I raised four sons who attended and graduated from the Roslyn public school district, of which Dr. Tassone is superintendent. One of my sons became a professor and another son became an elementary-school teacher. Both sons entered the thankless and underpaid teaching profession because they wanted to make a difference.

title: Lawsuit Deepens Nassau Tax Nightmare
description: WITH a staggering $2.7 billion debt, a record $300 million deficit, a nosediving credit rating and rising taxes that are already among the nation's highest, the last thing Nassau County wants is another fiscal catastrophe.

title: Creative Writing
description: Some of the most imaginative flowerings of modern literature are in a special genre: the personal expense account. What has been the wildest, woolliest item you have tried to put on your account? And for how much? How did you explain it, and what happened? Or if you're a boss, what has been the most striking item you have encountered? Send your stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your name and telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Oil Flowing in Sudan, Raising the Stakes in Its Civil War
description: The pipeline here was built with the breathtaking speed born of a poor, violent nation seeking economic redemption through the discovery of oil. In just a year, 936 miles of steel were welded together and sunk a yard beneath the sandy soil of Sudan.

title: The World; The Real Power Struggle Isn't Just About Nukes
description: STEP outside the United States for even a few days, and the country has never looked more powerful: An economy that won't quit, a military that has never faced fewer direct challenges, a popular and business culture that has become the world's most eagerly-sought export.

title: Bigger Media Voices
description: To the Editor:

title: An Unfamiliar Pas de Deux as Camera Meets Tutu
description: ''THE movie,'' to some 150 dancers in New York this summer, meant one thing: a $20 million feature film that Columbia Pictures was making in the city. Indeed, as the British director Nicholas Hytner and his crew claimed a series of its outposts, the dance world seemed like a conquered province. The Paul Taylor Dance Company studios became the fictional Broadway Dance Studio; the Kit Kat Klub, off Times Square, served as a salsa hot spot; the Brooklyn Armory was reconfigured as ballet studios, and New York State Theater became a makeshift sound stage.

title: Hokies Give Orangemen Reminder, and Beating
description: Virgnia Tech quarterback Michael Vick provided Syracuse with a painful reminder of what they do not have anymore. And in the process, he may have propelled his own team toward something special this season.

title: Homosexuality Issue Splits Father and Son
description: Ever since he was elected to the California State Senate in 1992, William J. Knight has been trying to win passage of a law that would ban state recognition of same-sex marriages. But without success.

title: Victor Borge Gets Kennedy Invitation
description: WHEN a letter from the Kennedy Center arrived at his home in Greenwich, Victor Borge said he almost didn't open it. ''I assumed it was just another invitation to the Honors Concert in December,'' he said, ''and I didn't feel like going all the way to Washington.''

title: Children's Books
description: WHEN JFK WAS MY FATHER

title: The Rorschach Chronicles
description: The illustrations spread out on my desk look like freeze frames from some 1940's melodrama. In one, a man who might be Fred MacMurray, his brow furrowed in a way that strongly suggests limited acting range, turns his back on an elderly woman wearing a martyred expression. In another, a young woman is shadowed by a crone swathed in black. And in a third, a man wearing a tie and pleated pants covers his face as he stands beside the bed of an alarmingly inert woman, whose bare breasts are rendered in Vargas-vintage pinup style. The women remind me of Judy Garland or Gene Tierney, their hair upswept and their lipstick dark and dramatic.

title: To Pooh Corner
description: To the Editor: Thank you for your description of Ashdown Forest and its many Winnie-the-Pooh locations (Q & A, Aug. 29).

title: 'Ideal' Police Recruit Forced Out, Spurring Debate on Scrutiny
description: At a time when police officials say they want to recruit more city residents, members of minority groups and people with college and military experience, Army Lieut. Manuel Gomez seems like the perfect candidate for the New York Police Department.

title: Calabrian Roots
description: To the Editor: Thank you for the wonderful article on Calabria (''Calabria by the Sea,'' by Paul Hofmann, Sept. 26).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TERMAN, DAISY
description: TERMAN-Daisy. Heartfelt condolences to husband Isaiah, children Jane & Michael; granddaughter Selena & family. Daisy was the inspiration for our continuous involvement in cultural activities. Three Arrows Co-op Society Alice Appenzeller, President

title: Ideas & Trends; They Exist. Therefore They Are. But, Do You Care?
description: IT sounds like a philosophical cousin to the age-old question of whether a tree falling in the forest makes a sound if no one is around to hear it. In this case, though, Federal officials are seeking to add an economic variable to the puzzle: just how much is it worth to you to know that a once-dammed river is running wild again -- even if you never visit it?

title: Paris Days
description: The guests at last week's Paris fashion shows put on an amazing show of their own, especially those in clothes by Japanese designers, who challenge the status quo. There were sequined day dresses, bottom, from Comme des Garcons, and designs by Junya Watanabe, right, that impose architectural shapes on the wearer. Issey Miyake, who introduced Ultrasuede in 1970, created a raised-surface jersey, worn by Foglia Gischia, left, a nonagenarian Parisian. Yohji Yamamoto's rib-knit sweaters, bottom right, have a 21st-century look.

title: Strutting My Stuff on the Stage
description: MOST of us have a more or less secret urge to tread the boards of a theater. I confess that, like Macbeth, I too would like to strut my petty hour upon the stage. But I have resisted the temptation until very recently, when audition notices in the local papers began to catch my eye and tempt my vanity.

title: Old-Time Rivals Make A Date to Go Dancing
description: MORE than most dance companies, American Ballet Theater prides itself on its versatility. And rightly so. Last spring it presented ''Giselle'' and other Old World heirlooms. For the fall season, which opens on Tuesday and runs for two weeks at City Center, the troupe will flaunt its progressive side, taking on the macabre expressionism of Agnes de Mille, the wry populism of Twyla Tharp and the quicksilver partnering of Nacho Duato.

title: Jane Rand, Michael Nedder
description: Jane Edwards Rand, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Rand 4th of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday to Michael Thomas Nedder, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles T. Nedder, also of Darien. The Rev. Edward Small performed the ceremony at St. Mary Roman Catholic Church in Ridgefield, Conn. The Rev. Iain MacLellan, a Roman Catholic priest who is a cousin of the bridegroom, assisted in the service.

title: Martinez Does the Job With Ease
description: Pedro Martinez grinned after one of his sweeping curveballs caused Chuck Knoblauch to duck, glared toward the plate when one of his fastballs soared by Chili Davis like a missile and had not even glanced when Roger Clemens sauntered across shallow left field while Martinez was warming up in the first inning.

title: Take 3 for Kerkorian: The Rebuilding of MGM
description: THIS time, it looks as if Kirk Kerkorian wants to build his film studio into a player.

title: Marit McCabe and Derek DuBois
description: IN the seaside town of Stonington, Conn., one house stands out from all the staid saltboxes: a converted Baptist church painted white and indigo, with a tower that rises like an enormous lifeguard stand. To many people, the church is known as ''the temple of fun.''

title: Political Memo; Furors All Around, But Pataki Lies Low
description: In the last month, deep in what is usually the snooze season in state politics, there have been enough fires burning to warm the heart of even the most jaded political junkie: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's holy war against the Brooklyn Museum of Art and its self-consciously shocking exhibition, President Clinton's decision to offer clemency to imprisoned members of a Puerto Rican nationalist group that carried out a bombing in New York City, and the nascent Senate contest between Hillary Rodham Clinton and Mr. Giuliani.

title: 'An Affair of State'
description: To the Editor:

title: Home as Concentration Camp
description: SOUL MURDER REVISITED

title: It Takes All Kinds; Rachel Robinson: The Survivor
description: Rachel robinson is the widow of a great and good man, but she is not a derivative human being. In 1947, she spent a searing and ultimately triumphal year at the side of her husband, Jack (Jackie) Roosevelt Robinson, as he desegregated Major League Baseball. In the course of his Hall of Fame career with the Brooklyn Dodgers, Robinson was a catalyst for the cultural changes that doomed segregation in America. Before Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., before Nelson Mandela's triumph, a black man forced white people to look at blacks in a new way. His death at the age of 52, in 1972, could have sent his wife into permanent mourning, all the more so because their child, Jackie Jr., died just a year earlier. What Rachel Robinson personifies instead is the strength of survivors.

title: A Diamond for Denmark's Library
description: The Royal Library of Denmark, founded in 1653, shifted into the 21st century last month with the opening of the Black Diamond, a new extension that expands its cultural functions and increases space for research, sorely needed since the institution's 1989 merger with the 500-year-old Danish University Library.

title: An Elite Company of Equals Presides Over the U.S. Game
description: No one dominates the United States Championship anymore. Prior to the late 1950's, when Bobby Fischer took over, Sammy Reshevsky had held sway. After Fischer's departure from the chess scene in 1972, Walter Browne won the championship six times.

title: A Little Hollywood in Everyday Life
description: THE new Design Center at Kean University here plans to put on an annual monthlong exhibition to acquaint the public with the design qualities of items from everyday life. The first show, ''The Art of the Movie Poster,'' is a festive one.

title: When a V.P. Runs for President
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: A table last Sunday in the special Mutual Funds Report about the performance of five hypothetical retirement portfolios misstated the percentage allocations of two funds in the portfolio prepared by Sheldon Jacobs, editor of The No-Load Fund Investor in Irvington, N.Y. The two funds, Strong Asia Pacific and T. Rowe Price European Stock, each accounted for 7.5 percent, not 8 percent, of the portfolio in both the third and fourth quarters this year.

title: The Mets Stave Off Elimination As the Red Sox Maul the Yanks
description: The Mets and the Red Sox aren't on course for a reprise of their 1986 World Series matchup just yet, but they are not quite ready to trade in their bats for golf clubs.

title: A New Home for South Fork Nature Lovers
description: Nearly a decade ago, environmentalists formed a group to provide a home for wildlife on Long Island, although the group was without a home itself. Cramped in a cabin on a group member's property in Amagansett, they still managed to create a center for nature. Now, after years of fund-raising and searching for a new space, they are on their way to creating a museum to share a wealth of information on South Fork's wildlife.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: The Last of the Name

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 11 of Arts & Leisure today about American Ballet Theater's season at City Center misstates the fee that the Martha Graham Trust is charging Ballet Theater to perform Graham's ''Diversion of Angels.'' According to Jane Hermann, who wrote the contract for the trust, it is a flat three-year agreement, not a one-year agreement, and the fee is considerably less than $55,000.

title: Chilean Fjords
description: To the Editor: A few years ago, my husband and I took the Chilean Fjord trip described by Shirley Christian (''A Glacial Cocktail Party,'' Oct. 3). But we were on the older ship, the Skorpios II.

title: Crime
description: There are no flies on Sue Grafton. Her 15th alphabet mystery, ''O'' IS FOR OUTLAW (Marian Wood/Holt, $26), comes across with a freshness that suggests she has been taking stock of her skills, sharpening them up for the long haul. Everything that has always worked for this first-class series works better here: the sturdy plotting, the animated characters, the breezy style and a heroine with foibles you can laugh at and faults you can forgive. The surprising thing is that Grafton applies her trusty tools to a device that could just as easily have blunted them -- the involvement of her sleuth in a criminal case that reaches into her private life.

title: Mr. Quark
description: Strange Beauty Murray Gell-Mann and the Revolution in Twentieth-Century Physics. By George Johnson. Illustrated. 434 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $30.

title: Disco Lives! Actually, It Never Died
description: WHEN the staged version of ''Saturday Night Fever'' opens on Thursday at the Minskoff Theater, it should, by rights, look as quaint as the 1950's of ''Grease'' did in the 1970's. ''Saturday Night Fever,'' the movie released in 1977, marked the apogee of disco, a lucrative moment in pop that quickly generated a backlash, a record-business crash and a widespread repudiation. Twenty years is the usual nostalgia gap, the time it takes for fond memory to replace the embarrassment of succumbing to a long-gone trend; hence the Broadway-bound ''Saturday Night Fever,'' despite negative reviews of its London production. But while there's plenty of nostalgia attached to disco, the music doesn't seem distant. In all but name, the disco era never ended. Only the haircuts are obsolete.

title: New Choices In Insurance
description: TRAVEL insurance is entering another period of change. Beth L. Godlin, senior vice president of Access America, said companies like hers were always looking for new products to sell, and one is an annual policy, which is expected to be widely available early next year.

title: Peacekeepers In Indonesia Kill 3 Gunmen In a Firefight
description: In the sharpest clash of their three-week deployment in East Timor, Australian troops reported today that they were ambushed and pinned down by armed men and that they killed three of their attackers before being rescued by helicopter.

title: The World, Comparatively Speaking
description: THIS summer I attended a party where the game of travel simile was being played. It's an easy enough game, and players themselves hardly realize they're playing, so natural and spontaneous are the comparisons that form its trumps. Take place X and describe it in terms of place Y -- there, you're playing, and may the best, the most accurate and most pithy comparison win.

title: When Jenny Gets Blue
description: Remember mood rings in the 1970's? Two decades later, ''mood'' technology is back: Moody Pets, a Philadelphia-based pet-accessory company, has just introduced Moody dog and cat collars. Available at Petco stores for $25 to $30, the leather collars are studded with stones that change color with body temperature and supposedly help owners interpret their pets' psyches. A handy mood-reading color chart is included. For instance, amber-brown signifies a ''nervous, introspective'' mind-set, while dark blue connotes a ''fun-loving, frolicsome'' sensibility.

title: BENEFITS
description: Support for Afghan Women

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MIZRAHI, MARLA
description: MIZRAHI-Marla, 44. Mother of Angus, Morris, Angelo, Sarah. Daughter of Morris and Sarah Beyda Mizrahi. Gifts C/O PO Box 149, Summertown, TN. 38483.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Familiar Faces by Warhol

title: A Day for Underdogs, With Some Bite
description: The hammer hung just above the Mets' heads last night, waiting ominously as Game 4 of the National League Championship Series began, prepared to knock them out once and for all and send them away into the off season. The Mets had endured all manner of absurdity in the last three weeks -- a precipitous losing streak; a manager suggesting he should be dismissed and commenting that he didn't think most of his players were very smart; lineup changes and team meetings, and a mind-boggling sprint into the league championship series. But in a three-games-to-none hole to the mighty Atlanta Braves, a rapid conclusion to this series might have almost been merciful.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HORSTMAN, DOROTHY
description: HORSTMAN-Dorothy. Country and Western Music Historian and Author died September 13, 1999 in New York City. Survived by daughters Fritzi and Madi. Songwriter and pioneer in music journalism. Born Dorothy Ann Bernis, wedded James R. Horstman in 1959. Author of ''Sing Your Heart Out, Country Boy'' and ''America's Best-Loved Country Songs'' (will be published posthumously). Her spirit will live on anywhere country music is heard and loved. She was a true friend. Her memorial will be on October 29th in New York City. (For more information, please call 310-451-8908).

title: A Juror's Awful Burden of Proof and Justice
description: I WOKE up in darkness to be on time for my command performance tour of citizenship, also known as jury duty. As a potential juror in New York County Criminal Court, I arrived in Room 1121 at 111 Centre Street at 8:30 A.M. I knew that jury duty had been renovated to be shorter and easier. And after three postponements I knew my jig was up.

title: A Low-Key Path To a World Title
description: MOMENTS before the start of their regional championship match two weeks ago, players from the world champion Ultimate Frisbee team Cigar huddled on the sidelines. They sized up their opponents, plotted defensive strategies and reviewed the rule on interference from pine trees in the end zone. Then they each grabbed hold of a white disk. ''All this talk is making me dizzy,'' they chanted. ''Yo, baby, yo, baby, let's get busy.''

title: Playing Muse, Alter Ego and Any Age She Can
description: THE story Marisa Coughlan tells of being discovered by Kevin Williamson starts out normally enough. In March 1998, her agent got her a meeting with the casting directors of Mr. Williamson's big-screen directorial debut, ''Teaching Mrs. Tingle.'' The next month she was called back to perform two scenes from the film for Mr. Williamson himself, including her attention-grabbing turn as Linda Blair's demon-possessed pre-teen-ager in ''The Exorcist.'' A few weeks later she learned she'd won the part. But the tale's penultimate chapter, which Mr. Williamson refers to as ''the time she lied to me,'' suggests that things could have turned out very differently.

title: 'For Life We Learn'
description: To the Editor:

title: In a Chat Room You Can Be N E 1
description: 'Yo yo yo, what's up what's up?'' The lines scroll up my screen. Different fonts, different colors, the words whiz by, everyone's screen name sounding vaguely pornographic. I'm on America Online, in a chat room for young adults. There are hundreds of such chat rooms on AOL, and it has taken a lot of Net navigating simply to find one that has room enough to let me in.

title: In the Trauma of Barbarity, Art Speaks Out
description: THOUGH artists are usually advised to choose what they know as their subject matter, the risks of such a strategy here are obvious. By any measurement, Colombia is one of the most violent countries in the world, with guerrillas, drug dealers, paramilitary groups and gangs of ordinary criminals all killing and kidnapping against the backdrop of a decades-long civil conflict in which more than 300,000 people have died.

title: Jack Welch's Tribute To the Master Inventor
description: As he nears the end of his career, Jack Welch is returning to General Electric's roots. He has agreed to raise $80 million to preserve historic sites associated with Thomas Alva Edison.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FUTTERMAN, SOPHIA J.
description: FUTTERMAN - Sophia J., of Watermill, NY, died on October 11, from complications of pancreatic cancer, following a brief illness. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to The Earth School Parents Assoc., for children's gardening education, 600 E. 6 St, NYC 10009.

title: Jessica Bass And Patrick Kirk
description: Jessica Tracy Bass, the daughter of Melinda Aikins Bass of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Stanley Bass of Riverdale, the Bronx, is to be married this afternoon to Patrick James Kirk, the son of Nancy Kirk of Manhattan and the late Francis P. Kirk Jr. Judge Ingrid S. Braslow of Family Court of Westchester County in White Plains is to officiate at the Regal U.N. Plaza Hotel in Manhattan.

title: Let's Get It Right
description: Nomar Garciaparra was jogging past third base and Derek Jeter was tossing a baseball in foul territory during batting practice today. Garciaparra jokingly asked Jeter if he was going to imitate Garciaparra's stance during the game, which is what Jeter did during the All-Star Game at Fenway Park in July.

title: Piazza Plays in Pain
description: Mike Piazza was awakened at about noon yesterday by a phone call from the Mets' trainer, Fred Hina, and knew immediately that he would be able to play in Game 4 of the National League Championship Series.

title: Passing a Hankie, and a Proud Tradition
description: JOSE LIMON died in 1972, but the Limon Dance Company, which he founded with his mentor, Doris Humphrey, has survived, preserving certain family traditions. All were displayed this month when the company opened its New York City season at the Joyce Theater.

title: Builders Press On in Wisconsin Cow Country
description: JOHN GEHL has begun doing something this fall that hasn't been done in a long time in Waukesha County: He has his cows producing milk on a new dairy farm.

title: A Shimmer In the Shower
description: New Yorkers are lighting up in bathrooms again -- this time, with scented candles. Lavatories both private and public are a-flicker, from Haven Spa on Mercer Street, where matching candles and matchbooks by Bloom fill the bathrooms, to Barneys New York, which burns Diptyque and Mariage Freres candles for special events. Now, retailers are selling potent aromatic candles billed for bathroom use. This fall, Origins introduces its Candles for the Bath collection, with candles that the company says will burn for 90 hours ($18.50 a candle; to order: 800-674-4467). Perfumes Isabell has diminutive Shimmering Bath Lights ($22 for four at Clyde's, on Madison Avenue at 74th Street). And Rigaud, the French candle maker, has just come out with what it says is its first new candle in nearly 50 years -- the Environmental Bath votive in pink or blue ($27.50 at Bergdorf Goodman). Other candles coming to stores in the next few weeks are the Pillar from Tova, the skin-care products line ($23.50; to order: 800-556-8682), the Cleopatra from Tocca ($28 at Sephora Rockefeller Center) and the Lasco Personal Candle from Lasco New York ($13, at C. O. Bigelow Chemists, 414 Avenue of the Americas at Ninth Street).

title: Promises, Promises From the Airlines
description: GOVERNMENT reports show that fewer planes are arriving on time, more middle seats are occupied and more bags are arriving late or damaged. But not to worry: the 14 domestic passenger airlines that belong to the Air Transport Association announced on Sept. 15 that within 90 days their policy will become ''customer first.'' The similar policies adopted by the 14 airlines are aimed at staving off support for a passenger bill of rights in Congress.

title: In the Beginning of the Blues, There Was a Violin
description: THE blues has become so pervasive in American music that people just assume it has been around forever, as if African slaves, no sooner than their plight in this country became clear to them, reached out for a guitar and started singing the blues. Even those whose knowledge of American music runs a bit deeper are usually surprised to learn that the blues is only as old as this century.

title: Corrections
description: An answer in the Q & A column on page 28 of the Travel section today about renting wardrobe trunks refers imprecisely to those available from Liberty Moving and Storage and misstates the prices. The trunks do not have chests of drawers. Depending on the length of a cruise, they usually rent for $250 to $350, not $300 to $500.

title: Fort Greene Is Not A Culinary Wasteland
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Thwarts Gun Sales Ban In Los Angeles
description: A Federal judge has cleared the way for the continued sales of firearms at the largest gun show in the nation here, overturning an ordinance by county officials that would have banned such sales.

title: A Superpower Flaunts Its Ignorance
description: The Senate's rejection of the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty has unleashed a torrent of gloomy historical analogies. The Republicans are retreating to isolationism, we are told, and this latest humiliation of the President is comparable in impact and significance to the Senate's refusal to ratify Woodrow Wilson's signature on the Versailles Treaty, ending World War I, in 1920.

title: October 10-16; Gore Lands Endorsement Of A.F.L.-C.I.O.
description: Vice President Al Gore won the biggest plum awarded so far in the Presidential campaign: the endorsement of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. With Mr. Gore slipping in the polls and his rival, former Senator Bill Bradley, rising, Gore supporters hoped the labor federation's endorsement would reverse the Vice President's slide.

title: U.S. ASKS RUSSIA TO ALTER TREATY FOR HELP ON RADAR
description: In a dramatic reversal of previous policy, the United States is now offering to help Russia complete a large missile tracking radar if Moscow agrees in exchange to renegotiate what both countries long saw as a landmark arms control agreement.

title: The Italian Way With Cashmere
description: With its heavy stone and concrete walls and mellow piano from the ''Eyes Wide Shut'' soundtrack playing in the background, the interior of Manrico Cascimir seems a different world from the bustle of Madison Avenue.

title: When Clubs Were Trumps, They Cut Deals While They Stacked the Deck
description: WHEN political clubs were at the peak of their power in the early 1900's, mayors, governors and Presidents all courted the favor of their swaggering, cigar-chomping bosses.

title: Backtalk; A Soccer Shrine Is Captive To a Mushrooming Tax Bill
description: A battered tin sign says: ''Metropolitan Oval -- Soccer Games Every Sunday.''

title: Sports of The Times; For Rocker, It's Another Night in Fun City
description: JOHN ROCKER ducked a plastic water bottle heaved at him by one of the lunatic fringe in Shea Stadium last night, but he could not dodge trouble on the mound.

title: Time Off to Dive Into Reality Rather Than Retreat From It
description: IN a late 20th-century version of J. M. W. Turner's search for the untrammeled landscape, a small band of contemporary artists is spending this month trekking in the Himalayas, seeking fresh vision as well as fresh scenery.

title: The World: White Doctors, Black Patients; Not a Simple Case of Health Racism
description: NOT even sickness and death are beyond the reach of racial inequality. Blacks are more likely than whites to suffer from dangerous conditions like diabetes, high blood pressure and kidney failure. Black women are more likely than whites to die in childbirth.

title: Teachers Are Underpaid And Underappreciated
description: Dr. Tassone's essay on ''the scarcity of qualified public-school teachers and school administrators'' leaves me quite perplexed. After all, I am an experienced teacher, with certification from New York State and a master's degree in education and I have applied twice to the Roslyn school district for a position to no avail.

title: October 10-16; A Lean Fighting Machine
description: After years of resisting change, the Army announced plans to create lighter, more mobile combat brigades.

title: Working Wonders
description: Work is a place dedicated to harnessing employees' skills and energy but not necessarily promoting their mental health. To promote consideration of workers' psychological well-being, the New Jersey Psychological Association will present its first Healthy Workplace awards Saturday at its annual conference, at the Sheraton Woodbridge. The association wants to highlight state employers that provide family-friendly benefits, health and safety programs, employee involvement in decision-making, and -- as job security becomes a thing of the past -- skill development. The winner of the large-company award is Public Service Electric and Gas, singled out for preparing workers for the coming demands of electricity deregulation. The mid-size company winner is Organon, the pharmaceutical company in West Orange. An honorable mention goes to Hunter Douglas, the maker of window blinds, in Saddle River. Dr. Elaine Garrod, who practices in West Orange and is co-chairwoman of the committee that chose the winners, says that in a tight job market, the awards may persuade people to choose one of these companies. CARL SOMMERS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRISSEY, GARY EUGENE
description: CRISSEY-Gary Eugene. On October 13th at age 61. Loving father of Pamela Ragusa & Nicole Mitchell. Grandfather of Isabelle Mitchell. Son of Eugene and Dorothy Crissey and brother of Jon Crissey. Memorial service at St. Patrick's Old Cathedral, Mott and Prince Streets. Interment private. Contributions in his memory may be sent to Friends Indeed, 594 Broadway, Suite 706, New York, New York 10012.

title: Where English Cuisine Is Anything But
description: FOR lovers of literature, English food can conjure stuffed goose followed by vintage port; for survivors of American Anglophile schools, it recalls cardboard roasts and boiled vegetables. To the trend spotter, it means ''Modern British,'' extensive and promiscuous use of recipes and ingredients from the Pillars of Hercules to the Strait of Malacca, often served to 300 diners at a time. And to the Italian friends whom I told about the serious eating I was planning in Oxford, it was cause for concern.

title: Chilean Fjords
description: To the Editor: On the subject of sailing Chile's fjords, travelers also have the option of booking the trip before reaching Chile. Global Quest is a longtime representative in the United States for the Skorpios III and her sister vessels, Skorpios I and II, and is booking weekly cruises through May. Bookings can be made by calling (800) 221-3254 or faxing (516) 747-8367. Information is also available at www.globalquesttravel .com.

title: 'White Flight' Student Exploited Trenton School
description: To the Editor:

title: Missouri Senate Race Hits All the Hot Issues
description: When it comes to hot-button issues, few Election 2000 contests can boast as many as the United States Senate contest in Missouri.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Prozac Mother and Child
description: Here's the scene: my doctor's office, packets of trial-size Viagra in ridiculously erect stacks upon his desk; in a bowl, a scramble of candied goods in blister pouches -- the by-now-passe Prozac, the mild, middle of the road Zoloft, the newer, niftier stuff like Remeron and Effexor; it's all mixed together in a foiled, tinselly heap. My doctor reaches out -- he is a tall, lanky man with black hair that falls like fresh ink before his eyes -- and tosses me six free panels of the Prozac. ''One hundred twenty milligrams a day,'' he says. ''Let's see if that does it.''

title: Consumers May Be Losers in a Verdict on Auto Parts
description: NOW that a court in Marion, Ill., has imposed a record $1.2 billion judgment against State Farm for ordering some collision damage to be repaired with generic car parts, three groups that consumers rank among the least-trusted -- insurers, auto body shops and trial lawyers -- are arguing over what it means.

title: Brookfield Libel Suit Is Settled
description: VERONICA BERRILL, a retired Brookfield High School teacher, said she feels vindicated. About four years after filing a lawsuit against a couple who she claimed libeled her, the 1996 case was settled Oct. 7 just before jury selection was scheduled to begin in Danbury Superior Court.

title: LIPA Accused of Hiding Surcharge for Debt
description: TAKING a new tack in their running feud with the Long Island Power Authority, officials in Suffolk County have accused the agency of secretly collecting a 5.1 percent surcharge from all customers to amass $1.3 billion over 10 years for early retirement of debt on the defunct Shoreham nuclear power plant, and of trying to mask the surcharge with new, higher-interest borrowing.

title: Ovation For Reed Is Most Deserved
description: As Rick Reed made the long, slow walk to the dugout, the fans at Shea Stadium, stunned and disappointed, still managed to rise and give him an ovation. It went on even after he reached the bench, a loud reward for his effort, but Reed never heard any of it.

title: The Politics of 'No'
description: One big lesson from the angry fights between President Clinton and Republican Congressional leaders is that they get a thrill from saying ''no.'' Last week, Senate Republicans thundered ''no'' to the nuclear test ban treaty, handing the White House its biggest defeat since health care in 1994. Mr. Clinton thundered back with a ''no'' on the Republican schemes to cut taxes and spending, knowing that his vetoes will be easily sustained. Each side can mount campaigns, raise money, build support and get everyone excited over blocking the other side. What is missing, of course, is any consideration of an electorate that wants the centrists on both sides to get together and make government work.

title: POSTINGS: Quakers Transform Brooklyn Cheese Warehouse; A School for Learning Disabled
description: A former cheese warehouse in the Cobble Hill section of Brooklyn has been converted into the Mary McDowell Center for Learning, a private, 101-pupil Quaker school for 5- to 12-year-old learning disabled children.

title: The Nation: The New Scandalisms; It Depends on What Your Definition of Linguistic Trend Is
description: ON a recent episode of the new NBC drama ''Law & Order: Special Victims Unit,'' a male character referred to ''getting a Lewinsky.'' Most of the audience instantly understood what he was talking about.

title: Davids Island Plans
description: County Executive Andrew J. Spano and Mayor Timothy C. Idoni of New Rochelle are moving ahead with plans to turn at least part of Davids Island into a county park.

title: In New Europe, a Lingual Hodgepodge
description: Day and night on France's windy western coast, Radio Kerne transmits a bright mix of music sprinkled with local news. It is a new station run by young people for a young audience -- but with a difference.

title: Heart Transplants
description: The State Health Department has granted the Westchester Medical Center permission to perform heart transplants, making it the second hospital in the state permitted to perform the five most common organ transplants: kidney, pancreas, liver, heart and lung. The other hospital is Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan.

title: As Amusing as Ever
description: To the Editor:

title: Senate Campaigner Uses His Millions Very Effectively
description: When Jon S. Corzine began talking about running for the United States Senate from New Jersey early this year, there were at least 300 million reasons for fellow Democrats to listen.

title: A Link to the Quiet Little Life of St. Therese
description: The relics of St. Therese of Lisieux, the Emily Dickinson of Roman Catholic sainthood, arrived yesterday at Our Lady of the Scapular Church on East 28th Street to begin a four-day stay in Manhattan.

title: Critic's Notebook: On Musicals
description: SHELDON HARNICK, who wrote the lyrics, went from Manhattan to the Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam to look in on a run through -- no sets, no costumes -- of ''The Apple Tree,'' which began previews on Oct. 8, opens on Oct. 29, when Mr. Harnick will see it again, and runs through Dec. 19. ''The first two were wonderful,'' said Mr. Harnick from his Upper West Side apartment the other evening. ''The third needed to be fixed, but they're easy fixes.''

title: Arrests Shake Ancient Roots of Iran's Jews
description: At the Yousuf Abad synagogue in Teheran, the packed congregation gathered for the Sabbath was approaching the end of Friday prayers. It was the moment one worshiper had been waiting for, when the rise of hundreds of fervent voices made him inaudible to all but a stranger beside him.

title: Joshua Hare and Lee Cohen
description: Lee Susan Cohen, a producer of television documentaries, and Dr. Joshua Michael Hare, a cardiologist, are to be married today by Rabbi Marcel Blitz at the B'nai Israel Synagogue in Baltimore.

title: Most Likely To . . .
description: LEADING THE CHEERS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOUGHERTY, KENNETH W.
description: DOUGHERTY-Kenneth W. Of Morris Township and New York City, formerly of Philadelphia, PA. Died at home on Wednesday, October 13, 1999. Husband of Katharine (nee Sutro), father of Elizabeth Halle and Sarah B.

title: Creating Savory Apple Dishes and Leaving Desserts Behind
description: THE first thought, as fresh, newly harvested apples come into the market, is dessert. But apples, with their tart-sweet flavor, are a fine companion for savory dishes. When cooked until tender, they also soften enough to thicken a sauce.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOVENETSKY, SAM
description: KOVENETSKY-Sam. October 15, 1999, at age 87. Adoring and beloved husband of Betty. Loving father of Rolf and Regina. Dear grandfather of David and Rachel Kovenetsky. Devoted step-father of Rick and Chris Shain. Stepgrandfather of Brahman, Autumn and April. Great-grandfather of Cody. A man of all seasons. A pioneer of the labor movement. Founding father of Local 1-S, dedicated to serving the workers of Macy's for 40 years. Labor liaison to Governor Carey. Appointed by Governor Cuomo to serve as Commissioner of the Unemployment Appeals Board for 17 years. He served on the Boards of United Way of NYC, Empire Blue Cross Blue Shield, Group Health Insurance Inc., American Cancer Society-New York Divison, Brooklyn Psychiatric Center, Greater New York Fund, City of Hope-Robal Chapter, B'nai Brith-Business and Labor Lodge, past president of the New York Chapter of the Industrial Relations Research Association. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the NYC Central Labor Council's Camp Program. Rest in peace, my darling, my best friend. Service Monday, 11:15 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Do You Have A Best Friend?
description: Who's your best friend? Somebody you met in kindergarten? On your first job? A neighbor who dropped by to lend a hand and turned into an important part of your life?

title: Ilana Laurence and Regis Zaleman
description: Ilana Civia Laurence, the daughter of Patricia Laurance and Judge Stuart Laurence of New York, is to be married this afternoon to Regis Zaleman, a son of Michele Guinault-Picciotto of Seillans, France, and Dr. Pierre A. Zaleman of Paris. Cantor Elisheva R. Dienstfrey is to perform the ceremony at the Westbeth Loft in New York.

description: EVANGELIST-Felix G. Of Stamford, formerly of Greenwich, CT. On October 14, 1999. Survived by his wife, Elinor Sautter Evangelist, and his grandson, Andrew Gropper. Father of the late Jane E. Gropper.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAMBERT, JEAN
description: LAMBERT-Jean. Born December 31, 1914, died August 6 in Paris. This remarkable writer, teacher, translator, and meilleur des amis will not be forgotten by former Smith College colleagues and students as well as all other American friends. For info (post-Smith life, French obits, books including newly reissued memoir about his father-in-law, Gide, familier) email: sumnerglimcher@nyu.edu
