description: First Son

title: F.Y.I.
description: Mystery Tombstone

title: Saving, Through a Child's Eyes
description: At the age of 7, most of us were doing well enough if we could add and subtract. Richard K. Anderson Jr. has already rung the opening bell at the New York Stock Exchange (while he was still in kindergarten) and testified before Congress, the youngest person to do either. At a Manhattan conference next Saturday, H. Carl McCall, the New York State Comptroller, plans to give him and his father, Richard K. Anderson Sr., what Mr. McCall calls the ''Empower Your Future Award'' to honor their role in promoting savings and investments. The father has a financial planning and money management firm, Anderson Financial Services, in Crown Heights, Brooklyn.

title: Population Growth Is Our Problem, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: The View From/White Plains; Head of Arts Council Mixes Art and Money on Her Palette
description: IN the nine years since she has been executive director of the Westchester Arts Council, Janet T. Langsam has become known as someone not averse to mixing art and business. Now she is bringing that blend of money savvy and interest in esthetics to the forefront in the annual gala entitled, appropriately, ''Monopoly.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHULL, RICHARD B.
description: SHULL-Richard B. On October 14, 1999. Beloved husband of Deborah Thomas Shull. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. on Sunday from 2-4 and 6-9 PM. Funeral service at ''The Little Church Around the Corner'' 1 E. 29th St., on Monday, 12 noon. Interment Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. Donations in his memory may be made to the Episcopal Actors Guild, 1 E. 29th St., NYC or the Actors Fund of America, 729 7th Ave., NYC.

title: Sales to Minors
description: Over the last two weeks, the District Attorney's Office arrested workers at two stores during a sting to identify those selling alcohol to minors.

title: The Return of the Suit That Speaks (Quietly) for Itself
description: LAST summer, Dr. Andre L. Churchwell bought himself a new blue suit. Not just any blue suit, but a single-breasted, two-button model with peak lapels and a dapper ticket pocket -- a ringer, he was quick to note, for ''the suit Pierce Brosnan was wearing when he first met Renee Russo in 'The Thomas Crown Affair.' ''

title: The Incubator Of Dreams
description: The other day I stood in the artificial light of a big closet in my temporary grace-and-favor digs to look for garments that I had managed, as I always manage to do when I move, to lose. For no reason at all, the words white lawn dresses entered my head, and I was overwhelmed with tenderness for my joyful nomadic past and with sadness for my spectacularly unsettled present, and I sat down on two unpacked cartons, one marked pillows, the other K for kitchen, and I leaned my head against the red fur of an old coat and had a little weep and imagined I could smell the iodine-and-jasmine fragrance of Indian khus, a fragrance from another time, another place, another room.

title: Are the Glory Days Over For the Dip-Buyers?
description: WILL they or won't they buy the dip?

title: Be Different! (Like Everyone Else!)
description: Are you a unique individual? What a stupid question! How could you not be? You are the only person ever to have been born at 12:08:32 A.M. on June 17, 1973, in the maternity ward of Enos T. Throop Memorial Hospital in Picpus, N.Y. You are easily distinguishable from the infants born in the same location on the same day at 12:07 and 12:09, respectively -- their parents were different from yours, for one thing, unless, of course, you are one of a set of twins or triplets. Even then, your fingerprints will be unique, and the graph of your voiceprint equally singular, identifiably yours alone, even when you talk in a growl or a falsetto. Anyway, the important thing is that you know that you are you, an inimitable human being, with a collection of tastes, tendencies, tropisms, penchants and small perversities that have never been gathered together in exactly the same way in the history of the world.

title: Views and Comfort in a Chappaqua Colonial
description: IT was with great pleasure that we recently witnessed the ever evolving style of Crabtree's Kittle House. Right now, Gregory Gilbert is chef, and his creative dishes projected so many levels of savoriness and refinement that dining here again was like dining here for the first time.

title: 'White Flight' Student Exploited Trenton School
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBSON, NATHAN HANFORD, D.D.S.
description: JACOBSON - Nathan Hanford, D.D.S. Age 89. First dentist in Elmont, L.I. Son of Dora Menken and Harry Jacobson. Brother of the late Eugene Debs Jacobson and Sylvia Feldhammer. Husband of Roslyn (nee Sank) and father of Eric, Neil, Donna and Mark. Grandfather of Alexander, William, James, Cecelia, Max and Allie Rose. Sports enthusiast, poet, celebrator of life. He was loved and will be remembered.

title: Standing Tall
description: EVEN though she is a religious person, Sheri Bouldin knows there are few saints in this life.

title: The Nation; Triangulation: Politics' New Geometry Is Old Math
description: GOV. GEORGE W. BUSH of Texas gets no higher praise from President Clinton's devotees than when they applaud the Republican for proving himself a deft triangulator. But asked about his triangulation skills over lunch at the Governor's Mansion in Austin last week, Mr. Bush looked as if he wanted to smash the sweet potato pie into his questioner's face.

title: Debating Stadium Costs and Benefits
description: If Michael Graney has his way, this perennial second city will be looking for a band of young men to banish its chronic inferiority complex and improve the economy.

title: You Ought to Be in Frosting: The Latest Thing in Cakes
description: An enticing smell drifted through the door of Cakes and Shapes, a tiny bakery on West 39th Street near Ninth Avenue. Just inside, 10-year-old Keisha Phipps gazed approvingly at a cake that featured a large picture of her, braids and all, wreathed with butter-cream icing.

title: Payroll Tax, Temptation And Trouble
description: IT might be the most often-cut corner in starting up a business: putting off remitting payroll taxes to the Internal Revenue Service. You don't have to talk to many veteran company founders to find one who has tried it -- and probably regrets it.

title: Autobytel Brings On-Line Auctions to Consumers
description: Auctions are one the oldest ways to sell cars and other commodities, but now they are getting a modern twist -- on the Internet, of course.

title: Corrections
description: A subheading in the National/International Arts Guide last Sunday about the Wexford Festival Opera referred incorrectly in some copies to the country in which it takes place. It is Ireland, not England.

title: Schottenheimer Is an Unlikely Coaching Candidate
description: Right now, Giants Coach Jim Fassel is fighting to keep his reputation as an offensive guru intact. He is fighting to keep his players from fracturing into a bunch of bickering children. And it may not be too early to say that Fassel is fighting for his job. Fassel made it clear this week with a rousing speech to his players that he has a lot of fight left in him.

title: Revelations From a Delta Journey
description: IN 1941 and 1942, the folklorist Alan Lomax visited the Mississippi Delta to document its African-American folk music. One of his major objectives was to record the Delta's most famous cultural product, the blues. ''Mississippi the Blues Lineage'' (Rounder 11661-1825), whose contents Mr. Lomax selected before a stroke incapacitated him several years ago, represents his early-40's Delta blues fieldwork. It's part of the ambitious ''Alan Lomax Collection,'' whose eventual 140 or more CD's will embrace Mr. Lomax's 50-plus-years of worldwide song collecting.

title: Pamela Moses and Erich Huggler
description: Pamela Abigail Moses, the daughter of Carolyn and Peter T. Moses of Englewood, N.J., was married yesterday on Martha's Vineyard to Erich Evans Huggler, a son of Barbara Anderson of Sanibel, Fla., and Walter F. Huggler of Devon, Pa. The Rev. Stephen P. Bauman, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at the Old Whaling Church in Edgartown, Mass.

title: Alison Bayer, Jonathan Brown
description: Alison D. Bayer, a daughter of Bea and Mitchell Bayer of New York, is to be married today to Jonathan Wood Brown, the son of Sandra Brown of Kennett Square, Pa., and Garrett Wood Brown of Philadelphia. Rabbi Steven Carr Reuben is to officiate at the San Ysidro Ranch, a resort in Montecito, Calif.

title: BEST SELLERS: October 17, 1999
description: Weeks

title: Q and A
description: Walking Tours of Berlin

title: A Show About Nothing (but Larry David)
description: Larry David may have teamed up with Jerry Seinfeld to create one of the most popular sitcoms in television history, but as a stand-up comic in the 1970's and 80's he was not what you'd call a crowd pleaser. If a routine wasn't going well, as was often his perception, he'd sometimes leave the stage in mid-joke. Most comics try to win over obnoxious hecklers through humor; Mr. David preferred to yell at them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYER, SEYMOUR
description: MAYER-Seymour. Died October 13, 1999. He was almost 102. Beloved husband of the late Clara Mayer. Loving father of Marjorie and Martin Diamond. Cherished grandfather of Caryn and Ned. Private services were at graveside.

title: Taking Stock in the Past for the Future
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: The Big City; Towering Case Of Trump Writ Large
description: IN an apparently unprecedented action, Donald J. Trump revealed on Friday that he is not fond of a sign on a building that spells out his name.

title: Tax Returns Of Charities To Be Posted On the Web
description: The detailed tax returns that charities file annually with the Federal Government are to be posted on the Internet beginning today, giving quick and easy access for the first time to comprehensive details on how charities use their money.

title: Monarch's Maze Wins 3d in 4 Starts
description: Monarch's Maze won for the third time in four starts yesterday when he outran seven rivals in the $150,000 Jamaica Handicap at Belmont Park. And, although he had not run in seven weeks, he also finished in the money for the seventh straight time.

title: Jean Shepherd, a Raconteur And a Wit of Radio, Is Dead
description: Jean Shepherd, the New York radio raconteur and author whose rambling jazzlike monologues on the air puzzled many but delighted fans over two decades, died Saturday . He was believed to be in his 70's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUCKERMAN, LEONORA
description: ZUCKERMAN-Leonora. Beloved wife of George. Adored mother of Myles, Jonathan and Royce Burns. Cherished grandmother of Michal, Ruth and Cyndi. Services today, 9:45 AM, at ''Parkside Memorial Chapels,'' 98-60 Queens Blvd, corner 66th Ave, Forest Hills.

title: Ferrari Is Disqualified, Making Hakkinen No. 1
description: SEPANG, Malaysia  Hours after being sprayed with champagne and handed their trophies Sunday, Ferrari's Formula One team was stripped of its victory in the Malaysian Grand Prix, catapulting Mika Hakkinen from third to first place and giving him the 1999 championship.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAU, HAROLD A.
description: BLAU-Harold A. A charming, brilliant, witty gentleman whose friendship will be greatly missed. Harriette Getz and Family

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CAMERON, WILLIAM A.
description: CAMERON-William A. A memorial service will be held at the Central Presbyterian Church, 593 Park Avenue at 64 Street, NYC, 11AM, Thursday, October 21st.

title: Sports of The Times; Down But Not Out: Piazza And Mets
description: IT was well into the evening after the longest game in post-season history, and Mike Piazza was the last Met to come out of training room and join the interviews. Shawon Dunston had a cluster on the other side talking about his great at-bat in the 15th inning. Robin Ventura, who like Piazza had had a woeful series until the 15th, was now mobbed by cameras and talking about his miraculous game-winning run batted in.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: John Clark, 73, Psychiatrist Who Studied Sects
description: Dr. John G. Clark, a Harvard psychiatrist whose study of new religious sects in the 1970's raised public awareness of the overwhelming influence of some groups over their members, died on Oct. 7 at a nursing home in Belmont, Mass. He was 73 and had been suffering from a long illness, his family said.

title: Richard Hough, 77, Historian and Biographer
description: Richard Hough, a historian and novelist whose prolific career included books on Captain Bligh and a biography of the British war hero Earl Mountbatten, died on Oct. 7. He was 77 and had homes in London and Gloucestershire, England.

title: Officials Deny Permit For Protest of Klan Rally
description: An Assemblyman from Manhattan has been denied a permit to demonstrate against a ''white pride'' rally of the Ku Klux Klan, which had already been denied a permit. The Assemblyman, Scott M. Stringer, who represents the West Side of Manhattan, now plans to appeal, his lawyers said yesterday.

title: Onslaught by the Taliban Leaves Afghans Dead or Homeless
description: Those who only had their houses burned or crops destroyed often apologize because their story is not bad enough. They are sheepish about complaining.

title: Parcells Calls the Play and Takes the Heat
description: Ray Lucas threw it and watched it float and hang like mist hovering in the end zone. Keyshawn Johnson was supposed to catch it but, instead, the Colts' Jeff Burris did.

title: Using Consumer Loyalty May Be a Boon For Profit-Hungry Net Service Providers
description: Before his favorite football team started an Internet service, Brett Fennell jumped from one on-line service to another. But when the Baltimore Ravens offered Internet access with premium information about the team, Mr. Fennell found a provider he plans to keep.

title: Sports of The Times; A Turn for the Better Turns Bad for the Jets
description: NOT long after Ray Lucas arrived in the Jets locker room yesterday, he was on cloud nine; he would be a starting quarterback for the first time since he was at Rutgers in 1995. But when he finally returned to the locker room after the 16-13 loss to the Colts, he was on crutches.

title: If Boston Sees Clemens, He'll Be Throwing Inside
description: The Red Sox swung freely and comfortably against Roger Clemens, and Clemens intimated afterward that if he pitches against them again in this series -- ''I hope I don't have to,'' he said -- he will be ready to knock some hitters down.

title: Weakness in Numbers
description: The military coup in Pakistan and the news that there are now six billion people on the planet are not unrelated. Pakistan is just one of many countries in which high population growth has fueled urbanization, unemployment and depletion of resources, which have made the state increasingly hard to govern except through tyrannical means.

title: Fragile Networks of Lives, and of Hope, Emerge
description: There have been times in the last month when Bettina DeCaumette has thought about moving her business, the Palmyra Tea Room and Art Gallery. But she knows it would lose something by leaving the ambience of this small borough's downtown.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRISSEY, GARY EUGENE
description: CRISSEY-Gary Eugene. On October 13th at age 61. Loving father of Pamela Ragusa & Nicole Mitchell. Grandfather of Isabelle Mitchell. Son of Eugene and Dorothy Crissey and brother of Jon Crissey. Memorial service at St. Patrick's Old Cathedral, Mott and Prince Streets, Tuesday, October 19, 2 PM. Interment private. Contributions in his memory may be sent to Friends Indeed, 594 Broadway, Suite 706, New York, New York 10012.

title: SBC Communications to Offer High-Speed Internet Connections
description: Firing the latest salvo in the local telephone industry's battle against cable television providers, SBC Communications Inc. intends to announce today that it will spend $6 billion in the next three years to deploy high-speed Internet systems, people close to the company said yesterday.

title: Morgan Stanley to Offer On-Line Trading to All Its Customers
description: In old-line Wall Street's latest entry into the Internet stock-trading bazaar, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter is preparing to introduce an overhaul of its brokerage business and to offer all its clients the option of buying and selling stocks on line at discount prices.

title: It's Demons vs. Angels in Computer Game With a Religious Theme
description: The last time Robert Westmoreland promoted a new concept for a computer game, the industry first laughed but then chased him, after his idea proved a huge winner. And starting today, he hopes that history repeats itself -- the Lord and the marketplace willing.

title: A David Bowie Who Takes It Lightly
description: David Bowie, that fey chameleon of pop music, has metamorphosed into a giggly middle-aged man in clunky boots and an oversize sweatshirt. At least that's the character he has elected to offer as himself tonight for the latest segment of the VH1 series ''Storytellers.''

title: Poor People Are Fighting Baffling Surge in Asthma
description: The asthma epidemic visited Children's National Medical Center one recent Friday, the day after a furious rainstorm kicked up allergens all over Washington. By 9 A.M., the emergency room, where children come in more often for failing lungs than for broken bones, was jumping. Harried nurses barked orders for the pharmacy to send more drugs. In bed after bed, young faces, all African-American, were buried under clear plastic breathing masks.

title: Braves Haunted by 19 Runners They Left Stranded
description: The Atlanta Braves stood around the losing clubhouse after their 15-inning, 5-hour-46-minute marathon with the Mets and lamented how they could not hold a one-run lead in the 15th. Their laments were misplaced. The Braves lost the game long before that inning. They are trying to get to their fifth World Series in the 1990's, but they sure are taking a strange route.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENRY, JANET
description: HENRY-Janet. St. John's Episcopal Hospital, South Shore, would like to extend their deepest sympathy to the family of Janet Henry in their time of sorrow. Nancy Simmons Regional Administrator

title: Vernon de Tar, 94, Organist Influential in Church Music
description: Vernon de Tar, the organist and choirmaster at the Episcopal Church of the Ascension in Greenwich Village for 42 years and a teacher at the Union Theological Seminary, Yale University and the Juilliard School, died on Oct. 7 in Kennett Square, Pa., where he lived. He was 94.

title: Black Day in Pakistan
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLEN, ETHEL
description: ALLEN-Ethel. 76, of NYC. Oct.12, 1999. Memorial services, 1:00 PM, Oct. 20, 1999, Riverside Church, 490 Riverside Drive. 212-870-6703.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TANNENBAUM, SARAH
description: TANNENBAUM-Sarah. Congregation Orach Chaim and Sisterhood record with profound sorrow the passing of our beloved member for more than half a century. A survivor of the Holocaust, a true ''Aiches Chayil,'' together with her husband they built a home of the highest ideals of Torah and Chesed. We extend heartfelt sympathy to her husband Joseph, her children Lisa (Dr. Jeffrey Glanz), Evelyn, and grandchildren. May they be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Michael D. Shmidman, Rabbi Wolf Scheck, President

title: Making 'Contact' Without Conflict; How a Hit Dance Play Evolved, Cordially
description: Not long ago, in the early hours of a Manhattan morning, the choreographer Susan Stroman wandered into an underground pool hall that turned into a swing club after midnight. What caught her eye in the sea of black-clad couples swirling in the smoky darkness was a single dancer in a yellow dress.

title: A Strained Relationship Turns Sour
description: Like many relationships in Hollywood, the one between the trade papers -- Variety and The Hollywood Reporter -- and the movie studios is an odd one. The papers need studio advertisements to survive. And the studios need the trade papers to promote their latest deals, spin the news and learn what rivals are doing.

title: Nuclear Plant Safety Rules Were Broken, Inquiry Finds
description: Supervisors at a Government nuclear fuel factory near Richland, Wash., sometimes told workers to ignore rules intended to prevent accidental nuclear reactions, according to an Energy Department investigation that has gained new interest because of a recent accident in Japan.

title: Bowden vs. Bowden Could Be Upsetting
description: Two of the most memorable predictions in my lifetime have been intoned by Jon Landau and Beano Cook. Back in the 1970's, Landau was a rock critic who listened, watched and was moved enough by a New Jersey singer-songwriter to declare him the ''rock-and-roll future.''

title: A Gain for Arabs in East Jerusalem
description: Interior Minister Natan Sharansky announced today that he had ended an Israeli policy that had stripped thousands of Palestinians from East Jerusalem of their right to live there.

title: Cleaner New York Air
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A front-page news analysis article on Thursday about the Republican-led defeat of the test ban treaty misidentified the treaty that the Senate approved in 1996. It was Start II, not the SALT agreement.

title: Oddity and Normality Vie in Subway Killer's Confession
description: Throughout his murder trial, Andrew Goldstein, a 30-year-old man with a psychiatric file thicker than most Presidential biographies, has sat like some Sphinx at the defense table, rarely talking to his lawyers, often resting his head on his arms, or staring forward, emotionless and silent.

title: Artistic Standards
description: To the Editor:

title: Sam Renick, Multifaceted Jockey, 87
description: Sam Renick, one of the country's leading jockeys half a century ago and later a pioneer in racing television and one of the founders of the Jockeys' Guild, died Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 87 years old.

title: A Forest Legacy
description: If he were to walk away from the conservation issue right now, President Clinton would already have achieved a respectable legacy, including his considerable efforts to restore the Everglades, preserve Utah's red rock wilderness, save California's redwoods and protect Yellowstone National Park from destructive mining. But in terms of scope and political audacity, nothing quite matches the proposal he announced last week to protect more than 40 million acres of national forest from commercial development. If his scheme survives legal and Congressional challenges, no sure thing, it will almost surely be recorded as a signature environmental achievement of his Administration.

title: Test Ban Treaty's Defeat Is Senate's Shame
description: To the Editor:

title: Harry Potter and the Magic Stock; A Children's Book Series Helps Rejuvenate a British Publisher
description: You've read the books. You may even see the movie. Now, behold the stock.

title: To Talk Like New York, Sign Up for Spanish
description: Sitting on their mothers' laps, six small children wait quietly in a second-floor schoolroom on the Upper East Side. The oldest child is 2; the youngest just turned 1. One sucks his thumb. Another plays with her belly button.

title: Test Ban Treaty's Defeat Is Senate's Shame
description: To the Editor:

title: Huard, Not Marino, Answers Challenge
description: It was early in the first quarter when Miami quarterback Dan Marino flicked an 8-yard strike to wide receiver Tony Martin. That play against the New England Patriots put Marino over 60,000 passing yards for his career, making him the first player to surpass that mark. Unfortunately, it was about the only good thing Marino did all day.

title: Other Kinds of Pressure
description: Orlando Hernandez smirked when he was asked about feeling pressure in Game 5 on Monday, and discussed how fans in Cuba had thrown rocks, tomatoes and ''anything they can find'' on the field. Essentially, he said, the rowdiest fans at Fenway Park would not unnerve him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EVANGELIST, FELIX G.
description: EVANGELIST-Felix G. Of Stamford, formerly of Greenwich, CT. On October 14, 1999. Survived by his wife, Elinor Sautter Evangelist, and his grandson, Andrew Gropper. Father of the late Jane E. Gropper.

title: Smooth Waters for the Challengers
description: As the skippers who will sail for the right to challenge the holder of the America's Cup met in Auckland, New Zealand, last night for the traditional eve-of-racing gathering, they seemed reluctant to start the sort of verbal duels that have frequently roiled cup waters.

title: Rapp Collins Forms Interactive Agency
description: Rapp Collins Worldwide in New York, part of Omnicom Group, has formed an interactive agency and acquired an equity stake in a Canadian Internet services company, Critical Mass Inc. in Calgary, Alberta.

title: Pettitte Comes Through Loud and Clear As the Yankees Drown Out the Red Sox
description: The Yankees were within a couple of outs of wrapping up a satisfying 9-2 victory over the Red Sox in Game 4 of the American League Championship Series tonight, when the heated rivalry between the two sides boiled over.

To his wife Gertrude, the entire Betcher family and all who loved him, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Matthew E. Fink, M.D. President and CEO Henry Singman, M.D. President, Medical Board Sundar Koppolu, M.D. Chairman of Anesthesiology Robert L. Salant, M.D. President Doctors Alumni Association

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, BENJAMIN
description: BERMAN-Benjamin. On October 17, 1999. Beloved husband of Shirley, devoted father of Evan and Nancy, Martin, Elyse and Louis, cherished grandpa of Howard and Sherry and best friend of ''Brandy.'' Funeral service Monday, 10 AM, from I.J. Morris, 1895 Flatbush Ave, Brooklyn. Interment New Montefiore Cemetery.

title: Political Memo; Minority Voters Dot Bush's Campaign Calendar
description: When Gov. George W. Bush of Texas swept into Washington on Friday, his first stop was not an affluent suburb or a ritzy business district, nor were his first encounters with stalwart Republican voters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAMTON, MARGOT (NEE SIEGEL)
description: SAMTON-Margot (nee Siegel). Of Scarsdale. 90 years old. Cherished wife of 67 years of Henry A. Samton; beloved mother of Annette Marcus, Claude and Peter Samton; adored grandmother of Josh, Matthew, Zach, Noah and Daniel Samton, Jessie and Mimsy Marcus; revered mother-in-law of Emily Samton and Paul Marcus; dear aunt of Albert Brunell, Dr. Peter Schrag and Katherine Wangh. Passed away October 16, 1999. Service at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave, Tuesday, October 19, 12:30 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAKER, CROWELL
description: BAKER-Crowell. The Trustees of The Church Club of New York note with sorrow the death of their fellow Board Member, Crowell Baker, and send their heartfelt condolences to his family. Chauncey G. Olinger Jr., Pres.

title: Everyone Healthy, Rangers Move Into Tie for 1st
description: The Rangers had anticipated something like this all summer long. Theo Fleury scoring goals. Four solid lines dividing ice time. A healthy Mike Richter making save after tricky save. And the Rangers perched atop their division.

title: Williams Wins On Her Fourth Try
description: Emily Williams of Loveland, Ohio, turned her fourth try in the Medal Final into a winning one when she beat a field of 225 riders at the Pennsylvania National Horse Show in Harrisburg yesterday.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Fifty-two years ago, we started with a beacon of hope, and today that beacon is no more. We stand in darkness. Our economy has crumbled, our credibility is lost, state institutions lie demolished.''

title: Test Ban Treaty's Defeat Is Senate's Shame
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, HELEN ROTH
description: SCHNEIDER-Helen Roth. On October 17, 1999. Beloved wife of Nathan for 49 years. Loving mother of Julie Kaufmann, cherished grandmother of Samara and Davie, dear sister of Daniel Roth. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St, Monday, 7-9 PM, with service Tuesday, 11:30 AM. Interment at New Mt. Carmel Cemetary.

title: THIS WEEK
description: EVENTS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TONKIN, JOSEPH
description: TONKIN-Joseph. On October 15, at age 94. Beloved husband of the late Celina Tonkin. Loving son of the late Nathaniel Tonkin and Lily Freedman Tonkin and brother of the late A. Ted Tonkin. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, at 81 St, Tuesday, 12 noon. Interment Mt. Neboh Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BARBASH, ROSLYN
description: BARBASH-Roslyn. 1/5/11-10/18/85. Wise physician, loving wife and mother, loyal friend. You are vividly remembered with affection by all whose lives you touched

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Bear Stearns Securities To Pay $3.5 Million More

title: Montenegrins See Split With Serbia
description: With its economy spinning toward disaster, tiny Montenegro is close to taking one more formal step toward independence from Slobodan Milosevic's Yugoslavia: the establishment of its own currency.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERMELSTEIN, IRENE
description: MERMELSTEIN-Irene. On October 16, 1999, at the age of 90 years. Much beloved mother, grandmother and great-grandmother. She was loved by all and gave her heart and soul to her family. She is survived by daughter, Myra Koss, who took care of her for more than five years; son, Seymour and daughter-in-law Sue; granddaughter, Laura Koss-Feder, who will always cherish her grandmother; and grandchildren, Sally and Lee Mermelstein; and great-granddaughter, Natalie Nelson. She was the widow of David. Funeral services were held on October 17, 1999.

title: Jim Jensen, a News Anchor At WCBS-TV, Is Dead at 73
description: Jim Jensen, a gravelly voiced and popular WCBS-TV news anchor and news reporter who was a major figure in New York television for years, died on Saturday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 73 and lived on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

title: Compressed Data; Trying to Draw Eyes To a New Web Site
description: Speaking of cyber celebrities, Cindy Crawford, who has turned heads on the fashion runway, will now try to draw eyes to a Web site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANZANO, FRANKLIN
description: LANZANO-Franklin. New York City educator, died October 15, 1999. For information, contact Higgins Funeral Home, New City, NY.

title: Sounds Like Parker, But Bigger
description: More than half the members of the Carnegie Hall Jazz Band are brass players, so they gave Charlie Parker's music a super-enlarged, fanfarelike feeling on Thursday night in the first concert of the band's season. The better portion of the evening was given over to 17-piece versions of tunes Parker either wrote or made famous by performing with small groups. The first half recreated the instrumentation and repertory of the 1953 concert at Massey Hall in Toronto, in which Parker played with Bud Powell, Dizzy Gillespie and Charles Mingus.

title: PAKISTANI GENERAL FORMS NEW PANEL TO GOVERN NATION
description: Pakistan's military ruler, saying his nation had ''hit rock bottom,'' redrew its Government tonight, creating a military and civilian council to run the country and giving no timetable for relinquishing the absolute power he seized five days ago.

title: A Killing Shocks Jamaicans Into Soul-Searching
description: When robbers murdered an 85-year-old woman in her Kingston home in August, what has become a routine crime in violent Jamaica soon had extraordinary repercussions.

title: Maker of On-Screen Guide For TV Has Eye on Future
description: A decade ago, Henry Yuen couldn't program his videocassette recorder. Now he is vying to become the Bill Gates of television.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHULL, RICHARD B.
description: SHULL-Richard B. We mourn the loss of our fellow Player. A wonderful actor, his presence gave us great joy, many laughs and delightful companionship. He will be greatly missed. Our deepest sympathies to his beloved Deborah. The Players

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, MELVIN, M.D.
description: KAHN-Melvin, M.D. In fond memory of an enduring friendship of more than 60 years. Bob Goldston

title: The Knicks Reverting To Their Old Ways
description: The same Knicks who nearly collapsed under selfish play last season have been giving in to their spotlight cravings again, running the court as if they were models on a runway.

title: Subway Shuttle Gets $74 Million Makeover
description: Ever since the Dodgers left Brooklyn in 1957, the Franklin Avenue shuttle, which used to ferry baseball fans to and from Ebbets Field, has been a grimy symbol of decline for the borough.

title: Ford Creates Regional Jobs And Shuffles Its Executives
description: After five years of experimenting with a complex management structure that gave managers global responsibility for certain functions, like worldwide small car development, the Ford Motor Company plans to return on Jan. 1 to a more traditional organization in which many executives will have regional responsibilities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENBERG, JEAN
description: EISENBERG-Jean. Beloved wife of the late William. Devoted mother of Ann Karmin and Robert Eisenberg. Sister of Audrey Danis. Loving grandmother of Lisa, Rachael, Deborah, Sarah and Spenser. Great-grandmother of Alexa. Services were held yesterday.

title: Bear Stearns Agrees to Pay $3.5 Million in Baron Case
description: The Bear Stearns Securities Corporation, the Wall Street brokerage firm subsidiary that processes securities transactions for thousands of smaller firms, has agreed to pay an additional $3.5 million to cover losses incurred by customers of A. R. Baron & Company, a defunct brokerage firm whose trades it cleared.

title: Big U.S. Buyout Firm Enters the Fray in Europe
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, the United States leveraged buyout firm, is negotiating two deals worth as much as $1.6 billion in its first significant foray in Europe since it set up offices here at the beginning of the year, executives close to the company said today.

title: Moscow Journal; Raise a Glass to the Effervescent View of Russia!
description: The American who brought consumer capitalism to Russia 40 years ago came back for a visit last week -- to the reports of bribery and money laundering, to the Mercedesful of impeccably suited thugs, to the political wars among the lap-dog newspapers and television networks of too-wealthy tycoons, to the throngs of street urchins and dumpster-miners trampled in the stampede to wealth.

description: To the Editor:

title: Test Ban Treaty's Defeat Is Senate's Shame
description: To the Editor:

title: Compressed Data: Y2K Pulse; Year 2000 Campaigners Take to the Streets
description: Campaigners calling for more aggressive preparations for Year 2000 computer disruptions have been frustrated over the general apathy they have encountered and the increasing difficulty of getting media coverage for their message.

title: The Four A's plans a Web site about agencies for marketers to use when reviewing their accounts.
description: THE trade organization representing the nation's advertising agencies is planning one of its most ambitious projects ever, providing information on line about members that could help them win new clients.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: African Editor Jailed for Wedding News
description: When this tiny kingdom's only independent newspaper discovered that the King's newest bride-to-be had dropped out of high school -- not once, but twice -- before being picked to be the young ruler's eighth wife, the paper's Sunday editor, Bheki Makhubu, figured he had a sure-fire front-page story.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JENSEN, HAROLD JIM
description: JENSEN-Harold Jim. October 16. Print and broadcast journalist for 45 years. Beloved husband of Rachel Gordon. Loving father of Denene, Heidi and Lisa, and the late Randall, and the proud daddy of Noah. He leaves five grandchildren and his sisters June and Arlene, and brother Carl. He will be missed by the many who knew and respected him. Memorial services will be held on Wednesday, October 20, 2 PM at St. Peter's Church, 619 Lexington Ave., NYC.

title: A City Impinges, Through a Lens, Not Always Darkly
description: If you surfed, sat through or tuned in, turned on and dropped out of the high and mighty PBS mastodon ''American Photography: A Century of Images'' last week, you probably also went rifling through your collection of photography books, craving images you knew would delight you and looking for those that asked something new of you.

title: Bush Sends 2 Signals In Minority Contacts
description: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas routinely reaches out to minorities on the campaign trail in an effort to show swing and independent voters that he is near enough to the center to warrant their allegiance. Mr. Bush, the Republican front-runner, acknowledged that he wanted that message to be heard not only by minority members but also by other voters simply taking the measure of what kind of Republican he is.

title: A Comic Megastar, Possums, and Don't You Forget It
description: ''Aqua!''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHOMER, ROBERT R., V.M.D.
description: SHOMER-Robert R., V.M.D. Age 85, of Mahawah, NJ. Practiced as a veterinarian for 60 years in Teaneck, NJ. Husband of Mary, father of Andrea Miller, Barbara Kelsey, and Carla Shomer. Brother of Ralph Shomer, beloved grandfather and great-grandfather. Predeceased by Leona Shomer, 1996. Services were held at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, Paramus, NJ.

title: Media Talk; Will Journal's Managing Editor Go to CNN?
description: Paul E. Steiger, the managing editor of The Wall Street Journal, is considering an offer from CNN to take the helm of the network's financial news outlets -- including the troubled CNNfn financial network -- which have been without their own leader since the departure of Lou Dobbs in June.

title: In America; Keeping The Faith
description: The dominant religion in Indiana for most of this century has been basketball. The houses of worship more often than not were funky, rundown arenas that offered the faithful a rocking, roaring escape from the hard life and cold nights in places like Muncie and Fort Wayne and French Lick and Logootee.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Billions in the Name of a Great Party
description: A quarter-million dollars. A billion dollars. Even $3 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOVENETSKY, SAM
description: KOVENETSKY-Sam. October 15, 1999, at age 87. Adoring and beloved husband of Betty. Loving father of Rolf and Regina. Dear grandfather of David and Rachel Kovenetsky. Devoted step-father of Rick and Chris Shain. Stepgrandfather of Brahman, Autumn and April. Great-grandfather of Cody. A man of all seasons. A pioneer of the labor movement. Founding father of Local 1-S, dedicated to serving the workers of Macy's for 40 years. Labor liaison to Governor Carey. Appointed by Governor Cuomo to serve as Commissioner of the Unemployment Appeals Board for 17 years. He served on the Boards of United Way of NYC, Empire Blue Cross Blue Shield, Group Health Insurance Inc., American Cancer Society-New York Divison, Brooklyn Psychiatric Center, Greater New York Fund, City of Hope-Robal Chapter, B'nai Brith-Business and Labor Lodge, past president of the New York Chapter of the Industrial Relations Research Association. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the NYC Central Labor Council's Camp Program. Rest in peace, my darling, my best friend. Service Monday, 11:15 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Accounts
description: * Netpliance, Austin, Tex., which makes a personal Internet access device, to McGarrah/Jessee, Austin, to handle its first national branding account, with billings estimated at more than $15 million. Rosen Brown Direct, Portland, Ore., handles direct marketing.

title: As Green Monster Scowls, Yankee Fans Stand Tall
description: In Fenway Park's bathrooms, Red Sox fans snatch Yankee fans' baseball caps, deposit them in toilets and use the toilets. In the stands, they madly chant the reverse of the Yankee Stadium mantra ''Boston stinks!'' substituting Yankees for Boston. And since ''1998! 1998!'' (the last year the Yankees won the World Series) isn't quite as stinging as ''1918! 1918!'' (the last time the Red Sox won the World Series) they sarcastically chant the name of the Yankees' pitcher (''AN-dy! AN-dy!'').

title: Looking Out for Rocker
description: Leo Mazzone, Atlanta's pitching coach, was assigned the task of trying to save the Braves' closer, John Rocker, from himself yesterday. When Rocker, whose comments have inflamed the Shea Stadium fans, went out to left field to shag balls during batting practice, Mazzone stood beside him, positioning himself between Rocker and the fans.

title: Nisource Increases Its Bid for Columbia Energy to $6.2 Billion
description: Nisource Inc., a Midwestern utility, has raised its bid for Columbia Energy Group, a natural gas company in the East, to $74 a share in cash, or $6.2 billion, Nisource said over the weekend.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an illustration on Saturday with an analysis of an advertisment written by Vice President Al Gore to denounce the Senate's vote against ratifying the nuclear test ban treaty omitted the text of the finished version, after his editing. The text appears today, on page A17.

title: Sports of The Times; It's a New Fall Season for the Mets
description: By the 10th inning, Mookie Wilson started having flashbacks, that strange feeling that sometime in another life he had witnessed a wild game like this.

title: Bearing With the Pain, and Fighting a Trend; Devotees of No-Drug Childbirth Frustrated by Rise in Use of Anesthesia
description: Last Saturday, as a long morning of labor dragged into afternoon, Elba M. Quinones soaked in a warm tub at an outpatient birthing center in Greenwich Village, trying to ease her pain. Her contractions came every three minutes. And when they intensified, her screams at times became primal. Once she howled to her husband that she couldn't take it any more.

title: Coaches Had Doubts, but Valentin Had Other Ideas
description: The animated conversations about John Valentin took place in the ancient newspaper offices of The Jersey Journal in Jersey City 14 years ago. Every night, Larry Babich would shuffle 30 feet from the newsroom to the sports department and ask Mike Hogan about Valentin's future. Hogan barely looked up from his typewriter before telling Babich nothing had changed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODSKY, HAROLD P.
description: BRODSKY-Harold P. Born on November 18, 1920, in Rockaway, NY. Passed away on October 17, due to a brief illness. Son of the late William and Beatrice Brodsky. He is survived by his loving and devoted wife Shirley; his loving sons Peter (Vangela) and Stephen; grandchildren Nicole, Brett, Chelsea, Jake and Rachel. He was a decorated Marine Lieutenant in World War II and fought in the Pacific Campaign for three years in the Third Marine Division. He graduated Columbia University in 1942, and majored in physical education. He owned a manufacturing company in the Bronx for 35 years. He will be greatly missed and always remembered.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Lee Lozano, 68, Conceptual Artist Who Boycotted Women for Years
description: Lee Lozano, an eccentric artist who pursued Conceptual Art and painting in the 1960's and then left the New York art world for self-imposed exile that included an embargo on contact with other women, died on Oct. 2 in the Dallas Health and Rehabilitation Center in Texas. She was 68 and lived in Dallas.

title: Driver in Hit-and-Run Killed in Second Crash
description: A Long Island man who was fleeing the scene of a car accident in Brooklyn was killed early yesterday when he got into a second crash as he tried to escape, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LESSER, FLORENCE (NEE SARVER)
description: LESSER-Florence (nee Sarver). Of Dumont, NJ. Beloved wife of the late Jerome. Devoted mother of Craig Lesser. Services ''Wien & Wien'', 129 Engle St, Englewood, NJ, on Monday, October 18, 1 PM. For information: 1-800-322-0533.

title: Good-Natured Anarchy Within Power Struggles
description: The dance component of the New Europe '99 Festival got off to a cheerful, elegant start on Wednesday night at Dance Theater Workshop with Sasha Pepelyaev's Kinetic Theater in ''One Second Hand.'' The magical opening scene suggested a dark, snowy Russian landscape. The music, a combination of live violin and synthesizer, had a rollicking folk-song feel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEATING, PIERSON
description: KEATING-Pierson. Partners and friends of Pierson Keating at Nordeman Grimm express their heartfelt sympathies in the death of one of their founding partners and esteemed colleague. Executive search pioneer, sportsman, philanthropist and gracious friend to all, he will be deeply missed. We send our love and sympathies to his wife and children.

title: Ella Mae Morse, 75, Vocalist Who Transcended Pop Genres
description: Ella Mae Morse, the sultry, swinging pop-jazz singer whose 1942 hit, ''Cow-Cow Boogie,'' became the first million seller for the fledgling Capitol Records and helped establish the label, died on Saturday at the Western Arizona Regional Medical Center in Bullhead City. She was 75 and lived in Bullhead City.

title: Credit Offerings Scheduled for This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: Equity and Convertible Debt Offerings Scheduled for This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Editorial Observer; Beware of Spies Who Think They Can Be Smart Venture Capitalists
description: The Central Intelligence Agency has worn many disguises and operated countless front companies, but until now it has never established a Silicon Valley venture capital firm. The decision to set up the nonprofit investment company, named In-Q-It, is outlandish. Maybe the Federal Bureau of Investigation would like to get into the banking business or the Secret Service might like to spin off a subsidiary that provides personal security for celebrities.

title: Dancers Dare To Innovate With Protest And Hip-Hop
description: Compagnie Kafig, a French-Algerian troupe, is rightly one of the most talked-about groups on the experimental dance scene in France. Full Circle Souljahz, Bronx-based, deserves to be talked about more.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOX, FLORENCE J.
description: FOX-Florence J. Passed away in Los Angeles, CA, on October 16, 1999. Beloved mother of Samantha and Debra Fox Diamond; cherished grandmother of Eli Diamond; dear sister of Leo Jacobs and Bess Sherman. Memorial service in New York to be announced.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Nigeria's Promising Start
description: When former Gen. Olusegun Obasanjo was inaugurated as president of Nigeria in late May, he took over a once-prosperous nation that had been reduced to misery by a series of larcenous military regimes. In the late 1970's, Mr. Obasanjo was himself Nigeria's military ruler, although the first to turn over power to a civilian. In 1995, Gen. Sani Abacha, the country's most ruthless leader, jailed him for three years. But General Obasanjo remained close to the military and, bankrolled by some of Nigeria's most nefarious officers, won elections this year. There was reason for skepticism about his intentions.

title: Rookie Pitcher Fails, But He Doesn't Hide
description: In the cramped visitors' locker room, the Atlanta Braves players tried to dress quickly, grabbing their clothes from lockers that had tatters of plastic still stapled to the wood. The sheets of plastic that were there to protect their clothes from the anticipated champagne bath had been torn down.

title: EU Sets Up Framework On Crime and Refugees
description: TAMPERE, Finland  The European Union now has the bare bones of a common judicial and immigration policy that seeks to make life tougher for organized criminals while providing more equitable treatment for refugees.

title: Media Talk; Mythic City Editor Is Brought Back to Life
description: In a year fixated on the millennium, a 65th anniversary does not amount to much. But as an artifact of its time, the reissue of Stanley Walker's classic 1934 book, ''City Editor,'' (Johns Hopkins University Press) has its moments as a saucy explication of the Depression-era newspaper world. It's a baseline for how far we've come and how far we haven't.

title: Those Irrelevant Small Cards Can Hold Vital Information
description: The unimportant can be important. Declarers who understand this are careful with irrelevant small cards played from the closed hand, because they may give valuable information to the opposition.

title: The 'Designated Spear Catcher' on Campaign Finance
description: IT has become one of the enduring rituals on Capitol Hill:

title: Giants on TV, Parental Discretion Advised
description: The Dallas Cowboys have not been a welcome sight, and ''Monday Night Football'' has not been a welcome forum during the past three decades of Giants football.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, ALBERT
description: GORDON-Albert. Beloved husband of Marcia (nee Demov). Devoted father of Fred and father-inlaw of Irene, cherished grandfather of Jeffrey and Rachel, loving brother and uncle. Services Monday 1 PM, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRAGO, ROSARIO P. (BUD), M.D.
description: DRAGO-Rosario P. (Bud), M.D. On October 16, 1999. Beloved husband of Betty (nee Brisgal) Drago. Loving father of Joseph, Mariann Drago Berliner, Carl, Bud, John, Eleanor Drago-Severson and Paul. Cherished brother of Sylvia Romeo. Loving grandfather of 17 grandchildren and two greatgrandchildren. Rosario was a Knight of Malta, a graduate of the University of Illinois College and Medical School. He was commanding medical officer at Greenville, SC, A.A.B. He was Chair of St. Francis Hospital in the Bronx as well as St. Clare's Hospital in NYC. He was past president of the Catholic Physician Guild and supervising physician of NYS Office of Disabilities. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held Tuesday, 10:30 AM, at St. Barnabas Church. Entombment following at Woodlawn Cemetery. The family will be present Monday, 2-4 and 7-9, at F. Ruggiero & Sons, Inc., 732 Yonkers Ave., Yonkers, NY. Donations can be made to the Joseph and Eleanora Drago Scholarship Fund at St. Barnabas High School, 425 E. 240th St., Bronx, NY 10470.

title: Knoblauch's Woes Aren't Costly
description: Chuck Knoblauch was scooping up grounders before the bottom of the first inning when he a bounced a throw to Tino Martinez that caused the fans to taunt him. Knoblauch then gave the fans even more ammunition by throwing a ball about 20 feet to Martinez's left that hit the photographers' booth beside the first-base dugout. The fans at Fenway Park howled.

title: Supporters of Linux Worry That Commercialization Could Bring Chaos
description: Graying nerds who recall the Balkanization of Unix into a slew of incompatible operating systems may be reliving history with the proliferation of Linux brands.

title: Test Ban Treaty's Defeat Is Senate's Shame
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Mac Attack: Score One for France
description: To the Editor:

title: Jets' Once-Promising Season Ends Before Mets'
description: In this season of the unthinkable for the Jets, they lost another game today, another quarterback and, apparently, any realistic chance of salvaging the campaign that many fans believed would end at the Super Bowl.

title: Essay; Anti-Anti-Corruption
description: When anti-Communism became dominant in the U.S., a group on the left -- not Communist itself, but resentful of the ideological victors -- launched attacks on the anti-Communists. They called us unreconstructed cold warriors, triumphalist dupes unable to envision the convergence of the Soviet and American systems. Thus was anti-anti-Communism born.

title: Indonesia's Low-Key Opposition Leader Faces a Tough Battle in Presidential Ballot
description: The banners read ''Megawati or revolution'' and there are many people here who believe that they are not only a threat but also a prediction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DELLER, HAROLD. (CPA)
description: DELLER-Harold. (CPA). Beloved husband of the late Roslyn. Devoted father of Lisa Deller. Dear brother of Doris Wieder. Services Monday, 12 noon, at Schwartz Bros. Jeffer Memorial, Queens Blvd. and 76th Rd., Forest Hills.

title: Sports of The Times; Torre Remains Calm In the Fans' Storm
description: THERE was more shame added to the battered Boston Red Sox lore here last night, in the form of plastic bottles and debris hurled by more than a few fans at the team they love to hate. It should be more humiliating to this sports-mad city than any baseball defeat could be.

title: DEVISING NEW MATH TO DEFINE POVERTY
description: The Census Bureau has begun to revise its definition of what constitutes poverty in the United States, experimenting with a formula that would drop millions more families below the poverty line.

title: Thrillers Of Cold War In a Hall Of Justice
description: The lobby of the Federal courthouse in Brooklyn: pictures of President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore. A large bronze eagle. A metal detector and security guards. A poster of Cary Grant kissing Ingrid Bergman.

title: Islamic Militants With Japanese Hostages Hold Kyrgyz at Bay
description: Ever since five new nations emerged in Central Asia from the ruins of the Soviet Union, there have been warnings that the region was ripe for Islamic insurrection and insurgency. This summer, just such an insurgency erupted in Kyrgyzstan, the smallest and most democratic country in the region.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENHAIM, JENNY (NEE SALINAS)
description: BENHAIM-Jenny (nee Salinas). Of Riverdale, NY, on October 16, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Victor. Devoted mother of Muriel Saunders and the late Ned. Loving grandmother of William M. and Lorraine Saunders White and great-grandmother of Brendan and Alison Saunders. Services and funeral are private. Memorials to the American Cancer Society in memory of her son, Ned Benhaim, would be appreciated. For further information contact Barrett Funeral Home, Tenafly, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRITZ, STANLEY L.
description: DRITZ-Stanley L. Age 88. Beloved husband of 63 years of Dorothy, devoted father of James, loving grandfather of three and greatgrandfather of three. He was the former President of John Dritz and Sons, Inc, as well as President of The National Notion Association and captain of the Syracuse University tennis team. He was an inspiration to his loving family and was respected by his entire business community. Memorial contributions to Syracuse University, 820 Comstock Ave, Suite 100, Syracuse, NY 13244-5040, or The American Parkinson Disease Association, Inc, 1250 Hylan Blvd, Suite 4B, Staten Island, NY 10305-1946, would be appreciated. Funeral service, Monday 1 PM, at The Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Ave, White Plains, NY.

title: A Grand Slam That Wasn't
description: Even though Robin Ventura appeared to have hit a grand slam in the 15th inning last night, the final score of the Mets' victory over the Atlanta Braves was 4-3, not 7-3, in Game 5 of the National League Championship Series at Shea Stadium.

title: Media Talk; Worth Strives to Be Internet-Oriented
description: Pssst . . . Hey, you -- rich guy. Need a house in the Hamptons? A Gulfstream jet? Want to buy one on line?

title: At Mid-Century, Choking on the Class System
description: Perhaps it's a simple matter of an actor who hasn't been told when to back off, but Reg Rogers pushes so hard in ''Look Back in Anger'' that the play seems to cower in the corner whenever he enters.

title: Compressed Data; Flooz Receives Help From Whoopi Goldberg
description: The actress Whoopi Goldberg has just signed on to be the chief promoter of a form of on-line gift currency. By using her celebrity in exchange for stock in the company, Ms. Goldberg adds her name to a list of cyberrepresentatives that already includes the former ''Star Trek'' actor William Shatner and the tennis star Anna Kournikova.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLADSTONE, KENNETH
description: GLADSTONE-Kenneth. To a man who lived goodness. Our lives have been blessed by knwing you. Our hearts go out to our dearest friend Lucy and your family. Love and respect always. Batyah Kahane and Family

title: Scientists Are Mystified by Deaths Of Lobsters in Long Island Sound
description: Marine experts suspect that a mysterious pathogen has killed tens of thousands of lobsters in Long Island Sound this fall.

title: Only Extra Thrills
description: By the time the Mets' 15-inning, 4-3 victory over Atlanta ended last night, the Yankees-Red Sox playoff game had reached the seventh inning and ESPN's Washington-Arizona National Football League game was in the second half. Oh, it was long, but those many scoreless innings were rarely boring.

title: A Correction; Complete Text Of Gore Ad
description: Following is the script of a television advertisement made by Vice President Al Gore criticizing the vote by the Senate last week not to approve an arms control treaty. The script was omitted from an article about the advertisement in Saturday's paper:

title: Big Effort Is Small Comfort
description: In Wayne Chrebet's first appearance of the season, he snared five passes before halftime for 51 yards today. But the Jets receiver, who had been sidelined with a broken foot, could not hook up with quarterback Ray Lucas in the second half of the 16-13 loss to the Indianapolis Colts.

title: Design Fantasies for a Strip of the West Side
description: There are only three more days to see an exhibition of new designs for the redevelopment of the far West Side of mid-Manhattan. I strongly urge you to see the show, on display through Wednesday in Vanderbilt Hall, the former waiting room at Grand Central Terminal. The five proposals on view are not uniformly great, but each is packed with intelligence, energy and pure, raw city love. And one, by the British architect Cedric Price, is a gem.

title: INSIDE
description: A Solo Step for Montenegro

title: Appointments Made At 3 Agencies
description: Three agencies are making executive appointments.

title: Test Ban Treaty's Defeat Is Senate's Shame
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIRAFFAELE, MARY
description: DIRAFFAELE-Mary. On October 17, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Alfred, Sr., devoted mother of Theresa Santangelo and Alfred, Jr. Loving grandmother of Chrisann and Anthony, cherished great-grandmother of Autumn Rose. Reposing Ralph Aievoli and Son Funeral Home, 1275 65th St, corner of 13th Ave, Brooklyn, Monday and Tuesday, 2-4:30 PM, and 7-9:30 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Wednesday, 9:30 AM, St. Ephrem's Church.

title: F.B.I. Study Finds Gun Use In Violent Crimes Declining
description: In the clearest evidence yet that recent efforts to reduce gun violence through new laws and police pressure are working, a Federal Bureau of Investigation report released yesterday shows that a 7 percent drop in homicides in 1998 was entirely attributable to a decrease in killings committed with guns.

title: Henderson Now Upset With Wendell
description: One day after he stormed past Manager Bobby Valentine after being replaced in left field by Melvin Mora once he was in the field, Rickey Henderson said yesterday that he was no longer upset with Valentine over the botched switch in Game 4 of the National League Championship Series.

title: A Raucous, and Error-Filled, Night at Fenway
description: Certainly most neutral observers, even some umpires, would agree that the Red Sox were the victims of two more bad calls by umpires tonight at Fenway Park. One call contributed to a 9-2 Yankee victory, giving New York a 3 games to 1 edge in the American League Championship Series.

title: Monday Morning Quarterback
description: Highlights and lowlights from the weekend.

title: Peace Changing the Face of the Prairie
description: Beneath the flat, broad plains of North Dakota, where the push of a button could have ignited a nuclear attack, the earth is exploding.

title: E-Commerce Report; In the holiday selling season, knowing when traffic peaks will be a key to success.
description: PART of what has made E-commerce one of the most compelling spectator sports of the year is this fact: No matter how much experience executives have had running multimillion-dollar companies in other industries, when it comes to Web retailing, many of them are still making things up as they go along.

title: Patents; A device makes on-line data accessible to neo-Luddites who don't know a mouse from a VCR.
description: THIS may be the digital age, but even as technology spreads, people are left out -- some because they cannot afford the hardware and services needed to join the information era, but others because they don't like or can't master computers. Three inventors have patented a system that allows those who haven't made the leap from printed paper to computer screens to receive digital data on their televisions simply by turning the pages of a book, newspaper or magazine.

title: After 15 Pitchers and 15 Innings, Mets Live
description: Robin Ventura was waving his hand wildly, pushing his long ball back as he neared first base and, with it, pushing the National League Championship Series into pandemonium and a return to Atlanta. Ventura's ball cleared the right-field wall last night, but he never made it around for his grand slam. He was mobbed by his teammates near second base, his shot having driven in the winning run in the bottom of the 15th inning for a stunning 4-3 Mets victory over the Atlanta Braves in Game 5 of the N.L.C.S.

title: Clearing the Smoke About Cigarettes
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Just Before Indonesia's Finale, the Cast Is Changing
description: Two days before an electoral assembly votes to choose the next President, it is impossible to predict the outcome or even to say, in the final moments, who all the candidates will be to lead the fourth-most-populous nation.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: Want to Fight City Hall? Get a Permit
description: THE Yankees probably don't realize it -- they do have other things on their minds, like the World Series -- but they could become a free-speech issue before the month is out. The same goes for the Mets, who may yet pull off the greatest comeback since Lazarus.

title: How the Church Aided 'Heretical' Astronomy
description: Many people know that the Roman Catholic Church once waged a long and bitter war on science, and on astronomy in particular. But that seemingly well-established fact of history, it turns out, is wrong.

title: Ironclad Regimen for Ironman Training
description: Most mornings, Bob Spina Jr. is up by 5 and out the door before his wife and three daughters are awake. It is still dark, but he gets in a 15-mile run, a 60-mile bike ride or a swim before most of his neighbors in Massapequa are putting filters in their coffee makers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURG, YOSEF, DR.
description: BURG-Yosef, Dr. Emunah of America expresses its heartfelt grief at the passing of our longtime friend, Dr. Yosef Burg, a revered spokesman for religious Zionism, advisor and counselor to prime ministers, a unique and irreplaceable Jewish leader throughout the world. We express our condolences to his wife, Rifka, and the entire family. Dr. Sylvia Schonfeld, National President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALPERT, BETTY LANGBERG
description: ALPERT-Betty Langberg. On October 17, 1999 at age 94. Beloved wife of the late Harry Alpert. She is survived by her children Deborah and Martin Fishbein of Philadelphia, PA., her nieces and nephews Paula and Ephraim Biran, Arnold and Dagnija Langberg plus many great and great greats. Mrs. Alpert was an executive of the Lion Ribbon Company of NYC and NJ from 1920 to 1985. She will be remembered by all who knew her and worked with her as a caring and giving person, always cheerful and positive. Graveside services Wednesday 11:00 AM at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. Those desiring transportation contact Frank E. Campbell at 212288-3500. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Children's Defense Fund, 25 E Street, N.W., Washington, DC 20001.

title: Richard Nixon, Unedited
description: It is a cliche, but irresistibly apt. We will have Richard Nixon to kick around some more, at least until the supply of White House tapes runs out at an as yet unknown point in the millennium after next.

title: Lawsuit Says The Police Barred Access To Vital Drugs
description: Four men who were arrested last year at a Manhattan rally for a slain gay college student filed a civil rights lawsuit yesterday claiming the police prevented them from getting vital prescription medications while they were in custody.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAPERSTEIN, BELLE (NEE GREENBERG)
description: SAPERSTEIN-Belle (nee Greenberg), of West Orange, formerly of New York. Wife of the late Herbert, Mother of Beverly Hertzoff and the late Nina Fox. Mother-inlaw of Edwin Hertzoff and Jay Fox. Nanny to Amy, Clayton, Debra, David, Caren, Ian, Alexandra and seven great-grandchildren. Services on Sunday, October 24 at 2:15 PM at Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Road, Union, New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAIGHT, YOLANDA
description: HAIGHT-Yolanda. The Board of Directors and membership of the Junior League of Northern Westchester notes with sadness the untimely death of League member Yolanda Haight, and extend heartfelt sympathies to her husband Drew and two sons, Andrew and Aaron. Her commitment to community service, ebullient spirit and strength of character will continue to inspire. She will be greatly missed and always remembered. Mary Alice Hickey, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURG, YOSEF, RABBI
description: BURG-Yosef, Rabbi. The Rabbinical Council of America mourns the passing of a great scholar and eloquent statesman who led and served Medinat Yisrael and the Jewish people with distinction and dignity. Rabbi Kenneth N. Hain, President Rabbi Steven M. Dworken, Executive VP

title: Forgotten Barber Makes Two Plays to Remember
description: A star as a rookie two years ago, Tiki Barber has largely been a forgotten man on the Giants this season.

title: Causes of Brutality
description: To the Editor:

title: In Survival Mode at Shea
description: Should the Mets win the next two games against the Atlanta Braves, and wind up in the World Series against the Yankees, they would become the first team in history to win a seven-game playoff series after losing the first three. But if there is any team capable of defying history, it is these Mets, a team that wins just when people least expect it, a team that not only thrives on adversity but seems absolutely to require it.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PRICEWATERHOUSE COOPERS, New York, the world's largest accounting and consulting firm, bought 12 percent of Methodfive Inc., New York, a Web site designer and Internet consultant, as it expands its electronic-business services.

title: McCain Outmaneuvered in Vote On Campaign Finance Change
description: Senator John McCain tried to win a test vote today on his legislation to ban the large, unlimited donations to political parties that have been proliferating over the last decade. But he was outmaneuvered.

title: Mirer Front And Center After Being Left Out
description: The Jets are going back to Rick Mirer at quarterback, subject, of course, to Bill Parcells's second thoughts.

title: Kittles's Return Unclear As the Net Plays It Safe
description: Kerry Kittles can ride a stationary bike and do therapeutic exercises while his Nets teammates dash up and down the court, or he can join them in their drills and scrimmages while clenching his teeth and ignoring the pain in his right knee. It is his choice because, for all intents and purposes, Kittles is now his own doctor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, SAUL
description: WOLF-Saul. On October 17, 1999. Graveside services will be held at Kensico Nonsectarian cemetery, Valhalla, NY, Wednesday, October 20. For more information call 914-949-0347.

title: Asian Officials Say Some Students Duped by Unscrupulous Agents : Pitfalls of Studying Abroad
description: UBOL RATCHATHANI, Thailand  When Navin Rattaseri, 16, was sent from Thailand to study in the United States, he expected newfound liberty, not a military nightmare. "I was so excited to get freedom from my parents and actually go to America," he said.

title: VITAL SIGNS: DIAGNOSIS; Test Zooms In on Tick-Borne Ailment
description: Researchers at Yale and the Connecticut Agricultural Experiment Station have developed a new blood test to better detect ehrlichiosis, a disease carried by deer ticks that often goes undiagnosed because it lacks a telltale sign like the bull's-eye rash of Lyme disease.

title: Fluency a Must for Executives : Why English Is Big Business
description: LONDON  English is the language of international business, as much for the Spanish executive who has to communicate with contacts in Germany as for a Brazilian trying to make a deal in Russia.

title: A Cast of Bohemians Looks as if They Are
description: There is a wonderful segment in a 1996 opera video called ''The Art of Singing: Golden Voices of the Century'' that captures Renata Tebaldi and Jussi Bjorling from a live television broadcast in the 1950's singing the famous solo arias and love duet from Puccini's ''Boheme.'' The Italian diva does not look like a struggling tubercular seamstress, and the great Swedish tenor hardly cuts the figure of a malnourished bohemian poet in 1830's Paris. They look like well-fed, comfortably middle-aged people. But who cares? Their glorious singing makes you believe in these characters.

title: Metro Business; GPU to Cut Costs and Jobs
description: GPU Inc., the owner of utilities with 2 million customers in New Jersey and Pennsylvania, said yesterday that it would cut costs by $100 million over the next two years. Its goal is to increase earnings and improve service, officials said.

title: Do Doctor Groups Serve Patients?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about a campaign by Prime Minister Tony Blair to combat British resistance to further integration with Europe misidentified the target of criticism by former Prime Minister John Major. Mr. Major said the Conservative Party's recent decision to distance the party further from European integration was ''absurd and crazy''; he did not say Mr. Blair's policy was.

title: U.S. Steps Up Pressure on Taliban to Deliver Osama bin Laden
description: With the Islamic Taliban movement of Afghanistan under a threat of United Nations sanctions if it does not turn over a Saudi-born militant for trial in the United States, a Clinton Administration envoy met with a Taliban representative today in New York to press for action.

title: Q & A
description: Chameleon Colors

title: ENTERGY TO ACQUIRE 8 ADDITIONAL GAS TURBINES
description: The Entergy Corporation said yesterday that it planned to acquire eight gas turbines from the General Electric Company's General Power Systems unit for $160 million. The eight turbines are in addition to the 24 gas turbines and 4 steam turbines that Entergy said last week it would buy from GE Power Systems for $1.9 billion. Entergy, based in New Orleans, provides electricity to 2.5 million customers in the Southern United States and another 2 million customers overseas. GE Power Systems, a maker of power generation equipment, is based in Schenectady, N.Y. Delivery of the turbines is scheduled for as early as 2001, Entergy said.

title: Study Suggests Cause Of Gulf War Illness
description: A study paid for by the Pentagon has concluded that an experimental drug given to American troops in the Persian Gulf war may have been the cause of chronic illnesses afflicting tens of thousands of veterans.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CAMERON, WILLIAM A.
description: CAMERON-William A. A memorial service will be held at the Central Presbyterian Church, 593 Park Avenue at 64 Street, NYC, 11AM, Thursday, October 21st.

title: Holocaust Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: Hamm and Inkster Receive Top Honor for 1999
description: Mia Hamm appeared embrassed by it all.

title: MEETING BOYCOTTED BY AMERICANS
description: A shareholders meeting of Companhia Energetica de Minas Gerais was postponed for one week after two of the Brazilian power company's shareholders, the Southern Company and the AES Corporation, boycotted the event. The American companies, which are minority partners in the state-controlled utility known as Cemig, were hoping to prevent a vote confirming an earlier decision curtailing their management capacities. A legal battle is under way between the companies and Itamar Franco, the Governor of Minas Gerais state, because Mr. Franco moved to annul the effects of a 1997 transaction allowing them to manage Cemig.

title: THOMSON STOCK OFFERING
description: France will sell part of its stake in Thomson Multimedia, the world's fourth-largest consumer electronics maker, in an initial share sale that values the company at as much as 2.7 billion euros, or $2.9 billion. The French Government is shedding a 23.6 percent stake of the company by selling part of its stake, held through Thomson S.A., and by offering new shares to the public, existing shareholders and employees. A total of 29.4 million shares will be sold for 18 to 21.5 euros each, raising a maximum of 632 million euros.

title: New Treatments Lag In Fighting Asthma
description: Despite the seemingly endless rise in asthma cases, new treatments for the disease have been noticeably slow in coming.

title: Pierre Moulin, 73; Started Pierre Deux Shops
description: Pierre Moulin, who with his business partner, Pierre LeVec, created the Pierre Deux fabric shops and the charming Provencal mix of colorful cotton, glazed tile and antique armoires known as the Pierre Deux look, died Sunday at his Greenwich Village apartment. He was 73.

title: Celebrating an Ecologist's Eloquence and Vision
description: The onetime chicken coop known almost reverently as The Shack still stands, rough-boarded and stark in the middle of a clearing surrounded by tall pines, oaks and maples planted decades ago by the former occupant and his family.

title: Avon Steps Up Buyback
description: Avon Products Inc., the world's largest direct seller of cosmetics and fragrances, said yesterday that it was speeding up its $1.1 billion stock-buyback program to finish in the fourth quarter because its shares are cheap. Avon will repurchase $500 million of common stock in the quarter. Avon's shares rose $1.0625 yesterday, to $27.4375, less than half the 52-week high of $56.1875.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Sunday Styles section this week about the popularity of hand-tailored suits for men misspelled the name of a clothing store and the surname of its current owner. It is Moe Ginsburg, not Ginzburg; the owner is Paul Ginsburg.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: A News Operation Of a Different Sort

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Saturday showing weekly drops in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index misstated the period covered. The drops were the worst since World War II, not the worst ever for the index.

title: Brahms's Spirit But Hold the Impishness
description: New York Philharmonic

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERBERG, MARK L.
description: SILVERBERG-Mark L. It is with great sadness that we mourn the untimely passing of the son of our beloved Board President, Michael Silverberg and his wife Charlottecourageous leaders in the forefront of the fight against mental illness. We extend our affection and heartfelt sympathy to the Silverberg family. The Board of Directors National Alliance for the Mentally Ill -NAMI-NYC Metro

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, HELEN ROTH
description: SCHNEIDER-Helen Roth. On October 17, 1999. Beloved wife of Nathan for 49 years. Loving mother of Julie Kaufmann, cherished grandmother of Samara and Davie, dear sister of Daniel Roth. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St, Monday, 7-9 PM, with service Tuesday, 11:30 AM. Interment at New Mt. Carmel Cemetary.

title: Shifting Sand Beneath a Heroic Image
description: LAWRENCE

title: Length of Stay Is a Target For H.M.O.'s
description: More and more managed care companies in the metropolitan area are refusing to pay for one or more days of patient hospital stays as a way to increase their own profits, hospital administrators say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LERNER, JULES
description: LERNER-Jules. The National Board of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, mourns the death of Jules Lerner, husband of Shani Lerner, our esteemed colleague. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire family. May his memory be for a blessing. Bonnie Lipton, National President Dr. Laura S. Schor, National Executive Director

title: Do Doctor Groups Serve Patients?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NADLER, FAY
description: NADLER-Fay. On October 14, 1999. Age 93. Beloved wife of the late Abe. Loving mother of Harvey. Also survived by grandsons Daniel Drew and Jeffrey Neil, their wives Jeanine and Joanna, and great granddaughters Jessie Alana, Sarah Michelle and Siri Jennifer. Contributions in her memory may be sent to the Sarah R. Neuman Nursing Home, 845 Palmer Ave, Mamaroneck, NY 10543.

title: Going Bump (And Worse) In the Night And Onstage
description: For a fellow who looks as if he has just crawled out of Dr. Caligari's cabinet, the man who presides as the master of ceremonies for ''Shockheaded Peter: A Junk Opera,'' the wondrously inventive evening of Victorian gore and ghoulishness at the New Victory Theater, really isn't very frightening, at least not in the way he would like to be.

title: U.S. Sales Help Ford Deliver 11% Profit Gain in Quarter
description: Strong sales of sport utility vehicles, pickup trucks and large cars in the United States gave the Ford Motor Company better-than-expected earnings in the third quarter, even as the company acknowledged severe problems in its European operations.
