title: Op-Art
Muse Creative Starts Group in New York
description: Muse Creative Holdings L.L.C. in Los Angeles, which owns agencies like Muse Cordero Chen & Partners, said yesterday that it had opened Esperanto Group in New York, a multicultural consulting company offering strategic planning services to advertisers and agencies.

title: INSIDE
description: A Budget Showdown Looms For President and Congress

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Plastics From Plants

title: Thank You On 4 Notes: The Mobile Zap Mama
description: Marie Daulne, who leads Zap Mama, had her own way of saying thank you when the group performed on Thursday night at Irving Plaza. She sang ''Merci beaucoup'' on four notes including a quick, hiccupy break and hoot, a technique she learned from pygmy traditional music in Congo. Putting an African twist into the European phrase was just one of the culture-hopping combinations Ms. Daulne devises for Zap Mama, the five-woman vocal group that recently added a backup band.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PECK, JANE COCHRAN COLEMAN
description: PECK-Jane Cochran Coleman, 89, a fourth generation Houstonian, passed away peacefully, surrounded by her family and loved ones on Friday, October 15, 1999. In 1930, Jane married Stewart P. Coleman of Corpus Christi, Texas and moved to New York City for the duration of his employment with the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey. He died in 1969. Jane was married to Arthur K. Peck, a principal in the firm Rob, Peck and McCooey, in 1973, until his death in 1990. She was an active member of various charities and organizations in Houston and New York, an avid gardner, and a devoted wife, mother, grandmother, and greatgrandmother. In New York, Jane was a member of: The Colony Club, The Rockaway Hunting Club, Cedarhurst Yacht Club, Lawrence Beach Club, The Garden Club of Lawrence, The Junior League, and Trinity Episcopal Church in Woodmere. In addition, she was a member of the New York Stock Exchange. Family and friends are invited for visitation from 6:00 p.m. to 9:00 p.m. on Wednesday, October 20, 1999, at the family home in Houston, Texas. Funeral services will be held 2:00 p.m., Thursday, October 21, 1999, at Palmer Memorial Episcopal Church, 6221 Main Street, Houston, with interment at Glenwood Cemetery. A reception will follow at the family home. For information: Geo. H. Lewis & Sons, 713-789-3005

title: THE MONEY MOVERS: A special report; Tracking How Pair Went From Russia to Riches
description: Six years ago, a self-effacing Russian emigre with scant business experience set up a modest New Jersey company that planned to introduce entrepreneurs from the new Russia to American capitalists.

title: Gambling Economists
description: To the Editor:

title: Public Interests; One Hillary Is Enough
description: Hillary Clinton has a new mortgage, thank heavens. The New York Senate race doesn't need another controversy about the Clinton family finances. Things are complicated enough right now, what with the debate about elephant dung in the arts and the ongoing investigation into exactly what Rudy Giuliani thinks about raising the minimum wage.

title: Of Breasts, Behavior and the Size of Litters
description: Though much has been said and thought about the female breast, there remains one aspect that has received little consideration: the actual number that a woman has, with two accepted as the immutable standard.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOPKINS, JOHN J., SR.
description: HOPKINS-John J., Sr., the Honorable on Saturday October 16, 1999 of Upper Montclair, NJ. Husband of 49 years of Lois Ginley Hopkins. Father of Gail H. Shepard and her husband Thomas of Verona, Patrice H. Musicaro and her husband Michael of Reno, Nevada, Dr. Diane H. Williams & her husband Alan of Beaverton, Oregon, John J. III (Jay) & his wife Barbara of West Long Branch & Francis Ginley & his wife Patricia of Bloomfield. Brother of Mary Wedlock of Scranton, PA, Frank Hopkins & Ann Lerche both of Silver Springs, Maryland & the late Paul Hopkins. Also survived by 13 grandchildren. Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral from the O'Boyle Funeral Home, 309 Broad St., Bloomfield, on Thursday at 10:00 am. The funeral service will be held at First Congregational Church of Montclair, 40 South Fullerton Ave. Montclair, at 11:00 am. Interment private. In lieu of flowers the family requests memorial donations be made to the Boston College Law School in memory of the Honorable John J. Hopkins Sr. C/O Louise Parent, Associate Director-Law School Fund, Boston College Law School, 855 Centre St., Newton, Mass. 02459, or the University of Scranton, c/o the Office of Institutional Advancement Scranton, PA 18510-4615. Friends may call Wednesday 7-9 P.M.

title: Another Campaign Finance Fight
description: After months of delays, the Senate has finally begun its debate on campaign finance. A surprise gambit last night by Senator John McCain to get a test vote on his bill, co-sponsored by Russell Feingold of Wisconsin, was blocked by defenders of the current system. Another attempt is due today. Now is the time for Trent Lott, the majority leader, to fulfill a promise to allow votes on the main bill and also on amendments that might expand the support for reform.

title: Medical Relief And a Peace Prize
description: To the Editor:

title: Harding Nervous and Rusty in Return
description: For more than five and a half years, Tonya Harding had been persona non grata in figure skating. As a result of the Nancy Kerrigan clubbing incident in January 1994, Harding has been banned for life from Olympic, world and national competition, a pariah who went from a 1992 Olympic favorite to an embarrassment.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday with a music review of a Weill Recital Hall performance of Milton Babbitt's early works by the soprano Dawn Upshaw and the Met Chamber Ensemble misidentified the figure saluting Ms. Upshaw and James Levine. He was the conductor and composer Lukas Foss, not Mr. Babbitt.

title: Medical Relief And a Peace Prize
description: To the Editor:

title: Spitzer and Pataki Dueling Over Environmental Mantle
description: One Monday last April, hundreds of representatives of New York's private environmental groups gathered in Albany for Earth Day Lobby Day, an annual meet-and-greet session with elected officials.

title: France Telecom to Buy German Carrier Stake
description: France Telecom S.A. began a frontal attack today on its former partner, Deutsche Telekom A.G. of Germany, agreeing to pay about $8 billion for a controlling stake in Germany's third-largest mobile telephone carrier.

title: Subway Killer's Defense Cites Past Attacks
description: Lawyers for a schizophrenic man accused of pushing a woman to her death in front of a subway train opened their case yesterday by unveiling voluminous medical records to show that the defendant had such a long history of unprovoked attacks against strangers that he himself feared he would do it again if released from a hospital.

title: Sports of The Times; Mets Can't Save 3 Runs Ventura Lost
description: THE more he thought about it, the more Robin Ventura decided he would have liked that grand slam home run.

title: Cuts by Nissan Are Deeper Than Foreseen
description: Hobbled by years of losses and high debts, the Nissan Motor Company surprised Japan and the auto industry today with details of a radical overhaul plan that will make unexpectedly deep cuts at the company, Japan's No. 3 auto maker, and reverberate more broadly through the economy.

title: VITAL SIGNS: TECHNOLOGY; Reading, Writing and Defibrillation
description: On television, zapping a heart rhythm back to normal looks so simple a class of sixth graders could probably learn it in a minute, right?

title: Mirage Resorts Profit Falls in Quarter
description: Mirage Resorts Inc., the third-largest United States casino company, said today that its third-quarter profit fell 10 percent as expenses climbed after it opened new casino resorts in Las Vegas and Mississippi.

title: Investors Continue to Be Hesitant As Stocks Finish the Day Mixed
description: Stock prices were mixed yesterday, but investors remained hesitant and analysts said there were no indications that the recent steep slide in the market had ended.

title: PECO ENERGY UNIT BUYS UTILITY SERVICE COMPANIES
description: The Peco Energy Company's Exelon Infrastructure Services Inc. unit said yesterday that it had acquired five privately held utility service contracting companies for $194.5 million in cash, plus stock in Exelon. Exelon said the five companies, with combined annual revenue of nearly $300 million, were Chowns Communications Inc., MRM Technical Group, OSP Consultants Inc., Syracuse Merit Electric Inc. and Trinity Industries. Peco, a Philadelphia-based holding company, has agreed to merge with the Unicom Corporation, parent of Commonwealth Edison, the utility that serves Chicago.

title: Blood Donor Gifts
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, ALBERT
description: GORDON-Albert. Temple Beth Sholom of Roslyn Heights, NY, mourns the passing of our beloved member Albert Gordon. We extend heartfelt condolences to his wife, Marcia, and family. Rabbi Alan B. Lucas President Martin Kay

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, ZOFIA (SONIA)
description: STEIN-Zofia (Sonia). Wife of the late Maks, mother of Bianca Lloyd and the late Jack Stein, loving grandmother of five and greatgrandmother of seven. Passed away October 15, 1999. Services were held. The family will be grateful if any contributions in her memory would go toward the New York Chapter of Hadassah or to Sloan-Kettering Cancer Research.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOVENETSKY, SAM
description: KOVENETSKY-Sam. The officers, members and staff of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union mourn the loss of retired RWDSU vice president, Sam Kovenetsky. Sam was a devoted trade unionist and great leader whose lifelong dedication to working men and women and their families improved the quality of life for generations of members. Our sympathy goes out to his wife, Betty, and his family. Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union UFCW, AFL-CIO, CLC Stuart Appelbaum, President Charlie Hall, Sr., Secretary-Treasurer Lenore Miller, President Emeritus

title: For Morgan, So Much to Say and So Little Time
description: One of Joe Morgan's frustrations as a baseball analyst for NBC and ESPN is the lack of sufficient time to say everything that is on his mind. Part of that stems from Morgan's failure to be a chatterbox seeking to hog every free moment for himself.

title: No Agreement Yet With White House on Financial Overhaul
description: Senior Administration officials met with Senate Republicans tonight in a last-ditch attempt to reach an agreement on legislation overhauling the nation's financial system.

title: A Professor's Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEERBURGER, KATHLEEN G.
description: LEERBURGER-Kathleen G. Devoted mother of Benedict A. Leerburger. Grandmother of Marian Leerburger-Mahl and Ellen Leerburger Durkee. Great grandmother of Alec and Kaitlyn LeerburgerMahl. On October 16. Services at 11AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. Donations to American Kidney Fund in lieu of flowers.

title: Comeback From a Near-Death Free Fall
description: IT'S not that the man the fans called Bobby O. doesn't know from comebacks. After all, in the 1986 World Series, he pitched Game Three and the classic, Game Six, for the Mets, stonily willing them to victory when they were on their knees. But though Bobby Ojeda has played for the Red Sox, the Indians and the Yankees too, it wasn't until his mother prodded him this weekend that he finally watched some of the playoffs. That's because there are comebacks, and then there is coming back, as in near-death freefalls.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIZZA, GREGORIA (NEE MAZZARINO)
description: ZIZZA-Gregoria (nee Mazzarino). On October 16, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Carmelo, devoted mother of Agata, Antonino, Maria and Salvatore. Loving sister of Giuseppe Mazzarino. Cherished grandmother of nine and greatgrandmother of four. Funeral Wednesday, 8:45 AM, from Andrew Torregrossa & Sons Funeral Home, 1305 79 St, Brooklyn, NY. Mass of Christian Burial, 9:20 AM, St. Mary Mother of Jesus Church. Entombment Greenwood Cemetery. Visiting 2 to 5 and 7 to 10 PM.

title: Brain Tumors: Elusive, Varied and Not Always Deadly
description: Ruth had undergone a mysterious personality change that defied psychiatric explanation. Charles awoke each morning with a severe headache that eased as the day progressed. Kathleen experienced partial facial paralysis, slurred her words and drooled. Marlys suffered a grand mal seizure that rendered her unconscious for about 15 minutes.

title: Law Exempts 261,000 From State Income Tax
description: Because the Governor and the Senate President were out of town, the Assembly Speaker, Jack R. Collins, yesterday signed a bill he had sponsored raising the minimum taxable income level.

title: Settlement Withdrawn In L.I. Overassessment
description: The Long Island Power Authority yesterday withdrew its offer to accept $625 million from Suffolk County as settlement for the county's past overassessment of the Shoreham nuclear power plant and said it would return to court within the next two weeks to seek the full $1.3 billion judgment two courts have levied against the county.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWNLOW, KENDALL H.
description: BROWNLOW-Kendall H. Son of Louise Harper Eddy of Providence, Rhode Island and Donald G. Brownlow, Elverson, PA. Brother of Douglas Brownlow and the Reverend Pamela Bakal, beloved friend to all. Longtime resident of Brooklyn Heights. Landlord and co-owner of Hicks Brothers Deli, Office Manager of McVicker & Higgenbotham, Inc. Letter Shop. Funeral service Wednesday, 7:00PM, Grace Episcopal Church, Brooklyn Heights, NY. Donations may be made to The American Diabetes Association.

title: DANA TO CLOSE 14 PLANTS AND 29 WAREHOUSES
description: The Dana Corporation, the world's largest maker of light-truck axles, said yesterday that it would close 14 plants and 29 distribution centers to cut costs in its replacement-parts business and that its chairman would step down in April. Dana also said its third-quarter profit from operations rose to $172 million, or $1.03 a share, from $136 million, or 82 cents, a year earlier. The chairman, Southwood Morcott, 61, will retire on April 30 and will probably be succeeded by the chief executive and president, Joe Magliochetti, 57, Dana said. Dana's shares fell $3, to $30.375, on the Big Board.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, JOEL E.
description: MILLER-Joel E., age 42. Died peacefully at home October 11, 1999. He is survived his beloved grandmother, Mildred E. Miller; his devoted brother Keith D. Miller; two nieces and a nephew; and many loving, appreciative friends. Contributions may be made to the Jacob Perlow Hospice, Attn: Paul Brenner, 6 Fierman, 1st Ave and 16 Street, New York City 10003.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRISON, WILMA CURLEY
description: HARRISON-Wilma Curley. Died on October 16th, 1999, at St. Luke's Hospital. She was born in Brooklyn, on April 1st, 1937 to Tomas and Wilma (Abt) Curley. She was a Prima Ballerina and Choreographer. A graduate of the School of American Ballet, she danced with them & the New York City Ballet, The Joffrey, Royal Danish, San Francisco & New Jersey Ballet Companies. She appeared at Radio City and on T.V. She appeared for Jerome Robbins in his ''Opus Jazz'' & ''West Side Story'', directed his work with other companies. She is survived by two sons, Timothy and Gene, two granddaughters, Kristin and Danielle and two sisters, Joan O'Brien and Gail Clark. Friends may call at Krtil Funeral Home on 70th Street & 1st Avenue Tuesday from 2-4 P.M. & 7-9 P.M. Mass will be celebrated at Holy Trinity Church on 81 St. and Amsterdam Ave. at 11 A.M. Information: Krtil Funeral Home, 212-744-3084.

title: Lesson From Pakistan
description: To the Editor:

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Shaggy Dog Tales And Her Own Hiding Place
description: Rickie Lee Jones

title: Dangerous and Thrilling
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Fighting Spirit' Little Help in Cancer Fight
description: Optimism and a fighting attitude may help breast cancer patients cope with their illnesses, but positive thinking is unlikely to increase their chances of survival, according to a study by British researchers.

title: Do Doctor Groups Serve Patients?
description: To the Editor:

title: VITAL SIGNS: THERAPY; When Hostile Heart Patients Face Rehab
description: Heart attack victims who are generally hostile people tend to be younger, heavier and unhappier than most coronary patients -- and to get more benefit from cardiac rehabilitation programs, a study conducted in New Orleans has found.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article in some editions yesterday about the Mets' victory over Atlanta in Game 5 of the National League Championship Series misidentified the player who scored the winning run. He was Roger Cedeno, who was brought in as a pinch-runner for Matt Franco.

title: Legg Mason Buying British Fund Group
description: Legg Mason Inc. agreed today to buy the British fund group Johnson Fry Holdings for $70 million in cash in the first international acquisition by Legg Masaon, the 100-year-old brokerage firm and money manager.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Rite Aid Ousts Its Chief And Will Restate Earnings

title: Sports of The Times; Basic Civility Is the Loser Every Time
description: THE weather turned chilly here yesterday, nasty, like the mood of the louts who used the Yankees and the umpires as targets for bottle-throwing practice Sunday night. It was nature's way of saying that winter is soon to drop its blanket on New England while the Red Sox drift off to a hibernating sleep.

title: Nominee as Ambassador Runs Into Adversary
description: During her single six-year term in the United States Senate, Carol Moseley-Braun repeatedly clashed with the chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina.

title: Bill Signed to Strengthen Law on Toy Firearms
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani signed legislation yesterday requiring toy guns sold in New York City to be transparent or brightly colored. The measure is to strengthen an existing law intended to keep toy guns from being mistaken for actual firearms.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURG, JOSEPH, DR.
description: BURG-Joseph, Dr. AMIT is deeply grieved at the passing of a great religious Zionist and outstanding leader of the State of Israel. A Torah scholar and former teacher in the AMIT Eisenberg High School in Tel Aviv, Rabbi Dr. Burg was a good friend and advisor in AMIT's mission to save the forgotten children of Israel. Heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife and children. Sondra Sokal, Nat'l Pres Marvin Leff, Exec Director

title: Appeal Ruling Favors Immigrant Held on Secret Evidence
description: An immigration appeals panel, ruling in the case of a Palestinian man detained for 18 months and threatened with deportation based on secret evidence that the Government says links him to terrorism, has found that the man was not a terrorist threat and should not be deported.

title: Mets, in a Bind, Turn to Leiter on Short Rest
description: Al Leiter looked perplexed and then shook his head. The pitcher who after each start remembers the nuance of almost every pitch he throws, who can describe in minute detail the movement he put on a ball, could not recall the only time he had pitched on three days of rest.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: THE DOLLAR FALLS. The dollar fell against the yen amid concern a report on consumer prices today could prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates again. In New York, the dollar settled at 105.08 yen, down from 105.42.

title: Killer's Parents Consider Suit In School Case
description: In the first public sign of discord between the families of the teen-agers responsible for the killings at Columbine High School, the parents of one of the gunmen are considering a lawsuit against Jefferson County, contending that the authorities ignored indications that the other gunman had violent tendencies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JENSEN, JIM
description: JENSEN-Jim. An unfortunately brief but memorable time in our lives. Condolences to his beloved Rachel, adored Noah and Natalie and Mel. Barbara and Ralph

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRISON, HENDERSON W.
description: MORRISON-Henderson W., Nassau County Supreme Court Justice, on October 17, 1999 of Sun City, Florida, and Garden City, New York. Beloved husband of Grace M. (nee Kearns). Loving father of William, Mary Elizabeth Santini, Kathleen McShane, Patricia DeJoseph and Grace Ellen Morrison-Doyle. Cherished grandfather of seventeen grandchildren. Dear brother of Robert.

title: Yanks All Aboard for World Series
description: Orlando Hernandez chuckled when asked if he had ever pitched before fans as angry as those in Fenway Park. If you pitch badly in Cuba, he said of his homeland, then your own fans will kill you.

title: Dell Shares Plunge in After-Hours Trading
description: Shares in the Dell Computer Corporation tumbled in after-hours trading yesterday after the company warned that rising memory chip prices would hurt its third-quarter earnings.

title: Inspiration Born of New Brain Cells
description: To the Editor:

title: The Heartbreak of 'Butterfly,' Without the Libretto
description: Within the once-venerable genre of opera turned into ballet, Stanton Welch's ''Madame Butterfly'' for the Australian Ballet is a creditable job, even if one keeps waiting for the helicopter to land onstage.

title: Jeter Is At Home Anywhere In Playoffs
description: The first pitch was still about two hours away and most of Fenway Park was barren when a very large and very loud fan wearing a Red Sox jacket and hat began screaming at the Yankees, who were around the batting cage. Almost every Yankee ignored the energetic fan's diatribe, except Derek Jeter.

title: Starr's Abuses
description: To the Editor:

title: $129 Million in Martha Stewart Stock Sale
description: Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia Inc., built from Martha Stewart's homemaking tips on cooking, entertaining, gardening and crafts, raised $129.6 million in an initial stock sale yesterday.

title: Cardinal Readmitted to Hospital
description: John Cardinal O'Connor, who has been undergoing radiation treatments for a brain tumor, was readmitted to the hospital yesterday at the request of his doctors, the Cardinal's spokesman said.

title: Distant Worlds Made Closer
description: Yo-Yo Ma, cellist

title: Candidate on the Stump Is Surely on the Web
description: The modern campaign headquarters is no longer a rented storefront decorated with bumper stickers, bunting and empty soda cans. Increasingly it has an annex open any hour of the day or night, at an address starting with www.

title: CMS ENERGY SHARES RISE 9% ON NEWS OF ASSET SALE
description: Shares of the CMS Energy Corporation, owner of a Michigan utility, rose 9 percent yesterday, as it was disclosed that it was considering selling about $1 billion in assets and that it was in talks with some business customers to resolve an electricity rate dispute. Shares rose $2.9375 each, to $35.1875. CMS might sell about $1 billion in assets that are not expected to add to profits, a company spokesman, Kelly Farr, said. CMS is also making progress in discussions with commercial and industrial customers to resolve a rate case pending before the Michigan Public Service Commission, Mr. Farr said.

title: Study Links Antisocial Behavior to Early Brain Injury That Bars Learning
description: Scientists have identified rare cases in which injuries to the brain in infancy prevented people from learning normal rules of social and moral behavior in childhood and adolescence. When the infants reached adulthood, they showed no guilt or remorse for their extremely bad behavior and seemed destined never to get along in social situations.

title: Red Sox Fail to Win Series (This Is News?)
description: Let the lamentations begin again for the Boston Red Sox, an old source of heartache in New England. Wait until next year, next century, next millennium. They are without a World Series championship since World War I. Let's hope they don't need World War III to win another.

title: SAMSUNG MOTORS TO RESUME OPERATIONS
description: Creditors of the South Korean auto maker Samsung Motors Inc., now under court management, will allow the company to operate its plant in Pusan for three months starting next Monday, by injecting 20 billion won, or $16.6 million, in new loans. The decision was made to allow ailing components suppliers to use up their existing inventory. Samsung will clear the inventories by manufacturing 6,000 cars in the three months. The proceeds from the sales of the cars will be used to repay some company debt, estimated at 4.2 trillion won, or $3.5 billion.

title: Rivals' Deal Raises Questions on Fate of British Aerospace
description: Ever since the end of the cold war, Europe's fragmented military industry has come to resemble a ponderous mating rite in which the surprises came not so much from the urge to consolidate as from the partners ticking the dance card.

title: Perseverance Is Key to a Good Life With Asthma
description: Until about three years ago, Dawn Bosquez, a 30-year-old resident of Denver, was getting most of her medical care for asthma in emergency rooms. About once a month, she would wake up unable to breathe and would frantically call an ambulance or friend to rush her to the hospital, where she would be given oxygen and inhaled medications to bring the attack under control.

title: Sports of The Times; A Scary Room Nobody Mentions
description: IN the tunnel on their way to and from the Monday night television cameras, the Giants and the Dallas Cowboys were not far from it. And all of them were hoping that they would stay far from it.

title: Sierra Leone Victims and Rebels Hear Albright's Message of Peace
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright today cuddled a 3-year-old girl whose arm had been hacked off by rebels, then met with rebel leaders responsible for thousands of such mutilations in this country's eight-year civil war, urging them to stick to a fragile peace agreement.

title: Looking Back On 120 Years Of Light
description: In 1878, Thomas Alva Edison declared that he would replace gas lamps with electric light. Fourteen months later, on Oct. 21, 1879, he succeeded: he demonstrated 30 incandescent electric lamps, each with its own separate switch. Within a few years, a power station had been built in New York City to feed this invention and a new era was born.

title: So Expressive Yet So Self-Contained
description: Tallis Scholars

title: At Home Abroad; City Of Ghosts
description: In most great cities, monuments to the past are an unnoticed part of the landscape. In Berlin, the past -- the terrible past -- is inescapable.

title: Warner-Lambert Signs Up a Partner to Work on Cancer Drug
description: Onyx Pharmaceuticals Inc. said today that it had entered a collaborative agreement with the Warner-Lambert Company to jointly develop and market a new cancer drug.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDWARDS, AGNES (NAN)
description: EDWARDS-Agnes (Nan). Died October 4, 1999 at Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center, age 79. Born in Glasgow, Scotland, she move to London in 1938 with the outbreak of war in 1939 in the country's complete mobilization she chose nursing training at Royal Free Hospital. After attaining her RN degree she was assigned to General RN duties at a POW hospital for the duration. After coming to the U.S. she voluteered for the Peace Corps under Sargent Shriver and in 1962 shipped out with the second Peace Corps unit ever activated to serve as nursing instructor at the main hospital in Erzerum, Turkey. In 1964 she returned to New York City to marry Stuart D. Edwards her surviving husband. In 1970 she joined the JDR, III Fund as Secretary to the Director, retiring in 1980. Survivors include her sisters, Grace Blum, Ida Rothenhaus, & Bessie Porter, all of California, her nieces Lenore Lewis of Oak Park, California, Claire Cheslow of Agoura Hills, Calif., and Janet Denning of Dubai, UAE and a nephew, Aron Blum of Warwick, NY. Her funeral urn has been sent to her sister Grace P. Blum of LaGuna Hills, California.

title: Starr's Successor Sworn In To Oversee Clinton Inquiry
description: Robert W. Ray, a career Federal prosecutor, was sworn in today to replace the independent counsel Kenneth W. Starr, and he vowed to complete Mr. Starr's five-year-old, $47 million criminal investigation of President Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton in a ''prompt, responsible and cost-effective manner.''

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Serving Up Two Operas That Test the Taste Buds
description: Symphony orchestras tour mainly to advertise their own prowess. The Montreal Symphony's visit to Carnegie Hall over the weekend was something more: an exercise in taste and imagination that took excellence in execution for granted.

title: Top Americans Find Sailing Smooth in America's Cup Qualifying
description: The top three skippers in the United States' bid to recapture the America's Cup won all five of the races they sailed today as the four-month, eight-nation campaign for the cup began here.

title: Chief Is Ousted at Rite Aid And Earnings Are Restated
description: Directors of the Rite Aid Corporation stepped in yesterday in an effort to stem a series of disasters at the nation's third-largest drugstore chain, ousting Martin L. Grass, the chief executive, announcing that the company will restate $500 million in pretax earnings since 1997 and placing control with four independent board members.

title: South Pole Rescue
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RITTER, BRUCE REV.
description: RITTER-Bruce Rev. Many mourn the loss of Father Bruce Ritter who did so much for the youth by founding Covenant House, which is still helping thousands to find jobs and a safe haven. Helen Corroon

title: Profit at Xerox Fell 11% in Third Quarter
description: Ten days after warning that its third-quarter results would be dismal, the Xerox Corporation made good on that promise yesterday, and then some.

title: On Baseball; Braves' Lead No Longer Seems Insurmountable
description: As incredible as it may seem, the Atlanta Braves have the look of a loser. They have actually positioned themselves to suffer another post-season disappointment. The Mets, on the other hand, have put themselves in position to be winners. Who woulda thunk it?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, BEATRICE F.
description: SHAPIRO-Beatrice F. 73, of Las Vegas, NV, formerly of West Orange, NJ and Hoboken, NJ, on October 18, 1999. Beloved wife of Arthur Shapiro, mother of Alexis Peter and Oliver Simon; grandmother of three. Sister of Paul Fogelson, aunt of seven. Dear friend of many. The lives of all who knew her well were enriched by knowing her and are diminished by her passing. Brava, Beatrice! Memorial contributions can be made to the Metropolitan Opera. Services will be held on Tuesday, 12 noon, at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd at 76 Road, Forest Hills, NY.

title: Drug May Be Cause of Veterans' Illnesses
description: A scientific survey underwritten by the Pentagon has concluded that an experimental drug given to American troops during the Persian Gulf war to protect against a nerve gas may be responsible for the chronic illnesses afflicting tens of thousands of veterans.

title: Breast Cancer Fears
description: To the Editor:

title: Pakistan's Military Temptation
description: In Pakistan, a corrupt and incompetent democratic government has been replaced by a military dictator who now pledges bold and necessary reforms. Gen. Pervez Musharraf's speech to the Pakistani people Sunday night was reassuringly statesmanlike. But one big omission was a schedule for restoring democratic rule.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BILLINGS, MARION
description: BILLINGS-Marion. 84, of Briarcliff Manor, on October 16, 1999. She was the former personal manager for the late Sergio Franchi, the Italian tenor. Also worked for the William Morris Talent Theatrical Agency in NYC. Survived by one son, Gary Billings, and one daughter, Bonnie Billings, and longtime companion Edward Risman. Donations to the ALS Foundation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHELDON, JUDY
description: SHELDON-Judy. On October 18, 1999. Beloved sister of Anita. Memorial services, 4 PM, Wednesday, October 20, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76 St, NYC.

title: Fenway Has Fans' Attention
description: On Oct. 27, 1986, the Washington Redskins played the Giants in a Monday night football game at Giants Stadium. Several miles away, at Shea Stadium, the Boston Red Sox were playing the Mets, who were on their way to a World Series victory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, FLORENCE
description: ROSENTHAL-Florence. Age 93. Mother of Judith Case & Richard Glass. Grandmother of Deborah, James, Nancy, Jonathan and Nicholas. Great grandmother of Aviva, Zoe, Benjamin, Maxwell, Jackson, Sam, Jacob, Elizabeth, Jessie and Sasha. Sister of Beatrice. Remembered with love. ''My life closed twice before its close;/It yet remains to see/If Immortality unveil/A third event to me.''

title: Mr. Starr Cuts Out
description: Common sense and the rule of law both dictate that any independent counsel charged with investigating a president has a civic obligation to make a final report to the nation on his or her findings. Kenneth Starr is skittering away from that obligation even though the taxpayers, after the expenditure of $47 million, have every right to expect him to be the government's most knowledgeable official on the Monica Lewinsky scandal, Whitewater and related matters. Mr. Starr, who accepted the job of independent counsel in 1994, likes to blame the White House for damaging his reputation. But no one in the Clinton administration can fairly be blamed for his failure to stay the course.

title: JAPANESE INSURANCE MERGER
description: Japan's thirdlargest casualty insurer, the Mitsui Marine and Fire Insurance Company, said it would form a holding company with the Nippon Fire and Marine Insurance Company and the Koa Fire and Marine Insurance Company, creating Japan's biggest casualty insurer. The merged company will command 6.09 trillion yen, or $57.6 billion, of assets, surpassing those of the Tokio Marine and Fire Insurance Company, the nation's largest casualty insurer. The agreement to form an alliance comes as 7 of Japan's 10 largest banks have announced merger plans.

title: Molinari Breaks Ranks to Endorse McCain
description: In an abrupt turnabout, the Staten Island Borough President, Guy V. Molinari, endorsed Senator John McCain of Arizona for President yesterday, breaking ranks with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, Gov. George E. Pataki and a host of other New York Republicans who have lined up behind Gov. George W. Bush of Texas.

title: Holocaust Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: Theme of the Spring Season: Anyone Can Join the Club
description: Ballyhoo and fashion writers tend to go together like ham and eggs. Mention the looks that surfaced at the spring shows in New York and Europe -- The new volume! Discreet chic! The return of 1970's glamour! -- and ordinary people start ducking into their overcoats like so many Yertles.

title: The Brooding Fire Of Spain and Portugal
description: Diana Thedim

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JARECKI, LOTTE
description: JARECKI-Lotte on October 12, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Walter. Devoted aunt of Doris Wallace and Gitta Wood. Cherished great aunt of Amelia, Lucy, Michelle and Simon. Loving cousin of Ruth Kaufmann, and dear, dear friend. Service of Remembrance at Whitney Center, 200 Leeder Hill Drive, Hamden, CT., October 24 at 1:30PM. For info 203-281-6745.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Ruling Requires Warrants For Crime Scene Searches
description: There is no exception for crime scenes to the Constitution's requirement of a search warrant, the Supreme Court ruled today. The unanimous opinion overturned a West Virginia man's conviction for murdering his wife and reaffirmed a principle the Court established 21 years ago.

title: Sam Kovenetsky, 87, Veteran Labor Leader
description: Sam Kovenetsky, a longtime labor leader in New York, died Friday at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 87 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Clinton and Republicans to Meet on Budget Differences
description: President Clinton and Congress moved closer to a showdown over the Federal budget today as the President vetoed a foreign aid bill and then invited Congressional leaders to a meeting at the White House on Tuesday to discuss their differences.

title: Nortel Buying Software Maker
description: The Nortel Networks Corporation, North America's No. 2 maker of phone equipment, agreed today to buy Clarify Inc., a software company that specializes in products for electronic business, for $2.1 billion in stock.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Volatility Isn't What It Used to Be (It's Worse)
description: IN 1987, the stock market seemed to go crazy, with prices first soaring and then plunging -- a process that culminated in the crash 12 years ago today. The volatility, which was greater than at any time since the 1930's, stunned and scared investors around the world.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a $3.5 million payment by the Bear Stearns Securities Corporation to cover losses incurred by customers of A. R. Baron & Company, a defunct firm whose trades it processed, misstated the amount being sought from former Baron employees and insiders by the trustee responsible for overseeing the liquidation of Baron. It is $50 million, not $450 million.

title: New York Psychologists Forming Alliance With a Teachers' Union
description: Unhappy that managed care has cut into psychologists' income and autonomy, the New York State Psychological Association and its 3,200 members agreed this month to join the American Federation of Teachers -- the first time a group of American psychologists has affiliated with a union.

title: A Good Comeback
description: When Yankees Manager Joe Torre attended mass with Andrea Rae, his 3-year-old daughter, on Sunday, he took her to light some candles after Mass. A Red Sox fan recognized Torre and told him, ''If one of those candles is for a victory, I'm going to blow it out.'' Torre told the fan, ''I never light a candle asking for good things to happen like that.'' JACK CURRY

title: Dangerous and Thrilling
description: To the Editor:

title: VITAL SIGNS: RISKS AND REMEDIES; For Hepatitis C, a Test and a Quiz
description: The 300,000 Americans who may have been exposed to hepatitis C through tainted blood transfusions before 1992 can take an Internet quiz this week to gauge their risk and order a free home-test kit.

title: Edinburgh Journal; Rebirth Hasn't Been Easy for Scotland's Parliament
description: The first Scottish Parliament in nearly 300 years opened in July with pomp, circumstance and the Queen of England herself, wearing a special dress with a Scottish-thistle motif. It was the dawn of ''a new constitutional age,'' proclaimed the Queen, whose presence was intended as much to remind the unruly Scots who is sovereign (she is) as to wish them well.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENDERSON, CELENE ANITA
description: HENDERSON-Celene Anita. Of Springfield, NJ, on October 15, 1999. Daughter of Marguerite and the late Robert J. Henderson. The family of Celene requests that donations be sent to The Cystic Fibrosis Foundation, 36 Seventh Avenue, Suite 509, New York, New York 10011. The family also wished for everyone's greater awareness of organ donation.

title: VITAL SIGNS: PATTERNS; Riding the Cycle of Stress and Smoke
description: Cigarettes do help smokers relax -- from tension caused by smoking, a new study argues.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It used to be said the candidate had to have a good message, a good ground game and enough money to wage a good air game on TV. This is the first cycle that it can be proven that a candidate needs to have a good on-line game as well.''

title: DAIMLER'S SOUTH AFRICAN OUTPUT
description: The auto maker DaimlerChrysler plans to relocate production of its C-class Mercedes-Benz sedans for right-side steering markets to South Africa from Germany. The move will increase the company's investment in South Africa 31 percent, to about $212 million. No new jobs will be created in South Africa, and no jobs will be cut at the German plant in Bremen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROGOVIN, JACK
description: ROGOVIN-Jack. Age 87, passed away on October 17, 1999 in Hollywood, Florida due to complications of pneumonia and a heart attack. Longtime teacher of French, Spanish & Russian and Guidance Counselor at Tilden High School in Brooklyn. Active in the Teachers Union. He served in the Army Signal Corps, South Pacific during W.W.II. Devoted husband of the late Gussie whom he visited faithfully every day for more than a dozen years after she contracted Alzheimers. Survived by numerous loving nieces and nephews. In lieu of flowers please make contributions to the Alzheimers Disease and Related Disease Association of Broward County, FL (He was President of the Fort Lauderdale chapter for many years.) Services 11AM Thurs, New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, L.I., NY.

title: Richter's Play Is Sharp and Pain Free
description: Of the many positive signs in the Rangers' 4-1 victory over the Atlanta Thrashers on Sunday, the most important to the Rangers' long-term outlook was Mike Richter's splendid -- and pain-free -- performance.

title: People
description: * Lance Smith was named to the new position of president at the New York, St. Louis and Canadian offices of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles Communications, part of MacManus Group. He had been president for multinational clients at Ammirati Puris Lintas, New York, part of the Interpublic Group of Cos.

title: Perdue Offers a Plan to Fight Odor and Pollution
description: Here in the heart of the busiest poultry-raising area in the world, there are remarkably few chickens in plain sight across the gentle countryside, but Frank LeCates can smell the birds all about him.

title: Kodak Revenue and Operating Income Rise
description: Eastman Kodak reported today that its third-quarter operating income rose 17 percent as revenue increased for a third consecutive quarter, putting Kodak on track to end two years of falling sales.

title: Front Row; Could it be time to dust off those blouses and, gasp, stockings? Both style anachronisms showed up in the European collections.
description: Blouses Are Back (Hose, Too)

title: Camby to Carry Knicks on His Thin Shoulders
description: There was the banishment on the bench, and a period when Marcus Camby was as silent and undetectable as a gas leak last season. The longer he sat, the more he seethed and the more dangerous he became to the opposition.

title: Coca-Cola will try to promote its top brand with more emotion.
description: THE Coca-Cola Company, the maker of the world's best-known brand, will soon be exhorting consumers to take what amounts to a magical mystery tour of the mouth by enjoying the ''unique taste sensation'' and ''sparkle on your tongue'' of its flagship product.

title: J. E. Williams, 68, Dies; Won the Medal of Honor
description: James E. Williams, who as a patrol-boat commander in the Vietnam War won the Medal of Honor and became one of the most highly decorated sailors in Navy history, died on Wednesday at a hospital in Florence, S.C. He was 68.

title: Citigroup, Exceeding Forecasts, Reports a Big Rebound in Its Profit for Third Quarter
description: Citigroup, the nation's largest financial services company, said yesterday that its third-quarter profit had more than tripled as its banking and trading businesses rebounded from weak performances a year earlier, when global financial turmoil hurt big banks and securities firms.

title: Rockefeller Center Quietly Closes Theater
description: Days before a sumptuously restored Radio City Music Hall reopened this month to blazing fanfare, the owners of Rockefeller Center closed another theater, just down the block, without any publicity.

title: Exchange Teachers Also Learn A Language
description: TOKYO  In 1993, Trevor Hill, dissatisfied with what he called the "academic Japanese" he had learned at Princeton University, exiled himself to rural Japan, where "if I didn't know how to speak Japanese I would starve."

title: Neither Isolationists Nor Fools
description: ''Isolationism'' and ''partisanship'' were the names, ''reckless'' and ''dangerous'' the characterizations with which a stunned Clinton Administration and much of the press greeted the Senate's rejection last week of the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty. Vice President Al Gore, whose TV commercial attacking the Republicans was broadcast almost immediately after the roll call, declared the vote ''the single most reckless action that I have seen the Senate take . . . in my lifetime.''

title: Assaults Against Teachers Increase in New York City
description: Assaults against teachers in New York City schools rose by almost 15 percent last year, a new report by the United Federation of Teachers finds, but the total number of violent incidents against the union's members dropped significantly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIVIGLIA, ALEXANDER
description: SIVIGLIA-Alexander of Scarborough, NY, died on Sunday October 17, 1999 of heart failure. He was 95 years old. He is survived by his son Peter and Peter's wife Anne, his grandchildren Ellen and Judy and Ellen's husband Rich and a great-grandson Jacob. The son of immigrants, he illuminated the opportunities America provides and the success that diligence and hard work can achieve in our country. Services will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations to The Multiple Sclerosis Society or the Parkinson's Disease Assn. would be appreciated.

title: Lawmakers Reject Clinton Changes to Finance-Overhaul Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18  Senate and House lawmakers moved tonight toward completion of a bill overhauling the nation's financial system. But the measure still failed to satisfy President Clinton's concerns about adequately protecting consumers and minorities.

title: Kissinger's Latest Mission; Briefs Sixth Graders in Visit to His Old Neighborhood
description: Henry A. Kissinger, German refugee, walked into a classroom of children of immigrants from the Dominican Republic and looked for common ground.

title: Protecting U.N. Workers
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Mora Finds It's Better To Give Than Receive
description: WHO is Melvin Mora?

title: Ring Envy
description: General Manager Brian Cashman has been sitting behind home plate wearing a Yankee jacket for the last three games, so several Red Sox fans have recognized him and told him why Nomar Garciaparra is better than Derek Jeter and why Boston is better than New York. Cashman said that some of the fans have even asked to try on his 1998 World Series ring, the sort of ring that has not been seen on a Red Sox official for decades.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAUSS, IRENE
description: KRAUSS-Irene. Beloved wife of Howard. Devoted mother of Deborah and Melissa. Dear sister of Robert Waksman. Services on Wednesday, October 20, 12:30 PM, Hirsch & Sons, 1225 Jerome Avenue, Bronx, New York.

title: Critic's Notebook: A Contest Befitting Monk; Competition Shows Where Jazz Piano Is Today
description: ''Jazz'' means entirely different things to different people, but there was no question about the goal of this year's Thelonious Monk International Piano Competition. The competitors were judged as contemporary artists by contemporary artists; the criteria were hard, and the process seemed free of nostalgia and commercialism.

title: CLINTON PROPOSES A DISCOUNT SYSTEM ON MEDICARE COSTS
description: In a break from three decades of Medicare policy, the Clinton Administration asked Congress today to steer Medicare patients to certain doctors and hospitals that offer discounts on the price of care they provide to people who are elderly or disabled.

title: Snake Owner Is Killed in Fall
description: A 36-year-old man who was building new cages for his menagerie of large snakes in his Brooklyn loft was killed Sunday night in what police officials said yesterday appeared to be an accident.

title: Manual Addresses Needs Of Children in Disasters
description: Although disas ters from hurricanes to earthquakes to political unrest -- can be devastating for anyone, they can be particularly hard on children. But the special health needs of these youngest victims often go unmet, experts say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLEASON, FRANCIS X.
description: GLEASON-Francis X. On October 18, 1999. Beloved husband of Mary. Loving father of Francis X., M.D. Devoted grandfather of Cara, Sean and Brian. Mass Thursday, 9:30AM, Saint Patrick's Church. Reposing at Ridge Chapels, 405 91 Street, Brooklyn, N.Y. Visiting Wednesday, 2-5 PM and 7-9 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAMTON, MARGOT
description: SAMTON-Margot. The wonderful mother of our Partner, Peter, has passed and we mourn her warmth and sincere interest in the well-being of others. The Partners and staff of Gruzen Samton admired her keen interest in our professional lives, our families, and our personal happiness. We extend our sincere condolences to Peter, Claude and Annette, and her beloved Henry. The Partner of Gruzen, Stamton, Architects Jordan Gruzen Joseph Donovan Michael Gelfand Michael Kazan Scott Keller Gerard Vasisko

title: Up There, Where the Air Is Rarefied
description: Listening to an array of performers sing 28 songs by Jimmy Van Heusen at Alice Tully Hall on Friday evening, two things became clear. The first was that Van Heusen, who wrote mostly for the movies and became Frank Sinatra's house composer during the singer's ''swinging'' years, was a melodist of near-genius. The second was that Hollywood songwriting has always tended to be (for a lack of a better word) an ''impure'' craft compared to that of the theater.

title: Blue-Collar City Finds a Fund-Raiser Too Steep
description: Lionel Drean-Delva was marveling at the police officers, Secret Service agents and Presidential advance teams scurrying around his sleepy residential street this afternoon when a friend told him the reason for all the commotion. President Clinton was coming to town, to this modest neighborhood of ranch homes and one-car garages, to entertain an assortment of political contributors willing to donate as much as $25,000 each to New Jersey's 80 Democratic candidates for the state Assembly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BANK, DIANA (DONYA)
description: BANK-Diana (Donya), On October 16, 1999, at the age of 92. Beloved wife of the late Louis. Mother of two sons, Stanley and Carolyn, and Jerry and Mary Ann. Grandmother of Matthew. Graveside Service, Wednesday, 11 am, at the New Mount Carmel Cemetery, Glendale, NY. Contributions in her memory may be made to Hadassah. Information: Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mt. Vernon, NY 10552

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHELAN, SONDRA
description: PHELAN-Sondra. A loyal and committed alumna and member of The Ethel Walker School Board of Trustees. Her enthusiasm, compassion, and deep caring for her alma mater will be greatly missed by all who knew and worked with her. Our deepest sympathies go to her two sisters and niece who also attended the School, to her husband and children, as well as her entire family. Elizabeth Cesare, Board President

title: Williams Says Bad Calls Incited the Fenway Fans
description: Sometimes, Jimy Williams talks in riddles. Sometimes, he responds to questions with rambling answers that do not really address the questions. Sometimes, he does not care to talk at all. And sometimes, like today, when discussing George Steinbrenner, Williams can be direct and sarcastic. Among those supporting him was Don Zimmer, an old friend and a Yankee coach, who is a Steinbrenner employee but a Williams ally.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIDDELL, DONALD MACY
description: LIDDELL-Donald Macy. In deepest mourning, the family of their beloved Donald Macy Liddell has announced that on Sunday, October 17, he died at New York Hospital, after a long illness. The burial service will occur at the Woodlawn Cemetery in Baltimore. A Memorial Service will take place in New York City, at St. James Episcopal Church at 12 noon on Wednesday, November 3. Survivors include his wife, Jane Hawkes Liddell, his son, D. Roger Brooke Liddell, his daughter, Jane Liddell Bass, both of New York City and five grandchildren.

title: Japanese Change Tack in Teaching To Combat Poor Scores of Students : English Revisited
description: TOKYO  (Akiko Yamamoto contributed to this report.)

title: In Strong Pursuit of Luxury; But U.S. Designers Are Passed By in Race to Consolidate
description: That Calvin Klein Inc. is on the block should come as no surprise. Many other fashion houses have been tempted by the incredible prices that brand-name companies are receiving as they are snapped up in a wave of luxury fever.

title: Irene Heskes, 76, a Historian Of Music in the Yiddish Theater
description: Irene Heskes, a historian and author who specialized in sacred and secular Jewish music, including music of the Yiddish theater, died on Thursday at Long Island Jewish Hospital. She was 76 and lived in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CASEY, ELIZABETH F.
description: CASEY-Elizabeth F. October 19, 1960-January 30, 1998. Lizzie, we celebrate your life always, especially on your birthday. Taken from us too soon. Loved and cherished, you live on in our hearts forever. The Casey Family

title: EXECUTONE TO SELL PHONE BUSINESS FOR $44.3 MILLION
description: Executone Information Systems Inc. agreed yesterday to sell its Internet telephone unit to Inter-Tel Inc. for about $44.3 million in cash to focus on its on-line-lottery business. The company said Claricom Inc., a unit of Staples Communications, waived its right to buy the division. Claricom was granted the option as part of its 1996 purchase of Executone's direct-sales offices. Inter-Tel, based in Phoenix, develops software for phone networks. The company is selling its telephone and health care businesses and using the cash to become an on-line seller of Internet lottery services and software. Executone plans to sell tickets on behalf of state lotteries.

title: A Good Sign for Pettitte
description: Tom Pettitte was unable to watch his son Andy pitch against the Rangers in Game 2 of the division series at Yankee Stadium because he had an enlarged prostate. But the elder Pettitte was at Fenway Park on Sunday to see his son defeat the Red Sox, 9-2.

title: Piazza's Thumb Still Numb And Sore
description: The back of Mike Piazza's left hand is still swollen. His left forearm has a miserable black-and-blue mark on it. His fingers sometimes tingle, and his left thumb, the one that swelled up from an ill-fated cortisone shot, is still sore. But Piazza, who came out of Game 5 after John Rocker struck him out in the 13th inning, said he would be fine for Game 6. The reason he came out? After Kevin Lockhart slammed his helmet into Piazza's forearm when he was thrown out at the plate in the top of the 13th inning, Piazza knew almost instantly that something was wrong.

title: 2 FBC Executives Given Promotions
description: Two executives at the New York office of FBC Worldwide, part of True North Communications, are being promoted to share supervision of the creative output.

title: Panel Backs Firing Exercises in Puerto Rico
description: A Presidential panel recommended today that the United States military be allowed to resume live firing exercises on Navy property in Puerto Rico but that the range be shut down in five years, despite demands from the territory's governor that it be closed immediately and all bombing halted.

title: Harold Passer, 77, Nixon Adviser And Forecaster of the Economy
description: Harold Clarence Passer, an economic forecaster for business and the Government, including the Nixon White House, died on Oct. 8 at his home in Portsmouth, N.H., where he retired in 1983. He was 77.

title: Ruth's Daughter Cheers for Sox
description: Julia Ruth Stevens, the daughter of Babe Ruth, attended Game 5 on Monday night and participated in pre-game ceremonies. In a news conference before the game, she was asked about the Curse of the Bambino.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, MARTHA
description: WEINSTEIN-Martha, Best friend and constant companion for 53 years of Seymour. Wonderful, loving mother of David, Amy Sills and Suzin Rubin. Devoted motherin-law of Stephen Sills and Michael Rubin. Adored ''Mama'' of Sara and Zach Weinstein; Adam, Jacob and Daniel Sills; Ali, Matthew and Sam Rubin. Loving sister of Anne Kirschner and Sophie Rubenstein. She enriched the lives of all who knew her and will be remembered for her quiet loving and caring manner. Services Tuesday 1 PM at Park Avenue Synagogue, 87th Street and Madison Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOMON, NATHAN
description: SOLOMON-Nathan, 99, of NYC, on October 18, 1999. Active in American,Israeli and Jewish causes. Husband of the late Irene for 56 years. Survived by son Sol and daughter Elaine, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Funeral Wednesday, 10:15 AM, Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expwy., Fresh Meadows.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REBANAL, ARACELI R.
description: REBANAL-Araceli R. Of New York City. On Sunday, October 17, 1999. Loving daughter of the late Vicenta (nee Ras) and Sotero Rebanal. Dear sister of Rev. Jeremias Rebanal, Sr. Therese Agnes, O.C.D., Atty Levi Rebanal, Msgr Atonio Rebanal and Raphy R. Rabanal, M.D. and the late Atty Uriel Rebanal. Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral from McLaughlin Funeral Home, 625 Pavonia Ave, Jersey City, N.J. on Thursday, October 21st, 9AM. Funeral Mass at St. Aedan's R.C. Church, Jersey City, 10AM. Interment in the Philippines. Viewing Wednesday, 5-9PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORSDALE, C. LOUIS
description: FORSDALE-C. Louis. Professor Emeritus of Communication and Education at Teachers College, Columbia University died at age 77 of a heart attack in St. Joseph's Hospital in Albuquerque, N.M. on Sept. 22. A gifted and compassionate teacher, scholar of the impact of mass communications on the future of the human condition, lyrical photographer, astute analyst of film as an art form, lover of Mozart, Suzanne Farrell and Emily Dickinson, Lou influenced the lives and the classrooms of hundreds of graduate students and countless colleagues with his selfless generosity of spirit and imagination. He devoutly believed in the highest potential of his students and was rarely disappointed. In the early 70's, Lou introduced a professor from the University of Toronto by the name of Marshall McLuhan to media cogniscenti in NYC. McLuhan's observation that electronic communications were creating a ''global village'' reinforced Lou's own theories including the understanding that the visual impact of mass media far exceeded the importance of the text. His students have worked with educational systems throughout the country to place the arts at the core of educational curricula. Lou leaves behind his cherished children John Forsdale of Sante Fe and Lynn Denny and grandsons Oliver, Morgan and Cooper Denny of Lamy, N.M. The Department of Arts and Humanities and the Teachers College Community mourn the loss of Louis Forsdale. A memorial service in Milbank Chapel at Teachers College is planned for 4:00pm, Sunday, November 7.

title: ASHANTI BID REDUCED
description: The precious metals company Lonmin P.L.C. cut its offer by a fifth for Ghana's troubled Ashanti Goldfields Company, which is facing a crisis over the repayment of margin calls from gold hedging operations that could cost it $270 million. The revised offer values Ashanti, Africa's third-largest gold producer, at $5.99 a share, compared with $7.51 in a previous bid. Lonmin already owns 32 percent of Ashanti.

title: SIEMENS CONFIRMS TALKS
description: The German electronics giant Siemens A.G. confirmed that it was in talks with Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, the United States buyout firm, to sell its Siemens Nixdorf Retail and Banking Systems unit. A spokesman said the talks involved Siemens, Kohlberg and another party he declined to identify. The Siemens unit, which makes automated teller machines, cash registers and other computerized systems for retailers, has an estimated value of $768 million.

title: Money Manager Buys Stake in Rival
description: Affiliated Managers Group Inc., the 11th-biggest publicly traded money manager in the United States, agreed today to buy a 70 percent stake in the closely held Frontier Capital Management Company. for an undisclosed amount, increasing its managed assets by about $4 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDOLPH, SONYA
description: RUDOLPH-Sonya, age 70, mother of Barbara, Diane and Julia, sister of Warren & Robert, grandmother of Pamela, David, Jennifer and Jonathan, died on October 18th, 1999. Funeral service are private. Donations may be sent to the Brearley School.

title: Torre Says Knoblauch Will Sit in Late Innings to Help Defense
description: Joe Torre invited Chuck Knoblauch into the tiny manager's office at Fenway Park yesterday, closed the door and spoke in that soothing fashion that is supposed to make arduous changes easier for players to digest. Torre has often been lauded for calmly handling 25 personalities while making players feel as if he is their favorite uncle.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROCHLIN, PAUL
description: ROCHLIN-Paul In my dreams, you race the waves, your laughter pealing to the sky. There is no pain, only joy and love and promise. Marjori

title: The Giants Could Use Wheatley's Skills Now
description: The Giants have spent much of this awful season trying to find a franchise running back who can, well, run. This has not been easy. Gary Brown was hit by a car while riding his motorcycle last summer, and is just getting back to form. LeShon Johnson battled back from cancer last year, then injured his hand this season. Joe Montgomery hurt his hamstring in training camp and Sean Bennett his knee in Week 3. Maybe Joe Morris can still play.

title: Fixing What Ails Pakistan: Can the Coup Leader Deliver on His Promises?
description: Pakistan's new dictator, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, essentially told the country on Sunday that he had to destroy democracy temporarily to save it.

title: VULCAN TO INVEST $20 MILLION IN FATBRAIN.COM
description: Vulcan Ventures Inc., the investment vehicle of the billionaire Paul Allen, said yesterday that it would spend $20 million to increase its stake in Fatbrain.com Inc. to about 12 percent. Mr. Allen, a co-founder of the Microsoft Corporation, is increasing his stake in the company, based in Sunnydale, Calif., from 4.9 percent. Vulcan is paying about $20.88 a share, or 10 percent more than last week's average closing price. Fatbrain.com sells books on engineering and other technical subjects on the Internet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TONKIN, JOSEPH
description: TONKIN-Joseph. On October 15, at age 94. Beloved husband of the late Celina Tonkin. Loving son of the late Nathaniel Tonkin and Lily Freedman Tonkin and brother of the late A. Ted Tonkin. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, at 81 St, Tuesday, 12 noon. Interment Mt. Neboh Cemetery.

title: Raising Healthy Eaters
description: To the Editor:

title: Breast Cancer Fears
description: To the Editor:

title: Critic's Notebook; Now a Word From Our Spon . . . uh, um . . . Our Friend
description: Fans of the PBS ''Newshour'' must have noticed by now, with gratitude let's hope, that the program has gained two new correspondents.

title: Another Title Bid By United
description: D.C. United is making a bid to regain the title it lost last year to the Chicago Fire. After a 2-0 victory over Miami on Saturday in Game 1 of their Eastern Conference playoff series, United proved again that it would be the strongest challenger for the title. Jaime Moreno scored both goals to put United a victory away from reaching the conference finals.

title: A Call for Equal Access for All Investors
description: Arthur Levitt, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, stepped up his campaign against selective disclosure yesterday, asking companies to let all investors take part in conference calls about important information.

title: Lawmakers Reject Clinton Changes to Finance-Overhaul Bill
description: Senate and House lawmakers moved tonight toward completion of a bill overhauling the nation's financial system. But the measure still failed to satisfy President Clinton's concerns about adequately protecting consumers and minorities.

title: Shades of Chaplin In Witty Vignettes
description: Quasar Dance Company

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Emergency Treatment To Stop AIDS Virus
description: Frustrated by the continued spread of H.I.V., a growing number of AIDS doctors are trying out an experimental treatment: an application of drugs meant to abort infection in a person who was recently exposed to the virus through unsafe sex.

title: Madness and a Singer Who Goes All the Way
description: The Minnesota Contemporary Ensemble, founded in 1993 and directed by Duane Schulthess, brought an inventively theatrical but musically uneven program to Miller Theater at Columbia University on Wednesday.

title: Giving Without Borders
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Players Have a Day in School, And the Questions Are Tough
description: Half a day after banging helmets with opponents like Emmitt Smith in the Giants' Monday night victory over the Dallas Cowboys, Sam Garnes was facing an equally daunting task. Cramming his 6-foot-3-inch, 225-pound frame into a desk intended for third graders at Boys Harbor in Harlem, Garnes had to be ready for Tanisha Miller.

title: It's agency hunting season for everything from beauty products to boysenberry jam.
description: MARKETERS of products as disparate as cosmetics sold on line and jams sold in supermarkets are naming or changing agencies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCH, IDA
description: HIRSCH-Ida. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University records with profound sorrow the passing of Ida Hirsch, beloved mother of our dear friend, Michael D. Hirsch. Michael, an esteemed memeber of the executive board of our Young Men's Division, and his wife, Jane, are respected members of our Society of Founders. To Michael, Jane, and the entire family, we offer our heartfelt condolences. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University Burton P. Resnick, Chairperson Board of Overseers Albert Einstein College of Medicine Dr. Dominick P. Purpura The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean Albert Einstein College of Medicine David H. Schwartz, Chairman Young Men's Division

title: A Hated Man in Queens, Rocker Is a Fan of the Bronx
description: The rowdy John Rocker and his Atlanta Braves teammates are returning to New York, the site of Rocker's war of words with the city's baseball fans. But Rocker, who exchanged expletives and obscene gestures with Mets fans throughout the National League Championship Series, said he did not expect to have such a nasty relationship with those who cheer for the Yankees.

title: Looking Back at the Increasingly Rare Backward View
description: BACK in the 1960's, when my baby-booming family loaded seven children for a long haul in the station wagon, the seating arrangement might have looked like this: the toddler squeezed in the front seat between Mom and Dad; the older three girls in the back seat; the baby on a mattress between the second and third seats, and midsized youngsters in what we always called the ''way-back'' -- the third, rear-facing seat that was almost always a feature of the big wagons.

title: G.M. and Canadian Union Reach Tentative Agreement
description: Dodging a threatened strike, the General Motors Corporation reached a tentative contract agreement tonight with the Canadian Auto Workers union that will provide generous raises to the company's 21,000 Canadian factory workers even as it allows the company to continue to downsize.

title: FINANCIER RELEASED, WITH CONDITIONS
description: Giancarlo Parretti, the Italian financier who was arrested earlier this month in Orvieto, Italy, and held for extradition to the United States on fraud charges, was released from jail by a court in Orvieto but ordered not to leave Italy and to report three times a week to local police officials, pending a court decision on the extradition request. Mr. Parretti, who had been a fugitive for nearly three years, was indicted by Federal prosecutors in California on numerous charges of fraud in getting control in 1990 of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer for $1.3 billion and subsequently driving it to financial ruin. John Tagliabue

title: Dashboard Panache: Dials and Gauges and Lights. Oh My!
description: EVERY time you get into your car, truck, minivan or sport utility vehicle, you start a fresh relationship with it. That relationship is largely governed by how you interact with the instruments, controls and switches laid out before you on the dashboard, a piece of automotive equipment that has been evolving for more than 100 years.

title: Hunt Marketing Bought by DDB Seattle
description: DDB Seattle, formerly known as Elgin DDB, has acquired Hunt Marketing Group, a direct marketing agency in Seattle. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Whither 'N.Y.P.D. Blue'?
description: The pressure is on ABC to find a positive solution to the public relations fiasco regarding its tentative decision to dislodge ''N.Y.P.D. Blue'' from its longtime home on Tuesday nights at 10.

title: A Larger Legacy May Await Generations X, Y and Z
description: Boston College researchers say that the widely cited estimate that $10.4 trillion of wealth will be transferred to younger generations over a half-century is far short of the likely amount. They estimate the wealth transfer will be $41 trillion to $136 trillion.

title: An October Bust? Not This Time
description: For those who tirelessly warn that the economic boom is a bubble overdue to burst, these must seem like perilous days. Last week, worries about inflation and possible interest-rate increases sent stock prices into their biggest swoon in a decade -- in what some noted was the week before the anniversary of the infamous Black Monday of 1987. When stocks rebounded this week, after consumer prices showed only a modest increase, there was talk of volatility.

title: 'Partial Birth' Deceptions
description: Once again a woman's right to choose abortion is under direct attack in Congress. The Senate is poised to vote today on the latest Congressional attempt to impose a national ban on so-called partial birth abortions. Billed by its proponents as a narrow targeting of a single late-term procedure, the measure is actually a backdoor attempt to severely constrict abortion rights throughout all stages of pregnancy.

title: 'Latino Expo' in Midtown
description: A Hispanic business conference to be held in midtown Manhattan next week is expected to attract more than 10,000 people, the event's organizer said yesterday.

title: No Mystery on Asthma
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RENICK, SAMUEL W.
description: RENICK-Samuel W. Passed peacefully at his home in Manhattan on Saturday October 16, 1999. Cherished uncle and grand uncle to Binnie and Avery. Sammy, a legendary figure in the racing world will be remembered by many. Funeral services to be held on Thursday, October, 21, 1999 at 10 A.M. at Frank E. Campbell/The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. A Memorial Service will be held at a later date. Memorial contributions may be made to The Jockeys' Guild, P.O. Box 250, Lexington, KY. 40588.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS RISES. Natural gas rose 3 percent on expectations that a cold spell next week across the Eastern United States would raise demand. The November delivery contract rose 8.7 cents, to $3.007 per million B.T.U.'s.

title: Political Stalemate Continues Over Banking Bill
description: Senate Republicans and senior officials in the Clinton Administration failed to agree today on legislation to overhaul the nation's financial system, and said they would resume negotiations on Wednesday.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: MOVEMENT IN BANK BALI SCANDAL
description: The International Monetary Fund and the World Bank welcomed a decision by Indonesia's Supreme Court authorizing the release to Parliament of a confidential report said to implicate top officials in the Bank Bali political corruption scandal. State auditors had said releasing the report, the results of an audit of payments by Bank Bali to a company connected to the party of President B. J. Habibie, would violate Indonesian bank secrecy laws. The I.M.F. and World Bank have suspended payments in an aid package worth more than $40 billion. Asked if he expected the I.M.F. to resume its loans if the report on Bank Bali is published, the Finance Minister, Bambang Subianto, said: ''Yes of course. I expect it would really help.''

title: MY JOB: FRED BECKHARDT -- Ticket Broker; A Get-Rich Business? Just Isn't So
description: With two New York baseball teams in the post-season for the first time in 43 years, fans have gone to extraordinary lengths for tickets. Broadway tickets are hot, too. Benefiting from all the demand are brokers, who are licensed to resell tickets at modest markups. Fred Beckhardt, 72, works out of his home on the Upper West Side.

title: German Public Employees Protest Schroder Austerity Plan
description: Tens of thousands of teachers, police officers and other civil servants closed down the center of Berlin today, protesting Chancellor Gerhard Schroder's plans to trim what his Government has called ''the nanny state'' in Germany.

title: Cleveland Mayor Warns Newark an Arena Is No Cure-All
description: This city, in the grip of fevered hoop dreams that it can be revitalized through the magic of a sports arena, got some sober pointers today from the Mayor of the city that has become the poster child for such transformations.

title: He Sets the Values Car Makers Live By
description: FAR from the nation's automotive capital toils a respected analyst who influences one in every three new cars driven off dealer lots. That totes up to $80 billion in purchasing each year.

title: THE CHEF
description: ALMOND toast is a traditional French teatime snack with an American-style rags-to-riches history. Created by French bakers to use up day-old brioche, this easy sweet is simply sliced stale bread spread with a rich almond-butter ''cream'' and baked until the topping is golden and the bread toasted.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAUER, RENATE
description: SAUER-Renate. On October 15, 1999 after a short illness. Beloved wife of the late Dr. John J. Sauer. She will be remembered and greatly missed by her many friends whose lives she touched. Donations may be made in Renate's memory to the Jacob Perlow Hospice, Beth Israel Medical Center, First Avenue at 16th Street, New York, NY 10003.

title: Braves' Closer Uninjured In Crash
description: John Rocker, the garrulous Braves closer who has spent much of this series trading insults with Mets fans, was uncharacteristically mum at Turner Field tonight. The Atlanta left-hander refused to discuss a Monday morning auto accident that involved his Corvette.

title: CALENDAR
description: A Day of Winemaking

title: ENTRADE IN $50 MILLION DEAL FOR NATIONWIDE AUCTION
description: Entrade Inc., an Internet-commerce and auction company, said that it had bought the closely held Nationwide Auction Systems for about $50 million in cash, stock and notes to expand its on-line services. Details were not disclosed. Nationwide Auction, based in City of Industry, Calif., is the nation's largest-volume public-auction company that sells surplus property like vehicles and construction equipment from municipalities, law enforcement agencies, corporations and utility companies. It is expected to have about $110 million in auction revenue this year. Entrade, in Northfield, Ill., said it hoped to diversify its product base and add customers by offering Nationwide's service on line. Nationwide has 250,000 registered bidders.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FREIBERG, SYLVIA
description: FREIBERG-Sylvia. July 15, 1911 to October 20, 1998. Stronger than she realized, Sylvia lived almost three years after the death of her beloved husband, Sam, bringing much joy (and much laughter) to her family and friends. Now her ashes lie next to his beneath cherry and crabapple trees planted by their children, sons-in-law and grandchildren. How we miss them both. The Family

title: Ford Finds That Remaking a Fixture Is Risky Business
description: WEARING a dark blue Bill Blass shirt with the Ford Motor Company scripted over his heart, Rick Crossland, the brand manager for the 2000 Taurus, bounded onstage at the Boar's Head Inn here one day last month to deliver a sales presentation. The target customers for the new Taurus, Mr. Crossland announced in a buoyant voice, would be the very people who already owned Tauruses, some four million in number. Ford was not chasing new buyers, in other words. It just wanted to keep the old ones.

title: Clinton Renews His Appeal on Gun Control
description: President Clinton today renewed his call to Congress to approve a far-reaching gun control bill, but prospects for its passage appeared increasingly bleak as lawmakers remained deadlocked over the pivotal issue of regulating gun shows.

title: Janus Fund Manager Plans to Step Down
description: The Janus Capital Corporation said today that James Craig, who has helped build it into one of the fastest-growing American fund companies, was stepping down as manager of its flagship $33 billion Janus Fund to become the firm's research director.

title: Rally Racing in the Jungle: Don't Lose the Compass
description: PETER FLEMING wrote in ''Brazilian Adventure,'' the 1933 travel classic about a British expedition through Latin America's largest country, that ''the Brazilian chauffeur appears to believe that it is his business, like the matador's, to reduce to its narrowest the margin between life and death.''

title: House Honors Aaron
description: The House joined the Senate on Tuesday in Washington in honoring Henry Aaron, who made baseball history a quarter-century ago by breaking Babe Ruth's career home run record. ''This is one day I know I'll never forget,'' Aaron, the former Braves and Brewers slugger, said after the House unanimously approved a resolution recognizing him as one of the sport's greatest players. The Senate approved a similar resolution last week.

title: Buckle Up, Turn the Key And Get in Touch With Your Inner Springsteen
