description: SURELY few people would dare try to harmonize with the Supremes, belt it out with the Rolling Stones or warble along with Willie Nelson -- except when they are in their cars.

title: To Sip a Grape, Not Pluck It
description: NO one would ever suggest that it is better to drink a glass of orange juice than to eat an orange, or to drink apple cider instead of eating an apple. After all, the fruits contain fiber, an important component in the diet. But that contrary advice is just what research indicates about grapes. Drinking a glass of grape juice or red wine may be more beneficial than eating a bunch of grapes.

title: HOST MARRIOTT TO SELL STAKE IN RITZ-CARLTON BOSTON
description: The Host Marriott Corporation said it would sell its controlling interest in the Ritz-Carlton Boston to Millennium Partners for $122 million. Host Marriott, a lodging real estate investment trust in Bethesda, Md., owns or holds controlling interests in 123 hotels operated under the Marriott, Hyatt, Ritz-Carlton and Swissotel names. It said the sale was part of its strategy of selling some assets so it could repurchase shares. Millennium Partners, a New York-based real estate developer, will operate the hotel as a Ritz-Carlton and incorporate it into Millennium's residential, hotel and retail project at Boston Commons.

title: Whispering Through Monte Carlo's Curves
description: EVERY spring, the streets of Monte Carlo ring with the sound of Formula One engines when the principality plays host to the annual Monaco Grand Prix. Every January, during the storied Monte Carlo Rally, the Maritime Alps above the city echo with the roisterous sound of powerful vintage road racers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHUNG, RUTH W.
description: CHUNG-Ruth W. Of New York City, passed away on October 18, 1999, at the age of 83. Family matriarch and beloved wife of over 50 years of the late C.Y. and sister of the late Irene Lee, Elsie Wu, and Dale Bing Wong. Devoted mother of Janice Lee, cherished Auntie of Betty, Doris, Gloria, Kent, Alan, Carol, Ronald, Linda, and Andrew. Adored great aunt to many grand nieces and nephews. She will always be remembered for her loving warmth and kindness, her bountiful generousity and fiesty spirit, her distinctive laugh, and her everlasting beauty. The family will receive visitors at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street on Thursday from 25 and 7-9 P.M. Funeral services will be held on Friday at 11:30 A.M. Interment will follow at Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, NY.

title: U.S. Seeks to Break Impasse Blocking Khmer Rouge Trials
description: Hoping to break a deadlock between the Cambodian Government and the United Nations over how to bring former Khmer Rouge leaders to trial for war crimes, the United States has proposed the outlines of a compromise, an American official said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAMTON, MARGOT (NEE FIEGEL)
description: SAMTON-Margot (nee Fiegel). Of Scarsdale. 90 years old. Cherished wife of 67 years of Henry A. Samton; beloved mother of Annette Marcus, Claude and Peter Samton; adored grandmother of Josh, Matthew, Zach, Noah and Daniel Samton, Jessie and Mimsy Marcus; revered mother-in-law of Emily Samton and Paul Marcus; dear aunt of Albert Brunell, Dr. Peter Schrag and Katherine Wangh. Passed away October 16, 1999. Contributions in her memory may be sent to New York Tree Trust, Arsenal 830 Fifth Avenue, NYC 10021.

title: CUNY Students Ask Regents To Keep Remedial Program
description: They chanted no slogans and carried no placards, but a panel of students from the City University of New York yesterday urged New York's Regents to vote no on CUNY's plan to phase out remedial education at its four-year colleges.

title: Mandela Visits Israel With Praise but Rifts Linger
description: It was a trip intended to heal old wounds, and as Nelson Mandela concluded his first visit to Israel today, he took pains to praise ''my friends'' -- Prime Minister Ehud Barak and President Ezer Weisman -- for their regional peacemaking efforts and the ''warmth'' of their reception.

title: With Time To Spare, The Devils Experiment
description: With Jason Arnott and Petr Sykora scoring only one goal each in the Devils' first six games, Coach Robbie Ftorek is looking for ways to put some spark in the forwards who made up two-thirds of the Devils' top line last season.

title: Congressional Memo; Agenda of Budget Fight Turns Largely on Politics
description: In this year's version of their annual budget showdown, President Clinton and the Republican-led Congress are fighting over how much money the Federal Government should spend to hire teachers and police officers.

description: BASEBALL

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing of the Media Business page yesterday about new creative leadership at an advertising agency's New York office misstated the agency name. It is FCB Worldwide, not FBC.

title: Winston Cup: All White at the Wheel
description: IN Nascar's 51-year history, it has had only one black driver of any note, Wendell Scott, in the 1950's and 60's.

title: Lessons From a Brief Fling in the Fast Lane
description: BRAKE, clutch, throttle, shift now hold that trail brake,'' barked Jeff, my instructor in ''heel and toe'' downshifting, a driving technique that comes as naturally as patting my head and rubbing my belly while whistling the Pachelbel Canon.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SEAY, JONATHAN ROSS
description: SEAY-Jonathan Ross. July 30, 1965-October 18, 1999. In loving memory. ''I can sit quietly looking for a long, long time in absolute silence, and possibly, yes, still possibly - the old pure music will come to me again. Of course on the other hand, I may hear only the little noise of insects in the grass ... But I am sailing to Athens! Make voyages! - Attempt them!-there is nothing else...'' We will miss you, dear friend. Your Willow Cabin

title: Clinton and G.O.P. Take Step Toward a Budget Accord
description: President Clinton and Republican Congressional leaders took the first step tonight toward striking a deal on the Federal budget, meeting at the White House for more than 90 minutes and promising to work diligently toward a final agreement over the next week or so.

title: Going All Out for the 4-Wheel Version of Veterans Day
description: EVERY August, tens of thousands of enthusiasts make the trek to the dusty Laguna Seca race track, near Monterey, Calif., to watch old race cars compete in a gentle environment, with none of the bump-and-grind aggressiveness prevalent in modern racing. So when dust flew and metal collided in this year's event, spectators had more excitement than they had bargained for.

title: A Top Editor Is Leaving 2 Publications
description: Harold Evans, the editorial director of The Daily News and U.S. News & World Report, said yesterday that he would leave both publications at the end of the year to work on two book projects likely to become television documentaries.

title: The Implacable Yankees
description: The Mets' 10-9 loss to the Atlanta Braves early this morning ended their thrilling, turbulent quest for the National League championship. Our congratulations to the Braves, our condolences to the courageous Mets and our sympathies to all those who had been looking forward to the first subway World Series in New York City since 1956. The city's hopes now rest with the Yankees, who in their usual admirable, methodical way have captured their second straight American League pennant, their third in four years and their 36th of this century.

title: Western Officials Worry of Bias If Asians Lead UN Peacekeepers : New Timor Force Raises Questions
description: SINGAPORE  The Australian-led multinational force in East Timor could be replaced by United Nations peacekeepers by the end of the year, Foreign Minister Alexander Downer of Australia said Tuesday, but some Western officials are already worried that possible Asian replacements may not have the political will to enforce their mandate.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS

description: YOU'VE been driving around for years, your child safe and snug in his car seat in the back, your mind blissfully at ease, right?

description: The Microsoft Corporation reported quarterly earnings yesterday that convincingly surpassed Wall Street's expectations and reflected strong demand for personal computers and their software.

description: Ya gotta believe.

title: A Recital More Given To Nuance Than Fury
description: The urge to give concerts catchy titles should be reconsidered before it becomes too much of a nuisance. Marilyn Nonken, a pianist who is heard regularly in new music concerts with Ensemble 21 and other groups, called her Thursday evening recital at the Miller Theater ''Fists of Fury,'' evoking images of Muhammad Ali playing the clustery music of Henry Cowell. But Ms. Nonken's program did not require her to use her fists much. Just the opposite: she played music that demanded the agile, speedy fingerwork that has become her calling card.

title: EN ROUTE: Australia; Sydney's On Top Of the World
description: PARIS, surely, and New York and probably London, but after that it's hard to think of another city that matches Sydney, the home port of the good life, for the sheer excellence and exuberance of its restaurants.

description: IN a city where it's a good idea to pick your local baseball club and stick with it, especially these days, the playoffs have been a little stressful for Mike Mitaro.

description: WHAT if there was a fuel that was cheap, limitless and clean-burning? A fuel whose supply and price were strategically secure, free from the caprice of oil-producing nations? A fuel that relied on engineering fundamentally no more esoteric than that of a restaurant stove?

title: Prosecutors Press Theory That Killer Hates Women
description: Prosecutors yesterday scornfully attacked a defense psychiatrist's testimony that a psychotic episode had caused a mentally ill man to push a woman in front of a speeding subway train. During cross-examination, they broadened their argument that the attack was motivated by the man's rage toward women, disclosing that he had attacked only women in a dozen previous assaults.

title: Citigroup Stock Buyback
description: Citigroup said yesterday that it would increase its existing stock repurchase program by $3 billion. The repurchases, which represent about 2 percent of the company's shares outstanding, will be made from time to time in the open market, primarily to aid employee benefit plans, the New York-based financial services holding company said. Shares of Citigroup closed at $44.9375, up $1.25, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

description: A Brooklyn couple were shot to death early yesterday morning in their apartment, the police said.

title: Police Tie Recent Rape to 7 Cases in Queens and Nassau
description: A 55-year-old Queens woman who was raped on Monday was probably the victim of a serial rapist suspected in attacks on six other women in Queens and one in Nassau County, the police said yesterday.

title: Car Artists Make Their Every Trip A Traveling Show
description: ON a recent, drizzly Friday, a navy blue '85 Impala cruised slowly down a leafy street in suburban Clifton, N.J. The passenger window framed a grin of pure delight directed toward Stephen Hooper's driveway. The Impala circled around and crept to a halt. From the driver's side beamed another enchanted smile.

description: Bolstering the Bell Atlantic Corporation's bid to sell long-distance communications services to New York consumers by the end of the year, the New York State Public Service Commission told Federal regulators yesterday that the company had opened its local networks to competitors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRANDSTETTER, ROBERT DANIEL, M.D.
description: BRANDSTETTER-Robert Daniel, M.D., died at Sound Shore Medical Center of Westchester on October 18 after a long illness. He was the beloved husband of Gwyn and cherished son of Christian Brandstetter. He deeply loved his children, William, Daniel, Jennifer, Karen, Elizabeth and Kathleyn. His grandchildren, Ashley and Christian, infused his life with joy. Robert Brandstetter was born in the Bronx on February 27, 1947, the youngest son of Christian and the late Muriel Brandstetter. He graduated from DeWitt Clinton High School and served as a Hospital Corpsman in the United States Navy. Following his honorable discharge, he was a Pulmonary Technician and later Supervisor of the Pulmonary Laboratory at Morrisania Hospital in the Bronx for five years. He received his B.A. degree, Magna Cum Laude, from Herbert H. Lehman College and was awarded his M.D. degree from the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in 1977. Dr. Brandstetter completed his internship and residency at New York HospitalCornell University Medical Center and a clinical and research fellowship in pulmonary medicine at Massachusetts General HospitalHarvard Medical School, where he receive the 1981 Fellowship Teaching Award. Following completion of his training, Dr. Brandstetter joined the staff of the former New Rochelle Hospital Medical Center (now Sound Shore Medical Center of Westchester) in 1982 as Acting Chief of Pulmonary Medicine. Throughout his nearly two decades of service to Sound Shore Medical Center, he held increasingly responsible positions, including Chief of Critical Care Medicine, Acting Director of Medicine, Associate Director of Medicine and Director of Medical Education. He was the visionary who forged Sound Shore Medical Center's partnership with the Mercy College Graduate Program in Acupuncture and Oriental Medicine and offered complementary medicine practitioners the opportunity to train in a hospital setting. As coordinator of the Department of Medicine's weekly Grand Rounds lecture series, Dr. Brandstetter brought Nobe Laureates, foreign diplomats and internationally renowned speakers to Sound Shore Medical Center. A member of Phi Beta Kappa, Dr. Brandstetter was Board Certified in Internal Medicine, Critical Care Medicine and Pulmonary Medicine. He received numerous awards for his extraordinary work, including the Dr. William C. Schraft Memorial Teaching Award, the Medical Center's Attending Teaching Award and the Medal For Outstanding Contribution to Science and Letters from Mercy College. He served on the Editorial Boards of Chest, Heart and Lung, the Journal of Intensive Care Medicine, Archives of Internal Medicine, and was the author of two books. He published over 300 papers in medical journals throughout the United States andabroad. In addition to his wife, Gwyn, his father, children and grandchildren, Dr. Brandstetter is survived by his sisters Muriel Del Conte and Beverly Montouri, loving aunts, uncles, cousins, nieces and nephews, the thousands of patients he treated and his extended family at SoundShore Medical Center. He is predeceased by his mother, Murial and older brother, Christy. All of the people who knew and loved him will remember that he embraced life, with zeal and passion; he cherished every moment of life. Visiting hours are from 2-4 PM and 7-9 PM on Wednesday and Thursdayat Lloyd Maxcy Funeral Home, 16 SheaPlace in New Rochelle. The Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Friday at 10:30 AM at St. Gabriel's Church in New Rochelle. A reception to celebrate his life and honor his memory will be held in the Goldstein Auditorium at SoundShore Medical Center immediately following the funeral Mass. In lieu of flowers, friends may donate to the Robert Daniel Brandstetter Memorial Scholarship Fund at Sound Shore Medical Center of Westchester.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURG, YOSEF
description: BURG-Yosef. The United States Holocaust Memorial Museum mourns the passing of Dr. Yosef Burg, Chairman of the International Council of Yad Vashem and esteemed elder statesman and scholar. Having fled the Nazis himself in 1939, Dr. Burg's fervent commitment to the survivors and memory of the Holocaust took root in the immediate post-war period and was expressed throughout his long and distinguished career. His leadership in the cause of Holocaust remembrance and his generosity as a colleague will be greatly missed. The Museum extends its deepest condolences to his family and the people of Israel. Miles Lerman, Chairperson Ruth B. Mandel, Vice Chairperson Sara J. Bloomfield, Executive Director

description: For Pastrami Fans, A New Old-Fashioned Deli

title: METRICOM TO LEASE WIRELESS TOWERS FROM CROWN CASTLE
description: Metricom Inc., a provider of wireless Internet services, agreed yesterday to rent space on 500 communication towers from the Crown Castle International Corporation for as much as $126 million over 10 years as it prepares to offer its high-speed data service nationwide. Crown Castle, which is based in Houston and owns and manages more than 7,000 communication towers in the United States, said it would receive $1,500 to $2,100 a month per tower, depending on location. Metricom, based in Los Gatos, Calif., plans to introduce a high-speed wireless data service called Ricochet next summer in 12 major cities. The service, which the company wants to offer in 46 markets by mid-2001, allows users to connect to the Internet and corporate data networks at speeds faster than traditional computer modems.

title: National Urgency And a Local Focus
description: AL GORE vows an education revolution if elected President. Bill Gates pledges $1 billion for minority scholarships to college, one of the largest gifts in the history of philanthropy. Voters say education is the top domestic priority.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, JAMES WARREN

Cherished grandfather & great-grandfather. He was a pioneer in the telecommunications industry. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Thursday, October 21, 1999, 2-5 and 7-9PM. Memorial Mass Friday, October 22, 10AM, St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Ave. at 84th St.

The burial service will occur at the Woodlawn Cemetery in Baltimore. A Memorial Service will take place in New York City, at St. James Episcopal Church at 12 noon on Wednesday, November 3. Survivors include his wife, Jane Hawkes Liddell, his son, D. Roger Brooke Liddell, his daughter, Jane Liddell Bass, both of New York City and five grandchildren.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROGOVIN, JACK

Longtime teacher of French, Spanish & Russian and Guidance Counselor at Tilden High School in Brooklyn. Active in the Teachers Union. He served in the Army Signal Corps, South Pacific during W.W.II. Devoted husband of the late Gussie whom he visited faithfully every day for more than a dozen years after she contracted Alzheimers. Survived by numerous loving nieces and nephews. In lieu of flowers please make contributions to the Alzheimers Disease and Related Disease Association of Broward County, FL (He was President of the Fort Lauderdale chapter for many years.) Services 11AM Thurs, New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, L.I., NY.
