A Funeral Liturgy will be celebrated at 1:30 PM on Friday, October 22, 1999, at the Princeton University Chapel, Princeton, NJ. Burial will be private. Contributions may be made to Operation Smile, 6435 Tidewater Dr., Norfolk, VA 23509.

title: Hoffman Reverses His Slide
description: After quarterback Gavin Hoffman transferred from Northwestern, where he started all 12 games last season, he was expected to make a big impact at Pennsylvania. So when he threw five interceptions and only three touchdown passes in the Quakers' first four games, some wondered if his Big 10 credentials were relevant.

title: 40 Hours At Work; Another 40 In Elevator
description: Nicholas White endured a very, very long workweek.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEST, ROBERT E.
description: WEST-Robert E., 73, Died early Saturday, October 16, after a yearlong struggle with cancer. He is survived by his sons Rodney, Stephen and Richard; by his stepdaughter Prudence Procter Haines; by five grandchildren Amber, Nick and Eliza West and Jennifer and Sam Haines; by his brothers Donald and Richard West; his former wife Doris Barnes who is the mother of his sons; and by his friend and wife of 27 years, Winifred Sexton West. Colleagues, friends and family will gather in memory of Mr. West at Makefield Quaker Meeting (Mt. Eyre & Dolington Rd, Yardley, PA) at 3pm on Saturday, November 13. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Chandler Hall Hospice, Newtown, PA

title: I.B.M. Plans to Stop Selling Its PC's in Retail Outlets
description: I.B.M., which helped touch off a boom in computer retailing when it introduced its personal computer nearly two decades ago, said yesterday that consumers in North America soon would not find its PC's in stores; they will have to buy them on the Internet.

title: A New Universal Language; In Class of Many Tongues, Computer Skills Are Focus
description: For generations, Henry Street, on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, has been a first stop for immigrants learning to adjust to America. At settlement houses, churches and community centers, newcomers from Europe and Asia all learned the skills -- and the language -- they would need to survive in the new world.

title: Five Commutes That Make You Feel Better About Yours
description: IT wasn't long after workers jumped off their horses and into trains, buses and cars that commuting became a small American obsession. Few people really enjoyed it. Even 30 years ago, when more people commuted by public transit and highways weren't nearly as crowded, train delays, bus breakdowns and traffic jams marred many a family dinner.

title: Bradley Accepts Gore's Offer, And 7 Debates Will Be Held
description: A week after Vice President Al Gore personally challenged him to a series of debates, former Senator Bill Bradley said today that he had agreed to participate in at least seven joint appearances with Mr. Gore before the New Hampshire primary, the nation's first.

title: Structure and Basics Bring South Bronx School Acclaim
description: In a ragged corner of the South Bronx, a small educational experiment is producing some of the most impressive results that the New York City school system has seen in years. Employing unconventional techniques, a school has won praise from left and right and is helping shape the national debate on how the most disadvantaged students should be taught.

title: Rate Debate Heats Up on Rise in Consumer Prices
description: The Consumer Price Index rose four-tenths of one percent in September, the biggest monthly increase since April, the Labor Department reported yesterday. But only petroleum prices exerted any lasting inflationary pressure.

title: Riders' Survey Says Service On L.I.R.R. Is Worsening
description: In another sign of the deteriorating relations between the Long Island Rail Road and its weary riders, nearly one out of three passengers says service is getting worse, according to an annual survey released today by a state-chartered advocacy group.

title: How Nascar's Power Figure Keeps Everybody Happy
description: PLAYERS' UNIONS and egotistical team owners in most sports have turned the iron-fisted commissioner into a rusty relic. So why, then, has everyone in stock-car racing been so eager to submit to the near-dictatorial control of one man?

title: Parents and Educators Seek Regents Test Exemption
description: A consortium of parents and educators at 35 New York City alternative high schools will ask lawmakers at a hearing today in Manhattan to force the State Board of Regents to exempt alternative-school students from the new English Regents exam. The Regents board itself has so far rejected the group's request.

title: Accounts
description: Goodhome.com, San Rafael, Calif., a decorative home furnishings site, to Citron Haligman Bedecarre/Euro RSCG, San Francisco, part of the Euro RSCG Worldwide unit of Havas Advertising, to handle its first branding account. Billings were estimated at $25 million.

title: Separating the Chirp From the Ping, Unless It's a Grunch
description: SO your car is making a noise that's driving you crazy, but, of course, it puts on the silent treatment when the service technician tries to check it on a drive around the block. ''It sounds like a chirp,'' you insist. ''Or maybe a squeak or a squeal. And sometimes there's a chuckle, a kind of chattering sort of sound.''

title: Proof of Your Existence, Complete With Bad Photo
description: NOBODY wants Sergio Davila's money. Not the bars and nightclubs that won't let Mr. Davila in, though he is 27 years old. Not the Safeway market in his San Francisco neighborhood that denied him a convenience card. Not the Bank of America that refused his $400 to open a checking account. He even had trouble enrolling in a course at a local college.

title: People
description: Jeannette McClennan was named president at Ogilvy Interactive North America, part of the Ogilvy One Worldwide unit of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, owned by WPP Group P.L.C. She succeeds J. G. Sandom, who left to become president at Rapp Digital Direct, New York, part of the Rapp Collins Worldwide unit of Omnicom Group. Ms. McClennan had been vice president and managing director at Organic, New York.

title: With Rover, BMW Got More and Less Than It Asked For
description: BMW of Germany is one of the world's great automotive icons. Its cars ooze class, sophistication and engineering excellence. Land Rover, the British sport utility vehicles made by the BMW-owned Rover Group, enjoys a similar profile in another part of the motoring firmament.

title: A Brighter Idea That Some Eyes Are Finding Too Bright
description: ''I FEEL like I just stared at an arc welder and cannot see,'' said one E-mail complaint to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration about the intense, bluish-white headlights now turning up on German and Japanese luxury cars.

title: Annan Says Quick Elections in Kosovo May Not Help Tensions
description: The Secretary General of the United Nations, Kofi Annan, warned today that the ''built-in tension'' between the ethnic Albanians in Kosovo who want independence and the United Nations, which is administering the territory as part of Yugoslavia, would mount as time goes on.

title: Nixon, in Public and Private
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOKOLOFF, ALBERT BERTRAM
description: SOKOLOFF-Albert Bertram born March 17, 1919 died October 18, 1999. Preceded in death by his wife and lifetime soulmate, Miriam. Adored father of Barbara and Alan Folkart, Judy and Peter Slade, Peter and Annie Sokoloff. Grandfather of Wayne, Jeffrey, Mark, Debra, Peter, Kristina and Jen. Great-grandfather of Julia, Matthew and Emma. Brother of Stanley Sokoloff. Beloved uncle and cousin to many. A W.W. II Army veteran awarded two Purple Hearts, while serving in Europe with the 1st Infantry Division. He was a general contractor by profession. Formerly affiliated with Cong. Sons of Israel, Woodwere, NY. He spent many years as an active volunteer with the Boy Scouts, serving as Cubmaster, Scoutmaster, and District Executive and organized Nassau County's first Scout troop for orthodox Jewish boys. He was elected to Scouting's honorary organiztion, the Order of the Arrow. Those who loved Dad fondly recall his unique piano renditions of Moonlight Sonata and Fur Elise. Those melodies shall forever stir sentimental and sweet memories. Interment will be at 10:30 A.M. on Wednesday, October 20 at Star of David Cemetery, N. Lauderdale, FL. A New Jersey memorial service will be held at 1 P.M. on Thursday, October 21st at the Folkart home at 6 Greaves Place, Cranford, NJ. Following the memorial service, traditional Shiva will continue at the same address.

title: SCANDINAVIAN PHONE DEAL
description: Sweden and Norway agreed on the details of merging their state-owned phone companies, Telia A.B. and Telenor A.S., ending a night of talks to iron out last-minute disagreements. The final accord was signed yesterday morning. The nations plan to sell shares in the new company in April. The cross-border merger, forming Scandinavia's largest phone company, with $10 billion in sales, has been fraught with conflict over how much control each country will have.

title: Steak Sauce With Bite
description: THE best-known steak and cheese combination in this country may be the Philadelphia cheese steak, but the French know there is a more elegant way to combine these two foods: top a steak with a simple blue cheese sauce. It is the kind of dish I crave from time to time -- a good steak served with something powerfully salty and rich; anchovy butter or a combination of butter, soy sauce and ginger also do the trick.

title: Martin/Williams Wins Top Honors
description: Martin/Williams Advertising in Minneapolis, part of Omnicom Group, took top honors, winning two awards, at the Creative Excellence in Business Advertising awards sponsored by the American Business Press.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NISSENSON, ALFRED
description: NISSENSON-Alfred. On October 18, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Rose. Loving father of Samuel and father-in-law of Gloria. Cherished grandfather of Jennifer and James. Also survived by many dear nieces and nephews. Graveside services Friday 1:15 P.M. at Mount Judah Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASHION, ARCHIBALD, H.
description: CASHION-Archibald, H., 89, of Madison, NJ on Oct. 17, 1999. A man loved by family and friends who was a partner of the law firm of Whitman & Ransom. He graduated from Columbia University Law School and was a 50 year resident of Madison. Memorial Services will be held at the Grace Episcopal Church, 4 Madison Avenue, Madison, NJ on Sunday, October 24, 1999 at 2:00 P.M. For information: Wm. A. Bradley, 973-635-2428.

title: At the Ball, a Deadly Thief in the Night
description: Without the curse of the Red Sox to amuse them on Friday evening, a modest crowd of New Yorkers turned to the curse of the Red Death, in a program of music inspired by works of Poe at Avery Fisher Hall. Leon Botstein led the American Symphony Orchestra in Andre Caplet's ''Conte Fantastique,'' something between a tone poem and a harp concerto, based on Poe's ''Masque of the Red Death,'' as well as works by Florent Schmitt, Einojuhani Rautavaara and Rachmaninoff.

title: BP AMOCO BACKS PIPELINE
description: The leader of an 11-company group drilling for oil around the Caspian Sea, BP Amoco P.L.C., for the first time said it backed a $2.5 billion pipeline through Turkey that would link the region with Western oil markets. BP had previously rejected the proposal to ship oil from Baku, Azerbaijan, to the Mediterranean seaport of Ceyhan. Competing proposals would have routed the crude through Russia or Georgia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPER, FAY
description: COOPER-Fay. Of Boca Raton, FL and South Orange, NJ. On October 19, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Donald J. Devoted mother of Arlene Cooper and Richard Cooper. Loving grandmother of Jonathan, Ariane and Gregory Brainin. Services Thursday, October 21st at Menorah Chapels, Union, New Jersey. For further information call 908 964-1500.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGENFELD, CHARLOTTE
description: SIEGENFELD-Charlotte. On October 18, 1999. Beloved wife Saul, loving mother of Jane, Andy and Billy. Famously proud grandmother and great grandmother. Devoted friend and dedicated teacher. Donations may be sent to her favorite charity, The New York Times Neediest Case Fund.

title: CHINA GROWING AT 7% PACE
description: China's economy grew about the same pace in the third quarter as the preceding one, as stagnant state investment offset an increase in production and exports. Gross domestic product rose about 7 percent from a year ago, the National Statistics Bureau said. That is little changed from the 7.1 percent growth in the second quarter.

title: ISLANDERS
description: Rich Pilon, the Islanders' veteran defenseman, will miss three to four weeks with a sprained left knee, the team announced yesterday, one day after achieving its second victory of the season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHOMER, ROBERT R. V.M.D.
description: SHOMER-Robert R. V.M.D. The Jewish Braille Institute of America mourns the passing of a long-time and dedicated Trustee, Dr. Robert R. Shomer. As a devoted friend of the blind and visually impaired he will be missed by those whose lives were enriched by his deep caring. May his memory serve as a blessing and his family be comforted among the mourners of Zion. Barbara B. Friedman, President Gerald M. Kass, Executive Vice President

title: Sox Rue Their Own Mistakes
description: The passion that drove the Red Sox this summer still flickered late in the final game of their season. They loaded the bases in the eighth inning, threatened to come back against the Yankees, and when Pedro Martinez began doing short sprints in the bullpen, wearing a heavy parka in the cold, the Fenway Park crowd roared, knowing that Martinez would pitch if the game went into extra innings.

title: Poll Finds Decline in Teen-Age Fear and Violence
description: Just over half of American teen-agers believe that a murderous rampage could erupt at their schools, and just under half say they know someone their age who has tried to commit suicide, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: Four Are Sentenced In Tuition Fraud Case
description: Four men who stole tens of millions of dollars in Government benefits for a fictitious yeshiva in Brooklyn were sentenced yesterday to prison terms ranging from two and a half to six and a half years, the United States Attorney's office in Manhattan announced.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Irene Heskes, an author and music historian, omitted a survivor. He is her brother, Lawrence Newman of Niskayuna, N.Y.

title: In Sorrow, A Reservoir Of Strength
description: THINK of adversity as lightning. Then think of lightning as being more than just randomly cruel.

title: Cookbook Classics
description: To the Editor:

title: Forget the Last Lap, the Race Here Is at the Turnstile
description: AS swarms of people streamed across the parking lots toward the Bristol Motor Speedway last August, hours before the flag would signal the start of the Nascar 500-lap stock car race, Worden and Sonja Chamberlain relaxed in their car, unwinding after an hourlong, 51-mile drive from Boone, N.C.

title: NEW TODAY
description: A Focus on Education

title: Foreign Affairs; Penny Pinchers
description: You can think about the tug of war between the Republicans and President Clinton over the State Department's budget in a lot of ways. I prefer to think about it like this: Out of every dollar spent by the U.S. government each year, about one penny goes to pay for our embassies and diplomats abroad, democracy support programs, denuclearizing Russia, foreign loans and foreign aid. One penny. The Republicans now want to take that penny and cut it back more.

title: Students Urge Colleges to Join A New Anti-Sweatshop Group
description: In their latest effort to fight sweatshops, students from more than 100 colleges called on their institutions yesterday to join a new student-created group that would set a strict code of conduct for overseas factories that make apparel bearing university names.

title: Punish Taliban For War on Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Klan Group Sues the City To Hold Rally
description: A Ku Klux Klan group made good on its threat to sue New York City yesterday, saying it should not have been barred from holding a rally in Manhattan on Saturday. The lawsuit seeks to further its broader effort to overturn state laws prohibiting the wearing of masks in public demonstrations.

title: A Doyen Endures the Dishing-Out
description: Not for 25 years has Schuyler Garrison Chapin endured such indignities -- carping friends, and days of opening the papers to read about when he might be thrown out of his job.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEINTRAUB, SHEILA
description: WEINTRAUB-Sheila. 10/16/4010/20/90. Cherished mother, now more than ever... Alliso

title: Aide to Starr Successor Rejects Conflict Claim Involving Giuliani
description: Robert W. Ray, the newly chosen independent counsel in charge of the closing stages of the wide-ranging investigation of President Clinton, was interviewed and hired by Rudolph W. Giuliani to be a Federal prosecutor in New York nearly 11 years ago, a spokesman for Mr. Ray's office said today.

title: AIR CANADA COUNTERPROPOSAL
description: Canada's largest airline, Air Canada, announced a $628 million plan to repurchase 35 percent of its own stock and acquire its main domestic rival, Canadian Airlines. The plan is Air Canada's attempt to thwart a hostile takeover proposal made two months ago by the Onex Corporation, which wants to buy both airlines and combine them. Air Canada's global airline alliance partners, the UAL Corporation and Deutsche Lufthansa A.G., have agreed to help finance the airline's proposal to defeat the takeover by Onex, which is getting financial help from UAL's main American rival, the AMR Corporation.

title: A Face Lift For a Polished Performer
description: AUREOLE may be New York's foremost celebrity restaurant. It deserves the title not because celebrities eat there but because, in the classic definition, it is a restaurant famous for being famous. Diners fill Aureole's tables day after day and night after night, partly because it serves very good food but mostly because, like Everest -- the quintessential celebrity mountain -- it is there, and famously there. In the last 10 years, however, the surrounding peaks look a lot higher.

title: Doctor, How Do You Repair a Split Personality? With Crazy Glue?
description: Remember movies that believed so completely in psychiatry as a miracle cure? In ''Spellbound,'' just as soon as Ingrid Bergman could figure out what was causing Gregory Peck's bizarre Salvador Dali designed dreams, he'd be healed. In ''The Three Faces of Eve,'' as soon as Lee J. Cobb could get Joanne Woodward's multiple personalities to talk to one another, she'd be able to lead a normal life. Twenty years later Ms. Woodward returned the favor, playing psychiatrist to Sally Field's scattered character in the television movie ''Sybil.'' ''Angels Don't Dance,'' Richard Brockman's alternately insightful and simplistic drama, is that kind of story.

title: Leiter Wished for Another Start
description: Al Leiter admitted that, when he went home after Game 3 last Friday, his Mets down by 3-0 in games, he was only hoping that he would get another start in the N.L.C.S. Manager Bobby Valentine's moment of doubt came earlier, last Wednesday in Atlanta, after the Mets lost Game 2.

title: Where Fans Can Ride Off Into the Sunset
description: Not many towns of 1,800 people could hold an annual film festival showing only Hollywood movies that were filmed within a few miles. Since 1990 Lone Pine, a little hamlet at the base of the Sierra Nevada's steep eastern slope, has held one of the nation's quirkiest and most specialized film festivals, showing only movies and television episodes filmed in the area and inviting as its featured guests only the actors, directors, producers and film technicians who worked on location here, with rare exceptions. Even films made 50 miles up the road are excluded.

title: Wit and Pathos United by a Beat
description: When DJ Squeeze, an M.C. at the 20th-anniversary party for VP Records at the Theater at Madison Square Garden, shouted out island names from Puerto Rico to Haiti and Trinidad, shouts burst out like thunderclaps from the crowd. But only one word caused a truly mighty racket: ''Jamaica!''

title: It Talked Too Much to Be a Book
description: One of the most satisfying acting ensembles the season is likely to produce has come and gone before virtually anyone knew it was around. The all-pro quintet, consisting of Edward Herrmann, Blythe Danner, Philip Bosco, Elizabeth Wilson and David Aaron Baker, has just finished an all-too abbreviated run in A. R. Gurney's genteel and gently comic ''Ancestral Voices'' at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater, leaving exceedingly pleasant memories in its wake.

title: U.S. Bishops Urging Catholics To Be Politically Involved
description: Calling the election year 2000 both a ''great spiritual milestone'' and an ''important civic challenge,'' the nation's Roman Catholic bishops are to issue a statement today saying participation in the political process is a moral obligation for Catholics and asking them to reflect on how politics can be used to advance church principles like stopping abortion, helping poor children, protecting immigrants' rights and providing families affordable housing.

title: JAPANESE OIL COMPANY ARRESTS
description: Japanese prosecutors arrested several officials from some of Japan's biggest oil companies after raids on the offices of 11 companies last week on suspicion that the companies had rigged jet-fuel bids to the Defense Agency. Nippon Mitsubishi Oil, Japan's largest oil refining company, said two of its officials were arrested in relation to the charges of bid-rigging. Four other oil companies -- Showa Shell Sekiyu, Japan Energy, Cosmo Oil and Idemitsu Kosan -- also said that employees were arrested. The Tokyo prosecutors' office declined to comment on the arrests.

title: Nixon, in Public and Private
description: To the Editor:

title: Hollywood, City Hall and a Production Deal That Wasn't
description: Robert De Niro, a star in two of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's all-time favorite films -- ''The Godfather Part II'' and ''Analyze This'' -- came to Gracie Mansion last spring to flesh out his proposal to build film studios at the Brooklyn Navy Yard. The meeting went well enough for the Mayor to perform his Godfather routine for the accomplished actor.

title: Confidentiality Breached in N.B.A. Drug Testing
description: The National Basketball Association briefly suspended its new drug-testing program last week, after union leaders complained that confidentiality had been breached during the first three weeks of the program.

title: SOUTHERN TELLS OF EFFORTS TO BUY GAS PIPELINE COMPANY
description: The Southern Company, the largest United States power generator and owner of Atlanta's electric utility, has tried unsuccessfully for a year to negotiate a buyout of a natural-gas pipeline company, including the El Paso Energy Corporation or the Coastal Corporation, Southern's chief financial officer said yesterday. The executive, William Westbrook, said that Southern had had talks with El Paso, Coastal and other gas companies but that no agreement could be reached on price. Both El Paso and Coastal declined to comment. El Paso has a stock market value of about $4.8 billion, and Coastal, $8.5 billion.

title: This Farm System's Crop Is Green
description: DESPITE the name, a stock car is far removed from anything in stock at a car dealer. The chassis is a cage of heavy steel tubing that protects the driver in a crash; to this are attached a hand-assembled V8 engine that produces about 750 horsepower, a four-speed transmission, a rupture-resistant gasoline tank and wheels, tires and suspension designed just for racing. The only parts that might be interchangeable with mass-produced cars are the hood and the roof.

title: Putting Fertility First
description: There are now six billion people on the planet, we are told, and many characterize humanity's arrival at this milestone as a catastrophe. Family-planning activists responded to it with calls for more financing to address the ''unmet needs'' of hundreds of millions of women.

title: Four to Try To Get Job As Daluiso Substitute
description: The season-ending knee injury sustained by Brad Daluiso during the final play of Monday night's 13-10 victory over the Dallas Cowboys had Giants management studying their scouting reports and calling kickers all over the country.

title: Inflation and the Economy
description: Two recent price reports appear to signal that the hated scourge of inflation may be on the rise. Consumer prices, the government reported yesterday, rose at about a 5 percent annual rate last month, and at a 4 percent rate over the last three months -- about 50 percent faster than in the recent past. Wholesale prices did even worse, rising at about a 10 percent rate in September and at a 7.5 percent rate for the last three months.

title: Psychologists' Alliance
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A sports picture caption on Thursday about the ceremonial first pitch at Yankee Stadium, thrown out by a son of the late Catfish Hunter, misidentified the son. It was Paul Hunter, not his brother Todd.

title: Chief at Coke Bottler Is Retiring, Three Months Ahead of Schedule
description: Surprising some analysts, Coca-Cola Enterprises, the largest bottler for the Coca-Cola Company, announced yesterday that its chief executive, Henry A. Schimberg, would retire at the end of the year, three months earlier than expected. His replacement, for the moment, is the company's 67-year-old chairman.

title: Big Drug Makers Register Strong Gains in Quarter
description: If the world's largest pharmaceutical companies were to choose a theme to accompany this week's third-quarter earnings announcements, it might be ''Let the Good Times Roll.''

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: U.S. Indicts McDonnell Douglas And Chinese in Equipment Deal
description: A Federal grand jury indicted the McDonnell Douglas Corporation and a powerful state-owned aerospace company in China today on charges of conspiring to hide important details of a 1994 sale of American machining equipment, some of which was diverted to a Chinese military site.

title: Anatomically Incorrect: Decoding the Pig
description: EVEN for experienced cooks, approaching the meat counter can be a prelude to bewilderment. The names of various cuts of meat often change from shop to shop, and some seem designed more to confuse than to enlighten the shopper.

title: READER'S DIGEST TO BUY $50 MILLION STAKE IN COMPANY
description: The Reader's Digest Association said it had agreed to pay $50 million for an 18 percent stake and an option to buy an additional stake in Branddirect Marketing Inc., a direct marketing company based in Shelton, Conn. Reader's Digest, based in Pleasantville, N.Y., said the companies had also agreed to develop and market Reader's Digest-branded membership clubs. Reader's Digest shares rose 6.25 cents yesterday, to $28.4375.

title: Puerto Rico Governor Faces Senators Over Firing Range
description: In a standoff with powerful senators, the Governor of Puerto Rico told a Congressional committee today that the United States military should never resume live firing exercises on the territory's island of Vieques, despite the recommendation of a Presidential panel that the exercises resume.

title: Schools Face Having to Give More Data To Parents
description: Millions of parents of public-school students stand to receive reams of new information about the performance of the children and their schools, and about the qualifications of their teachers, under a bill making its way through the House of Representatives with unusual bipartisan support.

title: U.N. Council in Rare Accord: Fight Terrorism
description: At a time when the United Nations Security Council often has trouble reaching agreement on whether one crisis or another constitutes a threat to international peace, the 15-member panel has been able to coalesce solidly on the growing dangers of international terrorism. Today, the Council voted unanimously to wage a common fight against terrorists everywhere.

title: The Vice President Presents Himself
description: This new 60-second television commercial is being broadcast in Iowa and New Hampshire for the next three weeks. The commercial is a sweeping, if quick, biography to introduce Mr. Gore to voters.

title: Ornamental vs. Functional
description: To the Editor:

title: A 200-Point Rally Fades, but Dow Manages a Solid Gain
description: Stock prices were generally firmer yesterday, helped by positive earnings reports from big drug makers and inflation numbers that were in line with expectations.

title: Pro- and Anti-Barak Settlers Play a Game of King of the Hill
description: When Motti Katz drove his truck up to a hill near this Jewish settlement today to remove an empty shipping container planted on the hilltop, he ran into barricades of boulders and barrels.

title: Liberties; President Lonely Guy
description: It was a disturbing image, with elements of Nixon, Lear and ''Caddyshack.''

title: Thwarted by Light Breezes, Team Conner Loses Twice
description: ''Have a good day,'' Dennis Conner called cheerily to American tourists here today -- although his own day in the America's Cup challengers trials could have been much better.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSTAN, ALICE
description: ROSTAN-Alice. Died on Monday October 18, 1999, at her home. Funeral services will be held on Friday, October 22, 1999, 11:30 A.M. at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: Hong Kong Radio-TV Chief Shifted to Japan
description: In a move that has stirred new fears about freedom of the press here, Hong Kong today abruptly reassigned the director of its government-owned broadcaster, Radio Television Hong Kong.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Back in Building, And on the Wall

title: Fewer Men Are Working, as Home Duties Beckon
description: With the gender gap shrinking for five decades, can parity be far behind? The percentage of men who work keeps falling, to about 75 percent at last count from 86 percent in 1950. Meantime, the percentage of women working has risen to 67 percent from less than 60 percent over the same period.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FARINA, ANTHONY
description: FARINA-Anthony. Gone one year. I will never forget you. Your SP Shirley

title: The Heart of Baseball
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDGELL, STEPHANIE
description: EDGELL-Stephanie. On Oct. 17, 1999. Beloved daughter of Stephen Maurice Edgell and Elsie Aldrich Edgell Campbell, sister of Stephen M. Edgell Jr. and Helena Franklin, and aunt of Stephen M. Edgell III, Helena Rozier, George Franklin, Cynthia Franklin, & Sheila Lieber. Cherished by her many friends for her extraordinary kindness, dry wit, perceptiveness & generosity. A lover of literature and the arts, a skilled potter, ardent traveller and caring social worker, she will be deeply missed. Please call (203) 454-9847 about funeral services. Donations may be made to the Greenwich, CT. Public Library, (203) 622-7900.

title: Big Spanish Banks Plan $11.5 Billion Merger
description: Spain's No. 2 and No. 3 banks announced a $11.5 billion merger today that would create a strong rival to the nation's biggest banking company, Banco Santander.

title: Usual, and Unusual, Offers of Help to Flood's Victims
description: After weeks of complaints that flood relief was slow in coming, efforts to help pay for damage and dislocation from Tropical Storm Floyd have picked up some speed this week in Washington, Trenton and, of all places, Atlantic City.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A Whole Other Type of E-Trade
description: SINCE the first cave man exchanged his favorite club for a neighbor's animal pelt, barter has been an accepted form of commerce. Now some Internet companies have turned themselves into virtual trading posts, making barter a way of life.

title: Paine Webber to Join Trading Network
description: Paine Webber Inc., the fourth-biggest United States securities firm by number of brokers, has agreed to become the first full-service firm to invest in the Redibook electronic communications network.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JULIA, RAUL
description: JULIA-Raul. A Mass will be held in honor of the late Raul Julia at Holy Trinity Church, 213 West 82nd Street on Saturday, October 23 at 6:30PM. October 24 marks the fifth anniversary of Mr. Julia's death.

title: House Approves Medicare Extension for the Disabled
description: With an overwhelmingly bipartisan vote, the House of Representatives today passed a bill expanding Medicaid and Medicare so that hundreds of thousands of people with disabilities could return to work and keep their health insurance coverage.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Monday with an article about the debate over the use of regional anesthesia in childbirth misidentified a couple shown in a class at the Elizabeth Seton Childbirthing Center in Greenwich Village. They were Suchita and Dhiraj Nayar -- not Guillermina Ramirez and Saul Flores, who also attended a class there.

title: Appreciating the Depreciation In a Certified Used Luxury Ride
description: REALLY, status had nothing to do with his decision to acquire a BMW 740IL, said Frank Blatcher, a lawyer from Media, Pa. ''I didn't get it because of other people's perceptions,'' he said. ''I got it because of me. I just like the way it handles; it corners like a sports car.''

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE DOLLAR GAINS. The dollar was little changed as traders awaited reports today on trade statistics and other figures. In New York, the dollar settled at 105.28 yen, up from 105.08; the euro traded at $1.0838, down from $1.0842.

title: WHX ENDS TALKS WITH WEIRTON STEEL ABOUT A MERGER
description: The WHX Corporation, a holding company, has terminated discussions with the Weirton Steel Corporation about a possible business combination. WHX said yesterday that the talks had explored combining the companies' steel manufacturing operations. It gave no specific reason for ending the talks. In July, WHX said the companies were in preliminary talks about a joint venture or other business combination. Weirton Steel shares slipped 18.75 cents, to $2.25, and WHX shares were unchanged at $10.

title: Jets' Williams Requires a Respirator as He Recovers From an Infection
description: The Jets have had numerous medical problems this season, but Kevin Williams's remains the most serious case. Williams, a second-year backup cornerback, contracted a sore throat three weeks ago that turned into a virulent infection, which required three surgical procedures. Williams is recovering at Lenox Hill Hospital, where he remains heavily sedated and is on a respirator to help his breathing.

title: Corrections
description: The Personal Health column in Science Times yesterday, about types of brain tumors, included outdated references to John Cardinal O'Connor's condition. The Cardinal had a small tumor removed from his brain nearly two months ago, not this month. He has been receiving radiation treatment; the therapy is not in the future.

title: After They Rejoice, Yankees Have Ample Time to Regroup
description: His Yankee-blue shirt glistening wet from champagne, Ramiro Mendoza rushed over to a corner of the visitors' clubhouse, threw his right arm around the neck of Orlando Hernandez and pulled his teammate close, in a headlock. ''Poppy!'' Mendoza squealed.

title: Meeting Eases Tensions In Port Authority Dispute
description: Officials of the City of Elizabeth and Union County, who have been locked in a dispute with the Port Authority over the development of 177 acres near Newark International Airport and Port Elizabeth, said an effort to resolve the dispute yesterday had been fruitful and would continue on Friday.

title: Nolan Sparkles for the Sharks on Offense and on Defense
description: Owen Nolan leads the National Hockey League in scoring. And the big San Jose right wing not only assisted on another goal, but he also drew a controversial second-period penalty that led to a two-man advantage and both of his team's scores last night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVITIS, ESTHER
description: LEVITIS-Esther. October 17, 1999, in her 89th year. Beloved wife of the late Louis Levitis; survived by her loving children, Susan and Saul Nimowitz, and Gerald and Karen Levitis; grandchildren David Nimowitz, Debby and Aby Laznik, and Wendy, Jason and Daniel Levitis; great-grandchildren Aaron and Jake Laznik and many friends. She spent her long life helping others, improving the world, fighting injustice, teaching children to love to learn, and loving her family. ''if love were a noodle, she'd be a kugel.'' Burial Thursday, October 21. Memorial gatherings in New York and C.V.E. Florida to follow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOMON, NATHAN
description: SOLOMON-Nathan. Sutton Place Synagogue records with sorrow the loss of our devoted member and Patron. We were enriched by his profound knowledge of Judaism and friendliness. Condolences to the bereaved family. Allan Schranz, Rabbi Robert W. Berend, President

title: Business Travel; Horror stories about life on the road are getting some attention that could make a difference.
description: AROUND 6 A.M., Rich Borden got that sinking feeling at the airport in Sao Paulo, Brazil, where he had just flown in on a red-eye from Paris. Nine hours in coach across the Atlantic and all he wanted was to grab his luggage, hurry to his hotel, shower, change and hit the deck for a 10 A.M. meeting.

title: Want the Secret to Selling Cars? First, Be Bob Tasca
description: CLICK-THUD. Click-thud. Click-thud. Over and over, Bob Tasca Sr. unlatched the door of the car and pushed it closed, listening for creaks and feeling for resistance. ''See that? It practically closes itself,'' he said with approval. He walked to the front of another car, stooped down and eyed its length as if lining up a target in a shotgun sight.

title: Minivan Makeovers: New Inside Looks for Soccer-Mom Mobiles
description: OVER the years, plenty of thought has gone into perfecting the multitudinously expressive body of the car: its fins, fenders and grilles. No doubt the guy who invented the wheel probably had a few ideas about how much va-voom to throw into its curve.

title: INSIDE
description: Consumer Prices Edge Up

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARDNER, ROSALIND
description: GARDNER-Rosalind. On October 19, 1999. Beloved wife of Jack. Devoted mother of Geoffrey and Jean Gardner, and Gerry and Jeffrey Morgan. Cherished grandmother of Kristen, Gregg, David, and Nicole. Loving sister of Alfred and Lewis Bloom.

title: Friends of the Salmon
description: To the Editor:

title: Nixon, in Public and Private
description: To the Editor:

title: Giants' Kickoff Went Deeper Than Strategy Had Planned
description: Believe it or not, there are worse things you can do than kicking the football to Deion Sanders with one second remaining in a game you lead by 3 points.

title: RALSTON PURINA TO SPIN OFF BATTERY UNIT IN APRIL
description: The Ralston Purina Company said that it would spin off its Eveready and Energizer battery unit in April. Ralston shareholders will get one share in the battery business for every three Ralston shares they own, according to a preliminary filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The new company, Energizer Holdings Inc., will have about 100 million shares outstanding and will be led by Ralston's chairman, William Stiritz. Ralston, which is based in St. Louis, said in June that it would spin off the unit to focus on its more profitable pet foods business. Ralston shares rose 50 cents, to $31.375.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMMARATA, JOHN
description: CAMMARATA-John. On October 17, 1999 of Marlboro, NJ formerly of Syosset, NY. Beloved husband of Nina (nee Sicari). Loving father of John II and Annamarie McGowan. Fond father-in-law of Diane Cammarata and Martin McGowan. Dearest grandfather of Sara, John III, Joseph & Gina. Dear brother of Vincent. Reposing at the Beney Funeral Home, Inc of Syosset, 79 Berry Hill Rd. Visiting Wed & Thurs, 2-4 & 7-9pm. Funeral Mass 10:30am Friday at Maria Regina RC Church, Jerusalem Ave, Seaford, NY. Entombment St Charles Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY.

title: On Baseball; No. 7 Train to Shea Stalls in Atlanta
description: The Subway Series will not take the IRT to Queens. It will ride Marta in Atlanta instead.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERBERG, MARK L.
description: SILVERBERG-Mark L. It is with great sadness that we mourn the untimely passing of the son of our beloved Board President, Michael Silverberg and his wife Charlottecourageous leaders in the forefront of the fight against mental illness. We extend our affection and heartfelt sympathy to the Silverberg family. The Board of Directors National Alliance for the Mentally Ill -NAMI-NYC Metro

title: VOTE ON CAMPAIGN FINANCES IS BLOCKED BY SENATE G.O.P. FOR FOURTH YEAR IN A ROW
description: For the fourth year in a row, Senate Republicans have blocked a final vote on legislation to overhaul the campaign finance system. The Senate majority leader today declared the issue ''dead for the year.''

title: Nissan's Planned Cuts Arouse Ire and Offers of Help in Japan
description: Less than 24 hours after the Nissan Motor Company announced a far-reaching overhaul that includes plant closings and job cuts, Nissan, Japan's No. 3 auto maker, discovered today that candor does not play well here politically.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Hospital May Discharge Cardinal Today
description: Doctors say John Cardinal O'Connor is recovering normally from radiation therapy for a brain tumor but is suffering from slight dehydration and a small blood clot in his left leg, his spokesman said yesterday.

title: A Savvy C.I.A.
description: To the Editor:

title: Bates Will Promote ESPN Outside U.S.
description: ESPN International, the overseas operations of the sports cable television network ESPN, said yesterday that it had awarded its international branding assignment to Bates Worldwide in New York, part of Cordiant Communications Group P.L.C. Billings have not been determined.

title: NATIONAL ORIGIN: Finger Lakes; A Heartland Crop, A New York Address
description: As a gusty wind bit the air and the autumn colors started to fade around the Finger Lakes, the season's last loads of freshly harvested buckwheat were arriving at Birkett Mills, the 200-year-old reason this is the heart of America's buckwheat country.

title: Sports of The Times; Now the Mets Have Whole New Attitude
description: FOUR weeks ago to the day, the Mets barreled into town full of heady pretensions and the fragile confidence of a team that was having its first dreams of the top after a decade of mediocrity. They had put distance between themselves and Cincinnati in the National League wild-card race and had pulled within a game of the Braves -- the foe they have chased for so long in the East Division. With three games at Turner Field, the Mets were certain they would come out even with Atlanta at the very least.

title: Credit Ratings Are Lowered At 4 Hospitals In New Jersey
description: Four northern New Jersey hospitals had their credit ratings lowered by a major bond-rating agency today, a sign that the financial pressures threatening many inner city hospitals have begun to affect affluent communities as well.

title: Mannesmann Seeking a British Mobile Phone Company
description: Mannesmann A.G., Germany's fast-growing engineering and telecommunications group, confirmed today that it was negotiating with Orange P.L.C., Britain's third-largest mobile phone operator, raising speculation about one more takeover in Europe's rich and expanding mobile phone market.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PACK, RICHARD, M.
description: PACK-Richard, M. A memorial service will be held for Richard M. Pack on Friday, October 22, 1999, at 5 p.m. at the National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences, 111 West 57th Street, NYC. Pack died last July 1st. at the age of 83 after a long and distinguished career in broadcasting, spending the last 18 years as editor of Television Quarterly. For information: Trudy Wilson (212) 586-8424.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: A Platinum Era of Giving Is Foreseen by Researchers

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHELAN, SONDRA
description: PHELAN-Sondra. We deeply mourn the passing of our beloved colleague and friend. Her wise and understanding heart will remain with us always. Gillian Walker, Anne Rivers, Marcia Stern, Susan Shimmerlik, Pat Heller, Ana Escalante, Martha Edwards The Unique Minds Program

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  READER, STANLEY
description: READER-Stanley. The members of Rockrimmon Country Club are saddened by the passing of their longtime member and friend and express sincere sympathy to his family. Leonard Danon, President

title: STUNG BY DEBATE, INDONESIAN LEADER ENDS ELECTION BID
description: Humiliated by a midnight ballot in the national assembly that condemned his record, President B. J. Habibie withdrew as a candidate for President today and the assembly prepared to vote hours later for Indonesia's next leader.

title: Alexander's to Get Loan for Old Store
description: Vornado Realty Trust agreed to lend $50 million to the real estate developer Alexander's Inc. to finance development costs at the site of its former flagship store in midtown Manhattan and at a Brooklyn shopping center.

title: Nathalie Sarraute, Novelist, Is Dead at 99; A Dean of the Nouveau Roman Movement
description: Nathalie Sarraute, the Russian-born French novelist who remained an influential and innovative literary figure long after she first gained fame as the doyenne of the Nouveau Roman movement in the late 1950's, died today at her home in Paris. She was 99 and also had a country home in Cherence in Normandy.

title: Beyond Black and White
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: ANOTHER TARGET FOR MANNESMANN
description: One day after acknowledging negotiations with Orange P.L.C. the British wireless network operator, Mannesmann A.G., confirmed that it was also bidding for Cablecom Holding, Switzerland's largest cable company. But rivals said Mannesmann, Germany's biggest mobile phone company, was becoming vulnerable. Referring to Klaus Esser, Mannesmann's chief executive, Ron Sommer, head of Deutsche Telekom A.G., said: ''Maybe someone is going to see Esser going after Orange and think: here is a good asset. I have to go visit him with some flowers and maybe a check.''

title: SCHRODERS GIVES UP EFFORT TO BUY NEW YORK ADVISER
description: Schroders, Britain's largest independent investment bank and fund manager, said yesterday that talks to buy Beacon Group, a New York merger adviser, had ended without an agreement, setting back its United States expansion plans. Schroders had been in talks to acquire Beacon, reportedly for more than $400 million in stock. Schroders has been looking for United States acquisitions since last spring. It said the talks with Beacon were stopped by mutual agreement. Beacon was founded in 1993 by Geoffrey Boisi, a former Goldman Sachs Group executive.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Tailoring Laughs To the First Lady

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUET, JEAN
description: HUET-Jean. The trustees, staff and members of The Metropolitan Museum of Art's Business Committee mourn the passing of Jean Huet, Co-Chairman of the Metropolitan's Business Committee and formerly Chairman of the Museum's International Business Committee. Since 1993, he served as an advocate for the Museum in the international business community. His leadership, advice and counsel will be greatly missed. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Michele, and to the entire Huet family. James R. Houghton, Chairman Philippe de Montebello, Director David E. McKinney, President Steven Rattner, Trustee & Chair, The Business Committee

title: I.O.C.'s Drug Plan Criticized at Hearing
description: The International Olympic Committee's plan to create an anti-doping agency to combat athletes' use of performance-enhancing drugs -- a proposal flayed by foreign government officials when it was proposed eight months ago in Lausanne, Switzerland -- received further censure today at a Senate hearing.

title: Just Be Sure It's Your Money, Not His
description: THE 39-year-old woman, a political consultant, was expecting the worst. Separated from her husband and with a toddler in tow, she wanted to buy a two- or three-bedroom apartment on the Upper East Side. But she had heard about how Manhattan co-op boards have grown increasingly hard-nosed, especially in the fancy Fifth Avenue and Park Avenue co-ops where she was looking. She was worried.

title: In Defense of Browser Traps
description: To the Editor:

title: Women as Candidates
description: To the Editor:

title: A Contrite Ditka Admits The Pressure Got to Him
description: Mike Ditka insists he has mellowed, and yet, on his 60th birthday Monday, he was fined $20,000 by his employer, the New Orleans Saints, for two obscene gestures he made over the weekend to the home fans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ETTINGER, FRANK J.
description: ETTINGER-Frank J. Died October 19, 1999 in Baltimore. In grief we cherish the memory of his wit and wisdom, courage and love. Survived by his wife Irene. Sons Bruce and Peter. Grandchildren Jesse, Kerry, Brady and Claire. Sister Ruth. Services private.

title: Population and Anarchy
description: To the Editor:

title: 80 Minutes, No Miracle
description: Americans seem to have an inexhaustible penchant for collective self-delusion about how easy it is to improve schools. Over and over again, we get excited about structural gimmicks -- longer school days, longer school years and, now, longer classes. Though many teachers are not yet sold on the idea, ''block scheduling'' -- using fewer classes that run as long as 80 minutes each -- is being introduced in an increasing number of American high schools.

title: Garden's Lush New Site Offers Thousands of Plants
description: You shall probably never see a Web site as lovely as a tree, but a new site might come close. The New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx is putting digitized images of 75,000 plant specimens on the Web (www.nybg.org/bsci/hcol/vasc). The plants, like the Macleania pentaptera pictured here, are type specimens -- individual plants used by botanists to identify a species -- and the high-resolution images will allow scientists to examine them for taxonomy. So far, the garden has posted 2,500 images from its collection, which includes specimens from all over the world, some more than 100 years old. BRUCE HEADLAM

title: CITADEL PLANNING TO ACQUIRE MORE RADIO STATIONS
description: Citadel Communications, a radio broadcaster mostly in midsize United States markets, said yesterday that it expected to spend at least $250 million to acquire stations in the next six months. The chairman and chief executive, Lawrence Wilson, said the figure was ''a bare minimum'' of what Citadel, based in Las Vegas, Nev., might spend the next year. Citadel's stock has almost doubled in the last 12 months, closing yesterday at $41.625, up $4.625. At least some of the purchases are likely to come from Clear Channel Communications, which intends to sell as many as 125 stations, worth as much as $4 billion, as part of its proposed purchase of AMFM Inc. Mr. Wilson declined to say which stations the company was likely to buy.

title: Corrections
description: A listing on Oct. 13 with an article about cookbooks that stand the test of time referred incorrectly to ''The Old World Kitchen'' by Elisabeth Luard, first published by Bantam in 1986. It is indeed still available, in a 1998 edition from the Akadine Press.

title: Lady Knights Are In the Spotlight
description: The Rutgers players were scattered along the sideline of the Rutgers Athletic Center in Piscataway, N.J., yesterday, signing stacks of posters. It is a sign of the national attention the program is receiving, but perhaps not as revealing as the preseason poll in one magazine that ranks the Lady Knights as the No. 1 team in the nation.

title: Calvin Griffith, 87, Is Dead; Tight-Fisted Baseball Owner
description: Calvin Griffith, who in his three decades as owner of the Washington Senators and their successor, the Minnesota Twins, personified a lost age when baseball teams were run as tight-spending family businesses, died yesterday at a hospital in Melbourne, Fla. He was 87.

title: Justice Overturns Lawyer's Sentence For Insulting Judge
description: A State Supreme Court justice has overturned a 10-day jail sentence for a Legal Aid lawyer who was accused of making a rude comment to a judge and not apologizing properly.

title: Court in Japan Halts Publication of Dead Author's Letters
description: Reviving the controversy that followed the novelist Yukio Mishima throughout his life, a Tokyo court has banned further publication of a memoir by a writer who says he had a homosexual relationship with him. The court ruled on Monday that the use of Mishima's letters represented copyright infringement.

title: Parties Trade Accusations Over Race and Nominations
description: The two political parties traded angry accusations over race and nominations today after the Democratic leader of the Senate accused Republicans of demonstrating an ''array of anti-minority sentiment'' in recent weeks.

title: New Privacy Rules for Children's Web Sites
description: The Federal Trade Commission today unveiled tough new privacy rules for Web sites for children, detailing how privacy policies should be posted and how companies must comply with a new law that will prohibit them from collecting personal information without parental permission.

title: Bush and Clinton Cross Swords
description: In an exchange that suggested a growing dynamic in the 2000 Presidential race, President Clinton seized the occasion of Elizabeth Dole's departure from the Republican field today to take a swipe at the front-runner, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, and the Bush campaign promptly returned the favor.

title: Off-Duty Police Captain Is Charged in Fatal Accident
description: An off-duty police captain was arrested yesterday and accused of criminally negligent homicide and drunken driving after he drove his unmarked police car onto a closed lane of the Throgs Neck Bridge and struck and killed a construction worker, the police said.

title: Smaller G.O.P. Field Aids Everyone but Bush
description: For Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, it may be too much success -- and too soon.

title: Boeing in Deal to Develop Missiles Overseas
description: The Boeing Company said today that it would join French and British manufacturers to develop a sophisticated air-to-air missile, opening a head-on competition with the Raytheon Company to supply at least $1.65 billion worth of missiles for a new generation of European warplanes.

title: Home for Books Amid the Trees
description: The Parks Department opened its own library yesterday in a building in Central Park where the public can research park topics, check out books and examine art about parks.

title: Top Albany Education Officials Rebut State Claim in New York City School Aid Trial
description: New York State's top education officials dealt a blow to the state's own case in a school financing trial yesterday, testifying that New York City schools needed more money to address the needs of disadvantaged students and especially to help those students meet the new statewide education standards.

title: Mets Gone, Braves' Jordan Only Grudgingly Lets Go
description: Brian Jordan did not play for the Atlanta Braves when they met the Yankees in the 1996 World Series, but he plays for them now. A couple of comments he made early yesterday morning will illustrate for the Yankees the type of player they will encounter in this year's World Series.

title: Career Diplomat Is First Asian to Get Top Job : Japanese Envoy Wins Unesco Director's Post
description: PARIS  A Japanese career diplomat, Koichiro Matsuura, was elected director-general of Unesco on Wednesday, the first Asian to get the top job the United Nations agency created after World War II to promote international cultural cooperation.

title: How to Make A Clean Start
description: Q. How do you delete a program from the Start menu in Windows 95? We have America Online 3.0 and 4.0 on the menu but do not use them anymore since we got AOL 5.0. We tried to right-click on the names, but the Delete option did not appear. Do you have any suggestions?

title: Russians Firmly Reject U.S. Plan to Reopen ABM Treaty
description: Senior Russian officials today strongly rejected an American proposal to renegotiate the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty, raising the stakes for the United States debate over antimissile defenses.

title: In Crowded G.O.P. Field, Dole Was Hobbled by Her Stand on Issues, Not Her Sex
description: Wherever she spoke, Elizabeth Dole unfailingly brought up the trailblazing nature of her candidacy. She often managed to get introduced by a woman in authority and would quip, ''Hmm. A female President . . . Sounds good to me.'' Banners, signs and even the chocolate mousse cake at a recent luncheon for her urged, ''Let's Make History.''

title: Youngster Held on Charge Of Incest With 5-Year-Old
description: The case of an 11-year-old Swiss-American boy charged with aggravated incest has caused an international dispute over the treatment of children in the American justice system.

title: Jack of All Trades, Master of Treasure Hunts
description: AT a table at the Avenue of the Americas flea market, Alan Boss spotted a hefty down payment for his children's college tuition. He paid $3,000 for two engraved silver peace medals, commissioned by President Washington in 1793. Several years later at a Sotheby's auction, a medal identical to one of Mr. Boss's sold for $50,000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, HELEN
description: SHAPIRO-Helen. On October 19, 1999. Beloved widow of Abraham, devoted mother of Leonard and Philip, adored sister of Gertrude Sallen, Ira Sallen & the late Evelyn Tobias & Jessie Cohen Blauner. A source of strength, wisdom, music & unconditional love. Services Sunday, October 24, 1 PM, at Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Flushing, New York.

title: The Keepers Of the Garden's Soul
description: ''COLETTE wanted to be buried in her garden with a sign that said something like, 'Here I am, surrounded by le debris des reves,' '' Frank Cabot said, using the French for ''ruin of dreams.'' Mr. Cabot, the founder of the Garden Conservancy, a group devoted to preserving distinctive American gardens, was musing about the near impossibility of its mission.

title: Flavors Are the Same, but New iMacs Have Some Spice
description: THE bubble-like, blue-and-white iMac was a classic from the day it was born. Apple has now come up with a born-again iMac that is so good it even has a glowing halo built into its new design. There are three new models, ranging in price from $999 to $1,499.

title: Braves' Empty Victory
description: To the Editor:

title: A Professor Lands in Hot Water When His Modem Calls Police
description: Yigal H. Ehrlich, a 56-year-old professor in Staten Island, has experienced something of an Internet emergency: When installing MCI Worldcom Internet software recently, his computer mistakenly dialed 911.

title: When Fears of Bioterrorism Grow
description: To the Editor:

title: Unesco's New Director Is Envoy From Japan, Its Biggest Donor
description: The Unesco executive board today chose Japan's Ambassador to France, Koichiro Matsuura, as director general of the organization. Mr. Matsuura's nomination for a six-year term is expected to be confirmed by 186-nation general conference of Unesco when it meets here on Nov. 12.

title: FERROFLUIDICS AGREES TO TAKEOVER BY JAPANESE
description: The Ferrofluidics Corporation, a maker of magnetic fluids, agreed yesterday to be acquired by Ferrotec of Tokyo for about $40.4 million, forming a company with a broader range of products. Ferrotec will pay $6.50 a share for Ferrofluidics, based in Nashua, N.H. Ferrofluidics's magnetic-fluid products are mainly used by semiconductor-equipment makers. It had sales of $23.1 million in the year ended June 27. Shares in Ferrofluidics rose $2.03125, or 52 percent, to $5.96875. Ferrotec, with sales of about $40 million, makes products based on similar technology used in hard-disk drives, as well as temperature-control devices used in semiconductor components. No jobs are expected to be eliminated at Ferrofluidics.

title: Iranian Jews' Arrest
description: To the Editor:

title: Davis Is Taking Aim at Ring No. 3
description: Chili Davis will not talk anymore about his plans for next spring, whether he will be back for another baseball season or whether this run through the World Series will be the final one of career.

title: Asian Stock Issues Find Halting Demand
description: With Asia's stock markets shaking off two years of near-paralysis, it is no surprise that Asian companies are rushing to raise billions of dollars. The surprise is how hard they are finding the job.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHEELER, KENNETH
description: WHEELER-Kenneth. Educator. On October 18, 1999. Visitation Thursday 3-8PM. Services Friday at 10 AM, at Woodward Funeral Home, 1 Troy Avenue, Brooklyn, New York. Interment Calverton National Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIDDELL, DONALD MACY
description: LIDDELL-Donald Macy. The Order of Colonial Lords of Manors in America extends its deepest sympathy to the family of Donald Macy Liddell, our past President, amazing financial advisor and dear friend. Timothy Field Beard, President Joseph Kerr Pistell, Secretary

title: Bulk Buying Adds the Suspense of Auctions
description: FOR me, the concept of bulk buying has always conjured up images of cold warehouses filled with shoppers wrestling with mammoth containers of mayonnaise or struggling toward their cars under the weight of a pallet of canned green beans.

title: Low on Cash, Dole Withdraws From G.O.P. Race
description: Elizabeth Dole, the first woman to be taken seriously as a candidate for her party's Presidential nomination, dropped out of the race today, saying she could not raise enough cash to compete with the fortune raised by one Republican rival and inherited by another.

title: Valentine Has Room For Rogers Next Year
description: Kenny Rogers stuck his hand through the circle of reporters around John Olerud in the early hours of yesterday morning and wished his teammate farewell. At least for now.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIONNI, LEO
description: LIONNI-Leo. On behalf of all graphic designers, the American Institute of Graphic Arts laments the loss of Leo Lionni, who influenced our visual landscape for almost four generations. Leo was a committed teacher, author, critic, editor, painter, sculptor, printmaker, designer, cartoonist and illustrator. Our AIGA medalist for 1984, Leo for us was always a designer, an inspiration and a delight.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: MIDDLE EAST

title: School Official Defends Alternative to an Exam
description: A top New York City Board of Education official yesterday joined students, parents and educators representing 35 alternative high schools in defending the use of elaborate end-of-the-year portfolios as alternatives to the new English Regents examination.

title: Clinton to See Barak and Arafat in Effort to Speed Peace Moves
description: President Clinton will use a visit to Norway early next month to give ''added momentum'' to the Middle East peace effort and will meet there together with Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel and the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, Administration officials said today.

description: To the Editor:

title: A More Subdued Tyson Getting Ready to Return
description: The promoter Dan Goossen introduced Mike Tyson this afternoon at a news conference for his heavyweight bout Saturday against Orlin Norris at the MGM Grand, and everyone waited and waited and waited some more.

title: Luddites at the Gas Pump
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRANDSTETTER, ROBERT DANIEL, M.D.
description: BRANDSTETTER-Robert Daniel, M.D., died at Sound Shore Medical Center of Westchester on October 18 after a long illness. He was the beloved husband of Gwyn and cherished son of Christian Brandstetter. He deeply loved his children, William, Daniel, Jennifer, Karen, Elizabeth and Kathleyn. His grandchildren, Ashley and Christian, infused his life with joy. Robert Brandstetter was born in the Bronx on February 27, 1947, the youngest son of Christian and the late Muriel Brandstetter. He graduated from DeWitt Clinton High School and served as a Hospital Corpsman in the United States Navy. Following his honorable discharge, he was a Pulmonary Technician and later Supervisor of the Pulmonary Laboratory at Morrisania Hospital in the Bronx for five years. He received his B.A. degree, Magna Cum Laude, from Herbert H. Lehman College and was awarded his M.D. degree from the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in 1977. Dr. Brandstetter completed his internship and residency at New York HospitalCornell University Medical Center and a clinical and research fellowship in pulmonary medicine at Massachusetts General HospitalHarvard Medical School, where he received the 1981 Fellowship Teaching Award. Following completion of his training, Dr. Brandstetter joined the staff of the former New Rochelle Hospital Medical Center (now Sound Shore Medical Center of Westchester) in 1982 as Acting Chief of Pulmonary Medicine. Throughout his nearly two decades of service to Sound Shore Medical Center, he held increasingly responsible positions, including Chief of Critical Care Medicine, Acting Director of Medicine, Associate Director of Medicine and Director of Medical Education. He was the visionary who forged Sound Shore Medical Center's partnership with the Mercy College Graduate Program in Acupuncture and Oriental Medicine and offered complementary medicine practitioners the opportunity to train in a hospital setting. As coordinator of the Department of Medicine's weekly Grand Rounds lecture series, Dr. Brandstetter brought Nobe Laureates, foreign diplomats and internationally renowned speakers to Sound Shore Medical Center. A member of Phi Beta Kappa, Dr. Brandstetter was Board Certified in Internal Medicine, Critical Care Medicine and Pulmonary Medicine. He received numerous awards for his extraordinary work, including the Dr. William C. Schraft Memorial Teaching Award, the Medical Center's Attending Teaching Award and the Medal For Outstanding Contribution to Science and Letters from Mercy College. He served on the Editorial Boards of Chest, Heart and Lung, the Journal of Intensive Care Medicine, Archives of Internal Medicine, and was the author of two books. He published over 300 papers in medical journals throughout the United States and abroad. In addition to his wife, Gwyn, his father, children and grandchildren, Dr. Brandstetter is survived by his sisters Muriel Del Conte and Beverly Montouri, loving aunts, uncles, cousins, nieces and nephews, the thousands of patients he treated and his extended family at Sound Shore Medical Center. He is predeceased by his mother, Muriel and older brother, Christy. All of the people who knew and loved him will remember that he embraced life, with zeal and passion; he cherished every moment of life. Visiting hours are from 2-4 PM and 7-9 PM on Wednesday and Thursday at Lloyd Maxcy Funeral Home, 16 SheaPlace in New Rochelle. The Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Friday at 10:30 AM at St. Gabriel's Church in New Rochelle. A reception to celebrate his life and honor his memory will be held in the Goldstein Auditorium at SoundShore Medical Center immediately following the funeral Mass. In lieu of flowers, friends may donate to the Robert Daniel Brandstetter Memorial Scholarship Fund at Sound Shore Medical Center of Westchester.

title: Computers Are the Balanchine Behind Those Dancing Fountains
description: PEOPLE standing in front of the Bellagio casino here appeared to forget about winning a jackpot as soon as the fountain in the resort's lake began dancing to Lionel Richie's song, ''All Night Long.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SULLIVAN, MARIE MCNAMEE (MOLLY)
description: SULLIVAN - Marie McNamee (Molly) on October 20, 1999. Beloved sister of Raymond P. Sullivan, Katherine S. Meehan and the late John McNamee Sullivan and William Mayo Sullivan. Devoted aunt of twelve nieces and nephews. Mass of Christian burial at St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Ave. and 66th St., Friday Oct. 22nd at 10AM. Interment at Calvary Cemetery.

title: No Slouching, Please, Toward a Well-Tailored Millennium
description: Once upon a time, everybody wanted to be in pictures. Now, every able-bodied celebrity or demi-celebrity wants to be in the furniture business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CALAJO, RITA
description: CALAJO-Rita. On October 19, 1999. Beloved sister of Angela and Olga. Also survived by two loving nephews. Mass of Christian Burial Friday, 10:30 AM at St. John the Evangelist RC Church, 55th St. and 1st Ave., NYC. For further information contact Krtil Funeral Home, 212-744-3084.

title: More Words to Savor
description: To the Editor:

title: BIG WHOLESALE GROCERY OPERATION TO ELIMINATE JOBS
description: The Fleming Companies, one of the biggest United States wholesale grocery operations, plans to cut 700 jobs, or almost 2 percent of its work force, to cut costs. Fleming, which has about 39,000 employees, said it would make the cuts the next 18 months as it centralizes its corporate functions in two national centers, in Dallas and Oklahoma City. The job cuts follow Fleming's announcement in January that it would cut 220 jobs, or 12 percent of its corporate staff, to streamline its business and improve profit margins. In December the company said it would take a $627 million charge to restructure. The shares of Fleming, based in Oklahoma City, rose $1.75, to $11.25. Fleming supplies about 3,000 supermarkets in 41 states and owns about 250 stores.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JENSEN, JIM
description: JENSEN-Jim. The Alcoholism Council of New York regrets the passing of Jim Jensen and remembers, with appreciation, his years of service on our Board of Directors.

title: MEXICO TV POWER STRUGGLE
description: In a management showdown over control of Grupo Televisa S.A., Mexico's biggest broadcast conglomerate, the chairman, Emilio Azcarraga Jean, forced his cousin Alejandro Burillo Azcarraga to resign from all executive posts. Mr. Burillo will continue as vice president of the board of Grupo Televisa and will retain his 25.1 percent stake in Grupo Televicentro S.A., the holding company that controls the television empire. Televisa officials said Mr. Burillo's departure would give Mr. Azcarraga more freedom to cut costs at the broadcaster. They said his cousin disagreed with that strategy.

title: A Dangerous Education Bill
description: The Republican Party is being pulled in contradictory directions on the question of how to close the school performance gap between affluent white children and poor minority children. Progressive Republican reformers have seen that school districts tend to ignore the poorest, least prepared students unless pressured from above. But the Republican leadership in Congress views federal pressure as evil, even when it is applied on behalf of the nation's most vulnerable children.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBHABER, BERNARD
description: LIEBHABER-Bernard, 83, Great Neck, New York, October 19,1999. Loving and devoted husband to Ruth (Feinberg) Liebhaber; loving, kind provider and role model to sons Stephen, Lou and Ruven, daughters-in-law Nancy, Barbara and Gail; adoring grandfather to Sarah, Aaron, David and Jordan; loyal brother to Martha Ring and Dr. Harvey Liebhaber, and dear friend to so many. We will miss you deeply but our fond memories of you will live on in our hearts. Funeral services 11:00 A.M., Thursday, October 21, 1999 at Temple Emanuel, Hicks Lane, Great Neck, New York. Information: Riverside Nassau North Chapel, 516-487-9600

title: Minimalism Still Finds Shelter in the West
description: Los Angeles design ranges from the neo-Baroque to neo-Pop, but there is still a taste for the minimalism and economy of materials that characterize prewar and postwar Modernist architecture.

title: History on Their Side, Champs Calmly Wait
description: Yesterday was a casual day at Yankee Stadium. Only about a dozen players took part in a voluntary, indoor workout. David Cone bypassed throwing baseballs to do some packing for the off season, and Joe Torre wore blue jeans during a relaxing session with the smallest assemblage of reporters he had seen in three weeks.

title: Winters Gets Praise and Humor Prize
description: Jonathan Winters was awarded the Mark Twain Prize for humor by the Kennedy Center Center for the Performing Arts tonight, getting praise from contemporaries like Steve Allen and Sid Caesar as well as from younger proteges, including Bonnie Hunt and Robin Williams, who starred with him in television situation comedies.

title: Mannesmann Agrees to Buy Orange for $33 Billion
description: Mannesmann A.G., Germany's biggest mobile phone company, announced early today that it had agreed to buy the cellular operator Orange P.L.C. of Britain for $:19.8 billion, or $33 billion, in stock and cash, gaining a base in Europe's third-largest phone market.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: From the Land of the Bauhaus, A Look at the California House
description: The German publisher Taschen recently turned John Lautner's Chemosphere House in Los Angeles into a satellite office. So it's apt that Taschen's new book is ''California Interiors'' ($39.99), about homes from Sonoma to San Diego Counties. Written by Diane Dorrans Saeks and edited by Angelika Taschen, the wife of the company's founder, Benedikt Taschen, it has more than 40 interiors and traces the experimental pulse, from hip homes by the designer Stephen Chin to classics like the Storer House to Mickey Muennig's organic Big Sur architecture.

title: In Third World, Unwanted Fertility
description: To the Editor:

title: Flyers Prove Much Hungrier Than Rangers
description: The supposedly much-improved Rangers' offense has, in fact, been worse than it was last season when a punchless Ranger team could at least score on the power play.

title: Opportunity Went Unanswered
description: Bobby Valentine, master of all managerial minds, had one ploy left in his duffel bag of tricks. It was the 11th inning of Game 6 of the playoff series with Atlanta and the Braves had runners at first and third with one out. As Brian Jordan took his bat to the plate, the Mets' manager went to the mound.

title: U.S. Judge Refuses to Halt Suit Seeking to Disband New York City's Street Crime Unit
description: In a decision that could lead to a Federal trial over the stop-and-frisk practices of the New York Police Department, a Federal judge refused yesterday to dismiss a lawsuit seeking abolition of the city's elite Street Crime Unit and other changes in police conduct.

title: Corrections
description: The State of the Art column in Circuits last Thursday, about the Intel Play QX3 Computer Microscope, misstated its operating-system requirement. The microscope works only with Windows 98, not with other versions of Windows.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: COLUMBIA ENERGY GROUP, Herndon, Va., will form a joint venture with Metromedia Energy of Eatontown, N.J., to provide energy services to homes and businesses.

title: Sports of The Times; A FAREWELL TO A SUBWAY SERIES
description: Cancel the limo. Don't bother upgrading the funds in your EZ-Pass account. Never mind laying in extra Metrocards.

title: Furor in Japan as Military Official Advocates Nuclear Weapons
description: A political furor erupted today over the proposal by a senior Defense Ministry official that Japan abandon one of its most hallowed principles: its longtime renunciation of nuclear weapons. As a result, the official was forced to resign.

title: Queens Woman Is Arrested in Scalding of Superintendent's Baby
description: A 40-year-old Queens woman who routinely screamed at neighbors and banged on their doors in the dead of night was arrested yesterday after she doused the building superintendent's baby with a cup of scalding water, burning the boy's genital area, the police said.

title: Cooper in German Deal
description: Cooper Industries, a Houston-based maker of electrical and lighting fixtures, agreed this week to buy a unit of Weidmuller G.m.b.H. of Germany that makes boxes for electrical switches and connectors. Cooper said it was buying the electrical enclosures business of the Weidmuller UK Group, a unit of closely held Weidmuller. Terms were not disclosed. The business had sales of about $15 million last year.

title: Sharpton Is Unlikely Ally of Klan in Suit Against City on Rally
description: The Amsterdam News, the largest black newspaper in New York City, and the Rev. Al Sharpton said yesterday that they had each filed legal papers supporting the right of a Ku Klux Klan group to demonstrate this Saturday in lower Manhattan.

title: Jury to Deliberate in Garage Magnate's Murder-for-Hire Trial
description: Prosecutors devoted their closing argument yesterday to painting an eccentric developer and parking garage magnate as a scheming, obsessed man so infuriated with his business partner that he hired a hit man to have him killed. Defense lawyers used their final words to the jury to portray him as the innocent victim of a shake-down by his own employees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCH, DAVID, PHD.
description: HIRSCH-David, PhD. 69, of Providence, R.I. on October 19, 1999. Beloved husband of Roslyn, nee Zipper. Devoted father of Joseph Hirsch and Helene Wingens. Dear brother of Rosalyn Suchow. Loving grandfather of 2 grandchildren. Services will be held at Jewish Memorial Chapel, 841 Allwood Rd, Clifton, N.J. today at 1:00 p.m.

title: Outback and Agency End Association
description: Outback Steakhouse and the New York office of TBWA/Chiat/Day have parted ways. The agency had handled the restaurant chain's account since April 1998. Spending was estimated at $22.8 million by Competitive Media Reporting.

title: Holbrooke's Job at U.N. Begins on Capitol Hill
description: Since his confirmation as chief delegate to the United Nations, Richard C. Holbrooke has turned himself from high-flying diplomat to part-time lobbyist, walking the halls of Congress and buttonholing members on the elevator, on the Capitol subway, at their doors -- anywhere he can find them.

title: James Abbe, Photographer and Art Dealer, 87
