description: James Abbe, a photographer who became an American folk art expert and dealer, died on Oct. 7 at his home in Brookville, N.Y. He was 87.

title: Recruit Commits
description: Taliek Brown, a 17-year-old point guard from St. John's Prep in Queens, said yesterday that he had verbally committed to attend the University of Connecticut in September. If the 6-foot-1-inch Brown, who averaged 27 points and 6 assists last season, signs a letter of intent with the defending national champion Huskies, he may replace Khalid El-Amin at point guard. El-Amin, a junior, is expected to declare for the National Basketball Association draft after this season. JACK CAVANAUGH

title: Castle First, Prince Later: Marketing to Ms.
description: THE words ring with romantic promise: ''Evenings in front of the fireplace, and a morning jog along secluded pathways with familiar footsteps at my side. . . .''

title: Facing Jail, Vichy Aide Says He'll Go Into Exile
description: With only hours to go before he was to spend his first night in jail, Maurice Papon, the 89-year-old career civil servant convicted last year of complicity in Nazi war crimes, said today that he would flee the country rather than surrender.

title: CRANE TO CREATE A SEPARATE BUSINESS
description: The Crane Company said yesterday that it would spin off its Huttig Building Products subsidiary to shareholders and then acquire the Rugby USA building-products business of Rugby Group of Britain. The two units will be combined to create a business with 74 distribution centers and annual sales of $1.4 billion. Crane's shareholders will own 68 percent of the new business; Rugby shareholders will own 32 percent. Rugby had revenue of $1.5 billion in 1998. Crane, based in Stamford, Conn., makes engineered industrial products and distributes doors and windows. Huttig and Rugby USA distribute building products used in home construction and remodeling. Crane's stock slipped 43.75 cents yesterday, to $21.25.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: Manhattan

title: Corrections
description: A credit on Tuesday with a photograph of Gwen Ifill, a correspondent on ''The Newshour With Jim Lehrer'' on PBS, misstated the photographer's surname. He is Peter Howard, not Peter Brown.

title: Pettitte Feels for His Beaten Friend Rogers
description: Kenny Rogers is one of Andy Pettitte's closest friend, so it was only natural for him to try to console him early yesterday after the Braves eliminated the Mets. ''I called him and left a message on his voice mail,'' Pettitte said. ''I told him I'd call him in a couple of days. I'm sure he doesn't want to talk now.

title: Assignments Traded On 2 Unilever Brands
description: The United States home and personal care unit of Unilever said yesterday that it would switch the accounts of two large detergent brands between two roster agencies.

title: INDONESIA CHOOSES AN ISLAMIC CLERIC AS NEW PRESIDENT
description: In the first democratic transfer of power in its history, Indonesia chose a new President today, Abdurrahman Wahid, a respected Muslim leader whose message is tolerance, inclusion and self-respect.

title: Lucas Hopes to Miss Only One Game
description: Ray Lucas, whose lifelong dream to be a starting National Football League quarterback lasted 3 hours 1 minute before a game-ending sack resulted in a sprained ankle, was back, bubbling and speaking of a quick return to the Jets' lineup today.

title: Coolly Expressive, Floating Soft Phrases
description: Dame Kiri Te Kanawa, soprano

title: NORTHGATE EXPLORATION TO ACQUIRE A ROYAL OAK MINE
description: Northgate Exploration said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Kemess gold and copper mine in northern British Columbia for $180 million. Kemess is one of three mines belonging to Royal Oak Mines, an insolvent company based in Kirkland, Wash., with other operations in Ontario and the Northwest Territories. The transaction is expected to close by the end of the year, according to Northgate, a Toronto mining investment company. Northgate was delisted from the New York Stock Exchange because of a failure to meet listing requirements and now trades for less than $1 on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Prospects for Bank Law Are Fading in Political Fight

title: Darkly Mythic World Arrives From Japan; Master of Animation Tries Hollywood
description: Admirers of Japanese animation, including many of the leading figures in the American animation community, get a certain catch in their voices when they mention the name Hayao Miyazaki, as though describing someone not quite human, like one of the ghostly forest spirits who populate his work.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINOGRAD, ROSLYN (HERZ)
description: WINOGRAD-Roslyn (Herz). October 18, 1999. Residence: Providence, RI, formerly of New Rochelle, NY. Wife of the late Max Winograd. Mother of Lois Seegal of Pikesville, MD and Carol Cederbaum of Westport, CT. Sister of Beryl Black of Warwick, MA and Sarasota, FL and the late Jeanne Herz. Grandmother of Mark and Deborah Cederbaum. Funeral services were held Wednesday at Temple Beth El, Providence, RI. Services by the Max Sugarman Memorial Chapel, Providence, RI

title: A Site for School Support
description: To the Editor:

title: Albright Vows To Increase Aid to Nigeria
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright praised the five-month-old democratic Government of Nigeria today and pledged more financial support for the nation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, HAROLD
description: KAUFMAN-Harold. On October 20, 1999, in Lake Worth, FL. The world is a lesser place today. Tiger passed away peacefully surrounded by his family. Survived by his beloved wife and best friend, Jean; his loving children, Carol Haberman, Barbara and Kenneth Silver, and Stephen and Ronni Kaufman; his adored grandchildren, Lisa, Michael, Margo, Eric, Greg, Adam, Joshua and Jessica; his brother, Bernard, and his wife Harriet; his sister, Helene Gilinsky, his sister-in-law, Rhoda Klein & his wonderful cousin, Dr. Arnold Wechsler. Services 11:15AM on Friday, October 22, Beth Israel Memorial Chapel, Delray Beach, FL.

title: Chase Posts Better-Than-Expected Earnings in 3d Quarter
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation, the nation's third-largest bank, said yesterday that its third-quarter earnings were 67 percent higher than last year -- a report that was better than expected and came less than two weeks after the company said it was moving thousands of jobs out of Manhattan to save money.

title: The Klan's Equal Right
description: To the Editor:

title: Full-Service Brokerage Firms Seek Foothold on Line
description: Morgan Stanley Dean Witter calls it ''ichoice.'' Merrill Lynch named its offering ''unlimited advantage.'' But the message from America's two biggest traditional brokerage firms is the same: Clients can trade stocks on line for cut-rate prices and keep their broker, too.

title: An Arrested Teacher Apparently Kills Self
description: A high school teacher and basketball coach in Garfield, N.J., who had just been accused of sexually abusing a female student apparently killed himself yesterday by stepping in front of a train, the authorities said.

title: A Park and Sculpture Will Honor Japanese-Americans
description: Hundreds of families were crowded together in despair in the desert heat of an Arizona internment camp in 1942 when Eleanor Roosevelt suddenly appeared one day pleading with them not to lose faith in American democracy.

title: Accounts
description: * Dealtime.com, Stamford, Conn., a Web-based comparison shopping service, to Margeotes/Fertitta & Partners, New York, part of the MDC Communications Corp., to handle its first account. Billings were estimated at $25 million.

title: HICKS, MUSE IN $67.8 MILLION DEAL IN MEXICO
description: Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst, a Dallas buyout firm, said yesterday that it would buy one-third of Grupo Minsa, a large Mexican corn flour maker, for $67.8 million from the controlling shareholder, Promotora Empresarial del Occidente. The transaction gives Hicks, Muse a share in the growing United States and Mexican tortilla industry, while Promotora Empresarial gets cash it needs to complete its delayed purchase of Minsa's warehouse subsidiary. Separately, Hicks, Muse will also buy stakes in other Promotora Empresarial subsidiaries for an undisclosed amount.

title: Metro Business; Developer Is Sued By Former Deputy
description: The developer of New York's Metropolitan Tower and Riverterrace, Harry Macklowe, has been sued by his former second in command, Warren Cole, who asserts that Mr. Macklowe tried to coerce him into accepting a small fraction of what he says he is owed.

title: With a Stone-Mate, The Puzzles Begin
description: THE STONE is a brilliant concept, badly executed. The idea is to sell physical objects that unlock a virtual world. The Web space is a series of puzzles, and the stone functions as an entry key.

title: A developer promotes its malls as destinations for fun, adventures and maybe a few purchases.
description: THE commercial depicts a suburban dad greasing a pig, then setting him free in the living room for a fun, family chase.

title: As Willful As Ever And Puffing On a Cigar
description: Something different and outlandish, at least, has popped up at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's high-minded Next Wave Festival: the Lyons Opera Ballet's production of ''Carmen,'' in a dance treatment by the experimental Swedish choreographer Mats Ek.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: KMART CORP., Troy, Mich., named Joseph Osbourn chief information officer and senior vice president, succeeding Donald Norman, who resigned. Mr. Osbourn had been vice president for information services at Walt Disney World in Orlando, Fla.

title: Appeals Court Rejects Damages Against ABC in Food Lion Case
description: A divided Federal appeals court yesterday threw out all but $2 of the damages that a jury had ordered ABC News to pay to the Food Lion supermarket chain after it reported that the grocery chain sold beef and other food that was unsanitary.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Mrs. Dole Departs
description: In the end, not even her brave stand on gun control, her swarm of sorority sisters or her winning ways with large crowds could save Elizabeth Dole's campaign for the Republican presidential nomination. In the end, there simply was not enough money. As she explained yesterday in her graceful departure from the race, the big bucks were elsewhere. Gov. George W. Bush of Texas has his $60 million campaign bankroll, and the publishing millionaire Steve Forbes has the family fortune. At the present rate, their cash advantage going into the primary season next year would be 80 to 1, Mrs. Dole figured. ''Perhaps I could handle 2-to-1 or even 10-to-1, but not 80-to-1,'' she told friends, supporters and the largest collection of television cameras she had seen since she launched her campaign nine months earlier.

title: Golfing by Himself
description: To the Editor:

title: DAEWOO IN OUTSOURCING TALKS
description: A South Korean auto maker, the Daewoo Motor Company, is negotiating a potential outsourcing agreement under which the Hyundai Motor Company would supply Daewoo Motor with engines for its popular minicar Matiz, a Daewoo Motor spokesman said. Daewoo Motor is aiming for Matiz sales of around 500,000 units next year, but its own engine factories have a maximum annual manufacturing capacity of only 300,000 units, the spokesman said. Daewoo Motor has also been in talks with the Kia Motors Corporation about a possible Matiz engine-supply arrangement, the Daewoo spokesman said.

title: Education Board Votes Raises For School System's Managers
description: The New York City Board of Education voted yesterday to grant raises to up to 480 managerial employees, including Chancellor Rudy Crew's deputies and the 32 community school district superintendents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BREININ, JANICE
description: BREININ-Janice. On October 20, 1999. Beloved wife of Daniel. Loving mother of Barbara Charles. Cherished grandmother of Lauren. Dear sister of Rita Rosenbloom. Services Friday. 11:30am at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHORE, SANFORD HALPERN
description: SHORE-Sanford Halpern. Age 97, died on October 20, 1999. Beloved husband of Eleanor Goodman Shore. Married for 68 years. Longtime resident of Larchmont, then New Rochelle. Loving father of Vivian Zelvin, Alfred, Richard and Douglas Shore. Cherished grandfather of Lynn, Michael and Diana Zelvin (Harris); Robert, Adam, Allison, David, Jaime and Jonathan Shore. Great-grandfather of Zachary Shore. Funeral will be held at George T. Davis Funeral Home,14 LeCount PL. New Rochelle, NY, Friday, October 22 at 11:30 AM. Burial at Mt. Hope Cemetery.

title: Sniping Over Budget Resumes in Congress
description: After a conciliatory meeting at the White House on Tuesday night, Republicans and Democrats in Congress reverted to form today, sniping at each other over the budget and attending more to political positioning than to bridging their differences.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARMENTER, CHARLES ROSS
description: PARMENTER-Charles Ross. In his 88th year, on October 18, 1999. Beloved uncle of Nina Visart of Pasadena, CA; Sandra Campbell of Toronto, Canada; and John Radcliff of British Columbia. Also survived by eight grandnieces and grandnephews. Ross was Music Editor of The New York Times from 1955-1964, having joined The Times in 1934. Also, he was author of 11 books and several unpublished manuscripts. In his later years, he became an acknowledged expert in the interpretation of early Mexican colonial pictorial manuscripts called lienzos. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Memorial service Saturday, October 23, 1999, at 2PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: From Interact, a New Game Pad That Shakes, Rattles and Rolls
description: Video-game veterans have long known that those knobby ''analog'' controllers offer better control than the older up-down-left-right button controllers. Now PC gamers can have tighter control over their virtual battles with Interact's Hammerhead FX game pad (www.interact-acc.com), which sells for $39.99.The smoothly sculpted device houses tiny vibrating motors that offer force-feedback shakes, rattles, and rolls in response to on-screen blasts and bang-ups. JOE HUTSKO

title: Airlines Continue to Report Weak Quarterly Profits
description: The nation's airlines continued to report weakened third-quarter earnings yesterday as rising fuel prices, the growing number of airplane seats and bad weather helped to reduce profits from last year's record highs.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Crowning Glory

title: U.P.S. Says It Could Raise $4.6 Billion in Stock Sale
description: United Parcel Service said yesterday that it could raise as much as $4.6 billion when it sells its shares to investors for the first time in its 92-year history later this year, making its initial public offering perhaps the biggest ever.

title: Popular Russian Prime Minister Tours Chechnya Front
description: With his popularity ratings soaring, Russian Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin today hopped a 10-minute ride aboard a Sukhoi-25 fighter plane on a one-day tour of the war zone along the border of rebellious Chechnya.

title: Trade Deficit Narrowed in August as Exports Grew
description: Reflecting some long-awaited gains from economic recovery abroad, the huge American trade deficit narrowed in August for the first time in four months as exports rose faster than imports.

title: MAN IN THE NEWS -- Abdurrahman Wahid; Revered, Criticized by Some, and Often Prankish
description: The revealing title of a biography of Indonesia's new President, published just last week, is ''Gus Dur: Who Are You?'' It is a question many people, using his common nickname, ask about President Abdurrahman Wahid. Indeed, the better people know him, the more often they ask it.

title: If Museum Is Evicted, Art's Fate Is Uncertain
description: The target of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's public fire in his battle against the Brooklyn Museum of Art has been the museum's trustees, whom the Mayor says he wants to oust as irresponsible and insensitive for staging an exhibition he considers offensive.

title: Judge Bars Use of Secret Data to Hold Immigrant
description: A Federal District judge ruled today that the use of secret evidence of alleged terrorist connections to detain immigrants violated the due-process protections of the Constitution.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPER, FAY
description: COOPER-Fay. Of Boca Raton, FL and South Orange, NJ. On October 19, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Donald J. Devoted mother of Arlene Cooper and Richard Cooper. Loving grandmother of Jonathan, Ariane and Gregory Brainin. Services Thursday, October 21, 1PM at Menorah Chapels, Union, New Jersey. For further information call 908 964-1500. Contributions in her memory to The Boca Raton Museum of Art, 801 W. Palmetto Park Rd, Boca Raton FL 33486, UJA, or charity of your choice.

title: Cardinal Home After Treatment for Clot
description: John Cardinal O'Connor was released from the hospital yesterday after being treated for a blood clot in his left leg. He had gone to the hospital to be examined after completing radiation therapy for a brain tumor. Cardinal O'Connor, 79, left Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center around 2:30 P.M. and returned to work at his residence at Madison Avenue and 51st Street, said Joseph Zwilling, director of communications for the Archdiocese of New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUSK, ELLEN
description: LUSK-Ellen. We deeply mourn the passing of our beloved friend and mentor. Her warm heart and wise counsel continue to inspire us. Our love forever, Emily and Andy Meisler

title: Gay Books Are Facing The Downside Of Acceptance
description: The great vexation for lesbians and gay men in book publishing has been that their assimilation into that world in particular and into the cultural life in general has made it more difficult for their books to get published and be sold, rather than easier. That is because, in part, the first gay literature to come to public attention was considered notorious no matter its quality, and its celebrity appealed to a certain dark stealth when, for instance, one purchased Radclyffe Hall's landmark novel ''The Well of Loneliness.'' But to make it to the book racks now, gay writing must compete with the mainstream work that, at least in some instances, it has become. Acceptance, as every minority group has found, has its difficulties.

title: AOL Exceeds Expectations; Agrees to Invest In a PC Maker
description: Expanding its growing domain into the PC market, America Online punctuated a stronger-than-expected earnings report yesterday by announcing that it would invest $800 million in Gateway Inc., taking a 5 percent stake in the maker of consumer computers.

title: Crisis in Colombia as Civil Strife Uproots Peasants
description: For Jose Moreno, his family of six and his neighbors, life as refugees began suddenly in mid-July with the arrival of a group of armed men at their small village north of here.

title: A Crewman Is Badly Hurt On the Seas
description: Fierce winds today sent a Japanese crewman to the hospital with injuries thought to be severe, but three series leaders mastered the conditions to remain undefeated in the challenger races leading to the America's Cup finals.

title: 3 Firms to Join Redibook Trading Network
description: The electronic trading network founded by the trading giant Spear, Leeds & Kellogg plans to add three partners to the five it already has.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAZAR, ROSA
description: LAZAR-Rosa. Age 86. Passed away peacefully on October 19, 1999 at her home. Beloved wife of Arthur Lazar for what would be 58 years on this November 9. Loving mother and mother-in-law of Matti and David Schlang and the late Laurence Lazar. Cherished grandmother of Lisa and Julie Schlang. Loving sister of Blanche Blank and the late Harold and Morton Davis. Beloved sister-in-law, aunt and great aunt. Rosa was a kind, generous person who brought joy to everyone around her. She will be greatly missed by all whose lives she touched. A service will be held today at 11AM at Mount Carmel Cemetery, Glendale NY.

title: The Public Nixon
description: To the Editor:

title: For Getting Dressed Without the Glare
description: Barbara Barry, the Los Angeles taste maker, has designed For Him (right) and For Her dressing tables, basins and accessories modeled on the dressing rooms of the affluent, circa 1940, as part of the Barbara Barry Collection. ''People are looking for the luxury of refinement rather than over-the-top 80's gold,'' said Chris Lohman, the general manager of Kallista, a Wisconsin manufacturer that is producing the new line. It ranges from Baccarat glass drawstring pulls to toilet seats and faucets in finishes like nickel, chrome, brass and sterling silver. A two-piece toilet lists for $875; For Her dressing table, $6,082; For Him dresser, $4,890. The entire collection is at the French Designer Showhouse, 34 East 69th Street, through Nov. 14; admission $20.

title: A Drought, a Flood And High Water Bills, Too; Service Complaints and Land Feuds Plague New Jersey's Biggest Water Company
description: Long before the summer's drought stopped them from watering their lawns, long before Tropical Storm Floyd's torrents overwhelmed a treatment plant and forced them to boil their water, many customers of United Water Resources were already frustrated.

title: Musicians' Garden Of Verses
description: Stefon Harris Quartet

title: Finder's Fees Went to Allies Of Rowland
description: Two of Gov. John G. Rowland's closest advisers were among those who were paid finder's fees by firms that got investments of state pension money, Connecticut officials announced today.

title: Elizabeth Dole Bows Out of Race
description: WASHINGTON  In a development that underscored the large lead held by George W. Bush in the Republican presidential race, and might widen it, a prominent rival, Elizabeth Dole, announced Wednesday that she lacked the funds to continue her pursuit of the nomination.

title: Limit Campaign Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Sea Monster Surfaces on the Net
description: This month was a historic one for scientists and armchair daredevils who like their calamari 25 feet long and marinated in ethanol. The American Museum of Natural History has unveiled in its Hall of Biodiversity, the first giant squid available for public viewing in New York City. You can read about it at www.amnh.org, by clicking on the squid icon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUSHTON, PAULA
description: RUSHTON-Paula. The Board of Trustees of the Reece School express their heartfelt sympathy to fellow board member Wyatt Rushton on the death of his beloved mother Paula Rushton. We extend our condolences to the entire Rushton family.

title: Douglas Returns To Play for Nets
description: Sherman Douglas, a catalyst for the Nets during the 1997-98 season and one of the players sorely missed during last season's tailspin, has rejoined the team as a backup point guard.

title: Giving Up Trump Tricks To Make the Game Anyway
description: The fourth annual China Cup, which was contested last week in Shenzhen, China, was sought by invited world-class players from three continents. Top honors went to a Scandinavian team: Jens Auken, Dennis Koch Palmund, Soren Christiansen and Morten Andersen, all of Denmark, and Magnus Lindkvist and Peter Fredin, both of Sweden. A North American team consisting of Fred Gitelman, Eric Kokish, George Mittelman, Ralph Katz and George Jacobs snatched second place from the Chinese team in the final round.

title: In America; Bradley's Poverty Push
description: Bill Bradley, eschewing small themes in favor of a grander vision of America, will argue today, at a speech in Brooklyn, that the United States has a moral obligation to do what it can to lift as many children as possible from the punishing confines of poverty.

title: The Shadows Of the Past Throw Sparks
description: Postmodernism may have spawned a return to stringent modernism, but a competing trend is Baroque-style decorativeness, as in Patrice Butler's ornate chandeliers, making their American debut at Jenny Armit Design and Decorative Arts in Los Angeles. Mr. Butler (above) trained as an architect before turning to what he calls ''jewels for the house.'' His one-of-a-kind designs, which can cost as much as $20,000, range from chandeliers -- in crystal, glass beads, semiprecious stones or metal -- to elaborate pendants and torchiers. ''I want my work to evolve from historical pieces without being postmodern pastiche,'' he said. They are made to order from Jenny Armit, 8210 Melrose Avenue; (323) 782-9173.

title: BROWSER
description: An eclectic selection of events and sites on the Web.

title: Profit Increases 37% At Nabisco Holdings
description: The Nabisco Holdings Corporation, the biggest United States cookie and cracker company, said today that its third-quarter profit rose 37 percent, the most in more than four years, amid a turnaround led by its chief executive, James Kilts.

title: Fearing Isolation in Old Age, Gay Generation Seeks Haven
description: David Krongelb, a Fort Lauderdale businessman, came out of the closet in his 20's and believed that the door would never close on him again. He is 50 now, and wonders if he will need that secret place once more when he grows old.

title: Tonight's N.F.L. Matchup
description: Kansas City (3-2) at Baltimore (2-3)

title: 3 Phone Companies Meet Estimates on Profit
description: Bell Atlantic and BellSouth, two of the largest local phone companies, said yesterday that third-quarter profit rose, matching estimates, as sales of data, Internet and wireless services soared.

title: A Tolerant and Inclusive Muslim Tradition Thrives
description: The election of Indonesia's most important Muslim religious leader as its first democratically chosen President was welcomed today by Western Governments and human rights advocates. They describe the new leader as a champion of human rights and religious tolerance.

title: The Big City; Ventures Feed The Pleasures Of Indolence
description: IF you are a New Yorker whose favorite cooking appliance is the telephone, or if you can't make it as far as the corner to pick up your dry cleaning, then you are already part of what Ross Stevens calls the city's ''delivery culture.'' But your indolent pleasures have only just begun.

title: Web Site Removes Charities' Tax Reports
description: The Web site where the tax returns of 190,000 charities were posted on Monday pulled most of the returns off the Internet yesterday after discovering that the names of donors and the amounts they gave were included in three tax returns.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SQUADRILLI, RENATA
description: SQUADRILLI-Renata of NYC and Rome, Italy, on 10/19/99. Adored mother of Beatrice and Armanda, beloved wife and soulmate of the late Alex, cherished mother-in-law to Renato and Cheryl. She loved life and music, and touched everyone she met with her beauty, magnetism, and grace. Donations in her name may be made to the American Cancer Society or Metropolitan Community Church of New York, 212-629-7440.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYER, RALPH M.
description: MEYER-Ralph M. Beloved husband of Ruth, loving father of Leslie & Len Brenner & Sandi & Elliott Marsden, adored grandfather of Chanit, Eric, Lauren and Matthew. Dear brother of Margot & Harvey. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island at 11:30 AM on Thursday.

title: Exhibitions, Talks And a Crafts Sale
description: Interiors and Exteriors

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Whatever Makes Your Shoes Shine
description: Coming soon: a cross between the slab in ''2001: A Space Odyssey'' and a glow-in-the-dark billboard. Computerized shopping kiosks from Max Studio, a women's clothing chain, are to be tested later this year in Los Angeles at shoe stores, coffeehouses, health clubs and Max Studio stores. The kiosks, five feet tall with 19-inch computer screens, will be made of milky-colored resin and lighted from the inside. They will provide immediate gratification for those who find the Web (www.maxstudio.com) too slow. The entire Max Studio line will be on the hard drive. While a Web-site purchase could take 10 minutes, a kiosk purchase could take just three, said Leon Max, the company's owner. Now, if someone could figure out how to choose a handbag in three minutes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILSON, WILLIAM H.
description: WILSON-William H. On October 18, 1999, at home in Manhattan, from AIDS related illness. Born April 18, 1948, Middletown, CT. Predeceased by father, William F. Wilson Jr., and by mother, Dorothy Tefft Wilson; survived by sister and a family of loving friends. Author, editor, scholar; graduated Phi Beta Kappa, Yale 1969; attended Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism. Memorials may be made to The Robert Mapplethorpe Laboratory for AIDS Research, C/O Jerome Groopman, M.D., Beth Israel/Deaconess Medical Center, Harvard Institutes of Medicine, West Campus HIM 351, Deaconess Road, Boston, MA. 02215. Memorial service to be announced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLANSKY, IRVING
description: POLANSKY-Irving of Teaneck, NJ. Beloved husband of the late Mina. Adored father of Arleen Sugarman, Franklin and Bruce Polansky. Father-in-law of Douglas Sugarman and Betty Polansky. Proud grandfather of Scott and Branden, brother of Hy, and nieces & nephews. Services ''Gutterman-Musicant'', Hackensack, Thursday, 1pm. 1-800-378-1892.

title: More Than Mostly Mozart For Now, at Least
description: Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center

title: A Long-Missing Brother Is Disturbingly Present
description: LOST

title: The Discreet Charm of Screens
description: MORE flexible than a wall, more mysterious than a veil, a decorative screen can hide many design sins, not to mention dirty laundry. Mario Buatta, whose taste in screens runs from chintz to chintz, uses them in every room, from the foyer to the bedroom, for a shot of color as well as privacy.

title: People
description: * John Zeigler, president and chief executive at the DDB Singapore and DDB Southeast Asia units of DDB Worldwide Communications Group, owned by Omnicom Group, was promoted to the new post of director for digital strategy at DDB Worldwide, New York. Mr. Zeigler is succeeded by Greg Taucher, managing director for worldwide accounts for the Asia-Pacific region, Tokyo, who becomes chairman at DDB Singapore Group and president and chief executive for DDB Southeast Asia. Norman Rigg, who had been chairman and chief executive at DDB Group Canada in Toronto, succeeds Mr. Taucher. Frank Palmer, president and chief executive at Palmer Jarvis DDB in Vancouver, adds Mr. Rigg's duties to his responsibilities.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the United States' deployment of thousands of nuclear weapons abroad during the cold war misidentified one place where William M. Arkin, the co-author of a magazine article about the deployment, said the United States still keeps nuclear weapons. He listed Greece, not Greenland.

title: Medicare Plan Sacrifices Quality
description: To the Editor:

title: Encyclopedia Britannica on Line, But Its Site Is Quickly Overrun
description: The Encyclopedia Britannica, once sold door to door, is now coming in through the Internet. This week, Encyclopedia Britannica said all 32 volumes would be available at www.britannica.com, free of charge. The site will also feature news feeds, magazine articles and a list of Web sites chosen by Britannica's editors. Within days of the opening of the site, however, the Britannica servers were overrun, leaving millions of grade-school term papers in limbo. BRUCE HEADLAM

title: Can't Swing a Ferrari? Try a Really Racy Kitchen
description: Pininfarina, the Italian design company responsible for the Ferrari, has other products and designs, like a kitchen (top) for Snaidero (showrooms: 877-762-4337). Now, an exhibition -- ''Extra Design: Pininfarina Design in 20 Objects for Daily Use,'' at the Italian Cultural Institute in Los Angeles through Nov. 26 -- shows the work of Pininfarina's research and development department. Paolo Pininfarina, the head of the department, said the products represent ''the fundamental ideas of Italian design.'' They include the Gewiss light (above left), leather chairs for Poltrona Frau (above right, $1,850 each at the A. E. Jordan Collection showroom at the Pacific Design Center in Los Angeles) and even golf clubs. The institute is at 1023 Hilgard Avenue; (310) 443-3250.

title: S. L. Dritz, 88, Retooler of Zipper And Other Handy Sewing Items
description: Stanley L. Dritz, the last of four brothers whose gadgets made their family name a household word for generations of people who sew, died Saturday at the White Plains Hospital. He was 88.

title: Father and Son in Union Charged in Kickbacks
description: A Federal indictment unsealed yesterday charges a father and son who run the local office of a health-care workers union with taking $200,000 in kickbacks from a contractor hired to renovate the union's headquarters in Newark.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUMAN, JACK
description: SCHUMAN-Jack. 80, retired Executive Vice President of The Fink Baking Corporation, after a long and valiant struggle. A leader in the food service industry for over 50 years, he leaves behind his devoted wife, Rita, and beloved daughter, Mady, both of New York City. Service Friday 12 noon at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave. Visiting hours Thursday 6-9 P.M. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Care.

title: Blanchard Gets a Call And Then The Job
description: Cary Blanchard watched Monday night's game between the Giants and the Dallas Cowboys at home with his wife, Mindi, in Edmund, Okla.

title: Labeling the Spinmeisters
description: To the Editor:

title: Medicare Plan Sacrifices Quality
description: To the Editor:

title: Former Leader of Pakistan May Face Corruption Trial
description: The military said today that Nawaz Sharif, the Prime Minister the army overthrew last week, is being investigated for corruption, including stealing hundreds of millions of dollars from state banks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAPE, ELIZABETH
description: PAPE-Elizabeth. On October 17. Beloved daughter of Gerald Pape & Barbara Pape Carter, dear sister of Vincent and Christopher Pape & Jennifer Moss. Loving companion to Eric Butler. Graduate SUNY Purchase. Gifted dancer with Kevin Wynn and several modern dance companies. Donations may be made to Dance Space, 451 Broadway, New York City 10013.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE DOLLAR GAINS. The dollar rose against the yen on optimism that rising United States stocks will continue to lure international investors. In New York, the dollar settled at 106.50 yen, up from 105.28 on Tuesday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about Tuesday's trading in the stock market misidentified a company that offered its shares to the public for the first time. It is World Wrestling Federation Entertainment Inc., not World Wide Wrestling Federation Entertainment.

title: Ballet Theater Leaps, the American Way
description: American Ballet Theater opened its 60th-anniversary season on Tuesday night at City Center with a gala that was enjoyably understated and homey. There were only two front-of-curtain speeches, one by Kevin MacKenzie, artistic director of the company, and the other by Cynthia Gregory, the much-loved ballerina who once epitomized the ''American'' in Ballet Theater. And the audience responded to the mixed bag of choreography with knowing affection.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEPHERD, JEAN
description: SHEPHERD-Jean. Died October 16, 1999, humorist, broadcaster and writer. Entertained and educated many via WOR/Radio for over twenty years. ''In God we trust, all others pay cash...'' David Chowes, New York City.

title: Freeman Is Sold To Its Managers
description: Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C. in London has sold Cliff Freeman & Partners in New York, the creatively focused agency in New York that produced campaigns for the Little Caesars pizza chain, to that agency's managers for an estimated $4.6 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHELAN, SONDRA
description: PHELAN-Sondra. The Lincoln Hall Board of Managers acknowledges with deep regret the passing of Sondra Phelan who faithfully served on the Board for 23 years. Mrs. Phelan served on the Executive and Scholarship Committees. She was a strong advocate for childrens' rights and was dedicated to helping the youth in our care. The staff and Board extend sincere condolences to Mrs. Phelan's family on their loss.

title: Dow Gains on Better-Than-Expected Microsoft Earnings
description: Stocks had their best day in almost seven weeks yesterday as better-than-expected earnings from the No. 1 software maker, Microsoft, led to gains in computer-related shares.

title: Subway Series That Got Away
description: Felix and Brenda Manglinong, newlyweds from Sacramento, Calif., spread a Mets jersey between them yesterday as if examining a religious frock. Married on Saturday, they had flown to New York this week with hopes of spending their honeymoon in a frenzy of giddy borough-hopping. A Subway Series, they said, that's how they wanted to spend the first days of their marriage, watching the Mets face the Yankees in a battle for New York.

title: Essay; The Forbes Factor
description: Elizabeth Dole's withdrawal was not good news for the Republican front-runner, George W. Bush, who hoped she would stay in, split his opposition and muddy up debates. Her supporters will go mainly to John McCain, partly to Steve Forbes.

title: At the 1934 World's Fair, Speaking the Wrong Language
description: Charles Lang, the clear-speaking inventor hero of David Mamet's pithy fable of a play, ''The Water Engine,'' which has been given a befittingly lucid revival by the Atlantic Theater Company, is a man uncontaminated by the pollutions of contemporary English.

title: A Need for Fashion
description: To the Editor:

title: The Web Discovers Its Voice
description: AT first, it seemed like a typical chat room. A list of people with names like Lizardog and Lisarae appeared on the computer screen. Curious visitors came and went. Someone had typed a few words of hello.

title: Instability in Nigeria
description: To the Editor:

title: A Haunted Germany
description: To the Editor:

title: Blood, Gore, Sex and Now: Race
description: FOR years, when Orpheus Hanley, a composer and computer-game sound designer in San Diego, sat down to play a computer game, he often felt a gnawing sense of estrangement from the action. Part of the problem, he recently explained, was that as an African-American, he seldom found characters within the game that looked or behaved anything like him.

title: Passivity Is the Word On Year 2000 Marketing; Most Big Companies Playing It Low Key
description: Considering the once-in-a-millennium marketing opportunity that potential Year 2000 computer malfunctions present, the nation's large manufacturers and retailers of consumer products -- even many that stand to benefit from fears of disruption -- have been remarkably restrained.

title: PG&E ANNOUNCES BUYBACK AFTER A REGULATORY SETBACK
description: The PG&E Corporation, owner of California's largest utility, said yesterday that it would buy back as much as $500 million of its shares, which fell 10.3 percent, to $22.1875, in two days on concerns that it would not get the $842 million in electric and natural gas rate increases it requested two years ago. The announcement came a day after a California Public Utilities Commission judge proposed raising PG& E's rates $243 million; the San Francisco-based company, which serves 8.3 million Californians, said such an increase would not be enough.

title: 26 Trenton Students Stricken After Eating Fruit Cups
description: Twenty-six middle school students were apparently stricken with food poisoning today at a new charter school here after the cafeteria served tainted fruit cups, according to state education officials.

title: Sony Has a Free (and Secret) Fix For Out-of-Sync DVD Players
description: Consumers buy DVD players looking to get a razor-sharp picture and high-fidelity surround sound, and they get it -- most of the time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARRELL, MILDRED L.
description: FARRELL-Mildred L. Suddenly, on October 18, 1999. Retired vice president of Citibank. Widow of Leslie M. Farrell. Survived by 2 sisters, Doris Stinebert and Janet Mitchell, and five nieces and nephews, Kim Mitchell, Judith Gill, Barry Todd, H. Kirk Unruh and Craig Unruh. A memorial service will be held at the convenience of the family.

title: How Congress Was Cornered
description: The Congressional budget process has been in place for 25 years. For those of us who have worked on Federal budgets during that time, there is one unavoidable lesson: No budget is effective if it has no support, and no budget will have support unless it is credible.

title: All Sprewell, All the Time at the Garden
description: Jeff Van Gundy nearly got through an entire pre-game news briefing without being asked about or mentioning Latrell Sprewell. Asked if he was a little Spreed-out, the Knicks' coach said, ''I'm not; I'm just hoping at some point you guys are.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWADRON, LESTER
description: SCHWADRON-Lester. On October 19, 1999. In Missouri. Formerly of Roslyn, N.Y. Beloved husband of the late Muriel. Devoted father of Howard and the late J. Stuart. Dear grandfather of Stuart, Emily, and Brian. Mr. Schwadron was a respected dentist in the Forest Hills area for over 42 years and also taught at the NYU Dental School. Funeral services Friday, 12 noon ''Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels'', Queens Boulevard at 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about political developments in Indonesia misstated the percentage of voters in East Timor who voted for independence in a referendum on Aug. 30. It was 78.5 percent, not 87.5.

title: INSIDE
description: Inquiry for Pakistan Ex-Chief

title: Getting Power to the People: The North American Electricity Grid
description: YOU go home, unlock the front door and flip a switch, and your hallway lights up.

title: Medicare Plan Sacrifices Quality
description: To the Editor:

title: In Third World, Unwanted Fertility
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Charge Man In Phone Sex With Child
description: The police have charged a man with coercing a 10-year-old girl to participate in phone sex, the Passaic County Prosecutor's office said. The authorities said they found elaborately chronicled and illustrated fantasies about his friends' children in his house.

title: Judge Rules Grocery Chain Cannot Use a Tax Shelter
description: A tax court judge has ruled that Winn-Dixie Stores cannot deduct interest paid on loans it took out on life insurance policies covering 36,000 of its employees in 1993, throwing into doubt several billion dollars of income tax deductions taken by hundreds of major corporations since 1987.

title: Indonesia's Presidential Surprise
description: Indonesia's new democratic era got off to a wobbly but encouraging start yesterday with the national assembly's unexpected choice of Abdurrahman Wahid, the leader of a moderate Muslim civic organization, as president of the world's fourth most populous nation. Mr. Wahid is respected for his personal integrity and strong support of human rights. But he is frail after a recent stroke and has had limited experience with the economic issues that now require urgent attention.

title: Safe Places to Survey Quakes
description: MAJOR earthquakes aren't occurring more frequently now than they have in the past. It just seems that way, given the recent earthquakes in Turkey, Greece, Taiwan and Mexico, which have produced a succession of all-too-familiar images: collapsed buildings, rescue crews hunting through rubble and victims being pulled from the wreckage. Many people in the United States have their own reasons for reflecting upon the subject: last Sunday, for example, was the 10th anniversary of the devastating Loma Prieta earthquake in Northern California, and it came just one day after a quake shook Southern California.

title: Jack Lynch, 82, of Ireland; Eased North-South Tensions
description: Former Prime Minister Jack Lynch, who declined to send Irish troops to fight the British police in Northern Ireland at the start of the sectarian violence there 30 years ago, died today at a hospital in Dublin. He was 82 and lived in Cork, his native city, south of Dublin.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COPPER RISES. Copper prices rose on perceptions that demand for metal products is growing fast enough to erode ample stockpiles. In New York, copper for December delivery rose 2.2 cents, to 81.3 cents a pound.

title: Fuel Cell May Be the Future 'Battery'
description: THE next time the batteries in your laptop or cell phone conk out at the most inconvenient moment, take heart.

title: Joe Camel, the Marlboro Man And the Cynical Art of Denial
description: By now few viewers can be astonished to learn that cigarette makers have not been models of candor when it comes to their products' effects on the health of their customers. But a little recapitulation can't hurt, and ''Tobacco Wars,'' which begins tonight on The Learning Channel, is a forceful reminder of an industry's half-century of efforts to obscure, obfuscate and delude.

title: A New Inflexibility in Overhauling U.S. Financial Laws
description: After more than 20 years of battles, truces and unholy alliances over legislation to reshape the nation's financial system, the measure's fate rests on what has turned into a bitter and perhaps symbolic political fight between President Clinton and Senator Phil Gramm.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAUBKIN, FRANCES
description: TAUBKIN-Frances. At age 64. On October 20, 1999. Loving wife of Stewart. Devoted mother of Nancy, Peter & wife Kathy. Cherished grandmother of Nathan. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Cancer Research Fund of the Damon Runyon Walter Winchell Foundation, 675 Third Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10017. Services are today, Ocotber 21, at ''Riverside Nassau North Chapels'', Great Neck, New York.

title: Roller Coaster Halts, And Bags Are Packed
description: Shawon Dunston stood in the middle of the clubhouse early yesterday morning, still in uniform after the Mets' season-ending loss to the Braves, his head down. He could not look everyone in the eye, Dunston said later, but he wanted to tell the team that he had reluctantly joined at the trading deadline one thing before he went home.

title: Gaps in Enrollment For Children's Insurance
description: A study released yesterday by a national health-care consumers group has found that 650,000 poor children in New York and New Jersey have not been signed up for a supplemental Federal health insurance program that was introduced two years ago.

title: PEPSICO BACKS BRAZILIAN DRINK
description: Pepsico formed an agreement with Companhia de Bebidas das Americas, or Ambev, to bottle and distribute Guarana Antarctica, a Brazilian soft drink made from the highly caffeinated Amazonian guarana berry. Ambev will export guarana extract to Pepsico with the aim of making Guarana Antarctica, the No. 2 soft drink in Brazil after Coca-Cola, one of the 10 best-selling soft-drink brands worldwide within five years. Guarana is a stimulant believed by some to have aphrodisiac effects.

title: AT HOME WITH: Susan Faludi and Russ Rymer; Sympathy for Men, Empathy With One
description: IT'S almost midnight in the Hollywood Hills. At a neighborhood bar with a disco ball and gaudy red drapes, one of the regulars is sitting with her boyfriend nursing her thrice-weekly chardonnay.

title: Spencer a No-Show of Sorts
description: Even though several players bypassed the optional workout, one noticeable absence was Shane Spencer.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a United States proposal for procedures to try former Khmer Rouge leaders on war crimes charges misstated the proposed number of judges at one point. It is five, not six.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Big Board Fumbles Martha Stewart Deal
description: THE Martha Stewart Omnimedia initial public offering was the hottest one to hit the New York Stock Exchange in many years. The shares, which were offered at $18 each, more than doubled when they began trading on Tuesday morning. Then they went much higher.

title: I.B.M. Warns That Profits Will Decline
description: I.B.M. warned investors yesterday that its profits would be as much as 15 percent below expectations in the current quarter and in the first quarter of next year, because corporations' efforts to deal with the Year 2000 computer problem were dampening demand for its big mainframe systems.

title: Creative Labs Introduces Redesigned MP3 Player
description: Hardly six months after Creative Labs entered the competitive market for portable audio digital players, commonly called MP3 players, the Singapore-based electronics company has introduced a radically redesigned player called the Nomad II.

title: Selling Russia on Missile Defense
description: Russia has made it clear that it does not like American proposals to renegotiate the 27-year-old Antiballistic Missile Treaty in order to permit America to build defenses against nuclear attacks from unpredictable nations like North Korea. Moscow has even rebuffed Washington's offer to help Russia create its own missile defense by financing a new radar system in Siberia. But Russia's current resistance may be a bargaining ploy. America should keep trying to negotiate mutually agreeable modifications to the treaty. What Washington must not do is abandon the treaty in frustration if such revisions prove beyond immediate reach.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I've learned that the current political calendar and election laws favor those who get an early start and can tap into huge private fortunes or who have a pre-existing network of political supporters.''

title: Sports of The Times; The Yankees Are Prepared to Face the Braves and an Old Friend
description: THEY rode buses together for long, hot summers in the minor leagues, and rose to the majors to spend more than a few nights chilling out on the bench. They would engage in the chatter of chances, wondering when their respective turns might come.

title: U.S. Urging Immunization For Meningitis For Collegians
description: A Federal health advisory panel today urged first-year college students to consider being immunized against bacterial meningitis, an extremely rare but potentially fatal infection.

title: Records Show Puerto Ricans Got U.S. Help With Clemency
description: The Justice Department took extraordinary steps to enhance the chances of clemency for a group of imprisoned Puerto Rican nationalists after receiving regular expressions of interest from the White House, according to documents released today.

title: Roche Cancels Bond Offering On Genentech
description: Roche Holding A.G. said today that it would not proceed with an offering of bonds convertible to 5.5 million shares in Genentech Inc., the biotechnology company in which it holds a controlling stake.

title: Creator of the Fantastic Four Is Ready to Spin More Tales on Line
description: NEXT to his superheroes, Stan Lee has the most recognizable name in comic books. The longtime writer and editor for Marvel Comics helped create, among others, the Fantastic Four, Spider-Man, the Silver Surfer and the X-Men. In his 60-year career, he has become perhaps one of the best-read authors in the United States.

title: Wherefore Art Thou, Art?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Family Portraits, Together Again
description: The chutzpah of Asher Wertheimer! A rich London art dealer and the son of a self-made German Jew, he commissioned John Singer Sargent (1856-1925), then at the height of his fame as a portraitist, to paint no less than a dozen likenesses of his family. And he willed that nine of them should join the pantheon of great British citizens at the National Portrait Gallery after his and his wife's deaths.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Morgan Stanley Finds Its Dream Address Taken

title: Intellectuals Urge Turkey to End the War Against Its Kurds
description: Turkey's most prominent cultural figure, the novelist Yasar Kemal, has urged the Government to ''save Turkey from her shame'' by granting more rights to Kurds and ending the war that has been under way in the mostly Kurdish southeast for 15 years.

title: Speeding Is Cited in Fatal Accident on Bridge
description: The off-duty police captain accused of driving drunk and killing a construction worker on the Throgs Neck Bridge on Wednesday was going nearly twice the posted speed limit with his headlights off in a lane that was closed for construction, according to a complaint that was filed yesterday in Queens Criminal Court.

title: Sojo at His Ill Father's Side
description: Joe Torre revealed yesterday that utility player Luis Sojo would be unavailable to play in the opener of the American League Championship Series with the Red Sox. Sojo left Yankee Stadium after two innings because his father had emergency heart surgery for an aortic aneurysm.

title: On My Mind; The Deadly Cargo
description: More often now, the special cargo arrives in China from Israel -- files from Israeli military computers, crates with the makings of missiles and other weapons, and the men in the lab coats, the engineers and scientists who know how to put it all together.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARMON, NORA ALKALAY SCHUELLER
description: HARMON-Nora Alkalay Schueller Born Nagy Bisce, Hungary 1909, died New York City October 9, 1999. A beautiful, courageous, strong woman, she lived and died on her own terms. She will be remembered by all who knew her for her charm, intelligence and beauty. A Memorial will be held on Saturday, October 30th at 12:30PM at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue. Servus, Nora. Lilot, Christopher, Nicholas, Keith

title: Three Plays Connected by Themes of Deviance
description: Daphne Rubin-Vega was last seen on the New York stage in ''Rent'' wearing body-clinging leather and singing about feeling like ''a cat in heat.'' Now, in ''Gum,'' which is set in an unnamed, Middle Eastern theocracy, she is swathed in a chador and intimating that, well, she's still feeling like a cat in heat.

title: Duchamp's Replications. Duchamp's Replications.
description: Among the culture-rattling notions generated by Marcel Duchamp (1887-1968) were (1) that artists can designate what is art, including ''readymade'' objects like a urinal, a snow shovel, a bottle rack, and (2) replication. Turned off by the growing practice of artists repeating their motifs to create a lucrative ''signature'' style, he gradually reached the paradoxical decision that the way to avoid getting stuck in that groove was to keep to the images he had already made, replicating them literally. The replications, of course, would be works of art in their own right.

title: INSIDE ART
description: A Botticelli With a Hitch

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in New York City.

title: A Sunday in the Park With Others From Everywhere
description: Ever since I moved to New York three years ago and landed in Park Slope, Brooklyn, I've had my eye on Manhattan, determined that if my ship ever came in, I'd promptly redirect its course toward that island's shore. I was after the kind of New York described by Joan Didion in her essay ''Goodbye to All That'' in which the city is ''an infinitely romantic notion, the mysterious nexus of all love, money and power, the shining and perishable dream itself.'' As a young writer in search of experience, how could I want to live anywhere else?

title: Needed: More Doctors
description: To the Editor:

title: Still Pining For Series Via Subway
description: THE brain tells you that it demeans all of Gotham to suggest its self-esteem is somehow enhanced by the success of its baseball teams.

title: SOUTH AFRICA INFLATION DROPS
description: Inflation in South Africa fell to 1.9 percent in September, its lowest level since 1968, when it stood at 1.7 percent. The drop in the consumer price index, from 3.2 percent in August, was driven largely by a sharp reduction in mortgage rates. The core inflation rate, which excludes mortgage rates, was unchanged from a year earlier at 7.9 percent.

title: Not So Fizzy in Russia
description: To the Editor:

title: Social Services Group Wins Suit Over Contributions to Charity
description: A Manhattan judge has sided with a social services organization in its legal battle with another New York philanthropic group over who is entitled to millions of dollars in donated money.

title: Residential Real Estate; Condos Sell Quickly in TriBeCa East
description: Since the two condominium loft buildings on opposite corners of Church Street in TriBeCa opened for sale last summer, most of their apartments have been sold for $550 to $600 a square foot on average, indicating that Manhattan's strong housing market is filtering into the neighborhood's eastern section.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHMIDT, BENNO CHARLES
description: SCHMIDT-Benno Charles. Died October 21, 1999. Beloved husband of Nancy Montgomery Schmidt; father of Benno, Jr., Ralph, Thomas (deceased), John, William; stepfather of James, Ruth and Stephen Fleischmann; grandfather of 15 and great-grandfather of one. Benno was born in Abilene, Texas, on January 10, 1913. He graduated from the University of Texas in 1933 and the University of Texas Law School in 1936, and was a member of the Texas Law School faculty 1936-1940. He joined the Office of the General Counsel, War Production Board, in 1941-1942. He served in the U.S. Army 1942-1945, stationed in England and France, retiring as Colonel. He was awarded the Legion of Merit, the Bronze Star, the Legion d'honneur, the Croix de Guerre with Palms and the French Medal of Merit. He served as General Counsel, Economics Division, State Department, 1945-1946. He was General Partner in J.H. Whitney & Co., 1946-1998; Managing Partner, 1960-1992; and Senior Partner, 1993-1998. In this position he led the first and one of the premier venture capital firms of the world. His other honors, commitments and appointments are far too numerous to list. Among many, he was Chairman of the President's Cancer Panel, 1971-1980; Chairman, Memorial Hospital, 1971-1982; Chairman, Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1982-1990; Chairman, BedfordStuyvesant Development Corporation, 1969-1984; Chairman, Fund for the City of New York, 1968-1977; Chairman, Roosevelt Island Development Corporation, 1969 - 1976; Trustee, Whitney Museum of American Art, 1965-1984; Chairman, Freeport-McMoRan Inc., 1975-1984; Honorary Officer of the Order of Australia. He loved great art and assembled a beautiful collection of Impressionists, Modern and Australian art. He was a great sportsman and sports fan, following baseball, football and hockey and playing golf until about the end of his life. Above all he was the most loving, dedicated and generous father, husband and grandfather, finding his greatest happiness in the love of family. A service will be held at 11 AM Tuesday, October 26, 1999 at St. James Church, 71st Street and Madison Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Avenue, New York, New York 10021.

title: Study Finds Mixed Results In Reducing Welfare Rolls
description: About a third of the people who left New Jersey's shrinking welfare rolls since 1997 found jobs and managed to support themselves a year after their public assistance ended, a new study commissioned by the state found.

title: Venus And Mars Colliding
description: In the opening scenes of ''Body Shots,'' a groggy young man rises from his date's bed, urinates on her closed toilet and mops up the mess with her bathroom rug. Moments later, a distraught young woman at the wheel of a car speeding through the night in a blinding downpour skids to a spinning stop, shoves open the door and vomits onto the rain-swept road.

title: Detergent Moves To Ammirati Puris
description: The United States home and personal care unit of Unilever has changed agencies for a third detergent brand.

title: A call for restrictions on psychological research by advertisers into products for children.
description: DEPLORING what they see as an unfair and conflict-ridden manipulation of the young, a group of psychologists and other professionals has called on the American Psychological Association to restrict the use of psychological research by advertisers pitching toys, video games, snack food and other products to children.

title: 'In Company: Robert Creeley's Collaborations'
description: New York Public Library

title: For Tyson's Opponent, Later Is Better Than Never
description: It seems that timing and time have never been friends of Orlin Norris, who will fight Mike Tyson at the MGM Grand on Saturday night in a 10-round heavyweight bout. His younger brother, Terry, a junior middleweight, overshadowed him by winning a world championship first. Meanwhile, Orlin Norris has only been on the doorstep to a world title.

title: KOREAN JOBLESS RATE DROPS
description: South Korea's jobless rate fell to a 20-month low of 4.8 percent in September, a sharp drop from 5.7 percent in August. The number of people unemployed fell to 1.07 million from 1.24 million. Korea has a population of about 46 million and anyone who works at least an hour a week is considered employed.

title: What's in a Web Address? Maybe a Lawsuit
description: Executives of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company have been boasting this week about their new on-line stock trading service and the head start they got on their competitors on Wall Street. But when it came to the Internet address they desired, somebody got a jump on them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERSON, ROSE
description: GERSON-Rose. At 97 years (nee Schlanger). Beloved wife of the late Benjamin, loving mother of Melvin and Sylvia, Janyce Dratch and the late Sol. Adored grandmother of the late Ivan, Roberta, and Adrienne. Cherished great grandmother of Joanna, Meredith, David, Nicole, Tara, and Lindsay. She was loved by all.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 12.

title: What Public Schools Can Offer
description: To the Editor:

title: GORE VOWS TO BAN NEW OIL DRILLING ALONG TWO COASTS
description: Vice President Al Gore said today that as President he would ban any new offshore drilling for oil and gas along the California and Florida coasts.

title: WYNN'S TO BUY GOSHEN RUBBER FOR $85 MILLION
description: Wynn's International Inc., an auto-parts and specialty chemical supplier, agreed yesterday to buy a rival, the Goshen Rubber Companies, for $85 million in cash and debt. Wynn's, based in Orange, Calif., will buy all of the outstanding shares of the closely held Goshen and pay off an undisclosed amount of bank debt. Goshen Rubber, based in Goshen, Ind., makes sealing products, O-rings and gaskets used in the automobile industry. It had revenue of $172.6 million for the fiscal year ended June 30. Wynn's rubber sealing products and industrial lubricants are used in cars, planes and ships.

title: Colgate Net Up 12% in Quarter
description: The Colgate-Palmolive Company, the world's largest toothpaste maker, said yesterday that its third-quarter earnings rose 12 percent as it sold more products in North America and Asia and cut costs.

title: Who's an Isolationist?
description: To the Editor:

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Just in time for cold weather, Laight Street arrives in TriBeCa like a breeze from South Beach. This updated brasserie, in half of what used to be City Wine and Cigar, concentrates on seafood, but you don't have to read the menu to figure that out. A cool, mysterious-looking fish tank greets you as you squeeze in the front door, and fresh oysters, clams and crabs are piled high on a serpentine counter outfitted with round, porthole-style lights.

title: Under Tighter Rules, a Reluctant Giuliani Passes the Hat
description: It was a dream event for any would-be senator: a meeting with the cream of America's business lobbyists, 70 people who could raise huge sums of money for an expensive political campaign, at the United States Chamber of Commerce in Washington. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani had already canceled the meeting once during Hurricane Floyd, then rescheduled it for Oct. 19. So it was with some surprise that the chamber got a call from the Mayor's staff late last week, canceling the meeting a second time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NICKENS, ANNIE
description: NICKENS-Annie. The members of the Brooklyn Museum of Art Community Committee are deeply saddened by the sudden death of Annie Nickens, a devoted member and dear friend. We extend our deepest sympathy to her family. Edith Gothelf, President Community Committee

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDELSTEIN, BEN
description: EDELSTEIN-Ben. United Merchants legend, then career counselor to thousands, died of cancer yesterday. Brilliant, funny, not easy and never boring. He will be greatly missed by his loving wife Mal O'Reilly, son Cliff, daughter Joan, grandchildren Marc, Karen, David and everyone who knew him. Services Sunday 11:30 AM, ''Wien & Wien'', Hackensack, New Jersey. 800-378-1892.

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: Toasters at Risk Once Again

title: Team Time Trial Is Reintroduced in the Tour de France
description: The organizers of the Tour de France confirmed the rumors today. It's back to the future and back to Futuroscope, too, in 2000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHELAN, SONDRA
description: PHELAN-Sondra. The Officers and Trustees of the William J. Matheson Foundation note with sadness the passing of our dedicated and courageous Trustee, Sondra Phelan. She will be missed. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to her husband, Jim, and to her children.

title: Fraud Trial Starts for Ex-Teamster Official
description: Federal prosecutors detailed their case yesterday against the teamsters' former political director, accusing him of conspiring with Democratic Party officials, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s secretary-treasurer and others to siphon union money to the 1996 re-election drive of Ron Carey, the teamsters' former president.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Scout Leader Accused Of Child Pornography
description: A Long Island Cub Scout leader was accused yesterday of trading pornographic pictures of children over the Internet after the police received a tip from a computer repairman.

title: Clinton's Security Adviser Attacks Precepts of 'New Isolationists'
description: The White House national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, expanding on an attack initiated by President Clinton, said last night that ''new isolationists'' who defeated the nuclear test ban treaty wanted to build ''a fortified fence around America.''

title: In His Own Words
description: BILL BRADLEY

title: SMITHKLINE SHARE SELLOFF
description: Shares of SmithKline Beecham P.L.C. plummeted 12 percent on news that the company's new diabetes drug, Avandia, faces a problem on regulatory approval from the European Union. The London-based company, which won approval for the drug in the United States, called the problem temporary. The problem overshadowed a report showing that profits rose 13 percent, to $:339 million, or $566 million, in the third quarter.

title: Doctor at South Pole Received Medical Help via Video
description: Jerri L. Nielsen, the doctor who developed breast cancer while trapped at the South Pole by winter weather, diagnosed her illness and treated herself with the help of a cancer specialist in Indianapolis who guided her via video-conferencing and E-mail.

title: Casting a Fresh Perspective on Beethoven Sonatas
description: In the late 1980's Robert Taub gave a series of performances of Milton Babbitt's solo piano works, which was so illuminating that a listener came away from his concerts thinking of Mr. Babbitt's music in an entirely different way. Mr. Taub has not abandoned new music since then, but in recent years he has been spending a lot of time coming to terms with the Beethoven Sonatas.

title: Congress Rejects Idea of Using Managed Care for Medicare
description: Congress today rebuffed a proposal by President Clinton to steer Medicare patients to certain hospitals and medical suppliers who offer discounted prices to the Government. But lawmakers said they would re-examine the proposal next year, when they consider bigger changes in Medicare.

title: At Mayor's Rally for the Yankees, a Few Rules
description: Hundreds of New Yorkers, under the watchful eyes of the police, filed into the refurbished City Hall Park yesterday and received Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's endorsement of their collective dream: a 25th World Series title, now as few as four games away.

title: Paying for Stadiums
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPSTEIN, NORMAN
description: EPSTEIN-Norman, age 86, after a long illness. Father of Don, (Cara) and Susan Levitt. Loving grandfather of Morgan, Jacob, Jordan and Melissa. Graveside service Friday, October 22, 11:30AM, at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Glendale, Queens. Contributions may be made in Norman's name to the I.T.P. Society, c/o Children's Blood Foundation, 9 E 53rd St, NYC 10022

title: Soft Money and Hard Bargains
description: You could almost hear the laughter coming from board rooms and executive suites all over the country when Senate opponents of campaign-finance reform expressed dismay that anyone could think big political contributions are corrupting elections and government. On Tuesday, those opponents prevailed, blocking a final vote this year on banning soft-money contributions. But the innocent and benign system described by the Senators arguing against reform hardly passed the laugh test for those of us on the receiving end of the soft-money shakedown.

title: With Children
description: Too often taking children out to eat is more about endurance than enjoyment. But these 12 restaurants are welcoming to families, relaxing for parents and adept at putting children at ease, making them less conscious of being on their best behavior. (These summaries are taken from dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times by William Grimes, Eric Asimov and others.)

title: Slight to Puerto Rico
description: To the Editor:

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: A Paramedic With a Pen

title: Singed by a Disco Inferno
description: THE overture is only a warning.

title: 9% KOREAN GROWTH SEEN
description: Raising its forecast, a Government research group predicted that South Korea's economy would grow 9 percent this year. The Korea Development Institute, one of the most influential Government research groups, had previously forecast that gross domestic product would grow 7.5 percent, rebounding sharply from the 5.8 percent contraction last year.

title: Defense Rests Murder Case With a Video Confession
description: The defense lawyers for a schizophrenic man accused of pushing a woman to her death in front of a speeding Manhattan subway train rested their case yesterday with an unusual twist. They played their client's videotaped confession to committing the murder.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing of the Media Business page on Wednesday about the awarding of an ESPN International advertising account to Bates Worldwide misidentified the office of another agency, Wieden & Kennedy, that handles ESPN's domestic account. It is the New York office, not the agency's headquarters in Portland, Ore.

title: Dignitaries Pay Tribute to Nyerere
description: Inside a stadium thronged by thousands of mourners standing and sitting under a merciless sun, leaders from all corners of Africa and officials from the West paid tribute today to Julius K. Nyerere, the founding father of Tanzania and one of the most influential independence leaders on the continent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHUNG, RUTH W.
description: CHUNG-Ruth W. Of New York City, passed away on October 18, 1999, at the age of 83. Family matriarch and beloved wife of over 50 years of the late C.Y. and sister of the late Irene Lee, Elsie Wu, and Dale Bing Wong. Devoted mother of Janice Lee, cherished Auntie of Betty, Doris, Gloria, Kent, Alan, Carol, Ronald, Linda, and Andrew. Adored great aunt to many grand nieces and nephews. She will always be remembered for her loving warmth and kindness, her bountiful generosity and feisty spirit, her distinctive laugh, and her everlasting beauty. Funeral services will be held on Friday at 11:30 A.M. Interment will follow at Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUMAN, JACK
description: SCHUMAN-Jack. 80, retired Executive Vice President of The Fink Baking Corporation, after a long and valiant struggle. A leader in the food service industry for over 50 years, he leaves behind his devoted wife, Rita, and beloved daughter, Mady, both of New York City. Service today 12 noon at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Care.

title: Starwood Duties To Weiss Stagliano
description: Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide in White Plains has awarded the creative duties for consumer and trade advertising for its hotels carrying the Luxury Collection and St. Regis brand names to Weiss Stagliano Partners in New York. Billings were estimated at more than $3 million.

title: Back From the Underworld With a Minimalist Score
description: Some people who go to see ''Operation: Orfeo'' by the Danish company Hotel Pro Forma at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave Festival may find the use of smoke forces them to leave early. They will be the lucky ones.

title: Senate Votes to Ban a Controversial Abortion Procedure
description: The Senate voted 63 to 34 today to ban a particular kind of abortion procedure that its opponents call ''partial birth'' but fell slightly short of the votes that would be needed to override President Clinton's expected veto.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: What Public Schools Can Offer
description: To the Editor:

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Design; G.M. Offers a Sneak Preview of Its Cars of Tomorrow
description: DETERMINED not to be a wallflower at next year's big parties, General Motors is trying on a rack of new outfits in an effort to bedazzle those who haven't been asking for a dance.

title: Scores Die as Bombs Ravage Chechen Capital
description: At least 10 explosions devastated a downtown market and maternity hospital in Grozny, Chechnya, on Thursday evening, according to accounts from the breakaway Russian republic.

title: Metro Business; Bookseller to Expand
description: Barnesandnoble.com Inc., the No. 2 on-line bookseller, will expand its Manhattan headquarters to 165,000 square feet in a 15-year lease, the building's owners said yesterday.

title: N.F.L. MATCHUPS WEEK 7
description: GAME OF THE WEEK

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLASSER, CAROL
description: GLASSER-Carol. On October 21, 1999. Beloved wife of Harvey. Devoted mother of Barbara and Jonathan. Cherished daughter of Helene Hahn. Loving sister of Rabbi Sanford Hahn. Adored grandmother of Raffaella and Ava Glasser. Service Sunday, 12Noon, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st St. and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC.

title: PHILIPS PROFIT DOUBLES
description: The Dutch consumer electronics manufacturer Royal Philips Electronics said its profit more than doubled in the third quarter, beating analysts' expectations. Profit soared to 374 million euros, or $403 million, from 147 million. The company attributed its rebound to growth in its consumer products unit, along with gains in its Asian investments, especially its $1.6 billion investment in a joint venture with LG Group of South Korea to manufacture flat-panel computer and television monitors.

title: You'll Wish They Were Just in the Belfry
description: In the beginning were the biblical plagues. In the fullness of time, they begat cinema's plagues of ants, bees, spiders, birds and various viruses.

title: House Sends Clinton Another Spending Bill He's Sure to Veto
description: For the second straight day, the House of Representatives today approved and sent President Clinton a spending bill he is sure to veto.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDERS, JOHN E.
description: SANDERS-John E. Professor Emeritus of Geology at Barnard College, Columbia University and noted environmental research scientist, died at Phelps Memorial Hospital in Sleepy Hollow, NY, at age 73 after a brief illness October 20. Beloved husband of Barbara, devoted father of Philip, Thomas, and Stephanie & cherished fatherin-law of Janice Sanders and John Sullivan. Doting grandfather of William, Katherine, Daniel and Scott. For funeral information call Community Unitarian Church, 468 Rosedale Avenue, White Plains, NY 914-946-1660. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to: Ohio Weslyan University, Columbia University or Phelps Memorial Hospital.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Dear Lena Horne: Check Your Mail

title: Ross Parmenter, 88, Music Critic And Author of Books on Mexico
description: Ross Parmenter, a former music news editor of The New York Times and the author of several books on Mexico, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 88.

title: Alex Brown
description: Feature

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRACHMAN, ALICE WEST
description: DRACHMAN-Alice West, age 95. Widow of Oliver C. Drachman, died October 16, 1999, Tucson, AZ. Survivors are son James West Drachman, Tucson; daughter Anne Drachman Tartaul, La Jolla, CA; grandchildren James D. Drachman, San Diego, Ann Eve Berry, Phoenix, Oliver DrachmanRandall, New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEMPEL, BLANCHE
description: LEMPEL-Blanche (Blume), died peacefully, in her own home Wednesday evening, October 20, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Lemel (Leon); loving mother of Paul and daughter-in-law, Frances, the late Michael Klahr and his wife, Phyllis, Yolande Krieger, and Steven and daughter-in-law, Jolanda.
