She will be dearly missed by her grandchildren, Lisa Lempel-Sander, Andrea Lempel-Federmann, Barbara Lempel, Vivien Krieger and Elena Lempel, and by her greatgrandchildren, Bria, Ethan and Liran. She will live in our thoughts and hearts by the memory of her life and she will be remembered in our community through her Yiddish writings. Service Friday, October 22, 1999, 10:15 AM, at the Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY (718) 445-0300.

title: Citizens of Poverty Yearning to Be Free
description: As profoundly as Italian neo-realism has influenced American movies (where would Martin Scorsese be without Rossellini and De Sica?), it takes a work like David Riker's smudgy, no-frills film ''The City'' (''La Ciudad'') to remind you of the genre's power in bringing home the brute Darwinian realities of poor people's lives.

title: Alex Katz
description: Marlborough

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE DOLLAR SLIDES. The dollar slipped, dampened by the morning fall in the stock market. In New York, the dollar settled at 105.86 Japanese yen, down from 106.50 on Wednesday; the euro traded at $1.0820, up from $1.0752.

title: Taking the Tears Out of a Potentially Tear-Jerking Plot
description: As a mentally retarded woman who, thanks to brain surgery, briefly achieves a state bordering on normalcy, Elisabeth Shue slowly unfurls through John Duigan's film ''Molly'' like a flower reaching for the sun. But if Ms. Shue infuses ''Molly'' with a flicker of joy, her sweetly likable performance is the only coherent element in a film that has the impersonal feel of a television drama slapped together in a rush.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Oct. 14 about the awarding of the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science to Robert A. Mundell misstated the amount. This year's award is valued at $976,000, not $1 million.

title: Islanders Want More Out of Isbister and Czerkawski
description: Brad Isbister and Mariusz Czerkawski, both wings, have played on opposite ends of the Islanders' top line since the opening day of training camp. In that month and a half, four centers have come and gone as Butch Goring, the Islanders' coach, has tirelessly searched for the most potent mix.

title: Indonesia Opposition Leader Chosen as the Vice President
description: The day after voting down her bid for the presidency, Parliament today elected Megawati Sukarnoputri, a popular leader of the opposition to the ousted Suharto Government, to the post of Vice President.

title: Fed Learns Bartenders Are More Popular Than Bouncers
description: IS Alan Greenspan yesterday's hero?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAFUZ, EDWARD J.
description: MAFUZ-Edward J., M.D. On October 17, 1999. Beloved son of Eduardo and the late Araceles. Loving husband of America. Devoted father of Rose Marie and Pamela. Reposing Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home, 117 West 72 Street, NYC.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE FALLS. Coffee fell 5 percent on speculation that crops in Brazil had not been damaged as much as expected by a prolonged dry spell. In New York, coffee for December delivery fell 4.8 cents a pound, to 90.60 cents.

title: Scientists Find Enzyme Linked To Alzheimer's
description: The long, brutal process that leads to Alzheimer's disease starts when a single enzyme snips a protein that protrudes from brain cells, leading to the release of toxic shards. Now scientists report that they have found that enzyme, opening the door to developing drugs that might block it and, if the drugs prove safe, to preventing or slowing the disease.

title: Death of Teacher After Groping Arrest Shocks Town
description: From the headquarters of Fire Company 4, to the halls of the high school, to the railroad signal tower that attracted the grief-stricken, people in this small, close-knit town were stunned today at the apparent suicide of a popular teacher and coach.

title: Aiding Despotism
description: To the Editor:

title: Seagram Loss Is Smaller Than Expected
description: The Seagram Company, whose businesses range from Universal Pictures to Absolut vodka, today reported a smaller-than-expected loss in its first quarter, aided by gains in music and at its theme parks.

title: Ruth Marten
description: Littlejohn Contemporary

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLIVER, ROSE
description: OLIVER-Rose. On October 20, 1999, of heart disease, at her residence in Peterborough, NH. She was a clinical psychologist with a Ph.D. from CUNY. For a number of years she was associated with the Institude for Rational-Emotive Therapy, in addition to her private practice. Survivors are her daughter Theresa Oliver, son John and wife Priscilla, grandchildren Peter and wife Julie, Anna, Christopher, Eric, Heather, great-grandchildren Cole and Clay, sister Anna London, and many nieces and nephews. Services at ''The Riverside'', Sunday, October 24, 9:45AM, at Amsterdam Ave. and 76th Street.

title: Johnson Says Knicks Can Use a Pep Talk
description: While some players practiced their shooting or worked individually with coaches as the Knicks were finishing a long practice session today, Larry Johnson grabbed a large bucket and submerged his left foot in ice.

title: Major Public Employees' Union Is Set to Endorse Mrs. Clinton
description: New York's largest public employees' union stayed neutral in Senator Charles E. Schumer's defeat of Alfonse M. D'Amato last year, but its president said today that the group will back Hillary Rodham Clinton's Senate candidacy over that of her likely opponent, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: Saul Steinberg
description: PaceWildenstein Gallery

title: Ruthless in a Greedy World. Sounds Familiar, Doesn't It?
description: When Becky Sharp meets Jos Sedley, the brother of her best friend, Amelia, she sees what we do: a pudgy, pompous little man, bound to be fonder of wine and food than he ever will be of a wife. ''He's very handsome,'' the calculating Becky confides to Amelia, in what is just the beginning of the social hypocrisy that is the world of ''Vanity Fair.''

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.

title: Who's at Feinstein's? Why, It's Feinstein!
description: To describe Michael Feinstein as the consummate variety-show entertainer of 1960-something is not to belittle this diehard nostalgist who served his apprenticeship as Ira Gershwin's secretary. Since making his New York cabaret debut more than a decade ago, Mr. Feinstein has added multiple layers of show business savvy to the boyish, slick-haired singer and pianist.

title: Stoutmire Is Seeking Fresh Start With Jets
description: Sixteen days ago, Omar Stoutmire was out of work, having been released by the expansion Cleveland Browns after only two games. It was a comedown for a man who had started at free safety for the Dallas Cowboys last season, but Stoutmire kept his faith. And now he makes his second start for the Jets as the team travels to Oakland to face the Raiders this Sunday.

title: Coca-Cola Earnings Slid 11.4% in Quarter
description: In a performance that indicated improving sales but not better profits, the Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that its third-quarter earnings fell 11.4 percent but that revenue rose 9.4 percent.

title: S.E.C. Settles On-Line Stock Auction Case
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said this week that it had settled charges against three men who tried to sell stock at the Internet auction site Ebay.

title: Urban Sprawl Benefits Dairies in California
description: Nearly four decades ago, Gennie DeBoer was one of many dairy farmers forced by relentless urbanization to flee the farmland in Los Angeles County where her immigrant parents had settled, to build a new life elsewhere. Though a challenge, the move turned out to be a blessing.

title: Close, but No Banking Cigar; A Heavily Political Issue Holds Up an Effort at Change
description: After a week of difficult negotiations among Senator Phil Gramm and President Clinton's top economic advisers over a bill to overhaul the nation's financial system, it became evident today that there would be no new law unless an agreement can be reached over the legislation's effect on rules that encourage banks to make loans to the poor.

title: LIBERTY MEDIA GROUP TO BUY ASCENT FOR $513.6 MILLION
description: Liberty Media Group, the AT&T Corporation's cable television programming company, agreed to buy Ascent Entertainment Group for about $513.6 million in stock to offer more services to travelers. Each Ascent share will be swapped for 0.4626 of a Liberty Media class A share. That values Ascent at $17.26 a share based on Wednesday's closing price. Ascent, based in Denver, offers pay-per-view entertainment and information services through the On Command Corporation, which is 57 percent-owned by Ascent. The sale excludes the Colorado Avalanche hockey team, the Denver Nuggets basketball franchise and the Pepsi Center, all of which Ascent is selling to the billionaire Donald Sturm.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILSON, WILLIAM H.
description: WILSON-William H. On October 18, 1999, at home in Manhattan, from AIDS related illness. Born April 18, 1948, Middletown, CT. Predeceased by father, William F. Wilson Jr., and by mother, Dorothy Tefft Wilson; survived by sister and a family of loving friends. Author, editor, scholar; graduated Phi Beta Kappa, Yale 1969; attended Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism. Memorials may be made to The Robert Mapplethorpe Laboratory for AIDS Research, C/O Jerome Groopman, M.D., Beth Israel/Deaconess Medical Center, Harvard Institutes of Medicine, West Campus HIM 351, Deaconess Road, Boston, MA. 02215. Memorial service to be announced.

title: Yes, a Private Dancer, but Not What You Think
description: If any dance review should be written in the first person, it is this one. On Wednesday night, as part of the New Europe '99 Festival, I went to Joyce SoHo where I did not so much attend the Cie Felix Ruckert from Berlin as took part in three solos performed by three different dancers in three separate cubicles.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: MIDDLE EAST

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORODKIN, ESTHER
description: BORODKIN-Esther, of Coconut Creek, FL and Valley Stream, NY. Beloved mother of Barry, Linda, and Richard Melnikoff. Grandmother of Jack and Tracy. Sister of Beatrice Wanger. She will be forever missed. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI, Friday, 12:30PM.

title: Donald M. Liddell, 92, Investment Adviser
description: Donald Macy Liddell Jr., a retired investment adviser, died on Sunday at New York Hospital. He was 92 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Public Interests; Let Rudy Be Rudy
description: Rudolph Giuliani needs to sit down and take deep breaths before he decides to run for the Senate. Sure, he could probably do the job. Don't worry about people who tell you he lacks a collegial temperament. Have you seen the Senate lately? Half the members are impossible and the other half are in a permanent sulk because they aren't president.

title: Benno C. Schmidt, Financier, Is Dead at 86
description: Benno C. Schmidt, the right-hand man of the financier John Hay Whitney and a pioneering venture capitalist who became an important backer of biotechnology ventures, a New York civic leader and the head of the Federal Government's war on cancer, died yesterday at his home in New York. He was 86.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORNSTEIN, TONI GREENHOUSE
description: ORNSTEIN-Toni Greenhouse. Of Aventura, Fla. Devoted mother of Linda Landis and mother-in-law of Alan Landis. Sister of the late Jesse Chinich. Loving grandmother of Scott and Dana Landis. Services Sunday 11:15AM, ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam.

title: Corrections
description: A profile on Aug. 25 about Samuel R. Berger, President Clinton's national security adviser, referred incompletely to the context of a comment he made in 1991 that ''grand strategies'' were mostly rationales developed after the fact to explain successful ad hoc decisions. Mr. Berger made that remark at a panel discussion in which he talked about the 10 years in which he was developing an international law practice for his firm, Hogan & Hartson. After the article appeared, his office said his comment applied only to the specific work of putting together a law practice and not to his vision of American foreign policy in his current job.

title: Li Xubai -- 'Summoning the Seasons'
description: Kaikodo

title: Business, Not Bombast, in the Lull Before the Storm
description: If the Nielsen ratings were based strictly on the Yankees' watching, then Atlanta's Game 6 victory over the Mets in the National League Championship Series Tuesday would have had complete viewership. In their homes in Manhattan, in Westchester and New Jersey and Long Island, the Yankees were all watching, and the Braves' aggressiveness on the bases made a strong impression on them.

title: Party, but Be True to Your Sweetheart
description: In the genial ensemble film ''The Best Man,'' Taye Diggs puts on glasses to play a Chicago novelist whose book has been selected for Oprah Winfrey's book club. He also appears in a candlelit bathtub covered with rose petals, since the movie doesn't forget to get its priorities straight. The main point about the novel written by Harper Stewart (Mr. Diggs) is that it is called ''Unfinished Business.'' Harper has some. It seems that he closely modeled one character on an old flame named Jordan (Nia Long) who once kissed Harper to the tune of a Stevie Wonder song when they were in college. ''Jordan's the best girlfriend you never had,'' one of his buddies remarks.

title: Bradley Challenges Nation To Eliminate Child Poverty
description: Describing poverty as a ''slow motion national disaster,'' former Senator Bill Bradley called yesterday for reducing the number of poor children by half over the coming decade by raising the minimum wage, increasing spending on child care programs and providing an array of tax benefits to poor parents who work.

title: The Crown Jewels Are Glittering Anew
description: The world has changed. Two years ago, Don Ohlmeyer, then the president of NBC West Coast, said that he wished the World Series between the Florida Marlins and the Cleveland Indians would end in a sweep so the network could get on with its prime-time schedule.

title: Many Banks Make Money On Lending in Poor Areas
description: Making home loans to poor people may not be as profitable as lending to everyone else, but it is not bad business, either.

title: Douglas to Skip Nets' Road Trip
description: While the Nets hit the road for two exhibition games, Sherman Douglas will stay home in Washington to work on his conditioning. He will join them when they return to New Jersey next week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLARSKY, WILLIAM
description: WOLARSKY-William, M.D. On October 16, 1999 in Palm Beach, Florida. Beloved husband of Anne (Rosengarten), loving father of Ellen Kuris of Princeton, NJ, and Dr. Evan R. Wolarsky of Pennington, NJ, devoted father-inlaw of Rosalie Wolarsky and Dr. Jay Kuris. Proud grandfather of Jeremy, Benjamin and Gabriel Kuris and Eric and Nina Wolarsky. Dr. Wolarsky was on staff at Bronx Lebanon Hospital from his internship in 1933 to 1975, becoming an attending physician in internal medicine and an associate in gastroenterology. Subsequently, he became medical director of the Daughters of Jacob and chairman of the Boro-Medical Group. He served in World War II as a captain in the Third Army with General Patton and was awarded the Croix de Guerre.

title: See the U.S.A. In a Chevrolet
description: ''I'd like a nice copy to show my kids,'' said Monte Hellman, the director of ''Two-Lane Blacktop.'' This week he got one when Anchor Bay released that classic 1971 road film, starring James Taylor, Warren Oates, Dennis Wilson and Laurie Bird, on tape and DVD. Either way is fine with Mr. Hellman; the movie has never been on video. But DVD is better, he said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERRIAM, JOSEPH P.
description: MERRIAM-Joseph P., 88, former Pound Ridge, New York resident, husband of the late Frances R. Merriam, in North Branford, CT., October 16, 1999. A management consultant with Cresap, McCormick & Paget, he retired as Vice Chairman in the mid 1970's. Towards the end of his career he specialized in helping museums with retail operations, including the Metropolitan Museum of Art's gift shop operations. He was active in Pound Ridge community affairs serving as President of the Businessmen's Association and the Hiram Halle Memorial Library board of trustees. Father of John P. Merriam of Montpelier, VT., and Abigail Merriam Lederman of Wyncote, PA.; brother of Richard P. Merriam of Ocala, FL., and Philip W. Merriam of Middletown, CT.; and grandfather of five.

title: Monsanto Says Its Profit Fell 54% in Quarter
description: The Monsanto Company reported that its third-quarter profit from continuing operations fell 54 percent, even as sales of its arthritis drug topped the billion-dollar mark for the year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARMENTER, CHARLES ROSS
description: PARMENTER-Charles Ross. In his 88th year, on October 18, 1999. Beloved uncle of Nina Visart of Pasadena, CA; Sandra Campbell of Toronto, Canada; and John Radcliff of British Columbia. Also survived by eight grandnieces and grandnephews. Ross was Music Editor of The New York Times from 1955-1964, having joined The Times in 1934. Also, he was author of 11 books and several unpublished manuscripts. In his later years, he became an acknowledged expert in the interpretation of early Mexican colonial pictorial manuscripts called lienzos. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Memorial service Saturday, October 23, 1999, at 2PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: Corrections
description: An article in House & Home yesterday about the increasing number of single women who own and maintain their homes misidentified the headquarters city of Owens Corning, a manufacturer of building materials. It is Toledo, Ohio, not Chicago.

title: A Scorsese Devil Hunt
description: PROP garbage on the streets of Hell's Kitchen helps set the early-90's tone for Martin Scorsese's ''Bringing Out the Dead.'' Though his latest film explores one more urban inferno and colorfully reaffirms Mr. Scorsese's role as the Dante of the Cinema, creating its air of nocturnal torment took some doing. After all, New York City has had its cosmetic makeover, and this filmmaker is rightly regarded as a national treasure. Yet old demons die hard, at least on this film's evidence. So Mr. Scorsese is still trawling Manhattan's underworld, looking for the devil he knows.

title: Mark Morrisroe
description: Pat Hearn Gallery

title: IRON MOUNTAIN TO BUY A RIVAL FOR $630 MILLION
description: Iron Mountain Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Pierce Leahy Corporation, a rival provider of records storage and information management services, for $630 million in stock. Iron Mountain will also assume about $570 million in Pierce Leahy debt. At Wednesday's closing price, the deal values each Pierce Leahy share about $37. But Iron Mountain's stock plunged 12 percent yesterday, falling $3.875 a share, to $26.625, on the New York Stock Exchange, and Pierce Leahy gained only 18.75 cents, to $26. Pierce Leahy's shareholders will own about 35 percent of the new company, which is expected to have $870 million in annual revenue and annualized earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization of about $240 million.

title: In a Man's World, Is a Subterranean Feminine Soul the Indomitable Muse?
description: ''Figurative Art From the 20th Century,'' a grab bag of sketches, paintings and sculptures at C & M Arts, has enough big names to justify its rather overreaching title. The roster includes Picasso, Matisse, Leger, Giacometti, de Kooning and other well-known suspects.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDELSTEIN, SARAH
description: EDELSTEIN-Sarah. The National Board of Hadassah, WZOA, mourns the death of Sarah Edelstein, mother of Leah Silverstein, our esteemed colleague. Our heartfelt condolences go to the entire family. May her memory be for a blessing. Bonnie Lipton, National President Dr. Laura S. Schor, National Executive Director

title: Scientists Find What May Be Oldest Trace Of Dinosaurs
description: Scientists have unearthed a trove of fossils in Madagascar, including the bones of two dinosaurs that may be the oldest ever found.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLASER, HELEN
description: GLASER-Helen. Passed away on Thursday, October 14th, 1999 in California. She is survived by two loving sisters, Elise Kapell and Claire Strauss. Helen held a Master's Degree in Language and Art & had an extensive art collection. She was a theater and ballet critic for several Palo Alto newspapers. Memorial services were held in San Francisco, California on Tuesday, October 19, 1999.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the legacy of the ecologist Aldo Leopold misstated the location of the Gila National Forest, a protected wilderness area he helped to establish. It is in New Mexico, not Arizona.

title: In Lowly Beads There's History As Well as Beauty
description: Diamonds may be a girl's best friend, but beads are for everybody. Their appeal is ancient, universal and primal.

title: As Gay People Face Old Age
description: To the Editor:

title: Inquiry Into Construction Bidding Brings 55 Guilty Pleas to Bribery
description: Thirty-one architects, real estate brokers and managers and 24 companies have pleaded guilty to bribery charges relating to bid rigging on construction projects ranging from the Bertelsmann skyscraper in Times Square to a bank on Wall Street, prosecutors said.

title: War Crimes and Exile
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Consultants Woo Employees by Offering a Piece of the Action
description: Help wanted: Prestigious firms, already offering six-figure salaries, will now let employees take up to two months off each year or get special access to Internet investment funds.

title: Big Day Looms In Stock Offer By Developer Of Optic Links
description: When Cisco Systems Inc. agreed to acquire the Cerent Corporation in August for almost $7 billion, many everyday investors had a common reaction: What is Cerent?

title: Weeding Out Terrorists
description: To the Editor:

title: Mattel's Earnings Tumble By 42% in Third Quarter
description: Mattel Inc. posted bleak third-quarter financial results yesterday, reporting a 42 percent earnings drop caused by a huge loss at a software company it spent $3.8 billion to acquire only five months ago.

title: Court Upholds Conviction Of Vichy Aide Who Has Fled
description: France's highest court today upheld the conviction of Maurice Papon, the 89-year-old former civil servant who announced Wednesday that he would live outside France rather than serve his 10-year jail sentence for sending hundreds of Jews to Nazi death camps.

title: He Puts On His Dress One Leg At a Time
description: The best part of ''Men Cry Bullets'' is not when Gloria's blond debutante cousin chases Gloria's pet pig, Jack, with an ax. The best part is when Gloria, having learned of the slaughter, leaps onto the dining room table and embraces the pork roast, sobbing, ''I'm a terrible mother.''

title: Midwest Wholesomeness, Big-City Wit
description: SELECTED LETTERS OF DAWN POWELL, 1913-1965

title: ZHONE TO ACQUIRE PREMISYS FOR $248 MILLION
description: Premisys Communications Inc., a telecommunications-equipment maker, agreed yesterday to be acquired by the closely held Zhone Technologies Inc. for about $248 million in cash. The shareholders of Premisys, which is based in Fremont, Calif., can tender their shares for $10 each, a price 35 percent less than its 52-week closing high of $15.375 last November. Premisys, with sales of $92.4 million for the year ended June 30, makes equipment that helps companies handle Internet traffic. Zhone, based in Oakland, Calif., was founded in September and is headed by three former executives of Ascend Communications Inc. The company provides communications equipment.

title: Rita Moreno, With Songs, Stories and Salt
description: For every song she sings in her effervescent cabaret act at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel, Rita Moreno has a salty anecdote or observation. At Wednesday's opening night performance of a show that runs through Nov. 13 (59 West 44th Street, Manhattan), Ms. Moreno, the singer and actress, told some funny New York stories. Recalling the language problems involved in moving from Puerto Rico to New York as a child (she was 5), she remembered how chagrined she was by a mother who confused y's with j's and pronounced long e's as short i's, sometimes with embarrassing results.

title: Gillette Issues Warning; Says It May Shed Units
description: The Gillette Company warned today of an unexpected drop in fourth-quarter profit and said that it might sell its Braun appliance and stationery-products businesses like Paper Mate and Parker pens, which have been pulling down its earnings.

title: A Woman On the Run, Racism Back Home
description: In ''Crazy in Alabama,'' a madcap woman named Lucille cuts off her husband's head and heads off to meet her destiny, which she hopes will involve the hit television series ''Bewitched'' (the year is 1965) and an acting career.

title: Police Officers Charged In Beating of Suspect
description: Two narcotics officers with the 33d Precinct in Washington Heights have been charged in connection with the beating of a suspect in their custody and then lying about the incident, the Manhattan District Attorney's office said yesterday.

title: 3 Staff Members Are Accused Of Selling Drugs at Group Home
description: Three employees of a foster care home operated by the city in the Bronx were arrested yesterday on charges that they sold heroin and cocaine at the home to an undercover agent posing as a staff member, the authorities said.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Is Harry Potter Evil?
description: I happened to be in London last summer on the very day ''Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban,'' the third book in the wildly popular series by J. K. Rowling, was published. I couldn't believe my good fortune. I rushed to the bookstore to buy a copy, knowing this simple act would put me up there with the best grandmas in the world. The book was still months away from publication in the United States, and I have an 8-year-old grandson who is a big Harry Potter fan.

title: New Video Releases
description: The Blair Witch Project

title: Survey Says 78.7 Million Own Stocks in United States
description: The number of stock owners in the nation soared to 78.7 million people early this year, 85 percent more than in 1983 when the long bull market was getting under way.

title: A Theory Is Behind Glavine's Game 1 Start
description: Bobby Cox says he does not know if the advantage that left-handed pitchers are said to enjoy in Yankee Stadium is real or imagined, but he will go along with theory for now. Hence, Cox, the Atlanta Braves' manager, named Tom Glavine as the Game 1 starter, assuring that he can start Game 5 in the Bronx if it is necessary.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: EVENTS

title: Clemens Happy to Get Game 4 Starting Call
description: During his tenure as manager of the Yankees, Joe Torre has forced a future Hall of Famer to platoon (Wade Boggs), benched an All-Star during the World Series (Tino Martinez in 1996) and replaced a former Gold Glove winner for reasons of defense (Chuck Knoblauch), all in the name of winning.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: No Knights To the Rescue

title: Surgery on Right Knee to Sideline Giants' Brown
description: The Giants, who lost their place-kicker, Brad Daluiso, for the season on Monday night with a freakish knee injury, may also lose their best running back, Gary Brown, with a knee injury.

title: Sports of The Times; El Duque Deserves To Open
description: IF the Yankees were a coin, its motto would be ''In El Duque We Trust.''

title: A Columbine Student Is Seized in a Threat to 'Finish the Job'
description: A Columbine High School senior is to face charges on Friday after threatening, the authorities say, to ''finish the job'' of the two classmates who in April shot to death 12 students and a teacher before killing themselves.

title: Chip Makers on Taiwan Are Soon Back in Business
description: The personal computer industry has a variety of things to worry about these days, but it turns out that supply problems from the deadly earthquake in Taiwan last month may not be one of them.

title: In Quiet Fields, Father Ritter Found His Exile; After Scandal, Covenant House Founder Had a Simple, Solitary Life Upstate
description: The dying priest celebrated Mass every day alone in his chapel overlooking nothing but wooded hills and the clover field where he knew he would be buried. He worked in his garden, he wrote, and he visited with friends who had remained in touch despite his scandal-stained public life, 200 miles and one decade away.

title: Appeals Judge Halts Release Of Immigrant
description: A Federal appeals court judge today blocked the release of a 31-year-old Palestinian immigrant who has been detained for 18 months on the basis of classified evidence of alleged links to terrorists. The judge also ruled that the case be taken up next week by a three-judge panel.

title: Questions About Author Halt Distribution of Book on Bush
description: A major New York publishing house suspended distribution and promotion of a controversial new biography of George W. Bush today after a Texas newspaper reported that the author was convicted 11 years ago of hiring a hit man in a failed attempt to murder his boss.

title: As Gay People Face Old Age
description: To the Editor:

title: Bombings in Chechnya
description: The gruesome bombing of a marketplace and maternity hospital yesterday in Grozny is the latest tragedy in what is becoming Russia's second full-blown war with Chechnya since the end of the Soviet era. The first war, which began five years ago, was a disaster for both tiny Chechnya and gigantic Russia, with Chechnya left charred and angry while the Russian military was humiliated by its own incompetence.

title: COURT ORDERS CITY TO ALLOW PROTEST BY KU KLUX KLAN
description: A Federal court ruled last night that the Ku Klux Klan must be allowed to demonstrate in lower Manhattan this weekend, saying that the Giuliani administration had violated the group's First Amendment rights by refusing to permit the rally if Klan members wore their traditional masks.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Kashmiris to Press Case, Trying Not to Be Forgotten
description: As the United Nations drew up plans in recent weeks to take over East Timor, a lonely band of Kashmiris was in the shadows, trying to make a case that their region, like East Timor, is still unfinished business for the United Nations and deserves more international attention.

title: A Key Senator Again Blocks the Banking Bill
description: For the second consecutive year, as legislation to overhaul the nation's financial system looked as though it had a good chance of passing Congress, Senator Phil Gramm, the Texas Republican who heads the Senate Banking Committee, stood in its path and brought the bill to a standstill.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, HAROLD
description: KAUFMAN-Harold. On October 20, 1999, in Lake Worth, FL. The world is a lesser place today. Tiger passed away peacefully surrounded by his family. Survived by his beloved wife and best friend, Jean; his loving children, Carol Haberman, Barbara and Kenneth Silver, and Stephen and Ronni Kaufman; his adored grandchildren, Lisa, Michael, Margo, Eric, Greg, Adam, Joshua and Jessica; his brother, Bernard, and his wife Harriet; his sister, Helene Gilinsky, his sister-in-law, Rhoda Klein & his wonderful cousin, Dr. Arnold Wechsler. Services 11:15AM on Friday, October 22, Beth Israel Memorial Chapel, Delray Beach, FL.

title: Adversity Brings Out Best in Braves
description: The Atlanta Braves are deflecting Team of the Decade questions like so many foul tips off a baseball bat, professing indifference to the opportunity to be designated baseball's best of the 1990's.

title: Strolling Among Ancient Monarchs
description: THE reinstallation of a museum's permanent collection may sound like a routine affair, pulled together in caffeine-fueled sessions of wall painting and heavy lifting. But it takes at least as much brain power as muscle to succeed.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: Quarterly Net More Than Triples at Tyco
description: Tyco International Ltd., the world's biggest maker of electronic connectors, said yesterday that fiscal fourth-quarter profit more than tripled on higher sales and cost cuts made at newly acquired companies.

title: Beijing Journal; When Parents Sin (in China's Eyes) Children Suffer
description: With a mother's anger and a mother's fear, Gou Qinghui displayed the empty green folder that is supposed to hold her baby boy's birth certificate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAZAR, ROSA
description: LAZAR-Rosa. The Congregation of Westchester Reform Temple mourns the death of its longtime and founding member and extends sympathy to her bereaved family. Marjorie Miller, President Richard J. Jacobs, Rabbi Kenneth M. Chasen, Asst. Rabbi Stephen Merkel, Cantor Jack Stern Jr., Rabbi Emeritus

title: Metro Business; Midtown Building Sale
description: Reckson Associates Realty Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire 1350 Avenue of the Americas for $126.5 million.

title: NOKIA'S PROFIT JUMPS
description: The biggest maker of cellular phones, the Finnish company Nokia, said its third-quarter profit rose 38 percent as new models outsold the competition. Net income rose more than expected, to 638 million euros ($687 million), from 464 million euros a year earlier. Nokia, Europe's fifth-largest company by market value, is designing sleek phones with sophisticated functions to beat competition from Motorola and Ericsson.

title: Suffragists Slept Here And Roused a Nation
description: ''I am at the boiling point!'' Elizabeth Cady Stanton wrote to Susan B. Anthony about the fledging women's rights movement in the spring of 1852. ''If I do not find some day the use of my tongue on this question, I shall die of an intellectual repression, a woman's rights convulsion! Oh, Susan! Susan! Susan! You must manage to spend a week with me before the Rochester convention, for I am afraid that I cannot attend it. . . . How much I do long to be free from housekeeping and children, so as to have some time to read and think and write.''

title: Mannesmann Shares Fall After $33 Billion Cellular Phone Bid
description: Mannesmann A.G., Germany's aggressive and acquisitive engineering and telecommunications giant, intensified the competition to dominate European mobile phone markets today, offering nearly $33 billion in stock and cash for Orange P.L.C., Britain's No. 3 cellular operator.

title: Anarchy Used to Be So Much Simpler
description: Simplicity never equals naivete for Faust, the venerable German band that performed on Monday night at the Knitting Factory. Its music used simple structures and modest technology -- drones and riffs, echo machines and wah-wah pedals -- for compositions with intimations of happy anarchy and looming disaster.

title: 3 Officers Are Indicted On Sex-Related Charges
description: A Brooklyn grand jury has indicted two New York City police officers on charges that they sodomized a female prisoner while on duty in Kings County Criminal Court and a third officer who was accused of encouraging the woman to accept a similar proposal.

title: Orange Police Head Who Quit Says U.S. Inquiry Was Not Cause
description: After announcing his resignation on Tuesday, the top official in the Orange Police Department said today that his departure was not a result of a Federal inquiry into the department's handling of a murder investigation earlier this year.

title: WIND RIVER MAKES STOCK DEAL FOR INTEGRATED SYSTEMS
description: Wind River Systems Inc., a maker of software for consumer electronics, said late yesterday that in its biggest acquisition to date, it planned to buy a rival, Integrated Systems, for $437 million in stock. Wind will pay 0.92 of a share for each share of Integrated Systems, which works out to a 75 percent premium above yesterday's closing price. Wind, which is based in Sunnyvale, Calif., and employs 800, plans to keep all 700 employees of Integrated Systems, based in nearby Alameda, Calif. Wind provides software that runs on embedded chips used in products like microwave ovens and cellular telephones. Integrated Systems' products speed up the design of embedded software. Wind's shares fell 93.75 cents yesterday, to $20.625; those of Integrated Systems were off 12.5 cents, at $10.5625.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERKINS, JAMES B.
description: PERKINS-James B., a resident of Stamford, CT. died of cancer, on October 14, 1999 at his home. Born June 29, 1919, Plainfield, NJ, son of the late Seymour and Maude R. Perkins. Graduate of Rutgers University, Veteran of WWII, associated with Deering Milliken Inc. and Springs Industries until his retirement in 1985. Survived by his wife Billie M. Perkins; sons: James B. Perkins Jr., John W. Perkins, Jeffrey M. Perkins and a daughter Suzanne Perkins; his sister Mrs. Susan Jarrell. Predeceased by his brother Seymour Perkins Jr. Services private. Memorials may be made to Bennett Cancer Center, Shelburne Road, Stamford, CT. 06902 or Hospice Care, 1029 Main Street, Stamford, CT. 06902.

title: The D.A. and the F.B.I.
description: To the Editor:

title: Growing Up With a Defect, and Charm and Mischief
description: In ''Sixth Happiness,'' a boy who cannot grow grows up.

title: CANADIAN PACIFIC'S STRONG RESULTS
description: Higher oil prices and increased rail traffic contributed to a 32 percent gain in Canadian Pacific's third-quarter earnings, to a record $270 million (Canadian), or about $181 million (United States). The results were stronger than expected for the company, which operates a railroad as well as businesses in shipping, energy, hotels and real estate.

title: N.T.T. TO REORGANIZE
description: The world's largest phone company, the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation of Japan, confirmed that it would reorganize within three years by cutting jobs at local units. N.T.T. will work to complete ''as soon as possible'' a plan starting in the next fiscal year, said Kanji Koide, a senior vice president at N.T.T. Under the plan, N.T.T. will transfer some employees to its affiliates and not fill the positions of people who retire. The company would not specify how many positions would be eliminated.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Supreme Court Roundup on Oct. 13 about an agreement to hear Kenneth W. Starr's appeal of a case growing out of his prosecution of Webster L. Hubbell referred incorrectly to Mr. Starr's defense of an indictment of Mr. Hubbell on tax charges. Mr. Starr argued that a grant of immunity applied only to the act of producing documents and did not provide immunity with respect to the contents of the documents.

title: New Mistake Mars Report On Math Test
description: The company that miscalculated the test scores of thousands of New York City students last spring has fumbled again, printing math scores for all of the state's eighth graders on the wrong forms.

title: Spare Lyre For Orpheus
description: ''Operation: Orfeo,'' at the Brooklyn Academy of Music through tomorrow, is part of both the Next Wave Festival and New Europe '99, a citywide celebration of a new generation of European performing artists.

title: Bradley Offers Plan To Cut Child Poverty
description: Former Senator Bill Bradley called for reducing the number of poor children by half in the next decade by raising the minimum wage, increasing spending on child-care programs and providing an array of tax benefits to poor parents who work.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Rise 4.7% on New York Exchange
description: Open positions of short sales on the New York Stock Exchange increased 4.7 percent in the most recent monthly period, the exchange said yesterday. Uncovered short sales rose to 3.99 billion shares for the month ended Oct. 15, compared with 3.81 billion shares in September.

title: Viacom, Posting Strong Net, Affirms Plan on Blockbuster
description: Sumner M. Redstone, the chairman and chief executive of Viacom, said yesterday that the company would stick with its plans to spin off Blockbuster, the video rental company, to shareholders early in 2000.

title: What Public Schools Can Offer
description: To the Editor:

title: BRAZIL MOVE TO SAVE JOBS
description: In a move to ease unemployment pressure, Brazil's lower house of Congress approved a bill prohibiting self-service gasoline stations. The bill's supporters hope to save the jobs of about 300,000 attendants at 27,000 gas stations. The bill is sponsored by Brazil's Communist Party.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: LG&E ENERGY CORP., Louisville, Kentucky's largest utility owner, agreed to buy six natural-gas turbines and six steam generators from General Electric Co., Fairfield, Conn., for a power plant it plans to build in Texas. Terms of the contract were not disclosed.

title: Mergers Bring Luxury Goods To the Global Middle Class
description: ROME  Well-heeled customers searching for Gucci shoes or Louis Vuitton luggage in earlier days had to venture to the most exclusive shopping districts such as the Rue du Faubourg Saint-Honore in Paris or Bond Street in London.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPSTEIN, JACK
description: EPSTEIN-Jack. An extraordinary person. For 93 years he brought a sense of joy and boundless energy to all aspects of his life and amazement to all who met him. He was a tireless worker for Union Temple of Brooklyn, Deborah Hospital, Child Care and other charitable organizations. His love and devotion for his late wife, Irene, was legendary. His entire family, children, grandchildren, great grandchildren, brothers, sister, nieces and nephews loved him enormously and feel fortunate to have had Jack in their lives for all these action-packed years. Funeral service will be held at Boulevard-Riverside Chapel, 1895 Flatbush Ave, Brooklyn, NY, on Sunday, October 24, 1999 at 11:30 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JULIA, RAUL
description: JULIA-Raul. A Mass will be held in honor of the late Raul Julia at Holy Trinity Church, 213 West 82nd Street on Saturday, October 23 at 6:30PM. October 24 marks the fifth anniversary of Mr. Julia's death.

title: Titans Understand What Is in a Name
description: Eddie George grimaced when he was asked to recall his initial days as a Houston Oiler and then as a Tennessee Oiler before becoming a Tennessee Titan. For this fleet, powerful running back, the task seemed more troublesome than a fourth-and-1 run into the teeth of a vicious defense.

title: Council Ready to Transfer East Timor to U.N.
description: An international administration for East Timor, backed by 10,000 troops, is widely expected to be approved by the Security Council in the next few days. That would open the way for a formal transfer of authority in the territory from Indonesia to the United Nations, officially ending a quarter-century of Indonesian rule.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PERRY, EDWARD C.
description: PERRY-Edward C. June 27, 1908 to October 22, 1993. Dear Edward, your spirit is always with me, your presence is greatly missed. Much love, Fito

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHEINMAN, DIANA
description: SCHEINMAN-Diana. (nee Friedenberg). Of York, PA. On October 21, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Sidney. Devoted mother of David, Robert and Daniel. Cherished grandmother of Nina and Jay. Services at Temple Beth Israel, York, PA, Monday, October 25th, 11AM. Contributions may be made to a favorite charity.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: By a Wide Margin, House Renews School Aid to the Poor
description: In a rare display of bipartisanship, the House voted overwhelmingly today to renew for five years the largest Federal program to help educate poor children.

title: When Driving Was Fun
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''To all my children throughout the nation, I beg you sincerely to return to work. Do not be goaded into emotional actions, because what you see here today is your mother standing before you.''

title: Rangers, Feeling Desperate, Pondered Calling Up Daigle
description: The Rangers head into Friday night's rematch with the Philadelphia Flyers at Madison Square Garden on what seems a note of desperation.

title: In Prospect Park
description: Prospect Park, the jewel in the crown of Brooklyn, is undergoing a renaissance. A foray through the 526-acre swath of green offers gracefully landscaped paths for the jogger (below), a cosmopolitan mix of visitors and a backyard for neighborhood families.

title: 'Trippy World'
description: Baron/Boisante

title: He's Not Gay but Pretends to Be. Chaos Ensues.
description: ''Three to Tango,'' a leering screwball sex comedy set in contemporary Chicago, is like an overly boisterous party guest who is so nervous meeting strangers that he compulsively spews out bawdy jokes in a loud, belligerent voice. As it turns out, the movie has plenty of reason to be nervous. For the tolerance toward homosexuality exhibited by the story of Oscar Novak (Matthew Perry), an avidly heterosexual architect who, for business reasons, is coerced into pretending he's gay, often feels strained and shallow.

title: The Lives of McCain-Feingold
description: Trent Lott declared the McCain-Feingold campaign finance reform bill dead on Tuesday when it failed to overcome the roadblocks thrown in its way by, among others, Mr. Lott. Mitch McConnell, the Senate Republicans' chief fund-raiser, said the bill had made no headway in gaining support. They were being deceptive. In fact, the test votes this week reflected significant progress, with 55 senators -- including 10 Republicans, 3 more than were on board this summer -- endorsing a soft-money ban in one form or another. That base can be expanded if Mr. McCain and other supporters make good on their promise to bring this measure up again and again, forcing the Senate to deal with it.

title: U.S. Moves to Shut Down the 'Chutzpah Trust'
description: The Government is moving to shut down the latest version of what critics call the ''chutzpah trust,'' under which a legitimate charitable-giving device is adapted to let wealthy donors escape all taxes.

title: The Schools and the Constitution
description: Everyone knows that New York City's schools are in desperate straits, with hordes of students failing to graduate, too many uncredentialed teachers, and facilities that are crowded and decaying. But a state court in Manhattan will now have to determine whether the schools are in such abysmal shape that they violate the state Constitution's mandate that all children be provided an education.

title: COMPASS BANCSHARES ADDS TO HOLDINGS IN TEXAS
description: Compass Bancshares Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired Hartland Bank N.A. of Austin, Tex., for $86 million in cash. Hartland has six branches in Austin, increasing the number of Compass branches there to 19. Compass, which is based in Birmingham, Ala., now has 295 branches in Texas, Arizona, Alabama and Florida. Hartland has assets of $300 million, while Compass has about $17.7 billion. Compass's shares fell 25 cents, to $24.9375, in Nasdaq trading yesterday.

title: Quality Day Care, Early, Is Tied to Achievements as an Adult
description: Good early childhood education has a powerful influence on poor children that lasts into young adulthood, affecting things like reading and mathematics skills and even the timing of childbearing, researchers announced today, citing the first study ever to track participants from infancy to age 21.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOUIS, SUSANNE M.
description: LOUIS-Susanne M. We wish to announce the passing of our beloved mother and grandmother Susy on October 20. She passed away peacefully at home. She experienced life to the fullest and gave very much to very many. The family wishes to thank Eva, Maria, Shirley, Fastina and, above all, Dr. John Capriccio, for their love and care. Memorial service to be announced.

title: With That Wascally Wabbit, That's Not All, Folks
description: Operatic rabbits, enigmatic frogs, vexatious birds and hotheaded hunters and hombres are running amok in Greenwich Village, and there's still more than a week to go before Halloween.

title: Deserted but Determined
description: Buried inside the news pages of The Palm Beach Post from Dec. 18, 1990, are 180 words. They tell of a 13-year-old boy, Ronald Jean, barely 5 feet and 100 pounds, who was abandoned by his mother at a Greyhound bus station three months earlier.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SESLOWE, SAM
description: SESLOWE-Sam. Died on October 21, 1999. Beloved husband of Pauline. Loving father of Kenneth and Judy and Jerry and Marsha. Devoted grandfather of Emily and Alan Rosenfeld, Jonathan, Lisa and Stacey Seslowe and greatgrandfather of Aerin and Chloe. Graveside services Friday 11AM at Knollwood Park Cemetery, Brooklyn, N.Y.

title: Inquiry Casts Shadow on Agency Meant to Help New York Revival
description: For five years, the Empire State Development Corporation, the state agency charged with fostering a climate conducive to business, has been credited with helping to rejuvenate New York with its efforts to create jobs, eliminate red tape and direct ambitious projects like the redevelopment of Times Square.

title: INSIDE
description: House Passes Education Bill

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHMAN, FRITZIE
description: ROTHMAN-Fritzie nee Steigerwald. On October 20, in her 89th year. Dear cousin of the late Esther Strunsky and of Frances Whitney.

title: Loggers Find Canada Rain Forest Flush With Foes
description: Disembarking from an inflatable boat at James Bay, a party of eco-tourists hiked one recent morning into a primeval cathedral of the world's largest temperate rain forest.

title: A Modest Hero Who Drops From the Sky
description: The first call about the lady with the lump in her breast came to the 109th Airlift Wing of the New York Air National Guard in June.

title: Board Delays Release Date For Immigrant
description: A three-member panel of the Board of Immigration Appeals, in a sharply divided decision today, delayed until midnight on Monday its order releasing a 31-year-old Palestinian immigrant who has been detained in prison for 18 months on secret evidence accusing him of being connected with terrorist groups.

title: Lois Chapter 11 Signals a Shift In Ad Industry
description: An era may be coming to an end in New York advertising. George Lois, the colorful, outspoken art director who has created some of the best-known campaigns of the last four decades, has filed for bankruptcy for his agency company, Lois/USA.

title: In a Child's Tiny Bricks, The Logic Of Computers
description: Some 50 years ago, the science fiction writer Isaac Asimov formulated the three laws of robotics. The first is, ''A robot may not injure a human being or, through inaction, allow a human being to come to harm.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'LEARY, JOHN W. SR.
description: O'LEARY-John W. Sr., a resident of Lake Placid, NY died on Oct. 15 at the Adirondack Medical Center. Born March 31, 1929, in Elizabeth, NJ, son of the late Dennis and Ann Mahoney O'Leary. Graduate of Lehigh University. Associated with Ingersol Rand/Dresser Rand for 42 years. Survived by sons, William Jr., Peter, Richard, Paul and Joseph O'Leary and daughters, Hope Frenette & Constance Keller and 16 grandchildren. A service will be held Monday at 10:30 AM at Saint Agnes Church, Lake Placid. Memorial contributions may be made to Adirondack Medical Center Capital Campaign, P.O. Box 120, Saranac Lake, NY 12983 or the American Cancer Society.

title: Giuliani Has A Candidate For Mayor, But in Indiana
description: As part of his continuing program to be a dutiful member of his party, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani campaigned here today for the Republican candidate for mayor who is seeking the seat held by the outgoing Republican incumbent, Stephen Goldsmith.

title: Parcells Is Flicking a Switch To Turn On the Passing Game
description: In a behind-the-scenes move to make some thing anything -- happen to the Jets' anemic passing game, Coach Bill Parcells has put his offensive coordinator, Charlie Weis, in charge of the wide receivers as well.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENLER, JOE
description: KENLER-Joe. Beloved husband of Hannah. Devoted father of Robert, Elaine Trager, Janet Seligman and Joan Berger. Cherished grandfather of Lori, Michael, Victoria, Catherine, Andrew & David, and great-grandfather. ''He will be missed.'' Services Sunday, 9 AM, ''Sinai Chapels,'' 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, New York.

title: New York Runners Take Center Stage
description: Belmont Park will stage its annual tournament for race horses bred in New York State today, with 72 horses competing in seven stakes races with purses totaling more than $1 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATORIN, IRVING
description: MATORIN-Irving. Age 89, of Neponsit, NY, died on October 21, 1999 in New York City. A brother of True Craftsman's Lodge #

title: HEINZ ADDING UNITED BISCUITS' FROZEN FOODS
description: H. J. Heinz & Company, the world's largest ketchup maker, agreed yesterday to buy the frozen-foods unit of United Biscuits Holdings P.L.C. for about $317 million in cash. United Biscuits' frozen-foods business had about $360 million in sales in 1998 and employs about 3,000 at plants in Britain and Spain. Heinz said its offerings would join its Weight Watchers frozen meals in Britain, where frozen-food sales are rising at about 5 percent to 10 percent a year. United Biscuits, which is based in Edinburgh and is Britain's biggest cookie maker, put its frozen-foods business up for sale to focus on its main McVitie's cookie unit and KP snacks business, which are expanding in Europe. Shares of Heinz, which is based in Pittsburgh, fell 93.75 cents, to $45.50.

title: A Timor Leader's Emotional Return
description: With controlled fury, as if with each word he could begin to rebuild his shattered homeland, the leader of East Timor, Jose Alexandre Gusmao, exhorted his weeping countrymen today to show the world their strength.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIRNBAUM, LEE
description: BIRNBAUM-Lee. On October 21, 1999. Loving wife of the late Robert Birnbaum, beloved mother of Karen Stechel & Ronnie. Loving mother-in-law of Temi and Dr. Richard Stechel. Cherished grandmother of Jaime, Erica, Matthew &Todd. Services at Guttermans's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, New York, Sunday, 11:45AM. She will be in our hearts forever.

title: First, Teach Basics
description: To the Editor:

title: On Web, Models Auction Their Eggs to Bidders for Beautiful Children
description: To the horror and disgust of mainstream infertility groups, a longtime fashion photographer has begun offering up models as egg donors to the highest bidders, auctioning their ova via the Internet to would-be parents willing to pay up to $150,000 in hopes of having a beautiful child.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLARSKY, WILLIAM, M.D.
description: WOLARSKY-William, M.D. On October 16, 1999 in Palm Beach, Florida. Beloved husband of Anne (Rosengarten), loving father of Ellen Kuris of Princeton, NJ, and Dr. Evan R. Wolarsky of Pennington, NJ, devoted father-inlaw of Rosalie Wolarsky and Dr. Jay Kuris. Proud grandfather of Jeremy, Benjamin and Gabriel Kuris and Eric and Nina Wolarsky. Dr. Wolarsky was on staff at Bronx Lebanon Hospital from his internship in 1933 to 1975, becoming an attending physician in internal medicine and an associate in gastroenterology. Subsequently, he became medical director of the Daughters of Jacob and chairman of the Boro-Medical Group. He served in World War II as a captain in the Third Army with General Patton and was awarded the Croix de Guerre.

title: THE CABLE GUYS
description: Jesse Ventura and Pat Buchanan and Ross Perot would be nowhere without the new media and their need for spectacle and outrage. But even a pop-culture candidate can have an idea or two worth wrestling with. In The Times Magazine

title: Braves Make Sharp Left Turn for Relief
description: ''They're just as effective against right-handed hitters as they are against left-handed hitters,'' Leo Mazzone, the Braves' pitching coach, said today. ''So really, when you bring them in, it doesn't matter if the hitter is left-handed or right-handed.''

title: Corrections
description: Articles on Tuesday and Thursday about Republican opposition to President Clinton's nomination of Carol Moseley-Braun as Ambassador to New Zealand referred incorrectly to a Confederate flag that was at issue in 1993 when Ms. Moseley-Braun, as Senator from Illinois, persuaded the Senate to reject a renewed patent for an emblem for the United Daughters of the Confederacy. (A similar error occurred in an earlier article, on July 23, 1993.) The emblem included the Stars and Bars, the first national flag of the Confederacy -- not the later Confederate battle flag.

title: NO PROGRESS IN DAEWOO TALKS
description: Negotiations between South Korea's ailing Daewoo Group and its foreign creditors have shown no special progress, a Citigroup vice chairman, H. Onno Ruding, said. Mr. Ruding, who is attending the Seoul Economic Forum 1999, told reporters that the lack of progress could damage the credibility of South Korea and its conglomerates. Samuel Len

title: NORTH KOREAN TV VIEWED IN SOUTH
description: The South Korean Government is allowing domestic news corporations to show North Korean satellite TV broadcasts. Private citizens can also view North Korean satellite broadcasts at special sites, a Unification Ministry spokesman said. In the past, Seoul selected and filtered North Korean programs for domestic television stations and newspaper companies, citing national security concerns. The North began its satellite TV broadcasts in June.

title: U.S. Missile Defense
description: To the Editor:

title: Expert Disputes Schizophrenia Defense
description: A psychologist testifying for the prosecution said yesterday that the man accused of killing a woman by pushing her in front of a subway train may be exaggerating his mental illness.

title: Iran's Former Hanging Judge Now Sides With Reformers
description: Much about Ayatollah Sadegh Khalkhali these days his simple white smock, his bare feet, his shuffling gait, his concern for his visitors' well-being -- speaks of an almost penitential gentleness. Long gone are his days as the chief judge of Iran's revolutionary courts, when his name was enough to strike terror, his word sufficient to set execution squads to work with their gallows, their shootings and their stonings.

title: Yankees' Jeter Has A Wonderful Life
description: When Derek Jeter eases out of the dugout at Yankee Stadium or glides along the streets of the Upper East Side or hustles through a hotel lobby in any city, it is fascinating to watch the people who find themselves near him. They point, they whisper, they nod. Some squeal.

title: Gore Is Playing Leapfrog With Bradley's Schedule
description: So here is a little oddity from the campaign trail: Former Senator Bill Bradley discussed child poverty at a Baptist church in Bedford-Stuyvesant on Thursday. Vice President Al Gore, Mr. Bradley's only rival for the Democratic Presidential nomination, gave a speech about child poverty at a Methodist church in Washington on Wednesday.

title: POSSIBLE EMBRAER DEAL
description: Shares in the jet aircraft producer Empresa Brasileira de Aeronautica, or Embraer, were suspended from trading on the Sao Paulo stock exchange pending an announcement from the company planned for Monday. Speculation that Embraer could announce the sale of a minority stake to a European aerospace company like Dassault Aviation; Saab, a unit of Investor, or British Aerospace pushed the company's shares up more than 10 percent this week. Foreign aircraft producers have been courting Embraer because of the company's success in selling small passenger jets.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COTTER, WILLIAM
description: COTTER-William. October 23, 1998. Dearest Will, one lonely year without you. You are forever in my heart. Love always, Elaine.

title: Hard Hats and Cranes Abloom in City Center
description: Fourteen years ago, Dean Jernigan, son of a carpenter and a department store clerk, sensed the stirrings of a trend. ''I saw major consumption,'' he said, ''a society that likes to collect things.'' Too many things for attics and storerooms.

title: Biggest Trash Hauler in U.S. Says It Will Take a Charge
description: Waste Management, the nation's largest trash hauler, said today that it expected to take a third-quarter charge and have lower 1999 earnings because an audit found irregularities with its accounting.

title: Citing Distrust of Author, Publisher Kills Book on Bush
description: St. Martin's Press, the publisher of a controversial biography of George W. Bush, took the unusual step of killing the disputed book yesterday, issuing an alert to booksellers around the country to return thousands of copies for shredding or burning because company executives no longer trusted the author.

title: Warrick Returns for Bowden Versus Bowden
description: The Bowdens will have Clemson's Memorial Stadium covered tonight. Ann will sit on the Florida State side of the field to cheer her husband, Bobby, with their daughter Ginger. Another daughter, Robyn, is married to the Tigers' defensive backs coach, Jack Hines, so she will remain on the Clemson side.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 14 about the Rhode Island Attorney General's suit against paint manufacturers for the cost of removing lead paint from buildings included an erroneous reference to a comparable issue in New York. The city sued a group of manufacturers in 1989; it is not merely looking at the possibility. The suit is still pending.

title: Air Force Willing to Abandon Joint Fighter to Save the F-22
description: To save its expensive F-22 jet fighter from Congressional budget-cutters, the Air Force is willing to sacrifice another, less-costly new jet fighter -- to the consternation of the Navy and the Marines who also want to use the cheaper jet, a senior Air Force official said.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COLLINS, BROTHER JAMES X.
description: COLLINS-Brother James X. Sixth anniversary. Our thoughts and prayers are always with you. Your many friends from Manhattan College and around the world.

title: A Rare Dictionary Is Born, the Product of an Immigrant's Life on the Margin
description: The first thing you should know about Felipe Lopez, who immigrated from Oaxaca 21 years ago in the trunk of a smuggler's car, is that his name is not really Felipe Lopez, and that he does not consider himself Mexican.

title: Still the Capital of Free Speech?
description: To the Editor:

title: 5 G.O.P. Hopefuls Kick Off Debates
description: In the first televised debate of the 2000 Presidential campaign, five Republican candidates last night excoriated President Clinton for his stewardship of foreign policy and virtually ignored the front-runner who did not take part, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas.

title: Unverified Account Spawned Many News Reports
description: An old allegation about George W. Bush, recycled by anonymous sources in a book that has been withdrawn by its publisher, was widely reported last week, even by news organizations whose reporters had long since decided that the rumor was probably false.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARSTOW, RICHARD I.
description: BARSTOW-Richard I. who, for 50 years, practiced medicine from his office in Norfolk, CT, died peacefully October 19, 1999 in Middlebury, VT, surrounded by his family. He was 93. Born in 1906, he opened his medical practice in Norfolk in 1936, retiring in 1986. A memorial service will be held Saturday, October 30, 11 AM, Church of Christ Congregational, Norfolk, CT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHER, BERNARD
description: FISCHER-Bernard. Beloved husband of Alva. Loving father of Ronald, Richard & Debra & father-inlaw of Patti and Beth. Adoring grandfather of Simon, Dena and Marlee. Devoted brother. Services Sunday 12 noon at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: Tyson Reaches to the Past To Jump-Start His Career
description: Mike Tyson started this year against Francois Botha on Jan. 16, a bout that was supposed to kick off an ambitious schedule of four fights designed to help Tyson regain respect and viability in the heavyweight division. He was coming off an 18-month layoff resulting from the revocation of his boxing license in Nevada for biting Evander Holyfield's ears during a June 29, 1997, bout.

title: Shrunken and Splintered Klan Is Still a Potent Lure for the Disaffected
description: Two years ago and at the behest of some new friends, James W. Sheeley left the upstate home he shares with his mother and twin brother and drove eight hours to western Pennsylvania. There, a large cross in flames melted away his life's frustrations, and he knew what he wanted to be.

title: After Early Struggles, Glavine Regains Old Form
description: The changeup had deserted him and the strike zone had shrunk and then the doubt crept in on Tom Glavine. The defending Cy Young award winner, who will start Game 1 of the World Series for the Atlanta Braves on Saturday night, had such an uncharacteristically poor beginning to this season that opponents, for at least a few months, could believe that one of the most reliable pitchers of the decade was perhaps wearing down, befuddled by a newly consistent strike zone that seemed to take away the outside corner on which he thrived.

title: Lead to Beat a Fatal Squeeze Found Only in Post-Mortems
description: A most unusual defense was called for on the diagramed deal, and although many players uncovered it in the post-mortem, none of them saw it in the course of the action. It occurred during the Open Pairs Championship at the start of the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals in March.

title: Treating Asthma Like an Allergy
description: To the Editor:

title: Judges Award Hamed A Unanimous Decision
description: Naseem Hamed is known as much for his entrance into the ring as he is for his boxing skills. For about 10 minutes tonight, he turned downtown Detroit into Las Vegas, dancing to a Motown song, gyrating on a stage with exploding fireworks and rockets.

title: KOREAN EXPORT PROJECTIONS
description: South Korea's exports will surpass $140 billion this year for the first time, the Commerce, Industry and Energy Ministry said. The recovery in the global economy, stable foreign exchange rates and higher export prices for key South Korean products are reasons behind the optimistic projection, the ministry said. It had earlier projected that exports would reach $134 billion and later revised its projection to $139 billion. Samuel Len

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHMIDT, BENNO
description: SCHMIDT-Benno. The Board of Govenors and membership of Deepdale Golf Club note with sorrow the untimely passing of our esteemed member. Our deepest sympathy is extended to the bereaved family. Irwin H. Kramer, President

title: Expatriates Take Over in West : Shifting Scene In Chinese Art
description: NEW YORK  Slowly, irresistibly, the Chinese art scene in the West, from auction houses to museums, is passing into the hands of the multifaceted expatriate Chinese elite.

title: Belgrade Says Montenegrins Will Decide Their Own Future
description: Yugoslav officials today played down the possibility of armed confrontation between Serbia and Montenegro, saying the Montenegrins would themselves decide whether to remain within Yugoslavia.

title: Paralegal Divorce Firms Assailed
description: They call out with flashy signs, subway banners and ads in the Yellow Pages, promising to deliver hassle-free divorces at rock-bottom prices. Some say they can do it by mail, while others assure ''no signature required.''

title: Appeals Court Bars Klan Masks; Group Still Plans to Stage Rally
description: A Federal appeals court blocked a lower court decision yesterday and barred members of the Ku Klux Klan from rallying in lower Manhattan today with their faces shielded by masks. The decision was a victory for the Giuliani administration.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GOSS GRAPHIC SYSTEMS, Westmont, Ill., which makes printing presses, won approval for its prenegotiated bankruptcy plan of reorganization, which includes provisions to reimburse trade creditors on a nine-month time-payment plan.

title: OMNIPOINT SET TO TAKE OVER EAST/WEST COMMUNICATIONS
description: The Omnipoint Corporation, a wireless provider, agreed yesterday to acquire East/West Communications Inc. and its five wireless licenses for $121 million in stock and cash. The acquisition of East/West, which is based in Rye, N.Y., gives Omnipoint wireless licenses covering a population of 22.2 million in Los Angeles; Washington; Sarasota, Fla.; Reno, and Santa Barbara, Calif. Omnipoint said it paid $3 million for 300,000 East/West shares and agreed to buy the remaining 4.4 million shares for newly issued preferred shares worth $118 million. Omnipoint, based in Bethesda, Md., said it would assume $15 million in debt and redeem $8 million in East/West preferred shares.

title: 6,000 U.N. Peacekeepers Planned for Sierra Leone
description: The Security Council voted today to authorize a 6,000-member peacekeeping force for Sierra Leone, where an uneasy coalition of elected officials and former rebels has pledged to restore order after the latest round of a civil war.

title: Italian Entry Overcomes Storm and America One
description: Luna Rossa, the swift, stylish Italian entry in the America's Cup challengers series, recorded its seventh straight victory today -- but by only 150 feet after a dramatic, storm-swept, 12-mile duel with the previously unbeaten San Francisco yacht America One.

title: Atlantans Take Genteel Aim At Another New York Team
description: Even within Atlanta's gauzy fantasy of itself as the chivalrous competitor, far too polite to pour beer on an enemy fan, there is room for a dream of serial slaughter.

title: Regulating Hog Farms
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIGHT ERICSSON OUTLOOK
description: The world's thirdlargest mobile phone maker, Ericsson, raised its estimate for 1999 sales and posted better-than-expected earnings because of increasing demand for its network equipment and mobile phones. Ericsson's shares soared to a record high. The company's third-quarter net income fell 16 percent, to 2.6 billion kronor ($321 million), from 3.1 billion a year ago. Analysts informally surveyed had forecast only 2.34 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ELAHI, CYRUS
description: ELAHI-Cyrus. One with love in his heart never dies.

title: REPUBLICANS SEEK A UNIFORM PARING OF 1.4% IN BUDGET
description: Republican leaders in Congress announced a plan today to reduce Government spending across the board by 1.4 percent.

title: Giants' Brown Lost for Season as the Cycle Goes On
description: Gary Brown to LeShon Johnson to Sean Bennett, then back to Brown, then back to Bennett, then Johnson, then Brown and finally this week back to Johnson again -- with the rookie Joe Montgomery waiting impetuously in the wings.

title: Experts Say Lapses Led to Japan's A-Plant Failure
description: The Japanese nuclear accident three weeks ago occurred largely because managers counted on workers to follow rules but never explained why the rules were important, three Energy Department experts said today, after touring the plant this week.

title: Healthy Battle of Agendas
description: Further evidence of a real contest for the Democratic Presidential nomination, if any were needed, can be found in the fact that both Vice President Gore and former Senator Bill Bradley are moving aggressively to lay out specific policy positions on various issues. This is a positive development. In the early stages of a campaign, candidates tend to narrow the field of fire by avoiding detailed agendas and sticking with safe generalizations. For different reasons -- Mr. Bradley because he wants greater credibility and Mr. Gore because he needs greater traction -- neither man has that luxury. Both have already offered prescriptions for improving the health care system. On Thursday, Mr. Bradley offered some bold ideas on poverty while Mr. Gore risked the wrath of the oil companies with a challenging proposal on offshore drilling.

title: World Bank Suspects Russian Passed Data to Moscow Bank
description: The World Bank said today that it was launching an investigation ''as a matter of urgency'' into the actions of a former member of Russia's delegation to the international development institution who is suspected of passing insider information to a major Russian bank.

title: The Misfire That Wounded Colt's
description: If Eliot Spitzer, New York State's Attorney General, has his way, more of the nation's gun manufacturers will follow the lead of the Colt's Manufacturing Company and cut back big parts of their business to please the advocates of gun control.

title: Bernie Privin, 80, Big-Band Trumpeter
description: Bernie Privin, a big-band trumpeter who performed and recorded with Tommy Dorsey, Benny Goodman, Artie Shaw, Louis Armstrong and others, died on Oct. 8 in White Plains Hospital in White Plains, N.Y. He was 80 and lived in Hartsdale.

title: Corrections
description: The obituary of Wilt Chamberlain on Oct. 13 misstated his year in college when he led the University of Kansas to the N.C.A.A. title game. He was a sophomore, not a junior.

title: Big Gains By Gramm In Diluting Lending Act
description: Community-lending advocates and banking industry officials found one thing to agree on yesterday about the rewrite of the Community Reinvestment Act: It is not going to improve lending in poor neighborhoods.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 4 about an alliance of environmental groups and labor unions to protect jobs and the environment referred incorrectly to a World Trade Organization ruling on a United States law banning the import of shrimp caught in nets that endanger sea turtles. An appellate panel of the trade organization ruled that the United States must stop applying the law in a discriminatory manner. It did not overturn the law.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Agreement to Overhaul Nation's Financial System

title: Gun Control and Suicide
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Deadlines In Nassau: Election Day And Budget
description: The last reel of Nassau County's most interesting off-year election campaign in memory is playing out like a cliffhanger.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: Today's KEY GAMES

title: Wilma Curley, 62, Ballet and Broadway Dancer
description: Wilma Curley, a ballet and Broadway dancer who became noted for restaging works by Jerome Robbins, died on Oct. 16 at St. Luke's Hospital in Manhattan. She was 62 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARMENTER, CHARLES ROSS
description: PARMENTER-Charles Ross. In his 88th year, on October 18, 1999. Beloved uncle of Nina Visart of Pasadena, CA; Sandra Campbell of Toronto, Canada; and John Radcliff of British Columbia. Also survived by eight grandnieces and grandnephews. Ross was Music Editor of The New York Times from 1955-1964, having joined The Times in 1934. Also, he was author of 11 books and several unpublished manuscripts. In his later years, he became an acknowledged expert in the interpretation of early Mexican colonial pictorial manuscripts called lienzos. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Memorial service Saturday, October 23, 1999, at 2PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Contributions in his memory may be made to the 92nd Street Y.

title: AGILENT TECHNOLOGIES UNIT TO RAISE $1.1 BILLION
description: Agilent Technologies Inc., the test and measurement instrument company owned by the Hewlett-Packard Company, disclosed yesterday that its initial public offering would raise about $1.1 billion. The sale will consist of 57 million common shares offered at $19 to $22 each, according to an amended registration statement that Agilent filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Agilent did not provide details about the size and price of the offering when it initially filed in August. The public will own 13 percent of Agilent after the initial offering, with the remaining shares held by Hewlett-Packard. Agilent will have 437 million shares outstanding after the offering. Assuming a price of $20.50, in the middle of the expected range, the company would have an initial market value of almost $9 billion.

title: Religion Journal; Falwell Finds an Accord With Gay Rights Backer
description: Two months ago the Rev. Jerry Falwell, well known for conservative political and theological views, took the unusual step of agreeing with the Rev. Mel White, a supporter of gay rights, to convene a meeting bringing together 200 of each man's associates.

title: Still the Capital of Free Speech?; Whose Judgment?
description: To the Editor:

title: PROFITS AT AIR CANADA
description: Canada's largest airline, Air Canada, reported third-quarter profit of $124 million (Canadian) or about $83.1 million, in contrast to a loss of $61 million (Canadian) a year earlier, when results were hurt by a pilots' strike. The airline said the results reflected efficiency improvements and were the best performance since Air Canada was privatized 11 years ago. Greater operating efficiency is an argument Air Canada has been making to support its proposal to take over the Canadian Airlines Corporation and foil an alternative plan by the Onex Corporation to buy both airlines and merge them. Timothy Pritchard

title: Lessons Born in Cameroon
description: The language of Richard Bona's lyrics is Douala, from his native Cameroon, and like many African songwriters, he sings lessons and parables. The language of his music is less specific; it draws on pop and jazz from across Africa, the Americas and Europe. Mr. Bona has worked as a studio musician and sideman in France and the United States, performing with Manu Dibango, Salif Keita, Joe Zawinul and Joni Mitchell. In his own songs he draws on the music he learned as a child in Cameroon, and he also borrows from Sting, Paul Simon and Ms. Mitchell as freely as they have from African and Caribbean sources.
