His songs assume a virtuosity so complete that it only has to whisper.

title: KEYCORP TO SELL CREDIT CARD HOLDINGS TO HELP PROFITS
description: Keycorp said yesterday that it had decided to sell its $1.3 billion credit card portfolio, which shrank 10 percent in the last 12 months, by early next year to help profits. Keycorp said in May that it might sell some units to improve its earnings, which lag behind those of some other regional banks. Fee income from the portfolio, the 23d largest in the United States, dropped to $16 million in the third quarter, from $21 million in the second quarter, and its loans outstanding have fallen from about $1.45 billion in the last year. It may fetch about $220 million, based on the average paid for other credit card portfolios this year.

title: Pushing Smallness to the Limits of Refinement
description: The second episode of Maurizio Pollini's Perspectives series at Carnegie Hall examined the nature of smallness on Wednesday night. Only 6 of 59 items used the word ''little'' (Schoenberg's Piano Pieces, Op. 19), but there were Bagatelles, or trifles (Beethoven and Webern) and a raft of other exercises (Berg, Stravinsky and Chopin) advertising shortness in fact if not in name.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOBIN, JOHN J.
description: TOBIN-John J. Age 66 of Matawan, New Jersey (Old Bridge Township) on Thursday, October 21, 1999. Beloved husband of Janet A. nee Logan Tobin. Devoted father of John P., Robert J. and Brian L., Tobin. Dearest brother of Eileen and James Tobin. Services on Monday October 25, 8:30 AM at Day Funeral Home, Inc., 361 Maple Place, Keyport, NJ 9:30 AM Mass at Most Holy Redeemer RC Church, Old Bridge, NJ. Interment, St. Joseph's Cemetery, Keyport, NJ. Friends may visit, Saturday and Sunday 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLIVER, ROSE
description: OLIVER-Rose. On October 20, 1999, of heart disease, at her residence in Peterborough, NH. She was a clinical psychologist with a Ph.D. from CUNY. For a number of years she was associated with the Institude for Rational-Emotive Therapy, in addition to her private practice. Survivors are her daughter Theresa Oliver, son John and wife Priscilla, grandchildren Peter and wife Julie, Anna, Christopher, Eric, Heather, great-grandchildren Cole and Clay, sister Anna London, and many nieces and nephews. Services at ''The Riverside'', Sunday, October 24, 9:45AM, at Amsterdam Ave. and 76th Street.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL RISES. Crude oil rose after Phillips Petroleum shut down Norway's second-largest oilfield because of a gas leak on an offshore platform. In New York, crude oil for December delivery rose 84 cents, to $23.45 a barrel.

title: Cathedral Bars Ezra Pound From Its Poets' Corner
description: The dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine has overruled a vote by a group of prominent American writers to honor Ezra Pound with a place in the Poets' Corner of the cathedral.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BLACKWELL, JOSEPH B. JR.
description: BLACKWELL-Joseph B. Jr. Happy 100th birthday in Heaven. Rest in peace, Dear Father. Your Loving Children, Grandchildren and Great-Grandchildren

title: Another Setback for BP Amoco in Its Investment in Russia
description: BP Amoco has suffered what may be the harshest setback yet in its struggle to preserve a $571 million investment in Sidanko, a bankrupt Russian oil conglomerate that once symbolized opportunity for foreigners in Russia's petroleum industry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASIEL, BETTY L.
description: ASIEL-Betty L. Of White Plains, New York died on October 22, 1999 at Presbyterian Hospital. She was 81 years old. Mrs. Asiel is survived by her husband, E. Nelson Asiel; three children, Harold N., Terri L., John H. Asiel; two grandchildren, Carrie A. Grammas and Scott N. Asiel & one great granddaughter, Alexandria K. Grammas. Visiting hours on Sunday, October 24th, 3:30-5:30 P.M. at McMahon, Lyon & Hartnett Funeral Home, 491 Mamaroneck Avenue, White Plains, New York, (914) 949-7777. Burial will be private.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO SLIDES. The dollar rose against the single European currency after United States stocks staged a rebound. In New York, the euro settled at $1.0675, down from $1.0820 on Thursday.

title: CENTRAL EUROPEAN WIRELESS DEAL
description: Europe's biggest phone company, Deutsche Telekom, will pay Mediaone Group Inc. $2 billion for its stakes in wireless telephone systems in Poland, Hungary and Russia. The deal further expands the German telephone company's position in Central Europe. Telekom already owns 51 percent of the Hungarian telephone company, Matav, and recently agreed to buy 35 percent of a Croatian cellular telephone network. If consummated, the deal would give Telekom full control over Hungary's biggest cellular operator. Telekom would also acquire 22 percent of Poland's second-largest cellular operator and a controlling interest in the Russian Telephone Development Corporation. Edmund L. Andrews

title: What the Deserving Deserve and Whether They Get It
description: How to define and judge merit has been at the center of bitter debates over college admissions and affirmative action. Reports last month that the Educational Testing Service, creator of the most widely used college entrance examinations, was considering a program to identify disadvantaged students set off a whirl of protest. The plan, labeled ''Strivers,'' has been shelved, but the debate over merit continues. Arts & Ideas asked educators how they would define that elusive term. Joyce Jensen compiled their responses.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 11 about the use of the insanity defense in the trial of Andrew Goldstein, who is accused of pushing a young woman to her death in front of a subway train in Manhattan, misstated the first time medical experts were allowed to testify in an insanity defense case. It was in 1760 in England, not in 1843.

title: INSIDE
description: Vichy Official Arrested

title: Four Children Report Illness From Coke Products
description: Four schoolchildren in Belgium said yesterday that they experienced nausea, headaches and rashes after drinking Coca-Cola products bought from a vending machine near their school. But a spokesman for the Coca-Cola Company in Atlanta said the soft drinks were not the cause.

title: Lord Grey, 89, Queen's Last Governor in Ulster
description: Lord Grey of Naunton, the last official representative of the Queen of England in Northern Ireland, died on Sunday in Naunton, Gloucestershire. He was 89.

title: In New Haven, Not Your Usual Mall Battle
description: As battles over proposed shopping malls go, this one appears classic: a tug-of-war between those who believe a major new retail center will revitalize a city and those who warn that it will suck the life out of an already faltering downtown.

title: Japan's Nuclear Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Canada's Private Control Towers; Sale of Air Traffic System Has Led to Technical Advances
description: An air traffic controller in the gleaming new tower here tapped the tip of his rubber eraser at different spots on the touch screen as if he were playing a xylophone, each touch making data instantly pop into view, and read off arcane instructions for a waiting Aeroflot plane. ''Atis is Golf,'' the controller, Christopher P. Cole, said, touching one box on the screen, which suddenly showed the letter ''G.'' ''S.I.D. Bulls,'' he said, touching another, which filled with a ''B.''

title: First Amendment Decisions; The Klan Loses
description: Yesterday's decision by a federal appellate panel upholding New York City's right to forbid masked Ku Klux Klan members to stage a rally today in lower Manhattan was a legal victory for Mayor Rudolph Giuliani but a low moment for the First Amendment and a city that prizes freedom of expression. Few would quarrel with Mr. Giuliani's depiction of the Klan as a ''disgusting, horrible organization that represents the very worst of American history.'' But when the city is allowed to selectively target the free-speech rights of a deservedly unpopular group like the Klan, it diminishes the rights of everyone.

title: Surveying the Results, 20 Years and Millions of Dollars Later
description: Ed Yingling, the chief lobbyist for the American Bankers Association, was weary this evening as he reflected on the agreement to overhaul the nation's financial system and the many years of lobbying behind it.

title: Resolving Museum Rift
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLUCK, RUTH RUBIN
description: GLUCK-Ruth Rubin. Cherished wife of Marshall. Loving mother of Abbe and Simon. Adored daughter of Anna and the late Moses Rubin. Beloved sister of Judy Rubin. Dear daughter-in-law of Gertrude and Milton Shapiro. Admired sister-in-law of Bill, Richard and Melissa Gluck and Garth Hayden. In her too-short time with us she amazed us all with her ability to achieve so much while remaining completely devoted to her family. She was an accomplished corporate attorney at Metropolitan Life for 30 years, a perpetual student of Judaism and the arts, and the best wife and mother a family could hope for. Her intelligence, grace and beauty marked every aspect of her life and made her one of those few special people among us. She will be loved and with us always. Service at Park Avenue Synagogue, 87th Street and Madison Ave., Monday, October 25, at 10:30 AM.

title: How Controversial Art Killed a Museum; In a Case That Parallels 'Sensation,' Cultural Leaders Took On Miami
description: Several years ago, an art museum here challenged the sensibilities of the community. Much uproar ensued. The Mayor and city commissioners reacted by trying to cancel the museum's lease. The museum went to court, and won. The First Amendment prevailed.

title: First Amendment Decisions; The Press Wins
description: The decision by the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit in the case of Food Lion v. ABC properly preserves the right of the press to report truthful information. First Amendment principles require that a plaintiff like Food Lion suing for libel prove that the news report was false and was made with actual malice. The court wisely says that the plaintiff cannot get around this high standard of proof in trying to recover defamation-like damages by relying on other charges.

title: Business Owner Is Killed During Robbery in Bronx
description: A 47-year-old Long Island man was killed Thursday night during a robbery at a Bronx meatpacking company, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MAHONEY, HONORABLE J. DANIEL
description: MAHONEY-Honorable J. Daniel. October 23, 1996. Always cheerful. Never to be forgotten. Forever loved

title: Emotional Rangers Fall Short Of Goals
description: As Coach John Muckler had demanded of them, the Rangers came out with more emotion last night. For Muckler's sake, they started out by trying to play a simpler game.

title: ACCORD REACHED ON LIFTING OF DEPRESSION-ERA BARRIERS AMONG FINANCIAL INDUSTRIES
description: The Clinton Administration and top Republican lawmakers reached an agreement early today to overhaul the financial system, repealing Depression-era laws that have restricted the banking, securities and insurance industries from expanding into one another's businesses.

title: Nicholas Metropolis, 84, a Maker Of the A-Bomb and Computers
description: Dr. Nicholas C. Metropolis, a mathematician who was one of the initial team of scientists involved with the Manhattan Project and who later became a pioneer in computer science, died last Sunday at a nursing home in Los Alamos, N.M. He was 84.

title: New Stock Rides a Rocket and Then a Parachute Into the Market
description: It is not often that a stock can drop $85 in an afternoon and still be a spectacular success, but it happened yesterday to Sycamore Networks Inc.

title: In Indonesia, All Eyes on Economy
description: Two days after he became the first democratically elected President in Indonesian history, Abdurrahman Wahid spent yesterday closeted with five eminent local economists.

title: Schwab Web Site Goes Down Yet Again
description: The Charles Schwab Corporation's Web trading site failed today for almost two hours, the third disruption in three days, because of an unspecified software problem, the company, the largest Internet brokerage firm, said.

title: Blasts in Chechen Capital Unleash New Wave of Refugees
description: A fresh flood of Chechen refugees swept westward today down the main highway into Ingushetia, the neighboring republic, propelled by fear of a widening war with Russia after explosions killed scores in Grozny, Chechnya's capital.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about Mattel Inc.'s third-quarter results misstated the company's expectations for future profit. It expects to earn 70 to 80 cents a share for the full year, not for the fourth quarter.

title: The Army's Top NCO in Europe Is Charged With Sexual Assault
description: One of the highest noncommissioned officers in the Army has been charged with sexually assaulting a female soldier in Germany last April in the latest in a series of embarrassing sex-related incidents in the military.

title: Sports of The Times; Atlanta's Cox Was Once A Yankee
description: BOBBY COX had as many bad knees as his team mate Mickey Mantle just not as many home runs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENJAMIN, ZELDA
description: BENJAMIN-Zelda, of Berkeley Heights, New Jersey, formerly of New York City. Wife of the late Gershon Benjamin, noted well known artist in the New York-New Jersey area. Mother of Joan Facey. Funeral services held on October 15, 1999. For information: Menorah Chapels at Millburn 2950 Vauxhall Road, Union, NJ.

title: Disturbed Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Khartoum Journal; Artist Returns From Europe to Rediscover Sudan
description: There does not seem to be much here for an artist the caliber of Rashid Diab. There is only one small gallery. It is hard to find canvas or paint. No one has enough money to buy Mr. Diab's paintings, abstractions that like Sudan itself are a gorgeous mix of Arab and African influences. Even small works go for $1,000 or more.

title: Financial Services Industry Faces a New World
description: During the careers of every living executive in the finance industry, bankers have made loans, brokers have sold stocks, insurers have underwritten policies to protect against disasters, and, with exceptions that sometimes made headlines, they rarely trespassed on one another's turf.

title: The City Life; A Park Along the River
description: When it is completed sometime in 2003, the Hudson River Park will stretch for five miles along lower Manhattan's western shoreline. To date, a 1,000-foot strip has officially been finished. It is a lovely 1,000 feet, as Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and Gov. George Pataki noted recently when they declared the entire waterway park some 333 yards closer to reality. Even a few weeks after the opening of this ''first phase'' of the shoreline park, the mums were still bright, the roses tended, the tables and chairs that are set along the pathway so free of graffiti and gum that they somehow look strange in a public place.

title: Devils Battle Elite Stars But Lose in Overtime
description: Coach Robbie Ftorek of the Devils viewed tonight's game against the Dallas Stars as a serious challenge to his team, not only because the Stars are the defending Stanley Cup champions, but also because the Devils had gone six days without a game.

title: Amazon Sues Big Bookseller Over System For Shopping
description: Amazon.com has filed suit against its rival Internet book and music seller Barnesandnoble.com, accusing it of illegally copying Amazon's patented checkout system and demanding an immediate end to its use.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: SIEMENS UNIT IS SOLD
description: As expected, the United States buyout firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, which recently set up offices in London, and Goldman Sachs Group Inc. announced they would acquire Siemens Nixdorf Retail and Banking Systems, a unit of Siemens that makes automated teller machines, cash registers and other computerized systems for retailers. The two paid 1.44 billion marks, or $790 million, for the German company, which disclosed this week that it was in talks. The acquisition is the first major purchase in Europe for Kohlberg Kravis. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHEINMAN, DIANA. (NEE FRIEDENBERG)
description: SCHEINMAN-Diana. (nee Friedenberg). Of York, PA. On October 21, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Sidney. Devoted mother of David, Robert and Daniel. Cherished grandmother of Nina and Jay. Services at Temple Beth Israel, York, PA, Monday, October 25th, 11AM. Contributions may be made to a favorite charity.

title: In Turnabout, Federal Panel Votes Against A Vaccine
description: In a rare and embarrassing reversal, a Federal health advisory panel yesterday withdrew its recommendation that all infants be immunized against the virus that causes a severe form of diarrhea after the vaccine was linked to a painful and potentially fatal bowel obstruction.

title: When the Image Is the Idea; At the Library, Illustrations That Aren't Gimmicks
description: When the inventor of the lightning rod, Sir William Harris, needed to illustrate the phenomenon of electricity for a new treatise, he decided against a minutely observed etching or a complex numerical chart. Instead he lined several pages of the manuscript with gold-leaf and then simply ran an electric current right across them.

title: Aid Colombian Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Buyers Show Rare Enthusiasm At Drouot's Antiquities Sales : Old-Style Auctions
description: PARIS  To those who love nothing better than the excitement of buying a work of art in open competition, Drouot stands out as the last holdout where some of the auctions retain their authentic flavor of yore. There, prices largely reflect the ups and downs in the mood of the public, rather than the ever soaring ambitions of consignors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRUCKMAN, IRVING
description: DRUCKMAN-Irving October 21, 1999, in his 96th year. Beloved husband of the late Gladys and Abigail. Dear father of Daniel, Michael and Barbara Lokos. Adored grandfather of Kathy, James and William and great grandfather of Linus and Annika. Services were held on Friday, October 22nd.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REISER, ALBERT I., M.D.
description: REISER-Albert I., M.D., of New York. On October 21, 1999 after an extended illness. Dear husband of Inez. Loving father of Janet and Peter. Devoted grandfather of Rebecca and Sarah. Dedicated psychiatrist. He will be greatly missed. Services on Sunday, October 24, at 9:30 AM at ''The Riverside'', Amsterdam Avenue at 76th Street.

title: UNITED STATIONERS SEEKS DAISYTEK INTERNATIONAL
description: United Stationers Inc., the top United States wholesaler of office supplies, furniture and janitorial products, has offered $20 a share in cash for Daisytek International, United said yesterday. Daisytek's stock rose 81.25 cents yesterday, to $15.25. Daisytek, the world's leading distributor of office supplies including floppy disks and inkjet cartridges, said last week that it had received an ''inadequate'' unsolicited offer from a company it refused to identify and had adopted a ''poison pill'' anti-takeover defense to stave off other offers. The move led to a lawsuit in Delaware Chancery Court this week by a Daisytek shareholder. United is based in Des Plaines, Ill.

title: DERLAN OF CANADA BUYING BOEING AIRCRAFT GEAR HOLDING
description: The Boeing Company, the world's biggest aircraft builder, agreed yesterday to sell a unit that makes military-aircraft gears to Derlan Industries of Canada to focus on its other military and civilian products. The price was not disclosed. The unit, Boeing Precision Gear Inc., based in Bedford Park, Ill., has 315 employees. The employees will be offered jobs with Derlan, a Boeing spokeswoman, Madelyn Bush, said. Derlan, based in Toronto, makes aerospace parts and pumps. Derlan is not buying the gear unit's plant.

title: An Easygoing 'Figaro' Speaks for Itself
description: When Jonathan Miller's production of ''Le Nozze di Figaro'' opened at the Metropolitan Opera last year, its success was virtually guaranteed. No company could have assembled a starrier cast: Bryn Terfel as Figaro, Cecilia Bartoli as Susanna and Renee Fleming as the Countess, for starters. The production itself had a simplicity and directness that were refreshing after the quirky Jean-Pierre Ponnelle staging that had been in the Met's repertory since 1985, although Mr. Miller adopted the easy symbolism of the ruined manor look that Ponnelle had taken to extremes.

title: A Shostakovich Work Plumbs Death's Depths
description: As a nod to the new millennium, and in commemoration of its own 100th anniversary, the Philadelphia Orchestra is devoting its programs this season exclusively to works from the 20th century. Of course while a season without Beethoven and Brahms may sound risky, the programs are not as daring as the idea suggests. The orchestra's concert at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night under Wolfgang Sawallisch offered Rachmaninoff's popular Piano Concerto No. 2, a work that just barely qualifies, having been composed mostly in 1900 and given its premiere in 1901.

title: New Hampshire Warns Bush, 'Don't Be a Stranger Hee-ahh'
description: On his first campaign swing through New Hampshire since early September, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas tried today to turn questions about why he is not spending more time here into an attack on his priorities as a family man.

title: Noting an Anniversary With a Work on Scent
description: For dancegoers unfamiliar with Ballet: The Daring Project, a bit of explanation may serve to characterize this company, directed by Valentina Kozlova and Margo Sappington, which performs through tomorrow night at the Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at West 19th Street, Chelsea. Whatever its name may imply, this is not an experimental organization but a troupe that emphasizes balletic entertainment. The three works by Ms. Sappington that it offered on Thursday night included two lightweight new pieces.

title: Irate at Mannesmann Deal, Vodafone Weighs Response
description: Despite a show of public nonchalance, Vodafone Airtouch P.L.C., the world's leading mobile phone operator, is privately considering a range of options including a hostile bid for Mannesmann A.G. after the German company's move into the British wireless market, executives close to the discussions said today.

title: Sojo's Absence Presents Torre With a Challenge
description: The father of the utility infielder Luis Sojo died Thursday evening, and the Yankees do not know when Sojo will be available to play in the World Series, if at all.

title: Soaring Attendance at U.S. Museums Fuels Building Boom
description: NEW YORK  The fin de siecle has brought an explosion of activity in the once rarefied and increasingly user-friendly realm of the American art museum. A robust national economy, a growing art-hungry audience and innovative programming and management strategies have triggered numerous museum expansions and the construction of new museums from Washington to San Francisco.

title: Corrections
description: Articles on Tuesday and Thursday about Republican opposition to President Clinton's nomination of Carol Moseley-Braun as Ambassador to New Zealand referred incorrectly to a Confederate flag that was at issue in 1993 when Ms. Moseley-Braun, as Senator from Illinois, persuaded the Senate to reject a renewed patent for an emblem for the United Daughters of the Confederacy. (A similar error occurred in an earlier article, on July 23, 1993.) The emblem included the Stars and Bars, the first national flag of the Confederacy -- not the later Confederate battle flag.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDERS, JOHN E.
description: SANDERS-John E. Professor Emeritus of Geology at Barnard College, Columbia University and noted environmental research scientist, died at Phelps Memorial Hospital in Sleepy Hollow, NY, at age 73 after a brief illness October 20. Beloved husband of Barbara, devoted father of Philip, Thomas, and Stephanie & cherished fatherin-law of Janice Sanders and John Sullivan. Doting grandfather of William, Katherine, Daniel and Scott. Funeral service Sat., Oct. 23rd, 2PM at the Community Unitarian Church, 468 Rosedale Ave., White Plains, NY; 914-946-1660. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to: Ohio Weslyan University, Columbia University or Phelps Memorial Hospital.

title: Citing Fire Hazard, City Forces Out Brooklyn Loft Renters
description: Residents of as many as 45 loft apartments were forced to vacate a Brooklyn building last night by the city's Department of Buildings, which said the owners had renovated the structure, once a dilapidated factory, without obtaining city permits or installing adequate fire escapes.

title: Unwise Abortion Tactic
description: To the Editor:

title: Journal; Send In More Clowns
description: There's no faster way for a politician to offend P.C. sensibilities on the left than to attack gun control and affirmative action. There's no faster way to offend P.C. sensibilities on the right than to defend flag-burning and gays in the military. What major politician would dare offend the left and right? As far as I can determine there's just one, Jesse Ventura, who in his notorious interview in Playboy not only took all these positions but further riled the entire political spectrum by dismissing Tailhook as ''much ado about nothing'' and religion as ''a crutch for weak-minded people.'' Then he mocked the single largest bipartisan constituency in the country -- the overweight. The only way he could have topped that would have been to call for the mandatory spaying of household pets.

title: In New York City, Language Can Unite
description: To the Editor:

title: Penelope Mortimer, 81, Author of 'Pumpkin Eater'
description: Penelope Mortimer, an English author who drew on her complex and often turbulent relationships with men in writing novels like ''The Pumpkin Eater'' and a heatedly debated account of the romantic life of Queen Elizabeth, the Queen Mother, died on Tuesday at a London hospice. She was 81 and lived in Willesden, a suburb in north London.

title: H. Stuart Hughes, 83, Historian of Modern Europe
description: H. Stuart Hughes, a historian who wrote extensively on the intellectual history of modern Europe, died on Thursday in San Diego, where he lived as a professor emeritus of the University of California at San Diego. He was 83.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, MARIA
description: DAVIS-Maria, age 89, of Fort Lauderdale, died October 21, 1999, formerly of New York City. Predeceased by her husband, Russell Davis. Survived by her son, John Billovitz of Fort Lauderdale; sisters, Helen Neundorfer of Ridgefield, CT, and Anna Obojkovits of Tobaj, Austria; many nieces and nephews. Reposing Waterbury & Kelly Funeral Home, Briarcliff Manor, NY, on Sunday & Monday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral mass St. Theresa Church, Briarcliff Manor, Tuesday, 10 AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: WORLD SERIES PREVIEW: Up for Grabs, a Series and a Decade; Two Best Teams of 90's Get Set for a Rematch
description: Throughout much of the 1980's, George Steinbrenner boasted of the Yankees' won-lost record, the best in the decade, he proudly and pointedly claimed. But Major League Baseball wasn't giving out trophies for the best cumulative record, so the owner's claim of superiority fell on deaf ears.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''You can come here and wear a Mets or Yankees cap and not worry about getting soaked with beer. I mean, those guys up north will boo their own team if they get mad at something.''

title: In Adirondacks, Fight Over Parcel Reflects a Larger Battle
description: John A. Gibbs, a New York State forester, walked along a ribbon of dirt road through one of the hundreds of public woodlands in the Adirondack Park, a Vermont-size patchwork of state preserves and private land.

title: Rowers and Fans Are Set To Line the Charles River
description: The annual Head of the Charles Regatta in Boston, which 35 years ago started as a fall get-together for colleges that call the Charles River their home course, has evolved into rowing's autumnal pilgrimage. This weekend, the regatta will attract more than 5,400 competitors from around the world who will contest 20 events.

title: Ex-Vichy Aide Seized and Returned to France
description: The manhunt for Maurice Papon, the 89-year-old Nazi collaborator, ended swiftly when the Swiss police arrested him late Thursday at a modest hotel in one of Europe's most exclusive ski resorts, where he was hiding under a false name.

title: Joao Cabral, 79, Unflinching Poet, Is Dead
description: Joao Cabral de Melo Neto, one of the century's most distinguished and influential poets in the Portuguese language, died here on Oct. 9 after a long illness. He was 79.

title: Treating Asthma Like an Allergy
description: To the Editor:

title: Roscoe Egger Jr., 79, Dies; Former Head of the I.R.S.
description: Roscoe L. Egger Jr., a commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service in the Reagan Administration, died on Oct. 14 at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn. He was 79 and lived in Green Valley, Ariz.

title: Man's Body Is Found On Parkway Ramp
description: A well-dressed man was found dead yesterday morning on the shoulder of a ramp off the Garden State Parkway, the state police said.

title: John E. Sanders, 73, Geologist and Professor
description: John E. Sanders, a geologist and a longtime professor at Barnard College who was also a major figure 20 years ago in a plan to clean up the Hudson River, died Wednesday at a hospital in Sleepy Hollow, N.Y. He was 73.

title: Tying the Healing Hands
description: Next week Congress will debate legislation that would make it far more difficult for doctors everywhere to prescribe pain medication for the terminally ill. This proposal, introduced in the House by Henry Hyde, Republican of Illinois, and in the Senate by Don Nickles, Republican of Oklahoma, intends to overturn Oregon's law on physician-assisted suicide, and it is an affront to anyone who favors compassionate care of patients at the end of life.

title: Issue Much Lobbied
description: The agreement to overhaul the financial system ends 20 years of intense lobbying and a reliable source of campaign cash.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORNSTEIN, TONI GREENHOUSE
description: ORNSTEIN-Toni Greenhouse. Of Aventura, Fla. Devoted mother of Linda Landis and mother-in-law of Alan Landis. Sister of the late Jesse Chinich. Loving grandmother of Scott and Dana Landis. Services Sunday 11:15AM, ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam.

title: Strong Notes of Discord Mar Championship Tenor
description: The uncertainty of his future with the Yankees and the questions about his shoulder gnawed at David Cone. But after the Yankees defeated Texas in the first round of the playoffs, Cone spoke with his teammate Chili Davis and they agreed: this is not the time to worry about such matters, not when the Yankees are pursuing another championship.

title: Managing Editor Will Remain With The Wall Street Journal
description: Two questions hanging over The Wall Street Journal's future were answered yesterday.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Teen-Ager Held In Killing Of a Girl, 16
description: A Newark teen-ager has been arrested in the shooting death of the 16-year-old Irvington girl with whom he had two children. The shooting occurred four days after she told the police he had kidnapped and raped her, the police said.

title: Jack Bromwich, 80, Australian Tennis Star
description: Jack Bromwich, who won the Australian Open singles championship twice in a tennis career that was interrupted by World War II, died earlier this week in Geelong, Australia. The ambidextrous Bromwich, who won 17 major doubles titles and was a prolific representative of Australia in Davis Cup play, was 80.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HOLNESS, ELSA
description: HOLNESS-Elsa. October 23, 1985. Loving in God always; loved in God forever. Nieces Shirley & Lorraine

title: Bus Driver in Crash Said to Have Ignored Light
description: The driver of a school bus that collided with a dump truck on Thursday morning in Central Bridge, N.Y., failed to stop at a flashing red traffic light, the police said yesterday.

title: Still the Capital of Free Speech?
description: To the Editor:

title: Off the Bench or as a Starter, Camby Just Wants Playing Time
description: Following the Knicks' improbable run through the playoffs last season, it was accepted that Latrell Sprewell would be promoted from sixth man to a starting role this season. But Marcus Camby, who also flourished in the post-season, will most likely find himself in the same role: as a source of energy off the bench.

title: A Lot of Attention for a Small El Al Plane Deal
description: Airbus Industrie released blueprints for a synagogue in the sky: a converted business-class lounge, complete with ark and Torah.

title: Ezra Pound Barred From a Poets' Corner
description: The dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine has overruled a vote by a group of prominent American writers to honor Ezra Pound with a place in the Poets' Corner of the cathedral. The dean, the Very Rev. Harry S. Pritchett Jr., said in a letter to the writers last week that the cathedral in Manhattan could not commemorate Pound because of his anti-Semitic writings and broadcasts from Fascist Italy during World War II and the lingering pain they have caused members of the cathedral's congregation. The dean's decision is but another chapter in a dispute that has shadowed Pound's reputation for more than 50 years.

title: An Actress on the Move, Literally
description: If it isn't six different roles (very different) in one play, it's one very long one, spanning 17 years. Marathon performances appear to be a way of life for Priscilla Lopez, who scores one coup d'theatre after another. Practically speaking, the difference between her feats of theatrical endurance is the commute.

title: Kate Gralnick, Timothy Surber
description: Kate Gralnick, the daughter of Beth and Jeff Gralnick of Weston, Conn., was married yesterday to Timothy Clark Surber, a son of Anne and G. C. Surber of Trumbull, Conn. Rabbi Ari Fridkis officiated at Le Chateau, a restaurant in South Salem, N.Y. The Rev. Stephen Gleeson, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: Barry White, the Basso of Love, Signs as Fans Sigh
description: No roses, no zinfandel, not a bearskin rug in sight. Still, Barry White, the baritone ambassador of love, was making knees weak last Wednesday afternoon, when he stopped by the Barnes & Noble at Fifth Avenue and 48th Street to sign copies of his autobiography, ''Love Unlimited: Insights on Life and Love'' (Broadway Books, $23).

title: The High Life
description: LIFE AND DEATH

title: Letters to the Editor And a Former Classmate
description: Students in Terry Solomon's classes at Hopewell Valley Central High School recently tackled a subject that wasn't in the original lesson plans for the semester: an article about a former classmate that appeared in the New Jersey section Oct. 10, with the headline ''White Flight: Lessons He Learned While Venturing to Trenton From the Comforts of Hopewell.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINETT, PAUL
description: LINETT-Paul. Beloved husband of the late Frances. Loving father of Eugene & Diane Linett, and Ellen and Bernie Schreiber. Cherished grandfather of Mathew, Lisa, Ivy and Stacy. Dear brother of Lillian and Herbert Szerlip and the late Jacob & Bea Linett, and brotherin-law of Helen & Gene Beerman. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island at 1:30PM on Sunday.

title: POSTINGS: Lawsuits Involved the Flatiron and the New York Stock Exchange; A Building as a Trademark
description: Metes and bounds once sufficed to determine the ownership of real estate. But a new kind of property dispute -- intellectual property -- is raising novel questions as to who controls the skyline.

title: Today, The Musical Dies
description: As the producer of a forthcoming Broadway musical, ''The Night They Raided Minsky's,'' I read with considerable distress Albert Innaurato's impassioned plea that we ''bury this moribund art form'' (The Way We Live Now, Sept. 26). However, I recalled reading, over 30 years ago now, ''The Season,'' by William Goldman, which more or less predicted the end of Broadway theater itself. Buoyed by the realization that Goldman's forecast had not yet come true -- since the hardest thing to find these days is a Broadway theater without a show in it -- I decided that Innaurato might similarly be ahead of his time.

title: Unsung Champion
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIERCE, LEWIS
description: PIERCE-Lewis. Director, Singer, Actor. Died October 14, 1999 at home. Member of Actors Equity & the Musician's Union. Husband of Margaret. Father of Roy and Sara. Grandfather of James and Peter. The world is a less interesting place without him. Donations in his name may be made to the Jacob Perlow Hospice, New York.

title: America First
description: To the Editor:

title: Life After Balanchine? Suzanne Farrell Has Made Her Own
description: BOTH the dancing and the life of Suzanne Farrell are American legends, complete with ballet triumphs, blazing talent, ferocious work, thorny love relationships and personal torments. They could, in fact, be fashioned into a drama, opera, or a film. True, ''The Red Shoes'' has been done, but the absorbing 1997 documentary ''Suzanne Farrell, Elusive Muse'' was nominated for an Academy Award.

title: In the Patch, Pumpkins Are for Picking
description: NOW is the season of wart-fleshed gourds, of bushel baskets brimming with apples, of orange orbs whose ribs coax you to reach for a knife. It's the season that keeps farmers like Greg Scibilia busy lifting. These last few weeks at Whistle Stop Farm in Ringoes, every free hand has been loading, hoisting and hauling autumn's prime crop to his farm's retail stand. Not all the bounty is picked, however. Much is left behind where it belongs.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: October 24, 1999
description: Weeks

title: The View From/Stamford; Laboratory of Dance: Creating a Hoedown of a Ballet Company
description: THE tutus were left behind. Way behind. Instead, the dancers of the Zig Zag Ballet, giving their debut performance at the Rich Forum in Stamford recently, sported capris, pin-striped suits and unitards printed in the Diaghilev-Picasso style.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPSON, HERBERT J., M.D.
description: LIPSON-Herbert J., M.D. 86. Formerly of Baldwin, L.I., New York died Saturday, Oct. 16, 1999 in El Paso, Texas. Graveside Services were held at Fort Bliss National Cemetery, El Paso, Texas on October 18, 1999. Survivors include his wife, Genevieve, his sons Stuart of Miami, Florida and Michael of Phoenix, Arizona and 3 grandchildren. He was a retired Lt. Colonel in the Air Force, where he served as a medical doctor for four years during World War II. Dr. Lipson practiced medicine in Baldwin, Long Island for thirty-five years and in El Paso, Texas for ten years. He will be missed by all.

title: James S. Moran Dies at 91; Master of the Publicity Stunt
description: James Sterling Moran, who became a legend in the publicity business with stunts like selling a refrigerator to an Alaskan Eskimo, died on Monday at a retirement home in Englewood, N.J. He was 91.

title: For the New Garde, Cabaret's the Thing
description: IT was the night of a thousand designs, on murals, arches and carpets, but just one star: Patti LuPone, and for one night only.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about the nuclear test ban treaty misidentified the home state of Senator Jesse Helms. It is North Carolina, not South Carolina.

title: Short-Handed Without Sojo
description: The Yankees will operate one player short during the first two games of the Series after deciding today against replacing the utility infielder Luis Sojo with outfielder Shane Spencer on their 25-man roster..

title: Sour on the Status Quo, Argentines Vote Today
description: Crime and unemployment are up, wages are down, and polls indicate that a growing number of Argentines think that their politicians are stealing fortunes. Voters want change after 10 years of Peronist rule, and every recent poll suggests that they will get it, choosing the decidedly downbeat Mayor of Buenos Aires, Fernando de la Rua, as President in the elections on Sunday.

title: None of the Above
description: The Big Test

title: Wind as a Metaphor For Human Emotions
description: Rosalyn A. Engelman

title: Wine Choice Affected By Menu or Season
description: PERFECTION is as elusive in wine as it is in life. There is no single perfect wine for a special dinner. The season, the menu, one's pocketbook and palate all contribute to the decision of which wine to serve.

title: September Unemployment Rate Stays Below 5 Percent
description: New Jersey's unemployment rate was under 5 percent in September, for the 23d month in a row, and the number of people employed continued to climb, the state Department of Labor said last week.

title: Larger Buses, Fewer Stops: Riders Feel Left at Curb
description: Bus riders are bombarding the Metropolitan Transit Authority with protests as the agency paves the way for a new fleet of larger buses on the Upper East Side.

title: Backtalk; A Former Coach's Primal Scream Over a Stubborn Stereotype
description: I love sports and I love coaching. I am also a lesbian. I loved coaching girls' high school soccer. Yet the joy I felt mixed incessantly with the shame of knowing that as a female coach I was trapped in a cliche and an expectation: the lesbian coach.

title: Nobody's Spared in Dame Edna's One-Man Show
description: DAME EDNA EVERAGE, the Melbourne housewife, social anthropologist, talk-show host, investigative journalist and self-styled megastar, has clearly outgrown the control of her mentor, Barry Humphries. He's the Australian wizard who, as a young actor and writer, created the character for a Melbourne revue in 1955 and has been at her side ever since. The extent to which this gloriously opinionated, mauve-haired golem has taken over Mr. Humphries is now nakedly apparent in ''Dame Edna: The Royal Tour'' at the Booth Theater on Broadway.

title: Surprises from Jakarta to Wall Street
description: Funny how the election of a new president can send financial markets roiling, especially when it isn't the president everyone is expecting.

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-24-99: Test Run; Let the Games Begin
description: The Toys ''R'' Us at Union Square is the fourth store I visit on this fine autumn Saturday in my fruitless search for the Sega Dreamcast, ''the ultimate video-game console: a polygon-crunching monster with power to spare.'' I could more easily get my hands on a piece of the True Cross. The $199 Dreamcast made its debut in early September with 300,000 presell orders and first-day revenues more than three times those of ''The Phantom Menace.'' But with no actual Dreamcasts in stock, the video-games department here at Toys ''R'' Us is nothing more than a shrine. One 7-year-old boy cannot stop the jitters of excitement running through his pencil-thin legs. His grandmother stands gazing at the back of his head with a look of stultified hatred. ''You were so cute four years ago,'' she seems to be thinking. ''Who are you?''

title: Deal on Bank Bill Was Helped Along By Midnight Talks
description: At a fund-raiser at Senator Edward M. Kennedy's home here shortly after 6 o'clock on Thursday evening, President Clinton asked one of his closest friends in the Senate, Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut, how the talks were going with Republicans over the most important financial legislation since the Great Depression.

title: Settling Into New Condominiums in the East Village
description: AFTER 10 years as a renter in a tiny two-bedroom apartment on East Seventh Street, Gary Greenblatt found a housing deal in his own neighborhood last year that he first suspected was too good to be true. He and his Brazilian-born wife, Rosane Chamecki, a dancer and choreographer, were enabled by a lottery to become the buyers of a three-bedroom duplex apartment, with two full baths and 16 windows, in a newly built condominium at Avenue A and East 13th Street. The price was $154,575.

title: Why City's Schools Fail
description: To the Editor:

title: Walden Pond vs. the Mall
description: RECLAIMING THE COMMONS

title: Our Towns; A Polyglot City That Dreams In English
description: QUESTION: Why did the Clifton City Council adopt an English-only policy for city notices?

title: Homecoming; The Bill Bradley Campaign as a Celebration and Affirmation of the Garden State
description: OH, the indignities of being from New Jersey. Seven million residents, but no network television station. Two professional football teams, both of which go by another state's name. Life sandwiched between Manhattan and Philadelphia can be galling.

title: Sailing The Blue Highway
description: ONE of the first things I noticed when we arrived for our much-anticipated week at Aruba's famous windsurfing village last December was the so-called Blue Highway, a streak of light blue water about a quarter-mile offshore where masters of the sport zip back and forth at speeds as high as 40 miles an hour.

title: On Politics; Beyond the Sound Bite: A Century of Speechifying
description: There have been famous orators in Congress, like John C. Calhoun or Everett M. Dirksen. And there have been authors, lots of them, notably in recent times Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, who dashes off books on public policy and still has time to advise other members of Congress about what's wrong with their thinking.

title: Paying Up Is Speaking Up
description: Those who claim that our political system is awash in money, corruption and influence peddling were predictably upset that the Senate again defeated the campaign finance restriction proposed by Senators Russell Feingold and John McCain. The Senate's failure to ban ''soft money'' -- large contributions to political parties that are made to avoid tight restrictions on donations to candidates -- drew laments from editorial pages to corporate boardrooms, where some business executives now plead, ''Stop us before we spend again.''

title: Brosius Shows Series Form
description: If Scott Brosius follows form, the Atlanta Braves better beware on Sunday night.

title: Tracy Charters And Jason Franks
description: Tracy Lorraine Charters, a daughter of Patsy Kahn and Al Kahn of New York, was married in New York yesterday to First Lieut. Jason Edward Franks, the son of Fritzi and Philip Franks of Gladwyne, Pa. The Rev. Dr. Angela Anselmo, an interfaith minister, officiated.

title: A Time to Gather, Arrange, Enjoy
description: Hold off lifting those tropical cannas until after a killing frost. Gather red-orange fruit clusters of viburnum, and blackberry lily with its shiny black berries and papery pods, to use in arrangements with grasses, goldenrods, Korean chrysanthemums and salvias -- like black and silver gray Salvia discolor and scarlet pineapple sage (Salvia elegans).

title: Free to Be Personal, Not Political
description: WHEN ''A Palestinian Girl'' opened at the Haifa Theater in 1985, protests arose over the very title. On that basis alone, some season ticket holders canceled their subscriptions. Others packed the premiere and, as the curtain fell, exploded into spontaneous debate over whether the subject matter itself was subversive.

title: Writer Helps Soweto Strip the Shame From AIDS
description: For three years, Lucky Mazibuko obeyed his society's unwritten rules. He kept silent about the virus in his blood. He wept at night, when his mother could not hear him. He hid his suffering from the world and waited quietly for death.

title: Left on a Genteel Doorstep
description: Daughter of Fortune

title: BENEFITS
description: As the Twig Is Bent . . .

title: October 17-23; Exile Denied
description: Maurice Papon's efforts to flee justice didn't last long. The 89-year-old former civil servant convicted last year of helping to send hundreds of French Jews to Nazi death camps was supposed to start serving his 10-year-sentence on Wednesday. Instead, he issued a defiant statement saying his only honorable choice was to flee France and go into exile. Mr. Papon was a fugitive for only a few hours before Swiss police caught up with him in a Gstaad hotel on Thursday night. Swiss officials handed him back to the French and he was in jail by Friday evening. SUZANNE DALEY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, ARTHUR ROCKWELL
description: SMITH-Arthur Rockwell. A resident of Truro, MA, and South Kent, CT, died at home on October 15, 1999. He was the husband of Margaret Walker Smith. He was predeceased by his brothers, George and Hayden Smith. Mr. Smith was born on April 26, 1910, in New York City, the son of Arthur and Alice Smith. He was a graduate of Saint Bernard's School in New York, Saint Paul's School in Concord, NH, and Yale University. He started teaching at South Kent School in Connecticut in 1954 through 1979. In addition to his wife, he is survived by his daughters, Margaret McAvoy, of Kent, Ellen Knapp, of Boulder, CO, and his son, Lawrence, of Exeter, NH, five grandchildren. In his honor, the family requests that gifts be made to South Kent School, 40 Bulls Bridge Rd., South Kent, CT 06785 or to The American Cancer Society.

title: An Idealist Who Sees the Beauty in Diversity
description: WITH close to 20 years' experience as a choreographer, Jose Montalvo is hardly a novice, yet for a long time this tall, simpatico Frenchman of Spanish descent was known -- when he was known at all -- as a peripheral artist more interested in experimentation than fame. Then he created ''Paradis,'' a delightful multimedia, multicultural collage of a work. After that, everything was different.

title: Katherine Banucci and Neal Smith
description: Katherine Renata Banucci, a daughter of Phyllis and Gene Banucci of Danbury, Conn., is to be married this afternoon to Neal Anthony Smith, the son of Ceceline and Wellesley Smith of Cleveland Heights, Ohio. The Rev. Michael Zeman, a minister of the United Church of Christ, is to perform the ceremony at the Talmadge Hill Community Church in Darien, Conn.

title: In the Region /New Jersey; Builders' Showrooms Cater to the Appetite for Extras
description: FIVE months ago Alan Burtick and his wife, Josephine Cavanaugh, bought a 2,600-square-foot house in a 411-unit single-family home subdivision being developed in Mansfield Township, in Burlington County.

title: Amid the Board-Room Din, Can a Company Get Back on Key?
description: IT was a formula that worked for decades: arcane technical expertise plus family control plus Swiss security and stability. And it made Societe Generale de Surveillance the world leader in the obscure but vital field of cargo inspection and verification.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, ROBERT R.
description: MILLER-Robert R. Beloved brother of Joan Hanie. Dear uncle of Kurt Hanie & Kristin Houghton. Loving great-uncle of Logan and Kevin Hanie, David & Jacklyn Houghton. Services on Monday, 10 AM, at Walter B. Cooke Funeral Chapel, 117 West 72nd Street, New York City. Friends may call on Sunday, 2-5 PM, at the Chapel.

title: In an Inflation Measure, A Way to Pan for Gold
description: WHAT makes gold soar will eventually make stocks swoon.

title: For Potters From Spain, A New World of Styles
description: OVER the last 400 years, the innovative potters of Puebla, a town east of Mexico City, have done what potters do best: they have taken dazzling designs from the ceramics of other cultures and reproduced them. Then, to mark them as Mexican, they have added images of a cactus here, a parrot there.

title: One Day, 19 New-Wave Shops: I'd Rather Be Napping
description: FOR at least a decade now, I have been a dedicated catalogue shopper, chatting with the ladies of Saks and Neiman Marcus via their 800-numbers while safely tucked beneath my quilt. When the clothes arrive, I try them on with my own shoes and accessories any time I choose. The model of convenience.

title: Migrating Monarch Butterflies Exceed Expected Numbers
description: Monarch butterflies, which stop in Cape May in September and October on their migration south to the mountains outside Mexico City, have been appearing in southern New Jersey in record numbers this year, said Louise Zemaitis, acting director of the Monarch Monitoring Project of the New Jersey Audobon Society.

title: Like Siblings, but Without the Rivalry
description: The lockers in Fenway Park are a No. 2 pencil or two wider than those found in most high schools, and after the Yankees edged the Red Sox in Game 4 and took a commanding lead in the series, the catchers Joe Girardi and Jorge Posada were crammed together at their lockers, side by side.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about American Ballet Theater's season at City Center misstated the year that Rudolf Nureyev made his debut with the Martha Graham Dance Company and referred incorrectly to the audience's reaction to his performance. It was 1975, not 1984, and he was not jeered. The article also misstated the extent of Graham's training in classical dance. She studied some ballet but not point work.

title: The Rural Life; The Ideal Light
description: On a warm October afternoon, high in a sugar maple, a crow disemboweled a hornet's nest, discarding shreds of gray hornet-paper like leaves in a monochrome fall. A hail of ladybugs rose and then fell against the south side of the house. They were hapless fliers burdened by ungainly wing-covers, clattering almost inaudibly against the parched siding, seeking cracks and lifted clapboards to winter under. The sight of so many ladybugs in flight, each one armed with a faint acrid stench, looked like the threat of a hard season coming. When that many creatures take shelter at once, you wonder what they're sheltering from. Soon we'll know.

title: Lenora Avila and George Bynoe
description: SOME people cure heartache with Jane Austin novels, kick-boxing classes, cleaning sprees or lessons in black-and-white photography. George Allen Bynoe, 56, cured his by going back to church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOBSTEIN, ALIX GRACE
description: LOBSTEIN-Alix Grace, on October 22, 1999 in Geneva, Switzerland. She was the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Albert Labouchere of Paris, and granddaughter of the late philanthropist Grace Whitney-Hoff of Detroit and Paris. Survivors include her 4 children, Elaine deWitt Tournesac, and Emmanuel, Francois and Jean-Louis deWitt, all of Paris, several grandchildren and great-grandchildren. A private burial will be held Monday in Geneva. A memorial service will be held Thursday, Nov. 4th at the Eglise Protestante de l'Etoile, Paris 17.

title: Once, the Braves Were a Joke
description: Once upon a time, before Ted was married to Jane, the Atlanta Braves were a losing team. Talk about ancient history.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASIEL, BETTY L.
description: ASIEL-Betty L. Of White Plains, New York died on October 22, 1999 at Presbyterian Hospital. She was 81 years old. Mrs. Asiel is survived by her husband, E. Nelson Asiel; three children, Harold N., Terri L., John H. Asiel; two grandchildren, Carrie A. Grammas and Scott N. Asiel & one great granddaughter, Alexandria K. Grammas. Visiting hours on Sunday, October 24th, 3:30-5:30 P.M. at McMahon, Lyon & Hartnett Funeral Home, 491 Mamaroneck Avenue, White Plains, New York, (914) 949-7777. Burial will be private.

title: Do I Hear a Moo?
description: Mad Cows Sing, a Danish jazz septet, doesn't have any singers, let alone berserk bovine types. Rather, its name is a victory of the marketable moniker over content. But musically, there is plenty of content.

title: What's So Bad About Hate
description: Hate-crime legislation will be another knee-jerk response from politicians to a world depicted by the news media (rightly or wrongly) as increasingly more violent. It may prove that the press with its seemingly endless coverage of events like Columbine, Matthew Shepard and James Byrd will have a larger role in the prevention of hate crimes (however defined) than any piece of legislation could hope to do.

title: At Play in Formlessness With Nothing to Cling To
description: ''MORNING SONG,'' which opens on Wednesday for four performances as part of the Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, begins with several people sitting on stools and chatting into microphones. This informal talk-show panel then shifts into singing an intense rock song. A single woman dances to the bleating of an alarm clock. A tall man in a bear suit puts in an appearance, and an aromatic meal is cooked and consumed onstage in the course of the performance, which was created by the Flemish theater director Jan Lauwers and his international ensemble Needcompany.

title: A Failed Truce Among Leapfroggers
description: For a while, it looked as though the war between the states over next year's schedule for Presidential caucuses and primaries was over. The dozen or so upstart states that had been leapfrogging each other in the headlong scramble to be the first to caucus or hold a primary seemed by last weekend to have sorted themselves out or to have given up hope that national party leaders, especially Democratic leaders, would countenance more leapfrogging.

title: Shifting From Blood and Guts to Heart and Brains
description: IT'S not hard to believe that any director, even a veteran director, would feel butterflies at his first meeting with Meryl Streep, especially if that gold-standard actress was considering taking the lead in his new film.

title: October 17-23; One Less Candidate
description: Elizabeth Dole pulled out of the Presidential race -- before she had even officially announced her candidacy and long before a single ballot had been cast. She said she couldn't raise enough money to compete with the financial fortunes raised by Gov. George W. Bush of Texas or inherited by Steve Forbes.

title: A Sculptor's Response On Appeal of Abstract Art
description: To the Editor:

title: Soldier President
description: EISENHOWER

title: Correction
description: A report last Sunday about the wedding of Kerry Ann Armstrong and George Andrew Cheney included an outdated reference to the Roman Catholic priest who performed the ceremony. He was the Rev. Bradley Beaupre; the Rev. John C. Ozug was called away for an emergency.

title: Click Here to Save
description: IBM REDUX

title: From Land or Sea, the Picks Are Exciting
description: TO eat like a prince and pay like a pauper is the dream of every thrifty gourmet. The three-course $22 fixed-price dinner served every night except Friday and Saturday at 107 Ocean Bistro in Locust Valley makes it a reality. It offers a rare opportunity to sample the creative cooking of the chef-owner, Tom Schaudel, that is usually available only to those able to spend $20 to $25 for an entree alone. Mr. Schaudel and his kitchen crew generate the same excitement on nearly every plate, be it for an a la carte meal or fixed-price dinner.

title: Keeping in Shape The Ballet Way
description: DALE ROBINSON, who concedes that she is obsessed with fitness, is getting to fulfill a childhood fantasy of being a ballet dancer. But her mother has to hear about it every week.

title: Thinking of Mother and Creating a Series
description: It's dinnertime at the Gray household, and stage 18 on the Paramount Studios lot is heady with the smell of Chinese food. Around the family kitchen table, Amy Brenneman and her ''Judging Amy'' co-stars are rehearsing lines and cracking jokes -- when Ms. Brenneman sticks chopsticks in her ears, she elicits especially large laughs -- while wolfing the scene's meal: cartons of kung pao beef.

title: 'Threatening' Calls to Critic of Bars Lead to an Arrest for Harassment
description: Marcia Lemmon, a Community Board 3 member known for her opposition to bars in the neighborhood, said she thought at first it was a wrong number. Her phone would ring, and there would be an eerie silence when she picked up. But after a couple of times, she said, the calls became more than an annoyance.

title: Clayton Williams, 65, Ex-Inmate Who Helped Peers Rejoin Society
description: Clayton Williams, who used his experience as a criminal and a convict to help others like himself rejoin society, died on Oct. 14 in a Bronx hospital. He was 65.

title: Ms. Walker and Mr. Robinson
description: Julia Biddle Walker, the daughter of Julia and C. Carter Walker Jr. of Washington, Conn., was married there yesterday to Christopher Franklin Robinson, a son of Judith and Richard Robinson of Knoxville, Tenn. The Rev. Robert L. Ficks 3d performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church.

title: Letters to the Editor And a Former Classmate

description: HIPOLITO CUEVAS runs a 90-watt radio station that serves New Haven's 20,000 Spanish-speaking residents. He proudly calls it ''a full-service station,'' with news, public affairs, lots of music and many advertisers.

description: So what is Andrew Sullivan saying? That hate is complicated, irrational and quixotic and can be returned by those who are hated -- and that there-fore we shouldn't try to fight it? That the only defense is for the hated to rise above it?

title: In Clinton's Derailed Proposal for Medicare, a Question of Savings
description: CRITICS say the latest Clinton Administration proposal for a new managed care option in the Medicare program -- rebuffed in Congress last week but expected to be taken up next year -- is unlikely to achieve its goals of saving money for taxpayers and improving care for the 39 million older and disabled Americans whose health care costs are covered by the program. But Administration officials say this new option, which is still being developed, is a worthwhile experiment.

title: A Lost Kingdom of Satisfied Kids
description: THE moment of truth arrived, on a serving tray. My daughter, the grilled cheese maven, fixed her eyes on mine as her favorite lunch was placed before her. The chirpy Bahamian waiter suggested ketchup. The guy, I thought, had guts, interjecting himself between Lizzie and the one meal this heart-rendingly finicky eater would gladly step over my lifeless body for.

title: Patience Pays: Yankees Wait, Then Pounce
description: Orlando Hernandez stalked into the Yankees' clubhouse tonight, his work finished in Game 1 of the World Series. He had struck out 10, allowed one hit in seven innings -- and the Yankees were losing, 1-0. Furious that he had to come out of the game for a pinch-hitter, Hernandez barked in broken English, ''No like National League.''

title: Who's Afraid of the Pokemon Monster?
description: IF you know where to look you soon realize they are everywhere, from backpacks in the Bronx to back pockets in Queens. Magmar. Drowzee. Tangela. Pikachu.

title: The World; Victoria Would Not Be Amazed by Chile Today
description: CHILEANS like to call themselves the English of Latin America, referring to their reserved social etiquette and taste for afternoon tea, proper high-cut clothes and Tudor architecture. Probing even deeper into the national psyche, Chilean intellectuals identify national traits that hark back to another English century entirely.

title: Checklist of the Many Chores for the Season
description: THINGS are starting to wind down. But the tools should stay out and ready. It is not time to put them away just yet. In fact, the garden is still very much abloom in spite of the fact that the seasons have changed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LICHTMAN, CECIL
description: LICHTMAN-Cecil. 86. Of South Orange, NJ, and Palm Beach, FL, on October 22, 1999. Adored husband of Sima (nee Kislak-Jelin) and the late Doris (nee Schiffhaus); loving father of Richard and Jane, Joan, Paul and Heather Lichtman; grandfather of four grandchildren; brother of Jules; and stepfather of Abraham, Frederick, Anne, Sarah Jane Jelin, and Deborah Newmyer and the late William Jelin. Also survived by 13 step-grandchildren. Funeral service Sunday, October 24, 1999, at 1PM from Oheb Shalom Congregation in South Orange, NJ. Donations may be made to St. Barnabas Development Foundation for the Renal Dialysis Center, 95 Old Short Hills Rd., West Orange, NJ 07052.

title: For 28 Years, a Tag Sale Unites Volunteers
description: THEY said 1998 was positively their last year. They were getting older and if there were not enough young people to take over, it was obviously time to close down. But last week they were back for the 28th time: that same small committee of women who produce Planned Parenthood's gigantic tag sales and auctions at Lyndhurst here.

title: A Russian Versed in Theory Wins the World Junior Title
description: The 1999 World Junior Championship of the International Chess Federation, in Yerevan, Armenia, showed a general superiority of eastern players throughout the final standings, expecially at the top. The 67-player Swiss-system tournament, which ended Sept. 30, was won by a 20-year-old Russian grandmaster, Aleksandr Galkin, who tallied 10 1/2-2 1/2. The runner-up in this competition for entrants under 21 years old was Rustem Kasimdzhanov, an Uzbek grandmaster, who scored 10-3. Third prize was garnered by Karen Asrian, an Armenian grandmaster, who beat out his countryman, the international master Lev Aronian, on tiebreak after each had scored 9 1/2-3 1/2.

description: CONDOMINIUMS are making a spectacular comeback in Fairfield County, selling briskly to first-time buyers, empty-nesters, single professionals and investors.

title: October 17-23; Teen Worries, Up and Down
description: Being an American teen-ager today seems both scarier and safer than a few years ago, according to a new nationwide poll of more than 1,000 teen-agers by The New York Times and CBS News. The survey found that more than half believed that their school could conceivably be struck by the kind of massacre that devastated Columbine High School in Colorado. But in their more immediate, everyday lives, teen-agers reported feeling safer: Only 24 percent said they feared becoming a crime victim, compared to 40 percent in 1994, and concern about violence was generally down. CAREY GOLDBERG

title: Six Are Killed Across City In Seven Hours
description: It was an unusually violent night on the streets of New York City, full of shootings, stabbings and arson. Within seven hours -- from 9:30 P.M. Friday to 4:30 A.M. yesterday -- the Police Department reported six killings across the city, including the discovery of a woman gagged inside a burning house.

title: Plotting Course for Round-the-World Entry

The Rudigers had a grand adventure, but their absolute goal was denied when an onboard fire in the Mediterranean Sea cut short the cruise and the family eventually returned home to California. But the smell of salt air and the taste of offshore voyaging left a lasting impression on the boy.

title: Bashing The Burbs
description: It seemed to me that the subtext of Kevin Spacey's character in ''American Beauty'' was not that he had lost his ''warrior mojo,'' as David Gates suggests, but that he had, in fact, never grown up (The Way We Live Now, Oct. 3). Spacey's character may have ''reclaimed his manhood'' by pumping iron and listening to rock, but he grew up when he stopped treating his daughter's friend like a sex object and instead comforted her, cooked for her, listened to her -- when he acted like a man, caring for an adolescent.

title: Miranda on The Hot Seat
description: As one whose major field when receiving a Ph.D. at the University of Michigan was constitutional law, I have long wondered why an alternative to the Miranda warning would not be preferable. If suspects were immediately brought in, when arrested, and questioned by the police in the presence of an independent, court-appointed magistrate (to insure no third-degree tactics were employed), we could no doubt improve our conviction record and save time and money in the process. Suspects wouldn't have time to concoct an alibi, as now currently happens.

title: The Nation; There's Something About A Candidate in Uniform
description: ALTHOUGH Al Gore has been on the national political stage for decades, there is much that many voters still do not know about him, and he has recently been drawing attention to one of those blind spots: his military service in Vietnam.

title: No Spreading Chestnut, but the Urban Smithy Still Stands
description: It is dark inside the squat, flat-roofed building that houses Blacksmith of Trenton on a gritty stretch of North Olden Avenue. Except for a few small windows, the main source of light in the long, cavelike interior comes from a glowing forge. In fact, a hand forge has been continuously lighted here since 1883. Blacksmith of Trenton is not just the oldest but also the only commercial blacksmith left in New Jersey, and only one of around 20 blacksmith businesses still operating around the country, said Alex Parubchenko, who has owned the business since 1971. This month, Mr. Parubchenko was given an award for small business of the year by the City of Trenton. Mr. Parubchenko discussed the secrets of his success.

title: The Cable Guys
description: Before you decide whether to seek the Presidency of these United States on the Reform Party ticket -- and they say they are interested if you are -- there are some things you should know. The party's leftists are recruiting an anti-abortion, anti-immigration creationist, Pat Buchanan, as their champion. The party's centrists -- the heirs of prairie populism, with its dirty fingernails and rage at Eastern elites -- are eyeing a New York developer, Donald Trump, who made his fortune castling the rich and beating poorer people at games of chance. The party's most popular leader, Jesse Ventura, has contempt for one of its founding goals -- and some of the potential candidates are not precisely sure what those are, anyway.

title: It's Pianissimo for the Car Horn Concerto
description: For years, motorists have ignored a city law banning them from honking their horns except in emergencies.

title: A Home Office: Decisions, Decisions
description: THE first steps to creating a home office are evaluating your space needs and then finding a suitable place in your home. Next, estimate the amount of electrical power you need for equipment; after that you can determine if the existing household circuits can deliver the power without overloading.

description: After overseeing the five-year, nearly $50 million investigation that led to the impeachment of President Clinton, Whitewater independent counsel Kenneth W. Starr resigned. He was replaced by Robert W. Ray, a 39-year-old career Federal prosecutor who vowed to complete the inquiry of Mr. Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton ''in a prompt, reasonable and cost-effective manner.''

title: In the Region /Long Island; Short-Term Leases Luring Small-Space Tenants
description: ALAN GROSS'S office at 33 South Service Road in Jericho measures just 100 square feet, and it doesn't even have a window. But for the 37-year-old managing partner of Livewire USA, the fully furnished office he moved into Sept. 1 was the perfect fit for his business.

description: Jennifer Kahn Zeidman and Eugene Paul Bloch were married last evening in Washington. Rabbi M. Bruce Lustig performed the ceremony at the Four Seasons Hotel.

description: THE artist bent her brush to the canvas, finishing a third small white rectangle in an uneven field of green with an elliptical yellow mass above it, then stopped to assess her work.

Phillips of New York, was married yesterday to Christopher Alan Leppla, a son of Nancy Leppla of Fresno, Calif., and the late Dr. Bruce Leppla. The Rev. Robert Taylor performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Riverside, Conn.

title: IN MY... TRAVEL BAG: BARRY SALZMAN
description: Business travel can wreak havoc on a travel bag, says Barry Salzman, president for the international division of DoubleClick, the Internet advertising sales company based in New York. His Tumi leather bag becomes scuffed during his frequent trips around the world to meet with clients and colleagues. The road is no kinder to the body, Mr. Salzman said, which is why he packs a supply of powdered protein drinks and a jump rope to exercise in hotel rooms at night. ''You'll be happy to know that I don't use it on the plane,'' he said.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday about the Olympic runner Evelyn Ashford, with a front-page article about the long friendship between her coach, Pat Connolly, and another former Olympian, Willye White, misstated the year in which Ashford was shown competing in Seoul. It was 1988, not 1984.

title: Lily Rutherfurd And Bruce Kinlin
description: Elizabeth Polk Rutherfurd, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Winthrop Rutherfurd Jr. of New York, was married last evening to Bruce David Kinlin, a son of Mrs. Francis Sargent Kinlin of Jonesport, Me., and the late Mr. Kinlin. The Rev. Mark G. Hallinan performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title: Guadeloupe as Language Lab
description: I'D been in Guadeloupe only 48 hours and already I had attended a birthday party where I ate curried goat with wild peas (pois des bois, greatly prized) and drank the local rum punch; had struggled 4,800 feet up to and down from a volcano after five hours' sleep, and had soaked or muddied about a third of my wardrobe, including my one pair of sneakers -- which, however, were totally inadequate for near-vertical paths of rock and mud.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Fiat Multipla and Ford Ka; Making the Scene, Avant-Garde Europeans Hit New York's Streets
description: AZ SNIDER was making his way through the afternoon crush of pedestrians in Rockefeller Center when the sight of a green, four-wheeled, six-passenger frog stopped him cold.

title: Discovering Mrs. Hirsch
description: THE notice went up by the elevator like similar announcements before it: Mrs. Mina Hirsch, a longtime resident of our building on West 76th Street, had died. The widow's family planned a small gathering, the notice continued, and would welcome condolence calls at her apartment. Her apartment! My husband and I had the same swift response. Her apartment might be available, and it had more space than ours.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Documented Aliens

title: Lives; A Life Goes
description: In 1982, Philip Workman was sentenced to death in a Tennessee court for killing a police officer during a robbery. ''We sat in the back row,'' recalls his brother, Terry, ''and the judge pointed his finger at us: 'Not one word from you when I read the verdict.' Everyone in the room wanted us to suffer.'' Behind bars since then, Philip has remained close to his daughter, Michele, and her children, as well as to Susan, whom he met five years ago when she answered an ad he placed from prison: ''If you believe in Matthew 25:40, I would like to know your heart.'' At first, they weren't permitted to see each other, so Philip made tapes. ''It was love on first hearing,'' Susan says. These days, his family often gathers around the speakerphone at Susan's to talk to him. ''Paw paw,'' crows his 7-year-old grandson. ''Hello there,'' Philip answers. ''It's so good to be with you all.''

title: East Timor's Aftermath
description: On Aug. 30, East Timor voted for independence from Indonesia after 24 years of brutal repression. Within days, however, pro-Jakarta militias, aided and supported by the Indonesian Army, resumed a campaign of violence and terror, rampaging through the cities of Dili, Suai, Maliana and Balibo, wielding machetes, guns, clubs and knives.

title: The Slumber Is Over As La-Z-Boy Expands
description: FOR years, La-Z-Boy Inc. had a somewhat sleepy image: a midsized Midwestern company that was modestly well run and known for its signature product -- a comfortable reclining chair. But a string of acquisitions -- three announced this year -- have some investors thinking there may be a lot of spring in this 72-year-old business, which is based in Monroe, Mich.
