title: Dogs Won't Have Their Day at the Track
description: After months of disputes, the Parks Department decided last week to shelve a plan to build a dog run on the field inside the small running track in Riverside Park. Instead, a temporary dog run is to open this week at the upper level of the park by Riverside Drive and 72d Street, near the statue of Eleanor Roosevelt.

title: Trouble in Paradise
description: To the Editor:

title: A Municipal Mechanic
description: ''THE king of mayors.''

title: When a Grand View Has a Steep Price
description: I NO longer recall what led us to the Capilano Suspension Bridge; it hadn't been in my husband's plans for Vancouver, and it would certainly not have been in mine. But I will never forget the pride with which I set out to cross it; a stroll for most people, this walk-in-air would be a triumph for me, a victory over fear.

title: Out of Marx's Shadow Steps a Subtle Serialist
description: AS the artworks of this century age and grow distant, we gain a better perspective on their import. The music of the Venetian composer Luigi Nono, which was widely characterized during his lifetime as Marxist agitprop and viewed primarily through the lens of the political texts he often adopted, has come to sound different after the fall of Communism in Europe. If we regard Nono's works in purely musical terms, his Serial compositions are revealed as concentrated explorations of subtle tone colors, supremely calibrated pianissimos, and spatial and acoustic innovation.

title: Owners Plan to Restore Ski Lodge Damaged by Fire
description: The base lodge at the Mountain Creek ski area that was destroyed by an electrical fire on Oct. 10 will be replaced by the beginning of ski season Dec. 18, Intrawest, its owner, said Thursday.

title: Bringing America Up to Speed
description: NEW art has rarely had as many reluctant champions as ''Sensation,'' the exhibition of work by young English artists from the collection of Charles Saatchi, the English advertising executive, at the Brooklyn Museum of Art. People both inside and outside the art world have been defending to the death the exhibition's right to be seen in a public museum, while turning up their noses at the art it contains or dismissing it wholesale.

title: How I Really Got That Story
description: I RECENTLY entered into high-level negotiations for an interview and photo shoot with a young Hollywood actress, soon to co-star in her first big-budget movie. Her publicity agent dictated the terms: Star Girl wouldn't wear fur in photographs. My magazine couldn't discuss her relationship with her boyfriend (also an actor). We had to mention in the photo credits the cosmetics line she endorsed. And most important, we couldn't pose her in provocative clothing: no bikinis, lingerie or cleavage, despite the fact that Star Girl had made her initial splash baring her breasts in a steamy thriller only a year earlier.

title: Stevenson of Cuba Arrested in Miami
description: Teofilo Stevenson, the three-time Olympic superheavyweight boxing gold medalist, was arrested at Miami International Airport early yesterday for aggravated battery and resisting arrest with violence, the police said.

description: THE Nissan Motor Company could well serve as a metaphor for postwar Japan.

description: AQUAGRILL **

title: Celebrating Picasso in Barcelona
description: The Picasso Museum in Barcelona will hold a double inauguration on Tuesday, adding two medieval mansions to its exhibition space and unveiling in them what the museum considers to be its most important temporary exhibition ever, ''Picasso: Interior and Exterior Landscape,'' on view through Jan. 30.

title: A New World of Finance
description: Even without new laws enacted by Congress, the financial world has hurtled through many changes in recent years. Now with the agreement in Washington on Friday to overhaul the nation's banking laws, American businesses and consumers face even more transformation. Legislation agreed to by the White House and the Republican leadership will sweep away the Depression-era curbs that have kept banks, securities firms and insurance companies from moving into one another's arenas. The proposed deregulation is designed to help American companies expand abroad and become more efficient at home. But the breakthrough agreement was made possible by the lawmakers' willingness to try to protect consumers and poor communities from being trampled in the process.

title: Recycling Yard Fatality
description: Peekskill officials have asked the Federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration to investigate the second fatality in five months at a private recycling yard, Patrick Garvey, the City Manager, said.

title: When Three Sewers was a Home Run
description: Want to know what earned you a double in a Cropsey Avenue stickball game? How about the Hunts Point rules for playing skully, an antiquated game featuring bottle caps and a chalked circle on the sidewalk?

title: Miranda on The Hot Seat
description: Paul Cassell, the law professor who challenges the Miranda decision, may or may not be ideologically driven, but he has a strong constitutional argument (Roger Parloff, Sept. 26). The Fifth Amendment, upon which Miranda is purportedly based, bars involuntary confessions, whereas Miranda requires the exclusion of perfectly voluntary confessions if its often-confusing requirements are not met.

title: Unmasked Klan Is Besieged at Manhattan Rally
description: Eighteen Ku Klux Klan members, vastly outnumbered by scores of reporters, photographers and television crews, hundreds of riot-helmeted police officers and thousands of counterdemonstrators, stood in silent protest for an hour and 15 minutes yesterday in the limp finale to a constitutional melodrama stretching from City Hall to the United States Supreme Court.

title: Once Scorned, Now Shiny, Shuttle Returns
description: Kaitlin Byrd, 11, has been watching the reconstruction of the Franklin Avenue Shuttle for the last 18 months, catching peeks of progress from the street and her living room. ''I sort of have an obsession with the shuttle,'' she said, as she rode on the train's ceremonial first trip Monday.

title: Stars in Their Eyes; 'Doubts Pop Into Your Mind. Like, Man, Is It Really Going to Happen?'
description: June 4, the day after he moved to New York from Miami, is a date etched in Mick LeRoy's consciousness. That morning, Mr. LeRoy, 30, a muscular actor with chiseled features and easygoing charm, got a job as a waiter at Charley O's near Times Square. That afternoon, he was introduced to the director of an Off Off Broadway play, who hired him on the spot to understudy a major character in a drama called ''Soul Love.''

title: October 17-23; A Memorial Addresses a Wrong
description: The Federal agents moved swiftly, rounding up the fathers in thousands of families and taking them away without a pretense of due process. The families soon followed, with armed guards railroading them to desert internment camps -- 120,000 men, women and children forced into domestic exile solely because their Japanese ancestry suddenly became suspect after Pearl Harbor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, FRIEDA (NEE KABAKOV)
description: LEVINE-Frieda (nee Kabakov) of Deal, New Jersey. Formerly of Jersey City, New Jersey. Born in Minsk, Russia. Passed away on September 30th, 1999 after a brief illness. Wife of Morton M. Levine, deceased in 1990. Adored mother of Isadora L. Chamlin & husband George, Deal; Irwin Levine and wife Renee, NYC; loving grandmother of Raina Baim, husband Neil, NYC; Kenneth Chamlin, Deal; Jordana and Joelle Levine, NYC; great grandmother of Ari Baim. Always the optimist, mentally and physically active throughout her life. A woman of style, grace and dignity, whose spirituality and love of family will inspire us always.

title: What's So Bad About Hate
description: Sullivan's article was a true portrait of what hate is and is not. As a 16-year-old high-school student, I was glad to see that he did not try to explain away Columbine with simple phrases like guns, video games, peer pressure. It was nice not to be condescended to by someone who has all the answers.

title: The World: Secular Rules; In Indonesia, Islamic Politics Doesn't Mean Religion
description: IT doesn't take a theologian to describe the political role of Islam here.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-24-99; The Battle Of the Binge
description: Back in the 70's -- my college time -- an English professor I barely knew named Ted Stirling spotted me on the quad and invited me to a small, informal reading after supper. Maybe he felt sorry for me. I had marooned myself in the French ghetto of la litterature comparative, and had further exiled myself in the cul-de-sac between Latin and Spanish. So I went that night to sit on stuffed sofas beneath scowling bishops in gilt frames and to discuss Wallace Stevens's poem ''Thirteen Ways of Looking at a Blackbird.'' Afterward, Stirling bought the students a pitcher of beer at the pub, and we strained to act intelligently and comfortably while drinking with an elder. (''Stevens an insurance agent! Surely you jest, Professor. Why, that would make poets the unacknowledged underwriters of the world, wouldn't you agree?'')

title: Delicate as a Cirrus Cloud
description: Seasoned bargain-hunters value Spain, especially the Rueda region. The lucky ones have discovered '98 Basa, a stylish knockoff of Marquis de Riscal whites, which put Rueda on the wine map in the 70's.

title: UNIVERSITY PRESSES; The Conversion of Lorelei Lee
description: IN SEARCH OF AMERICAN JEWISH CULTURE By Stephen J. Whitfield. Illustrated. 307 pp. Hanover, N.H.: Brandeis University Press/ University Press of New England. $26.

description: Q: Your screenplay for ''Bringing Out the Dead,'' about an unbalanced ambulance driver, won't change your image, dating back to ''Taxi Driver,'' as a very dark writer. What draws you to these characters?

title: Student Is Still Missing A Year After Vanishing
description: It has been one year since Kristine Kupka, a 28-year-old Baruch College student, left the Brooklyn home she shared and never returned. The police believe that Ms. Kupka, who was five months pregnant, was killed, but her body has not been found.

title: Tribe in U.S. Is a Rich Ally For Aborigine
description: When Letty Scott, an Australian who traces her maternal ancestry to a community of desert Aborigines, decided to go international with her campaign against what she sees as persistent police brutality against her people, she found help in some unexpected places. Not least was Foxwoods, the Connecticut casino resort run by Pequot Indians.

title: Style; Gimme Shelter
description: For most of us, the words ''temporary housing'' bring to mind a bland space filled with so-so furniture, where we kill time until the Real Thing comes along. The trouble with most of us is that we are not Donna Karan.

title: October 17-23; A Drop in Gun Violence
description: A seven percent drop in homicides last year was entirely attributable to a decrease in killings committed with guns, according to a report released by the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The decline appears to be the clearest evidence yet that recent efforts to reduce gun violence through new laws and police pressure are working. There was also a 10 percent drop in robberies carried out with guns, accounting for the biggest decrease of any one category of crime.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption on Oct. 10 about the sculptor J. Seward Johnson Jr. misstated the title of the painting he was shown recreating and the name of the artist. It is ''The Japanese Footbridge and the Water Lily Pool at Giverny,'' not ''On Poppied Hill.'' The artist was Monet, not Manet.

The paneled chambers of the General Assembly and the Security Council still glow with the elegance of the dreams that inspired them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AXLER, MELVIN

title: Europe's Walls for Gypsies
description: Ten days ago, the Czech town of Usti nad Labem managed to symbolize both of Europe's 20th-century pathologies -- Communism and Nazism -- when it erected a six-foot-high concrete wall to separate a Gypsy neighborhood from one of ethnic Czechs. The wall, called a ''law and order'' measure by the town's mayor, has been condemned by the Czech Republic's government and Parliament, and by President Vaclav Havel. But it still stands, and is very popular in Usti nad Labem.

Absolutely no presents, she insisted. Instead, as she tearfully told her girlfriends gathered in an East Side brownstone, she wanted them to assure her she wouldn't ''disappear down a black hole'' as a mother of two in Manhattan.

title: Two Great Talents of Musical Theater, Where Their Paths Intersected
description: SOME people need to hold on to the myth that musicals are meant to give you a real good time, or at least inspire you to become a good person. And no one has demythologized musicals better than Stephen Sondheim, whose nervy genius and divine perversity have empowered the musical theater to validate our neuroses and just let us be honestly reflective, intelligently miserable and simply lonely, knowing we're in very good company.

title: Owning A Co-op in Splitsville
description: WHEN Franck Amsallem was going through a divorce in 1992, the last thing he was concerned about, he says, was what would eventually become of the co-op apartment in Brooklyn that he and his wife had purchased.

In fact, the notion that they could be the good guys nearly vanished with ''The Green Berets,'' a 1968 John Wayne turkey that was washed away in the churning political waters of its era.

title: Echoes of '68 on Columbia's Campus
description: ALFRED LERNER HALL, the new student center at Columbia University, will plunge some baby boomer alumni into a cool nostalgic bath. The architect, Bernard Tschumi, has long made a touchstone of ''the events of '68'': the student uprisings that for many epitomize the turmoil of the 1960's. Columbia University's architecture school was one of the epicenters. It was here that faculty members joined students in protesting a gymnasium scheduled to rise in Morningside Park. From there the protest spread outward until it had engulfed much of the campus in a generalized rebellion against authority, war and civilized restraint.

title: What's So Bad About Hate
description: Andrew Sullivan's article (Sept. 26) is the best writing on the phenomenon of hate crimes that I've read -- timely, balanced and profoundly attuned to the human condition. He pens an eloquent plea that in our civic life we ''co-exist despite hate'' and, as much as humanly possible, rise above it. He points the way. We as a people will be sadder but wiser to heed his call.

When the water was again calm at the end of today's matches, officials had listened to the bruised and battered contestants and postponed the last races of the first round-robin in the Louis Vuitton Cup series until Wednesday. Round 1 was to have concluded Sunday.

The gallery has been given blue walls for the occasion and there is a lot of blue in landscape paintings where the ocean figures prominently. As viewers follow the paintings around the room, their meaning and import grow.

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-24-99: The Ethicist; Be Medicareful
description: My mother has Alzheimer's disease and her doctor has warned me that she soon will need to be placed in a nursing home. Several years ago, her lawyer advised me to transfer her assets to my name so that she could qualify for Medicaid and I could inherit her money. This is perfectly legal, and according to other people in the same situation I've spoken to, it is widely done. But is it ethical? /G.O.

title: Fade to Black
description: When I was a baby, my mother dressed me in black, which, if you know my mother, makes perfect sense. She has had a lifelong fascination with black, but the decision to create an all-black apartment seemed extreme, even to me. So, right before she and my dad were about to move out of their spacious apartment overlooking Central Park West (complicated by the fact that the space had to be restored to its original color), I asked her,What is it with you and black?

title: University Presses Books in Brief: Nonfiction; An Artist for Life
description: In 1936, when Morris Wyszogrod turned 16, his parents pawned belongings to send him to Warsaw's Marshal Josef Pilsudski School of Graphics, an exclusive art school which accepted only a few Jewish students. Their sacrifice saved his life. During World War II, Wyszogrod told a young German officer he was an artist. He was given pen, ink and paper to write nameplates of soldiers, then asked to paint the officer's portrait in charcoal. He was rewarded with a special identification card that read ''The Jew shown in this photograph . . . is permitted to walk unescorted between the airfield and the Jewish district.'' The Kunstmahler, as he became known, painted more portraits of officers and their girlfriends and made a sign that said ''Fr Juden und Hunde Zutritt Verboten!'' (''Entry forbidden to Jews and dogs''), while secretly producing fake ID's for members of the Jewish resistance. Wyszogrod's talent was also his salvation at the Budzyn, Plaszow and Theresienstadt concentration camps, where he redecorated SS living quarters, produced pornographic drawings and painted coffins for German soldiers. A Brush With Death: An Artist in the Death Camps (State University of New York, cloth, $44.50; paper, $14.95) is a heartbreaking, succinctly told memoir, as well as a fascinating parable of the way society treats artists. Wyszogrod includes drawings he made in the camps, photographs and loving descriptions of his father, a professional musician from Lublin who fixed instruments, and his Warsaw-born mother, a theatrical costume designer. After the liberation of Theresienstadt in 1945, he learned they had perished in the camps, along with his three siblings. He was reunited with his Uncle Mendel in New York in 1947. In 1952 he married Helen Rosenberg, who survived the war in Poland. They have two children and six grandchildren. His daughter Diane, who married the son of Auschwitz survivors, edited her father's poignant story. Susan Shapiro

title: Saugatuck Women Regain Title
description: Whitecaps in the Charles River Basin delayed the 35th Head of the Charles Regatta yesterday in Cambridge, Mass., but once races got under way the Saugatuck Rowing Association of Westport, Conn., regained the women's club four with coxswain title.

title: October 17-23; Scientists Find Enzyme Linked to Alzheimer's
description: Scientists have known for years that to forestall or treat Alzheimer's disease they needed to prevent hard balls of debris from accumulating in the brain. Now researchers at Amgen have taken the first step toward that goal. They found an elusive enzyme that snips a brain protein in two, initiating the formation of the debris. The next challenge, experts say, is to find a drug that will block that enzyme. If the scientific theory is correct, such a drug might halt the death of brain cells in people with the disease and even prevent the disease in people destined to get it. GINA KOLATA

title: Israel's Y2K Problem
description: Imagine anyone starting a war over the moronic myths enumerated in Goldberg's article. Still, one has to ask: if both cities were attacked at the same time and we could save only one, which city would we defend with the lives of our sons and daughters -- Jerusalem, the birthplace of religion, or Athens, the birthplace of democracy?

title: A Linguistic Big Bang
description: When the greek historian herodotus was traveling in Egypt, he heard of a bizarre experiment conducted by a King named Psammetichus. The inquisitive monarch, wrote Herodotus, decided to wall up two baby boys in a secluded compound. Whatever came out of the boys' mouths, reasoned the King, would be the root language of our species -- the key to all others. Herodotus tells us that eventually the children came up with the Phrygian word for bread, bekos. In addition to demonstrating the superiority of the Phrygian tongue, the King's inquiry proved that even if left to their own devices, children wouldn't be without language for long. We are born, Herodotus suggested, with the gift of gab.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLUCK, RUTH RUBIN
description: GLUCK-Ruth Rubin. Cherished wife of Marshall. Loving mother of Abbe and Simon. Adored daughter of Anna and the late Moses Rubin. Beloved sister of Judy Rubin. Dear daughter-in-law of Gertrude and Milton Shapiro. Admired sister-in-law of Bill, Richard and Melissa Gluck and Garth Hayden. In her too-short time with us she amazed us all with her ability to achieve so much while remaining completely devoted to her family. She was an accomplished corporate attorney at Metropolitan Life for 30 years, a perpetual student of Judaism and the arts, and the best wife and mother a family could hope for. Her intelligence, grace and beauty marked every aspect of her life and made her one of those few special people among us. She will be loved and with us always. Service at Park Avenue Synagogue, 87th Street and Madison Ave., Monday, October 25, at 10:30 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Advanced Research Foundation, 449 E. 68th St., Ste 2, NY NY 10021.

''I love real earthy, nutty-flavored mushrooms,'' he said enthusiastically, ''because they soak up the flavor of anything you cook them with.''

title: Footnotes; Black Studies
description: 1. One of the most stylish black rooms of the 20th century -- the hall at Folly Farm, in Berkshire, England -- was done not by a decorator but by an architect. Sir Edwin Lutyens (1869-1944) is widely admired for his bold reinterpretation of Renaissance classicism, and this 1912 room is no exception. Glossy black walls are framed by white enamel-painted woodwork, while the balcony is painted red to match the lacquered cabinet below it. Lutyens is probably best known for his romantic country houses, some of which have gardens by the legendary Gertrude Jekyll. But he also designed the British Embassy in Washington and the Viceroy's House in New Delhi. Lutyens's smallest although certainly not least important project was a gift he designed for Queen Mary in the early 1920's -- a doll house, with flush toilets, electricity and working elevators.

They occupy a 90-gallon tank in a sunny spot in the middle of the living room of his Bronx apartment. Mr. Maldonado also owns a boa constrictor named Diamond, but his caiman, a two-and-a-half-foot relative of the crocodile, is now in a friend's custody, returning only for occasional visits.

title: Art Club
description: When Timothy Greenfield-Sanders was a film student in the 70's, he got advice from some people whose pictures he snapped. ''Are you crazy, photographing me from below?'' was Bette Davis's contribution to his education. A quarter-century later, he is the photographer of choice for celebrities like Monica Lewinsky -- and the celebritizer of the New York art world. Starting Oct. 29, Mary Boone's gallery in Manhattan will be covered floor to ceiling with 700 of Greenfield-Sanders's portraits: every picture he has taken, over 20 years, of an artist, dealer, curator, museum director or art critic (excluding this one but including the Mayor of New York). ''Timothy Greenfield-Sanders: Art World,'' will also appear in book form next month. A shifting barometer of downtown taste, the photographs include Andy Warhol on one hand and, on the other, many people who fulfilled Warhol's prediction about fame. Superstar or shooting star, everyone through Greenfield-Sanders's lens somehow ends up looking like a Marxist revolutionary, improbably suave and preposterously serious. He has photographed dozens of artists almost at the instant they splashed on the scene (see the Starn twins and Elizabeth Peyton) -- and sometimes earlier. The pictures of David Hammons (1980) and David Wojnarowicz (1983) are virtually clairvoyant. Two decades ago he started out with portraits of artists who came of age in the 50's, and they may still be his catchiest pictures. These include Joan Mitchell, who refused to take off her glasses, and an equally brassy Elaine de Kooning, doing her best Dorothy Parker. Portraiture, like all art, is in the eye of the beholder; de Kooning told Greenfield-Sanders that the portrait looked just like her, ''aloof and demur.'' Michael Kimmelman

title: Give Us This Day...
description: Indulging in a daily happy hour is not the usual advice found in self-help books. But the kind of happy hour Stephanie Stokes Oliver prescribes is not the kind spent in a bar, but an hour a day doing ''something that makes you happy.'' That is one of the entries in her ''Daily Cornbread'' ($22.95, Doubleday) which is subtitled ''365 Secrets for a Healthy Mind, Body and Spirit,'' Ms. Olivery, who lives in Montclair, was the founder of Heart and Soul magazine, which was aimed mainly at African-American women, and now runs her own media consulting firm. Her book's entry for June 19 tells readers that day is Juneteenth, a celebration that commemorates the day in Texas, June 19, 1865, that slaves were informed they had been freed - two and a half years earlier. She recommends readers' own celebrations that day. Other entries are dedicated to developing healthy habits (''Go ride a bike,'' May 1) and a spiritual outlook (''No one can make your life complete but you,'' Feb. 5).

description: Because of an editing error, an automobile review of the Mitsubishi Eclipse last Sunday misstated the car's production site. As noted in a table with the review, it is Normal, Ill., not Japan.

title: Big Thoughts, Still Uncensored
description: RADIO ANNOUNCER: The following is a dramatization.

title: Numbers That Don't Matter Much These Days
One Man's Home Is Another's Disaster Area
description: MEMO to the Environmental Protection Agency, Washington:

title: University Presses Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: HARLEM GALLERY

title: Meredith Simpson, Christopher Ernst
description: Meredith Jane Simpson, a daughter of Emily and William F. Simpson of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Christopher David Ernst, the son of Patricia and Clifford Ernst of Fredericksburg, Tex. Judge Colleen McMahon of Federal District Court in White Plains officiated at Estherwood, a historic house in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

title: Food; Fresh Prince
description: What becomes a man who assumes a legendary post? For Eberhard Mller, who took over the kitchen of Lut ce five years ago, after the restaurant's founding chef, Andre Soltner, retired, the answer is: humility.

title: Henry's Series Interest
description: Enthusiasm turned to resignation this season as John Henry, the owner of the Florida Marlins, watched as his young team finished with the National League's worst record. But Henry still has a chance for a World Series ring.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OWENS, GRADY JR.
description: OWENS-Grady Jr. On September 12. Of Orange County, NY. Businessman and community leader. Son of the late Grady and Bridget Healy Owens. Born July 20, 1938. Survived by his wife of 29 years, two daughters, Diane Fulston, Erin Owens one son, Grady III and one grandson Bryce Fulston. A brother Franklin Owens and three sisters, Catherine Owens, Maureen Dubison, Alice Gray. We mourn the passing of our beloved brother. His cherished memory will live forever in our hearts.

title: New Owner For a Pair Of Papers
description: For 66 years, The Villager, a weekly newspaper, has covered Greenwich Village. Now it and its sister paper, The Downtown Express, published every other week and dedicated to the neighborhoods below Canal Street, have a new owner.

title: Got a Best Friend?
description: Who's your best friend? Somebody you met in kindergarten? On your first job? A neighbor who dropped by to lend a hand?

title: Memorial for Leo Castelli
description: A memorial service for the art dealer Leo Castelli is to be held on Tuesday at 6 P.M. in the Great Hall at Cooper Union, East Seventh Street at Third Avenue, in the East Village. Among those who are to speak are Agnes Gund, president of the Museum of Modern Art; Ivan Karp, Mr. Castelli's assistant; Richard Gray, president of the Art Dealers Association of America, and the artist Keith Sonnier. Mr. Castelli died in August at the age of 91.

title: The View From/Yorktown; Jazz Party Adds Nuptials As a Surprise Attraction
description: THE 75 guests at Joan Gilbert's antique Tudor house here last Sunday knew they were coming to hear a jazz jam session and to eat from a table laden with hors d'oeuvres, miniature pumpkins and decorative autumn leaves. But they did not know until they got there that they would also be attending a wedding.

title: Trance Casts a Spell Over the Youth Of a Worried Israel
description: ONE day last May, 10,000 young people crowded into a beach-side park north of here, dressed in tank-top T-shirts and tie-dye shorts, brandishing rings from every visible body part -- ears, noses, lips, bellybuttons -- and dancing wildly to a techno beat that has become the latest casus belli in Israel's most overlooked war: the one between the generations. The music, a throbbing, lyric-free form of psychedelic electronica known as trance, has swept the country in recent years, enveloping everyone from bar mitzvah candidates to elite Air Force pilots, and prompting the authorities to clamp down on what they consider a subversive form of entertainment that promotes the use of illegal drugs.

title: How Much of a River Can a City Claim?
description: THE Shepaug River flows through Litchfield County, slicing deep valleys in some of Connecticut's most scenic nature preserves. It has long been a favorite place for sportsmen, hikers, picnicking families and nature lovers. It is also a source of drinking water for Waterbury, an arrangement the city has had since 1921. But conservation groups and towns along the river have long claimed that the diversion of millions of gallons of water a day to the city has lowered the river and damaged its ecosystem. Two years ago, they filed a lawsuit challenging the 1921 agreement.

title: Streetscapes/Appellate Division, 25th Street and Madison Avenue; A Milky White Courthouse With Rooftop Sculptures
description: THE milky white 1900 Appellate Division courthouse at 25th Street and Madison Avenue had barely made it past the half century mark when the first problems with deteriorating marble arose and almost cost the building its distinctive rooftop ring of sculptures. Now a second major repair campaign is beginning, with uncertain promise -- marble and New York City air don't mix well.

title: An Epidemic of Death
description: NIGHT FALLS FAST

title: Art for Humanity's Sake
description: CANDOR and PERVERSION

title: In Bizarre Ending, Tyson Bout Is Declared a No Contest
description: The bizarre boxing world of Mike Tyson continued tonight.

title: Putting the W's in www
description: Weaving the Web

title: Pop That's Produced Alone at Home Gets Personal
description: THE way some guys feel about their sports car or their frisbee-catching golden retriever, F. M. Cornog feels about his Tascam 388. This simple eight-track analog recorder sits silently, splendidly, on a table in an upstairs room of his Summit, N.J., home, bathed in natural light from windows framed by leafy suburban trees. Mr. Cornog sits down in his humbly appointed home studio, which also includes a few scattered instruments (guitars, a selection of keyboards, a bass with just two strings on it), some Asbury Park souvenir postcards tacked up as art and a taped-up picture of his musical inspiration, Paul Christopher Moschette, a lounge singer on a Jersey Shore cruise boat.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: COLUMBUS CIRCLE; A Final Sale That Means Goodbye to the Vendors
description: For nearly five years, Alis and Tak Cicek of Queens had the equivalent of their own little clothing shop at the heart of Columbus Circle. ''This is my life,'' said Alis, as she and her husband sat on metal folding chairs in their kiosk outside the New York Coliseum. ''I take care of myself here.''

title: Word for Word/Culture Clash; Martha vs. the W. W. F.: The Final Confit
description: THE news from Wall Street last week drew attention to probably the most startling contrast imaginable in American popular culture: Martha Stewart and the World Wrestling Federation, both going public to investors on the same day.

title: Instead of the Singing Telegram, Generators and Cooling Systems
description: It's noisy on Hudson Street. The sound is coming from a big office building and its neighbors' howls of complaint.

title: I'm Irrational, You're Irrational
description: SLEEPING WITH EXTRA-TERRESTRIALS The Rise of Irrationalism and Perils of Piety. By Wendy Kaminer. 278 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $24.

title: INVESTING WITH: James B. Rubin; Resurgence Asset Management
description: WHEN it comes to James B. Rubin's line of work, it's fine to be a control freak. As chief investment officer and co-chairman of Resurgence Asset Management, a $1 billion manager of hedge funds and other investments in White Plains, Mr. Rubin often strives to influence the fates of companies in which he has invested.

title: How the Other Half Lived It Up
description: TIME and again this summer, Michael Kane was drawn up a marble staircase at Grand Central Terminal, then up two more flights in the terminal's southwest corner to a glass door guarded by ornate metal gates. Behind those doors, he had heard, was a hall that resembled a 13th-century Italian palazzo, once the private offices of a tycoon named John W. Campbell.

title: Ousted Loft Tenants Are Caught Off Guard
description: Dozens of tenants of a loft apartment building in Williamsburg found a nasty surprise waiting for them early yesterday when they came home from late-night revels: their recently converted building was locked and guarded by the police.

title: Morning Becomes Bryant Gumbel
description: Last winter, Bryant Gumbel climbed onto a private plane heading back to New York after a weekend of golf on Kiawah Island, S.C. Accompanied by a longtime golfing buddy, Gumbel gave no sign that he was under pressure, no hint that he was facing a difficult decision.

title: Habitats/Lighthouse Hill, Staten Island; A Landmark 1959 Home With All the Wright Stuff
description: THE house had been on the market, on and off, for years. Depending on your perspective, it is a very 1950's house that needs to be modernized with new baths and a new kitchen -- or it's an architectural treasure.

title: For Israel, Long Denied Full U.N. Privileges, Some Progress
description: Israel, isolated at the United Nations for 50 years, is very close to securing a place in a regional group from which it can compete for a Security Council seat and other positions, Israeli and Western diplomats said this week.

title: High-Risk Irony Goes in Search of Its Time
description: AS one of its fans has said, watching a theater production by the experimental Wooster Group is like walking through the Port Authority bus terminal or a shopping mall: there is no single point of focus, no right interpretation.

title: How to Play The Internet, With Apple
description: MAYBE it's time to look at Apple Computer Inc. in a different light: as an Internet stock. As Apple points out in advertising for new versions of its popular iMac computer, 90 percent of iMac owners are connected to the Internet -- an astonishingly high share -- and most of them got wired the first day they owned the machine. So maybe Apple is an Internet platform company.

title: Looming At Center Of Ranger Problems
description: Watching P. J. Stock cover Eric Lindros is like watching a barking terrier chase a sport utility vehicle. What would the terrier do if it actually caught the S.U.V.? And what would the S.U.V. do to a terrier that accidentally slipped beneath its moving wheels?

title: Saints and Sinners
description: THE 27TH KINGDOM

title: Patching the Safety Net For the Mentally Ill
description: THESE days, Julia Rothstein can't be sure where her son will end up living. She said that after being evicted for rowdyism from his apartment in Huntington this summer, her 48-year-old son, diagnosed as a manic depressive, found shelter in hospitals, a crisis center and his car.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRAGER, SYLVIA A. (NEE ALTSCHULER)
description: PRAGER-Sylvia A. (nee Altschuler). 84, of Hollywood, FL, passed away Friday, October 22, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Abbey; loving mother of Louise Posman and Chuck, Dr. Mark and Lynn Altschuler; cherished grandmother of Abbey and Scott, Alisa and Dan, Elizabeth, Andrew, and Michael; adored great-grandmother of Nichole; dear sister of Elsie and Morris Ross. Graveside service Sunday, 12 noon, at Mount Judah Cemetery, Ridgewood, NY. For further information, contact Menorah Chapels Inc., Staten Island.

title: Melville, a Modern
description: To the Editor:

title: O'Neill Gets His Wish, and He Might Even Be Happy
description: Paul O'Neill had been ornery and cranky while waiting five days for the World Series to start tonight. He was tired of being bombarded with questions and simply wanted to play baseball, not talk about it.

title: Sublimity in Simplicity
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Build Atop a Building
description: BUILDING on top of a building is both an academic and a concrete pursuit for Arun Rimal, a professor of structural engineering at the Columbia University School of Architecture, Planning and Preservation.

title: Maddux Steps In, And Can't Quite Win
description: Greg Maddux got a note from his wife this morning. She was taking their children and getting out of the way. Tom Glavine was still feeling as sick as he sounded Friday night when he called the house to give Maddux a warning, and Maddux -- who had planned to spend today reviewing hitters in preparation for his Game 2 start -- was now the starter for Game 1.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FEDERICO, GENE
description: FEDERICO-Gene. Philosopher, perfectionist, consummate magician with type, Gene put the ''art'' into Art Director and was a long time member and Hall of Fame laureate of the Art Directors Club. He will be remembered Tuesday, October 26, 6PM, at the ADC Gallery, 250 Park Avenue South.

description: THE PLAY GOES ON

description: EPSTEIN-Jack. We mourn the loss of our friend and benefactor. Sincere condolences to his family. Child Care Women's League Lucille Silvey, President

description: WAGSHUL-Ruth. The Members and all employees of Herzfeld & Rubin, P.C. mourn the death of this warm, caring and conscientious fellow employee and extend to her husband Michael, her sons Bruce and Jeffrey Eisenhart, her siblings and her mother, Ethel Nadler, our deepest sympathy. We pray that they take comfort in the memories of her many acts of love for her family and friends. Herbert Rubin, President

description: With Chris Terreri making his first start in goal this season, the Devils absorbed their second defeat in two nights tonight.

description: METCALF-George S. on October 22, 1999. Native of Poughkeepsie, NY. Beloved husband of Jean (nee Caputa). Loving father of Diane and Robert. Reposing at Edward D. Lynch Funeral Home, 43-07 Queens Blvd., Sunnyside, NY. Visitation Monday, 2-5 and 7-9:30 PM. Cremation Fresh Pond Crematory

title: A Gallery for Those Just Getting Started
description: A retail gallery designed for up-and-coming professional artists and beginner art collectors, called Get Real Art, opened at 156 Fifth Avenue on Oct. 16. With the entrance on the corner of West 20th Street, Get Real Art displays 1,000 original works by more than 50 artists in the two-floor 3,300-square-foot gallery. The current display consists mostly of paintings in various styles ($200 to $10,000), but also includes an elaborate metal mobile ($22,500), and decorative clocks ($70 to $200) and chairs ($100-$200).

title: Nassau Budget Crisis Opens the Political Field
description: POLITICALLY and financially, this week is make-or-break time for Nassau County.

title: A Need for Child Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Fidelity's Big Three Look Bullish on Technology
description: There is some good news for whipsawed technology investors. The three biggest mutual funds managed by Fidelity Investments still appear to be bullish on the sector.

title: Refining the Financing For Special Education
description: I agree with Jane Goldblatt that all children are entitled to ''an equal opportunity to get a good education'' [letter, Oct. 17]. All children should receive an education that will allow them to function independently to the best of their ability. The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act states that all children are entitled to a free and appropriate education in the least restrictive environment. It does not provide unlimited financing to children with disabilities. It does, however, guarantee their right to an education that will enable them to attain the skills necessary to function as independently as possible in the environment. The financing for special education does not deny any child ''an equal opportunity to get a good education.''

title: Flexibility in Temporary Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Beyond Irving and Cheever; Westchester Writers Abound, Drawing Inspiration From the Suburban Muse
description: THINK about Westchester as a literary setting and two authors immediately come to mind -- Washington Irving and John Cheever. ''The Legend of Sleepy Hollow'' has cast a long literary shadow over the county. The fictional adventure of the hapless schoolmaster Ichabod Crane has spawned its own tourist industry, with tours of historic homes, re-creations of the ride of the Headless Horseman and advertisements encouraging visitors to see ''the real Sleepy Hollow.'' In the book world, a surprising number of contemporary novelists have drawn inspiration from Irving's tale.

title: McCain Welcomes Rival To Web Site
description: This being the age of the computer, almost every Presidential candidate has a site on the World Wide Web, some fancier than others but all of them overflowing with self-serving biographical data and the latest on what the candidate is thinking and doing.

title: October 17-23; A Faulty Antidote
description: The Pentagon may have moved closer to solving the mystery of ''gulf war syndrome.''

title: University Presses Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: THE ADVENTURES OF

title: A Decade in Hell
description: SOMEBODY ELSE

title: Their Mission In Hitler's Europe: Save the Children
description: IN an airless room at the Royal National Hotel, Ursula Rosenfeld was summoning her ghosts. ''I was just under 8 when Hitler came to power,'' Ms. Rosenfeld began, in the faint wisp that is her voice. The camera focused closely on her delicately drawn 74-year-old face as she remembered a childhood birthday party in Quakenbrueck, Germany: ''The table was set, I was very excited. Nobody came. It sounds trivial, but it was the first comprehending for a child that you are ostracized, that there's something different about you.''

title: Pro Arte Begins 27th Season
description: AS the Pro Arte Singers enter their 27th season, Connecticut's only fully professional chorus can thank its founding artistic director, Arthur Sjogren, for its flourishing life and longevity.

title: Can't Tell His Age, Can't Hit His Pitches: El Duque Is Baffling
description: The major debate surrounding Orlando Hernandez these days is about his age. He says he is 30; records show that he is 34.

title: BEST SELLERS: October 24, 1999
description: Weeks

title: Television Focuses on Africa's Human History
description: TRACING the course of the Nile from its highland sources downstream through the vast Sudanese Desert, Alan Moorehead, renowned chronicler of African exploration, noted in his 1962 book, ''The Blue Nile,'' that 180 miles north of Khartoum, at Meroe (where nearly 200 narrow pyramids still cluster in the hollows of the pale brown dunes), ''we come on the first evidence of ancient civilizations which are a flat denial of the primitiveness of Africa, indeed, they are hardly African at all.''

title: Parcells to Start Mirer Again Today, but for How Long?
description: For the ninth time in only 39 games, Bill Parcells is changing quarterbacks.

title: New School on the Block Discovers Trouble Next Door
description: Just a month after occupying its new quarters, a private school on Bergen Street near Court Street was having problems with a next-door neighbor.

title: An Italian Old-Timer That's Bounced Back
description: DON'T count Casa Rustica out. This 15-year-old Smithtown restaurant, once one of the best on the Island, has had some lean times. On a visit a few years ago, the decor and food were equally tired.

title: Miss Edmund, Dr. Alvarado
description: Genvieve Anne Edmund, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Edmund of Moorestown, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Cristobal Gerardo Alvarado, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Cristobal C. Alvarado of Manhasset Hills, N.Y. The Rev. William Bergen performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in Manhattan.

title: Herons Replace Hoodlums At a Park With a Pond
description: The president of the Fox Hills Tenants Association, the Rev. Hattie Smith-Davis, remembers when Eibs Pond Park, near the Park Hill Houses complex, was little more than ''a cemetery for stolen cars'' and a hiding place for fugitives from the police. Four years ago, in hopes of restoring the park, the group asked the city for money. But the Parks Department said it didn't have money to give to the project.

title: Jury Adjourns in Trial Of Garage Developer
description: A Manhattan jury deliberated for a third day yesterday without reaching a verdict in the trial of the parking garage developer Abraham Hirschfeld, accused of hiring a hit man to kill his former business partner.

title: The Nation; Playing It Safe Can Sure Be Risky
description: TRAVELERS do it in the wake of a terrorist attack when they decide to drive to Florida for vacation rather than get on a plane. Diners do it when they forego a sandwich at lunch and then load up on iced tea and fat-free cookies in the mid-afternoon. And Bobby Valentine, the manager of New York Mets, did it during the sixth game of the National League Championship Series, perhaps costing his team a chance to advance to the World Series that began last night.

title: Walking a Mile in Vanderbilt's Golf Shoes
description: THE newest golf course on Long Island is also one of the oldest. Steeped in history, the private estate course of William K. Vanderbilt 2d played host to royalty, Hollywood legends and lions of industry in its former life. Now the course at the Eagle's Nest has been restored for commoners to enjoy.

title: Detour to Angelfish And a Patron Saint
description: I JUGGLED the figures, looked at the timetables, spun alternative travel scenarios and finally threw my hands up in frustration. How could I squeeze in a trip to Sinai on my round-the-world journey without blowing my budget?

title: October 17-23; Indicting McDonnell Douglas
description: A Federal grand jury indicted McDonnell Douglas -- a unit of Boeing, -- and a state-owned aerospace company in China on charges of conspiring to hide important details of a 1994 sale of American machining equipment. The equipment was intended for a McDonnell Douglas airliner project in China, but six of the machines were diverted to a Chinese military plant, although they were never put to use. The companies denied any wrongdoing and vowed to contest the charges. JEFF GERTH

title: Sports of The Times; El Duque Provides Some New Series Memories
description: JOHN SMOLTZ still recalls the acrid smell of burning automobiles. Jim Leyritz still tries to will Carlton Fisk's fly ball foul. Kevin McGlinchy still shudders at the televised horror of Mookie's grounder going under Buckner's glove.

title: A Call for Replay
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Using Baseball for a Greater Message
description: TEN-YEAR-OLD Dennis Cue was so impressed when he learned that a white manager had hired Jackie Robinson to be the first African-American in major league baseball that it changed his opinion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUTIN, SIDNEY B.
description: LUTIN-Sidney B. On October 22, 1999 after a long life. Beloved husband of Vivian, father of Marge and Mark, grandfather of Daniel, Josh, Doug and Rob.

description: At the age of 59, John Schuerholz is a dinosaur. His colleagues represent an endangered species.

description: GLASSER-Carol. On October 21, 1999. Beloved wife of Harvey. Devoted mother of Barbara and Jonathan. Cherished daughter of Helene Hahn. Loving sister of Rabbi Sanford Hahn. Adored grandmother of Raffaella and Ava Glasser. Service Sunday, 12Noon, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st St. and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC.

Paulson and the late Milton Paulson, Janice Blau, the late Sidney Blau, and brother-inlaw of Molly, wife of the late Jerome Blau. Cherished grandfather of Daniel and Lisa Kahn. title: VOTES IN CONGRESS
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey, and New York.

title: Bashing The Burbs
description: In years past, Hollywood made movies from Broadway musicals, but Broadway itself was too creative to base its musicals on anything that originated in Hollywood. Today, except for Stephen Sondheim and Harold Prince, Broadway musicals are mostly rehashes of Hollywood movies.

title: A Night for Spectral Pleasures
description: FRIGHTFUL fun abounds at the Haunted Halloween Weekend in Central Park, presented by the Central Park Conservancy. Shakespeare's Haunted House adds a new thrill to the Belvedere Castle and is not recommended for children under 5. The Faux-Real Theater Company will perform 45-minute sessions of interactive theater in which Shakespeare's ghost rises to confront the ghosts of his creations, including Macbeth, Caliban and Hamlet.

title: Impaired Vision
description: To the Editor:

title: Where On-Line Traders Find Satisfaction
description: Who's happiest with their E-broker? On-line brokerage customers of Fidelity Investments, according to a new survey by Spectrem Group and NFO Interactive, two market research firms.

title: Throwaway Cities
description: THE OLD NEIGHBORHOOD What We Lost in the Great Suburban Migration, 1966-1999. By Ray Suarez. 264 pp. New York: The Free Press. $25.
