description: BAYLIS-Dorothy S. (nee Smith) of Locust, NJ, formerly of New York City, NY, on October 23, 1999. Wife of the late Chester Baylis, Jr. Mother of Robert M. Baylis. Sister of Muriel S. Quintal. Grandmother of Robert W. Baylis, David M. Baylis and John C. Baylis. Greatgrandmother of Emma, Caroline and Jack. Aunt of Richard M. Quintal and Barbara Berglund. Funeral service Monday 10AM at St. George's By the River Episcopal Church, Rumson, NJ. Interment to follow in Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. In lieu of flowers memorial donations may be sent to St. George's By the River Episcopal Church, Waterman Ave., Rumson, NJ 07760. For info contact John E. Day Funeral Home, 85 Riverside Ave, Red Bank, NJ, 732-747-0332

title: More Flights To the Caribbean
description: THE Caribbean has long held a special allure for vacationers, but even today the logistics involved for most Americans to get to such islands as Nevis, St. Vincent, Bequia and St. Bart's usually require a minimum of three flights, including at least one leg on a puddle jumper. Not only does that make even a long weekend to those islands nearly impossible, it also cuts deeply into a vacation. And after American Airlines replaced most jets with turboprops last year on routes between San Juan and other Caribbean islands, travel time to many Caribbean destinations increased even more.

title: Board Election a Factor In Redistricting Power
description: THERE is no multimillion-dollar county executive race like the one two years ago going on in Westchester nor are there hot contests for the United States Senate or State Attorney General as there were last year. And there won't be a Presidential race until next year or a United States Senate race that will presumably feature Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH/The Buena Vista Social Club; Noche de La Habana, Wherever They Go
description: IT was shortly before 8 P.M. on Thursday, and Diane Ghioto, the owner of Isla, a spanking new Cuban restaurant on Downing Street, stood overseeing the polishing of windows and chrome table tops. ''Everything has to be just right tonight,'' she told her staff of waiters in guayabera shirts as they awaited the arrival of the Buena Vista Social Club.

title: Early Turnovers and Backup Quarterback Win for Army
description: Coming into today's game against Army, the New Mexico State coach, Tony Samuel, told his players they would have to cut down on turnovers if they were to end a three-game losing streak.

title: Commercial Property /111 Eighth Avenue; Developers Taking a Manhattan Formula to Chicago
description: A LITTLE less than two years ago, a group called Taconic Investment Partners bought the old Port Authority freight handling building occupying the block bounded by Eighth and Ninth Avenues and 15th and 16th Streets. The purchase was the first step in a development pattern that combined old construction with new technology, a pattern that the partners are now hoping to build on in Chicago and elsewhere.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''People don't want to deal with vendors, they don't want to cook, they don't want to hear about bickering and jealousy among the staff. They want the butler to deal with it.''

title: Stars in Their Eyes; Despite Rising Housing Costs, New York Remains a Magnet for the Young
description: NEW YORK has always attracted the young and hopeful from around the country. Its lure has been summed up in song lyrics: ''If you can make it there, you'll make it anywhere.'' And in images: the picture of a young woman newly arrived at Grand Central Terminal with a suitcase and a wistful expression.

title: Rebuffing West, Russia Pounds Chechnya
description: Rebuffing Western appeals that it seek a political solution in the North Caucasus, Russia continued its attacks in Chechnya today and proceeded with plans to increase its forces in and around the breakaway republic to 100,000 men -- a jump of 40,000 from just a month ago.

title: Alissa Churchill, Thomas Carley
description: Alissa Jean Churchill and Thomas Keir Carley were married yesterday at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Joan and John Carley, in Lincoln, Mass. The ceremony was performed by David G. Carley, a brother of the bridegroom who was designated a state civil marriage officer for the day.

title: David Holbrook, Andrea Kline-Greif
description: Andrea Kline-Greif is to be married this afternoon to David D. Holbrook at the River Club in New York. Judge Arlene H. Hahn of New York City Housing Court is to officiate.

title: Leather Jackets
description: Since designers and many of their clients have abandoned the formal suit jacket for today's casual style of dress, women in New York and Paris are wearing an alternative: a short, fitted leather jacket with a ring collar in bright colors. The design is a sophisticated takeoff on the biker's racing jacket. The style also owes a nod to the popular western denim jacket that has replaced the traditional sports jacket among younger women. Even the 1960 Andre Courreges vinyl version, left, is enjoying a revival.

title: America's Other Motherland
description: WONDERS OF THE AFRICAN WORLD By Henry Louis Gates Jr. Photographs by Lynn Davis. 275 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $40.

title: The Collector
description: I don't deny that it may be self-expression, but I think the works in the exhibit ''Sensation: Young British Artists From the Saatchi Collection'' (Deborah Solomon, Sept. 26) belong in an old-fashioned exposition hall, like P. T. Barnum's Hall of Curiosities and Wonders. The Javits Center might be put to good use for this purpose.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BONO, LUDWIG P.
description: BONO-Ludwig P. August 9, 1906October 15, 1999. A notable New York architect with an excellent reputation for high quality architectural and interior design. He designed many churches, chapels, convents, mausoleums and other quality monumental designs for the Catholic Archdiocese of New York and many religious buildings for New York Protestant and Jewish congregations. Mr. Bono was born in Jersey City, New Jersey; spent his early years in Pittsburgh, and his childhood and early youth in Biella, Italy, where he received a degree from the Biella Polytechnic Institute in 1927. He returned to the United States in 1928, working in the respected office of McKim, Meade, & White, assisting in the design of significant public buildings in Washington, D.C. In 1945, he opened his own office in the Bronx, New York, completing many small and large projects. He was the architect for the Stella D'Oro Biscuit Company designing their main headquarters in the Bronx, and many factories, restaurants, high quality residences in Riverdale, N.Y., and other projects in New York City and throughout the country. His specialty church and mausoleum projects were considered the very highest examples of this architectural genre at the time. Mr. Bono was granted honorary knighthood in the Knights of the Holy Sepulchre by the Catholic Church. He was preceded in death by his wife, Lea, and is survived by two sons: his son Richard, an architect in York, Pennsylvania; and his son, Robert of Staten Island, New York, and by a granddaughter, Lea. Mr. Bono was buried beside his wife in the Gate of Heaven Cemetery in Westchester, N.Y. on Wednesday, October 20, 1999. Services were held in the beautiful stained glass St. Francis Chapel he designed.

title: Bradley Relies On Wall Street To Raise Funds
description: One of the biggest surprises of this campaign year has been former Senator Bill Bradley's ability to be competitive with the Vice President in the campaign cash sweepstakes. Mr. Bradley has raised nearly $20 million this year and has more cash in the bank than Vice President Al Gore.

title: Room at the Inn In the Holy Land
description: JERUSALEM'S ultimate geopolitical fate may be a matter of bitter dispute. But as the unchallenged spiritual capital of the Holy Land, it is the millennial destination of choice for thousands of Christians.

title: A Toothless Ban Barely Nibbles at Big Rigs
description: Karen Bendix finds it easy to peer out from her grill alongside Route 31 here and spot tractor-trailers with out-of-state license plates. The trucks are probably violating the state's new law intended to protect residents and businesses from big rigs.

title: The Quiet Help Of Family Members
description: LINDA K. WILLIAMS ticked off her expenses: rent for the small, neatly furnished apartment that she shares with her teen-age son, electricity, phone, groceries, medicine, life insurance, occasional evenings out, new clothing, the bus commute to work, the boy's allowance and lunch money. The expenses total nearly $19,000, but her take-home pay as a secretary is only $15,700. How does she make ends meet? Gradually, Ms. Williams explained how her sisters help, and also a boyfriend.

title: Ninepins Rallies For Second Victory
description: Ninepins took the lead over the 14th and final fence and went on to a 22-length victory in the $150,000 Breeders' Cup Grand National Steeplechase at the Far Hills Races in Far Hills, N.J., yesterday.

title: Foreign Affairs; Playing Russian Roulette
description: The most important story out of Russia last week was buried in the business pages: Russia's top stock-market watchdog quit after declaring that Boris Yeltsin's government was simply not interested in enforcing laws to protect shareholders in Russia.

title: Venture Capital Crooning
description: If Timothy C. Draper's efforts to ingratiate himself in New York last week offer any evidence, transplanting the Silicon Valley ethos even to the financially fertile soil of Manhattan will yield an uncertain harvest. To celebrate plans for his Draper Fisher Jurvetson venture capital firm to open a New York branch, he got the crowd at a New York Venture Group breakfast to sing along with the words he handed out to ''New York, New York.'' His last two verses:

title: Palermo Court Rules in Favor Of Andreotti
description: Closing a chapter in Italian postwar history, a three-judge panel in Palermo today acquitted Giulio Andreotti, seven times Prime Minister of Italy, of charges that he was the Sicilian Mafia's main protector in Rome.

title: Teachers: the Experienced And the New Are Needed
description: I applaud Superintendent Frank Tassone's Opinion essay [''Quality Teachers and Hen's Teeth,'' Oct. 10] in which he points out that our salaries and benefits do not compare with what people in other professions are earning. Until I experienced firsthand the huge gap between what one earns for one's time and effort in the business world as opposed to public school teaching, I hadn't fully grasped the extent of the disparity.

title: 'Hitler's Pope'
description: To the Editor:

title: Antoinetta Chieco, Michael Cutrona
description: Antoinetta Chieco, a daughter of Franca and Tommaso Chieco of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Michael Anthony Cutrona, the son of Marianne Cutrona and Justice Anthony Cutrona, also of Brooklyn. The Rev. Thaddeus A. Grzelak performed the ceremony at the Shrine Church of St. Bernadette in Brooklyn.

title: The Fun and Games of Living a Virtual Life
description: WHEN talking about the movie ''Being John Malkovich,'' it's best to begin by stating what it's not. It sounds like a documentary, but it isn't; it's a feature film, starring John Malkovich playing himself. And it's definitely not based on Mr. Malkovich's life. When the screenplay's author, Charlie Kaufman, wrote it in 1994, he'd never even met Mr. Malkovich.

title: The Untouchables
description: THE CAPE

title: Cancer Study
description: Will reducing fat in the diet of women who have survived breast cancer reduce the risk of the cancer recurring? That is the question researchers at the Zalmen A. Arlin Cancer Institute at the Westchester Medical Center in Valhalla will help the American Health Foundation answer.

title: Ariane Schreiber and Jeffrey Horn
description: Ariane Marie Schreiber and Jeffrey Michael Horn were married yesterday at St. Mary's, Our Lady of the Isle Church in Nantucket, Mass. The Rev. Thomas Lopes, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Remembering Slavery
description: To the Editor:

title: East Timor's Aftermath
description: On Aug. 30, East Timor voted for independence from Indonesia after 24 years of brutal repression. Within days, however, pro-Jakarta militias, aided and supported by the Indonesian Army, resumed a campaign of violence and terror, rampaging through the cities of Dili, Suai, Maliana and Balibo, wielding machetes, guns, clubs and knives.

title: Hardaway's Career Enters Third Act, With Kidd a Co-Star
description: Anfernee Hardaway walked into Ancient Art, a tattoo parlor in Memphis, this summer with one simple request. He wanted something printed on his right arm that signaled his rebirth as an outstanding player after his last few frustrating years in Orlando. He wanted something to capture his arrival in Phoenix, where he will team with Jason Kidd to form, on paper, the most potent backcourt in the National Basketball Association.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-17

title: Year 2000 Activists Share Tales of Public Apathy
description: The crowd in the small, overheated hotel meeting room sighed when Douglas Stewart described a meeting on Year 2000 computer problems that he helped organize in Santa Fe, N.M.

title: Ties to Sierra Leone
description: To the Editor:

title: Officials Call for Defeat of Pipeline
description: IT is called the Millennium Pipeline, and the company that wants to build it says the 442-mile underground pipeline will insure that the Northeast has an adequate supply of natural gas for decades. But critics question the wisdom of ending the line in a crowded section of Mount Vernon and, more broadly, whether it is really needed at all.

title: Ms. Shanahan, Mr. Brecher
description: Christin Conway Shanahan, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Shanahan Jr. of New York, and Steven Louis Brecher, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Herman Brecher of Baltimore, were married last evening at the Knickerbocker Club in New York. The Rev. Kevin A. McGrath, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the ceremony, with Rabbi Albert Sturmer taking part.

title: Housing Development To Be Privately Owned
description: IF all goes as planned, Mount Vernon's 50-year-old public housing complex will become privately owned early next year, marking the first time in the county's history that a public housing development for low-income residents switches to private operation.

title: As Oil Prices Rise, So Could Heating Bills
description: AN 86 percent increase in crude oil prices this year, coupled with forecasts of the first winter in four years with normal cold temperatures, are expected to boost the cost of keeping warm with oil heat this winter.

title: What Time Is It in the Transept?
description: THE SUN IN THE CHURCH

title: The Unrecognized
description: To the Editor:

title: A British Web Site Offers Y2K Alerts
description: If you plan to travel by rail in Japan on Dec. 31, don't panic if the train suddenly stops at midnight. The interruption, expected to last only 10 minutes, is intended by Japan Rail as a precaution against Y2K disruption.

title: The 18-Year Itch
description: Waiting

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KITCHEN, ELLEN C.
description: KITCHEN-Ellen C. Service on Saturday, October 30, 2PM, The Explorers Club 46 E. 70 St., NY. Mrs. Kitchen died June 23, in St. Louis.

title: OPINION; Taking a Stand on Nassau's Budget
description: ABOUT a century ago, the New York City government was embroiled in the famous Tammany Hall graft scandal. The Democratic boss, William Marcy Tweed, was sent to prison, as were many of his subordinates, after been having found guilty of tampering with the public purse strings. Newspaper stories of the time uncovered widespread corruption, patronage and misappropriation of funds that prompted such public outrage that the machine eventually collapsed.

title: The Nation: Encyclopedia Green; The High Road at a High Cost
description: AS Internet users stampeded to visit the Encyclopaedia Britannica's sleek new Web site last week, the venerable intellectual icon was nearly road kill on the information highway.

title: PERSONAL BUSINESS; Guidance For the Uninsured
description: FOR uninsured Americans seeking health care, the scramble continues. The Census Bureau reported recently that the number of Americans without health insurance rose last year to 44 million -- the highest level in a decade.

title: The Sound of the Symphony, in a Box
description: THE Society for the Encouragement of National Industry, founded in 1801, lists the names of many famous French entrepreneurs and inventors on the walls of its headquarters on the Place St.-Germain, around the corner from the Cafe Deux Magots: Bleriot, the aviation pioneer; the Lumiere brothers, early moving-picture makers, and -- along with others from the mid-19th century, without further explanation -- Cavaille-Coll.

title: Twists and Turns in a Writer's Imagination
description: WILLIAM SYDNEY POR TER O. Henry to us all -- tells the audience it's ''strange how life can suddenly twist,'' a pat lead-in to the theme of fiction imitating fact.

title: Nuclear Leak Report
description: A report issued last week by the Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission said that although a leak at the Indian Point Unit 2 station in Buchanan on Aug. 31 posed no immediate threat to health or safety, it was preventable and was aggravated by an inadequate management response.

title: EVENING HOURS
description: Gatherings and parties celebrated good works and charitable giving.

title: Having a Ball
description: It is not unheard of for marketing consultants, whose mission is searching tirelessly for creative ways to stand out from the crowd, to go, shall it be said, a wee bit over the top.

title: Mattingly Considers Returning to Yanks
description: Chris Chambliss interviewed with the Cleveland general manager, John Hart, for the Indians' vacant managerial job at a time when there is a question about whether the Yankees will retain him as their hitting coach.

title: University Presses Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry; Cozy but Not Comfy
description: The quintessential university town of Madison, Wis. -- with its assortment of block parties and literary cafes, dairy fairs and Turkestan folk song concerts -- is the setting of THE SOCIETY OF FRIENDS (University of Missouri, paper, $17.95), Kelly Cherry's wry, ruminative collection of interconnected stories. Nina Bryant, an unmarried English professor and novelist, is the protagonist of seven of these tales; the six others explore the personal trials -- divorce, remarriage, applying for tenure -- of Nina's neighbors on a cozy urban road named Joss Court. Cherry sets the tone with ''The Prowler: A Prologue,'' in which the Joss Court residents are spooked by an unseen interloper who overturns garbage cans, pounds on doors and sends mysterious letters. Each story then elaborates on this theme of invisible threat: Nina worries that her young adopted daughter will never have a father; sees her dead father's ghost in her dying mother's kitchen; and falls wildly in love with a history professor. The emotional complexity and perceptive humor of ''Not the Phil Donahue Show'' is characteristic: Shelley, a nurse, feels confused and abandoned when her college-age daughter announces that she's fallen in love with a woman. Only Cherry's fondness for distracting, punny one-liners feels off key (as when someone comments to a performance artist named Jazz Piano, ''You have so many ironies in the fire''). But Cherry traces the shifts in her characters' emotional lives with an observant, elegiac precision, as if she were detailing the visceral effects of the changing seasons. Megan Harlan

title: Emergency Response
description: Tropical Storm Floyd showed weaknesses in Briarcliff Manor's ability to alert community officials and residents to dangerous situations, Mayor Keith Austin said last week.

title: Communicating Through Photographs
description: PHOTOGRAPHY has arguably become one of the most potent instruments of communication for the contemporary artist. Its versatility, suggested truthfulness and the way in which artists distort or interpret ''reality'' has been a part of photography since the advent of the daguerreotype in 1839. In the 1860's and 70's, the Victorian photographer Julia Margaret Cameron created soft-focused, dreamlike fantasies featuring costumed subjects depicting literary, biblical and mythological tales. This narrative approach helped to popularize photography, a fact that would prove valuable for each ensuing generation of photographers.

title: Household Chores
description: Janifer Dumas's Lives column (Oct. 3) eloquently depicts the tragic situation faced by too many people with mental illness and by those who love them.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CHINATOWN; A Bermuda Triangle for Pedestrians at Chatham Square
description: When Barbara Lau was crossing Chatham Square the other day and saw a car hit three elderly women, she was stunned until she realized which intersection they were crossing.

title: Liberties; Why Can't a Woman . . .
description: It could be a long time before we see a woman President in Washington. But we'll see one in Hollywood.

title: Mauresmo in Final Without Playing
description: Top-seeded Amelie Mauresmo of France advanced to the final of the Eurotel Indoor tournament without even hitting a ball yesterday in Bratislava, Slovakia, after a wasp sting forced Kveta Hrdlickova of the Czech Republic to withdraw.

title: San Diego
description: It's fall, a time when San Diego, best known as a sun-drenched summer destination, really goes to work -- as in farm work. Indeed, it's the season when this pearl on the craggy Southern California coast harvests and shows off two of its lesser-known products: apples and grapes.

title: Clinton's Successes In Foreign Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Violence Isn't Stylish
description: To the Editor:

title: Not Time Yet To Put Tools Away
description: THINGS are starting to wind down in the garden, but it is not time to put the tools away just yet.

title: FIVE QUESTIONS: for JUAN SOMAVIA; Making Markets Work for All
description: FOR decades, the International Labor Organization has been derided as an ineffectual, anticapitalistic talking shop, when it has been noticed at all. But its new director-general, Juan Somavia, is intent on changing all that.

title: New Jersey Ranked Low On Insuring Children
description: Efforts to provide health care to children in New Jersey have fallen short in comparison with other states, according to a study by a national watchdog group.

title: Finding My Body Beautiful's Limits
description: SEVERAL painful experiences this past summer have made it obvious that I am not as fit as I used to be. This is seriously depressing news, because I was never very fit in the first place.

title: Do the Right Thing
description: The Catholic Moral Tradition Today

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPATT, SONDRA
description: SPATT-Sondra. Beloved mother of our esteemed Board Member, Robert Abrams. His lifetime of devotion to the aged is a tribute to his mother. We offer our most sincere condolences to the family. Menorah Home and Hospital Fred Abrams, President Paul Melinger, Chairman of the Board Shirley Windheim, Chief Executive Officer

title: What's So Bad About Hate
description: You may deplore the policies and calculated, dangerous silences of a specific pope, or those of his bishops, without expressing ''hate toward the institution of the Catholic Church and all those who perpetuate its doctrines,'' as Andrew Sullivan claims I have done. Some popes are deplorable. Some rabbis are deplorable, as I mentioned in my article in The Nation, but I certainly don't believe they bring discredit to Judaism. I assume Sullivan understands this, just as I assume he understands the difference between speech that gives offense and speech from which a reasonable person may infer a threat of violence, though he seems to have lost sight of such distinctions. I agree with him that criminalizing ''hate speech'' is a bad idea; the rest of his article is only what's to be expected from someone who has made a career of failing to understand the struggle for civil rights in America.

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 35 of The Times Magazine today about the screenwriter and director Paul Schrader misspells the surname of the director of ''Bringing Out the Dead,'' for which Mr. Schrader wrote the screenplay. He is Martin Scorsese, not Scorcese.

title: WARY OF ABUSES, U.S. SHARPLY CUTS VISAS FOR RUSSIANS
description: The United States Embassy in Moscow has sharply curtailed the number of visas issued to Russians, particularly students and scholars, despite Washington's avowed desire to spread Western values in Russia.

title: University Presses Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: True Adventures With the King of Bluegrass By Tom Piazza. Country Music Foundation/ Vanderbilt University, $17.95.

title: The Traveler, Redefined as Travel Agent
description: FOR the last three years Dr. Howard Derman, a Houston neurologist, has been a travel agent on the side. But he has never booked a cruise, a flight or even a hotel reservation for anyone but himself. The same goes for Andrew W. Menachem, a stockbroker in Miami.

title: South Africa Moves To Cut Highway Deaths
description: South African authorities say that the Government is stepping up efforts to make the country's notorious roads safer after a bus crash last month killed 26 British tourists and highlighted the dangers of driving here. Earlier this month, even as reform measures were being considered, 19 people were killed and dozens hurt in a crash in the Eastern Cape Province, bringing the death toll to 79 in less than three weeks. Even by the standards of South Africa, where speeding, drunken driving and unlicensed drivers are common and traffic enforcement rare, the toll has been remarkably high. President Thabo Mbeki and others have worried publicly about the effect that the bus crashes will have on the country's reputation, which is already suffering because of the high crime rate.

title: When Late Is Too Late
description: AS baby boomers, we have had amazing fortune. A strong economy has given many of us comfortable careers and the stock market has made us more comfortable still. Many in our group are successful, wealthy and not nearly done yet.

title: Sports of The Times; The Origin of a Series That Might Have Been
description: UNTIL Andruw Jones went for a walk, the dream of a Subway Series was nice while it lasted. Maybe next year.

title: Israeli Military Aid
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLIVER, ROSE
description: OLIVER-Rose. On October 20, 1999, of heart disease, at her residence in Peterborough, NH. She was a clinical psychologist with a Ph.D. from CUNY. For a number of years she was associated with the Institude for Rational-Emotive Therapy, in addition to her private practice. Survivors are her daughter Theresa Oliver, son John and wife Priscilla, grandchildren Peter and wife Julie, Anna, Christopher, Eric, Heather, great-grandchildren Cole and Clay, sister Anna London, and many nieces and nephews. Services at ''The Riverside'', Sunday, October 24, 9:45AM, at Amsterdam Ave. and 76th Street.

title: Striving to Become Israel's Louvre
description: TEDDY KOLLEK, the former Mayor of Jerusalem, is now 88 years old, but every Thursday he still goes to his office at the Israel Museum. He founded the museum on a stony hilltop in 1965, and it remains one of his pet projects. On my way into his office, his secretary warned me that he was in a crabby mood. But sitting at his desk, chomping on a cigar and barking orders, Mr. Kollek was the image of octogenarian contentment.

title: A Fault-Free Show By Thin Air
description: Amy Ylvisaker-Reistrup of Lexington, Va., made her third ride in an American Grand Prix Association competition a winning one when she rode Thin Air to the only fault-free score in the jumpoff in the $50,000 Grand Prix de Penn National at the closing session of the Pennsylvania National Horse Show yesterday in Harrisburg, Pa.

title: Plans for New Power Plants Spur Fears in Asthma Valley
description: With two companies planning to build large electrical power plants in Astoria and an existing plant in Long Island City preparing to expand, local concerns about chronic air pollution are escalating.

title: Redistricting Raises States' Election Stakes
description: Most states will not hold legislative elections until next year. But Virginia is an exception. It will vote this year, on Nov. 2, with all 140 seats in its Senate and House of Delegates up for grabs.

title: Scary Once, Scary Again
description: On the night of frightful goblins -- and, of course, gobbling goodies -- nostalgia runs more rampant than mascara in the rain. ''Halloween's pleasures are rooted in memories of the holiday from childhood,'' says Christopher Radko, a designer of holiday decorations. From classic cartoon villains to sitcom spooks, these Halloween items are geared toward a new generation of tricksters. But for baby boomers clinging to their youth, they are real treats.

title: The World; A Glimpse of the Future In the Pain of Today
description: THE camp for victims of mutilation lies on a hill in the most scenic stretch of Freetown, a favorite spot for British vacationers before war destroyed Sierra Leone. The palms dotting the surrounding hills, the nearby wide white beach, the faded resorts promising respite, all stand in contrast to life inside the camp: a one-legged girl hopping along one a labyrinthine walkway; a young man with one arm sitting on the porch of his tarpaulin tent-house; an older man with arms hacked off below the elbows; yet another with very short stumps.

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-24-99; What They Were Thinking
description: June 17, 1999, Redwood City, Calif.

title: October 17-23; Campaign Reform Loses In the Senate
description: The Senate played its accustomed role in the struggle to overhaul the campaign finance law: for the fourth consecutive year Republicans used a filibuster to kill the legislation.

title: Oh, What a Web . . .
description: The Cubs, the last major league team to install lights in their park, apparently have not caught up with the technology age yet. General Manager Ed Lynch spent much of today denying that Don Baylor, the Braves' hitting coach, was Chicago's new manager, though information indicating that was found on the team's official Web site.

title: Ms. Chamberlin, Mr. Commander
description: Mary Ellen Chamberlin and Mark Thomas Commander were married yesterday in Bernardsville, N.J. The Rev. Chester Carina performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Roman Catholic Church.

title: Separating the Pilgrims From the Puritans
description: Critics of the seal of the Town of Southampton [''Anti-Bias Task Force Says No to a Pilgrim,'' Oct. 10] have overlooked another significant discrepancy in the image of the Pilgrim: The English who claimed Southampton were Puritans rather than Pilgrims. Southampton, like Southold, East Hampton, Oyster Bay and Huntington, was established as an outpost of the New Haven Colony, which was founded by the Puritans John Davenport and Theophilus Eaton in 1638. While Pilgrims have sometimes been described as extreme Puritans, their history in America indicates substantial differences between the two.

title: Doing What the Islands Do Best
description: AT the Hyatt Regency Dorado Beach Resort on the north coast of Puerto Rico, the general manager, Michael Walsh, has been working on a nature brochure describing the tropical flora on the property and writing a book about its history. The resort had its beginnings in the 1950's when Laurance Rockefeller created it as a low-key haven-cum-natural-wonders. ''I think people are looking for a cultural experience,'' Mr. Walsh said.

title: Publishing, the Moral Mirror of Politics
description: THE publishing world has offended Barbara Bush's family so much this month, it's almost enough to make her regret her whole literacy campaign.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIEGLER, BARBARA SUTRO
description: ZIEGLER-Barbara Sutro. Of New York City, on October 21, 1999 at the age of 91. Widow of Dr. James E. Ziegler, Jr. She will be greatly missed by her brother-in-law, Karl Ziegler, her nieces, Lady Barbara Bowen Larcom and Mary Sutro Callender, her nephews, Dr. Michael Sedgwick Sutro and Denis O'Sullivan Sutro, her many loving relatives and friends. An accomplished photographer and artist, Mrs. Ziegler was a lifelong and generous patron of the arts. In lieu of flowers, a contribution may be made to the New York Philharmonic or your favorite charity.

title: Carving Out a Hideaway Where It's Already Home
description: I'VE been spending a lot of weekends down at the family farm in Maryland sitting on a knoll overlooking a field of soybeans that slopes down to a stream that winds through the woods.

title: Prisoner in Ones Own Home
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: On Baseball; Nervous? Braves' Anemic Hitters Ought to Be
description: Derek Jeter, who in a moment would bat with the bases loaded in the eighth inning of a game the Yankees were losing, 1-0, on Saturday night, looked at a spectator in the first row of the box seats next to the Yankees' dugout and posed a question.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SALOSHIN, EDITH
description: SALOSHIN-Edith. Two lonely years since you went to heaven. Your love was the highlight of my life, with memories to linger on. Rest in peace. Fred and Cliffor

title: In Silk Stocking District, a Hard-Fought Race for City Council Is Costly
description: In a spirited race on the East Side of Manhattan two years ago, Eva Moskowitz, a college professor, came closer to defeating an incumbent member of the City Council than any other challenger that year. Now, Ms. Moskowitz is running for the seat again and counting on the name recognition from that race, a Democratic advantage in voter registration and her vigorous grass-roots organization.

title: Anonymous Donors

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLUCK, RUTH RUBIN
description: GLUCK-Ruth Rubin. The Officers, Trustees, Clergy and Members of Park Avenue Synagogue mourn the passing of a devoted congregant. We extend to her husband, Marshall, and the entire family our heartfelt sympathy. David H. Lincoln, Senior Rabbi Geoffrey J. Colvin, Ch. of the Bd. Paul S. Schreiber, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OKUN, ANNA (SOLOWAY)
description: OKUN-Anna (Soloway). Died on October 21, 1999. Formerly of Mount Vernon and Peekskill, NY. Beloved wife of the late Manuel. Loving sister of the late Harold and Bessie Soloway. Graveside services at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY, Monday, October 25, at 1 PM. Shiva private. Donations to the charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDENSTEIN, PHILIP
description: GOLDENSTEIN-Philip. 98 years old. Beloved husband of the late Sally. Devoted father of Buddy and the late Howard. Loving brother of Pauline Lobelson. Cherished grandfather of Gary, Lauren, Lee, Jana, Barry, Avery and Neil. Services 9:30 AM, Monday, at ''The Riverside,'' Amsterdam Avenue at 76th Street.

title: Forbes Lavishly Champions Austerity
description: Steve Forbes, the multimillionaire publisher who is again running for President, brought his anti-tax crusade here this weekend, spending his own money lavishly in order to promote his view that the Government should have less and spend less.

title: C.I.A. in Silicon Valley
description: To the Editor:

title: Supermarket Workers Resuming Contract Talks
description: Contract negotiations for a union representing 5,000 supermarket workers at five chains on Long Island and in Queens, Brooklyn and Staten Island are to continue today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Cable and Wireless Denies It's Ready for a Takeover

title: GOLF; Casey Martin Earns a Spot On PGA Tour
description: Casey Martin's golf wasn't pretty, but when the Nike Tour Championship ended today, his tie for 37th place was a beautiful thing to him.

title: Giants Assess The Damage
description: About an hour after the Giants' 31-3 victory over the New Orleans Saints yesterday, the rookie running back Joe Montgomery was seated outside the X-ray room beneath the Giants Stadium stands. Montgomery held a large X-ray in his hand.

title: Ailing Cardinal O'Connor Returns to Deliver Homily
description: John Cardinal O'Connor, speaking in a halting but jocular voice yesterday, delivered his first homily in three weeks at St. Patrick's Cathedral after suffering the side effects of radiation therapy for a brain tumor.

title: G.O.P. World View: Who Needs You?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUNG, HOPE ASPELL
description: YOUNG-Hope Aspell. Died in her 96th year. She was cherished by her young friends.

title: In the Castle of Indolence You Can Hear the Sound of Your Own Mind
description: Now and then my father would walk me down Market Street and Church Street to visit his mother's home, either to show me off like some chub or pike he had caught on one of his fishing expeditions or, more likely, to let me watch his four sisters and four brothers lying around reading books, oblivious of the workaday world but kept going by the beef sandwiches his mother plied them with all day. I was 8, perhaps, and they, he said, were shiftless.

title: Harry Potter vs. the Censors
description: To the Editor:

title: Indonesia Cabinet to Include Ousted Party
description: In his first speech since surprisingly winning office last week, President Abdurrahman Wahid conceded today that he would have to include members of President Suharto's discredited administration in the Cabinet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAUS, CAROL (NEE KEMP)
description: STRAUS-Carol (nee Kemp). Of Hollywood, FL. Beloved wife of the late Abraham. Devoted mother of Herbert and Sonja Straus, Karen Straus and Joyce and Michael Koplik. Loving grandmother of Elayne Suber, Amanda and Adam Straus, and Abigail, Kathryn and Michelle Koplik. Proud greatgrandmother of Jackson Suber. She was one of a kind, beloved by friends and family, and all who were touched by knowing her. Graveside services October 25, Miami, FL, Mt. Nebo Memorial Gardens.

title: Van France, Who Engineered Disneyland's Cheer, Dies at 87
description: Van Arsdale France, the man who wrote the manual for teaching Disneyland employees precisely how to smile, died on Oct. 13 at a hospital in Newport Beach, Calif. He was 87 and a resident of Santa Ana, Calif.

title: Sanders Hears the Talk, Then Walks the Walk
description: Talk may be cheap, but for the Dallas Cowboys, for Deion Sanders, it was like a burr in the saddle, a bee sting, a lightning bolt.

title: Man Is Stabbed to Death In Street Fight in Chelsea
description: A 28-year-old man was stabbed to death on a Chelsea street corner early yesterday morning after he and his friends got into a fight with about a dozen men, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUINN, ROBERT J.
description: QUINN-Robert J. Passed away, surrounded by family at his home on the beach in Malibu, CA, after a long illness. He was 72. Bobby was born in New York, NY, October 3, 1927, and began his distinguished career with NBC in the 1940s as a mail clerk. He worked his way up, becoming Stage Manager for the ''Howdy Doody Show,'' Technical Director, then Assistant Director for Jack Paar's ''Tonight Show'' and eventually the Director of ''Tonight Show starring Johnny Carson'' from 1968 till Johnny's last performance May 22, 1992. Bobby was a member of the Director's Guild of America. He was honored to receive ''Best Director'' of Musical/Variety category in 1992 for the ''Tonight Show starring Johnny Carson'', and in the same year was nominated for a television Emmy Award. Quinn is survived by his wife, Charlotte. He also leaves behind nine children, Patricia Quinn Hilton of Brentwood, NY, Douglas Quinn of Hicksville, NY, Kathleen Quinn Gorlitz of Oak Park, CA, Kevin Quinn of Manhattan Beach, CA, Brian Quinn of Hermosa Beach, CA, Colin Quinn of Oak Park, CA, Robert Quinn, Jr. of Hicksville, NY, Demarest Quinn of Greenwich, CT, James Quinn of NY, NY, 13 grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. A visitation will be held on Monday, October 25 from 6 to 9PM and funeral services will be held on Tuesday, October 26, at 1 PM, all at Pierce Brothers Valley Oaks Memorial Park, Westlake Village, CA. In lieu of flowers, please send donations in his name to ''Make A Wish'' Foundation, 1875 Century Park East, Suite 1460, Los Angeles, CA 90067.

title: Offerings In Equities And Debt
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Sports Of The Times; The All-Century Player Who Haunts Baseball
description: ONE of the lovely things to look forward to next New Year's Day -- when the world does not, after all, come crashing down on our heads -- is an end to the plague of lists.

title: Putting Investment Road Shows on the Internet
description: In the two weeks before they issue stock to the public, company executives often make an exhausting round of meetings across the country, sometimes the world -- in what is called a road show.

title: Credit Offerings Scheduled for This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills and an auction of two-year notes on Wednesday.

title: Kidnapped Boy, 4, Is Freed; Police Arrest a Suspect
description: A 4-year-old boy who was kidnapped from a Manhattan playground on Saturday afternoon and taken to an apartment in the Bronx was released yesterday morning by his captor, who was later arrested, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a sports column yesterday evaluating the New York Rangers affixed a name erroneously to a hockey player who has been unimpressive since joining his new team. The characterization was intended to apply to a current Ranger, Kevin Hatcher, not the former Ranger Ulf Samuelsson.

title: Belmont Falls at the Gate; Simulcasting Raises Handle
description: Belmont Park ran its final races of the season yesterday before giving way to Aqueduct for the next six and a half months, and reported that its average attendance for the 32-day autumn meeting had dropped by 9 percent.

title: Mexican President Defends Equity of Party's 1st Primary
description: Speakng two weeks before Mexico's first presidential primary, President Ernesto Zedillo today defended the fairness of the process and renewed his pledge to remain neutral.

title: Easter Seal Society Presents Awards
description: The National Easter Seal Society has named the recipients of its 10th annual Equality, Dignity and Independence Awards, which honor communications judged to support people with disabilities.

title: He Has New Nickname to Go With Million-Dollar Offers
description: Latrell Sprewell stood among a group of college basketball players, satisfying autograph requests as the headphones to his portable CD player sat just enough off of his ears to allow him to hear and laugh as Marcus Camby called out Sprewell's new nickname. ''Max,'' Camby shouted, giggling uncontrollably, repeating it until he was sure Sprewell had heard.

title: Asthma-Proof Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Revised Banking Legislation Raises Concerns About Privacy
description: If Congress votes as expected this week to overhaul the nation's Depression-era banking laws, it will be doing more than paving the way for the creation of one-stop financial supermarkets. It will also be offering companies unprecedented opportunities to amass and share reams of private data about their customers.

title: U.S. Men's Eight Wins 3d Straight
description: The United States men's eight, winner of this year's world championship, won its third consecutive Head of the Charles championship eights title yesterday in Cambridge, Mass.

title: The Strategy For I.B.M.: Loss-Leader PC Sales
description: I.B.M. was once as closely linked to personal computers as Kleenex is to tissue. But no more.

title: Canada's Link to the Queen Grows Livelier
description: Editors' Note Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARTY, HARRIET M.
description: HARTY-Harriet M. Of Garden City, NY. Died on October 23, 1999. Beloved wife of the late John P. Harty. Loving mother of John P. and Emmett J. Dear grandmother of John Patrick, Caroline P., Margaret A., Emmett J. Jr., Daniel W. and Faith A. Loving sister of Gordon Gallagher and Edward Gallagher. Mass of Christian Burial, Monday, 11 AM, St. Joseph's R.C. Church, Garden City. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to: Mercy Hospice, 1220 Front Street, Uniondale, NY 11533-9936 are appreciated.

title: A Clinton Whiz Kid Who's Still There and Still a Believer
description: GENE SPERLING, director of the National Economic Council, assistant to the President for economic policy and legendary workaholic, was alternating between Diet Coke and coffee at 10 P.M. on Thursday.

title: Just Like the Old Days
description: Fred Wilpon and Sandy Koufax were teammates some years ago on the baseball team at Lafayette High School in Brooklyn. Koufax went on to become one of the best pitchers in baseball history. Wilpon didn't make it. He had to settle for owning 50 percent of the Mets.

title: The Yankees Enjoy Southern Hospitality
description: Nobody uttered the words, but many of the Yankees were thinking the same thing as they hauled their bats and gloves to the clubhouse tonight after their 7-2 mauling of Atlanta in Game 2 of the World Series: remember 1996.

title: Modernizing Medicare
description: The Senate Finance Committee voted last week to put off consideration of legislative measures that would give Medicare the same tools that private health insurers commonly use to control costs and the quality of care. That probably means that debate on this crucial issue will be delayed to next year. The Clinton administration had proposed a comprehensive plan to improve Medicare, including a new prescription-drug benefit. Unless Congress acts, Medicare will not have the flexibility to create new choices of coverage for beneficiaries that will help reduce costs, for them and for the program.

title: Morning Programs Bare Teeth in Maneuvering to Schedule Guests
description: Steve Friedman, the senior executive producer of CBS's new ''Early Show,'' which joins the network morning show competition next week, was rather gleeful. He noted that ratings for the longtime morning leader, NBC's ''Today,'' showed small signs of slippage last week.

title: Standoff on Budget Yields An Unexpected Dividend
description: For all the political blood shed over President Clinton's spending proposals and efforts by Republicans to cut taxes, the standoff this year over budget policy has led the two parties into a third course, the slashing of the national debt, that could have enormous political and economic consequences.

title: Family Planning Choices Are Still Too Few
description: To the Editor:

title: Another Revamping At Leo Burnett
description: After dividing into seven ''agencies within an agency'' in September 1997, Leo Burnett U.S.A., part of Leo Group, is being reorganized to operate as one large unit again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUMERGRADE, SAUL R.
description: SUMERGRADE-Saul R. On October 23, 1999, after a brief illness, at the age of 93. Beloved husband of Alice, devoted father of Nancy and Donald Mutterperl, and Michael and Patti Sumergrade; adoring grandfather of John and Heather Mutterperl, Jeffrey Mutterperl, Jane and Jim Webster, and Jenny Sumergrade; dear brother of the late Herman, Harry and Byrde. He always had a twinkle in his eye and a smile for his loving family and friends. Family will receive friends Tuesday, 7-9 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., at 81st St. Funeral service at Frank E. Campbell, Wednesday, 9:30 AM. In lieu of flowers contributions to Helen Keller Services for the Blind, or your favorite charity.

title: It Only Gets Better, Right?
description: On a day when the Jets reached a low point of the Bill Parcells regime, there were echoes: this was the fourth time in the 1990's the Jets started with a 1-6 record.

title: The Yankees' Traditional Fall Line Is on Display
description: Paul O'Neill batted .190 against left-handed pitchers this year, the worst in the American League, and left-handed batters hit .140 against the Braves left-hander John Rocker. In cold, hard statistics, it was the worst possible matchup for the Yankees in Game 1 of the World Series on Saturday.

title: Accounts
description: * Gamesville.com, Boston, a Web company that offers games that can be played for prizes, to DeVito/Verdi, New York, to handle its first account. Spending is estimated at $25 million through November 2000.

title: New Media Directors At TBWA/Chiat/Day
description: Two offices of TBWA/Chiat/Day, part of the TBWA Worldwide unit of Omnicom Group, have named new media directors.

title: You've Got Mail, Indeed
description: THE ''check'' is in the mail. So too are the ''important national survey,'' the ''Priority Express Gram'' and other ''time-sensitive material'' that is ''personal and confidential'' as well as ''extremely urgent.''

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about James S. Moran, a press agent known for publicity stunts, misspelled the name of another publicist, who said the era of such stunts was over. He is Sy Presten, not Cy Preston.

title: A President In Caucasus Is Baffled By Moscow
description: With each passing day, Ruslan Aushev, the president of the tiny enclave of Ingushetia in Russia's Northern Caucasus, is becoming more and more desperate with what he calls the ''imperial thinking'' in Moscow and Russia's prosecution of war in neighboring Chechnya, which has sent almost 170,000 refugees fleeing into his impoverished republic.

title: ONE EUROPE, 10 YEARS: A special report; Germany's East and West: Still Hostile States of Mind
description: Four years ago, Gabriela Mendling came here to Germany's ''Far East.'' She trawled streets with names like Salvador Allende and Karl Marx in search of a home.

title: Elite Colleges Step Up Courting of Minorities
description: It was not yet 8:30 on a Saturday morning, but as soon as Kara Beverly climbed aboard Amtrak train No. 84 in Washington, she had Ralph Ellison's ''Invisible Man'' open on her lap.

title: In Chaotic Markets, Fantastic Results
description: THE PREDICTORS

title: Another Diamond in Woods's Crown
description: Instead of being spoiled by success, Tiger Woods seems motivated by it.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Cone May Be Leaving in Style
description: David Cone planned to keep his jersey, his cap and his glove from tonight's World Series game, and he was thinking about searching for a used baseball that he forgot to tuck in his pocket. Cone knew that he might never get another chance to pitch in the Yankee uniform he once said he wanted to wear forever. Cone needed some mementos. Just in case.

title: Warrick Issue Marred the Day
description: Who would have thought that the man who has returned the expression, ''dadgum,'' back to metropolitan sports pages and national airwaves would believe in something as cosmic as karma? But there was Bobby Bowden, a homey and lived in 69 years old, suggesting just that after a milestone 300th victory captured in a historic coaching confrontation with his second son, Tommy.

title: On Baseball; Yanks Can Bring Back Girardi
description: Joe Girardi has pondered his muddled future more and more as November nears and another season culminates with the Yankees in the World Series. This is precisely where Girardi wants to be, in the sort of winning situation that any player would love, playing on a team he adores, with a manager who deeply respects him.

title: He's No Ticket Master
description: George Steinbrenner temporarily lost his tickets to Game 2. He borrowed a Yankees parka to wear during Game 1 and returned the jacket before removing the tickets from a pocket.

title: Sigmund Diamond, 79, Professor at Columbia
description: Sigmund Diamond, a Columbia professor of sociology and history who studied American business titans, female industrial workers and Federal Bureau of Investigation information gathering, died on Oct. 14 in Norwich, Conn. He was 79 and lived in Salem, Conn.

title: Polytechnic U. Plans a Makeover Using Gift, but Not Everyone Is Happy
description: When we last left the Cinderella tale of Polytechnic University in Brooklyn, it was celebrating a bequest of $175 million from one of its former chemistry professors and his wife and grappling with the pleasant problem of how to spend it.

title: Khannouchi Sets World Record In Only His Third Marathon
description: Six years after emigrating from Morocco, Khalid Khannouchi is chasing the American dream. He has a Web site and a sport utility vehicle. He hopes to win a gold medal for the United States in the 2000 Olympics in Sydney.

title: Deliberations Suspended As Two Jurors Fall Ill
description: Deliberations in the trial of Abe Hirschfeld, the real estate developer accused of hiring a hit man in a failed plot to kill his former business partner, were suspended yesterday after two jurors fell ill.

title: MEDIA; Getting in Sync in MTV Land
description: In the media industry's latest attempt to attain true convergence of television and the Internet, MTV plans to start a music-trivia game show in which viewers can play along by logging onto MTV's Web site.

title: A Sleeper Movie Awakened by a Hungry Audience
description: The stylish couple getting their midmorning caffeine blast on the sunbaked terrace of a Sunset Strip coffeehouse look like any of the other black-clad power types in designer sunglasses, cell phones resting on the table, giving every impression of being in the middle of a lucrative deal that would make other power types sick with envy if they only knew.

title: U.S. and Africa: Unfulfilled Promises and Skepticism
description: Editors' Note Appended

title: Deregulation to Unleash New Competition : Giant Banks Prepare For a U.S. Onslaught
description: The global financial industry, fresh from a round of megamergers, now must brace for another jolt of competition in the wake of a historic change in U.S. banking laws, executives said over the weekend.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAGUARDIA, JOAN S.
description: LaGUARDIA-Joan S. Age 87, of Ft. Lee, NJ, died October 23, 1999. Born in 1912, in Brooklyn, NY, of Tommasina and Saviano Sbordone. Graduate of CCNY, she was the only woman to pass the New York State CPA exam in 1937. Author of ''Like Coming Home,'' a memoir of growing up as a daughter of Italian immigrants. Loving wife of the late Alexander R. LaGuardia. Adoring mother of Angela L. Barnes of Sante Fe, NM, Thomasina J. LaGuardia, and Diana J. LaGuardia, both of Manhattan. Doting grandmother of Alexa B. Epstein, Peter D. Barnes Jr., Diana H. Barnes and Gabriel Samrock. Great-grandmother of Emily, Ethan and William. Dear sister of Theresa Catalanotte and Mary Miller. Cremation was private. A Memorial Mass will be held at Madonna Church on the Hill, Ft. Lee, NJ, on Monday, October 25, 1999, at 10 AM. Interment of the cremains will occur at a later date in Most Holy Trinity Cemetery, East Hampton, NY.

title: Airbus May Build 28 Planes for China
description: China will order 28 planes from Airbus Industrie worth about $1.8 billion, President Jacques Chirac of France announced today after a meeting with President Jiang Zemin of China.

title: High-Tech Gets Low Priority in Berkeley
description: In the midst of California's latest gold rush, here is a city looking for lead.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEGAL, NORMAN H.
description: SEGAL-Norman H. Of Heritage Hills, Somers, NY, and Indian Springs, Boynton Beach, FL. Died October 23, 1999, at the age of 77 years. Beloved husband of Rhoda (Goldberg) Segal. Loving father of Lynn (Ken) Walker and Nancy (Kevin) Culligan. Dear brother of Pearl Ruskin, Ralph Segal and the late Milton Segal. Devoted grandfather of Dale, Sarah, Ryan, Kate and Casey. Funeral service Monday (today), 12 noon, at BallardDuran Funeral Home, 2 Maple Ave., White Plains, NY. Interment King Solomon Cemetery, Clifton, NJ. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Northern Westchester Hospital, Critical Care, in memory of Norman Segal, 400 East Main St., Mt. Kisco, NY 10549, would be appreciated.

title: A Boon for Unity?/ Smiles Almost All Around : For Belgium, Crown Prince's Wedding Comes at Opportune Time
description: BRUSSELS  The forthcoming wedding of the crown prince to a fetching bourgeoise has given the country something to smile about after a monumental series of national scandals and crises. The government hopes the marriage on Dec. 4 will revive national pride and perhaps halt what many observers see as the slow fragmentation of Belgium.

title: Adding a Spice for Today To an American Original
description: Eugene Loring's ''Billy the Kid,'' revived by American Ballet Theater on Wednesday night after a 16-year absence from the repertory, is a small-scale treasure that proves the wisdom of the company's decision to present its smaller works in the intimate setting of the City Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REINER, MARTIN
description: REINER-Martin. Beloved husband of Anita. Loving father of Susan and Milton Erman, and Richard and Ellen Reiner. Adored grandfather of Joanna, Michael, Erica and Jenny. Services Monday, 11:30 AM, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck.

title: Israel Sentences Maryland Man In U.S. Murder
description: Saying nothing and showing no emotion as he stood before three Tel Aviv district judges and a gallery packed with reporters, Samuel Sheinbein was sentenced to 24 years in prison today for the murder of a neighborhood acquaintance in Maryland in 1997.

title: Unnecessary Reform
description: Pat Buchanan is expected to bolt the Republican Party today to run for the Reform Party nomination, and Donald Trump said yesterday he too is joining the Reform Party in advance of a possible Presidential bid. But there is likely to be little celebration inside the Reform ranks, because while both men may generate a lot of national attention, they are unlikely to improve the party's diminishing prospects.

title: Mrs. Clinton Again Asks Minimum Wage Rise
description: With two economists and the head of New York's largest coalition of labor unions by her side, Hillary Rodham Clinton implicitly attacked Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday for not supporting an increase in the Federal minimum wage and suggested that he had not done enough to help the poor in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAYNES, NANCY TOWNSEND
description: HAYNES-Nancy Townsend. Age 86, of Naples, FL, formerly of Bronxville, NY, died on Friday, October 22, 1999. She was born in NYC and was a graduate of Vassar College and The Brearley School and was a member of Christ Church, Bronxville, since 1952. Surviving are her children Lathrop T. Haynes and Patricia C. Haynes. Mrs. Haynes was preceded in death by her husband Lathrop L. Haynes in 1973. Private graveside services will be held at Kensico Cemetery.

title: Cable and Wireless Evades The Whirlwind of Mergers
description: Sitting pensive in his wood-paneled office here, Graham Wallace dismissed the constant whispers among investors and analysts around London's financial district -- the rumors that his far-flung global telecommunications company Cable and Wireless is ripe for a takeover and ready to sell out.

title: Rediscovering The Passion And Power Of the Duet
description: If there is anything like a slow whirlpool, its essence is captured in the quality with which Lar Lubovitch spins out ''Meadow,'' the poetic, dreamlike work he has choreographed for American Ballet Theater.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASSERMAN, MARILYN M.
description: WASSERMAN-Marilyn M. Wonderful wife of Arnold J. Wasserman for 52 years, beloved mother of Andrew Roy Wasserman and Joanne Dougan, and loved grandmother of Nici Wasserman and Fiona Starr Dougan. Died on Thursday, October 21, at Alta Bates Hospital in Berkeley, CA, from a cerebral hemorrhage. She also leaves a loving brother, Dr. Howard I. Maibach and sister-inlaw Siesel Wile Maibach. The burial will take place at 2 PM, on Tuesday, October 26, at Mt. Hebron Cemetery in Flushing, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the National Alliance for Breast Cancer.

title: In America; Fleeing The Taliban
description: I asked the young woman who was sitting in my office if she had ever seen her husband before the marriage ceremony. She said she hadn't even seen him at the ceremony.

title: Media Talk; Time Plans to Break Its News-Only Shell
description: The future of the weekly news magazine may not lie in, well, reporting weekly news. Beginning next Monday, in five special issues whose theme is the future, Time magazine will publish a serialized novel by Caleb Carr, a writer of historical thrillers. Bertelsmann's Random House is currently negotiating with Mr. Carr to publish the book in the fall of 2000.

title: Family Planning Choices Are Still Too Few
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Trump Leaves G.O.P. And May Oppose Buchanan

title: THIS WEEK
description: EVENTS

title: Enter Farce And Erudition; Ambiguity Fires a Novelist and Playwright
description: As an undergraduate studying philosophy at Cambridge, Michael Frayn always attended his supervisor's lectures, an academic experience so excruciating that, after a few weeks, he was the only student there.

title: Clinton Is Going on the Offensive To Offer the Elderly a Drug Plan
description: President Clinton is opening a new attack on drug companies, saying they charge too much and have grossly misrepresented his proposal to offer drug coverage to all Medicare beneficiaries, White House officials said today.

title: An Innocent Abroad in New York, Fresh From Frisco
description: What is all this fuss about Jennifer Love Hewitt? Apparently she became the beloved of teen-agers everywhere, playing Sarah, girlfriend of the troubled but cute Bailey Salinger (Scott Wolf), on Fox's hit drama ''Party of Five.''

title: Media Talk; Scheduling Woes End for 'N.Y.P.D. Blue'
description: Under pressure from the news media, fans and the outspoken executive producer Steven Bochco, ABC Entertainment executives had to make an almost Solomonic decision about whether the perennial hit ''N.Y.P.D. Blue'' should be knocked from its longtime slot on Tuesday at 10 P.M. in favor of a promising new drama, the touchy-feely ''Once and Again.'' They came up with what all sides described as the best possible solution to the scheduling problem.

title: Trump Quits Grand Old Party for New
description: Denouncing Patrick J. Buchanan as a ''Hitler lover,'' Donald J. Trump announced today that he was resigning his Republican registration in advance of a possible challenge to Mr. Buchanan in his expected quest for the Reform Party Presidential nomination.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NASSO, JULIUS
description: NASSO-Julius. On October 23, 1999, of Malverne, NY, and Fort Lauderdale, FL. Beloved husband of Annina. Loving father of Gilda Reinhardt and Julia Nasso-Silvestri. Dear grandfather of seven grandchildren and four greatgrandchildren. Loving brother of Vincent Nasso and Martino Nasso. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Avenue at 12th Street, Garden City, NY, Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday, 11 AM, Our Lady of Lourdes R.C. Church, Malverne, NY. Entombment Greenwood Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY. Donations to the North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System, Divison of Nephrology, North Shore University Hospital, 100 Community Drive, Great Neck, NY 11021 are appreciated.

title: Raiders Take a Page From Their Old Playbook
description: Oakland Coach Jon Gruden kept playing cat and mouse with the Jets' defensive coordinator, Bill Belichick, in the first half today, and Belichick was winning. Gruden had to play conservatively, keeping a receiver or a back in to block because he did not know where the Jets' defensive pressure was going to come from.

title: Capturing Birds, And Their Image
description: For Jonathan Shaw, a wildlife artist, a bird in the hand is indispensable. Mr. Shaw of Sleepy Hollow, N.Y., who paints with his right hand while holding a bird in his left, was part of an expedition throughout October to catch, band and release birds of prey on Schunemunk Mountain in Orange County. The operation was part of a United States Fish and Wildlife Service study.

title: Paramount Awards a Percentage Of Box-Office Receipts to Author
description: Viacom's Paramount Pictures studio has made an unusual deal with Michael Crichton, the author, for his newest novel. Instead of collecting millions of dollars by selling the rights to the studio, Mr. Crichton has opted to take a sizable percentage of the box office receipts.

title: Vikings Are Looking Like George's Team
description: The oddness of this strange, quirky season, in which the traditionally good teams are bad and the bad teams are good, crystallized perfectly at the Metrodome yesterday in Minneapolis. This simple statement sums it all up: Quarterback Jeff George saved the Minnesota Vikings from falling into the abyss by leading his team past San Francisco, 40-16.

title: Walter Stone, 'Honeymooners' Writer, 79
description: Walter Stone, the chief writer for the original ''Honeymooners'' television series starring Jackie Gleason, died on Wednesday in Miami Beach. He was 79 and lived on Bay Harbor Island, Fla.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNOG, SUZANNE
description: SCHNOG-Suzanne Adlerstein. 65, in Westport, CT, on October 22. Wife of the late Norbert Schnog. Beloved mother of Neal, Jeanne, Callie and two grandchildren. Services today at 11 AM, Temple Israel, Westport, CT.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''From the start I was a foreigner, and intolerance of foreigners in the east is unbelievable.''

title: Bank Measure Raises Concerns on Privacy
description: If Congress votes as expected this week to overhaul the nation's banking laws, it will be be offering companies broad opportunities to amass and share private data about their customers.

title: After Weeks of Futility, Giants Get Some Offense
description: The offense scored four touchdowns, which is normally a month's worth. It got 7 points on one of those desperation passes that almost never work. In the game's final minute, even though it no longer mattered, the defense put up a goal-line stand, just to be obstinate.

title: Villahermosa Journal; A Rising Tide Lifts All Political Resentments
description: As his windshield wipers beat against a relentless rain, Eduardo Gomez pulled his car up to the edge of a swampy lagoon littered with plastic bottles and broken chairs. He gestured toward a cluster of houses that stood, dark and silent, in the middle of the waters.

title: Not-So-Fond Memory
description: When the Braves' Brian Hunter made two errors in the eighth inning of Game 1, he became the first first baseman to do so since Frank Torre made two in one inning in the 1958 World Series. Joe Torre remembered that day vividly today, recalling the plays and the long post-game car ride by his brother's side.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

title: McCain Having to Prove Himself Even in Arizona
description: While Senator John McCain enjoys a wave of friendly publicity in his quest for the Republican Presidential nomination, he is struggling to prevent his great ambition from collapsing in the most unlikely of places: his home state, Arizona.

title: TECHNOLOGY: Digital Commerce; In the Internet rat race, greater value seems to be put on devising the next business plan than on making it work.
description: THE desire to cash out big is not a new motivating force in the technology industry. But what is striking about today's Internet economy is how much of that money lust is focused on selling business plans for their own sake, rather than planning viable businesses.

title: A Faulty Charter Reform
description: In politics, a dusting of sugar often disguises something far less appetizing. Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's Charter Revision Commission recommendation, scheduled to appear on New York City ballots on Nov. 2, offers just such a packet of debatable or even destructive changes softened by a few sweet-sounding but unnecessary proposals.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the World Briefing column on Tuesday about the retirement of Hanan Porat, a National Union Party member of Parliament in Israel, misstated the number of seats held by the party. It was four, not two.

title: Monday Morning Quarterback
description: Highlights and lowlights from the weekend. By JOE DRAPE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLAHER, SHEILA (WELBY)
description: GALLAHER-Sheila (Welby). Age 58, died October 21 in Nashua, NH, formerly of New York City; wife of Peter, mother of Andrew and Jeanne. Mass in St. Christopher Church, Wednesday, 10 AM. Visiting at Farwell Funeral Home, 18 Lock St., Nashua, on Monday, 6-8 PM and Tuesday, 2-4 and 6-8 PM.

title: The Big City; ATTEMPT IS MADE TO CROSS TIMES SQ. BEARING AN INFANT
description: IT began, like all great adventures, with an idle dream. Was there any way to get a baby in a stroller across Times Square on matinee day? Old-timers scoffed. It might have been possible years ago, during the brief calm between the peep shows and Disney, but even then no one had dared.

title: Atlanta's Lineup Changes Don't Work in the Field or at the Plate
description: The thinking behind Braves Manager Bobby Cox's decision to shake up his lineup was that perhaps inserting the left-handed hitters Ozzie Guillen, hitting .250 in the post-season, and Keith Lockhart, hitting .286, would kick-start a moribund offense -- that had managed just one hit off the Game 1 starter Orlando Hernandez -- against the right-hander David Cone, the Game 2 starter.

title: Despite Missteps, Louisiana's Governor Is Re-elected
description: In the end, all the campaign embarrassments and miscues had little if any effect on Gov. Mike Foster's bid for a second term. He proved himself to be one of the state's most popular Republican officeholders in years and won going away in Saturday's election, brushing off 10 challengers.

title: Albany Funds For Child Care Going Unspent
description: When New York State's new budget was passed in August, it appeared to throw an $800 million lifeline to New York's low- and moderate-income parents, roughly doubling the amount of money previously available to them to pay for child care.

title: Maria Piscator, 101, Theater Arts Teacher
description: Maria Ley Piscator, a theater arts teacher and director and the widow of the theatrical director Erwin Piscator, died on Oct. 14 at the Jewish Home and Hospital for the Aged in Manhattan. She was 101.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOSCANO, PETER R.
description: TOSCANO-Peter R. Professor Emeritus of Economics, Loyola University, Chicago. Beloved husband of Margo (nee Ledee). Loving father of Louis and Ellyn Toscano Tama. Loving brother of Concetta DeStefano, Rose DeMatteis and John Toscano. Cherished grandfather of four. Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Tuesday at 9:30 AM, Sacred Heart Church, 83-17 78th Avenue, Glendale, NY. Interment will follow at St. John's Cemetery, Middle Village, NY.

title: Compressed Data; An E-Commerce Site For E-Commerce Vendors
description: Electronic commerce is made possible by advanced communications services and equipment. So it is noteworthy that many of the companies that sell those services and equipment don't rely more heavily on E-commerce themselves. But Telezoo.com, a Web site that began operating earlier this year, is meant to change that.

title: With Sticks of Stone, Rangers Blanked in 3d Straight
description: In one room last night at Madison Square Garden, the Rangers' newest franchise player, Theo Fleury, was lamenting the team's lack of closeness, both on and off the ice, after the Rangers had been shut out for the third consecutive game for the first time in nearly half a century.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 17 about the cello that Yo-Yo Ma forgot in a taxi referred to it incorrectly. It was a 1733 Montagnana, not a Stradivarius.

title: F.A.L.N. Cost Us
description: To the Editor:

title: Editorial Observer
description: Among the many effects of democracy's spread through much of the developing world in the last few decades is the birth of a new American industry, democracy promotion. Beginning in the early 1990's, Washington began a wide variety of programs worldwide to help third-world countries democratize, including training election observers, improving parliamentary libraries, cajoling political parties to form coalitions, teaching citizens' groups how to lobby and helping independent newspapers write business plans. Last year the American government spent $719 million on these efforts.

title: Brosius Picks Up Where He Left Off
description: When Scott Brosius was selected the most valuable player in last year's World Series, the Yankees third baseman said that he did not have a place in mind for the trophy in his home in McMinnville, Ore.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFF, BARBARA
description: WOLFF-Barbara. The New York City BID Managers' Association, representing New York's 41 business improvement districts, notes with sadness the death of Barbara Wolff, our dear colleague, mentor and friend. For more than 20 years, Barbara provided extraordinary leadership and guidance to large and small business improvement districts throughout New York City. Each of the organizations that we represent embodies Barbara's passionate commitment to the neighborhoods and downtowns of New York City. The breadth, diversity and strength of our programs is a tribute to her vision, wisdom and dedication. She will be greatly missed by all of us who were privileged to work with her. We extend our sincere condolences to her family. Monica Blum, Chairperson BID Managers' Association

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: A Conductor's Privilege Turns Spring to Autumn
description: Over the years the German conductor Christian Thielemann, the general music director of the Deutsche Oper Berlin and a busy figure on the guest conducting circuit, has had a lot a praise from critics, including this one, for his musically probing and architectonic performances. But maybe the praise is going to his head. His work with the New York Philharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday night was disappointing. His interpretations were mannered and the playing of the orchestra was labored.

title: Patents; New books on ferreting out patent data and exploring the limits of intellectual property.
description: ALONG with the proliferation of new patents, it seems, comes a proliferation of new patents books.

title: Exploring Black Kingdoms of Antiquity
description: ''Roots'' meets Kenneth Clark's ''Civilization'' as Henry Louis Gates Jr., the prolific scholar, turns tour guide in a six-hour series with the unscholarly title of ''Wonders of the African World.'' Like other black Americans, he has been drawn to the history of civilizations created and ruled by blacks in Africa centuries before Europeans decided the continent was dark.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Reject the Global Buddy System
description: The Clinton Administration has been trying to frame the foreign policy debate for the 2000 election in the simplest possible terms: It's Clintonian internationalism versus Republican isolationism. Samuel Berger, the national security adviser, offered the fullest version of this thesis last Thursday, arguing that the Senate's rejection of the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty means we have returned once again to the ''old debate'' of the 1930's.

title: Treasurer's Downfall in Kickback Scheme Shakes Connecticut Political Establishment
description: They were the nation's youngest Governor and the nation's youngest State Treasurer, glad-handing contributors eager to be associated with a popular administration.

title: Robert Quinn, 72, Johnny Carson's Director
description: Robert J. Quinn, the longtime director of NBC's ''Tonight'' show when Johnny Carson was host, died on Thursday at his home in Malibu, Calif. He was 72.

title: Wendy Scott, 50, Who Faked Illness for Attention
description: Wendy Scott, who had one of the most severe cases on record of a syndrome in which people feign illness or make themselves sick to get medical treatment, died on Oct. 14 at a hospice in South London. She was 50.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MORDETSKY, HARVEY
description: MORDETSKY-Harvey. Birthday remembrances of a good, kind and decent man, my best friend. Russell

title: Glavine Return a Question
description: Tom Glavine was back at Turner Field to throw on the side today, but he went home before Game 2 began to continue to recover from the virus that forced him to miss his Game 1 start against the Yankees.

title: Colombia Begins Talking Peace With Rebels
description: After nearly a year of false starts, dashed hopes and spiraling violence, the Colombian Government and the country's principal Marxist guerrilla group today began formal negotiations aimed at ending more than three decades of violent civil conflict.

title: A Peaceful Retreat From Life
description: The composing career of Giovanni Pergolesi is a tiny cannon that has set off a two-and-a-half century roar. He died at 26 in 1736 and is remembered for two pieces of his own and a raft of fakes. Authentic without question is the comic opera or intermezzo ''La Serva Padrone,'' also the darkly beautiful ''Stabat Mater'' for the church. One of the more prominent fakes is the music on which Stravinsky based his synthesis of 18th-century style, ''Pulcinella.''

title: Party of Peron Loses Its Hold On Argentina
description: Mayor Fernando de la Rua of Buenos Aires, a somber centrist who campaigned pledging to clean up Government graft and breathe oxygen into a sluggish economy, appeared to win a landslide victory in presidential elections today, ending a decade of rule under the flamboyant and unpredictable Carlos Saul Menem.

title: Tyson Forced to Wait As Panel Reviews Fight
description: Mike Tyson's boxing fate and $10 million purse is in the hands of the Nevada State Athletic Commission until it can determine whether he intentionally threw a late punch Saturday night that caught Orlin Norris on the jaw and caused him to fall in an awkward manner and injure his right knee. Norris couldn't continue, and the bout was ruled no contest because it was stopped on an accidental foul.

title: Compressed Data; The PC Industry Shows Strong Growth
description: The personal computer industry is continuing to show significant global growth, with third-quarter shipments of machines increasing by 23.2 percent over the comparable quarter last year, according to a Dataquest report to be issued on Monday.
