title: An Editor Gets the Scoop On Tournament Opponents
description: Those who write about bridge are usually at some disadvantage in playing at a tournament. It is difficult to give complete focus to the bidding and play if part of one's mind is devoted to an article that must be written later.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORTIZ, PROVIDENCIA R.
description: ORTIZ-Providencia R. October 22, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Julio; loving mother of Julia Griffin; devoted mother in-law of William Griffin; cherished grandmother of Patricia and Michael. Reposing at the Frederick Funeral Home of Flushing, Northern Blvd, at 193rd St. Visiting hours Sunday and Monday 3-5 and 7-9PM. Funeral mass Tuesday 9:45AM, St. Kevin's RC Church. Interment Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUM, ROBERT EDWARD
description: BLUM-Robert Edward. 100, of Salisbury, CT, died at his home October 22, 1999. Devoted husband of the late Ethel Halsey Blum. Survived by his son, John R.H. Blum and daughter-in-law, Jeanne C. Blum, and his daughter, Alice B. Yoakum and son-in-law, Robert H. Yoakum, all of Lakeville, CT; nine grandchildren and 19 great-grandchildren. Memorial service on Saturday, October 30, 11 AM, Salisbury Congregation Church. In lieu of flowers, contributions would be welcomed to Berkshire Taconic Community Foundation, P.O. Box 569, Salisbury, CT 06068; or Maine Community Foundation, P.O. Box 148, Ellsworth, ME 04605.

title: People
description: * Wendy Riches was named to the new post of president at D'Arcy Marketing Communications Group, New York, part of the D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles Communications unit of MacManus Group. She had been president for global direct marketing and E-commerce at Hasbro Inc., Pawtucket, R.I.

title: State Child Care Aid Slow to Reach Clients
description: Funds for child care were doubled, to $800 million, in the state budget passed in August. But millions of dollars in subsidies are going unspent because the state has no detailed plan for getting the new money into the hands of low- and moderate-income parents, and because there are not nearly enough day care providers to meet the demand.

title: Right-Wing Political Party Leads in Swiss Elections, Endangering 40-Year Coalition
description: Switzerland's most conservative political party surged to stunning gains today in the country's parliamentary elections, apparently capturing the largest share of the vote nationwide and raising fears that this middle-of-the-road country is following its neighbor Austria in a lurch to the right.

title: Jets Have Time on Their Hands, Not on Their Side
description: It got worse for the Jets today, and it comes at a point in the season when they have time on their hands. They blew a 20-3 lead today, blew a mini-revival by Rick Mirer at quarterback and all but officially blew their season.

title: G.O.P. World View: Who Needs You?
description: To the Editor:

title: Harsh Critique of Teachers Urges Attention to Training
description: As the nation struggles to train more than 2.5 million new teachers over the next decade, college and university presidents must pay more attention and devote increasing resources to their schools of education, a leading higher-education group argues in an unusual report scheduled for release today.

title: Sports of The Times; For Saints and Ditka, Other Side of a Rout Not So Heavenly
description: WITH two minutes left in the shambles of a rout by the Giants, a flock of reporters rushed to the New Orleans Saints' interview room yesterday and jockeyed for position. It is rare that the coach of a team that loses by 31-3 is this highly sought. But this was Mike Ditka, the volatile head coach whose reaction to the Saints' deepening morass this season has taken him to the brink of a meltdown.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Israel's movement toward membership in a regional grouping at the United Nations, which would allow it to compete for a Security Council seat and other positions, misstated the timing of the repeal of a General Assembly resolution that equated Zionism with racism. The resolution was rescinded on Dec. 16, 1991, not during the first year of the Clinton Administration, which was 1993.

title: Media Talk; Wrestling Is Making UPN a Competitor
description: ''Action'' may have been the most talked about, most publicized and most debated new show of the television season, but when put in the ring against a bunch of big, sweaty wrestlers, the new Fox comedy has found itself slammed into submission.

title: In Film, Immigrants Bring Real Life to Acting Jobs
description: Cesar Monzon lives in a single basement room in Queens, thousands of miles from his family in Peru, whom he has seen for only two weeks in 11 years. When he does not have work, he spends his days on a Queens corner with dozens of other immigrants, hoping that a contractor will drive up with an offer of low-paying, back-straining work.

title: Robert Blanchon, 34, Conceptual Artist
description: Robert Blanchon, a conceptual and video artist whose work often dealt with the subject of gay identity and AIDS, died on Oct. 4 in Chicago. He was 34 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Harry Potter vs. the Censors
description: To the Editor:

title: Clemens Gets Message
description: As Roger Clemens was about to leave Turner Field on Saturday night after the Yankees' victory, George Steinbrenner shouted across the clubhouse to him, ''Did you get my message?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSTRIN, H. HOWARD
description: OSTRIN-H. Howard. October 23, age 88, after a very long illness. Predeceased by his beloved wife Ruth. Survived by his devoted daughter Abigail, and remembered always for his dedication to family, friends, the law and the Jewish community.

title: E-Commerce Report; Consumer products are being reviewed on more Web sites, some featuring comments from anyone with an opinion.
description: TRADITIONALLY, advice on consumer purchasing decisions has been the province of print publications like Consumer Reports, PC Magazine or Car and Driver. While many of these publications have moved their content on line, the growth of the Web has empowered another source of buying advice: the neighbor, cousin or uncle who just bought a particular item and is more than willing to share an opinion.

title: Compressed Data; Quiet, Please: Test In Progress
description: It has been three months since I.B.M. and major record labels began the experiment: selling albums over high-speed Internet cable modems in 1,000 households in metropolitan San Diego. But efforts to assess the music test's progress, have met the sound of silence. The companies have effectively imposed a publicity blackout.

title: Essay; Bagels vs. Doughnuts
description: A sea change in American taste took place at the beginning of this decade: The bagel overtook the doughnut in popularity. Today we spend three-quarters of a billion dollars a year on bagels, only a half-billion on doughnuts.

title: Banking Suspects Don't Represent All Russians
description: To the Editor:

title: N.B.A. Drug Breach
description: To the Editor:

title: Family Planning Choices Are Still Too Few
description: To the Editor:

title: What's in a Cap?
description: The Yankees right-hander Roger Clemens was introduced as part of the all-century team before Game 2 of the World Series.

title: Gray Interrogates Rose at an Inappropriate Time
description: Jim Gray is off my party list. He can't come to my cat's bat mitzvah for I fear the withering questions he would ask me: ''Your family is forgiving, so would you admit why you don't feed Biscuit her preferred brand of Iams?''

title: Harry Potter vs. the Censors
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Giants Make a Stand, Relatively
description: DON'T take the Giants' 31-3 rout of the Saints too seriously. Don't assume that the Giants suddenly are off and running and passing toward Super Bowl XXXIV, or even the playoffs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AXLER, MELVIN
description: AXLER-Melvin. The world and we have lost a rare gem of a man. Eternity has gained a beautiful soul. Deepest sympathy to Cynthia, his family and brother, Joe. Terry and Harvey Rosen

title: Ice Breakers
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: INSIDE
description: Senator John H. Chafee Dies

title: Experiment Seeks to Protect Ovaries From Cancer Treatment
description: In an experimental operation last Thursday that one doctor called ''great work'' but another called ''preposterous,'' surgeons in Brooklyn removed a woman's ovaries, sliced them into thin strips and implanted them into her arm.

title: Free Speech: Who's Accountable?
description: To the Editor:

title: Drunken Driver Faces 4 Manslaughter Counts
description: A 26-year-old woman was charged with four counts of aggravated manslaughter yesterday, after police said she was driving drunk during a head-on collision that killed four family members on Sunday.

title: Editors' Note
description: A news analysis article yesterday about Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright's visit to Africa described criticism of American policy by some Africans who believe that while President Clinton has spoken of democracy in Africa, the United States has not done enough to help resolve the many conflicts that have erupted or expanded on the continent since he visited last year.

title: Another Torre Celebrates
description: Frank Torre happily talked about celebrating an anniversary yesterday. It was the third anniversary of Torre's heart transplant, which took place the day before the Yankees defeated the Braves to clinch the 1996 Series. Torre said he felt fine and was thankful that could watch his brother, Joe, try to manage the Yankees to a third title in four years.

title: Reporter Defends Interview With Rose
description: A day after his contentious interview with Pete Rose before Game 2 of the World Series on Sunday night, the NBC reporter Jim Gray defended his tough questioning of Rose about whether he would admit to gambling on baseball in order to be reinstated.

title: Berkshire Hathaway and Others Plan to Buy MidAmerican Energy
description: Berkshire Hathaway Inc., the investment vehicle of Warren E. Buffett, is leading an investor group that will buy the MidAmerican Energy Holdings Company for $2 billion.

title: Yanks Must Decide On O'Neill's Option
description: The Yankees must decide soon whether to keep Paul O'Neill for next season by exercising a $6.5 million option. Last month, his agent spoke twice with Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman about the team's plans. ''I think they will pick up the option,'' said Joe Bick, who represents O'Neill. ''That's just my opinion. Paul is still what he's always been, and for what he's been, the money is pretty reasonable.''

title: Are Cybersquatters the New Pioneers?
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Knoblauch Won't Let Demons Win
description: THE solid single on an 0-2 fastball that Chuck Knoblauch remembered being ''up and in'' was almost lost in the machine-gun fire of hits that followed. Someone had to make first contact against Kevin Millwood, though. Someone had to send the comforting message to the Yankee dugout Sunday night that Millwood would not be blowing smoke on what became a very chilly World Series night for Atlanta.

title: A Halloween Scare for Parents: Traffic
description: It's not the ghosts, the goblins or even all that sugar that puts many children at risk when they go out trick or treating.

title: It's Up to a Queasy Glavine to Stop the Yankees
description: Tom Glavine is the first in the last line of defense for the Atlanta Braves in this World Series, and over the past two days, his manager asked the pitcher repeatedly if he has had enough time to recover from a stomach virus, if he would be ready to pitch in Game 3 tonight.

title: Abroad at Home; The Story of K
description: Credit to the Commissioner of Immigration, Doris Meissner, for a difficult and important decision. She has ended the long effort to deport an alien on the basis of secret evidence, declining to seek further review of court rulings against her agency, the Immigration and Naturalization Service.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRANDIN, SUSANNE P. (WILSON)
description: GRANDIN-Susanne P. (Wilson) of Chestnut Hill, October 24, 1999 at home, age 81 years. Wife of 59 years of John L. Grandin, Jr. Mother of John L. Grandin III, Edward W. Grandin and Preston B. Grandin all of Chestnut Hill. Also survived by 5 grandchildren, Jay, Louisa, Andrew, Will & Mercedes. A Memorial Service will be held at Trinity Church, Copley Square, Boston on Saturday, October 30 at 11AM. Private interment. Longtime trustee of Boston Symphony Orchestra. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be sent to the Boston Symphony Orchestra, 301 Massachusetts Avenue, Boston, MA. 02115.

title: New Way Of Looking At Diseases Of the Brain
description: A highly respected neuroscientist has developed a provocative new theory of how the brain is organized which, if confirmed, would explain how and why the mind produces symptoms found in several seemingly unrelated disorders.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column in Business Day yesterday, about the proliferation of direct mail, misstated the figures for sales generated by it. They totaled $421.2 billion in 1998, not $421.2 million -- as compared with $390 billion in 1997, not $390 million.

title: Sports of The Times; Stewart, a Golfer With Style and Class
description: Until yesterday, until his Learjet's strange and spooky crash, Payne Stewart's life had never been better. He had won his second United States Open with a 15-foot par putt on the 18th green at Pinehurst No. 2 in June, and he was on the American team that snatched the Ryder Cup from the European pros in a Sunday comeback last month at The Country Club outside Boston.

title: Taking a Literary Source Into an Animated World
description: Grace Ellen Barkey

title: France Joins U.S. in a Push For Midsize Museums
description: Their buildings, collections and traditions may be very different, but regional museums in France and the United States have at least one thing in common: acute awareness that Americans usually visit museums in Paris, that French tourists head for museums in New York and that museums in medium-size cities in both countries are all too often overlooked.

title: Benefits Of Being So Annoyed
description: Punk rock supposedly expresses rage, but often the music is really stimulated by irritation. Deep irritation, mind you, the kind caused by an unreachable itch or the repeated shove the school bully gives to the brain. All grown up, the brain discovers other bullies. On the outside there are rule makers, the government and the rich; on the inside, raging hormones. Righteous anger blows off steam, but it's too overblown to last. So the punk rock brain employs wit to alleviate the stress.

title: Kendra's Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ETKIN, GEORGE
description: ETKIN-George, died October 15, 1999 at 89 years of age. He was the widower of Sylvia Nash Etkin. He graduated from City College in NY and then received a law degree from Fordham University. He was a petty officer first class in the United States Navy during WW II. After the war Mr. Etkin worked as legal counsel for Dumont Laboratories, a pioneer in TV broadcasting, and then for Metromedia. George and Sylvia moved to Sarasota in 1983. He was an ardent supporter of Israel, youth tennis and a lover of classical music. He is survived by his two sons, Thomas and Peter and six grandchildren. Services were held in Sarasota. For information Toale Brothers Funeral home.

title: POOR SHOWING FOR CELANESE
description: Investors gave a frigid greeting to the share debut of Celanese A.G., the biggest chemical company yet to be spun off by Hoechst A.G. Its shares closed more than 8 percent below their opening price, at 14.85 euros. The decline was doubly disappointing because the opening price was at the bottom end of a range set by Celanese's investment bankers. Celanese, which has sales of 5.2 billion euros, or $5.6 billion, is running heavy losses because of a prolonged downturn in world chemical prices.

title: Birds Ruffle Their Feathers And the Stage Is a Drum
description: Wofa

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISLER, GOLDY
description: WEISLER-Goldy. Age 93. Beloved wife of the late Frederick L. Weisler. Mother of Ruth and Harvey Lebo and Max Weisler. Adored grandmother of Mark (Susan), Larry and Ned Lebo and Frances and Nancy Weisler. Great grandmother of Jessica and Shelby Lebo and Nicole and Austin Lebo.

title: For Gore and Bradley, A Search for Distinction
description: Vice President Al Gore and former Senator Bill Bradley have a lot more in common than either would like to admit to Presidential primary voters.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: VAIL RESORTS INC., Avon, Colo., the largest U.S. ski-resort operator, agreed to buy the closely held Internet companies Vailnet and Internetworks for undisclosed prices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDENSON, ROBERT M., PH.D
description: GOLDENSON-Robert M., Ph.d 91 A Memorial Service was held October 23 at Princeton University. A Westchester resident for 40 years, he was Chief Psychologist of United Cerebral Palsy of Westchester, and the author of ten books. He is survived by his wife, Irene, of Jamesburg, NJ, two sons and daughters-in-law, Daniel and Suzanne of Princeton, NJ, and Ronald and Ellen of Cohasset, MA, a brother William, and two grandsons, Andrew and Jeffrey.

title: In Court, Psychiatrist Rebuts Defense Claim in Train Killing
description: A psychiatrist testifying for the prosecution said yesterday that a schizophrenic man accused of pushing a woman in front of a subway train joked with the psychiatrist that people ''didn't take me seriously'' before the fatal attack and openly discussed the chances that his insanity defense would work.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING
description: THE last letter of the alphabet is becoming the last word, as it were, in names.

title: Clinton Signs Military Budget Bill, Avoiding Split Among Democrats
description: President Clinton signed a $268 billion spending bill for the Pentagon today, avoiding the risk of a split among Democrats at the very moment that the parties are speeding toward the end of their budget battle. At the same time, he vetoed a separate spending bill for some other Federal agencies, attacking Republicans as making ''wrong choices.''

title: The Truth About Licorice
description: To the Editor:

title: Accounts
description: * Lernout & Hauspie, Burlington, Mass., a speech and language solutions company, to Gearon Hoffman, Boston, to handle the account of its dictation division, which had been in-house. Billings were estimated at $2 million to $3 million.

title: Schwarz to Quit After 17 Years As Leader of Mostly Mozart
description: In a move that Lincoln Center officials say caught them by surprise, Gerard Schwarz has said that he will relinquish the music directorship of the Mostly Mozart Festival when his contract ends in 2001. Mr. Schwarz, who became the festival's first music director in 1984 after two years as its music adviser, said on Sunday that he had told Nathan Leventhal, president of Lincoln Center, on Wednesday about his desire to leave the festival.

title: Campaign Corruption
description: To the Editor:

title: INQUIRY AT DAEWOO SECURITIES
description: South Korea's Financial Supervisory Commission has begun investigating the Daewoo Securities Company on suspicions that it provided money to cash-short Daewoo Group affiliates in a bid to prop up their business operations. The investigation is part of a broader inquiry into questionable financial transactions among affiliates of South Korea's major conglomerates, a commission official said. Daewoo Securities, which was spun off from Daewoo Group, had been a crucial source of financing for Daewoo affiliates.

title: The Church and Astronomy
description: To the Editor:

title: Creating a Portrait of Bush, as an Upbeat Leader Promising a Fresh Start
description: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, the front-runner for the Republican Presidential nomination, unveiled his first television advertisements today, and they cast him as a humble, upbeat leader devoted to lower taxes and better education.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: A New Breed Of Magazine Designed to Startle
description: If you opened the August issue of Flaunt magazine smack in the middle expecting to see a picture of, say, Elizabeth Hurley languishing at the beach, the fringes of her Gucci halter dress tickling the water's surface, you would have been disappointed.

title: Front Row
description: Elegantly Modern Jewelry

title: Celestial Gamma Rays Open Window on the Heavens
description: Ancient sky watchers saw the heavens as a kind of cosmic sculpture garden, eternal and unchanging.

title: Dreamworks and Imagine Plan an Internet Venture
description: In what its principals say is a first glimmer of the rapidly approaching digital entertainment world, executives at Dreamworks SKG and Imagine Entertainment said today they would join to create a new Internet entertainment company and World Wide Web site offering short films, streaming video, live events, games, performance art, continuing series, ''nonlinear interactive features'' and whatever else they can think of.

title: Pro Golfer and 5 Others Die In a Baffling Jet Accident
description: A Learjet that took off from Orlando, Fla., this morning carrying the golfer Payne Stewart and apparently five others traveled a wayward path across the country for four hours with no one at the controls, shadowed by Air Force jets that watched it finally crash in a South Dakota field. Everyone on board was killed.

title: On a Galaxy's Assembly Line, Where the Black Holes Merge
description: A new calculation suggests that dense star clusters, which are sprinkled throughout galaxies in Earth's cosmic neighborhood, act as assembly lines for tightly orbiting pairs of black holes and then spit them out of the cluster. There, they eventually fall together and merge into one.

title: It's Coming: Stock Up on Good Humor
description: So will the turn of the millennium mean a blip or a glitz or a monumental mess for America? Robert X. Cringely, the PBS specialist on nerdism, is the latest investigator to address the question. In ''Y2K: The Winter of Our Disconnect,'' he chats with officials, computer know-it-alls and ''survivalists'' and comes up with more reasons for indifference than for panic.

title: Russian Student Visas
description: To the Editor:

title: Pakistani Report Alleges Graft by Ex-Premier
description: Pakistan's deposed Prime Minister, Nawaz Sharif, skimmed hundreds of millions of dollars from public works, wheat imports, sugar exports and other Government projects, according to detailed records compiled by the nation's most prominent criminal investigator.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEE, RAYETTA
description: NEE-Rayetta. On October, 19, 1999. Graduate of The Masters School, Bryn Mawr College, Oxford University, Harvard Law School, and The NYU Law School Tax Program, Rayetta will be deeply missed by her classmates, by her friends from the summer house, and from The Church of The Ascension, where she served as Warden of the Vestry, and by her colleagues and clients. Memorial Service will be held Saturday, November 6, 1999, 3 P.M. at The Church of the Ascension, Fifth Avenue at 10th Street, NY, NY 10003. In lieu of flowers, and in thanks for their great kindness, contributions can be made to The Church of the Ascension or to Jacob Perlow Hospice, Beth Israel Hospital Center, First Avenue at 16th Street, NY, NY 10003.

title: BMW to Raise Stake in Rolls-Royce, Its Aerospace Partner, to 10%
description: BMW will raise its stake in Rolls-Royce P.L.C. to 10 percent and give Rolls-Royce control of a joint venture that builds plane engines, the companies said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AUER, REZIKA
description: AUER-Rezika. On October 23, 1999 of Baiting Hollow, L.I. Beloved wife of Lucijan. Loving mother of Peter. Dear grandmother of Jennifer and Cliff. Leaving the Beney Funeral Home, Inc. of Syosset, 79 Berry Hill Road, Wednesday, 10:00 am for Pinelawn Memorial Park. In Lieu of flowers donations to Rezika Auer Memorial Fund c/o The Community Church of Syosset, 36 Church Street, Syosset, N.Y. 11792

title: Democracy Sprouts in Kyrgyzstan's Hostile Soil
description: The deserts, steppes and mountains of Central Asia have given birth to some of history's most brutal conquerors, but very few democrats.

title: JAPANESE SURPLUS JUMPS
description: Japan's merchandise trade surplus rose more than 20 percent in September, as the rising yen cut import costs and export sales rose. The surplus grew 21.8 percent, to 1.16 trillion yen, or $9.6 billion, seasonally adjusted, from August, Finance Ministry figures showed. That was in line with expectations. From a year ago, the surplus fell 9.7 percent, to 1.39 billion yen, unadjusted. Exports, by value, rose four-tenths of 1 percent and imports fell 6.1 percent.

title: Buchanan Bolts G.O.P. for Reform Party Run
description: Patrick J. Buchanan put aside a lifetime of Republican fervor today and shifted his lagging Presidential quest to a run for the Reform Party nomination.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRAWFORD, THELMA V.
description: CRAWFORD-Thelma V. Beloved wife to Frank Earl and Stanley Paffrath. Mother of John & Nancy Paffrath. Died from cancer. Sister to Ethel Lynch and Andrew Kish. Memorial to be announced. Contributions to be sent to Cabrini Hospice, New York City.

title: Solomon And Baby, According To Handel
description: Some Handel oratorios are born theatrical, like ''Esther,'' which was staged by Millennial Arts Productions two years ago; others have theatricality thrust upon them, like ''Messiah,'' which is to be staged by the same company in December, set in Bedlam. ''Solomon,'' highly theatrical but only in part, is a special case: one reason, perhaps, it is so rarely encountered.

title: Jose, the Vulnerable Case, Carmen, Herself Only More So
description: Lyons Opera Ballet

title: Poses and Hobblings, Crowds and Grimaces
description: Virpi Pahinken and Sara Gebran

title: ESTEE LAUDER BUYS BEAUTY-PRODUCT MAKER, JO MALONE
description: The Estee Lauder Companies, the largest United States maker of cosmetics sold in department stores, has acquired Jo Malone Ltd., adding a niche brand to its product line. The buyer, the New York-based maker of Clinique, Aveda and its namesake cosmetics line, will gain Jo Malone's line of about 200 skin-care and fragrance products. Jo Malone has a flagship store in London and sells its products through catalogues and a few premium specialty stores, including Saks Fifth Avenue. Shares of Estee Lauder, which sells its products in 110 countries, rose $1.0625 each, to $46.0625. Jo Malone's products include a lime- basil-and-mandarin cologne; a nutmeg-and-ginger body lotion and Jo Malone cleansing milk.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COHEN, IRA A.
description: COHEN-Ira A. October 26, 1989. One of a kind, we love and miss you. Your family and friends.

title: Ford to Install Safety Bars in Big Pickups
description: The Ford Motor Company plans to start installing hollow, energy-absorbing steel bars below the front and rear bumpers of all its industrial-size pickup trucks in the 2001 model year to reduce the risk that they will ride over cars in crashes, Ford officials said in interviews today at a safety conference here.

title: STRONG NUMBERS AT AD GIANT
description: The world's No. 3 advertising agency holding company, WPP Group P.L.C., posted a 12 percent rise in sales, to $897 million, for the quarter that ended Sept. 30. WPP agencies include Ogilvy & Mather and J. Walter Thompson.

title: TOPPS GETS SALES LIFT FROM NINTENDO TIE-IN
description: The Topps Company, seller of Bazooka gum and baseball cards, said sales of candy and trading cards featuring the Nintendo Company's Pokemon video-game characters might exceed $80 million in its fiscal year 2000, sending shares as much as 23 percent higher. Sales of trading cards based on the games and animated television series, are ''very strong,'' New York-based Topps said. Topps said its Pokemon-product sales could be $80 million to $100 million in the fiscal year ending Feb. 26. Topps shares rose $2 each, to $10.50.

title: Public Interests; Standing Pat
description: Patrick Buchanan's formal secession from the Republican Party lost quite a bit of its drama because of a balky sound system. A political primal scream requires amplification. One minute the Buchanan of yore was howling about the New World Order, and the next he was just like any other slightly flummoxed after-dinner speaker, betrayed by bad audio-visual aids. (''O.K., let me go back and say we're going to cut those cancerous trade deficits. . . .'')

title: Twirling Big Ideas in the Air and Sending Them Home, Effortlessly
description: When Midori is playing, a very fine line of violin tone -- hardly more than brushed off the string and whisper-soft -- can contain a huge, bulging quantity of musical character. She showed this essential aspect of her artistry at once on Friday night at Carnegie Hall, in the first movement of Mozart's A Major Sonata (K. 526). In her quietness, clarity and balance, she respected the Classical, domestic origins of the music, but at the same time her phrasing projected a great strength of musical communication through the hall.

title: WORLD SERIES: A World of Difference; Challenges Have Added Depth to Torre's Perspective on Life
description: Joe Torre peers at sunsets as if he were watching them for the first time. He recognizes the vibrant flowers he never bothered to look at before, absorbing their beauty. He sees bright stars on dark, clear nights, studying them more than staring at them. Things change.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUM, ROBERT E.
description: BLUM-Robert E. The Board and staff of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, Inc. mourn the passing of Robert E. Blum, director emeritus since 1969. A major supporter of many New York institutions, he was crucial to the development of Lincoln Center, having served as treasurer from 1956 to 1963. In those years he made his greatest contribution as a problem-solver, a strong yet self-effacing personality who could bring together people with different points of view. We extend our condolences to his children, John and Alice, and to his grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Beverly Sills, Chairman Nathan Leventhal, President Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, Inc.

title: Officials Say Bureaucratic Snag Kept Suspect in Boy's Kidnapping on Streets
description: A bureaucratic snag may have allowed a Bronx man accused of kidnapping a 4-year-old boy from a Manhattan playground to remain on the streets even after he was arrested last spring while still on probation for sexually abusing two young children, city officials said yesterday.

title: Ho-Hum. Slow Day at Office As Major Indexes Decline.
description: Stock prices weakened a bit yesterday as traders in large-capitalization issues took some profits following last week's bounce in major averages. Market interest rates, which moved higher in the morning but later retreated and closed little changed, provided another source of instability.

title: Wayne E. Oates, 82, Is Dead; Coined the Term 'Workaholic'
description: Wayne E. Oates, the tireless writer of 57 books dealing with the relationship between theology and psychiatry, and the man who thought up the word ''workaholic,'' died on Thursday at a Louisville hospital. He was 82.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIBIAN, GEORGE
description: GIBIAN-George. 75. Unexpectedly, at home, in Ithaca, N.Y. on October 24, 1999. He was the Goldwin Smith Professor of Russian and Comparative Literature at Cornell University and a decorated veteran of W.W. II. He was born in Prague. Scholar, author, editor, translator and devoted family man, George is survived seven children, fifteen grandchildren, two brothers, and his partner Karen Brazell.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'LEARY, WILLIAM J. SR.
description: O'LEARY-William J. Sr. A resident of Lake Placid, NY died on October 15 at the Adirondack Medical Center. Born March 31, 1929, in Elizabeth, NJ, son of the late Dennis & Ann Mahoney O'Leary. Graduate of Lehigh University. Associated with Ingersol Rand/ Dresser Rand for 42 years. Survived by sons, William Jr., Peter, Richard, Paul and Joseph O'Leary and daughters, Hope Frenette & Constance Keller & 16 grandchildren. A service will be held Monday at 10:30 AM at Saint Agnes Church, Lake Placid. Memorial contributions may be made to Adirondack Medical Center Capital Campaign, POB 120, Saranac Lake, NY 12983 or the American Cancer Society.

title: George C. Scott Memorial
description: A public memorial service for the actor George C. Scott is to be held on Thursday at 2 P.M. at the O'Neill Theater, 230 West 49th Street, Manhattan. Among those scheduled to speak are the actors Jason Robards, Nathan Lane, Campbell Scott, Kate Burton and Elizabeth Wilson and the producers Ted Mann and Paul Libin. Mr. Scott died in September at 71.

title: A Home Of the Blues, Singing a New Tune
description: Driving into this sleepy upper Delta city toward the crossroads where Highway 49 meets Highway 61, the first thing one sees is a sign that boasts ''Clarksdale: Home of the Big Frog.'' There is little mention that Clarksdale is famous for more than amphibians: it is probably the most legendary blues site in the South. Dozens of blues legends were born or lived in this city or its county, Coahoma, among them John Lee Hooker, Muddy Waters, Charley Patton, Pinetop Perkins, Son House and W. C. Handy. Nearly every Delta blues musician of note performed in Clarksdale regularly, including Robert Johnson, Howlin' Wolf and Sonny Boy Williamson. And many of them died here, most notably Bessie Smith. To this day a visitor arriving on a lucky night can see a venerable musician rocking the barroom at one of the dozen crumbling juke joints downtown.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWEITZMAN, SPENCER JOSEPH
description: SCHWEITZMAN-Spencer Joseph. Suddenly, at the age of 18. Beloved son of Alfred and Susan, cherished brother of Sarah & Jason, adored grandson of Viola Sommer. He will be missed and remembered by many. Services on Tuesday, October 26, at 10 AM at the Ferncliff Cemetery and Crematory, Hartsdale, New York.

title: 3M Reports Its Profits for the Third Quarter Were 18% Higher
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, the maker of Post-It notes and Scotch tape, said today that its third-quarter earnings rose 18 percent, more than expected, as sales rose and the cost of raw materials fell.

title: Yankee Atlantans
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NASSO, JULIUS
description: NASSO-Julius. On October 23, 1999, of Malverne, NY, and Fort Lauderdale, FL. Beloved husband of Annina. Loving father of Gilda Reinhardt and Julia Nasso-Silvestri. Dear grandfather of seven grandchildren and four greatgrandchildren. Loving brother of Vincent Nasso and Martino Nasso. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Avenue at 12th Street, Garden City, NY, Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday, 11 AM, Our Lady of Lourdes R.C. Church, Malverne, NY. Entombment Greenwood Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY. Donations to the North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System, Divison of Nephrology, North Shore University Hospital, 100 Community Drive, Great Neck, NY 11021 are appreciated.

title: Oil Companies Post Big Income Gains
description: Major oil companies said yesterday that third-quarter earnings rose substantially, with some more than doubling, largely because of the increased price of crude oil.

title: SAMSUNG TO SHIP TUBES
description: A unit of a leading South Korean conglomerate, the Samsung Display Devices Company, signed a six-year, $600 million contract with Royal Philips Electronics N.V., the Dutch electronics and consumer products giant, to ship about 7.2 million color display tubes for computers. Samsung Display Devices will begin shipping 15-inch and 17-inch color display tubes to Philips next year, a spokesman for Samsung said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORLIN, HARRIET
description: GORLIN-Harriet. On October 22, 1999 at age 74. Wife of the late Sol Gorlin. Loving mother of Rebecca J. Gorlin. Interment private.

title: French to Buy Brazilian Aircraft Stake
description: A French aerospace consortium agreed today to acquire a stake in Empresa Brasileira de Aeronautica S.A., a rapidly growing aircraft maker that is one of corporate Latin America's biggest success stories.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARROLL, MIRIAM JAMES
description: CARROLL-Miriam James, Sister. Beloved member of the Sisters of Charity, on Sunday, October 24, 1999 at the Convent of Mary the Queen, Yonkers, New York. Dear daughter of the late James and Elizabeth Snyder Carroll. Mass of the Resurrection today 9:30 AM at the Convent of Mary the Queen, 35 Vark Street, Yonkers, New York. Interment is at St. Joseph's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Sisters of Charity Development Fund, 6301 Riverdale Ave., Bronx, NY 10471. F. Ruggiero & Sons, Inc., Yonkers, New York.

title: Cell Phones: Questions but No Answers
description: Almost since there have been cellular phones, there have been worries that the radio waves they emit might cause brain cancer. Yet despite years of studies, no one has established a solid link, and the industry has long sought to reassure the public that the technology is perfectly safe.

title: In Michigan, School Choice Weeds Out Costlier Students
description: A University of Michigan study of the state's school-choice programs found that the spread of charter schools and inter-district transfers had created new educational opportunities for many of the neediest families and serious problems for only a few of the state's school districts. But it said that most of the programs were designed to attract only the students who cost the least to educate.

title: London Journal; In Labor's Britannia, Lords Blow Own Trumpets
description: Some peers wrote in Latin. Others wrote in verse. Almost all hoped that their unique credentials -- whatever those credentials might be -- would prove useful if they were allowed to stay in the House of Lords.

title: Chairman of Dun & Bradstreet Steps Down
description: The Dun & Bradstreet Corporation, which is under shareholder pressure to increase earnings and consider selling assets, said today that Volney Taylor had resigned as chairman and chief executive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARD, PENNY
description: BARD-Penny. On October 24, 1999. Of Villanova, PA. Formerly of East Meadow, N.Y. Beloved wife of Jed Abramowitz. Daughter of Norman & Shirley Bard. Loving mother of Jacob, Alex and Peter. Sister of Amy Bard and Stuart Kuritsky and Michael and Susan Bard. Daughter-in-law of Julius and Jean Abramowitz. Sister-inlaw of Alton Abramowitz & Susan Gorelick and Gwen and Allan Leeds. Aunt of Liza, Sally, Spencer, Sophia and Blythe.

title: Closer Jets Get, the Farther They Fall
description: The Jets' plane ride back from California Sunday night was not exactly a pleasure trip.

title: EUROPEAN BANK DEAL
description: Scandinavia's fifth-largest bank, SEB A.B., said it would buy BfG Bank A.G. of Germany from Credit Lyonnais S.A. for 1.6 billion euros, or $1.7 billion, to expand in asset management and Internet banking in Europe. The purchase will create a bank with 2.5 million private clients and $88 billion in assets under management. BfG, with 1 percent of a German retail banking market that includes 3,600 other banks, is finding it difficult to sustain earnings growth and has warned that 1999 profit might drop. The European Commission told Credit Lyonnais, which owns 50 percent plus one share in BfG, to sell its stake in return for about $25 billion in aid from France. Credit Lyonnais said it would lose money on the sale.

title: A Classical Approach To the Graham Karma
description: A woman in white stands onstage, a dancer embodying contained lyricism, and a man falls to her feet or cartwheels for joy. Splashed like paint on a canvas, another woman in red embodies passion as she races across in a diagonal. Her youthful counterpart in yellow springs onto a partner's shoulders. A male and female ensemble amplifies these images. The work of course is ''Diversion of Angels,'' Martha Graham's celebrated and luminous ode to love.

title: Braves' Williams Ponders Yankee Ties
description: The question made Gerald Williams raise his head and open his eyes wide. Then he chuckled.

title: Mourning In Golf Country
description: The area around this tourism destination is home to many of the best touring professionals, including Payne Stewart, who died in a plane crash today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINMAN, ILENE
description: FEINMAN-Ilene. Passed away peacefully after a long illness. Beloved wife of 45 years to Jerry. Devoted mother to David and Tammy Feinman, Nancy and Don Nowak, and Wilma Beth Feinman. Adoring grandmother to Rebekah and Ariel. Loving sister to Barbara & Paul Seidenberg. She will always be missed. Services 12:30 today, Schoem Chapel, Paramus, N.J.

title: Management Changes For McCann-Erickson
description: McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising in New York is making changes in management for its largest operating regions.

title: New Alliance Will Promote Wireless Access to Internet
description: A group of leading technology companies said yesterday that they would form an alliance to create products that would allow consumers to get high-speed Internet access through a wireless system within the next year.

title: Women Nearer to Equality, N.C.A.A. Says
description: Two years ago, the National Collegiate Athletic Association predicted that it would take 10 to 12 years to achieve equality in men's and women's athletic programs at its member schools.

title: On Sex, Students Have a Lot to Learn
description: Despite renewed efforts across the country to educate teen-agers about sex and repercussions like pregnancy and disease, many young people say they still need more information. A new study of high school students suggests that they are right.

title: Doubts About Dam Breaching
description: To the Editor:

title: Going Gently, Into Sleep and Old Age
description: Next time you skip a few hours of sleep so you can get in a little more work, or maybe just that last bit of Letterman, consider the possible consequences: you may pay for the sleep deprivation not just the next morning, but somewhere down the road as well.

title: Link Opens West Bank to Gaza's Job Hunters
description: Khader Juneed, 23, had never set foot outside Gaza in his life, and his family didn't want him to, either. His parents feared he might never return, and so when he came home proudly last week with a shiny new Israeli-issued permit that would allow him to travel to the West Bank, they forbade him to use it.

title: Under Antarctica, Clues to an Icecap's Fate
description: The beautiful swirls, tracery and arabesques gracing a collection of radar pictures of Antarctica made public last week would be worthy of exhibition by a gallery of abstract art.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUMERGRADE, SAUL R.
description: SUMERGRADE-Saul R. On October 23, 1999, after a brief illness, at the age of 93. Beloved husband of Alice, devoted father of Nancy and Donald Mutterperl, and Michael and Patti Sumergrade; adoring grandfather of John and Heather Mutterperl, Jeffrey Mutterperl, Jane and Jim Webster, and Jenny Sumergrade; dear brother of the late Herman, Harry and Byrde. He always had a twinkle in his eye and a smile for his loving family and friends. Family will receive friends Tuesday, 7-9 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., at 81st St. Funeral service at Frank E. Campbell, Wednesday, 9:30 AM. In lieu of flowers contributions to Helen Keller Services for the Blind, or your favorite charity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, JACK M.
description: LEVY-Jack M. At 85, in Seattle, WA, on October 23, 1999. Architect and engineer. Beloved father of Arthur, Joan, Steven, and Ronald. Cherished grandfather of Scott, David, Suzanne, and Miriam. Dear brother of Jimmie.

title: Growers' Lament: The Crop's Bright Red, but So Is the Ink
description: In one way, the news this year from Bruce Grim's orchard, and from orchards all over this region that proudly calls itself the Apple Capital of the World, is very good news indeed. ''Vintage!'' Mr. Grim proclaimed as he plucked a red Delicious from a tree and sliced it open with a pocketknife. ''Lots of crunch. Lots of snap.''

title: Coaching Carousel May Turn
description: METROSTARS

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: A Lopez in Every Garage; Former G.M. and VW Executive Wants His Own Factory
description: Jose Ignacio Lopez de Arriortua has long dreamed of building a car factory here in his Basque hometown. But that dream caused him, by his own reckoning, to commit the biggest mistake of his life.

title: Coca-Cola Tests Find No Problem
description: The Coca-Cola Company, the world's largest soft-drink company, said today that its initial tests on drinks that Belgian schoolchildren said last week had made them sick indicated no problems with the beverages.

title: Business Seeks A Bigger Role In Campaigns For Congress
description: The United States Chamber of Commerce will step up its assistance to Congressional candidates that it considers friendly to business in an effort to counter the growing political influence of organized labor and other liberal groups, the chamber's president said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVA, FILOMENA BARRETO, M.D.
description: SILVA-Filomena Barreto, M.D. Age 53. Of Scarsdale, New York. Died October 25, 1999. Survived by loving husband Jose V. Silva, M.D., children Paulo, Nicole and Mark, mother Cremina V. Barreto, brother Joao Sales Barreto, M.D. and sisters Fatima P. Pereira, Maria Lourdes Moniz & Suzette Barreto Mascarenhas, M.D. Services and viewing at Bennett Funeral Home, Scarsdale, 914-725-1137, Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9PM and Wednesday, 58PM. Funeral at Saint Pius X Church, Scarsdale, N.Y. 914725-2755, Thursday, 11AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Filomena B. Silva Memorial Fund, in care of her family, for charities of her choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CROWLEY, DR. ROBERT E.
description: CROWLEY-Dr. Robert E. Of Croton-on-Hudson, on October 20. Retired Chief of Dental Services for the V.A. Hospital in Montrose and Clinical Professor at Columbia University College of Dentistry and Oral Surgery. Beloved husband of the late Carolyn & loving father of Robert E. Wake Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM, Riverdale-onHudson Funeral Home, Bronx. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday 10 AM at St. Margaret of Cortona. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: A Defense To Avoid Execution
description: Aaron J. McKinney killed a gay student at the University of Wyoming last year in ''a five-minute emotional rage'' because the student, Matthew Shepard, had made sexual advances that reminded him of homosexual abuse he had suffered as a child, Mr. McKinney's lawyer told a jury today as his murder trial began here.

title: Argentina's Switch: Electing a Less Flamboyant Leader
description: As Argentines woke up today after a night of dancing in the streets and car-honking celebrations, they were greeted by triumphant posters that showed President-elect Fernando de la Rua beside an Argentine flag and the slogan, ''We all won.''

title: Prosecutors Say Scholar Misused Funds and Drugs
description: A professor of anthropology at John Jay College of Criminal Justice who has studied drugs and drug cultures for 25 years was accused in a Federal complaint yesterday of misusing funds from a $2.6 million Federal grant to buy drugs for addicts he interviewed and to pay for travel and other personal expenses.

title: Think Big on Health
description: To the Editor:

title: An Author's Space Odyssey and His Stay at the Chelsea
description: On a recent autumn morning in a suite at his beloved Chelsea Hotel, legendary New York City home of hipsters and artists, Sir Arthur C. Clarke, 81, the author of more than a hundred books of essays and science fiction, co-writer with Stanley Kubrick of the film, ''2001: A Space Odyssey,'' and the dreamer who in 1945 came up with the idea of the ''comsat,'' or communications satellite, held court in a wheelchair tended by his two Sri Lankan valets, Hector and Lenin.

title: Executive Shifts At Wieden & Kennedy
description: Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore., is shifting responsibilities among top creative executives.

title: Neighborhood Coalition Sues Over Trump Building Project
description: The battle over Donald J. Trump's effort to build the world's tallest residential building went to court yesterday, as a coalition of neighborhood and civic groups filed a lawsuit asserting that the building would violate city zoning regulations.

title: An Ancient Skull Challenges Long-Held Theories
description: A human skull that is prominently displayed at the National Museum here has been attracting crowds and controversy in equal measure since it was first unveiled early this month. After two decades in storage, the fossilized cranium has now been identified by Brazilian scientists as the oldest human remains ever recovered in the Western Hemisphere.

title: A Little-Known Killer of the Seemingly Healthy
description: An apparently healthy, athletic 7-year-old boy named Billy dies mysteriously in his sleep in his bedroom in Sarasota, Fla., while his father grinds coffee in the nearby kitchen. An apparently healthy 19-year-old woman from Minnesota, known to be a good swimmer, dies after a near-drowning while swimming laps in a pool 4 feet deep. An apparently healthy 30-year-old Florida mother walks to a fountain for a drink after playing soccer and drops dead.

title: No Republican, but Still a Thorn
description: At first glance, Patrick J. Buchanan appears sapped of the political potency that made him an important player in the 1996 Presidential campaign. His pitch then to the economically distressed now carries little appeal given the resurgence in New Hampshire. His comments about Hitler in his new book have drawn denunciations from all quarters.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Inside Art column of Weekend on Friday about auction Web sites misstated the planned policy of Sothebys.Amazon .com on who will be allowed to sell when the site goes on line. It will be open to anyone, not just dealers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURTON, VICTOR C.
description: BURTON-Victor C. 75. Of Palm Beach, FL. Formerly of Great Neck, N.Y. On October 9, 1999. You will always be alive in our hearts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LORREN, HARRIET
description: LORREN-Harriet. Beloved friend of Myrna Wapner. Former Principal of P.S. 279, Brooklyn. Cherished daughter of Richard. Loving sister of Suellen and Martin Wasserman. Dearly beloved niece, aunt and great-aunt. Services Wednesday, 10 AM, at Parkside Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBLATT, JACOB
description: GOLDBLATT-Jacob, 92, of Hollywood, FL passed away Monday, October 25, 1999. Formerly of Great Neck, NY and Passaic, NJ He was the beloved husband of Lillian Leibman Goldblatt, who passed away July 16, 1998. Mr. Goldblatt is survived by his devoted son, Mark and daughter-in-law, Ann & cherished grandson, Max, all of Los Angeles, CA. & brother, Herman Goldblatt of Clifton, NJ. Graveside services will be held Wednesday, Oct. 27, 1999 in New Mount Carmel Cemetery, Queens, NY at 11:30 AM. Information: Riverside Gordon Memorial Chapel, Hollywood, FL 954-921-1776.

title: U.N. Creates an Authority To Start Governing East Timor
description: The Security Council today created the authority for the United Nations to take over East Timor and administer the former Indonesian territory until it is strong and stable enough to become fully independent, a process that officials said could take years.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN GAINS. The dollar slipped against the Japanese yen as speculation that a United States interest rate increase is ahead hurt stocks and bonds. In New York, the dollar settled at 105.31 yen, down from 105.97 on Friday.

title: 'My Hometown,' the Sequel; Success Transforms Springsteen's Bleak Birthplace
description: The big factories are gone now, and the old-timers no longer shuffle off to the Court Jester after swing shifts at the textile mill. The local kids these days are more likely to be at home watching ''Seinfeld'' reruns than down by the railroad tracks drinking beer on the hoods of their hemi-powered Plymouths.

title: Be It Ever So Homely, the Yankees Call It Home
description: There is -- the absence of much in the way of fall foliage notwithstanding -- no place like Yankee Stadium in autumn, where men in pinstripes play for history, a giant bat stands guard like Mighty Casey at the main entrance and, lest one overlook the refined, smaller touches, plastic baseballs pose as beer-tap handles.

title: Political Peacekeeper Savors Senate Victory
description: ''CAN we brag?'' asks Senator Charles E. Schumer. And for a moment, just a moment, he is not talking about his prominent role on the team of Congressional arm twisters who helped force a late-night compromise last week on the most important financial legislation in 60 years.

title: Fearing Millennial Action, Israel Is Ready to Oust 20 Christians
description: Fearing a possible outburst of millennium-related violence, Israeli authorities rounded up members of two Christian groups living on the slopes of the Mount of Olives today and ordered 20 deported.

title: Man Is Charged in Slaying of Off-Duty Officer
description: A suspect was arrested today in the Sunday morning shooting death of an off-duty Irvington police officer outside an Elizabeth social club.

title: Visitors: Hoods Off, Hands Out
description: O.K., the boys in the hoods had their fun, and the republic emerged intact. Indeed, the Ku Klux Klan klatch in Foley Square on the weekend gave everyone involved a free shot at self-congratulation. Here in the capital of solipsism, it doesn't get better than that.

title: LIBERTY MEDIA TAKING STAKE IN EMMIS COMMUNICATIONS
description: The Emmis Communications Corporation, a television and radio station owner, agreed yesterday to sell 2.7 million class A common shares to the AT&T subsidiary Liberty Media Group for about $150 million. Liberty Media will become Emmis's second largest shareholder after its chairman and chief executive, Jeffrey Smulyan. The stake represents about 14 percent of Emmis, which is based in Indianapolis, before a pending public offering. Liberty Media, based in Englewood, Colo., is a separately traded subsidiary of the AT&T Corporation's Broadband & Internet Services unit.

title: 90 Groups Apply to Operate Charter Schools
description: Ninety groups have applied to open charter schools in New York State next year, including 35 whose schools would be run by profit-making companies, state officials announced yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRESSMAN, FAY E.
description: PRESSMAN-Fay E. Of Forest Hils, New York, died Oct. 24, 1999 of brain cancer. She was beloved wife of Lenny, dearest mother to Anita and Jay, devoted sister to Warren, special niece to Marilyn, wonderful aunt to Glen and Eric, cherished great aunt to Olivia. We will all miss you.

title: Barbara Wolff, 58, City Official Active in New York Development
description: Barbara Wolff, a veteran New York City official who was instrumental in setting up the city's business improvement districts program and in the commercial revitalization program that followed the blackout of 1977, died Oct. 15 at her home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. She was 58.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
description: AT&T, the nation's most widely held stock, posted quarterly results yesterday that exceeded analysts' expectations and underscored the increasing importance in the communications industry of new services at the expense of traditional products.

title: The Mets Will Address Card Playing Next Year
description: One week after their enchanting but troubled season ended, the Mets are still dealing with controversy. General Manager Steve Phillips said yesterday that he would wait until spring training to discuss with Rickey Henderson and Bobby Bonilla their apparent card playing in the clubhouse during the final innings of the Mets' Game 6 loss to the Atlanta Braves last Tuesday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Ford to Add Safety Bars To Its Big Pickup Trucks

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARTHUR, JOHN W. JR.
description: ARTHUR-John W. Jr. On October 23, 1999. Husband of the late Doris Sawyer Arthur. Father of Meredith Quarrier, Eleanor Raybold and David Arthur. Also survived by seven grandchildren and three great grandchildren. Mr. Arthur began his banking career in Manhattan rising through the management ranks. He was elected President of the American Institute of Banking in 1950. In 1965 he was appointed Vice President of the Trust Department of the Bank of New York where he remained until his retirement in 1968. Memorial service was at St. David's Episcopal Church, Southfield, Michigan.

title: Free Speech: Who's Accountable?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEPER, NIEL
description: PEPER-Niel. Beloved husband of Carol, father of Elliot and the late David. Graduate of Columbia University and New York University, noted artist, set designer with Juilliard Opera Company, retired Professor at Dowling College, Navy veteran. Died October 24, services private, memorial service to be held at a later date.

title: BANK MERGER VETOED
description: Norway rejected a $3.1 billion bid for Christiania Bank from a foreign rival, Meritanordbanken of Finland, to insure that the nation's second-largest bank remains under domestic control, the Finance Ministry said. In its veto of the Swedish-Finnish proposal, the State Bank Investment Fund, which manages the state's 34.7 percent Christiania stake, cited a parliamentary decision to hold at least one-third of Christiania and its larger rival, Den Norske Bank A.S.A.

title: Arming Unsung Heroes of Health Care
description: Hospitals may not be called pest houses anymore, but they are still terrible places to be sick. They are all crawling with bacteria, with strangers who are sometimes kindly but sometimes not, with the potential for bad accidents; hospitals assault the senses from every direction, and then they send a bill.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHMIDT, BENNO C.
description: SCHMIDT-Benno C. The Board of Trustees and staff at The Whitney Museum of American Art note with great sadness the passing of our dear friend & former Trustee, Benno C. Schmidt. We extend our most heartfelt condolences to his children, Benno Jr., Ralph, John, and William; his stepchildren, Ruth, Stephen and James; and to his entire family. Leonard A. Lauder, Chairman Joel S. Ehrenkranz, President Maxwell L. Anderson, Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFF, BARBARA
description: WOLFF-Barbara. On behalf of the people of Queens County, I extend sincere sympathy to the family, friends and colleageus of Barbara Wolff, Assistant Commissioner of the NYC Department of Business Services. Her dedication to many Queens' neighborhoods have made them better places to live, work and operate a business. All those involved in community development, neighborhood revitalization and government were privileged to have had the opportunity to know and work with her. Claire Shulman, President, Borough of Queens

title: Mr. Falwell's Progress
description: When warring communities get together for the purpose of increasing understanding and combating violence, it is a noteworthy event. The gathering of the Rev. Jerry Falwell and his supporters and 200 gay Christians in Mr. Falwell's Thomas Road Baptist Church in Lynchburg, Va., last weekend was such an occasion -- and a telling moment in Mr. Falwell's personal evolution and that of the gay rights movement.

title: World Briefing
description: MIDDLE EAST

title: 2 Young Girls Playing With Matches Die in Brooklyn Fire
description: Two young sisters who were playing with matches died yesterday after inadvertently setting fire to a mattress in their apartment in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, fire officials said.

title: Aaron Gladly Takes All-Century Honor
description: One day after he was named to baseball's all-century team, Hank Aaron compared the honor to his induction into the Hall of Fame.

title: Banks and Privacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Ezra Pound and Anti-Semitism
description: To the Editor:

title: INCO EARNINGS STRENGTHEN
description: Lower production costs and higher prices for nickel contributed to better-than-expected quarterly earnings at Inco Ltd., one of the world's leading metals businesses. The Toronto-based company earned $12 million (United States), or 4 cents a share, in contrast to a loss of $24 million a year earlier. A 41 percent rise in the average selling price of nickel, to $3.06 a pound, helped offset a slight decrease in the price of copper.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THORNTON, BEATRICE
description: THORNTON-Beatrice. Beloved wife of the late William. Devoted mother of Linda Paper and Robert. Loving grandmother of Scott, Darin, Chris, Nichole and Tyler. Cherished great grandmother of Mara and Brandon. Services Wednesday, 10AM at ''BoulevardRiverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island.

title: Mole Rats Lack Rivalry
description: To the Editor:

title: Ezra Pound and Anti-Semitism
description: To the Editor:

title: $50 Million Voted to Rebuild in Flood Area
description: Reacting to weeks of complaints that state officials were slow to help victims of last month's flood, New Jersey legislators passed a bill today that dedicates $50 million to repair homes damaged by Tropical Storm Floyd.

title: Mayor Says Charter Changes Will Protect the City's Gains
description: Embarking on a last-minute campaign for changes in the City Charter, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday strongly urged New Yorkers to approve the revisions by telling them that the city could easily revert to a place of rampant crime and poverty after he leaves office.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAGHINIA, MILANI, PARVIZ
description: TAGHINIA-MILANI-Parviz. On October 24, 1999 in New York City. Beloved husband of Nahid Taghinia-Milani, loving father of Leila Taghinia-Milani Heller, dear father-in-law of Henry Heller, adored grandfather of Alexander and Philip Heller. Interment will be private. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, October 28, at 2 PM at the Church of All Souls, 1157 Lexington Avenue at 80 St. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to: Lenox Hill Hospital/Cardiac Care Unit, c/o Development Department, 100 East 77th St., New York, New York 10021. He devoted his life to numerous enterprises & charities that benefitted the well-being of many, and his immeasurable kindness and generosity to his family and friends will be dearly missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GABLEMAN, ARTHUR
description: GABLEMAN-Arthur. Age 87, of Sunrise, Fla. formerly of Flushing, NY on October 23, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Sylvia. Devoted father of David, Paul and Bruce. Loving father-in-law of Marge, Joan & Grace. Cherished grandfather of Glenn, Gregg, Amy and Keith. His kindness and sense of humor will remain everlasting memories with all who knew and loved him.

title: Deceptive Attacks on a Drug Benefit
description: The pharmaceutical industry is staging a misleading advertising campaign against President Clinton's new Medicare drug benefit proposal. Its new ads are trying to raise groundless fears that government is going to take over everyone's medicine cabinet, which is far from what the Clinton proposal would actually do.

title: In His Own Words; PATRICK J. BUCHANAN
description: At his home yesterday in Falls Church, Va., he explained why he was leaving the Republican Party to seek the Reform Party's Presidential nomination:

title: Bothered by Interview
description: Several Yankees remained angered yesterday by an interview between Jim Gray of NBC and Pete Rose.

title: Doubles Qualifiers
description: The Serena Williams-Venus Williams and Martina Hingis-Anna Kournikova doubles teams are among the first to qualify for the eight-team doubles draw at the Chase Championships at Madison Square Garden beginning the week of Nov. 15. Also qualifying for the WTA Tour finale is the team of Lisa Raymond and Rennae Stubbs.

title: Lifting a Musty Curtain For a Peek Inside the Crypt; The Creepy Chaos Behind 'Shockheaded Peter'
description: In the gravy-dark recesses of the mind (and backstage at the New Victory Theater on 42d Street) strange phantasms scuttle beneath the floorboards and rattle locked doors, demanding to be let out.

title: Treasuries Recover a Bit After Big Fall Early in Day
description: Treasury bonds recouped early losses yesterday after yields at one point during the day climbed to a two-year high of 6.40 percent, luring buyers to the market.

title: Pakistan Military Says 7 Civilians Will Join New Government
description: The military announced tonight the names of seven civilians who will join the Government of Gen. Pervez Musharraf, the army chief who seized power on Oct. 12 and ousted Pakistan's elected Government.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ACHSTATTER, ANTHONY
description: ACHSTATTER-Anthony. Of Tamarac, Fla. on October 24, 1999. Beloved husband of JoANN (nee Monderine). Devoted father of Gerard and James Achstatter. Loving father-in-law of Nancy and Thea. Loving stepfather of Ernest and Richard Naspretto. Cherished grandfather of Matthew, Lauren, Daniel, Elizabeth, Angelina and Alicia. Visiting at the Leo F. Kearns Funeral Home, 61-40 Woodhaven Boulevard, Rego Park, NY 2-4 and 7-9PM Tuesday. Funeral Wednesday 8:45AM. Mass at Our Lady of Hope Church 9:30AM. Interment is at All Faith/ Lutheran cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKS, LOUIS
description: MARKS-Louis. Beloved husband of Nettie. Devoted father of Gerald, Charles and Darryl. Adored grandfather and great-grandfather. Graveside services Tuesday, 11 AM, at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: For the Bald Truth, Pick the Braves

title: BRITISH BREWERY DEAL
description: The Britain brewer and pub operator Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries P.L.C. agreed to acquire a rival, Mansfield Brewery P.L.C., for $419 million in cash and stock. Mansfield had been for sale since July, when founding family trusts announced their intention to sell their combined 48 percent ownership. After the purchase, Wolverhampton & Dudley will own four breweries and operate nearly 2,000 pubs, mainly in England's Midlands region.

title: The Church and Astronomy
description: To the Editor:

title: Excite@Home To Acquire Bluemountain
description: Excite@Home will pay up to $1 billion to acquire Bluemountain.com, a privately held electronic greeting card company with little revenue but millions of loyal users.

title: Yanks' Starters Are Murderers' Row of the 90's
description: Andy Pettitte was at his locker at Yankee Stadium yesterday when David Cone walked by. ''Awesome, man, awesome,'' Pettitte gushed to his fellow pitcher.

title: Animal Allergies
description: Q. You hear all the time about people who are allergic to cats and dogs. Do cats and dogs ever develop allergies?

title: Sports of The Times; Yankee Fans Must Guard Their Guests at the Park
description: SOMETHING happened in Atlanta in recent days that was bizarre by New York standards. Yankee fans bearing the ''NYY'' emblem on their caps, jackets and shirts were allowed to attend the World Series games unmolested.

title: Amid Cordial Setting, Sprewell Mulls Contracts
description: Latrell Sprewell was still weighing his options today, deciding how many seasons he would commit to the Knicks. That Sprewell and the Knicks had overcome the latest obstacle in his career and pledged their allegiance to each other was indisputable.

title: People
description: * Sinead Clancy was named to the new position of president at Jumpstart Media, New York. She had been a sales representative at 24/7 Media, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUHN, JACK W. JR.
description: KUHN-Jack W. Jr. The Officers and Board of Trustees of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations profoundly mourn the death of a cherished friend and colleague. A long time Trustee, Jack served our sacred cause with caring concern and dedication to the great ideals of our faith. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his loving wife, Heloise, his children and all his loved ones. Jerome H. Somers, Chrmn Rabbi Eric H. Yoffie, Pres Rabbi Alexander M. Schindler President Emeritus

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about a tax court decision denying deductions to Winn-Dixie Stores for loans against corporate-owned life insurance misidentified the carrier of the policies. It was the American International Group, not the American Heritage Life Insurance Company.

title: A Gene, a Threat and a Buildup of Iron
description: As many as 1 in 10 people may be at increased risk of heart attack or stroke simply because they carry a gene that can lead to a serious metabolic disorder, even if they are in good health, recent studies suggest.

title: The Giants Win Again But Keep Losing Players
description: The Giants won the game Sunday but lost a running back, two safeties and a defensive tackle, a situation that had Giants Coach Jim Fassel scrambling to find stand-ins -- however unpolished -- for the next game in Philadelphia.

title: Earnings Are Up 13% at American Express
description: The American Express Company said yesterday that its third-quarter profit had risen 13 percent, meeting expectations, as customers spent more with its credit cards and increased investments with its financial planners.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOREN, SYDELLE (ROSENBERG)
description: SOREN-Sydelle (Rosenberg). The Mesivta of Long Beach marks with profound sorrow the loss of Mrs. Sydelle Rosenberg Soren (Sora Rasha bas Nachman) of blessed memory. Mother of our dear friends, Mr. Stephen Rosenberg, Mrs. Lisa Lifshitz and Mrs. Eileen Plotkin. Her strength of character and her extraordinary selflessness will long be remembered and will remain the source of her family's dedication to Torah and philanthropy. Our heartfelt condolences to her devoted children, Mr. Stephen Rosenberg, Mr. and Mrs. Howard Lifshitz and Mr. and Mrs. Michael Plotkin, her sister, Mrs. Florence Spiro, to all her cherished grandchildren, Mordechai, Yitzchok, Doni, Yehuda, Zecharia, Arik, Shaul, Dana, Ali, Avrohom Yaakov, Zev Nachman, Stella, Jake, and Ben, and the entire family. May the benevolence of the Murray Rosenberg Foundation, in memory of her husband bring her eternal merit. May the family be comforted and spared some further sorrow. HaRav Yitzchok Feigelstock Rosh HaYeshiva Rabbi Shlomo Lesin, Executive Vice President

title: Y.& R. Executive To Bradley Campaign
description: Marvin Waldman, a top creative executive at the New York office of Young & Rubicam Advertising, said yesterday that he would leave at the end of the year to join the Presidential campaign of Bill Bradley, working on ''all aspects'' including ads.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about Paramount Pictures' arrangement with the author Michael Crichton for rights to his new book cited the terms imprecisely. Mr. Crichton will earn a portion of the studio's receipts from a movie, not of the film's overall box-office receipts.

title: To the Rear, March!
description: Early on, George W. Bush and some other prominent Republicans went through the motions of trying to prevent Patrick Buchanan's announcement that he was ''ending my lifelong membership in the Republican Party.'' But in the end, no one seemed very upset by Mr. Buchanan's exit or by Donald Trump's simultaneous defection to the Reform Party. But while Mr. Trump's presidential dreaming had the feel of a self-indulgent lark, Mr. Buchanan's seems a blend of financial scheming, retro rage and perhaps a bit of self-delusion. Does anyone believe that Mr. Buchanan's ''peasant army'' really exists? It may be ready to storm the castle, but it certainly did not help its man in the G.O.P. polls.

title: Rangers Catch a Break to Remember Goals
description: The Rangers have not scored a goal in 234 minutes 31 seconds, nearly 12 periods of play. They do not play again until Saturday in Montreal. What essentially amounts to a week off could not have come at a better time for a team that has fallen apart in one week.

title: Ezra Pound and Anti-Semitism
description: To the Editor:

title: Encounters With an Eerie Iceberg and a Riot of Calculated Confusion
description: Music can speak to us by adding on or by taking away, and the Berlin Philharmonic's evening at Carnegie Hall on Sunday, the first of three, gave us a little bit of both. At the beginning, a suite from Luigi Nono's ''Prometeo,'' a self-described ''opera for listening''; then the Mahler Ninth Symphony. The first is an exercise in sublime reticence, the second in sublime garrulity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCORMACK, GLADYS
description: McCORMACK-Gladys. October 24, 1999. Beloved wife of the late James. Gladys was born in Belfast, Northern Ireland, in 1907 and immigrated to the U.S. at the age of 22 and settled in NYC. She is survived by a sister, Margaret Todd, in County Antrim, Northern Ireland, and one niece and two nephews. Reposing at the John J. Barrett & Son Funeral Home, 424 West 51 St., NYC, Wednesday, 58:00 PM with services at 7:00 PM. Interment Thursday, Calverton National Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLINCH, JAMES J.
description: CLINCH-James J. On October 24, 1999 of Westbury, LI. Retired VicePresident of the Bank of New York. Retired Professor of Nassau Community College. Retired Judge for the American Board of Arbitration and Retired Chairman of the Real Estate Advisory Committee for the N.Y.S. Teachers Retirement System. Devoted husband of Muriel. Beloved father of Wayne M., Elizabeth Agnes DeRose and the late Kevin J. Loving grandfather of Anthony, Andrew and Alexander DeRose. Reposing Donohue Funeral Home, 293 Castle Avenue, Westbury on Tuesday between the hours of 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday 10 AM Our Lady of Hope R.C. Church, Carle Place, LI. Interment St. John's Cemetery, Middle Village, Long Island.

title: Payne Stewart, Winner Of 3 Majors, Dies at 42
description: Even casual fans could recognize Payne Stewart on the golf course, with the trademark knickers, or plus fours, that he wore during competition. But beyond his colorful apparel, Stewart was recognized and appreciated for his talent and his competitive spirit.

title: Rivals Reach Milestones in Genome Race
description: Two rival teams racing to decode the human genome have each neared or passed significant milestones.

title: U.S. Official Finishes Talks In Beijing
description: The United States Treasury Secretary, Lawrence H. Summers, finished two days of meetings in China today with both sides extolling financial cooperation and exuding friendship. But there was no sign of progress on the overarching issue, China's entry into the World Trade Organization.

title: Making Real Profits From a Vision of a Product
description: THE NEW NEW THING

title: South African Writer Wins Top British Prize for Second Time
description: ''Disgrace,'' J. M. Coetzee's powerful novel about life in post-apartheid South Africa, won the Booker Prize, Britain's most important literary award, tonight.

title: Shift to the Right Undermines Swiss 'Magic' Formula
description: GENEVA  Outwardly, Switzerland's embrace of fervent nationalism in last weekend's elections was about refugees and the country's place in Europe, but it was also very much about Swiss identity shaped by the recent furor over its less-than-glorious role in World War II and its uncertainty over what path to take in the future.

title: Cage and Douglas Rejoin Nets
description: Michael Cage will practice with the Nets today for the first time since leaving just before the opening of training camp on Oct. 5. The 37-year-old veteran returned to his wife and three children in Phoenix and contemplated retirement before deciding to play another season. Though he is not expected to contribute much on the floor, his presence in the locker room will be invaluable to a team whose star players, Stephon Marbury and Keith Van Horn, are 22 and 24, respectively.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUBIN, THELMA
description: LUBIN-Thelma. October 25, 1999. Of Fort Lee, N.J. After an extended illness. Beloved wife of Jules. Devoted mother of Barbara Davidson and Laurie Siegel. Adored ''Nanny'' of Stacy, Adam & Jason. Services will be held at 12 Noon Wednesday, October 27, Gutterman-Musicant, 401 Park Street, Hackensack, New Jersey. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Hackensack Hospice, C/O Hackensack Medical Center.

title: Victim's Sister In Sharp Clash With Lawyers Of Defendant
description: A month after Gladys Ricart was shot to death on her wedding day, her sister and lawyers for the businessman accused of killing her clashed over the nature of the couple's relationship before the shooting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASIEL, BETTY L.
description: ASIEL-Betty L. The Board of Directors, Administration and staff of The Burke Rehabilitation Hospital note with deep sorrow the death of Betty L. Asiel, wife of Board Member, E. Nelson Asiel. Longtime friend and member of the Burke Auxiliary, Mrs. Asiel was an active volunteer at Burke since 1975. We extend our sincere condolences and join the Asiel family in mourning. Peter J. De Luca President, Board of Directors Mary Beth Walsh, M.D. Executive Medical Director/CEO John J. Ryan Executive Director/Administration

title: A Woman Can Lead
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Our two parties have become nothing but two wings on the same bird of prey.''

title: Elias and Morrison Finally Agree to Terms
description: The verdict was predictable. Every time there has been a conflict between management and players on the Devils, the winner is Lou Lamoriello, the president and general manager. And Lamoriello was the winner again today when he announced that Patrik Elias and Brendan Morrison had agreed to terms after they had been locked out from the beginning of training camp as unsigned restricted free agents.

title: Mega-Mergers, Mega-Influence
description: Congress is about to eliminate the legal walls that separate commercial banks, brokerage firms and insurance companies -- opening the doors to a new wave of mega-mergers. Critics worry that huge banks will dampen competition and pay less attention to the average customer.

title: How Baseball Grew a Gambler
