description: The fans have forgiven Pete Rose his sins, voting him onto Major League Baseball's all-century team and giving him a standing ovation before Game 2 of the World Series on Sunday. But major league officials clearly aren't satisfied -- they apparently want an admission that he gambled on baseball and a show of contrition before they will even consider him eligible for the Hall of Fame.

title: Corrections
description: A report in Sunday Styles this week about the wedding of Katharine Day Bacon misstated the bridegroom's surname in one reference. He is Mark Lane Pener, not Bacon.

title: Immigrant Freed After Being Held For 19 Months In Terrorism Case
description: A Palestinian immigrant who had been held for 19 months on secret evidence accusing him of terrorism was freed last night from a New Jersey jail after the Justice Department decided not to appeal a court order to release him.

title: Latin Rhythms, From the 30's to Now
description: Six decades of Latin American music danced across New York stages over the weekend. The singer Ibrahim Ferrer and the pianist Ruben Gonzalez, who gained international recognition with the ''Buena Vista Social Club'' album, harked back to Cuban music from the 1930's into the 1960's at the Beacon Theater on Friday night. Then the Fania All-Stars performed on Saturday night at Madison Square Garden, carrying the music from Cuba to Puerto Rico, New York City and beyond.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSMAN, SYLVIA
description: GROSSMAN-Sylvia. Temple BethEl of Great Neck records with profound sorrow the passing of its member. We extend heartfelt sympathy to her bereaved family. Shelley M. Limmer, President Jerome K. Davidson, Rabbi

title: Pakistan Ruler Seen as 'Secular-Minded' Muslim
description: The Chicago anesthesiologist picked up his morning newspaper and read a headline that roiled him. ''Pakistan Wakes Up to a Dictator,'' it said.

title: At 52, First Lady Feels Like Raising a Million, and Does
description: With skits, songs and a fair amount of bashing of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, a lineup of Broadway stars celebrated Hillary Rodham Clinton's 52d birthday last night with a mix of politics and entertainment that helped her raise close to $1 million for her expected campaign for the United States Senate.

title: TV Ratings Rises
description: Game 2 of the World Series generated a 15.7 Nielsen rating, a 9.7 percent increase over last year's 14.3, when the Yankees played San Diego.

title: Youth Violence
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FLUHR, RHODA
description: FLUHR-Rhoda. My Beautiful Mother-gone 25 years today. Always my role model. Love, Ellen

title: Quick Spread Of Truck Strike By Teamsters
description: The teamsters' union strike against the nation's largest nonunion trucking firm, the Overnite Transportation Company, spread across the nation yesterday, but company officials insisted that the strike was having only a negligible effect on its operations.

title: SWEETENED OFFERS FROM PLANE MAKERS
description: The two biggest airplane manufacturers -- the Boeing Company and Airbus Industrie -- both sent new offers for the sale of three or four midsize jets to El Al, Israel's national airline, an El Al spokesman said. The offers were received as the airline's board convened in Tel Aviv to decide between previous Boeing and Airbus bids. The new proposals will be evaluated tonight at another meeting of the board.

title: Untapped Potential for a Common Herb
description: Anesthesiologists, like many doctors, tend to be wary of herbal medicines. Just this year, several anesthesiology associations began a campaign to warn people facing surgery that their doctors needed to know if they were taking herbal remedies, since some could have dangerous interactions with anesthesia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEFFELL, RABBI A. BERNARD
description: LEFFELL-Rabbi A. Bernard. We record with sorrow the passing of our beloved colleague who was founding rabbi of Congregation Shaare Zedek in Montreal from his ordination in 1954 until his retirement four years ago. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Freda, sons Jonathan, Daniel, David and Michael, mother, Marion and to all who were touched through his rabbinate. Rabbi Seymour L. Essrog, Pres. Rabbi Joel H. Meyers, Exec. VP The Rabbinical Assembly

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEORGITSIS, NICOLAS M.
description: GEORGITSIS - Nicolas M. Of Greenwich, CT., and Palm Beach, FL, on October 23, at his home. Husband of Iro Georgitsis of Greenwich and Palm Beach. Father of Melina Georgitsis of Paris, France and Michael and Ares P. Georgitsis of Greenwich, CT. Brother of Stamatis Georgitsis of Athens, Greece. Funeral service will be held on Wednesday at 2 PM at the Greek Orthodox Church of Our Saviour, 2195 Westchester Avenue East, Rye, New York. Interment Nenita, Chios, Greece. There will be no calling hours. Memorial contributions may be made to the St. Jude Children's Research Hospital, 501 St. Jude Place, Memphis, TN. 38105.

title: STAMPS.COM AGREES TO ACQUIRE ISHIP.COM
description: Stamps.com Inc., an Internet postage company, agreed to buy the closely held Iship.com for about $305 million in stock to create a one-stop Internet mailing and shipping source. Stamps.com will exchange eight million of its shares for the shares, warrants and options outstanding of Iship.com, which is based in Bellevue, Wash. Stamps.com's shares rose $1.375 yesterday, to $39.50. After the merger, customers will be able to buy and print stamps, compare rates among shippers and arrange for package pickup and tracking from one Web site. Stamps.com, based in Santa Monica, Calif., is one of two companies licensed by the Postal Service to allow customers to buy and print stamps on the Internet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUZZELL, CLAIRE
description: BUZZELL-Claire. 92. Of Fort Lauderdale, Florida, passed away on October 23rd, 1999. She is predeceased by her loving husband, Al, and devoted son, Robert. Riverside-Gordon Memorial Chapel, Tamarac, FL, 954-523-5801.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Trying to Get a Grip on Equity Options
description: BRINGING increased competition and fairer trading to the world of equity options is, it seems, easier said than done.

title: Argentina After Mr. Menem
description: Argentine voters have clearly wearied of the flamboyant style of President Carlos Saul Menem, who rode the old populist party of Juan Domingo Peron to power in 1989 and has held office ever since. On Sunday they resoundingly elected Fernando de la Rua, the decidedly uncharismatic, non-Peronist Mayor of Buenos Aires, to succeed Mr. Menem after his second term ends in December.

title: Hong Kong Begins Selling Its Stock Portfolio
description: When Hong Kong's government plunged into the stock market in August 1998, buying $15 billion worth of shares, it drew ridicule from some rather lofty sources. Milton Friedman, the Nobel Prize-winning economist, called the intervention a ''crazy idea.''

title: GIULIANI TO ORDER HOMELESS TO WORK FOR THEIR SHELTER
description: For the first time since the turn of the century, homeless people in New York City will be required to work as a condition of shelter, under a Giuliani administration policy to be put into effect before the end of the year, an administration official said yesterday.

title: A 'Firebird' With Respect for the Past
description: Christopher Wheeldon has been much celebrated in recent years as the rare choreographer with an affinity for the classical ballet canon. Nobody appears to have told Mr. Wheeldon, a 26-year-old soloist with the New York City Ballet and the recently appointed principal guest choreographer with the Boston Ballet, that fairy tales, romanticism and charm are out of fashion. Mr. Wheeldon continues to follow his own lights. His new ''Firebird,'' performed by the Boston company on Saturday afternoon at the Wang Theater here, is a miracle of audacious imagination, skill and reverence for tradition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMOWITZ, PENNY BARD
description: ABRAMOWITZ-Penny Bard. Age 46. Beloved wife of Jed. Adoring mother of Jacob, Alex, and Peter. Loving sister of Amy and Michael. Adored by mother and father Norman and Shirley; loved by many friends and relatives. Died on Sunday, October 24, long before her time. She will live on in the hearts of the many who loved her.

title: John Chafee, Republican Senator and a Leading Voice of Bipartisanship, Dies at 77
description: Senator John H. Chafee of Rhode Island, the last of the Rockefeller Republicans and an increasingly isolated voice of internationalism and bipartisanship in his party, died on Sunday.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Seeking Land for Tribe of Girl Who Helped Lewis and Clark
description: Here in the valley where the Shoshone Sacagawea led Lewis and Clark to one of the most serendipitous encounters in the annals of discovery, the stores are full of Indian art, the pastures are grazed by Indian-bred horses, and the land itself is imprinted with Indian names. But there are no American Indians here.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SAMUELS, HOWARD J.M 10
description: SAMUELS-Howard J.m 106/84. After 15 years, love and memory remain as intense. See you, Pal. BB

title: Warning a Rookie
description: After the Yankees left Atlanta, Derek Jeter and Tino Martinez advised the 30-year-old rookie Clay Bellinger on what to expect for Game 3 of the World Series at Yankee Stadium.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: A Martian Theory Dries Up

title: 17 Ellington Bands From Just One
description: There's a ton of talent in the Lincoln Center Jazz Orchestra, and it doesn't take much of a pretext to dislodge it. Many orchestra members lead their own bands out in the world of nightclubs, and some day it would be rewarding to see a program that contrasts what they all hear in their heads -- how, say, the saxophonist Ted Nash composes, chooses musicians and arranges for them as opposed to what the trombonist Wycliffe Gordon does.

title: Campaign Corruption
description: To the Editor:

title: DIEBOLD TO BUY BRAZILIAN A.T.M. MAKER
description: The automated teller machine manufacturer Diebold Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired Procomp Amazonia Industria Electronica S.A., a Brazilian maker of A.T.M.'s, for $225 million in cash and stock. Procomp, based in Sao Paulo, is the world's sixth-largest A.T.M. manufacturer, Diebold said. Diebold, of Canton, Ohio, is the second-largest maker of A.T.M.'s in the United States, overshadowed only by the world leader, the NCR Corporation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDA, HENRY C.
description: RUDA-Henry C. On October 24, 1999 at age 80. Beloved husband of Caroline (nee Small). Loving brother of Eleanor Caflisch. Dear uncle to many nieces & nephews. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Tuesday 2-5 and 79PM with service Wednesday 11:30AM. Interment in Woodlawn Cemetery.

title: Beijing Quickly Detains Sect's Protesters
description: Defiant followers of the outlawed Falun Gong spiritual movement tried to mount a protest in Tiananmen Square today but were quickly detained by the police, according to witnesses.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE RISES. Coffee prices jumped on signs that recent rainfall in Brazil, the world's top producer, came too late to spare its crop from damage. In New York, coffee for December delivery rose 6.85 cents, to 99.75 cents a pound.

title: Foreign Policy Choices
description: To the Editor:

title: Newspaper Magazine Shares Profits With a Subject
description: Except for its girth -- 164 pages -- the Oct. 10 issue of The Los Angeles Times Magazine did not appear to be unusual. Its sole theme was the new Staples Center sports arena, but newspaper magazines often devote entire issues to one topic, like fashion or philanthropy.

title: Finding Promise in Compromise
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Sports of The Times; For Yanks, a Closer Who Is Taken for Granted
description: BEFORE he warms up in the Yankee bullpen, Mariano Rivera picks up a lead ball that weighs between two and three pounds. Holding it in his right hand, he swings it around and around, across his body, up and down for a few minutes. It makes a real baseball seem lighter and smaller. And to the hitters he faces after arriving at the mound, it's as if he were throwing that lead ball.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KAPLAN, ELLIOTT
description: KAPLAN-Elliott. Loving you, missing you. Only 1 year. Mom

title: Reading Harry Potter
description: To the Editor:

title: HIGH COSTS HURT DEUTSCHE BANK
description: Germany's biggest bank, Deutsche Bank A.G., posted disappointing results for the third quarter, which included costs from its takeover of the Bankers Trust Corporation. Deutsche said net income in the quarter rose 1.3 percent from the year before, to 77 million euros, or about $81.6 million. The biggest drag on earnings was in administrative costs, which rose from 2.3 billion euros to 4.1 billion euros; much of that expense came from bonuses paid to retain investment bankers at Bankers Trust. Edmund L. Andrews

title: Metro Business; LIPA Wins a Legal Round
description: The Long Island Power Authority won another round yesterday in its legal battle to recover more than $1.3 billion in property taxes that it overpaid Suffolk County for the decommissioned Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRANDIN, SUSANNE P. (WILSON)
description: GRANDIN-Susanne P. (Wilson) of Chestnut Hill, October 24, 1999 at home, age 81 years. Wife of 59 years of John L. Grandin, Jr. Mother of John L. Grandin III, Edward W. Grandin and Preston B. Grandin all of Chestnut Hill. Also survived by 5 grandchildren, Jay, Louisa, Andrew, Will & Mercedes. A Memorial Service will be held at Trinity Church, Copley Square, Boston on Saturday, October 30 at 11AM. Private interment. Longtime trustee of Boston Symphony Orchestra. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be sent to the Boston Symphony Orchestra, 301 Massachusetts Avenue, Boston, MA. 02115.

title: ASSURANCE ON DAEWOO RESCUE
description: In a bid to quell jitters in South Korea's financial market, Lee Hun Jai, chairman of the Financial Supervisory Commission, said that domestic banks with the highest exposure to the debts of Daewoo Group should be able to weather losses if they reserve cash amounting to 50 percent of their loans this year and the remaining half in 2000. If necessary, he said, the Government would inject public funds into Seoulbank, Korea First Bank, Daehan Investment Trust, Korea Investment Trust and Seoul Guaranty Insurance to help them survive cash shortages. Samuel Len

title: Holbrooke Accuses House of Hurting U.S. Role in the World
description: Richard C. Holbrooke, the United States representative at the United Nations, went on the offensive against the Republican-led House of Representatives today, charging that persistent Congressional tampering with budget bills covering foreign operations and payments to the United Nations was damaging American national security interests.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLY, MARY LOU
description: KELLY-Mary Lou. On October 26, 1999. In deep faith and enduring hope, cherished wife of James R., loving mother of James F., solicitous sister of Reverend James N. Loughran, S.J. and the late John F. Jr., precious daughter of the late John F. and Ethel Loughran. Typically, rather than the flowers that gave her such delight, Mary Lou requested that donations be sent to St. Peter's (Jersey City) or Mount St. Vincent's Colleges (Riverdale), where the spirits of Sts. Ignatius and Elizabeth Seton, which first formed and then sustained her, permeate the pursuit of truth. With the insight that loyal friendship brings, her colleagues at P.S. 105, where Mary taught for over thirty years, on the occasion of her necessary but too-early retirment wrote, Blessed they with peaceful spirits. Blessed they with gentle hearts. Visitation is on Wednesday and Thursday 2-5 PM and 7-9PM at McLaughlin & Son's Funeral Home Inc., 9620 3rd Ave., Brooklyn. Mass of Christian burial is Friday 9:30 A.M., Our Lady of Angel's Church, Bklyn. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery, Brooklyn.

title: Freedom in Chechnya
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article by The Associated Press in Science Times on Oct. 12 about colon cancer screenings for the elderly misstated a guideline from the American College of Physicians on follow-up tests. A patient who gets a positive reading on the initial screening, the fecal occult blood test, should have one of two follow-ups, according to the guidelines: a complete colonoscopy, or a flexible sigmoidoscopy plus barium enema X-ray. The barium X-ray is not needed with the colonoscopy.

title: Cold War Secrecy, Reheated by Terror
description: The Government's use of secret evidence to detain immigrants is a cold war-era practice that re-emerged amid the terrorism jitters of the 1990's.

title: Op-Art
Luciano Soprani, 53, Designer Who Won Fashion Fame in 80's
description: Luciano Soprani, a proponent of the slouchy, tailored look that dominated Italian fashion in the early 1980's, died on Saturday at a hospital in Milan. He was 53.

title: CISCO SYSTEMS TO BUY TASMANIA NETWORK FOR $25 MILLION
description: Cisco Systems Inc., the biggest Internet-equipment maker, agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Tasmania Network Systems Inc. for $25 million in stock, adding to its software that speeds computer networks. Cisco said it would take a charge of as much as 1 cent a share in its second quarter to cover the purchase. The transaction has been approved by both companies' boards, though shareholders of Tasmania, based in San Jose, Calif., still must approve it. The purchase will expand Cisco's line of so-called network caching software products, which increase the speed of content delivery on networks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASIEL, BETTY L.
description: ASIEL-Betty L. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Betty L. Asiel, a cherished friend who was deeply devoted to the Jewish community. We extend our sincerest condolences to her beloved husband, E. Nelson Asiel, who shared her commitment to Jewish causes; her three children, Harold, Terri, and John; her two grandchildren; and her great-granddaughter. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair James S. Tisch, President John S. Ruskay, Executive VP

title: 'One Love' May Vanquish Kingston Gang Violence
description: Bullet holes and boarded-up windows remain in this poverty-stricken area of west Kingston as a testament to the days of the 1970's and 1980's when gunmen from rival political parties exchanged wild bursts of gunfire on the streets.

title: Why Some Surfaces Need Not Shimmer
description: The Berlin Philharmonic is no longer Herbert von Karajan's orchestra. No real surprise, perhaps; Karajan died 10 years ago, and the term of his successor as music director, Claudio Abbado, is already winding down. But the change has never been so apparent as in the orchestra's visit to Carnegie Hall this week.

title: A New Index Tracks Bribe-Paying Countries
description: Transparency International, an independent organization that tracks corruption among government officials around the world, announced yesterday that it had added a new index to rank nations that appear to condone bribe paying by their companies doing business abroad.

title: Making Fabulous Sense In That Divine Madness
description: Maturity. Is it something to be dreaded? Bette Midler, who is in her early 50's, sardonically used the M-word several times to describe herself at Monday's opening-night show of her two-evening engagement at Madison Square Garden. And her largely middle-class, middle-aged audience loved her for it.

title: Ringing Up the Hits
description: The Yankees' approach during their at-bats is drawing much attention in this post-season, some saying the Yankees are an American League team playing like a National League team. Joe Torre drew on a boxing analogy in describing the patient, measured way his hitters go through each at-bat.

title: The Co-Founder of Netscape Is an Entrepreneur Once Again
description: For some people in Silicon Valley the garage still holds more allure than the board room.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Ex-Treasury Chief Rubin Accepts a Top Citigroup Job

title: Corrections
description: A caption on Oct. 18 with an article about Montenegro's desire for greater independence from Serbia misstated the location of Montenegro's President, Milo Djukanovic, in the picture. He was at the right, not the left. The caption also misstated the names of the man who was actually at the left, and of his employer. He was Gerard Stoudmann, not Steudler; he works for the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (not ''Organization of'').

title: Sports of The Times; Where Have You Gone, Melvin Mora?
description: WATCHING the 1999 Atlanta Braves morph into the 1998 San Diego Padres, I cannot help thinking about Melvin Mora, the overnight sensation, after nine years in the bushes, who became the Mets' surprise weapon in the last weeks of their season.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Weekend on Friday about visits to women's history landmarks in western New York misidentified the suffragist who wrote an 1861 diary passage saying she had ''fitted out a fugitive slave for Canada with the help of Harriet Tubman.'' The author was Susan B. Anthony, not Elizabeth Cady Stanton.

title: Interviewer Of Rose Is Snubbed By Curtis
description: Pete Rose's appearance Sunday at Game 2 continued to reverberate through the World Series last night when the Yankees' Chad Curtis refused to be interviewed by NBC's Jim Gray after winning Game 3 with a home run, citing the reporter's contentious interview with Rose.

title: BANK REJECTS TAKEOVER BID
description: One of South Africa's biggest banks, Standard Bank, has rejected a $4.4 billion takeover bid by a smaller rival, Nedcor, saying the proposed stock merger undervalued Standard. Nedcor made its bid public late last month. A merger has been the subject of speculation in recent months as the industry looks to consolidate in the face of competition from smaller financial services firms and foreign banks. Henri E. Cauvin

title: Sanity on Trial
description: To the Editor:

title: Remembering Dad's Pride
description: Luis Sojo will remember his father, Ambrosio, as a happy man who was proud that his youngest son was on the Yankees and playing in the World Series.

title: Triumphs and Failings Of a Wandering Woman
description: PASSIONATE NOMAD

title: G.O.P. Spending Plan Under Attack by Its Own Members
description: Republican leaders of Congress today scaled back their plan to cut spending across the board to balance the Federal budget, but the plan still drew opposition from within their own ranks as well as from the nation's top military officer.

title: NO TRADE AGENDA YET
description: With a month to go before new global trade talks are to begin in Seattle, ministers from 24 countries met for two days in Lausanne, Switzerland, to try to draw up the agenda. But so little progress was made, diplomats said privately, that Mike Moore, the director general of the World Trade Organization, told participants he feared the Seattle meeting could fail. Publicly, the United States representative, Charlene Barshefsky, and others said they were optimistic that the group would decide on an agenda by Nov. 5.

title: German Bank Forces Out Executives After Scandal
description: Rocked by a real estate scandal that has cost it more than $2 billion, Hypovereinsbank A.G. in Munich forced out several top executives today in an attempt to put an end to the matter.

title: Group Seeks Public Bid In Effort to Buy the Jets
description: BuytheJets.com, an on-line fan group that is being blocked from making an offer to buy the Jets, wants the United States Justice Department to force open the bidding.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SEVIN, MALVIN PEACE
description: SEVIN-Malvin Peace. October 27th, your birthday. Our wonderful memories and love for you will always keep you alive in our hearts & thoughts. Love forever. Audrey, Irik and Jaar-me

title: First Lady Tries to Put Mayor on Defensive Over the Minimum Wage
description: On Sept. 28 in Washington, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said he would be against raising the minimum wage ''until I saw that it had no impact on jobs.'' But by last Sunday, he said he expected to ''eventually support'' raising the minimum wage, although he wanted to see some studies first.

title: Pope Describes His Feelings In Unusual Letter to the Aged
description: Pope John Paul II has described his own intimations of mortality in an unusually personal letter addressed to ''my elderly brothers and sisters,'' which was released today by the Vatican.

title: Dishes That Say 'Home'
description: YOU don't have to be a carryout regular to realize the importance of roast chicken in what business types call the meal-replacement market. Even the sound of it -- roast chicken, said slowly, with relish -- is homey and satisfying, suggesting warmth and contentment in a foil container, and it's the rare carryout restaurant that doesn't offer it.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: GOLD FALLS. Gold fell more than 3 percent as jewelers in Asia reduced purchases after prices soared. In New York, gold for December delivery fell $10.10, or 3.4 percent, to $290.40 an ounce.

title: Holyfield Says Commission Needed to Be More Decisive
description: Evander Holyfield, who once had his ears bitten by Mike Tyson, said the Nevada State Athletic Commission officials should have taken a more decisive stance last Saturday night when the Tyson-Orlin Norris bout was ruled a no-contest.

title: Sad Reflections of a Country Star
description: Merle Haggard sang his song ''Footlights'' at Town Hall on Monday night, and he lingered over the words. Its narrator is a popular singer; he admits out front that he lives an enviable life. Then he tells of something he often does onstage: throwing his guitar up in the air and almost letting it fall to the ground. ''The crowd goes nearly wild,'' he sings in the present tense.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAUSS, CAROL
description: STRAUSS-Carol. The Board of Trustees of the Fire Island Synagogue mourns the passing of Carol Strauss, mother of Joyce Koplik. Our deepest condolences to Joyce, Michael, Abigail, Katherine and Michelle.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Dow Takes On a New, High-Technology Look
description: THE Dow Jones industrial average, whose performance has trailed the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index in recent years, dropped four lagging stocks yesterday and substituted four companies that have done much better.

title: Jeers for Rocker
description: The Atlanta reliever John Rocker, who developed a contentious relationship with Mets fans, spoke glowingly of Yankee fans recently, mentioning how knowledgeable he feels they are.

title: Next Steps on North Korea
description: North Korea, the secretive Stalinist dictatorship with the ability to build nuclear bombs and intercontinental missiles, poses one of the most dangerous foreign policy problems facing America. But the North's rulers, beset by crop failures and isolated by the worldwide collapse of Communism, may now see their best chance of survival not in continued belligerence but in a broad accommodation with the United States. The Clinton administration's long-awaited policy review on North Korea says the time has come to test that possibility.

title: Connecticut Has Corned Beef, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Doctors and Lying
description: To the Editor:

title: O'Neill Fails To Run to First On 2 Occasions
description: Paul O'Neill's fans, who are the majority of Yankee supporters, will insist that he is a talented, dedicated athlete who hates failure more than most competitors. O'Neill's detractors will contend that while this is true, he also is a self-absorbed star who occasionally gets so caught up in his own frustrations that he sometimes loses sight of the bigger perspective around him.

title: Who Will Care for Our Children?
description: To the Editor:

title: Teen-Age Birth Rate in U.S. Falls Again
description: The nation's teen-age birth rate fell again last year to a near-record low, Federal health officials said today, continuing an encouraging trend that spans ethnic groups, geographical areas and ages.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARLEY, MARGARET
description: HARLEY-Margaret, on October 26, 1999. Beloved widow of Neil. Mother of Margaret-Ann, Neil Jr., Bobby, and the late Kevin; grandmother of Megan, Erin, Neil III, Terrence, Robin and Dustin. She was a graduate of Mount St. Vincent College and a world traveller. Her favorite pastimes included The New York Times crossword puzzle and Jeopardy. Visiting hours Thursday, 2-5 & 6-9PM at the John Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 First Ave. Mass at St. John the Martyr, 72 St & 2nd Ave, Friday 10AM. Donations may be made to Breast Cancer Research, SloanKettering, C/O Larry Norton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, DARA
description: LEVINE-Dara, age 39, in Santa Fe, on October 1, 1999. Cherished daughter of Fran and Alan, sister of Lisa, Sharon, and Daniel, aunt of Jordana and Zoe, niece of Renay, Irv, Phyllis and Leba and cousin to many. Your beauty was legendary. A true artist, you always viewed every aspect of life with fresh eyes. Though you were distant from us in the prosaic sense, you nevertheless touched each of us with a profundity which we'll experience and ponder forever.

title: Indonesian Leader Forms 'Mixmaster' Cabinet
description: Like a political conjurer, the new President of Indonesia produced a Cabinet today that satisfied a dazzling range of constituencies in this fractured country while lowering the profile of the military and addressing the immediate need for stability.

title: Metro Business; Tenants Are Sought For Times Sq. Site
description: Two months after securing a tenant for a $545 million office tower it plans to build in Times Square, Boston Properties has started talking with potential tenants for a second skyscraper in the neighborhood.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKEL, HERBERT JR.
description: FRANKEL-Herbert Jr. On October 26 at age 73. Loving husband of Rita Bordow Frankel and cherished father of Tracy and Thomas and daughter-in-law Lisa. Adoring Gramps of Jordan and Sarah. Dear brother of Dr. Saul. Service Thursday, 11:30 A.M., at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue (at 81 Street), New York City.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Barbara Wolff, a New York City official who was instrumental in setting up the city's business improvement districts, misstated the date of her death. It was this past Friday, not Oct. 15.

title: House Passes Measure on Internet Domain Names
description: The House of Representatives passed legislation today to crack down on cybersquatting, the practice of buying up popular words as Internet addresses in the hopes of reselling them to companies and trademark holders at a hefty profit.

title: Two Tuscans Who Pass the Gnocchi Test
description: GNOCCHI are hardly more than dumplings, usually made of potato, flour and egg, though sometimes with other ingredients like semolina and vegetables. Good gnocchi are airy and delicate. Bad gnocchi, as is true with bad dumplings everywhere, blaze an acid trail through your insides.

title: The Defendant on the Couch
description: Once again, New Yorkers are watching with dismay as a trial raises agonizing questions about how to deal with a psychotic criminal. Andrew Goldstein, whose psychiatric chart is thicker than his file of press clips, pushed a stranger, Kendra Webdale, in front of an onrushing subway train, maybe because she was a woman, but for no other apparent reason. Like many horrible crimes, this is not the work of a normal, psychologically functional human being.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ECKMAN, FRANCES B.
description: ECKMAN-Frances B. Age 92. Loving widow of Leo Eckman (of blessed memory). Adoring mother of Judith Eckman Jadow and (Julian Jadow). Treasured grandmother of Anna, Lindsay, Eric and Jon. Loved by nieces, nephews and friends. Died on Sunday, October 24, 1999. She will live on in all our hearts.

title: 1.7 Million Copies Sold / Controversial Consumer Guide : 'Don't Buy This,' Japanese Are Told
description: TOKYO  It is a 200-page book that might not raise eyebrows if it were published in Europe or the United States, but five months and 1.7 million copies later, "Katte wa Ikenai" or "Don't Buy This" has sparked a small revolution in Japan.

title: DaimlerChrysler Reports Stronger Results
description: Having discovered three months ago that hell hath no fury like an analyst scorned, DaimlerChrysler reported better-than-expected third-quarter earnings today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUM, ROBERT EDWARD
description: BLUM-Robert Edward, 100. Of Salisbury, CT, died at his home on October 22, 1999. Devoted husband of the late Ethel Halsey Blum. Survived by his son, John R.H. Blum and daughter-in-law, Jeanne C. Blum, and his daughter, Alice B. Yoakum and son-in-law, Robert H. Yoakum, all of Lakeville, CT; nine grandchildren and nineteen greatgrandchildren. Memorial service on Saturday, October 30, 11 AM, Salisbury Congregation Church. In lieu of flowers, contributions would be welcomed to Berkshire Taconic Community Foundation, P.O. Box 569, Salisbury, CT. 06068; or Maine Community Foundation, P.O. Box 148, Ellsworth, ME. 04605.

title: Fiscal Woes Take a Toll on G.O.P. Patronage
description: It has come to this in Nassau County, home of the nation's most resilient Republican machine: Facing the toughest challenge yet to their control of the county Legislature, Republican lawmakers are cutting the jobs of about two dozen politically connected -- but not well-enough-connected -- county employees.

title: Shares Trade Mostly Lower; The Dow Falls 47.80 Points
description: Stock prices fell yesterday, led lower by retailers and four companies that are being replaced in the Dow Jones industrial average.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I really like the issues of managing a large institution and I want to really get back involved. I'd also like to fish, read books and play tennis, but life is a trade-off.''

title: Insurers Urge Auto Makers To Stress Making Cars Safer
description: Designing cars that provide more protection for their occupants will do more for automotive safety than designing sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks that are less lethal to car occupants in collisions, according to a new data analysis presented by insurance industry officials at a safety conference here.

title: Trading System Deal
description: Two of the country's nine electronic communications networks, or E.C.N.'s, said yesterday that they had agreed to merge, in what could mean consolidation of the trading systems now competing with traditional markets.

title: In High Technology, the Grind Evolves
description: In May 1994, Jeff Treuhaft, 25, joined a little Silicon Valley start-up called Mosaic, later to be renamed the Netscape Communications Corporation. The pace was brutal -- 18 hours a day, seven days a week in the early months -- but the work was exhilarating.

title: President of N.F.L. to Resign
description: Neil Austrian, who has been the National Football League's president and chief operating officer since 1991, will leave at the end of the year.

title: London to Demand Action if Commission Rules Against French Ban : Britain Looks to EU to Settle Beef
description: BRUSSELS  A senior British cabinet member confirmed Tuesday that Britain would not retaliate officially against the French ban on British beef, but he said the government expected the European Commission to take immediate action if a scientific committee found this week that the ban was unwarranted.

title: Foreign Affairs; The War Over Peace
description: If you want to make sense of the current foreign policy debate in America, think of it like this: The key to the 20th century is not the three world wars (I, II and the cold war) that punctuated it, but rather how we designed the peace that followed these wars. The peace of Versailles was mishandled. The peace after World War II was well managed. Remarkably, what Republicans and Democrats are still debating today is how, and how much, America should shape the post-cold-war peace.

title: A 20,000-Bottle Weekend
description: THE next time you are trapped washing wineglasses after the guests leave, cheer up. After each big tasting at the New York Wine Experience last week, members of the staff at the Marriott Marquis Hotel had to wash and dry some 27,000 of them.

title: Job Cutbacks Made At FCB New York
description: FCB New York has reduced its staff of about 820 employees by less than 5 percent, the agency announced in a statement, as part of a reorganization intended to improve efficiency.

title: Bluegrass, One Big Party
description: Bluegrass musicians have a few distinct advantages over those in other genres. They have a strong, genuine link to their past and respect for their elders. They still rely heavily on the oral tradition, getting together frequently to exchange licks and tunes. Their ranks are constantly swelling: for most people it is not enough to be a fan of bluegrass, one must also buy an instrument and learn to pick a little. And, as the International Bluegrass Music Association convention and fan fest held here last week proved, they know how to party.

title: Head of Marketing Quits Conde Nast
description: Catherine Viscardi Johnston has resigned unexpectedly as executive vice president for sales and marketing at Conde Nast Publications in New York, part of Advance Publications. A successor has not been named.

title: Tokyo Journal; TV Star Loses Marriage, Privacy and Her Job Too
description: Since her resignation from Japan's equivalent of the ''Today'' show this month, the private life of one of the country's most popular television personalities has become one of its most talked about off-screen dramas.

title: World Briefing
description: THE AMERICAS

title: FOOD STUFF
description: Chilies, Sweet or Hot, At Union Square

title: A Vote for Los Angeles
description: To the Editor:

title: Braves Seem Resigned As Balloon Deflates
description: Mike Remlinger slumped back into his chair and cursed. It was his changeup that Chad Curtis blasted into the left-field bullpen in the 10th inning last night, sending the Yankees skipping onto the field and the Braves plummeting into an enormous hole that threatens to swallow them in the World Series.

title: Public Library Receives Nureyev Film Collection
description: The New York Public Library announced yesterday that the world's largest archive of film, video and audiotapes of Rudolf Nureyev has been given to the Dance Collection of the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts. Called the Rudolf Nureyev Collection, the archives range from film clips of Nureyev as a student at the Kirov Ballet in Leningrad to documentaries made after his death in 1993 at the age of 54.

title: Tea, With a Latte Attitude
description: TOO much information.

title: Golfer's Doomed Flight Still Mystery to Officials
description: WASHINGTON  Investigators were sifting Tuesday through a small, blackened crater in a South Dakota pasture where the private jet carrying the golfer Payne Stewart and five other people had crashed, ending an eerie flight that millions of people, including Mr. Stewart's wife, had followed live on television.

title: If Today Is Oct. 27, This Must Be Another Family/Job Crisis
description: THERE'S a small gift to working parents on the calendar this year. Halloween falls on a Sunday. That means no racing home for trick-or-treat. No sending the kids off with someone else because we can't make it back in time, and no starting out so late that the youngest ones, already overwhelmed by the anticipation of it all, fall apart.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RODIN, BERNARD M.
description: RODIN-Bernard M. Of Old Brookville, L.I. Beloved husband of Francine, devoted father of Michele Jawin, Sherri Cila, & Bonni Rodin. Dear brother of Birdie Kletter. Cherished grandfather of Jordan, Sam, & Gabriella Cila & Alixandra Jawin. Services Thursday, 1 PM, at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEWART, PAYNE
description: STEWART-Payne. The members and staff of Waterville Golf Club, Ireland, note with great sadness the loss of fellow-member and Honorary Captain, Payne Stewart. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his mother Bee, wife Tracey, children Chelsea and Aaron, and longtime caddy Michael Hicks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, JACK M.
description: LEVY-Jack M. At 85, in Seattle, Washington, on October 23, 1999. Architect and engineer. Beloved father of Arthur, Joan, Steven, and Ronald. grandfather of Scott, Mitchell, Gary, Kenneth, Tracy, David, Suzanne and Miriam and four great-grandchildren. Dear brother of Jimmie.

title: Mayor Accuses Critics of Scare Tactics
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani today defended his plan to make homeless people work in exchange for their beds in city shelters, insisting that the work requirement would apply only to able-bodied adults.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Former Treasury Secretary Joins Leadership Triangle at Citigroup
description: Robert E. Rubin, arguably the best-known financier of his generation and the recently retired Treasury Secretary, has taken a top position at Citigroup, the nation's largest financial services company.

title: Rooting From the Bench
description: What if the Yankees had reached the World Series without Bernie Williams for the entire schedule and Paul O'Neill for half the season? This is roughly what Atlanta has accomplished without Andres Galarraga all season and without Javy Lopez for half the season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONAHAN, JEREMIAH P., REV. MONSIGNOR
description: MONAHAN-Jeremiah P., Rev. Monsignor. Suddenly on October 25, 1999. Chancellor of the Archdiocese of New York, loving brother of Patricia Paoli and her husband Ralph, Agnes O'Donohue and her husband John, Catherine Lessuk and Andrew Monahan. Dear uncle of Ralph, Brian and Andrew Paoli, Tara Melendez, Doreen Morse, Sean O'Donohue, Andrew Monahan, Geraldine Schuttenberg, Margaret Monahan and Laura Lessuk. Family will receive friends Wednesday, October 27 from 2:00-5:00 and 7:00-9:00 PM at William's Funeral Home, 5628 Broadway at 232 Street, Bronx. On Thursday, October 28, Monsignor will lay in state in The Lady Chapel at Saint Patrick's Cathedral from 2:00-9:00 PM. Mass of Christian burial will be celebrated at Saint Patrick's Cathedral on Friday, October 29th at 10:00 AM. Interment Saint Raymond's Cemetery, Bronx, NY.

title: Helms Would Act on Nominee In Return for Sensitive Papers
description: Under criticism for his handling of a racially sensitive nomination, Senator Jesse Helms says he will hold a hearing next week on the choice of former Senator Carol Moseley-Braun to be ambassador to New Zealand if the Clinton Administration supplies internal documents on accusations that she used money from her 1992 campaign for personal use and never declared it as income.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAGHINIA, MILANI, PARVIZ
description: TAGHINIA-MILANI-Parviz. On October 24, 1999 in New York City. Beloved husband of Nahid Taghinia-Milani, loving father of Leila Taghinia-Milani Heller, dear father-in-law of Henry Heller, adored grandfather of Alexander and Philip Heller. Interment will be private. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, October 28, at 2 PM at the Church of All Souls, 1157 Lexington Avenue at 80 St. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to: Lenox Hill Hospital/Cardiac Care Unit, c/o Development Department, 100 East 77th St., New York, New York 10021. He devoted his life to numerous enterprises & charities that benefitted the well-being of many, and his immeasurable kindness and generosity to his family and friends will be dearly missed.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: AUTO RACING

title: BURLINGTON TO BUY ARCO FIELDS FOR $304 MILLION
description: Burlington Resources Inc., which explores for oil and natural gas in the United States, agreed yesterday to buy fields in Ecuador, Colombia and Peru from ARCO for $304 million. About $90 million of Burlington's payment will cover this year's expenses for the fields. The properties include the Villano field in Ecuador, which is estimated to hold about 200 million barrels of crude oil. ARCO, the eighth-largest oil company in the United States, has been acquired by BP Amoco P.L.C.

title: A Tribute to Italy's Farm Cooking
description: LYNNE ROSSETTO KASPER'S impeccable first book, ''The Splendid Table'' (William Morrow, 1992), finely captured the cooking of Emilia-Romagna in north-central Italy. So I was disappointed at first to see that in her latest book, ''The Italian Country Table'' (Scribner, $35), Ms. Kasper decided to explore the farmhouse cooking of the entire country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARTOLF, MICHAEL J.
description: BARTOLF-Michael J., 50, passed away of brain cancer on October 23, 1999, he leaves behind his long time companion, Bill Keating, twin brother, Philip, and sister-in-law, Patsy, brother, Steven, and parents, Jane and Joseph. He was taken too soon and we all mourn his loss.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NODEL, SHULAMITH
description: NODEL-Shulamith. Passed away peacefully on Sunday, October 24. Service was privately held on Monday, October 25.

title: For Giants, Good Things Start With Beating Eagles
description: It's simple for the Giants now. Win on Halloween at Veterans Stadium in Philadelphia or things get really scary.

title: The Neighbor You Know
description: IT was a New Yorker cartoon in search of a caption. Slumped over the small but stylish bar at the small but stylish Coup, an avant-nerd with shaved head and heavy-framed black glasses poured forth his troubles to a svelte female bartender wearing a white boa and a look of concern. Farther back, deep in the murkily lit dining room, a young woman with the lungs of Ethel Merman was sharing her innermost secrets with a tableful of friends and, unknown to her, the rest of the room.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUKASHOK, EVE
description: LUKASHOK-Eve. Beloved daughter of Muriel and the late Milton Lukashok and loving sister of Edward Lukashok. Services 12 noon, Wednesday, at the ''Riverside,'' Amsterdam Avenue at 76th Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINETT, PAUL
description: LINETT-Paul. The Board of Directors of the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the USA mourn the loss of Paul Linett, retired President of Linett Clothes, Ltd., who had served both CMA as Board member and the clothing industry for many years with class and distinction. Our deepest condolences to his family. Homi B. Patel, President Harvey J. Weinstein, Chairman Robert A. Kaplan, Executive Director Bernard Ferster, General Counsel

title: Toshiba and Fujitsu Post Weak Results
description: Toshiba, one of Japan's technology giants, lost money in the first half of its fiscal year, as restructuring costs and costs related to its pension program ate into profits.

title: Just Another Girl, Unlike Any Other
description: Elizabeth Carr was such a historic one-of-a-kind when she was born that the doctors who helped give her life also gave her a heart-shaped silver pendant engraved with the number 1. She wears it to this day, at age 17.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: The Pro-Gun Congress
description: The Senate's approval in May of several common-sense gun control measures raised hopes that Congress would respond to the massacre at Columbine High School by making it harder for juveniles, felons and those with a record of mental illness to obtain deadly firepower. But as President Clinton sadly acknowledged this week, the House-Senate committee addressing the issue remains deadlocked, which means that Congress is likely to go home without doing anything on gun control.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZARIN, NATHAN
description: ZARIN-Nathan. Age 81. Died October 25, 1999. Brother of Elsie Zarin Goll, the late Anna Kahn and the late Herman Zarin, devoted uncle. Graveside services Thursday 2:00 P.M. at Beth Moses Cemetery, Farmingdale, L.I., N.Y.

title: Defense Witness Is Barred in Subway Trial
description: Testimony in the trial of a schizophrenic man accused of pushing a woman in front of a speeding subway train concluded yesterday with the judge in the case barring testimony from a man whose description of the defendant's actions just before the killing could have strongly bolstered the defense's case.

title: Kosher and Old World on Broadway
description: To the Editor:

title: Republican Leaders Retreat on Spending
description: Republican leaders of Congress scaled back their plan to cut spending across the board to balance the Federal budget, but the plan still drew opposition from inside their own ranks as well as from the nation's top military officer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERNBACH, OSCAR, JUR.D.
description: STERNBACH-Oscar, Jur.D. On October 25, 1999. Beloved husband of Ellen, loving father of Susanne Appel, and her husband, David Appel, adoring grandfather of Rebecca & Daniel. He will be profoundly missed. Services on Thursday, 1:15 PM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: FOX-PAINE TO BUY WATKINS-JOHNSON FOR $270 MILLION
description: Fox-Paine & Company, a New York-based buyout firm, agreed yesterday to acquire the Watkins-Johnson Company, which makes wireless communications equipment, for $41.125 a share, or about $270 million. Watkins-Johnson, based in Palo Alto, Calif., put itself up for sale in March. It is selling its telecommunications division to a subsidiary of Marconi North America. The company sold its semiconductor equipment group to Silicon Valley Group in July. After these transactions, Watkins-Johnson's operations will consist of its wireless products group, which is a supplier of radio-frequency components and subsystems for wireless and wire line communications equipment.

title: A French Pocket of Good In the Evil of the Holocaust
description: The petite gray-haired woman in her 60's happened to be walking past a plaque commemorating the triumph of good over evil, but she needed no prompting to recall what happened here more than half a century ago.

title: Court Upholds Extensive Stops Of Black Men After a Crime
description: A Federal appeals court ruled yesterday that police officers in Oneonta, N.Y., did not violate the Constitution when they tried to stop every black man in town in 1992 after a woman said she had been robbed in her home by a young black man.

title: I.B.M. AUTHORIZES $3.5 BILLION STOCK BUYBACK
description: The International Business Machines Corporation authorized a buyback of as much as $3.5 billion of its stock, as profit warnings for the fourth and first quarters have sent its shares tumbling. I.B.M., the world's largest computer maker, has repurchased $29.8 billion in stock since 1995. The new buyback would be the 10th in that time. The move comes after a 19 percent plunge in I.B.M.'s stock on Thursday. The stock has gained just 3.5 percent this year. I.B.M. shares rose $1.625, to $95.50. By repurchasing stock, a company can raise earnings per share by spreading its profit over a smaller number of shares.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STORCH, BARBARA BLOOM ''BOBBI''
description: STORCH-Barbara Bloom ''Bobbi''. Of Tamarac, FL, passed away on October 23, 1999. Retired NYC teacher, avid tennis player and wonderful wife and mother.

title: Curtis Experiences A Career Moment
description: Chad Curtis knew the ball was leaving Yankee Stadium, which would turn him into a World Series hero and put the Yankees within one victory of winning their second straight championship. Curtis knew it was gone. Everyone knew.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLLINS, HUGH GAWTRY
description: COLLINS-Hugh Gawtry formerly of Millbrook, NY died at Bloomfield, CT Oct 24, 1999, age 94. He is survived by his wife of 68 years, Frances Fisher Collins, his daughter, Anne Flagler Collins, M.D., and sons, Dennis Gawtry Collins, Farnham Fisher Collins, and Anthony Philip Collins, seven grandchildren, and eleven great grandchildren. Services will be held at Grace Episcopal Church, Millbrook, NY Friday, October 29 at 11 AM.

title: Giuliani's New Policy on Work for the Homeless Leaves Many Unanswered Questions
description: On an average night, 21,000 men, women and children bed down in the New York City homeless shelter system. In an average year, city data show, more than 80,000 different people use the shelters.

title: Siena Is Favored To Win the League
description: Siena, which returns four starters from its National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament squad last season, was selected as the favorite to win the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference, ahead of Iona, Loyola of Maryland, Fairfield and St. Peter's.

title: An Undiplomatic Skirmish in a Pasha's Palace in Jerusalem
description: Dozens of Israeli police officers briefly surrounded the elegant American Colony Hotel today, turning a converted pasha's palace -- an institution in the Arab part of the city -- into a short-lived front line in the battle over Jerusalem's sovereignty.

title: Leaving Sydney to Dine in Paradise
description: FOR more than a century, Sydneysiders have sought relief from urban woes in the magnificent Blue Mountains, just two hours to the west, and in recent years some of the city's best chefs have joined them.

title: With Poignant Sensuality, Romeo the Star-Crossed Lover
description: The Bulgarian-born mezzo-soprano Vesselina Kasarova has what is arguably the most distinctive voice in opera today. Her singing is neither conventionally beautiful nor technically consistent. But her earthy, dusky-toned, vibrant voice is unforgettable and deeply affecting.

title: Man Kills Ex-Girlfriend and Himself at Her Queens Home
description: A 24-year-old man who was scheduled to go on trial next month on charges of harassing his former girlfriend shot her once in the head and then killed himself as the couple's 1-year-old daughter looked on in the woman's Queens home yesterday morning, the police said.

title: Former Professor Gives Stanford $150 Million
description: Stanford University today announced a $150 million gift from the co-founder of two prominent Silicon Valley companies, that will create a new biotechnology center.

title: Sakharov's Advice On ABM Defense
description: To the Editor:

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Oct. 14 about word-a-day Web sites included an outdated reference to the lexicographer responsible for the Random House Dictionary's site (www.randomhouse.com/jesse). The material is now prepared by Wendalyn Nichols and others at Random House; Jesse Sheidlower's last day there was Oct. 1. A new Web address will be announced shortly.

title: Compaq Reports Earnings Of $140 Million in Quarter
description: Compaq Computer reported yesterday that it earned $140 million in the third quarter, beating Wall Street's expectations despite sluggish sales. The company, which has been plagued by bloated costs and management turmoil, took a charge of $868 million to cover severance pay and other cutbacks, which was offset by a gain of $1.2 billion on the sale of most of Altavista, the Internet search engine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLASS, RAY
description: GLASS-Ray. Died on October 26, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Jack. Devoted mother of Judy and Harvey Wertheim and Susan Garfinkel Nevo and Menachem Nevo. Loving grandmother of Allison, Brittney, Joshua and Jennifer and great grandmother of Rebecca. Services Wednesday 12:30PM at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'' 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, New York.

title: Hormone That Slimmed Fat Mice Disappoints as Panacea in People
description: Five years ago, researchers discovered a hormone that seemed to make fat mice slim. In 1995, to much fanfare, it was announced that there was a human form of it, raising hopes that the hormone might do the same thing for people that it did for the mice.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: A Night Out For Mr. Zagat

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORZACK, MOLLIE (MILLIE)
description: ORZACK-Mollie (Millie). Beloved wife of Sidney of Bradenton, FL. Died on Tuesday, October 26th. Beloved mother of Leonard and Sharon Lafer, stepmother of Sandi Berman, grandchildren and great grandchildren. Interment at the Riverside - Boulevard Chapel, Broadway, Hewlett, NY, Thursday, at 1:30 PM. We shall miss this gentle, kind, wonderful lady.

title: Altercation At Stadium Involves Clemens
description: Roger Clemens, who will start Game 4 of the World Series for the Yankees tonight, was involved in an altercation with a man as he left the parking lot at Yankee Stadium after a workout Monday afternoon. Clemens admitted yesterday that he had pushed the man away because he had felt threatened by him. The incident was brief and quickly interrupted by security guards; several fans witnessed it.

title: Democracy and Anarchy in Concert
description: The Orpheus Chamber Orchestra's labor-intensive rehearsal process has not changed in recent years, although it has been greatly streamlined since the ensemble's early days in the 1970's.

title: Nasdaq Data on Short Sales
description: Open positions of short sales on the Nasdaq stock market rose 5.2 percent in the most recent monthly period, the National Association of Securities Dealers, which oversees the market, reported yesterday.

title: Yanks Come Off the Mat to Win
description: A day earlier, Bobby Cox, the Atlanta manager, was talking about Tom Glavine, his starting pitcher for Game 3 of the World Series. Taking note that Glavine had been unable to make his scheduled start in the Series opener because he had the flu, Cox said: ''We expect somewhere around seven,'' meaning innings. ''A good seven would be fine.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PATRAKA, ELLA
description: PATRAKA-Ella, of Englewood, NJ, on October 26. Beloved wife of the late Irwin; dear sister of Jean Grushkin and the late Carrie Abramovitz; loving aunt of Dr. Joel Abramovitz, Dena Grushkin Florczyk, Jonas and Paul Grushkin. Services Temple Emanu-El, 147 Tenafly Road, Englewood, NJ, Friday, 9:30AM Contributions to I.C.U. of Englewood hospital or Hadassah would be appreciated. For info ''Wien & Wien'', 800 322-0533.

title: Shortage of Skills? A High-Tech Myth
description: We've got bipartisan agreement that our new high-tech economy demands radical education reforms. What worked once won't work anymore.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARNER, JO
description: WARNER-Jo. A painter, she died on October 25, 1999, from complications of bone marrow cancer. Raised in Idaho Falls, and a graduate of The University of Colorado, and The Art Students League, in New York, she had many one woman exhibitions during her career at galleries including the Camino and Phoenix, in New York. Two of her oil paintings were included in the Museum of Modern Art's Circulating Exhibition from 1961 to 1963 and were viewed throughout the U.S. and Europe. She was married for 29 years to Peter E. DeBlasio, and she was the very loving mother of Caralee DeBlasio, of Manhattan, and Alessandra DeBlasio, of Washington, D.C.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAEFFER, SYLVIA
description: SCHAEFFER - Sylvia. Beloved wife of Louis. Loving mother of Ivan and Esther, Albert, Helen and Tina. Cherished grandmother of Avi, Caroline, Samuel and Jonathan. Loving aunt and great-aunt. Services at ''Boulevard-Riverside Chapel,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI, at 1:30 PM Wednesday.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: A Melding of Talents

title: Pete Rose's Failing
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKS, DUKE CEDRIC
description: MARKS-Duke Cedric. Husband of Daisy, father of Walter and Peter. Died October 26, 1999.

title: Bar Association Panel Urges Veto of CUNY's Remedial Policy
description: A commission of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York yesterday urged the State Board of Regents to reject a remedial policy adopted by the City University of New York that would bar students who do not pass English or mathematics tests from entering the university's four-year colleges.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUBANKO, WALTER A.
description: LUBANKO-Walter A. Of Brookville, NY, husband of Mary Anne Lubanko, died on October 24, 1999. He was a graduate of Princeton University and Harvard University Law School. He started his career at the law firm of Simpson, Thacher and Bartlett in New York. He later joined Lehman Brothers and F. Eberstadt and Co, where he worked as an investment banker. In 1976 he started his own investment banking firm, W.A. Lubanko and Co., Inc. Among his many achievements, one of his proudest was helping launch Mitchell Energy and Development Co. as a publicly traded company. The loves of his life included Mary Anne, his four sons, skiing,golf, the state of Texas and a good home cooked meal. He was especially proud he skied until age 73 the last year of his life. In addition to his wife Mary Anne, Mr. Lubanko leaves behind four sons, David, Stephen, Mark and Matthew. Funeral arrangements have yet to be made. In lieu of flowers please make a donaton to the Salvation Army.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEFFELL, RABBI A. BERNARD
description: LEFFELL-Rabbi A. Bernard. The Board of Trustees of the Solomon Schechter School of Westchester and our entire community notes with sorrow the passing of Rabbi Bernard Leffell, father of our esteemed Trustee, Michael Leffell. We extend our condolences to Michael and Lisa, Ben, Adam, Lauren and Ari and to Michael's entire family. May the memory of Rabbi Leffell be a blessing. M. Mac Schwebel, Chair Board of Trustees James M. Dubin, Vice Chair Board of Trustees Dr. Elliot Spiegel, Headmaster

title: Corrections
description: A front-page contents entry on Sunday about the cover article in The Times Magazine, on the Reform Party, referred incorrectly to a political figure involved. It should have said Patrick Buchanan, not Pat Robertson.

title: Hoyt Axton, 61, Songwriter, Singer and Actor in Movies
description: Hoyt Axton, the amiably growly singer, songwriter and movie actor who wrote the Three Dog Night hit ''Joy to the World,'' died yesterday at his ranch in Victor, Mont., The Associated Press reported. He was 61 and recently suffered two heart attacks.

title: General Says Chechnya Drive Will Last as Long as Needed
description: Russian troops continued to move within a few miles of the Chechen capital today, and a top federal military commander said the campaign had entered a new phase that would last as long as needed to defeat guerrillas fighting the Russian forces.

title: Minnesota President, Pre-empting N.C.A.A., Penalizes Men's Team
description: The University of Minnesota president, Mark Yudof, announced yesterday that he would not allow the men's basketball team to participate in any post-season tournaments this season as a result of an internal investigation into alleged academic cheating in the program.

title: Scallops That Do A Flamenco
description: FEW foods are as convenient as scallops, which not only have great flavor and texture, but also cook fast. Other mollusks, like clams, oysters and mussels, have to be shucked right before eating, but scallops are shucked soon after harvest and sold virtually ready to cook. Even a large one needs only to be browned on both sides. A good searing caramelizes the natural sugars and leaves the superb interior cool, creamy and delicious.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Putting a French Touch on an Office Tower Lobby
description: An office building at Lexington Avenue and 57th Street is not where one might expect to encounter a little bit of Paris, a touch of Gustav Klimt and a dab of Danube, the new David Bouley restaurant in TriBeCa. But enter the recently renovated two-story lobby of 135 East 57th Street, a 32-story, 400,000-square-foot building at the northwest corner of Lexington, and that's just what the visitor sees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, SOLOMON
description: BERNSTEIN-Solomon. On October 25th, 1999. Age 99. Devoted husband of Mary. Beloved father of Barbara. Services Wednesday, 1 PM from I.J. Morris, 1895 Flatbush Avenue, Bklyn. Interment Knollwood Park Cemetery.

title: Who Will Care for Our Children?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUMERGRADE, SAUL
description: SUMERGRADE-Saul. We extend our deepest condolences to Alice and the entire Sumergrade family. Saul was a wonderful and loyal friend and will be sorely missed. Steven, Lynn, Gordon, Joe, Jordana, Anthony and Michael Jacobson

title: CLINTON TO UNVEIL RULES TO PROTECT MEDICAL PRIVACY
description: President Clinton will soon announce sweeping new Federal rules to protect the privacy of billions of medical records and will assail Congress for failing to enact any safeguards, Administration officials said today.

title: Man's Release Leads to Hope In I.N.S. Cases
description: When the guards came to his cell on Monday night, he held out his arms for the manacles as usual.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAN, DAVID R.
description: FELDMAN-David R. On October 26, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Sylvia. Devoted father of Mark and Carol, Richard and Dorothy. Cherished grandfather of Eric and Sean, Stacey and Rory. Services Thursday 12 noon at ''Gutterman's Inc'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: No Call Behind the Plate
description: Joe Torre, the Yankees' manager, said he was unsure whether Joe Girardi or Jorge Posada would catch Game 4 tonight, when Roger Clemens starts. Since late August, Girardi has been working with Clemens.

title: The Midas Spice: From Flower to Saffron
description: Starlings were swirling overhead, searching for a last nip from the grapevines. Their prospects did not look hopeful; for miles around this rise in the hills, everything looked gray, vacant, bleak.

title: Knicks' Johnson Is Back And Pieces Fall Into Place
description: Larry Johnson has been like a glass of warm milk and a dose of Valium for the Knicks since his return this week, able to soothe the jangled nerves of his coach and restore calm and order on the floor.

title: Proud To Be Dull
description: In the old days, candidates toured the country and gave speeches to tell people about their views. But now the old-fashioned stump speech is passe. Vice President Al Gore and former Senator Bill Bradley, the two Democratic candidates, have opted for a new format: a faux town meeting. The setting for tonight is not a large hall with scattered bridge chairs, bad acoustics and confusion, but a stage arranged for television in a comfortable modern auditorium at Dartmouth College.

title: Bush Under Attack as He Sags in New Polls
description: After months of relatively smooth sailing toward the Republican primaries, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas found himself in less placid straits today, with his two main Republican rivals attacking him at the same time that several new polls suggested some give in Mr. Bush's lead.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN RISES. Japan's currency gained on speculation that the Government would spend more to bolster the economy than investors had expected. In New York, the dollar settled at 104.69 yen, down from 105.31 on Monday.

title: Sanity on Trial
description: To the Editor:

title: Jury Deadlocks in 2d Trial Of Parking Garage Magnate
description: The trial of Abraham Hirschfeld, the eccentric parking garage developer accused of hiring a hit man to kill his former business partner, ended in deadlock last night, with the jury evenly divided over his guilt or innocence.

title: Census Ad Campaign Tries to Entice the Indifferent
description: The commercial shows an empty school hall as the words, ''Built to hold 875,'' flash on the screen. Suddenly students pour out of classrooms and down stairs, filling the hall to overflowing. ''Now holds 1,145,'' the screen says.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SHAMROCK FARMS CO., Phoenix, a dairy business, disclosed it had held talks with Eskimo Pie Corp., Richmond, maker of frozen novelties, ice cream and sorbet, about raising its stake in the company and possibly buying it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NUTT, LORNA A. (NEE ASHEN)
description: NUTT-Lorna A. (nee Ashen) of Englewood, N.J. on October 23, 1999. Beloved mother of Suzanne Nutt and Stephen Yablon, Charlotte and David Nganele and Robert and Ann Nutt. Beloved friend of Dr. William Soule. Loving grandmother of Alex, Julie, Sophia, Marie, Thomas and Matthew. Memorial. Service Saturday, October 30, 1999 3 PM at the Barrett Funeral Home, 148 Dean Dr., Tenafly, N.J. Interment private. In lieu of flowers donations to Fountain House, 425 West 47th St., NYC, NY or the Nursing staff at the Englewood Hospital Hospice Services would be appreciated.

title: AIRBUS GETS FRENCH ORDER
description: Europe's No. 3 airline, Air France S.A., said it would buy eight Airbus Industrie jets for use on long-haul routes, the European plane maker's fifth success against the Boeing Company in a month. Air France will place an order for 8 of the A330-200's and may take as many as 13, giving the deal a value of as much as $1.6 billion.

title: Lucent and Nortel Report Strong Earnings
description: Profiting from the revolution in communications, North America's two titans of telecommunications equipment, Lucent Technologies Inc. and the Nortel Networks Corporation of Canada, each reported strong quarterly financial results yesterday that exceeded analysts' expectations.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SAVAGE, DAVID
description: SAVAGE-David. October 27, 1989. Remembered with love by his family.

title: Newt Gingrich On Fox News
description: Newt Gingrich has answered the question of where he will draw a salary now that he now longer receives his pay from the Government. Fox News is to announce today that it has hired Mr. Gingrich in an exclusive deal to provide political commentary.

title: Money Talks, at a Price
description: To the Editor:

title: Seeking Harmony in Discord; The Orpheus Ensemble Reconsiders the Way It Makes Music
description: Over the last two years, a quiet, bloodless revolution has taken place at Orpheus, the conductorless chamber orchestra that will play at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday. In the spring, the group's founder, president and executive director, Julian Fifer, gave up his position and handed the reins to Harvey Seifter, a tough, experienced administrator who came to Orpheus from the theater world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHWISBERG, BLANCHE
description: SHWISBERG-Blanche. Age 81, born March 21, 1918 Brooklyn New York. Died on October 24, 1999. Survivors are husband Soll daughter Phyllis and son Rick and four grandchildren. Services were held Tuesday, Oct. 26, 1999, El Camino Memorial Park, San Diego, CA.

title: Msgr. Jeremiah Monahan, 65, New York Archdiocese's Chancellor
description: Msgr. Jeremiah P. Monahan, who as chancellor of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York served as steward of the church's secular affairs, including financial matters, construction projects and administration, died Monday at a hospital in Manhattan.

title: BULLETIN BOARD
description: Departing Headmasters

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Workplace page last Wednesday about the decline of men in the work force misstated the rise in the percentage of women who are working. In 1998, 60 percent of all women worked, not 67 percent -- up from 34 percent in 1950, not 59 percent.

title: Mass Transfers Are Planned At a Firehouse Deemed Unruly
description: All 54 firefighters and officers stationed in a Queens firehouse will be transferred as part of a massive shake-up by fire officials who have complained about poor performance and a lack of discipline there.

title: Ford Goes Global in Effort to Control the Clock
description: TURN on a TV set almost anywhere around the world at about 9 P.M. local time on Monday, and chances are a Ford commercial will be on.

title: Redress Indian Claims
description: To the Editor:

title: China Detains More Sect Members at Rally
description: For the second straight day, scores of followers of the outlawed Falun Gong spiritual movement appeared in Tiananmen Square today and were immediately taken away by the police.

title: Miscellany
description: Creatability, Coral Gables, Fla., a Hispanic communications agency, opened a New York office.

title: QUESTION OF EVIDENCE: A special report.; To Bomb Sudan Plant, or Not: A Year Later, Debates Rankle
description: In the 14 months since President Clinton ordered a cruise missile attack on a pharmaceutical plant in Sudan, his aides have steadfastly defended the decision. Mr. Clinton, they say, acted on evidence that left no doubt that the factory was involved with chemical weapons and linked to Osama bin Laden, the Saudi exile they blame for blowing up two American embassies in East Africa.

title: Jessie Foveaux, 100, Dies; Sold Her First Book at 98
description: Jessie Lee Brown Foveaux, who sold her first book for $1 million when she was 98, died on Saturday in a hospital in Duluth, Minn., where she was vacationing with her daughter. She was 100.

title: Players Struggle With Stewart's Loss
description: One day after Payne Stewart's death in a plane crash, his friends and peers were still trying to cope.

title: Reading-Score Rise Tied to More Money
description: Increased financing for poor and low-achieving school districts helped Connecticut register the nation's biggest increase in fourth-grade reading scores between 1992 and 1998, according to a national report released today.

title: Chambliss's Days as the Yankees' Hitting Coach May Be Numbered
description: The game behind the game goes on this week simultaneously with the game itself. The Yankees defeated the Atlanta Braves, 6-5 in 10 innings, in the third game of the World Series last night, but three coaches on the two teams had other action going.

title: Sidestepping Patent Questions, Governments Produce Drugs at Prices Patients Can Afford : In Asia, the AIDS Fight Takes Some New Twists
description: KUALA LUMPUR  Faced with an alarming rate of HIV infections, governments in Asia are battling AIDS in a radically different way than African countries, especially when it comes to providing drugs to treat the disease, experts say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LATCHFORD, WILLIAM J.
description: LATCHFORD-William J. Of NY NY. On October 25, 1999. Beloved husband of Marie, devoted father of Joanne, loving father-in-law of James, cherished grandfather of Kaitlyn and James. Retired employee of Columbia Broadcasting System. Visiting: Andrett's Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave, Manhattan, 25 PM and 7-9 PM Wednesday and Thursday. Mass of Christian burial, Friday, 10 AM, at the Church of the Epiphany, 2nd Ave & 22 Street. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Bagels vs. Doughnuts: The Sequel
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCNERNEY, PETER MICHAEL
description: McNERNEY-Peter Michael. A longtime resident of Manhattan died Thursday, October 21, at the University of California at San Diego Medical Center. The cause of death was complications from a chronic hepatitis B infection. Mr. McNerney is survived by his mother, Mrs. Mae McNerney of Valley Stream, NY, sisters, Patricia Troy of Van Nuys, CA, Judith Keenan of Hauppauge, NY, and Barbara Casey of Staten Island, NY, and his brother, Dr. John McNerney of Mahwah, NJ, and his life partner of almost three years, Mr. John Ball of San Diego, CA. as well as numerous cousins, nieces, nephews and many other dear friends. A funeral Mass will be held on Saturday, October 30, at Blessed Sacrament Church, 201 N. Central Ave, Valley Stream, L.I. at 9 AM. Following the Mass a memorial gathering will be held at the Father Carroll Knights of Columbus Hall at 1 East Lincoln Ave in Valley Stream, NY. The family requests that any memorial be made to God's Love, We Deliver in NY or to Food and Friends in Washington, DC (both organizations provide hot meals to people living with AIDS/HIV).

title: China Faces Hard Decision On Trade Deal
description: The Treasury Secretary, Lawrence H. Summers, said today that even if an agreement was reached to get China into the World Trade Organization, the deal could not come up for a vote on Capitol Hill until next year.

title: Ex-Officer, Convicted in Illegal Raid, Is Freed by Governor
description: A former police lieutenant who was convicted of illegally raiding two East Harlem apartments and terrorizing their occupants in a search for a missing police radio was released from jail yesterday after Gov. George E. Pataki commuted her two-year sentence.

title: Giuliani and Principals Union Near Deal on Ending Tenure
description: After nearly four years of bitter contract negotiations, the Giuliani administration and the union representing New York City's principals appear to be close to a deal that would give city and state education officials the power to swiftly and permanently remove incompetent principals from the school system.

title: Berkeley Faces the 90's
description: To the Editor:

title: Immigrants on the Team
description: To the Editor:

title: Girl, 16, Is Found Bound and Beaten at Queens High School
description: A 16-year-old student at a Queens high school was found bound and beaten in the boys' locker room after school yesterday, the authorities said. The girl, a sophomore at Bayside High School, whose name was not released, was in stable condition last night at Long Island Jewish Hospital, a hospital official said. The police said they had no suspects.

title: COMPAGNIE GENERALE TO BUY GEOSCIENCE FOR $67 MILLION
description: Compagnie Generale de Geophysique of France said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Geoscience Corporation for $6.71 a share, a total of $67 million. The transaction will unite Geoscience's expertise in marine seismic data equipment with Compagnie Generale's Sercel unit, a maker of land seismic data acquisition systems. Tech-Sym, a maker of communications and seismic exploration systems, owns 80 percent of Geoscience, based in Houston. Compagnie Generale provides seismic data acquisition, processing and interpretation services.

title: Appeals Court Upholds Ban On a Type of Late Abortion
description: In a sharply divided vote, a Federal appeals court in Chicago today upheld the constitutionality of laws in Illinois and Wisconsin that criminalize a late-term abortion procedure that opponents call ''partial birth.'' Neither law has yet been enforced.

title: Gwynn Receives Clemente Award
description: Tony Gwynn returned to Yankee Stadium under more enjoyable circumstances last night in his first visit since his San Diego Padres lost the first two games of the World Series a year ago.

title: New Indonesian Leadership Stirs Financiers' Skepticism
description: This country's new Government is getting a skeptical reception from a constituency that does not vote but could play a determining role in the future -- foreign investors.

title: A Gay Crusader Sees History on His Side
