description: LATE on a spring afternoon, the phone rang in the spartan Chelsea offices of the Gay, Lesbian and Straight Education Network.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RIKER, JOHN L.
description: RIKER-John L. To commemorate the first anniversary of his death, there will be a memorial service Wednesday, November 3, 1999, 4:30 PM, St. Ignatius Loyola Church, 84 St. & Park Ave., NYC.

title: Improbably, Silence Prevails As The Voice Awaits Its Sale; Time and Competition Erode Weekly's Sharp Profile
description: The Village Voice is for sale, but does anybody care?

title: Bagels vs. Doughnuts: The Sequel
description: To the Editor:

title: EL PASO ENERGY CUTS 607 JOBS AFTER ACQUIRING SONAT
description: The El Paso Energy Corporation said yesterday that it had cut 607 jobs in the reorganization that accompanied its acquisition of Sonat Inc. On Monday, Houston-based El Paso Energy completed the $6 billion purchase of Sonat -- a transaction that creates the largest natural gas transmission system in North America, with 40,000 miles of pipeline. El Paso said it now employed 4,575 people, compared with 5,500 people at the end of last year.

title: Teamwork Is Easy For Berry
description: In 1998, John Berry returned two interceptions for touchdowns and was the co-captain on a Williams College team that posted an 8-0 record, the school's fourth perfect season in 114 years.

title: Business Travel; The best and the worst in a magazine's survey of phone response times at frequent-flier programs.
description: A RECENT survey of response times of airline representatives in frequent-flier program telephone service centers found that Southwest Airlines and Alaska Airlines did the poorest job of responding to their customers, while America West and UAL's United Airlines did the best.

title: Manager Fired by Company Supports Teamsters on Strike
description: In an effort to turn up the pressure during its three-day-old strike against Overnite Transportation, the teamsters union deployed an unusual weapon yesterday: a former Overnite manager who said the company systematically broke the law by dismissing workers who supported the union.

title: GTE SELLS LOCAL PHONE LINES IN OKLAHOMA TO DBA
description: The GTE Corporation, which is being acquired by the Bell Atlantic Corporation, agreed yesterday to sell 129,092 local telephone lines in Oklahoma to the closely held DBA Communications L.L.C., as it sheds slower-growing businesses. Terms were not disclosed. The sale includes 27 telephone exchanges, and 140 GTE employees will transfer to DBA. Earlier this year, DBA agreed to buy local telephone lines in Texas and New Mexico from GTE. The value of the three properties purchased by DBA is $1.7 billion.

title: For the Day When the Feet Become Still
description: There was lively dancing to be seen in ''The Next Step,'' the gala benefit program on Monday night at the Kaye Playhouse. But the printed program also included this sobering reminder: ''It is undeniably inevitable that each dancer you see performing in tonight's gala will someday have to stop dancing.''

title: Clemency for Pollard
description: To the Editor:

title: British Are Angry as Beef Ban Is Studied
description: ''Just say non,'' said one sign outside a British supermarket that urged customers to avoid French food products.

title: Index of Consumer Confidence Falls for 4th Consecutive Month
description: Consumer confidence in the economy has fallen in October for the fourth consecutive month amid concerns about falling stock prices, the Conference Board, a private industry group, said yesterday.

title: Before, And After: A Deli Lives On
description: IN his foreword to the new ''Second Avenue Deli Cookbook: Recipes and Memories From Abe Lebewohl's Legendary Kitchen,'' Jack Lebewohl writes of his brother's murder:

title: Large Study Urged for New Method of Detecting Lung Cancer
description: Doctors and scientists urged the Federal Government today to start a large study of a new way of detecting lung cancer as soon as possible, seizing what they see as a small window of time to discover if the method works before it becomes so widely used that no one will question it.

title: THE CHEF; A Pumpkin Pleasure Dome Filled With Spices and Pecans
description: THERE can't be another bread that smells better as it is baking, or that looks more inviting when you cut into it, than this pumpkin spiral. The shape was inspired by a bread that Toy Dupree, who has been working with me at the bakeries from the start, saw Pueblo women making in beehive ovens in Taos, N.M. Over the years, I have refined and changed the recipe, and now it is the quintessential fall bread, spiced with cinnamon, ginger and cloves, studded with pecans and coiled around on itself until it gently domes in the center, evoking the shape of those Pueblo ovens.

title: Youth Convicted in Fatal Attack Over a Basketball Game
description: A Brooklyn teen-ager was convicted of manslaughter yesterday for initiating an attack on members of a rival basketball team that ended in the fatal stabbing of a 14-year-old boy.

title: Editor Quits Amid Turmoil Surrounding Book on Bush
description: The editor in chief of St. Martin's Press abruptly resigned from the company yesterday in another sign of continuing turmoil at the New York publishing house after its cancellation of a biography of Gov. George W. Bush of Texas by an author with a criminal record.

title: Gore Eager to Connect With New Hampshirites
description: A student was asking Vice President Al Gore if he would visit his high school. ''Absolutely!'' Mr. Gore responded, then laughed at his quickness to please. ''You caught me at a vulnerable moment.''

title: With 1-2 Punch, Yankees Grab 3-0 Lead
description: Joe Torre was not sure whether he would start Chad Curtis in Game 3 of the World Series last night. Maybe it was a better idea to start Ricky Ledee in left field instead; Curtis, after all, had not had a hit in 13 career at-bats against the Atlanta starter, Tom Glavine.

title: Devils Say No Plans Exist To Trade Elias or Morrison
description: Lou Lamoriello has traded away most of the players who confronted him in contract disputes. But Lamoriello, the president and general manager of the Devils, insisted today that he had no intention of trading Patrik Elias or Brendan Morrison, the two restricted free agents who reached an agreement with the Devils on Monday after a long contract dispute that kept them away from the team since the opening of training camp.

title: Gore-Bradley Race Places Left at Front and Center Among Democrats
description: For the first time since the 1980's, the fight for the Democratic Presidential nomination has set off a fierce competition for the loyalties of the party's once-embattled liberal wing.

title: Clemente and the Weight of Gesture
description: There is always something disembodying about the hours spent in an art museum. The substantive world rises up around you in bronze, marble, porcelain and wood, in the interlaced texture of paper, the rough surface of paint. And yet it is all held at a distance, intangible except to the eye. Even abstract painting makes a gestural appeal to the body, which nearly always goes unanswered by the viewer. Deep taboo is what keeps you from fondling a Brancusi or running your fingers over the strands of pigment that wind through a Pollock. If you like, you may face Ingres's portrait of Ferdinand-Philippe-Louis-Charles-Henri, Duc d'Orleans, now visiting the Metropolitan Museum in New York, and try to capture in your own posture the hauteur of that regal left arm. But you may not even think about rubbing the frame.

title: MANAGEMENT: A Network of Their Own; From an Exclusive Address, a Group for Women Only
description: For Janet Tiebout Hanson, leaving Goldman, Sachs after 14 years was ''like stepping off a cliff.'' She had risen to vice president, after spending her entire professional career at the Wall Street firm, with all the power and prestige it conferred.

title: Correction Officer Shoots Gunman on Street
description: An off-duty correction officer in Queens shot and wounded an armed man who tried to rob him last night, the police said.

title: INSIDE
description: Dow to Change Lineup

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NADER, GEORGETTE
description: NADER-Georgette. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family joins with the physicians and staff in the Department of Medicine in acknowledging with sadness the passing of Georgette Nader, the beloved mother of our dear friend and devoted colleague, Nadim Salomon, M.D. To Dr. Salomon, his family and all of his mother's loved ones we extend our heartfelt condolences. Matthew E. Fink, M.D. President and CEO Stephen G. Baum, M.D. Chairman, Dept. of Medicine Henry Singman, M.D. President, Medical Board Robert L. Salant, M.D. President, Doctors Alumni Association

title: Hearst Executive Wins Public Service Award
description: The Advertising Council in New York will present its annual award for public service to Frank A. Bennack Jr., president and chief executive at Hearst in New York.

title: B.A.T.'S PROFIT DROPS
description: The maker of Lucky Strike cigarettes, British American Tobacco P.L.C., said that charges related to its $8.3 billion acquisition of Rothmans International pushed down its third-quarter profit by 8.3 percent. British American bought Rothmans, the maker of Dunhill and other brands, in June.

title: MERGER POSSIBILITY DENIED
description: The world's second-largest liquor company, Allied Domecq P.L.C., denied persistent news reports that it had been approached by Pernod-Ricard S.A. of France about a merger. Philip Bowman, the chief executive, made the denial after the company reported a 1.9 percent fall in second-half profit. Allied Domecq, whose brands include Ballantine's whisky, Beefeater gin, Baskins-Robbins ice cream and Dunkin' Donuts, cited problems with its 3,500 pubs before it sold them. Alan Cowell

title: Still Crafty And Subtle And Knows How to Stomp
description: Elvis Costello let his voice precede him Monday night at the Beacon Theater. He emerged in darkness, banging out chords on his guitar. The lights stayed off as he was quietly joined by his frequent collaborator, the pianist Steve Nieve. By the time listeners could see Mr. Costello's face, they were absorbed, drawn in by the music and kept there by the words.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZONA, JAMES W., REVEREND
description: ZONA-James W., Reverend. The Diocese of Brooklyn announces the death of the pastor of St. Mary's Church, 10-08 49th Street, Long Island City, on Oct. 24. Reposing in Conway Funeral Home, 82-19 Northern Blvd., Jackson Heights, Wednesday, Oct. 27, from 2-5 and 7-9 P.M., and Thursday, Oct. 28, from 2-5 P.M. Mass of Transferral at Our Lady of Fatima Church, 2502 80th St., Jackson Heights, at 7:30 P.M. Funeral Mass at St. Mary's Church, Friday, Oct. 29, at 10:30 A.M. All priests are invited to concelebrate. He was a member of the Priests' Purgatorial Society. Most Rev. Thomas V. Daily Bishop of Brooklyn

title: Bush on His Achievements as Governor
description: This is one of a series of new 30-second television commercials to be broadcast in Iowa and New Hampshire in coming weeks. It highlights what George W. Bush considers to be his most important achievements as Governor of Texas.

title: Chicago Has Pastrami
description: To the Editor:

title: Brosius Is Reluctant To Bask in the Glow
description: Scott Brosius' smile evaporated as the crowd of reporters around his locker grew Monday, and as questions were hurled at him, he deflected or dodged most -- when they were about him and his World Series success -- and offered mostly curt responses to the others.

title: Of 'Me' and 'We' Moments
description: I grew up a military brat, went to the Naval Academy and spent seven years in the Navy. I could have commanded my own ship eventually. Instead, at 28, I made the wrenching decision to take a job as an engineer at Honeywell.

title: David H. Hirsch, 69, a Professor Emeritus
description: David H. Hirsch, a professor emeritus of English and American literature and Judaic studies at Brown University, died on Oct. 19 at St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston, N.J. He was 69 and lived in Providence, R.I.

title: To Celebrate Music Teacher, Film Toughened Up School
description: Nineteen years ago, Roberta Guaspari, devastated by a wrecked marriage, left her mother's house in upstate New York, took her two little boys and moved to East Harlem with a crate full of old violins and the need for a job. She talked her way into New York City's Central Park East School, a center of progressive public education where paint-spattered smocks spilled into the hallways and even middle-class parents begged for admission. She became something of a local hero, taking her best students to perform at a triumphal concert at Carnegie Hall.

title: Anxious Wife Tried to Call Golfer During Fatal Flight
description: Payne Stewart's wife, Tracey, was one of the millions of people transfixed by television reports on Monday about his Learjet flying uncontrolled across the United States, and she tried to call him on his cellular phone, a family member said.

title: CALENDAR
description: Studying Restaurant Design

title: Social Security Scare-Mongering
description: Social Security is one of the oldest weapons in politics. By charging that various Republican schemes would wreck the Social Security system, Democrats over the years have blocked tax cuts, a constitutional amendment to balance the budget and the recent G.O.P. proposal to replace part of the retirement system with private investment accounts. Now the Republicans seem to be making political headway using the same weapon against Democrats. They are advancing a ludicrous claim that deep Republican budget cuts are needed to stop a Democratic ''raid'' on Social Security.

title: From a Giant Job to an Internet Fledgling
description: When he resigned as president and chief operating officer of the world's largest hotel company in April, the conventional wisdom was that after a summer vacation, Richard D. Nanula would land a similarly important job with a big company in the Northeast.

title: ACKERLEY TO SELL BILLBOARD BUSINESS TO ELLER
description: Ackerley Group agreed yesterday to sell its Miami-Fort Lauderdale and West Palm Beach, Fla., outdoor billboard business to Eller Media, a unit of Clear Channel Communications Inc., for $300 million. Ackerley, based in Seattle, owns or operates 17 television and radio stations, as well as the Seattle Supersonics professional basketball team. It had revenue of $257 million in 1998. Eller Media, acquired by Clear Channel in 1997 for $1.15 billion in cash and stock, is an outdoor advertising company based in Phoenix. Clear Channel, based in San Antonio, owns more than 270 radio and 20 TV stations, as well as an outdoor advertising business.

title: Khatami's Visit to France Is Regarded as Step Forward
description: TEHRAN  When President Mohammed Khatami arrives in France on Wednesday, his second state visit to the West, it will be another marker along Iran's journey toward detente with Europe.

title: Parliamentary Disorder
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Maneuvering Over Budget Bills Continues as Social Security Surplus Grows
description: The budget battle turned to tactical skirmishes today, as Republicans struggled to write bills financing seven Federal agencies and foreign aid without tapping Social Security funds, triggering vetoes or tearing apart their thin majority in Congress.

title: Spreading the Census Message; Bureau Pushes the Importance of Participating, Especially to Those Least Likely to Be Counted
description: Behind the boccie champions and the marching bands in this year's Columbus Day Parade, long after the perennial favorite, the Rockettes, came an unlikely crowd pleaser: a red-and-white float showing off that normally staid bureaucracy, the United States Census Bureau.

title: Essay; Straw Men Never Die
description: ''It would be easy,'' said the president, ''easy for a president of the United States to buy some popularity by going along with the new isolationists. But I submit to you that it would be disastrous for our nation and the world.''

title: Report Urges Monitors Aboard Every School Bus
description: Every school bus should carry a trained monitor to watch the children, escort them from the bus and walk them safely across the street if necessary, according to a report issued by a Westchester County grand jury convened to study school bus safety.

title: Owens Corning Goes to Court Over a Fake Internet Message
description: This much is known: A lawsuit was filed this week in Federal District Court in Manhattan. But no one knows who was sued.

title: In its biggest campaign, Fuji plays down technology to focus on brand identity.
description: THEY'RE the photos that people really wish their colleagues would keep to themselves. The baby sleeping. The teen-ager on the phone. The dog's face in close-up. They document the everyday moments of interest to no one but the closest of kin and friends.

title: Rowland Firmly Defends Conduct in Fund-Raising
description: Beset by mounting allegations that his administration mixed fund-raising with state business before last year's election, Gov. John G. Rowland gave an emotional defense of his conduct today, challenging journalists to find proof of corruption and report it to Federal authorities.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO FALLS. The euro fell against the dollar after a money supply report reinforced expectations that the European Central Bank will raise interest rates. In New York, the euro settled at $1.0500, down from $1.0586.

title: 5 Supermarket Chains Reach Contract Accord
description: A tentative contract settlement has been reached at five large supermarket chains in three boroughs and on Long Island.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Hewlett-Packard Shares Fall on Earnings Concern

title: The Big City; Aftermath Of 40 Hours In an Elevator
description: THE elevator from hell was back in service yesterday at the McGraw-Hill Building, and it operated smoothly during an unscientific survey. How much, passengers were asked during a dozen trips at lunchtime, should Nicholas White get for being trapped in this box for 40 hours without food or water?

title: Do Americans Want Stricter Gun Laws?
description: To the Editor:

title: NORWICH LOOKS TO SPAIN
description: Pressing a European expansion to enhance distribution networks, Norwich Union P.L.C., Britain's fifth-largest life insurance company, said it was weighing moves to take control of the insurance businesses of Caixa Catalunya, Spain's seventh-biggest life insurer. After its acquisition of another Spanish insurer in July, the British company said it was discussing buying substantial stakes in Caixa's Ascat life insurance unit.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: MANHATTAN

title: 3 Titles in 4 Years and 25 for the Century
description: The Yankees will get to ride up Broadway again, thanks to a record-tying 12-game winning streak in the World Series that has added 1996, 1998 and now 1999 to their already lustrous record of world championships. In all, they have 25, by far the most in major league history. Here's a look at the last three:

title: Wired Virtual Patients Simulate Emergencies for Students
description: LAST Friday, three respiratory-therapy students at the Borough of Manhattan Community College were faced with an unsettling learning experience: They were staring into the face of what looked like a young boy having a severe allergic reaction to peanuts. His larynx and tongue were swelling and his breathing was strained.

title: Misguided Shelter Reform
description: New Yorkers remember vividly when homeless women with children were sleeping in Grand Central Terminal and violent, mentally ill people were a regular hazard on the streets. New York City has made a great deal of progress by coaxing these people into shelters, where they get help with drug addiction, mental problems and the domestic calamities that caused their lives to fall apart.

title: Like a Miner's Canary?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Blind Leading the Sighted
description: GREGG VANDERHEIDEN regularly washes his own clothes, but unlike most people, he never loses any socks. He is immune to that modern plague because he uses sock sorters, small plastic rings that keep each pair together in the laundry.

title: Move Over, Beanies, Here Come Buggies
description: Huggy Buggies are plump, clutchable toy vehicles in Jell-O-bright colors. They have a cartoonlike curbside appeal. Before her career at a toy concern in New York, Alise Robinson, their inventor, taught preschool, where she decided that children need ''tactile toys that encourage fantasy.'' Huggy Buggies, about five inches long, are made of rubber and bounce like the Pillsbury Doughboy. There is a truck, a plane, a sedan and a pug-nosed helicopter. $10 each at MOMA Design Store, 44 West 53d Street, (800) 793-3167 or www.momastore.com.

title: Architects in California Help to Design Stronger Buildings at Quake Site : On-Line Reconstruction in Turkey
description: BUDAPEST  A California company is harnessing Hungarian software and the Internet to help Turkey recover from the devastating earthquake there in August.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONAHAN, JEREMIAH P., REV. MONSIGNOR
description: MONAHAN-Jeremiah P., Rev. Monsignor. Suddenly on October 25, 1999. Chancellor of the Archdiocese of New York, loving brother of Patricia Paoli and her husband Ralph, Agnes O'Donohue and her husband John, Catherine Lessuk and Andrew Monahan. Dear uncle of Ralph, Brian and Andrew Paoli, Tara Melendez, Doreen Morse, Sean O'Donohue, Andrew Monahan, Geraldine Schuttenberg, Margaret Monahan and Laura Lessuk. Family will receive friends Wednesday, October 27 from 2:00-5:00 and 7:00-9:00 PM at William's Funeral Home, 5628 Broadway at 232 Street, Bronx. On Thursday, October 28, Monsignor will lie in state in The Lady Chapel at Saint Patrick's Cathedral from 2:00-9:00 PM. Mass of Christian burial will be celebrated at Saint Patrick's Cathedral on Friday, October 29th at 10:00 AM. Interment Saint Raymond's Cemetery, Bronx, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRANDIN, SUSANNE P. (WILSON)
description: GRANDIN-Susanne P. (Wilson) of Chestnut Hill, October 24, 1999 at home, age 81 years. Wife of 59 years of John L. Grandin, Jr. Mother of John L. Grandin III, Edward W. Grandin and Preston B. Grandin all of Chestnut Hill. Also survived by 5 grandchildren, Jay, Louisa, Andrew, Will & Mercedes. A Memorial Service will be held at Trinity Church, Copley Square, Boston on Saturday, October 30 at 11AM. Private interment. Longtime trustee of Boston Symphony Orchestra. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be sent to the Boston Symphony Orchestra, 301 Massachusetts Avenue, Boston, MA. 02115.

title: A Domain Of One's Own
description: Q. I recently purchased a domain name from Network Solutions and was under the impression that it cost only $29. A month later, I got a bill for $70 for a registration fee. Is this a legitimate charge, or am I being fleeced?

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PLM INTERNATIONAL INC., San Francisco, an equipment-leasing company, will sell a subsidiary, American Finance Group Inc., to Temple-Inland Inc., Diboll, Tex., for $29 million in cash.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HASSING, ABRAHAM
description: HASSING-Abraham. (May 12, 1919-October 26, 1999) Beloved husband of the late Dorothy, father of Lois Ratner (David) and Betty Catsicis (Paul), cherished grandfather of Bonnie Ward (Larry), Laurie Philipson (Baron), Paul Ratner (Caryn), a great-grandfather of Austin David Philipson and Daniel Steven Ward, brother-in-law of Mollie Palatnik & Vern Hoffnung. Brooklyn College graduate, retired Court Clerk-New York State Supreme Court, former Councilman-Lauderdale Lakes, FL. Rest peacefully, Dad. We know your broken heart will mend as our beloved mother, Dorothy, welcomes you to eternity. Funeral service Friday, October 29, 10AM, at Bloomfield-Cooper Funeral Chapel, Manalapan, New Jersey. Interment Wellwood Cemetery, Farmingdale, New York.

title: Dracula Hears Philip Glass and Gets Thirsty
description: Tod Browning's 1931 ''Dracula'' now seems more comical than scary, with its overstated gestures and poses and its lines that everyone has memorized and many have parodied (''I never drink. . .'' -- pause -- ''wine.'') Yet with Bela Lugosi as the Count, it remains an entrenched horror classic, eclipsing both the arguably more artful silent ''Nosferatu'' that preceded it and the many more recent high-budget, high-gore, full-color retellings.

title: Attempting The Spanish Conquest, With Piano
description: Spain's most interesting composers, Isaac Albeniz among them, did themselves few favors, writing piano music so difficult to perform that the few who understand its sensuality are unable to play the notes; the few who play the notes can do little more. Ambidextrous in this respect is Alicia de Larrocha, who has managed to make the Albeniz-Granados repertory both deeply personal and technically complete. Claudio Arrau played ''Iberia'' to great effect earlier in his career. Arthur Rubinstein loved this music but furtively left out a lot.

title: A Surprise Possibility: A Dignified Democrat Race
description: The Democratic Presidential candidates tonight discussed important, complicated issues in their first joint event and invited voters to judge them not for campaign jabs but by their earnest concerns about problems from health care to homosexuals' rights to campaign finance.

title: Admission Test Nightmare: Exams Are Lost in Transit
description: When Kevin Asadi put down his No. 2 pencil after completing the grueling Law School Admission Tests earlier this month, he could not stop a huge grin from spreading across his face.

title: Arrests by New Jersey Troopers Showed Another Big Drop in September
description: Arrests by the New Jersey State Police were down 42 percent in September from the same period last year, and the head of the state troopers' union said yesterday that he attributed the decline to low morale and troopers' fear of being accused of racial profiling.

title: Toward a Future With Flair
description: ARCHITECTURE is a fractured field. There are some architects who build but seldom break new ground. And then there are the experimenters whose idiosyncratic designs and arcane language can scare off clients with the power to promote them.

title: A Movie Palace For Grown-Ups
description: Ex-Centris, a new three-screen cinema in Montreal, left, has no concession stands. But there is sound that exceeds THX standards, and air-conditioning that comes from below and through the seats (hence, no refreshments allowed that could spill and gum up the works). One theater converts to an exhibition space; the floor is hinged so it can be leveled. Another theater can be converted for live performances; it has a five-ton screen that can roll backward 28 feet to reveal a stage. The posh complex has a two-story cafe and bar, open until 3 A.M., that draws a music and film industry crowd like a chic hotel lobby. The theaters charge the standard ticket price. Ex-Centris was built by Daniel Langlois, an entrepreneur who founded Softimage, three-dimensional computer animation. Mr. Langlois has plans to open a similar grown-up movie theater in Manhattan. Ex-Centris is at 3536 Boulevard Saint Laurent; (514) 847-3536.

title: BET HOLDINGS PLANS $1 BILLION INVESTMENT IN RADIO
description: BET Holdings Inc., owner of Black Entertainment Television, will spend as much as $1 billion to enter the radio business, BET's founder, chairman and chief executive, Robert L. Johnson, said yesterday in an interview, confirming a report in The New York Post. BET is looking to buy stations worth as much as $1 billion from Clear Channel Communications Inc., which intends to sell as many as 125 of them as part of its proposed purchase of AMFM Inc., Mr. Johnson said. BET, which aims to acquire 20 to 30 stations, seeks to enter large midsize markets. Earlier this week, the closely held company said it had created a new venture with Liberty Media Group to buy United States radio stations. Liberty owns about 35 percent of BET.

title: A New Web Site for Armchair Marathoners
description: As race time approaches for the 30th New York City marathon on Nov. 7, runners, spectators and enthusiasts can get a preview of the 26.2-mile pageant of sweat, muscle and determination by way of a new Web site.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Thursday about Mr. Holbrooke's efforts to persuade Congress to make the overdue payments misidentified the committee headed by Representative David Dreier, Republican of California. It is the House Committee on Rules, not the subcommittee on rules and organizations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERNBACH, OSCAR, JUR. D.
description: STERNBACH-Oscar, Jur. D. On October 25, 1999. Beloved husband of Ellen, loving father of Susanne Appel, and her husband, David Appel, adoring grandfather of Rebecca & Daniel. He will be profoundly missed. Services on Thursday, 1:15 PM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: MP3 Goes on the Road: A Digital Player for the Car
description: Portable digital audio devices, commonly known as MP3 players, continue to evolve faster than the music they play. A new Atlanta-based company recently introduced a twist on an old idea: an MP3 player for the car.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about criticism of Republican members of Congress by Richard C. Holbrooke, the United States representative at the United Nations, over foreign aid and overdue payments to the organization, misspelled the given name of the spokesman for the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, which has been involved with both issues. He is Marc Thiessen, not March.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASKETBALL

title: Vast Numbers of Sect Members Keep Pressure on Beijing
description: In a brazen act of civil disobedience, thousands of members of the banned Falun Gong spiritual movement have descended on Beijing in recent days and weeks, hoping, the members say, to press the Government to reverse its condemnation.

title: A Corridor to Mideast Peace
description: The opening this week of the first ''safe passage'' corridor between the Palestinian-ruled Gaza Strip and the other main areas of Palestinian administration, on the West Bank, may have lacked the political drama of earlier steps on the road to Middle East peace. But it was a crucial advance.

title: G.O.P. Social Security Ads Put Democrats on Defensive in Bid for Seats
description: Representative Earl Pomeroy, a Democrat from North Dakota, was able to go to college after his father died only because of Social Security benefits for survivors. And he has devoted his six years in Congress in large part to pension issues and Social Security.

title: U.S. to Expand Anti-Discrimination Rights for Illegal Immigrants Working in This Country
description: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission has announced that it will extend broad anti-discrimination rights to illegal immigrants for the first time, a policy some critics said could be hard to enforce and others contended would encourage illegal immigration.

title: Wide-Ranging Movie Sites Offer the Rare and Offbeat
description: BLOCKBUSTER last week announced that it would offer movie rentals over the Internet by the middle of next year and said it was evaluating ways to transmit movies into people's homes on demand. But you don't have to wait until then to order movies over the Internet and have them delivered to your door.

title: No Buffoon, This Falstaff But Proud, Even Sad
description: There were two stories to report from the New York City Opera on Tuesday night. The first is the marvelous new production of Verdi's ''Falstaff,'' directed with vitality and imagination by Leon Major and offering a performance by the remarkable young American baritone Mark Delavan that should finally prod the Metropolitan Opera to sign him for something soon. The Met can boast few better Verdi baritones on its roster this season.

title: Crucial Errors of Omission Also Haunt the Braves
description: The box score of their final game of 1999 will show that the Atlanta Braves committed no errors. The box score, however, doesn't always tell the whole story. Ryan Klesko, the Braves' first baseman, failed to make a makable play in the third inning of Game 4 last night, and the Yankees, as they did during the entire post-season, capitalized on it for a 4-1 victory and two record-tying World Series feats.

title: A Coliseum for Modern Gladiators
description: Many architects dream about shaping their hometown skyline. Laurinda Spear and Bernardo Fort-Brescia of Arquitectonica have just done so in Miami. The city is now book-ended by two of Arquitectonica's Brasilia-Modern structures. Nineteen years ago, Arquitectonica put up Atlantis, a sleek slab of an apartment building on Brickell Avenue that was a favorite backdrop for the television show ''Miami Vice.'' Now, at the other end of the cityscape, Arquitectonica has crowned 14.5 acres at the edge of Biscayne Bay with the 782,400-square-foot American Airlines Arena, below, a $220 million effort that Mr. Fort-Brescia breezily compares to the Coliseum in Rome in shape and scale. ''We're reintroducing the perfect ellipse,'' he said. This new coliseum is owned by the Miami Heat basketball team. The arena will officially open on New Year's Eve with a concert by Gloria Estefan. She is also a tenant in the complex, where she plans to open a branch of her restaurant, Bongos. The artist Frank Stella designed a sculpture that will double as an abstract band shell. Ms. Spear's colorful fabrics, furniture, lighting and laminates are used throughout the compound. Panels of the arena wall appear to open, revealing vast gridded glass walls underneath, illuminated with colored light. The arena can be seen from anywhere in Miami, but possibly the best view is from the cruise ships that sit in the harbor like ducks in a row. Most of that fleet, which includes Carnival and Cunard, is operated by Mickey Arison, the owner of the arena and the Miami Heat.

title: The Lords Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Indonesia To Revive Investigation Of Suharto
description: The new Indonesian Government said today that it would reopen a corruption inquiry into former President Suharto that was dropped as one of the final acts of the previous Government.

title: 500,000th Runner  Is Honored
description: When the New York City Marathon began in 1970, it had 127 runners. This year, it has accepted 29,995, bringing the 30-year total to 502,819.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, ALVIN S.
description: FRIEDMAN-Alvin S., 81, of Lake Worth, FL died on October 24, 1999. Born in Mt. Vernon, NY, he lived there until 1967, residing thereafter in Greenwich, CT and Somers, NY before moving to Lake Worth in 1995. He is survived by his wife Gloria, and was predeceased by his wife of 55 years, Frances Feinsod Friedman. He is also survived by three childrenRobert, Marsha Silverman and David, two brothers-Herbert and William, seven grandchildren and two great grandchildren.

title: Trying to Turn Stocks Into a National Pastime
description: Three years ago, corporate America thought that the mostly male audience watching the World Series aspired to drive Chevy pickup trucks, shave with Gillette's razors and drink Coors beer -- judging by the amount of money that was spent on expensive ad time to promote those brands.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLLACK, SEYMOUR
description: POLLACK-Seymour. On October 27, 1999. Beloved husband of Selma. Devoted father of Daryl, Glenn, Jill and Bruce. Cherished grandfather of Jeffrey, Daniel, Jennifer, David, Jason, Julie and Melissa. ''He will be remembered forever.'' Services Thursday, October 28th, 12:30 PM, Temple Beth Sholom, Roslyn, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAGHINIA, MILANI, PARVIZ
description: TAGHINIA-MILANI-Parviz. On October 24, 1999 in New York City. Beloved husband of Nahid Taghinia-Milani, loving father of Leila Taghinia-Milani Heller, dear father-in-law of Henry Heller, adored grandfather of Alexander and Philip Heller. Interment will be private. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, October 28, at 2 PM at the Church of All Souls, 1157 Lexington Avenue at 80 St. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to: Lenox Hill Hospital/Cardiac Care Unit, c/o Development Department, 100 East 77th St., New York, New York 10021. He devoted his life to numerous enterprises & charities that benefitted the well-being of many, and his immeasurable kindness and generosity to his family and friends will be dearly missed.

title: Food Inspectors Facing Charges In Bribery Case
description: Eight Federal food inspectors who monitored shipments of fresh fruit and vegetables sold each year at the Hunts Point Terminal Market in the Bronx have been arrested in a bribery and kickback scheme that allowed wholesalers to cheat their suppliers, Federal authorities said yesterday.

title: O'Neill Plays On Hours After Father Dies
description: Paul O'Neill got the phone call at 3 A.M. yesterday, word that his father, Charles O'Neill, who had been suffering from heart disease, had died at age 79.

title: ST. JOE TO SPIN OFF STAKE IN FLORIDA EAST COAST
description: The St. Joe Company said yesterday that it planned to spin off its 54 percent stake in Florida East Coast Industries to St. Joe's shareholders. The holding of 19.6 million shares is worth about $701 million, based on Florida East Coast's closing stock price on Tuesday. St. Joe's stock rose $1.625 a share yesterday, to $22.875. St. Joe, based in Jacksonville, Fla., is a real estate development company with interests in Florida and elsewhere in the Southeast. Florida East Coast, based in St. Augustine, Fla., is a holding company for the Florida East Coast freight railroad as well as trucking, telecommunications and real estate businesses. St. Joe will not retain an equity interest in Florida East Coast.

title: Faster And Faster, But Why?
description: ANOTHER generation of faster microprocessors is about to arrive in the stores, just in time to spark a new wave of holiday technology lust among the pocket-protector crowd.

title: Accounts
description: * Rainday.com, Manhasset, N.Y., a Web site that is part of the Worldwide Weather Insurance Agency, to 2 Guys Who Do Ads Inc., New York, to handle its first account. Billings are estimated at $3 million.

title: Young Hopeful Of a Return in '99
description: San Francisco quarterback Steve Young is trying to find a way to play football again this year, despite his fourth concussion in three years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DELANEY, THOMAS F.
description: DELANEY-Thomas F., 88. On Oct. 26, 1999 of West Hempstead, N.Y. Cherished husband of Isabel. Devoted father of Carol & Richard Staszak, Jill Axthelm & Charles Jones, Thomas F. Jr. & Julie Igoe, Paul & Kathy. Also survived by eight grandchildren and three great grandchildren. Retired Vice President, Industrial Relations, Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, 1939-1975. Former chairman of company bargaining committee and chief labor negotiator and counsel. Began career as attorney, United States Trucking Corporation. Joined MetLife's law division in 1939. Became Vice President in charge of Industrial Relations department in 1969, responsible for handling all labor relations matters for the company, before retirement in 1975. Continued as Labor Arbitrator, American Arbitration Association; Mediator and Fact-Finder, New York State and Nassau County PERBS; Member of Advisory Arbitration PanelCSEA/Nassau County C.B.A.; Chairman, Nassau County Public Employment Relations Board; Labor Relations consultant to Nassau County, Chief Negotiator; Member Arbitration Board, Nassau County P.B.A. and S.O.A.; Chairman, Member Conciliation Board, Diocese of Rockville Centre. Attended Brooklyn Preparatory School, Fordham College, Fordham Law School. Member New York Bar; Admitted U.S. Supreme Court; Member Emeritus, Association of Life Insurance Counsel; Former Member, National Affairs Committee-New York Chamber of Commerce & Industry. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Avenue at 12th Street, Garden City, Thursday 7-9PM and Friday 2-4 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian burial St. Thomas the Apostle Church, West Hempstead, 10AM Saturday. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-22

title: DAEWOO RESCUE PLAN NEXT WEEK
description: South Korea's chief presidential economic adviser, Lee Ki Ho, said that the Government would announce a detailed plan to deal with the liquidity crisis at the Daewoo Group about the middle of next week. He said that the policy on the Daewoo crisis would focus on how to share the losses. Mr. Lee added that by the end of this year, the Government would finish its corporate sector reorganization and would then concentrate on improving the structure of corporate governance in the nation's nonbanking financial sector.

title: Metro Business; Shopping Center In Harlem Approved
description: A proposal to build a $160 million shopping center in East Harlem to be anchored by Home Depot and Costco superstores cleared its final hurdle yesterday when the City Council approved it by a vote of 44 to 0.

title: Orders for Durable Goods Slipped 1.3% in September
description: Durable goods orders fell in September for the first time in five months as the Boeing Company booked fewer orders for its most expensive airliners and Hurricane Floyd caused some factories to close, Government figures showed today.

title: A Central Asian Land Where Lenin Has Not Been Toppled
description: For many years, when this Central Asian capital was called Frunze, the busiest place on Frunze Avenue was the Mikhail Vasilyevich Frunze Museum.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Calling at Random
description: To the Editor:

title: Steaming Up In Spa Style
description: Halloween in the bathroom? Teledyne Water Pik's new Misting Massage shower head looks like the mask of a ''Star Wars'' storm trooper. Remain calm: this gizmo is harmless. In a chrome, white or shiny brass finish, ranging in price from $47 to $56, it comes with 21 nozzles and as many as seven spray settings that have poetic names like Bay Shore, Monsoon and Sea Foam. (The latter claims to be an ''aerated bubble spray and lather enhancer.'') The Misting Spray setting produces a uniquely thick, Seattle-like fog that closely replicates a spa experience. A new version, to be released in January, will marry the shower head with a flexible gooseneck attachment. For dealer locations: www.waterpik.com or (800) 525-2774.

title: Speeding Up the Fiber-Optic Highway
description: IN the race for greater bandwidth and faster Internet access, fiber-optic lines have been hailed as the ultimate speedway, able to transmit information at virtually the speed of light.

title: Dreamworks in Distribution Deal With a British Animation Studio
description: Dreamworks SKG said today that it had entered into an exclusive long-term affiliation with Aardman Animations, the British studio best known for its series of stop-motion clay animation shorts starring the cheese-loving Wallace and his long-suffering dog, Gromit.

title: Yank Fans Get What They Expected, Yet Again
description: This is not to say that there was a distinct lack of suspense in the 1999 World Series, but at the Carriage House, a sports bar on Seventh Avenue in Park Slope, Brooklyn, Jeff Barr lighted his victory cigar at 8:45 P.M.

title: Shows, Sales and Talks
description: Looking at Places

title: Egg Auction On Internet Is Drawing High Scrutiny
description: Days after a new Web site auctioning models' services as egg donors made a wide-ranging publicity splash, some are questioning whether the auction is for real, or just a ploy to attract Internet traffic.

title: Hooked on Latin
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. and Russia Agree on Joint Defense Against Y2K Debacles
description: Russia and the United States have agreed on the final details for a special command post in Colorado to insure that potential Year 2000 computer glitches in either nation's missile warning systems do not lead to an accidental launching of a nuclear warhead.

title: Rivera Closes Out The Perfect Ending
description: When another situation turned tense for the Yankees last night, Joe Torre did what he has done all season. The manager summoned Mariano Rivera, he stayed calm in the dugout and he waited for Rivera to throttle the Braves and help the Yankees soar to another World Series title. Been there, done that.

title: Marilyn Monroe Auction Is an Icon's Best Friend
description: With deep-pocketed bidders competing to outspend one another, the carefully preserved baubles of Marilyn Monroe were sold last night, including the show-stopping dress that she was wearing when she sashayed into Madison Square Garden and sang ''Happy Birthday'' to President Kennedy in 1962.

title: Braves Proud of Overcoming All but Yanks
description: The fans had mocked the team's war chant, and Queen was warbling ''We Are the Champions'' when Atlanta's John Rocker turned into the clubhouse as the Yankees celebrated their world championship on the field at Yankee Stadium last night.

title: COPPER MINING PLAN
description: The world's biggest mining company, Anglo American P.L.C., agreed to spend almost $1 billion to buy and develop state-owned Zambian copper mines that may become the third-largest copper producer in the world. Anglo's Zambia Copper Investments Ltd. unit plans to buy an 80 percent stake in the mines and refineries for as much as $215 million and to invest as much as another $731 million. The project is part of the plan of Anglo's chairman, Julian Ogilvie Thompson, to build an industrial metals division.

title: Linda Pezzano, 54, Marketer Who Aided 'Trivial Pursuit'
description: Linda F. Pezzano, a marketing consultant who helped what once was an obscure Canadian board game, Trivial Pursuit, achieve sales totaling more than $1 billion, died Tuesday at a hospice in Manhattan. She was 54.

title: Prime Minister and Others Slain in Armenian Siege
description: Gunmen proclaiming a coup d'etat stormed the Parliament in Armenia's capital city of Yerevan this evening, killing the nation's Prime Minister, Parliament Speaker and other officials before claiming to seize about 50 hostages.

title: Amazon Says Its Losses May Grow Next Quarter
description: Amazon.com, by far the biggest merchant on the Internet, reported yesterday that its losses in the third quarter were slightly less than analysts had expected. But the company also warned that it expected to lose far more than it had previously indicated in the fourth quarter, as it tripled its spending on marketing and advertising to compete vigorously this Christmas.

title: Kittles and Williams Back on the Court
description: Kerry Kittles scrimmaged yesterday with his Nets teammates for the first time since undergoing arthroscopic surgery on his right knee in May, and Jayson Williams, also recovering from right knee surgery as well as a broken right leg, played for the first time since his knee operation on Sept. 14.

title: Few Thrills As Devils Hold On At Home
description: he Devils were hardly at their best tonight, but they accomplished what they wanted, a 2-1 victory over the St. Louis Blues in a game at Continental Arena where the announced crowd of 13,347 seemed to be more interested in the baseball game in the Bronx.

title: Pushpin Style Aims for the Imperfect
description: WERE it not largely obscured by a privet hedge, Gary Guerrette's three-bedroom bungalow might cause a neighborhood revolt. But in low-key Water Mill, N.Y. -- where picturesque dilapidation can be a badge of honor -- the rippling asphalt-shingle roof, buckling wood steps and architectural malaise pass without remark.

title: Tranghese Seeks Better Marketing
description: Mike Tranghese, the Big East Conference commissioner, criticized the National Collegiate Athletic Association yesterday for not marketing basketball properly.

title: Swiss Voters Tilt Right, Unsettling Political and Social Traditions
description: Outwardly, the strong gains posted by fervent nationalists in Switzerland's weekend elections were about refugees and the country's place in Europe. But the voting was also very much about Swiss identity, shaped by the recent furor over Switzerland's role in World War II and its uncertainty over what path to take in the future.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about a Ku Klux Klan rally in Manhattan misspelled the surname of the group's grand dragon in some copies. He is James W. Sheeley, not Sheely.

title: A Cute Little Tank Adds Insult to Injury
description: PICTURE the brain of a high school sophomore in the body of a military assault vehicle, and you have Tiny Tank. The hero of a Playstation game by the same name, Tiny is the flagship product of Sentrax, a military contractor in this fictional world. The company thought Tiny would be a good public relations tactic -- something cute and approachable to sell a robot defense program to the American public.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOOM, GUSTAVE
description: BLOOM-Gustave. Of Bronx, NY, on October 26, 1999. Beloved husband of Molly, devoted father of Stanley Bloom and Doris Lindauer. Loving grandfather of Jennifer and Stephanie. Services from Wien & Wien, 129 Engle St, Englewood NJ today at 10AM. Contributions to Children's Heart Fund at New York Presbyterian Hospital would be appreciated.

description: Roger Clemens earned his ring, not personal post-season redemption, last night at Yankee Stadium. It was too late to annul 1986, or other past failures, if that's what he'd come here to do.

description: PARIS  Call it the "restless money theory." In the decorous world of private banking, where introductions, connections, relationships and image have traditionally been the formula for success, executives are increasingly concerned about the issue of client loyalty.

description: THERE's good news for the mechanically challenged host.

title: Seeking New State Laws for Farm Workers
description: They are often forced to work seven days a week, and they are sometimes paid just $210 for their 80-hour weeks. Some of them get fired when they ask for a raise, and many of them are assigned housing with broken toilets, no heat or little hot water.

description: The opening of the 1,000th McDonald's restaurant in Germany this month was supposed to be a festive occasion, a moment to toast German-American friendship. Instead, it illustrated the growing strains in this pivotal relationship.

description: Our Constitution, envy of the world, is made of currency too valuable to be spent reinforcing preconceived conclusions.

title: Ukraine's Election Seems Rigged to Favor Sitting President
description: Ukraine, which often boasts of being the first post-Soviet society to freely elect a President, looks poised to re-elect one. This time, however, don't expect much bragging.

Husband of the late Sally Ann; father of Victoria Oliva of Cambridge, MA, Thomas of Elkins Park, PA., & Edward of Medford, NJ; brother of Peter of Lawrenceville, NJ; also three grandchildren. Memorial service Saturday, October 30 at St. Peter's Episcopal Church, South St & Miller Rd, Morristown, NJ at 11 A.M. Donations to CPR Education, C/O Gill St. Bernard's School, St. Bernard's Road Gladstone, NJ 07934. For information contact the Doyle Funeral Home, 973-539-0622.

title: M.T.A. Shortchanged Itself In Reuters Deal, Report Says
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority should have demanded as much as $4.6 million more from a Times Square developer last year when it allowed him to scale back the size of an entrance to the busiest subway station in the country, according to a report by the authority's inspector general.

title: Digital Video Camera Is Freed Of Its Tether to the PC
description: Cams -- tech slang for tiny video cameras for personal computers -- have been popping up in all sorts of shapes and styles. The latest, Video Blaster Webcam Go, is the first to free itself from its wired connection to the PC.

title: Clashes in Bethlehem Cast Shadow on Millennium Plans
description: Street battles engulfed the entrance to Bethlehem today for the third day in a row, casting a shadow over preparations for millennium celebrations in the town revered as the birthplace of Jesus.

title: On Opening Day, A Triumph for Adonis
description: Aqueduct opened for its 40th season yesterday with a new $4 million paddock and other improvements for winter racing, and with memories of the days when titans of the track -- such as Kelso, Forego and Secretariat -- ran memorable races there.

title: FCB Executive To Join Y.& R.
description: Ron Bess, a longtime Chicago agency executive, said yesterday that he would leave FCB Worldwide there, where he had been president, to join Young & Rubicam Inc. in New York as chairman and chief executive of the Diversified Communications Group.

title: Bookmarks/Sustained by Classics : German Publisher Guards A Legacy of Independence
description: FRANKFURT  Suhrkamp Verlag, one of Germany's most prestigious literary publishing houses, is preparing to mark a half-century of closely guarded independence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORZACK, MOLLIE (MILLIE)
description: ORZACK-Mollie (Millie). Beloved wife of Sidney of Bradenton, FL. Died on Tuesday, October 26th. Beloved mother of Leonard and Sharon Lafer, stepmother of Sandi Berman, grandchildren and great grandchildren. Interment at the Riverside - Boulevard Chapel, Broadway, Hewlett, NY, Thursday, at 1:30 PM. We shall miss this gentle, kind, wonderful lady.

title: Hewlett-Packard's Shares Fall 12 Percent
description: Shares in the Hewlett-Packard Company fell more than 12 percent today after analysts suggested there would be an earnings shortfall in the fourth quarter, which ends this month.

title: Cashman Stays Silent About Future
description: The general manager of the team that would go on to win a second straight World Series walked through a mall in Boston about two weeks ago, looking like someone who had just lost the job he desired all of his life. Brian Cashman had heavy bags under his eyes, his last authentic smile was one month old and he was trying to invigorate his day by buying a toy for his 1-year-old daughter.

description: To the Editor:

title: HOUSE BACKS BAN ON USING MEDICINE TO AID IN SUICIDE
description: Alarmed by an Oregon law allowing physician-assisted suicide, the House of Representatives today passed a bill that would make it a Federal crime for doctors to prescribe drugs to help terminally ill patients end their lives.

title: Police Look Into Business Dealings of 2 Slain Stock Promoters
description: The two partners in an Internet stock promotion operation who were found shot to death on Tuesday inside a mansion here were linked to ''shady'' business dealings and may have been killed to be silenced, the Monmouth County Prosecutor said today.

title: No Snubs For Gray, But Issue Lingers
description: No one snubbed Jim Gray last night.

description: A picture caption in Business Day on Monday with a report in the Media Talk column about the television wrestling show ''Smackdown'' misspelled the name of the wrestler shown. He was Paul Wight, not Wright.

title: Guild.com Awards Its First Account
description: Guild.com in Madison, Wis., an electronic commerce company selling arts and crafts products, has awarded its first account to Publicis & Hal Riney in San Francisco, part of Publicis S.A. Billings were estimated at $15 million.

title: Sending the Boys Off To Meet Their Fate
description: THE VOYAGE

title: Rangers Need Assist In Finding The Goal
description: The Rangers went back to work today, skating for the first time since last Sunday's game at Madison Square Garden, where they were left disgraced and disgusted after their third straight shutout loss.

title: A Threat Mostly to Ourselves
description: The Senate's failure to ratify the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty set off a contentious debate on American leadership and led President Clinton to decry a ''new isolationism'' in the Republican majority. However, this is purely a discussion of political preferences rather than a debate affecting our basic and intrinsic security.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Indonesia and Australia Act to Ease Timor Strains
description: SINGAPORE  Indonesia and Australia are taking steps to ease bilateral tensions, a move that should help reduce chances of a serious armed conflict in East Timor and hasten the entry of United Nations peacekeepers, UN and Australian officials said Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANER, HERBERT
description: DANER-Herbert, of Rego Park. Beloved husband of Lillian. Devoted father of Penelope Daner. Services Thursday. For information: ''Wien & Wien'', 1-800-322-0533.

title: Springsteen's Hometown, Then and Now
description: To the Editor:

title: Different Sides of Poulenc, Master of the Potpourri
description: Saturday night's concert by the Eos Orchestra at the 92d Street Y was devoted to the music of Poulenc, whose strengths and weaknesses as a master of the potpourri were put on show in the two longer works played: the Piano Concerto of 1950 and the Double Piano Concerto of 1932, pieces that could hardly be more different (given the composer's range), close as they are in genre.

title: Where Sensuality and Solidarity Meet
description: Melissa Etheridge let a fan touch her hair Tuesday night at the Theater at Madison Square Garden. She crouched at the edge of the stage and bent her head, just for a moment, toward the reaching throng. It wasn't a calculated move, but it was incredibly intimate, showing just how far Ms. Etheridge would go in the moment of musical connection.

title: Soaked in Victory, Steinbrenner Savors It All Again
description: Down the corridor strode the Boss with knots of backslappers, arm-huggers and air kissers in his wake. This was after George Steinbrenner's Yankees clinched the fifth World Series championship of his 27-year reign. This was the owner's personal victory parade through his personal canyon of heroes, backstage in his big stadium.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''This is a patriotic action. This shake-up is needed for the nation to regain its senses.''

title: Intertrust's Stock Soars in Trading Debut
description: In a session at which investors seemed eager to pour money into new technology issues, shares in the Intertrust Technologies Corporation tripled their offering price in trading yesterday.

title: This Word 'Relationship'
description: To the Editor:

title: LENNOX TO ACQUIRE SERVICE EXPERTS FOR $157 MILLION
description: The climate-control company Lennox International Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to purchase Service Experts Inc. for stock valued at $157 million. Service Experts, based in Nashville, provides heating, ventilation and air-conditioning services and replacement equipment. In the transaction, Service Experts stockholders will exchange each of their shares for 0.67 Lennox shares. Lennox, based in Richardson, Tex., makes and sells products for the heating, ventilation, air-conditioning and refrigeration markets. Shares of Lennox fell 24 percent, dropping $3.25 each, to $10, and Service Experts dropped 20 percent, or $1.5625 a share, to $6.

title: Plan Would Abolish Sheriffs' Offices and Move Duties to Courts
description: The office of county sheriff would be abolished and the sheriffs' duties taken over by the state's judicial branch under a proposal offered today by the co-chairmen of the State Legislature's judiciary committee.

title: Father's Suit Dismissed In Accidental Death
description: A State Superior Court judge dismissed a wrongful death suit on Monday that was filed against a Franklin jeweler who accidentally shot his wife during a 1995 robbery.

title: Leyritz Lets 'Er Rip, Again, in October
description: Jim Leyritz was added to the Yankees' post-season roster based, in large part, on his tremendous history as a power hitter in October.

title: Pinball Line Closing Down
description: FOR dedicated pinball players, there is only one ball left in play. On Monday, WMS Industries, one of two remaining pinball game manufacturers, announced that its pinball division would close, a victim of Lara Croft and a corporate bottom line.

title: Steinberg Sells Sports Firm
description: Leigh Steinberg, the agent whose client list includes the quarterbacks Steve Young, Troy Aikman and Drew Bledsoe, sold his firm yesterday for $120 million in cash and stock to Assante Corporation, a Canadian money management firm.

title: NAVISTAR TO REPURCHASE $243 MILLION IN COMMON SHARES
description: The Navistar International Corporation said yesterday that it planned to repurchase up to $243 million in common shares on the open market. The company seeks to repurchase up to 9.3 percent of its 63.6 million shares outstanding. The shares are currently valued at $2.6 billion. The stock rose $1 a share, to $41.875. The Chicago-based company, which produces heavy and medium trucks, school buses and diesel engines, posted revenue of $8.3 billion in the last 12 months.

title: A Cruel Plan for the Homeless
description: To the Editor:

title: Islanders Come Up Short, but Not in Effort
description: It is not easy to find the upside in a 6-3 loss, but Coach Butch Goring of the Islanders tried hard to accentuate the positives after his team was beaten tonight by the Florida Panthers.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BLANKENSHIP, KIM
description: BLANKENSHIP-Kim. Tell Saint Peter you were in the New York Times. We love you, T & M
