description: GOODNER-Kathleen W. Born in Ireland, of Bronxville, N.Y., on October 27, 1999. Wife of John T. Goodner, MD. Mother of MaryLou Resciniti and John McAllister Goodner. Grandmother of Alex Resciniti. Also surviving are her brothers and sisters in England & Ireland and Father Leo McAllister of Sacramento, California. Mass of Christian Burial Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to your favorite charity.

title: Race for Council Heats Up In Staten Island Rematch
description: Their first contest was a nonpartisan special election this year for a City Council seat on Staten Island. But now the heated rematch between City Councilman James S. Oddo and his Democratic challenger, John N. Sollazzo, has become a highly partisan affair.

title: Portuguese Recall Wartime Tales of Aid to Their Neighbors
description: The long line of people, film extras portraying refugees from the Spanish Civil War, filed into the 17th-century square of this Portuguese village of whitewashed houses and secrets kept for six decades.

title: Defending the Stone
description: To the Editor:

title: More Debate, but No Immediate Changes, Are Expected After Ruling on Abortion
description: Some called it ''chilling'' and ''contradictory.'' Others called it ''well reasoned'' and ''remarkable.'' But no one affected by Tuesday's Federal appeals court decision upholding the criminalization of a rare late-term abortion procedure was predicting instant change in Wisconsin or Illinois, the states involved.

title: Former Top Editor at St. Martin's Takes Job With Talk Magazine
description: Robert B. Wallace, the former editor in chief of St. Martin's Press who resigned abruptly two days ago, has a new job. After a breakfast-time wooing yesterday morning by Tina Brown, the editor in chief of Talk Magazine, Mr. Wallace, a veteran of both ABC News and Rolling Stone magazine, decided to join Talk as editorial director.

title: Study Says New TB Strains Need an Intensive Strategy
description: International health officials and scientific experts say that strains of tuberculosis resistant to various drugs are spreading faster than anticipated overseas and that a new treatment strategy is needed to prevent what has already become an epidemic from spinning out of control.

title: Teen-Age Birth Rate
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSEN, CHARLES AXEL
description: JOHNSEN-Charles Axel. Died at the age of 82, on October 26, 1999. Beloved husband of Julia. Loving father of Robert and Alfred. Cherished father-in-law of Joan and Christine. Loving grandfather of Katharine, Michael, Erika and Gregory. Fond brother of Mildred Cantwell. He served in the 82nd Airborne Division of the U.S. Army during World War II. An employee at The New York Times, he retired in 1979. Visitation at Hanley Funeral Home, 60 New Dorp Lane, Staten Island, New York, on Friday, October 29th at 9:30 A.M., with a funeral service following at 10:30 AM. Interment is to follow at Moravian Cemetery, Staten Island.

title: 13 Districts Pursue New Jersey School-Choice Plan
description: Thirteen New Jersey school districts have applied to be among 10 to be chosen for the first year of a three-year school choice pilot program, in which they would open their doors to students from other districts.

title: Live From Las Vegas, A Concert on the Internet
description: As the Internet grows, bigger stunts are needed to attract attention. It's hard to imagine what will top the on-line iBash that the new streaming video company, Pixelon, will stage this weekend. The company plans to call attention to its new ability to send full-screen, live pictures over the Internet by giving a party in Las Vegas, hiring acts like the Who, the Dixie Chicks and Faith Hill and broadcasting their performances live. The show begins at 2:30 P.M. on Friday, Pacific standard time, and ends at midnight.

title: They're Bigger. But Better?
description: It is my intention to inveigh against what seems to be the gradual (continuing?) publishing practice of making books that are so fat and windy that they sit, with some exceptions, like hefty neglected lumps on the shelves waiting for the first clever marketer to include a backpack with their purchase. In a world where everything else, excepting movies, is getting leaner and faster and miniaturized, there is little question that books appear to be going in the other direction. Perhaps it's just perception, and therefore unfair, but look at that bookcase in front of you and you'll sense that the pursuit of knowledge, information and pleasure that are the occasions for reading has become looming.

title: Toward Zero Population
description: To the Editor:

title: BROWSER
description: An eclectic collection of events and sites on the Web.

title: Those Dark Corners of the Web: Sites for Horror and the Occult
description: HALLOWEEN is a holiday with ancient roots that span many cultures. The modern observance is thought to be a mixture of influences from the Celtic festival of Samhain, Pomona Day in ancient Rome and the Christian holidays of All Saints' and All Soul's Days. In tune with its varied ancestry, Halloween sites on the Web range from serious to silly.

title: Making It Easy to Put TV Signals on Your Computer
description: TV cards, which let you watch television on your computer monitor, have been slow to gain popularity. Cable hook-ups and antennas are often not conveniently located near computers, and some people don't like the distraction of a television running in a window on their monitor while they're trying to work.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RODIN, BERNARD M.
description: RODIN-Bernard M. The Chwatt family mourns the untimely passing of our longtime friend and business associate. We will all miss his clever anecdotes, warm smile, brilliant business mind, and tremendous sense of humor and wit. Our deepest sympathy to his wife, Fran, and his entire family. He will be sorely missed by us all.

title: Variable-Price Coke Machine Being Tested
description: Taking full advantage of the law of supply and demand, the Coca-Cola Company has quietly begun testing a vending machine that can automatically raise prices for its drinks in hot weather.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MIRKIN, MELVIN
description: MIRKIN-Melvin, died October 23, at age 75, in Las Vegas. Husband of Claire. Father of Judi and Lisa and father-in-law of Steven and Bruce. Loving grandfather of Joshua and Niko, Scott, April and Benjamin. Brother of Allan and Vera. Services were in Las Vegas.

title: Excerpts From Comments by Gore and Bradley at Candidates' Forum at Dartmouth
description: Following are excerpts from a candidates' forum involving Vice President Al Gore and former Senator Bill Bradley last night at Dartmouth College, in Hanover, N.H., as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency.

title: Six Innovators to Be Honored
description: SIX visionaries will be lugging weighty chunks of the here-and-now home as the latest winners of the Daimler Chrysler Design Awards. The awards, menu-shaped slabs of cast tombasil, a copper alloy similar to white bronze, weighing in at more than 15 pounds each, will be presented in a ceremony tonight at the Four Seasons restaurant in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LISMAN, RUTH ELLIOTT
description: LISMAN-Ruth Elliott. On October 26, 1999. Beloved wife of Bruce. Loving mother of Kate and Maggie. Devoted daughter of Eleanor and the late Allen. Cherished sister of Jeff. Dear daughter-in-law of Lily and Irving. We loved her and will miss her. Service Thursday, 1:45PM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in her memory to the Breast Cancer Research Foundation, 767 5th Ave., NY NY 10153, Attn: Pamela J. Harrington.

title: Bold Bidding, Elegance At the End
description: In one common bidding situation, the experts take action on hands that traditional textbooks would recommend passing. It occurs when a player with opening values is faced by an opening bid on his right and has no clear-cut action. In such circumstances, an overcall in a respectable four-card suit is nowadays considered acceptable, even if vulnerable.

title: Caymans Launch Campaign to Redress 'Tainted' Image
description: IT HAS been a nasty hurricane season in the Caribbean. Meteorologists are already halfway through their alphabetical list of names, and there is still a month to go. But the weather, say Cayman Islands' private bankers, is the least of their problems.

title: A Day in the Life of a Trade Diplomat
description: While his driver is weaving through traffic to get him to the office, Iftekhar Chowdhury's day begins, as nearly all do, trying to insure that the economically struggling Bangladesh partakes in the fruits of globalization.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLY, MARY LOU
description: KELLY-Mary Lou. On October 26, 1999. In deep faith and enduring hope, cherished wife of James R., loving mother of James F., solicitous sister of Reverend James N. Loughran, S.J. and the late John F. Jr., precious daughter of the late John F. and Ethel Loughran. Typically, rather than the flowers that gave her such delight, Mary Lou requested that donations be sent to St. Peter's (Jersey City) or Mount St. Vincent's Colleges (Riverdale), where the spirits of Sts. Ignatius and Elizabeth Seton, which first formed and then sustained her, permeate the pursuit of truth. With the insight that loyal friendship brings, her colleagues at P.S. 105, where Mary taught for over thirty years, on the occasion of her necessary but too-early retirment wrote, Blessed they with peaceful spirits. Blessed they with gentle hearts. Visitation is on Wednesday and Thursday 2-5 PM and 7-9PM at McLaughlin & Son's Funeral Home Inc., 9620 3rd Ave., Brooklyn. Mass of Christian burial is Friday 9:30 A.M., Our Lady of Angel's Church, Bklyn. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery, Brooklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTFRIEND, MOSES
description: GOTTFRIEND-Moses. Age 78. In New York City on October 26, 1999, at home. Cherished father of Caroline and David Gabay. Beloved grandfather of Rebecca Batya Gabay and Hannah Berucha Gabay. Services Thursday 12 Noon at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Hineni Heritage Center, New York, N.Y. or Young Israel of Harrison, N.Y. would be appreciated.

title: Los Angeles Times Staff Protests Magazine Deal
description: Senior editors at The Los Angeles Times met with the publisher yesterday and expressed a sense ''of betrayal'' after the disclosure that the newspaper shared profits from a special magazine section with the subject of the section, the Staples Center sports arena, according to a staff member at the meeting.

title: Thriving on the Keyboard
description: To the Editor:

title: West, a Rookie, to Start As Giants' Free Safety
description: Two months ago, he was very nearly cut by the Giants. Six months ago, he was their sixth-round draft choice, a selection that caused great bewilderment. And 12 months ago, he was getting ready to play the University of Utah, a game his San Jose State team would lose, 49-17.

title: Whetting a Child's Imagination
description: IMAGYNASIUM

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a study of school choice programs in Michigan misstated the affiliation of the authors. They are professors at Michigan State University, not the University of Michigan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHIFFER, SYLVIA NEBELKOPF
description: SCHIFFER-Sylvia Nebelkopf, 85, on Oct. 26. Courageous & devoted mother of E. Harold (Lynn), grandmother of Elana and Daniel. Wife of the late Jacob ''Jack''. Aunt and great aunt. Graduate of PS 47 School for the Deaf, New York City Class of 1928, Sylvia was an excellent lip reader and was chosen to represent PS 47 at the White House upon graduation honoring Mrs. Grace Anna Goodhue Coolidge, teacher of the deaf.

title: Olerud Ready to Test Free-Agent Market
description: John Olerud wants to explore free agency and will not come to terms with the Mets during the coming 15 days in which they have exclusive rights to negotiate with him, the first baseman's agent said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZARIN, NATHAN
description: ZARIN-Nathan. Age 81. Died October 25, 1999. Brother of Elsie Zarin Goll, the late Anna Kahn and the late Herman Zarin, devoted uncle. Graveside services Thursday 2:00 P.M. at Beth Moses Cemetery, Farmingdale, L.I., N.Y.

title: Going Victorian
description: High-end fabrics are introduced to the trade the same way as high-concept couture. ''We're trying to set a tone or capture the imagination,'' said Donna Woods, the design director for Scalamandre. Above are Havana, left, and Bon Oeuf, two quirky Italian prints that are part of Scalamandre's fall collection. Rather than go futuristic, Ms. Woods got Victorian. She was inspired by 19th-century hobbies like egg collecting and decoupage. Havana's cigar band pattern was taken from a decoupage glass bowl she found in a flea market. It and the polka-dot eggs sell for about $120 a yard. Scalamandre, (212) 980-3888.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASHLEY, JACK
description: ASHLEY-Jack. Beloved husband of the late Stella. Devoted father of Perry and Sheilah, and Larry. Adored grandfather of Jonathan, Susan, Melissa, Jennifer, Daniel, Alyssa and Mike. Most proud Great Grandpa Jack to Alec, Zachary and Kayla. 90 years was not long enough. Service Thursday, 11:30AM at ''Riverside Memorial Chapel'', 21 West Broad St, Mount Vernon. Interment private.

title: EXODUS COMMUNICATIONS AGREES TO BUY SERVICE METRICS
description: Exodus Communications Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Service Metrics Inc. for $280 million in stock to monitor better the performance of Web sites run through its data centers. Service Metrics, based in Boulder, Colo., will become a subsidiary of Exodus. Exodus, which has data centers that run Internet sites for large companies, will add Service Metrics' 60 employees to its 1,200 employees. Exodus, based in Santa Clara, Calif., has benefited as more organizations run their Web sites from so-called server farms, where computers are stored and maintained by companies like Exodus.

title: L. C. D. Dashboard: A Chameleon
description: INFORMATION overload is never good. At the wheel of a car, it can be downright hazardous.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARLETON, ROBERT O.
description: CARLETON-Robert O., Died Wednesday, October 27, 1999. Beloved husband of Zaida. Cherished father of Paul. Graduate of Harvard University, Columbia University and the New School of Research. Retired from the United Nations. Highly decorated WWII Army Veteran. Funeral service Saturday, 11:30AM, Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 Street. Visiting Friday 2-5 and 7-9PM. Memorial service at a later date.

title: Brazil Duns MCI for Taxes Of Unit While State-Owned
description: In a clash that is heightening concern over Brazil's treatment of foreign investors, the Government is seeking to get hundreds of millions of dollars of back taxes and fines from the Brazilian unit of MCI Worldcom.

title: SWEDISH BUS COMPANY SOLD
description: The British transportation company Stagecoach Holdings P.L.C. said it had agreed to sell Swebus to Concordia Bus Sweden A.B., a unit of the Norwegian investment company Schoyen Gruppen A.S., for $165 million. Schoyen, backed by a private equity fund affiliated with the New York investment bank Goldman, Sachs, will also assume Swebus's debt of about $171 million.

title: Gerald Trautman, 87, Ex-Chief And Avid Builder of Greyhound
description: Gerald H. Trautman, a retired chairman, president and chief executive of the Greyhound Corporation, died Monday at a hospital in Phoenix, where he lived. He was 87.

title: U.S. to Aid Iraqi Opposition To Develop a Military Cadre
description: The Administration has authorized the first direct military training for opponents of President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, senior officials said today.

title: Andras Hegedus, 76, Hungarian Prime Minister Turned Dissident
description: Andras Hegedus, a former Prime Minister of Hungary whose political odyssey transformed him from a dogmatic Stalinist apparatchik into an outspoken -- and barely tolerated -- dissenter, died on Saturday. He was 76.

title: Helms Orders 10 Women From House Out of a Senate Hearing
description: Senator Jesse Helms, the hard-nosed chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, ordered Capitol police officers today to remove 10 female House members from a Senate hearing after he said they were disrupting the meeting by trying to present him with a letter supporting an international treaty against the discrimination against women.

title: Tennessee Report Says Rules Weren't Violated
description: The president of the University of Tennessee, J. Wade Gilley, said yesterday that the school's general counsel's office had not found any ''kind of systemic, unwarranted or tutorial help'' in the school's athletic department and said that none of its student athletes violated National Collegiate Athletic Association rules.

title: Supreme Court to Review Use of Electric Chair
description: Prompted by several flawed executions in Florida's electric chair, the United States Supreme Court has agreed to review for the first time whether electrocution violates the Constitution. By taking the case, legal scholars said yesterday, the Court will inevitably refresh its definition of cruel and unusual punishment.

title: Man Behind Immigration Signs Admits He Hired Illegal Workers
description: A man who caused a furor with billboards calling for an end to immigration admitted yesterday that he had employed illegal immigrants at an East Village burrito restaurant that he partly owned until earlier this year.

title: Despite Stronger Yen, Sony Posts Profit of $445 Million in Quarter
description: The stronger yen delivered a punch to the Sony Corporation but the blow was less severe than it might have been, thanks to strong sales of personal computers and digital cameras.

title: WARNING ON ISOLATIONISM
description: In a speech scheduled for delivery today, Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers plans to expand the White House's argument that Congress is turning isolationist, saying that cuts in support to the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund and other institutions amount to ''the malign neglect of our global standing.'' In an advance text of the speech, Mr. Summers says, ''It is a striking irony of this time that the economy that has gained most from rising global integration and cooperation seems to need ever-greater assurance that these things are in its interest.''

title: Leonard E. Boyle Dies at 75; Modernized Vatican Library
description: The Rev. Leonard E. Boyle, the former keeper of manuscripts and chief librarian of the Vatican Library, who was dismissed from his post in 1997, died on Monday in Rome. He was 75.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABERMAN, ARTHUR A.
description: ABERMAN-Arthur A. On October 26, 1999. Devoted husband of Blanche. Loving father of Arlyne and Susan. Educator, philanthropist and good friend to many. Graveside service 11AM Thursday, New Montifiore Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARTUR, M.
description: WARTUR-M. Harry, 92, on October 27, in Queens, NY. Beloved husband of the late Bertha Stern Wartur, loving father of C. Lawrence Wartur & Susan W. Wolfson. Grandfather of Lisa Wartur Cohen, Ellen Paula Wolfson, Roger Samuel Wolfson. Funeral Service at Parkside Memorial Chapel, Queens Blvd, Rego Park, New York at 11AM, October 29, 1999. He leaves many glorious memories

title: Defending the Stone
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about AT&T's third-quarter earnings misstated the recent performance of its consumer long-distance telephone unit. While its revenue has declined, profit margins have increased recently, not fallen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLLINS, HUGH GAWTRY
description: COLLINS-Hugh Gawtry formerly of Millbrook, NY died at Bloomfield, CT Oct 24, 1999, age 94. He is survived by his wife of 68 years, Frances Fisher Collins, his daughter, Anne Flagler Collins, M.D., and sons, Dennis Gawtry Collins, Farnham Fisher Collins, and Anthony Philip Collins, seven grandchildren, and eleven great grandchildren. Services will be held at Grace Episcopal Church, Millbrook, NY Friday, October 29 at 11 AM.

title: Parcells Is Leaning To Lucas Again
description: The Jets returned to practice for the first time during this bye week, with Ray Lucas warming up for his likely return as the starter. That would happen Nov. 7 at the Meadowlands against the Arizona Cardinals.

title: Asians Hedge Bets On U.S. Currency
description: KUALA LUMPUR  The U.S. dollar has long been the currency of choice for Asia's mega-rich. But these days, private bankers say their clients are casting a slightly more skeptical eye on the U.S. currency, nervous about the future direction of U.S. interest rates and the overall sustainability of the continued American economic expansion.

title: GORE AND BRADLEY MOSTLY IN CONCERT ON ARRAY OF ISSUES
description: Vice President Al Gore, in his first televised encounter with former Senator Bill Bradley, pointedly but gently pressed his rival tonight to defend what Mr. Gore called costly proposals that would ''shred the social safety net.''

title: America's World Role
description: To the Editor:

title: A Ceramist Who Confronted Nature
description: IT'S rare that pottery can give you a good scare, but Axel Salto's does. You think twice about touching it. It gives you goose bumps; it looks like goose bumps.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Cheaper Power to the People; In Germany, a Radical Deregulation Benefits Households
description: Until last month, Michael Loebl greeted his monthly electricity bill in much the same way as his taxes: too high, yet beyond his control.

title: Welfare Offices Break Law On Interpreters, U.S. Says
description: New York City and the two counties on Long Island have erected illegal barriers to securing public assistance benefits for people who do not speak English, according to an investigation by the Federal Government.

title: A Horn of Plenty For Opera in Detroit; How to Thrive in a Blue-Collar City
description: As an opera lover who sees several performances a month in Vienna and other European capitals, Astrid Eywo is used to occasionally sitting elbow to elbow with American tourists. But on Oct. 29 she will be the tourist, having flown here from Vienna for the opening of the Michigan Opera Theater's production of Jules Massenet's ''Werther.''

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about John Cardinal O'Connor's return to St. Patrick's Cathedral on Sunday to deliver a homily misstated the position held at the Vatican by Archbishop Jean Louis Tauran, who celebrated the Mass. He is the Secretary for Relations with States, not the assistant to the Secretary of State.

title: Paul O'Neill's Father Dies
description: Charles O'Neill, the father of Yankees right fielder Paul O'Neill, died early yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan of complications from heart disease. Mr. O'Neill, 79, a minor league ballplayer, had recently suffered several heart attacks. Article, SportsThursday, page D1.

title: Hot Dogs Are Examined After 2 Deaths
description: Food safety inspectors are exploring whether two recent deaths were caused by contaminated frankfurters that were produced at a Bronx processing plant, and the products have been recalled nationwide.

title: How Taxes Subsidize Clinton-Giuliani Senate Race
description: As Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani began taking questions at his daily news conference the other morning, Sunny Mindel, the City Hall press secretary, quietly passed a reporter a slip of paper suggesting a subject to raise. On the paper was a news article, but it had nothing to do with Mr. Giuliani or his administration. It was about upstate broadcast editors' complaints about Hillary Rodham Clinton's campaign for the Senate.

title: A Little Something for You, and for Humanity
description: I HOPE I am not the first person to tell you that you do not need a hemp linen pillow stuffed with buckwheat hulls. So what if it has a zipper for easy hull removal? Never mind that the photo on the Ethical Shopper home page made this $24 pillow look deeply comfortable (www.ethicalshopper.com).

title: 3 Learjet Cases Examined After Crash in South Dakota
description: Federal officials investigating the mysterious crash of a Learjet in South Dakota said they were scrutinizing three other Learjet crashes in which the passengers and pilots may have been incapacitated by a loss of oxygen.

title: Publicis Acquires Two Agencies
description: The Publicis unit of Publicis S.A. said yesterday that it had acquired two agencies in New York: Gramercy Group, specializing in direct marketing and sales promotion, and Lobsenz Stevens, specializing in public relations. Terms were not disclosed.

title: People Grow Old, Houses Grow Old. Both Can Adapt.
description: I NEVER thought, somehow, that the Rolling Stones would be the ones to sum up the experience of installing a new bathroom for our mother on the farm in Maryland.

title: Catch the Latin Fever
description: It's a South Miami restaurant inspired by a cigar box, a Cuban cigar box, and looking like a Greek temple. Southside Cafe is a new restaurant designed by Maritere Cabarrocas and Jorge and Luis Trelles, architects at the University of Miami, who are sometimes identified as magic realists. The outside of the bar is finished in mahogany. But inside, all the wood is humble pine, stained to match the mahogany. The Cuban-American architects hired a carpenter, who once turned baseball bats in Havana, to make the spindled room dividers. The architecture matches the food, a hybrid of Cuban, Caribbean and Mediterranean cooking. When the restaurant opened on Oct. 15, cigar smoke and Spanish filled the air as the Cuban-American community found a new hangout from which to dream about the future. Southside Cafe, 6901 Red Road; (305) 665-9051.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAMINER, PHYLLIS
description: KAMINER-Phyllis. Adored wife of Henry. Beloved mother of Martin and Ariel. Dear sister of Sandra Handel. Cherished daughter of the late Gladys and Max Wasserman. She was Founder and President of Instructional Systems, Inc. Passed away on October 27 after a prolonged illness. As a friend, a mentor, a philanthropist, a visionary leader and an invincible optimist, she will continue to inspire all who knew her. Services ''Wien & Wien,'' Hackensack, NJ, Friday, 10 AM (1-800-378-1892). Donations to the Online Scholarship Fund of The Jewish Theological Seminary would be appreciated.

title: The Yankees Win
description: Maturity in sports has many looks, but right now it looks like the New York Yankees, who won their 25th World Series last night against the Atlanta Braves. Clearly, the Yankees were able to dominate the Braves, whom they swept, but just as clearly they were able to dominate themselves and their own fortunes. Patience is a word that has been much used around the Yankees dugout this season, and what it means is a privileged manner of looking at baseball. What this team seems to see is not a game where one event cascades into another as the innings slip by, the past steadily commandeering the present. To this team baseball looks like a game of constant renewal, with each pitch, each batter, each defensive out.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUKASHOK, EVE
description: LUKASHOK-Eve. Eve was grace personified. All those who knew her will miss her. Eddy and Hannah Low

title: In America; The Long Dark Night
description: It was peculiar. The women kept pointing to their heads.

title: Oregon Considers Challenge
description: Elected officials in Oregon raised the possibility today that they would mount a constitutional challenge to any Federal measure that tried to overturn state law allowing physician-assisted suicide.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUM, ROBERT EDWARD
description: BLUM-Robert Edward, 100. Of Salisbury, CT, died at his home on October 22, 1999. Devoted husband of the late Ethel Halsey Blum. Survived by his son, John R.H. Blum and daughter-in-law, Jeanne C. Blum, and his daughter, Alice B. Yoakum and son-in-law, Robert H. Yoakum, all of Lakeville, CT; nine grandchildren and nineteen greatgrandchildren. Memorial service on Saturday, October 30, 11 AM, Salisbury Congregation Church. In lieu of flowers, contributions would be welcomed to Berkshire Taconic Community Foundation, P.O. Box 569, Salisbury, CT. 06068; or Maine Community Foundation, P.O. Box 148, Ellsworth, ME. 04605.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKEL, HERBERT JR.
description: FRANKEL-Herbert Jr. On October 26 at age 73. Loving husband of Rita Bordow Frankel and cherished father of Tracy and Thomas and daughter-in-law Lisa. Adoring Gramps of Jordan and Sarah. Dear brother of Dr. Saul. Service Thursday, 11:30 A.M., at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue (at 81 Street), New York City.

title: Dow and S.& P. Both Gain But Nasdaq Falls Slightly
description: After slumbering through much of the session, stocks sprang to life in the final hour yesterday to carry two of the major averages to solid gains.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BERG, MARC L. DR.
description: BERG-Marc L. Dr. Ten years has not diminished loving thoughts of you. Never will stop missing your poetic touch. Pearl, Steven, Joann and Families

title: Buchanan's New Home
description: To the Editor:

title: Why Praise Falwell?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Effort Of a Lifetime For Biographer And Subject
description: Norman Sherry, a deeply cultivated scholar of English literature, has been working for more than 20 years on a three-volume authorized biography of Graham Greene, and that otherwise happy fact leads to a melancholy observation. Mr. Sherry's first two volumes have been praised by critics. And yet it is close to a certainty that a relatively small number of people, including those who love Greene, will buy any of Mr. Sherry's eventual three volumes, and even fewer will read them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ESSELSTYN, THE REV. JUNE MITCHELL (MICKI) BINGHAM
description: ESSELSTYN-The Rev. June Mitchell (Micki) Bingham, 57, on October 27, at her home in Gainesville, FL, of a brain tumor. Wife of Erik C. Esselstyn for 32 years. Mother of June Eriksson (Jody) Esselstyn, RN, of New Haven, CT and Blakeman Bingham Esselstyn of Boston, MA. Daughter of June Bingham Birge of Riverdale, NY & the late Congressman Jonathan Bingham. Sister of Sherry Bingham Downes of Chestnut Hill, MA, Timothy W. Bingham, Esq. of New Haven, and Claudia Bingham Meyers of Great Falls, VA. Stepdaughter of Robert B. Birge of Riverdale. Micki Esselstyn attended Riverdale School and graduated from Rosemary Hall and Smith College. She received her Master of Social Work degree from Boston University, with practicum at the Boston Hebrew Home for the Aged, and many years later, her Master of Divinity degree from New York Theological Seminary. Ordained in the United Church of Christ, she held interim ministries, the most recent being at St. Andrew's Presbyterian Church in Jacksonville, FL. She was also Director of Art of Living Ministries, a counseling service for clergy. Her memorial service will be at the Church of the Redeemer, 185 Cold Spring St. in New Haven at 11 AM on Saturday, November 6 (203787-5711). Interment private. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Cross Creek Initiative, 117 NW 16th Ave., Gainesville, FL 32601.

title: Rally Ends 7-Day Slump In Treasuries
description: Prices of Treasury securities were up sharply for the first time in a week yesterday after the release of a weaker-than-expected report on durable goods orders for September.

title: Building the Borgs
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS CLIMBS. Natural gas jumped on expectations for a report of a lower-than-normal rise in United States inventories. In New York, natural gas for December delivery rose 7.5 cents, to $3.223 for a million B.T.U.'s.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Historical Figure Looks Like Herself

title: Cheaper Digital Camera Connects Directly to PC
description: UMAX, a company known for its scanners, is introducing a low-cost digital camera on Monday that borrows a feature from palm-size devices: linking to a PC with a single touch of a button. The camera, called Astracam, connects to a Windows-based computer through a cradle that is plugged into a U.S.B. port. Press a button on the cradle and images from Astracam's memory load onto the computer. The cradle also recharges the camera's two AAA batteries.

title: Enshrining Flawed Men
description: To the Editor:

title: Making It Easy to Find Where the Money Goes
description: GEORGE was first spotted in Bremerton, Wash. He attended an arts festival in Seattle, made his way to a coffee shop in Jackson Hole, Wyo., and was last seen in Salt Lake City.

title: Helping Heart That Recognizes No Borders
description: YOU can take your pick of heart-stopping stories to introduce Joelle Tanguy. This one takes place in Somalia, with the barrel of an AK-47 resting against her throat.

title: Robert Blum, 100, Businessman; Helped Develop Lincoln Center
description: Robert Edward Blum, a retired business executive and civic leader who was an early problem solver for Lincoln Center, died Friday at his home in Salisbury, Conn. He was 100.

title: On to Cooperstown?
description: With two World Series rings as the Yankee manager and another in his sights, Joe Torre was asked before Game 4 whether he was conscious of having a chance to be elected to baseball's Hall of Fame.

title: Abortion Rights in Peril
description: This week's federal appeals court decision upholding statutory bans on so-called partial birth abortion in Illinois and Wisconsin is a serious assault on the reproductive freedom guaranteed women under Roe v. Wade. The sharply divided 5-to-4 opinion by the Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit conflicts with the decision only last month by the Eighth Circuit Court of Appeals striking down similar bans in Nebraska, Arkansas and Iowa. Thus the stage seems to be set for a Supreme Court showdown on the roiling partial birth issue. Surely the nation's top court cannot stand aloof when an anti-abortion statute similar to one found unconstitutionally vague and burdensome in Iowa is narrowly upheld weeks later in neighboring Wisconsin, posing a threat to doctors of life imprisonment.

title: In a Gentle Kaleidoscope, Diversity Is the Star
description: Everything but the aardvark seems thrown into ''Paradis,'' a one-hour dance piece from France that ingeniously mixes onstage performers with astonishingly polished video images of humans and four-legged or slithery creatures. Children will love this delightful one-hour work, which runs through Sunday at the Joyce Theater.

title: Sprewell in No Hurry to Decide on Deal
description: Latrell Sprewell was on his way to Madison Square Garden last night, with a child in the front seat, another in the back and his brother in the rearview mirror.

title: Stewart Crash Stirs a Star Player's Emotions
description: Davis Love 3d lost his father in a plane crash 11 years ago. When Payne Stewart was killed in a plane crash Monday, it was a shock to everyone in the golf world, but for Love it stirred painful memories. It was the sudden loss of another person who had been dear to him, a Ryder Cup teammate, someone he respected and admired.

title: Yankees Sweep Braves for 25th Title As Clemens Gets His Series Dream
description: Roger Clemens was traded to the Yankees on the first day of spring training, and on the last day of the World Series he became a Yankee. He and his teammates heard all year how the team wasn't as good as the record-setting Yankees of 1998, but when it came to achieving any team's ultimate goal -- winning the World Series -- the Yankees, and Clemens, were every bit as good.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERSTEIN, REVA
description: SILVERSTEIN-Reva. The Riverdale Jewish Center extends profound condolences to Beverly Albert on the loss of her beloved mother. May the families be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: Defending the Stone
description: To the Editor:

title: DEEP POCKETS: A special report.; Forbes's Spending Has Effect Beyond His Standing in Polls
description: Last year, as Iowa voters were preparing to elect a United States senator and an assortment of state and local officials, the Steve Forbes organization flooded the state with money for a lucky bunch of Republican statehouse candidates in order to gain their support.

title: Keeping Home PC's Afloat Through Y2K
description: ROBERT BENNETT doubted that his home computer had Year 2000 problems, so when a visitor to his West Side apartment in Manhattan raised the subject 16 months ago, Mr. Bennett decided to prove his point.

title: Wheels for 2000: The Details Count
description: ''More George Jetson than Georg Jensen'' is the way Marc Newson, the Australian designer, describes his new concept car for Ford. Introduced at the Tokyo Auto Show last week, the 021C is what Mr. Newson calls retro-futurist, a sort of 60's vision of what the year 2000 looks like. J. Mays, Ford's vice president in charge of design, wanted a product designer to take a fresh look at his industry. He had been intrigued by Mr. Newson's work ever since he saw his Lockheed lounge chair in a Madonna video. Auto makers are getting ready for the huge number of teen-agers expected to buy their first cars in the next decade. The 021C is a basic car, built on an existing chassis, and Mr. Mays said, ''It is capable of being produced tomorrow.'' Evoking small cars of the early 60's, Mr. Newson's car is a composite of round-cornered rectangles, shapes found in his Dish Doctor dish rack for Magis, his furniture for Cappellini and his lamps for Flos.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUGER, NANCY HORNBY
description: ZUGER-Nancy Hornby. On October 25, 1999. A long-time resident of Gramercy Park, an advocate for the neighborhood and arts. Survived by her sister Barbara Spafford, nieces Alice Spafford and Barbara Savage, nephew William Savage and his wife Marge, one great-niece and two greatnephews. Funeral Mass 11AM Saturday at the Church of the Epiphany (22nd St and 2nd Ave). In lieu of flowers, please send memorial donations to the Scleroderma Research Fund, Presbyterian Hospital, C/O Dr. Ralph Blume, 161 Ft Washington Ave, NY NY 10032.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANDELSMAN, JOSEPH
description: HANDELSMAN - Joseph. The Board of Governors and Members of High Ridge Country Club acknowledge with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Joseph Handelsman. We extend our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife, Joyce, and their family. Morton West, President Daniel Amster, Secretary

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Natwest's hostile bid for the Bank of Scotland is turning out to look like an overly long soap opera.
description: THE hostile bidding war for National Westminster Bank that the Bank of Scotland started last month is turning out to be not much of a war at all.

title: 3 Queens Students Charged In Sexual Attack at School
description: Three students at Bayside High School in Queens were charged yesterday in the beating and sexual assault of a girl who the police said was beaten into unconsciousness and sodomized on Tuesday in a basement bathroom.

title: A Hotel of One's Own
description: The little notice, thumbtacked to the peeling wallpaper, is easy to miss. In spindly script, oxidized by time, it reads: ''Please don't throw hair, papers or anything else in the slopbucket.''

title: Nonchalantly Subtracting And Adding
description: The flexibility of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center has always made it difficult to define exactly what the society is. It gives the impression of being an ensemble sometimes, although mostly it is a collective of soloists and freelancers who band together in combinations dictated by the needs of a program. But it is also a presenting organization that imports independent ensembles, sometimes for concerts that might as easily be part of Lincoln Center's Great Performers series and sometimes for collaborations with the society's own players.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRUCHTMAN, YETTA
description: FRUCHTMAN-Yetta. On October 26th. Beloved wife of the late Theodore, mother of Gloria and Irwin, grandmother and great grandmother. She was a quiet rock to our family for a century. Graveside services on Thursday, October 28 at 11 A.M., at Mount Hebron Cemetery, Queens. Call 718-939-9405 for directions.

title: Westchester to Keep 914; Others Get New Code
description: The decision has been made, and for some it's heartbreaking. Westchester County gets to keep the 914 area code; other counties do not.

title: Governor Says Ramsey Case Will Stay in Local Hands
description: After consultation with the officials investigating the 1996 killing of JonBenet Ramsey, Gov. Bill Owens of Colorado said today that ''substantial new evidence'' had convinced him that there was no need to appoint a special prosecutor to take over the case from the local authorities.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Monday showing the global holdings of Cable and Wireless, the British telecommunications company, included one company in China and two in Singapore erroneously. The British company does not have a stake in China Telecom, in the Keppel Group or in Singapore Press Holdings. Those companies hold stakes along with Cable and Wireless in two of the other companies listed -- the first in Hong Kong Telecom and the two others in MobileOne of Singapore.

title: Trust Plan Cleared For Fund Giant
description: The FMR Corporation, parent of Fidelity Investments, the world's biggest mutual fund company, has won Federal approval to open a Federal savings and loan aimed at providing trust services to its clients nationwide.

title: Kosovo's Gypsies
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKS, DUKE
description: MARKS-Duke. Sweet, dear, cherished man. You will be in my heart forever. Joan

title: Braves' Getting There Is Not Good Enough
description: HOW WILL history remember Bobby Cox and the Atlanta Braves? For the last decade, the manager and his team have done nearly everything an organization is supposed to do.

title: The Only Thing We Have to Fear
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Kansas City Southern May Delay a Spinoff
description: Kansas City Southern Industries, a rail and financial services company that owns Janus Capital, said today that it might delay the proposed spinoff of its financial business until next year.

title: Rheingold Shifts Its Account Again
description: The Rheingold Brewing Company in White Plains has awarded its account to Ryan Drossman/MARC, New York, part of MARC USA. Billings were estimated at $1 million to $2 million.

title: New Video Releases
description: Lolita

title: Gore vs. Bradley
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; A MIGHTY TEAM WITH A MORTAL TOUCH
description: They win. They feel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRAPEAU, GEORGE
description: DRAPEAU-George, Jr. October 25, age 91. For 50 years beloved husband of Muriel (nee Cohan) of Pelham, NY. Also survived by three devoted children, Suzanne Hobbs, George, and Constance D. Kennedy, & one gradson. Devoted brother of Constance MacGrath, Louis Drapeau, Marcelle Bonzagni and Marie Sullivan. Retired in 1979 following a 47-year career with the New York Daily News. Served in both theaters of World War II, Retired Commander, USNR. A Memorial Mass will be held at St. Catharine's Church, Pelham, NY, on Tuesday, Nov. 9, at 10:00 AM. Donations to Sound Shore Medical Center Foundation, 16 Guion Place, New Rochelle, New York 10802, or St. Catharine's Parish, 25 2nd Avenue, Pelham, New York 10803, appreciated.

title: And the Beat Goes On, Even When It Shouldn't
description: ''The Suburbans'' is the kind of breezy little movie that can't get arrested these days. It's cute and jokey and has no particular edge. Rock-and-roll and relationships are its concerns, as was the case with Allison Anders and Kurt Voss's ''Sugar Town,'' a better and more ambitious recent film that had no luck in finding an audience. Even at their best, inexpensive films without a sting have a way of getting lost in the shuffle.

title: Jury in Subway Death Told Verdict Will Be a Ruling on Mental Illness
description: A Manhattan jury began its deliberations last night in the trial of a schizophrenic man who pushed a woman in front of a speeding subway train, after prosecutors and defense lawyers both told the panel its verdict would be viewed as a broad statement on society's treatment of the mentally ill.

title: Halloween, When It's Convenient
description: To the Editor:

title: The Best Way To Disarm
description: To the Editor:

title: Banned in China, Thriving in New York; A Mystical Exercise Regimen Draws Immigrants and the Deeply Curious
description: About 10 to 12 people stand in a circle near a well-traveled path in Riverside Park at 6 A.M. every day and together they move their hands in smooth and deliberate strokes -- up and down, in an arc and around again.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: Bubble, Bubble, Toil and Trouble

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LISMAN, RUTH S. ELLIOTT
description: LISMAN-Ruth S. Elliott. The officers of The Breast Cancer Research Foundation extend our most sincere condolences to the family of Ruth S. Elliott Lisman who waged a valiant battle against her disease. She was determined to help young investigators find a cure for breast cancer. We promise to fulfill her wishes. Evelyn H. Lauder Deborah Krulewitch Susan B. Hirschhorn Pamela J. Harrington The Breast Cancer Research Foundation

title: Letterman Is on the Line
description: Upon winning the World Series, one receives two phone calls, Yankee Manager Joe Torre said yesterday. The first call is from the President; the second is from David Letterman.

title: American International Profit Rises 17%
description: American International Group, a leading insurance company, said yesterday that its third-quarter earnings had risen 17.6 percent, buoyed by life insurance and money management businesses acquired earlier in the year.

title: Type of Penicillin Is in Critical Supply
description: A nationwide shortage of a powerful form of penicillin that began quietly last spring, when a leading manufacturer shut down operations, is now becoming critical, with hospital pharmacies running out of the drug and new supplies harder and harder to obtain.

title: Builder Who Was Target of Union Protest Agrees to Unionization
description: A construction company that was the target of a union protest rally that created havoc in midtown Manhattan 15 months ago has effectively signed a peace accord with the city's unions by agreeing yesterday to become a unionized operation.

title: Buchanan's Reform Tour Is Snubbed by Ventura
description: It is a different world for Patrick J. Buchanan as he works the political fringe, going forth as a makeover candidate stumping somewhere between Republican pariah and Reform Party swain.

title: Future Isn't Here Yet, Rangers Tell Malhotra
description: If the Rangers were not struggling so miserably, the issue of Manny Malhotra's playing time would not be in the spotlight. On that, the Rangers' coach, John Muckler, and their president and general manager, Neil Smith, agree.

title: Cloning of Mammoth Is Unlikely, an Expert Says
description: Hopes of cloning a frozen Siberian mammoth have been dimmed by the finding that while DNA retrieved from other mammoths retains genetic information it is highly fragmented.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALAN, RICHARD
description: ALAN-Richard. Passed away on October 23rd, 1999, due to complications of AIDS. A resident of Cos Cob, CT, Alan played piano for several State dinners at the White House during the Reagan Administration, performed on Broadway during productions of ''Aspects of Love,'' ''The Phantom of the Opera'' and ''The Will Rogers Follies,'' and also worked for Walt Disney Studios in Orlando, FL. Alan is survived by his mother, Gerry Borchetta Butterfield; her husband, Bob Butterfield; and brothers James Mottle of California, Tim Mottle of Illinois, Chris Mottle of Rhode Island, and Bruce Mottle of Massachusetts, as well as numerous aunts, uncles-especially Uncle John Servicidionieces, nephews and loving friends. Services will be held at 10 AM on October 30th at The Presbyterian Church of Old Greenwich, Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers, the family has requested donations be made to the Connecticut Hospice, 61 Burban Drive, Branford, CT. 06405.

title: The Gore-Bradley Debate; Substance . . .
description: One main substantive difference emerged from the debate on Wednesday between Al Gore and Bill Bradley: the question of how much money the government will have and how to spend it.

title: SUNSOURCE WILL ACQUIRE AXXESS TECHNOLOGIES
description: Sunsource Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the privately held Axxess Technologies Inc. for $125 million in cash and a note. Axxess, which is based in Tempe, Ariz., makes key duplication systems and identification-engraving vending systems. Its customers include Wal-Mart, Lowe's and Petsmart. In the transaction, expected to close by the end of the year, Sunsource, based in Philadelphia, will pay $80 million in cash and a $45 million note of its Hillman Group unit. Sunsource, which sells parts and services to retail stores and industrial markets, said Axxess will fit with Hillman, which sells merchandising systems and in-store service work to hardware stores.

title: The Team of the 90's Plays Coy at the Mere Mention of Dynasty
description: George Steinbrenner ignored some of the questions shouted at him in the Yankees' clubhouse after his team completed its World Series sweep of the Atlanta Braves on Wednesday night, but the mention of a particular word turned his head, a word rarely heard in baseball in the last quarter century: dynasty.

title: Endorsements for Tuesday's City Election
description: New York City's off-year election next Tuesday is expected to draw a very small turnout, which lends even more weight to every single vote. The few vigorously contested races include two for the City Council and one for Staten Island district attorney. Following are our recommendations for those races as well as for two ballot proposals.

title: In 2 Leaders' Words: An Outline for Hope in Nigeria
description: Following are excerpts from President Clinton's news conference yesterday with President Olusegun Obasanjo of Nigeria, as provided by the Federal Document Clearing House, a transcription service:

title: A Love Triangle Ignited By What Might Have Been
description: Though Samantha Morton proved herself a raw, electrifying actress in ''Under the Skin,'' she now turns up in the kind of tremulously carnal shy-flower role that once would have been played by Sarah Miles. ''Dreaming of Joseph Lees'' casts her as a prim-looking spinster who works at a sawmill and sends a lusty pig farmer named Harry (Lee Ross) in pursuit of her. Harry courts Eva (Ms. Morton) so unabashedly that he makes her blush, which is to say that he gets her attention. Harry's sister teases Eva about this, claiming that Eva is ''lookin' at him like he was burnin' you from the inside out.''

title: Northern, Southern, Sleepy and Dynamic
description: This old river town, with a site of uncommon beauty and a populace of uncommon civility, has a reputation as a stick-in-the-mud all the same. Mark Twain suggested that he'd like to come here for the apocalypse because it was always 20 years behind the times. Decades later, John Gunther detected ''a certain stately and also sleepy quality'' in the place.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: With Dropped Jaws, Braves Recount Their Undoing by Yanks
description: Chipper Jones was shaking his head and chuckling a little at the absurdity of the situation. The most consistent team of the 1990's had just been rendered road kill by the Yankees, and Jones could not even find it in himself to be terribly upset.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-18

title: Ginette Harrison, 41, A Mountain Climber
description: Ginette Lesley Harrison, an outstanding alpinist, was lost in an avalanche on Sunday on one of the most treacherous Himalayan mountains. She was 41.

title: Assisted Suicide: A Federal Crime?
description: To the Editor:

title: N.F.L. MATCHUPS -- WEEK 8
description: GAME OF THE WEEK

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWMAN, ETTA
description: NEWMAN-Etta. Condolence to our colleague, Jerry Newman, on the loss of his mother, Mrs. Etta Newman. Your family at Leslie Fay

title: Life-and-Death Matters, Messy Yet Laughable
description: Death by disease and accident is blithely addressed. A man vomits noisily. A dead cat flies through the air. Horrific events float to the surface and disappear into thin air in ''Morning Song.'' But life goes on, though not without heartfelt laughter at its dark vagaries.

title: Giants' Johnson Is Playing With Pain
description: The practice field outside of Giants Stadium had cleared out, with the players rushing off to the locker room. The equipment had been packed away, and only LeShon Johnson remained.

title: Keep Everything After 1800 to a Minimum (and Hold the Profane)
description: From her vantage point in a basement office at Corpus Christi Church, on West 122d Street in Morningside Heights, Louise Basbas has watched the early-music world in New York City expand, contract and expand again since 1975, when she started the Music Before 1800 concerts at the church. She has also seen period instrument performers and their listeners shift their gaze from medieval and Renaissance music, through the Baroque and Classical eras and well into the Romantic. And although she has not been entirely immune to the lure of modernity, she has mostly kept to the repertory described in the title of her series.

title: Mental Health Privacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAMINER, PHYLLIS
description: KAMINER-Phyllis. Adored wife of Henry. Beloved mother of Martin and Ariel. Dear sister of Sandra Handel. Cherished daughter of the late Gladys and Max Wasserman. She was Founder and President of Instructional Systems, Inc. Passed away on October 27th. after a prolonged illness. As a friend, a mentor, a philanthropist, a visionary leader and an invincible optimist, she will continue to inspire all who knew her. Services ''Wien & Wien,'' Hackensack, NJ, Friday, 10 AM (1-800-378-1892). In lieu of flowers donations are being accepted at the Online Scholarship Fund of The Jewish Theological Seminary.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, ALVIN S.
description: FRIEDMAN-Alvin S., 81, of Lake Worth, FL died on October 24, 1999. Born in Mt. Vernon, NY, he lived there until 1967, residing thereafter in Greenwich, CT and Somers, NY before moving to Lake Worth in 1995. He is survived by his wife Gloria, and was predeceased by his wife of 55 years, Frances Feinsod Friedman. He is also survived by three childrenRobert, Marsha Silverman and David, two brothers-Herbert and William, seven grandchildren and two great grandchildren.

title: Strong Summer Apt to Propel Economic Boom to a Record
description: The American economy turned in its best quarterly performance of the year this summer, virtually guaranteeing enough momentum to carry the nation to its longest economic expansion in history early next year.

title: A Musical That's Willing to Be Quiet
description: Sometimes a murmur is more startling than a shout. For its first enchanted hour, ''James Joyce's 'The Dead,' '' the new stage adaptation of the classic short story at Playwrights Horizons, makes a sterling virtue out of a trait rarely associated with American musicals: shyness.

title: Health Care Agencies Merged
description: Wellness Worldwide is consolidating two agencies, Lewis Gace Bozell and Dugan/Farley Communications, to form Bozell Global Healthcare in Fort Lee, N.J.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Brad Kahlhamer
description: Deitch Projects

title: I.B.M. to Announce New, Flexible Transistors
description: Heralding an era in which computers, and especially computer displays, can blend into the fabric of everyday life, I.B.M. researchers will report today that they have developed flexible transistors that can be embedded in curved surfaces or even in thin, foldable materials.

title: Suburbs Share City Problems From Shortfall In School Aid
description: Suburban school districts that educate large numbers of poor and minority children fare just as badly under New York State's school financing system as urban districts, according to a new report.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FUCHS, THEODORE
description: FUCHS-Theodore. On October 27, 1999. Beloved husband of Jessie. Dear father of Yolanda and Bob Hill. Services today 2:30 P.M., at Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, L.I., NY.

title: At Tyco, Accounting 'Baths' Begin Before the Deals Close
description: TYCO INTERNATIONAL was a highflying stock with a reputation for acquiring and improving the performance of companies in distinctly low-flying industries. Then questions were raised about its accounting and the stock began to slip.

title: In Wake of Flight 800 Disaster, U.S. Proposes Rules for Safer Fuel Tanks on Planes
description: Responding to the explosion of a T.W.A. jetliner that killed 230 people off Long Island in 1996, the Federal Government proposed rules today that would tighten design and maintenance standards for fuel tanks on aircraft.

title: Humbert Would Swear This Isn't the Same Lolita
description: LO'S DIARY

title: Parcells Targets 3 Areas To Improve
description: The Jets are using this bye week to work on three problems Bill Parcells says they must overcome if they are to turn around their season after a 1-6 start.

title: New York's Yankees
description: New York had been a city of five boroughs for only three years when in 1901 two businessmen bought a baseball team called the Baltimore Orioles, moved it and renamed it the New York Highlanders. In 1913 that team became the Yankees. If it is hard to imagine a 20th-century history of the city without the Yankees, it is even harder to imagine a history of the Yankees without a consolidated city to play in. Since 1901 the franchise, as Highlanders or Yankees, has played ball in Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx. But the team has never played for any one of those boroughs. Then and now, it plays for all of them, and for Staten Island and the suburbs too.

title: Where Hearts Don't Cheat, And Love Is the Current
description: Clint Black, despite his lonesome-cowboy name, has a congenital disrespect for the dark side of life. When he sang about love on Tuesday night at the Supper Club, it sounded like a public service announcement for the National Love Board: the words were temperate, lightly cautionary, encouraging, focused.

title: CITADEL BROADCASTING TO ACQUIRE 36 RADIO STATIONS
description: The Citadel Broadcasting Company agreed yesterday to acquire 36 radio stations from Broadcasting Partners Holdings L.P. for $190 million. The stations are in Maine, New Jersey, Texas, Connecticut, Massachusetts, Louisiana and New York State. Citadel Broadcasting is a unit of the Citadel Communications Corporation, which is based in Las Vegas, Nev., and owns and operates radio stations, primarily in midsize markets. It had revenue of $126.5 million in the nine months ended on Sept. 30. Citadel Communications' stock was up 37.5 cents, to $46.375.

title: Residential Real Estate; On Riverside Drive, Restoration and Conversion
description: The owners of an 11-story rental apartment building constructed in 1908 at Riverside Drive and 91st Street are converting it into a condominium, and plan to restore some large apartments that had been broken up over the years to their original floor plans.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: ASTRA ZENECA'S PROFITS JUMP
description: The drug maker Astra Zeneca P.L.C. said its profits soared 43 percent in its third quarter, in part because of better-than-expected sales of Losec, its anti-ulcer drug. Astra Zeneca, formed through Zeneca Group's acquisition of Astra A.B. of Sweden, said its income increased to $657 million from $458 million a year earlier. The company warned, though, that sales in the fourth quarter would be softer.

title: Autumn Views
description: Crisp, clear autumn days are perfect for enjoying the New York views offered by these 12 restaurants. (These summaries are taken from dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times by William Grimes, Eric Asimov and others.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, MERYL
description: GREENBERG-Meryl. On October 27, 1999. A woman of grace, wisdom and class, more than the sum of her roles. Beloved wife of the late Abel. Cherished mother of Adrienne and Alvin Bodenstein, Doris and Joel Leifer. Adored grandmother of Marcy and Steven Pontell, Mark and Ann Marie Lieberman, Lawrence and Elizabeth Bodenstein, Shari and Amos Balaish, Mitchell & Bethany Lieberman, Elyse and Yaakov Anker, David Leifer and 15 great grandchildren. Funeral service Friday, 10:00 AM, Plaza Memorial, 91 St. and Amsterdam Ave., NYC. We celebrate your life and will hold you in our hearts forever.

title: A Director Trades in the Hatchets for Violins
description: As a director best known for his ''Nightmare on Elm Street'' and ''Scream'' series, Wes Craven has long been associated with violence. Now he has made a film about violins. This may appear to be a fabulous typographical error, if not such a hot movie idea.

title: Day of Contrition at The Los Angeles Times
description: Faced with a rebellion by distraught and angry staff members, the publisher of The Los Angeles Times told them in a meeting today that she intended to take steps to keep the news content of the paper free from any appearance of commercial influence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCAFEE, MARY ANN
description: McAFEE-Mary Ann. On October 26, 1999. Survived by her daughter Kathryn Hall Baxter, son, James Armstrong Baxter, grandson William Stuart Baxter-Bray and brothers William Gage McAfee and Stuart Reeves McAfee. Memorial services Monday, November 1st, 3PM at Church of the Heavenly Rest, NY, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations for lung cancer research may be made to The Lionel Grossbard Research Fund, Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, 161 Fort Washington Ave., Suite 222, New York, NY 10032.

title: PRICEWATERHOUSECOOPERS TO TRIM 1,000 POSITIONS
description: PricewaterhouseCoopers , the world's largest accounting and consulting firm, is cutting 1,000 support jobs in the United States to reduce costs as it plans to invest billions of dollars to expand the services it offers. The New York-based firm will dismiss 700 to 750 employees in the United States, and 250 jobs will be eliminated through attrition and a hiring freeze already in place, according to a spokesman, Steven Silber. The cuts will save about $91 million, which the company can then spend on acquisitions, training, technology and new services, he said.

title: ARCH COAL MAY CLOSE TWO MINES AND ELIMINATE JOBS
description: Arch Coal Inc. said yesterday that it might cut 622 jobs and close two southern West Virginia mines after a United States District Court ruling blocked the company, the second-largest United States coal producer, from expanding at the two sites. Arch Coal, based in St. Louis, could shutter its Hobet 21 mining complex, based in Boone and Lincoln counties, and the Ruffner complex, in Logan County, as early as the end of the year, the company said. After last week's ruling, West Virginia officials banned mines from building most new valley fills or expanding existing fills, which are used to store excess rock and build water retention structures. The fills are essential for mining in steep terrain, and both the Hobet and Ruffner complexes need to extend theirs to remain open, Arch Coal said.

title: Umpires to Vote on Representation by Mail
description: The fight over Richie Phillips, who has represented major league umpires for 20 years, will end one month from tomorrow. The pro-Phillips faction among the umpires and the insurgent group that bolted from his mass-resignation strategy reached agreement yesterday for the National Labor Relations Board to conduct a mail ballot on the umpires' labor representative.

title: 25 WORLD CHAMPIONSHIPS
Tough Love In Spacey, Hippie Guise
description: Macy Gray has a funny little voice. With more breath than tone, more scratch than sweetness, it puffs out her phrases like smoke signals. She uses its quirks to sound childish or worldly, sleepy or jazzy; she syncopates as if she happened to find herself telling stories with a band nearby. Yet for all her casual charm, Ms. Gray is hardly a naif. Her songs are a fond and deliberate throwback to the soul music of the late 1960's and early 1970's. Ms. Gray has set out to revive the way that era's performers combined seemingly flaky improvisation with a sure sense of identity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, ELSIE SOLIS ALCOTT
description: MILLER-Elsie Solis Alcott, age 95, of Bennington, Vermont died on October 27, 1999. Beloved mother of Phyllis Lee, and grandmother of Henry Lee, Thomas Lee, Alexandra Stack, and Cynthia Dow. Great grandmother of Carolyn, David and Jackson Lee, and Kip and Cornelia Stack.

title: Profit Falls 16% At News Corp.
description: The News Corporation, the media company controlled by Rupert Murdoch, said yesterday that its first-quarter profit fell 16 percent because of tough comparisons to last year's video sales of ''Titanic.''

title: I.M.F. AMENDS BRAZIL ACCORD
description: Brazil's central bank reached an agreement with the International Monetary Fund allowing the bank to use more foreign reserves to prevent a sharp weakening of the domestic currency, the real. Under the accord, which alters a previous section of the fund's $41.5 billion aid package to Brazil, about $2 billion of reserves can be used for this purpose by the end of the year. The real rallied on the news, settling in New York trading at 1.9840 to the dollar.

title: Aetna Says It Is Under S.E.C. Review
description: Aetna Inc., the nation's biggest health insurer, said yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission had started a review of the way the company accounted for its August purchase of the money-losing Prucare unit of the Prudential Insurance Company of America. That deal made Aetna the industry leader with more than 20 million customers, including 1.2 million in New York and nearby areas.

title: THUNDER IN THE BRONX: On Baseball; Scouting Report on the Front Office: Great Job
description: The lineup on the field included names like Knoblauch, Jeter, O'Neill, Williams, Martinez, Girardi and Brosius. Everyone knows them. The names in the Yankees' other lineup are not so well known: Michael, Didier, Taylor, Oppenheimer, Webber, Wurth, Hansen, Caro.

title: ALBUM OF THE WEEK
description: THE TIGER LILLIES: ''Shockheaded Peter: A Junk Opera'' (NVC Arts/Atlantic). Parents flustered by the horrors of the video arcade should examine the classics of kiddie literature. Children's tales have long incarnated the dark corners of the littlest psyches, from Grimm's dark forest to Roald Dahl's rotting giant peach.

title: Slicing Up the 20's and 90's In a Time-Warped Stew
description: Plop an eager-beaver 1920's newspaper reporter onto the streets of contemporary Manhattan, make him blissfully unaware that he has landed in the wrong decade, film his adventures in black and white, and you have Adam Abraham's amusing one-joke film, ''Man of the Century.'' This farcical riff on movie nostalgia echoes early Woody Allen (and Stanley Tucci's recent comedy, ''The Impostors'') in its lampooning of the hoariest celluloid stereotypes. The movie is also shrewd enough to avoid wearing out its welcome. It's only 77 minutes long.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAUS, ESTELLE
description: KRAUS-Estelle. Wife, mother, and beloved daughter-in-law. Passed away October 28, 1999 in Delray Beach, FL. Estelle was an extraordinary woman who pioneered in business for many years. She is survived by her daughter Dr. Michelle Kraus of Menlo Park, CA. and her son Andrew Kraus of Rockville, MD. Funeral will be 1:30 Friday, October 29, 1999 at Bloomfield Cooper Jewish Chapels, 44 Wilson Avenue, Manalapan, NJ.

title: Gore Steps Up the Attack Against Bradley on Health Care
description: Vice President Al Gore ripped apart Bill Bradley's health care proposal today, saying it cost too much, in part because it would provide insurance even for the wealthy, and would swallow up the entire budget surplus.

title: Suddenly, Cosell's Back And He's Still Cosell
description: There is a once-upon-a-time quality to the life of Howard Cosell. You almost have to educate younger viewers that a television personality with his voice, erudition, bombast, ego, arrogance, toupee, neuroses, sense of social justice and inner anger towered over sportscasting for nearly two decades.

title: EU Takes Up French Case Against British Beef
description: BRUSSELS  The European Union's main scientific advisory committee on Thursday began reviewing the French government's claim that British beef remains unsafe because of "mad cow" disease and that France is justified in continuing to ban it.

title: An Ayatollah's Cruelty
description: To the Editor:

title: Nigeria Gets U.S. Help, but Bigger Plan for Africa Snags
description: As President Clinton met today with Nigeria's recently elected President and pledged a tripling of aid to the country, his Administration's biggest initiative for Africa -- a bill that could ease Africa's access to the American market -- seemed imperiled in the Senate.

title: Parade or School? Mayor Favors Yanks
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani set aside his sometimes stern demeanor yesterday. He issued no pointed lectures on jaywalking, fare-beating, ferret-owning or hanging paintings that offend his sense of good taste. Instead, he sent a signal of encouragement to a type that rarely finds support in high places: the truant.

title: A G.O.P. Event Features Talk, Little Sparring
description: Five Republican candidates for President sat side-by-side on a stage here tonight but paid little heed to one another as they offered views on issues including military spending, campaign finance and overhauling the tax system.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about a $150 million gift to Stanford University by James H. Clark, a Silicon Valley entrepreneur and former professor, ranked the donation imprecisely. According to The Chronicle of Higher Education, it was the seventh largest private gift or grant to American higher education since 1967; of the seven, five have been to universities.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Public Lives column yesterday about a new book of works by the photographer David Seidner, who died in June, misstated the title. It is ''Portraits,'' not ''American Photographs: 1900/ 2000.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTINEZ, ALICE EUGENIA
description: MARTINEZ-Alice Eugenia Johnson. On October 27, 1999 at age 97. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Arturo Martinez. Mother of Alice Eugenia Aragones. Grandmother of Jay Johnson Aragones, Alice Eugenia Vergara, and Patricia Courtney Aragones. Great grandmother of Peter Augustine, Benedict Xavier, and Alice Christina Vergara. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Sunday, 3-7 PM. Funeral mass at St. Thomas More Church, 65 East 89 Street, Monday, 10:30 AM. Interment private. Because of her strong desire for the education of young women, contributions in her memory may be made to The Convent of the Sacred Heart, 1177 King Street, Greenwich, CT. 06830.

title: An All-American Style, Straight From Germany
description: American Ballet Theater continued its focus on American choreographers on Wednesday night at City Center with the premiere of John Neumeier's ''Getting Closer,'' set to Ned Rorem's String Symphony.

title: Viewer Ratings
description: The Yankees' four-game sweep of the Atlanta Braves generated a 16.0 Nielsen rating for NBC, a 13 percent increase over last year's 14.1 for the Yankees' sweep of the San Diego Padres, which was the lowest-rated World Series ever.

title: FIGURE SKATING ; Kwan Attempts a High-Level Comeback
description: Putting her new life as just another U.C.L.A. freshman on hold, Michele Kwan slipped back into a starring role today, and into a pair of elbow-length black gloves befitting a figure-skating diva.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEIM, BERTHA NEE OSER
description: HEIM-Bertha nee Oser. Died on October 27, 1999, age 99. Beloved wife of the late Leopold. Loving mother of Gerda and the late Liselotte. Devoted grandmother of Michael, Peter, Helen, Elizabeth and Catherine. Proud great grandmother of Kate, Aliza, Lucas, Lisel, Maggie, Nathan, and Tyler. You will always be in our hearts. Services will be held at Omega Funeral Home, Elmsford, NY on Friday, October 29 at noon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARAZDUK, JACK
description: HARAZDUK-Jack. On October 28, 1999. Beloved husband of Anne, loving father and father-in-law of Julie and Jonathan Braunhut and the late Richard. Devoted grandfather of David and Ian. Jack was a friend to all. Funeral Sunday 10:30am, Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Ave., (exit 17 Saw Mill) Dobbs Ferry, New York. Memorials to the American Heart Association appreciated.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN FALLS. The dollar rose against the yen as reports showed the United States economy is growing without fueling a pickup in inflation. In New York, the dollar settled at 105.04 yen, up from 104.17 on Wednesday.

title: A Clearer View of the Economy; The Commerce Department Answers Its Critics
description: With millions of Americans enjoying today's prosperity, some experts have complained that the Government's methods for measuring the economy have failed to capture its true strength and dynamism. Now the Commerce Department has responded with confirmation that the critics have been at least partly right.

title: Rafael Alberti, 96, Widely Read Spanish Poet
description: Rafael Alberti, one of Spain's most popular poets and the last member of the ''Generation of 1927,'' a group of artists whose ranks included the poet Federico Garcia Lorca and the film director Luis Bunuel, died today at his home in El Puerto de Santa Maria, in southern Spain. He was 96.

title: Oregon Chafes at Measure To Stop Assisted Suicides
description: Oregonians have long prided themselves on being in the forefront on many social issues -- sometimes with ideas that catch on in the rest of the nation, and sometimes not.

title: Sampras to Make Return in Paris
description: Pete Sampras will play his first tournament in more than two months when he competes in the Mercedes Super 9 Paris indoor tournament next week.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Marilyn's Piano Goes to Mariah

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDERS, SARAH
description: SANDERS-Sarah. Of St. Paul, MN. Survived by husband Arthur. Infants wear buyer-Daytons, Donaldsons and The Golden Rule. Shiva 555 Mt. Curve Blvd, St. Paul, MN 55116.

title: Rising Costs of Medications Take Bigger Share of Insurance Outlays
description: Health insurance companies in New York are starting to pay as much for prescription drugs as they pay for care of hospitalized patients, a stunning change in direction for the region's health care dollars.

title: Pharmacia & Upjohn Earnings Rose 13%
description: Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc., the maker of the baldness treatment Rogaine, said today that its third-quarter earnings rose 13 percent on sales of newer medicines like Xalatan, the world's top-selling glaucoma drug, and the incontinence pill Detrol.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about Indonesia's new Cabinet misidentified the American organization represented in Jakarta by Eric Bjornlund, who commented on the composition of the Cabinet. It is the National Democratic Institute for International Affairs, not the Carter Center.

title: Pat York
description: Zalman Gallery

title: Assisted Suicide: A Federal Crime?
description: To the Editor:

title: Home Sweet Home: Just Ask Clemens
description: Wearing a leather jacket and slacks, Roger Clemens strolled through the hallway of the lowest level of Yankee Stadium, departing a few hours after he had pitched seven and two-thirds innings in the Yankees' 4-1 victory and brought them a World Series sweep of the Atlanta Braves.

title: John McCain's Temper
description: To the Editor:

title: A.M.A. and 6 Others Set Up Medical Internet Company
description: The American Medical Association and six other medical societies said yesterday that they had created an Internet company that, starting next year, will publish consumer information on health care and help doctors set up their own medical Web sites to communicate with patients by E-mail.

title: Remnants of Tibetan Splendor, Divine and Intimate
description: Tibetan Buddhist art is like no other art. It burns with a sharp, nervy incandescence, like a fire generously stoked but tightly contained. The most comprehensive gathering of such material in the West belongs to the Newark Museum. And this fall an unparalleled amount of that work is on view as the museum celebrates its 90th birthday.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL FALLS. Crude oil plunged more than 5 percent on expectations for lower demand and a rise in output from world producers. In New York, crude oil for December delivery fell $1.24, or 5.4 percent, to $21.68 a barrel.

title: Acquittals in Massacre Arouse Brazil
description: Three years ago, 19 landless farm workers were killed in a confrontation with the police at this bend in a highway in the southeastern Amazon. More than 1,500 people witnessed the Para state military police open fire, and the incident was filmed and shown on Brazilian television hundreds of times.

title: Fat in a Land of Low Fat
description: To the Editor:

title: When Saying The Obvious Invites Wrath
description: THERE was a protest in mid-Manhattan yesterday outside a building on Third Avenue that is home to the law firm of Fischbein Badillo Wagner Harding. The Badillo in that jawbreaker is Herman Badillo, a fixture in New York politics and chairman of the City University of New York.

title: It Wasn't All Dainty Ladies and Their Beaux in Frills and Satin
description: In its new exhibition, ''Watteau and His World: French Drawing From 1700 to 1750,'' the Frick Collection has struck gold.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENKIN, MARTIN
description: HENKIN-Martin. Devoted husband of Bette. Loving father of David and Frank. Cherished grandfather. Fond brother. Services were held Wednesday, October 27, 1999.

title: On My Mind; The Great Encounter
