description: Given their assets and handicaps, Vice President Gore and Bill Bradley came off quite nicely in their first television whatever. But the questioners in the New Hampshire audience, so well educated and well mannered, did themselves no credit.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 12.

title: Berlusconi Wins in Court
description: An appeals court in Milan today upheld the acquittal of Silvio Berlusconi, a former Italian Prime Minister who was charged with tax fraud, unlawful appropriation and false accounting involving a land deal.

title: A Man and His Lawn Mower: Determination and a Smile
description: The Straight Story

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDENBERG, RAYMOND J.
description: GOLDENBERG-Raymond J., 85, of Margate, Florida. Beloved husband of Ida, father of Iris (Randy) Simens and Fredda (Michael) Weinberg, grandfather of Marissa, Courtney, Mariel and Chelsea. Services will be at 9:30 AM Sunday at Schwartz Bros., Queens Boulevard and 76th Road, Forest Hills, NY.

title: Williams Makes Donation, $2.1 Million, to St. John's
description: Nets center Jayson Williams announced yesterday that he would donate $2.1 million to St. John's, his alma mater, to help underprivileged high school graduates attend the university. The gift, which Williams is giving in honor of Lou Carnesecca, the former Red Storm coach, is believed to be the second largest donation made to a university by a professional athlete.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.

title: Fed's Chief Calls Cooling Unavoidable
description: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, called the economy's recent growth rate unsustainable today, but said the rise in long-term interest rates appeared to be containing the risks of inflation.

title: Taking the Mall Mentality To Its Ultimate Vapidity
description: The ghost of Gracie Allen may be providing some ethereal guidance to four young actors at Performance Space 122 these days. Do they have any inkling, you wonder, how comically inspired they are in Richard Maxwell's fresh and affectionate new play, ''Showy Lady Slipper''?

title: Web Site Picks Pagano Schenck
description: Sixdegrees.com in New York, which operates a World Wide Web site devoted to ''personal community'' networks, has awarded its first account to Pagano Schenck & Kay Advertising in Boston, part of EPB Communications. Billings were estimated at $6 million to $10 million.

title: Bradley, After Round 1 With Gore, Comes Out Punching
description: At a campaign rally this morning, former Senator Bill Bradley did something he does not often do: poke fun at Vice President Al Gore, his rival for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAEFFER, SYLVIA
description: SCHAEFFER-Sylvia. JTA, the Global News Service of the Jewish People, mourns the death of Sylvia Schaeffer, mother of our beloved Vice President, Ivan Michael Schaeffer. JTA's Board of Directors offers its heartfelt condolences to the Schaeffer family. May you be comforted among the mourners of Zion. Shoshana S. Cardin, President Mark J. Joffe, Publisher

title: Public Interests; Bradley's Gestalt Therapy
description: Thanks to this week's presidential debates forums, town halls, whatever you want to call them -- we now know that Bill Bradley's idea of a great leader is Jimmy Carter (''integrity''), Woodrow Wilson (''the ability to see around corners'') or Mikhail Gorbachev (''courage''). Who could not find this interesting? Once again, Mr. Bradley demonstrated that he is a new kind of candidate, a man who skips the predictable tributes to Lincoln and F.D.R., and instead names three former heads of state so high-minded their constituents practically ran them out of town on a rail.

title: Giuliani Helps a Campaign Hoping for Help in Return
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani today endorsed the Republican candidate for Erie County executive, Joel Giambra, who if he wins will overturn longtime Democratic control of one of the most powerful jobs in upstate New York. Mr. Giambra would also be of pivotal importance to Mr. Giuliani in his expected campaign for United States Senate next year.

title: 'Video Hound,' New and Bigger
description: Even with the Internet, some of the most formidable video guides are still measured in pounds and numbers of pages. In the case of the new 2000 edition of ''Video Hound's Golden Movie Retriever'' (Visible Ink Press), that's five pounds and 1,700 pages (with 12 blank ones for notes or whatever).

title: Harsh Homeless Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Business; Paris-Based Market Picks New York Site
description: Fauchon, the 114-year-old high-end food company whose main store is on the Place de la Madeleine in central Paris, plans to open its first American branch in New York in the spring. It will occupy 3,600 square feet in the Swissotel New York-The Drake, at 56th Street and Park Avenue, in a space that has long housed a cafe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RODIN, BERNARD M.
description: RODIN-Bernard M. Long Island University and Tilles Center for the Performing Arts mourn the passing of our dear friend and long-time supporter. Roger B. Tilles, Chair David J. Steinberg, President

title: Foes of Test Ban Treaty Now Take Aim at Monitoring System
description: Eager to insure that a treaty banning nuclear testing is never revived, some of the accord's most ardent foes in the Senate are discussing a plan to gut a $300 million global monitoring system that is half built and seen as essential to making the pact work.

title: HOUSE APPROVES A 1% BUDGET CUT ACROSS THE BOARD
description: The House today narrowly passed the last spending bill of the year, an $85 billion measure for labor, health and education programs, containing a 0.97 percent across-the-board cut in Federal spending. The cut would create on paper a budget that did not tap Social Security money.

title: UConn Big East Choice, With Room for Rutgers
description: In the last six seasons, the Connecticut women's basketball team has achieved records of 30-3, 35-0 (with a national title), 34-4, 33-1, 34-3 and 29-5 and has brought respectability to the Big East Conference.

title: NORSK PLANS CUTS
description: Norway's second-largest company, Norsk Hydro, said it planned to sell assets worth 12.6 billion kroner ($1.6 billion) and reduce its work force by 6 percent, about 2,300 jobs, in an effort to reverse a four-year drop in profit. Hydro will focus on expanding its energy and aluminum divisions while cutting costs in its unprofitable fertilizer business, which is among the world's largest.

title: Back on the Road
description: The day after facing off in New Hampshire, the Democratic Presidential contenders were on the trail again, trading criticism. Page A30.

title: 'In Black and White'
description: Admit One Gallery

title: If the Killing Is Over With, It's Too Late for One Student
description: East Timor won its independence from Indonesia a couple of months ago. You probably heard. President Suharto had already been gone for more than a year. Indonesia's new president has now appointed a ''national unity Cabinet,'' and the Security Council has just created a United Nations mission to govern East Timor for now. The killing and the destruction that began when Indonesia annexed East Timor in 1975 may finally be over. The timing couldn't be better -- or worse -- for ''Punitive Damage,'' Annie Goldson's worthy documentary about a Malaysian college student who died in East Timor for his cause.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BELL ATLANTIC CORP., New York, joined a Labor Department program to hire at least 2,000 employees in the next year through a program to place welfare recipients and people with disabilities in union jobs.

title: CHURCH & DWIGHT TO BUY HOUSEHOLD-CLEANER BRANDS
description: The Church & Dwight Company, the maker of Arm & Hammer products, agreed yesterday to buy two bathroom-cleaner brands for $55 million to enter that market. Church & Dwight, based in Princeton, N.J., will purchase the Clean Shower brand from Clean Shower L.P. and the Scrub Free brand from Benckiser Consumer Products , as well as the Delicare fine-fabric wash brand from Benckiser. Financial details were not disclosed. The acquisitions will double Church & Dwight's household-cleaner business, which includes Brillo soap pads and Sno Bol toilet cleaner. It estimated the bathroom-cleaner product market at $450 million.

title: The Gore-Bradley Debate; . . . and Style
description: As candidates as different as Ronald Reagan and Bill Clinton have demonstrated, communication is an essential part of campaigning and of governing. From a theatrical standpoint, the first meeting between Al Gore and Bill Bradley offered a striking showcase for two candidates who have obviously been working on their performance skills.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SAVAGE, MARILYN
description: SAVAGE-Marilyn. 10/29/45-2/9/94. Wish I could wish you a happy birthday. Not being able to will never seem right. Miss you always. Vick

title: Biologists Find Progenitors Of Earth's Flowering Plants
description: After more than a hundred years of arguing, theorizing and frustration, evolutionary biologists have at last answered a question so difficult that Darwin himself called it the ''abominable mystery'': how did the world's flowering plants, the most diverse and important group of plants on earth, first evolve?

title: More Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown
description: ''Women'' (''Elles''), a sensuous but overstuffed soap opera about women of a certain age confronting the usual insecurities, offers one solution to the problem of how to cram five personal dramas into the same movie. You hang them on the transparently mechanical premise that one of the five characters is a television personality preparing a documentary in which she asks her friends what they would do if they had three wishes.

title: Koop Criticized for Role in Warning on Hospital Gloves
description: In the spring of 1997, Dr. C. Everett Koop, the former Surgeon General, made a telephone call to Dr. Linda Rosenstock, director of the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health. The agency was about to warn health workers that latex gloves widely used in hospitals could cause serious, even life-threatening allergic reactions. Dr. Koop told her that the language of the warning was ''way overstated'' and could cause health workers to abandon gloves that could protect them against infection, Dr. Rosenstock said.

title: Baseball's Moral Victory
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARTUR, M. HARRY
description: WARTUR-M. Harry, in Queens age 92. Beloved husband of the late Bertha Stern Wartur. Loving father of C. Lawrence Wartur of Queens, and Susan W. Wolfson of West Haven, CT. Dear father-inlaw of Susan Joy Wartur & Steven Wolfson. Beloved grandfather of Lisa Wartur Cohen and her husband Robin Jay Cohen of Queens & Ellen Wolfson of San Francisco and Roger Wolfson of New York City. Mr. Wartur received his Civil Engineering Degree from Cornell University in 1927 and had a distinguished career, serving as chief engineer in the construction of roads, bridges, highways and shipyards in Brooklyn, Manhattan, Queens, Connecticut, New Jersey, Egypt, Panama, the Dominican Republic, El Salvador and Santo Domingo. He also conducted projects on railroads, telecommunications, water supply, sewerage and sewer treatment in several states. Mr. Wartur was a licensed professional engineer in New York and New Jersey, and was a Fellow of the American Society of Civil Engineers, a Member of the Moles, and a panelist for the American Arbitration Association. He served as a member of the Board of Directors of the Rego Park Jewish Center. Funeral services will be held at the Parkside Memorial Chapel at 98-60 Queens Blvd, Rego Park at 11:15 A.M. Friday, October 29, 1999. Donations may be made to the Rego ParkJewish Center at 97-30 Queens Blvd, Rego Park, N.Y. 11374.

title: Earliest Divorce Case: X and Y Chromosomes
description: Like archeologists exploring a succession of levels at a dig site, two Boston scientists have discovered four distinct layers of evolution in the structure of the human X chromosome. From the chronology of the layers, the scientists have inferred some of the landmark events in the evolution of sex chromosomes -- an epic battle of the sexes that stretches back to the dawn of mammalian time.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RAPHAEL, AARON
description: RAPHAEL-Aaron. Dear Papa, Happy Birthday. Love Honey, Marvin, Gus & Jetta

title: 3 Charged in Armenia Parliament Seizure
description: Armenian prosecutors brought terrorism charges today against three of five gunmen who seized the Parliament on Wednesday, killing eight people, most of them Government officials, and holding 40 hostages.

title: The Best Way To Disarm
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIDELL, WILLIAM
description: BIDELL-William F. Of Franklin Square. On October 27. Beloved husband of the late Vivian. Dearest father of Marian Karcher, William and Thomas. Also survived by seven grandchildren. Reposing at Krauss Funeral Home, Inc, 1097 Hempstead Tpke, Franklin Square, Friday 2-5 and 7-10PM. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday 9:45AM St. Catherine of Sienna RC Church, Franklin Square. Interment St. Charles Cemetery.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It's Halloween and the Democrats are up to their old tricks.''

title: George Hill 3d, 66, Ad Agency Founder
description: George J. Hill 3d, a co-founder of the Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos advertising agency in Boston, died Friday at his home in Dedham, Mass. He was 66.

title: Stock Promoters Were Informers, Said to Aid Inquiries in Fraud
description: The two on-line stock promoters found shot to death on Tuesday in a mansion in Colts Neck, N.J., had been informers in investigations of securities fraud, regulatory and law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: A Bankruptcy In Japan Gets The Attention Of 'Vultures'
description: The vultures are coming! The vultures are coming!

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day last Saturday about four children in Belgium who reported feeling ill after drinking Coca-Cola products misstated the site of a bottling plant where one product was produced. It is in East Kilbride, Scotland, not England.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Oct. 4 about planned joint ventures between NBC and Lou Dobbs, a former anchor of CNN's daily financial news program ''Moneyline News Hour,'' misstated the given name of a co-anchor who succeeded Mr. Dobbs. He is Stuart Varney, not Scott.

title: On a Sad and Misty Morning, Fond Recollections of Stewart
description: It was a day of golf and another day of grieving.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIGERT, PHYLLIS ANN
description: STEIGERT-Phyllis Ann (nee Fahey) of Albertson, NY, on October 28, 1999. Beloved wife of Robert. Devoted mother of Pamela Ann Rubinstein, Victoria Regina Simenson and Robert W. Steigert, Jr. Loving grandmother of Lars Simenson, Marissa Ladd, Emilia Steigert and the late Craig Rubinstein. Dear sister of Patricia Determann. Visitation will be from 2-5 and 7-10 PM Saturday and Sunday at Weigand Brothers Funeral Home, 49 Hillside Avenue, Williston Park, NY. Funeral Mass will be at 10 AM Monday at St. Aidan's R.C. Church, with interment in Flushing Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations in Phyllis' memory may be made to the FranciscansSt. Anthony's Guild, PO Box 2948, Paterson, New Jersey 07509-9952.

title: Kellogg Net Up 20% in Quarter
description: The Kellogg Company, the world's leading cereal maker, said today that its third-quarter profit rose 20 percent on increased sales of Rice Krispies Treats and other convenience foods.

title: Court Affirms Ruling That Allows Strip Clubs to Stay Open
description: A state appeals court has upheld a decision that strip clubs can operate in certain areas of New York City providing that no more than 40 percent of their business is devoted to adult entertainment.

title: Profit More Than Triples at MCI Worldcom
description: MCI Worldcom Inc., which is acquiring the rival Sprint Corporation in what will be the largest corporate takeover ever, said today that its third-quarter profit more than tripled as demand for data services surged.

title: Siren Song: Early Music
description: For a quarter-century, the Music Before 1800 concert series has diverted New York audiences with performances of early music played on period instruments. Its base is Corpus Christi Church in Morningside Heights, where the series founder, Louise Basbas, right, is the choir director. The series has presented an intriguing sampling of American and European artists devoted to the music of the medieval through early Classical periods. On Sunday, Music Before 1800 will open its 25th season with the New York debut of Musica Pacifica, an instrumental ensemble from San Francisco, which will perform Italian music of the 17th and 18th centuries.

title: James Barsness
description: George Adams

title: Jurors Acquit Bronx Man In Shooting of Police Officer
description: Just eight days after a New York police captain was shot in the face in 1997 while executing a search warrant in a Bronx apartment filled with weapons, police officials announced that they had identified the gunman and posted a $21,000 reward for his capture.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEHMANN, MEIER
description: LEHMANN-Meier, The Officers, Directors, Staff and Students of the Hebrew Academy of Long Beach note with profound sorrow the sudden passing of Mr. Meier Lehmann A''H, beloved husband of Tammy and beloved father of current HALB students Daniela, Kelly, Joey, Mikey and Benjy. May the Almighty console the bereaved family, as well as the entire community, amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

title: VODAFONE BID IS DOUBTED
description: Responding to newspaper reports that Vodafone Airtouch of Britain was considering a hostile bid for Mannesmann, Klaus Esser, chief executive of the German telecommunications and engineering company, said he doubted a hostile takeover was in the works. Mr. Esser made the comments to the daily German financial newspaper Handelsblatt. Mannesmann has announced plans to acquire Orange P.L.C., Britain's third-largest mobile phone operator.

title: Sprewell Is Favoring Long-Term Extension
description: Even for a player who accelerates through life as fearlessly as Latrell Sprewell, there is a time to heed the caution light.

title: Stalking Ectoplasm
description: This is a busy season for South Jersey Ghost Research, a ghost-hunting club whose members, armed with detecting gear, identify possible haunts and investigate spectral reports. Recently two observers joined them.

title: For Turks, Art to Mark 700th Year
description: Turkey may be recovering from a crushing earthquake, but nothing will stop that proud country from commemorating next year's 700th anniversary of the founding of the Ottoman Empire. Turks are rediscovering their pre-republic past with an enthusiasm that would have been unthinkable 20 years ago. In London they were among the top bidders at Sotheby's record-breaking Islamic Week auctions, which just ended, and they are expected to appear in New York on Monday for Christie's sale of Orientalist paintings and works of art from the estate of Akram Ojjeh, a Syrian-born financier who died in 1991. The Orientalist paintings go on view today.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY /Collecting; Morgans: Time Travel Made Easy
description: IN the rainy, early-morning hours of a Saturday this month, a traveler here might have mistaken the Interlaken Inn for a ''Great Gatsby'' set. In a roped-off lot, three rows of cars evoked the 1930's, an age of automotive innocence when ''motoring'' was an act of faith in a machine -- and was often an adventure.

title: Offer for Air Canada to Exclude American Stake
description: Faced with virtually certain defeat of its plan to buy Canada's two major airlines and merge them, the Onex Corporation raised its offer today for Air Canada by more than half and took steps to insure that a new, merged carrier is Canadian-controlled by removing American Airlines as an important partner.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: INSIDE
description: New Proposals for Aircraft

title: 20 Free Agents Sign Up Early
description: On the first day eligible players could file for free agency, 20 took that step yesterday. They included Mike Jackson, the Cleveland closer; Steve Trachsel, the Cubs' 18-game loser; Greg Vaughn of Cincinnati; Todd Zeile, Tom Goodwin, Roberto Kelly, Jeff Fassero and Luis Alicea of Texas, and Ricky Gutierrez, Tony Eusebio, Stan Javier and Brian Williams of Houston.

title: Small Employers Describe Health Insurance Concerns
description: The rising cost of health insurance is hitting small employers particularly hard, with premiums for the smallest companies rising 9.2 percent last year, according to a new survey.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in New York City.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Church's Haunted House Draws Fire
description: The sign ''Hell House'' -- suggests any Halloween haunted house, but this one is very different. Blood-spattered teen-agers die in a drunken-driving wreck. A young girl who has been raped by her father commits suicide. A gay man dies of AIDS. And a young woman dies of a botched abortion and descends to hell.

title: Capturing The Moods Of a Nation
description: WHILE the legal battle continues over ''Sensation,'' the show of work by young British artists at the Brooklyn Museum of Art that has drawn fire from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, it is nice to know that the museum continues to go about its business of mounting exhibitions.

title: Returning to City College To Revisit a 1969 Struggle
description: It was 6:30 on a rainy spring morning 30 years ago that more than 200 black and Puerto Rican students padlocked the gates of the south campus at City College and took over 17 buildings to force the college to accept more minority students.

title: Lynda Benglis
description: Cheim & Read

title: PENTAIR TO CONSIDER SALE OF LINCOLN INDUSTRIAL UNIT
description: Pentair Inc. said yesterday that it had hired Banc of America Securities to explore strategic alternatives for its Lincoln Industrial lubrication systems business, including a possible sale. The company, a manufacturer based in St. Paul, said its primary business interests were in woodworking tools, water treatment equipment and casings for electronics; Lincoln makes automated lubrication systems. Pentair acquired Lincoln in 1986 as part of its purchase of the McNeil Corporation. A spokesman said Lincoln, based in St. Louis, had annual sales of about $100 million and employed 700 people.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUMERGRADE, SAUL
description: SUMERGRADE-Saul. Congregation Rodeph Sholom notes with sorrow the passing of our devoted long time member, Saul Sumergrade. Our deepest sympathy is extended to his beloved wife, Alice, and all their dear ones. Robert N. Levine, Sr. Rabbi Mark Biderman, President.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Film Promotion From a Distance

title: N.H.L.: ROUNDUP -- NEW JERSEY
description: The Devils will activate Patrik Elias and Brendan Morrison today, making the two young forwards eligible for tonight's game at Carolina.

title: In Another Sport in Another Country, a Similar Success
description: Their 25th World Series championship puts the Yankees well ahead of all major league baseball teams and nearly all other franchises in the professional sports leagues of North America. But the Yankees lead one team by just a single title: the Montreal Canadiens of the National Hockey League, who have won the Stanley Cup 24 times. The Yankees passed the Canadiens on Wednesday night when they beat the Atlanta Braves by 4-1 to take the 1999 baseball championship in a four-game sweep.

title: Woods Is Slightly Injured While Playing a Bad Lie
description: The next time Tiger Woods sees his ball lodged against a rock, he may think twice about hitting it.

title: SAMSUNG AND THOMSON IN TIE
description: The Samsung Electronics Company of South Korea will set up a joint venture with Thomson-CSF of France in January to operate Samsung's military industry operations. Each company will hold a 50 percent stake. Samsung did not disclose the capitalization of the joint venture, which aims to market its military communications hardware, satellite communications systems, terminals and radar equipment through Thomson's sales network.

title: China Sect Members Covertly Meet Press and Ask World's Help
description: Members of the outlawed Falun Gong spiritual movement held a daring, clandestine meeting with a handful of foreign journalists today to appeal for international pressure to halt the Government's relentless crackdown.

title: In Pursuit of Spirits Doing Time in the Afterlife
description: Halloween is coming. And while we could celebrate by renting ''The Blair Witch Project'' or reading aloud H. P. Lovecraft's horror stories, we decided we wanted to go ghost hunting. The Ghost Hunting 101 manual, which we found on the Internet, advised against beginners seeking out ghosts on their own. So we contacted the author, the New Jersey-based ghost hunter Dave Juliano, to ask how we should proceed.

title: Chanel's United States unit puts several branding and marketing eggs in Young & Rubicam's basket.
description: THE American arm of the French couture house Chanel is fashioning a new relationship with Young & Rubicam Inc., hiring the agency company for a wide range of branding, marketing and media tasks involving its cosmetics and fragrance products.

title: Assisted Suicide: A Federal Crime?
description: To the Editor:

title: E.D.S. Profit Rises 18% in Third Quarter
description: The Electronic Data Systems Corporation's third-quarter profit climbed 18 percent as a surge of new contracts and cost cutting began to pay off for E.D.S., the second-biggest United States computer services company.

title: Hopes for Rescue of Daewoo Again Dim
description: Efforts to overhaul Daewoo, the huge South Korean conglomerate that the Korean Government pulled back from the brink of bankruptcy this summer, are losing momentum.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Firefighters Union Challenges Transfers
description: The 54 firefighters who had been told they would be transferred from a Queens firehouse on Monday will remain in their jobs until a court hearing in which union officials will challenge the transfers.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Seizure of Ecstasy at Airport Shows Club Drug's Increase
description: Three hard-sided suitcases sitting unclaimed at Newark International Airport after a flight from Amsterdam last Friday attracted the curiosity of customs inspectors. Searching the suitcases, they found 200,000 tablets of MDMA, a mind-altering stimulant popularly known as Ecstasy.

title: James Velez, 25; Tormented by Baffling Illness
description: James Velez, a medical riddle who inexplicably scratched himself to the point of self-mutilation and who was the center of one of the most ambitious attempts to attain an independent life for a profoundly disabled individual, died on Wednesday at a hospital in Manhattan. He was 25 and lived in Queens.

title: Gore vs. Bradley
description: To the Editor:

title: Jericho Journal; The Wheel of Fortune Turns for a Biblical Town
description: Sometimes the young Mayor of the oldest city in the world gets ahead of himself.

title: Movement on Rivera's Pitches Is Tough on Bats
description: Television cameras caught the image of Atlanta's Chipper Jones chuckling in the Braves' dugout Wednesday night in the ninth inning of Game 4. Atlanta was on the verge of being swept in the World Series, but Jones could not help himself, after watching Ryan Klesko try to hit against the Yankee closer Mariano Rivera.

title: INSIDE ART
description: After 71 Years, An Expansion

title: WEAK CURRENCY HELPS BANK
description: A decline in the value of Brazil's currency in the third quarter contributed to a rise in profits at Banco Bradesco, the country's largest nongovernment bank. Bradesco's net income climbed 18 percent, to 279.1 million reais, or $140 million, reflecting the bank's increased holdings of foreign currency.

title: They're the Boss
description: Marc Antony

title: Assisted Suicide: A Federal Crime?
description: To the Editor:

title: Clean Record in Construction Finally Pays
description: RAY QUARTARARO would like you to know he is not a crook. And in Mr. Quartararo's line of work -- New York's commercial construction business -- that passes for big news.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUET, JEAN
description: HUET-Jean. Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, SG Americas. A memorial service will be held on Friday, October 29 at 11AM at Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, 980 Park Avenue at 84th St., New York City. Born in Barcelona, Spain, Mr. Huet received his degree from the Paris-based Institut d'Etudes Politiques. He began his career with Societe Generale in 1968 in the Inspection Generale, achieving the rank of Inspecteur Principal. In 1978 he joined the International Division as Area Manager of North America and Great Britain. He came to the United States five years later as Deputy General Manager of SG in the U.S. From 1988 until 1993, he served as General Manager of Societe Generale in London before returning to the U.S. as Chief Executive Officer. Mr. Huet was responsible for leading the significant growth in SG's activities in the United States, Canada and Latin America over the last several years. He was also active in the professional, academic and cultural affairs of New York and the U.S. Mr. Huet served as a member of the Board of the French-American Chamber of Commerce in the United States, Co-Chairman of the Business Committee of the Meotropolitan Museum of Art, Co-Chair of the Carnegie Hall Corporate Fund, and Chair of the Advisory Board of the Center for French Civilization and Culture of New York University, among others. His professional and civic accomplishments were recognized in 1997 when he was awarded the French Legion of Honor, one of the French Republic's highest civilian honors. He is survived by Veronique and Jean-Michel and their mother Michel Huet.

title: Mariners May Face Tampering Charges
description: A friendly phone call placed by the Seattle Mariners' new general manager, Pat Gillick, to the parents of Mets first baseman John Olerud could get Gillick in trouble. Commissioner Bud Selig said yesterday that his office would review whether the call from Gillick on Monday, the day he was introduced as general manager, could constitute tampering, since Olerud is eligible for free agency this winter.

title: El Al Will Buy From Both Boeing and Airbus
description: After 10 months of internal debate over whether it should buy its next jets from Boeing or Airbus, El Al, Israel's national airline, has decided to do both: It will purchase three Boeing 777's and three or four Airbus A330's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DELANEY, THOMAS F.
description: DELANEY-Thomas F., 88. On Oct. 26, 1999 of West Hempstead, N.Y. Cherished husband of Isabel. Devoted father of Carol & Richard Staszak, Jill Axthelm & Charles Jones, Thomas F. Jr. & Julie Igoe, Paul & Kathy. Also survived by eight grandchildren and three great grandchildren. Retired Vice President, Industrial Relations, Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, 1939-1975. Former chairman of company bargaining committee and chief labor negotiator and counsel. Began career as attorney, United States Trucking Corporation. Joined MetLife's law division in 1939. Became Vice President in charge of Industrial Relations department in 1969, responsible for handling all labor relations matters for the company, before retirement in 1975. Continued as Labor Arbitrator, American Arbitration Association; Mediator and Fact-Finder, New York State and Nassau County PERBS; Member of Advisory Arbitration PanelCSEA/Nassau County C.B.A.; Chairman, Nassau County Public Employment Relations Board; Labor Relations consultant to Nassau County, Chief Negotiator; Member Arbitration Board, Nassau County P.B.A. and S.O.A.; Chairman, Member Conciliation Board, Diocese of Rockville Centre. Attended Brooklyn Preparatory School, Fordham College, Fordham Law School. Member New York Bar; Admitted U.S. Supreme Court; Member Emeritus, Association of Life Insurance Counsel; Former Member, National Affairs Committee-New York Chamber of Commerce & Industry. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Avenue at 12th Street, Garden City, Thursday 7-9PM and Friday 2-4 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian burial St. Thomas the Apostle Church, West Hempstead, 10AM Saturday. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery.

title: Leave the Personal to the States
description: Demonstrating again what Justice Sandra Day O'Connor has called its underdeveloped capacity for self-restraint, the House of Representatives voted overwhelmingly for a bill that would make it a crime for doctors to prescribe drugs to help terminally ill patients end their lives.

title: Excerpts From the Five Republican Candidates' Debate at Dartmouth
description: Following are excerpts from a Republican Presidential candidates' forum last night involving Gary L. Bauer, former president of the Family Research Council; the publisher Steve Forbes; Senator Orrin G. Hatch of Utah; Alan Keyes, a radio commentator and former Assistant Secretary of State, and Senator John McCain of Arizona, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency. The candidates answered questions from an audience at Dartmouth College, in Hanover, N.H.

title: Jim Isermann -- 'Fifteen'
description: Institute of Contemporary Art

title: President of Gap Resigns, but Stays on the Board
description: Robert Fisher, the son of the founders of Gap Inc., announced yesterday that he would step down as president of the flagship Gap division, which has had lackluster sales in recent months.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRANOFF, EDITH BLONSTEIN
description: GRANOFF-Edith Blonstein, 86, of Princeton, NJ on October 28, 1999. Former resident of Neponsit, NY. Wife of the late Samuel, mother of Iris (Harry) Brenner and Felicia Katz, sister of Martin Blonstein, grandmother of Marc Shapiro, Lynn S. Starr and Andrew Katz, great grandmother of Jamie Belle and Adam Justin Starr. Services Friday 1PM at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY. information: Orland's Ewing Memorial Chapel, 609-883-1400

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about the Community Re investment Act, which encourages banks to lend in low- and middle-income neighborhoods, misstated the frequency of inspections to check compliance by banks and savings and loans with less than $250 million in assets. For most, the examinations generally occur every two to three years, not every 18 months.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREEDSON, SAM
description: FREEDSON-Sam. The family of Forbidden Broadway send our deepest sympathy to our producer John Freedson on the death of his beloved father Sam. Sam was treasured by all who knew him. We extend our sincerest condolences to John's mother Anita and to David, Margaret and Ramon.

title: How to Lose Your Mooring but Remain Immobile
description: As he demonstrated a decade ago with his semi-autobiographical film, ''Cinema Paradiso,'' Giuseppe Tornatore can be awfully good at plucking nostalgic heartstrings. And in his first English-language film, ''The Legend of 1900,'' the Italian director has created a lavish, poetically ambitious period piece, drenched in romantic atmosphere that wants to tap into our tear ducts while aspiring to be the thinking man's ''Titanic.'' But to be the thinking man's anything requires some serious thought. And this solemn, ersatz epic not only misses the boat intellectually but also fails as entertainment.

title: Abraham Polonsky, 88, Dies; Director Damaged by Blacklist
description: Abraham Polonsky, a director and screenwriter who was an early Hollywood master of film noir and who worked under many disguises after being blacklisted in the McCarthy era, died on Tuesday at his home in Beverly Hills. He was 88.

title: STORAGETEK WILL CUT AS MANY AS 1,750 JOBS
description: The Storage Technology Corporation, a storage product maker that was exploring a possible sale, said it would cut as many as 1,750 jobs, or 20 percent, of its work force, after its third-quarter profit fell 91 percent. The company, known as Storagetek, said it expected $150 million in annual savings from the cuts. Its shares rose 31.25 cents, to $14.9375. The shares have lost 58 percent of their value this year. Storagetek warned that it would miss earnings forecasts as customers delay purchases because of Year 2000 issues.

title: Cone Stays, but Will He Really?
description: The Yankees were 90 minutes into their new yet continuous reign as World Series champions and David Cone was standing near the first-base line at Yankee Stadium doing television interviews. Except for some reporters, security guards, police officers and the ever-accommodating Cone, the Stadium was mostly barren.

title: Theoretical Disasters Test State's Year 2000 Plan
description: Outside, it was a quiet, sunny fall morning, but inside the subterranean State Emergency Management Office Building here, it was shortly after midnight, Jan. 1, 2000, and all hell was breaking loose.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Canteen does make an impression.

title: A Slab of the Choicest Tenderloin
description: IF ever there was a neighborhood to inspire a fashion crisis, it's the meatpacking district.

title: Mayor Needs Old Magic in San Francisco Race
description: For an hour, it was 1995 again, when Willie Lewis Brown Jr. was the newly minted Mayor and San Francisco was dazzled by his possibilities.

title: Accounts
description: * Cyprus Tourism Organization to Bates U.K., London, part of the Bates Worldwide unit of Cordiant Communications Group P.L.C., to handle its consolidated worldwide account, which had been serviced by various local agencies. Billings were estimated at $22 million.

title: The Bronx Roar
description: Domination softened by a human touch. This is what the Yankees displayed in their run to a 25th World Series title, which they clinched Wednesday night at Yankee Stadium. Even while coping with their manager's illness and the deaths of several family members, the Yankees outplayed opponents all season. SECTION G.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTFRIEND, MOSES
description: GOTTFRIEND-Moses. Our heartfelt condolences to Caroline and David Gabay on the passing of Moses Gottfriend, beloved father of Caroline and grandfather of Rebecca and Hannah. ''Goodness is forever.'' His goodness is your legacy. l Hineni Rebbetzin Esther Jungreis, Pres. Barbara Janov, Exec. Director

title: Chris Ofili
description: Gavin Brown's Enterprise

title: 3 Gunmen Charged in Armenia Killings
description: Armenian prosecutors brought terrorism charges against 3 of 5 gunmen who seized the Parliament on Wednesday, killing 8 people, including Prime Minister Vazgen Sarkisian, and holding 40 hostages.

title: JUSTICE DEPARTMENT CHALLENGES VIASOFT DEAL
description: The Justice Department said yesterday that it would challenge the Compuware Corporation's proposed $168 million purchase of the Year 2000 software maker Viasoft , arguing the transaction would mean higher prices for mainframe software. Compuware, a provider of software products and staffing services to large companies, had hoped to add Viasoft's E-commerce transformation software to its line of products. It offered to buy its Phoenix-based competitor in July for $9 a share. Viasoft's shares fell $1.0625 each, to $7.50, while Compuware rose 6.25 cents, to $26.875, before trading was halted for both companies. The Justice Department said the two companies were head-to-head competitors for mainframe testing.

title: As Confetti Falls, Questions Will Fly About 2000
description: The Yankees' championship celebrations have evolved beyond the uncontrolled spraying of champagne. Sure, there was some dousing done after they wiped out the Atlanta Braves in the World Series, completing their sweep with a 4-1 victory in Game 4 at Yankee Stadium on Wednesday night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKS, DUKE
description: MARKS-Duke. His friends and family mourn the passing of a truly kind, generous-hearted man. Cherished husband of Daisy, beloved father of Walter and Peter, caring grandfather of Ben, Annie and Sam. We miss you. The Seckel, Corpuel and Teich Families

title: Spitzer Asks Court to End Suit Against Apollo Theater
description: Bringing a quiet end to an often rancorous dispute over a storied Harlem landmark, the State Attorney General, Eliot L. Spitzer, asked a court yesterday to dismiss his office's lawsuit against the state-owned Apollo Theater.

title: Mullen Selected By Lending Tree
description: Lending Tree Inc. in Charlotte, N.C., an on-line loan marketplace that connects consumers to lenders, said yesterday that it had awarded its first account to Mullen Advertising in Wenham, Mass. Billings were estimated at $50 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTINEZ, JULIO
description: MARTINEZ-Julio. The Project Return Foundation family mourns the untimely passing of our founder, who went on the become New York State Commissioner of Substance Abuse Services. His career was devoted to helping substance abusers find a better life through recovery. We honor his commitment and achievements and send our sincere condolences to all his family. He will be missed by all. Project Return Foundation Jane Velez, President Dr. Judith D. Wallach, Chairperson

title: A Maternal Bond Glows in the Dying of the Light
description: Life may not be as perfectly bittersweet as it is painted in ''Lost for Words.'' But it ought to be.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Economy Expands Briskly, With Labor Costs Benign

title: Help for Afghan Women
description: To the Editor:

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: One Closing, xA Second Likely

title: Knoblauch, Weak Link, Has Strong Role
description: Chuck Knoblauch had to sit down to keep talking. He was too drained to stand any longer. It was evident Wednesday night in the way he methodically unlaced his cleats, the way he slowly pulled off his uniform and the way he barely budged when Clay Bellinger swooped in and kissed him on the forehead.

title: Sports of The Times; Bellinger Enjoys Taste Of Big Time
description: AT the cacophonous end of another memorable Yankees World Series run, the cameras sought out the stars, and their faces glistening with champagne lighted up the night. Far away from center stage of this now familiar theater, Clay Bellinger found his wife outside the clubhouse, they kissed, and their eyes welled with tears.

title: Peacekeepers at a Loss on Failure to Protect Serb Convoy
description: Officials of NATO and the United Nations struggled today to explain how they failed to protect a convoy of Serbian civilians from a sudden and ferocious Albanian attack on Wednesday.

title: U.N. Council Shelves Proposal on Upgrading Iraq Oil Industry
description: A recommendation by Secretary General Kofi Annan that Iraq be allowed to double the amount it may spend on upgrading its oil industry was shelved by the Security Council today, somewhat to the surprise of the United States and Britain, which were prepared for a spirited debate with France and Russia over the request.

title: Official Fears Impact of Rule On Homeless
description: Acknowledging that strict new welfare rules have mistakenly cut some people from the rolls, the city official in charge of homeless services expressed concern yesterday that work requirements and other new rules for homeless people could risk wrongly depriving some families of shelter.

title: Fears Rise for Chechen Refugees as Winter Nears
description: An early autumn chill has already descended on the border regions around Chechnya, fast on the heels of fighting that has forced almost 200,000 Chechens to flee their homes as Russian troops bomb and strafe their breakaway republic.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 24 about the retirement of Tony Benn, a longtime member of the Labor Party, from the British Parliament misstated the family name of his wife, Caroline. In a letter dated Oct. 11, she said it was DeCamp, not Middleton.

title: Yagudin Leads Weiss After the Short Program
description: He was dressed like a refugee from Alexander's Ragtime Band, with a gold trombone stenciled on one leg of his green velvet suit and a keyboard sash flying from his waist. But the two-time world champion Aleksei Yagudin's skates were operating in full harmony tonight as he took the lead after the men's short program at Skate America.

title: UNITRIN CONTINUING TO CUT ITS STAKE IN BAKER HUGHES
description: Unitrin Inc., an insurance and consumer finance company, sold shares of Baker Hughes Inc. for about $85 million, further cutting its stake in the third-largest United States oilfield service company to just under 5 percent. Chicago-based Unitrin said it sold 2.8 million shares at an average price of $30.22 between Sept. 10 and this Wednesday, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. In September, Unitrin reported it had trimmed its stake to 5.8 percent and intended to sell more. The recent move cut Unitrin and two unidentified Unitrin subsidiaries' total stake in Houston-based Baker by to 16.4 million, or a 4.98 percent holding. Shares of Baker have risen about 57 percent this year but have fallen in recent weeks. Shares of Baker gained 31.25 cents yesterday, to $27.9375.

title: The Concerto as a Metaphor for the Individual in Society
description: CONCERTO CONVERSATIONS

title: Washington Voters Face Choice to Tax Themselves or Not
description: The fierce debate over Initiative 695, a measure on the ballot here in Washington State next Tuesday that would all but do away with an unpopular state tax on automobiles, does not quite have the gravitas of the battle in Washington, D.C., over how to preserve Social Security or Medicare.

title: A War Over Words And Where They Go
description: If good fences make good neighbors, the Damucks and Marty Bodwicz need a tall, thick wall, able to withstand the caprices of cordless phones, baby monitors and video recorders. By all accounts, the three are not good neighbors at all, and their enmity is reaching the courts in an unconventional way.

title: Los Angeles Acts to Oust Besieged Schools Chief
description: With 660 schools, 67,000 employees and 700,000 students, nearly 70 percent of them Hispanic, the Los Angeles Unified School District is a fair proxy for the future of the nation's second-largest city. These days, that future looks cloudy at best.

title: City Hall Uses a Celebration to Get Even
description: There could hardly be a happier day for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani than one in which he presides over a victory party for his beloved New York Yankees. But politics is politics, and the Giuliani administration also took advantage of yesterday's ticker tape frenzy to exact some political revenge.

title: Finding the Connections To Cole Porter's Music
description: Bobby Short

title: Dozens More From Sect Arrested in Beijing
description: Dozens more followers of the banned Falun Gong spiritual movement were detained today in Tiananmen Square, a few of them dragged away shouting, in the fifth straight day of protests while hundreds and perhaps thousands of fugitive believers were said to remain hidden around the city.

title: Coming Full Circle, Strawberry Sheds Tears
description: Darryl Strawberry strode to the podium at City Hall yesterday and thanked George Steinbrenner, Joe Torre, his teammates and the fans for the support they had given him during a year in which he was arrested in April and then suspended from baseball for almost four months. It was a rousing celebration for the Yankees that Strawberry once thought would not include him.

title: $35,000 Awards To New Writers
description: The 10 recipients of the 1999 Whiting Writers' Awards have been announced by the Pierpont Morgan Library. The awards, given annually to young emerging writers by the Mrs. Giles Whiting Foundation, are $35,000 each this year.

title: PARENTS BLAMING PARENTS
description: Can mothers and fathers be held responsible for the murderous actions of their children? Some families of victims say yes and are taking their cases to court. A report by Lisa Belkin in The Times Magazine.

title: Deal Is Reached On Lithuania Oil
description: Lithuania sold a minority stake in Mazeikiu Nafta, owner of the country's oil refinery and pipeline, to the Williams Companies of the United States for $150 million after the Prime Minister resigned to protest the sale.

title: The Yankees, Champions for All
description: To the Editor:

title: AIR CANADA SPURNS NEW OFFER
description: The chief executive of Air Canada, Robert Milton, said the Onex Corporation's revised takeover bid of $1.5 billion for both Air Canada and Canadian Airlines was inferior to Air Canada's own proposal for combining the two air carriers. Onex has increased the price for Air Canada by almost 60 percent in the new proposal. It also has removed American Airlines as a financial backer to satisfy concerns that a newly merged airline should remain Canadian-controlled.

title: Safety Alert
description: Standard time resumes at 2 A.M. tomorrow; clocks should be set back an hour.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GORIN, MARGARET
description: GORIN-Margaret. 10/31/11-2/16/97. Beloved sister to Irene and Leo and aunt of Kathy and Mark and great aunt of Alex and Destiny Rose. We miss you always

title: Impasse in Senate Delays Action On Africa-Caribbean Trade Bills
description: The Senate today temporarily set aside a package of trade bills for African and Caribbean nations while Republican and Democratic leaders tried to break a partisan impasse over several unrelated amendments.

title: Spinning a Little History In a Studio Painted Pink
description: In October 1955 Memphis woke up to a radical new sound: not the twangy rhythm-and-blues of an awkward young singer named Elvis Presley, who was already on his way to stardom, but the dulcet voices of WHER, the nation's first ''all girl'' radio station.

title: Ex-Teamster Official Is Charged With Graft
description: A board of Federal monitors yesterday charged a top lieutenant of Ron Carey, the former teamsters' union president, with embezzling more than $12,500 and with breaching his fiduciary duty to union members.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARTUR, M. HARRY
description: WARTUR-M. Harry. The Jewish Center of the Hamptons mourns the passing of M. Harry Wartur, father of Charles L. Wartur. We extend our deepest condolences to Charles and his family. Rabbi David J. Gelfand Cantor Debra Stein-Davidson Donald Zucker, President

title: Tyco Shares Fall Again After New Questions About Accounting
description: Shares of Tyco International fell almost 9 percent yesterday after a report raised more questions about the company's accounting practices.

title: Grief, Real And Imagined
description: When planes fall from the sky, or boats sink in the seas, or trains collide -- whenever the worst that can happen happens -- everyone in earshot is given pause. And pause we must, over this past week's sadness with Payne Stewart, the husband, the father and yes, the golfer. And we do. Not because we golf. Because we breathe.

title: Memo From Islamabad; Why Democracy Means Little to Pakistan's Poor
description: An answer to the mystery of why so many ordinary Pakistanis rejoiced when the military smashed their democracy can be found right here within the city limits of the nation's capital, in a small, centuries-old village nestled into the Margalla Hills.

title: Toshiba Faces $1 Billion Bill Over a Lawsuit
description: The Toshiba Corporation said today that it would spend about $1 billion to settle a class-action lawsuit brought by two people contending that the company, the world's leading maker of laptop computers, had sold five million defective machines in the United States since 1987.

title: McCain on the Story of His Life
description: This is the first commercial of the Presidential campaign for Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, broadcast this week in New Hampshire. It is chiefly a biographical sketch.

title: To Keep Out Illegal Cars, Mexico Plans a Huge Fee
description: A Government plan to require deposits of up to $800 from travelers who drive cars with American license plates into Mexico has provoked dismay from critics who say it could persuade hundreds of thousands of tourists to cancel trips here.

title: Embracing Fear as Fun To Practice for Reality; Why People Like to Terrify Themselves
description: These are the times when things go bump in the night. When the Cyclone roller coaster at Coney Island climbs toward a blackened sky, the wooden supports creaking as the cars rumble toward the terrifying, 85-foot first drop, sending the riders into a frenzy of screams. When a 6-year-old boy listens with dread and fascination to a bedtime retelling of ''Jack and the Beanstalk,'' the story of a monster and his young nemesis. And when a teen-age girl in a darkened movie theater finds her palms sweaty and her breath shallow as the macabre final twist of ''The Sixth Sense'' unfolds.

title: Knicks Search for Form and Motivation
description: The Knicks spent their languid preseason searching for something to inspire them to begin a sequel to their dramatic success last season. At times, you could almost see them look at their director, Coach Jeff Van Gundy, and ask: What's my motivation?

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Thursday with the the Making Books column misstated the title of the book being reviewed. It is ''Empire Express: Building the First Transcontinental Railroad,'' not ''The Empire Express.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REITMAN, SEYMOUR
description: REITMAN-Seymour. The sweetest and best of men. He will sorely be missed by all his family and friends. Norman & Barbara

title: All-French Semis
description: Top-seeded Mary Pierce rallied to beat Irina Spirlea of Romania, 3-6, 6-2, 6-3, yesterday and turn the $520,000 Generali Ladies tournament in Linz, Austria, into an all-French affair.

title: With Smiles and Tears, Stewart's Family and Friends Say Goodbye
description: It was a memorial service that fit the personality of Payne Stewart -- emotional, humorous, unique and unforgettable.

title: J. Howard Edgerton, 91, Official In S.& L. Industry in California
description: J. Howard Edgerton, who decades ago built the California Federal Savings and Loan Association into the nation's largest savings institution, died Oct. 14 at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 91.

title: O'Neill Finds Comfort Being With His Friends
description: Andrew and Aaron O'Neill, ages 10 and 7, bounced around the clubhouse at Yankee Stadium yesterday morning. They had hardly slept, their father said, because they were so excited about the parade being held for the Yankees yesterday.

title: Senator Leads Move to Block Ruling on Strip Mines
description: Led by Senator Robert C. Byrd, the West Virginia Congressional delegation is planning 11th-hour legislation to block what environmentalists call a landmark Federal court ruling that severely restricts the state's strip mining of mountaintops.

title: Brooklyn Robbery Suspect, 17, Is Shot to Death by the Police
description: A rookie police officer fatally shot a 17-year-old robbery suspect in the back of the neck early yesterday morning in Brooklyn after another suspect opened fire on the officers, the police said.

title: Some Haunted Houses Never Change
description: If the ever vigilant Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, is truly determined to snuff out inflation aborning, then he can do no better than to take sharpened pencil in hand, make his way to the nearest theater showing 'House on Haunted Hill'' and strike fearlessly until the film's feeble pulse beats no more.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINBERG, BARBARA
description: STEINBERG-Barbara Ruth on October 29, 1999 at the age of 58. Loving mother of Laura Steinberg Tisch, Jonathan and Nicholas Steinberg. Adoring grandmother to Charles and Henry Tisch and mother-in-law to Maria Steinberg. Devoted daughter to Abe and Frieda Herzog. Dear sister of Martin Herzog and beloved companion of Justin Hornik. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St, Sunday 11:30am. Interment New Montefiore Cemetery, Wellwood, NY.

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article on Tuesday about the presidential election in Argentina misstated the title of Domingo Cavallo, who finished third. He is a Congressman, not a Senator.

title: RULES ON PRIVACY OF PATIENT DATA STIR HOT DEBATE
description: President Clinton kicked off an intense debate today on how to protect the privacy of medical records in an era when doctors can test their patients for genetic defects and send the information around the world with the click of a computer mouse.

title: Hurdles to Tobacco Pact Seen at Global Meeting
description: More than 100 nations agreed this week on the need for a global treaty to control tobacco sales, but some of the big hurdles to such a pact quickly became evident.

title: Tale of an 'Impossible' Slam: He Got By With a Little Help
description: Some feats at the bridge table are simply ''impossible'': you cannot, barring a revoke, make a grand slam missing the ace of trumps.

title: Writers and Editors
description: To the Editor:

title: Art Dealer Is Convicted Of Attempt At Extortion
description: Andrew Crispo, the prominent New York art dealer, was convicted yesterday of attempted extortion and obstruction of justice in connection with his threats to kidnap the 4-year-old daughter of a lawyer who had worked on his bankruptcy case.

title: Milutinovic Is Leaving MetroStars
description: After a calamitous season as the worst team in Major League Soccer, the MetroStars and Bora Milutinovic agreed to part ways yesterday, leaving the team with the task of hiring its sixth coach since it started play in 1996.

title: A Day Off, Sanctioned By Fan No. 1 In the City
description: Just before 10 A.M. yesterday, a dozen teen-agers from the Upper West Side on their way to the Yankee victory parade jammed into the tail end of the downtown No. 1 train -- their boom box blaring, cigarettes smoking and a bottle of Cointreau passing between them.

title: Sampras Returning
description: Pete Sampras will begin his comeback from injury at next week's Paris Open against either Francisco Clavet of Spain or Jiri Novak of the Czech Republic, following yesterday's draw. Sampras, a two-time Paris Open winner, has been out for two months because of a strained right hip and herniated disk.

title: Julio Martinez, Ex-Drug Official, Dies at 55
description: Julio Martinez, a former drug addict who helped found the Phoenix House and Project Return programs for addicts and who eventually became the director of New York State's drug treatment programs, died on Thursday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. He was 55 and lived in the Bronx.

title: Ilgauskas Will Miss At Least 8 Weeks
description: Cavaliers center Zydrunas Ilgauskas will miss at least the first eight weeks of the season with a sore left foot, the team said yesterday.

title: Slumping Rangers Lose Injured Kamensky for 2 Weeks
description: If the Rangers score a goal tonight for the first time in four games, they will have to do it without Valery Kamensky.

title: Dr. Theodor H. Benzinger, 94, Inventor of the Ear Thermometer
description: Dr. Theodor H. Benzinger, a medical researcher who invented the ear thermometer and a device to measure calorie loss, died on Tuesday at a retirement home in Bethesda, Md. He was 94.

title: Death Penalty Gets Attention Of High Court
description: The death penalty kept the Supreme Court working late this week. Twice the Justices responded to the pleas of death row inmates, hours away from execution, not only by granting last-minute stays of execution but also by accepting their cases for full argument and decision.

title: U.S. Panel Moves to Force Disclosure in Gene Testing
description: Concerned that investigators in gene therapy experiments are trying to keep information about patient deaths and serious side effects out of public view, members of a Federal oversight panel are planning to rewrite their rules to force greater disclosure.

title: U.S. Appeals Trade Ruling on Tax Breaks
description: The United States filed an appeal today against a World Trade Organization ruling that invalidated $2.5 billion in tax breaks to American companies with overseas subsidiaries.

title: Corrections
description: A headline on the Market Place column of Business Day on Thursday about a takeover battle for a British bank reversed the identities of the potential acquirer and the target. It is the Bank of Scotland that has made a $34 billion hostile bid for National Westminster Bank.

title: Panel Backs British in Beef Dispute With France
description: Britain won a major victory over France today when a panel of European Commission scientists ruled that British beef was safe to eat despite French arguments for a continued ban to guard against so-called mad cow disease.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN GAINS. The yen rose against the dollar amid expectations that investors would channel more money into Japanese stocks. In New York, the dollar settled at 104.16 yen, down from 105.04 on Thursday.

title: The Pleasure of Playing, With Life and Death Offstage
description: The grand Dutch tradition of Mahler interpretation is evidently continuing in the work of Hans Vonk, who conducted the St. Louis Symphony at Carnegie Hall on Thursday in a resplendent account of the composer's Third Symphony. The work may be, like every Mahler symphony, a matter of life and death, but Mr. Vonk found no cause there for desperation. He conducted a performance of huge dynamic range and sometimes of startling changes in tempo or color, but his choices were dictated less by urgent expressive needs than by a pleasure in the music and a justified pride in how his orchestra can play it.

title: Homeless Plan: Sheer Demagogy; Low-Cost Housing
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about saffron misidentified the origin of the variety of the spice that Richard Olney, a food writer, once introduced to the cookbook author Paula Wolf ert. It came from Kashmir, not Greece.

title: French Finance Minister Named in Party Scandal
description: PARIS  Allegations of corruption with potentially major impact have begun to wash up close to the government of Prime Minister Lionel Jospin and its finance minister, Dominique Strauss-Kahn, French socialism's designated-guarantor of good sense to the international business and investment communities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, AARON F.
description: GOLDSTEIN-Aaron F. 90 Retired Justice of the Supreme Court of the State of NY. Loving husband of Sophie (Factor). Father of Drs. Edward (Patty) and Leonard (Barbara) Goldstein. Grandfather of Lizzie (Rick), Stephen (Amy), Jonah, Geoffrey, and Jesse. Greatgradfather of Judson. Graveside funeral is on Sunday, October 31, at 10 A.M., at the Old Montefiore Cemetery.

title: PUMA TECHNOLOGY ACQUIRES PROXINET FOR $86 MILLION
description: Puma Technology Inc. acquired Proxinet Inc. yesterday for 2.6 million Puma common shares. Based on Puma Technology's closing stock price on Thursday, the deal was worth about $86 million. Puma said the acquisition provides real-time access to users of hand-held devices, cellular phones and other wireless devices and Internet appliances. Puma Technology's stock rose $3.9375, to $37, in Nasdaq trading. Puma Technology is a mobile device management company.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Cracks in Canada's Glass Ceiling; Women Get Some Top Posts, but Few Boardroom Keys
description: In the early 1990's, Barbara G. Stymiest, a partner at the accounting firm Ernst & Young here, was irritated to discover that her Toronto golf club reserved Saturday morning tee times for men, on the assumption that wives could play all week long.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Toshiba to Spend $1 Billion To Settle Laptop Lawsuit

title: Calipari's Return Is Friendlier Than His Departure
description: Keith Van Horn thought his former coach John Calipari might be in for a hostile reception tonight at the Meadowlands. It was Calipari's first appearance at Continental Arena since he was fired on March 15, and Van Horn thought it might get venomous.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I'll take my chances admitting we went to the Yankee parade. I pay them enough every year. They'll have to get over it.''

title: Bitter Deadlock Leads to a Mistrial in a Youth's Slaying
description: A Brooklyn judge declared a mistrial yesterday in the case of a teen-ager accused of fatally stabbing another youth in a dispute stemming from an after-school basketball game.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSTEN, CHARLOTTE
description: OSTEN-Charlotte, 89. On October 29, 1999. Formerly of Great Neck, NY. Beloved wife of the late Leonard and mother of Donald, of Nashville, TN, and Margery Loewenwarter, of Croton-on-Hudson, NY. Devoted grandmother of Cheryl Grieve and of Scott, and great grandmother of newborn Gregory. Services will be private.

title: Midas Touch Was Billionaire's Gift to Bush
description: If George W. Bush can thank his father for a well-known name, for much of his wealth he can thank Richard E. Rainwater, a billionaire investor from Fort Worth.

title: Flat-Tax Follies
description: The Republican presidential candidates who debated in New Hampshire Thursday night did not quarrel much. But it was especially discouraging that they embraced a flat tax to replace the progressive income tax. In the 1996 G.O.P. primaries, Steve Forbes made the flat tax a centerpiece of his campaign, only to have Bob Dole demolish the idea by pointing out the absurdity of lowering tax rates on rich people like Mr. Forbes and raising them on the middle class. This week Mr. Forbes said he was delighted at the revival of his issue. But Republicans would do well to drop it or risk being seen as a servant of the privileged.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINBERG, ELIZABETH (NEE SMITH)
description: FEINBERG - Elizabeth (nee Smith). On October 21, 1999. Respected and beloved former teacher at New Dorp High School, Staten Island. Former Chairman of the Department of English, Walton High School, Bronx. Beloved wife of the late Sol Feinberg, dear mother-in-law of Wera Hildebrand, loving grandmother of Andrea and Kirsten Hildebrand, devoted great-aunt of Thomas Miles. A memorial service will be held Saturday, November 6th at the Horn-Dannecker Funeral Home, 336 W. 23 St, NYC at 2PM. In lieu of flowers please make donations in her memory to either The Recordings for the Blind or Save the Children Foundation of Appalacia.

title: Bobbing Up in the Polls, McCain Is Feeling Buoyant
description: Mainlining glazed doughnuts and mixing it up with reporters in the back of his bus, the Straight Talk Express, Senator John McCain really seems to be having the fun that all Presidential candidates talk about having.

title: Williams Immediately Seeks Care for a Painful Shoulder
description: The throbbing in his shoulder persisted for more than four months, but Bernie Williams played through it, finishing the regular season with a .342 batting average and 115 runs batted in and performing spectacularly on defense in the post-season. But now he can rest, and Williams, the Yankees' center fielder, wants to have his injured left shoulder taken care of immediately.

title: The Yankees, Champions for All
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FUTTERMAN, SIDNEY
description: FUTTERMAN-Sidney. Beloved husband of the late Myra. Loving father of Bennett and Lisa and Larry. Devoted grandfather of Shira, Jemma, Abby, Matthew, Noah, Heather, David and Rachel. Dear brother of Tem Weisman and the late Annette Goldenberg. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island at 1:30 PM on Sunday.

title: Working Hard So the Fans Can Party
description: It's not every pop heartthrob who arrives onstage at Madison Square Garden, as Ricky Martin did on Thursday night, citing the Venezuelan revolutionary Simon Bolivar and telling the crowd, ''We are uniting the Americas.'' Now that he has taught his fellow Americans what ''la vida loca'' means, Mr. Martin has moved on to greater ambitions.

title: Less Than Amazin' Outing for Mets Fans
description: Jam-packed lower Broadway was a lonely place to be a Mets fan yesterday.

title: A Call That Brazil Airlines Merge Gets a Cool Reception
description: Three of Brazil's leading airlines have dismissed a proposal from a competitor that they all merge into a company to be called Air Latina.

title: Meddling With Oregon's Law
description: There is something cruel and intrusive about a bill passed by the House of Representatives this week making it a federal crime for doctors to prescribe lethal drugs so that terminally ill patients can end their own lives. Congress is behaving like a bad-tempered elephant, stomping and trumpeting to overturn an assisted-suicide law approved twice by the voters of Oregon. The Oregon law, a responsible effort to ease suffering at the end of life, allows physicians to aid suicides of the terminally ill under carefully defined circumstances.

title: Two Mayors Ask Apology From a Third
description: The mayors of Newark and Jersey City demanded an apology today from the mayor of Elizabeth, who said nonpartisan elections imposed an unnecessary expense and led to less-responsive local government.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE RISES. Coffee rose on expectations that a prolonged dry spell is damaging crops in Brazil, the world's top grower. In New York, coffee for December delivery rose 3.5 cents, or 3.6 percent, to $1.002 a pound.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAMINER, PHYLLIS
description: KAMINER-Phyllis. The Neuropsychoanalysis Center of the New York Psychoanalytic Institute mourns the passing of the beloved wife of our esteemed member of the Board, Henry Kaminer, MD. We extend our deepest sympathy to her devoted husband and their family. Arnold Z. Pfeffer, MD, Chairman

title: Rumors of Violence Close School and Put Police and Educators on Alert
description: A bomb threat scrawled on a bathroom wall led to the closing of a Monmouth County school today, while rumors of impending gang violence at a number of Essex County schools led to heightened scrutiny by school and law enforcement officials.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLLINS, MARTIN S.
description: POLLINS-Martin S. Retired radio, television and entertainment executive. Died on October 28, 1999 at the age of 80 in New York City. Martin was born in Manhattan and served in the Navy during WWII. He was a senior executive in spot sales for ABC and NBC, Vice President of Distribution for Paramount Pictures and President of Gannett Productions in New York City. He is survived by his wife Judith, sister Elinor Ellis, daughters Terri Carr and Phyllis Maguire, three grandchildren, Lindsay and Morgan Maguire, and Ryan Carr. A memorial service will be held at ''The Riverside'', Sunday, October 31st, 11:15AM. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Make a Wish Foundation, 85 Old Shore Road, Port Washington, New York 11050.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINSBERG, ROSE
description: GINSBERG-Rose. 94 years young. Cherished aunt of Sheila Graziano. Loving grand aunt of Richard Kapner and Kevin Kapner. Also survived by other nieces, nephews, grand nieces and grand nephews. Private services. For information call ''Bernheim Apter Goldsticker'' Surburban Funeral Chapel, Maplewood, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, ELEANOR A.
description: BROWN-Eleanor A. 76 on October 28, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Ben Brown, mother of Joshua and Jennifer, grandmother of Gideon and Daniel, mother-in-law of Julie and Talbot. A creative spirit and keen mind, Eleanor was attorneyat-law, fashion designer, and loving wife and mother. She also was current President, Executive Council, Committee on the Status of Women (U.N. Congress of NonGovernmental Organizations), President, International Federation of Women Lawyers (FIDA), and President, Sociological Initiatives, Inc. Services will be held on Sunday, October 31, 9:30 A.M. at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: LIMIT ON DAEWOO AID
description: South Korea will inject no more than 3 trillion won ($1.5 billion) to aid two investment trust companies that have been heavily exposed to Daewoo losses, the Minister of Finance and Economy, Kang Bong Kyun, said. In a bid to calm uncertainties arising from the Daewoo Group's financial crisis, Mr. Kang said all investors would be able to redeem their bonds held in investment trusts, which hold trillions of won worth of notes linked to the ailing conglomerate. The finance minister said that the amount of public funds required to address the problems of the investment trust sector will be made clear next week when an audit of 12 Daewoo affiliates is completed.

title: Modernize Medicare?
description: To the Editor:

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: TODAY'S KEY GAMES

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINK, HELEN
description: FINK-Helen. Beloved wife of the late Al. Devoted mother of Fran and Dick Wolff and Len and Nancy. Dear sister of Adele Klein. Loving grandmother and great grandmother. Service Sunday, at 12 Noon, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Princeton Makes It Three in a Row
description: Princeton and Notre Dame won men's titles, and Brown and Georgetown took women's titles yesterday in the two cross-country events held at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.

title: Arrests, Injuries and Scuffles Amid a Day of Celebration
description: As the New York Yankees ticker-tape parade marched up Broadway and dignitaries celebrated the team's World Series victory inside the gated confines of City Hall Park, the police were kept busy yesterday with scattered scuffles and unruliness among the throngs of fans packed into the surrounding blocks and along the parade route.

title: Investigators Say Inquiry On Bank of New York Stalls
description: More than a year after Federal authorities began their investigation at the Bank of New York, law enforcement officials say the global money laundering inquiry has bogged down and may never be solved unless Russia or other countries help American prosecutors crack the case.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: Modernize Medicare?
description: To the Editor:

title: MOTOROLA MAKES DEAL TO INCREASE WIRELESS PRODUCTS
description: Motorola Inc., the world's No. 2 maker of cellular phones, bought the closely held Software Corporation of America , bolstering its efforts to supply wireless products to police departments. Terms were undisclosed. The Software Corporation's 80 employees will join Motorola, and Shirley Eis, the company's founder and chief executive, will continue to run the company as a Motorola unit president. The software maker's products provide police officers with real-time wireless access to Federal, state and local crime data bases. Software, based in Stamford, Conn., has a Canadian division called Talkthru Canada Inc. Shares of Motorola, based in Schaumburg, Ill., rose $3.625, to $97.3125.

title: NEWELL RUBBERMAID ADDS UNIT OF MCKECHNIE OF BRITAIN
description: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., the maker of Levolor blinds and Calphalon cookware, bought the consumer-goods unit of McKechnie P.L.C. for $:81.5 million ($133.7 million), to expand its variety of products and distribution network in Europe. Newell will add Harrison Drape, Spur Shelving, the cabinet maker Douglas Kane and the window-trim maker Nenplas-Homelux to its window furnishings, hardware and home storage operations. The businesses generated sales of $:93 million in the year that ended on July 31, McKechnie said. McKechnie, based in Walsall, England, makes fasteners and bearings for planes and plastic wheel parts for cars. Newell Rubbermaid, based in Freeport, Ill., also makes Goody hair accessories, Burnes picture frames and Rolodex office products.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORWIN, OSCAR
description: CORWIN-Oscar. On October 28, 1999 of Fort Lee, NJ. Beloved husband of Viola. Devoted father of Steven and Philip. Loving grandfather of Noah, Ellissa and Alexander. Services Sunday 10A.M. at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: West Nile Virus Found in Bird in Maryland
description: A dead bird found in Maryland has tested positive for the West Nile virus, the disease that killed seven people in the New York region this summer and made dozens of others ill, officials from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said yesterday.

title: Moving Beyond Race
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTINEZ, JULIO
description: MARTINEZ-Julio. The Project Return Foundation family mourns the untimely passing of our founder, who went on the become New York State Commissioner of Substance Abuse Services. His career was devoted to helping substance abusers find a better life through recovery. We honor his commitment and achievements and send our sincere condolences to all his family. He will be missed by all. Project Return Foundation Jane Velez, President Dr. Judith D. Wallach, Chairperson

title: 2 Plead Guilty in Scheme Involving Real Estate
description: A mortgage processor and a legal secretary admitted yesterday that they falsified documents and cleansed files at the request of their employers, implicating them in a scheme involving the fraudulent sale of hundreds of rundown, overvalued properties.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALPERN, GERTRUDE
description: ALPERN-Gertrude. The Board of Governors and members of Fairview Country Club note with profound sorrow, the passing of Gertrude Alpern, a distinguished former member.
