On behalf of all our members we express our deepest condolences to her family. Bernard Steinweg, President Heidi Klein, Secretary

title: Jets Say They Still Have Time to Turn Things Around
description: The Jets' 1-6 record has had a profound effect on linebacker Dwayne Gordon, who recalled the philosopher George Santayana today. Asked whether he had learned anything from history -- other teams overcoming bad starts to reclaim a season -- Gordon replied, ''Those who cannot remember the past are condemned to repeat it.''

title: Clinton, at Rally in Philadelphia, Is Doubtful About Endorsements
description: President Clinton raised doubts today about whether Presidents can sway the results of local elections, even as he came to the aid of a Democratic mayoral candidate here who is in danger of losing City Hall to a Republican for the first time in half a century.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VELEZ, JAMES
description: VELEZ-James. Though we were not privileged to know you, we are inspired by your courage. Rabbi Simeon Kolko Sherri and Zachary Kolko

title: Frank DeVol, 88, a Composer For Movies and TV Sitcoms
description: Frank DeVol, the composer of more than 50 film scores along with such familiar television tunes as ''The Brady Bunch'' song, died on Wednesday at a nursing home in Lafayette, Calif. He was 88.

title: Scaring the Salaryman Isn't the Japanese Way
description: Mitsubishi Motors just announced plans to cut 10,000 jobs. Last week Nissan, now owned by Renault and answering to its tough-minded foreign boss, pledged to slash 16,500.

title: GENERAL GROWTH PROPERTIES BUYS MALL IN HOUSTON
description: General Growth Properties Inc., the second-largest shopping-mall company in the United States, said yesterday that it had acquired a mall in Houston for $133 million and was considering a joint venture to acquire half of another. The Chicago-based real estate investment trust acquired the Baybrook Mall from Rreef USA Fund-III, a pension fund. General Growth has been one of the most active buyers in the consolidation under way in the industry. Baybrook Mall was developed in 1978 and remodeled in 1995. It has 1.08 million square feet and is 95 percent occupied. General Growth also said it was considering a joint venture with an institutional owner of another mall.

title: Coke Assigns Larger Roles To 3 Officers
description: Coca-Cola said yesterday that three top executives would assume greater authority, apparently setting up a succession contest for the top job and easing some criticism that the chairman and chief executive, M. Douglas Ivester, lacked a second in command.

title: Sanders Goes From Out of Football to Likely Starter
description: It now appears that Brandon Sanders, the free agent the Giants signed three days ago, and not the rookie Lyle West, will start for the team at free safety against the Philadelphia Eagles on Sunday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: Vampire Moms and Mexican Macabre
description: Among the holidays, I've always loved Halloween a little too well. More than Christmas, for example, because Christmas comes with its burden of guilt and anxiety: Santa's godlike eye cast backward over the year, and for adults the more painful consciousness that in truth it isn't goodness that determines who receives what.

title: SHERATON MAKES OFFER TO BUY THE REST OF CIGA OF ITALY
description: Sheraton International began an all-cash takeover offer yesterday for the shares it does not already own in CIGA S.p.A. of Italy. Sheraton is a wholly owned subsidiary of Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide Inc. Sheraton will offer about 95 cents for each CIGA ordinary share and about $1.17 for each CIGA savings share, for a total value of $297 million, Starwood said. Savings shares are a type of preferred stock. Sheraton already holds 72.91 percent of CIGA common shares and about 30.85 percent of the outstanding savings shares. It acquired its stake in 1994. Starwood owns, manages and franchises hotels under the names St. Regis, Luxury Collection, Westin, Sheraton, Four Points and W. Over all, Starwood has more than 700 hotels in 76 countries.

title: U.S. to Spend $20 Million To Acquire King's Papers
description: The Library of Congress has reached a tentative agreement with the family of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. to buy the private papers of Dr. King for $20 million.

title: Olerud Keeps Options Open, Joining Rogers and Dunston on Free-Agent List
description: John Olerud and the Mets have been through this exercise before. The Mets just hope that it turns out the same this time as it did two years ago.

title: Nassau County Republicans Pass Budget With Large Tax Increase
description: Faced with a weekend budget deadline and elections on Tuesday, the Nassau County Legislature early this morning approved a new budget for the year 2000 that would eliminate this year's $300 million deficit, cut spending next year by $45 million and, for the first time in seven years, impose a major increase in property taxes.

title: Bradley Sees Florida as Pivotal to a Southern Strategy
description: When George Platt, the chairman of the Broward County Democratic Committee, introduced former Senator Bill Bradley at a campaign rally today, he ticked off the familiar highlights of Mr. Bradley's resume: Princeton graduate, Olympian, Rhodes scholar. But a huge cheer went up among the 800 retirees when he hit the next item: former New York Knick.

title: They Cling, Fall and Rise, Remaining Always Mysterious
description: Brenda Baden-Semper

title: INSIDE
description: Nasdaq Hits a Record

title: Tyson Receives No Sanctions for Late Hit
description: The Nevada State Athletic Commission voted 4-0 yesterday not to sanction Mike Tyson and released his purse of $8.7 million after a hearing to determine whether the former heavyweight champion had intentionally hit Orlin Norris after the bell in the first round of their bout last Saturday night.

title: September New-Home Sales Fell
description: Sales of new homes fell in September to the lowest level in almost two years as higher mortgage costs cooled housing from the robust pace earlier this year, Government figures showed today.

title: Israel's Place on the Map
description: To the Editor:

title: DaimlerChrysler Shifts U. S. Managers to Increase Local Control
description: The American unit of DaimlerChrysler announced a sweeping reorganization of its senior executive ranks today, a move that the company said was intended to preserve a good deal of autonomy for the former Chrysler Corporation, which Daimler-Benz of Germany bought last November.

title: Broadcaster in Buyback
description: Sinclair Broadcast Group said this week that it planned to buy back up to $300 million of its common stock. The Baltimore-based broadcasting company has about 48 million shares outstanding, which are currently valued about $434.9 million. Sinclair said that it expected to finance the repurchases with proceeds from pending dispositions of assets and from bank borrowings. The company's shares were down 6.25 cents today at $9.6875 in Nasdaq trading.

title: Robert L. Mills, 72, Theorist In Realm of Subatomic Physics
description: Dr. Robert L. Mills, a physicist who made major contributions to the study of subatomic particles, died on Wednesday at his summer home in East Charleston, Vt. He was 72.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RANIERI, THOMAS
description: RANIERI-Thomas. On October 29. President of F. Ranieri & Son, Inc. Beloved husband of Maria (nee Avona). Loving father of Frank, Connie and Rose Crosby. Dear grandfather of Danielle & Nicole. Also survived by Mildred Waldron, Anthony Ranieri and Angelina Patanio. Visiting Saturday & Sunday 2-5 PM and 7-9 PM at M.J. Smith Sons, Inc., 248 Prospect Pk West at Prospect Avenue, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial, on Monday, at 10 AM at Holy Name RC Church.

title: Attack on Sudan
description: To the Editor:

title: Homeless Plan: Sheer Demagogy
description: To the Editor:

title: Propaganda, The Sly Art That Makes Opposites Look Alike
description: Compare and contrast. They had Five-Year plans. We had the New Deal. They had the White Sea Canal. We had the Boulder Dam. They had forced collectivization. We had dust bowls. They had state-sponsored Socialist Realist photography. We had the photographic realism of the Farm Security Administration. They had Aleksandr Rodchenko, Boris Ignatovich, Elizar Langman and Arkady Shaikhet. We had Dorothea Lange, Russell Lee, Ben Shahn and Walker Evans.

title: Investigation Into Shooting Clears Officer
description: The United States Attorney for Connecticut announced today that he would not prosecute a white police officer in the 1997 shooting death of a young black driver. The announcement ended a 20-month investigation into possible civil rights violations by the officer, who had been cleared of any criminal wrongdoing in state and local investigations.

title: Illegal Workers' Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Slayings Bring Speculation On the Internet
description: In the real world, the world of flesh and blood and families, mourners were grieving yesterday for two stock promoters shot to death Monday night in a New Jersey mansion, while investigators continued to comb the house for clues about who had killed them.

title: Charter Reform, on the Merits
description: Next Tuesday, New Yorkers have a chance to make permanent many of the remarkable successes our city has enjoyed over the past six years. Fourteen proposed changes to the City Charter will be on the ballot, all designed to insure that New York City never returns to the days of high crime, high taxes and cyclical fears of bankruptcy.

title: Mutually Assured Chaos By an International Cast
description: Deja Donne Production

title: Shares Surge Again, With Nasdaq in Lead
description: Stocks extended their powerful rally yesterday as the Nasdaq composite index moved into record territory and blue-chip stocks pulled to within 5 percent of the record they set in August.

title: Macao Journal; Packing Up, Portugal Polishes Image
description: In less than two months, Portugal will give up this vest-pocket colony to China. Like well-mannered guests in a summer rental, the Portuguese are spending their last days tidying up after themselves.

title: Op-Art
A Contract for Principals
description: One of the most debilitating problems faced by New York City's school system is its inability to keep good principals and dismiss bad ones. Suburban schools routinely lure away some of the city's most talented school administrators by offering higher salaries with fewer headaches. And underperforming principals in New York are protected from removal by an outdated tenure agreement.

title: Lockheed Martin Profit Falls And 2000 Forecast Is Revised
description: The Lockheed Martin Corporation, the nation's largest military contractor, posted a 32 percent decline in third-quarter income today and, after cutting in half its profit forecast for next year, said its president was stepping down.

title: ENRON IN TALKS TO BUY CANADIAN PULP AND LUMBER MILL
description: The Enron Corporation, an energy trading company that also provides price guarantees for buyers and sellers of pulp and paper products, said yesterday that it was in talks with the Canadian province of British Columbia to buy the government-owned Skeena Cellulose Inc., a pulp and lumber mill owner. Enron declined to provide details of the negotiations. Enron is examining Skeena's books to determine the quality of the company's assets, said Don Zadravec, a spokesman for the province's Ministry of Employment and Investment, which oversees Skeena. The province owns a 58 percent stake in Skeena, while Toronto-Dominion Bank owns 22 percent and Skeena's employees own 20 percent. Enron is the world's largest energy trader.

title: Holiday Masquerade At the Pumpkin Patch; Poor Crop Tests Farmers' Wits
description: It took the Rivera family two interminable hours to drive from the Bronx to a farm that had escaped the great pumpkin shortage of 1999, but the reward was a bonanza. ''We'd heard of the shortage, so we were glad to see these fields were full,'' said Jamie Rivera, a New York City police officer.

title: Celebration in a Melting Pot
description: Autumn in New York was never better than this. For the second consecutive October, thousands of Yankee fans converged on City Hall yesterday. The lucky ones sat; most stood. They all came to celebrate the franchise's third World Series championship in four years.

title: For Yanks, a Raucous and Heartfelt Ride
description: With toilet paper streaming from office buildings and cheers roaring up from teeming sidewalks, New York threw yet another ticker-tape parade for its world champion Yankees yesterday that was by turns jubilant and somber, but at times surprisingly rowdy.

title: Making Marzipan From Lonely Hearts
description: You can't get much more retro than ''Stars in Your Eyes,'' a hopelessly passe new musical featuring a man in the moon in a white cutaway who winks and twirls and grins while saying things like, ''Can't you see I'm beaming?''

title: Badillo and CUNY
description: To the Editor:

title: A Newspaper's Integrity
description: To the Editor:

title: I.R.S. Shift on Tip Reporting Pleases Restaurateurs
description: At Gabriel's Bar and Restaurant near Lincoln Center, the waiters and bartenders are required to report their tips to the management every night. When they forget -- as the bartenders did three nights in a row this week -- the owner, Gabriel Aiello, calls to remind them and hopes they are telling the truth so that the Internal Revenue Service does not come after him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEBLASIO, JO
description: DeBLASIO-Jo. A painter, known by the name of Jo Warner. Died on October 25, 1999, from complications of bone marrow cancer (multiple myeloma). Raised in Idaho Falls, and a graduate of The University of Colorado and The Art Students League of New York, she had many one woman exhibitions during her career at galleries including the Camino and Phoenix, in New York. Two of her oil paintings were included in the Museum of Modern Art's Circulating Exhibition from 1961 to 1963 and were viewed throughout the U.S. and Europe. She was married for 29 years to Peter E. DeBlasio, and she was the very loving mother of Caralee DeBlasio, of Manhattan, and Alessandra DeBlasio, of Washington, D.C.

title: Jury Still Considering Subway Killing Verdict
description: A Manhattan jury deliberated for a full day yesterday without reaching a verdict in the murder trial of a schizophrenic man accused of pushing a woman in front of a speeding subway train.

title: A French Town's Story
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Schiller Is Leaving Turner
description: Harvey Schiller is leaving as the president of Turner Sports after five years and is expected to become the president of the YankeeNets company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRAKER, GEORGE W.
description: FRAKER-George W. Age 83. Of New Canaan, Connecticut. Died at home on Thursday, October 28. Service to be announced.

title: 3 in a Row? Easy as Tick-Tack-Toe
description: Nineteen black, blue and white buses noisily steered away from Yankee Stadium yesterday, the beginning of a caravan that took the Yankees to the ticker tape parade and another World Series celebration. The Yankees have been in this enviable setting before, so they knew this delightful routine even with their eyes at half-staff.

title: TOBACCO AD BAN DELAYED
description: Britain's high court delayed the ban on tobacco advertising at the end of this year until the European Court of Justice rules on the validity of the plan. Britain had planned a moratorium on tobacco advertising in newspapers and magazines and on billboards beginning Dec. 10, more than a year before the European Union's deadline on July 2001. The European Court of Justice is not expected to rule on the matter until late next year. Britain's Health Department vowed to appeal the high court's decision.

title: George E. Valley Jr., 86; Helped Build Nation's Radar Defenses
description: Dr. George Edward Valley Jr., an emeritus professor of physics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, who helped build the country's radar defenses and was Chief Scientist of the Air Force, died on Oct. 16 at Beth Israel Hospital in Boston. He was 86 and lived in Concord, Mass.

title: After four and a half centuries, Lutheran and Catholic officials affirm a consensus on an issue that sparked the Protestant Reformation.
description: On Oct. 31, 1517, Martin Luther, a 33-year-old monk, theology professor and popular preacher, posted a Latin document on the door of the Castle Church of Wittenberg, Germany. Within weeks, copies of the document, containing 95 theses about church teachings on indulgences, were being passed from hand to hand throughout Germany, and a movement was under way that would radically alter the world.

title: MEXICO TAX ACCORD REACHED
description: The United States and Mexico announced an agreement on how to tax 4,500 foreign-owned assembly plants in Mexico, avoiding the double taxing that American executives had feared. Under the accord, which will last through the end of 2002, Mexico will not require the plants, known as maquiladoras, to register as permanent enterprises and pay full corporate taxes. Instead, the plants will pay taxes on 6.9 percent of their assets or 6.5 percent of their costs. The assembly plants account for nearly half of Mexico's overall exports, which are booming.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about House approval of an across-the-board spending cut misidentified the Democratic Representative from Kentucky who voted for it. He is Ken Lucas. (Frank D. Lucas, another Democrat, is from Oklahoma.)

title: The Yankees, Champions for All
description: To the Editor:

title: Policy by Coercion
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the deteriorating condition of the United Nations headquarters in Manhattan referred imprecisely to exemptions from New York City's building code for diplomatic buildings. The United Nations headquarters are exempt, but other diplomatic missions, consulates and foreign government offices have been required since 1993 to comply.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLASTRIK, SIMONE
description: PLASTRIK-Simone. The Editors of Dissent Magazine mourn the passing Simone Plastrik. Simone was listed on our masthead as the Business Manager, but she was much more than that: she was our heart and soul. We extend our deepest sympathy to her family and to her many, many friends. We will miss her deeply. Mitchell Cohen Michael Walzer Co-Editors

title: Armenia's Tragedy
description: The terrorists who assassinated several of Armenia's top political leaders on Wednesday do not appear to have been motivated solely by the government's controversial willingness to talk peace with its neighbor Azerbaijan over the disputed province of Nagorno-Karabakh. A statement broadcast as a prelude to their surrender cited a hodgepodge of grievances against Prime Minister Vazgen Sarkisian, one of their victims, including a loss of national pride, corruption and economic decline. The Nagorno-Karabakh war, however, is a factor. The assassinations will set back the peace talks. It is this war, moreover, that has kept Armenia in misery, degrading the economy and fueling corruption.

title: Openings Go Unfilled as City Officials Plan How to Spend Day-Care Money
description: In Flatbush, Brooklyn, a woman whose six-room house has been revamped into a nursery for 10 children takes in only half that number most days. Near Yankee Stadium in the Bronx, a former day-care worker who has filled her living room with books, building blocks and a computer has managed to recruit only one 4-year-old girl into her care. On the western fringe of Park Slope, Brooklyn, there is a building with two sandboxes out back that lie fallow most days, hungry for the rough-and-tumble of toddlers for whom they were built.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MIKRON INSTRUMENTS CO., Oakland, N.J., which manufactures infrared noncontact temperature measurement devices, has purchased the thermal imaging systems division of Texas Infrared Inc., Hancock, Mich. for an undisclosed amount.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Mrs. Clinton, Ms. Hanover: Meeting That Wasn't to Be
description: For a brief moment it looked like a do-not-miss event: Hillary Rodham Clinton and Donna Hanover were to do ''theatrical readings'' next week at a fund-raising event to celebrate a film about Susan B. Anthony and Elizabeth Cady Stanton.

title: Bonilla Could Return Next Season
description: Steve Phillips, the Mets' general manager, said yesterday that he could envision a scenario in which Bobby Bonilla, the highly paid, but little-used, lightning rod, would remain with the Mets next season.

title: MOUNTAIN TOURS IN NORTH KOREA
description: South Korea's largest business group, the Hyundai Group, received an official letter from North Korea, giving it exclusive rights to develop tours to the scenic Mount Keumkang in North Korea until 2028. The chairman of Hyundai Group, Chung Mong Hun, said his company would move ahead with various investment projects in North Korea. His group will also hold ''road shows'' later this year to encourage investment in Mount Keumkang projects.

title: Elton Brand Readies For N.B.A. Season
description: IT happened in July, at an early scrimmage of the United States Olympic basketball team. Elton Brand -- 6 foot 8 and 270 pounds, the college player of the year as a sophomore, the No. 1 choice in the National Basketball Association draft the week before and one of two nonprofessionals on the squad -- got the ball and went up for a shot. The Seattle Supersonics' perennial all-star Vin Baker, long arms stretching up from a 6-foot-11 frame, cleanly blocked the ball.

title: The Envoy
description: THE ABYSSINIAN

title: In the Region /Westchester; Avalon Joins New Roc City for New Rochelle Revival
description: WITH New Roc City, the massive entertainment and retail center in the heart of the downtown, up and running for a month, site work has begun on the next component of this city's revitalization.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL /2000 Ford Focus; The Econobox Turns a Corner and Picks Up Some Edge
description: JUDGING by the models arriving in dealer showrooms this fall, one might think that small-car sales are booming and profits from economy models are soaring.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEHMANN, MAIER
description: LEHMANN-Maier. Young Israel of Woodmere mourns the untimely death of our beloved member Maier A''H, beloved husband of Tammy. Father of Daniella, Joey, Kelly, Mikey, Benjy; son, brother and friend. May Hashem comfort them among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Hershel Billet, Rabbi Ira Scharaga, President

title: Washington Memo; Gentler Look at the U.S. World Role
description: In the aftermath of the White House's acrid defeat on a treaty banning nuclear testing, President Clinton declared that the Republicans in Congress are now driven by a reckless ''new isolationism.'' The Treasury Secretary charged Congress with ''malign neglect'' of America's obligations. The national security adviser accused Republicans in Congress of pursuing a ''survivalist'' foreign policy.

title: A Little Deli in a Big Pickle Begs a Landlord for a Break
description: Along with cold cuts, pickles and chips, a popular deli on the Upper East Side has cooked up a new offering for its customers: petitions that urge the landlord of the soon-to-be-closed restaurant to renew its lease.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: The Tennis Partner

title: Q&A/Dr. Donna J. Demarest; Nurse Who Heeded Call to Tribal College
description: FIVE years ago when she was 55, Dr. Donna J. Demarest decided it was time to do something she had wanted to do for a long time: improve the health of American Indians.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WENCKO, GEORGE
description: WENCKO-George A. Age 86, of NYC, died on Friday at Cabrini Medical Center. All services in Lorain, OH, on Monday. For information, contact Dovin Funeral Home, 1-888-245-5118.

title: The Philosopher and the Warrior of Suffrage
description: KEN BURNS usually prides himself on the wide scope of his historical knowledge. But it wasn't long ago that the director of ''The Civil War'' made a humbling discovery: He knew next to nothing about Elizabeth Cady Stanton and only slightly more about Susan B. Anthony, the two 19th-century women who campaigned longest and hardest for a constitutional amendment that would give women the right to vote. He now regards them as, hands down, ''the two most important women in American history.''

title: Tracie Hoffman and Jason Cohen
description: Tracie Lee Hoffman, the daughter of Linda and Peter A. Hoffman of New York, was married last evening to Jason Fredric Cohen, the son of Lynne and Hy Cohen of Audubon, Pa. Rabbi David Lincoln officiated at the Union League Club in New York.

title: It's a Law. Estate Owners Will Keep Their Distance.
description: Grazing cows were about the only residents of Meadowbrook Farm visible from Mine Brook Road here on a brilliant fall morning last week, when the wooded Somerset hills were ablaze with the colors of autumn. Mayor Hugh Fenwick would no doubt have been pleased.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry; Hot Seat in the Senate
description: BIG UGLY (Simon & Schuster, $23) is a sequel to ''Mackerel by Moonlight,'' the first novel of William Weld, the former Governor of Massachusetts. It follows a raffish erstwhile Federal prosecutor, Terry Mullally, from Boston to Washington, where he has just taken his seat as junior Senator from Massachusetts. He immediately finds himself in political and legal hot water, caught between the competing Presidential candidacies of two powerful Senate colleagues, compromised by questionable fund-raising tactics, tempted by investment schemes of breathtaking illegality and haunted by a past with enough dirty secrets to end his career and perhaps send him to prison for life. Mastery of narrative strategy is not among Weld's strengths. ''Big Ugly'' takes up and abandons so many plot lines and characters that it relinquishes any claim to suspense or narrative drive. And those story strands Weld does sustain tend not so much to develop as merely persist. Moreover, their ultimate resolution is far too facile to provide much satisfaction. What Weld possesses -- most unexpectedly in a moonlighting politician -- is voice. Mullally's account of his experiences is witty, personable and cynically knowing. The specificity of his mordant observations about politics, the law and assorted colleagues shows a real writer's eye and ear at work. It's finally less surprising to find a politician writing well than to discover that someone with this level of skeptical insight succeeded in enduring the twaddle that inevitably accompanies a political career. Erik Tarloff

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLD, ABRAHAM
description: GOLD-Abraham (Abe). Beloved husband of Honey. Devoted and caring stepfather of Steven Hirschberg, Rada Salomon, Peggy Noonan Foster & husband Dennis Foster. Cherished grandfather of Bran Noonan. Loving brother of the late Bill, Rose Rose, Rickey Lieberman and Sylvia Farber. Mentor and friend to many. His company, A. Gold Fabric was honored by the tie industry with its Achievement Award. He served with distinction as a Colonel in the ETO during World War II. Family receiving at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Sunday 7-9PM with services Monday 11:30AM. Contributions to N.C.J.W. New York Section, 9 E. 69 St., NYC 10021 or the charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: Playing With Matches
description: House Fires

title: Tricky Thieves Find $200,000 Under Bed
description: A woman talked her way into the home of an elderly Bronx man on Friday and then distracted him while her accomplices made off with jewelry, other valuables and $200,000 that he had kept hidden under an upstairs bed, the police said.

title: How Five Gunshots Inspired an Oratorio
description: WHAT did you do in the war, Daddy? Sir Michael Tippett was nobody's daddy; a lively homosexual existence kept him from that. But his oratorio ''A Child of Our Time'' was the answer he could have given to any children of his time, or later. The New York Philharmonic presents the oratorio beginning on Thursday at Avery Fisher Hall, and astonishingly, those performances will be the orchestra's first of the work. But they are by no means the first for its principal guest conductor, Sir Colin Davis, who has been a fervent champion of Tippett's music since the 1960's. He conducted a performance of ''A Child of Our Time'' in London during the summer to honor the composer, who died in January of last year.

title: Y2K Travel: Still Questions in the Air
description: TWO months before 1999 ends and computers get their real test of whether they know that time marches onward (and not back 100 years), the Y2K preparedness of air transportation systems worldwide falls into two categories: ''ready'' and ''unknown.''

title: Before the Prosperity, There Was Barbecue
description: When the Olympic champion Carl Lewis came home to Willingboro to accept an award earlier this year, he brought a couple of friends, Oprah Winfrey and her boyfriend Steadman Graham. Word had it that before the ceremony, the three sneaked over to this town in Camden County.

title: The Magic Flutist
description: Ice Fire Water A Leib Goldkorn Cocktail. By Leslie Epstein. 264 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $23.95.

title: All Back to Normal: Woods Is the Leader
description: It has been a strange week at the Tour Championship, but the name in first place looked familiar.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Tourism From Scratch In Central Asia's Wilds
description: THE place is remote, romantic and implausibly gorgeous. Deep in Central Asia and thinly populated, Kyrgyzstan boasts some of the world's most spectacular Alpine scenery, ideal for trekking, climbing, camping, horseback riding, white-water rafting, canoeing, sailing, scuba diving and almost everything else one might want to do in the great outdoors. In short, it is a tourist's heaven.

title: Manicures and Pedicures, In a Relaxing Way
description: Arranged in a long row with manicurists and pedicurists seated opposite customers, B. B. Nail, a nail and beauty salon that opened in Murray Hill Sept. 27, was filled with chatter on a recent Friday evening.

title: Commercial Property; Reckson Invests Heavily in Its Manhattan Portfolio
description: FOR several years after breaking out of its home base on Long Island, Reckson Associates Realty Corporation conspicuously avoided New York City. In a 1996 interview, Scott Rechler, the company's president, defined its operating territory as ''within a 50 mile radius of Manhattan with Manhattan and the boroughs carved out.''

title: Student Awards
description: The Westchester Children's Association, an advocacy group since 1914, has announced the winners of its 1999 Youth Leadership Awards.

title: SOVEREIGN ISLANDS -- A special report.; Getting Sick on the High Seas: A Question of Accountability
description: Shortly after midnight last Feb. 25, James Curtis, a 59-year-old retired businessman from Maryland, was found unconscious in a public restroom aboard the Sensation, one of the 14 ships of Carnival Cruise Lines. He was revived by the ship's nurse and taken to the infirmary.

title: State Knew of Risky Heroin Treatment Before Patient Deaths
description: When New Jersey investigators filed a lawsuit against Dr. Lance L. Gooberman earlier this month that linked his unusual heroin detoxification treatment to six patient deaths, officials in the State Attorney General's office proclaimed they had stopped an ''unlawful'' treatment that put addicts' lives in danger.

title: Alison Graham, Robert Faggen
description: Alison Joanne Graham, a daughter of Elizabeth P. Graham and Dr. Andrew J. Graham of Woodbridge, Conn., is to be married this morning to Prof. Robert Faggen, the son of Gilbert S. Faggen of New York and the late Anita A. Faggen. Cantor Keith Miller is to officiate at the Hotel Bel Air in Los Angeles.

title: Less Than Full Disclosure
description: After management at Amazon.com announced its third-quarter results, Wall Street analysts issued downgrades. Profits appear to be much further off than had been thought.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINBERG, BARBARA RUTH
description: STEINBERG-Barbara Ruth on October 29, 1999 at the age of 58. Loving mother of Laura Steinberg Tisch, Jonathan and Nicholas Steinberg. Adoring grandmother to Charles and Henry Tisch and mother-in-law to Maria Steinberg. Devoted daughter to Abe and Frieda Herzog. Dear sister of Martin Herzog and beloved companion of Justin Hornik. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St, Sunday 11:30am. Interment New Montefiore Cemetery, Wellwood, NY.

description: ''I COULD take off my shoe and show you I don't have a cloven hoof,'' said David Hunter, putting a self-mocking spin on his contentious line of work.

description: It was the kind of game where Chris Weinke did not know whether to laugh or cry. In the end, of course, he could see the humor in this, because Florida State had the last laugh.

description: To the Editor:

title: October 24-30; A Birthday Bash For a (Presumed) Candidate
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton found another way to mix business and pleasure, using the occasion of her 52d birthday to hold a fundraiser in Manhattan to finance her expected campaign for the United States Senate. An array of Broadway stars, from Joel Grey to Rosie O'Donnell, presented a night of songs, skits paying tribute to Mrs. Clinton and insults directed at Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Mayor of New York, who is Mrs. Clinton's presumed opponent in the contest for the Senate seat next year.

title: Driving for Business Success, Women Polish Golf Swings
description: THE SETTING -- For many women in the schmooze-centric business world, one of the biggest handicaps is having no handicap at all. A golf handicap, that is. The Golf Club at Chelsea Piers, in the sports complex at the western end of 23d Street, offers a solution with Female Executive and All Lady clinics.

title: IN PERSON: Battling Development With Will and Wile; Using Botany and History as Weapons, Elizabeth Morgan Usually Wins
description: ELIZABETH MORGAN, botanist and historian, does not like the spotlight. She prefers to work behind the scenes, occasionally emerging to make a surgical strike to block the spread of what she calls a disease: suburban sprawl.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-20

description: LADY BIRD A Biography of Mrs. Johnson. By Jan Jarboe Russell. Lisa Drew/Scribner, $26.

title: From the Humble Mini-Series Comes the Magnificent Megamovie
description: MOVIES and television have been feeding off each other for years, each trying to capture whatever part of the mass audience is the other's territory. In this age of political strategy dictated by public opinion poll, movies and television behave like a pair of rival party candidates for the same office: each side quietly adopts policies that differ from the other's only in degree, rarely in substance.

title: DAVID FILO
description: He doesn't sleep under his desk any more, but David Filo, the co-founder of Yahoo, the world's most popular Web site, spends a lot of time in his cubicle at the company's headquarters in Santa Clara, Calif. Several times each day, Mr. Filo uses one of his company's most popular creations -- My Yahoo -- to keep up with what's going on in the world. My Yahoo lets users create a page with their most used features in one place.

description: KORN-Jack. 6/18/10-10/31/94 Forever remembered and loved by his family.

description: FENCING THE SKY

description: He has flopped into bed exhausted, knowing his sleep would last three hours. Thank God, Luis Castillo has said to himself before drifting off, and he has thought about what he would've missed if he hadn't written that letter to the Yankees.

title: Bitten by the Tax Bug
description: The top 1 percent of Americans are making more and paying a bigger share of income taxes.

description: To the Editor:

title: The Siren Charms of Venice
description: WE are sorry to inform you. . .'' ''Regretfully, impossible. . .'' ''Non e possibile. . .'' Twenty-two faxes, twenty-two responses, all rejections. No, I wasn't trying to get into medical school -- I was looking for a reasonably priced place to rest my head in Venice for four or five midweek days in September. That planned visit was just over a month away, more lead time than I've ever allowed for making hotel reservations. Still, I was coming up empty-handed and beginning to get nervous.

title: Tiles and Drawings, and Beyond
description: 'The Tile Club and the Aesthetic Movement in America (1877-1887)'

title: An Empire Built on Collegiality
description: PETER KINDERSLEY bicycles from his home across the River Thames every morning, slicing through traffic to his office in Covent Garden, his suit pants bound with steel clips to avoid catching in the sprockets. Mr. Kindersley, chairman and former chief executive of the British publisher Dorling Kindersley, then marches up four flights of stairs, dismissing the lift as simply a modern excuse for laziness.

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-31-99: Encounter; A Joy Ride With Ralph Nader
description: The Mercedes Gelaendewagen is the fastest, most expensive and all-around most blazingest sport utility vehicle in the world, and when your faithful correspondent was recently offered the chance to drive one, he jumped at it. This is because your correspondent is most definitely not in league with the self-flagellating, I'm-perfectly-happy-with-my-Corolla-lying, NPR-pledge-week-donating S.U.V.-bashers who have made life unbearable, or at least mildly annoying, for the millions of red-blooded men who cruise the Main Streets of America in S.U.V.'s designed to ford wide rivers and haul sheep and goats.

title: A New Way to See Bermuda's Capital
description: Visitors to Bermuda have a new method of transportation -- trolleylike buses that tour the capital, Hamilton, and the dockyard area.

title: Correction
description: A chart in Sunday Styles last week with an article about the correlation between income and number of children in Manhattan families, with a mother age 40 to 44, included some erroneous figures. For families with two children living in Chinatown, the median income is $18,357, not $19,357; in Greenwich Village, those with three or more children have a median income of $60,150, not $80,150, and on the Upper West Side, those with one child have a median income of $99,550, not $98,650.

title: Man Accused of In-Flight Attack Loses a Lawsuit
description: People are always filing lawsuits seeking to vindicate their constitutional rights, but a Federal District judge says a Manhattan lawyer went too far in a suit having to do with air travel.

title: Resurrecting a Cosmic Fantasy of Love and Death
description: IN the magical, mystical cinematic world of Michael Powell, anything is possible. Time and space are boundless -- and so is the imagination. That was his genius.

title: World Court Chief Faults U.S. Over Its U.N. Dues
description: The American judge who now serves as president of the World Court said in an interview this week that there was ''no question'' that the United States was legally obliged to pay the past assessments it owes the United Nations.

title: Parents Blaming Parents
description: On a warm Tuesday night in September, 120 people, nearly all African-American, fill the echoing auditorium at the Masonic Temple in Brooklyn. ''No Weapons Allowed, Persons Subject to Scanning'' warns a faded sign at the door, and the words have particular resonance here tonight. The special guests for this evening are Michael and Vonda Shoels, the parents of 18-year-old Isaiah, one of the 12 students slaughtered at Columbine High School six months ago by Eric Harris and Dylan Klebold.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: From Confidentiality to Anybody Who Tunes In
description: ANALYZE this: Radio psychologists, who used to go couch to couch only on the AM-FM dials, are breaking into television. Dr. Joy Browne, of WOR-AM (710) in New York and national syndication, is leading the way with a daytime show that began broadcasting last month. With the film ''Mumford,'' about a ''psychologist'' who cures a town's psychic ills, and ''The Shrink,'' a sitcom in the works at ABC about a therapist more disturbed than his patients, the psychoanalyzed Mafia dons of ''The Sopranos'' on HBO and last spring's film ''Analyze This,'' media versions of shrinks are hot. Anyone who thinks otherwise is in denial.

title: Amy Lesser and Jay Courage
description: Amy Lesser and Jay Michael Courage were married yesterday at their home in Locust Valley, N.Y., by Malcolm MacKay, the associate town justice in Centre Island, N.Y.

title: Caroline Newstead and Jason Hacker
description: Caroline Ellen Newstead, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Charles Newstead of McLean, Va., is to be married this afternoon to Jason Evan Hacker, the son of Rochelle Stassa of Larchmont, N.Y., and Stuart Hacker of Stamford, Conn. Rabbi Norman Cohen will perform the ceremony at the V.I.P. Country Club in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Kathleen Nolan, Eric Schoenfield
description: Kathleen Maura Nolan, a daughter of Patricia and Jack P. Nolan of Providence, R.I., was married last evening at the Providence Biltmore Hotel to Eric Murray Schoenfield, a son of Eli and Roberta Schoenfield of New York. Rabbi Sol Goodman officiated at the ceremony, with the Rev. Anne Coburn, an Episcopal priest, taking part.

title: October 24-30; Rubin Takes a Job
description: When Robert E. Rubin, the recently retired Treasury Secretary, announced that he would join Citigroup, America's largest financial services company, heads turned both in Washington and on Wall Street. Mr. Rubin, a veteran financier, had long said that he might return to the trading pit. But fw expected the 61-year-old to jump back into the sea of commerce head first, much less accept an offer from an arch-rival of Goldman, Sachs, his old company. In his new role, Mr. Rubin will help plot strategy at Citigroup's helm. JOSEPH KAHN

title: Witches Cast as the Neo-Pagans Next Door
description: An hour before sundown, 40 adults have formed a circle in a small backyard, the limbs of a barren tree overhead. Most are dressed in black, many in capes. But the occasion, a gathering of local witches' covens, is expectant, not somber.

title: Kathleen Tanner, Peter Bergen Jr.
description: Kathleen Marie Tanner and Peter James Bergen Jr. were married yesterday in Hoboken, N.J. Msgr. Frank Del Prete performed the ceremony at SS. Peter and Paul Church. Canon Andrew W. Mullins of the Episcopal Church of the Epiphany in New York took part in the service.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GREENBERG, HERBERT
description: GREENBERG-Herbert. You are with us always. ''The heart that has truly loved never forgets.'' Love forever. Sylvia, Susan, Gwen.

title: Microbes on The Move
description: I am somewhat confused (The Way We Live Now, Oct. 10). If, as Jeffrey Goldberg reports, the effects of President Clinton's trip to Africa were largely ''ephemeral and symbolic,'' then why go to such lengths to demean Senator Larry Craig's criticism that the $42 million it cost ''was an awful high price to pay for an apology'' -- especially when that money could, theoretically, have been pumped into Africa's national health system?

title: The Last Tribal Battle
description: For Domingo Neves de Souza, it was only a half-hour's walk to the edge of the unknown. Two years ago in September, he ventured out from the Brazilian rubber plantation where he lived to go fishing. With his two daughters and three of their friends, he pushed deep into the western Amazon, following a winding tributary of the Igarape River. Hidden in the thick surrounding forest, de Souza had long been told, were naked Indians who still set their lives to the forest's rhythms, just as they had for thousands of years: eating what the forest grew, hunting by bow and arrow. But for the 33-year-old rubber tapper, these Indians were an invisible presence, felt more than seen. Until that day, when they stepped out from the trees.

title: A Linebacking Throwback Helps Still-Perfect Delbarton Thump Wayne Valley
description: As the Delbarton High School football team gathered this morning, hours before a matchup of unbeaten squads, the Green Wave assistant coach Rik Dugan gave a motivational speech that rivaled the best southern revivalist's in volume and tone.

title: 'Little People's' Voices
description: To the Editor:

title: POSTINGS: A Web Site With Resumes; For Renters With Pets
description: It happens too often to people on the move, say officials of the Humane Society of the United States: that beautiful, affordable apartment across town or across the country would be just right for the family -- except for that ''No Pets Allowed'' clause in the lease.

title: Washington
description: Call it the calm before the electoral storm. As the city cranks out dollars and spin for the Presidential sweepstakes, the bigger news at the moment is the return of boom times. Northern Virginia's high-tech hub, arguably the epicenter of the Internet, is fueling a robust economy.

title: In Some Offices, Employees Will Never Escape From the Phone
description: FOR Bob Aylward, vice president of the Seattle Mariners baseball team for business and sales, having a wireless phone in the office is just as vital as having one on the road.

title: Linda Carrubba, Andres Rodriguez
description: Linda LaMar Carrubba and Andres Ignacio Rodriguez Ferrari were married on Friday at their home in Somerville, Mass. Jennifer E. Innis, a minister in training at the First and Second Unitarian Universalist Church of Boston, performed the ceremony.

title: New Role for Loop Landmark
description: Daniel H. Burnham, the architect and city planner who designed many American landmarks, including the Flatiron Building in Manhattan, conceived the Reliance Building in Chicago as a center for business and a harbinger of skyscrapers and walls of glass.

title: Amid Pakistani Poverty, Opulent Palace of Ex-Premier
description: The Mogul emperor Shah Jahan had the Taj Mahal. Louis XIV had Versailles. And Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif was going to have Jati Umrah -- until the Pakistani Army unceremoniously booted him out of power this month, impounding his palatial home.

title: Spooky Shakespeare at Sea
description: THE tall ship Peking will become a spooky ghost ship today as ''William Shakespeare's Haunted Ship'' has its final performances at the South Street Seaport. The interactive show -- with songs, eerie sounds and flashing lights -- is performed by 30 actors from the Faux-Real Theater Company. The language is entirely from Shakespeare, and the costumes suggest classic performances. (Jy Murphy and Corey Carthew are shown at left.) The idea behind the production is that Shakespeare's plays have been performed so many times in New York that his spirit has been channeled to the seaport, where it walks the decks of the Peking at Halloween. The show is for all ages, but children should be warned that Shakespearean ghosts will pop out at unexpected moments.

title: Harry and the Muggles
description: To the Editor:

title: Off-Season Challenge: How to Beat the Yanks
description: Gord Ash thought he saw a glimmer of vulnerability. ''I believe there was a bit of a stumbling block this year,'' the Toronto Blue Jays' general manager said.

title: Pro-Business Senator to Head Vital Environmental Panel
description: For the first time since Congress began passing landmark environmental laws three decades ago, the critically important Senate Environment and Public Works Committee is about to be headed by someone who wants to make those laws more friendly to business.

title: A Ballerina's Life After Balanchine
description: BOTH the dancing and the life of Suzanne Farrell are American legends, complete with ballet triumphs, blazing talent, ferocious work, thorny love relationships and personal torments. They could, in fact, be fashioned into a drama, opera, or a film. True, ''The Red Shoes'' has been done, but the absorbing 1997 documentary ''Suzanne Farrell, Elusive Muse'' was nominated for an Academy Award.

title: The Siren Swipe of the Debit Card
description: LOOK at the people in front of you at the grocery check-out or at the gas pump. Odds are they are swiping plastic through a card-reading machine, cards that often are debit cards, not credit cards.

title: A Red to Nurse and Gulp
description: Although you may not see the name Louis-Dressner Selections on the bottle, Joe Dressner and his wife, Denyse Louis, who are based in Manhattan, import especially tasty wines from France, where they spend perhaps a quarter of the year working with growers.

title: Creative Writing
description: Some of the most imaginative flowerings of modern literature are in a special genre: the personal expense account. What has been the wildest, woolliest item you have tried to put on your account? And for how much? How did you explain it, and what happened? Or if you're a boss, what has been the most striking item you have encountered? Send your stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your name and telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: As the Battlegrounds Shift, the Draft Fades in Europe
description: Nicolas Dombroski, an 18-year-old mathematics student, was not happy at having to spend his whole Saturday at the French Air Force base here learning about what soldiers do.

title: Abortion: An Endangered Right
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Lansbury, Mr. Greenwald
description: Katharine Rose Lansbury, the daughter of Rose and Edgar Lansbury of Manhattan, was married yesterday to Jonathan F. I. Greenwald, a son of Evelyn Greenwald and Dr. A. Seth Greenwald of Cleveland Heights, Ohio. The Rev. Richard Leonard, a Unitarian-Universalist minister, performed the ceremony at the Cosmopolitan Club in Manhattan.

title: STILL STANDING -- A special report.; Ignoring Scars, Milosevic Is Stubbornly Pressing On
description: Slobodan Milosevic gray and remote, internationally isolated and politically unpopular, charged with war crimes, his army restive and its reservists outraged, his economy ruined and his factories bombed, his refineries and electricity system smashed and his sources of fuel unclear, his roads and railways holed and his bridges collapsed -- has not only survived the loss of Kosovo, but gained a second wind.

title: Footnotes
description: 1. Mexican wrestling, or lucha libre, is the legacy of a Jalisco tax collector named Salvador Lutteroth Gonzales. In the 1930's, he built Mexico's first wrestling arena with the money he won in the National Lottery. Though soccer is Mexico's No. 1 sport, wrestling remains a close second, mainly because its superheroes cross over into film. El Santo, who fought 15,000 matches in 44 years, made 53 movies in which he fought such nemeses as Dracula and a whole slew of mummies from the catacombs of Guanajuato.

title: Why the Silence On Chechnya?
description: To the Editor:

title: BENEFITS
description: Healing With Music

title: Cleric's Trial Becomes Flash Point of Iran's Political Fate
description: Iran's ruling Muslim clerics today began the apostasy trial of one of the country's most popular politicians, Abdullah Nouri, a cleric who has gone from being one of the most trusted aides to Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini to taking a key leadership role in a campaign to end the clerical dictatorship Mr. Khomeini imposed after the Islamic revolution in 1979.

title: Sports of The Times; A Valuable Lesson: Fleeting Fame
description: HAVE you heard that Michael Jordan's restaurant, the burger-fare establishment on North LaSalle Street in downtown Chicago, is reinventing itself? Soon it will become Sammy Sosa's, switching identities in midflight, from slam dunk to grand slam.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Long Island copies last Sunday with an article about offices with shared services misidentified a tenant at Completesuite in Jericho. He is William J. Turkish, a lawyer, not David Hirsch, who has offices in the same building. The caption also misstated the given name of Completesuite's owner. He is Jeffrey Saporta, not Jerry.

title: Voters With Disabilities Too Often Disenfranchised
description: To the Editor:

title: Celebrating Where 'The World Opened Up'
description: WHEN Cheryl McPherson, one of 10 children from a poor black family in Philadelphia, arrived in Guilford in 1974 as part of the program A Better Chance, she said she felt that she had entered a foreign land. At school she had to adjust to a rigorous academic schedule; outside school, she had to adjust to life in a town with only 8,000 residents, nearly all white.

title: October 24-30; An Editor Calls It Quits
description: In the wake of an embarrassing recall of a controversial biography of Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, the editor-in-chief of St. Martin's Press, Robert B. Wallace, resigned, saying that he did not want to be associated with such books and had had no control over publication of this one.

title: New Role for Small Theater Troupes: Entrepreneur
description: ORDINARILY, a fire inspection would not make people jittery. If violations are found in their building, they simply correct them. But when firefighters found a problem at the storefront theater of Collective Unconscious, a troupe on the Lower East Side, the members realized that the very life of their theater was at stake.

title: Refocusing Animals For the Winter
description: AS the outdoor season ceases to beckon, life quiets down and energies are refocused on a range of indoor activities. For people, that defines time on the computer, reading, increased television and other hobbies. For pets, however, the range of possibilities is more restrictive.

title: New Mosquito Controls
description: The County Executive's office has budgeted $250,000 for a new mosquito surveillance and control program, to be known as Mosquito Sting, an acronym for Stop the Insects' Next Generation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLAHERTY, JAMES E.
description: FLAHERTY-James E. Jr. Of Douglaston, NY on October 27, 1999. Son of the late James and Alice Flaherty. Beloved husband of Joan H. Flaherty. Devoted father of James E. III, Joseph P., John M. Flaherty, Julie A. Foti and Joan A. Ganci. Father-in-law of Gloria Flaherty and Michael Ganci. Cherished grandfather of Christie, James IV, Alexandra, Louis, Nicole and Jordyn. Fond brother of Maureen Bellandi, Kathleen Alves, and Sally Turrill. Visiting in the Doyle B. Shaffer, Inc., Funeral Home, Little Neck Parkway and Northern Boulevard, Little Neck, on Sunday 2-5 and 7-9. Mass of Christian burial will be offered in St. Anastasia, R.C. Church on Monday at 11 A.M. Interment All Saints Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to Sloan-Kettering Oncology Department, Mercy Hospital would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RANIERI, THOMAS
description: RANIERI-Thomas. On October 29. President of F. Ranieri & Son, Inc. Beloved husband of Maria (nee Avona). Loving father of Frank, Connie and Rose Crosby. Dear grandfather of Danielle & Nicole. Also survived by Mildred Waldron, Anthony Ranieri and Angelina Patanio. Visiting Saturday & Sunday 2-5 PM and 7-9 PM at M.J. Smith Sons, Inc., 248 Prospect Pk West at Prospect Avenue, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial, on Monday, at 10 AM at Holy Name RC Church.

title: INVESTING; Seeing Value in a Stake, And Even in the Steaks
description: SAM ZELL is hoping that investors are as keen on surf and turf as he is.

title: A Closer Look at the High Seas and the Fine Print
description: When it comes to medical malpractice suits, the law, the fine print and recent Congressional action favor the cruise industry.

title: Suffolk County Gears Up for 631 Area Code
description: SEAMLESSLY and without celebration, a new area code will take effect in Suffolk County on Monday, marking the end of Long Island as the land of 516.

title: The Forgotten War
description: INSIDE SUDAN

title: Another Point of View
description: To the Editor:

title: From the Economy, a Familiar Song
description: By now, everybody on Wall Street seems to know the lyrics by heart. Every three months the preliminary gross domestic product figures arrive, and right on cue the market analysts' glee club begins to sing, Another quarter of lovely growth, another quarter of moderate inflation, but who knows, it might end any day. The stock market duly applauds, and then recommences worrying about the next hint of wage pressure or flagging consumer demand.

title: Anne Robison, Kemper Matt Jr.
description: Anne Kendell Robison, the daughter of Jane R. Benasutti of Austin, Tex., and the late Bob H. Robison, was married yesterday to Joseph Kemper Matt Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Matt of Fayetteville, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Gregory Cootsona performed the ceremony at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York. The Rev. Gregory LeStrange, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the service.

title: Whitney Rogers, Jonathan Malkiel
description: Whitney MacCoy Rogers, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur M. Rogers Jr. of Oyster Bay, N.Y., was married yesterday to Jonathan Porter Malkiel, the son of Burton G. Malkiel of Princeton, N.J., and the late Judith Atherton Malkiel. The Rev. Churchill G. Pinder performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on page 11 of the Travel section today about the Father Ryan House in Biloxi, Miss., refers incorrectly in some copies to the location of the photo in the grouping. The house is shown at the lower left, not the lower right.

title: A Rare Opportunity To Reverse Losses
description: The Internal Revenue Service, granting another extension, is giving taxpayers who last year converted regular individual retirement arrangements to Roth IRA's a chance to reconsider. Until Dec. 31, they may switch their accounts back to regular IRA's -- should they wish to do so -- opening up an opportunity for those whose portfolios have lost value in the recent rocky market.

title: Ms. Pollakowski, Mr. Plantemoli
description: Lisa Ann Pollakowski and Leonard John Plantemoli were married yesterday at Christ Church United Methodist in Manhattan. The Rev. Stephen P. Bauman, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony, in which the Rev. Brendan W. Downing, a Roman Catholic priest, took part.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LORBERBAUM, SHIRLEY
description: LORBERBAUM-Shirley J. Of Boca Raton, Florida, died Friday, October 22, in Dalton, Georgia. Mrs. Lorberbaum was a carpet industry pioneer, a community leader, philanthropist and, along with her husband, co-founded Aladdin Mills, which in 1994 merged with Mohawk and Karastan to become the second largest U.S. carpet mill. She was the first female president of the Dalton/Whitfield Chamber of Commerce where she was the guiding force behind the Education is Essential Foundation. Some of the many boards on which she served were Carpet & Rug Institute, Wachovia Bank of Dalton, Department of Family and Children's Services of Whitfield County, Oscar N. Jonas Memorial Foundation and Creative Arts Guild. Gov. Zell Miller appointed her to his special task force to report on the state of Georgia's children. Under Mrs. Lorberbaum's direction, the Alan S. Lorberbaum Family Foundation recently provided the funding to establish a new facility for Whitfield-Dalton Day Care Center. This is a continuation of her lifelong advocacy for children's rights. Survivors include her husband, Alan Lorberbaum; daughter, Suzanne Helen, Denver, Colorado; sons, Jeffrey Lorberbaum, of Dalton, Georgia; and Mark Lorberbaum, of Boca Raton, Florida; and five grandchildren.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTINEZ, JULIO
description: MARTINEZ-Julio. The phsicians and staff of the Methadone Maintenance Treatment Program (MMTP) of Beth Israel Medical Center join with their colleagues from Beth Israel's other chemical dependency programs, and with the leadership of its parent company, Continuum Health Partners, in acknowledging with sadness the passing of our dear friend and former colleague, Julio Martinez, who served with great distinction for many years as New York State's Commissioner of Substance Abuse Services. Our heartfelt condolences to his family and all who loved and respected him. Robert G. Newman, M.D. President and CEO, Continuum Matthew E. Fink, M.D. President and CEO, Beth Israel Addie Corradi, Admin., MMTP Stanley Yancovitz, M.D. Chief of Chemical Dependancy

title: Irvine Hopes Experience In Japan Is an Advantage
description: While Japan's motor racing culture has helped to create several Formula One world champions, the favor has not yet been returned.

title: All for One, One for All Takes On New Meaning
description: MANY candidates vying for top office in cities and towns around the state aren't running for office this year; instead, they're walking. In a trend that political observers said shows a growing weakness in the state's Democratic and Republican parties, candidates for mayor and first selectman are running virtually unopposed in 40 percent of the races. In 54 of the 134 contests this year, the candidates face no opponents or are running against candidates from minor parties or those not represented by any party.

title: Debbie Gould, Keith Agisim
description: Dr. Deborah Beth Gould, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur H. Gould of Berkley Heights, N.J., was married last evening to Keith David Agisim, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Elliot S. Agisim of Ridgefield, Conn. Rabbi Stuart Gershon officiated at the Fiddler's Elbow Country Club in Bedminster, N.J.

title: A Timorese Era Closes Quietly As Army Goes
description: Ending a failed 24-year occupation that culminated in a rampage of destruction, the last 900 Indonesian soldiers left on this island territory pulled down their red-and-white flag and departed from East Timor today.

title: MUSIC; Cream of New York's Composers: A Portrait
description: ''WHO are these people?'' you might ask, if you suddenly found them, in suits and T-shirts, with hair of every length, arrayed in a grand, curved sweep on the staircase in the Alexander Hamilton United States Custom House in lower Manhattan. The answer is that they are 52 of New York's most distinguished composers, together for the first time and representing nearly every style of music, from Broadway, with Stephen Sondheim peering from on high, to the rigors of atonal modernism, represented up front by (from left) George Perle, Milton Babbitt and Elliott Carter.

title: Kenneth MacKenzie, 79, Dancer Of Lead Roles at Ballets Russes
description: Kenneth MacKenzie, an American dancer with Col. W. de Basil's Ballets Russes in the 1940's and a star of one of that troupe's most controversial productions, died on Sept. 23 at his home in New Hope, Pa. He was 79.

title: Anti-Violence Mural Has Fans in Park Slope
description: To the Editor:

title: Convicted Robber Challenges 'Three Strikes' Sentencing Law
description: A Paterson man who three years ago was the first person in New Jersey sentenced under the ''three strikes'' sentencing law, is now the first in the state to challenge its constitutionality.

title: Martha Grayson, Allan Kessler
description: Dr. Martha Shelley Grayson is to be married today to Allan Philip Kessler at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. Rabbi Michael A. White is to perform the ceremony.

title: Reinstate Rose
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The Search Engine
description: Jim Clark's ''wildly simple notion'' to solve the health care crisis and make himself many more millions is too wild and too simple. Clark is obviously a genius, but he is much too optimistic. I'm surprised that Lewis failed to note that herding five-sevenths of American doctors into the Healtheon network (200,000 more than belong to the A.M.A.) would constitute a monopoly by anybody's definition. That's a big no-no.

title: Living Hand to Mouth
description: Thumbsucker

title: From Soup to Pancakes, the Other Faces of Pumpkin
description: THE odds are that you will have some spare pumpkin around the house. Though jack-o'-lantern pumpkins are not the variety that is ideal for cooking -- mainly because of a relatively high water content in the flesh -- they are acceptable in many recipes.

title: A Free Spirit Who Is Looking for His Soul
description: THE interview is scheduled for 1 P.M. -- location mysteriously, maddeningly still to be determined. But by 12:59 P.M., there is still no word from Woody Harrelson.

title: Denis Roche, William Mark
description: Denis Mary Roche, a daughter of Jane and Kevin Roche of Hamden, Conn., was married yesterday to William Michael Mark, a son of Mary and Edward Mark of Newport, R.I. The Rev. John McGuire, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Sakonnet Vineyards in Little Compton, R.I.

title: October 24-30; A New Protest In Tiananmen Square
description: They looked like dazed tourists in tennis shoes, but the appearance on Tiananmen Square of clusters of Falun Gong believers was a sign that the campaign to crush the popular spiritual movement was in trouble.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Portraits of the Artists
description: The advent of the compact disk improved sound quality, but brought an end to great album art and sophisticated liner notes. IN THE GROOVE: Vintage Record Graphics, 1940-1960 (Chronicle, paper, $18.95), Eric Kohler's lovingly produced collection of 250 album covers, traces the beginning of this graphic design to 1947, when a young designer named Alex Steinweiss folded a thin cardboard sheet in half to create what would become the standard LP jacket for the next four decades. Early jackets by artists like Jim Flora relied heavily on graphics and hand-lettered typefaces rather than photography; the mild-mannered, bow-tied Flora's polymorphous caricatures of Bix Beiderbecke and Gene Krupa are as nutty as any underground cartoonist's work today. Some high points are Neil Fujita's cover of a pensive, red-lighted Miles Davis for ''Round About Midnight'' and David Stone Martin's iconic freehand logo of the Blue Note trumpet player, still in use half a century later. Delightful rarities include a Picassoesque line drawing for a 1958 Kenny Burrell album by a young Andy Warhol. The text is studded with tasty tidbits: younger vinylphiles may be surprised that the first ''concept'' album to structure songs around a theme was Frank Sinatra's ''Songs for Swingin' Lovers.'' Although rock 'n' roll revitalized record sales in the 1950's, it had little impact on album cover design until the Beatles era, because songs were released as singles. Eric P. Nash

title: For Tandoori, Port Chester and New Rochelle
description: IN vanguard Indian restaurants here in the county, the stage was set to introduce the cuisine. Draped ceilings, sari-clad wait staff, sitar music -- elements like those made up a kind of Asian barber pole, which immediately identified the goods. But Indian food has become standard fare in the last decade, and diners no longer need visual aids to understand what they will be served. Although the old exotic ambience remains delightful, new ventures often inhabit rooms decorated in a different key. There is plenty of room for both.

title: The Nation: Tribalism; In Politics, Ethnic Posturing Isn't Simple Anymore
description: IT once seemed so easy. Toward the end of every mayoral campaign in New York City, candidates would head to the Lower East Side where, crowded in by cameras, they would eat a knish or a pastrami sandwich and talk about how much they loved Israel. Or toward the finish of a Presidential campaign, the candidates would turn up in the Polish section of Chicago for some kielbasa, a pro-forma denunciation of Soviet domination of Eastern Europe and more photographs. This was ethnic politics in its most primal form, an unstated calculation that the most elementary of gestures -- a visit, a picture, a noncontroversial proclamation or two -- would produce a payback in the form of the ''Jewish vote'' or the ''Polish vote.''

title: Held Accountable
description: It's a tradition that must date back almost to Gutenberg: Book-jacket blurbs, those boldface nuggets of puffery and flattering quotes meant to entice browsers to pick the book up off the store shelf and carry it to the cashier.

title: Gore Is Finding Insider Image Tough to Shake
description: When Vice President Al Gore uprooted his campaign headquarters from K Street and moved to Nashville, the change was intended to distance the campaign from Washington's famous avenue of influence where many of the Vice President's advisers have earned millions of dollars in lobbying fees.

title: New Concepts: Jackson Brings a Light to L.A.
description: The biggest kid in the National Basketball Association jumped out of the largest freshwater lake in North America this summer and ended up on Phil Jackson's front lawn.

title: Residential Life Is Returning to Atlanta's Downtown
description: BILL GOULD said he felt like an urban pioneer when he stepped through a kudzu-shrouded doorway and into what would be his new home nine years ago.

title: Rutgers Left Wondering After Big Loss
description: The doubts gushed out after another Rutgers football defeat today.

title: U.F.O.? No, Just New Bike Lights
description: It's dusk, and just inside the West 67th Street entrance to Central Park, Jerry Fisher stands lit up like a Christmas tree. Mr. Fisher is hawking the battery-operated bicycle lights he manufactures at home. With enough of them clipped to him to rival the lights at Tavern on the Green across the way, he is attracting his share of attention.

title: A Gift or an Estate? That Is the Multimillion-Dollar Question
description: ALL that stands between Paula Kennedy and the man she loves is a $12 million tax lien from the Internal Revenue Service. She inherited $150,000 and one undeveloped lot on Lake Winnipesaukee, N.H., from her mother, who died 13 years ago, but the I.R.S. says she and her brothers owe millions in gift and estate taxes. Until the case is settled, she fears that if she marries Joseph S. Kennedy, his assets will be drawn into the case. To keep up appearances, because they live together in Scotch Plains, N.J., she has legally changed her name.

title: The Market: Inventory Down, Prices Up
description: BY some accounts, the house on New Rochelle's Van Meter Fenway was a mess, the sort of home that should have gone for a relative pittance to anyone who was ready to stomach perhaps $100,000 in repairs.

title: Mothers Hope They're One in a Million
description: ''We're looking for a few good moms,'' says Donna Dees-Thomases.

title: Making an Investment In Students' Futures
description: AN innovative program in Bridgeport is linking economically disadvantaged students with sponsors willing to pay all or some of their tuition to Kolbe Cathedral High School.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the rating box last Sunday with the Dining Out column misstated the name of the Smithtown restaurant being reviewed. As noted in the column, it was Casa Rustica; another restaurant, called Cafe Rustica, is in Great Neck.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In /Morristown, N.J.; Presence of the Past in a Lively Downtown
description: HISTORIC Morristown, twice George Washington's headquarters in the Revolutionary War, is in the midst of a downtown revival as retail chains return and the demand for housing soars after years of stagnation.

title: Twentysomethings' Lament
description: THE almost overnight success of the Jerry Yangs of America has made them the symbol of my age group, replacing the goofy Adam Sandler image that once defined Generation X.

title: The View From/White Plains; If It Looks Real Scary, It Must be Halloween
description: JESSICA SCHWARTZ was looking for fangs. Not just any fangs only the most realistic would do. ''They have the ones you stick on, but I want the ones you mold: you mix up the stuff like dentists use, then you mold each fang and shape it and put it over the tooth.''

title: Jeannemarie O'Brien, Yves Casimir
description: Jeannemarie O'Brien and Yves Achille Casimir were married yesterday at St. Patrick's Old Cathedral in New York. The Rev. Richard Viladesau performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: Sophisticated Tools for Selling Local Wares
description: BACK then, no one called it a mixing of high and low culture, but beginning in 1917, the Metropolitan Museum of Art held annual exhibitions of industrial art. In the 1920's, many companies tried to improve the artistic quality of their products and used museum collections as a major resource. It was a widespread notion that if industries identified themselves with high art and passed these views on to their ad men, American culture would benefit.

title: In Bad Taste
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Neighbors Say: Woodsman, Don't Spare Those Trees
description: When Leslie Charry walks her dog along Palisade Avenue, a quiet street reminiscent of some suburbs, she grimaces at the sight of the unpruned maple trees lining the eastern side. Her husband regularly walks over to the trees and fills trash bags full of the leaves, branches and debris strewn in the area.

title: A Hollywood Film Crew Departs; Duane St. Says Good Riddance
description: Some call it Hollywood-on-the-Hudson, a neighborhood where loft-dwelling film stars mingle with executives of Miramax, the movie company with headquarters there, and where on-location filming and videotaping is done nearly every day.

title: Mellower Now, A Resolute Romantic Keeps Trying
description: THE reports from Germany confirm it: Pina Bausch has mellowed.

title: GOING OUT

title: Mix and Match Frills on Flights
description: BUSINESS travelers are learning to love the growing network of no-frills airlines -- such as EasyJet, Ryanair, Virgin Express and British Airways' own low-cost clone Go -- that collectively serve more than 50 destinations in Europe. The appeal is not just their low fares that can save you up to 80 percent on the cost of full-fare tickets, but low one-way fares that allow you the flexibility you need for traveling midweek. There is no requirement for a Saturday night stay-over.

title: To Develop Or Preserve? Battle Lines Are Drawn
description: The southwest corner of Staten Island along the Arthur Kill is almost entirely zoned for manufacturing, making it short on houses and people and long on horse stables and abandoned factories. But this serenely disheveled landscape in and around Charleston may soon quicken with activity if the developers of a retail center and two residential areas win approval for their projects.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about investing in Apple Computer for its Internet potential misidentified an Adobe Systems software program that contributed to the popularity of Apple's Macintosh computers among designers of Web sites. It is GoLive, not InDesign.

title: October 24-30; Peron's Heirs Lose Their Grip
description: After 10 years of the flamboyant rule of President Carlos Saul Menem, Argentines gave a landslide presidential election victory to the unabashedly uncharismatic Mayor of Buenos Aires, Fernando de la Rua, and his center-left Alianza coalition. Mr. De la Rua is not expected to take Argentina in a direction very different from the policies of President Menem, but his victory broke a decade of dominance by the Justicialist party founded half a century ago by General Juan Domingo Peron. More than anything else, the vote for Mr. De la Rua appeared to reflect a popular rejection of the extravagance and perceived tolerance of corruption by Mr. Menem and other Peronist leaders. CLIFFORD KRAUSS

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-31-99; What They Were Thinking
description: Detective Mike Jannazzo, N.Y.P.D., West 36th Street, New York, June 9, 1999

title: A Minority of One
description: Herman badillo, former new york city commissioner of housing relocation, Bronx Borough President and Congressman, current chairman of the City University of New York and perennial candidate for mayor, is one of those rare figures in public life with a genuine penchant for the harsh truth. For example, while it is almost obligatory for minority politicians to support the ''open admissions'' policy that has permitted tens of thousands of black and Hispanic students to attend a CUNY college, Badillo, who was born in Puerto Rico, has spent years criticizing the institution as a swamp of mediocrity. Along with his political patron, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, he subjected both a former CUNY chancellor, Ann Reynolds, and a former school chancellor, Ramon Cortines, to such a merciless and public battering that they left town. But nothing Badillo has said has aroused quite so much fury as some casual remarks he made after a speech to a school-reform group last month.

title: Baylor to Accept Deal as Manager
description: Don Baylor, the Atlanta Braves' hitting coach, has accepted an offer to manage the Chicago Cubs, The Atlanta Journal-Constitution reported today.

description: Last week against the San Francisco 49ers, quarterback Jeff George, now oddly the savior of the Minnesota Vikings, threw a rocket pass to the superstar wide receiver Randy Moss. It had been a long time since Moss saw a football aimed for him, in game conditions, that was flying at warp speed.
