title: Debating the Rebound in Bank Stocks
description: SUDDENLY, over the last two weeks, the long-suffering bank stocks have roared to life, bid higher by investors with renewed confidence that inflation will remain in check despite irrepressible economic strength. The Standard & Poor's Banks Composite index jumped an astonishing 22.4 percent during the fortnight ended Friday.

title: Ms. Schuchinski, Mr. Schwartzberg
description: Jane Carla Schuchinski, a daughter of Vivian and Luis Schuchinski of Upper Montclair, N.J., is to be married this morning to Michael Scott Schwartzberg, a son of Mildred and Harvey Schwartzberg of Springfield, N.J. Rabbi Dan Ehrenkrantz is to officiate at the Crystal Plaza, a caterer in Livingston, N.J.

title: For Little Smiles ('Cheese')
description: It's that time of year, when parents start contemplating holiday cards and gifts bearing the smiling, upturned faces of their offspring. For parents who have exhausted the studio cards with the velvet curtain backdrop and ''I Grandma'' T-shirts, there's an upscale alternative. At Kate Burton Photography, a new studio and store at 316 East 84th Street, parents can arrange fine-art photo shoots for their children and turn the results into extravagantly nontacky cards and trinkets.

title: First Lady Of Flowers Surveys Domain
description: BEFORE the throng arrived to greet Lady Bird Johnson here, the Native Plant Center at Westchester Community College hummed only with the sound of bumblebees. A tiger swallowtail butterfly hovered in the Joe Pye Weed, while smaller butterflies flitted through the evening primroses.

title: Thoreau's Soggy Beach Trek
description: AMAN may stand there and put all America behind him,'' declared Henry David Thoreau in his book ''Cape Cod.'' By ''there'' he meant the Outer Cape's Atlantic beach, an unbroken stretch of some 30 miles that he walked in October of 1849. One pictures him standing in the sand, a windblown figure under a black umbrella. At his back, civilization recedes; ahead, Thoreau faces, in the choppy gray Atlantic, the wildness of nature that he sought so singlemindedly.

title: Food; Salem's Lot
description: Halloween may be the most celebrated black sabbath of the year. But unless you're living in Salem, Mass., you probably would not think to link the hawk-nosed, broomstick-flying variety of witch with the poor put-upon locals who were accused of being possessed and forced to stand trial during that long hot summer of 1692.

title: Liberties; The Vulture Culture

title: Nursing Home Demolition To Be Pursued Despite Ruling
description: New York City's top lawyer said yesterday that he would continue legal efforts to tear down a Queens nursing home that had been at the center of a battle over the city's commitment to public health care, despite a court ruling on Friday that blocked the planned demolition.

title: October 24-30; Filming in Black and White
description: Hard as Hollywood tries to get it right, it often falls back on the old cliches. The latest offering in this genre is ''Music of the Heart,'' with Meryl Streep playing the real-life Roberta Guaspari. Abandoned by her Navy officer husband, she moved her two small sons and a crate of violins to East Harlem and talked her way into a job at New York City's Central Park East school. Threatened by budget cuts, Ms. Guaspari conducted her best violin students in a triumphal concert at Carnegie Hall. In real life, Central Park East is one of the most acclaimed public schools in the country, a harmonious blend of races and classes in a rough neighborhood; even middle-class parents beg to be admitted. In the movie, it becomes a stereotypical ghetto school with lazy tenured teachers, racial discord and routine violence, where one stern but courageous teacher saves the day. While lauding Ms. Guaspari, Deborah Meier, the founder of Central Park East, complains that the movie turned a chance to tell a complex story of a good school nurturing a fellow risk-taker into a simple tale of good guys versus bad guys. ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS

title: The Knockdown
description: Did I miss something? Or did Deborah Y. Abramson (Lives, Oct. 10) fail to express even the slightest remorse for foolishly provoking a fight between her large ''energetic black Lab mix'' and a ''tiny mutt with withered legs'' -- a needless act that sent the elderly owner of the tiny dog to the hospital with a possible broken hip?

title: South Africa Falls to Australia in a Cup Thriller

title: Voters' Guide to the Referendum on 14 Revisions to New York City's Charter
description: In June, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani appointed a 15-member commission to consider revising the New York City Charter, its basic governing document. He named a former Deputy Mayor, Randy M. Mastro, as chairman and strongly hinted that his primary goal was to block the mayoral ambitions of a bitter political foe, Public Advocate Mark Green. Under the current charter, Mr. Green would finish Mr. Giuliani's term if the Mayor runs for the United States Senate next year and wins.

title: MUSIC; Still the Place to Take a Chance
description: NEW YORK and music have always been synonymous for me. Growing up in Queens, I always looked forward to Saturday morning, which meant a subway ride through colorful stops like Sunnyside and Flushing (in my child's mind, I saw a bright place and a giant toilet) to Manhattan for my weekly piano and Dalcroze Eurythmics lessons. I was 3 when I first made that jaunt. Looking back to those lessons, which I adored, I realize that eurythmics, a study of musical values through movement (or in my case, a study of physical coordination through my more naturally developed musical sense), introduced me to a principle that I have used throughout my working life as a composer and performer: the inseparability of music and movement, the voice and the body.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLS, ROBERT LAURENCE
description: MILLS-Robert Laurence, 72. Of Columbus, OH and East Charleston, VT, died of prostate cancer October 27, 1999 at his Vermont home. A member of the faculty at The Ohio State University from 1956 until his retirement in 1995, he was an elder of Indianola Presbyterian Church and active in the international student community. He is survived by his wife of 51 years, Elise Ackley Mills; his brother, William H. Mills; children Katherine (Joseph) Anderson of Silver Spring, MD, Edward (Mildred) Mills of Pittsburgh, PA, Jonathan Mills of New Brunswick, NJ, Susan (Thomas) Warner of Lewisburg, PA, and Dorothy Mills of Columbus, OH; and four grandchildren. He was pre-deceased by his sister Helen K. Mills. A man of uncompromising integrity and extraordinary good will, he will be remembered with admiration and deep affection.

title: Bringing Out the Dead
description: IT was cold and dark in the cemetery where Latoya Franklin stood stone still, her arms clinging to a friend from behind. It was quiet, so quiet that the friend, Vern Witherbee, could hear Latoya's bones shake. They looked straight ahead. There was a squeak. Then Latoya jumped four feet backward, screaming bloody murder. Tears streamed down her face as huge gray rats scampered out of a coffin and across her feet, before disappearing into a hole.

title: Tracing a Path, Real and Historical
description: CONCEPTUAL ART is often cited as the major new art form of the second half of the 20th century. An offshoot of the mode is installations in which the concept is embodied and made visible. Currently at Wave Hill here is a rambling outdoor installation that serves a variety of ends. A central concept behind it is that only a small part of Wave Hill's 28 acres is known to most of its visitors, and that those who follow the path laid out by Laura Anderson Barbata will get to know more of its terrain and more of the 1,200 genera and 3,250 species in its botanical collection.

title: Style; Men in Masks
description: It was mayhem from the first bell. A minute into the opening round of the featured wrestling match at the Arena Mexico, in Mexico City, the three rudos were intent on tearing the masks off their opponents, the tecnicos. The latter responded by pounding the head of Shocker, the most popular of the rudos, into a corner post.

title: Rustic Plus
description: ITALIAN food can be as rustic as the traditional appetizer for which Bruschetta is named. While studying the contemporary menu and well-stocked wine list, my party and I savored a complimentary order of bruschetta: four slices of grilled bread, drizzled with olive oil and topped with a mound of chopped tomatoes and julienned basil. Warm, elegant and light, this dish set the tone for what lay ahead: Italian food, some of it with a twist, but never taken too far from from its simple roots.

title: Family Values, or the Lack, At Issue in a Tight Election
description: Only three states had governors' races scheduled this year: Kentucky, Louisiana and Mississippi.

title: Ideas & Trends; In Panama, a Party But No Guests
description: WHEN the United States gave up its colonial ambitions and handed over the Philippines to the Filipinos in 1946, Harry S. Truman sent the living symbol of American power in the Pacific -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur -- to do the deed. When Richard M. Nixon returned Okinawa to Japan 30 years ago, he dispatched a man capable of teaching even Japanese politicians a thing or two about mixing business and politics: Vice President Spiro Agnew.

title: ART/ARCHITECTURE; In Houston, a Museum That Speaks for Itself
description: IN 1985, the Spanish architect Rafael Moneo, who had just been chosen as the chairman of Harvard University's Graduate School of Design, delivered a speech with this shocking message: Ideas must be built in order to be called architecture. Drawings and theories, he observed, had become refuges for a profession that no longer saw itself as vital. The historic connection between construction and architecture had broken down and even what was built adhered too closely to the architect's drawing board. Only when a building could exist without relying on the architect's protection or reflecting his ego could it be said to succeed. This quality of standing alone Mr. Moneo called solitude, and to him solitude became the final mark of an authentic architecture.

title: Just Imagine . . .
description: Over this past century, business has given us the car, the radio, the television, the personal computer, the jet, the trash compactor and shampoo combined with conditioner. Send your ideas to Outlook 2000, Money & Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to Outlook-2000@nytimes.com. Include your name and telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Three Home Runs by Curtis
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The West Is Still the Best
description: The race for the Eastern Conference title is wide open, but whoever wins will be a decided underdog to the Western Conference champion because that's where the league's power lies, from the defending champion Spurs to the new-age Lakers and the old-money Jazz. Here's a look at each of the 29 teams, listed in their predicted order of finish.

title: October 24-30; An Odd Couple Fights for a Nomination
description: When last seen in battle, Patrick J. Buchanan's fabled pitchfork brigades had successfully crossed the moat in the 1996 New Hampshire Presidential primary but were subsequently driven from the Republican castle by the establishment forces of Bob Dole. Now Mr. Buchanan is back under a different banner, aiming to mount up on Ross Perot's Reform ticket with its $12.6 million in Federal subsidy. He vows a charge upon the two ''party elite'' nominees.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SIMON, BERNARD E.
description: SIMON-Bernard E., M.D. Mount Sinai School of Medicine and The Mount Sinai Hospital of Mount Sinai NYU Health will hold a memorial service to mark the passing in August of our dear friend and esteemed colleague Bernard E. Simon, M.D., Clinical Professor of Surgery Emeritus and internationally-renowned plastic surgeon who was associated with Mount Sinai for more than 60 years, and one of three physicians who donated their services to a group of severely disfigured atomic bomb survivors known as the Hiroshima Maidens, who underwent reconstructive surgery at Mount Sinai. Family, Trustees, faculty, staff, students, friends and admirers are invited to attend at 5PM Wednesday, November 3, in the Hatch Auditorium, Guggenheim Pavillion, Fifth Avenue at 100th Street.

title: BUSINESS; Practicing What U.S. Preaches?
description: IS it the Ugly American all over again?

title: It's a Coming-Out Party For a Sophomore Passer
description: The Princeton Tigers, behind the precision passing of Tommy Crenshaw, manhandled the Columbia Lions today to earn their first Ivy League victory of the season, 44-15, at Princeton Stadium.

title: State's Representatives In Washington
description: Have a problem, or an opinion? Here's how to let somebody know in Washington.

title: Rediscovering A Colorful College Town
description: THE members of my family who live in Madison, Wis., are always a little amused when I come to their town for a visit. Inevitably I announce my arrival from a pay phone at the University of Wisconsin Memorial Union, a place they feel I should have outgrown since I was an undergraduate here a decade ago. But the Union, the hub of the university's -- and probably even the city's -- social life, is the best place I know to find out what is happening in this town that counts 40,000 students among its 200,000 inhabitants.

title: Hiding a Secret? Not From Your Garbageman
description: THERE is perhaps only one other professional who knows as much about you as your bartender. This stranger knows something about your spouse's morning habits; he knows the cuckold, the insomniac, the moneyed, the repossessed and the hammer-toed. He knows your brand of breath mint and he knows your shoe size.

title: Labor Dispute
description: WHAT A BLESSING SHE

title: After the War, Yugoslavs Resume Play
description: Team competition is very popular in Europe. Indeed, it may be the leading form of organized chess expression in Germany. It also plays an important role in the Netherlands. And Yugoslavia, hardly more than two months after the cessation of the NATO bombing, held its team championship -- business as usual -- in the resort city of Vrnjacka Banja.

title: Taking the Political To a Personal Level
description: WHO hasn't wanted to ask actors about the thin moral and ethical line they would or would not cross to take the money -- good money, much needed -- for a commercial that violates deep-felt convictions?

title: It's a Handbag. Really, It Is.
description: The unisex handbags by As Four, a young international design team, look like anything but handbags. Doughnut-shaped creations sold in sets of four at Horn in the East Village, they come in industrial orange canvas (above, $222.22) or a fusion of glittery honeycomb brocaded with lacey miniature flower buds ($444.44). Horn, 328 East Ninth Street, expects to have a gunmetal leather version later this year. They are also sold at Colette in Paris.

title: Night of the Living, and Unliving, Dead
description: Joyce Carol Oates will be doing it. So will Roger Corman. Even an English professor who wrote a book about doing it will be doing it -- staying up all night tonight to watch horror movies on television.

title: Abstract Introspection In 2 Distinct Styles
description: THIS month, a crepuscular atmosphere pervades the Simon Gallery here, where Judith Murray and Merrill Wagner are showing paintings that are predominantly dark, brooding and introverted.

title: Leafy Suburbs Can Come At a Cost, A Young Life
description: IN Florida and North Carolina, they have hurricanes; in California, earthquakes; in Kansas, tornadoes. We have trees. Large and graceful trees that this time of year transform ordinary suburban streets into blazing canopies of autumn color. Huge trees that snap like twigs in every storm. And when they fall, they fall without warning, they fall without mercy, they fall with utter disregard for property or life.

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-31-99: On Language; Rip-Tootin' Poorbacks
description: 'Vice President Al Gore today continued his efforts to put a new face on his Presidential campaign,'' wrote Katherine Q. (for Quimby) Seelye of The New York Times from Nashville, '' . . . promising supporters a rip-tootin' candidacy.'' His actual words were ''a rip-tootin' campaign that is going to win in the year 2000.''

title: Corrections
description: A 1910 photograph of a group of four houses at the southeast corner of 89th and Lexington with the Streetscapes column on Oct. 10 carried an erroneous credit. It was from the New-York Historical Society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLLINS, MARTIN S.
description: POLLINS-Martin S. Retired radio, television and entertainment executive. Died on October 28, 1999 at the age of 80 in New York City. Martin was born in Manhattan and served in the Navy during WWII. He was a senior executive in spot sales for ABC and NBC, Vice President of Distribution for Paramount Pictures and President of Gannett Productions in New York City. He is survived by his wife Judith, sister Elinor Ellis, daughters Terri Carr and Phyllis Maguire, three grandchildren, Lindsay and Morgan Maguire, and Ryan Carr. A memorial service will be held at ''The Riverside'', Sunday, October 31st, 11:15AM. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Make a Wish Foundation, 85 Old Shore Road, Port Washington, New York 11050.

title: Islanders Show Their Failings
description: The talent hasn't been there, but now the energy is gone, too, and the Islanders are sinking.

title: Jubilee Concert for Music Teachers
description: WESTCHESTER has a number of fine conservatories and college music departments, but 60 years ago many unaffiliated artists formed the Music Teachers Council of Westchester, with a stated mission of maintaining and improving teaching standards and making the community aware of the importance of high-quality music education.

title: Eve Maldonado, Peter J. O'Toole
description: Eve Michael Maldonado, the daughter of Irma and Daniel Maldonado of Germantown, Md., was married yesterday to Peter Justin O'Toole, a son of Vitaline O'Connell O'Toole of Madison, Conn., and Thomas O'Toole of Washington. The Rev. William D. Aldridge Jr. performed the ceremony at Metropolitan Memorial United Methodist Church in Washington.

title: Why the Silence On Chechnya?
description: To the Editor:

title: A More Perfect Union
description: A NECESSARY EVIL

title: To Build a Home, First Tear One Down
description: WHEN Zara Moradi Ghadamian bought a ranch house in Kings Point, she didn't care that the three-bedroom home was in immaculate condition. It didn't matter to her that the beige Formica kitchen was brand-new or that the previous owners had taken care to fix every leak and polish every doorknob before putting their 40-year-old home on the market.

title: The Nation; Candidates, Taking a Stand, Mix Policy and Persona
description: IT was once a sure-fire attack strategy in Presidential debates: Candidates turn to their rivals and scold them for espousing policies that are fanciful, shallow and even risky. ''Where's the beef?'' asked Walter F. Mondale, memorably needling Gary Hart during the Democratic primary campaign in 1984.

title: Political Briefing; Seeking New Rules For a Campaign Tool
description: Few things have had more influence in recent years on the way political campaigns are run in this country than the Internet.

title: Guard Shoots Cabby Who Bit Piece of Ear
description: An off-duty security guard shot a livery cab driver in Brooklyn early yesterday after the driver bit off a large part of the guard's ear, the police said.

title: Testifying to the Commercial Power of Sacred Steel
description: AFRICAN-AMERICAN gospel music is moving outside the church to an unheard-of degree. Gospel brunches have become Sunday institutions at clubs like House of Blues, while the contemporary gospel star Kirk Franklin crosses over to the pop charts, selling millions of albums that mix religious -- or sometimes just spiritual -- themes with hip-hop language and rhythms. In the last few years, music like little heard before on record has emerged from several black Pentecostal churches, with a hard-driving style called sacred steel making the biggest inroads. A recent compilation, ''Sacred Steel -- Live!,'' is the fifth CD devoted to the genre released in the last two years by Arhoolie Records, a label that specializes in folk and ethnic music.

title: THEATER; Ready to Rumble: A Heavy Puncher Who's Outrageous
description: HE doesn't have slaughtered pigs or Virgin Marys with elephant dung in his backpack. But when the German theater director and performance artist Christoph Schlingensief arrives at P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center in Long Island City, Queens, he will likely be bringing some surprises. His avant-garde performance/installation ''Wagner Refugee Camp: A Search for Germany'' opens there next Sunday.

title: Need a Cartoon? There's a Bank for It
description: YOU can't help smiling when visiting the spacious warehouse of an office of the Cartoon Bank overlooking the Hudson River here.

title: ART/ARCHITECTURE; A Closer Look Reveals a Dutch Michelangelo
description: FOR Michelangelo, who was uniquely qualified to judge, sculpture was superior to painting. And yet it is rare for a sculptor other than Michelangelo himself, Donatello or Bernini to be included among the many heroes of Renaissance and Baroque art.

title: Candidates Vie for Council And District Attorney Slots
description: Candidates throughout the city spent the weekend making a barrage of telephone calls and walking through neighborhoods to urge voters to go to the polls on Tuesday for elections for several City Council seats, judgeships and district attorney positions.

title: Pierce and Testud Advance to Final
description: Top-seeded Mary Pierce will play Sandrine Testud in an All-French final today in Linz, Austria, at the Generali Ladies tournament after both won yesterday in the semifinals.

title: Medicare Drug Benefit
description: To the Editor:

title: The Nation: Head Start, Everyone; Toddling Off to Preschool
description: WHAT is the right age for children to start school?

title: A Cozy Cafe With Some Dishes to Please
description: CHEZ JEAN PIERRE in Stamford is an example of how dining out can be like a non-lethal version of Russian roulette. So much depends on what you order. In the very same restaurant, you can have an Olympian experience or an ordinary one.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOBLE, DR. JEROME
description: NOBLE-Dr. Jerome. September 25th, 1916-October 29th, 1999. The better part of a century of loving and helping others. Husband, father, grandfather. Proud member of the U.S. Navy Medical Corps and of the Marines during the first three invasions of World War II, and in the Pacific. Commissioning Officer of the U.S.S. Beatty. Caring physician and friend.

title: In Helping the Many, Don't Neglect the Few
description: With the move toward inclusion in special education, which aims to teach children with disabilities in the regular classroom, many school districts are seeing inclusion of all students in the regular classroom as a panacea. Teachers are now being faced with diverse classrooms that include students for whom English is a second language, who have disabilities, who are gifted and who are gifted and disabled. Confusion abounds, and most teachers are not trained for the variety of special needs of students in an all-inclusive classroom.

title: Hargrave's New Owners Ready for Big Splash
description: THE new owners of Hargrave Vineyard, Marco Borghese and his wife, Ann Marie, seemed dazed. And who wouldn't be, under the circumstances?

title: Finding the Reality That Lies Just Beyond the Real
description: GREGORY GILLESPIE's ''Self-Portrait in a Black Shirt'' (1968-69) is one of those remarkable paintings that, if known only in reproduction, creates a startling effect when seen in person.

title: From a Gallop to a Saunter: Mideast Leaders Fear That Talks Have Stalled
description: Prime Minister Ehud Barak steamrolled into office with grand plans of forging a permanent Israeli-Palestinian peace agreement by next September. Stopwatches were set at the blow of his whistle. And then, after an uplifting summit meeting early this fall, almost two months yawned by without a single official negotiating session.

title: Nothing Sacred in Cemetery Vandalism
description: IT'S Halloween, and if you're in the market for a really scary story, forget the Stephen King books and the Hollywood horror movies. Cemeteries around the state are the places where you'll find the most macabre tales, chilling stories of grave robberies -- and vandalism.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Deanna Kirk; Grown-Up Crooning
description: I'VE just sold the first glass of wine!'' shouted a waitress last Wednesday night as she stood before the only couple dining at Deanna's, a more upscale version of the popular East Village hole-in-the-wall jazz club that was shut down after a fire four years ago. A few feet away, a huddle of restaurant staff members hooted and applauded. The couple turned as red as the merlot until Deanna Kirk, the restaurant's owner and namesake, stepped over to explain.

title: As Crises Come and Go, Hale House Persists
description: THIRTY years after her mother rescued the first baby of a heroin addict, through the cocaine years and the beginning of the AIDS years, Hale House and Lorraine Hale endure.

title: Affirmative Action
description: Mattie Grady-Smith, a lawyer, has been appointed to direct the county's Affirmative Action/Equal Employment Opportunities program. Her appointment is part of County Executive Andrew J. Spano's effort to increase the number of women and members of minorities in the county's work force, Mr. Spano said.

title: Values Collide as Madison Ave. Runs Into 125th St.
description: First it was copulating tortoises. Then the basketball player toting a gun. And early this month, it was an expletive unfit for publication in a family newspaper.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FEIRSTEIN, ABRAHAM
description: FEIRSTEIN-Abraham. Gone 16 years but never forgotten. Remembering your extraordinary love, kindness and caring every day. Edna and family

title: Embraceable You
description: When Audrey Storch's breast cancer was diagnosed four and a half years ago, her sons, then 4 and 7, struggled with her absences for surgery and treatment. She left behind a photograph to help them cope, but a picture isn't particularly cuddly. Then she hit on the idea of a stuffed doll with a picture frame, but it took her recovery and a school invention contest to come up with one. The crude doll her younger son entered did not win a prize, but it helped him sleep at night. Ms. Storch consulted, designed and developed, and she came up with the Huggee Miss You doll, which holds a 4-by-6-inch photo in its face. Making and selling the dolls is now Ms. Storch's full-time occupation, and she is donating 10 percent of profits to breast cancer research. She has a Web site, www.huggeemissyou.com, on which the dolls ($24.95 plus $6.95 for shipping) may be ordered. It also directs viewers to places that sell them, like Imaginarium stores and some shops in North Jersey. Dolls may also be ordered from JAAM, Post Office Box 2130, Wayne, N.J. 07470; (877) 365-5677, which is toll-free.

title: The Miss Match
description: In the great spectator sport known as fashion, the starlet Leelee Sobieski scores major points for the delicacy of her deportment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLEN, SOPHIE
description: ALLEN-Sophie. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family and its parent company Continuum Health Partners Inc. join with the faculties and staffs of The Alan and Barbara Mirken Department of Neurology and the HymanNewman Institute for Neurology and Neurosurgery (INN) in mourn the passing of Sophie Allen, beloved mother of our esteemed colleague, Jeffrey Allen, M.D., Director of the Division of Pediatric Neurology. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Dr. Allen and his family. Morton P. Hyman, Chairman, Boards of Trustees Beth Israel and Continuum Robert G. Newman, M.D., President & CEO, Continuum Matthew E. Fink, M.D. President and CEO Beth Israel Medical Center Susan B. Bressman, M.D., Chairman, Alan and Barbara Mirken Department of Neurology Alejandro Berenstein, M.D., Director, INN Fred J. Epstein, M.D., Co-Director, INN Henry S. Singman, M.D., President, Medical Board Robert L. Salant, M.D., Pres. Doctors' Alumni Assoc.

title: In the Region /Long Island; For Suffolk, an Employer-Assisted Housing Program
description: WHAT better way for an employer to woo, or retain, employees in today's tight local labor market than to help them purchase a home?

title: Symphony Recruits a Jazzman
description: The first thing to know here is that Thomas Oboe Lee plays flute, not oboe -- although his parents, bless them, could not have predicted that when he was born in China in 1945). They also may not have guessed that in addition to his career as a jazz flutist, he would become a decorated composer, with a Kennedy Center Award, a Rome Prize, Guggenheim and National Foundation of the Arts grants, and on and on.

title: You Want to Paint a Cornice? Sure It's the Right Color?
description: Most people would not have noticed. But when Ron Melichar moved into a 19th-century brownstone at 141st Street and Convent Avenue in 1985, it immediately registered on him that the ornate metal cornice atop his home in the Hamilton Heights Historic District was green, in striking contrast to the building's graceful limestone surface.

title: GURU: John Mahdessian; Dry Cleaning for Perfectionists and the Merely Finicky
description: BOB SAKS is particular about his socks. They are made of cashmere, and when he sends them to the cleaners, he expects them to be de-pilled, de-linted, ironed flat and folded in tissue. If there's one fuzzy ball clinging to them, he will send them back. The same goes for his silk and cashmere boxer shorts, and his Wrangler jeans, which he wants to be starched so heavily they will stand on their own.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEBLASIO, JO
description: DeBLASIO-Jo. A painter, known by the name of Jo Warner, died on October 25, 1999 from complications of bone marrow cancer (multiple myeloma). Raised in Idaho Falls, and a graduate of the University of Colorado and the Art Students League of New York, she had many one woman exhibitions during her career at galleries including the Camino and Phoenix in New York. Two of her oil paintings were included in the Museum of Modern Art's Circulating Exhibition from 1961 to 1963 and were viewed throughout the U.S. and Europe. She was married for 29 years to Peter E. DeBlasio, and she was the very loving mother of Caralee DeBlasio of Manhattan and Alessandra DeBlasio of Washington, DC.

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-31-99:; Pay on Delivery
description: A couple of weeks ago, the morning after I gave birth to my second child, a particularly garrulous nurse stopped by my room and asked if I had been given an epidural pain block during labor. When I told her I hadn't, she was so instantly approving I half-expected her to slap a gold star on my hospital gown. I had been a good girl, it seemed. My baby would feed more eagerly and efficiently, I'd be up and around sooner and, my burbly visitor implied, in the long run I'd feel better about myself.

title: Texas Town, Southern Style
description: THE string of flat, narrow barrier islands curving along the Texas coast are more like wide sandbars than chunks of land jutting from the sea. They're home to a scattering of beach towns, fishing villages and resorts with gleaming hotels and condominiums. Galveston, the only real city to speak of, is at the top of the strand.

title: Catherine Rinaldi, David Skoblow
description: Catherine Alice Rinaldi, an aide to Gov. George E. Pataki, and David Victor Skoblow, a lawyer, were married yesterday in Manhattan. The Rev. Brian Brennan performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLEN, MICHAEL LEWIS
description: ALLEN-Michael Lewis. Age 61, on Saturday, October 30, after a short illness. Devoted husband of Beverly; adored father of Nancy Markhoff, Richard, and Jeffrey; and father in-law of Michael Markhoff, and Mari Korper Allen; beloved grandfather of Adam and Abigail Markhoff. Brother of Leonore Schwartz. Memorial service to be held on Monday, November 1, 11:30 AM at the Clinton Inn, 145 Dean Dr., Tenafly, NJ, 201871-3200. In lieu of flowers, please make donations in his memory to Council for a Liveable World, 110 Maryland Ave., N.E., Washington, DC 20002 or the Calvary Fund, c/o Calvary Hospital, 1740 Eastchester Rd., Bronx, NY 10461.

title: Can That Be Joseph Papp Underneath the Makeup?
description: IN Michael Weller's new satirical comedy, ''The Heart of Art,'' a character named Arthur Dick is the short, mercurial, cigar-smoking impresario of the People Playhouse in Manhattan, a home to ''challenging drama'' and ''provocative playwrights.'' Mr. Dick has had a ''huge impact on American theater'' and has fostered the careers of many young writers, but he needs to be a father figure, meddles with their plays and becomes involved in feuds. He is, in the words of one angry dramatist, the ''collective nightmare of every playwright since the dawn of time.''

title: Defense Against Attack
description: To the Editor:

title: Watching the Watchers
description: Mark Ghuneim said he had little to hide until he noticed the video surveillance cameras. They watched him as he walked to the corner deli, recorded his transactions at the A.T.M. and captured him on his Vespa scooter. Even worse, he said, was the absence of public dialogue about their arrival. So Mr. Ghuneim, an on-line music executive, began documenting every camera he spotted in Manhattan south of 72d Street.

title: THE GUIDE
description: 'Mysteries of Egypt'

title: Farm-Zoo's Neighbors Cry Foul
description: SCREAMS pierced the springtime darkness at an upscale housing development on Old Country Road. Springing from their beds, residents raced to their windows and scanned their backyards.

title: New Orleans Casino Swaggers Past the Doubts on Opening Day
description: The first of the nightly Mardi Gras parades wound its way through a vast new windowless casino on Thursday night, its costumed stilt walkers dancing past the carefully re-created French Quarter and Garden District, past Pete Fountain and his clarinet and buffet tables heaped with jambalaya, but hundreds of people never even looked up.

title: Making an Austen Heroine More Like Austen
description: FANNY PRICE, the heroine of ''Mansfield Park,'' should have been one of Jane Austen's most memorable creations. Fanny is a Regency Cinderella, a poor girl shipped off to live with ill-tempered wealthy relatives. She ultimately wins her prince -- in this case, her cousin Edmund (nobody worried too much about genetics in those days). Fanny always takes the high road; she's the only character who sticks to her principles and resists all temptation to change.

title: BEST SELLERS: October 31, 1999
description: Weeks

title: Elegy to a Dumpscape
description: It must be tempting, from a distance, to wax elegiac about some of the esthetic aspects of the Fresh Kills landfill, so I can understand the impulse that motivated Stephen Wilkes and Verlyn Klinkenborg (Oct. 10).

title: Blooms and Greenery to Steal a March on Spring
description: PLANTS march to their own tune, not the calendar's arbitrary dictates. My ''winter'' garden, for example, started to show in late September. At least, that's when I saw the first cream-incised leaves of the ever so elegant Italian arum (A. italicum var. Marmoratum).

title: A Play for a Past Century, This One and the Next
description: JUST when ''everyone is millennium-crazed,'' as the McCarter Theater's artistic director, Emily Mann, put it, how is it that New Jersey's most serious, seriously regarded, socially conscious, prestigious and risk-taking theater -- not all these adjectives are arguable -- is producing an all-too-often produced comedy by Oscar Wilde as its last play of the century? Especially when that play is of another century. ''The Importance of Being Earnest'' is 105 years old, thank you. (''A Christmas Carol,'' which follows in December, does not count as the last play of the year. In one version or another, it is the last play of every year.)

title: Raising Money With Imagination and Thrift Shop Creativity
description: SOUTHPORT is not a typical community, the Southport Congregational Church not a typical church, and ''Rooms With a View,'' its annual charity event, not a typical designers' show house.

title: Italian Boat Wins Cup Trials' First Round
description: There's an old, telling story about Italy's first America's Cup challenge, in 1983. One could always foresee an Italian tack, it was said, when the crewmen, in unison, tossed their freshly lighted smokes over the side.

title: Will Trade Acupuncture For Manicure and Pasta
description: IF she could, Amy Sacco would probably pay for everything with pasta. ''So how hungry are you?'' she slyly asks whenever she is given a hefty bill for equipment or services for her Chelsea restaurant and bar, Lot 61. She says she has exchanged food and drink for waitress uniforms, work on Lot 61's Web site, lamps and artwork.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KRINSKY, NEWMAN, GERTRUDE
description: KRINSKY-NEWMAN-Gertrude. 3/9/18-11/1/49. To our big sister. Always in our hearts, your grace, your spirit, remembered with love

title: Yankee Pride Makes Fans of Everyone
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: School Choice Program Draws Few Districts
description: Thirteen of more than 600 New Jersey districts have applied to take students in as part of a pilot program allowing children to attend schools outside their districts. In September, the state Board of Education sent applications to superintendents so that they would notify schools of the program.

title: Tracking and Patching Leaky Roofs
description: EVEN if you don't see signs of a roof leak in the rooms below the attic, it's a good idea to make a yearly inspection of the roof from inside the attic itself. It is possible that you have a roof leak, but the water may be collecting in the attic insulation or running into unseen areas like the wall cavities. The best time to make a leak inspection is during, or immediately after, a rainstorm.

title: Ideas & Trends; Here's One Top 10 List Nobody Wants to Make
description: LIKE music CD's, box office receipts and the world's richest people, corruption has its own top 10 list.

title: INVESTING WITH -- Rudolph K. Kluiber; State Street Research Aurora Fund
description: FOR managers of most small-capitalization value funds, it has been a brutal few years. But Rudolph K. Kluiber, portfolio manager of the $393.2 million State Street Research Aurora Fund, has had little trouble maintaining an upbeat attitude, even as investors have shunned the kinds of stocks he likes and flocked to large growth equities.

title: China Enacts Tough Law To Undercut Banned Cult
description: After a week of secret deliberations, China's top legislative body today issued a stringent new ''anti-cult'' law designed to aid the Government's crackdown on the Falun Gong spiritual movement.

title: Sometimes a Great Notion
description: VIEWS FROM

title: Lab Humans
description: Undue Risk

title: Italian Experience Omitted In a Black-White Essay
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Postings column last Sunday on the trademark status of the Flatiron Building misstated the building's ownership. A partnership of Barry Gosin, Jeffrey R. Gural and James D. Kuhn, who are principals in Newmark & Company Real Estate Inc., owns a 52 percent interest in the building. The Newmark company itself is the leasing and managing agent but not the owner.

title: Prescriptions for a Troubled Patient: The Theater
description: Earlier this month, nine American playwrights gathered in Provincetown, Mass., to discuss the future of American theater. The meeting, organized by the Provincetown Repertory Theater, was recorded before an audience in the town hall. The moderator, Steven Drukman, who is writing a history of American avant-garde theater, began by asking whether there are two separate theater cultures in the United States: nonprofit and commercial Broadway. Here are edited excerpts from the session.

title: Vegetables and More Around Murray Hill
description: ALI BABA ++

title: The Gulf Between the Ears
description: THE UNDISCOVERED MIND How the Human Brain Defies Replication, Medication, and Explanation. By John Horgan. 325 pp. New York: The Free Press. $25.

title: Appreciating Variety
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: RAIN MIRROR

title: F.Y.I.
description: But One Statue to Lose

title: Minding His Own Business And Watching Israel's
description: Benjamin Netanyahu, technology financier? ''I'm looking at the possibility of something with starting a venture capital operation,'' possibly by combining existing Israeli firms, Mr. Netanyahu said in an brief interview after speaking to Columbia Business School executive M.B.A. students on Friday. He already advises BATM Advanced Communications, an Israeli maker of switches for fiber optic cable whose stock market value has gone from roughly $100 million to $1.6 billion in a year -- ''with no relation to my activities at all,'' he said.

title: Anti-Violence Mural Has Fans in Park Slope
description: To the Editor:

title: Is a Cold Soda Worth More on a Hot Day?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURTON, VICTOR C.
description: BURTON-Victor C. 75. Of Palm Beach, FL. Formerly of Great Neck, N.Y. On October 9, 1999. You will always be alive in our hearts.

title: Hey, Everyone's Cool, Teen-Age Aliens Too
description: Liz Parker, the 16-year-old heroine of the new WB drama ''Roswell,'' works after school as a waitress at the Crashdown Cafe. The burger joint that attracts goggle-eyed tourists in search of U.F.O.'s also turns out to be where Liz dies and, through the magic of science fiction, comes back to life.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: JAMAICA/FOREST HILLS

title: Albee's Advice to Actors: Keep It Simple
description: AT a recent rehearsal at Choate Rosemary School in Wallingford, a tall figure dressed in faded blue jeans and a brown shirt silently positioned himself on the downstage edge. He leaned forward to catch every word the actor spoke. After a few lines of his monologue, the actor looked deferentially to the man before continuing.

title: Things to Consider On Election Day
description: According to the Nassau County Comptroller's office, Nassau County spends between 70 and 80 cents of every tax dollar on non-discretionary budget items. On the surface, there seems little room to cut spending and little alternative to raising taxes yet again. But a quick look at Suffolk County shows a completely different picture. Suffolk County has 100,000 more people than Nassau County but a payroll slightly more than two-thirds the size of the one in Nassau. Suffolk County enjoys the same amount and quality of services enjoyed by the people of Nassau County. Then why do they spend less than 53 cents of every tax dollar on non-discretionary programs and services? Efficiency and concern for the taxpayer, that's why. Using Suffolk County as a gauge, the bloated patronage mill in Nassau County costs taxpayers more than $400 million more than it should, more than enough to cover our recent deficits. Nassau County uses the excuse of these mandated programs to justify employing hundreds more people than is actually necessary. And they continue to raise our taxes to keep the gravy train rolling.

title: Q & A
description: Shroud of Turin

title: Spurs Pressing To Get Out Vote In San Antonio
description: Tim Duncan has threatened to leave, via free agency. The owner, Peter Holt, is implying that he may move the team. Even the gracious David Robinson has joined the gallant fight to make the people of San Antonio pay for a new arena.

title: The Woman Behind the Bows
description: The new movie ''Music of the Heart'' includes a Carnegie Hall scene in which an ensemble of about 30 child violinists perform Bach onstage as if they were miniature disciples of Itzhak Perlman. Can you figure out which are actors and which are true violinists?

title: Kerry Connolly, James Sandnes
description: Kerry Ellen Connolly and James Theodore Sandnes, lawyers in New York law firms, were married yesterday by the Rev. Richard R. McKeon Jr. at the Zion Episcopal Church in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

title: Nassau's G.O.P. Incumbents Facing a Challenge, for a Change
description: ''Joey, we need your help!'' shouted Josep Puleo, 64, as he wheeled a shopping cart out of the King Kullen supermarket here and saw the Democratic candidate for county legislator, Joseph Scannell, passing out leaflets.

title: Sleepless in San Jose
description: Larry Ellison, a collector of jets, including military fighters, has declared war on the city of San Jose, Calif. His target: an airport regulation that he says unfairly restricts the nighttime use of his $38.7 million Gulfstream GV.

title: Booting Up for the Election
description: As the last of 1,200 electronic voting machines were readied for delivery to election districts in Bergen County, Francis Hernandez and William Carriero, above right, installed sheets with the names of candidates and loaded an electronic tape, below, that records the tally.

title: For Reference, on the Front Lines
description: I HAVE always thought of librarians as superior beings. They seem so modest, and yet they know so much. The local library is my second home. I haunt the place like an unquiet ghost, always hoping to find inspiration, entertainment, reassurance and a functioning copy machine. The World Wide Web is no substitute for a library, because it has no librarians in it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCAFEE, MARY ANN
description: MCAFEE-Mary Ann. The Brokers and Staff of Douglas Elliman mourn the loss of our dear friend and colleague Mary Ann McAfee after a recent illness. Mac started her real estate career w/Douglas Elliman and consistently represented the firm in a thoroughly professional, honest and straightforward manner.She was a valued member of our team & one of the most dedicated to her profession. We extend our deepest sympathy to her family and shall miss her greatly.

title: Raising The Specter Of an Oil Shortage
description: JUST about a year ago, some analysts were saying oil prices could fall to $5 a barrel by year-end. Oil company executives told Congress that prices would linger around $10 a barrel for the next decade.

title: Madeline Meehan, James Welker
description: Madeline Isabel Eugenia Meehan was married on Thursday to James Miller Welker. The Rev. William L. Arnet, a nondenominational minister, officiated at the Family Division of Territorial Court in Charlotte Amalie on the island of St. Thomas, the Virgin Islands. Afterward, the Rev. Fred W. Hintz, a Eucharist minister, led a celebration of the marriage with the Rev. William H. Kenny, a Roman Catholic deacon, on the beach at Magens Bay.

title: OPINION; Rise and Fall of Our Hockey Team
description: THERE were a couple of inches of snow on the ground, it was under 20 degrees and a fierce wind was blowing across the parking field at the Nassau Coliseum. I was trudging toward the entrance to see the Islanders play with my wife's parting question wending through my thought process -- ''Why are you going out on a night like this to see a hockey game?'' she asked. ''Are you crazy?''

title: VICARIOUS CONSUMPTION; Rest and Relaxation, But Not for the Weak
description: THE top of the world, the bottom of the ocean, the edges of space -- all were virgin territory at the beginning of this century. Now all of them are visited regularly by people who have a sense of adventure -- not to mention a lot of money.

title: Love and History, Lavishly Elegant
description: IN the movie ''Lust for Life'' Van Gogh shouts at Gauguin, ''You look too fast!'' That remark presages the course of 20th-century art. At the end of the century, there is a premium on art that is absorbed instantly. Much of it does not stand up to a second look. Viewers who want a chance to take their time ought to consider thematically related exhibitions of late 19th-century painting, ''James Tissot, Victorian Life/Modern Love'' at the Yale Center for British Art in New Haven, and ''Elegance and Opulence: Art of the Gilded Age'' at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LOWER MANHATTAN; A Police Station Without Cops Or Criminals
description: As they round the corner of Clinton Street onto Broome, some drivers slow down these days to take a second look at a 65-year-old building that bears an eagle with a crest that says, ''12th Precinct.''

title: A Reminder
description: Standard time resumed at 2 A.M. today. Clocks were set back one hour.

title: JERSEY DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Mysteries of the Deep, Close to Home
description: I HAD a boat, most of a spring and summer and a cargo of books, and thus prepared to sail the Inside Passage to Alaska from Seattle to Juneau. To put oneself afloat on a sea-route so old and heavily traveled was to join the epic cavalcade of those, present and past, who'd found some kind of meaning in these waters. In an average day's sailing, one might have to alter course to give way to a Holland America Line cruise ship; a squad of family gill-netters; a NOAA research vessel full of scientists doing fieldwork; the garbage scow, piled high with crushed cars, fridges, filing cabinets. I always suffer from mild delusions when I'm alone for long at sea, and it would be no great surprise to find myself hauling the wheel to starboard to get clear of a survey-pinnace, under a yellowed lugsail, from the Vancouver expedition, or skirting a fog-cliff, a red-and-black-painted Haida canoe, laden with Chilkat blankets, going south to trade.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the New Jersey roots of Bill Bradley's presidential campaign misstated the business of Martin & Glantz, in which a campaign aide, Gina Stritzler Glantz, is a principal. It is a public-affairs consulting firm, not an advertising firm. A listing of campaign aides with the article misspelled the surname of Mr. Bradley's fund-raising director. She is Betty Sapoch, not Szabo.

title: Bookend; The Race to the Bottom
description: A few years ago I received a book from an old friend with an accompanying note stating that although he was normally protective of the books he lent, this was something he would be happy never to see again. Published sometime around 1913 for children, the book is entitled ''Like English Gentlemen'' and tells the story of Robert Falcon Scott's death in the Antarctic. Dedicated to Peter Scott, the dead explorer's son, it was almost certainly written by J. M. Barrie, the playwright and author of ''Peter Pan''; Scott's son was named for Peter Pan, and the title is a quotation from Peter Pan's Never-Never Land wife, Wendy: ''Our sons will die like English gentlemen.'' The book climaxes with Scott's famous words, written as he lay dying in his snowbound tent: ''I do not regret this journey, which has shown that Englishmen can endure hardships.'' In the back of the book is a brief note: ''If after reading this little story you feel you would like to help, please would you send your contribution, however small, to the fund . . . for the future of Peter Scott and other relatives?''

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about the film ''Music of the Heart'' misspelled the given name of the actor who plays Meryl Streep's love interest. He is Aidan Quinn, not Aiden.

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-31-99: The Ethicist; A Free Ride
description: My deadbeat neighbor, although able, works only sporadically. His daughter received a free ride to college, based on financial need. Our kids will get little aid for college. It seems grossly unfair. Is there an ethical alternative that neither punishes the daughter for her father's sloth nor penalizes hard-working parents like us? Or should we just go on a mad spending spree between now and the first tuition payment? /K.P.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Ensemble With Silent Films

title: Wary of an Invasion of Cars, Street Shuns New Neighbor
description: When the Salvation Army bought three adjacent houses for roughly $1.2 million in a northern Flushing neighborhood, the easy zoning rules are what made the site so attractive, said Lieut. Col. William H. Lamarr, a divisional commander for the group. The Salvation Army plans to tear the houses down and put up a new church. ''We can build without getting a variance,'' Colonel Lamarr said of the site, on Parsons Boulevard near 32d Avenue.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I am glad they are going because now we are free from intimidation, free from terror, and now we can develop our own country.''

title: Credit Giant Feels Heat Of Agitators
description: WHEN directors of the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation handed walking papers to Volney Taylor, the chief executive, last Monday, it looked as if peace might be near for the troubled old-line credit data company. After the stock hit a low for the year in late August, D.& B.'s largest shareholder had demanded an auction of the company, only to be rebuffed repeatedly by Mr. Taylor.

title: Marbury-Van Horn Duo May Be Up With the Best
description: Granted, they were only preseason games, but in them, Scott Layden watched the Nets' Stephon Marbury and Keith Van Horn twice dominate the Knicks in ways that provoked thoughts of some of basketball's most revered duos.

title: Freeing Student Killer
description: Now that New York's highest court has overruled a Westchester County judge's decision to imprison Hopeton (Shawn) Minott -- who killed a student in 1994 at Mount Vernon High School -- Mr. Minott is to be freed from Greene Correctional Facility near Albany.

title: Isolationism's Return
description: Isolationism -- the notion that American interests are best served by minimal involvement in foreign affairs and alliances -- has been a recurrent issue in American political debate. The issue has now resurfaced with surprising passion, with President Clinton, Vice President Al Gore and their senior advisers joining in an attack on those they call the ''new isolationists.'' Their main targets are the senators who voted to kill the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty, but lately their ire has expanded to include almost anyone who has opposed military intervention in Kosovo, full financing of foreign aid and the repayment of America's $1 billion debt to the United Nations. For their part, Republicans have accused the White House of caricaturing honest differences of opinion on complicated issues.

title: After Its Latest Facelift, A Younger, Sexier Dow
description: THE Dow Jones industrial average has long been viewed as the most prominent measure of the financial health of corporate America. Maybe now it should be seen as a barometer of how fast the economy is changing.

title: The Thrill of Discovering an Unheard Sound
description: THE search for new music can take you on some long trips. In 1994 the search took me to the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival, a place that had become a kind of mecca to music fans since its inception in 1969 and is now almost overgrown in its mass popularity, drawing a couple of hundred thousand people every year. I had been told that it was the place where you could still make discoveries. Even then, the festival was booking international headliners: the Allman Brothers, Wynton Marsalis, Little Richard, Buddy Guy. But I had been writing about music -- jazz and pop -- for nearly 10 years, and I was looking for something new, something that hadn't yet been picked up by a major label or sucked into the electronic media whirlwind. The year before, a friend had raved about a relatively unknown northern Mississippi bluesman named R. L. Burnside who, he said, played the best rhythm guitar he had ever heard.

title: Murder Trial of 13-Year-Old Puts Focus on Michigan Law
description: Two years to the day after an 11-year-old boy fatally shot a stranger walking out of a convenience store, opening statements were made today in his trial on a charge of first-degree murder, in a case that is drawing attention to Michigan's tough three-year-old juvenile justice law.

title: How Teen-Agers Feel
description: To the Editor:

title: Need a Laugh? Try a Cartoon. There's a Bank for It
description: YOU can't help smiling when visiting the spacious warehouse of an office of the Cartoon Bank overlooking the Hudson River in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

title: The World: From the Caucasus to China; Zealots' Latest Targets Are Poor, Remote and Vulnerable
description: THE appearance of Islamic insurgents in this remote Central Asian country in recent weeks has not only shocked regional leaders and their Russian and Chinese neighbors. It has also awakened the world to a troubling new phenomenon: the existence of a floating army of religious fighters who are roaming this part of the world in search of regimes to overthrow.

title: Ideas & Trends: Fear, Itself; The Right Dose of Scare Tactics
description: BE afraid. Be very afraid.

title: Chat: Alan to Bill to Trent, Janet to Bill, and Larry to Bob
description: IT was a busy week in Washington for politics and policy on economic and financial issues. Imagine that you could take a peek at the E-mail traffic among the big players. You might, or might not, have seen something like this. (And no, the addresses are not real.)

title: Cross-Cultural Menu Provides Excitement
description: WHAT'S in a name? At Duo, in Hauppauge, nearly everything. The owners of the restaurant, previously called Solo, had a falling out and one left, taking the name with him. Duo was born, but the remaining partner soon sold it. What diners find today is, in short, a new restaurant with new ownership, chef and menu.

title: Valerie Storff and David Brooks
description: Valerie Claire Storff, the daughter of Marilyn and William W. Storff of New York, was married yesterday to David Lippincott Brooks, a son of Lee and C. M. Brooks of Mesa, Ariz. The Rev. Whitney H. Burr performed the ceremony at St. Christopher's Episcopal Church in Chatham, Mass.

title: Where Rabbit Ears Make Their Last Stand
description: Ben Christiansen, 11, wants his MTV. And his CNN. And especially his ESPN.

title: The Father of Parks, and Traffic
description: ROBERT A. CARO was running late, terribly late. Driving from the Bronx to Long Island to interview Robert Moses for what would become the book ''The Power Broker,'' Mr. Caro had gotten hopelessly stuck in traffic -- on the very network of bridges and expressways that Moses had built.

title: The View From/Greenwich; An Afternoon to Honor Remaking Lives, Rebuilding Dignity
description: ON a recent Sunday at the Warburg estate in back country Greenwich, a George Gershwin song, ''They Can't Take That Away From Me,'' echoed the theme of the afternoon's benefit: the dignity of criminal offenders who are also parents.

title: Senseless Congressional Cuts
description: The across-the-board federal spending cut approved by the House last week must have seemed to Republican leaders like a good way to send a message of frugality. Perhaps it was viewed that way by the 35 percent of Americans who, according to polls, think the G.O.P. Congressional leaders are doing a good job. But it makes no economic or budgetary sense to apply the budget knife to every program on the federal books just because Republicans want to score some political points. President Clinton is right to threaten a veto if the cuts get to his desk.

title: The Importance of Matthew Barney
description: To accept Michael Kimmelman's statement that ''Matthew Barney is the most important American artist of his generation'' requires a gigantic leap of faith, at least based on the evidence in your article (Oct. 10).

title: Muted Echoes of the Civil War
description: MY 9-year-old son, Sam, thinks I've become morbid, and maybe I have. For some years now, I've been drawn to cemeteries. Which may be why our first stop, after landing in Biloxi, Miss., is the old city graveyard, conveniently situated just a couple of blocks from our B & B.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTINEZ, ALICE EUGENIA
description: MARTINEZ-Alice Eugenia Johnson. On October 27, 1999 at age 97. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Arturo Martinez. Mother of Alice Eugenia Aragones. Grandmother of Jay Johnson Aragones, Alice Eugenia Vergara, and Patricia Courtney Aragones. Great grandmother of Peter Augustine, Benedict Xavier, and Alice Christina Vergara. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Sunday, 3-7 PM. Funeral mass at St. Thomas More Church, 65 East 89 Street, Monday, 10:30 AM. Interment private. Because of her strong desire for the education of young women, contributions in her memory may be made to The Convent of the Sacred Heart, 1177 King Street, Greenwich, CT. 06830.

title: Political Briefing; Making Peace, Missouri-Style
description: In the Missouri Senate race, one of the most mean-spirited elections in the country, both candidates professed last week to want peace.

title: Charter Schools
description: Five groups that want to open charter schools in Westchester are among 90 applicants to the State University of New York's Charter School Institute in Purchase.

title: October 24-30; Assassination in Armenia
description: Prime Minister Vazgen Sarkisian had just finished answering questions from members of Armenia's Parliament when five men in trenchcoats, some toting Kalashikov automatic rifles, rushed in. One emptied his weapon into Mr. Sarkisian while others turned on the audience, firing into the front row where Government dignitaries sat.

title: Habitats /400 Chambers Street; Former Navy Man Finds A Home by the River
description: WHEN Ralph Ferraioli left the South Bronx 41 years ago to join the Navy, there was only one problem with his career choice. He didn't know how to swim.

title: Correction
description: A chart in Sunday Styles last week with an article about the correlation between income and number of children in Manhattan families, with a mother age 40 to 44, included some erroneous figures. For families with two children living in Chinatown, the median income is $18,357, not $19,357; in Greenwich Village, those with three or more children have a median income of $60,150, not $80,150, and on the Upper West Side, those with one child have a median income of $99,550, not $98,650.

title: Kwan Is Spinning as Both Student and Athlete
description: On weekdays, when anonymity swallows her up in the stampede of 24,000 U.C.L.A. undergrads hustling to get to class on time and struggling to stay awake once they get there, Michelle Kwan's mandatory accessories are books and a baseball cap. On weekends like this one, when world-class competition calls to her like a siren, it's back to Spandex, sequins and a Mona Lisa smile for the inevitable celebrity spotlight.

title: Retirees Aid Pupils In Reading
description: SHAFTS of sunlight streamed through the windows and illuminated the pairs of reading partners who sat at the round wooden tables in the library of Public School 16 here, surrounded by bookshelves full of children's classics. Some studied workbooks, carefully sounding out rhyming words in whispered tones. Others sat and discussed simple storybooks.

title: When Ike Sabotaged Halloween
description: AS apartment houses go, 333 Central Park West was children's heaven. Especially on Halloween in the 1950's, when scores of kids were let loose to race through the hallways, buzz the elevator buttons at will, and drive the doormen crazy. Only trouble was, I lived next door.

title: To Win, the Flyers Rally Last and Best
description: The Devils lost to the Philadelphia Flyers, 5-3, tonight after a collapse late in the third period. Now it looks as though the Devils may lose their two biggest pugilists, Krzyzstof Oliwa and Randy McKay, for several days as well.

title: Store Parties Are Socializing Lite
description: IT'S been said that every nation has the government it deserves. To which a corollary might be added: Every city gets the night life it deserves. In the New York of 1999, we're getting it in stores.

title: An Island Bombing Range
description: A presidential panel created by Defense Secretary William Cohen recommended earlier this month that the Navy cease all training activities on the island of Vieques near Puerto Rico in five years. In the interim, the Navy would be allowed to use the island for live bombing exercises. That phase-out plan is not fast enough. The Navy should discontinue the shelling right now and promptly return the land to Puerto Rico.

title: Giants' Kickoff Returner Sees a Chance to Star
description: He was in the Giants' spring minicamp a few days when the veterans gave him a nickname: Hollywood.

title: Stylistic Change
description: To the Editor:

title: After Crashes, Audi Recalls Its TT
description: COULD a spoiler spoil the Bauhaus look of the Audi TT? The designers thought so, according to a German magazine, and that is why the sporty TT did not get a spoiler even though Audi's own test drivers are said to have recommended one.

title: Streetscapes/The Poppenhusen Institute in College Point; 1870 Community Center for a Queens Neighborhood
description: FOR a century, the Poppenhusen Institute served as a community center for the College Point section of Queens. But by the 1970's the Victorian structure at 14th Road and 114th Street was a white elephant. Trustees were selling off artworks and fixtures and were considering selling the building for possible demolition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINK, HELEN
description: FINK-Helen. Beloved wife of the late Al. Devoted mother of Fran and Dick Wolff and Len and Nancy. Dear sister of Adele Klein. Loving grandmother and great grandmother. Service Sunday, at 12 Noon, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: THE BOOK OF WAR

title: Nurturing Nature's Way
description: To the Editor:

title: Like Mother, Like Daughter: Handmade Body Care
description: Until she opened her natural body care business, Carol's Daughter, in a storefront in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, Lisa M. Price used her living room in Bedford-Stuyvesant as a showcase. She still mixes her recipes by hand in her kitchen, just as she did when she started in 1993.

title: Where W. Got Compassion
description: David Grann's article (Sept. 12) had numerous mistakes about me and one overarching error.

title: Suddenly Hot: Uptown Has Its SoHa
description: UNDER a canopy of honey locusts and magnolia trees in an amber Sunday evening glow, a bevy of young women in long skirts and sensible shoes gather for a roundup of the weekend's events. This collegial scene, so familiar on the Barnard College and Columbia University campuses for decades, is now transposed against a new one down the hill past the stately campus gates.

title: Boeing Failed To Disclose 1980 Findings
description: Sixteen years before T.W.A. Flight 800 exploded with a loss of 230 lives in 1996, a Boeing study showed that the central fuel tanks of its jumbo jets were taking in heat from air-conditioning units directly under them, but the company failed to report the finding to safety investigators until last summer, Federal and company officials said yesterday.

title: Argentines Get a Peek at Government-to-Be
description: As a candidate, President-elect Fernando de la Rua refused to debate and kept his speeches vague. But as his administration begins to take shape a week after his election, he is preparing Argentina for sharp cuts in public spending and revealing an open style of governing full of trial balloons and freewheeling public debate among his advisers.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: The Serpent Club

title: What Autumn Coats Whisper
description: The subtle look, smooth and functional, of autumn's first coats mirrors the need of today's businesswoman to appear serious in a competitive world. Her style speaks in whispers rather than bold statements. When she goes to a benefit luncheon, it is no longer a dressed-up three-hour affair of food and a fashion show. Now, she attends a luncheon held to less than two hours and featuring a symposium on a subject like breast cancer. What gives her look dash is a casualness that avoids dressed-down sloppiness. Necklaces have become nonexistent. Her chief accessory is a roomy leather bag of the best quality. The shoes are her one note of whimsy.

title: Opening Up a Toy Box By Moving a Few Blocks
description: Geppetto's Toy Box, an alternative to chain toy stores, moved several blocks in the West Village last week, going to 11 Christopher Street, at Gay Street, after four years at 161 Seventh Avenue South (between Perry and Waverly Streets).

title: Time to Share the Wealth
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Appreciating the Leaves, and Even the Work
description: THE glory of the fall season with all its beautifully colored canopies of tree leaves has passed its peak. Only remnants remain of one of nature's greatest shows.

title: Political Briefing; Consumer's Guide To the Candidates
description: Speaking of politics, the Web and speedy answers . . .

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELMAN, ABBE J.
description: SELMAN-Abbe J., Dr. Edie, Josh, Richie and the Selman family, please accept our heartfelt condolences on the loss of our dearest friend. A most generous, gentle, caring and compassionate man in both his professional and personal life. He was always there when anyone needed him. Dr. Norman E. Klein Bill Wasserman

title: The World; A Link That Drives Palestinians Apart
description: IN jeans and T-shirts, each carrying a small gym bag, a group of young Gaza men drew taunts and stares as they wandered the streets here Friday evening in a fruitless search for work. ''They told us we were ruining Ramallah,'' said Adham A'jour, 22, taken aback by the hostility. ''People in the West Bank should be more understanding of our situation.''

title: Union County to Build Wall To Contain Rahway River
description: Officials in Union County have decided to go ahead with a project to hold back the Rahway River and hope that the state will eventually reimburse the county the $1 million it plans to spend.

title: SHORTS
description: GUIDE

title: In a Bad State
description: REBELLION

title: Suicide and Pain
description: To the Editor:

title: The Importance of Matthew Barney
description: Having seen ''Cremaster 2'' with a half-empty opening-night audience at Film Forum, I can easily recognize the allusions and symbolism that Barney weaves together in the nearly complete series. Kimmelman outlined it well. Still, there does not exist a solid foundation of quality in ideas, content or even sheer formal beauty or power to justify the grand spectacle that Barney is reaching for.

title: Mayors and Their Challengers; Incumbents Cite Achievements, and Contenders Appear Undaunted by the Odds Against Them
description: WHEN Mary Margaret Mulrooney was an assistant district attorney in the Bronx, a judge nicknamed her the bulldog. As she seeks to unseat Mayor John D. Spencer of Yonkers, she says the name still fits.

title: Creative, Refined Food at Bargain Prices
description: ''I'VE been at restaurants that charge twice as much as this one and aren't nearly as good.'' That accurate observation was made recently by a justifiably enthusiastic diner at the new Close to Home restaurant at 320 Maple Avenue in Smithtown (360-8080).

title: Our Towns; In Suburbia, Fences Vanish But Dogs Stay
description: KATY'S behaving beautifully. She approaches the edge of the large lawn and pulls back, frightened, as if she's about to fall off the end of the earth. ''She's an all-star,'' announces Tony Wilmot, a friendly man wearing a blue hat that says ''Invisible Fence.''

title: Guinness on Tap
description: A POSITIVELY FINAL APPEARANCE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WENGER, MATTHEW
description: WENGER-Matthew. Died on October 29, 1999, after a prolonged illness. Beloved son of Louis and Anne Wenger. Loving brother of David, Daniel, and Tasha. Cherished grandson of Josephine Hoyt. Services Sunday, 12:30 PM, at ''Congregation Beth Sholom'', 441 Deer Park Avenue, Babylon, NY. Interment at Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Farmindale, NY.

title: Is a Cold Soda Worth More on a Hot Day?
description: To the Editor:

title: Dominique Anglade, Eric Neblung
description: Dominique Alberte Anglade, a daughter of Fredline and Serge Anglade of Wesley Hills, N.Y., was married yesterday to Eric Peter Neblung, a son of Christa and Dieter Neblung of Ringwood, N.J. The Rev. William Bergen, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title: Tricia Cohen, Jason Pantzer
description: Tricia Ruth Cohen, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Cohen of Chappaqua, N.Y., was married last evening to Jason Michael Pantzer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward S. Pantzer of New York. Rabbi David Posner officiated at the Plaza in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COLE, CHARLES J.
description: COLE-Charles J. Dad, it's been a long seven years. We love and miss you and know that you are with us always. Your Gang

title: Mae Hsieh, Gregory Bylinsky
description: Mae Hsiao-mei Hsieh, the daughter of Lydia and Tsuying Hsieh of Silver Spring, Md., was married yesterday to Gregory Eugene Bylinsky, the son of Gwen and Gene Bylinsky of Riverside, Conn. The Rev. Verity A. Jones, a minister of the Disciples of Christ, performed the ceremony at Oxon Hill Manor in Oxon Hill, Md.

title: All-Century Became All About Rose and Gray
description: Those watching the introduction of the all-century team last Sunday before Game 2 of the World Series surely hoped it would stir emotions similar to those created at last July's lovefest for Ted Williams before the All-Star Game.

title: Jennifer Lach and Paul Gill
description: IN person, Jennifer Lach does not come across as particularly bold or adventuresome. She is studious-looking and composed, and seems like the sort of person who would always win spelling bees in school.

title: Foreign Affairs; The Last 100 Days
description: I don't know how Al Gore will do in the upcoming race. I think he's got a lot more substance than the press has given him credit for. But if Mr. Gore's candidacy does go down early, it could have one interesting side effect. It might actually free up the Clinton Administration to govern in its final months without worrying about politics. Having missed out on its first 100 days -- due to a variety of scandals and mishaps -- the Clinton Administration could be the first in history to be known for its last 100 days. Imagine if the President, unconstrained by any campaign, actually felt free to do only the right things in foreign policy with his last 100 days.

title: Stow All Pythons in the Overhead Bin
description: Big Trouble

title: In Helping the Many, Don't Neglect the Few
description: We think it laudable that more school districts are using teachers of gifted education to enrich regular classroom activities [''Is This the Place Where All the Children Are Above Average?'' Oct. 17]. All children can benefit from being exposed to challenging material in a way that develops their thinking skills.

title: Attention to Foliage and Seedpods
description: Peony foliage that has held up well and turned tawny gold can be left until spring; if it is diseased or unsightly, cut it down. Also cut bearded iris leaves to five inches and clean up debris (it may harbor borers). Don't remove healthy foliage of Siberian iris or red-hot poker (Kniphofia): it will protect plants and add interest to the winter garden. Straw-colored foliage of hosta is attractive, but it may provide a refuge for slugs during winter.

title: Will a Tower Slip Through a Law's Rear Window?
description: Some buildings in New York go up fast, seemingly overnight. But at least one building apparently did not go up fast enough. Zoning rules for that area were changed before the developer could complete the foundation for a 20-story luxury apartment building at 224 West 18th Street, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues. Now he must appeal to a special city panel or restrict the project to just a dozen floors.

title: A Studio Where the Saints Go Marching Out
description: Since 1907, Jersey Statuary Company of Jersey City has occupied a small two-story house crammed with plaster casts of Roman Catholic saints, prayer cards and boxes of rosaries. The company salesroom is also the work space of Gino DeSanctis, a sculptor and painter with Jersey Statuary who casts and paints his work on the premises. To the accompaniment of Italian broadcasts on his shortwave radio, Mr. DeSanctis, 77, recently described the craft he has practiced for more than 45 years.

title: Right Questions
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: October 24-30; A Mysterious Flight to Death
description: Something, possibly something quite small, went wrong on a Learjet chartered in Orlando, Fla., on Monday by Payne Stewart, the golfer. It was evidently big enough to disable or kill the two pilots, but not big enough to stop the airplane from flying 1,400 miles, presumably on autopilot, to a pasture near in South Dakota, where it crashed when one of its engines ran out of fuel.

title: Abortion: An Endangered Right
description: To the Editor:

title: Can Merrill's Funds Get Back on Track?
description: TRYING to turn around a big, struggling mutual fund business sounds like a full-time job. But for Robert C. Doll Jr., chief investment officer for Merrill Lynch's stock funds, it will be just part of a day's work.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Private Sector column on Oct. 3 about an annual competition at Rockefeller Center for antique cars misidentified the metal used in the winner, a 1938 Bugatti 57SC Atlantic. It is aluminum, not magnesium alloy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, SAMUEL
description: FISHER-Samuel. October 30, 1999, at 94. Beloved husband of Betty. Devoted father of Jerome and Shirley. Grandfather of Mark and Randi Fisher, and Brenda and David Shapiro. Great-grandfather of Jessica, Daniel, Zachary, Ben and Adam. Supermarket operator, real estate investor, and philanthropist.

title: An Airport Enters The Realm of Museums
description: San Francisco International Airport recently became the first airport to be accredited by the American Association of Museums, a private organization that sets professional museum standards in the United States. The association has accredited more than 750 institutions, from the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York to zoos to local historical sites.

title: They Love New York
description: Trick or treat, Hillary, and Happy Halloween to you too, Rudy. Odds are, you're going to be the stars of most of tonight's masquerades.

title: Bringing Polish to a 'Profane' Masterpiece
