description: EVEN amid the dizzying heterogeneity of 20th-century musical styles, ''Carmina Burana,'' by the German composer Carl Orff, remains one of a kind. Written in 1936, this ''profane cantata'' sets medieval Latin texts depicting the pleasures of drink, gambling and divers country matters. Primitive in its harmonic cast and rhythmic vitality, the music conveys a raw elemental quality befitting the sensuality of the texts. If the devil gets the best tunes in opera, the sinners in Orff's work get the best choruses.

title: Playing by the (New) Rules
description: After more than a decade of declining scores, unimaginative offense and borderline thuggery, a special committee approved these four changes for the coming season. By MIKE WISE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYER, VIVIAN MICHELE
description: MAYER-Vivian Michele. Died unexpectedly at home in San Diego, California, on October 21st, 1999. Beloved sister of Barbara Mayer Lambert & devoted aunt to Corey Lambert. Services were held in San Diego. Shiva will be observed on Monday evening, November 1st, at the home of Steven and Barbara Lambert.

title: Lives; Just Win, Baby
description: I went to graduate school in Iowa City, at the Iowa Writers' Workshop, where the most passionate thing I did was attend University of Iowa basketball games. My closest friend at Iowa, Philip, liked to say his childhood was about Walt Frazier. Every night he'd hear his mother and father screaming at each other in the next room, and he'd just stare at the Knicks game on the little black-and-white TV at the edge of his bed, trying to will himself into ''Clyde's'' body. In the spring of 1980, when Iowa beat Georgetown to qualify for the Final Four, Philip and I jumped up and down and cried and hugged each other in a way we wouldn't have dreamed of doing otherwise.

title: After Merger, a Study of Employee Attitudes
description: WHEN Mount Sinai Medical Center and New York University Medical Center merged last year, the combined health center consisted of five campuses and four hospitals.

title: Pittsburgh Outplayed By No. 3 Va. Tech
description: At one point during the fourth quarter of the game between Virginia Tech and Pittsburgh tonight, game officials lost track of the downs on the field and had to telephone officials in the booth above the field to find out whether it was second down or third down.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Aretha

title: A Pessimistic Forecast For Real Estate Trusts
description: Shares of real estate investment trusts, or REIT's, are unlikely to recover anytime soon from the slump they've been mired in for the last 19 months, investors and analysts said at an industry convention in Los Angeles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, GERTRUDE
description: ROSENBERG-Gertrude. 99, died at her home in Mount Kisco on October 25, 1999. The widow of Max Rosenberg of Bedford Hills, she was a past President of the Senior Citizens of Mount Kisco and a devoted volunteer at Northern Westchester Hospital into her nineties. She will be missed by her grandchildren, great grandchildren, nieces and nephews. Ed & Ruth (Rosenfeld) Bellsey Edith & Ben Rosenberg

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, AARON F.
description: GOLDSTEIN-Aaron F., Judge. The Jewish Center of Atlantic Beach records with profound sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Judge Aaron F. Goldstein, husband of Sophie Goldstein. May the family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem and know no further sorrow. Dr. Basil Herring, Rabbi Arthur Udell, President Armand Lindenbaum, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLD, ABE
description: GOLD-Abe. NCJW NY Section mourns the loss of Abe Gold, devoted husband of our esteemed Honorary Vice President, Honey Gold. He was respected and loved by all who knew him. His genial presence will be sadly missed. Bernice Friedes, Jean Krosner Co-Presidents Helen C. Heller, Exec. Director

title: POSTINGS: Part of $300 Million Master Plan; For St. John's Campus, A Cesar Pelli Church
description: Gyms, dorms, libraries and laboratories are the normal stuff of campus expansion. A church is not.

title: Lights, Camera and a Cast of Annoyed Neighbors
description: To Leonard Golubchick, the principal of Public School 20 on the Lower East Side, the film crew trailers parked near the Essex Street school two weeks ago were cause for alarm. Because they obscured sight lines, Mr. Golubchick said, the trailers made it dangerous for children to cross the street.

title: Q. & A.
description: Returning Security Deposits

title: Backtalk; The N.B.A.'s Drug Program Is Nothing More Than a Masquerade
description: For a few festive hours tonight, millions of children and adults will happily dress up or don masks and pretend to be something or someone they are not. On Tuesday, the National Basketball Association's regular season will open for the 53d time, while a majority of players begin their 82-game version of All Hallows' E'en, dressing up as entertainers and role models, masking their off-court dependence on a post-game treat of choice: smoking a joint.

title: Two County Propositions on Ballot for Voters
description: WESTCHESTER will go to the polls Tuesday to vote on greater autonomy for Westchester Community College, decide which party will control the County Board of Legislators and determine the fate of many judicial candidates and local office seekers.

title: Oral Hygiene, a Laughing Matter
description: This fall, a slew of dentally directed products is in stores, carrying a simple, shiny message: oral hygiene is fun! For youngsters, Johnson & Johnson offers Wild String, a bright blue Cherry Berry-flavored dental floss (55 yards retail for $2.79); Wild Flossers (right), plastic dinosaur-shaped floss holders (20 for $2.39), and Reach's Power brush (right), a battery-powered vibrating toothbrush ($8.99). For grown-ups, Sonicare's Sonic Toothbrush ($79 to $129 at Bed, Bath and Beyond) hums a perfect C, beeping every 30 seconds to remind the brusher to move to another quadrant. New from Reach is the Plaque Sweeper, a toothbrush with neon-colored ''power bristles'' and a rubber handle. Alessi has a Baby Bathroom travel kit for grown-ups, including two brightly colored toothbrush covers, a toothpaste cap and Otto (above), an egg-shaped character designed by Philippe Starck that dispenses floss ($38 for the kit, $19 for Otto alone, at Karikter, 19 Prince Street, at Elizabeth Street).

title: To Match Fall Colors, A Big Red From Italy
description: PERFECTION is as elusive in wine as it is in life. There is no single perfect wine for a special dinner. The season, the menu, one's pocketbook and palate all contribute to the decision of which wine to serve.

title: Development In Long Beach
description: To the Editor:

title: SOAPBOX; Speaking for Himself
description: THE author of ''White Flight,'' the cover article on Oct. 10, (we're still talking about this?) describes me as ''tall, thin, and bespectacled,'' but only one of these descriptors is accurate -- I'm thin, no one has ever mistaken me for tall (I'm 5 feet 7 inches), and I've never worn glasses. I say this because the author's batting average is worth noting in relation to readers forming judgments about my experience at Trenton High School. Altogether, I felt extremely misrepresented in Lisa Suhay's article.

title: An Actor, Present and Future
description: Don't bother asking Paul S. Iacono what he wants to be when he grows up. ''I want to stay what I am, but not just in theater,'' he says. ''I'd like movie work.''

title: One Internet, Two Nations
description: After the Stono Rebellion of 1739 in South Caroli na the largest uprising of slaves in the colonies before the American Revolution -- legislators there responded by banishing two forms of communication among the slaves: the mastery of reading and writing, and the mastery of ''talking drums,'' both of which had been crucial to the capacity to rebel.

title: Melville's Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JORMARK, PHILIP
description: JORMARK-Philip. On October 30, 1999. Beloved husband of Beulah (nee Lewis). Loving father of Susan, Robin, and Renay Podberesky. Cherished grandfather of Jenna and Marisa. Funeral Sunday 12 noon, from the Garlick-Riverside Memorial Chapel, Bronx, NY.

title: Sweeping Views of the Park And a Row of Idling Buses
description: Last fall, New York City Transit began parking express buses to Staten Island along the north side of Central Park South, much to the annoyance of residents across the street, many with million-dollar views of the park.

title: Bugged
description: Deborah Gordon flinches as a backhoe slits open the earth next to a colony of ants. Swipes with a pickax reveal an intricate structure of chambers and channels winding deep beneath the nest entrance. Ants spill out, antennae fibrillating. ''I hate this part,'' the biologist from Stanford University says. ''I hate it because to study these ants I have to destroy this miraculous thing.''

title: Oh, That Blasted Skin
description: Sanding your face hardly seems like a pleasant way to spend an afternoon. But ever since crystal clearing, or microdermabrasion, was introduced a year ago at Bliss, a day spa in SoHo, the staff can barely keep up with the demand for power sloughing.

title: Mentally Ill Man's Kin Absent From His Trial
description: During each day of the trial of Andrew Goldstein, the schizophrenic man accused of pushing Kendra Webdale in front of a subway train, Ms. Webdale's mother and sister have sat resolutely in the courtroom's second row, just behind prosecutors. But the rows behind Mr. Goldstein have remained empty.

title: BROOKLYN MUSEUM RECRUITED DONORS WHO STOOD TO GAIN
description: Far more than has been previously disclosed, the ''Sensation'' exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum of Art has been financed by companies and individuals with a direct commercial interest in the works of the British artists in the show, according to court documents and interviews with people involved in the exhibition.

title: A Film About Film That Seeks to Tap A Common Dream
description: THE first time Chris Smith filmed Mark Borchardt was in 1995. Mr. Borchardt, a lanky, affable Wisconsinite with a passing resemblance to a long-haired Weird Al Yankovic, was traveling to the Toronto Film Festival with his parents, hoping to meet the film critic Roger Ebert, buy him a beer and interest him in his half-finished, homegrown film.

title: It Gets Worse
description: THE RED DEVIL

title: Try a Carbon Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: Paul Kline and Brooke Remick
description: Mary Brooke Remick, the daughter of Mary and William Remick of Kewanee, Ill., and Paul Jan Kline, the son of Harriet and Norman Kline of Larchmont, N.Y., were married yesterday in Tiburon, Calif. The Rev. Gerald P. Caprio, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Old St. Hilary's Church.

title: Census Fight Is Put on Hold Until a Count Is Completed
description: After three years of partisan wrangling, legislative brinkmanship and legal suits, a strange new mood has enveloped the battle over the 2000 census: peace.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York.

title: Ahead on Turnpike New Rest Areas And Billboards
description: The New Jersey Turnpike Authority has some good news and some bad news. The authority agreed last week to spend $16 million to renovate its rather aging service areas. At the same time, it is moving ahead with a plan that to some people will make the northern section of the turnpike uglier by putting up billboards.

title: Corrections
description: The On Language column on page 26 of The Times Magazine today, about the origins of words used by Vice President Gore and George W. Bush, misspells the given name of a correspondent who has covered Mr. Gore for The Times. She is Katharine Q. Seelye, not Katherine.

title: Skewered
description: MY KITCHEN WARS

title: After Injury, a Dancer Rediscovers His Art; Through Arduous Lessons, Ballet Performer Finds Hope, and a Place Onstage
description: Marc Brew clutches the barre with one hand, and elegantly raises the other. Suddenly, his arm stops in midair, frozen in space as if held there by scaffolding.
